ʃi stɑpt ən fɪʃt ðə stoʊn ɹɪŋ ɑn ɪts kɔɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə fɹʌn ə hɝ dʒɹɛs. waɪ wɑz ɪt nɑt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ? ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd soʊ fæst ʌp tɪl naʊ ðət ʃi kəd hɑɹdli kætʃ əɹ bɹɛθ. waɪ nɑt naʊ? ənlɛs ðəɹ wɑz səm ænsɝ ɹaɪt hɪɹ? ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn ənsɝteɪnli. ðə waɪldflaʊɹz tɔntɪd hɝ, ən ðə lɑɹksɔŋ mɑk hɝ. ðɪs pleɪs sim tu mʌtʃ ə hɝ oʊn meɪkɪŋ.

She stopped and fished the stone ring on its cord out of the front of her dress. Why was it not changing? Everything had changed so fast up till now that she could hardly catch her breath. Why not now? Unless there was some answer right here? She looked around uncertainly. The wildflowers taunted her, and the larksong mocked her. This place seemed too much of her own making.

dɪtɝmənd, ʃi taɪɾənd əɹ hæn ɝaʊn ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. "teɪk mi wɛɹ aɪ nid tə bi." ʃi ʃʌɾ əɹ aɪz ən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn ðə ɹɪŋ. ɪt wɑz stoʊn, æftɝ ɔl; ɝθ ʃəd ɡɪv əɹ səm filɪŋ fəɹ ɪt. "du ɪt. teɪk mi wɛɹ aɪ nid tə bi." wʌns əɡɛn ʃi ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ, fɛɾ ə tʃɹɪkəl ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪndə ðə ɹɪŋ. ʃi nu ɪt dɪd nɑt niɾ ɛni floʊ ʌv paʊɝ dɝɛktəɾ əɾ ɪt tə wɝk, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə də ɛniθɪŋ tə ɪt. oʊnli tə ɡɪv ɪt mɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ tə juz. "teɪk mi tə wɛɹ aɪ kən faɪn ən ænsɝ. aɪ nid tə noʊ wʌt ðə blæk ədʒɑ wɑns. teɪk mi tə ði ænsɝ."

Determined, she tightened her hand around the ter'angreal. "Take me where I need to be." She shut her eyes and concentrated on the ring. It was stone, after all; Earth should give her some feeling for it. "Do it. Take me where I need to be." Once again she embraced saidar, fed a trickle of the One Power into the ring. She knew it did not need any flow of Power directed at it to work, and she did not try to do anything to it. Only to give it more of the Power to use. "Take me to where I can find an answer. I need to know what the Black Ajah wants. Take me to the answer."

"wɛl, juv faʊn jəɹ weɪ ət læst, tʃaɪld. ɔl sɔɹts ʌv ænsɝz hɪɹ."

"Well, you've found your way at last, child. All sorts of answers here."

ɛɡwinz aɪz snæpt oʊpən. ʃi stʊɾ ɪn ə ɡɹeɪt hɔl, ɪts væs doʊm silɪŋ səpɔɹɾəd baɪ ə fɔɹəst ə mæsɪv ɹɛdstoʊn kɑləmz. ən hæŋɪŋ ɪn mɪdɛɹ wɑz ə sɔɹɾ ə kɹɪstəl, ɡlimɪŋ ən spɑɹklɪŋ əz ɪt sloʊli ɹivɑlvd. ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən, bʌt ʃi θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi ðə sɔɹd ɹænd hæd bɪn ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪn ðət dʒɹim. ðəɾ ʌðɝ dʒɹim. ðɪs ɔl fɛl soʊ ɹil, ʃi hæd tə kip ɹimaɪndɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹim, tu.

Egwene's eyes snapped open. She stood in a great hall, its vast domed ceiling supported by a forest of massive redstone columns. And hanging in midair was a sword of crystal, gleaming and sparkling as it slowly revolved. She was not certain, but she thought it might be the sword Rand had been reaching for in that dream. That other dream. This all felt so real, she had to keep reminding herself it was a dream, too.

ən oʊld wʊmən stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz ə ðə kɑləm, bɛn ən hɑbəlɪŋ wɪð ə stɪk. ʌɡli dɪd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə dɪskɹaɪb hɝ. ʃi hæɾ ə boʊni, pɔɪntəd tʃɪn, ən ivən boʊniɝ, ʃɑɹpɝ noʊz, ən ɪt sim ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ wɔɹts ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɛɹz ɑn əɹ feɪs ðən ðəɹ wɑz feɪs.

An old woman stepped out of the shadows of the column, bent and hobbling with a stick. Ugly did not begin to describe her. She had a bony, pointed chin, an even bonier, sharper nose, and it seemed there were more warts growing hairs on her face than there was face.

"hu ɑɹ ju?" ɛɡwin sɛd. ði oʊnli pipəl ʃi hæd sin soʊ fɑɹ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd wɝ ðoʊz ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi nu, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi cʊɾə fɝɡɑɾən ðɪs pʊɹ oʊld wʊmən.

"Who are you?" Egwene said. The only people she had seen so far in Tel'aran'rhiod were those she already knew, but she did not think she could have forgotten this poor old woman.

"dʒʌs pʊɹ oʊl sɪlvi, maɪ leɪɾi," ði oʊld wʊmən kækəld. ət ðə seɪm taɪm ʃi mænədʒd ə stup ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn mɛn fəɹ ə kɝtsi, əɹ pɑsəbli ə kɹɪnʒ. "ju noʊ pʊɹ oʊl sɪlvi, maɪ leɪɾi. sɝv jəɹ fæmli feɪθfəli ɔl ðiz jɪɹz. dʌz ðɪs oʊl feɪs stɪl fɹaɪɾən ju? doʊn lɛɾ ɪt, maɪ leɪɾi. ɪt sɝvz mi, wən aɪ niɾ ɪt, əz ɡʊɾ əz ə pɹɪɾiɝ."

"Just poor old Silvie, my Lady," the old woman cackled. At the same time she managed a stoop that might have been meant for a curtsy, or possibly a cringe. "You know poor old Silvie, my Lady. Served your family faithfully all these years. Does this old face still frighten you? Don't let it, my Lady. It serves me, when I need it, as good as a prettier."

"ʌv kɔɹs, ɪt dʌz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪts ə stʃɹɔŋ feɪs. ə ɡʊd feɪs." ʃi hoʊp ðə wʊmən bɪlivd ɪt. huɛvɝ ðɪs sɪlvi wɑz, ʃi sim tə θɪŋk ʃi nu ɛɡwin. pɝhæps ʃi nu ænsɝz, tu. "sɪlvi, jə sɛd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt faɪndɪŋ ænsɝz hɪɹ."

"Of course, it does," Egwene said. "It's a strong face. A good face." She hoped the woman believed it. Whoever this Silvie was, she seemed to think she knew Egwene. Perhaps she knew answers, too. "Silvie, you said something about finding answers here."

"oʊ, juv kʌm tə ðə ɹaɪt pleɪs fəɹ ænsɝz, maɪ leɪɾi. ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn ɪz fʊl ʌv ænsɝz. ən sikɹəts. ðə haɪ lɔɹdz wəd nɑt bi pliz tə si əs hɪɹ, maɪ leɪɾi. oʊ, noʊ. nʌn bʌt ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ɛntɝ hɪɹ. ən sɝvəns, ʌv kɔɹs." ʃi ɡeɪv ə slaɪ, skɹitʃɪŋ læf. "ðə haɪ lɔɹdz doʊn swip ən mɑp. bʌɾ u siz ə sɝvənt?"

"Oh, you've come to the right place for answers, my Lady. The Heart of the Stone is full of answers. And secrets. The High Lords would not be pleased to see us here, my Lady. Oh, no. None but the High Lords enter here. And servants, of course." She gave a sly, screeching laugh. "The High Lords don't sweep and mop. But who sees a servant?"

"wʌt kaɪndə sikɹəts?"

"What kind of secrets?"

bʌt sɪlvi wɑz hɑbəlɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə kɹɪstəl sɔɹd. "plɑts," ʃi sɛɾ əz ɪf tə hɝsɛlf. "ɔl ə ðɛm pɹitɛndɪŋ tə sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, ən ɔl ðə waɪl plɑɾɪŋ ən plænɪŋ tə ɹɪɡeɪn wʌt ðeɪ lɔst. itʃ wʌn θɪŋkɪŋ i əɹ ʃiz ði oʊnli wʌn plɑɾɪŋ. ɪʃəml ɪz ə ful!"

But Silvie was hobbling toward the crystal sword. "Plots," she said as if to herself. "All of them pretending to serve the Great Lord, and all the while plotting and planning to regain what they lost. Each one thinking he or she is the only one plotting. Ishamael is a fool!"

"wʌt?" ɛɡwin sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "wʌt dɪd jə seɪ əbaʊɾ ɪʃəml?"

"What?" Egwene said sharply. "What did you say about Ishamael?"

ði oʊld wʊmən tɝn tə pɹizɛn ə kɹʊkəd, ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪɾɪŋ smaɪl. "dʒʌst ə θɪŋ pʊɹ foʊks seɪ, maɪ leɪɾi. ɪt tɝnz ðə fɔɹseɪkənz paʊɝ, kɔlɪŋ əm fulz. meɪks jə fil ɡʊd, ən seɪf. ivən ðə ʃædoʊ kæn teɪk biɪŋ kɔld ə ful. tʃɹaɪ ɪt, maɪ leɪɾi. seɪ, bælzəmən ɪz ə ful!"

The old woman turned to present a crooked, ingratiating smile. "Just a thing poor folks say, my Lady. It turns the Forsaken's power, calling them fools. Makes you feel good, and safe. Even the Shadow can't take being called a fool. Try it, my Lady. Say, Ba'alzamon is a fool!"

ɛɡwinz lɪps twɪtʃt ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə smaɪl. "bælzəmən ɪz ə ful! jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt, sɪlvi." ɪɾ æktʃəli  dɪd fil ɡʊd, læfɪŋ ət ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ði oʊld wʊmən tʃʌkəld. ðə sɔɹd ɹivɑlv dʒʌs bɪɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. "sɪlvi, wʌɾ ɪz ðæt?"

Egwene's lips twitched on the edge of a smile. "Ba'alzamon is a fool! You are right, Silvie." It actually did feel good, laughing at the Dark One. The old woman chuckled. The sword revolved just beyond her shoulder. "Silvie, what is that?"

"kælændɝ, maɪ leɪɾi. jə noʊ ðæt, doʊn ju? ðə sɔɹd ðət kænɑt bi tʌtʃt." əbɹʌpli ʃi swʌŋ əɹ stɪk bɪhaɪn hɝ; ə fʊt fɹəm ðə sɔɹd, ðə stɪk stɑpt wɪð ə dʌl θwæk ən baʊndəd bæk. sɪlvi ɡɹɪnd waɪɾɝ. "ðə sɔɹd ðəɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə sɔɹd, ðoʊ ðɛɹz pɹɛʃəs fju noʊz wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz. bʌt nʌn kən tʌtʃ ɪt seɪv wʌn. ðeɪ sɔ tə ðæt, hu pʊɾ ɪt hɪɹ. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl hoʊl kælændɝ wʌn deɪ, ən pɹuv tə ðə wɝl hiz ðə dʒɹæɡən baɪ duɪŋ ɪt. ðə fɝs pɹuf, ɛniweɪ. luz θɝɪn kʌm bæk fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝl tə si, ən ɡɹɑvəl bɪfɔɹ. ɑ, ðə haɪ lɔɹdz doʊn laɪk hævɪŋ ɪt hɪɹ. ðeɪ laɪk nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ðeɪd ɹɪd ðɛmsɛlvz ʌv ɪt, ɪf ðeɪ kʊd. ɪf ðeɪ kʊd. aɪ səpoʊz ðɛɹz ʌðɝz wəd teɪk ɪt, ɪf ðeɪ kʊd. wʌt wʊdnt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɡɪv, tə hoʊl kælændɝ?"

"Callandor, my Lady. You know that, don't you? The Sword That Cannot Be Touched." Abruptly she swung her stick behind her; a foot from the sword, the stick stopped with a dull thwack and bounded back. Silvie grinned wider. "The Sword That Is Not a Sword, though there's precious few knows what it is. But none can touch it save one. They saw to that, who put it here. The Dragon Reborn will hold Callandor one day, and prove to the world he's the Dragon by doing it. The first proof, anyway. Lews Therin come back for all the world to see, and grovel before. Ah, the High Lords don't like having it here. They like nothing to do with the Power. They'd rid themselves of it, if they could. If they could. I suppose there's others would take it, if they could. What wouldn't one of the Forsaken give, to hold Callandor?"

ɛɡwin stɛɹɾ ət ðə spɑɹklɪŋ sɔɹd. ɪf ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən wɝ tʃɹu, ɪf ɹænd wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən əz mɔɪɹeɪn kleɪmd, hi wəd wild ɪt wʌn deɪ, ðoʊ fɹəm ðə ɹɛst ʌv wʌt ʃi nu ʌv ðə pɹɑfəsiz kənsɝnɪŋ kælændɝ, ʃi kəd nɑt si haʊ ɪt kəɾ ɛvɝ kʌm tə bi. bʌɾ ɪf ðɛɹz ə weɪ tə teɪk ɪt, meɪbi ðə blæk ədʒɑ noʊz haʊ. ɪf ðeɪ noʊ ɪt, aɪ kən fɪɡjɝ ɪɾ aʊt.

Egwene stared at the sparkling sword. If the Prophecies of the Dragon were true, if Rand was the Dragon as Moiraine claimed, he would wield it one day, though from the rest of what she knew of the Prophecies concerning Callandor, she could not see how it could ever come to be. But if there's a way to take it, maybe the Black Ajah knows how. If they know it, I can figure it out.

kɔʃəsli, ʃi ɹitʃt aʊt wɪð ðə paʊɝ, pɹoʊbɪŋ ət wʌtɛvɝ hɛld ən ʃildɪd ðə sɔɹd. hɝ pɹoʊb tʌtʃt - sʌmθɪŋ - ən stɑpt. ʃi kəd sɛns wɪtʃ ə ðə faɪv paʊɝz hæd bɪn juz hɪɹ. ɛɹ, ən faɪɝ, ən spɪɹət. ʃi kəd tʃɹeɪs ði ɪntʃɹəkət wiv meɪd baɪ seɪaɪdɑɹ, sɛt wɪð ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ðəɾ əmeɪz hɝ. ðəɹ wɝ ɡæps ɪn ðət wiv, speɪsəz wɛɹ əɹ pɹoʊb ʃəd slaɪd θɹu. wən ʃi tʃɹaɪd, ɪt wɑz laɪk faɪɾɪŋ ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs pɑɹɾ ə ðə wiv hɛɾ ɑn. ɪt hɪɾ əɹ ðɛn, wʌt ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs ə weɪ θɹu, ən ʃi lɛɾ əɹ pɹoʊb vænɪʃ. hæf ðət wɔl hæd bɪn woʊvən juzɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ; ði ʌðɝ hæf, ðə pɑɹt ʃi kəd nɑt sɛns əɹ tʌtʃ, hæd bɪn meɪd wɪð seɪɾɪn. ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪt, ɪɡzækli - ðə wɔl wɑz ɔl ʌv wʌn pis - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf. ə stoʊn wɔl stɑps ə blaɪnd wʊmən əz ʃʊɹli əz wʌn u kən si ɪt.

Cautiously, she reached out with the Power, probing at whatever held and shielded the sword. Her probe touched - something - and stopped. She could sense which of the Five Powers had been used here. Air, and Fire, and Spirit. She could trace the intricate weave made by saidar, set with a strength that amazed her. There were gaps in that weave, spaces where her probe should slide through. When she tried, it was like fighting the strongest part of the weave head on. It hit her then, what she was trying to force a way through, and she let her probe vanish. Half that wall had been woven using saidar; the other half, the part she could not sense or touch, had been made with saidin. That was not it, exactly - the wall was all of one piece - but it was close enough. A stone wall stops a blind woman as surely as one who can see it.

fʊtstɛps ɛkoʊɾ ɪn ðə dɪstəns. buts.

Footsteps echoed in the distance. Boots.

ɛɡwin kəd nɑt tɛl haʊ mɛni ðəɹ wɝ, əɹ fɹəm wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ, bʌt sɪlvi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən ɪmiɾiətli stɛɹɾ ɔf əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz. "hiz kʌmɪŋ tə stɛɹ əɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "əweɪk əɹ əslip, hi wɑns. . . ." ʃi sim tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛɡwin, ən pʊɾ ɑn ə wɝid smaɪl. "ju mʌs liv, naʊ, maɪ leɪɾi. hi mʌsnt faɪn jə hɪɹ, əɹ ivən noʊ juv bɪn."

Egwene could not tell how many there were, or from which direction they were coming, but Silvie gave a start and immediately stared off among the columns. "He's coming to stare at it again," she muttered. "Awake or asleep, he wants. . . ." She seemed to remember Egwene, and put on a worried smile. "You must leave, now, my Lady. He mustn't find you here, or even know you've been."

ɛɡwin wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi bækɪŋ ɪn əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz, ən sɪlvi fɑloʊd, flæpɪŋ əɹ hænz ən weɪvɪŋ əɹ stɪk. "aɪ æm ɡoʊɪŋ, sɪlvi. aɪ dʒʌst əv tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə weɪ." ʃi fɪŋɡɝd ðə stoʊn ɹɪŋ. "teɪk mi bæk tə ðə hɪlz." nʌθɪŋ hæpənd. ʃi tʃænəld ə hɛɹlaɪk floʊ tə ðə ɹɪŋ. "teɪk mi bæk tə ðə hɪlz." ðə ɹɛdstoʊn kɑləmz stɪl sɝaʊndəd hɝ. ðə buts wɝ kloʊsɝ, kloʊs ɪnʌf nɑt tə bi swɑloʊɾ ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn ɛkoʊz ɛnimɔɹ.

Egwene was already backing in among the columns, and Silvie followed, flapping her hands and waving her stick. "I am going, Silvie. I just have to remember the way." She fingered the stone ring. "Take me back to the hills." Nothing happened. She channeled a hairlike flow to the ring. "Take me back to the hills." The redstone columns still surrounded her. The boots were closer, close enough not to be swallowed in their own echoes anymore.

"ju doʊnt noʊ ðə weɪ aʊt," sɪlvi sɛd flætli, ðən wɛn ɑn ɪn ə nɪɹ wɪspɝ, ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪɾɪŋ ən mɑkɪŋ ət wʌns, ən oʊld ɹɪteɪnɝ u fɛlt ʃi kəd teɪk lɪbɝɾiz. "oʊ, maɪ leɪɾi, ðɪs ɪz ə deɪnʒɝəs pleɪs tə kʌm ɪntu, ɪf jə doʊnt noʊ ðə weɪ aʊt. kʌm, lɛt pʊɹ oʊl sɪlvi teɪk jə aʊt. pʊɹ oʊl sɪlvi wɪl tʌk jə seɪf ɪn jəɹ bɛd, maɪ leɪɾi." ʃi ɹæp boʊθ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ɛɡwin, ɝdʒɪŋ əɹ fɝðɝ fɹəm ðə sɔɹd. nɑt ðəɾ ɛɡwin niɾəd mʌtʃ ɝdʒɪŋ. ðə buts hæd stɑpt; hi - huɛvɝ i wɑz - wɑz pɹɑbli ɡeɪzɪŋ ət kælændɝ.

"You don't know the way out," Sylvie said flatly, then went on in a near whisper, ingratiating and mocking at once, an old retainer who felt she could take liberties. "Oh, my Lady, this is a dangerous place to come into, if you don't know the way out. Come, let poor old Silvie take you out. Poor old Silvie will tuck you safe in your bed, my Lady." She wrapped both arms around Egwene, urging her further from the sword. Not that Egwene needed much urging. The boots had stopped; he - whoever he was - was probably gazing at Callandor.

"dʒʌst ʃoʊ mi ðə weɪ," ɛɡwin wɪspɝd bæk. "ɔɹ tɛl mi. ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə pʊʃ." ði oʊld wʊmənz fɪŋɡɝz hæd sʌmhaʊ ɡɑɾən tæŋɡəld ɝaʊn ðə stoʊn ɹɪŋ. "doʊn tʌtʃ ðæt, sɪlvi."

"Just show me the way," Egwene whispered back. "Or tell me. There's no need to push." The old woman's fingers had somehow gotten tangled around the stone ring. "Don't touch that, Silvie."

"seɪf ɪn jəɹ bɛd."

"Safe in your bed."

peɪn ənaɪəleɪɾɪd ðə wɝld.

Pain annihilated the world.

wɪð ə θɹoʊt-ɹɛntʃɪŋ ʃɹik, ɛɡwin sæɾ ʌp ɪn ðə dɑɹk, swɛt ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn əɹ feɪs. fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi hæd noʊ aɪdiə wɛɹ ʃi wɑz, ən dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. "oʊ, laɪt," ʃi moʊnd, "ðæt hɝt. oʊ, laɪt, ðət hɝt!" ʃi ɹæn əɹ hænz oʊvɝ hɝsɛlf, ʃʊɹ əɹ skɪn mʌs bi skɔɹɾ əɹ wɛl tə meɪk sətʃ ə bɝnɪŋ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt faɪn ə mɑɹk.

With a throat-wrenching shriek, Egwene sat up in the dark, sweat rolling down her face. For a moment she had no idea where she was, and did not care. "Oh, Light," she moaned, "that hurt. Oh, Light, that hurt!" She ran her hands over herself, sure her skin must be scored or wealed to make such a burning, but she could not find a mark.

"wi ɑɹ hɪɹ," nɪneɪivz vɔɪs sɛd fɹəm ðə dɑɹknəs. "wɝ hɪɹ, ɛɡwin."

"We are here," Nynaeve's voice said from the darkness. "We're here, Egwene."

ɛɡwin θɹu hɝsɛlf təwɔɹd ðə vɔɪs ən ɹæpt əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊnd nɪneɪivz nɛk ɪn ʃɪɹ ɹɪlif. "oʊ, laɪt, aɪm bæk. laɪt, aɪm bæk."

Egwene threw herself toward the voice and wrapped her arms around Nynaeve's neck in sheer relief. "Oh, Light, I'm back. Light, I'm back."

"ɪleɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"Elayne," Nynaeve said.

ɪn ə fju moʊməns wʌn ə ðə kændəlz wɑz ɡɪvɪŋ ə smɔl laɪt. ɪleɪn pɔzd wɪð ðə kændəl ɪn hæn ən ðə spɪl ʃi hæd lɪt wɪð flɪn ən stil ɪn ði ʌðɝ. ðən ʃi smaɪld, ən ɛvɹi kændəl ɪn ðə ɹum bɝst ɪndə fleɪm. ʃi stɑpt ət ðə wɑʃstæn ən keɪm bæk tə ðə bɛd wɪð ə kul, dæmp klɔθ tə wɑʃ ɛɡwinz feɪs.

In a few moments one of the candles was giving a small light. Elayne paused with the candle in hand and the spill she had lit with flint and steel in the other. Then she smiled, and every candle in the room burst into flame. She stopped at the washstand and came back to the bed with a cool, damp cloth to wash Egwene's face.

"wɑz ɪt bæd?" ʃi æskt wɝidli. "ju nɛvɝ stɝd. jə nɛvɝ mʌmbəld. wi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə weɪk jə əɹ nɑt."

"Was it bad?" she asked worriedly. "You never stirred. You never mumbled. We did not know whether to wake you or not."

hɝidli, ɛɡwin fʌmbəl ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹd fɹəm ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk ən hɝld ɪɾ ən ðə stoʊn ɹɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum. "nɛks taɪm," ʃi pæntɪd, "wi dɪsaɪɾ ɑn ə taɪm, ən jə weɪk mi æftɝ ɪt. weɪk mi ɪf juv tə stɪk maɪ hɛɾ ɪn ə beɪsən ʌv wɔɾɝ!" ʃi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɹ wəd bi ə nɛks taɪm. wəd jə pʊt jəɹ hɛɾ ɪn ə bɛɹz maʊθ dʒʌs tə ʃoʊ jə wɝn əfɹeɪd? wəd jə də ɪt twaɪs dʒʌs kəz jud dʌn ɪt wʌns ən dɪdn daɪ?

Hurriedly, Egwene fumbled the leather cord from around her neck and hurled it and the stone ring across the room. "Next time," she panted, "we decide on a time, and you wake me after it. Wake me if you have to stick my head in a basin of water!" She had not realized that she had decided there would be a next time. Would you put your head in a bear's mouth just to show you weren't afraid? Would you do it twice just because you'd done it once and didn't die?

jɛɾ ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə mæɾɝ ə pɹuvɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd. ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd, ən nu ɪt. bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæd ðoʊz tɛɹæŋɡɹil kɔɹiənɪn hæd stʌɾid, ʃi wəɾ əv tə kip ɡoʊɪŋ bæk. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ði ænsɝ tə waɪ ðeɪ wɑntəɾ əm leɪ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ɪf ʃi kəd faɪn ænsɝz əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ ðəɹ - pɝhæps ʌðɝ ænsɝz, tu, ɪf hæf wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn toʊld əbaʊt dʒɹimɪŋ wɝ tʃɹu - ʃi hæd tə ɡoʊ bæk. "bʌt nɑt tənaɪt," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "nɑt jɛt."

Yet it was more than a matter of proving to herself that she was not afraid. She was afraid, and knew it. But so long as the Black Ajah had those ter'angreal Corianin had studied, she would have to keep going back. She was sure the answer to why they wanted them lay in Tel'aran'rhiod. If she could find answers about the Black Ajah there - perhaps other answers, too, if half what she had been told about Dreaming were true - she had to go back. "But not tonight," she said softly. "Not yet."

"wʌt hæpənd?" nɪneɪiv æskt. "wʌt dɪd jə . . . dʒɹim?"

"What happened?" Nynaeve asked. "What did you . . . dream?"

ɛɡwin leɪ bæk ɑn ðə bɛɾ ən toʊl ðɛm. ʌv ɪɾ ɔl, ði oʊnli θɪŋ ʃi lɛft aʊt wɑz əbaʊt pɛɹɪn tɔkɪŋ tə ðə wʊlf. ʃi lɛf ðə wʊlf aʊɾ ɔltəɡɛðɝ. ʃi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl ɡɪlti əbaʊt kipɪŋ sikɹəts fɹəm ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz pɛɹɪnz sikɹət tə tɛl, wən ən ɪf i tʃoʊz, nɑt hɝz. ðə ɹɛst ʃi ɡeɪv əm wɝd fəɹ wɝd, dɪskɹaɪbɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. wən ʃi wɑz dʌn, ʃi fɛlt ɛmptid.

Egwene lay back on the bed and told them. Of it all, the only thing she left out was about Perrin talking to the wolf. She left the wolf out altogether. She felt a little guilty about keeping secrets from Elayne and Nynaeve, but it was Perrin's secret to tell, when and if he chose, not hers. The rest she gave them word for word, describing everything. When she was done, she felt emptied.

"əsaɪd fɹəm biɪŋ taɪɝd," ɪleɪn sɛd, "dɪɾ i lʊk hɝt? ɛɡwin, aɪ kænɑt bɪliv i wəɾ ɛvɝ hɝt ju. aɪ kænɑt bɪliv i wʊd."

"Aside from being tired," Elayne said, "did he look hurt? Egwene, I cannot believe he would ever hurt you. I cannot believe he would."

"ɹænd," nɪneɪiv sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "wɪl əv tə lʊk æftɝ hɪmsɛlf əwaɪl lɔŋɡɝ." ɪleɪn blʌʃt; ʃi lʊk pɹɪɾi duɪŋ ɪt. ɛɡwin ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪleɪn lʊk pɹɪɾi duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ, ivən kɹaɪɪŋ, əɹ skɹʌbɪŋ pɑts. "kælændɝ," nɪneɪiv kəntɪnjud. "ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn. ðət wɑz mɑɹkt ɑn ðə plæn. aɪ θɪŋk wi noʊ wɛɹ ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪz."

"Rand," Nynaeve said dryly, "will have to look after himself awhile longer." Elayne blushed; she looked pretty doing it. Egwene realized that Elayne looked pretty doing anything, even crying, or scrubbing pots. "Callandor," Nynaeve continued. "The Heart of the Stone. That was marked on the plan. I think we know where the Black Ajah is."

ɪleɪn hæd ɹiɡeɪn əɹ pɔɪz. "ɪt dʌz nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ðə tʃɹæp," ʃi sɛd. "ɪf ɪts nɑɾ ə daɪvɝʒən, ɪts ə tʃɹæp."

Elayne had regained her poise. "It does not change the trap," she said. "If it is not a diversion, it is a trap."

nɪneɪiv smaɪld ɡɹɪmli. "ðə bɛst weɪ tə kætʃ huɛvɝ sɛɾ ə tʃɹæp ɪz tə spɹɪŋ ɪɾ ən weɪt fəɹ ɪm tə kʌm. əɹ hɝ, ɪn ðɪs ɪnstəns."

Nynaeve smiled grimly. "The best way to catch whoever set a trap is to spring it and wait for him to come. Or her, in this instance."

"ju min ɡoʊ tə tɛɹ?" ɛɡwin sɛd, ən nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd.

"You mean go to Tear?" Egwene said, and Nynaeve nodded.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn əz kʌɾ əs lus, ɪt simz. wi meɪk əɹ oʊn dɪsɪʒənz, ɹɪmɛmbɝ? ət list wi noʊ ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪz ɪn tiɹ, ən wi noʊ hu tə lʊk fəɹ ðɛɹ. hɪɹ, ɔl wi kən də ɪz sɪɾ ən stu ɪn əɹ oʊn səspɪʃənz ʌv ɛvɹibɑɾi, wʌndɝ ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ənʌðɝ ɡɹeɪ mæn aʊt ðɛɹ. aɪ wəd ɹæðɝ bi ðə haʊn ðən ðə ɹæbət."

"The Amyrlin has cut us loose, it seems. We make our own decisions, remember? At least we know the Black Ajah is in Tear, and we know who to look for there. Here, all we can do is sit and stew in our own suspicions of everybody, wonder if there is another Gray Man out there. I would rather be the hound than the rabbit."

"aɪ hæv tə ɹaɪt tə maɪ mʌðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. wən ʃi sɔ ðə lʊks ðeɪ ɡeɪv hɝ, hɝ vɔɪs bɪkeɪm dɪfɛnsɪv. "aɪ hæv ɔlɹɛɾi vænɪʃt wʌns wɪθaʊɾ əɹ noʊɪŋ wɛɹ aɪ wɑz. ɪf aɪ də ɪɾ əɡɛn. . . . jə də nɑt noʊ mʌðɝz tɛmpɝ. ʃi kəd sɛnd ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ən ðə hoʊl ɑɹmi əɡɛns tɑɹ vəlɑn. əɹ hʌntɪŋ æftɝ ʌs."

"I have to write to my mother," Elayne said. When she saw the looks they gave her, her voice became defensive. "I have already vanished once without her knowing where I was. If I do it again. . . . You do not know Mother's temper. She could send Gareth Bryne and the whole army against Tar Valon. Or hunting after us."

"ju kəd steɪ hɪɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"You could stay here," Egwene said.

"noʊ. əl nɑt lɛt jə tu ɡoʊ əloʊn. ən aɪ woʊn steɪ hɪɹ wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðə sɪstɝ titʃɪŋ mi ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, əɹ ɪf ðə nɛkst ɡɹeɪ mæn wɪl kʌm æftɝ mi." ʃi ɡeɪv ə smɔl læf. "aɪ wɪl nɑt wɝk ɪn ðə kɪtʃənz waɪl jə tu ɑɹ ɔf ædvɛntʊɹɪŋ, iðɝ. aɪ dʒʌst əv tə tɛl maɪ mʌðɝ ðən aɪm aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɔɹɾɝz, soʊ ʃi woʊn bɪkʌm fjʊɹiəs ɪf ʃi hɪɹz ɹumɝz. aɪ də nɑɾ əv tə tɛl əɹ wɛɹ wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ, əɹ waɪ."

"No. I will not let you two go alone. And I won't stay here wondering if the sister teaching me is a Darkfriend, or if the next Gray Man will come after me." She gave a small laugh. "I will not work in the kitchens while you two are off adventuring, either. I just have to tell my mother than I am out of the Tower on the Amyrlin's orders, so she won't become furious if she hears rumors. I do not have to tell her where we are going, or why."

"ju ʃʊɹli hæd bɛɾɝ nɑt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ʃi vɛɹi laɪkli wəd kʌm æftɝ jə ɪf ʃi nu əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, jə kænt noʊ haʊ mɛni hænz jəɹ lɛɾɝ wɪl pæs θɹu bɪfɔɹ ɪt ɹitʃəz hɝ, əɹ wʌɾ aɪz maɪt ɹɛɾ ɪt. bɛs nɑt tə seɪ ɛniθɪŋ jə doʊn maɪn ɛniwʌn noʊɪŋ."

"You surely had better not," Nynaeve said. "She very likely would come after you if she knew about the Black Ajah. For that matter, you can't know how many hands your letter will pass through before it reaches her, or what eyes might read it. Best not to say anything you don't mind anyone knowing."

"ðæts ənʌðɝ θɪŋ." ɪleɪn saɪd. "ði æmɪɝlɪn dʌz nɑt noʊ aɪm wʌn ə ju. aɪ hæv tə faɪn səm weɪ tə sɛn ɪt wɪð noʊ tʃæns ə hɝ siɪŋ ɪt."

"That's another thing." Elayne sighed. "The Amyrlin does not know I am one of you. I have to find some way to send it with no chance of her seeing it."

"aɪ wɪl əv tə θɪŋk ɑn ðæt." nɪneɪivz bɹaʊz fɝoʊd. "pɝhæps wʌns wɝ ɑn əɹ weɪ. jə kəd liv ɪɾ əɾ ɑɹɪŋɡəl ɑn ðə weɪ daʊnɹɪvɝ, ɪf wɪv taɪm tə faɪn sʌmwʌn ðəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn. ə saɪɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðoʊz peɪpɝz ði æmɪɝlɪn ɡeɪv əs maɪt kənvɪns sʌmbɑɾi. wɪl əv tə hoʊp ðeɪ wɝk ɑn ʃɪp kæptənz, tu, ənlɛs wʌn ə jə hæz mɔɹ kɔɪn ðən aɪ hæv." ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd doʊlfəli.

"I will have to think on that." Nynaeve's brows furrowed. "Perhaps once we're on our way. You could leave it at Aringill on the way downriver, if we have time to find someone there going to Caemlyn. A sight of one of those papers the Amyrlin gave us might convince somebody. We will have to hope they work on ship captains, too, unless one of you has more coin than I have." Elayne shook her head dolefully.

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑɾ ivən bɑðɝ. wʌt mʌni ðeɪ hæd pəzɛs hæɾ ɔl ɡɔn ɑn ðə dʒɝni fɹəm toʊmən hɛd, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju kɑpɝz itʃ. "wɛn. . . ." ʃi hæd tə stɑp ən klɪɹ əɹ θɹoʊt. "wɛn də wi liv? tənaɪt?"

Egwene did not even bother. What money they had possessed had all gone on the journey from Toman Head, except for a few coppers each. "When. . . ." She had to stop and clear her throat. "When do we leave? Tonight?"

nɪneɪiv lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɝ kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ɪt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bʌt ðən ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ju nid slip, æftɝ. . . ." hɝ dʒɛstʃɝ tʊk ɪn ðə stoʊn ɹɪŋ laɪɪŋ wɛɹ ɪt hæd baʊnst ɔf ðə wɔl. "wi wɪl ɡɪv ði æmɪɝlɪn wʌn mɔɹ tʃæns tə sik əs aʊt. wən wi fɪnɪʃ wɪð bɹɛkfəst, jə boʊθ pæk wʌt jə wɑnə teɪk, bʌt kip ɪt laɪt. wɪv tə liv ðə taʊɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn noʊɾɪsɪŋ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ. ɪf ði æmɪɝlɪn dʌzn ɹitʃ əs baɪ mɪddeɪ, aɪ min tə bi ɑn ə tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ʃɪp, ʃʌvɪŋ ðət peɪpɝ daʊn ðə kæptənz θɹoʊɾ ɪf nid bi, bɪfɔɹ pɹaɪm saʊnz. haʊ dʌz ðət saʊn tə jə tu?"

Nynaeve looked as if she were considering it for a moment, but then she shook her head. "You need sleep, after. . . ." Her gesture took in the stone ring lying where it had bounced off the wall. "We will give the Amyrlin one more chance to seek us out. When we finish with breakfast, you both pack what you want to take, but keep it light. We have to leave the Tower without anyone noticing, remember. If the Amyrlin doesn't reach us by midday, I mean to be on a trading ship, shoving that paper down the captain's throat if need be, before Prime sounds. How does that sound to you two?"

"ɪt saʊnz ɛksələnt," ɪleɪn sɛd fɝmli, ən ɛɡwin sɛd, "tənaɪɾ əɹ təmɑɹoʊ, ðə sunɝ ðə bɛɾɝ, əz fɑɹ əz aɪ kən si." ʃi wɪʃt ʃi saʊndəɾ əz kɑnfəɾənt əz ɪleɪn.

"It sounds excellent," Elayne said firmly, and Egwene said, "Tonight or tomorrow, the sooner the better, as far as I can see." She wished she sounded as confident as Elayne.

"ðɛn wi hæd bɛst ɡɛt səm slip."

"Then we had best get some sleep."

"nɪneɪiv," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ɪn ə smɔl vɔɪs, "aɪ. . . . aɪ doʊnt wɑnə bi əloʊn tənaɪt." ɪt peɪn əɹ tə meɪk ðəɾ ædmɪʃən.

"Nynaeve," Egwene said in a small voice, "I. . . . I don't want to be alone tonight." It pained her to make that admission.

"aɪ doʊnt, iðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ kip θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə soʊlləs. aɪ də nɑt noʊ waɪ, bʌt ðeɪ fɹaɪɾən mi ivən mɔɹ ðən ðə blæk ədʒɑ."

"I don't, either," Elayne said. "I keep thinking about the Soulless. I do not know why, but they frighten me even more than the Black Ajah."

"aɪ səpoʊz," nɪneɪiv sɛd sloʊli, "aɪ doʊn ɹɪli wɑnə bi əloʊn, maɪsɛlf." ʃi aɪd ðə bɛd wɛɹ ɛɡwin leɪ. "ðæt lʊks bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ θɹi, ɪf ɛvɹibɑɾi kips əɹ ɛlboʊz tə hɝsɛlf."

"I suppose," Nynaeve said slowly, "I don't really want to be alone, myself." She eyed the bed where Egwene lay. "That looks big enough for three, if everybody keeps her elbows to herself."

leɪɾɝ, wən ðeɪ wɝ ʃɪftɪŋ əbaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ə weɪ tə laɪ ðət dɪd nɑt fil soʊ kɹaʊɾəd, nɪneɪiv sʌɾənli læft.

Later, when they were shifting about trying to find a way to lie that did not feel so crowded, Nynaeve suddenly laughed.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" ɛɡwin æskt. "ju ɑɹ nɑt ðət tɪkəlɪʃ."

"What is it?" Egwene asked. "You are not that ticklish."

"aɪ dʒʌs θɔɾ ə sʌmwʌn hud bi hæpi tə kæɹi ɪleɪnz lɛɾɝ fəɹ hɝ. hæpi tə liv tɑɹ vəlɑn, tu. ɪn fækt, aɪd bɛɾ ɑn ɪt."

"I just thought of someone who'd be happy to carry Elayne's letter for her. Happy to leave Tar Valon, too. In fact, I'd bet on it."


tʃæptɝ twɛntieɪt


CHAPTER 28

eɪ weɪ aʊt


A Way Out

klæɾ oʊnli ɪn ɪz bɹitʃɪz, mæt wɑz dʒʌs fɪnɪʃɪŋ ə snæk æftɝ bɹɛkfəst - səm hæm, θɹi æpəlz, bɹɛd, ən bʌɾɝ - wən ðə dɔɹ ə hɪz ɹum oʊpənd, ən nɪneɪiv, ɛɡwin, ən ɪleɪn faɪld ɪn, ɔl smaɪlɪŋ əɾ ɪm bɹaɪtli. hi ɡɑɾ ʌp fəɹ ə ʃɝt, ðən stʌbɝnli sæt daʊn əɡɛn. ðeɪ kəɾ ət list əv nɑkt. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə si ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ət fɝst, ɪt wɑz.

Clad only in his breeches, Mat was just finishing a snack after breakfast - some ham, three apples, bread, and butter - when the door of his room opened, and Nynaeve, Egwene, and Elayne filed in, all smiling at him brightly. He got up for a shirt, then stubbornly sat down again. They could at least have knocked. In any case, it was good to see their faces. At first, it was.

"wɛl, jə də lʊk bɛɾɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Well, you do look better," Egwene said.

"æz ɪf jə hæd hæɾ ə mʌnθ ʌv ɡʊd fuɾ ən ɹɛst," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"As if you had had a month of good food and rest," Elayne said.

nɪneɪiv pɹɛst ə hæn tə hɪz fɔɹhɛd. hi flɪntʃt bɪfɔɹ i ɹɪkɔl ðət ʃi hæd dʌn mʌtʃ ðə seɪm fəɹ ət lis faɪv jɪɹz, bæk hoʊm. ʃi wɑz dʒʌs ðə wɪzdəm ðɛn, hi θɔt. ʃi wɑznt wɛɹɪŋ ðət ɹɪŋ.

Nynaeve pressed a hand to his forehead. He flinched before he recalled that she had done much the same for at least five years, back home. She was just the Wisdom then, he thought. She wasn't wearing that ring.

ʃi hæd noʊɾəst ɪz flɪntʃ. ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə taɪt smaɪl. "ju lʊk ɹɛɾi tə bi ʌp ən əbaʊt, tə mi. ɑɹ jə taɪɝɾ ə biɪŋ kupt ʌp, jɛt? jə nɛvɝ kəd stæn tu deɪz ɪn ə ɹoʊ ɪndɔɹz."

She had noticed his flinch. She gave him a tight smile. "You look ready to be up and about, to me. Are you tired of being cooped up, yet? You never could stand two days in a row indoors."

hi aɪd ðə læst æpəl kɔɹ ɹɪlʌktənli, ðən dʒɹɑpt ɪt bæk ɑn ðə pleɪt. ɔlmoʊst, hi stɑɹɾəd tə lɪk ðə dʒus ɔf ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɔl θɹi lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. ən stɪl smaɪlɪŋ. hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd wɪtʃ ə ðɛm wɑz pɹɪɾiəst, ən kəd nɑt. hæd ðeɪ bɪn ɛnibəɾi bʌɾ u - ən wʌt - ðeɪ wɝ, hi wʊɾə æskt ɛni ən ɔl ə ðɛm tə dæns ə dʒɪɡ əɹ ə ɹil. hi hæd dænst wɪð ɛɡwin ɔfən ɪnʌf, bæk hoʊm, ən ivən wʌns wɪð nɪneɪiv, bʌt ðət simd ə lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ.

He eyed the last apple core reluctantly, then dropped it back on the plate. Almost, he started to lick the juice off his fingers, but they were all three looking at him. And still smiling. He realized he was trying to decide which of them was prettiest, and could not. Had they been anybody but who - and what - they were, he would have asked any and all of them to dance a jig or a reel. He had danced with Egwene often enough, back home, and even once with Nynaeve, but that seemed a long time ago.

" 'wʌn pɹɪɾi wʊmən minz fʌn ət ðə dæns. tu pɹɪɾi wɪmən min tʃɹʌbəl ɪn ðə haʊs. θɹi pɹɪɾi wɪmən min ɹʌn fəɹ ðə hɪlz.' " hi ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv ən ivən taɪɾɝ smaɪl ðən əɹ oʊn. "maɪ dɑ juz tə seɪ ðæt. jəɹ ʌp tə sʌmθɪŋ, nɪneɪiv. jə ɑɹ ɔl smaɪlɪŋ laɪk kæts stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə fɪntʃ kɑɾ ɪn ə θɔɹnbʊʃ, ən aɪ θɪŋk aɪm ðə fɪntʃ."

" 'One pretty woman means fun at the dance. Two pretty women mean trouble in the house. Three pretty women mean run for the hills.' " He gave Nynaeve an even tighter smile than her own. "My da used to say that. You're up to something, Nynaeve. You are all smiling like cats staring at a finch caught in a thornbush, and I think I am the finch."

ðə smaɪlz flɪkɝɾ ən vænɪʃt. hi noʊɾəst ðɛɹ hænz ən wʌndɝd waɪ ðeɪ ɔl lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn wɑʃɪŋ dɪʃəz. ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ ʃʊɹli nɛvɝ wɑʃt ə dɪʃ, ən i hæɾ əz hɑɹɾ ə taɪm ɪmædʒənɪŋ nɪneɪiv əɾ ɪt, ivən noʊɪŋ ʃi hæd dʌn əɹ oʊn bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild. ðeɪ ɔl θɹi wɔɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋz, naʊ. ðət wɑz nu. ən nɑɾ ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli plɛzən sɝpɹaɪz. laɪt, ɪt hæd tə hæpən sʌmtaɪm. ɪts nʌn ə maɪ bɪznəs, ən ðəɾ ɪz ɔl ðəɹ ɪz tə ɪt. nʌn ə maɪ bɪznəs. ɪt dʒʌst ɪzənt.

The smiles flickered and vanished. He noticed their hands and wondered why they all looked as if they had been washing dishes. The Daughter-Heir of Andor surely never washed a dish, and he had as hard a time imagining Nynaeve at it, even knowing she had done her own back in Emond's Field. They all three wore Great Serpent rings, now. That was new. And not a particularly pleasant surprise. Light, it had to happen sometime. It's none of my business, and that is all there is to it. None of my business. It just isn't.

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, bʌɾ ɪt simd əz mʌtʃ fəɹ ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən əz fəɹ hɪm. "aɪ toʊl jə wi ʃəɾ æsk ɪm stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt. hiz stʌbɝn əz ɛni mjul wən i wɑns tə bi, ən tʃɹɪksəm əz ə kæt. jə ɑɹ, mæt. jə noʊ ɪt, soʊ stɑp fɹaʊnɪŋ."

Egwene shook her head, but it seemed as much for the other two women as for him. "I told you we should ask him straight out. He's stubborn as any mule when he wants to be, and tricksome as a cat. You are, Mat. You know it, so stop frowning."

hi pʊɾ ɪz ɡɹɪn bæk kwɪkli.

He put his grin back quickly.

"hʌʃ, ɛɡwin," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "mæt, dʒʌs kəz wi wɑnə æsk jə ə feɪvɝ dʌz nɑt min wi doʊn kɛɹ haʊ jə fil. wi də kɛɹ, ən jə noʊ ðæt, ənlɛs jəɹ biɪŋ ivən mɔɹ wʊl-hɛɾəd ðən juʒəwəl. ɑɹ jə wɛl? jə lʊk ɹɪmɑɹkəbli wɛl kəmpɛɹd tə haʊ aɪ læst sɔ ju. ɪt ɹɪli dʌz lʊk mɔɹ laɪk ə mʌnθ ðən tu deɪz."

"Hush, Egwene," Nynaeve said. "Mat, just because we want to ask you a favor does not mean we don't care how you feel. We do care, and you know that, unless you're being even more wool-headed than usual. Are you well? You look remarkably well compared to how I last saw you. It really does look more like a month than two days."

"aɪm ɹɛɾi tə ɹʌn tɛn maɪlz ən dæns ə dʒɪɡ ət ði ɛn ʌv ɪt." hɪz stʌmək ɡɹaʊld, ɹimaɪndɪŋ ɪm haʊ lɔŋ ɪt wɑz tə mɪddeɪ jɛt, bʌɾ i ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt, ən hoʊp ðeɪ hæd nɑt noʊɾəst. hi ɔlmoʊs dɪd fil əz ɪf i hæd hæɾ ə mʌnθ ə ɹɛst ən fud. ən hæd hæd wʌn mil ɪn ðə læs deɪ. "wʌt feɪvɝ?" hi æsk səspɪʃəsli. nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑɾ æsk feɪvɝz, ɪn ɪz ɹɛkəlɛkʃən; nɪneɪiv toʊl pipəl wʌt tə də ən ɪkspɛktəd tə si ɪt dʌn.

"I'm ready to run ten miles and dance a jig at the end of it." His stomach growled, reminding him how long it was to midday yet, but he ignored it, and hoped they had not noticed. He almost did feel as if he had had a month of rest and food. And had had one meal in the last day. "What favor?" he asked suspiciously. Nynaeve did not ask favors, in his recollection; Nynaeve told people what to do and expected to see it done.

"aɪ wɑn jə tə kæɹi ə lɛɾɝ fəɹ mi," ɪleɪn sɛd bɪfɔɹ nɪneɪiv kəd spik. "tə maɪ mʌðɝ, ɪn keɪɛmlɪn." ʃi smaɪld, meɪkɪŋ ə dɪmpəl ɪn əɹ tʃik. "aɪ wəɾ əpɹiʃieɪɾ ɪt soʊ vɛɹi mʌtʃ, mæt." ðə mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt θɹu ðə wɪndoʊz sim tə pɪk aʊt haɪlaɪts ɪn əɹ hɛɹ.

"I want you to carry a letter for me," Elayne said before Nynaeve could speak. "To my mother, in Caemlyn." She smiled, making a dimple in her cheek. "I would appreciate it so very much, Mat." The morning light through the windows seemed to pick out highlights in her hair.

aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf ʃi laɪks tə dæns. hi pʊʃt ðə θɔt ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd. "ðæt dʌz nɑt saʊn tu vɛɹi hɑɹd, bʌɾ ɪts ə lɔŋ tʃɹɪp. wʌt də aɪ ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt?" fɹəm ðə lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs, hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðət dɪmpəl hæd feɪld əɹ vɛɹi ɔfən.

I wonder if she likes to dance. He pushed the thought right out of his head. "That does not sound too very hard, but it's a long trip. What do I get out of it?" From the look on her face, he did not think that dimple had failed her very often.

ʃi dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, slɪm ən pɹaʊd. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si ə θɹoʊn bɪhaɪn hɝ. "ɑɹ jə ə lɔɪəl sʌbʒɪkt ʌv ændɝ? dʒju nɑt wɪʃ tə sɝv ðə laɪən θɹoʊn, ən jəɹ dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ?"

She drew herself up, slim and proud. He could almost see a throne behind her. "Are you a loyal subject of Andor? Do you not wish to serve the Lion Throne, and your Daughter-Heir?"

mæt snɪkɝd.

Mat snickered.

"aɪ toʊl jə ðət wəd nɑt wɝk iðɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "nɑt wɪð hɪm."

"I told you that would not work either," Egwene said. "Not with him."

ɪleɪn hæɾ ə ɹaɪ twɪs tə hɝ maʊθ. "aɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɝθ ə tʃɹaɪ. ɪɾ ɔlweɪz wɝks ɑn ðə ɡɑɹdz, ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. jə sɛɾ ɪf aɪ smaɪld - " ʃi kʌɾ ɔf ʃɔɹt, vɛɹi ɑbviəsli nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm.

Elayne had a wry twist to her mouth. "I thought it worth a try. It always works on the Guards, in Caemlyn. You said if I smiled - " She cut off short, very obviously not looking at him.

wʌd jə seɪ, ɛɡwin, hi θɔt, fjʊɹiəs. ðəɾ ɪm ə ful fəɹ ɛni ɡɝl u smaɪlz ət mi? hi kɛpt ɪz aʊtwɝd kɑm, ðoʊ, ən mænədʒ tə meɪnteɪn ɪz ɡɹɪn.

What did you say, Egwene, he thought, furious. That I'm a fool for any girl who smiles at me? He kept his outward calm, though, and managed to maintain his grin.

"aɪ wɪʃ æskɪŋ wɝ ɪnʌf," ɛɡwin sɛd, "bʌt jə də nɑt də feɪvɝz, də ju, mæt? hæv jə ɛvɝ dʌn ɛniθɪŋ wɪθaʊt biɪŋ koʊkst, wiɾəld, əɹ bʊlid?"

"I wish asking were enough," Egwene said, "but you do not do favors, do you, Mat? Have you ever done anything without being coaxed, wheedled, or bullied?"

hi oʊnli smaɪld ət hɝ. "aɪ wɪl dæns wɪð boʊθ ə ju, ɛɡwin, bʌɾ aɪ woʊn ɹʌn ɛɹənz." fəɹ ən ɪnstən i θɔt ʃi wɑz gɑnə stɪk aʊɾ əɹ tʌŋ ət hɪm.

He only smiled at her. "I will dance with both of you, Egwene, but I won't run errands." For an instant he thought she was going to stick out her tongue at him.

"ɪf wi kən ɡoʊ bæk tə wʌt wi plæn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə tu-kɑm vɔɪs. ði ʌðɝ tu nɑɾəd, ən ʃi tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃənz ɑn hɪm. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm sɪns kʌmɪŋ ɪn, ʃi lʊk laɪk ðə wɪzdəm ʌv oʊld, wɪð ə stɛɹ ðət kəd pɪn jə ɪn jəɹ tʃɹæks ən əɹ bɹeɪd ɹɛɾi tə læʃ laɪk ə kæts teɪl.

"If we can go back to what we planned in the first place," Nynaeve said in a too-calm voice. The other two nodded, and she turned her attentions on him. For the first time since coming in, she looked like the Wisdom of old, with a stare that could pin you in your tracks and her braid ready to lash like a cat's tail.

"ju ɑɹ ivən ɹuɾɝ ðən aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝd, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. wɪð jə sɪk soʊ lɔŋ - ən ɛɡwin, ən ɪleɪn, ən aɪ teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ə jə laɪk ə beɪb ɪn swɑɾəlɪŋ - aɪ hæɾ ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɑɾən. ivən soʊ, aɪ wəd θɪŋk juɾ əv ə lɪɾəl ɡɹæɾətud ɪn ju. juv tɔkt əbaʊt siɪŋ ðə wɝld, siɪŋ ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz. wɛl, wʌt bɛɾɝ sɪɾi ðən keɪɛmlɪn? də wʌt jə wɑnt, ʃoʊ jəɹ ɡɹæɾətud, ən hɛlp sʌmwʌn ɔl ət ðə seɪm taɪm." ʃi pɹədust ə foʊldəd pɑɹtʃmən fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ kloʊk ən sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ɪt wɑz sild wɪð ə lɪli, ɪn ɡoʊldən jɛloʊ wæks. "ju kænɑɾ æsk fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ðæt."

"You are even ruder than I remembered, Matrim Cauthon. With you sick so long - and Egwene, and Elayne, and I taking care of you like a babe in swaddling - I had almost forgotten. Even so, I would think you'd have a little gratitude in you. You've talked about seeing the world, seeing great cities. Well, what better city than Caemlyn? Do what you want, show your gratitude, and help someone all at the same time." She produced a folded parchment from inside her cloak and set it on the table. It was sealed with a lily, in golden yellow wax. "You cannot ask for more than that."

hi aɪd ðə peɪpɝ ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli. hi bɛɹli ɹɪmɛmbɝd pæsɪŋ θɹu keɪɛmlɪn, wʌns, wɪð ɹænd. ɪt wɑz ə ʃeɪm tə stɑp əm naʊ, bʌɾ i θɔɾ ɪt bɛst. ɪf jə wɑn ðə fʌn ə ðə dʒɪɡ, juv tə peɪ ðə hɑɹpɝ sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. ən ðə weɪ nɪneɪiv wɑz naʊ, ðə lɔŋɡɝ i kɛp fɹəm peɪɪŋ, ðə wɝs ɪt wəd bi. "nɪneɪiv, aɪ kænt."

He eyed the paper regretfully. He barely remembered passing through Caemlyn, once, with Rand. It was a shame to stop them now, but he thought it best. If you want the fun of the jig, you have to pay the harper sooner or later. And the way Nynaeve was now, the longer he kept from paying, the worse it would be. "Nynaeve, I can't."

"wʌt dʒju min, jə kænɑt? ɑɹ jə ə flaɪ ɑn ðə wɔl, əɹ ə mæn? ə tʃæns tə də ə feɪvɝ fəɹ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, tə si keɪɛmlɪn, tə mit kwin mɔɹɡeɪs hɝsɛlf ɪn ɔl pɹɑbəbɪləɾi, ən jə kænɑt? aɪ ɹɪli də nɑt noʊ wʌt mɔɹ jə kəd pɑsəbli wɑnt. doʊn jə skɪɾɝ əweɪ laɪk ɡɹis ɑn ə ɡɹɪɾəl ðɪs taɪm, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən! əɹ əz jəɹ hɑɹt tʃeɪnʒd soʊ jə laɪk siɪŋ ðiz ɔl ɝaʊn ju?" ʃi weɪvd əɹ lɛf hæn ɪn ɪz feɪs, pɹæktəkli hɪɾɪŋ ɪm ɪn ðə noʊz wɪð əɹ ɹɪŋ.

"What do you mean, you cannot? Are you a fly on the wall, or a man? A chance to do a favor for the Daughter-Heir of Andor, to see Caemlyn, to meet Queen Morgase herself in all probability, and you cannot? I really do not know what more you could possibly want. Don't you skitter away like grease on a griddle this time, Matrim Cauthon! Or has your heart changed so you like seeing these all around you?" She waved her left hand in his face, practically hitting him in the nose with her ring.

"pliz, mæt?" ɪleɪn sɛd, ən ɛɡwin wɑz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i hæd ɡɹoʊn hɔɹnz laɪk ə tʃɹɑlɑk.

"Please, Mat?" Elayne said, and Egwene was staring at him as if he had grown horns like a Trolloc.

hi skwɝmd ɑn ɪz tʃɛɹ. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt ðəɾ aɪ doʊnt wɑn tə. aɪ kænɑt! ði æmɪɝlɪnz meɪɾ ɪt soʊ aɪ kænt ɡɛɾ ɔf ðə blu - ði aɪlənd. tʃeɪnʒ ðæt, ən əl kæɹi jəɹ lɛɾɝ ɪn maɪ tiθ, ɪleɪn."

He squirmed on his chair. "It is not that I don't want to. I cannot! The Amyrlin's made it so I can't get off the bloo - the island. Change that, and I will carry your letter in my teeth, Elayne."

lʊks pæs bɪtwin ðɛm. hi səmtaɪmz wʌndɝɾ ɪf wɪmən kəd ɹiɾ itʃ ʌðɝz maɪnz. ðeɪ sɝɾənli sim tə ɹiɾ ɪz wən i list wɑntəɾ ɪt. bʌt ðɪs taɪm, wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd saɪlənli əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ðeɪ hæd nɑt ɹɛɾ ɪz θɔts.

Looks passed between them. He sometimes wondered if women could read each other's minds. They certainly seemed to read his when he least wanted it. But this time, whatever they had decided silently among themselves, they had not read his thoughts.

"ɪkspleɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd kɝtli. "waɪ wəd ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑnə kip jə hɪɹ?"

"Explain," Nynaeve said curtly. "Why would the Amyrlin want to keep you here?"

hi ʃɹʌɡd, ən lʊkt əɹ stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ði aɪ, ən ɡeɪv əɹ ɪz bɛst ɹufəl ɡɹɪn. "ɪts kəz aɪ wɑz sɪk. kəz ɪt wɛn ɑn soʊ lɔŋ. ʃi sɛd ʃi wəd nɑt lemi ɡoʊ əntɪl ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ aɪ wʊdnt ɡoʊ ɔf sʌmwɛɹ ən daɪ. nɑt ðəɾ aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə, ʌv kɔɹs. daɪ, aɪ min."

He shrugged, and looked her straight in the eye, and gave her his best rueful grin. "It's because I was sick. Because it went on so long. She said she would not let me go until she was sure I wouldn't go off somewhere and die. Not that I'm going to, of course. Die, I mean."

nɪneɪiv fɹaʊnd, ən dʒɝkt əɹ bɹeɪd, ən sʌɾənli tʊk ɪz hɛd bɪtwin əɹ hænz; ə tʃɪl ɹæn θɹu hɪm. laɪt, ðə paʊɝ! bɪfɔɹ ðə θɔt wɑz dʌn, ʃi hæd ɹilis hɪm.

Nynaeve frowned, and jerked her braid, and suddenly took his head between her hands; a chill ran through him. Light, the Power! Before the thought was done, she had released him.

"wʌt . . . ? wʌd jə də tə mi, nɪneɪiv?"

"What . . . ? What did you do to me, Nynaeve?"

"nɑɾ ə tɛnθ pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt jə dɪzɝv, ɪn ɔl laɪklihʊd," ʃi sɛd. "ju ɑɹ əz hɛlθi əz ə bʊl. wikɝ ðən jə lʊk, bʌt hɛlθi."

"Not a tenth part of what you deserve, in all likelihood," she said. "You are as healthy as a bull. Weaker than you look, but healthy."

"aɪ toʊl jə aɪ wɑz," hi sɛɾ ənizəli. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɛɾ ɪz ɡɹɪn bæk. "nɪneɪiv, ʃi lʊk laɪk ju. ði æmɪɝlɪn, aɪ min. mænɪdʒɪŋ tə lum ivən ɪf ʃiz ə fʊt tu ʃɔɹt fəɹ ɪt, ən bʊliɪŋ. . . ." ðə weɪ hɝ aɪbɹaʊz klaɪmd, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə ɹoʊd tə ɡoʊ daʊn ɛni fɝðɝ. əz lɔŋ əz i kɛpt əm əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɔɹn. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðeɪ nu. "wɛl. ɛniweɪ, aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ wɑnə kip mi hɪɹ kəz ə ðət dæɡɝ. aɪ min, əntɪl ðeɪ fɪɡjɝ aʊɾ ɪɡzækli haʊ ɪt dɪd wʌɾ ɪt dɪd. jə noʊ haʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ." hi ɡeɪv ə smɔl læf. ðeɪ ɔl dʒʌs lʊkt ət hɪm. meɪbi aɪ ʃʊdn əv sɛd ðæt. bɝn mi! ðeɪ wɑnə bi blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ. bɝn mi, aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn tu lɔŋ. aɪ wɪʃ nɪneɪiv wəd stɑp stɛɹɪŋ ət mi laɪk ðæt. kip ɪt ʃɔɹt. "ði æmɪɝlɪn meɪɾ ɪt soʊ aɪ kænɑt kɹɔs ə bɹɪdʒ əɹ bɔɹɾ ə ʃɪp wɪθaʊɾ ən ɔɹɾɝ fɹəm hɝ. jə si? ɪts nɑt ðəɾ aɪ də nɑt wɑnə hɛlp. aɪ dʒʌs kænt."

"I told you I was," he said uneasily. He tried to get his grin back. "Nynaeve, she looked like you. The Amyrlin, I mean. Managing to loom even if she is a foot too short for it, and bullying. . . ." The way her eyebrows climbed, he decided that was not a road to go down any further. As long as he kept them away from the Horn. He wondered if they knew. "Well. Anyway, I think they want to keep me here because of that dagger. I mean, until they figure out exactly how it did what it did. You know how Aes Sedai are." He gave a small laugh. They all just looked at him. Maybe I shouldn't have said that. Burn me! They want to be bloody Aes Sedai. Burn me, I'm going on too long. I wish Nynaeve would stop staring at me like that. Keep it short. "The Amyrlin made it so I cannot cross a bridge or board a ship without an order from her. You see? It's not that I do not want to help. I just can't."

"bʌt jəl ɪf wi kən ɡɛt jə aʊɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn?" nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪntɛnli.

"But you will if we can get you out of Tar Valon?" Nynaeve said intently.

"ju ɡɛt mi aʊɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən əl kæɹi ɪleɪn tə hɝ mʌðɝ ɑn maɪ bæk."

"You get me out of Tar Valon, and I'll carry Elayne to her mother on my back."

ɪleɪnz aɪbɹaʊz wɛn ʌp, ðɪs taɪm, ən ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, maʊðɪŋ ɪz neɪm wɪð ə ʃɑɹp lʊk ɪn əɹ aɪz. wɪmən hæd noʊ sɛns ə hjumɝ, səmtaɪmz.

Elayne's eyebrows went up, this time, and Egwene shook her head, mouthing his name with a sharp look in her eyes. Women had no sense of humor, sometimes.

nɪneɪiv moʊʃən ðə tu ʌv əm tə fɑloʊ hɝ tə ðə wɪndoʊz, wɛɹ ðeɪ tɝn ðɛɹ bæks tə hɪm ən tɔk soʊ sɔfli hi kəd kætʃ oʊnli ə mɝmɝ. hi θɔɾ i hɝɾ ɛɡwin seɪ sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ oʊnli niɾɪŋ wʌn ɪf ðeɪ steɪd təɡɛðɝ. wɑtʃɪŋ, hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɹɪli θɔt ðeɪ kəd ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɔɹɾɝ. ɪf ðeɪ kən də ðæt, əl kæɹi ðɛɹ blʌɾi lɛɾɝ. aɪ ɹɪli wɪl kæɹi ɪɾ ɪn maɪ tiθ.

Nynaeve motioned the two of them to follow her to the windows, where they turned their backs to him and talked so softly he could catch only a murmur. He thought he heard Egwene say something about only needing one if they stayed together. Watching, he wondered if they really thought they could get around the Amyrlin's order. If they can do that, I will carry their bloody letter. I really will carry it in my teeth.

wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, hi pɪkt ʌp ən æpəl kɔɹ ən bɪɾ ɔf ði ɛnd. wʌn tʃu, ən i heɪstəli spɪt ðə maʊθfʊl ə bɪɾɝ sidz bæk ɑntu ðə pleɪt.

Without thinking, he picked up an apple core and bit off the end. One chew, and he hastily spit the mouthful of bitter seeds back onto the plate.

wən ðeɪ keɪm bæk tə ðə teɪbəl, ɛɡwin hændəɾ ɪm ə θɪk, foʊldəd peɪpɝ. hi aɪɾ əm səspɪʃəsli bɪfɔɹ oʊpənɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt. əz i ɹɛd, hi bɪɡæn hʌmɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ ɪt.

When they came back to the table, Egwene handed him a thick, folded paper. He eyed them suspiciously before opening it out. As he read, he began humming to himself without knowing it.

wʌt ðə bɛɹɝ dʌz ɪz dʌn ət maɪ ɔɹɾɝ ən baɪ maɪ əθɔɹəɾi. oʊbeɪ, ən kip saɪlənt, ət maɪ kəmænd.

What the bearer does is done at my order and by my authority. Obey, and keep silent, at my command.

sɪuən sɑntʃ wɑtʃɝ ə ðə silz fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ən sild ət ðə bɑɾəm wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪn ə sɝkəl ʌv waɪt wæks əz hɑɹɾ əz stoʊn.

Siuan Sanche Watcher of the Seals Flame of Tar Valon The Amyrlin Seat And sealed at the bottom with the Flame of Tar Valon in a circle of white wax as hard as stone.

hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz hʌmɪŋ "eɪ pɑkət fʊl ʌv ɡoʊld" ən stɑpt. "ɪz ðɪs ɹil? jə dɪdnt . . . ? haʊ dɪd jə ɡɛt ðɪs?"

He realized he was humming "A Pocket Full of Gold" and stopped. "Is this real? You didn't . . . ? How did you get this?"

"ʃi dɪd nɑt fɔɹdʒ ɪt, ɪf ðəɾ ɪz wʌt jə min," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"She did not forge it, if that is what you mean," Elayne said.

"nɛvɝ jə maɪn haʊ wi ɡɑɾ ɪt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz ɹil. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl ðət nid kənsɝn ju. aɪ wəd nɑt ʃoʊ ɪɾ ɝaʊnd, wɝ aɪ ju, əɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪl teɪk ɪt bæk, bʌɾ ɪɾəl ɡɛt jə pæs ðə ɡɑɹdz ən ɑntu ə ʃɪp. jə sɛd jud teɪk ðə lɛɾɝ, ɪf wi dɪd ðæt."

"Never you mind how we got it," Nynaeve said. "It is real. That is all that need concern you. I would not show it around, were I you, or the Amyrlin will take it back, but it will get you past the guards and onto a ship. You said you'd take the letter, if we did that."

"ju kən kənsɪɾɝ ɪɾ ɪn mɔɹɡeɪsəz hænz ɹaɪt naʊ." hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə stɑp ɹiɾɪŋ ðə peɪpɝ, bʌɾ i foʊldəɾ ɪt bæk ʌp ɛniweɪ, ən leɪɾ ɪɾ ɑn tɑp ʌv ɪleɪnz lɛɾɝ. "ju wʊdn hæpən tə hæv ə lɪɾəl kɔɪn tə ɡoʊ wɪð ðɪs, wəd ju? səm sɪlvɝ? ə ɡoʊl mɑɹk əɹ tu? aɪ hæv ɔlmoʊst ɪnʌf fəɹ maɪ pæsədʒ, bʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ θɪŋz ɑɹ ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪkspɛnsɪv daʊnɹɪvɝ."

"You can consider it in Morgase's hands right now." He did not want to stop reading the paper, but he folded it back up anyway, and laid it on top of Elayne's letter. "You wouldn't happen to have a little coin to go with this, would you? Some silver? A gold mark or two? I have almost enough for my passage, but I hear things are growing expensive downriver."

nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "doʊn juv mʌni? jə ɡæmbəld wɪð hʊɹɪn ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi naɪɾ əntɪl jə ɡɹu tu sɪk tə hoʊl ðə daɪs. waɪ ʃəd θɪŋz bi mɔɹ ɪkspɛnsɪv daʊnɹɪvɝ?"

Nynaeve shook her head. "Don't you have money? You gambled with Hurin almost every night until you grew too sick to hold the dice. Why should things be more expensive downriver?"

"wi ɡæmbəl fəɹ kɑpɝz, nɪneɪiv, ən i wəd nɑɾ ivən də ðəɾ æftɝ ə waɪl. ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ. əl mænədʒ. doʊn jə lɪsən tə wʌt pipəl seɪ? ðɛɹz sɪvəl wɔɹ ɪn kɛɹhin, ən aɪ hɪɹ ɪts bæɾ ɪn tɛɹ, tu. aɪv hɝɾ ə ɹum əɾ ən ɪn ɪn ɑɹɪŋɡəl kɑsts mɔɹ ðən ə ɡʊd hɔɹs bæk hoʊm."

"We gambled for coppers, Nynaeve, and he would not even do that after a while. It doesn't matter. I will manage. Don't you listen to what people say? There's civil war in Cairhien, and I hear it is bad in Tear, too. I've heard a room at an inn in Aringill costs more than a good horse back home."

"wi hæv bɪn bɪzi," ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli, ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wɝid lʊks wɪð ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn ðət sɛɾ ɪm wʌndɝɪŋ əɡɛn.

"We have been busy," she said sharply, and exchanged worried looks with Egwene and Elayne that set him wondering again.

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ. aɪ kən meɪk aʊt." ðəɹ hæd tə bi ɡeɪmɪŋ ɪn ði ɪnz nɪɹ ðə dɑks. ə naɪt wɪð ðə daɪs wəd pʊɾ ɪm əbɔɹɾ ə ʃɪp ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɪð ə fʊl pɝs.

"It doesn't matter. I can make out." There had to be gaming in the inns near the docks. A night with the dice would put him aboard a ship in the morning with a full purse.

"dʒʌs jə dɪlɪvɝ ðət lɛɾɝ tə kwin mɔɹɡeɪs, mæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "æn də nɑt lɛɾ ɛniwʌn noʊ juv ɪt."

"Just you deliver that letter to Queen Morgase, Mat," Nynaeve said. "And do not let anyone know you have it."

"aɪl teɪk ɪt tə hɝ. aɪ sɛɾ aɪ wʊd, dɪdn aɪ? jə wəd θɪŋk aɪ dɪdn kip maɪ pɹɑməsəz." ðə lʊks i ɡɑt fɹəm nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ʌv ə fju hi hæd nɑt kɛpt. "aɪ wɪl də ɪt. blʌɾ ən - əl də ɪt!"

"I'll take it to her. I said I would, didn't I? You would think I didn't keep my promises." The looks he got from Nynaeve and Egwene reminded him of a few he had not kept. "I will do it. Blood and - I will do it!"

ðeɪ steɪɾ əwaɪl lɔŋɡɝ, tɔkɪŋ ə hoʊm fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt. ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn sæɾ ɑn ðə bɛd, ən nɪneɪiv tʊk ði ɑɹmtʃɛɹ, waɪl i kɛpt ɪz stul. tɔk ʌv ɛmənz fil meɪɾ ɪm hoʊmsɪk, ən ɪt sim tə meɪk nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin sæd, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ spikɪŋ ə sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ si əɡɛn. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðɛɹ aɪz mɔɪsənd, bʌt wən i tʃɹaɪd tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə sʌbʒɪkt, ðeɪ bɹɔɾ ɪt bæk əɡɛn, tə pipəl ðeɪ nu, tə ðə fɛstəvəlz ə bɛl taɪn ən sʌndeɪ, tə hɑɹvəs dænsəz ən pɪknɪk ɡæðɝɪŋz fəɹ ðə ʃɪɹɪŋ.

They stayed awhile longer, talking of home for the most part. Egwene and Elayne sat on the bed, and Nynaeve took the armchair, while he kept his stool. Talk of Emond's Field made him homesick, and it seemed to make Nynaeve and Egwene sad, as if they were speaking of something they would never see again. He was sure their eyes moistened, but when he tried to change the subject, they brought it back again, to people they knew, to the festivals of Bel Tine and Sunday, to harvest dances and picnic gatherings for the shearing.

ɪleɪn tɔk tə hɪm ə keɪɛmlɪn, ʌv wʌt tə ɪkspɛkt ət ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ən u tə spik tə, ən ə lɪɾəl ə ðə sɪɾi. səmtaɪmz ʃi hɛl hɝsɛlf ɪn ə weɪ ðət meɪɾ ɪm ɔl bʌt si ə kɹaʊn ɑn əɹ hɛd. ə mæn wəɾ əv tə bi ə ful tə lɛt hɪmsɛlf ɡɛɾ ɪnvɑlvd wɪð ə wʊmən laɪk hɝ. wən ðeɪ ɹoʊz tə liv, hi wɑz sɑɹi tə si ðɛm ɡoʊ.

Elayne talked to him of Caemlyn, of what to expect at the Royal Palace and who to speak to, and a little of the city. Sometimes she held herself in a way that made him all but see a crown on her head. A man would have to be a fool to let himself get involved with a woman like her. When they rose to leave, he was sorry to see them go.

hi stʊd, sʌɾənli filɪŋ ɑkwɝd. "lʊk, juv dʌn mi ə feɪvɝ hɪɹ." hi tʌtʃt ði æmɪɝlɪnz peɪpɝ, ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "ə bɪɡ feɪvɝ. aɪ noʊ jəɹ ɔl gɑnə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ" - hi stʌmbəld ə lɪɾəl ɑn ðət - "æn jəl bi ə kwin wʌn deɪ, ɪleɪn, bʌɾ ɪf jə ɛvɝ nid hɛlp, ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛvɝ ɛniθɪŋ aɪ kən du, əl kʌm. jə kən kaʊn ɑn ɪt. dɪɾ aɪ seɪ sʌmθɪŋ fʌni?"

He stood, suddenly feeling awkward. "Look, you have done me a favor here." He touched the Amyrlin's paper, on the table. "A big favor. I know you're all going to be Aes Sedai" - he stumbled a little on that - "and you will be a queen one day, Elayne, but if you ever need help, if there is ever anything I can do, I will come. You can count on it. Did I say something funny?"

ɪleɪn hæɾ ə hæn oʊvɝ əɹ maʊθ, ən ɛɡwin wɑz stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ oʊpənli wɪð ə læf. "noʊ, mæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd smuðli, bʌɾ əɹ lɪps twɪtʃt. "dʒʌst sʌmθɪŋ aɪ hæv əbzɝvd əbaʊt mɛn."

Elayne had a hand over her mouth, and Egwene was struggling openly with a laugh. "No, Mat," Nynaeve said smoothly, but her lips twitched. "Just something I have observed about men."

"ju wəɾ əv tə bi ə wʊmən tə ʌndɝstænd," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"You would have to be a woman to understand," Elayne said.

"dʒɝni wɛl ən seɪfli, mæt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɪf ə wʊmən dʌz niɾ ə hɪɹoʊ, ʃi nidz ɪm tədeɪ, nɑt təmɑɹoʊ." ðə læftɝ bʌbəld aʊɾ ə hɝ.

"Journey well and safely, Mat," Egwene said. "And remember, if a woman does need a hero, she needs him today, not tomorrow." The laughter bubbled out of her.

hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə dɔɹ kloʊzɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. wɪmən, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd fəɹ ət lis ðə hʌnʒɹədθ taɪm, wɝ ɑd.

He stared at the door closing behind them. Women, he decided for at least the hundredth time, were odd.

ðən ɪz aɪ fɛl ɑn ɪleɪnz lɛɾɝ, ən ðə foʊldəd peɪpɝ laɪɪŋ ətɑp ɪt. ði æmɪɝlɪnz blɛsɪd, nɑt-tə-bi-ʌndɝstʊd, bʌt wɛlkəm-æz-ə-faɪɝ-ɪn-wɪntɝ peɪpɝ. hi dænst ə lɪɾəl keɪpɝ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə flaʊɝd kɑɹpət. keɪɛmlɪn tə si, ən ə kwin tə mit. jəɹ oʊn wɝdz wɪl fɹi mi ʌv ju, æmɪɝlɪn. ən ɡɛt mi əweɪ fɹəm səlin, tu.

Then his eye fell on Elayne's letter, and the folded paper lying atop it. The Amyrlin's blessed, not-to-be-understood, but welcome-as-a-fire-in-winter paper. He danced a little caper in the middle of the flowered carpet. Caemlyn to see, and a queen to meet. Your own words will free me of you, Amyrlin. And get me away from Selene, too.

"jul nɛvɝ kætʃ mi," hi læft, ən mɛn ɪt fəɹ boʊθ ə ðɛm. "jul nɛvɝ kætʃ mæt kɔθən."

"You'll never catch me," he laughed, and meant it for both of them. "You'll never catch Mat Cauthon."


tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn


CHAPTER 29

eɪ tʃɹæp tə spɹɪŋ


A Trap to Spring

ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ðə spɪt dɔɡ wɑz laɪɪŋ əɾ ɪts iz. ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪt, nɪneɪiv mɑp swɛt fɹəm əɹ fɔɹhɛd wɪð əɹ hæn ən lin əɹ bæk ɪndə duɪŋ ðə wɝk i ʃəɾ əv dʌn. aɪd nɑɾ əv pʊɾ ɪt pæst əm tə ʃʌv mi ɪn ɪz wɪkɝ wil ɪnstɛɾ ə lɛɾɪŋ mi tɝn ðɪs laɪt-fɔɹseɪkən hændəl! ɛɛs sədaɪ! bɝn əm ɔl! ɪt wɑz ə mɛʒɝ ə hɝ əpsɛt ðət ʃi juz sətʃ læŋɡwədʒ, ən ənʌðɝ ðət ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən noʊɾəs ʃi hæd dʌn ɪt. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðə faɪɝ ɪn ðə lɔŋ, ɡɹeɪ stoʊn faɪɝpleɪs wəd sim ɛni hɑɾɝ ɪf ʃi kɹɔld ɪndə ɪt. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə bɹɪndəl dɔɡ wɑz ɡɹɪnɪŋ ət hɝ.

In a corner the spit dog was lying at its ease. Glaring at it, Nynaeve mopped sweat from her forehead with her hand and leaned her back into doing the work he should have done. I'd not have put it past them to shove me in his wicker wheel instead of letting me turn this Light-forsaken handle! Aes Sedai! Burn them all! It was a measure of her upset that she used such language, and another that she did not even notice she had done it. She did not think the fire in the long, gray stone fireplace would seem any hotter if she crawled into it. She was sure the brindle dog was grinning at her.

ɪleɪn wɑz skɪmɪŋ ɡɹis aʊɾ ə ðə dʒɹɪpɪŋ pæn ʌndɝ ðə ɹoʊsts wɪð ə lɔŋ-hændəld wʊɾən spun, waɪl ɛɡwin juzd ɪts twɪn tə bæs ðə mit. ðə ɡɹeɪt kɪtʃən wɛn ɑn əbaʊɾ ɪts mɪddeɪ ɹutin ɝaʊn ðɛm. ivən ðə nɑvəsɪz hæd ɡɹoʊn soʊ juz tə siɪŋ æksɛptɪd ðəɹ ðət ðeɪ hɑɹdli ivən ɡlænst ət ðə θɹi wɪmən. nɑt ðət ðə kʊks əlaʊd ðə nɑvəsɪz tə dɔɾəl fəɹ ɡɔkɪŋ. wɝk bɪl kɛɹɪktɝ, soʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd, ən ðə kʊks sɔ tə ɪt ðət ðə nɑvəsɪz bɪl stʃɹɔŋ kɛɹɪktɝ. ən ðə θɹi æksɛptɪd, tu.

Elayne was skimming grease out of the dripping pan under the roasts with a long-handled wooden spoon, while Egwene used its twin to baste the meat. The great kitchen went on about its midday routine around them. Even the novices had grown so used to seeing Accepted there that they hardly even glanced at the three women. Not that the cooks allowed the novices to dawdle for gawking. Work built character, so the Aes Sedai said, and the cooks saw to it that the novices built strong character. And the three Accepted, too.

lɑɹəz, ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə kɪtʃənz - ʃi wɑz ɹɪli ðə tʃif kʊk, bʌt soʊ mɛni hæd juz ði ʌðɝ fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ ðəɾ ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn əɹ taɪɾəl - keɪm oʊvɝ tə ɪɡzæmɪn ðə ɹoʊsts. ən ðə wɪmən swɛɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛm. ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ðən mɪɹli staʊt, wɪð leɪɝz ə tʃɪnz, ən ə spɑtləs waɪɾ eɪpɹən ðət cʊɾə meɪd θɹi nɑvəs dʒɹɛsəz. ʃi kæɹiɾ əɹ oʊn lɔŋ-hændəld wʊɾən spun laɪk ə sɛptɝ. ɪt wɑz nɑt fəɹ stɝɪŋ, ðət spun. ɪt wɑz fəɹ dɝɛktɪŋ ðoʊz ʌndɝ hɝ, ən smækɪŋ ðoʊz u wɝ nɑt bɪldɪŋ kɛɹɪktɝ kwɪkli ɪnʌf tə sut hɝ. ʃi stʌɾid ðə ɹoʊsts, snɪf dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli, ən tɝn əɹ fɹaʊn ɑn ðə θɹi æksɛptɪd.

Laras, the Mistress of the Kitchens - she was really the chief cook, but so many had used the other for so long that it might as well have been her title - came over to examine the roasts. And the women sweating over them. She was more than merely stout, with layers of chins, and a spotless white apron that could have made three novice dresses. She carried her own long-handled wooden spoon like a scepter. It was not for stirring, that spoon. It was for directing those under her, and smacking those who were not building character quickly enough to suit her. She studied the roasts, sniffed disparagingly, and turned her frown on the three Accepted.

nɪneɪiv mɛt lɑɹəz' lʊk wɪð ə lɛvəl lʊk ə hɝ oʊn ən kɛp tɝnɪŋ ðə spɪt. ðə mæsɪv wʊmənz feɪs nɛvɝ ɔltɝd. nɪneɪiv hæd tʃɹaɪd smaɪlɪŋ, bʌt ðət dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ lɑɹəz' ɪkspɹɛʃən. stɑpɪŋ wɝk tə spik tə hɝ, kwaɪt sɪvɪli, hæd bɪn ə dɪzæstɝ. ɪt wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf biɪŋ bʊliɾ ən tʃɪvid baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi hæd tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðæt, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ɪt ɹæŋkəld ən bɝnd, ɪf ʃi wɑz tə lɝn haʊ tə juz əɹ əbɪləɾiz. nɑt ðət ʃi laɪkt wʌt ʃi kəd də - ɪt wɑz wʌn θɪŋ tə noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ nɑt dɑɹkfɹɛnz fəɹ tʃænəlɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, bʌt kwaɪɾ ənʌðɝ tə noʊ ʃi hɝsɛlf kəd tʃænəl - jɛt ʃi hæd tə lɝn ɪf ʃi wɑz tə ɡɛt bæk ət mɔɪɹeɪn; heɪɾɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn fəɹ wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn tə ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝ ɛmənz fildɝz, pʊlɪŋ ðɛɹ lɪvz əpɑɹɾ ən mənɪpjəleɪɾɪŋ əm ɔl fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ pɝpəsəz, wɑz nɪɹli ɔl ðət kɛpt əɹ ɡoʊɪŋ. bʌt tə bi tʃɹiɾəd əz ə leɪzi, nʌn-tu-bɹaɪt tʃaɪl baɪ ðɪs lɑɹəz, tə bi fɔɹs tə kɝtsi ən skɝi fəɹ ðɪs wʊmən ʃi cʊɾə pʊɾ ɪn əɹ pleɪs wɪð ə fju wɛl-tʃoʊzən wɝdz bæk hoʊm - ðət meɪɾ əɹ ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz dɪd ðə θɔɾ ə mɔɪɹeɪn. meɪbi ɪf aɪ dʒʌs də nɑt lʊk ət hɝ. . . . noʊ! əl bi bɝn ɪf əl dʒɹɑp maɪ aɪz bɪfɔɹ ðɪs . . . ðɪs kaʊ!

Nynaeve met Laras' look with a level look of her own and kept turning the spit. The massive woman's face never altered. Nynaeve had tried smiling, but that did nothing to change Laras' expression. Stopping work to speak to her, quite civilly, had been a disaster. It was bad enough being bullied and chivied by Aes Sedai. She had to put up with that, however much it rankled and burned, if she was to learn how to use her abilities. Not that she liked what she could do - it was one thing to know Aes Sedai were not Darkfriends for channeling the Power, but quite another to know she herself could channel - yet she had to learn if she was to get back at Moiraine; hating Moiraine for what she had done to Egwene and the other Emond's Fielders, pulling their lives apart and manipulating them all for Aes Sedai purposes, was nearly all that kept her going. But to be treated as a lazy, none-too-bright child by this Laras, to be forced to curtsy and scurry for this woman she could have put in her place with a few well-chosen words back home - that made her grind her teeth almost as much as did the thought of Moiraine. Maybe if I just do not look at her. . . . No! I will be burned if I'll drop my eyes before this . . . this cow!

lɑɹəz snɪf mɔɹ laʊdli ən wɔkt əweɪ. ʃi ɹoʊl fɹəm saɪd tə saɪɾ əz ʃi kɹɔs ðə fɹɛʃli mɑpt ɡɹeɪ taɪlz.

Laras sniffed more loudly and walked away. She rolled from side to side as she crossed the freshly mopped gray tiles.

stɪl bɛndɪŋ wɪð spun ən ɡɹispɑ, ɪleɪn ɡlaʊɝɾ æftɝ hɝ. "ɪf ðət wʊmən stʃɹaɪks mi bʌt wʌns mɔɹ, aɪ ʃæl əv ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ɝɛst əɹ ən - "

Still bending with spoon and greasepot, Elayne glowered after her. "If that woman strikes me but once more, I shall have Gareth Bryne arrest her and - "

"bi kwaɪət," ɛɡwin wɪspɝd. ʃi dɪd nɑt stɑp bæstɪŋ ðə ɹoʊsts, ən ʃi nɛvɝ lʊkt əɾ ɪleɪn. "ʃi hæz ɪɹz laɪk ə - "

"Be quiet," Egwene whispered. She did not stop basting the roasts, and she never looked at Elayne. "She has ears like a - "

lɑɹəz tɝn bæk əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɪndid hɝd, hɝ fɹaʊn dipənɪŋ, ən əɹ maʊθ oʊpənd waɪd. bɪfɔɹ ə saʊn ɪmɝdʒd, ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɛntɝd ðə kɪtʃən laɪk ə wɝlwɪnd. ivən ðə stʃɹaɪp stoʊl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz sim tə bɹɪsəl. fəɹ wʌns, lin wɑz noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin.

Laras turned back as if she had indeed heard, her frown deepening, and her mouth opened wide. Before a sound emerged, the Amyrlin Seat entered the kitchen like a whirlwind. Even the striped stole on her shoulders seemed to bristle. For once, Leane was nowhere to be seen.

ət læst, nɪneɪiv θɔt ɡɹɪmli. ən nɑt bɪfɹtaɪm, iðɝ!

At last, Nynaeve thought grimly. And not beforetime, either!

bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪd nɑt ɡlæns əɹ weɪ. ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪd nɑt seɪ ə wɝd tə ɛniwʌn. ɹʌnɪŋ əɹ hæn əkɹɔs ə teɪbəltɑp skɹʌbd boʊn-waɪt, ʃi lʊkt əɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ən ɡɹɪməst əz ɪf ət fɪlθ. lɑɹəz wɑz əɾ əɹ saɪɾ ɪn ən ɪnstənt, ɔl smaɪlz, bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪnz flæt stɛɹ meɪɾ əɹ swɑloʊ ðɛm ɪn saɪləns.

But the Amyrlin did not glance her way. The Amyrlin did not say a word to anyone. Running her hand across a tabletop scrubbed bone-white, she looked at her fingers and grimaced as if at filth. Laras was at her side in an instant, all smiles, but the Amyrlin's flat stare made her swallow them in silence.

ði æmɪɝlɪn stɔkt əbaʊt ðə kɪtʃən. ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə wɪmən slaɪsɪŋ oʊtkeɪk. ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə wɪmən pilɪŋ vɛdʒtəbəlz. ʃi snɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə sup kɛɾəlz, ðən ət ðə wɪmən tɛndɪŋ ðɛm; ðə wɪmən bɪkeɪm ɪnɡɹoʊst ɪn stʌɾiɪŋ ðə sɝfəs ə ðə sup. hɝ fɹaʊn sɛt ðə ɡɝlz kæɹiɪŋ pleɪts ən boʊlz aʊt tə ðə daɪnɪŋ hɔl tə ə ɹʌn. hɝ ɡlaʊɝ pʊt ðə nɑvəsɪz dɑɹɾɪŋ laɪk maɪs saɪɾɪŋ ə kæt. baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi hæd meɪɾ əɹ weɪ hæf ɝaʊn ðə kɪtʃən, ɛvɹi wʊmən ðəɹ wɑz wɝkɪŋ twaɪs əz fæst əz ʃi hæd bɪn. baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi kəmpliɾəd əɹ sɝkət, lɑɹəz wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn ivən dɛɹɪŋ tə ɡlæns ət hɝ.

The Amyrlin stalked about the kitchen. She stared at the women slicing oatcake. She glared at the women peeling vegetables. She sneered into the soup kettles, then at the women tending them; the women became engrossed in studying the surface of the soup. Her frown set the girls carrying plates and bowls out to the dining hall to a run. Her glower put the novices darting like mice sighting a cat. By the time she had made her way half around the kitchen, every woman there was working twice as fast as she had been. By the time she completed her circuit, Laras was the only one even daring to glance at her.

ði æmɪɝlɪn stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɹoʊstɪŋ spɪt, fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, ən lʊkt ət lɑɹəz. ʃi oʊnli lʊkt, ɪkspɹɛʃənləs, blu aɪz koʊld ən hɑɹd.

The Amyrlin stopped in front of the roasting spit, fists on her hips, and looked at Laras. She only looked, expressionless, blue eyes cold and hard.

ðə lɑɹdʒ wʊmən ɡʌlpt, ən əɹ tʃɪnz wɑbəld əz ʃi smuðd əɹ eɪpɹən. ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪd nɑt blɪŋk. lɑɹəz' aɪz dʒɹɑpt, ən ʃi ʃɪftəd hɛvəli fɹəm fʊt tə fʊt. "ɪf ðə mʌðɝ wɪl pɑɹɾən mi," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə feɪn vɔɪs. meɪkɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn mɛn fəɹ ə kɝtsi, ʃi ɹʌʃt əweɪ, soʊ fɝɡɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi dʒɔɪn ðə wɪmən ət wʌn ə ðə sup kɛɾəlz ən bɪɡæn stɝɪŋ wɪð əɹ oʊn spun.

The large woman gulped, and her chins wobbled as she smoothed her apron. The Amyrlin did not blink. Laras' eyes dropped, and she shifted heavily from foot to foot. "If the Mother will pardon me," she said in a faint voice. Making something that might have been meant for a curtsy, she rushed away, so forgetting herself that she joined the women at one of the soup kettles and began stirring with her own spoon.

nɪneɪiv smaɪld, kipɪŋ əɹ hɛd daʊn tə haɪɾ ɪt. ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn kɛpt wɝkɪŋ, tu, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ ət ði æmɪɝlɪn, stændɪŋ wɪð əɹ bæk tə ðɛm nɑt tu peɪsɪz əweɪ.

Nynaeve smiled, keeping her head down to hide it. Egwene and Elayne kept working, too, but they also kept glancing at the Amyrlin, standing with her back to them not two paces away.

ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ stɛɹ əkɹɔs ði ɪntaɪɝ kɪtʃən fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi stʊd. "ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ ðɪs izəli kaʊd," ʃi mʌɾɝd sɔfli, "pɝhæps ðeɪ ɹɪli hæv bɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ əweɪ wɪð tu mʌtʃ fəɹ tu lɔŋ."

The Amyrlin was spreading her stare across the entire kitchen from where she stood. "If they are this easily cowed," she muttered softly, "perhaps they really have been getting away with too much for too long."

izəli kaʊɾ ɪndid, nɪneɪiv θɔt. pɪɾəfəl ɪkskjusɪz fəɹ wɪmən. ɔl ʃi dɪd wɑz lʊk ət ðɛm! ði æmɪɝlɪn ɡlænst oʊvɝ ə stoʊl-kʌvɝd ʃoʊldɝ, kɑɾ əɹ aɪ fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. sʌɾənli nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz tɝnɪŋ ðə spɪt fæstɝ. ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf ʃi hæd tə pɹitɛn tə bi kaʊd laɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls.

Easily cowed indeed, Nynaeve thought. Pitiful excuses for women. All she did was look at them! The Amyrlin glanced over a stole-covered shoulder, caught her eye for an instant. Suddenly Nynaeve realized she was turning the spit faster. She told herself she had to pretend to be cowed like everyone else.

ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɡeɪz fɛl ɑn ɪleɪn, ən əbɹʌpli ʃi spoʊk, nɪɹli laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹæɾəl ðə kɑpɝ pɑts ən pænz hæŋɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔlz. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ səm wɝdz əl nɑt tɑlɝeɪɾ ɪn ə jʌŋ wʊmənz maʊθ, ɪleɪn ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd. ɪf jə lɛɾ əm ɪn, əl si ðɛm skɹʌbd aʊt!" ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə kɪtʃən dʒʌmpt.

The Amyrlin's gaze fell on Elayne, and abruptly she spoke, nearly loud enough to rattle the copper pots and pans hanging on the walls. "There are some words I will not tolerate in a young woman's mouth, Elayne of House Trakand. If you let them in, I will see them scrubbed out!" Everyone in the kitchen jumped.

ɪleɪn lʊkt kənfjuzd, ən ɪndɪɡneɪʃən kɹɛpt əkɹɔs ɛɡwinz feɪs.

Elayne looked confused, and indignation crept across Egwene's face.

nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, smɔl fɹæntɪk ʃeɪks. noʊ, ɡɝl! hoʊl jəɹ tʌŋ! doʊn jə si wʌt ʃiz duɪŋ?

Nynaeve shook her head, small frantic shakes. No, girl! Hold your tongue! Don't you see what she is doing?

bʌɾ ɛɡwin dɪɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, wɪð ə ɹɪspɛkfəl ɪf dɪtɝmənd, "mʌðɝ, ʃi dɪd nɑt - "

But Egwene did open her mouth, with a respectful if determined, "Mother, she did not - "

"saɪləns!" ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɹɔɹ pɹədust ənʌðɝ ɹɪpəl ə dʒʌmps. "lɑɹəz! kən jə faɪn sʌmθɪŋ tə titʃ tu ɡɝlz tə spik wən ðeɪ ʃəɾ ən seɪ wʌt ðeɪ ʃʊd, mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə kɪtʃənz? kən jə mænədʒ ðæt?"

"Silence!" The Amyrlin's roar produced another ripple of jumps. "Laras! Can you find something to teach two girls to speak when they should and say what they should, Mistress of the Kitchens? Can you manage that?"

lɑɹəz keɪm wɑɾəlɪŋ fæstɝ ðən nɪneɪiv hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ðə wʊmən muv bɪfɔɹ, dɑɹɾɪŋ əɾ ɪleɪn ən ɛɡwin tə siz ən ɪɹ ʌv itʃ, ɔl ðə waɪl ɹɪpiɾɪŋ, "jɛs, mʌðɝ. ɪmiɾiətli, mʌðɝ. əz jə kəmænd, mʌðɝ." ʃi hɝid ðə tu jʌŋ wɪmən aʊɾ ə ðə kɪtʃən əz ɪf iɡɝ tə ɪskeɪp ði æmɪɝlɪnz stɛɹ.

Laras came waddling faster than Nynaeve had ever seen the woman move before, darting at Elayne and Egwene to seize an ear of each, all the while repeating, "Yes, Mother. Immediately, Mother. As you command, Mother." She hurried the two young women out of the kitchen as if eager to escape the Amyrlin's stare.

ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz naʊ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə nɪneɪiv tə tʌtʃ hɝ, bʌt stɪl lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə kɪtʃən. ə jʌŋ kʊk, tɝnɪŋ wɪð ə mɪksɪŋ boʊl ɪn əɹ hænz, tʃæns tə kætʃ ði æmɪɝlɪnz aɪ. ʃi ɡeɪv ə ɡɹeɪt skwik əz ʃi skʌɾəld əweɪ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ.

The Amyrlin was now close enough to Nynaeve to touch her, but still looking over the kitchen. A young cook, turning with a mixing bowl in her hands, chanced to catch the Amyrlin's eye. She gave a great squeak as she scuttled away across the floor.

"aɪ dɪd nɑt min fəɹ ɛɡwin tə bi kɑɾ ɪn ðæt." ði æmɪɝlɪn bɛɹli muvd əɹ lɪps. ɪt lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɝ mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf, ən fɹəm ði ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs, noʊ wʌn ɪn ðə kɪtʃən wɑntəd tə hɪɹ wʌt ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ. nɪneɪiv kəd dʒʌs meɪk aʊt ðə wɝdz. "bʌt pɝhæps ɪɾəl titʃ əɹ tə θɪŋk bɪfɔɹ ʃi spiks."

"I did not mean for Egwene to be caught in that." The Amyrlin barely moved her lips. It looked as if she were muttering to herself, and from the expression on her face, no one in the kitchen wanted to hear what she was saying. Nynaeve could just make out the words. "But perhaps it will teach her to think before she speaks."

nɪneɪiv tɝn ðə spɪɾ ən kɛpt əɹ hɛd daʊn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɔlsoʊ mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ ɪf ɛniwʌn lʊkt. "aɪ θɔt jə wɝ gɑnə kip ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn ʌs, mʌðɝ. soʊ wi kəd ɹipɔɹt wʌt wi faɪnd."

Nynaeve turned the spit and kept her head down, trying to look as if she were also muttering under her breath if anyone looked. "I thought you were going to keep a close eye on us, Mother. So we could report what we find."

"ɪf aɪ kʌm stɛɹ ət jə ɛvɹi deɪ, dɔɾɝ, səm wəd ɡɹoʊ səspɪʃəs." ði æmɪɝlɪn kɛpt ʌp əɹ stʌɾi ʌv ðə kɪtʃən. moʊst ə ðə wɪmən sim tə bi əvɔɪɾɪŋ ivən lʊkɪŋ ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən fəɹ fɪɹ ʌv ɪnkɝɪŋ əɹ ɹæθ. "aɪ plæn tə hæv jə bɹɔt tə maɪ stʌɾi æftɝ ðə mɪddeɪ mil. tə skoʊl jə fəɹ nɑt tʃuzɪŋ jəɹ stʌɾiz, soʊ aɪ ɪmplaɪd tə lin. bʌt ðəɹ ɪz nuz ðət kəd nɑt weɪt. ʃɛɹiəm faʊn ənʌðɝ ɡɹeɪ mæn. ə wʊmən. dɛɾ əz læst wiks fɪʃ, ən nɑɾ ə mɑɹk ɑn hɝ. ʃi wɑz leɪɾ aʊɾ əz ɪf ɹɛstɪŋ, ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ʃɛɹiəmz bɛd. nɑt vɛɹi plɛzən fəɹ ʃɛɹiəm."

"If I come stare at you every day, Daughter, some would grow suspicious." The Amyrlin kept up her study of the kitchen. Most of the women seemed to be avoiding even looking in her direction for fear of incurring her wrath. "I planned to have you brought to my study after the midday meal. To scold you for not choosing your studies, so I implied to Leane. But there is news that could not wait. Sheriam found another Gray Man. A woman. Dead as last week's fish, and not a mark on her. She was laid out as if resting, right in the middle of Sheriam's bed. Not very pleasant for Sheriam."

nɪneɪiv stɪfənd, ən ðə spɪt hɔltəd fəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ ʃi pʊɾ ɪt bæk tə ɹivɑlvɪŋ. "ʃɛɹiəm hæɾ ə tʃæns tə si ðə lɪsts vɛɹɪn ɡeɪv tə ɛɡwin. soʊ dɪɾ ɪleɪɾə. aɪ meɪk noʊ ækjəzeɪʃənz, bʌt ðeɪ hæd ðə tʃæns. ən ɛɡwin sɛɾ ɑlɑnə . . . bɪheɪvd ɑdli, tu."

Nynaeve stiffened, and the spit halted for a moment before she put it back to revolving. "Sheriam had a chance to see the lists Verin gave to Egwene. So did Elaida. I make no accusations, but they had the chance. And Egwene said Alanna . . . behaved oddly, too."

"ʃi toʊl jə ʌv ðæt, dɪd ʃi? ɑlɑnə ɪz ɝæfɛlɪn. ðeɪv stʃɹeɪnʒ aɪdiəz əbaʊɾ ɑnɝ ən dɛts ɪn ɝæfəl." ʃi ʃɹʌɡd dɪsmɪsɪvli, bʌt sɛd, "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kən kip ən aɪ ɑn hɝ. hæv jə lɝn ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl jɛt, tʃaɪld?"

"She told you of that, did she? Alanna is Arafellin. They have strange ideas about honor and debts in Arafel." She shrugged dismissively, but said, "I suppose I can keep an eye on her. Have you learned anything useful yet, child?"

"sʌm," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd ɡɹɪmli. wʌɾ əbaʊt kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn ʃɛɹiəm? meɪbi ʃi dɪdn dʒʌs faɪn ðət ɡɹeɪ mæn. ði æmɪɝlɪn kəd wɑtʃ ɪleɪɾə, tu, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. soʊ ɑlɑnə ɹɪli dɪd. . . . "aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ jə tʃɹʌst ɛls ɡɹɪnwɛl, bʌt jəɹ mɛsədʒ wɑz hɛlpfəl."

"Some," Nynaeve muttered grimly. What about keeping an eye on Sheriam? Maybe she didn't just find that Gray Man. The Amyrlin could watch Elaida, too, for that matter. So Alanna really did. . . . "I do not understand why you trust Else Grinwell, but your message was helpful."

ɪn ʃɔɹt, kwɪk sɛntənsəz, nɪneɪiv toʊld ə ðə θɪŋz ðeɪ hæd faʊn ɪn ðə stɔɹɹum ʌndɝ ðə laɪbɹɛɹi, meɪkɪŋ ɪt sim oʊnli ʃi ən ɛɡwin hæd ɡɔn, ən æɾəd ðə kənkluʒənz ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt kənsɝnɪŋ ðɛm. ʃi dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ɛɡwinz dʒɹim - əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt hæd bɪn; ɛɡwin ɪnsɪstəɾ ɪt hæd bɪn ɹil - ʌv tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. nɔɹ dɪd ʃi spik ə ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil vɛɹɪn hæd ɡɪvən ɛɡwin. ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk hɝsɛlf ɪntaɪɝli tʃɹʌs ðə wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp stoʊl - əɹ ɛni wʊmən u kəd wɛɹ ðə ʃɔl, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ - ən ɪt sim bɛs tə kip səm θɪŋz ɪn ɹɪzɝv.

In short, quick sentences, Nynaeve told of the things they had found in the storeroom under the library, making it seem only she and Egwene had gone, and added the conclusions they had reached concerning them. She did not mention Egwene's dream - or whatever it had been; Egwene insisted it had been real - of Tel'aran'rhiod. Nor did she speak of the ter'angreal Verin had given Egwene. She could not make herself entirely trust the woman wearing the seven-striped stole - or any woman who could wear the shawl, for that matter - and it seemed best to keep some things in reserve.

wən ʃi wɑz dʌn, ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz saɪlən soʊ lɔŋ ðət nɪneɪiv bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ðə wʊmən hæd nɑt hɝd. ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə ɹɪpit hɝsɛlf, ə lɪɾəl laʊɾɝ, wən ði æmɪɝlɪn faɪnəli spoʊk, stɪl hɑɹdli muvɪŋ əɹ lɪps.

When she was done, the Amyrlin was silent so long that Nynaeve began to think the woman had not heard. She was about to repeat herself, a little louder, when the Amyrlin finally spoke, still hardly moving her lips.

"aɪ sɛnt noʊ mɛsədʒ, dɔɾɝ. ðə θɪŋz liɑnʒɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz lɛft wɝ sɝtʃt θɝoʊli, ən bɝn æftɝ nʌθɪŋ wɑz faʊnd. noʊ wʌn wəd juz blæk ədʒɑ livɪŋz. əz fəɹ ɛls ɡɹɪnwɛl. . . . aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə ɡɝl. ʃi kəɾ əv lɝnd, hæd ʃi əplaɪd hɝsɛlf, bʌɾ ɔl ʃi wɑntəd wɑz tə smaɪl ət ðə mɛn ət ðə wɔɹɾɝz' pɹæktəs jɑɹd. ɛls ɡɹɪnwɛl wɑz pʊɾ ɑn ə tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ vɛsəl ən sɛn bæk tə hɝ mʌðɝ tɛn deɪz əɡoʊ."

"I sent no message, Daughter. The things Liandrin and the others left were searched thoroughly, and burned after nothing was found. No one would use Black Ajah leavings. As for Else Grinwell. . . . I remember the girl. She could have learned, had she applied herself, but all she wanted was to smile at the men at the Warders' practice yard. Else Grinwell was put on a trading vessel and sent back to her mother ten days ago."

nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd tə swɑloʊ ðə lʌmp ðət hæd fɔɹmd ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. ði æmɪɝlɪnz wɝdz meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ə bʊliz tɔntɪŋ smɔlɝ tʃɪlʒɹən. ðə bʊliz wɝ ɔlweɪz soʊ kəntɛmptʃuəs ə ðə lɪɾəlɝ tʃɪlʒɹən, ɔlweɪz soʊ ʃʊɹ ðə smɔl wʌnz wɝ tu stupəd tə ɹilaɪz wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ, ðət ðeɪ meɪd lɪɾəl ɛfɝt tə dɪsɡaɪz ðɛɹ snɛɹz. ðət ðə blæk ədʒɑ wɑz soʊ kəntɛmptʃuəs ə hɝ meɪɾ əɹ blʌd bɔɪl. ðət ðeɪ kəd sɛt ðɪs snɛɹ fɪld əɹ stʌmək wɪð aɪs. laɪt, ɪf ɛls wɑz sɛn əweɪ. . . . laɪt, ɛnibəɾi aɪ tɔk tə kəd bi liɑnʒɹɪn, əɹ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz. laɪt!

Nynaeve tried to swallow the lump that had formed in her throat. The Amyrlin's words made her think of bullies taunting smaller children. The bullies were always so contemptuous of the littler children, always so sure the small ones were too stupid to realize what was happening, that they made little effort to disguise their snares. That the Black Ajah was so contemptuous of her made her blood boil. That they could set this snare filled her stomach with ice. Light, if Else was sent away. . . . Light, anybody I talk to could be Liandrin, or any of the others. Light!

ðə spɪt hæd stɑpt. heɪstəli ʃi stɑɹɾəd dʒ tɝnɪŋ wʌns mɔɹ. noʊ wʌn sim tə hæv noʊɾəst, ðoʊ. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl stɪl duɪŋ ðɛɹ bɛs nɑt tə lʊk ət ði æmɪɝlɪn.

The spit had stopped. Hastily she started jt turning once more. No one seemed to have noticed, though. They were all still doing their best not to look at the Amyrlin.

"ænd wʌt dʒju min tə də əbaʊt ðɪs . . . soʊ-ɑbviəs tʃɹæp?" ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd sɔfli, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə kɪtʃən, əweɪ fɹəm nɪneɪiv. "du jə min tə fɔl ɪndə ðɪs wʌn, tu?"

"And what do you mean to do about this . . . so-obvious trap?" the Amyrlin said softly, still staring over the kitchen, away from Nynaeve. "Do you mean to fall into this one, too?"

nɪneɪivz feɪs ɹɛɾənd. "aɪ noʊ ðɪs tʃɹæp fəɹ ə tʃɹæp. mʌðɝ. ən ðə bɛst weɪ tə kætʃ huɛvɝ sɛɾ ə tʃɹæp ɪz tə spɹɪŋ ɪɾ ən weɪt fəɹ ɪm - əɹ əɹ - tə kʌm." ɪt saʊndəd wikɝ ðən ɪt hæd wən ʃi hæd sɛɾ ɪt tə ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn, æftɝ wʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd dʒʌs toʊl hɝ, bʌt ʃi stɪl mɛn ɪt.

Nynaeve's face reddened. "I know this trap for a trap. Mother. And the best way to catch whoever set a trap is to spring it and wait for him - or her - to come." It sounded weaker than it had when she had said it to Egwene and Elayne, after what the Amyrlin had just told her, but she still meant it.

"pɝhæps soʊ, tʃaɪld. pɝhæps ɪts ðə weɪ tə faɪn ðɛm. ɪf ðeɪ də nɑt kʌm ən faɪn jə hɛl taɪtli ɪn ðɛɹ nɛt." ʃi ɡeɪv ə vɛkst saɪ. "aɪ wɪl pʊt ɡoʊld ɪn jəɹ ɹum fəɹ ðə dʒɝni. ən əl lɛɾ ɪt bi wɪspɝɾ əbaʊt ðəɾ aɪ hæv sɛn jə aʊt tə ə fɑɹm tə hoʊ kæbɪdʒɪz. wɪl ɪleɪn bi ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð ju?"

"Perhaps so, child. Perhaps it is the way to find them. If they do not come and find you held tightly in their net." She gave a vexed sigh. "I will put gold in your room for the journey. And I will let it be whispered about that I have sent you out to a farm to hoe cabbages. Will Elayne be going with you?"

nɪneɪiv fɝɡɑt hɝsɛlf ɪnʌf tə stɛɹ ət ði æmɪɝlɪn, ðən hɝidli pʊɾ əɹ aɪz bæk ɑn əɹ hænz. hɝ nʌkəlz wɝ waɪɾ ɑn ðə spɪt hændəl. "ju skimɪŋ oʊld. . . . waɪ ɔl ðə pɹitɛns, ɪf jə nu? jəɹ slaɪ plɑts əv hæɾ əs skwɝmɪŋ nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæz. waɪ?" ði æmɪɝlɪnz feɪs hæd taɪɾənd, ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ fɔɹs ə mɔɹ ɹɪspɛkfəl toʊn. "ɪf aɪ meɪ æsk, mʌðɝ."

Nynaeve forgot herself enough to stare at the Amyrlin, then hurriedly put her eyes back on her hands. Her knuckles were white on the spit handle. "You scheming old. . . . Why all the pretense, if you knew? Your sly plots have had us squirming nearly as much as the Black Ajah has. Why?" The Amyrlin's face had tightened, enough to make her force a more respectful tone. "If I may ask, Mother."

ði æmɪɝlɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "pʊɾɪŋ mɔɹɡeɪs bæk ɑn ðə pɹɑpɝ pæθ wɛðɝ ʃi wɑns tə ɡoʊ əɹ nɑt wɪl bi hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf wɪθaʊɾ əɹ θɪŋkɪŋ aɪv sɛn əɹ dɔɾɝ tə si ɪn ə liki skɪf. ðɪs weɪ aɪ kən seɪ stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt ðəɾ ɪt wɑz nʌn ə maɪ duɪŋ. ɪt meɪ bi ə bɪt hɑɹɾ ɑn ɪleɪn, wən ʃi faɪnəli hæz tə feɪs əɹ mʌðɝ, bʌɾ aɪ hæv θɹi haʊnz, naʊ, nɑt tu. aɪ toʊl jə aɪɾ əv ə hʌnʒɹəd ɪf aɪ kʊd." ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ stoʊl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. "ðɪs əz ɡɔn ɑn lɔŋ ɪnʌf. ɪf aɪ steɪ ðɪs kloʊs tə ju, ɪt meɪ bi noʊɾəst. hæv jə ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ tə tɛl mi? əɹ tə æsk? meɪk ɪt kwɪk, dɔɾɝ."

The Amyrlin snorted. "Putting Morgase back on the proper path whether she wants to go or not will be hard enough without her thinking I've sent her daughter to sea in a leaky skiff. This way I can say straight out that it was none of my doing. It may be a bit hard on Elayne, when she finally has to face her mother, but I have three hounds, now, not two. I told you I'd have a hundred if I could." She adjusted her stole on her shoulders. "This has gone on long enough. If I stay this close to you, it may be noticed. Have you anything more to tell me? Or to ask? Make it quick, Daughter."

"wʌɾ ɪz kælændɝ, mʌðɝ?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"What is Callandor, Mother?" Nynaeve asked.

ðɪs taɪm ɪt wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn u fɝɡɑt hɝsɛlf, hæf tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd nɪneɪiv bɪfɔɹ dʒɝkɪŋ hɝsɛlf bæk. "ðeɪ kænɑt bi əlaʊd tə hæv ðæt." hɝ wɪspɝ wɑz bɛɹli ɑɾəbəl, əz ɪf mɛn fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɪɹz əloʊn. "ðeɪ kænɑt pɑsəbli teɪk ɪt, bʌt. . . ." ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ən əɹ sɑft wɝdz fɝmd ɪnʌf tə bi klɪɹ tə nɪneɪiv, ɪf tə noʊ wʌn tu peɪsɪz fɝðɝ əweɪ. "noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə dʌzən wɪmən ɪn ðə taʊɝ noʊ wʌt kælændɝ ɪz, ən pɝhæps əz mɛni aʊtsaɪd. ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ə tɛɹ noʊ, bʌt ðeɪ nɛvɝ spik ʌv ɪɾ ɪksɛpt wən ə lɔɹɾ ə ðə læn ɪz toʊld ɑn biɪŋ ɹeɪzd. ðə sɔɹd ðət kænɑt bi tʌtʃt ɪz ə sɑŋɡɹil, ɡɝl. oʊnli tu mɔɹ paʊɝfəl wɝ ɛvɝ meɪd, ən θæŋk ðə laɪt, niðɝ ə ðoʊz wɑz ɛvɝ juzd. wɪð kælændɝ ɪn jəɹ hænz, tʃaɪld, jə kəd lɛvəl ə sɪɾi ət wʌn bloʊ. ɪf jə daɪ kipɪŋ ðəɾ aʊɾ ə ðə blæk ədʒɑz hænz - ju, ən ɛɡwin, ən ɪleɪn, ɔl θɹi - jəl əv dʌn ə sɝvəs tə ðə hoʊl wɝld, ən tʃip ət ðə pɹaɪs."

This time it was the Amyrlin who forgot herself, half turning toward Nynaeve before jerking herself back. "They cannot be allowed to have that." Her whisper was barely audible, as if meant for her own ears alone. "They cannot possibly take it, but. . . ." She took a deep breath, and her soft words firmed enough to be clear to Nynaeve, if to no one two paces further away. "No more than a dozen women in the Tower know what Callandor is, and perhaps as many outside. The High Lords of Tear know, but they never speak of it except when a Lord of the Land is told on being raised. The Sword That Cannot Be Touched is a sa'angreal, girl. Only two more powerful were ever made, and thank the Light, neither of those was ever used. With Callandor in your hands, child, you could level a city at one blow. If you die keeping that out of the Black Ajah's hands - you, and Egwene, and Elayne, all three - you'll have done a service to the whole world, and cheap at the price."

"haʊ kəd ðeɪ teɪk ɪt?" nɪneɪiv æskt. "aɪ θɔɾ oʊnli ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kəd tʌtʃ kælændɝ."

"How could they take it?" Nynaeve asked. "I thought only the Dragon Reborn could touch Callandor."
