ði æmɪɝlɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ə saɪdweɪz lʊk ʃɑɹp ɪnʌf tə kɑɹv ðə ɹoʊsts ɑn ðə spɪt. "ðeɪ kəd bi æftɝ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls," ʃi sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "ðeɪ stoʊl tɛɹæŋɡɹil hɪɹ. ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ hoʊlz nɪɹli əz mɛni tɛɹæŋɡɹil əz ðə taʊɝ."

The Amyrlin gave her a sideways look sharp enough to carve the roasts on the spit. "They could be after something else," she said after a moment. "They stole ter'angreal here. The Stone of Tear holds nearly as many ter'angreal as the Tower."

"aɪ θɔt ðə haɪ lɔɹdz heɪɾəd ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ," nɪneɪiv wɪspɝɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli.

"I thought the High Lords hated anything to do with the One Power," Nynaeve whispered incredulously.

"oʊ, ðeɪ də heɪɾ ɪt, tʃaɪld. heɪɾ ɪt, ən fɪɹ ɪt. wən ðeɪ faɪn ə tɛɹən ɡɝl u kən tʃænəl, ðeɪ bʌndəl əɹ ɑntu ə ʃɪp fəɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪfɔɹ ðə deɪ ɪz dʌn, wɪð hɑɹdli taɪm tə spik ɡʊdbaɪz tə hɝ fæmli." ði æmɪɝlɪnz mɝmɝ wɑz bɪɾɝ wɪð mɛmɹi. "jɛt ðeɪ hoʊld wʌn ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl foʊkəsɪz ə ðə paʊɝ ðə wɝld əz ɛvɝ sin, ɪnsaɪd ðɛɹ pɹɛʃəs stoʊn. ɪts maɪ bɪlif ðəɾ ɪz waɪ ðeɪv kəlɛktəd soʊ mɛni tɛɹæŋɡɹil - ən ɪndid, ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ - oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz, əz ɪf baɪ duɪŋ soʊ ðeɪ kən dɪmɪnɪʃ ði ɛɡzɪstəns ə ðə θɪŋ ðeɪ kænɑt ɹɪd ðɛmsɛlvz ʌv, ðə θɪŋ ðət ɹimaɪnz əm ə ðɛɹ oʊn dum ɛvɹi taɪm ðeɪ ɛntɝ ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn. ðɛɹ fɔɹtʃɹəs ðəɾ əz bɹoʊkən ə hʌnʒɹəd ɑɹmiz wɪl fɔl əz wʌn ə ðə saɪnz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz ɹibɔɹn. nɑɾ ivən ði oʊnli saɪn; dʒʌst wʌn. haʊ ðət mʌst ɹæŋkəl ðɛɹ pɹaʊd hɑɹts. ðɛɹ daʊnfɔl wɪl nɑɾ ivən bi ðə wʌn ɡɹeɪt saɪn ə ðə wɝlz tʃeɪnʒ. ðeɪ kænɑɾ ivən ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt baɪ steɪɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə hɑɹt. ðəɾ ɪz wɛɹ lɔɹdz ə ðə læn ɑɹ ɹeɪz tə haɪ lɔɹdz, ən wɛɹ ðeɪ mʌs pɝfɔɹm wʌt ðeɪ kɔl ðə ɹaɪɾ ə ðə ɡɑɹɾɪŋ fɔɹ taɪmz ə jɪɹ, kleɪmɪŋ ðət ðeɪ ɡɑɹd ðə hoʊl wɝld əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən baɪ hoʊldɪŋ kælændɝ. ɪt mʌs baɪɾ ət ðɛɹ soʊlz laɪk ə bɛlɪfəl ə laɪv sɪlvɝpaɪk, ən noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ dɪzɝv." ʃi ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk, əz ɪf ɹilaɪzɪŋ ʃi hæd sɛd fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ʃi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd. "ɪz ðəɾ ɔl, tʃaɪld?"

"Oh, they do hate it, child. Hate it, and fear it. When they find a Tairen girl who can channel, they bundle her onto a ship for Tar Valon before the day is done, with hardly time to speak goodbyes to her family." The Amyrlin's murmur was bitter with memory. "Yet they hold one of the most powerful focuses of the Power the world has ever seen, inside their precious Stone. It is my belief that is why they have collected so many ter'angreal - and indeed, anything to do with the Power - over the years, as if by doing so they can diminish the existence of the thing they cannot rid themselves of, the thing that reminds them of their own doom every time they enter the Heart of the Stone. Their fortress that has broken a hundred armies will fall as one of the signs the Dragon is Reborn. Not even the only sign; just one. How that must rankle their proud hearts. Their downfall will not even be the one great sign of the world's change. They cannot even ignore it by staying out of the Heart. That is where Lords of the Land are raised to High Lords, and where they must perform what they call the Rite of the Guarding four times a year, claiming that they guard the whole world against the Dragon by holding Callandor. It must bite at their souls like a bellyful of live silverpike, and no more than they deserve." She gave herself a shake, as if realizing she had said far more than she had intended. "Is that all, child?"

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. laɪt, ɪɾ ɔlweɪz kʌmz bæk tə ɹænd, dʌzn ɪt? ɔlweɪz bæk tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪt wɑz stɪl ən ɛfɝt tə θɪŋk ə hɪm ðət weɪ. "ðæts ɔl."

"Yes, Mother," Nynaeve said. Light, it always comes back to Rand, doesn't it? Always back to the Dragon Reborn. It was still an effort to think of him that way. "That's all."

ði æmɪɝlɪn ʃɪftəɾ əɹ stoʊl əɡɛn, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə fɹɛnzid skɝi ɪn ðə kɪtʃən. "aɪl əv tə sɛt ðɪs æɹaɪt. aɪ niɾəd tə spik tə jə wɪθaʊt dɪleɪ, bʌt lɑɹəz ɪz ə ɡʊd wʊmən, ən ʃi mænɪdʒɪz ðə kɪtʃən ən ðə lɑɹɾɝz wɛl."

The Amyrlin shifted her stole again, frowning at the frenzied scurry in the kitchen. "I'll have to set this aright. I needed to speak to you without delay, but Laras is a good woman, and she manages the kitchen and the larders well."

nɪneɪiv snɪft, ən ədʒɹɛst əɹ hænz ɑn ðə spɪt hændəl. "lɑɹəz ɪz ə saʊɝ lʌmp ə lɑɹd, ən tu hændi wɪð ðət spun baɪ hæf." ʃi θɔt ʃi hæd mʌɾɝd ɪɾ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, bʌt ʃi hɝd ði æmɪɝlɪn tʃʌkəl ɹaɪli.

Nynaeve sniffed, and addressed her hands on the spit handle. "Laras is a sour lump of lard, and too handy with that spoon by half." She thought she had muttered it under her breath, but she heard the Amyrlin chuckle wryly.

"ju ɑɹ ə faɪn dʒʌdʒ ə kɛɹɪktɝ, tʃaɪld. jə mʌst əv dʌn wɛl əz ðə wɪzdəm ə jəɹ vɪlədʒ. ɪt wɑz lɑɹəz u wɛn tə ʃɛɹiəm ən dɪmændəd tə noʊ haʊ lɔŋ jə θɹi ɑɹ tə bi kɛp tə ðə dɝɾiəst ən hɑɹɾəst wɝk, wɪθaʊɾ ə tɝn ət laɪɾɝ. ʃi sɛd ʃi wəd nɑt bi ə pɑɹɾi tə bɹeɪkɪŋ ɛni wʊmənz hɛlθ əɹ spɪɹət, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ aɪ sɛd. ə faɪn dʒʌdʒ ə kɛɹɪktɝ, tʃaɪld."

"You are a fine judge of character, child. You must have done well as the Wisdom of your village. It was Laras who went to Sheriam and demanded to know how long you three are to be kept to the dirtiest and hardest work, without a turn at lighter. She said she would not be a party to breaking any woman's health or spirit, no matter what I said. A fine judge of character, child."

lɑɹəz keɪm bæk ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən dɔɹweɪ ðɛn, hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ tə ɛntɝ əɹ oʊn doʊmeɪn. ði æmɪɝlɪn wɛn tə mit hɝ, smaɪlz ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ əɹ fɹaʊnz ən stɛɹz.

Laras came back into the kitchen doorway then, hesitating to enter her own domain. The Amyrlin went to meet her, smiles replacing her frowns and stares.

"ɪɾ ɔl lʊks vɛɹi wɛl tə mi, lɑɹəz." ði æmɪɝlɪnz wɝdz keɪm laʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ kɪtʃən tə hɪɹ. "aɪ si nʌθɪŋ aʊɾ ə pleɪs, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ əz ɪt ʃəd bi. jə ɑɹ tə bi kəmɛndɪd. aɪ θɪŋk əl meɪk mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə kɪtʃənz ə fɔɹməl taɪɾəl."

"It all looks very well to me, Laras." The Amyrlin's words came loud enough for the entire kitchen to hear. "I see nothing out of place, and everything as it should be. You are to be commended. I think I will make Mistress of the Kitchens a formal title."

ðə staʊt wʊmənz feɪs flʌɾɝd fɹəm ʌnizinəs tə ʃɑk tə bimɪŋ plɛʒɝ. baɪ ðə taɪm ði æmɪɝlɪn swɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə kɪtʃən, lɑɹəz wɑz ɔl smaɪlz. hɝ fɹaʊn ɹɪtɝnd, ðoʊ, əz ʃi lʊk fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪnz dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ bæk tə hɝ wɝkɝz. ðə kɪtʃən sim tə lip ɪndə moʊʃən. lɑɹəz' ɡɹɪm stɛɹ sɛɾəld ɑn nɪneɪiv.

The stout woman's face fluttered from uneasiness to shock to beaming pleasure. By the time the Amyrlin swept out of the kitchen, Laras was all smiles. Her frown returned, though, as she looked from the Amyrlin's departing back to her workers. The kitchen seemed to leap into motion. Laras' grim stare settled on Nynaeve.

tɝnɪŋ ðə spɪɾ əɡɛn, nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd smaɪlɪŋ ət ðə bɪɡ wʊmən.

Turning the spit again, Nynaeve tried smiling at the big woman.

lɑɹəz' fɹaʊn dipənd, ən ʃi bɪɡæn tæpɪŋ əɹ spun ɑn əɹ θaɪ, əpɛɹənli fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ðət fəɹ wʌns ɪt hæd bɪn juz fəɹ ɪts ɪntɛndəd pɝpəs. ɪt lɛf smɪɹz ə sup ɑn ðə waɪɾ ə hɝ eɪpɹən.

Laras' frown deepened, and she began tapping her spoon on her thigh, apparently forgetting that for once it had been used for its intended purpose. It left smears of soup on the white of her apron.

əl smaɪl əɾ əɹ ɪf ɪf kɪlz mi, nɪneɪiv θɔt, ðoʊ ʃi hæd tə ɡɹɪɾ əɹ tiθ tə də ɪt.

I will smile at her if if kills me, Nynaeve thought, though she had to grit her teeth to do it.

ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn əpɪɹd, twɪstɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz ən skɹʌbɪŋ ðɛɹ maʊðz wɪð ðɛɹ slivz. əɾ ə stɛɹ fɹəm lɑɹəz, ðeɪ dæʃt tə ðə spɪɾ ən ɹɪzum ðɛɹ leɪbɝz.

Egwene and Elayne appeared, twisting their faces and scrubbing their mouths with their sleeves. At a stare from Laras, they dashed to the spit and resumed their labors.

"soʊp," ɪleɪn mʌɾɝd θɪkli, "teɪsts hɔɹəd!"

"Soap," Elayne muttered thickly, "tastes horrid!"

ɛɡwin tʃɹɛmbəld əz ʃi spun dʒus fɹəm ðə dʒɹɪpɪŋ pæn oʊvɝ ðə ɹoʊsts. "nɪneɪiv, ɪf jə tɛl mi ði æmɪɝlɪn toʊld əs tə steɪ hɪɹ, əl skɹim. aɪ maɪt ɹʌn əweɪ fəɹ ɹil."

Egwene trembled as she spooned juice from the dripping pan over the roasts. "Nynaeve, if you tell me the Amyrlin told us to stay here, I will scream. I might run away for real."

"wi liv æftɝ ðə wɑʃɪŋ ʌp ɪz dʌn," ʃi toʊl ðɛm, "dʒʌst əz kwɪkli əz wi kən fɛtʃ əɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz fɹəm əɹ ɹumz." ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd ʃɛɹ ði iɡɝnəs ðət flæʃt ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz. laɪt sɛnd wi ɑɹənt wɔkɪŋ ɪndə ə tʃɹæp wi kænt ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ʌv. laɪt sɛn ɪt soʊ.

"We leave after the washing up is done," she told them, "just as quickly as we can fetch our belongings from our rooms." She wished she could share the eagerness that flashed in their eyes. Light send we aren't walking into a trap we can't get out of. Light send it so.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾi


CHAPTER 30

ðə fɝs tɔs


The First Toss

æftɝ nɪneɪiv ən ði ʌðɝz lɛf hɪm, mæt spɛn moʊst ə ðə deɪ ɪn ɪz ɹum, ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn bɹif ɪkskɝʒən. hi wɑz plænɪŋ. ən iɾɪŋ. hi eɪt nɪɹli ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən bɹɔt hɪm, ən æsk fəɹ mɔɹ. ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ ðən hæpi tə əblaɪdʒ. ɪt wɑz bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz ən fɹuɾ i æsk fɔɹ, ən i paɪld wɪntɝ-ɹɪŋkəld æpəlz ən pɛɹz, wɛdʒəz ə tʃiz ən loʊvz ə bɹɛɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb, livɪŋ ɛmpti tʃɹeɪz fəɹ əm tə teɪk əweɪ.

After Nynaeve and the others left him, Mat spent most of the day in his room, except for one brief excursion. He was planning. And eating. He ate nearly everything the serving women brought him, and asked for more. They were more than happy to oblige. It was bread and cheese and fruit he asked for, and he piled winter-wrinkled apples and pears, wedges of cheese and loaves of bread inside the wardrobe, leaving empty trays for them to take away.

ət mɪddeɪ hi hæd tə ɛndʒjʊɹ ə vɪzət fɹəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ - æneɪjə, hi sim tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ əɹ neɪm wɑz. ʃi pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ɪz hɛɾ ən sɛn koʊl tʃɪlz θɹu hɪm. ɪt wɑz ðə wʌn paʊɝ, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd, nɑt sɪmpli biɪŋ tʌtʃt baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi wɑz ə pleɪn wʊmən dɪspaɪɾ əɹ smuð tʃiks ən ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi.

At midday he had to endure a visit from an Aes Sedai - Anaiya, he seemed to remember her name was. She put her hands on his head and sent cold chills through him. It was the One Power, he decided, not simply being touched by an Aes Sedai. She was a plain woman despite her smooth cheeks and Aes Sedai serenity.

"ju sim mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ," ʃi toʊl hɪm, smaɪlɪŋ. hɝ smaɪl meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə hɪz mʌðɝ. "ivən hʌŋɡɹiɝ ðən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd, soʊ aɪ hɪɹ, bʌt bɛɾɝ. aɪm ɪnfɔɹm jə ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə it ðə lɑɹɾɝz bɛɹ. bɪliv mi wən aɪ seɪ wɪl si juv ɔl ðə fud jə nid. jə də nɑɾ əv tə wɝi ðət wɪl lɛt jə mɪs ə mil bɪfɔɹ jə ɑɹ fʊli wɛl əɡɛn."

"You seem much better," she told him, smiling. Her smile made him think of his mother. "Even hungrier than I expected, so I hear, but better. I am informed you are trying to eat the larders bare. Believe me when I say we will see you have all the food you need. You do not have to worry that we'll let you miss a meal before you are fully well again."

hi ɡeɪv ðə ɡɹɪn i juzd ɑn ɪz mʌðɝ wən i ɪspɛʃli wɑntəɾ əɹ tə bɪliv hɪm. "aɪ noʊ jə woʊnt. ən aɪ də fil bɛɾɝ. aɪ θɔɾ aɪ maɪt si səm ə ðə sɪɾi ðɪs æftɝnun. ɪf juv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃənz, ʌv kɔɹs. meɪbi vɪzəɾ ən ɪn tənaɪt. ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ laɪk ə naɪɾ ə kɑmən-ɹum tɔk tə pɪk wʌnz spɪɹəts ʌp."

He gave the grin he used on his mother when he especially wanted her to believe him. "I know you won't. And I do feel better. I thought I might see some of the city this afternoon. If you have no objections, of course. Maybe visit an inn tonight. There's nothing like a night of common-room talk to pick one's spirits up."

hi θɔɾ əɹ lɪps twɪtʃt ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə bɪɡɝ smaɪl. "noʊ wʌn wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp ju, mæt. bʌt də nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə liv ðə sɪɾi. ɪɾəl oʊnli əpsɛt ðə ɡɑɹdz, ən bɹɪŋ jə nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ə tʃɹɪp bæk hɪɹ ʌndɝ ɛskɔɹt."

He thought her lips twitched on the edge of a bigger smile. "No one will try to stop you, Mat. But do not try to leave the city. It will only upset the guards, and bring you nothing but a trip back here under escort."

"aɪ wəd nɑt də ðæt, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sɛɾ aɪd stɑɹv tə dɛθ ɪn ə fju deɪz ɪf aɪ lɛft."

"I would not do that, Aes Sedai. The Amyrlin Seat said I'd starve to death in a few days if I left."

ʃi nɑɾəd əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ə wɝɾ i sɛd. "ʌv kɔɹs." əz ʃi tɝn fɹəm hɪm, hɝ aɪz fɛl ɑn ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf i hæd bɹɔt fɹəm ðə pɹæktəs jɑɹd, pɹɑpt ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum. "ju də nɑt nid tə pɹətɛk jɝsɛlf fɹəm ʌs, mæt. jə ɑɹ əz seɪf hɪɹ əz jə kəd bi ɛniwɛɹ. ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli seɪfɝ."

She nodded as if she did not believe a word he said. "Of course." As she turned from him, her eyes fell on the quarterstaff he had brought from the practice yard, propped in the corner of the room. "You do not need to protect yourself from us, Mat. You are as safe here as you could be anywhere. Almost certainly safer."

"oʊ, aɪ noʊ ðæt, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ du." æftɝ ʃi lɛft i fɹaʊn ət ðə dɔɹ, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf i hæd mænədʒ tə kənvɪns əɹ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ.

"Oh, I know that, Aes Sedai. I do." After she left he frowned at the door, wondering if he had managed to convince her of anything.

ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ivnɪŋ ðən æftɝnun wən i lɛf ðə ɹum fəɹ wʌɾ i hoʊpt wɑz ðə faɪnəl taɪm. ðə skaɪ wɑz pɝpəlɪŋ, ən ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn peɪntəd klaʊdz tə ðə wɛst ɪn ʃeɪdz ə ɹɛd. wʌns i hæɾ ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn hɪm, ən ðə bɪɡ lɛðɝ skɹɪp i hæd faʊn ɑn ɪz wʌn ɝliɝ fɔɹeɪ dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən bʌlʒɪŋ wɪð ðə bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz ən fɹuɾ i hæd skwɝəld əweɪ, wʌn lʊk ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ toʊld ɪm ðəɹ wɑz noʊ haɪɾɪŋ wʌɾ i ɪntɛndəd. hi taɪd ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz kloʊðz ʌp ɪn ə ɹoʊl wɪð ðə blæŋkət fɹəm ðə bɛɾ ən slʌŋ ðəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, tu. ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf dɪd fəɹ ə wɔkɪŋ stæf. hi lɛf nʌθɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. hɪz koʊt pɑkəts hɛld ɔl ɪz smɔlɝ bɪlɔŋɪŋz, ən ɪz bɛl paʊtʃ hɛl ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ði æmɪɝlɪn sits peɪpɝ. ɪleɪnz lɛɾɝ. ən ɪz daɪs kʌps.

It was more evening than afternoon when he left the room for what he hoped was the final time. The sky was purpling, and the setting sun painted clouds to the west in shades of red. Once he had his cloak around him, and the big leather scrip he had found on his one earlier foray dangling from his shoulder and bulging with the bread and cheese and fruit he had squirreled away, one look in the mirror told him there was no hiding what he intended. He tied the rest of his clothes up in a roll with the blanket from the bed and slung that across his shoulders, too. The quarterstaff did for a walking staff. He left nothing behind. His coat pockets held all his smaller belongings, and his belt pouch held the most important. The Amyrlin Seat's paper. Elayne's letter. And his dice cups.

hi sɔ ɛɛs sədaɪ əz i meɪɾ ɪz weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, ən səm ə ðɛm noʊɾəst hɪm, ðoʊ moʊs mɪɹli flɪkɝɾ ən aɪbɹaʊ, ən nʌn spoʊk tə hɪm. æneɪjə wɑz wʌn. ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ən əmjuz smaɪl ən ə ɹufəl ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd. hi ɹɪtɝn ə ʃɹʌɡ ən ðə ɡɪltiəst ɡɹɪn i kəd mænədʒ, ən ʃi wɛn saɪlənli ɑn, stɪl ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə taʊɝ ɡeɪts sɪmpli lʊkt ət hɪm.

He saw Aes Sedai as he made his way out of the Tower, and some of them noticed him, though most merely flickered an eyebrow, and none spoke to him. Anaiya was one. She gave him an amused smile and a rueful shake of her head. He returned a shrug and the guiltiest grin he could manage, and she went silently on, still shaking her head. The guards at the Tower gates simply looked at him.

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əntɪl i wɑz əkɹɔs ðə bɪɡ skwɛɹ ən ɪndə ðə stʃɹits ə ðə sɪɾi ðət ɹɪlif faɪnəli sɝdʒd ʌp ɪn hɪm. ən tʃɹaɪəmf. ɪf jə kæn haɪd wʌt jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du, də ɪt soʊ ɛvɹibɑɾi θɪŋks jə ɑɹ ə ful. ðən ðeɪ stæn ɝaʊnd weɪɾɪŋ tə si jə fɔl ɑn jəɹ feɪs. ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl bi weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz tə bɹɪŋ mi bæk. wən aɪ də nɑt ɹɪtɝn baɪ mɔɹnɪŋ, ðən ðəl stɑɹɾ ə sɝtʃ. nɑt tu fɹæntɪk ət fɝst, kəz ðəl θɪŋk aɪ hæv ɡɔn tə ɡɹaʊn sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹilaɪz aɪ hævənt, ðɪs ɹæbət wɪl bi ə lɔŋ weɪ daʊnɹɪvɝ fɹəm ðə haʊnz.

It was not until he was across the big square and into the streets of the city that relief finally surged up in him. And triumph. If you can't hide what you are going to do, do it so everybody thinks you are a fool. Then they stand around waiting to see you fall on your face. Those Aes Sedai will be waiting for the guards to bring me back. When I do not return by morning, then they'll start a search. Not too frantic at first, because they'll think I have gone to ground somewhere in the city. By the time they realize I haven't, this rabbit will be a long way downriver from the hounds.

wɪð əz laɪɾ ə hɑɹɾ əz i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ hævɪŋ ɪn jɪɹz, əɹ soʊ ɪt simd, hi bɪɡæn tə hʌm "wɝ oʊvɝ ðə bɔɹɾɝ əɡɛn," hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə hɑɹbɝ wɛɹ vɛsəlz wəd bi seɪlɪŋ daʊn tə tɛɹ ən ɔl ðə vɪlədʒəz əlɔŋ ði ɛɹɪnɪn bɪtwin. hi wəd nɑt bi ɡoʊɪŋ soʊ fɑɹ əz ðæt, ʌv kɔɹs. ɑɹɪŋɡəl, wɛɹ i wəd teɪk tə læn əɡɛn fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə tʃɹɪp tə keɪɛmlɪn, wɑz oʊnli hæfweɪ daʊnɹɪvɝ.

With as light a heart as he could remember having in years, or so it seemed, he began to hum "We're Over the Border Again," heading toward the harbor where vessels would be sailing down to Tear and all the villages along the Erinin between. He would not be going so far as that, of course. Aringill, where he would take to land again for the rest of the trip to Caemlyn, was only halfway downriver.

əl dɪlɪvɝ jəɹ blʌɾi lɛɾɝ. ðə nɝv ə hɝ, θɪŋkɪŋ aɪd seɪ aɪ wʊd, ðən nɑt. əl dɪlɪvɝ ðə blʌɾi θɪŋ ɪf ɪt kɪlz mi.

I'll deliver your bloody letter. The nerve of her, thinking I'd say I would, then not. I will deliver the bloody thing if it kills me.

twaɪlaɪt wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə kʌvɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ɪnʌf laɪt tə ɡɹeɪs ðə fæntæstɪkəl bɪldɪŋz, ən ði ɑdli ʃeɪp taʊɝz kənɛktəd baɪ haɪ bɹɪdʒəz spænɪŋ oʊpən ɛɹ oʊvɝ hʌnʒɹəd-peɪs dʒɹɑps. pipəl jɛt fɪl ðə stʃɹits, ɪn soʊ mɛni dɪfɹən kaɪnz ə kloʊðɪŋ ðəɾ i θɔɾ ɛvɹi neɪʃən mʌs bi ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd. əlɔŋ ðə meɪdʒɝ ævənuz, pɛɹz ə læmplaɪɾɝz juz ðɛɹ læɾɝz tə laɪt læntɝnz ətɑp tɔl poʊlz. bʌɾ ɪn ðə pɑɹɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn i sɔt, ði oʊnli laɪt wɑz wʌt spɪl fɹəm wɪndoʊz.

Twilight was beginning to cover Tar Valon, but there was still enough light to grace the fantastical buildings, and the oddly shaped towers connected by high bridges spanning open air over hundred-pace drops. People yet filled the streets, in so many different kinds of clothing that he thought every nation must be represented. Along the major avenues, pairs of lamplighters used their ladders to light lanterns atop tall poles. But in the part of Tar Valon he sought, the only light was what spilled from windows.

oʊɡiɝ hæd bɪl ðə ɡɹeɪt bɪldɪŋz ən taʊɝz ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, bʌɾ ʌðɝ, nuɝ pɑɹts hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌndɝ ðə hænz ə mɛn. nuɝ minɪŋ tu θaʊzən jɪɹz ɪn səm keɪsəz. daʊn nɪɹ saʊθ hɑɹbɝ, mɛnz hænz hæd tʃɹaɪd tə mætʃ, ɪf nɑt dupləkeɪt, ðə fænsɪfəl oʊɡiɝ wɝk. ɪnz wɛɹ ʃɪps' kɹuz kɛɹz bɔɹ ɪnʌf stoʊnwɝk fəɹ pæləsəz. stætʃuz ɪn nɪtʃɪz ən kʌpoʊləs ɑn ɹuftɑps, ɔɹnətli wɝkt kɔɹnɪsəz ən ɪntʃɹəkətli kɑɹv fɹizɪz, ɔl dɛkɝeɪɾəd tʃænlɝz' ʃɑps ən mɝtʃən haʊsəz. bɹɪdʒəz ɑɹtʃt əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹits hɪɹ, tu, bʌt ðə stʃɹits wɝ kɑbəlstoʊn, nɑt ɡɹeɪt peɪvɪŋ blɑks, ən mɛni ʌv ðə bɹɪdʒəz wɝ wʊɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə stoʊn, səmtaɪmz əz loʊ əz ðə sɛkən stɔɹiz ə ðə bɪldɪŋz ðeɪ dʒɔɪnd, ən nɛvɝ haɪɝ ðən fɔɹ.

Ogier had built the great buildings and towers of Tar Valon, but other, newer parts had grown under the hands of men. Newer meaning two thousand years in some cases. Down near South harbor, men's hands had tried to match, if not duplicate, the fanciful Ogier work. Inns where ships' crews caroused bore enough stonework for palaces. Statues in niches and cupolas on rooftops, ornately worked cornices and intricately carved friezes, all decorated chandlers' shops and merchant houses. Bridges arched across the streets here, too, but the streets were cobblestone, not great paving blocks, and many of the bridges were wood instead of stone, sometimes as low as the second stories of the buildings they joined, and never higher than four.

ðə dɑɹk stʃɹits hʌmd wɪð əz mʌtʃ laɪf əz ɛni ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. tʃɹeɪɾɝz ɔf ðɛɹ vɛsəlz ən ðoʊz u bɑt wʌt ðə vɛsəlz kæɹid, pipəl u tʃɹævəl ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn ən pipəl u wɝkt ɪt, ɔl fɪl ðə tævɝnz ən ðə kɑmən ɹumz ə ði ɪnz, ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð ðoʊz u sɔt ðə mʌni sətʃ foʊk kæɹid, baɪ fɛɹ minz əɹ mɝki. ɹɔkəs mjuzɪk fɪl ðə stʃɹits fɹəm bɪɾɝn ən flut, hɑɹp ən hæmɝd dʌlsɪmɝ. ðə fɝst ɪn mæt ɛntɝd hæd θɹi daɪs ɡeɪmz ɪn pɹɑɡɹɛs, mɛn kɹaʊtʃt ɪn sɝkəlz nɪɹ ðə kɑmən-ɹum wɔlz ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ ðə wɪnz ən lɔsəz.

The dark streets hummed with as much life as any in Tar Valon. Traders off their vessels and those who bought what the vessels carried, people who traveled the River Erinin and people who worked it, all filled the taverns and the common rooms of the inns, in company with those who sought the money such folk carried, by fair means or murky. Raucous music filled the streets from bittern and flute, harp and hammered dulcimer. The first inn Mat entered had three dice games in progress, men crouched in circles near the common-room walls and shouting the wins and losses.

hi oʊnli mɛn tə ɡæmbəl ən aʊɝ əɹ soʊ bɪfɔɹ faɪndɪŋ ə ʃɪp, dʒʌs lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə æɾ ə fju kɔɪnz tə hɪz pɝs, bʌɾ i wʌn. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz wʌn mɔɹ ðən i lɔst, əz fɑɹ əz i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ən ðəɹ hæd bɪn taɪmz wɪð hʊɹɪn, ən ɪn ʃaɪnɝ, wən sɪks əɹ eɪt tɔsɪz ɪn ə ɹoʊ wʌn fəɹ hɪm. tənaɪt, ɛvɹi tɔs wʌn. ɛvɹi tɔs.

He only meant to gamble an hour or so before finding a ship, just long enough to add a few coins to his purse, but he won. He had always won more than he lost, as far as he could remember, and there had been times with Hurin, and in Shienar, when six or eight tosses in a row won for him. Tonight, every toss won. Every toss.

fɹəm ðə lʊks səm ə ðə mɛn ɡeɪv hɪm, hi wɑz ɡlæɾ i hæd lɛft ɪz oʊn daɪs ɪn ɪz paʊtʃ. ðoʊz lʊks meɪɾ ɪm dɪsaɪd tə muv ɑn. wɪð sɝpɹaɪz i ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd nɪɹli θɝɾi sɪlvɝ mɑɹks ɪn ɪz pɝs naʊ, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt wʌn soʊ mʌtʃ fɹəm ɛni wʌn mæn ðət ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ ɔl bi ɡlæd tə si hɪm ɡoʊ.

From the looks some of the men gave him, he was glad he had left his own dice in his pouch. Those looks made him decide to move on. With surprise he realized that he had nearly thirty silver marks in his purse now, but he had not won so much from any one man that they would not all be glad to see him go.

ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn dɑɹk seɪlɝ wɪð taɪt kɝlz - wʌn ə ðə si foʊk, sʌmwʌn hæd sɛd, ðoʊ mæt wʌndɝd wʌt wʌn ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɑz duɪŋ soʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə si - hu fɑloʊɾ ɪm daʊn ðə dɑɹkən stʃɹit, ɑɹɡjuɪŋ fəɹ ə tʃæns tə meɪk ɡʊɾ ɪz lɔsəz. hi wɑntəd tə ɹitʃ ðə dɑks - θɝɾi sɪlvɝ mɑɹks wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf - bʌt ðə seɪlɝ ɑɹɡjuɾ ɑn, ən i hæɾ oʊnli juz hæf ɪz aʊɝ, soʊ hi ɡeɪv ɪn, ən wɪð ðə mæn ɛntɝd ðə nɛks tævɝn ðeɪ pæst.

Except for one dark sailor with tight curls - one of the Sea Folk, someone had said, though Mat wondered what one of the Atha'an Miere was doing so far from the sea - who followed him down the darkened street, arguing for a chance to make good his losses. He wanted to reach the docks - thirty silver marks was more than enough - but the sailor argued on, and he had only used half his hour, so he gave in, and with the man entered the next tavern they passed.

hi wʌn əɡɛn, ən ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ə fivɝ ɡɹɪp hɪm. hi wʌn ɛvɹi θɹoʊ. fɹəm tævɝn tə ɪn tə tævɝn i wɛnt, nɛvɝ steɪɪŋ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə æŋɡɝ ɛniwʌn wɪð ði əmaʊn ə hɪz wɪnɪŋz. ən i stɪl wʌn ɛvɹi tɔs. hi ɪkstʃeɪnʒd sɪlvɝ fəɹ ɡoʊld wɪð ə mʌni tʃeɪnɝ. hi pleɪɾ ət kɹaʊnz, ən faɪvz, ən meɪɾənz ɹuən. hi pleɪd ɡeɪmz wɪð faɪv daɪs, ən wɪð fɔɹ, ən θɹi, ən ivən oʊnli tu. hi pleɪd ɡeɪmz i dɪd nɑt noʊ bɪfɔɹ i skwɑɾɪd ɪn ðə sɝkəl, əɹ tʊk ə pleɪs ət ðə teɪbəl. ən i wʌn. sʌmwɛɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt, ðə dɑɹk seɪlɝ - ɹɑb, hi hæd sɛɾ ɪz neɪm wɑz - stæɡɝɾ əweɪ, ɪɡzɔstəd bʌt wɪð ə fʊl pɝs; hi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə pʊɾ ɪz weɪdʒɝz ɑn mæt. mæt vɪzəɾəd ənʌðɝ mʌni tʃeɪnɝ - əɹ pɝhæps tu; ðə fivɝ sim tə klaʊɾ ɪz bɹeɪn əz bædli əz ɪz mɛmɹiz ə ðə pæst wɝ klaʊɾəd - ən meɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə ənʌðɝ ɡeɪm. wɪnɪŋ.

He won again, and it was as if a fever gripped him. He won every throw. From tavern to inn to tavern he went, never staying long enough to anger anyone with the amount of his winnings. And he still won every toss. He exchanged silver for gold with a money changer. He played at crowns, and fives, and maiden's ruin. He played games with five dice, and with four, and three, and even only two. He played games he did not know before he squatted in the circle, or took a place at the table. And he won. Somewhere during the night, the dark sailor - Raab, he had said his name was - staggered away, exhausted but with a full purse; he had decided to put his wagers on Mat. Mat visited another money changer - or perhaps two; the fever seemed to cloud his brain as badly as his memories of the past were clouded - and made his way to another game. Winning.

ən soʊ hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ mɛni aʊɝz leɪɾɝ, ɪn ə tævɝn fɪld wɪð təbæk smoʊk - ðə tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ splaɪs, hi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz kɔld - stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ət faɪv daɪs, itʃ ʃoʊɪŋ ə dipli kɑɹv kɹaʊn. moʊst ə ðə peɪtʃɹənz hɪɹ simd ɪntʃɹəstəɾ oʊnli ɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ kʊd, bʌt ðə ɹæɾəl ə daɪs ən ʃaʊts ə pleɪɝz fɹəm ənʌðɝ ɡeɪm ɪn ðə fɑɹ kɔɹnɝ wɝ ɔlmoʊst səbmɝdʒ baɪ ə wʊmən sɪŋɪŋ tə ə kwɪk tun fɹəm ə hæmɝd dʌlsɪmɝ.

And so he found himself, he did not know how many hours later, in a tavern filled with tabac smoke - The Tremalking Splice, he thought it was called - staring down at five dice, each showing a deeply carved crown. Most of the patrons here seemed interested only in drinking as much as they could, but the rattle of dice and shouts of players from another game in the far corner were almost submerged by a woman singing to a quick tune from a hammered dulcimer.

"aɪl dæns wɪð ə ɡɝl wɪð aɪz ə bɹaʊn, əɹ ə ɡɝl wɪð aɪz ʌv ɡɹin, əl dæns wɪð ə ɡɝl wɪð ɛni kʌlɝ aɪz, bʌt jʊɹz ɑɹ ðə pɹɪɾiəst aɪv sin.

"I'll dance with a girl with eyes of brown, or a girl with eyes of green, I'll dance with a girl with any color eyes, but yours are the prettiest I've seen.

əl kɪs ə ɡɝl wɪð hɛɹ ə blæk, əɹ ə ɡɝl wɪð hɛɹ ʌv ɡoʊld, əl kɪs ə ɡɝl wɪð ɛni kʌlɝ hɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪts jə aɪ wɑnə hoʊld."

I'll kiss a girl with hair of black, or a girl with hair of gold, I'll kiss a girl with any color hair, but it's you I want to hold."

ðə sɪŋɝ hæd neɪm ðə sɔŋ əz "wʌɾ i sɛd tə mi." mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə tun əz "wɪl jə dæns wɪð meɪn," wɪð dɪfɹənt wɝdz, bʌɾ ət ðət moʊmən ɔl i kəd θɪŋk ʌv wɝ ðoʊz daɪs.

The singer had named the song as "What He Said to Me." Mat remembered the tune as "Will You Dance With Me," with different words, but at that moment all he could think of were those dice.

"ðə kɪŋ əɡɛn," wʌn ə ðə mɛn skwɑɾɪŋ wɪð mæt mʌɾɝd. ɪt wɑz ðə fɪfθ taɪm ɪn ə ɹoʊ mæt hæd θɹoʊn ðə kɪŋ.

"The king again," one of the men squatting with Mat muttered. It was the fifth time in a row Mat had thrown the king.

hi hæd wʌn ðə bɛɾ ʌv ə ɡoʊl mɑɹk, nɑɾ ivən kɛɹɪŋ baɪ ðɪs taɪm ðəɾ ɪz ændɔɝən mɑɹk aʊtweɪd ði ʌðɝ mænz ɪliɑnɝ kɔɪn, bʌɾ i skup ðə daɪs ɪndə ðə lɛðɝ kʌp, ɹæɾəld ɪt hɑɹd, ən spʌn əm əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ əɡɛn. faɪv kɹaʊnz. laɪt, ɪt kæn bi. noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ θɹu ðə kɪŋ sɪks taɪmz ɹʌnɪŋ. noʊbɑdi.

He had won the bet of a gold mark, not even caring by this time that his Andoran mark outweighed the other man's Illianer coin, but he scooped the dice into the leather cup, rattled it hard, and spun them across the floor again. Five crowns. Light, it can't be. Nobody ever threw the king six times running. Nobody.

"ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn lʌk," ənʌðɝ mæn ɡɹaʊld. hi wɑz ə bʌlki fɛloʊ, hɪz dɑɹk hɛɹ taɪɾ ət ðə neɪp ə hɪz nɛk wɪð ə blæk ɹɪbən, wɪð hɛvi ʃoʊldɝz, skɑɹz ɑn ɪz feɪs, ən ə noʊz ðət hæd bɪn bɹoʊkən mɔɹ ðən wʌns.

"The Dark One's own luck," another man growled. He was a bulky fellow, his dark hair tied at the nape of his neck with a black ribbon, with heavy shoulders, scars on his face, and a nose that had been broken more than once.

mæt wɑz skɛɹsli əwɛɹ ə muvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i hæd ðə bʌlki mæn baɪ ðə kɑlɝ, hɔlɪŋ ɪm tə hɪz fit, slæmɪŋ ɪm bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl. "doʊn jə seɪ ðæt!" hi snɑɹəld. "doʊn jə ɛvɝ seɪ ðæt!" ðə mæn blɪŋk daʊn əɾ ɪm ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt; hi wɑz ə fʊl hɛd tɔlɝ ðən mæt.

Mat was scarcely aware of moving before he had the bulky man by the collar, hauling him to his feet, slamming him back against the wall. "Don't you say that!" he snarled. "Don't you ever say that!" The man blinked down at him in astonishment; he was a full head taller than Mat.

"dʒʌst ə seɪɪŋ," sʌmbɑɾi bɪhaɪn ɪm wɑz mʌɾɝɪŋ. "laɪt, ɪts dʒʌst ə seɪɪŋ."

"Just a saying," somebody behind him was muttering. "Light, it's just a saying."

mæt ɹilist ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə skɑɹ-feɪs mænz koʊɾ ən bækt əweɪ. "aɪ. . . . aɪ . . . aɪ doʊn laɪk ɛnibəɾi seɪɪŋ θɪŋz laɪk ðəɾ əbaʊt mi. ɪm noʊ dɑɹkfɹɛnd!" bɝn mi, nɑt ðə dɑɹk wʌnz lʌk. nɑt ðæt! oʊ, laɪt, dɪd ðət blʌɾi dæɡɝ ɹɪli də sʌmθɪŋ tə mi?

Mat released his grip on the scar-faced man's coat and backed away. "I. . . . I . . . I don't like anybody saying things like that about me. I'm no Darkfriend!" Burn me, not the Dark One's luck. Not that! Oh, Light, did that bloody dagger really do something to me?

"noʊbɑdi sɛd jə wɑz," ðə bɹoʊkən-noʊz mæn mʌɾɝd. hi sim tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə bi æŋɡɹi.

"Nobody said you was," the broken-nosed man muttered. He seemed to be getting over his surprise, and trying to decide whether to be angry.

ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz fɹəm wɛɹ i hæd paɪld əm bɪhaɪn hɪm, mæt wɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə tævɝn, livɪŋ ðə kɔɪnz wɛɹ ðeɪ leɪ. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðəɾ i wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə bɪɡ mæn. hi hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðə mæn, ən ðə kɔɪnz, tu. ɔl i wɑntəd wɑz tə bi aʊtsaɪd, ɪn fɹɛʃ ɛɹ, wɛɹ i kəd θɪŋk.

Gathering his belongings from where he had piled them behind him, Mat walked out of the tavern, leaving the coins where they lay. It was not that he was afraid of the big man. He had forgotten the man, and the coins, too. All he wanted was to be outside, in fresh air, where he could think.

ɪn ðə stʃɹit, hi lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl ə ðə tævɝn nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə dɔɹ, bɹiðɪŋ ðə kulnəs ɪn. ðə dɑɹk stʃɹits ə saʊθhɑɹbɝ wɝ ɔl bʌɾ ɛmpti, naʊ. mjuzɪk ən læftɝ stɪl floʊɾəd fɹəm ði ɪnz ən tævɝnz, bʌt fju pipəl meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə naɪt. hoʊldɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf əpɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm wɪð boʊθ hænz, hi loʊɝɾ ɪz hɛd tə hɪz fɪsts ən tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk ət ðə pʌzəl fɹəm ɛvɹi saɪd.

In the street, he leaned against the wall of the tavern not far from the door, breathing the coolness in. The dark streets of Southharbor were all but empty, now. Music and laughter still floated from the inns and taverns, but few people made their way through the night. Holding the quarterstaff upright in front of him with both hands, he lowered his head to his fists and tried to think at the puzzle from every side.

hi nu hi wɑz lʌki. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɔlweɪz biɪŋ lʌki. bʌt sʌmhaʊ, hɪz mɛmɹiz fɹəm ɛmənz fil dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ hɪm əz lʌki əz i hæd bɪn sɪns livɪŋ. sɝɾənli hi hæd ɡɑɾən əweɪ wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt dil, bʌɾ i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɔlsoʊ biɪŋ kɑɾ ɪn pɹæŋks i hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ wəd səksid. hɪz mʌðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz sim tə noʊ wʌɾ i wɑz ʌp tə, ən nɪneɪiv eɪbəl tə si θɹu wʌtɛvɝ dɪfɛnsəz i pʊɾ ʌp. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt dʒʌst sɪns livɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ðəɾ i hæd bɪkʌm lʌki. ðə lʌk hæd kʌm wʌns i tʊk ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd pleɪɪŋ ət daɪs bæk hoʊm wɪð ə ʃɑɹp-aɪd, skɪni mæn u wɝk fəɹ ə mɝtʃən kʌm daʊn fɹəm bɛɹlən tə baɪ təbæk. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə stʃɹæpɪŋ ɪz fɑðɝ hæd ɡɪvən hɪm, tu, ɑn lɝnɪŋ mæt oʊd ðə mæn ə sɪlvɝ mɑɹk ən fɔɹ pɛns.

He knew he was lucky. He could remember always being lucky. But somehow, his memories from Emond's Field did not show him as lucky as he had been since leaving. Certainly he had gotten away with a great deal, but he could remember also being caught in pranks he had been sure would succeed. His mother had always seemed to know what he was up to, and Nynaeve able to see through whatever defenses he put up. But it was not just since leaving the Two Rivers that he had become lucky. The luck had come once he took the dagger from Shadar Logoth. He remembered playing at dice back home with a sharp-eyed, skinny man who worked for a merchant come down from Baerlon to buy tabac. He remembered the strapping his father had given him, too, on learning Mat owed the man a silver mark and four pence.

"bʌɾ aɪm fɹi ʌv ðə blʌɾi dæɡɝ," hi mʌmbəld. "ðoʊz blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛɾ aɪ wɑz." hi wʌndɝd haʊ mʌtʃ i hæd wʌn tənaɪt.

"But I'm free of the bloody dagger," he mumbled. "Those bloody Aes Sedai said I was." He wondered how much he had won tonight.

wən i dʌɡ ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkəts, hi faʊn əm fɪld wɪð lus kɔɪnz, kɹaʊnz ən mɑɹks, boʊθ sɪlvɝ ən ɡoʊl ðət ɡlɪɾɝd ən ɡlɪntɪɾ ɪn ðə laɪt fɹəm nɪɹbaɪ wɪndoʊz. hi hæd tu pɝsɪz naʊ, ɪt simd, ən boʊθ fæt. hi əndɪd ðə stʃɹɪŋz, ən faʊn mɔɹ ɡoʊld. ən stɪl mɔɹ stʌft ɪndə hɪz bɛl paʊtʃ bɪtwin ən ɝaʊn ən ɑn tɑp ə hɪz daɪs kʌps, kɹʌmplɪŋ ɪleɪnz lɛɾɝ ən ði æmɪɝlɪnz peɪpɝ. hi hæɾ ə mɛmɹi ʌv tɔsɪŋ sɪlvɝ pɛns tə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz kəz ðeɪ hæd pɹɪɾi smaɪlz əɹ pɹɪɾi aɪz əɹ pɹɪɾi æŋkəlz, ən kəz sɪlvɝ pɛns wɝ nɑt wɝθ kipɪŋ.

When he dug into his coat pockets, he found them filled with loose coins, crowns and marks, both silver and gold that glittered and glinted in the light from nearby windows. He had two purses now, it seemed, and both fat. He undid the strings, and found more gold. And still more stuffed into his belt pouch between and around and on top of his dice cups, crumpling Elayne's letter and the Amyrlin's paper. He had a memory of tossing silver pence to serving girls because they had pretty smiles or pretty eyes or pretty ankles, and because silver pence were not worth keeping.

nɑt wɝθ kipɪŋ? meɪbi ðeɪ wɝnt. laɪt, aɪm ɹɪtʃ! aɪm blʌɾi ɹɪtʃ! meɪbi ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd. sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ dɪd hilɪŋ mi. baɪ æksəɾənt, meɪbi. ðət kəd bi ɪt. bɛɾɝ ðət ði ʌðɝ. ðoʊz blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌst əv dʌn ɪt tə mi.

Not worth keeping? Maybe they weren't. Light, I'm rich! I am bloody rich! Maybe it was something the Aes Sedai did. Something they did Healing me. By accident, maybe. That could be it. Better that the other. Those bloody Aes Sedai must have done it to me.

ə bɪɡ mæn muvd aʊt fɹəm ðə tævɝn, ðə dɔɹ ɔlɹɛɾi swɪŋɪŋ ʃʌt tə kʌɾ ɔf ðə laɪt ðət maɪɾ əv ʃoʊn ɪz feɪs.

A big man moved out from the tavern, the door already swinging shut to cut off the light that might have shown his face.

mæt pɹɛst ɪz bæk kloʊs əɡɛns ðə wɔl, stʌf ðə pɝsɪz bæk ɪndə hɪz koʊt, ən fɝmd ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf. wɛɹɛvɝ ɪz lʌk tənaɪt hæd kʌm fɹʌm, hi dɪd nɑt min tə luz ɔl ðət ɡoʊl tə ə fʊtpæd.

Mat pressed his back close against the wall, stuffed the purses back into his coat, and firmed his grip on the quarterstaff. Wherever his luck tonight had come from, he did not mean to lose all that gold to a footpad.

ðə mæn tɝn təwɔɹd hɪm, pɪɹd, ðən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. "si-kul naɪt," hi sɛd dʒɹʌŋkənli. hi stæɡɝd kloʊsɝ, ən mæt sɔ ðət moʊst ə hɪz saɪz wɑz fæt. "aɪ hæv tə. . . . aɪ hæv tə. . . ." stʌmbəlɪŋ, ðə fæt mæn muvd ɑn ʌp ðə stʃɹit, tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf dɪsdʒɔɪntɪdli.

The man turned toward him, peered, then gave a start. "C-cool night," he said drunkenly. He staggered closer, and Mat saw that most of his size was fat. "I have to. . . . I have to. . . ." Stumbling, the fat man moved on up the street, talking to himself disjointedly.

"ful!" mæt mʌɾɝd, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ i mɛn ɪt fəɹ ðə fæt mæn əɹ fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. "taɪm tə faɪn ə ʃɪp tə teɪk mi əweɪ fɹəm hɪɹ." hi skwɪntɪɾ ət ðə blæk skaɪ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɛstəmeɪt haʊ lɔŋ tɪl dɔn. tu, meɪbi θɹi aʊɝz, hi θɔt. "pæs taɪm." hɪz stʌmək ɡɹaʊld ət hɪm; hi dɪmli ɹɪkɔld iɾɪŋ ɪn səm ə ði ɪnz, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt. ðə fivɝ ə ðə daɪs hæd hæɾ ɪm baɪ ðə θɹoʊt. ə hæn pʊʃt ɪndə ðə skɹɪp faʊn oʊnli kɹʌmz. "weɪ pæs taɪm. əɹ wʌn ə ðɛm wɪl kʌm pɪk mi ʌp wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ən stɪk mi ɪn əɹ paʊtʃ." hi pʊʃt əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɔl ən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɑks, wɛɹ ðə ʃɪps wəd bi.

"Fool!" Mat muttered, but he was not sure whether he meant it for the fat man or for himself. "Time to find a ship to take me away from here." He squinted at the black sky, trying to estimate how long till dawn. Two, maybe three hours, he thought. "Past time." His stomach growled at him; he dimly recalled eating in some of the inns, but he did not remember what. The fever of the dice had had him by the throat. A hand pushed into the scrip found only crumbs. "Way past time. Or one of them will come pick me up with her fingers and stick me in her pouch." He pushed away from the wall and started for the docks, where the ships would be.

ət fɝst i θɔt ðə feɪn saʊnz bɪhaɪn ɪm wɝ ɛkoʊz ə hɪz buts ɑn ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz. ðən i ɹilaɪz sʌmwʌn wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm. ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bi stɛlθi. wɛl, ðiz ɑɹ fʊtpædz, fəɹ ʃʊɹ.

At first he thought the faint sounds behind him were echoes of his boots on the cobblestones. Then he realized someone was following him. And trying to be stealthy. Well, these are footpads, for sure.

hɛftɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf, hi bɹifli kənsɪɾɝd tɝnɪŋ tə kənfɹʌn ðɛm. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dɑɹk, ən ðə fʊɾɪŋ ɑn kɑbəlstoʊnz ənsɝɾən, ən i hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ mɛni ðəɹ wɝ. dʒʌs kəz jə dɪd wɛl əɡɛnst ɡɔɪn ən ɡɑləd dʌzn meɪk jə ə blʌɾi hɪɹoʊ aʊɾ ʌv ə stɔɹi.

Hefting the quarterstaff, he briefly considered turning to confront them. But it was dark, and the footing on cobblestones uncertain, and he had no idea how many there were. Just because you did well against Gawyn and Galad doesn't make you a bloody hero out of a story.

hi tɝn daʊn ə nɛɹoʊɝ, twɪstɪŋ saɪd stʃɹit, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɔk ɑn tɪptoʊ ən muv kwɪkli ət ðə seɪm taɪm. ɛvɹi wɪndoʊ wɑz dɑɹk hɪɹ, ən moʊst ʃʌɾɝd. hi wɑz ɔlmoʊs tə ði ɛnd wən i sɔ muvmən əhɛd, tu mɛn piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə saɪd stʃɹit fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt lɛɾ aʊɾ ɑntu ənʌðɝ. ən i hɝd sloʊ fʊtstɛps bɪhaɪn hɪm, sɑf skɹeɪps ə but lɛðɝ ɑn stoʊn.

He turned down a narrower, twisting side street, trying to walk on tiptoe and move quickly at the same time. Every window was dark here, and most shuttered. He was almost to the end when he saw movement ahead, two men peering into the side street from where it let out onto another. And he heard slow footsteps behind him, soft scrapes of boot leather on stone.

ɪn ən ɪnstən i dʌkt ɪndə ðə ʃæɾoʊi kɔɹnɝ wɛɹ wʌn bɪldɪŋ stʌk aʊt fɝðɝ ðən ðə nɛkst. ɪt sim ðə bɛst i kəd də fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf nɝvəsli, hi weɪɾəd.

In an instant he ducked into the shadowy corner where one building stuck out further than the next. It seemed the best he could do for the moment. Gripping the quarterstaff nervously, he waited.

ə mæn əpɪɹd fɹəm bæk ðə weɪ hi hæd kʌm, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ əz i iz hɪmsɛlf əhɛd wʌn sloʊ stɛp əɾ ə taɪm, ən ðən ənʌðɝ mæn. itʃ kæɹiɾ ə naɪf ɪn ɪz hæn ən muvd əz ɪf stɔkɪŋ.

A man appeared from back the way he had come, crouching as he eased himself ahead one slow step at a time, and then another man. Each carried a knife in his hand and moved as if stalking.

mæt tɛnst. ɪf ðeɪ keɪm dʒʌst ə fju stɛps kloʊsɝ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ noʊɾəst ɪm haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dipɝ ʃædoʊz ə ðə kɔɹnɝ, hi kəd teɪk əm baɪ sɝpɹaɪz. hi wɪʃt ɪz stʌmək wəd stɑp flʌɾɝɪŋ. ðoʊz naɪvz wɝ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ðə pɹæktəs sɔɹdz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stil, nɑt wʊd.

Mat tensed. If they came just a few steps closer before they noticed him hiding in the deeper shadows of the corner, he could take them by surprise. He wished his stomach would stop fluttering. Those knives were a great deal shorter than the practice swords, but they were steel, not wood.

wʌn ə ðə mɛn skwɪntɪd təwɔɹd ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹiɾ ən sʌɾənli stʃɹeɪɾənd, ʃaʊɾɪŋ, "dɪdn i kʌm jəɹ weɪ, ðɛn?"

One of the men squinted toward the far end of the narrow street and suddenly straightened, shouting, "Didn't he come your way, then?"

"aɪ hæv sin nʌθɪŋ bʌt ðə ʃædoʊz," keɪm ði ænsɝ ɪn ə hɛvi æksɛnt. "aɪ wɪʃ tə bi aʊɾ ə ðɪs. ðəɹ ɑɹ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz muvɪŋ ðɪs naɪt."

"I have seen nothing but the shadows," came the answer in a heavy accent. "I wish to be out of this. There are the strange things moving this night."

nɑt fɔɹ peɪsɪz fɹəm mæt, ðə tu mɛn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks, ʃiðd ðɛɹ naɪvz, ən tʃɹɑɾəd bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm.

Not four paces from Mat, the two men exchanged looks, sheathed their knives, and trotted back the way they had come.

hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ, sloʊ bɹɛθ. lʌk. bɝn mi ɪf ɪts nɑt ɡʊd fəɹ mɔɹ ðən daɪs.

He let out a long, slow breath. Luck. Burn me if it's not good for more than dice.

hi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ si ðə mɛn ət ðə maʊθ ə ðə stʃɹit, bʌɾ i nu ðeɪ wɝ stɪl aʊɾ ɑn ðə nɛkst stʃɹit sʌmwɛɹ. ən mɔɹ bɪhaɪn ɪm ði ʌðɝ weɪ.

He could no longer see the men at the mouth of the street, but he knew they were still out on the next street somewhere. And more behind him the other way.

wʌn ə ðə bɪldɪŋz i wɑz kɹaʊtʃt əɡɛnst stʊɾ oʊnli ə sɪŋɡəl stɔɹi haɪ hɪɹ, ən ðə ɹuf lʊk flæɾ ɪnʌf. ən ə waɪt stoʊn fɹiz kɑɹvd ɪn hjudʒ ɡɹeɪp livz ɹæn ʌp ðə dʒɔɪnɪŋ ə ðə tu bɪldɪŋz.

One of the buildings he was crouched against stood only a single story high here, and the roof looked flat enough. And a white stone frieze carved in huge grape leaves ran up the joining of the two buildings.

izɪŋ ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf ʌp tɪl wʌn ɛn ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹuf, hi ɡeɪv ɪɾ ə hɑɹd ʃʌv. ɪt lændəd wɪð ə klæɾɝ ɑn ðə ɹuf taɪlz. nɑt weɪɾɪŋ tə si ɪf ɛniwʌn hæd hɝd, hi skɹæmbəld ʌp ðə fɹiz, ðə bɪɡ livz ɡɪvɪŋ izi toʊhoʊlz ivən fəɹ ə mæn ɪn buts. ɪn sɛkənz i hæd ðə stæf bæk ɪn hæn ən wɑz tʃɹɑɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹuf, tʃɹʌstɪŋ tə lʌk fəɹ ɪz fʊɾɪŋ.

Easing his quarterstaff up till one end rested on the edge of the roof, he gave it a hard shove. It landed with a clatter on the roof tiles. Not waiting to see if anyone had heard, he scrambled up the frieze, the big leaves giving easy toeholds even for a man in boots. In seconds he had the staff back in hand and was trotting across the roof, trusting to luck for his footing.

θɹi mɔɹ taɪmz i klaɪmd, itʃ taɪm ɡeɪnɪŋ wʌn stɔɹi. ðə slaɪtli sloʊpɪŋ, taɪld ɹufs ɹæn səm dɪstəns ət ðət lɛvəl, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə bɹiz ət ðət haɪt, pɹɪklɪŋ ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk wɪð ɪts tʃɪl ən ɔlmoʊs meɪkɪŋ ɪm θɪŋk i wɑz biɪŋ fɑloʊd. stɑp ðæt, ful! ðəɹ θɹi stʃɹits əweɪ baɪ naʊ, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmbɑɾi ɛls wɪð ə fæt pɝs, ən bæd lʌk tə ðɛm.

Three more times he climbed, each time gaining one story. The slightly sloping, tiled roofs ran some distance at that level, and there was a breeze at that height, prickling the hair on the back of his neck with its chill and almost making him think he was being followed. Stop that, fool! They're three streets away by now, looking for somebody else with a fat purse, and bad luck to them.

hɪz buts slɪpt ɑn ðə taɪlz, ən i dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt maɪt bi ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ bæk daʊn ɪndə ðə stʃɹit hɪmsɛlf. kɔʃəsli, hi muv tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹuf ən pɪɹd daʊn. ən ɛmpti stʃɹit leɪ ə ɡʊd fɔɹɾi fiɾ əɹ mɔɹ bɪloʊ hɪm, wɪð θɹi tævɝnz ən ən ɪn spɪlɪŋ laɪɾ ən mjuzɪk ɑntu ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz. bʌɾ ɔf tə hɪz ɹaɪt wɑz ə stoʊn bɹɪdʒ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðə tɑp flɔɹ ə hɪz bɪldɪŋ tə ðə wʌn ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd.

His boots slipped on the tiles, and he decided it might be a good idea to think about getting back down into the street himself. Cautiously, he moved to the edge of the roof and peered down. An empty street lay a good forty feet or more below him, with three taverns and an inn spilling light and music onto the cobblestones. But off to his right was a stone bridge running from the top floor of his building to the one on the other side.

ðə bɹɪdʒ lʊkt ɑfli nɛɹoʊ, ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu dɑɹknəs əntʌtʃt baɪ ðə tævɝn laɪts, ɑɹsɪŋ oʊvɝ ə lɔŋ fɔl tə hɑɹd kɑbəlstoʊnz, bʌɾ i tɔs ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf daʊn ən meɪd hɪmsɛlf fɑloʊ bɪfɔɹ i kəd θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt tu mʌtʃ. hɪz buts θʌmpt ɑntu ðə bɹɪdʒ, ən i lɛt hɪmsɛlf ɹoʊl ðə weɪ hi hæɾ əz ə bɔɪ fɔlɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə tʃɹi. hi fɛtʃt ʌp əɡɛns ðə weɪst-haɪ ɹeɪlɪŋ.

The bridge looked awfully narrow, running through darkness untouched by the tavern lights, arcing over a long fall to hard cobblestones, but he tossed the quarterstaff down and made himself follow before he could think about it too much. His boots thumped onto the bridge, and he let himself roll the way he had as a boy falling out of a tree. He fetched up against the waist-high railing.

"bæd hæbəts peɪ ɔf ɪn ðə lɔŋ ɹʌn," hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf əz i ɡɑt tə hɪz fiɾ ən pɪkt ʌp ðə stæf.

"Bad habits pay off in the long run," he told himself as he got to his feet and picked up the staff.

ðə wɪndoʊ ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə bɹɪdʒ wɑz taɪtli ʃʌɾɝd ən laɪtləs. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk huɛvɝ lɪvd ɪn ðəɹ wəɾ əpɹiʃieɪɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt. hi kəd si lɑts ə stoʊnwɝk, bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz əz mʌtʃ əz ə fɪŋɡɝhoʊld ɪn ɹitʃ ə ðə bɹɪdʒ, ðə naɪt hɪɾ ɪt. wɛl, stʃɹeɪnʒɝ əɹ noʊ stʃɹeɪnʒɝ, ɪnsaɪɾ aɪ ɡoʊ.

The window at the other end of the bridge was tightly shuttered and lightless. He did not think whoever lived in there would appreciate a stranger appearing in the middle of the night. He could see lots of stonework, but if there was as much as a fingerhold in reach of the bridge, the night hid it. Well, stranger or no stranger, inside I go.

hi tɝn fɹəm ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ ən sʌɾənli bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ʌv ə mæn ʃɛɹɪŋ ðə bɹɪdʒ wɪð hɪm. ə mæn wɪð ə dæɡɝ ɪn ɪz hænd.

He turned from the railing and suddenly became aware of a man sharing the bridge with him. A man with a dagger in his hand.

mæt ɡɹæbd ət ðə hæn əz ðə naɪf dɑɹɾɪd təwɔɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. hi bɛɹli kɑt ðə fɛloʊz ɹɪst wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, ən ðən ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf bɪtwin əm tæŋɡəld ɪtsɛlf ɪn ɪz lɛɡz, tʃɹɪpɪŋ ɪm tə fɔl bæk əɡɛns ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, tə fɔl hæf oʊvɝ ɪt pʊlɪŋ ði ʌðɝ mæn ɑn tɑp ə hɪm. bæləns ðəɹ ɑn ðə smɔl ə hɪz bæk, tiɾɝɪŋ wɪð ɪz əseɪləns bɛɹd tiθ ɪn ɪz feɪs, hi wɑz əz əwɛɹ ə ðə lɔŋ dʒɹɑp ʌndɝ ɪz hɛɾ əz i wɑz ə ðə bleɪd kætʃɪŋ feɪn munlaɪɾ əz ɪɾ ɛdʒ təwɔɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. hɪz fɪŋɡɝ ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə mænz ɹɪst wɑz slɪpɪŋ, ən ɪz ʌðɝ hænd wɑz kɑt wɪð ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf bɪtwin ðɛɹ bɑɾiz. oʊnli sɛkənz hæd pæst sɪns i fɝst sɔ ðə mæn, ən ɪn sɛkənz mɔɹ, hi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ daɪ wɪð ə naɪf ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt.

Mat grabbed at the hand as the knife darted toward his throat. He barely caught the fellow's wrist with his fingers, and then the quarterstaff between them tangled itself in his legs, tripping him to fall back against the railing, to fall half over it pulling the other man on top of him. Balanced there on the small of his back, teetering with his assailant's bared teeth in his face, he was as aware of the long drop under his head as he was of the blade catching faint moonlight as it edged toward his throat. His finger grip on the man's wrist was slipping, and his other hand was caught with the quarterstaff between their bodies. Only seconds had passed since he first saw the man, and in seconds more, he was going die with a knife in his throat.

"taɪm tə tɔs ðə daɪs," hi sɛd. hi θɔt ði ʌðɝ mæn lʊkt kənfjuz fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, bʌɾ ən ɪnstənt wɑz ɔl i hæd. wɪð ə hiv ə hɪz lɛɡz, mæt flɪpt əm boʊθ ɔf ɪndə ði ɛmpti ɛɹ.

"Time to toss the dice," he said. He thought the other man looked confused for an instant, but an instant was all he had. With a heave of his legs, Mat flipped them both off into the empty air.

fəɹ ə stʃɹɛtʃt-aʊt moʊmən i sim tə hæv noʊ weɪt. ɛɹ wɪsəl pæst ɪz ɪɹz ən ɹʌfəld ɪz hɛɹ. hi θɔɾ i hɝd ði ʌðɝ mæn skɹim, əɹ stɑɹt tə. ði ɪmpæk nɑkt ɔl ði ɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz lʌŋz ən meɪd sɪlvɝ-blæk flɛks dæns əkɹɔs ɪz blɝɪŋ vɪʒən.

For a stretched-out moment he seemed to have no weight. Air whistled past his ears and ruffled his hair. He thought he heard the other man scream, or start to. The impact knocked all the air out of his lungs and made silver-black flecks dance across his blurring vision.

wən i kəd bɹið əɡɛn - ən si - hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn tɑp ə ðə mæn u hæɾ ətæk hɪm, hɪz fɔl kʊʃən baɪ ði ʌðɝz bɑɾi. "lʌk," hi wɪspɝd. sloʊli hi klaɪm tə hɪz fit, kɝsɪŋ ðə bɹuz ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf hæd pʊɾ əkɹɔs ɪz ɹɪbz.

When he could breathe again - and see - he realized he was lying on top of the man who had attacked him, his fall cushioned by the other's body. "Luck," he whispered. Slowly he climbed to his feet, cursing the bruise the quarterstaff had put across his ribs.

hi ɪkspɛktəd ði ʌðɝ mæn tə bi dɛd - nɑt mɛni kəd sɝvaɪv ə θɝɾi-fʊt fɔl tə kɑbəlstoʊnz wɪð ənʌðɝz weɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə hɪm - bʌt wʌɾ i hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd wɑz tə si ðə fɛloʊz dæɡɝ dʒɹɪvən tə ðə hɪlt ɪndə hɪz oʊn hɑɹt. sətʃ ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi-lʊkɪŋ mæn tə hæv tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm. mæt dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i wəɾ ivən əv noʊɾəst ɪm ɪn ə kɹaʊɾəd ɹum.

He expected the other man to be dead - not many could survive a thirty-foot fall to cobblestones with another's weight on top of him - but what he had not expected was to see the fellow's dagger driven to the hilt into his own heart. Such an ordinary-looking man to have tried to kill him. Mat did not think he would even have noticed him in a crowded room.

"ju hæd bæd lʌk, fɛloʊ," hi toʊl ðə kɔɹps ʃɑkəli.

"You had bad luck, fellow," he told the corpse shakily.

sʌɾənli, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət hæd hæpən ɹʌʃt bæk ɪn ɑn hɪm. ðə fʊtpædz ɪn ðə twɪstɪŋ stʃɹit. ðə skɹæmbəl oʊvɝ ðə ɹuftɑps. ðɪs fɛloʊ. ðə fɔl. hɪz aɪz ɹoʊz tə ðə bɹɪdʒ oʊvɝhɛd, ən ə fɪɾ ə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ hɪt hɪm. aɪ mʌst əv bɪn kɹeɪzi. ə lɪɾəl ædvɛntʃɝ ɪz wʌn θɪŋ, bʌt ɹəɡoʊʃ iɡəl-aɪ wʊdn æsk fəɹ ðɪs.

Suddenly, everything that had happened rushed back in on him. The footpads in the twisting street. The scramble over the rooftops. This fellow. The fall. His eyes rose to the bridge overhead, and a fit of trembling hit him. I must have been crazy. A little adventure is one thing, but Rogosh Eagle-eye wouldn't ask for this.

hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz stændɪŋ oʊvɝ ə dɛd mæn wɪð ə dæɡɝ ɪn ɪz tʃɛst, dʒʌst weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə kʌm əlɔŋ ən ɹʌn ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ sɪɾi ɡɑɹdz wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts. ði æmɪɝlɪnz peɪpɝ maɪt ɡɛɾ ɪm əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm, bʌt meɪbi nɑt bɪfɔɹ ʃi faʊn aʊt. hi kəd stɪl ɛn ʌp bæk ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wɪθaʊt ðət peɪpɝ, ən pɑsəbli nɑɾ ivən əlaʊɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz.

He realized he was standing over a dead man with a dagger in his chest, just waiting for someone to come along and run shouting for city guards with the Flame of Tar Valon on their chests. The Amyrlin's paper might get him away from them, but maybe not before she found out. He could still end up back in the White Tower, without that paper, and possibly not even allowed outside the Tower grounds.

hi nu hi ʃəd bi ɑn ɪz weɪ tə ðə dɑks ɹaɪt ðɛn, ən ɑn ðə fɝs vɛsəl seɪlɪŋ ɪf ɪt wɑz ə ɹɑɾən tʌb fʊl ʌv oʊl fɪʃ, bʌɾ ɪz niz wɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf ɪn ɹiækʃən ðəɾ i kəd hɑɹdli wɔk. wʌɾ i wɑntəd wɑz tə sɪt daʊn fəɹ dʒʌst ə mɪnət. dʒʌst ə mɪnət tə stɛɾi hɪz niz, ən ðən i wɑz hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə dɑks.

He knew he should be on his way to the docks right then, and on the first vessel sailing if it was a rotten tub full of old fish, but his knees were shaking hard enough in reaction that he could hardly walk. What he wanted was to sit down for just a minute. Just a minute to steady his knees, and then he was headed for the docks.

ðə tævɝnz wɝ kloʊsɝ, bʌɾ i stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ði ɪn. ðə kɑmən ɹum ʌv ən ɪn wɑz ə fɹɛnli pleɪs, wɛɹ ə mæn kəd ɹɛst ə mɪnəɾ ən nɑt wɝi əbaʊɾ u maɪt bi snikɪŋ ʌp bɪhaɪn hɪm. ɪnʌf laɪt keɪm aʊt θɹu ðə wɪndoʊz fəɹ ɪm tə meɪk aʊt ðə saɪn. ə wʊmən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɪn bɹeɪdz, hoʊldɪŋ wʌɾ i θɔt wɑz ən ɑləv bɹæntʃ, ən ðə wɝdz "ðə wʊmən ə tæntʃəkoʊ."

The taverns were closer, but he started toward the inn. The common room of an inn was a friendly place, where a man could rest a minute and not worry about who might be sneaking up behind him. Enough light came out through the windows for him to make out the sign. A woman with her hair in braids, holding what he thought was an olive branch, and the words "The Woman of Tanchico."


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiwʌn


CHAPTER 31

ðə wʊmən ə tæntʃəkoʊ


The Woman of Tanchico

ðə kɑmən ɹum ə ði ɪn wɑz bɹaɪtli lɪt, ðə teɪbəlz nɑt nɪɹ ə kɔɹɾɝ fʊl soʊ leɪt. ə fju waɪt-eɪpɹən sɝvɪŋ wɪmən wɪð mʌɡz ʌv eɪl əɹ waɪn pæst əmʌŋ ðə mɛn, ən ə loʊ mɝmɝ ə tɔk ɹæn ʌndɝ ðə saʊn ʌv ə hɑɹp biɪŋ stʃɹʌmd ən plʌkt. ðə peɪtʃɹənz, səm wɪð paɪps klɛntʃt ɪn ðɛɹ tiθ ən wʌn pɛɹ hʌntʃt oʊvɝ ə stoʊnz bɔɹd, hæd ðə lʊk ə ʃɪps ɔfəsɝz ən maɪnɝ mɝtʃəns fɹəm ðə smɔlɝ haʊzɪz, ðɛɹ koʊts wɛl kʌɾ ən ə faɪn wʊl, bʌt wɪð nʌn ə ðə ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ðət ɹɪtʃɝ mɛn maɪɾ əv hæd. ən fəɹ wʌns ðəɹ wɑz noʊ klæk ən ɹæɾəl ə daɪs tə bi hɝd. faɪɝz bleɪzd ɑn ðə lɔŋ hɑɹθs ət ði ɛnz ə ðə ɹum, bʌɾ ivən wɪθaʊt ðoʊz ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn ə wɔɹm filɪŋ əbaʊt ðə pleɪs.

The common room of the inn was brightly lit, the tables not near a quarter full so late. A few white-aproned serving women with mugs of ale or wine passed among the men, and a low murmur of talk ran under the sound of a harp being strummed and plucked. The patrons, some with pipes clenched in their teeth and one pair hunched over a stones board, had the look of ship's officers and minor merchants from the smaller houses, their coats well cut and of fine wool, but with none of the gold or silver or embroidery that richer men might have had. And for once there was no clack and rattle of dice to be heard. Fires blazed on the long hearths at the ends of the room, but even without those there would have been a warm feeling about the place.

ðə hɑɹpɝ stʊɾ ɑn ə teɪbəltɑp, ɹisaɪɾɪŋ "mɑɹə ən ðə θɹi fulɪʃ kɪŋz," tə ðə mjuzɪk ə hɪz hɑɹp. hɪz ɪnstʃɹəmənt, ɔl wɝkt ɪn ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ, wɑz fɪt fəɹ ə pæləs. mæt nu hɪm. hi hæd seɪv mæts laɪf, wʌns.

The harper stood on a tabletop, reciting "Mara and the Three Foolish Kings," to the music of his harp. His instrument, all worked in gold and silver, was fit for a palace. Mat knew him. He had saved Mat's life, once.

ðə hɑɹpɝ wɑz ə lin mæn u wʊɾə bɪn tɔl ɪksɛp fəɹ ə stup, ən i muvd wɪð ə lɪmp wən i ʃɪftəɾ ɪz fʊɾɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəltɑp. ivən hɪɹ ɪnsaɪd, hi wɔɹ ɪz kloʊk, ɔl kʌvɝd wɪð flʌɾɝɪŋ pætʃəz ɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd kʌlɝz. hi ɔlweɪz wɑntəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn tə noʊ hi wɑz ə ɡlimən. hɪz lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz ən bʊʃi aɪbɹaʊz wɝ əz snoʊ-waɪɾ əz ðə θɪk hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd, ən ɪz blu aɪz hɛld ə lʊk ə sɑɹoʊ əz i ɹəsaɪɾəd. ðə lʊk wɑz əz ʌnɪkspɛktɪɾ əz ðə mæn. mæt hæd nɛvɝ noʊn tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn tə bi ə sɑɹoʊfəl mæn.

The harper was a lean man who would have been tall except for a stoop, and he moved with a limp when he shifted his footing on the tabletop. Even here inside, he wore his cloak, all covered with fluttering patches in a hundred colors. He always wanted everyone to know he was a gleeman. His long mustaches and bushy eyebrows were as snow-white as the thick hair on his head, and his blue eyes held a look of sorrow as he recited. The look was as unexpected as the man. Mat had never known Thom Merrilin to be a sorrowful man.

hi tʊk ə teɪbəl, sɛɾɪŋ ɪz θɪŋz ɑn ðə flɔɹ baɪ hɪz stul, ən ɔɹɾɝd tu mʌɡz. ðə pɹɪɾi jʌŋ sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz bɪɡ bɹaʊn aɪz twɪŋkəld ət hɪm.

He took a table, setting his things on the floor by his stool, and ordered two mugs. The pretty young serving girl's big brown eyes twinkled at him.

"tu, jʌŋ mæstɝ? jə də nɑt lʊk sətʃ ə hɑɹd-dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ mæn əz ðæt." hɝ vɔɪs hɛld ə mɪstʃəvəs ɛdʒ ə læftɝ.

"Two, young master? You do not look such a hard-drinking man as that." Her voice held a mischievous edge of laughter.

æftɝ ɹʌmɪdʒɪŋ ə bɪt, hi bɹɔɾ aʊt tu sɪlvɝ pɛniz fɹəm ɪz pɑkət. wʌn mɔɹ ðən peɪd fəɹ ðə waɪn, bʌɾ i slɪpt əɹ ənʌðɝ fəɹ əɹ aɪz. "maɪ fɹɛnd wɪl bi dʒɔɪnɪŋ mi."

After rummaging a bit, he brought out two silver pennies from his pocket. One more than paid for the wine, but he slipped her another for her eyes. "My friend will be joining me."

hi nu tɑm hæd sin hɪm. ði oʊld ɡlimən hæd nɪɹli stɑp ðə stɔɹi dɛd wən mæt keɪm ɪn. ðət wɑz nu, tu. fju θɪŋz stɑɹɾəld tɑm ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə lɛɾ ɪt ʃoʊ, ən nʌθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə tʃɹɑləks hæɾ ɛvɝ meɪɾ ɪm stɑp ə stɔɹi ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ðət mæt nu. wən ðə ɡɝl bɹɔt ðə waɪn ən ɪz kɑpɝz ɪn tʃeɪnʒ, hi lɛt ðə pjuɾɝ mʌɡz sɪɾ ən lɪsən tə ði ɛn ə ðə stɔɹi.

He knew Thom had seen him. The old gleeman had nearly stopped the story dead when Mat came in. That was new, too. Few things startled Thom enough for him to let it show, and nothing short of Trollocs had ever made him stop a story in the middle that Mat knew. When the girl brought the wine and his coppers in change, he let the pewter mugs sit and listened to the end of the story.

" 'ɪt wɑz əz wɪv sɛɾ ɪt ʃəd bi,' sɛd kɪŋ mæɾəl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əntæŋɡəl ə fɪʃ fɹəm ɪz lɔŋ bɪɹd." tɑmz vɔɪs simd ɔlmoʊs tə ɛkoʊ ɪnsaɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt hɔl, nɑɾ ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi kɑmən ɹum. hɪz plʌk hɑɹp saʊndəd ðə θɹi kɪŋz' faɪnəl fulɪʃnəs. " 'ɪt wɑz əz wi sɛɾ ɪt wəd bi,' ənaʊnst ɔɹəndɝ. ænd, fit slɪpɪŋ ɪn ðə mʌd, hi sæt daʊn wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt splæʃ. 'ɪt wɑz əz wi sɛɾ ɪt mʌs bi,' pɹoʊkleɪm kæɾɝ əz i sɝtʃt, ʌp tə hɪz ɛlboʊz ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ, fəɹ ɪz kɹaʊn. 'ðə wʊmən noʊz nɑt wɛɹɔf ʃi spiks. ʃiz ðə ful!' mæɾəl ən ɔɹəndɝ əɡɹid wɪð ɪm laʊdli. ən wɪð ðæt, mɑɹə hæd hæɾ ɪnʌf. 'aɪv ɡɪvən əm ɔl ðə tʃænsəz ðeɪ dɪzɝv ən mɔɹ,' ʃi mɝmɝd tə hɝsɛlf. slɪpɪŋ kæɾɝz kɹaʊn ɪndə hɝ bæɡ wɪð ðə fɝs tu, ʃi klaɪm bæk ɑntu hɝ kɑɹt, klʌk tə hɝ mɛɹ, ən dʒɹoʊv stʃɹeɪt bæk tə hɝ vɪlədʒ. ən wən mɑɹə hæd toʊld əm ɔl ðət hæpənd, ðə pipəl ə hip wəɾ əv noʊ kɪŋ əɾ ɔl." hi stʃɹʌm ðə meɪdʒɝ θim ə ðə kɪŋz' fulɪʃnəs wʌns mɔɹ, ðɪs taɪm slaɪɾɪŋ tə ə kɹɪʃɛndoʊ ðət saʊndəɾ ivən mɔɹ laɪk læftɝ, meɪɾ ə swipɪŋ baʊ, ən nɪɹli fɛl ɔf ðə teɪbəl.

" 'It was as we have said it should be,' said King Madel, trying to untangle a fish from his long beard." Thom's voice seemed almost to echo inside a great hall, not an ordinary common room. His plucked harp sounded the three kings' final foolishness. " 'It was as we said it would be,' announced Orander. And, feet slipping in the mud, he sat down with a great splash. 'It was as we said it must be,' proclaimed Kadar as he searched, up to his elbows in the river, for his crown. 'The woman knows not whereof she speaks. She is the fool!' Madel and Orander agreed with him loudly. And with that, Mara had had enough. 'I've given them all the chances they deserve and more,' she murmured to herself. Slipping Kadar's crown into her bag with the first two, she climbed back onto her cart, clucked to her mare, and drove straight back to her village. And when Mara had told them all that happened, the people of Heape would have no king at all." He strummed the major theme of the kings' foolishness once more, this time sliding to a crescendo that sounded even more like laughter, made a sweeping bow, and nearly fell off the table.

mɛn læft ən stæmp ðɛɹ fit, ðoʊ laɪkli ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm hæd hɝd ðə stɔɹi mɛni taɪmz bɪfɔɹ, ən kɔl fəɹ mɔɹ. ðə stɔɹi ʌv mɑɹə wɑz ɔlweɪz wɛl ɹəsivd, ɪksɛpt pɝhæps baɪ kɪŋz.

Men laughed and stamped their feet, though likely every one of them had heard the story many times before, and called for more. The story of Mara was always well received, except perhaps by kings.

tɑm nɪɹli fɛl əɡɛn klaɪmɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə teɪbəl, ən i wɑz mɔɹ ənstɛɾi ɪn ɪz wɔk ðən ə sʌmwʌt stɪf lɛɡ kəɾ əkaʊn fəɹ əz i keɪm tə wɛɹ mæt wɑz sɪɾɪŋ. kæʒəwəli pʊɾɪŋ ɪz hɑɹp ɑn ðə teɪbəl, hi dʒɹɑpt ɑntu ə stul ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə sɛkən mʌɡ ən ɡeɪv mæt ə flæt stɛɹ. hɪz aɪz hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ʃɑɹp əz ɔlz, bʌt ðeɪ sim tə bi hævɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl foʊkəsɪŋ.

Thom nearly fell again climbing down from the table, and he was more unsteady in his walk than a somewhat stiff leg could account for as he came to where Mat was sitting. Casually putting his harp on the table, he dropped onto a stool in front of the second mug and gave Mat a flat stare. His eyes had always been sharp as awls, but they seemed to be having trouble focusing.

"kɑmən," hi mʌɾɝd. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz stɪl dip, bʌɾ ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sim tə ɹɪvɝbɝət. "ðə teɪl ɪz ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz bɛɾɝ ɪn pleɪn tʃænt, ən ə θaʊzən ɪn haɪ, bʌt ðeɪ wɑn kɑmən." wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝd, hi bɛɹiɾ ɪz feɪs ɪn ɪz waɪn.

"Common," he muttered. His voice was still deep, but it no longer seemed to reverberate. "The tale is a hundred times better in Plain Chant, and a thousand in High, but they want Common." Without another word, he buried his face in his wine.

mæt kəd nɑt ɹikɔl ɛvɝ siɪŋ tɑm fɪnɪʃ pleɪɪŋ ðət hɑɹp wɪθaʊɾ ɪmiɾiətli pʊɾɪŋ ɪɾ əweɪ ɪn ɪts hɑɹd lɛðɝ keɪs. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪm ðə wɝs fəɹ dʒɹɪŋk. ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪlif tə hɪɹ ðə ɡlimən kəmpleɪnɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪz lɪsənɝz; tɑm nɛvɝ θɔt ðɛɹ stændɝdz wɝ əz haɪ əz hɪz. ət list sʌmθɪŋ ə hɪm hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd.

Mat could not recall ever seeing Thom finish playing that harp without immediately putting it away in its hard leather case. He had never seen him the worse for drink. It was a relief to hear the gleeman complaining about his listeners; Thom never thought their standards were as high as his. At least something of him had not changed.

ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl wɑz bæk, wɪð noʊ twɪŋkəl ɪn əɹ aɪz. "oʊ, tɑm," ʃi sɛd sɔfli, ðən ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn mæt. "ɪf aɪd noʊn i wɑz ðə fɹɛn jə əweɪɾəd, aɪd nɑɾ əv bɹɔt jə waɪn fəɹ ɪm ɪf jə ɡeɪv ə hʌnʒɹəd sɪlvɝ pɛns."

The serving girl was back, with no twinkle in her eyes. "Oh, Thom," she said softly, then rounded on Mat. "If I'd known he was the friend you awaited, I'd not have brought you wine for him if you gave a hundred silver pence."

"aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ hi wɑz dʒɹʌŋk," mæt pɹətɛstəd.

"I did not know he was drunk," Mat protested.

bʌɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən wɑz bæk ɑn tɑm, hɝ vɔɪs dʒɛntəl əɡɛn. "tɑm, jə nid səm ɹɛst. ðəl kip jə tɛlɪŋ stɔɹiz ɔl naɪɾ ən ɔl deɪ, ɪf jə lɛt ðɛm."

But her attention was back on Thom, her voice gentle again. "Thom, you need some rest. They'll keep you telling stories all night and all day, if you let them."

ənʌðɝ wʊmən əpɪɹɾ ɑn tɑmz ʌðɝ saɪd, lɪftɪŋ əɹ eɪpɹən ɔf oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd. ʃi wɑz oʊldɝ ðən ðə fɝst, bʌt noʊ lɛs pɹɪɾi. ðə tu maɪɾ əv bɪn sɪstɝz. "ə bjuɾəfəl stɔɹi, aɪv ɔlweɪz θɔt, tɑm, ən jə tɛl ɪt bjuɾəfli. kʌm, aɪv slɪpt ə wɔɹmɪŋ pæn ɪndə jəɹ bɛd, ən jə kən tɛl mi ɔl əbaʊt ðə kɔɹɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn."

Another woman appeared on Thom's other side, lifting her apron off over her head. She was older than the first, but no less pretty. The two might have been sisters. "A beautiful story, I've always thought, Thom, and you tell it beautifully. Come, I've slipped a warming pan into your bed, and you can tell me all about the court in Caemlyn."

tɑm pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə mʌɡ əz ɪf sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ɪɾ ɛmpti, ðən blu aʊɾ ɪz lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz ən lʊk fɹəm wʌn wʊmən tə ði ʌðɝ. "pɹɪɾi mɑɾə. pɹɪɾi sɑl. dɪɾ aɪ ɛvɝ tɛl jə ðət tu pɹɪɾi wɪmən əv lʌv mi ɪn maɪ laɪf? ðəɾ ɪz mɔɹ ðən moʊs mɛn kən kleɪm."

Thom peered into the mug as if surprised to find it empty, then blew out his long mustaches and looked from one woman to the other. "Pretty Mada. Pretty Saal. Did I ever tell you that two pretty women have loved me in my life? That is more than most men can claim."

"juv toʊld əs ɔl əbaʊɾ ɪt, tɑm," ði oʊldɝ wʊmən sɛd sædli. ðə jʌŋɡɝ ɡlɛɹɾ ət mæt əz ɪf ðɪs wɝ ɔl ɪz fɔlt.

"You've told us all about it, Thom," the older woman said sadly. The younger glared at Mat as if this were all his fault.

"tu," tɑm mɝmɝd. "mɔɹɡeɪs hæɾ ə tɛmpɝ, bʌɾ aɪ θɔɾ aɪ kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ðæt, soʊ ɪɾ ɛndəd wɪð əɹ wɑntɪŋ tə kɪl mi. dinə, aɪ kɪld. əz ɡʊɾ æz. nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɝəns. tu tʃænsəz aɪv hæd, mɔɹ ðən moʊst, ən aɪ θɹu ðɛm boʊθ əweɪ."

"Two," Thom murmured. "Morgase had a temper, but I thought I could ignore that, so it ended with her wanting to kill me. Dena, I killed. As good as. Not much difference. Two chances I've had, more than most, and I threw them both away."

"aɪ wɪl teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪm," mæt sɛd. mɑɾə ən sɑl wɝ boʊθ ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, naʊ. hi ɡeɪv əm ɪz bɛst smaɪl, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt wɝk. hɪz stʌmək mʌɾɝd laʊdli. "doʊn aɪ smɛl tʃɪkən ɹoʊstɪŋ? bɹɪŋ mi θɹi əɹ fɔɹ." ðə tu wɪmən blɪŋkt ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd stɑɹɾəld lʊks wən i æɾəd, "du jə wɑn sʌmθɪŋ tə it, tu, tɑm?"

"I will take care of him," Mat said. Mada and Saal were both glaring at him, now. He gave them his best smile, but it did not work. His stomach muttered loudly. "Don't I smell chicken roasting? Bring me three or four." The two women blinked and exchanged startled looks when he added, "Do you want something to eat, too, Thom?"

"aɪ kəd də wɪð mɔɹ ə ðɪs faɪn ændɔɝən waɪn." ðə ɡlimən ɹeɪzd ɪz kʌp hoʊpfəli.

"I could do with more of this fine Andoran wine." The gleeman raised his cup hopefully.

"noʊ mɔɹ waɪn fəɹ jə tənaɪt, tɑm." ði oʊldɝ wʊmən wʊɾə teɪkən ɪz kʌp ɪf i hæd lɛt hɝ.

"No more wine for you tonight, Thom." The older woman would have taken his cup if he had let her.

ɔlmoʊst ɑn tɑp ə ðə fɝst wʊmən, ðə jʌŋɡɝ sɛd, ɪn ə mɪkstʃɝ ə fɝmnəs ən pliɾɪŋ, "jul əv səm tʃɪkən, tɑm. ɪts vɛɹi ɡʊd."

Almost on top of the first woman, the younger said, in a mixture of firmness and pleading, "You'll have some chicken, Thom. It is very good."

niðɝ wəd liv əntɪl ðə ɡlimən əɡɹid tə it sʌmθɪŋ, ən wən ðeɪ dɪd ɡoʊ, ðeɪ ɡeɪv mæt sətʃ ə kɑmbəneɪʃən ə stɛɹz ən snɪfs ðəɾ i kəɾ oʊnli ʃeɪk ɪz hɛd. bɝn mi, jə wəd θɪŋk aɪ wɑz ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ ɪm tə dʒɹɪŋk mɔɹ! wɪmən! bʌt pɹɪɾi aɪz ɑn ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm.

Neither would leave until the gleeman agreed to eat something, and when they did go, they gave Mat such a combination of stares and sniffs that he could only shake his head. Burn me, you would think I was encouraging him to drink more! Women! But pretty eyes on the pair of them.

"ɹæn sɛd jə wɝ əlaɪv," hi toʊl tɑm wən mɑɾə ən sɑl wɝ aʊɾ ə hɪɹɪŋ. "mɔɪɹeɪn ɔlweɪz sɛd ʃi θɔt jə wɝ. bʌɾ aɪ hɝd jə wɝ ɪn kɛɹhin, ən minɪŋ tə ɡoʊ ɑn tə tɛɹ."

"Rand said you were alive," he told Thom when Mada and Saal were out of hearing. "Moiraine always said she thought you were. But I heard you were in Cairhien, and meaning to go on to Tear."

"ɹæn ɪz stɪl wɛl, ðɛn?" tɑmz aɪz ʃɑɹpən tə ɔlmoʊs ðə kinnəs mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd. "aɪ æm nɑt ʃʊɹ aɪ ɪkspɛktəd ðæt. mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz stɪl wɪð hɪm, ɪz ʃi? ə faɪn-lʊkɪŋ wʊmən. ə faɪn wʊmən, ɪf ʃi wɝ nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. mɛɾəl wɪð ðət sɔɹt, ən jə ɡɛt mɔɹ ðən jəɹ fɪŋɡɝz bɝnd."

"Rand is still well, then?" Thom's eyes sharpened to almost the keenness Mat remembered. "I am not sure I expected that. Moiraine is still with him, is she? A fine-looking woman. A fine woman, if she were not Aes Sedai. Meddle with that sort, and you get more than your fingers burned."

"waɪ wʊdn jə ɪkspɛkt ɹænd tə bi ɔl ɹaɪt?" mæt æskt kɛɹfəli. "du jə noʊ ʌv sʌmθɪŋ ðət kəd hɑɹm hɪm?"

"Why wouldn't you expect Rand to be all right?" Mat asked carefully. "Do you know of something that could harm him?"

"noʊ? aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ, bɔɪ. aɪ səspɛk mɔɹ ðən ɪz hɛlθi fəɹ mi, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ nʌθɪŋ."

"Know? I don't know anything, boy. I suspect more than is healthy for me, but I know nothing."

mæt əbændən ðət laɪn ə tɔk. noʊ jus fɝmɪŋ ɪz səspɪʃənz. noʊ jus lɛɾɪŋ ɪm noʊ aɪ noʊ mɔɹ ðænz hɛlθi maɪsɛlf.

Mat abandoned that line of talk. No use firming his suspicions. No use letting him know I know more than's healthy myself.

ði oʊldɝ wʊmən - tɑm kɔld əɹ mɑɾə - keɪm bæk wɪð θɹi tʃɪkənz wɪð kɹɪsp, bɹaʊn skɪnz, ɡɪvɪŋ ðə waɪt-hɛɹd mæn ə wɝid lʊk, ən mæt ə wɔɹnɪŋ wʌn, bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɛft. mæt ɹɪpt ɔf ə lɛɡ ən sɛt tə əz i tɔkt. tɑm fɹaʊn ɪndə hɪz kʌp ən nɛvɝ lʊkt ət ðə bɝdz.

The older woman - Thom called her Mada - came back with three chickens with crisp, brown skins, giving the white-haired man a worried look, and Mat a warning one, before she left. Mat ripped off a leg and set to as he talked. Thom frowned into his cup and never looked at the birds.

"waɪ ɑɹ jə hɪɹ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, tɑm? ɪts ðə læs pleɪs aɪɾ əv ɪkspɛktəd tə si ju, ðə weɪ jə fil əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ hɝd jə wɝ kɔɪnɪŋ mʌni ɪn kɛɹhin."

"Why are you here in Tar Valon, Thom? It's the last place I'd have expected to see you, the way you feel about Aes Sedai. I heard you were coining money in Cairhien."

"kɛɹhin," ði oʊld ɡlimən mʌɾɝd, ðə ʃɑɹpnəs feɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪz aɪz əɡɛn. "sʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl ɪt kɑzəz kɪlɪŋ ə mæn, ivən wən i dɪzɝvz kɪlɪŋ." hi meɪɾ ə flɝɪʃ wɪð wʌn hæn ən wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ə naɪf. tɑm ɔlweɪz hæd naɪvz səkɹiɾəd əbaʊt hɪm. dʒɹʌŋk i maɪɾ əv bɪn, bʌɾ i hɛl ðə bleɪd stɛɾi ɪnʌf. "kɪl ə mæn u nidz kɪlɪŋ, ən səmtaɪmz ʌðɝz peɪ fəɹ ɪt. ðə kwɛstʃən ɪz, wɑz ɪt wɝθ duɪŋ ɛniweɪ? ðɛɹz ɔlweɪz ə bæləns, jə noʊ. ɡʊɾ ən ivəl. laɪɾ ən ʃædoʊ. wi wəd nɑt bi hjumən ɪf ðəɹ wɑzn ə bæləns."

"Cairhien," the old gleeman muttered, the sharpness fading from his eyes again. "Such trouble it causes killing a man, even when he deserves killing." He made a flourish with one hand and was holding a knife. Thom always had knives secreted about him. Drunk he might have been, but he held the blade steady enough. "Kill a man who needs killing, and sometimes others pay for it. The question is, was it worth doing anyway? There's always a balance, you know. Good and evil. Light and Shadow. We would not be human if there wasn't a balance."

"pʊt ðəɾ əweɪ," mæt ɡɹaʊld ɝaʊn ə maʊθfʊl. "aɪ doʊnt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊt kɪlɪŋ." laɪt, ðət fɛloʊ ɪz stɪl laɪɪŋ ɹaɪɾ aʊt ðəɹ ɪn ðə stʃɹit. bɝn mi, aɪ ɔt tə bi ɑn ə ʃɪp baɪ naʊ. "aɪ dʒʌst æskt waɪ jəɹ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪf jə hæd tə liv kɛɹhin kəz jə kɪl sʌmwʌn, aɪ də nɑt wɑnə noʊ əbaʊɾ ɪt. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, ɪf jə kæn pʊl jəɹ wɪts aʊɾ ə ðə waɪn ɪnʌf tə tɔk stʃɹeɪt, əl liv naʊ."

"Put that away," Mat growled around a mouthful. "I don't want to talk about killing." Light, that fellow is still lying right out there in the street. Burn me, I ought to be on a ship by now. "I just asked why you're in Tar Valon. If you had to leave Cairhien because you killed someone, I do not want to know about it. Blood and ashes, if you can't pull your wits out of the wine enough to talk straight, I'll leave now."

wɪð ə saʊɝ lʊk, tɑm meɪd ðə naɪf dɪsəpɪɹ. "waɪ æm aɪ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn? aɪm hɪɹ kəz ɪts ðə wɝs pleɪs aɪ kəd bi, ɪksɛp meɪbi keɪɛmlɪn. ɪts wʌɾ aɪ dɪzɝv, bɔɪ. səm ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ stɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ mi. aɪ sɔ ɪleɪɾə ɪn ðə stʃɹit ði ʌðɝ deɪ. ɪf ʃi nu aɪ wɑz hɪɹ, ʃi wəd pil maɪ haɪɾ ɔf ɪn stʃɹɪps, ən ðən ʃi wəd stɑp biɪŋ plɛzənt."

With a sour look, Thom made the knife disappear. "Why am I in Tar Valon? I'm here because it is the worst place I could be, except maybe Caemlyn. It's what I deserve, boy. Some of the Red Ajah still remember me. I saw Elaida in the street the other day. If she knew I was here, she would peel my hide off in strips, and then she would stop being pleasant."

"aɪ nɛvɝ nu jə tə fil sɑɹi fəɹ jɝsɛlf," mæt sɛd dɪsɡʌstɪdli. "du jə min tə dʒɹaʊn jɝsɛlf ɪn waɪn?"

"I never knew you to feel sorry for yourself," Mat said disgustedly. "Do you mean to drown yourself in wine?"

"wʌt dʒju noʊ ʌv ɪt, bɔɪ?" tɑm snɑɹəld. "pʊɾ ə fju jɪɹz ɑn ju, si sʌmθɪŋ ə laɪf, meɪbi lʌv ə wʊmən əɹ tu, ən ðən jəl noʊ. pɝhæps jə wɪl, ɪf juv ðə bɹeɪnz tə lɝn. ɑə! jə wɑnə noʊ waɪ aɪm ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn? waɪ ɑɹ jə ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn? aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ jə ʃɪvɝɪŋ wən jə faʊn aʊt mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə nɪɹli sɔɪl jɝsɛlf ɛvɹi taɪm ɛnibəɾi ivən mɛnʃən ðə paʊɝ. wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ɛvɹi saɪd?"

"What do you know of it, boy?" Thom snarled. "Put a few years on you, see something of life, maybe love a woman or two, and then you'll know. Perhaps you will, if you have the brains to learn. Aaaah! You want to know why I'm in Tar Valon? Why are you in Tar Valon? I remember you shivering when you found out Moiraine was Aes Sedai. You nearly soiled yourself every time anybody even mentioned the Power. What are you doing in Tar Valon, with Aes Sedai on every side?"

"aɪ æm livɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðæts wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ hɪɹ. livɪŋ!" mæt ɡɹɪməst. ðə ɡlimən hæd seɪvd ɪz laɪf, ən meɪbi mɔɹ. eɪ feɪd hæd bɪn ɪnvɑlvd. ðət wɑz waɪ tɑmz ɹaɪt lɛɡ dɪd nɑt wɝk əz wɛl əz ɪt ʃʊd. ðəɹ kəd nɑt bi ɪnʌf waɪn ɑn ə ʃɪp tə kip ɪm ðɪs dʒɹʌŋk. "aɪ æm ɡoʊɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn, tɑm. ɪf jə nid tə ɹɪsk jəɹ ful laɪf fəɹ səm ɹizən, waɪ nɑt kʌm wɪð mi?"

"I am leaving Tar Valon. That's what I am doing here. Leaving!" Mat grimaced. The gleeman had saved his life, and maybe more. A Fade had been involved. That was why Thom's right leg did not work as well as it should. There could not be enough wine on a ship to keep him this drunk. "I am going to Caemlyn, Thom. If you need to risk your fool life for some reason, why not come with me?"

"keɪɛmlɪn?" tɑm sɛd mjuzɪŋli.

"Caemlyn?" Thom said musingly.

"keɪɛmlɪn, tɑm. ɪleɪɾə wɪl laɪkli bi ɡoʊɪŋ bæk ðəɹ sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, soʊ juɾ əv əɹ tə wɝi əbaʊt. ən fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɪf mɔɹɡeɪs pʊts əɹ hænz ɑn ju, jəl wɪʃ ɪleɪɾə hæd ju."

"Caemlyn, Thom. Elaida will likely be going back there sooner or later, so you'd have her to worry about. And from what I remember, if Morgase puts her hands on you, you will wish Elaida had you."

"keɪɛmlɪn. jɛs. keɪɛmlɪn wəd fɪt maɪ mud laɪk ə ɡlʌv." ðə ɡlimən ɡlænst ət ðə tʃɪkən plæɾɝ ən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. "wʌt dɪd jə du, bɔɪ? stʌf əm ʌp jəɹ sliv?" ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛft ə ðə θɹi bɝdz bʌt boʊnz ən kɑɹkəsɪz wɪð oʊnli ə fju stʃɹɪps ə flɛʃ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ.

"Caemlyn. Yes. Caemlyn would fit my mood like a glove." The gleeman glanced at the chicken platter and gave a start. "What did you do, boy? Stuff them up your sleeve?" There was nothing left of the three birds but bones and carcasses with only a few strips of flesh remaining.

"səmtaɪmz aɪ ɡɛt hʌŋɡɹi," mæt mʌɾɝd. ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə lɪk ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. "ɑɹ jə kʌmɪŋ wɪð mi, əɹ nɑt?"

"Sometimes I get hungry," Mat muttered. It was an effort not to lick his fingers. "Are you coming with me, or not?"

"oʊ, əl kʌm, bɔɪ." əz tɑm pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fit, hi dɪd nɑt sim əz ənstɛɾi əz i hæd bɪn. "ju weɪt hɪɹ - ən tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə it ðə teɪbəl - waɪl aɪ ɡɛt maɪ θɪŋz ən seɪ səm ɡʊdbaɪz." hi lɪmpt əweɪ, nɑt stæɡɝɪŋ wʌns.

"Oh, I will come, boy." As Thom pushed himself to his feet, he did not seem as unsteady as he had been. "You wait here - and try not to eat the table - while I get my things and say some goodbyes." He limped away, not staggering once.

mæt dʒɹæŋk ə lɪɾəl ə hɪz waɪn ən stʃɹɪpt ɔf ə fju ʃɹɛdz ðət wɝ lɛft ɑn ðə tʃɪkən kɑɹkəsɪz, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf i hæd taɪm tə ɔɹɾɝ ənʌðɝ, bʌt tɑm wɑz bæk kwɪkli. hɪz hɑɹp ən fluɾ ɪn ðɛɹ dɑɹk lɛðɝ keɪsəz hʌŋ ɑn ɪz bæk wɪð ə taɪd blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl. hi kæɹiɾ ə pleɪn wɔkɪŋ stæf əz tɔl əz i wɑz. ðə tu sɝvɪŋ wɪmən fɑloʊɾ ɑn iðɝ saɪd. mæt dɪsaɪɾɪd ðeɪ wɝ sɪstɝz. aɪdɛntɪkəl bɪɡ bɹaʊn aɪz lʊkt ʌp ət ðə ɡlimən wɪð aɪdɛntɪkəl ɪkspɹɛʃənz. tɑm wɑz kɪsɪŋ fɝst sɑl, ðən mɑɾə, ən pæɾɪŋ tʃiks əz i hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ, dʒɝkɪŋ ɪz hɛd fəɹ mæt tə fɑloʊ. hi wɑz aʊtsaɪd bɪfɔɹ mæt kəd fɪnɪʃ kəlɛktɪŋ ɪz oʊn bɪlɔŋɪŋz ən pɪk ʌp ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf.

Mat drank a little of his wine and stripped off a few shreds that were left on the chicken carcasses, wondering if he had time to order another, but Thom was back quickly. His harp and flute in their dark leather cases hung on his back with a tied blanketroll. He carried a plain walking staff as tall as he was. The two serving women followed on either side. Mat decided they were sisters. Identical big brown eyes looked up at the gleeman with identical expressions. Thom was kissing first Saal, then Mada, and patting cheeks as he headed for the door, jerking his head for Mat to follow. He was outside before Mat could finish collecting his own belongings and pick up his quarterstaff.

ðə jʌŋɡɝ ə ðə tu wɪmən, sɑl, stɑp mæt əz i ɹitʃt ðə dɔɹ. "wʌtɛvɝ jə sɛd tə hɪm, aɪ fɝɡɪv jə fəɹ ðə waɪn, ivən ɪf ɪts teɪkɪŋ ɪm əweɪ. aɪv nɑt sin ɪm ðɪs əlaɪv ɪn wiks." ʃi pɹɛst sʌmθɪŋ ɪndə hɪz hænd, ən wən i ɡlænst əɾ ɪt, hɪz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn kənfjuʒən. ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ə sɪlvɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn mɑɹk. "fɔɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz jə sɛd. bɪsaɪdz, huɛvɝ ɪz fiɾɪŋ jə ɪz nɑt duɪŋ ə ɡʊd dʒɑb ʌv ɪt, bʌt jə stɪl əv pɹɪɾi aɪz." ʃi læft ət ði ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs.

The younger of the two women, Saal, stopped Mat as he reached the door. "Whatever you said to him, I forgive you for the wine, even if it is taking him away. I've not seen him this alive in weeks." She pressed something into his hand, and when he glanced at it, his eyes widened in confusion. She had given him a silver Tar Valon mark. "For whatever it was you said. Besides, whoever is feeding you is not doing a good job of it, but you still have pretty eyes." She laughed at the expression on his face.

mæt wɑz læfɪŋ, tu, ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf, əz i wɛn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stʃɹit, ɹoʊlɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝ kɔɪn əkɹɔs ðə bæks ə hɪz fɪŋɡɝz. soʊ aɪ hæv pɹɪɾi aɪz, də aɪ? hɪz læftɝ ʃʌɾ ɔf laɪk ðə læs dʒɹɪp fɹəm ə waɪn bæɹəl: tɑm wɑz ðɛɹ, bʌt nɑt ðə kɔɹps. ðə wɪndoʊz ə ðə tævɝnz daʊn ðə stʃɹit pʊɾ ɪnʌf laɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz fəɹ ɪm tə bi ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. ðə sɪɾi ɡɑɹd wəd nɑɾ əv kæɹiɾ ə dɛd mæn əweɪ wɪθaʊɾ æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz, ət ðoʊz tævɝnz ən ət ðə wʊmən ə tæntʃəkoʊ, tu.

Mat was laughing, too, in spite of himself, as he went out into the street, rolling the silver coin across the backs of his fingers. So I have pretty eyes, do I? His laughter shut off like the last drip from a wine barrel: Thom was there, but not the corpse. The windows of the taverns down the street put enough light across the cobblestones for him to be sure of it. The city guard would not have carried a dead man away without asking questions, at those taverns and at The Woman of Tanchico, too.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə stɛɹɪŋ æt, bɔɪ?" tɑm æskt. "noʊ tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðoʊz ʃædoʊz."

"What are you staring at, boy?" Thom asked. "No Trollocs in those shadows."

"fʊtpædz," mæt mʌɾɝd. "aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt fʊtpædz."

"Footpads," Mat muttered. "I was thinking about footpads."

"noʊ stʃɹit θivz əɹ stʃɹɔŋ-ɑɹmz ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, iðɝ, bɔɪ. wən ðə ɡɑɹdz teɪk ə fʊtpæd - nɑt ðət mɛni tʃɹaɪ ðət ɡeɪm hɪɹ; ðə wɝd spɹɛdz - bʌt wən ðeɪ du, ðeɪ hɔl ɪm tə ðə taʊɝ, ən wʌtɛvɝ ɪts ði ɛɛs sədaɪ də tə hɪm, ðə fɛloʊ livz tɑɹ vəlɑn ðə nɛks deɪ əz waɪd-aɪɾ əz ə ɡusd ɡɝl. aɪ ʌndɝstæn ðəɹ ivən hɑɹɾɝ ɑn wɪmən kɑt θivɪŋ. noʊ, ði oʊnli weɪ jəl əv jəɹ mʌni stoʊlən hɪɹ ɪz sʌmbɑɾi sɛlɪŋ jə pɑlɪʃt bɹæs fəɹ ɡoʊld əɹ juzɪŋ ʃeɪv daɪs. ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ fʊtpædz."

"No street thieves or strong-arms in Tar Valon, either, boy. When the guards take a footpad - not that many try that game here; the word spreads - but when they do, they haul him to the Tower, and whatever it is the Aes Sedai do to him, the fellow leaves Tar Valon the next day as wide-eyed as a goosed girl. I understand they're even harder on women caught thieving. No, the only way you'll have your money stolen here is somebody selling you polished brass for gold or using shaved dice. There are no footpads."

mæt tɝn ɑn ɪz hil ən stʃɹoʊd pæs tɑm, hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɑks, kɔɹɾɝstæf θʌmpɪŋ ɔf ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz əz ɪf i kəd pʊʃ hɪmsɛlf əhɛd fæstɝ. "wɝ gɑnə bi ɑn ðə fɝst ʃɪp seɪlɪŋ, wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz. ðə fɝst, tɑm."

Mat turned on his heel and strode past Thom, heading toward the docks, quarterstaff thumping off the cobblestones as if he could push himself ahead faster. "We're going to be on the first ship sailing, whatever it is. The first, Thom."

tɑmz stɪk klɪk hɝidli æftɝ hɪm. "sloʊ daʊn, bɔɪ. wʌts jəɹ hɝi? ðəɹ ɑɹ plɛnti ʌv ʃɪps, seɪlɪŋ deɪ ən naɪt. sloʊ daʊn. ðəɹ ɑɹən ɛni fʊtpædz."

Thom's stick clicked hurriedly after him. "Slow down, boy. What's your hurry? There are plenty of ships, sailing day and night. Slow down. There aren't any footpads."

"ðə fɝs blʌɾi ʃɪp, tɑm! ɪf ɪts sɪŋkɪŋ, wɪl bi ɑn ɪt!" ɪf ðeɪ wɝn fʊtpædz, wʌt wɝ ðeɪ? ðeɪ hæd tə bi θivz. wʌɾ ɛls kəd ðeɪ bi?

"The first bloody ship, Thom! If it's sinking, we'll be on it!" If they weren't footpads, what were they? They had to be thieves. What else could they be?


tʃæptɝ θɝɾitu


CHAPTER 32

ðə fɝst ʃɪp


The First Ship

saʊθhɑɹbɝ ɪtsɛlf, ðə ɡɹeɪɾ oʊɡiɝ-meɪd beɪsən, wɑz hjudʒ ən ɹaʊnd, sɝaʊndəd baɪ haɪ wɔlz ə ðə seɪm sɪlvɝ-stʃɹikt waɪt stoʊn əz ðə ɹɛst ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. wʌn lɔŋ wɔɹf, moʊst ʌv ɪt ɹuft, ɹæn ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊnd, ɪksɛpt wɛɹ ðə waɪd wɔɾɝ ɡeɪts stʊɾ oʊpən tə ɡɪv æksɛs tə ðə ɹɪvɝ. vɛsəlz ʌv ɛvɹi saɪz laɪn ðə wɔɹf, moʊs mʊɹd baɪ ðə stɝn, ən dɪspaɪt ði aʊɝ dɑkmən ɪn kɔɹs, slivələs ʃɝts hɝiɾ əbaʊt loʊɾɪŋ ən ənloʊɾɪŋ beɪlz ən tʃɛsts, kɹeɪts ən bæɹəlz, wɪð ɹoʊps ən bumz, əɹ ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. læmps hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɹuf bimz lɪt ðə wɑɹfs ən meɪɾ ə bæn ə laɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə blæk wɔɾɝ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə hɑɹbɝ. smɔl oʊpən boʊts skʌɾəld θɹu ðə dɑɹknəs, ðə skwɛɹ læntɝnz ətɑp ðɛɹ tɔl stɝnpoʊsts meɪkɪŋ ɪt sim əz ɪf faɪɝəfliz skɪɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə hɑɹbɝ. ðeɪ wɝ smɔl oʊnli kəmpɛɹd tə ðə ʃɪps, ðoʊ; səm hæɾ əz mɛni əz sɪks pɛɹz ə lɔŋ ɔɹz.

Southharbor itself, the great Ogier-made basin, was huge and round, surrounded by high walls of the same silver-streaked white stone as the rest of Tar Valon. One long wharf, most of it roofed, ran all the way around, except where the wide water gates stood open to give access to the river. Vessels of every size lined the wharf, most moored by the stern, and despite the hour dockmen in coarse, sleeveless shirts hurried about loading and unloading bales and chests, crates and barrels, with ropes and booms, or on their backs. Lamps hanging from the roof beams lit the wharfs and made a band of light around the black water in the middle of the harbor. Small open boats scuttled through the darkness, the square lanterns atop their tall sternposts making it seem as if fireflies skittered across the harbor. They were small only compared to the ships, though; some had as many as six pairs of long oars.

wən mæt lɛɾ ə stɪl-mʌɾɝɪŋ tɑm ʌndɝ ən ɑɹtʃ ə pɑlɪʃt ɹɛdstoʊn ən daʊn bɹɔd stɛps tə ðə wɔɹf, kɹumɪn ɑn wʌn θɹi-mæstəd ʃɪp wɝ ənfæsənɪŋ ðə mʊɹɪŋ laɪnz nɑt twɛnti peɪsɪz əweɪ. ðə vɛsəl wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ ðən moʊs mæt kəd si, bɪtwin fɪftin ən twɛnti spænz fɹəm ʃɑɹp baʊ tə skwɛɹd stɝn, wɪð ə flæt, ɹeɪl dɛk ɔlmoʊs lɛvəl wɪð ðə wɔɹf. ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ wɑz ðəɾ ɪt wɑz kæstɪŋ ɔf. ðə fɝst ʃɪp ðət seɪlz.

When Mat led a still-muttering Thom under an arch of polished redstone and down broad steps to the wharf, crewmen on one three-masted ship were unfastening the mooring lines not twenty paces away. The vessel was larger than most Mat could see, between fifteen and twenty spans from sharp bow to squared stern, with a flat, railed deck almost level with the wharf. The important thing was that it was casting off. The first ship that sails.

ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn keɪm ʌp ðə wɔɹf: θɹi laɪnz ə hɛmp ɹoʊp soʊn daʊn ðə slivz ə hɪz dɑɹk koʊt mɑɹkt ɪm əz ə dɑkmæstɝ. hɪz waɪd ʃoʊldɝz sədʒɛstəd ðəɾ i maɪɾ əv bɪɡʌn əz ə dɑkmən hɔlɪŋ ɹoʊp ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wɛɹɪŋ ɪt. hi ɡlæns kæʒəwəli ɪn mæts dɝɛkʃən, ən stɑpt, sɝpɹaɪz ɑn ɪz lɛðɝi feɪs.
