"jɔɹ bʌndəlz seɪ wʌt jəɹ plænɪŋ, læd, bʌt jə maɪɾ əz wɛl fɝɡɛɾ ɪt. ðə sɪstɝ ʃoʊd mi ə dʒɹɔɪŋ ə ju. jəl bɔɹd noʊ ʃɪp ɪn saʊθhɑɹbɝ, læd. ɡoʊ bæk ʌp ðoʊz stɛɹz soʊ aɪ doʊn əv tə tɛl ə mæn ɔf tə wɑtʃ ju."

A gray-haired man came up the wharf: three lines of hemp rope sewn down the sleeves of his dark coat marked him as a dockmaster. His wide shoulders suggested that he might have begun as a dockman hauling rope instead of wearing it. He glanced casually in Mat's direction, and stopped, surprise on his leathery face. "Your bundles say what you're planning, lad, but you might as well forget it. The sister showed me a drawing of you. You'll board no ship in Southharbor, lad. Go back up those stairs so I don't have to tell a man off to watch you."

"wʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt . . . ?" tɑm mɝmɝd.

"What under the Light . . . ?" Thom murmured.

"ðæts ɔl tʃeɪnʒd," mæt sɛd fɝmli. ðə ʃɪp wɑz kæstɪŋ ɔf ðə læs mʊɹɪŋ laɪn; ðə fɝl tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ seɪlz stɪl meɪd θɪk, peɪl bʌndəlz ɑn ðə lɔŋ, slæntəd bumz, bʌt mɛn wɝ ɹɛɾiɪŋ ðə swips. hi pʊl ði æmɪɝlɪnz peɪpɝ aʊɾ ə hɪz paʊtʃ ən θɹʌst ɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑkmæstɝz feɪs. "æz jə kən si, ɪm ɑn ðə bɪznəs ə ðə taʊɝ, ət ði ɔɹɾɝ ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hɝsɛlf. ən aɪ hæv tə liv ɑn ðət vɛɹi vɛsəl ðɛɹ."

"That's all changed," Mat said firmly. The ship was casting off the last mooring line; the furled triangular sails still made thick, pale bundles on the long, slanted booms, but men were readying the sweeps. He pulled the Amyrlin's paper out of his pouch and thrust it in the dockmaster's face. "As you can see, I'm on the business of the Tower, at the order of the Amyrlin Seat herself. And I have to leave on that very vessel there."

ðə dɑkmæstɝ ɹɛd ðə wɝdz, ðən ɹɛɾ əm əɡɛn. "aɪ nɛvɝ sɔ sətʃ ə θɪŋ ɪn maɪ laɪf. waɪ wəd ðə taʊɝ seɪ jə kʊdnt ɡoʊ, ðən ɡɪv jə . . . ðæt?"

The dockmaster read the words, then read them again. "I never saw such a thing in my life. Why would the Tower say you couldn't go, then give you . . . that?"

"æsk ði æmɪɝlɪn, ɪf jə wɑnt," mæt toʊld ɪm ɪn ə wɪɹi vɔɪs ðət sɛɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛniwʌn kəd pɑsəbli bi stupəɾ ɪnʌf tə də ðæt, "bʌt ʃɪl əv maɪ haɪd, ən jʊɹz, ɪf aɪ də nɑt seɪl ɑn ðət ʃɪp."

"Ask the Amyrlin, if you want," Mat told him in a weary voice that said he did not think anyone could possibly be stupid enough to do that, "but she'll have my hide, and yours, if I do not sail on that ship."

"jul nɛvɝ meɪk ɪt," ðə dɑkmæstɝ sɛd, bʌɾ i wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi kʌpɪŋ ɪz hænz tə hɪz maʊθ. "əbɔɹd ðə ɡɹeɪ ɡʌl ðɛɹ! stɑp! ðə laɪt bɝn ju, stɑp!"

"You'll never make it," the dockmaster said, but he was already cupping his hands to his mouth. "Aboard the Gray Gull there! Stop! The Light burn you, stop!"

ðə ʃɝtləs fɛloʊ ət ðə tɪlɝ lʊk bæk, ðən spoʊk tə ə tɔl kəmpænjən ɪn ə dɑɹk koʊt wɪð pʌfi slivz. ðə tɔl mæn nɛvɝ tʊk ɪz aɪz ɔf ðə kɹumɪn dʒʌs dɪpɪŋ ðə swips ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ. "ɡɪv weɪ təɡɛðɝ," hi kɔld, ən swipbleɪdz kɝld ʌp fɹɔθ.

The shirtless fellow at the tiller looked back, then spoke to a tall companion in a dark coat with puffy sleeves. The tall man never took his eyes off the crewmen just dipping the sweeps into the water. "Give way together," he called, and sweepblades curled up froth.

"aɪl meɪk ɪt," mæt snæpt. ðə fɝst ʃɪp aɪ sɛd, ən ðə fɝst ʃɪp aɪ mɛnt! "kʌm ɑn, tɑm!"

"I'll make it," Mat snapped. The first ship I said, and the first ship I meant! "Come on, Thom!"

wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ tə si ɪf ðə ɡlimən fɑloʊd, hi ɹæn daʊn ðə wɔɹf, dɑdʒɪŋ ɝaʊn mɛn ən bæɹoʊz stækt wɪð kɑɹɡoʊ. ðə ɡæp bɪtwin ðə ɡɹeɪ ɡʌlz stɝn ən ðə wɔɹf waɪɾənd əz ðə swips bɪt dipɝ. hɛftɪŋ ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf, hi hɝld ɪɾ əhɛɾ ə hɪm təwɔɹd ðə ʃɪp laɪk ə spɪɹ, tʊk wʌn mɔɹ stɛp, ən dʒʌmpt əz hɑɹɾ əz i kʊd.

Without waiting to see if the gleeman followed, he ran down the wharf, dodging around men and barrows stacked with cargo. The gap between the Gray Gull's stern and the wharf widened as the sweeps bit deeper. Hefting his quarterstaff, he hurled it ahead of him toward the ship like a spear, took one more step, and jumped as hard as he could.

ðə dɑɹk wɔɾɝ pæsɪŋ bɪniθ ɪz fit lʊkt aɪsi, bʌɾ ɪn ə hɑɹtbiɾ i hæd klɪɹd ðə ʃɪps ɹeɪl ən wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə dɛk. əz i skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit, hi hɝɾ ə ɡɹʌn ən ə kɝs bɪhaɪn hɪm.

The dark water passing beneath his feet looked icy, but in a heartbeat he had cleared the ship's rail and was rolling across the deck. As he scrambled to his feet, he heard a grunt and a curse behind him.

tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn hɔɪstəd hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɑn ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ kɝs, ən klaɪmd oʊvɝ ɑntu ðə dɛk. "aɪ lɔs maɪ stɪk," hi mʌɾɝd. "aɪl wɑn ənʌðɝ." ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz ɹaɪt lɛɡ, hi pɪɹd daʊn ət ðə stɪl waɪɾənɪŋ stʃɹɪp ʌv wɔɾɝ bɪhaɪn ðə vɛsəl ən ʃɪvɝd. "aɪ hæɾ ə bæθ tədeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi." ðə ʃɝtləs stɪɹsmən stɛɹd waɪd-aɪd fɹəm ɪm tə mæt ən bæk əɡɛn, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə tɪlɝ əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ i kəd juz ɪt tə dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf fɹəm mædmən.

Thom Merrilin hoisted himself up on the railing with another curse, and climbed over onto the deck. "I lost my stick," he muttered. "I'll want another." Rubbing his right leg, he peered down at the still widening strip of water behind the vessel and shivered. "I had a bath today already." The shirtless steersman stared wide-eyed from him to Mat and back again, clutching the tiller as if wondering whether he could use it to defend himself from madmen.

ðə tɔl mæn sim nɪɹli əz stʌnd. hɪz peɪl blu aɪz bʌlʒd, ən ɪz maʊθ wɝk saʊnləsli fəɹ ə moʊmənt. hɪz dɑɹk bɪɹd, kʌt tə ə pɔɪnt, sim tə kwɪvɝ wɪð ɹeɪdʒ, ən ɪz nɛɹoʊ feɪs ɡɹu pɝpəl. "baɪ ðə stoʊn!" hi bɛloʊd faɪnəli. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə minɪŋ ə ðɪs? aɪv noʊ ɹum ɑn ðɪs vɛsəl fəɹ əz mʌtʃ əz ə ʃɪps kæt, ən aɪd nɑt teɪk væɡəbɑnz u lip ɑntu maɪ dɛks ɪf aɪ dɪd. seɪnɝ! vɑsə! hiv ðɪs ɹʌbɪʃ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd!" tu ɪkstʃɹimli lɑɹdʒ mɛn, bɛɹfʊɾ ən stʃɹɪp tə ðə weɪst, stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm kɔɪlɪŋ laɪnz ən stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə stɝn. ðə mɛn ət ðə swips kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ wɝk, bɛndɪŋ tə lɪf ðə bleɪdz, teɪkɪŋ θɹi lɔŋ stɛps əlɔŋ ðə dɛk, ðən stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ən wɔkɪŋ bækwɝdz, hɔlɪŋ ðə ʃɪp əhɛɾ ɑn ðɛɹ bleɪdz.

The tall man seemed nearly as stunned. His pale blue eyes bulged, and his mouth worked soundlessly for a moment. His dark beard, cut to a point, seemed to quiver with rage, and his narrow face grew purple. "By the Stone!" he bellowed finally. "What is the meaning of this? I've no room on this vessel for as much as a ship's cat, and I'd not take vagabonds who leap onto my decks if I did. Sanor! Vasa! Heave this rubbish over the side!" Two extremely large men, barefoot and stripped to the waist, straightened from coiling lines and started toward the stern. The men at the sweeps continued their work, bending to lift the blades, taking three long steps along the deck, then straightening and walking backwards, hauling the ship ahead on their blades.

mæt weɪv ði æmɪɝlɪnz peɪpɝ təwɔɹd ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn - ðə kæptən, hi səpoʊzd - wɪð wʌn hænd, ən fɪʃt ə ɡoʊl kɹaʊn aʊɾ ə hɪz paʊtʃ wɪð ði ʌðɝ, teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ivən ɪn ɪz heɪs ðət ðə fɛloʊ sɔ ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ wɛɹ ðət keɪm fɹʌm. tɔsɪŋ ðə hɛvi kɔɪn tə ðə mæn, hi spoʊk kwɪkli, stɪl weɪvɪŋ ðə peɪpɝ. "fɔɹ ði ɪnkənvinjəns ʌv əɹ bɔɹɾɪŋ əz wi dɪd, kæptən. mɔɹ tə kʌm fəɹ pæsədʒ. ɑn bɪznəs ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. pɝsənəl kəmæn ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ɪmpɛɹəɾɪv wi seɪl ɪmiɾiətli. tə ɑɹɪŋɡəl, ɪn ændɝ. ʌtmoʊst ɝdʒənsi. ðə blɛsɪŋz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɑn ɔl u eɪɾ ʌs; ðə taʊɝz ɹæθ ɑn ɛni hu ɪmpiɾ ʌs."

Mat waved the Amyrlin's paper toward the bearded man - the captain, he supposed - with one hand, and fished a gold crown out of his pouch with the other, taking care even in his haste that the fellow saw there were more where that came from. Tossing the heavy coin to the man, he spoke quickly, still waving the paper. "For the inconvenience of our boarding as we did, Captain. More to come for passage. On business of the White Tower. Personal command of the Amyrlin Seat. Imperative we sail immediately. To Aringill, in Andor. Utmost urgency. The blessings of the White Tower on all who aid us; the Tower's wrath on any who impede us."

sɝɾən ðə mæn hæd sin ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn sil baɪ ðət taɪm - ən lɪɾəl mɔɹ, mæt hoʊpt - hi foʊldəd ðə peɪpɝ əɡɛn ən θɹʌst ɪt bæk aʊɾ ə saɪt. aɪɪŋ ðə tu bɪɡ mɛn ənizəli əz ðeɪ keɪm ʌp ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə kæptən - bɝn mi, ðeɪ boʊθ əv ɑɹmz laɪk pɛɹɪnz! - hi wɪʃt i hæɾ ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf ɪn hænd. hi kəd si ɪt laɪɪŋ wɛɹ ɪt hæd lændəd, fɝðɝ daʊn ðə dɛk. hi tʃɹaɪd tə lʊk ʃʊɹ ən kɑnfəɾənt, ðə sɔɹɾ ə mæn ʌðɝz hæd bɛɾɝ nɑt tʃɹaɪfəl wɪð, ə mæn wɪð ðə paʊɝ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ bɪhaɪn hɪm. ə lɔŋ weɪ bɪhaɪn mi, aɪ hoʊp.

Certain the man had seen the Flame of Tar Valon seal by that time - and little more, Mat hoped - he folded the paper again and thrust it back out of sight. Eyeing the two big men uneasily as they came up on either side of the captain - Burn me, they both have arms like Perrin's! - he wished he had his quarterstaff in hand. He could see it lying where it had landed, further down the deck. He tried to look sure and confident, the sort of man others had better not trifle with, a man with the power of the White Tower behind him. A long way behind me, I hope.

ðə kæptən lʊkt ət mæt daʊtfəli, ən ivən mɔɹ soʊ ət tɑm ɪn ɪz ɡlimənz kloʊk ən nʌn tu stɛɾi əfʊt, bʌɾ i moʊʃən seɪnɝ ən vɑsə tə stɑp wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ. "aɪ wəd nɑɾ æŋɡɝ ðə taʊɝ. bɝn maɪ soʊl, fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ tʃɹeɪd teɪks mi fɹəm tiɹ tə ðɪs dɛn ʌv. . . . aɪ kʌm tu ɔfən tə æŋɡɝ . . . ɛniwʌn." ə taɪt smaɪl əpɪɹɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs. "bʌɾ aɪ spoʊk ðə tʃɹuθ. baɪ ðə stoʊn, aɪ dɪd! sɪks kæbənz aɪ hæv fəɹ pæsənʒɝz, ən ɔl fʊl. jə kən slip ɑn dɛk ən it wɪð ðə kɹu fəɹ ənʌðɝ ɡoʊl kɹaʊn. itʃ."

The captain looked at Mat doubtfully, and even more so at Thom in his gleeman's cloak and none too steady afoot, but he motioned Sanor and Vasa to stop where they were. "I would not anger the Tower. Burn my soul, for the time being the river trade takes me from Tear to this den of. . . . I come too often to anger . . . anyone." A tight smile appeared on his face. "But I spoke the truth. By the Stone, I did! Six cabins I have for passengers, and all full. You can sleep on deck and eat with the crew for another gold crown. Each."

"ðæɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs!" tɑm snæpt. "aɪ doʊn kɛɹ wʌt ðə wɔɹ əz dʌn daʊnɹɪvɝ, ðəɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs!" ðə tu lɑɹdʒ seɪlɝz ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ bɛɹ fit.

"That is ridiculous!" Thom snapped. "I don't care what the war has done downriver, that is ridiculous!" The two large sailors shifted their bare feet.

"ɪɾ ɪz ðə pɹaɪs," ðə kæptən sɛd fɝmli. "aɪ də nɑt wɑnə æŋɡɝ ɛniwʌn, bʌɾ aɪɾ əz sun nɑɾ əv ɛni bɪznəs jə kən bi ɑn əbɔɹd maɪ vɛsəl. laɪk lɛɾɪŋ ə mæn peɪ jə soʊ hi kən koʊt jə wɪð hɑt tɑɹ, mɪksɪŋ ɪn ðət bɪznəs. jə peɪ ðə pɹaɪs, əɹ jə ɡoʊ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hɝsɛlf kən dʒɹaɪ jə ɔf. ən əl kip ðɪs fəɹ ðə tʃɹʌbəl juv ɡɪvən mi, θæŋk ju." hi stʌf ðə ɡoʊl kɹaʊn mæt əz tɔst ɪm ɪndə ə pɑkəɾ ə hɪz pʌfi-sliv koʊt.

"It is the price," the captain said firmly. "I do not want to anger anyone, but I'd as soon not have any business you can be on aboard my vessel. Like letting a man pay you so he can coat you with hot tar, mixing in that business. You pay the price, or you go over the side, and the Amyrlin Seat herself can dry you off. And I'll keep this for the trouble you've given me, thank you." He stuffed the gold crown Mat has tossed him into a pocket of his puffy-sleeved coat.

"haʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ wʌn ə ðə kæbənz?" mæt æskt. "tə aʊɝsɛlvz. jə kən pʊt huɛvɝ ɪz ɪn ɪt naʊ wɪð sʌmwʌn ɛls." hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə slip aʊɾ ɪn ðə koʊl naɪt. ən ɪf jə doʊn oʊvɝwɛlm ə fɛloʊ laɪk ðɪs, hɪl stil jəɹ bɹitʃɪz ən seɪ hiz duɪŋ jə ə feɪvɝ. hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld laʊdli. "ænd wi it wʌt jə it, nɑt wɪð ðə kɹu. ən plɛnti ʌv ɪt!"

"How much for one of the cabins?" Mat asked. "To ourselves. You can put whoever is in it now with someone else." He did not want to sleep out in the cold night. And if you don't overwhelm a fellow like this, he'll steal your breeches and say he is doing you a favor. His stomach rumbled loudly. "And we eat what you eat, not with the crew. And plenty of it!"

"mæt," tɑm sɛd, "ɪm ðə wʌn u ɪz səpoʊz tə bi dʒɹʌŋk hɪɹ." hi tɝn tə ðə kæptən, flɝɪʃɪŋ ɪz pætʃ-kʌvɝd kloʊk əz wɛl əz i kəd wɪð blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl ən ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz hʌŋ əbaʊt hɪm. "æz jə meɪ hæv noʊɾəst, kæptən, aɪm ə ɡlimən." ivən ɪn ði oʊpən ɛɹ, hɪz vɔɪs sʌɾənli sim tə ɛkoʊ. "fɔɹ ðə pɹaɪs ʌv əɹ pæsədʒəz, aɪ wəd bi mɔɹ ðən ɡlæd tə ɛntɝteɪn jəɹ pæsənʒɝz ən jəɹ kɹu - "

"Mat," Thom said, "I'm the one who is supposed to be drunk here." He turned to the captain, flourishing his patch-covered cloak as well as he could with blanketroll and instrument cases hung about him. "As you may have noticed, Captain, I am a gleeman." Even in the open air, his voice suddenly seemed to echo. "For the price of our passages, I would be more than glad to entertain your passengers and your crew - "

"maɪ kɹu ɪz əbɔɹd tə wɝk, ɡlimən, nɑt bi ɛntɝteɪnd." ðə kæptən stʃɹoʊkt ɪz pɔɪntəd bɪɹd; hɪz peɪl aɪz pɹaɪs mæts pleɪn koʊt tə ðə kɑpɝ. "soʊ jə wɑn ə kæbən, də ju?" hi bɑɹkt ə læf. "æn maɪ milz? wɛl, jə kən əv maɪ kæbən ən maɪ milz. fəɹ faɪv ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz fɹəm itʃ ə ju! ændɔɝən weɪt!" ðoʊz wɝ ðə hɛviəst. hi bɪɡæn tə læf soʊ hɑɹɾ ɪz wɝdz keɪm aʊɾ ɪn wizəz. flæŋkɪŋ hɪm, seɪnɝ ən vɑsə ɡɹɪnd waɪd ɡɹɪnz. "fɔɹ tɛn kɹaʊnz, jə kən teɪk maɪ kæbən, ən maɪ milz, ən əl muv ɪn wɪð ðə pæsənʒɝz ən it wɪð ðə kɹu. bɝn maɪ soʊl, aɪ wɪl! baɪ ðə stoʊn, aɪ swɛɹ ɪt! fəɹ tɛn ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz. . . ." læftɝ tʃoʊkt ɔf ɛniθɪŋ ɛls.

"My crew is aboard to work, gleeman, not be entertained." The captain stroked his pointed beard; his pale eyes priced Mat's plain coat to the copper. "So you want a cabin, do you?" He barked a laugh. "And my meals? Well, you can have my cabin and my meals. For five gold crowns from each of you! Andoran weight!" Those were the heaviest. He began to laugh so hard his words came out in wheezes. Flanking him, Sanor and Vasa grinned wide grins. "For ten crowns, you can take my cabin, and my meals, and I'll move in with the passengers and eat with the crew. Burn my soul, I will! By the Stone, I swear it! For ten gold crowns. . . ." Laughter choked off anything else.

hi wɑz stɪl læfɪŋ ən ɡæspɪŋ fəɹ bɹɛθ ən waɪpɪŋ tɪɹz fɹəm ɪz aɪz wən mæt pʊld aʊt wʌn ə hɪz tu pɝsɪz, bʌt læftɝ stɑp baɪ ðə taɪm mæt hæd kaʊntəd faɪv kɹaʊnz ɪndə hɪz hænz. ðə kæptən blɪŋkt ɪn dɪsbɪlif; ðə tu bɪɡ kɹumɪn lʊk pɑliækst.

He was still laughing and gasping for breath and wiping tears from his eyes when Mat pulled out one of his two purses, but laughter stopped by the time Mat had counted five crowns into his hands. The captain blinked in disbelief; the two big crewmen looked poleaxed.

"ændɔɝən weɪt, jə sɛd?" mæt æskt. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə dʒʌdʒ wɪθaʊt skeɪlz, bʌɾ i leɪd sɛvən mɔɹ ɑn ðə paɪl. tu æktʃəli  wɝ ændɔɝən, ən i θɔt ði ʌðɝz meɪɾ ʌp ðə weɪt. kloʊs ɪnʌf, fəɹ ðɪs fɛloʊ. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi æɾəd ənʌðɝ tu ɡoʊl tɛɹən kɹaʊnz. "fɔɹ huɛvɝ jəl bi pʊʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə kæbən ðeɪ peɪd fɔɹ." hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðə pæsənʒɝz wəd si ə kɑpɝ ʌv ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt səmtaɪmz peɪd tə əpɪɹ dʒɛnɝəs. "ənlɛs jə min tə ʃɛɹ wɪð ðɛm? noʊ, ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. ðeɪ ɔt tə hæv sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ hævɪŋ tə kɹaʊɾ ɪn wɪð ʌðɝz. ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ jə tə it wɪð jəɹ kɹu, kæptən. jə ɑɹ wɛlkəm tə ʃɛɹ tɑmz milz ən maɪn ɪn jəɹ kæbən." tɑm stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm əz hɑɹɾ əz ði ʌðɝz dɪd.

"Andoran weight, you said?" Mat asked. It was hard to judge without scales, but he laid seven more on the pile. Two actually were Andoran, and he thought the others made up the weight. Close enough, for this fellow. After a moment, he added another two gold Tairen crowns. "For whoever you'll be pushing out of the cabin they paid for." He did not think the passengers would see a copper of it, but it sometimes paid to appear generous. "Unless you mean to share with them? No, of course not. They ought to have something for having to crowd in with others. There's no need for you to eat with your crew, Captain. You are welcome to share Thom's meals and mine in your cabin." Thom stared at him as hard as the others did.

"ɑɹ jə . . . ?" ðə bɪɹɾəd mænz vɔɪs wɑz ə hɔɹs wɪspɝ. "ɑɹ jə . . . baɪ ɛni tʃæns . . . ə jʌŋ lɔɹɾ ɪn dɪsɡaɪz?"

"Are you . . . ?" The bearded man's voice was a hoarse whisper. "Are you . . . by any chance . . . a young lord in disguise?"

"aɪ æm noʊ lɔɹd." mæt læft. hi hæd ɹizən tə læf. ðə ɡɹeɪ ɡʌl wɑz wɛl aʊɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs ə ðə hɑɹbɝ, naʊ, wɪð ðə wɔɹf ə bæn ə laɪt pɔɪntɪŋ ʌp ðə blæk ɡæp, nɑt fɑɹ əhɛd naʊ, wɛɹ ðə wɔɾɝ ɡeɪts lɛɾ aʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðə swips dʒɹoʊv ðə vɛsəl təwɔɹd ðət ɡæp kwɪkli. mɛn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi swɪŋɪŋ ðə lɔŋ, slæntɪŋ bumz ɝaʊn pɹɪpɛɹətɔɹi tə ənlæʃɪŋ ðə seɪlz. ən wɪð ɡoʊld ɪn ɪz hænz, ðə kæptən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ simd ɹɛɾi tə θɹoʊ ɛniwʌn oʊvɝbɔɹd. "ɪf jə doʊn maɪnd, kæptən, kəd wi si əɹ kæbən? jəɹ kæbən, aɪ min. ɪts leɪt, ən aɪ fəɹ wʌn wɑn ə fju aʊɝz' slip." hɪz stʌmək spoʊk tə hɪm. "æn sʌpɝ!"

"I am no lord." Mat laughed. He had reason to laugh. The Gray Gull was well out into the darkness of the harbor, now, with the wharf a band of light pointing up the black gap, not far ahead now, where the water gates let out onto the river. The sweeps drove the vessel toward that gap quickly. Men were already swinging the long, slanting booms around preparatory to unlashing the sails. And with gold in his hands, the captain no longer seemed ready to throw anyone overboard. "If you don't mind, Captain, could we see our cabin? Your cabin, I mean. It's late, and I for one want a few hours' sleep." His stomach spoke to him. "And supper!"

əz ðə vɛsəl pʊɾ ɪts baʊ ɪndə ðə blæknəs, ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn hɪmsɛlf lɛd ðə weɪ daʊn ə læɾɝ tə ə ʃɔɹt, nɛɹoʊ pæsədʒ laɪnd wɪð dɔɹz sɛt kloʊs təɡɛðɝ. waɪl ðə kæptən klɪɹɾ ɪz θɪŋz fɹəm ɪz kæbən - ɪt ɹæn ðə wɪdθ ə ðə stɝn, wɪð ɪts bɛɾ ən ɔl ʌv ɪts fɝnɪʃɪŋz bɪlt ɪndə ðə wɔlz ɪksɛp tu tʃɛɹz ən ə fju tʃɛsts - ən sɔ ðət mæt ən tɑm wɝ sɛɾəld, mæt lɝn ə ɡɹeɪt dil, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə fæk ðət ðə mæn wəd nɑt bi pʊʃɪŋ ɛni pæsənʒɝz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ kɔɹɾɝz. hi hæd tu mʌtʃ ɹɪspɛk fəɹ ðə kɔɪn ðeɪ hæd peɪd, ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðɛm, tə əlaʊ ðæt. ðə kæptən wəd teɪk ɪz fɝsts kæbən, ən ðəɾ ɔfəsɝ wəd teɪk ðə sɛkənz bɛd, pʊʃɪŋ itʃ loʊɝ mæn daʊn tɪl ðə dɛkmæstɝ wəɾ ɛn slipɪŋ ʌp ɪn ðə baʊ wɪð ðə kɹu.

As the vessel put its bow into the blackness, the bearded man himself led the way down a ladder to a short, narrow passage lined with doors set close together. While the captain cleared his things from his cabin - it ran the width of the stern, with its bed and all of its furnishings built into the walls except two chairs and a few chests - and saw that Mat and Thom were settled, Mat learned a great deal, beginning with the fact that the man would not be pushing any passengers out of their quarters. He had too much respect for the coin they had paid, if not for them, to allow that. The captain would take his first's cabin, and that officer would take the second's bed, pushing each lower man down till the deckmaster would end sleeping up in the bow with the crew.

mæt dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən kəd bi vɛɹi jusfəl, bʌɾ i lɪsən tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðə mæn sɛd. ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz bɛs tə noʊ nɑɾ oʊnli wɛɹ jə wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ, bʌɾ u jə wɝ dilɪŋ wɪð, əɹ ðeɪ maɪt dʒʌs teɪk jəɹ koʊɾ ən buts ən liv jə tə wɔk hoʊm θɹu ðə ɹeɪn ɪn bɛɹ fit.

Mat did not think that information could be very useful, but he listened to everything the man said. It was always best to know not only where you were going, but who you were dealing with, or they might just take your coat and boots and leave you to walk home through the rain in bare feet.

ðə kæptən wɑz ə tɛɹən neɪm hwɑn mɑliə, ən i spoʊk wɪð ɡɹeɪt voʊlubɪlɪɾi wʌns i hæd wɝkt aʊt mæt ən tɑm tə hɪz oʊn sæɾəsfækʃən. hi wɑz nɑt nɑbli bɔɹn, hi sɛd, nɑt hɪm, bʌɾ i wəd nɑɾ əv ɛniwʌn θɪŋk i wɑz ə ful. ə jʌŋ mæn wɪð mɔɹ ɡoʊl ðən ɛni jʌŋ mæn ʃəɾ əv baɪ ɹaɪt maɪt bi ə θif, ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn dɪd nɑt noʊ θivz nɛvɝ ɪskeɪp tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪð ðɛɹ hɔl. ə jʌŋ mæn dʒɹɛs laɪk ə fɑɹmbɔɪ bʌt wɪð ði ɛɹ ən kɑnfəɾəns ə ðə lɔɹɾ i dɪnaɪd biɪŋ - "baɪ ðə stoʊn, əl nɑt seɪ jə ɑɹ, ɪf jə seɪ jə ɑɹ nɑt." mɑliə wɪŋkt ən tʃʌkəld ən tʌɡd ðə pɔɪn ə hɪz bɪɹd. ə jʌŋ mæn kæɹiɪŋ ə peɪpɝ bɛɹɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn sits sil ən baʊn fəɹ ændɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sikɹət ðət kwin mɔɹɡeɪs hæd vɪzəɾəd tɑɹ vəlɑn, ðoʊ hɝ ɹizən sɝɾənli wɑz. ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs tə mɑliə sʌmθɪŋ wɑz əfʊt bɪtwin keɪɛmlɪn ən tɑɹ vəlɑn. ən mæt ən tɑm wɝ mɛsənʒɝz - fəɹ mɔɹɡeɪs, hi θɔt, baɪ mæts æksɛnt. ɛniθɪŋ i kəd də tə hɛlp ɪn soʊ ɡɹeɪɾ ən ɛntɝpɹaɪz wəd bi hɪz plɛʒɝ, nɑt ðəɾ i mɛn tə poʊk wɛɹ i wɑz nɑt wɑntəd.

The captain was a Tairen named Huan Mallia, and he spoke with great volubility once he had worked out Mat and Thom to his own satisfaction. He was not nobly born, he said, not him, but he would not have anyone think he was a fool. A young man with more gold than any young man should have by right might be a thief, if everyone did not know thieves never escaped Tar Valon with their haul. A young man dressed like a farmboy but with the air and confidence of the lord he denied being - "By the Stone, I'll not say you are, if you say you are not." Mallia winked and chuckled and tugged the point of his beard. A young man carrying a paper bearing the Amyrlin Seat's seal and bound for Andor. There was no secret that Queen Morgase had visited Tar Valon, though her reason certainly was. It was obvious to Mallia something was afoot between Caemlyn and Tar Valon. And Mat and Thom were messengers - for Morgase, he thought, by Mat's accent. Anything he could do to help in so great an enterprise would be his pleasure, not that he meant to poke where he was not wanted.

mæt ɪkstʃeɪnʒd stɑɹɾəld lʊks wɪð tɑm, hu wɑz stoʊɪŋ ɪz ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz ʌndɝ ə teɪbəl bɪlt aʊt fɹəm wʌn wɔl. ðə ɹum hæd tu smɔl wɪndoʊz ɑn iðɝ saɪd, ən ə pɛɹ ə læmps ɪn dʒɔɪntəd bɹækəts fəɹ laɪt. "ðæts nɑnsɛns," mæt sɛd.

Mat exchanged startled looks with Thom, who was stowing his instrument cases under a table built out from one wall. The room had two small windows on either side, and a pair of lamps in jointed brackets for light. "That's nonsense," Mat said.

"ʌv kɔɹs," mɑliə ɹɪplaɪd. hi stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm pʊlɪŋ kloʊðz aʊɾ ʌv ə tʃɛst ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɛɾ ən smaɪld. "ʌv kɔɹs." ə kʌbɝɾ ɪn ðə wɔl sim tə hoʊl tʃɑɹts ə ðə ɹɪvɝ i wəd nid. "aɪl seɪ noʊ mɔɹ."

"Of course," Mallia replied. He straightened from pulling clothes out of a chest at the foot of the bed and smiled. "Of course." A cupboard in the wall seemed to hold charts of the river he would need. "I'll say no more."

bʌɾ i dɪd min tə poʊk, ðoʊ hi ətɛmptəd tə dɪsɡaɪz ɪt, ən i ɹæmbəld waɪl i tʃɹaɪd tə pɹaɪ. mæt lɪsənd, ən ænsɝd ðə kwɛstʃənz wɪð ɡɹʌns əɹ ʃɹʌɡz əɹ ə wɝɾ əɹ tu, waɪl tɑm sɛd lɛs ðən ðæt. ðə ɡlimən kɛpt ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd waɪl ənbɝɾənɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ə hɪz pəzɛʃənz.

But he did mean to poke, though he attempted to disguise it, and he rambled while he tried to pry. Mat listened, and answered the questions with grunts or shrugs or a word or two, while Thom said less than that. The gleeman kept shaking his head while unburdening himself of his possessions.

mɑliə hæd bɪn ə ɹɪvɝ mæn ɔl ɪz laɪf, ðoʊ hi dʒɹimd ə seɪlɪŋ ɑn ðə si. hi hɑɹdli spoʊk ʌv ə kʌntʃɹi bɪsaɪd tiɹ wɪθaʊt kəntɛmpt; ændɝ wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn tə ɪskeɪp, ən ðə pɹeɪz i faɪnəli mænədʒd wɑz ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ɑbviəs ɛfɝts. "ɡʊd hɔɹsəz ɪn ændɝ, aɪv hɝd. nɑt bæd. nɑɾ əz ɡʊɾ əz tɛɹən stɑk, bʌt ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf. jə meɪk ɡʊd stil, ən aɪɝn ɡʊdz, bɹɑnz ən kɑpɝ - aɪv tʃɹeɪɾɪd fəɹ əm ɔfən ɪnʌf, ðoʊ jə tʃɑɹdʒ ə weɪɾi pɹaɪs - bʌt ðən juv ðoʊz maɪnz ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. ɡoʊl maɪnz, tu. wɪv tə ɝn əɹ ɡoʊld, ɪn tiɹ."

Mallia had been a river man all his life, though he dreamed of sailing on the sea. He hardly spoke of a country beside Tear without contempt; Andor was the only one to escape, and the praise he finally managed was grudging despite his obvious efforts. "Good horses in Andor, I've heard. Not bad. Not as good as Tairen stock, but good enough. You make good steel, and iron goods, bronze and copper - I've traded for them often enough, though you charge a weighty price - but then you have those mines in the Mountains of Mist. Gold mines, too. We have to earn our gold, in Tear."

min ɹəsivd ɪz ɡɹeɪɾəst kəntɛmpt. "ivən lɛs ə kʌntʃɹi ðən mʊɹændi ɪz. wʌn sɪɾi ən ə fju liɡz ə lænd. ðeɪ ʌndɝpɹaɪs ði ɔɪl fɹəm əɹ ɡʊd tɛɹən ɑlɪvz dʒʌs kəz ðɛɹ ʃɪps noʊ haʊ tə faɪn ði ɔɪlfɪʃ ʃoʊlz. ðeɪv noʊ ɹaɪt tə bi ə kʌntʃɹi əɾ ɔl."

Mayene received his greatest contempt. "Even less a country than Murandy is. One city and a few leagues of land. They underprice the oil from our good Tairen olives just because their ships know how to find the oilfish shoals. They've no right to be a country at all."

hi heɪɾəd ɪljən. "wʌn deɪ wɪl luɾ ɪljən bɛɹ, tiɹ daʊn ɛvɹi taʊn ən vɪlədʒ, ən saʊ ðɛɹ fɪlθi ɡɹaʊnd wɪð sɔlt." mɑliəz bɪɹɾ ɔlmoʊs bɹɪsəld wɪð aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ ət haʊ fɪlθi ði ɪljən lænd wɑz. "ivən ðɛɹ ɑlɪvz ɑɹ pjutʃɹɪd! wʌn deɪ wɪl kæɹi ɛvɹi læst ɪliɑnɝ pɪɡ ɔf ɪn tʃeɪnz! ðəɾ ɪz wʌt ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən sɛz."

He hated Illian. "One day we'll loot Illian bare, tear down every town and village, and sow their filthy ground with salt." Mallia's beard almost bristled with outrage at how filthy the Illian land was. "Even their olives are putrid! One day we'll carry every last Illianer pig off in chains! That is what the High Lord Samon says."

mæt wʌndɝd wʌt ðə mæn θɔt tiɹ wəd də wɪð ɔl ðoʊz pipəl ɪf ðeɪ æktʃəli  fʊlfɪl ðɪs skim. ði ɪliɑnɝz wəɾ əv tə bi fɛd, ən ðeɪ wəd ʃʊɹli də noʊ wɝk ɪn tʃeɪnz. ɪt meɪd noʊ sɛns tə hɪm, bʌt mɑliəz aɪz ʃoʊn wən i spoʊk ʌv ɪt.

Mat wondered what the man thought Tear would do with all those people if they actually fulfilled this scheme. The Illianers would have to be fed, and they would surely do no work in chains. It made no sense to him, but Mallia's eyes shone when he spoke of it.

oʊnli fulz lɛt ðɛmsɛlvz bi ɹul baɪ ə kɪŋ əɹ ə kwin, baɪ wʌn mæn əɹ wʊmən. "ɪksɛp kwin mɔɹɡeɪs, ʌv kɔɹs," hi pʊɾ ɪn heɪstəli. "ʃi ɪz ə faɪn wʊmən, soʊ aɪv hɝd. bjuɾəfəl, aɪm toʊld." ɔl ðoʊz fulz boʊɪŋ tə wʌn ful. ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ɹul tɛɹ təɡɛðɝ, ɹitʃɪŋ dɪsɪʒənz ɪn kɑnsɝt, ən ðət wɑz haʊ θɪŋz ʃəd bi. ðə haɪ lɔɹdz nu wʌt wɑz ɹaɪɾ ən ɡʊɾ ən tʃɹu. ɪspɛʃli ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən. noʊ mæn kəd ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ oʊbeɪɪŋ ðə haɪ lɔɹdz. ɪspɛʃli ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən.

Only fools let themselves be ruled by a king or a queen, by one man or woman. "Except Queen Morgase, of course," he put in hastily. "She is a fine woman, so I've heard. Beautiful, I'm told." All those fools bowing to one fool. The High Lords ruled Tear together, reaching decisions in concert, and that was how things should be. The High Lords knew what was right and good and true. Especially the High Lord Samon. No man could go wrong obeying the High Lords. Especially the High Lord Samon.

bɪɑn kɪŋz ən kwinz, bɪɑn ivən ɪljən, leɪ ə bɪɡɝ heɪtʃɹəd mɑliə ətɛmptəd tə kip hɪɾən, bʌɾ i tɔk soʊ mʌtʃ ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn aʊt wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ʌp tə, ən ɡɹu soʊ kæɹiɾ əweɪ baɪ ðə saʊn ə hɪz oʊn vɔɪs, ðəɾ i lɛt mɔɹ slɪp ðən i ɪntɛndəd.

Beyond kings and queens, beyond even Illian, lay a bigger hatred Mallia attempted to keep hidden, but he talked so much in trying to find out what they were up to, and grew so carried away by the sound of his own voice, that he let more slip than he intended.

ðeɪ mʌs tʃɹævəl ə ɡɹeɪt dil, sɝvɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt kwin laɪk mɔɹɡeɪs. ðeɪ mʌst əv sin mɛni lænz. hi dʒɹimd ə ðə si kəz ðən i kəd si lænz i hæɾ oʊnli hɝɾ ʌv, kəz ðən i kəd faɪn ðə minɝ ɔɪlfɪʃ ʃoʊlz, kəɾ aʊt-tʃɹeɪd ðə si foʊk ən ðə fɪlθi ɪliɑnɝz. ən ðə si wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðeɪ mʌst ʌndɝstæn ðæt, fɔɹst əz ðeɪ wɝ tə tʃɹævəl əmʌŋ ɑd pleɪsəz ən pipəl, pleɪsəz ən pipəl ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv stʌmɑtʃt ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt sɝvɪŋ kwin mɔɹɡeɪs.

They must travel a great deal, serving a great Queen like Morgase. They must have seen many lands. He dreamed of the sea because then he could see lands he had only heard of, because then he could find the Mayener oilfish shoals, could out-trade the Sea Folk and the filthy Illianers. And the sea was far from Tar Valon. They must understand that, forced as they were to travel among odd places and people, places and people they could not have stomached if they were not serving Queen Morgase.

"aɪ nɛvɝ laɪk dɑkɪŋ ðɛɹ, nɛvɝ noʊɪŋ u maɪt bi juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ." hi ɔlmoʊst spæt ðə læst wɝd. sɪns i hæd hɝd ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən spik, ðoʊ. . . . "bɝn maɪ soʊl, ɪt meɪks mi fil laɪk hʌlwɝmz ɑɹ bɝoʊɪŋ ɪndə maɪ bɛli dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ ət ðɛɹ waɪt taʊɝ, naʊ, noʊɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ plæn."

"I never liked docking there, never knowing who might be using the Power." He almost spat the last word. Since he had heard the High Lord Samon speak, though. . . . "Burn my soul, it makes me feel like hullworms are burrowing into my belly just looking at their White Tower, now, knowing what they plan."

ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən sɛd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ mɛn tə ɹul ðə wɝld. sɑmən sɛd ðeɪ mɛn tə kɹʌʃ ɛvɹi neɪʃən, pʊt ðɛɹ fʊɾ ɑn ɛvɹi mænz θɹoʊt. sɑmən sɛd tiɹ kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hoʊl ðə paʊɝ aʊɾ ʌv ɪts oʊn lænz ən bɪliv ðət wɑz ɪnʌf. sɑmən sɛd tiɹ hæɾ ɪts ɹaɪtfəl deɪ ʌv ɡlɔɹi kʌmɪŋ, bʌt tɑɹ vəlɑn stʊd bɪtwin tiɹ ən ɡlɔɹi.

The High Lord Samon said the Aes Sedai meant to rule the world. Samon said they meant to crush every nation, put their foot on every man's throat. Samon said Tear could no longer hold the Power out of its own lands and believe that was enough. Samon said Tear had its rightful day of glory coming, but Tar Valon stood between Tear and glory.

"ðɛɹz noʊ hoʊp fəɹ ɪt. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðəl əv tə bi hʌntəd daʊn ən kɪld, ɛvɹi læst ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən sɛz ði ʌðɝz maɪt bi seɪvd - ðə jʌŋ wʌnz, ðə nɑvəsɪz, ði æksɛptɪd - ɪf ðəɹ bɹɔt tə ðə stoʊn, bʌt ðə ɹɛs mʌs bi ɪɹæɾəkeɪtɪd. ðæts wʌt ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən sɛz. ðə waɪt taʊɝ mʌs bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd."

"There's no hope for it. Sooner or later they will have to be hunted down and killed, every last Aes Sedai. The High Lord Samon says the others might be saved - the young ones, the novices, the Accepted - if they're brought to the Stone, but the rest must be eradicated. That's what the High Lord Samon says. The White Tower must be destroyed."

fəɹ ə moʊmən mɑliə stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɪz kæbən, ɑɹmz fʊl ə kloʊðz ən bʊks ən ɹoʊl tʃɑɹts, hɛɹ ɔlmoʊs bɹʌʃɪŋ ðə dɛk bimz oʊvɝhɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ wɪð peɪl blu aɪz waɪl ðə waɪt taʊɝ tʌmbəld ɪndə ɹuən. ðən i ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əz ɪf ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌɾ i hæd dʒʌst sɛd. hɪz pɔɪntəd bɪɹd wæɡəld ənsɝteɪnli.

For a moment Mallia stood in the middle of his cabin, arms full of clothes and books and rolled charts, hair almost brushing the deck beams overhead, staring at nothing with pale blue eyes while the White Tower tumbled into ruin. Then he gave a start as if realizing what he had just said. His pointed beard waggled uncertainly.

"ðæɾ ɪz . . . ðæts wʌɾ i sɛz. aɪ . . . aɪ θɪŋk ðət meɪ bi ɡoʊɪŋ tu fɑɹ, maɪsɛlf. ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən. . . . hi spiks soʊ ðəɾ i kæɹiz ə mæn bɪɑn ɪz oʊn bɪlifs. ɪf keɪɛmlɪn kən meɪk kʌvənəns wɪð ðə taʊɝ, waɪ, soʊ kən tɛɹ." hi ʃɪvɝɾ ən dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊ ɪt. "ðæɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪ seɪ."

"That is . . . that's what he says. I . . . I think that may be going too far, myself. The High Lord Samon. . . . He speaks so that he carries a man beyond his own beliefs. If Caemlyn can make covenants with the Tower, why, so can Tear." He shivered and did not seem to know it. "That is what I say."

"æz jə seɪ," mæt toʊl hɪm, ən fɛl mɪstʃəf bʌbəl ɪnsaɪd. "aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ sədʒɛstʃən ɪz ðə ɹaɪt wʌn, kæptən. bʌt doʊn stɑp wɪð ə fju æksɛptɪd, ðoʊ. æsk ə dʌzən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə kʌm, əɹ tu. θɪŋk wʌt ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ wəd bi laɪk wɪð tu dʌzən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ɪt."

"As you say," Mat told him, and felt mischief bubble inside. "I think your suggestion is the right one, Captain. But don't stop with a few Accepted, though. Ask a dozen Aes Sedai to come, or two. Think what the Stone of Tear would be like with two dozen Aes Sedai in it."

mɑliə ʃʌɾɝəd. "aɪ wɪl sɛn ə mæn fəɹ maɪ mʌni tʃɛst," hi sɛd stɪfli, ən stɔkt aʊt.

Mallia shuddered. "I will send a man for my money chest," he said stiffly, and stalked out.

mæt fɹaʊn ət ðə kloʊz dɔɹ. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ ʃʊdn əv sɛd ðæt."

Mat frowned at the closed door. "I think I shouldn't have said that."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ jə maɪt θɪŋk ðæt," tɑm sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "nɛks jə kəd tʃɹaɪ tɛlɪŋ ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə waɪtkloʊks i ʃəd mɛɹi ði æmɪɝlɪn sit." hɪz bɹaʊz dʒɹu daʊn, laɪk waɪt kæɾəpɪlɝz. "haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən. aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛni haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən."

"I don't know why you might think that," Thom said dryly. "Next you could try telling the Lord Captain Commander of the Whitecloaks he should marry the Amyrlin Seat." His brows drew down, like white caterpillars. "High Lord Samon. I never heard of any High Lord Samon."

ɪt wɑz mæts tɝn tə bi dʒɹaɪ. "wɛl, ivən jə kænɑt noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɔl ðə kɪŋz ən kwinz ən noʊbəlz ðəɹ ɑɹ, tɑm. wʌn əɹ tu maɪt dʒʌst əv ɪskeɪp jəɹ noʊɾəs."

It was Mat's turn to be dry. "Well, even you cannot know everything about all the kings and queens and nobles there are, Thom. One or two might just have escaped your notice."

"aɪ noʊ ðə neɪmz ə ðə kɪŋz ən kwinz, bɔɪ, ən ðə neɪmz ʌv ɔl ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ə tɛɹ, tu. aɪ səpoʊz ðeɪ cʊɾə ɹeɪzd ə lɔɹɾ ə ðə lænd, bʌɾ aɪd θɪŋk aɪ wəɾ əv hɝɾ ə ði oʊl haɪ lɔɹd daɪɪŋ. ɪf jə hæd sɛɾəld fəɹ buɾɪŋ səm pʊɹ fɛloʊz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ kæbən ɪnstɛɾ ə teɪkɪŋ ðə kæptənz, wiɾ itʃ əv ə bɛd tə aʊɝsɛlvz, nɛɹoʊ ən hɑɹɾ əz ɪt maɪt bi. naʊ wɪv tə ʃɛɹ mɑliəz. aɪ hoʊp jə doʊn snɔɹ, bɔɪ. aɪ kænɑɾ əbaɪd snɔɹɪŋ."

"I know the names of the kings and queens, boy, and the names of all the High Lords of Tear, too. I suppose they could have raised a Lord of the Land, but I'd think I would have heard of the old High Lord dying. If you had settled for booting some poor fellows out of their cabin instead of taking the captain's, we'd each have a bed to ourselves, narrow and hard as it might be. Now we have to share Mallia's. I hope you don't snore, boy. I cannot abide snoring."

mæt ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ. əz i ɹɪkɔld, tɑm hæɾ ə snɔɹ laɪk ə wʊd-ɹæsp wɝkɪŋ ɑn ən oʊk nɑt. hi hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðæt.

Mat ground his teeth. As he recalled, Thom had a snore like a wood-rasp working on an oak knot. He had forgotten that.

ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə tu lɑɹdʒ mɛn - seɪnɝ əɹ vɑsə; hi dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ɪz neɪm - hu keɪm tə pʊl ðə kæptənz aɪɝn-baʊn mʌni tʃɛs fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə bɛd. hi nɛvɝ sɛɾ ə wɝd, oʊnli meɪd skɛtʃi baʊz, ən fɹaʊn əɾ əm wən i θɔt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt lʊkɪŋ, ən lɛft.

It was one of the two large men - Sanor or Vasa; he did not give his name - who came to pull the captain's iron-bound money chest from under the bed. He never said a word, only made sketchy bows, and frowned at them when he thought they were not looking, and left.

mæt wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wʌndɝ ɪf ðə lʌk ðət hæd bɪn wɪð ɪm ɔl naɪt hæd dɪzɝɾɪd ɪm ət læst. hi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð tɑmz snɔɹɪŋ, ən tʃɹuθ tə tɛl, ɪt maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn ðə bɛs lʌk ɪn ðə wɝl tə dʒʌmp ɑntu ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ ʃɪp weɪvɪŋ ə peɪpɝ saɪn baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ən sild wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɑn ɪmpəls i pʊld aʊt wʌn ə hɪz səlɪnʒɹɪkəl lɛðɝ daɪs kʌps, pɑpt ɔf ðə taɪt-fɪɾɪŋ lɪd, ən ʌpɛndəd ðə daɪs ɑntu ðə teɪbəl.

Mat was beginning to wonder if the luck that had been with him all night had deserted him at last. He was going to have to put up with Thom's snoring, and truth to tell, it might not have been the best luck in the world to jump onto this particular ship waving a paper signed by the Amyrlin Seat and sealed with the Flame of Tar Valon. On impulse he pulled out one of his cylindrical leather dice cups, popped off the tight-fitting lid, and upended the dice onto the table.

ðeɪ wɝ spɑɾəd daɪs, ən faɪv sɪŋɡəl pɪps stɛɹɾ ʌp ət hɪm. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz, ðət wɑz kɔld ɪn səm ɡeɪmz. ɪt wɑz ə luzɪŋ tɔs ɪn ðoʊz, ə wɪnɪŋ ɪn ʌðɝ ɡeɪmz. bʌt wʌt ɡeɪm æm aɪ pleɪɪŋ? hi skup ðə daɪs ʌp, tɔst əm əɡɛn. faɪv pɪps. ənʌðɝ tɔs, ən əɡɛn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz wɪŋkt ət hɪm.

They were spotted dice, and five single pips stared up at him. The Dark One's Eyes, that was called in some games. It was a losing toss in those, a winning in other games. But what game am I playing? He scooped the dice up, tossed them again. Five pips. Another toss, and again the Dark One's Eyes winked at him.

"ɪf jə juz ðoʊz daɪs tə wɪn ɔl ðət ɡoʊld," tɑm sɛd kwaɪətli, "noʊ wʌndɝ jə hæd tə liv baɪ ðə fɝst ʃɪp seɪlɪŋ." hi hæd stʃɹɪp daʊn tə hɪz ʃɝt, ən hæd ðət hæf oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd wən i spoʊk. hɪz niz wɝ nɑbi ən ɪz lɛɡz simd ɔl sɪnu ən stʃɹɪŋi mʌsəl, ðə ɹaɪɾ ə lɪɾəl ʃɹʌŋkən. "bɔɪ, ə twɛlv-jɪɹ-oʊld ɡɝl wəd kʌt jəɹ hɑɹɾ aʊɾ ɪf ʃi nu jə wɝ juzɪŋ daɪs laɪk ðəɾ əɡɛns hɝ."

"If you used those dice to win all that gold," Thom said quietly, "no wonder you had to leave by the first ship sailing." He had stripped down to his shirt, and had that half over his head when he spoke. His knees were knobby and his legs seemed all sinew and stringy muscle, the right a little shrunken. "Boy, a twelve-year-old girl would cut your heart out if she knew you were using dice like that against her."

"ɪɾ ɪzən ðə daɪs," mæt mʌɾɝd. "ɪts ðə lʌk." ɛɛs sədaɪ lʌk? əɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz lʌk? hi pʊʃt ðə daɪs bæk ɪndə ðə kʌp ən kæpt ɪt.

"It isn't the dice," Mat muttered. "It's the luck." Aes Sedai luck? Or the Dark One's luck? He pushed the dice back into the cup and capped it.

"aɪ səpoʊz," tɑm sɛd, klaɪmɪŋ ɪndə ðə bɛd, "ju ɑɹən gɑnə tɛl mi wɛɹ ɔl ðət ɡoʊl keɪm fɹʌm, ðɛn."

"I suppose," Thom said, climbing into the bed, "you aren't going to tell me where all that gold came from, then."

"aɪ wʌn ɪt. tənaɪt. wɪð ðɛɹ daɪs."

"I won it. Tonight. With their dice."

"ʌ-hʌ. ən aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ nɑt gɑnə ɪkspleɪn ðət peɪpɝ jə wɝ weɪvɪŋ ɝaʊnd - aɪ sɔ ðə sil, bɔɪ! - əɹ ɔl ðət tɔk əbaʊt waɪt taʊɝ bɪznəs, əɹ waɪ ðə dɑkmæstɝ hæd jəɹ dɪskɹɪpʃən fɹəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, iðɝ."

"Uh-huh. And I suppose you're not going to explain that paper you were waving around - I saw the seal, boy! - or all that talk about White Tower business, or why the dockmaster had your description from an Aes Sedai, either."

"aɪ æm kæɹiɪŋ ə lɛɾɝ tə mɔɹɡeɪs fəɹ ɪleɪn, tɑm," mæt sɛɾ ə ɡʊd dil mɔɹ peɪʃənli ðən i fɛlt. "nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv mi ðə peɪpɝ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ ʃi ɡɑɾ ɪt."

"I am carrying a letter to Morgase for Elayne, Thom," Mat said a good deal more patiently than he felt. "Nynaeve gave me the paper. I don't know where she got it."

"wɛl, ɪf jə ɑɹ nɑt gɑnə tɛl mi, aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə slip. bloʊ aʊt ðə læmps, wɪl ju?" tɑm ɹoʊld ɑn ɪz saɪɾ ən pʊld ə pɪloʊ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd.

"Well, if you are not going to tell me, I am going to sleep. Blow out the lamps, will you?" Thom rolled on his side and pulled a pillow over his head.

ivən æftɝ mæt hæd stʃɹɪpt ɔf daʊn tə hɪz smɔlkloʊðz ən kɹɔld ʌndɝ ðə blæŋkəts - æftɝ bloʊɪŋ aʊt ðə læmps - hi kəd nɑt slip, ðoʊ mɑliə hæd dʌn wɛl baɪ hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə ɡʊd fɛðɝ mætʃɹəs. hi hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt tɑmz snɔɹɪŋ, ən ðət pɪloʊ mʌfəl nʌθɪŋ. ɪt saʊndəɾ əz ɪf tɑm wɝ kʌɾɪŋ wʊd kɹɔs-ɡɹeɪn wɪð ə ɹʌsti sɔ. ən i kəd nɑt stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ. haʊ hæd nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin, ən ɪleɪn, ɡɑɾən ðət peɪpɝ fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn? ðeɪ hæd tə bi ɪnvɑlvd wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hɝsɛlf - ɪn səm plɑt, wʌn ə ðoʊz waɪt taʊɝ mækəneɪʃənz - bʌt naʊ ðəɾ i θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ðeɪ hæd tə bi hoʊldɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ bæk fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn, tu.

Even after Mat had stripped off down to his smallclothes and crawled under the blankets - after blowing out the lamps - he could not sleep, though Mallia had done well by himself with a good feather mattress. He had been right about Thom's snoring, and that pillow muffled nothing. It sounded as if Thom were cutting wood cross-grain with a rusty saw. And he could not stop thinking. How had Nynaeve and Egwene, and Elayne, gotten that paper from the Amyrlin? They had to be involved with the Amyrlin Seat herself - in some plot, one of those White Tower machinations - but now that he thought about it, they had to be holding something back from the Amyrlin, too.

" 'pliz kæɹi ə lɛɾɝ tə maɪ mʌðɝ, mæt,' " hi sɛd sɔfli, ɪn ə haɪ-pɪtʃt, mɑkɪŋ vɔɪs. "ful! ði æmɪɝlɪn wʊɾə sɛn ə wɔɹɾɝ wɪð ɛni lɛɾɝ fɹəm ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tə ðə kwin. blaɪn ful, wɑntɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ soʊ bæɾ aɪ kʊdn si ɪt." tɑmz snɔɹ sim tə tʃɹʌmpəɾ əɡɹimənt.

" 'Please carry a letter to my mother, Mat,' " he said softly, in a high-pitched, mocking voice. "Fool! The Amyrlin would have sent a Warder with any letter from the Daughter-Heir to the Queen. Blind fool, wanting to get out of the Tower so bad I couldn't see it." Thom's snore seemed to trumpet agreement.

moʊst ʌv ɔl, ðoʊ, hi θɔɾ əbaʊt lʌk, ən fʊtpædz.

Most of all, though, he thought about luck, and footpads.

ðə fɝs bʌmp ə sʌmθɪŋ əɡɛns ðə stɝn bɛɹli ɹɛdʒəstɝɾ ɑn hɪm. hi peɪd noʊ ətɛnʃən tə ə θʌmp ən skʌfəl fɹəm ðə dɛk oʊvɝhɛd, əɹ ðə tʃɹɛɾ ə buts. ðə vɛsəl ɪtsɛlf meɪɾ ɪnʌf nɔɪzɪz, ən ðəɹ hæd tə bi sʌmwʌn ɑn dɛk fəɹ ðə ʃɪp tə meɪk ɪts weɪ daʊnɹɪvɝ. bʌt stɛlθi fʊtstɛps ɪn ðə pæsədʒweɪ liɾɪŋ tə hɪz dɔɹ mɝdʒd wɪð θɔts ə fʊtpædz ən meɪɾ ɪz ɪɹz pɹɪk ʌp.

The first bump of something against the stern barely registered on him. He paid no attention to a thump and scuffle from the deck overhead, or the tread of boots. The vessel itself made enough noises, and there had to be someone on deck for the ship to make its way downriver. But stealthy footsteps in the passageway leading to his door merged with thoughts of footpads and made his ears prick up.

hi nʌdʒ tɑm ɪn ðə ɹɪbz wɪð ən ɛlboʊ. "weɪk ʌp," hi sɛd sɔfli. "ðɛɹz sʌmbɑɾi aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔl." hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi izɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɔf ðə bɛd, hoʊpɪŋ ðə kæbən flɔɹ - dɛk, flɔɹ, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt blʌɾi ɪz! - wəd nɑt kɹik ʌndɝ ɪz fit. tɑm ɡɹʌntɪd, smækt ɪz lɪps, ən ɹɪzum snɔɹɪŋ.

He nudged Thom in the ribs with an elbow. "Wake up," he said softly. "There's somebody outside in the hall." He was already easing himself off the bed, hoping the cabin floor - Deck, floor, whatever it bloody is! - would not creak under his feet. Thom grunted, smacked his lips, and resumed snoring.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm tə wɝi əbaʊt tɑm. ðə fʊtstɛps wɝ ɹaɪɾ aʊtsaɪd. teɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf, mæt pleɪs hɪmsɛlf ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə dɔɹ ən weɪɾəd.

There was no time to worry about Thom. The footsteps were right outside. Taking up his quarterstaff, Mat placed himself in front of the door and waited.

ðə dɔɹ swʌŋ oʊpən sloʊli, ən tu kloʊk mɛn, wʌn bɪhaɪn ði ʌðɝ, wɝ feɪnli aʊtlaɪn baɪ dɪm munlaɪt θɹu ðə hætʃ ət ðə tɑp ə ðə læɾɝ ðeɪ hæd kɹɛp daʊn. ðə munlaɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə ɡlɪn ɔf bɛɹ naɪf bleɪdz. boʊθ mɛn ɡæspt; ðeɪ ɑbviəsli hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn ɛniwʌn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm.

The door swung open slowly, and two cloaked men, one behind the other, were faintly outlined by dim moonlight through the hatch at the top of the ladder they had crept down. The moonlight was enough to glint off bare knife blades. Both men gasped; they obviously had not expected to find anyone waiting for them.

mæt θɹʌst wɪð ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf, kætʃɪŋ ðə fɝs mæn hɑɹd ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ wɛɹ ɪz ɹɪbz dʒɔɪn təɡɛðɝ. hi hɝɾ ɪz fɑðɝz vɔɪs əz i stʃɹʌk. ɪts ə kɪlɪŋ bloʊ, mæt. doʊn ɛvɝ juz ɪɾ ənlɛs ɪts jəɹ laɪf. bʌt ðoʊz naɪvz meɪɾ ɪt fəɹ ɪz laɪf; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹum ɪn ðə kæbən fəɹ swɪŋɪŋ ə stæf.

Mat thrust with the quarterstaff, catching the first man hard right under where his ribs joined together. He heard his father's voice as he struck. It's a killing blow, Mat. Don't ever use it unless it's your life. But those knives made it for his life; there was no room in the cabin for swinging a staff.

ivən əz ðə mæn meɪɾ ə tʃoʊkɪŋ saʊn ən foʊldəd təwɔɹd ðə dɛk, faɪɾɪŋ veɪnli fəɹ bɹɛθ, mæt stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən dʒɹoʊv ði ɛn ə ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf oʊvɝ ɪm ɪndə ðə sɛkən mænz θɹoʊt wɪð ə laʊd kɹʌntʃ. ðət fɛloʊ dʒɹɑpt ɪz naɪf tə klʌtʃ əɾ ɪz θɹoʊt, ən fɛl ɑn tɑp ə hɪz kəmpænjən, boʊθ ə ðɛm skɹeɪpɪŋ ðɛɹ buts əkɹɔs ðə dɛk, dɛθ ɹæɾəlz ɔlɹɛɾi saʊndɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ θɹoʊts.

Even as the man made a choking sound and folded toward the deck, fighting vainly for breath, Mat stepped forward and drove the end of the quarterstaff over him into the second man's throat with a loud crunch. That fellow dropped his knife to clutch at his throat, and fell on top of his companion, both of them scraping their boots across the deck, death rattles already sounding in their throats.

mæt stʊd ðɛɹ, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ət ðɛm. tu mɛn. noʊ, bɝn mi, θɹi! aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ ɛvɝ hɝɾ ənʌðɝ hjumən biɪŋ bɪfɔɹ, ən naʊ aɪv kɪl θɹi mɛn ɪn wʌn naɪt. laɪt!

Mat stood there, staring down at them. Two men. No, burn me, three! I don't think I ever hurt another human being before, and now I've killed three men in one night. Light!

saɪləns fɪl ðə dɑɹk pæsədʒweɪ, ən i hɝd ðə θʌmp ə buts ɑn ðə dɛk oʊvɝhɛd. ðə kɹumɪn ɔl wɛn bɛɹfʊt.

Silence filled the dark passageway, and he heard the thump of boots on the deck overhead. The crewmen all went barefoot.

tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, mæt ɹɪp ðə kloʊk fɹəm wʌn ə ðə dɛd mɛn ən sɛɾəld ɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, haɪɾɪŋ ðə peɪl lɪnən ə hɪz smɔlkloʊðz. ɑn bɛɹ fiɾ i pæɾəd daʊn ðə pæsədʒ ən klaɪm ðə læɾɝ, bɛɹli stɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz əbʌv ðə hætʃ koʊpɪŋ.

Trying not to think about what he was doing, Mat ripped the cloak from one of the dead men and settled it around his shoulders, hiding the pale linen of his smallclothes. On bare feet he padded down the passage and climbed the ladder, barely sticking his eyes above the hatch coping.

peɪl munlaɪt ɹəflɛktəɾ ɔf ðə tɔt seɪlz, bʌt naɪt stɪl kʌvɝd ðə dɛk wɪð ʃædoʊz, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saʊn ɪksɛp ðə ɹʌʃ ʌv wɔɾɝ əlɔŋ ðə vɛsəlz saɪdz. oʊnli wʌn mæn ət ðə tɪlɝ, ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk pʊld ʌp əɡɛns ðə tʃɪl, sim tə bi ɑn dɛk. ðə mæn ʃɪftəd, ən but lɛðɝ skʌft ɑn ðə dɛk plæŋks.

Pale moonlight reflected off the taut sails, but night still covered the deck with shadows, and there was no sound except the rush of water along the vessel's sides. Only one man at the tiller, the hood of his cloak pulled up against the chill, seemed to be on deck. The man shifted, and boot leather scuffed on the deck planks.

hoʊldɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf loʊ ən hoʊpɪŋ ɪt wəd nɑt bi noʊɾəst, mæt klaɪmd ɑn ʌp. "hiz dɛd," hi mʌɾɝd ɪn ə loʊ, ɹʌf wɪspɝ.

Holding the quarterstaff low and hoping it would not be noticed, Mat climbed on up. "He's dead," he muttered in a low, rough whisper.

"aɪ hoʊp i skwild wən jə kʌɾ ɪz θɹoʊt." ðə hɛvəli æksɛntɪd vɔɪs wɑz wʌn mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd kɔlɪŋ fɹəm ðə maʊθ ʌv ə twɪstɪŋ stʃɹiɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. "ðɪs bɔɪ, hi kɑzəz əs tu mʌtʃ ə ðə tʃɹʌbəl, weɪt! hu ɑɹ ju?"

"I hope he squealed when you cut his throat." The heavily accented voice was one Mat remembered calling from the mouth of a twisting street in Tar Valon. "This boy, he causes us too much of the trouble, Wait! Who are you?"

mæt swʌŋ ðə stæf wɪð ɔl ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ. ðə θɪk wʊd smæʃt ɪndə ðə mænz hɛd, ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk oʊnli pɑɹtli mʌfəlɪŋ ə saʊn laɪk ə mɛlən hɪɾɪŋ ðə flɔɹ.

Mat swung the staff with all his strength. The thick wood smashed into the man's head, the hood of his cloak only partly muffling a sound like a melon hitting the floor.

ðə mæn fɛl əkɹɔs ðə tɪlɝ, ʃʌvɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ, ən ðə vɛsəl lɝtʃt, stæɡɝɪŋ mæt. aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ hi sɔ ə ʃeɪp ɹaɪzɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz baɪ ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, ən ðə ɡlim ʌv ə bleɪd, ən i nu hi wəd nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ɪz stæf ɝaʊn bɪfɔɹ ɪt stʃɹʌk hoʊm. sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ðət ʃoʊn stʃɹik θɹu ðə naɪɾ ən mɝdʒd wɪð ðə dɪm ʃeɪp wɪð ə dʌl θʌŋk. ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ moʊʃən bɪkeɪm ə fɔl, ən ə mæn spɹɔld ɔlmoʊst ət mæts fit.

The man fell across the tiller, shoving it over, and the vessel lurched, staggering Mat. Out of the corner of his eye he saw a shape rising out of the shadows by the railing, and the gleam of a blade, and he knew he would never get his staff around before it struck home. Something else that shone streaked through the night and merged with the dim shape with a dull thunk. The rising motion became a fall, and a man sprawled almost at Mat's feet.

ə bæbəl ə vɔɪsəz ɹoʊz bɛlaʊdɛks əz ðə ʃɪp swʌŋ əɡɛn, ðə tɪlɝ ʃɪftɪŋ wɪð ðə fɝs mænz weɪt.

A babble of voices rose belowdecks as the ship swung again, the tiller shifting with the first man's weight.

tɑm lɪmp fɹəm ðə hætʃ ɪn kloʊk ən smɔlkloʊðz, ɹeɪzɪŋ ðə ʃʌɾɝ ɑn ə bʊlz-aɪ læntɝn. "ju wɝ lʌki, bɔɪ. wʌn ə ðoʊz bɪloʊ hæd ðɪs læntɝn. cʊɾə sɛt ðə ʃɪp ɑn faɪɝ, laɪɪŋ ðɛɹ." ðə laɪt ʃoʊɾ ə naɪf hɪl stɪkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə tʃɛst ʌv ə mæn wɪð dɛd, stɛɹɪŋ aɪz. mæt hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪm bɪfɔɹ; hi wɑz ʃʊɹ i wʊɾə ɹɪmɛmbɝd sʌmwʌn wɪð ðət mɛni skɑɹz ɑn ɪz feɪs. tɑm kɪkt ə dæɡɝ əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɛd mænz aʊtfləŋ hænd, ðən bɛn tə ɹɪtʃɹiv ɪz oʊn naɪf, waɪpɪŋ ðə bleɪɾ ɑn ðə kɔɹpsəz kloʊk. "vɛɹi lʌki, bɔɪ. vɛɹi lʌki ɪndid."

Thom limped from the hatch in cloak and smallclothes, raising the shutter on a bull's-eye lantern. "You were lucky, boy. One of those below had this lantern. Could have set the ship on fire, lying there." The light showed a knife hilt sticking up from the chest of a man with dead, staring eyes. Mat had never seen him before; he was sure he would have remembered someone with that many scars on his face. Thom kicked a dagger away from the dead man's outflung hand, then bent to retrieve his own knife, wiping the blade on the corpse's cloak. "Very lucky, boy. Very lucky indeed."

ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹoʊp taɪd tə ðə stɝn ɹeɪl. tɑm stɛpt oʊvɝ tə ɪt, ʃaɪnɪŋ ðə laɪt daʊn æstɝn, ən mæt dʒɔɪn hɪm. ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə ɹoʊp wɑz wʌn ə ðə smɔl boʊts fɹəm saʊθhɑɹbɝ, ɪts skwɛɹ læntɝn ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃt. tu mɔɹ mɛn stʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə pʊld-ɪn ɔɹz.

There was a rope tied to the stern rail. Thom stepped over to it, shining the light down astern, and Mat joined him. At the other end of the rope was one of the small boats from Southharbor, its square lantern extinguished. Two more men stood among the pulled-in oars.

"ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd teɪk mi, ɪts hɪm!" wʌn ə ðɛm ɡæspt. ði ʌðɝ dɑɹɾɪd fɔɹwɝd tə wɝk fɹæntəkəli ət ðə nɑt hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹoʊp.

"The Great Lord take me, it's him!" one of them gasped. The other darted forward to work frantically at the knot holding the rope.

"ju wɑnə kɪl ðiz tu əz wɛl?" tɑm æskt, hɪz vɔɪs bumɪŋ əz ɪt dɪd wən i pɝfɔɹmd.

"You want to kill these two as well?" Thom asked, his voice booming as it did when he performed.

"noʊ, tɑm," mæt sɛd kwaɪətli. "noʊ."

"No, Thom," Mat said quietly. "No."

ðə mɛn ɪn ðə boʊt mʌst əv hɝd ðə kwɛstʃən ən nɑt ði ænsɝ, fəɹ ðeɪ əbændən ði ətɛmp tə fɹi ðɛɹ boʊɾ ən lɛpt oʊvɝ ðə saɪd wɪð ɡɹeɪt splæʃəz. ðə saʊn ə ðɛm θɹæʃɪŋ əweɪ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ wɑz laʊd.

The men in the boat must have heard the question and not the answer, for they abandoned the attempt to free their boat and leaped over the side with great splashes. The sound of them thrashing away across the river was loud.

"fulz," tɑm mʌɾɝd. "ðə ɹɪvɝ nɛɹoʊz sʌmwʌɾ æftɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn, bʌɾ ɪt mʌst stɪl bi hæf ə maɪl əɹ mɔɹ waɪd hɪɹ. ðəl nɛvɝ meɪk ɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk."

"Fools," Thom muttered. "The river narrows somewhat after Tar Valon, but it must still be half a mile or more wide here. They'll never make it in the dark."

"baɪ ðə stoʊn!" keɪm ə ʃaʊt fɹəm ðə hætʃ. "wʌt hæpənz hɪɹ? ðəɹ ɑɹ dɛd mɛn ɪn ðə pæsədʒweɪ! wʌts vɑsə duɪŋ laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə tɪlɝ? hɪl ɹʌn əs ɑntu ə mʌdbæŋk!" neɪkəd seɪv fəɹ lɪnən ʌndɝbɹitʃɪz, mɑliə dæʃt tə ðə tɪlɝ, hɔlɪŋ ðə dɛd mæn ɔf ɹʌfli əz i pʊl ðə lɔŋ lɛvɝ tə pʊt ðə kɔɹs stʃɹeɪɾ əɡɛn. "ðæɾ ɪzən vɑsə! bɝn maɪ soʊl, hu ɑɹ ɔl ðiz dɛd mɛn?" ʌðɝz wɝ klæmbɝɪŋ ɑn dɛk naʊ, bɛɹfʊt kɹumɪn ən fɹaɪɾənd pæsənʒɝz ɹæpt ɪn kloʊks ən blæŋkəts.

"By the Stone!" came a shout from the hatch. "What happens here? There are dead men in the passageway! What's Vasa doing lying on the tiller? He'll run us onto a mudbank!" Naked save for linen underbreeches, Mallia dashed to the tiller, hauling the dead man off roughly as he pulled the long lever to put the course straight again. "That isn't Vasa! Burn my soul, who are all these dead men?" Others were clambering on deck now, barefoot crewmen and frightened passengers wrapped in cloaks and blankets.

ʃildɪŋ ɪz ækʃənz wɪð ɪz bɑɾi, tɑm slɪpt ɪz naɪf ʌndɝ ðə ɹoʊp ən sɛvɝɾ ɪɾ ɪn wʌn stʃɹoʊk. ðə smɔl boʊt bɪɡæn fɔlɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. "ɹɪvɝ bɹɪɡænz, kæptən," hi sɛd. "jʌŋ mæt ən aɪ hæv seɪv jəɹ vɛsəl fɹəm ɹɪvɝ bɹɪɡænz. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv kʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌnz θɹoʊɾ ɪf nɑt fəɹ ʌs. pɝhæps jə ʃəd ɹikənsɪɾɝ jəɹ pæsədʒ fi."

Shielding his actions with his body, Thom slipped his knife under the rope and severed it in one stroke. The small boat began falling back into the darkness. "River brigands, Captain," he said. "Young Mat and I have saved your vessel from river brigands. They might have cut everyone's throat if not for us. Perhaps you should reconsider your passage fee."

"bɹɪɡænz!" mɑliə ɪkskleɪmd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ plɛnti ʌv ðoʊz daʊn ɝaʊn kɛɹhin, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɪt ðɪs fɑɹ nɔɹθ!" ðə hʌɾəld pæsənʒɝz bɪɡæn tə mʌɾɝ əbaʊt bɹɪɡænz ən hævɪŋ ðɛɹ θɹoʊts kʌt.

"Brigands!" Mallia exclaimed. "There are plenty of those down around Cairhien, but I never heard of it this far north!" The huddled passengers began to mutter about brigands and having their throats cut.

mæt wɔk stɪfli tə ðə hætʃ. bɪhaɪn hɪm, hi hɝd mɑliə. "hiz ə koʊld wʌn. aɪ nɛvɝ hɝd ðəɾ ændɝ ɛmplɔɪɾ əsæsənz, bʌt bɝn maɪ soʊl, hiz ə koʊld wʌn."

Mat walked stiffly to the hatch. Behind him, he heard Mallia. "He's a cold one. I never heard that Andor employed assassins, but burn my soul, he is a cold one."

mæt stʌmbəl daʊn ðə læɾɝ, stɛpt oʊvɝ ðə tu bɑɾiz ɪn ðə pæsədʒ, ən slæm ðə dɔɹ ə ðə kæptənz kæbən bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi meɪɾ ɪt hæfweɪ tə ðə bɛd bɪfɔɹ ðə ʃeɪkɪŋ hɪt hɪm, ən ðən ɔl i kəd də wɑz sɪŋk daʊn ɑn ɪz niz. laɪt, wʌt ɡeɪm æm aɪ pleɪɪŋ ɪn? aɪ hæv tə noʊ ðə ɡeɪm ɪf aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə wɪn. laɪt, wʌt ɡeɪm?

Mat stumbled down the ladder, stepped over the two bodies in the passage, and slammed the door of the captain's cabin behind him. He made it halfway to the bed before the shaking hit him, and then all he could do was sink down on his knees. Light, what game am I playing in? I have to know the game if I'm going to win. Light, what game?

pleɪɪŋ "ɹoʊz ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ" sɔfli ɑn ɪz flut, ɹænd pɪɹɾ ɪndə hɪz kæmpfaɪɝ, wɛɹ ə ɹæbət wɑz ɹoʊstɪŋ ɑn ə stɪk slæntɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə fleɪmz. ə naɪt wɪn meɪd ðə fleɪmz flɪkɝ; hi bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðə smɛl ə ðə ɹæbət, ðoʊ ə veɪɡɹən θɔt dɪd kʌm ðəɾ i niɾəd tə faɪn mɔɹ sɔlt ɪn ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ əɹ taʊn. "ɹoʊz ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ" wɑz wʌn ə ðə tunz i hæd pleɪɾ ət ðoʊz wɛɾɪŋz.

Playing "Rose of the Morning" softly on his flute, Rand peered into his campfire, where a rabbit was roasting on a stick slanting over the flames. A night wind made the flames flicker; he barely noticed the smell of the rabbit, though a vagrant thought did come that he needed to find more salt in the next village or town. "Rose of the Morning" was one of the tunes he had played at those weddings.

haʊ mɛni deɪz əɡoʊ wɑz ðæt? wɝ ðəɹ ɹɪli soʊ mɛni, əɹ dɪɾ aɪ ɪmædʒən ɪt? ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə mɛɹi ət wʌns? wʌt wɑz ɪts neɪm? æm aɪ ɡoʊɪŋ mæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi?

How many days ago was that? Were there really so many, or did I imagine it? Every woman in the village deciding to marry at once? What was its name? Am I going mad already?

swɛt biɾɪd ɑn ɪz feɪs, bʌɾ i pleɪɾ ɑn, bɛɹli laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə bi hɝd, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə faɪɝ. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd toʊld ɪm i wɑz tɑvɝən. ɛvɹiwʌn sɛɾ i wɑz tɑvɝən. meɪbi hi ɹɪli wɑz. pipəl laɪk ðət - tʃeɪnʒd - θɪŋz ɝaʊn ðɛm. ə tɑvɝən maɪɾ əv kɑzd ɔl ðoʊz wɛɾɪŋz. bʌt ðət wɑz tu kloʊz tə sʌmθɪŋ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt.

Sweat beaded on his face, but he played on, barely loud enough to be heard, staring into the fire. Moiraine had told him he was ta'veren. Everyone said he was ta'veren. Maybe he really was. People like that - changed - things around them. A ta'veren might have caused all those weddings. But that was too close to something he did not want to think about.

ðeɪ seɪ ɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, tu. ðeɪ ɔl seɪ ɪt. ðə lɪvɪŋ seɪ ɪt, ən ðə dɛd. ðət dʌzn meɪk ɪt tʃɹu. aɪ hæd tə lɛɾ əm pɹoʊkleɪm mi. duɾi. aɪ hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs, bʌt ðət dʌz nɑt meɪk ɪt tʃɹu.

They say I'm the Dragon Reborn, too. They all say it. The living say it, and the dead. That doesn't make it true. I had to let them proclaim me. Duty. I had no choice, but that does not make it true.

hi kəd nɑt sim tə stɑp pleɪɪŋ ðət wʌn tun. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ʌv ɛɡwin. hi hæd θɔt wʌns ðəɾ i wəd mɛɹi ɛɡwin. ə lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ, ðət simd. ðət wɑz ɡɔn, naʊ. ʃi hæd kʌm ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz, ðoʊ. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn hɝ. hɝ feɪs. ɪt wɑz əɹ feɪs.

He could not seem to stop playing that one tune. It made him think of Egwene. He had thought once that he would marry Egwene. A long time ago, that seemed. That was gone, now. She had come in his dreams, though. It might have been her. Her face. It was her face.

oʊnli, ðəɹ hæd bɪn soʊ mɛni feɪsəz, feɪsəz i nu. tæm, ən ɪz mʌðɝ, ən mæt, ən pɛɹɪn. ɔl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl hɪm. ɪt hæd nɑt ɹɪli bɪn ðɛm, ʌv kɔɹs. oʊnli ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ɑn ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. hi θɔɾ ɪt hæd nɑt ɹɪli bɪn ðɛm. ivən ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz ɪt sim ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn wɔkt. wɝ ðeɪ oʊnli dʒɹimz? səm dʒɹimz wɝ ɹil, hi nu. ən ʌðɝz wɝ oʊnli dʒɹimz, naɪtmɛɹz, əɹ hoʊps. bʌt haʊ tə tɛl ðə dɪfɝəns? mɪn hæd wɔkt ɪz dʒɹimz wʌn naɪt - ən tʃɹaɪd tə plæn ə naɪf ɪn ɪz bæk. hi wɑz stɪl sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ mʌtʃ ðət hæd peɪn hɪm. hi hæd bɪn kɛɹləs, lɛɾ əɹ kʌm kloʊs, lɛt daʊn ɪz ɡɑɹd. ɝaʊn mɪn, hi hæd nɑt fɛlt ɛni nid tə bi ɑn ɪz ɡɑɹɾ ɪn soʊ lɔŋ, dɪspaɪt ðə θɪŋz ʃi sɔ wən ʃi lʊkt ət hɪm. biɪŋ wɪð əɹ hæd bɪn laɪk hævɪŋ bɑm suðd ɪndə hɪz wunz.

Only, there had been so many faces, faces he knew. Tam, and his mother, and Mat, and Perrin. All trying to kill him. It had not really been them, of course. Only their faces, on Shadowspawn. He thought it had not really been them. Even in his dreams it seemed the Shadowspawn walked. Were they only dreams? Some dreams were real, he knew. And others were only dreams, nightmares, or hopes. But how to tell the difference? Min had walked his dreams one night - and tried to plant a knife in his back. He was still surprised at how much that had pained him. He had been careless, let her come close, let down his guard. Around Min, he had not felt any need to be on his guard in so long, despite the things she saw when she looked at him. Being with her had been like having balm soothed into his wounds.

ən ðən ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl mi! ðə mjuzɪk ɹoʊz tə ə dɪskɔɹɾənt skɹitʃ, bʌɾ i pʊld ɪt bæk tə sɔfnəs. nɑt hɝ. ʃæɾoʊzpɔn wɪð əɹ feɪs. list ə ðɛm ɔl wəd mɪn hɝt mi. hi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ hi θɔt ðæt, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz tʃɹu.

And then she tried to kill me! The music rose to a discordant screech, but he pulled it back to softness. Not her. Shadowspawn with her face. Least of them all would Min hurt me. He could not understand why he thought that, but he was sure it was true.

soʊ mɛni feɪsəz ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz. səlin hæd kʌm, kul ən mɪstɪɹiəs ən soʊ lʌvli hɪz maʊθ wɛn dʒɹaɪ dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝ, ɔfɝɪŋ ɪm ɡlɔɹi əz ʃi hæd - soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ, ɪt simd - bʌt naʊ ɪt wɑz ðə sɔɹd ʃi sɛɾ i hæd tə teɪk. ən wɪð ðə sɔɹd wəd kʌm səlin. kælændɝ. ðət wɑz ɔlweɪz ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz. ɔlweɪz. ən tɔntɪŋ feɪsəz. hænz, pʊʃɪŋ ɛɡwin, ən nɪneɪiv, ən ɪleɪn ɪndə keɪdʒɪz, snɛɹɪŋ əm ɪn nɛts, hɝɾɪŋ ðɛm. waɪ ʃəɾ i wip mɔɹ fəɹ ɪleɪn ðən fəɹ ði ʌðɝ tu?

So many faces in his dreams. Selene had come, cool and mysterious and so lovely his mouth went dry just thinking of her, offering him glory as she had - so long ago, it seemed - but now it was the sword she said he had to take. And with the sword would come Selene. Callandor. That was always in his dreams. Always. And taunting faces. Hands, pushing Egwene, and Nynaeve, and Elayne into cages, snaring them in nets, hurting them. Why should he weep more for Elayne than for the other two?

hɪz hɛd spʌn. hɪz hɛd hɝɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ɪz saɪd, ən swɛt ɹoʊl daʊn ɪz feɪs, ən i sɔfli pleɪd "ɹoʊz ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ" θɹu ðə naɪt, fɪɹɪŋ tə slip. fɪɹɪŋ tə dʒɹim.

His head spun. His head hurt as much as his side, and sweat rolled down his face, and he softly played "Rose of the Morning" through the night, fearing to sleep. Fearing to dream.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiθɹi


CHAPTER 33

wɪðɪn ðə wiv


Within the Weave

fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, pɛɹɪn fɹaʊn daʊn ət ðə flæt stoʊn hæf hɪɾən ɪn widz baɪ ðə ɹoʊdsaɪd. ðɪs ɹoʊɾ ə hɑɹd-pæk dɝt, ɔlɹɛɾi kɔl ðə luɡɹd ɹoʊd naʊ ðeɪ wɝ nɪɹ ðə meɪnɛðɹəndʒɹɛl ən ðə bɔɹɾɝ ə mʊɹændi, hæd bɪn peɪvd wʌns, lɔŋ ɪn ðə pæst, soʊ mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sɛd tu deɪz ɝliɝ, ən bɪts ə peɪvɪŋ stoʊn stɪl wɝk ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə sɝfəs fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm. ðɪs wʌn hæɾ ən ɑd mɑɹkɪŋ ɑn ɪt.

From his saddle, Perrin frowned down at the flat stone half hidden in weeds by the roadside. This road of hard-packed dirt, already called the Lugard Road now they were near the Manetherendrelle and the border of Murandy, had been paved once, long in the past, so Moiraine had said two days earlier, and bits of paving stone still worked their way to the surface from time to time. This one had an odd marking on it.

ɪf dɑɡz hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk fʊtpɹɪns ɑn stoʊn, hi wʊɾə sɛɾ ɪt wɑz ðə pɹɪn ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ haʊnd. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ haʊnz fʊtpɹɪns ɪn ɛni ʌv ðə bɛɹ ɡɹaʊn i kəd si, wɛɹ sɑftɝ dɝɾ ɑn ðə vɝdʒ maɪt teɪk wʌn, ən noʊ smɛl ʌv ɛni dɔɡz tʃɹeɪl. dʒʌst ə feɪn tʃɹeɪs ɪn ði ɛɹ ə sʌmθɪŋ bɝnd, ɔlmoʊs ðə sʌlfɝəs smɛl lɛf baɪ sɛɾɪŋ ɔf faɪɹwɝks. ðəɹ wɑz ə taʊn əhɛd, wɛɹ ðə ɹoʊd stʃɹʌk ðə ɹɪvɝ; meɪbi səm tʃɪlʒɹən hæd snikt aʊt hɪɹ wɪð səm ə ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz' hændiwɝk.

If dogs had been able to make footprints on stone, he would have said it was the print of a large hound. There were no hound's footprints in any of the bare ground he could see, where softer dirt on the verge might take one, and no smell of any dog's trail. Just a faint trace in the air of something burned, almost the sulphurous smell left by setting off fireworks. There was a town ahead, where the road struck the river; maybe some children had sneaked out here with some of the Illuminators' handiwork.

ə lɔŋ weɪ jɛt fəɹ tʃɪlʒɹən tə snik. bʌɾ i hæd sin fɑɹmz. ɪt cʊɾə bɪn fɑɹm tʃɪlʒɹən. wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz, ɪts nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðət mɑɹkɪŋ. hɔɹsəz doʊn flaɪ, ən dɑɡz doʊn meɪk fʊtpɹɪns ɑn stoʊn. aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ tu taɪɝd tə θɪŋk stʃɹeɪt.

A long way yet for children to sneak. But he had seen farms. It could have been farm children. Whatever it is, it has nothing to do with that marking. Horses don't fly, and dogs don't make footprints on stone. I'm getting too tired to think straight.

jɔnɪŋ, hi dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪndə stɛpɝz ɹɪbz, ən ðə dʌn bɹoʊk ɪndə ə ɡæləp æftɝ ði ʌðɝz. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd bɪn pʊʃɪŋ əm hɑɹd sɪns livɪŋ dʒɹə, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛniwʌn u stɑp fəɹ ivən ə moʊmənt. wən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pʊɾ əɹ maɪn ɑn sʌmθɪŋ, ʃi wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz koʊl hæmɝɾ aɪɝn. lɔɪəl hæd ɡɪvən ʌp ɹɛɾɪŋ əz i ɹoʊd sɪks deɪz ɝliɝ, æftɝ lʊkɪŋ ʌp tə faɪn hɪmsɛlf lɛft ə maɪl bɪhaɪn ən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɔlmoʊst aʊɾ ə saɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə nɛks hɪl.

Yawning, he dug his heels into Stepper's ribs, and the dun broke into a gallop after the others. Moiraine had been pushing them hard since leaving Jarra, and there was no waiting for anyone who stopped for even a moment. When the Aes Sedai put her mind on something, she was as hard as cold hammered iron. Loial had given up reading as he rode six days earlier, after looking up to find himself left a mile behind and everyone else almost out of sight over the next hill.

pɛɹɪn sloʊd stɛpɝ əlɔŋsaɪd ði oʊɡiɝz bɪɡ hɔɹs, bɪhaɪn mɔɪɹeɪnz waɪt mɛɹ, ən jɔn əɡɛn. læn wɑz ʌp əhɛd sʌmwɛɹ, skaʊɾɪŋ. ðə sʌn bɪhaɪn əm stʊd noʊ mɔɹ ðən ən aʊɝ əbʌv ðə tʃɹitɑps, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd sɛd ðeɪ wəd ɹitʃ ə taʊn kɔld ɹɛmən, ɑn ðə meɪnɛðɹəndʒɹɛl, bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk. pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i wɑntəd tə si wʌɾ əweɪɾəd əm ðɛɹ. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt maɪt bi, bʌt ðə deɪz sɪns dʒɹə hæd meɪɾ ɪm wɛɹi.

Perrin slowed Stepper alongside the Ogier's big horse, behind Moiraine's white mare, and yawned again. Lan was up ahead somewhere, scouting. The sun behind them stood no more than an hour above the treetops, but the Warder had said they would reach a town called Remen, on the Manetherendrelle, before dark. Perrin was not sure he wanted to see what awaited them there. He did not know what it might be, but the days since Jarra had made him wary.

"aɪ doʊn si waɪ jə kæn slip," lɔɪəl toʊl hɪm. "aɪ æm soʊ taɪɝd baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi lɛts əs hɔl fəɹ ðə naɪt, aɪ fɔl əslip bɪfɔɹ aɪ kən laɪ daʊn."

"I don't see why you can't sleep," Loial told him. "I am so tired by the time she lets us halt for the night, I fall asleep before I can lie down."

pɛɹɪn oʊnli ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə ɪkspleɪn tə lɔɪəl ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt dɛɹ slip saʊnli, ðəɾ ivən ɪz laɪɾəst slip wɑz fʊl ə tʃɹʌbəl dʒɹimz. laɪk ðəɾ ɑd wʌn wɪð ɛɡwin ən hɑpɝ ɪn ɪt. wɛl, noʊ wʌndɝ aɪ dʒɹim əbaʊt hɝ. laɪt, aɪ wʌndɝ haʊ ʃi ɪz. seɪf ɪn ðə taʊɝ baɪ naʊ, ən lɝnɪŋ haʊ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. vɛɹɪn wɪl lʊk æftɝ hɝ, ən æftɝ mæt, tu. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛniwʌn niɾəd tə lʊk æftɝ nɪneɪiv; ɝaʊnd nɪneɪiv, tə hɪz maɪnd, ʌðɝ pipəl niɾəd sʌmwʌn tə lʊk æftɝ ðɛm.

Perrin only shook his head. There was no way to explain to Loial that he did not dare sleep soundly, that even his lightest sleep was full of troubled dreams. Like that odd one with Egwene and Hopper in it. Well, no wonder I dream about her. Light, I wonder how she is. Safe in the Tower by now, and learning how to be Aes Sedai. Verin will look after her, and after Mat, too. He did not think anyone needed to look after Nynaeve; around Nynaeve, to his mind, other people needed someone to look after them.

hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt hɑpɝ. hi wɑz səksiɾɪŋ ɪn kipɪŋ laɪv wʊlvz aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd, ɔlðoʊ ət ðə pɹaɪs ə filɪŋ əz ɪf i hæd bɪn hæmɝd-ænd-dʒɹɔn baɪ ə heɪsti hænd; hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk ə dɛd wʊlf maɪt bi kɹipɪŋ ɪn. hi ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf ən fɔɹst ɪz aɪz waɪɾ oʊpən. nɑɾ ivən hɑpɝ.

He did not want to think about Hopper. He was succeeding in keeping live wolves out of his head, although at the price of feeling as if he had been hammered-and-drawn by a hasty hand; he did not want to think a dead wolf might be creeping in. He shook himself and forced his eyes wide open. Not even Hopper.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn mɔɹ ɹizənz ðən bæd dʒɹimz nɑt tə slip wɛl. ðeɪ hæd faʊn ʌðɝ saɪnz lɛf baɪ ɹændz pæsədʒ. bɪtwin dʒɹə ən ðə ɹɪvɝ bɔɝn ðəɹ hæd bɪn nʌn pɛɹɪn kəd si, bʌt wən ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə bɔɝn baɪ ə stoʊn bɹɪdʒ ɑɹtʃɪŋ fɹəm wʌn fɪfti-fʊt ɹɪvɝ klɪf tə ənʌðɝ, ðeɪ hæd lɛf bɪhaɪn ə taʊn kɔl saɪɾən ɔl ɪn æʃəz. ɛvɹi bɪldɪŋ. oʊnli ə fju stoʊn wɔlz ən tʃɪmniz stɪl stʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə ɹuənz.

There had been more reasons than bad dreams not to sleep well. They had found other signs left by Rand's passage. Between Jarra and the River Boern there had been none Perrin could see, but when they crossed the Boern by a stone bridge arching from one fifty-foot river cliff to another, they had left behind a town called Sidon all in ashes. Every building. Only a few stone walls and chimneys still stood among the ruins.

bɪdʒɹæɡəl taʊnzpipəl sɛɾ ə læntɝn dʒɹɑpt ɪn ə bɑɹn hæd stɑɹɾəd ɪt, ən ðən ðə faɪɝ sim tə ɹʌn waɪld, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɛn ɹɔŋ. hæf ðə bʌkəts ðət kəd bi faʊn hæd hoʊlz ɪn ðɛm. ɛvɹi læs bɝnɪŋ wɔl hæd fɔlən aʊtwɝɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɪn, sɛɾɪŋ haʊsəz tə iðɝ saɪɾ əlaɪt. fleɪmɪŋ tɪmbɝz fɹəm ði ɪn hæd sʌmhaʊ tʌmbəld əz fɑɹ əz ðə meɪn wɛl ɪn ðə skwɛɹ, soʊ noʊ wʌn kəd dʒɹɔ mɔɹ wɔɾɝ fɹəm ɪt tə faɪt ðə faɪɝz, ən haʊsəz hæd fɔlən ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə θɹi ʌðɝ wɛlz. ivən ðə wɪn hæd sim tə ʃɪft, fænɪŋ ðə fleɪmz ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən.

Bedraggled townspeople said a lantern dropped in a barn had started it, and then the fire seemed to run wild, and everything went wrong. Half the buckets that could be found had holes in them. Every last burning wall had fallen outward instead of in, setting houses to either side alight. Flaming timbers from the inn had somehow tumbled as far as the main well in the square, so no one could draw more water from it to fight the fires, and houses had fallen right on top of three other wells. Even the wind had seemed to shift, fanning the flames in every direction.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ nid tə æsk mɔɪɹeɪn ɪf ɹændz pɹɛzəns hæd kɑzd ɪt; hɝ feɪs, laɪk koʊld aɪɝn, wɑz ænsɝ ɪnʌf. ðə pæɾɝn ʃeɪpt ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn ɹænd, ən tʃæns ɹæn waɪld.

There had been no need to ask Moiraine if Rand's presence had caused it; her face, like cold iron, was answer enough. The Pattern shaped itself around Rand, and chance ran wild.

bɪɑn saɪɾən ðeɪ hæd ɹɪɾən θɹu fɔɹ smɔl taʊnz wɛɹ oʊnli lænz tʃɹækɪŋ toʊld əm ɹænd wɑz stɪl əhɛd. ɹænd wɑz əfʊt, naʊ, ən hæd bɪn fəɹ səm taɪm. ðeɪ hæd faʊn ɪz hɔɹs bæk bɪɑn dʒɹə, dɛd, lʊkɪŋ əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn mɔl baɪ wʊlvz, əɹ dɑɡz ɹʌn waɪld. ɪt hæd bɪn hɑɹd fəɹ pɛɹɪn nɑt tə ɹitʃ aʊt, ðɛn, ɪspɛʃli wən mɔɪɹeɪn lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðə hɔɹs tə fɹaʊn ət hɪm. lʌkəli, læn hæd faʊn ðə tʃɹæks ə ɹændz buts, ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm wɛɹ ðə dɛd hɔɹs leɪ. wʌn but hil hæɾ ə θɹi-kɔɹnɝd ɡaʊdʒ fɹəm ə ɹɑk; ɪt meɪɾ ɪz pɹɪns pleɪn. bʌɾ əfʊɾ əɹ maʊntəd, hi sim tə bi steɪɪŋ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm.

Beyond Sidon they had ridden through four small towns where only Lan's tracking told them Rand was still ahead. Rand was afoot, now, and had been for some time. They had found his horse back beyond Jarra, dead, looking as if it had been mauled by wolves, or dogs run wild. It had been hard for Perrin not to reach out, then, especially when Moiraine looked up from the horse to frown at him. Luckily, Lan had found the tracks of Rand's boots, running from where the dead horse lay. One boot heel had a three-cornered gouge from a rock; it made his prints plain. But afoot or mounted, he seemed to be staying ahead of them.

ɪn ðə fɔɹ vɪlədʒəz æftɝ saɪɾən, ðə bɪɡəst ɪksaɪtmən ɛniwʌn kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ wɑz siɪŋ lɔɪəl ɹaɪɾ ɪn, ən dɪskʌvɝɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz ən oʊɡiɝ, fəɹ ɹil ən fəɹ tʃɹu. ðeɪ wɝ soʊ kɑɾ ʌp wɪð ðæt, ðət ðeɪ bɛɹli ivən noʊɾəst pɛɹɪnz aɪz, ən wən ðeɪ dɪd. . . . wɛl, ɪf oʊɡiɝ wɝ ɹil, ðən mɛn kəd vɛɹi wɛl əv ɛni kʌlɝ aɪz əɾ ɔl.

In the four villages after Sidon, the biggest excitement anyone could remember was seeing Loial ride in, and discovering that he was an Ogier, for real and for true. They were so caught up with that, that they barely even noticed Perrin's eyes, and when they did. . . . Well, if Ogier were real, then men could very well have any color eyes at all.

bʌɾ æftɝ ðoʊz keɪm ə lɪɾəl pleɪs neɪmd wɪlɝ, ən ɪt wɑz sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ. ðə spɹɪŋ ɑn ðə vɪlədʒ kɑmən wɑz floʊɪŋ əɡɛn, æftɝ ə jɪɹ ə hɔlɪŋ wɔɾɝ ə maɪl fɹəm ə stʃɹim wən ɔl ɛfɝts ət dɪɡɪŋ wɛlz hæd feɪld ən hæf ðə pipəl hæd muvd əweɪ. wɪlɝ wəd nɑt daɪ æftɝ ɔl. θɹi mɔɹ əntʌtʃt vɪlədʒəz hæd bɪn fɑloʊɾ ɪn kwɪk səksɛʃən, ɔl ɪn wʌn deɪ, baɪ sæməhə, wɛɹ ɛvɹi wɛl ɪn taʊn hæd ɡɔn dʒɹaɪ dʒʌs ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ, ən pipəl wɝ mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt ðə dɑɹk wʌn; ðən tɑlən, wɛɹ ɔl ði oʊld ɑɹɡjəməns ðə vɪlədʒ hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn hæd bʌbəl tə ðə sɝfəs laɪk oʊvɝfloʊɪŋ sɛspɪts ə mɔɹnɪŋ ɝliɝ, ən ɪt hæd teɪkən θɹi mɝɾɝz tə ʃɑk ɛvɹiwʌn bæk tə hɪz sɛnsɪz; ən faɪnəli faɪəl, wɛɹ ðə kɹɑps ðɪs spɹɪŋ lʊk tə bi ðə pʊɹɪst ɛniwʌn kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ, bʌt ðə meɪɝ, dɪɡɪŋ ə nu pɹɪvi bɪhaɪn ɪz haʊs, hæd faʊn ɹɑɾɪd lɛðɝ sæks fʊl ʌv ɡoʊld, soʊ nʌn wəd ɡoʊ hʌŋɡɹi. noʊ wʌn ɪn faɪəl ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə fæt kɔɪnz, wɪð ə wʊmənz feɪs ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən ən iɡəl ɑn ði ʌðɝ; mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ðeɪ hæd bɪn mɪntɪɾ ɪn meɪnɛðɝən.

But after those came a little place named Willar, and it was celebrating. The spring on the village common was flowing again, after a year of hauling water a mile from a stream when all efforts at digging wells had failed and half the people had moved away. Willar would not die after all. Three more untouched villages had been followed in quick succession, all in one day, by Samaha, where every well in town had gone dry just the night before, and people were muttering about the Dark One; then Tallan, where all the old arguments the village had ever known had bubbled to the surface like overflowing cesspits a morning earlier, and it had taken three murders to shock everyone back to his senses; and finally Fyall, where the crops this spring looked to be the poorest anyone could remember, but the Mayor, digging a new privy behind his house, had found rotted leather sacks full of gold, so none would go hungry. No one in Fyall recognized the fat coins, with a woman's face on one side and an eagle on the other; Moiraine said they had been minted in Manetheren.

pɛɹɪn hæd faɪnəli æskt əɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt, əz ðeɪ sæɾ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ kæmpfaɪɝ wʌn naɪt. "æftɝ dʒɹə, aɪ θɔt. . . . ðeɪ wɝ ɔl soʊ hæpi, wɪð ðɛɹ wɛɾɪŋz. ivən ðə waɪtkloʊks wɝ oʊnli meɪd tə lʊk laɪk fulz. faɪəl wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt - ɹænd kʊdn əv hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðɛɹ kɹɑps; ðeɪ wɝ feɪlɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i ɛvɝ keɪm, ən ðət ɡoʊld wɑz ʃʊɹli ɡʊd, wɪð ðɛɹ nid - bʌɾ ɔl ðɪs ʌðɝ. . . . ðət taʊn bɝnɪŋ, ən ðə wɛlz feɪlɪŋ, ænd. . . . ðəɾ ɪz ivəl, mɔɪɹeɪn. aɪ kæn bɪliv ɹænd ɪz ivəl. ðə pæɾɝn meɪ bi ʃeɪpɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn hɪm, bʌt haʊ kən ðə pæɾɝn bi ðəɾ ivəl? ɪt meɪks noʊ sɛns, ən θɪŋz əv tə meɪk sɛns. ɪf jə meɪk ə tul wɪð noʊ sɛns tə ɪt, ɪts weɪstəd mɛɾəl. ðə pæɾɝn wʊdn meɪk weɪst."

Perrin had finally asked her about it, as they sat around their campfire one night. "After Jarra, I thought. . . . They were all so happy, with their weddings. Even the Whitecloaks were only made to look like fools. Fyall was all right - Rand couldn't have had anything to do with their crops; they were failing before he ever came, and that gold was surely good, with their need - but all this other. . . . That town burning, and the wells failing, and. . . . That is evil, Moiraine. I can't believe Rand is evil. The Pattern may be shaping itself around him, but how can the Pattern be that evil? It makes no sense, and things have to make sense. If you make a tool with no sense to it, it's wasted metal. The Pattern wouldn't make waste."

læn ɡeɪv ɪm ə ɹaɪ lʊk, ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs tə meɪk ə sɝkəɾ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ kæmpsaɪt. lɔɪəl, ɔlɹɛɾi stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɪn ɪz blæŋkəts, lɪftəɾ ɪz hɛd tə lɪsən, ɪɹz pɹɪkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd.

Lan gave him a wry look, and vanished into the darkness to make a circuit around their campsite. Loial, already stretched out in his blankets, lifted his head to listen, ears pricking forward.

mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə taɪm, wɔɹmɪŋ əɹ hænz. faɪnəli ʃi spoʊk waɪl stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə fleɪmz. "ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ɪz ɡʊd, pɛɹɪn. ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz ɪz ivəl. ðə pæɾɝn ʌv eɪdʒ, ði eɪdʒ leɪs ɪtsɛlf, ɪz niðɝ. ðə pæɾɝn ɪz wʌɾ ɪz. ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ɔl laɪvz ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn, ɔl ækʃənz. ə pæɾɝn ðəɾ ɪz ɔl wʌn kʌlɝ ɪz noʊ pæɾɝn. fəɹ ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ, ɡʊɾ ən ɪl ɑɹ ðə wɔɹp ən ðə wuf."

Moiraine was silent for a time, warming her hands. Finally she spoke while staring into the flames. "The Creator is good, Perrin. The Father of Lies is evil. The Pattern of Age, the Age Lace itself, is neither. The Pattern is what is. The Wheel of Time weaves all lives into the Pattern, all actions. A pattern that is all one color is no pattern. For the Pattern of an Age, good and ill are the warp and the woof."

ivən ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu leɪt-æftɝnun sʌnʃaɪn θɹi deɪz leɪɾɝ, pɛɹɪn fɛl ðə tʃɪl i hæd hæɾ ɑn fɝs hɪɹɪŋ əɹ seɪ ðoʊz wɝdz. hi wɑntəd tə bɪliv ðə pæɾɝn wɑz ɡʊd. hi wɑntəd tə bɪliv ðət wən mɛn dɪɾ ivəl θɪŋz, ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ əɡɛns ðə pæɾɝn, dɪstɔɹɾɪŋ ɪt. tə hɪm ðə pæɾɝn wɑz ə faɪn ən ɪntʃɹəkət kɹieɪʃən meɪd baɪ ə mæstɝ smɪθ. ðəɾ ɪt mɪks pɑt mɛɾəl ən wɝs ɪn wɪð ɡʊd stil wɪð nɛvɝ ə kɛɹ wɑz ə koʊl θɔt.

Even riding through late-afternoon sunshine three days later, Perrin felt the chill he had had on first hearing her say those words. He wanted to believe the Pattern was good. He wanted to believe that when men did evil things, they were going against the Pattern, distorting it. To him the Pattern was a fine and intricate creation made by a master smith. That it mixed pot metal and worse in with good steel with never a care was a cold thought.

"aɪ kɛɹ," hi mʌɾɝd sɔfli. "laɪt, aɪ də kɛɹ." mɔɪɹeɪn ɡlæns bæk ət hɪm, ən i fɛl saɪlənt. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kɛɹɾ əbaʊt, bɪɑn ɹænd.

"I care," he muttered softly. "Light, I do care." Moiraine glanced back at him, and he fell silent. He was not sure what the Aes Sedai cared about, beyond Rand.

ə fju mɪnəts leɪɾɝ læn əpɪɹd fɹəm əhɛɾ ən swʌŋ ɪz blæk wɔɹ hɔɹs ɪn bɪsaɪd mɔɪɹeɪnz mɛɹ. "ɹɛmən laɪz dʒʌst oʊvɝ ðə nɛks hɪl," hi sɛd. "ðeɪ hæv hæɾ ən ɪvɛnfəl deɪ əɹ tu, ɪt simz."

A few minutes later Lan appeared from ahead and swung his black war horse in beside Moiraine's mare. "Remen lies just over the next hill," he said. "They have had an eventful day or two, it seems."

lɔɪəlz ɪɹz twɪtʃt wʌns. "ɹænd?"

Loial's ears twitched once. "Rand?"

ðə wɔɹɾɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ. pɝhæps mɔɪɹeɪn kən seɪ, wən ʃi siz." ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪv ɪm ə sɝtʃɪŋ lʊk, ðən hild əɹ waɪt mɛɹ tə ə kwɪkɝ stɛp.

The Warder shook his head. "I do not know. Perhaps Moiraine can say, when she sees." The Aes Sedai gave him a searching look, then heeled her white mare to a quicker step.

ðeɪ tɑp ðə hɪl, ən ɹɛmən leɪ spɹɛɾ aʊt bɪloʊ ðɛm, hɑɹɾ əɡɛns ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðə meɪnɛðɹəndʒɹɛl stʃɹɛtʃt mɔɹ ðən hæf ə maɪl waɪd hɪɹ, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bɹɪdʒ, ðoʊ tu kɹaʊɾəd, bɑɹdʒ laɪk fɛɹiz kɹɛpt əkɹɔs, pɹəpɛl baɪ lɔŋ ɔɹz, ən wʌn nɪɹli ɛmpti wɑz ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. θɹi mɔɹ ʃɛɹd lɔŋ stoʊn dɑks wɪð nɪɹli ə dʌzən ɹɪvɝ tʃɹeɪɾɝz' vɛsəlz, səm wɪð wʌn mæst, səm wɪð tu. ə fju bʌlki ɡɹeɪ stoʊn wɛɹhaʊzɪz sɛpɝeɪɾəd ðə dɑks fɹəm ðə taʊn ɪtsɛlf, wɛɹ ðə bɪldɪŋz simd moʊsli ʌv stoʊn, əz wɛl, ðoʊ ɹuft ɪn taɪlz ʌv ɛvɹi kʌlɝ fɹəm jɛloʊ tə ɹɛd tə pɝpəl, ən ðə stʃɹits ɹæn ɛvɹi wɪtʃ weɪ ɝaʊn ə sɛntʃɹəl skwɛɹ.

They topped the hill, and Remen lay spread out below them, hard against the river. The Manetherendrelle stretched more than half a mile wide here, and there was no bridge, though two crowded, barge like ferries crept across, propelled by long oars, and one nearly empty was returning. Three more shared long stone docks with nearly a dozen river traders' vessels, some with one mast, some with two. A few bulky gray stone warehouses separated the docks from the town itself, where the buildings seemed mostly of stone, as well, though roofed in tiles of every color from yellow to red to purple, and the streets ran every which way around a central square.

mɔɪɹeɪn pʊld ʌp ðə dip hʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk tə haɪɾ əɹ feɪs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹoʊd daʊn.

Moiraine pulled up the deep hood of her cloak to hide her face before they rode down.

əz juʒəwəl, ðə pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹits stɛɹɾ ət lɔɪəl, bʌt ðɪs taɪm pɛɹɪn hɝɾ ɔd mɝmɝz ʌv "oʊɡiɝ." lɔɪəl sæt stʃɹeɪɾɝ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl ðən i hæɾ ɪn səm taɪm, ən ɪz ɪɹz stʊd stʃɹeɪt, ən ə smaɪl dʒʌs kɝl ði ɛnz ə hɪz waɪd maʊθ. hi wɑz ɑbviəsli tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə lɛɾ ɑn ðəɾ i wɑz plizd, bʌɾ i lʊk laɪk ə kæt hævɪŋ ɪts ɪɹz skɹætʃt.

As usual, the people in the streets stared at Loial, but this time Perrin heard awed murmurs of "Ogier." Loial sat straighter in his saddle than he had in some time, and his ears stood straight, and a smile just curled the ends of his wide mouth. He was obviously trying not to let on that he was pleased, but he looked like a cat having its ears scratched.

ɹɛmən lʊk laɪk ɛni ʌv ə dʌzən taʊnz tə pɛɹɪn - ɪt wɑz fʊl ə mæn-meɪɾ ɝoʊməz ən mæn smɛl; wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋ smɛl ə ðə ɹɪvɝ, ʌv kɔɹs - ən i wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt læn cʊɾə mɛnt wən ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk stɝɾ əz i sɛntɪd sʌmθɪŋ - ɹɔŋ. əz sun əz ɪz noʊz tʊk ɪɾ ɪn, ɪt wɑz ɡɔn laɪk ə hɔɹs hɛɹ dʒɹɑpt ɑntu hɑt koʊlz, bʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪt. hi hæd smɛl ðə seɪm smɛl ət dʒɹə, ən ɪt hæd vænɪʃt ðə seɪm weɪ, ðɛn. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə twɪstəd wʌn əɹ ə nɛvɝbɹn - tʃɹɑlɑk, bɝn mi, nɑɾ ə twɪstəd wʌn! nɑɾ ə nɛvɝbɹn! eɪ mɹdʒɹɑl, ə feɪd, ə hæfmən, ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ ə nɛvɝbɹn! - nɑɾ ə tʃɹɑlɑk əɹ ə feɪd, jɛt ðə stɛntʃ hæd bɪn ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz ʃɑɹp, ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz vaɪl. bʌt wʌtɛvɝ ɡeɪv ɔf ðət sɛn lɛf noʊ læstɪŋ tʃɹeɪl, ɪt simd.

Remen looked like any of a dozen towns to Perrin - it was full of man-made aromas and man smell; with a strong smell of the river, of course - and he was wondering what Lan could have meant when the hair on the back of his neck stirred as he scented something - wrong. As soon as his nose took it in, it was gone like a horse hair dropped onto hot coals, but he remembered it. He had smelled the same smell at Jarra, and it had vanished the same way, then. It was not a Twisted One or a Neverborn - Trolloc, burn me, not a Twisted One! Not a Neverborn! A Myrddraal, a Fade, a Halfman, anything but a Neverborn! - not a Trolloc or a Fade, yet the stench had been every bit as sharp, every bit as vile. But whatever gave off that scent left no lasting trail, it seemed.

ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə taʊn skwɛɹ. wʌn ə ðə bɪɡ peɪvɪŋ blɑks hæd bɪn pɹaɪɾ ʌp, ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə skwɛɹ, soʊ ə ɡɪbət kəd bi ɪɹɛktəd. ə sɪŋɡəl θɪk tɪmbɝ ɹoʊz aʊɾ ə ðə dɝt, səpɔɹɾɪŋ ə bɹeɪs kɹɔspis fɹəm wɪtʃ hʌŋ ən aɪɝn keɪdʒ, ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ɪt fɔɹ peɪsɪz haɪ. ə tɔl mæn dʒɹɛst ɔl ɪn ɡɹeɪz ən bɹaʊnz sæɾ ɪn ðə keɪdʒ, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz niz ʌndɝ ɪz tʃɪn. hi hæd noʊ ɹum tə də ʌðɝwaɪz. θɹi smɔl bɔɪz wɝ pɪtʃɪŋ stoʊnz ət hɪm. ðə mæn lʊk stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, nɑt flɪntʃɪŋ wən ə stoʊn meɪɾ ɪt bɪtwin ðə bɑɹz. mɔɹ ðən wʌn tʃɹɪkəl ə blʌd steɪn ɪz feɪs. ðə taʊnzpipəl wɔkɪŋ baɪ peɪd noʊ mɔɹ maɪn tə wʌt ðə bɔɪz wɝ duɪŋ ðən ðə mæn dɪd, ðoʊ ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ðɛm lʊkt ət ðə keɪdʒ, moʊst ə ðɛm wɪð əpɹuvəl, ən səm wɪð fɪɹ.

They rode into the town square. One of the big paving blocks had been pried up, right in the middle of the square, so a gibbet could be erected. A single thick timber rose out of the dirt, supporting a braced crosspiece from which hung an iron cage, the bottom of it four paces high. A tall man dressed all in grays and browns sat in the cage, holding his knees under his chin. He had no room to do otherwise. Three small boys were pitching stones at him. The man looked straight ahead, not flinching when a stone made it between the bars. More than one trickle of blood stained his face. The townspeople walking by paid no more mind to what the boys were doing than the man did, though every last one of them looked at the cage, most of them with approval, and some with fear.

mɔɪɹeɪn meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn dɪsɡʌst.

Moiraine made a sound in her throat that might have been disgust.

"ðɛɹ ɪz mɔɹ," læn sɛd. "kʌm. aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi ɝeɪnʒd ɹumz əɾ ən ɪn. aɪ θɪŋk jəl faɪn ɪɾ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ."
