ədʒɹə bʌsəl fɹəm ɪz pleɪs baɪ ðə tɪlɝ, bʌt ʃi kɑmli sɛt daʊn əɹ bʌndəl ən sɛd bɹɪskli, "aɪ wɪl teɪk pæsədʒ daʊnɹɪvɝ . . . oʊ . . . seɪ, əz fɑɹ əz hiz ɡoʊɪŋ." ʃi nɑɾəd təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "aɪv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃənz tə slipɪŋ ɑn dɛk. koʊld ən wɛt də nɑt bɑðɝ mi."

Adarra bustled from his place by the tiller, but she calmly set down her bundle and said briskly, "I will take passage downriver . . . oh . . . say, as far as he is going." She nodded toward Perrin without looking at him. "I've no objections to sleeping on deck. Cold and wet do not bother me."

ə fju mɪnəts ə bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ fɑloʊd. ʃi pæst oʊvɝ θɹi sɪlvɝ mɑɹks, fɹaʊn ət ðə kɑpɝz ʃi ɡɑt bæk, ðən stʌft əm ɪndə hɝ pɝs ən keɪm fɔɹwɝd tə stæn bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn.

A few minutes of bargaining followed. She passed over three silver marks, frowned at the coppers she got back, then stuffed them into her purse and came forward to stand beside Perrin.

ʃi hæɾ ən ɝbəl sɛn tə hɝ, laɪɾ ən fɹɛʃ ən klin. ðoʊz dɑɹk, tɪltəɾ aɪz ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm oʊvɝ haɪ tʃikboʊnz, ðən tɝn tə lʊk bæk təwɔɹd ʃɔɹ. ʃi wɑz əbaʊɾ ɪz oʊn eɪdʒ, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd; hi kəd nɑt dɪsaɪɾ ɪf əɹ noʊz fɪɾ əɹ feɪs, əɹ dɑməneɪɾəd ɪt. jə ɑɹ ə ful, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. waɪ kɛɹ wʌt ʃi lʊks laɪk?

She had an herbal scent to her, light and fresh and clean. Those dark, tilted eyes regarded him over high cheekbones, then turned to look back toward shore. She was about his own age, he decided; he could not decide if her nose fit her face, or dominated it. You are a fool, Perrin Aybara. Why care what she looks like?

ðə ɡæp tə ðə wɔɹf wɑz ə ɡʊd twɛnti peɪsɪz, naʊ; ðə swips dʌɡ ɪn, kʌɾɪŋ waɪt fɝoʊz ɪn blæk wɔɾɝ. fəɹ ə moʊmən i kənsɪɾɝd tɔsɪŋ əɹ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd.

The gap to the wharf was a good twenty paces, now; the sweeps dug in, cutting white furrows in black water. For a moment he considered tossing her over the side.

"wɛl," ʃi sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt, "aɪ nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd maɪ tʃɹævəlz tə teɪk mi bæk tə ɪljən soʊ sun əz ðɪs." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz haɪ, ən ʃi hæɾ ə flæt weɪ ʌv spikɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ənplɛzənt. "ju ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɪljən, ɑɹ jə nɑt?" hi taɪɾənd ɪz maʊθ. "doʊn sʌlk," ʃi sɛd. "ju lɛf kwaɪɾ ə mɛs bæk ðɛɹ, jə ən ðəɾ ilmən bɪtwin ju. ði ʌpɹɔɹ wɑz dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ wən aɪ lɛft."

"Well," she said after a moment, "I never expected my travels to take me back to Illian so soon as this." Her voice was high, and she had a flat way of speaking, but it was not unpleasant. "You are going to Illian, are you not?" He tightened his mouth. "Don't sulk," she said. "You left quite a mess back there, you and that Aielman between you. The uproar was just beginning when I left."

"ju dɪd nɑt tɛl ðɛm?" hi sɛɾ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz.

"You did not tell them?" he said in surprise.

"ðə taʊnzfoʊk θɪŋk ði ilmən tʃud θɹu ðə tʃeɪn, əɹ bɹoʊk ɪt wɪð ɪz bɛɹ hænz. ðeɪ hæd nɑt dɪsaɪɾɪd wɪtʃ wən aɪ lɛft." ʃi meɪɾ ə saʊn səspɪʃəsli laɪk ə ɡɪɡəl. "ɔɹbən wɑz kwaɪt laʊɾ ɪn ɪz dɪsɡʌs ðəɾ ɪz wunz wəd kip ɪm fɹəm hʌntɪŋ daʊn ði ilmən pɝsənəli."

"The townsfolk think the Aielman chewed through the chain, or broke it with his bare hands. They had not decided which when I left." She made a sound suspiciously like a giggle. "Orban was quite loud in his disgust that his wounds would keep him from hunting down the Aielman personally."

pɛɹɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "ɪf i ɛvɝ siz ən il əɡɛn, hɪl blʌɾi sɔɪl hɪmsɛlf." hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən mʌɾɝd, "sɑɹi."

Perrin snorted. "If he ever sees an Aiel again, he'll bloody soil himself." He cleared his throat and muttered, "Sorry."

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ əbaʊt ðæt," ʃi sɛd, əz ɪf ɪz ɹɪmɑɹk hæd bɪn nʌθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. "aɪ sɔ hɪm ɪn dʒəhænə dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɪntɝ. hi fɔt fɔɹ mɛn təɡɛðɝ, kɪl tu ən meɪd ði ʌðɝ tu jild. ʌv kɔɹs, hi stɑɹɾəd ðə faɪt, soʊ ðət teɪks sʌmθɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɪt, bʌt ðeɪ nu wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ. hi dɪd nɑt pɪk ə faɪt wɪð mɛn u kəd nɑt dɪfɛn ðɛmsɛlvz. stɪl, hiz ə ful. hiz ðiz pəkjuljɝ aɪdiəz əbaʊt ðə ɡɹeɪt blækwʊd. wʌt səm kɔl ðə fɔɹəst ə ʃædoʊz. hæv jə ɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɪt?"

"I do not know about that," she said, as if his remark had been nothing out of the way. "I saw him in Jehannah during the winter. He fought four men together, killed two and made the other two yield. Of course, he started the fight, so that takes something away from it, but they knew what they were doing. He did not pick a fight with men who could not defend themselves. Still, he is a fool. He has these peculiar ideas about the Great Blackwood. What some call the Forest of Shadows. Have you ever heard of it?"

hi aɪɾ əɹ saɪdweɪz. ʃi spoʊk ə faɪɾɪŋ ən kɪlɪŋ əz kɑmli əz ənʌðɝ wʊmən maɪt spik ə beɪkɪŋ. hi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛni ɡɹeɪt blækwʊd, bʌt ðə fɔɹəst ə ʃædoʊz leɪ dʒʌst saʊθ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. "ɑɹ jə fɑloʊɪŋ mi? jə wɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət mi, bæk ət ði ɪn. waɪ? ən waɪ dɪdn jə tɛl əm wʌt jə sɔ?"

He eyed her sideways. She spoke of fighting and killing as calmly as another woman might speak of baking. He had never heard of any Great Blackwood, but the Forest of Shadows lay just south of the Two Rivers. "Are you following me? You were staring at me, back at the inn. Why? And why didn't you tell them what you saw?"

"æn oʊɡiɝ," ʃi sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɹɪvɝ, "ɪz ɑbviəsli ən oʊɡiɝ, ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ nɑt mʌtʃ mɔɹ dɪfəkəl tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt. aɪ mænədʒd ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ lʊk ɪnsaɪd leɪɾi ælizəz hʊd ðən ɔɹbən dɪd, ən əɹ feɪs meɪks ðət stoʊn-feɪs fɛloʊ ə wɔɹɾɝ. ðə laɪt bɝn mi ɪf aɪd wɑn ðət wʌn æŋɡɹi wɪð mi. dʌz i ɔlweɪz lʊk laɪk ðæt, əɹ dɪɾ i iɾ ə ɹɑk fəɹ ɪz læs mil? ɛniweɪ, ðət lɛft oʊnli ju. aɪ də nɑt laɪk θɪŋz aɪ kænɑɾ əkaʊn fɔɹ."

"An Ogier," she said, staring at the river, "is obviously an Ogier, and the others were not much more difficult to figure out. I managed a much better look inside Lady Alys's hood than Orban did, and her face makes that stone-faced fellow a Warder. The Light burn me if I'd want that one angry with me. Does he always look like that, or did he eat a rock for his last meal? Anyway, that left only you. I do not like things I cannot account for."

wʌns əɡɛn i kənsɪɾɝd tɔsɪŋ əɹ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd. sɪɹiəsli, ðɪs taɪm. bʌt ɹɛmən wɑz naʊ oʊnli ə blɑtʃ ə laɪt wɛl bɪhaɪn əm ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ən noʊ tɛlɪŋ haʊ fɑɹ ɪt wɑz tə ʃɔɹ.

Once again he considered tossing her over the side. Seriously, this time. But Remen was now only a blotch of light well behind them in the darkness, and no telling how far it was to shore.

ʃi sim tə teɪk ɪz saɪləns əz ən ɝdʒɪŋ tə ɡoʊ ɑn. "soʊ ðəɹ aɪ hæv æn" - ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ðən dʒɹɑpt əɹ vɔɪs, ðoʊ ðə kloʊsəs kɹumən wɑz wɝkɪŋ ə swip tɛn fiɾ əweɪ - "æn ɛɛs sədaɪ, ə wɔɹɾɝ, ən oʊɡiɝ - ən ju. ə kʌntʃɹimən, baɪ fɝs lʊk ət ju." hɝ tɪltəɾ aɪz ɹoʊz tə stʌɾi hɪz jɛloʊ wʌnz ɪntɛnli - hi ɹəfjuz tə lʊk əweɪ - ən ʃi smaɪld. "oʊnli jə fɹi ə keɪdʒd ilmən, hoʊld ə lɔŋ tɔk wɪð hɪm, ðən hɛlp ɪm tʃɑp ə dʌzən waɪtkloʊks ɪndə sɔsədʒ. aɪ əsum jə də ðɪs ɹɛɡjəlɝli; jə sɝɾənli lʊkt əz ɪf ɪt wɝ nʌθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi fəɹ ju. aɪ sɛn sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪn ə pɑɹɾi ʌv tʃɹævəlɝz sətʃ əz jʊɹz, ən stʃɹeɪnʒ tʃɹeɪlz ɑɹ wʌt hʌntɝz lʊk fɔɹ."

She seemed to take his silence as an urging to go on. "So there I have an" - she looked around, then dropped her voice, though the closest crewman was working a sweep ten feet away - "an Aes Sedai, a Warder, an Ogier - and you. A countryman, by first look at you." Her tilted eyes rose to study his yellow ones intently - he refused to look away - and she smiled. "Only you free a caged Aielman, hold a long talk with him, then help him chop a dozen Whitecloaks into sausage. I assume you do this regularly; you certainly looked as if it were nothing out of the ordinary for you. I scent something strange in a party of travelers such as yours, and strange trails are what Hunters look for."

hi blɪŋkt; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðəɾ ɛmfəsəs. "eɪ hʌntɝ? ju? jə kænɑt bi ə hʌntɝ. jəɹ ə ɡɝl."

He blinked; there was no mistaking that emphasis. "A Hunter? You? You cannot be a Hunter. You're a girl."

hɝ smaɪl bɪkeɪm soʊ ɪnəsən ðəɾ i ɔlmoʊst wɔkt əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. ʃi stɛp bæk, meɪɾ ə flɝɪʃ wɪð itʃ hænd, ən wɑz hoʊldɪŋ tu naɪvz əz nitli əz oʊl tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn cʊɾə dʌn ɪt. wʌn ə ðə mɛn ət ðə swips meɪɾ ə tʃoʊkɪŋ saʊnd, ən tu ʌðɝz stʌmbəld; swips θɹæʃt ən tæŋɡəld, ən ðə snoʊ ɡus lɝtʃt ə lɪɾəl bɪfɔɹ ðə kæptənz ʃaʊts sɛt θɪŋz ɹaɪt. baɪ ðət taɪm, ðə blæk-hɛɹd ɡɝl hæd meɪd ðə naɪvz dɪsəpɪɹ əɡɛn.

Her smile became so innocent that he almost walked away from her. She stepped back, made a flourish with each hand, and was holding two knives as neatly as old Thom Merrilin could have done it. One of the men at the sweeps made a choking sound, and two others stumbled; sweeps thrashed and tangled, and the Snow Goose lurched a little before the captain's shouts set things right. By that time, the black-haired girl had made the knives disappear again.

"nɪmbəl fɪŋɡɝz ən nɪmbəl wɪts wɪl teɪk jə ə ɡʊd dil fɝðɝ ðən ə sɔɹɾ ən mʌsəlz. ʃɑɹp aɪz hɛlp, əz wɛl, bʌt fɔɹtʃənətli, aɪ hæv ðiz θɪŋz."

"Nimble fingers and nimble wits will take you a good deal further than a sword and muscles. Sharp eyes help, as well, but fortunately, I have these things."

"æn mɑɾəsti, əz wɛl," pɛɹɪn mɝmɝd. ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs.

"And modesty, as well," Perrin murmured. She did not seem to notice.

"aɪ tʊk ði oʊθ ən ɹəsiv ðə blɛsɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt skwɛɹ ə tæməz, ɪn ɪljən. pɝhæps aɪ wɑz ðə jʌŋɡəst, bʌɾ ɪn ðət kɹaʊd, wɪð ɔl ðə tʃɹʌmpəts ən dʒɹʌmz ən sɪmbəlz ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ. . . . ə sɪks-jɪɹ-oʊld cʊɾə teɪkən ði oʊθ, ən nʌn wəɾ əv noʊɾəst. ðəɹ wɝ oʊvɝ ə θaʊzən ʌv ʌs, pɝhæps tu, ən ɛvɹi wʌn wɪð ən aɪdiə ʌv wɛɹ tə faɪn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. aɪ hæv maɪn - ɪt stɪl meɪ bi ðə ɹaɪt wʌn - bʌt noʊ hʌntɝ kən əfɔɹd tə pæs ʌp ə stʃɹeɪnʒ tʃɹeɪl. ðə hɔɹn wɪl sɝɾənli laɪ ət ði ɛn ʌv ə stʃɹeɪnʒ tʃɹeɪl, ən aɪ hæv nɛvɝ sin wʌn ɛni stʃɹeɪnʒɝ ðən ðə tʃɹeɪl jə fɔɹ meɪk. wɛɹ ɑɹ jə baʊnd? ɪljən? sʌmwɛɹ ɛls?"

"I took the oath and received the blessing in the Great Square of Tammaz, in Illian. Perhaps I was the youngest, but in that crowd, with all the trumpets and drums and cymbals and shouting. . . . A six-year-old could have taken the oath, and none would have noticed. There were over a thousand of us, perhaps two, and every one with an idea of where to find the Horn of Valere. I have mine - it still may be the right one - but no Hunter can afford to pass up a strange trail. The Horn will certainly lie at the end of a strange trail, and I have never seen one any stranger than the trail you four make. Where are you bound? Illian? Somewhere else?"

"wʌt wɑz jəɹ aɪdiə?" hi æskt. "əbaʊt wɛɹ ðə hɔɹn ɪz?" seɪf ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, aɪ hoʊp, ən ðə laɪt sɛn aɪ nɛvɝ si ɪɾ əɡɛn. "ju θɪŋk ɪts ɪn ɡildən?"

"What was your idea?" he asked. "About where the Horn is?" Safe in Tar Valon, I hope, and the Light send I never see it again. "You think it's in Ghealdan?"

ʃi fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm - hi hæd ðə filɪŋ ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ʌp ə sɛnt wʌns ʃi hæd ɹeɪzd ɪt, bʌɾ i wɑz ɹɛɾi tə ɔfɝ əɹ əz mɛni saɪd tʃɹeɪlz əz ʃi wəd teɪk - ðən sɛd, "hæv jə ɛvɝ hɝɾ ə meɪnɛðɝən?"

She frowned at him - he had the feeling she did not give up a scent once she had raised it, but he was ready to offer her as many side trails as she would take - then said, "Have you ever heard of Manetheren?"

hi nɪɹli tʃoʊkt. "aɪ hæv hɝɾ ʌv ɪt," hi sɛd kɔʃəsli.

He nearly choked. "I have heard of it," he said cautiously.

"ɛvɹi kwin ə meɪnɛðɝən wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðə kɪŋ ðə wɔɹɾɝ baʊn tə hɝ. aɪ kæn ɪmædʒən ə pleɪs laɪk ðæt, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz wʌt ðə bʊks seɪ. ɪt wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ lænd - moʊst ʌv ændɝ ən ɡildən ən mɔɹ bɪsaɪdz - bʌt ðə kæpəɾəl, ðə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf, wɑz ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. ðəɾ ɪz wɛɹ aɪ θɪŋk ðə hɔɹn ɪz. ənlɛs jə fɔɹ lɛd mi tə ɪt."

"Every queen of Manetheren was an Aes Sedai, and the king the Warder bound to her. I can't imagine a place like that, but that is what the books say. It was a large land - most of Andor and Ghealdan and more besides - but the capital, the city itself, was in the Mountains of Mist. That is where I think the Horn is. Unless you four lead me to it."

hɪz hækəlz stɝd. ʃi wɑz lɛktʃɝɪŋ ɪm əz ɪf i wɝ ən əntɔt vɪlədʒ laʊt. "jul nɑt faɪn ðə hɔɹn əɹ meɪnɛðɝən. ðə sɪɾi wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, wən ðə læs kwin dʒɹu tu mʌtʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz u hæd kɪld əɹ hʌzbənd." mɔɪɹeɪn hæd toʊld ɪm ðə neɪmz ə ðət kɪŋ ən kwin, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɛm.

His hackles stirred. She was lecturing him as if he were an untaught village lout. "You'll not find the Horn or Manetheren. The city was destroyed during the Trolloc Wars, when the last queen drew too much of the One Power to destroy the Dreadlords who had killed her husband." Moiraine had told him the names of that king and queen, but he did not remember them.

"nɑɾ ɪn meɪnɛðɝən, fɑɹmbɔɪ," ʃi sɛd kɑmli, "ðoʊ ə læn sətʃ əz ðət wəd meɪk ə ɡʊd haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs. bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ neɪʃənz, ʌðɝ sɪɾiz, ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, soʊ oʊl ðət nɑɾ ivən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɛm. ən θɪŋk ʌv ɔl ðoʊz stɔɹiz əbaʊɾ ɪt biɪŋ bæd lʌk tə ɛntɝ ðə maʊntənz. wʌt bɛɾɝ pleɪs fəɹ ðə hɔɹn tə bi hɪɾən ðən ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz fɝɡɑɾən sɪɾiz."

"Not in Manetheren, farmboy," she said calmly, "though a land such as that would make a good hiding place. But there were other nations, other cities, in the Mountains of Mist, so old that not even Aes Sedai remember them. And think of all those stories about it being bad luck to enter the mountains. What better place for the Horn to be hidden than in one of those forgotten cities."

"aɪ hæv hɝd stɔɹiz ə sʌmθɪŋ biɪŋ hɪɾən ɪn ðə maʊntənz." wəd ʃi bɪliv hɪm? hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɡʊɾ ət laɪɪŋ. "ðə stɔɹiz dɪd nɑt seɪ wʌt, bʌɾ ɪts səpoʊz tə bi ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst tʃɹɛʒɝ ɪn ðə wɝld, soʊ meɪbi ɪts ðə hɔɹn. bʌt ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst stʃɹɛtʃ fəɹ hʌnʒɹədz ə liɡz. ɪf jə ɑɹ gɑnə faɪn ɪt, jə ʃəd nɑt weɪs taɪm fɑloʊɪŋ ʌs. jəl niɾ ɪɾ ɔl tə faɪn ðə hɔɹn bɪfɔɹ ɔɹbən ən ɡæn."

"I have heard stories of something being hidden in the mountains." Would she believe him? He had never been good at lying. "The stories did not say what, but it's supposed to be the greatest treasure in the world, so maybe it is the Horn. But the Mountains of Mist stretch for hundreds of leagues. If you are going to find it, you should not waste time following us. You'll need it all to find the Horn before Orban and Gann."

"aɪ toʊl ju, ðoʊz tu hæv səm stʃɹeɪnʒ aɪdiə ðə hɔɹn ɪz hɪɾən ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt blækwʊd." ʃi smaɪld ʌp ət hɪm. hɝ maʊθ wɑz nɑt tu bɪɡ əɾ ɔl, wən ʃi smaɪld. "æn aɪ toʊl jə ə hʌntɝ əz tə fɑloʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ tʃɹeɪlz. jə ɑɹ lʌki ɔɹbən ən ɡæn wɝ ɪnʒɝd faɪɾɪŋ ɔl ðoʊz ilmɛn, əɹ ðeɪ maɪt wɛl bi əbɔɹd, tu. ət list əl nɑt ɡɛɾ ɪn jəɹ weɪ, əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə teɪk oʊvɝ, əɹ pɪk ə faɪt wɪð ðə wɔɹɾɝ."

"I told you, those two have some strange idea the Horn is hidden in the Great Blackwood." She smiled up at him. Her mouth was not too big at all, when she smiled. "And I told you a Hunter has to follow strange trails. You are lucky Orban and Gann were injured fighting all those Aielmen, or they might well be aboard, too. At least I will not get in your way, or try to take over, or pick a fight with the Warder."

hi ɡɹaʊl dɪsɡʌstɪdli. "wi ɑɹ dʒʌs tʃɹævəlɝz ɑn əɹ weɪ tə ɪljən, ɡɝl. wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ neɪm? ɪf aɪ hæv tə ʃɛɹ ðɪs ʃɪp wɪð jə fəɹ deɪz jɛt, aɪ kæn kip kɔlɪŋ jə ɡɝl."

He growled disgustedly. "We are just travelers on our way to Illian, girl. What is your name? If I have to share this ship with you for days yet, I can't keep calling you girl."

"aɪ kɔl maɪsɛlf mændɑɹb." hi kəd nɑt stɑp ðə ɡʌfɔ ðət bɝst aʊɾ ə hɪm. ðoʊz tɪltəɾ aɪz ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm wɪð hit. "aɪ wɪl titʃ jə sʌmθɪŋ, fɑɹmbɔɪ." hɝ vɔɪs ɹɪmeɪn lɛvəl. bɛɹli. "ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, mændɑɹb minz 'bleɪd.' ɪts ə neɪm wɝði ʌv ə hʌntɝ ə ðə hɔɹn!"

"I call myself Mandarb." He could not stop the guffaw that burst out of him. Those tilted eyes regarded him with heat. "I will teach you something, farmboy." Her voice remained level. Barely. "In the Old Tongue, Mandarb means 'blade.' It is a name worthy of a Hunter of the Horn!"

hi mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɪz læftɝ ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl, ən hɑɹdli wizd əɾ ɔl əz i pɔɪntəd tə ðə ɹoʊp pɛn bɪtwin ðə mæsts. "ju si ðət blæk stæljən? hɪz neɪm ɪz mændɑɹb."

He managed to get his laughter under control, and hardly wheezed at all as he pointed to the rope pen between the masts. "You see that black stallion? His name is Mandarb."

ðə hit wɛn aʊɾ ə hɝ aɪz, ən spɑts ə kʌlɝ blumd ɑn əɹ tʃiks. "oʊ. aɪ wɑz bɔɹn zɑɹin bæʃɪɹ, bʌt zɑɹin ɪz noʊ neɪm fəɹ ə hʌntɝ. ɪn ðə stɔɹiz, hʌntɝz əv neɪmz laɪk ɹəɡoʊʃ iɡəl-aɪ."

The heat went out of her eyes, and spots of color bloomed on her cheeks. "Oh. I was born Zarine Bashere, but Zarine is no name for a Hunter. In the stories, Hunters have names like Rogosh Eagle-eye."

ʃi lʊk soʊ kɹɛstfɔlən ðəɾ i heɪsən tə seɪ, "aɪ laɪk ðə neɪm zɑɹin. ɪt suts ju." ðə hit flæʃt bæk ɪndə hɝ aɪz, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən i θɔt ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə pɹədus wʌn ə hɝ naɪvz əɡɛn. "ɪɾ ɪz leɪt, zɑɹin. aɪ wɑn səm slip."

She looked so crestfallen that he hastened to say, "I like the name Zarine. It suits you." The heat flashed back into her eyes, and for a moment he thought she was about to produce one of her knives again. "It is late, Zarine. I want some sleep."

hi tɝn ɪz bæk tə stɑɹt fəɹ ðə hætʃ ðət lɛd bɛlaʊdɛk, pɹɪkəlz ɹʌnɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. kɹumɪn stɪl pæɾəd ʌp ðə dɛk ən bæk, wɝkɪŋ ðə swips. ful. ə ɡɝl wəd nɑt stɪk ə naɪf ɪn mi. nɑt wɪð ɔl ðiz pipəl wɑtʃɪŋ. wəd ʃi? dʒʌst əz i ɹitʃt ðə hætʃ, ʃi kɔl tə hɪm.

He turned his back to start for the hatch that led belowdeck, prickles running across his shoulders. Crewmen still padded up the deck and back, working the sweeps. Fool. A girl would not stick a knife in me. Not with all these people watching. Would she? Just as he reached the hatch, she called to him.

"fɑɹmbɔɪ! pɝhæps əl kɔl maɪsɛlf feɪl. maɪ fɑðɝ juz tə kɔl mi ðæt, wən aɪ wɑz lɪɾəl. ɪt minz 'fælkən.' "

"Farmboy! Perhaps I will call myself Faile. My father used to call me that, when I was little. It means 'falcon.' "

hi stɪfən ən ɔlmoʊs mɪs ðə fɝst stɛp ə ðə læɾɝ. koʊɪnsɪɾəns. hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf ɡoʊ daʊn wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd hɝ. ɪts tə bi. ðə pæsədʒweɪ wɑz dɑɹk, bʌɾ ɪnʌf munlaɪt fɪltɝd daʊn bɪhaɪn ɪm fəɹ ɪm tə meɪk ɪz weɪ. sʌmwʌn wɑz snɔɹɪŋ laʊdli ɪn wʌn ə ðə kæbənz. mɪn, waɪ dɪd juv tə ɡoʊ siɪŋ θɪŋz?

He stiffened and almost missed the first step of the ladder. Coincidence. He made himself go down without looking back toward her. It has to be. The passageway was dark, but enough moonlight filtered down behind him for him to make his way. Someone was snoring loudly in one of the cabins. Min, why did you have to go seeing things?


tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɪks


CHAPTER 36

dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪt


Daughter of the Night

ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ i hæd noʊ weɪ ʌv noʊɪŋ wɪtʃ kæbən wɑz səpoʊz tə bi hɪz, hi pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪndə sɛvɹəl. ðeɪ wɝ dɑɹk, ən ɔl ə ðɛm hæd tu mɛn əslip ɪn ðə nɛɹoʊ bɛdz bɪlt əɡɛnst itʃ saɪd, ɔl bʌt wʌn, wɪtʃ hɛld lɔɪəl, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪtwin ðə bɛdz - ən bɛɹli fɪɾɪŋ - skɹɪbəlɪŋ ɪn ɪz klɔθ-baʊn bʊk ə noʊts baɪ ðə laɪɾ ʌv ə ɡɪmbɔld læntɝn. ði oʊɡiɝ wɑntəd tə tɔk əbaʊt ði ɪvɛns ə ðə deɪ, bʌt pɛɹɪn, dʒɔz kɹikɪŋ wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ ə hoʊldɪŋ ɪz jɔnz ɪn, θɔt ðə ʃɪp mʌst əv ɹʌn fɑɹ ɪnʌf daʊnɹɪvɝ baɪ naʊ tə meɪk ɪt seɪf tə slip. seɪf tə dʒɹim. ivən ɪf ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd, wʊlvz kəd nɑt lɔŋ kip peɪs wɪð ðə swips ən ðə kɝənt.

Realizing that he had no way of knowing which cabin was supposed to be his, he put his head into several. They were dark, and all of them had two men asleep in the narrow beds built against each side, all but one, which held Loial, sitting on the floor between the beds - and barely fitting - scribbling in his cloth-bound book of notes by the light of a gimballed lantern. The Ogier wanted to talk about the events of the day, but Perrin, jaws creaking with the effort of holding his yawns in, thought the ship must have run far enough downriver by now to make it safe to sleep. Safe to dream. Even if they tried, wolves could not long keep pace with the sweeps and the current.

faɪnəli hi faʊn ə wɪndoʊləs kæbən wɪð noʊ wʌn ɪn ɪɾ əɾ ɔl, wɪtʃ suɾəd ɪm dʒʌst əz wɛl. hi wɑntəd tə bi əloʊn. ə koʊɪnsɪɾəns ɪn ðə neɪm, ðæts ɔl, hi θɔɾ əz i lɪt ðə læntɝn maʊntəɾ ɑn ðə wɔl. ɛniweɪ, hɝ ɹil neɪm ɪz zɑɹin. bʌt ðə ɡɝl wɪð ðə haɪ tʃikboʊnz ən dɑɹk, tɪltəɾ aɪz wɑz nɑɾ ʌpɝmoʊst ɪn ɪz θɔts. hi pʊɾ ɪz baʊ ən ʌðɝ bɪlɔŋɪŋz ɑn wʌn kɹæmp bɛd, tɔst ɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ðɛm, ən sæɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ tə tʌɡ ɔf ɪz buts.

Finally he found a windowless cabin with no one in it at all, which suited him just as well. He wanted to be alone. A coincidence in the name, that's all, he thought as he lit the lantern mounted on the wall. Anyway, her real name is Zarine. But the girl with the high cheekbones and dark, tilted eyes was not uppermost in his thoughts. He put his bow and other belongings on one cramped bed, tossed his cloak over them, and sat on the other to tug off his boots.

ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə hæd faʊn ə weɪ tə lɪv wɪð wʌɾ i wɑz, ə mæn sʌmhaʊ lɪŋkt wɪð wʊlvz, ən i hæd nɑt ɡɔn mæd. θɪŋkɪŋ bæk, pɛɹɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ɛlaɪəs hæd bɪn lɪvɪŋ ðət weɪ fəɹ jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ i ɛvɝ mɛt ðə mæn. hi wɑns tə bi ðət weɪ. hi æksɛps ɪt, ɛniweɪ. ðət wɑz noʊ səluʃən. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt wɑnə lɪv ðət weɪ, dɪd nɑt wɑnə æksɛpt. bʌɾ ɪf juv ðə bɑɹ stɑk tə meɪk ə naɪf, jə æksɛpt ɪɾ ən meɪk ə naɪf, ivən ɪf jud laɪk ə wʊdeɪks. noʊ! maɪ laɪf ɪz mɔɹ ðən aɪɝn tə bi hæmɝɾ ɪndə ʃeɪp.

Elyas Machera had found a way to live with what he was, a man somehow linked with wolves, and he had not gone mad. Thinking back, Perrin was sure Elyas had been living that way for years before he ever met the man. He wants to be that way. He accepts it, anyway. That was no solution. Perrin did not want to live that way, did not want to accept. But if you have the bar stock to make a knife, you accept it and make a knife, even if you'd like a woodaxe. No! My life is more than iron to be hammered into shape.

kɔʃəsli, hi ɹitʃt aʊt wɪð ɪz maɪnd, filɪŋ fəɹ wʊlvz, ən faʊnd - nʌθɪŋ. oʊ, ðəɹ wɑz ə dɪm ɪmpɹɛʃən ʌv wʊlvz sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə dɪstəns, bʌɾ ɪt feɪɾəd ivən əz i tʌtʃt ɪt. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn soʊ lɔŋ, hi wɑz əloʊn. blɛsədli əloʊn.

Cautiously, he reached out with his mind, feeling for wolves, and found - nothing. Oh, there was a dim impression of wolves somewhere in the distance, but it faded even as he touched it. For the first time in so long, he was alone. Blessedly alone.

bloʊɪŋ aʊt ðə læntɝn, hi leɪ daʊn, fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn deɪz. haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt wɪl lɔɪəl mænədʒ ɪn wʌn ə ðiz? ðoʊz ɔl bʌt slipləs naɪts ɹoʊld oʊvɝ hɪm, ɪɡzɔstʃən slækɪŋ ɪz mʌsəlz. ɪt keɪm tə hɪm ðəɾ i hæd mænədʒ tə pʊt ði il aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd. ən ðə waɪtkloʊks. laɪt-fɔɹseɪkən æks! bɝn mi, aɪ wɪʃ aɪ hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪt, wɑz ɪz læs θɔt bɪfɔɹ slip.

Blowing out the lantern, he lay down, for the first time in days. How in the Light will Loial manage in one of these? Those all but sleepless nights rolled over him, exhaustion slacking his muscles. It came to him that he had managed to put the Aiel out of his head. And the Whitecloaks. Light-forsaken axe! Burn me, I wish I had never seen it, was his last thought before sleep.

θɪk ɡɹeɪ fɑɡ sɝaʊndəd hɪm, dɛns ɪnʌf loʊ daʊn ðəɾ i kəd nɑt si hɪz oʊn buts, ən soʊ hɛvi ɑn ɛvɹi saɪd ðəɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ tɛn peɪsɪz əweɪ. ðəɹ wɑz ʃʊɹli nʌθɪŋ nɪɹɝ. ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl maɪt laɪ wɪðɪn ɪt. ðə mɪs dɪd nɑt fil ɹaɪt; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dæmpnəs tə ɪt. hi pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɪz bɛlt, sikɪŋ ðə kʌmfɝɾ ə noʊɪŋ i kəd dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf, ən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. hɪz æks wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ.

Thick gray fog surrounded him, dense enough low down that he could not see his own boots, and so heavy on every side that he could not make out anything ten paces away. There was surely nothing nearer. Anything at all might lie within it. The mist did not feel right; there was no dampness to it. He put a hand to his belt, seeking the comfort of knowing he could defend himself, and gave a start. His axe was not there.

sʌmθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə fɑɡ, ə swɝlɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪnəs. sʌmθɪŋ kʌmɪŋ ɪz weɪ.

Something moved in the fog, a swirling in the grayness. Something coming his way.

hi tɛnst, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ tə ɹʌn əɹ stæn ən faɪt wɪð ɪz bɛɹ hænz, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛniθɪŋ tə faɪt.

He tensed, wondering if it was better to run or stand and fight with his bare hands, wondering if there was anything to fight.

ðə bɪloʊɪŋ fɝoʊ bɔɹɪŋ θɹu ðə fɑɡ ɹizɑlvd ɪtsɛlf ɪndə ə wʊlf, ɪts ʃæɡi fɔɹm ɔlmoʊst wʌn wɪð ðə hɛvi mɪst.

The billowing furrow boring through the fog resolved itself into a wolf, its shaggy form almost one with the heavy mist.

hɑpɝ?

Hopper?

ðə wʊlf hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən keɪm tə stæn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɪt wɑz hɑpɝ - hi wɑz sɝɾən - bʌt sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə wʊlfs stæns, sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə jɛloʊ aɪz ðət lʊkt ʌp bɹifli tə mit hɪz, dɪmændəd saɪləns, ɪn maɪn əz wɛl əz bɑɾi. ðoʊz aɪz dɪmændəd ðəɾ i fɑloʊ, tu.

The wolf hesitated, then came to stand beside him. It was Hopper - he was certain - but something about the wolf's stance, something in the yellow eyes that looked up briefly to meet his, demanded silence, in mind as well as body. Those eyes demanded that he follow, too.

hi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ðə wʊlfs bæk, ən əz i dɪd, hɑpɝ stɑɹɾəd fɔɹwɝd. hi lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi lɛd. ðə fɝ ʌndɝ ɪz hænd wɑz θɪk ən ʃæɡi. ɪt fɛlt ɹil.

He laid a hand on the wolf's back, and as he did, Hopper started forward. He let himself be led. The fur under his hand was thick and shaggy. It felt real.

ðə fɑɡ bɪɡæn tə θɪkən, əntɪl oʊnli hɪz hæn toʊld ɪm hɑpɝ wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, əntɪl ə ɡlæns daʊn dɪd nɑɾ ivən ʃoʊ hɪm ɪz oʊn tʃɛst. dʒʌst ɡɹeɪ mɪst. hi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ɹæpt ɪn nu-ʃɪɹd wʊl fəɹ ɔl i kəd si. ɪt stʃɹʌk ɪm ðəɾ i hæd hɝd nʌθɪŋ, iðɝ. nɑɾ ivən ðə saʊn ə hɪz oʊn fʊtstɛps. hi wɪɡɡəld ɪz toʊz, ən wɑz ɹɪliv tə fil ðə buts ɑn ɪz fit.

The fog began to thicken, until only his hand told him Hopper was still there, until a glance down did not even show him his own chest. Just gray mist. He might as well have been wrapped in new-sheared wool for all he could see. It struck him that he had heard nothing, either. Not even the sound of his own footsteps. He wiggled his toes, and was relieved to feel the boots on his feet.

ðə ɡɹeɪ bɪkeɪm dɑɹkɝ, ən i ən ðə wʊlf wɔk θɹu pɪtʃ-blæknəs. hi kəd nɑt si hɪz hænd wən i tʌtʃt ɪz noʊz. hi kəd nɑt si hɪz noʊz, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. hi tʃɹaɪd kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən kəd nɑt tɛl ɛni dɪfɝəns. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl noʊ saʊnd. hɪz hæn fɛl ðə ɹʌf hɛɹ ə hɑpɝz bæk, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd fil ɛniθɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz buts.

The gray became darker, and he and the wolf walked through pitch-blackness. He could not see his hand when he touched his nose. He could not see his nose, for that matter. He tried closing his eyes for a moment, and could not tell any difference. There was still no sound. His hand felt the rough hair of Hopper's back, but he was not sure he could feel anything under his boots.

sʌɾənli hɑpɝ stɑpt, fɔɹsɪŋ ɪm tə hɔlt, tu. hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd . . . ən snæpt ɪz aɪz ʃʌt. hi kəd tɛl ə dɪfɝəns, naʊ. ən fil sʌmθɪŋ, tu, ə kwizi twɪstɪŋ ə hɪz stʌmək. hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən lʊk daʊn.

Suddenly Hopper stopped, forcing him to halt, too. He looked around . . . and snapped his eyes shut. He could tell a difference, now. And feel something, too, a queasy twisting of his stomach. He made himself open his eyes and look down.

wʌɾ i sɔ kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ðɛɹ, nɑɾ ənlɛs i ən hɑpɝ wɝ stændɪŋ ɪn mɪdɛɹ. hi kəd si nʌθɪŋ ə ðə wʊlf əɹ hɪmsɛlf, əz ɪf niðɝ hæd bɑɾiz əɾ ɔl - ðət θɔt nɪɹli taɪɾ ɪz stʌmək ɪndə nɑts - bʌt bɪloʊ hɪm, əz klɪɹ əz ɪf lɪt baɪ ə θaʊzən læmps, stʃɹɛtʃt ə væst ɝeɪ ʌv mɪɹɝz, simɪŋli hæŋɪŋ ɪn blæknəs ðoʊ əz lɛvəl əz ɪf ðeɪ stʊɾ ɑn ə væs flɔɹ. ðeɪ stʃɹɛtʃt əz fɑɹ əz i kəd si ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, bʌt ɹaɪt bɪniθ ɪz fit, ðəɹ wɑz ə klɪɹ speɪs. ən pipəl ɪn ɪt. sʌɾənli hi kəd hɪɹ ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz əz wɛl əz ɪf i hæd bɪn stændɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛm.

What he saw could not have been there, not unless he and Hopper were standing in midair. He could see nothing of the wolf or himself, as if neither had bodies at all - that thought nearly tied his stomach into knots - but below him, as clear as if lit by a thousand lamps, stretched a vast array of mirrors, seemingly hanging in blackness though as level as if they stood on a vast floor. They stretched as far as he could see in every direction, but right beneath his feet, there was a clear space. And people in it. Suddenly he could hear their voices as well as if he had been standing among them.

"ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd," wʌn ə ðə mɛn mʌɾɝd, "wɛɹ ɪz ðɪs pleɪs?" hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd wʌns, flɪntʃɪŋ əɾ ɪz ɪmədʒ kæs bæk əɾ ɪm mɛni θaʊzændfoʊld, ən hɛld ɪz aɪz fɔɹwɝɾ æftɝ ðæt. ði ʌðɝz hʌɾəld ɝaʊn ɪm simd ivən mɔɹ əfɹeɪd. "aɪ wɑz əslip ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. aɪm əslip ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn! wɛɹ ɪz ðɪs pleɪs? hæv aɪ ɡɔn mæd?"

"Great Lord," one of the men muttered, "where is this place?" He looked around once, flinching at his image cast back at him many thousandfold, and held his eyes forward after that. The others huddled around him seemed even more afraid. "I was asleep in Tar Valon, Great Lord. I am asleep in Tar Valon! Where is this place? Have I gone mad?"

səm ə ðə mɛn ɝaʊn ɪm wɔɹ ɔɹneɪt koʊts fʊl ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ʌðɝz pleɪnɝ ɡɑɹb, waɪl səm sim tə bi neɪkəd, əɹ ɪn ðɛɹ smɔlkloʊðz.

Some of the men around him wore ornate coats full of embroidery, others plainer garb, while some seemed to be naked, or in their smallclothes.

"aɪ, tu, slip," ə neɪkəd mæn nɪɹli skɹimd. "ɪn tɛɹ. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ laɪɪŋ daʊn wɪð maɪ waɪf!"

"I, too, sleep," a naked man nearly screamed. "In Tear. I remember lying down with my wife!"

"æn aɪ də slip ɪn ɪljən," ə mæn ɪn ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊl sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ʃeɪkən. "aɪ noʊ ðəɾ aɪ də slip, bʌt ðət kænɑt bi. aɪ noʊ ðəɾ aɪ də dʒɹim, bʌt ðət dʌz bi ɪmpɑsəbəl. wɛɹ dʌz ðɪs bi, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd? ɑɹ jə ɹɪli kʌm tə mi?"

"And I do sleep in Illian," a man in red and gold said, sounding shaken. "I know that I do sleep, but that cannot be. I know that I do dream, but that does be impossible. Where does this be, Great Lord? Are you really come to me?"

ðə dɑɹk-hɛɹd mæn u feɪst əm wɑz ɡɑɹbd ɪn blæk, wɪð sɪlvɝ leɪs əɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən ɹɪsts. naʊ ən əɡɛn i pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɪz tʃɛst, əz ɪf ɪt hɝt hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz laɪɾ ɛvɹiwɛɹ daʊn ðɛɹ, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm noʊwɛɹ, bʌt ðɪs mæn bɪloʊ pɛɹɪn sim kloʊkt ɪn ʃædoʊ. dɑɹknəs ɹoʊld ɝaʊn hɪm, kɝɛs hɪm.

The dark-haired man who faced them was garbed in black, with silver lace at his throat and wrists. Now and again he put a hand to his chest, as if it hurt him. There was light everywhere down there, coming from nowhere, but this man below Perrin seemed cloaked in shadow. Darkness rolled around him, caressed him.

"saɪləns!" ðə blæk-kloʊð mæn dɪd nɑt spik laʊdli, bʌɾ i hæd noʊ nid tə. fəɹ ðə speɪs ə ðət wɝd, hi hæd ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd; hɪz aɪz ən maʊθ wɝ hoʊlz bɔɹɪŋ ɪndə ə ɹeɪdʒɪŋ fɔɹdʒ-faɪɝ, ɔl fleɪm ən faɪɝi ɡloʊ.

"Silence!" The black-clothed man did not speak loudly, but he had no need to. For the space of that word, he had raised his head; his eyes and mouth were holes boring into a raging forge-fire, all flame and fiery glow.

pɛɹɪn nu hɪm, ðɛn. bælzəmən. hi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ət bælzəmən hɪmsɛlf. fɪɹ stʃɹʌk θɹu hɪm laɪk hæmɝd spaɪks. hi wəɾ əv ɹʌn, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt fil ɪz fit.

Perrin knew him, then. Ba'alzamon. He was staring down at Ba'alzamon himself. Fear struck through him like hammered spikes. He would have run, but he could not feel his feet.

hɑpɝ ʃɪftəd. hi fɛl ðə θɪk fɝ ʌndɝ ɪz hæn ən ɡɹɪpt ɪt hɑɹd. sʌmθɪŋ ɹil. sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ɹil, hi hoʊpt, ðən wʌɾ i sɔ. bʌɾ i nu ðət boʊθ wɝ ɹil.

Hopper shifted. He felt the thick fur under his hand and gripped it hard. Something real. Something more real, he hoped, than what he saw. But he knew that both were real.

ðə mɛn hʌɾəlɪŋ təɡɛðɝ kaʊɝd.

The men huddling together cowered.

"ju hæv bɪn ɡɪvən tæsks," bælzəmən sɛd. "sʌm ə ðiz tæsks juv kæɹiɾ aʊt. əɾ ʌðɝz, juv feɪld." naʊ ən əɡɛn ɪz aɪz ən maʊθ vænɪʃt ɪn fleɪm əɡɛn, ən ðə mɪɹɝz flæʃt wɪð ɹəflɛktəd faɪɝ. "ðoʊz u hæv bɪn mɑɹk fəɹ dɛθ mʌs daɪ. ðoʊz u hæv bɪn mɑɹk fəɹ teɪkɪŋ mʌs baʊ tə mi. tə feɪl ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk kænɑt bi fɝɡɪvən." faɪɝ ʃoʊn θɹu hɪz aɪz, ən ðə dɑɹknəs ɝaʊn ɪm ɹɔɪld ən spʌn. "ju." hɪz fɪŋɡɝ pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðə mæn u hæd spoʊkən ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ə fɛloʊ dʒɹɛs laɪk ə mɝtʃənt, ɪn pleɪnli kʌt kloʊðz ə ðə faɪnəs klɔθ. ði ʌðɝz ʃaɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɪm əz ɪf i hæd blækbəl fivɝ, livɪŋ ɪm tə kaʊɝ əloʊn. "ju əlaʊd ðə bɔɪ tə ɪskeɪp tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"You have been given tasks," Ba'alzamon said. "Some of these tasks you have carried out. At others, you have failed." Now and again his eyes and mouth vanished in flame again, and the mirrors flashed with reflected fire. "Those who have been marked for death must die. Those who have been marked for taking must bow to me. To fail the Great Lord of the Dark cannot be forgiven." Fire shone through his eyes, and the darkness around him roiled and spun. "You." His finger pointed out the man who had spoken of Tar Valon, a fellow dressed like a merchant, in plainly cut clothes of the finest cloth. The others shied away from him as if he had blackbile fever, leaving him to cower alone. "You allowed the boy to escape Tar Valon."

ðə mæn skɹimd, ən bɪɡæn tə kwɪvɝ laɪk ə faɪl stʃɹʌk əɡɛnst ən ænvəl. hi sim tə bɪkʌm lɛs sɑləd, ən ɪz skɹim θɪnd wɪð hɪm.

The man screamed, and began to quiver like a file struck against an anvil. He seemed to become less solid, and his scream thinned with him.

"ju ɔl dʒɹim," bælzəmən sɛd, "bʌt wʌt hæpənz ɪn ðɪs dʒɹim ɪz ɹil." ðə ʃɹikɪŋ mæn wɑz oʊnli ə bʌndəl ə mɪst ʃeɪp laɪk ə mæn, hɪz skɹim fɑɹ dɪstənt, ən ðən ivən ðə mɪst wɑz ɡɔn. "aɪ fɪɹ hɪl nɛvɝ weɪk." hi læft, ən ɪz maʊθ ɹɔɹd fleɪm. "ðə ɹɛst ə jəl nɑt feɪl mi əɡɛn. bɪɡɔn! weɪk, ən oʊbeɪ!" ði ʌðɝ mɛn vænɪʃt.

"You all dream," Ba'alzamon said, "but what happens in this dream is real." The shrieking man was only a bundle of mist shaped like a man, his scream far distant, and then even the mist was gone. "I fear he will never wake." He laughed, and his mouth roared flame. "The rest of you will not fail me again. Begone! Wake, and obey!" The other men vanished.

fəɹ ə moʊmən bælzəmən stʊɾ əloʊn, ðən sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɑz ə wʊmən wɪð hɪm, klæɾ ɔl ɪn waɪɾ ən sɪlvɝ.

For a moment Ba'alzamon stood alone, then suddenly there was a woman with him, clad all in white and silver.

ʃɑk hɪt pɛɹɪn. hi kəd nɛvɝ fɝɡɛɾ ə wʊmən soʊ bjuɾəfəl. ʃi wɑz ðə wʊmən fɹəm ɪz dʒɹim, ðə wʌn u hæɾ ɝdʒd ɪm tə ɡlɔɹi.

Shock hit Perrin. He could never forget a woman so beautiful. She was the woman from his dream, the one who had urged him to glory.

ən ɔɹneɪt sɪlvɝ θɹoʊn əpɪɹd bɪhaɪn hɝ, ən ʃi sæt, kɛɹfəli ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ sɪlkən skɝts. "ju meɪk fɹi jus ə maɪ doʊmeɪn," ʃi sɛd.

An ornate silver throne appeared behind her, and she sat, carefully arranging her silken skirts. "You make free use of my domain," she said.

"jɔɹ doʊmeɪn?" bælzəmən sɛd. "ju kleɪm ɪt jʊɹz, ðɛn? dʒju noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk?" ðə dɑɹknəs ɝaʊn ɪm θɪkən fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, sim tə bɔɪl.

"Your domain?" Ba'alzamon said. "You claim it yours, then? Do you no longer serve the Great Lord of the Dark?" The darkness around him thickened for an instant, seemed to boil.

"aɪ sɝv," ʃi sɛd kwɪkli. "aɪ hæv sɝv ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə twaɪlaɪt lɔŋ. lɔŋ dɪɾ aɪ laɪ ɪmpɹɪzən fəɹ maɪ sɝvəs, ɪn ən ɛnləs, dʒɹimləs slip. oʊnli ɡɹeɪ mɛn ən mɹdʒɹɑl ɑɹ dɪnaɪd dʒɹimz. ivən tʃɹɑləks kən dʒɹim. dʒɹimz wɝ ɔlweɪz maɪn, tə juz ən wɔk. naʊ aɪm fɹi əɡɛn, ən əl juz wʌɾ ɪz maɪn."

"I serve," she said quickly. "I have served the Lord of the Twilight long. Long did I lie imprisoned for my service, in an endless, dreamless sleep. Only Gray Men and Myrddraal are denied dreams. Even Trollocs can dream. Dreams were always mine, to use and walk. Now I am free again, and I will use what is mine."

"wʌɾ ɪz jʊɹz," bælzəmən sɛd. ðə blæknəs swɝlɪŋ 'ɹaʊn ɪm simd mɝθfəl. "ju ɔlweɪz θɔt jɝsɛlf ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən jə wɝ, lænfɝ."

"What is yours," Ba'alzamon said. The blackness swirling 'round him seemed mirthful. "You always thought yourself greater than you were, Lanfear."

ðə neɪm kʌɾ ət pɛɹɪn laɪk ə nuli hoʊnd naɪf. wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd bɪn ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. səm ə ðɛm wɝ fɹi.

The name cut at Perrin like a newly honed knife. One of the Forsaken had been in his dreams. Moiraine had been right. Some of them were free.

ðə wʊmən ɪn waɪt wɑz ɑn əɹ fit, ðə θɹoʊn ɡɔn. "aɪ æm əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz aɪ æm. wʌɾ əv jəɹ plænz kʌm tə? θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ən mɔɹ ʌv wɪspɝɪŋ ɪn ɪɹz ən pʊlɪŋ ðə stʃɹɪŋz ə θɹoʊn pʌpəts laɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ!" hɝ vɔɪs ɪnvɛstəd ðə neɪm wɪð ɔl skɔɹn. "θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz, ən jɛt luz θɝɪn wɔks ðə wɝld əɡɛn, ən ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔl bʌɾ əv ɪm liʃt. kən jə kəntʃɹoʊl hɪm? kən jə tɝn hɪm? hi wɑz maɪn bɪfɔɹ ɛvɝ ðət stʃɹɔ-hɛɹd tʃɪɾ aɪlaɪɛnə sɔ hɪm! hɪl bi maɪn əɡɛn!"

The woman in white was on her feet, the throne gone. "I am as great as I am. What have your plans come to? Three thousand years and more of whispering in ears and pulling the strings of throned puppets like an Aes Sedai!" Her voice invested the name with all scorn. "Three thousand years, and yet Lews Therin walks the world again, and these Aes Sedai all but have him leashed. Can you control him? Can you turn him? He was mine before ever that straw-haired chit Ilyena saw him! He will be mine again!"

"du jə sɝv jɝsɛlf naʊ, lænfɝ?" bælzəmənz vɔɪs wɑz sɑft, bʌt fleɪm ɹeɪdʒ kəntɪnjuəsli ɪn ɪz aɪz ən maʊθ. "hæv jə əbændən jəɹ oʊðz tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk?" fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðə dɑɹknəs nɪɹli əblɪɾɝeɪtɪd hɪm, oʊnli ðə ɡloʊɪŋ faɪɝz ʃoʊɪŋ θɹu. "ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt soʊ izəli bɹoʊkən əz ði oʊðz tə ðə laɪt jə fɔɹsʊk, pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ jəɹ nu mæstɝ ɪn ðə vɛɹi hɔl ə ðə sɝvəns. jəɹ mæstɝ kleɪmz jə fɝɛvɝ, lænfɝ. wɪl jə sɝv, əɹ dʒju tʃuz ən ɪtɝnəɾi ʌv peɪn, ʌv ɛnləs daɪɪŋ wɪθaʊt ɹilis?"

"Do you serve yourself now, Lanfear?" Ba'alzamon's voice was soft, but flame raged continuously in his eyes and mouth. "Have you abandoned your oaths to the Great Lord of the Dark?" For an instant the darkness nearly obliterated him, only the glowing fires showing through. "They are not so easily broken as the oaths to the Light you forsook, proclaiming your new master in the very Hall of the Servants. Your master claims you forever, Lanfear. Will you serve, or do you choose an eternity of pain, of endless dying without release?"

"aɪ sɝv." dɪspaɪɾ əɹ wɝdz, ʃi stʊd tɔl ən dɪfaɪənt. "aɪ sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk ən nʌn ʌðɝ. fɝɛvɝ!"

"I serve." Despite her words, she stood tall and defiant. "I serve the Great Lord of the Dark and none other. Forever!"

ðə væst ɝeɪ ʌv mɪɹɝ bɪɡæn tə vænɪʃ əz ɪf blæk weɪvz ɹoʊld ɪn oʊvɝ ɪt, ɛvɝ kloʊsɝ tə ðə sɛntɝ. ðə taɪd ɹoʊld oʊvɝ bælzəmən ən lænfɝ. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli blæknəs.

The vast array of mirror began to vanish as if black waves rolled in over it, ever closer to the center. The tide rolled over Ba'alzamon and Lanfear. There was only blackness.

pɛɹɪn fɛl hɑpɝ muv, ən i wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɡlæd tə fɑloʊ, ɡaɪɾəd oʊnli baɪ ðə fil ə fɝ ʌndɝ ɪz hænd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əntɪl i wɑz muvɪŋ ðəɾ i ɹilaɪzd i kʊd. hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʌzəl aʊt wʌɾ i hæd sin, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni səksɛs. bælzəmən ən lænfɝ. hɪz tʌŋ stʌk tə ðə ɹuf ə hɪz maʊθ. fəɹ səm ɹizən, lænfɝ fɹaɪɾənd ɪm mɔɹ ðən bælzəmən dɪd. pɝhæps kəz ʃi hæd bɪn ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz ɪn ðə maʊntənz. laɪt! wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɪn maɪ dʒɹimz! laɪt! ən ənlɛs i hæd mɪst sʌmθɪŋ, ʃi hæd dɪfaɪd ðə dɑɹk wʌn. hi hæd bɪn toʊld ən tɔt ðət ðə ʃædoʊ kəɾ əv noʊ paʊɝ oʊvɝ jə ɪf jə dɪnaɪɾ ɪt; bʌt haʊ kəɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd - nɑt dʒʌst ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd; wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən! - dɪfaɪ ðə ʃædoʊ? aɪ mʌs bi mæd, laɪk sɪmiənz bɹʌðɝ. ðiz dʒɹimz əv dʒɹɪvən mi mæd!

Perrin felt Hopper move, and he was more than glad to follow, guided only by the feel of fur under his hand. It was not until he was moving that he realized he could. He tried to puzzle out what he had seen, without any success. Ba'alzamon and Lanfear. His tongue stuck to the roof of his mouth. For some reason, Lanfear frightened him more than Ba'alzamon did. Perhaps because she had been in his dreams in the mountains. Light! One of the Forsaken in my dreams! Light! And unless he had missed something, she had defied the Dark One. He had been told and taught that the Shadow could have no power over you if you denied it; but how could a Darkfriend - not just a Darkfriend; one of the Forsaken! - defy the Shadow? I must be mad, like Simion's brother. These dreams have driven me mad!

sloʊli ðə blæknəs bɪkeɪm fɑɡ əɡɛn, ən ðə fɑɡ ɡɹædʒuəli θɪn əntɪl i wɔkt aʊɾ ʌv ɪt wɪð hɑpɝ ɑntu ə ɡɹæsi hɪlsaɪd bɹaɪt wɪð deɪlaɪt. bɝdz bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ fɹəm ə θɪkɪɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə hɪl. hi lʊk bæk. ə hɪli pleɪn dɑɾəd wɪð klʌmps ə tʃɹiz stʃɹɛtʃt tə ðə hɝaɪzən. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ə fɑɡ ɛniwɛɹ. ðə bɪɡ, ɡɹɪzəld wʊlf stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm.

Slowly the blackness became fog again, and the fog gradually thinned until he walked out of it with Hopper onto a grassy hillside bright with daylight. Birds began to sing from a thicket at the foot of the hill. He looked back. A hilly plain dotted with clumps of trees stretched to the horizon. There was no sign of fog anywhere. The big, grizzled wolf stood watching him.

"wʌt wɑz ðæt?" hi dɪmændəd, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ ɪn ɪz maɪn tə tɝn ðə kwɛstʃən tə θɔts ðə wʊlf kəɾ ʌndɝstænd. "waɪ dɪd jə ʃoʊ ɪt tə mi? wʌt wɑz ɪt?"

"What was that?" he demanded, struggling in his mind to turn the question to thoughts the wolf could understand. "Why did you show it to me? What was it?"

ɪmoʊʃənz ən ɪmədʒəz flʌɾəd ɪz θɔts, ən ɪz maɪn pʊt wɝdz tə ðɛm. wʌt jə mʌst si. bi kɛɹfəl, jʌŋ bʊl. ðɪs pleɪs ɪz deɪnʒɝəs. bi wɛɹi əz ə kʌb hʌntɪŋ pɔɹkjəpaɪn. ðət keɪm əz sʌmθɪŋ kloʊsɝ tə smɔl θɔɹni bæk, bʌɾ ɪz maɪnd neɪm ði ænəməl ðə weɪ hi nu ɪɾ əz ə mæn. jə ɑɹ tu jʌŋ, tu nu.

Emotions and images flooded his thoughts, and his mind put words to them. What you must see. Be careful, Young Bull. This place is dangerous. Be wary as a cub hunting porcupine. That came as something closer to Small Thorny Back, but his mind named the animal the way he knew it as a man. You are too young, too new.

"wɑz ɪt ɹil?"

"Was it real?"

ɔl ɪz ɹil, wʌɾ ɪz sin, ən wʌɾ ɪz nɑt sin. ðət sim tə bi ɔl ði ænsɝ hɑpɝ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɡɪv.

All is real, what is seen, and what is not seen. That seemed to be all the answer Hopper was going to give.

"hɑpɝ, haʊ ɑɹ jə hɪɹ? aɪ sɔ jə daɪ. aɪ fɛl jə daɪ!"

"Hopper, how are you here? I saw you die. I felt you die!"

ɔl ɑɹ hɪɹ. ɔl bɹʌðɝz ən sɪstɝz ðəɾ ɑɹ, ɔl ðət wɝ, ɔl ðət wɪl bi. pɛɹɪn nu ðət wʊlvz dɪd nɑt smaɪl, nɑt ðə weɪ hjumənz dɪd, bʌt fəɹ ən ɪnstən i hæd ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ðət hɑpɝ wɑz ɡɹɪnɪŋ. hɪɹ, aɪ sɔɹ laɪk ði iɡəl. ðə wʊlf ɡæðɝd hɪmsɛlf ən lɛpt, ʌp ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ʌp ən ʌp ɪt kæɹid hɪm, əntɪl i dwɪndəl tə ə spɛk ɪn ðə skaɪ, ən ə læs θɔt keɪm. tə sɔɹ.

All are here. All brothers and sisters that are, all that were, all that will be. Perrin knew that wolves did not smile, not the way humans did, but for an instant he had the impression that Hopper was grinning. Here, I soar like the eagle. The wolf gathered himself and leaped, up into the air. Up and up it carried him, until he dwindled to a speck in the sky, and a last thought came. To soar.

pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ æftɝ ɪm wɪð ɪz maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən. hi dɪɾ ɪt. hɪz aɪz bɝn sʌɾənli, ən i klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən skɹʌbd əɾ ɪz noʊz. əl bi kɹaɪɪŋ laɪk ə ɡɝl, nɛkst. wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, hi lʊkt ɝaʊn tə si ɪf ɛniwʌn hæd sin hɪm, ən ðət kwɪkli ɛvɹiθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd.

Perrin stared after him with his mouth hanging open. He did it. His eyes burned suddenly, and he cleared his throat and scrubbed at his nose. I will be crying like a girl, next. Without thinking, he looked around to see if anyone had seen him, and that quickly everything changed.

hi wɑz stændɪŋ ɑn ə ɹaɪz, wɪð ʃæɾoʊi, ɪndɪstɪŋk dɪps ən swɛlz ɔl ɝaʊn hɪm. ðeɪ sim tə feɪɾ ɪndə ðə dɪstəns tu sun. ɹænd stʊd bɪloʊ hɪm. ɹænd, ən ə ɹæɡəd sɝkəl ə mɹdʒɹɑl ən mɛn ən wɪmən ɪz aɪz sim tə slaɪd ɹaɪt pæst. dɑɡz haʊl sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ən pɛɹɪn nu ðeɪ wɝ hʌntɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. mɹdʒɹɑl sɛn ən ðə stɪŋk ə bɝn sʌlfɝ fɪl ði ɛɹ. pɛɹɪnz hækəlz ɹoʊz.

He was standing on a rise, with shadowy, indistinct dips and swells all around him. They seemed to fade into the distance too soon. Rand stood below him. Rand, and a ragged circle of Myrddraal and men and women his eyes seemed to slide right past. Dogs howled somewhere in the distance, and Perrin knew they were hunting something. Myrddraal scent and the stink of burned sulphur filled the air. Perrin's hackles rose.

ðə sɝkəl ə mɹdʒɹɑl ən pipəl keɪm kloʊsɝ tə ɹænd, ɔl wɔkɪŋ əz ɪf əslip. ən ɹænd bɪɡæn tə kɪl ðɛm. bɔlz ə faɪɝ flu fɹəm ɪz hænz ən kənsum tu. laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt fɹəm əbʌv tə ʃɹɪvəl ʌðɝz. bɑɹz ə laɪt laɪk waɪt-hɑt stil flu fɹəm ɪz fɪsts tə mɔɹ. ən ðə sɝvaɪvɝz kəntɪnjud tə wɔk sloʊli kloʊsɝ, əz ɪf nʌn ə ðɛm sɔ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. wʌn baɪ wʌn ðeɪ daɪd, əntɪl nʌn wɝ lɛft, ən ɹænd sæŋk daʊn ɑn ɪz niz, pæntɪŋ. pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ i wɑz læfɪŋ əɹ kɹaɪɪŋ; ɪt sim tə bi səm ʌv itʃ.

The circle of Myrddraal and people came closer to Rand, all walking as if asleep. And Rand began to kill them. Balls of fire flew from his hands and consumed two. Lightning flashed from above to shrivel others. Bars of light like white-hot steel flew from his fists to more. And the survivors continued to walk slowly closer, as if none of them saw what was happening. One by one they died, until none were left, and Rand sank down on his knees, panting. Perrin was not sure whether he was laughing or crying; it seemed to be some of each.

ʃeɪps əpɪɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə ɹaɪzəz, mɔɹ pipəl kʌmɪŋ, mɔɹ mɹdʒɹɑl, ɔl ɪntɛn ɑn ɹænd.

Shapes appeared over the rises, more people coming, more Myrddraal, all intent on Rand.

pɛɹɪn kʌpt ɪz hænz tə hɪz maʊθ. "ɹænd! ɹænd, ðəɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ kʌmɪŋ!"

Perrin cupped his hands to his mouth. "Rand! Rand, there are more coming!"

ɹænd lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm fɹəm ɪz kɹaʊtʃ, snɑɹlɪŋ, swɛt slɪkɪŋ ɪz feɪs.

Rand looked up at him from his crouch, snarling, sweat slicking his face.

"ɹænd, ðəɹ - !"

"Rand, they're - !"

"bɝn ju!" ɹænd haʊld.

"Burn you!" Rand howled.

laɪt bɝn pɛɹɪnz aɪz, ən peɪn sɪɹɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

Light burned Perrin's eyes, and pain seared everything.

ɡɹoʊnɪŋ, hi ɹoʊld ɪndə ə bɔl ɑn ðə nɛɹoʊ bɛd, ðə laɪt stɪl bɝnɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz aɪlɪdz. hɪz tʃɛs hɝt. hi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə ɪɾ ən wɪnst wən i fɛlt ə bɝn ʌndɝ ɪz ʃɝt, ə spɑt noʊ bɪɡɝ ðən ə sɪlvɝ pɛni.

Groaning, he rolled into a ball on the narrow bed, the light still burning behind his eyelids. His chest hurt. He raised a hand to it and winced when he felt a burn under his shirt, a spot no bigger than a silver penny.

bɪt baɪ bɪɾ i fɔɹst ɪz nɑɾɪd mʌsəlz tə lɛɾ ɪm stʃɹeɪɾən ɪz lɛɡz ən laɪ flæɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk kæbən. mɔɪɹeɪn. aɪ hæv tə tɛl mɔɪɹeɪn ðɪs taɪm. dʒʌst əv tə weɪt tɪl ðə peɪn ɡoʊz əweɪ.

Bit by bit he forced his knotted muscles to let him straighten his legs and lie flat in the dark cabin. Moiraine. I have to tell Moiraine this time. Just have to wait till the pain goes away.

bʌɾ əz ðə peɪn bɪɡæn tə feɪd, ɪɡzɔstʃən tʊk hɪm. hi bɛɹli hæɾ ə θɔt ðəɾ i mʌst ɡɛɾ ʌp bɪfɔɹ slip pʊld ɪm daʊn əɡɛn.

But as the pain began to fade, exhaustion took him. He barely had a thought that he must get up before sleep pulled him down again.

wən i oʊpən ɪz aɪz əɡɛn, hi leɪ stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə bimz oʊvɝhɛd. laɪɾ ət ðə tɑp ən bɑɾəm ə ðə dɔɹ toʊld ɪm mɔɹnɪŋ hæd kʌm. hi pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɪz tʃɛs tə kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf i hæɾ ɪmædʒən ɪt, ɪmædʒən ɪt soʊ wɛl ðəɾ i hæɾ æktʃəli  fɛlt ə bɝn. . . .

When he opened his eyes again, he lay staring at the beams overhead. Light at the top and bottom of the door told him morning had come. He put a hand to his chest to convince himself he had imagined it, imagined it so well that he had actually felt a burn. . . .

hɪz fɪŋɡɝz faʊn ðə bɝn. aɪ dɪdn ɪmædʒən ɪt, ðɛn. hi hæd dɪm mɛmɹiz ʌv ə fju ʌðɝ dʒɹimz, feɪɾɪŋ ivən əz i ɹɪkɔl ðɛm. ɔɹɾənɛɹi dʒɹimz. hi ivən fɛlt əz ɪf i hæd hæɾ ə ɡʊd naɪts slip. ən kəd juz ənʌðɝ wʌn ɹaɪt naʊ. bʌɾ ɪt mɛn i kəd slip. əz lɔŋ əz ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ wʊlvz ɝaʊnd, ɛniweɪ.

His fingers found the burn. I didn't imagine it, then. He had dim memories of a few other dreams, fading even as he recalled them. Ordinary dreams. He even felt as if he had had a good night's sleep. And could use another one right now. But it meant he could sleep. As long as there are no wolves around, anyway.

hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd meɪkɪŋ ə dɪsɪʒən ɪn ðət bɹif weɪkɪŋ æftɝ ðə dʒɹim wɪð hɑpɝ, ən æftɝ ə moʊmən i dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt hæd bɪn ə ɡʊd wʌn.

He remembered making a decision in that brief waking after the dream with Hopper, and after a moment he decided it had been a good one.

ɪt tʊk nɑkɪŋ ɑn faɪv dɔɹz ən biɪŋ kɝst ət twaɪs - ði ɪnhæbəɾənts ə tu kæbənz hæd ɡɔn ɑn dɛk - bɪfɔɹ i faʊn mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi wɑz fʊli dʒɹɛst, bʌt sɪɾɪŋ ɑn wʌn ə ðə nɛɹoʊ bɛdz kɹɔs-lɛɡəd, ɹɛɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ bʊk ə noʊts baɪ læntɝn laɪt. bæk nɪɹ ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, hi sɔ, noʊts ðət mʌst əv bɪn meɪɾ ivən bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd kʌm tə ɛmənz fild. lænz θɪŋz wɝ nitli pleɪst ɑn ði ʌðɝ bɛd.

It took knocking on five doors and being cursed at twice - the inhabitants of two cabins had gone on deck - before he found Moiraine. She was fully dressed, but sitting on one of the narrow beds cross-legged, reading in her book of notes by lantern light. Back near the beginning, he saw, notes that must have been made even before she had come to Emond's Field. Lan's things were neatly placed on the other bed.

"aɪ hæɾ ə dʒɹim," hi toʊl hɝ, ən pɹəsiɾəd tə tɛl əɹ ʌv ɪt. ɔl ʌv ɪt. hi ivən pʊld ʌp ɪz ʃɝt tə ʃoʊ hɝ ðə smɔl sɝkəl ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, ɹɛd, wɪð weɪvi ɹɛd laɪnz ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ fɹəm ɪt. hi hæd kɛp θɪŋz fɹəm əɹ bɪfɔɹ, ən i səspɛktəɾ i wəɾ əɡɛn, bʌt ðɪs maɪt bi tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hoʊl bæk. ðə pɪn wɑz ðə smɔləs pɑɹɾ ʌv ə pɛɹ ə sɪzɝz, ən ði iziəs meɪd, bʌt wɪθaʊɾ ɪt, ðə sɪzɝz kʌt noʊ klɔθ. wən i wɑz dʌn, hi stʊd ðəɹ weɪɾɪŋ.

"I had a dream," he told her, and proceeded to tell her of it. All of it. He even pulled up his shirt to show her the small circle on his chest, red, with wavy red lines radiating from it. He had kept things from her before, and he suspected he would again, but this might be too important to hold back. The pin was the smallest part of a pair of scissors, and the easiest made, but without it, the scissors cut no cloth. When he was done, he stood there waiting.

ʃi hæd wɑtʃt ɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən, ɪksɛp ðət ðoʊz dɑɹk aɪz hæɾ ɪɡzæmən ɛvɹi wɝɾ əz ɪt keɪm aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ, weɪɾ ɪt, mɛʒɝɾ ɪt, hɛld ɪɾ ʌp tə ðə laɪt. naʊ ʃi sæt ðə seɪm weɪ, oʊnli ɪt wɑz i hu wɑz ɪɡzæmənd, weɪd, ən hɛld ʌp tə ðə laɪt.

She had watched him without expression, except that those dark eyes had examined every word as it came out of his mouth, weighed it, measured it, held it up to the light. Now she sat the same way, only it was he who was examined, weighed, and held up to the light.

"wɛl, ɪz ɪɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt?" hi dɪmændəd faɪnəli. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz wʊlf dʒɹimz jə toʊl mi əbaʊt - aɪm ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz; ɪt mʌst əv bɪn! - bʌt ðət dʌzn meɪk wʌɾ aɪ sɔ ɹil. oʊnli, jə sɛd meɪbi səm ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ fɹi, ən i kɔld əɹ lænfɝ, ænd. . . . ɪz ɪɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, əɹ æm aɪ stændɪŋ hɪɹ meɪkɪŋ ə ful aʊɾ ə maɪsɛlf?"

"Well, is it important?" he demanded finally. "I think it was one of those wolf dreams you told me about - I'm sure it was; it must have been! - but that doesn't make what I saw real. Only, you said maybe some of the Forsaken are free, and he called her Lanfear, and. . . . Is it important, or am I standing here making a fool out of myself?"

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ wɪmən," ʃi sɛd sloʊli, "hu wəd də ðɛɹ bɛs tə dʒɛntəl jə ɪf ðeɪ hɝd wʌɾ aɪ dʒʌs dɪd." hɪz lʌŋz sim tə fɹiz; hi kəd nɑt bɹið. "aɪ æm nɑɾ əkjuzɪŋ jə ʌv biɪŋ eɪbəl tə tʃænəl," ʃi wɛn ɑn, ən ði aɪs ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm mɛltəd, "ɔɹ ivən ə biɪŋ eɪbəl tə lɝn. ən ətɛmpt ət dʒɛntəlɪŋ wəd nɑt hɑɹm ju, bɪɑn ðə ɹʌf tʃɹitmən ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ wəd ɡɪv jə bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹilaɪz ðɛɹ ɛɹɝ. sətʃ mɛn ɑɹ soʊ ɹɛɹ, ivən ðə ɹɛdz wɪð ɔl ðɛɹ hʌntɪŋ əv nɑt faʊn mɔɹ ðən θɹi ɪn ðə læs tɛn jɪɹz. bɪfɔɹ ði aʊtbɹeɪk ə fɔls dʒɹæɡənz, ət list. wʌɾ aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk klɪɹ tə jə ɪz ðəɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk jəl sʌɾənli bɪɡɪn wildɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. jə də nɑɾ əv tə bi əfɹeɪɾ ə ðæt."

"There are women," she said slowly, "who would do their best to gentle you if they heard what I just did." His lungs seemed to freeze; he could not breathe. "I am not accusing you of being able to channel," she went on, and the ice inside him melted, "or even of being able to learn. An attempt at gentling would not harm you, beyond the rough treatment the Red Ajah would give you before they realized their error. Such men are so rare, even the Reds with all their hunting have not found more than three in the last ten years. Before the outbreak of false Dragons, at least. What I am trying to make clear to you is that I do not think you will suddenly begin wielding the Power. You do not have to be afraid of that."

"wɛl, θæŋk jə vɛɹi mʌtʃ fəɹ ðæt," hi sɛd bɪɾɝli. "ju dɪd nɑɾ əv tə skɛɹ mi tə dɛθ dʒʌst soʊ jə kəd tɛl mi ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə bi fɹaɪɾənd!"

"Well, thank you very much for that," he said bitterly. "You did not have to scare me to death just so you could tell me there was no need to be frightened!"

"oʊ, jə də hæv ɹizən tə bi fɹaɪɾənd. əɹ ət lis kɛɹfəl, əz ðə wʊlf sədʒɛstəd. ɹɛd sɪstɝz, əɹ ʌðɝz, maɪt kɪl jə bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ dɪskʌvɝd ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə dʒɛntəl ɪn ju."

"Oh, you do have reason to be frightened. Or at least careful, as the wolf suggested. Red sisters, or others, might kill you before they discovered there was nothing to gentle in you."

"laɪt! laɪt bɝn mi!" hi stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ wɪð ə fɹaʊn. "jɔɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lid mi ɝaʊn baɪ ðə noʊz, mɔɪɹeɪn, bʌɾ aɪm noʊ kæf, ən ðɛɹz noʊ ɹɪŋ ɪn maɪ noʊz. ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ əɹ ɛni ʌðɝ wəd nɑt θɪŋk ə dʒɛntəlɪŋ ənlɛs ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹil ɪn wʌɾ aɪ dʒɹimd. dʌz ɪt min ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ lus?"

"Light! Light burn me!" He stared at her with a frown. "You're trying to lead me around by the nose, Moiraine, but I am no calf, and there's no ring in my nose. The Red Ajah or any other would not think of gentling unless there was something real in what I dreamed. Does it mean the Forsaken are loose?"

"aɪ toʊl jə bɪfɔɹ ðət ðeɪ maɪt bi. səm ə ðɛm. jəɹ . . . dʒɹimz ɑɹ nʌθɪŋ aɪ ɪkspɛktəd, pɛɹɪn. dʒɹimɝz əv ɹɪɾən ʌv wʊlvz, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk ðɪs."

"I told you before that they might be. Some of them. Your . . . dreams are nothing I expected, Perrin. Dreamers have written of wolves, but I did not expect this."

"wɛl, aɪ θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ɹil. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ sɔ sʌmθɪŋ ðət ɹɪli hæpənd, sʌmθɪŋ aɪ wɑzn səpoʊz tə si." wʌt jə mʌst si. "aɪ θɪŋk lænfɝ ɪz lus ət ðə vɛɹi list. wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?"

"Well, I think it was real. I think I saw something that really happened, something I wasn't supposed to see." What you must see. "I think Lanfear is loose at the very least. What are you going to do?"

"aɪ æm ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɪljən. ən ðən əl ɡoʊ tə tɛɹ, ən hoʊp tə ɹitʃ ɪt bɪfɔɹ ɹænd. wi hæd nid tə liv ɹɛmən tu kwɪkli fəɹ læn tə lɝn wɛðɝ i kɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ əɹ wɛn daʊn ɪt. wi ʃəd noʊ bɪfɔɹ wi ɹitʃ ɪljən, ðoʊ. wɪl faɪn saɪn ɪf hiz ɡɔn ðɪs weɪ." ʃi ɡlænst əɾ əɹ bʊk əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə ɹɪzum əɹ ɹɛɾɪŋ.

"I am going to Illian. And then I will go to Tear, and hope to reach it before Rand. We had need to leave Remen too quickly for Lan to learn whether he crossed the river or went down it. We should know before we reach Illian, though. We will find sign if he has gone this way." She glanced at her book as if she wanted to resume her reading.

"ɪz ðəɾ ɔl jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du? wɪð lænfɝ lus, ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn noʊz haʊ mɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz?"

"Is that all you are going to do? With Lanfear loose, and the Light alone knows how many of the others?"

"du nɑt kwɛstʃən mi," ʃi sɛd koʊldli. "ju də nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ kwɛstʃənz tə æsk, ən jə wəd kɑmpɹihɛn lɛs ðən hæf ði ænsɝz ɪf aɪ ɡeɪv ðɛm. wɪtʃ əl nɑt."

"Do not question me," she said coldly. "You do not know which questions to ask, and you would comprehend less than half the answers if I gave them. Which I will not."

hi ʃɪftəɾ ɪz fiɾ ʌndɝ əɹ ɡeɪz əntɪl ɪt bɪkeɪm klɪɹ ʃi wəd seɪ noʊ mɔɹ ɑn ðə mæɾɝ. hɪz ʃɝt ɹʌb peɪnfəli ət ðə bɝn ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. ɪt dɪd nɑt sim ə bæd hɝt - nɑt fəɹ biɪŋ stʃɹʌk baɪ laɪtnɪŋ ɪt dʌznt! - bʌt haʊ hi hæd kʌm baɪ ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. "ʌ. . . . wɪl jə hil ðɪs?"

He shifted his feet under her gaze until it became clear she would say no more on the matter. His shirt rubbed painfully at the burn on his chest. It did not seem a bad hurt - Not for being struck by lightning it doesn't! - but how he had come by it was another matter. "Uh. . . . Will you Heal this?"

"ɑɹ jə noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ənizi əbaʊt ðə wʌn paʊɝ biɪŋ juzd ɑn ju, ðɛn, pɛɹɪn? noʊ, əl nɑt hil ɪt. ɪts nɑt sɪɹiəs, ən ɪɾəl ɹimaɪn jə ʌv ðə nid tə bi kɛɹfəl." kɛɹfəl əbaʊt pɹɛsɪŋ hɝ, hi nu, əz wɛl əz əbaʊt dʒɹimz əɹ lɛɾɪŋ ʌðɝz noʊ ʌv ðɛm. "ɪf ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ ɛls, pɛɹɪn?"

"Are you no longer uneasy about the One Power being used on you, then, Perrin? No, I will not Heal it. It is not serious, and it will remind you of the need to be careful." Careful about pressing her, he knew, as well as about dreams or letting others know of them. "If there is nothing else, Perrin?"

hi stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ, ðən stɑpt. "ðɛɹ ɪz wʌn θɪŋ. ɪf jə nu ə wʊmənz neɪm wɑz zɑɹin, wəd jə θɪŋk ɪt mɛn ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ?"

He started for the door, then stopped. "There is one thing. If you knew a woman's name was Zarine, would you think it meant anything about her?"

"waɪ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt dʒju æsk ðɪs kwɛstʃən?"

"Why under the Light do you ask this question?"

"ə ɡɝl," hi sɛɾ ɔkwɝdli. "ə jʌŋ wʊmən. aɪ mɛɾ əɹ læs naɪt. ʃiz wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ pæsənʒɝz." hi wəd lɛɾ əɹ dɪskʌvɝ fəɹ hɝsɛlf ðət zɑɹin nu ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən sim tə θɪŋk fɑloʊɪŋ əm wəd lɛɾ əɹ tə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. hi wəd nɑt kip bæk ɛniθɪŋ i θɔt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, bʌɾ ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn kəd bi sikɹəɾɪv, soʊ kəd hi.

"A girl," he said awkwardly. "A young woman. I met her last night. She's one of the other passengers." He would let her discover for herself that Zarine knew she was Aes Sedai. And seemed to think following them would lead her to the Horn of Valere. He would not keep back anything he thought was important, but if Moiraine could be secretive, so could he.

"zɑɹin. ɪts ə sɑldəiən neɪm. noʊ wʊmən wəd neɪm əɹ dɔɾɝ ðəɾ ənlɛs ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə bi ə ɡɹeɪt bjuɾi. ən ə hɑɹtbɹeɪkɝ. wʌn tə laɪ ɑn kʊʃənz ɪn pæləsəz, sɝaʊndəd baɪ sɝvəns ən suɾɝz." ʃi smaɪld, bɹifli bʌt wɪð ɡɹeɪɾ əmjuzmənt. "pɝhæps juv ənʌðɝ ɹizən tə bi kɛɹfəl, pɛɹɪn, ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ə zɑɹin əz ə pæsənʒɝ wɪð ʌs."

"Zarine. It is a Saldaean name. No woman would name her daughter that unless she expected her to be a great beauty. And a heartbreaker. One to lie on cushions in palaces, surrounded by servants and suitors." She smiled, briefly but with great amusement. "Perhaps you have another reason to be careful, Perrin, if there is a Zarine as a passenger with us."

"aɪ ɪntɛn tə bi kɛɹfəl," hi toʊl hɝ. ət list i nu waɪ zɑɹin dɪd nɑt laɪk əɹ neɪm. hɑɹdli fɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə hʌntɝ ə ðə hɔɹn. əz lɔŋ əz ʃi dʌzn kɔl hɝsɛlf "fælkən."

"I intend to be careful," he told her. At least he knew why Zarine did not like her name. Hardly fitting for a Hunter of the Horn. As long as she doesn't call herself "falcon."

wən i wɛn ɑn dɛk, læn wɑz ðɛɹ, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ mændɑɹb. ən zɑɹin wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə kɔɪl ə ɹoʊp nɪɹ ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, ʃɑɹpənɪŋ wʌn ə hɝ naɪvz ən wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. ðə bɪɡ, tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ seɪlz wɝ sɛɾ ən tɔt, ən ðə snoʊ ɡus flu daʊnɹɪvɝ.

When he went on deck, Lan was there, looking over Mandarb. And Zarine was sitting on a coil of rope near the railing, sharpening one of her knives and watching him. The big, triangular sails were set and taut, and the Snow Goose flew downriver.

zɑɹinz aɪz fɑloʊd pɛɹɪn əz i wɔk baɪ hɝ tə stæn ɪn ðə baʊ. ðə wɔɾɝ kɝl tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə pɹaʊ laɪk ɝθ tɝnɪŋ ɝaʊn ə ɡʊd plaʊ. hi wʌndɝɾ əbaʊt dʒɹimz ən ilmɛn, mɪnz vjuɪŋz ən fælkənz. hɪz tʃɛs hɝt. laɪf hæd nɛvɝ bɪn əz tæŋɡəld əz ðɪs.

Zarine's eyes followed Perrin as he walked by her to stand in the bow. The water curled to either side of the prow like earth turning around a good plow. He wondered about dreams and Aielmen, Min's viewings and falcons. His chest hurt. Life had never been as tangled as this.

ɹænd sæɾ ʌp aʊɾ ə hɪz ɪɡzɔstəd slip, ɡæspɪŋ, ðə kloʊk i hæd juzd əz ə blæŋkət fɔlɪŋ əweɪ. hɪz saɪɾ ætʃt, ði oʊld waʊn fɹəm fɑlm θɹɑbɪŋ. hɪz faɪɝ hæd bɝn daʊn tə koʊlz wɪð oʊnli ə fju weɪvɝɪŋ fleɪmz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə ʃædoʊz muv. ðət wɑz pɛɹɪn. ɪt wɑz! ɪt wɑz hɪm, nɑɾ ə dʒɹim. sʌmhaʊ. aɪ ɔlmoʊs kɪl hɪm! laɪt, aɪ hæv tə bi kɛɹfəl!

Rand sat up out of his exhausted sleep, gasping, the cloak he had used as a blanket falling away. His side ached, the old wound from Falme throbbing. His fire had burned down to coals with only a few wavering flames, but it was still enough to make the shadows move. That was Perrin. It was! It was him, not a dream. Somehow. I almost killed him! Light, I have to be careful!

ʃɪvɝɪŋ, hi pɪkt ʌp ə lɛŋθ ʌv oʊk bɹæntʃ ən stɑɹɾəd tə ʃʌv ɪɾ ɪndə ðə koʊlz. ðə tʃɹiz wɝ skæɾɝd ɪn ðiz mʊɹændiən hɪlz, stɪl kloʊs tə ðə meɪnɛðɹəndʒɹɛl, bʌɾ i hæd faʊn dʒʌst ɪnʌf fɔlən bɹæntʃəz fəɹ ɪz faɪɝ, ðə wʊd dʒʌst oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi pɹɑpɝli kjʊɹd bʌt nɑt ɹɑɾən. bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊd tʌtʃt ðə koʊlz, hi stɑpt. ðəɹ wɝ hɔɹsəz kʌmɪŋ, tɛn əɹ ə dʌzən ə ðɛm, wɔkɪŋ sloʊli. aɪ hæv tə bi kɛɹfəl. aɪ kænɑt meɪk ənʌðɝ mɪsteɪk.

Shivering, he picked up a length of oak branch and started to shove it into the coals. The trees were scattered in these Murandian hills, still close to the Manetherendrelle, but he had found just enough fallen branches for his fire, the wood just old enough to be properly cured but not rotten. Before the wood touched the coals, he stopped. There were horses coming, ten or a dozen of them, walking slowly. I have to be careful. I cannot make another mistake.

ðə hɔɹsəz swʌŋ təwɔɹɾ ɪz feɪlɪŋ faɪɝ, ɛntɝd ðə dɪm laɪt, ən stɑpt. ðə ʃædoʊz əbskjʊɹd ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɝz, bʌt moʊst sim tə bi ɹʌf-feɪs mɛn wɛɹɪŋ ɹaʊn hɛlməts ən lɔŋ lɛðɝ dʒɝkɪnz soʊn ɔl oʊvɝ wɪð mɛɾəl dɪsks laɪk fɪʃ skeɪlz. wʌn wɑz ə wʊmən wɪð ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ ən ə noʊ-nɑnsɛns lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs. hɝ dɑɹk dʒɹɛs wɑz pleɪn wʊl, bʌt ðə faɪnəst wiv, ən ədɔɹnd wɪð ə sɪlvɝ pɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə laɪən. ə mɝtʃənt, ʃi sim tə hɪm; hi hæd sin əɹ sɔɹɾ əmʌŋ ðoʊz u keɪm tə baɪ təbæk ən wʊl ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ə mɝtʃən ən əɹ ɡɑɹdz.

The horses swung toward his failing fire, entered the dim light, and stopped. The shadows obscured their riders, but most seemed to be rough-faced men wearing round helmets and long leather jerkins sewn all over with metal discs like fish scales. One was a woman with graying hair and a no-nonsense look on her face. Her dark dress was plain wool, but the finest weave, and adorned with a silver pin in the shape of a lion. A merchant, she seemed to him; he had seen her sort among those who came to buy tabac and wool in the Two Rivers. A merchant and her guards.

aɪ hæv tə bi kɛɹfəl, hi θɔɾ əz i stʊd. noʊ mɪsteɪks.

I have to be careful, he thought as he stood. No mistakes.

"ju hæv tʃoʊzən ə ɡʊd kæmpsaɪt, jʌŋ mæn," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ hæv ɔfən juzd ɪɾ ɑn maɪ weɪ tə ɹɛmən. ðəɹ ɪz ə smɔl spɹɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ. aɪ tʃɹʌs juv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃən tə maɪ ʃɛɹɪŋ ɪt?" hɝ ɡɑɹdz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsmaʊntɪŋ, hɪtʃɪŋ ət ðɛɹ sɔɹd bɛls ən lusənɪŋ sæɾəl ɡɝθs.

"You have chosen a good campsite, young man," she said. "I have often used it on my way to Remen. There is a small spring nearby. I trust you have no objection to my sharing it?" Her guards were already dismounting, hitching at their sword belts and loosening saddle girths.

"nʌn," ɹænd toʊl hɝ. kɛɹfəl. tu stɛps bɹɔɾ ɪm kloʊs ɪnʌf, ən i lɛpt ɪndə ði ɛɹ, spɪnɪŋ - θɪsldaʊn floʊts ɑn ðə wɝlwɪnd - hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd kɑɹv fɹəm faɪɝ kʌmɪŋ ɪndə hɪz hænz tə teɪk əɹ hɛɾ ɔf bɪfɔɹ sɝpɹaɪz kəɾ ivən fɔɹm ɑn əɹ feɪs. ʃi wɑz ðə moʊs deɪnʒɝəs.

"None," Rand told her. Careful. Two steps brought him close enough, and he leaped into the air, spinning - Thistledown Floats on the Whirlwind - heron-mark blade carved from fire coming into his hands to take her head off before surprise could even form on her face. She was the most dangerous.

hi əlaɪɾɪd əz ðə wʊmənz hɛd ɹoʊl fɹəm ðə kɹʌpɝ ə hɝ hɔɹs. ðə ɡɑɹdz jɛld ən klɔd fəɹ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz, skɹimd əz ðeɪ ɹilaɪzd ɪz bleɪd bɝnd. hi dænst əmʌŋ əm ɪn ðə fɔɹmz læn hæd tɔt hɪm, ən nu hi cʊɾə kɪld ɔl tɛn wɪð ɔɹɾənɛɹi stil, bʌt ðə bleɪɾ i wildɪd wɑz pɑɹɾ ə hɪm. ðə læs mæn fɛl, ən ɪt hæd bɪn soʊ laɪk pɹæktəsɪŋ ðə fɔɹmz ðəɾ i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn ðə ʃiðɪŋ kɔl foʊldɪŋ ðə fæn bɪfɔɹ i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ i wɔɹ noʊ skæbɝɾ ən ðɪs bleɪd wʊɾə tɝn ɪt tə æʃ əɾ ə tʌtʃ ɪf i hæd.

He alighted as the woman's head rolled from the crupper of her horse. The guards yelled and clawed for their swords, screamed as they realized his blade burned. He danced among them in the forms Lan had taught him, and knew he could have killed all ten with ordinary steel, but the blade he wielded was part of him. The last man fell, and it had been so like practicing the forms that he had already begun the sheathing called Folding the Fan before he remembered he wore no scabbard and this blade would have turned it to ash at a touch if he had.

lɛɾɪŋ ðə sɔɹd vænɪʃ, hi tɝn tə ɪɡzæmɪn ðə hɔɹsəz. moʊs hæd ɹʌn əweɪ, bʌt səm nɑt fɑɹ, ən ðə wʊmənz tɔl ɡɛldɪŋ stʊd wɪð ɹoʊlɪŋ aɪz, wɪkɝɪŋ ənizəli. hɝ hɛdləs kɔɹps, laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, hæd meɪnteɪn ɪts ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz, ən hɛl ði ænəməlz hɛd daʊn.

Letting the sword vanish, he turned to examine the horses. Most had run away, but some not far, and the woman's tall gelding stood with rolling eyes, whickering uneasily. Her headless corpse, lying on the ground, had maintained its grip on the reins, and held the animal's head down.

ɹænd pʊld əm fɹi, pɔzɪŋ oʊnli tə ɡæðɝ ɪz fju bɪlɔŋɪŋz bɪfɔɹ swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. aɪ hæv tə bi kɛɹfəl, hi θɔɾ əz i lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə dɛd. noʊ mɪsteɪks.

Rand pulled them free, pausing only to gather his few belongings before swinging into the saddle. I have to be careful, he thought as he looked over the dead. No mistakes.

ðə paʊɝ stɪl fɪl hɪm, ðə floʊ fɹəm seɪɾɪn swiɾɝ ðən hʌni, ɹæŋkɝ ðən ɹɑɾɪd mit. əbɹʌpli hi tʃænəld - nɑt ɹɪli ʌndɝstændɪŋ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz i dɪd, əɹ haʊ, oʊnli ðəɾ ɪt simd ɹaɪt; ən ɪt wɝkt, lɪftɪŋ ðə kɔɹpsəz. hi sɛɾ əm ɪn ə laɪn, feɪsɪŋ hɪm, nilɪŋ, feɪsəz ɪn ðə dɝt. fəɹ ðoʊz u hæd feɪsəz lɛft. nilɪŋ tə hɪm.

The Power still filled him, the flow from saidin sweeter than honey, ranker than rotted meat. Abruptly he channeled - not really understanding what it was he did, or how, only that it seemed right; and it worked, lifting the corpses. He set them in a line, facing him, kneeling, faces in the dirt. For those who had faces left. Kneeling to him.

"ɪf aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," hi toʊl ðɛm, "ðæɾ ɪz ðə weɪ ɪts səpoʊz tə bi, ɪzən ɪt?" lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ ʌv seɪɾɪn wɑz hɑɹd, bʌɾ i dɪɾ ɪt. ɪf aɪ hoʊld ɪt tu mʌtʃ, haʊ wɪl aɪ kip ðə mædnəs əweɪ? hi læf bɪɾɝli. əɹ ɪz ɪt tu leɪt fəɹ ðæt?

"If I am the Dragon Reborn," he told them, "that is the way it is supposed to be, isn't it?" Letting go of saidin was hard, but he did it. If I hold it too much, how will I keep the madness away? He laughed bitterly. Or is it too late for that?

fɹaʊnɪŋ, hi pɪɹɾ ət ðə laɪn. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli tɛn mɛn, bʌɾ ɪlɛvən mɛn nɛlt ɪn ðət laɪn, wʌn ə ðɛm wɪθaʊɾ ɑɹmɝ ʌv ɛni sɔɹt bʌt wɪð ə dæɡɝ stɪl ɡɹɪpt ɪn ɪz hænd.

Frowning, he peered at the line. He had been sure there were only ten men, but eleven men knelt in that line, one of them without armor of any sort but with a dagger still gripped in his hand.

"ju tʃoʊz ðə ɹɔŋ kʌmpəni," ɹænd toʊl ðət mæn.

"You chose the wrong company," Rand told that man.

wilɪŋ ðə ɡɛldɪŋ, hi dʌɡ ɪn ɪz hilz ən sɛt ði ænəməl tə ə dɛd ɡæləp ɪndə ðə naɪt. ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ weɪ tə tɛɹ, jɛt, bʌɾ i mɛn tə ɡɛt ðəɹ baɪ ðə stʃɹeɪɾəst weɪ, ɪf i hæd tə kɪl hɔɹsəz əɹ stil ðɛm. əl pʊɾ ən ɛn tə ɪt. ðə tɔntɪŋ. ðə beɪɾɪŋ. əl ɛn ɪt! kælændɝ. ɪt kɔl tə hɪm.

Wheeling the gelding, he dug in his heels and set the animal to a dead gallop into the night. It was a long way to Tear, yet, but he meant to get there by the straightest way, if he had to kill horses or steal them. I will put an end to it. The taunting. The baiting. I will end it! Callandor. It called to him.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɛvən


CHAPTER 37

faɪɝz ɪn kɛɹhin


Fires in Cairhien

ɛɡwin ɹɪtɝn ə ɡɹeɪsfəl nɑd tə ðə ɹɪspɛkfəl baʊ ʌv ðə ʃɪps kɹumən u pæɾəd pæs hɝ, bɛɹfʊt, ɑn ɪz weɪ tə pʊl ə ɹoʊp ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sim tɔt, pɑsəbli ʃɪftɪŋ ə tʃɹaɪfəl ðə weɪ wʌn ə ðə bɪɡ skwɛɹ seɪlz sɛt. əz i tʃɹɑɾəd bæk təwɔɹd wɛɹ ðə ɹaʊnd-feɪs kæptən stʊd baɪ ðə tɪlɝmən, hi baʊɾ əɡɛn, ən ʃi nɑɾəd wʌns mɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ əɹ ətɛnʃənz tə ðə fɔɹəstəd kɛɹhin ʃɔɹ, sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm ðə blu kɹeɪn baɪ lɛs ðən twɛnti spænz ʌv wɔɾɝ.

Egwene returned a graceful nod to the respectful bow of the ship's crewman who padded past her, barefoot, on his way to pull a rope that already seemed taut, possibly shifting a trifle the way one of the big square sails set. As he trotted back toward where the round-faced captain stood by the tillerman, he bowed again, and she nodded once more before returning her attentions to the forested Cairhien shore, separated from the Blue Crane by less than twenty spans of water.

ə vɪlədʒ wɑz slaɪɾɪŋ pæst, əɹ wʌt hæd bɪn ə vɪlədʒ wʌns. hæf ðə haʊsəz wɝ oʊnli smoʊldɝɪŋ paɪlz ə ɹʌbəl wɪð tʃɪmniz stɪkɪŋ stɑɹkli aʊɾ ə ðə ɹuənz. ɑn ði ʌðɝ haʊsəz, dɔɹz swʌŋ wɪð ðə wɪnd, ən pisəz ə fɝnɪtʃɝ, bɪts ə kloʊðɪŋ ən haʊs wɛɹ lɪɾɝd ðə dɝt stʃɹit, tʌmbəld əbaʊɾ əz ɪf θɹoʊn. nʌθɪŋ lɪvɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn hæf-stɑɹv dɔɡ ðəɾ ɪɡnɔɹd ðə pæsɪŋ ʃɪp əz ɪt tʃɹɑɾəd aʊɾ ə saɪt bɪhaɪn ðə tɑpəld wɔlz ʌv wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə hæv bɪn ən ɪn. ʃi kəd nɛvɝ si sətʃ ə saɪt wɪθaʊɾ ə kwizinəs sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn əɹ bɛli, bʌt ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪnteɪn ðə dɪspæʃənət sɝɛnəɾi ʃi θɔɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪt hæv. ɪt dɪd nɑt hɛlp mʌtʃ. bɪɑn ðə vɪlədʒ, ə θɪk plum ə smoʊk wɑz ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪndə ðə skaɪ. θɹi əɹ fɔɹ maɪlz ɔf, ʃi ɛstəmeɪɾəd.

A village was sliding past, or what had been a village once. Half the houses were only smoldering piles of rubble with chimneys sticking starkly out of the ruins. On the other houses, doors swung with the wind, and pieces of furniture, bits of clothing and house ware littered the dirt street, tumbled about as if thrown. Nothing living moved in the village except for one half-starved dog that ignored the passing ship as it trotted out of sight behind the toppled walls of what appeared to have been an inn. She could never see such a sight without a queasiness settling in her belly, but she tried to maintain the dispassionate serenity she thought an Aes Sedai might have. It did not help much. Beyond the village, a thick plume of smoke was rising into the sky. Three or four miles off, she estimated.

ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə fɝst sətʃ plum ə smoʊk ʃi hæd sin sɪns ði ɛɹɪnɪn bɪɡæn tə floʊ əlɔŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ ə kɛɹhin, nɔɹ ðə fɝst sətʃ vɪlədʒ. ət lis ðɪs taɪm ðəɹ wɝ noʊ bɑɾiz ɪn saɪt. kæptən ɛlɪsɝ səmtaɪmz hæd tə seɪl kloʊs tə ðə kɛɹhinɪn ʃɔɹ kəz ə mʌdflæts - hi sɛd ðeɪ ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ - bʌt haʊɛvɝ kloʊs i keɪm, ʃi hæd nɑt sin ə sɪŋɡəl lɪvɪŋ pɝsən.

This was not the first such plume of smoke she had seen since the Erinin began to flow along the border of Cairhien, nor the first such village. At least this time there were no bodies in sight. Captain Ellisor sometimes had to sail close to the Cairhienin shore because of mudflats - he said they shifted in this part of the river - but however close he came, she had not seen a single living person.

ðə vɪlədʒ ən ðə smoʊk plum slɪpt əweɪ bɪhaɪn ðə ʃɪp, bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ənʌðɝ kɑləm ə smoʊk wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɪndə vju əhɛd, fɝðɝ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðə fɔɹəst wɑz θɪnɪŋ, æʃ ən lɛðɝlif ən blæk ɛldɝ ɡɪvɪŋ weɪ tə wɪloʊ ən waɪtwʊɾ ən wɔɾɝoʊk, ən səm ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz.

The village and the smoke plume slipped away behind the ship, but already another column of smoke was coming into view ahead, further from the river. The forest was thinning, ash and leatherleaf and black elder giving way to willow and whitewood and wateroak, and some she did not recognize.

ðə wɪn kɑɾ əɹ kloʊk, bʌt ʃi lɛɾ ɪt stʃɹim, filɪŋ ðə koʊl klinnəs ə ði ɛɹ, filɪŋ ðə fɹiɾəm ʌv wɛɹɪŋ bɹaʊn ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɛni sɔɹɾ ʌv waɪt, ðoʊ ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn əɹ fɝs tʃɔɪs. jɛt dʒɹɛs ən kloʊk wɝ ə ðə bɛst wʊl, wɛl kʌɾ ən wɛl soʊn.

The wind caught her cloak, but she let it stream, feeling the cold cleanness of the air, feeling the freedom of wearing brown instead of any sort of white, though it had not been her first choice. Yet dress and cloak were of the best wool, well cut and well sewn.

ənʌðɝ seɪlɝ tʃɹɑɾəd baɪ, boʊɪŋ əz i wɛnt. ʃi vaʊd tə lɝn ət list səm ʌv wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ; ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk filɪŋ ɪɡnɝənt. wɛɹɪŋ əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hæn meɪd fəɹ ə ɡʊd dil ə boʊɪŋ wɪð ə kæptən ən kɹu bɔɹn meɪnli ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn.

Another sailor trotted by, bowing as he went. She vowed to learn at least some of what it was they were doing; she did not like feeling ignorant. Wearing her Great Serpent ring on her right hand made for a good deal of bowing with a captain and crew born mainly in Tar Valon.

ʃi hæd wʌn ðəɾ ɑɹɡjəmənt wɪð nɪneɪiv, ðoʊ nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn ə ðə θɹi ʌv əm oʊld ɪnʌf fəɹ pipəl tə bɪliv ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ. ɛɡwin wɑz ɹɛɾi tə ədmɪt ðət boʊθ ʃi ən ɪleɪn hæd ɹəsiv stɑɹɾəld lʊks ɑn bɔɹɾɪŋ ðə blu kɹeɪn ðəɾ æftɝnun ət saʊθhɑɹbɝ, ən kæptən ɛlɪsɝz aɪbɹaʊz hæd klaɪmd ɔlmoʊs tə wɛɹ ɪz hɛɹ wʊɾə bɪɡʌn hæɾ i hæɾ ɛni, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn ɔl smaɪlz ən baʊz.

She had won that argument with Nynaeve, though Nynaeve had been sure she herself was the only one of the three of them old enough for people to believe she was Aes Sedai. But Nynaeve had been wrong. Egwene was ready to admit that both she and Elayne had received startled looks on boarding the Blue Crane that afternoon at Southharbor, and Captain Ellisor's eyebrows had climbed almost to where his hair would have begun had he had any, but he had been all smiles and bows.

"æn ɑnɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ tə tʃɹævəl ɑn maɪ vɛsəl? ən ɑnɝ ɪndid. aɪ pɹɑməs jə ə kwɪk dʒɝni əz fɑɹ əz jə wɪʃ. ən noʊ tʃɹʌbəl wɪð kɛɹhinɪn bɹɪɡænz. aɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ pʊɾ ɪn ɑn ðət saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ. ənlɛs jə wɪʃ ɪt, ʌv kɔɹs, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ændɔɝən soʊlʒɝz də hoʊld ə fju taʊnz ɑn ðə kɛɹhinɪn saɪd. ən ɑnɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"An honor, Aes Sedai. Three Aes Sedai to travel on my vessel? An honor indeed. I promise you a quick journey as far as you wish. And no trouble with Cairhienin brigands. I no longer put in on that side of the river. Unless you wish it, of course, Aes Sedai. Andoran soldiers do hold a few towns on the Cairhienin side. An honor, Aes Sedai."

hɪz aɪbɹaʊz hæd ʃɑɾ ʌp əɡɛn wən ðeɪ æsk fəɹ dʒʌst wʌn kæbən əmʌŋ əm - nɑɾ ivən nɪneɪiv wɑntəd tə bi əloʊn ət naɪɾ ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə bi. itʃ kəɾ əv ə kæbən tə hɝsɛlf ət noʊ ɛkstʃɹə tʃɑɹdʒ, hi toʊl ðɛm; hi hæd noʊ ʌðɝ pæsənʒɝz, hɪz kɑɹɡoʊ wɑz əbɔɹd, ən ɪf ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ ɝdʒən bɪznəs daʊnɹɪvɝ, hi wəd nɑt weɪɾ ivən ən aʊɝ fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls u maɪt wɑn pæsədʒ. ðeɪ sɛɾ əɡɛn ðət wʌn kæbən wəd bi səfɪʃənt.

His eyebrows had shot up again when they asked for just one cabin among them - not even Nynaeve wanted to be alone at night if she did not have to be. Each could have a cabin to herself at no extra charge, he told them; he had no other passengers, his cargo was aboard, and if Aes Sedai had urgent business downriver, he would not wait even an hour for anyone else who might want passage. They said again that one cabin would be sufficient.

hi wɑz stɑɹɾəld, ən ɪt hæd bɪn pleɪn fɹəm ɪz feɪs ðəɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, bʌt tʃɪn ɛlɪsɝ, bɔɹn ən bɹɛɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɑz nɑt wʌn tə kwɛstʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ wʌns ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ ɪntɛntʃənz klɪɹ. ɪf tu ʌv əm sim vɛɹi jʌŋ, wɛl, səm ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ jʌŋ.

He was startled, and it had been plain from his face that he did not understand, but Chin Ellisor, born and bred in Tar Valon, was not one to question Aes Sedai once they made their intentions clear. If two of them seemed very young, well, some Aes Sedai were young.

ði əbændən ɹuənz vænɪʃt bɪhaɪn ɛɡwin. ðə kɑləm ə smoʊk dʒɹu kloʊsɝ, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə hɪn ʌv ənʌðɝ mʌtʃ fɝðɝ stɪl fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk. ðə fɔɹəst wɑz tɝnɪŋ tə loʊ, ɡɹæsi hɪlz dɑɾəd wɪð θɪkəts. tʃɹiz ðət meɪd flaʊɝz ɪn ðə spɹɪŋ hæd ðɛm, taɪni waɪt blɑsəmz ɑn snoʊbɛɹi ən bɹaɪt ɹɛd ʃʊɡɑɝbɛɹi. wʌn tʃɹi ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɑz kʌvɝɾ ɪn ɹaʊnd waɪt flaʊɝz bɪɡɝ ðən əɹ tu hænz təɡɛðɝ. əkeɪʒənəli ə klaɪmɪŋ waɪld-ɹoʊz pʊt swɑθs ə jɛloʊ əɹ waɪt θɹu bɹæntʃəz θɪk wɪð ðə ɡɹin ə livz ən ðə ɹɛɾ ə nu ɡɹoʊθ. ɪt wɑz ɔl tu ʃɑɹp ə kɑntʃɹæs tə ði æʃəz ən ɹʌbəl tə bi ɪntaɪɝli plɛzənt.

The abandoned ruins vanished behind Egwene. The column of smoke drew closer, and there was a hint of another much further still from the riverbank. The forest was turning to low, grassy hills dotted with thickets. Trees that made flowers in the spring had them, tiny white blossoms on snowberry and bright red sugarberry. One tree she did not know was covered in round white flowers bigger than her two hands together. Occasionally a climbing wild-rose put swaths of yellow or white through branches thick with the green of leaves and the red of new growth. It was all too sharp a contrast to the ashes and rubble to be entirely pleasant.

ɛɡwin wɪʃt ʃi hæɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə kwɛstʃən hɝsɛlf ɹaɪt ðɛn. wʌn ʃi kəd tʃɹʌst. bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ paʊtʃ wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ʃi kəd bɛɹli fil ðə twɪstəd stoʊn ɹɪŋ ə ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪnsaɪd.

Egwene wished she had an Aes Sedai to question herself right then. One she could trust. Brushing her pouch with her fingers, she could barely feel the twisted stone ring of the ter'angreal inside.

ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪɾ ɪɾ ɛvɹi naɪt bʌt tu sɪns livɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ɪt hæd nɑt wɝk ðə seɪm weɪ twaɪs. oʊ, ʃi ɔlweɪz faʊn hɝsɛlf ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, bʌt ði oʊnli θɪŋ ʃi sɔ ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ɛni jus wɑz ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn əɡɛn, itʃ taɪm wɪθaʊt sɪlvi tə tɛl əɹ θɪŋz. ðəɹ wɑz sɝɾənli nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ.

She had tried it every night but two since leaving Tar Valon, and it had not worked the same way twice. Oh, she always found herself in Tel'aran'rhiod, but the only thing she saw that might have been any use was the Heart of the Stone again, each time without Silvie to tell her things. There was certainly nothing about the Black Ajah.

hɝ oʊn dʒɹimz, wɪθaʊt ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, hæd bɪn fɪld wɪð ɪmədʒəz ðət simd ɔlmoʊs laɪk ɡlɪmpsɪz ə ði ənsin wɝld. ɹænd hoʊldɪŋ ə sɔɹd ðət bleɪz laɪk ðə sʌn, tɪl ʃi kəd hɑɹdli si ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə sɔɹd, kəd hɑɹdli meɪk aʊt ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɪm əɾ ɔl. ɹænd θɹɛɾənd ɪn ə dʌzən weɪz, nʌn ə ðɛm ðə lis bɪt ɹil. ɪn wʌn dʒɹim i hæd bɪn ɑn ə hjudʒ stoʊnz bɔɹd, ðə blæk ən waɪt stoʊnz əz bɪɡ əz boʊldɝz, ən ɪm dɑdʒɪŋ ðə mɑnstʃɹəs hænz ðət muvd əm ən sim tə tʃɹaɪ tə kɹʌʃ ɪm ʌndɝ ðɛm. ɪt cʊɾə mɛn sʌmθɪŋ. ɪt vɛɹi pɹɑbli dɪd, bʌt bɪɑn ðə fæk ðət ɹænd wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ fɹəm sʌmwʌn, əɹ tu sʌmoʊnz - ʃi θɔt ðət mʌtʃ wɑz klɪɹ - bɪɑn ðæt, ʃi sɪmpli dɪd nɑt noʊ. aɪ kænɑt hɛlp hɪm, naʊ. aɪ hæv maɪ oʊn duɾi. aɪ doʊn ivən noʊ wɛɹ i ɪz, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪts pɹɑbli faɪv hʌnʒɹəd liɡz fɹəm hɪɹ.

Her own dreams, without the ter'angreal, had been filled with images that seemed almost like glimpses of the Unseen World. Rand holding a sword that blazed like the sun, till she could hardly see that it was a sword, could hardly make out that it was him at all. Rand threatened in a dozen ways, none of them the least bit real. In one dream he had been on a huge stones board, the black and white stones as big as boulders, and him dodging the monstrous hands that moved them and seemed to try to crush him under them. It could have meant something. It very probably did, but beyond the fact that Rand was in danger from someone, or two someones - she thought that much was clear - beyond that, she simply did not know. I cannot help him, now. I have my own duty. I don't even know where he is, except that it is probably five hundred leagues from here.

ʃi hæd dʒɹimd ə pɛɹɪn wɪð ə wʊlf, ən wɪð ə fælkən, ən ə hɔk - ən ðə fælkən ən ðə hɔk faɪɾɪŋ - ʌv pɛɹɪn ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm sʌmwʌn dɛdli, ən pɛɹɪn stɛpɪŋ wɪlɪŋli oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə taʊɝɪŋ klɪf waɪl seɪɪŋ, "ɪt mʌs bi dʌn. aɪ mʌs lɝn tə flaɪ bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɹitʃ ðə bɑɾəm." ðəɹ hæd bɪn wʌn dʒɹim ʌv ən il, ən ʃi θɔt ðət hæd tə də wɪð pɛɹɪn, tu, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ. ən ə dʒɹim ə mɪn, spɹɪŋɪŋ ə stil tʃɹæp bʌt sʌmhaʊ wɔkɪŋ θɹu ɪt wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz siɪŋ ɪt. ðəɹ hæd bɪn dʒɹimz ə mæt, tu. ʌv mæt wɪð daɪs spɪnɪŋ 'ɹaʊn ɪm - ʃi fɛlt ʃi nu wɛɹ ðət wʌn keɪm fɹəm - ʌv mæt biɪŋ fɑloʊd baɪ ə mæn u wɑz nɑt ðəɹ - ʃi stɪl dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt; ðəɹ wɑz ə mæn fɑloʊɪŋ, əɹ meɪbi mɔɹ ðən wʌn, bʌɾ ɪn səm weɪ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ðəɹ - ʌv mæt ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛspɝətli təwɔɹd sʌmθɪŋ ənsin ɪn ðə dɪstəns ðəɾ i hæd tə ɹitʃ, ən mæt wɪð ə wʊmən u sim tə bi tɔsɪŋ faɪɹwɝks əbaʊt. ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ, ʃi əsumd, bʌt ðət meɪd noʊ mɔɹ sɛns ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls.

She had dreamed of Perrin with a wolf, and with a falcon, and a hawk - and the falcon and the hawk fighting - of Perrin running from someone deadly, and Perrin stepping willingly over the edge of a towering cliff while saying, "It must be done. I must learn to fly before I reach the bottom." There had been one dream of an Aiel, and she thought that had to do with Perrin, too, but she was not sure. And a dream of Min, springing a steel trap but somehow walking through it without so much as seeing it. There had been dreams of Mat, too. Of Mat with dice spinning 'round him - she felt she knew where that one came from - of Mat being followed by a man who was not there - she still did not understand that; there was a man following, or maybe more than one, but in some way there was no one there - of Mat riding desperately toward something unseen in the distance that he had to reach, and Mat with a woman who seemed to be tossing fireworks about.
