An Illuminator, she assumed, but that made no more sense than anything else.

ʃi hæd hæd soʊ mɛni dʒɹimz ðət ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə daʊɾ əm ɔl. meɪbi ɪt hæd tə də wɪð juzɪŋ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil soʊ ɔfən, əɹ meɪbi wɪð dʒʌs kæɹiɪŋ ɪt. meɪbi ʃi wɑz faɪnəli lɝnɪŋ wʌɾ ə dʒɹimɝ dɪd. fɹæntɪk dʒɹimz, hɛktɪk dʒɹimz. mɛn ən wɪmən bɹeɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə keɪdʒ, ðən pʊɾɪŋ ɑn kɹaʊnz. ə wʊmən pleɪɪŋ wɪð pʌpəts, ən ənʌðɝ dʒɹim wɛɹ ðə stʃɹɪŋz ɑn pʌpəts lɛd tə ðə hænz ə lɑɹdʒɝ pʌpəts, ən ðɛɹ stʃɹɪŋz lɛd tə stɪl ɡɹeɪɾɝ pʌpəts, ɑn ən ɑn əntɪl ðə læst stʃɹɪŋz vænɪʃt ɪndə ʌnɪmædʒɪnəbəl haɪts. kɪŋz daɪɪŋ, kwinz wipɪŋ, bæɾəlz ɹeɪdʒɪŋ. waɪtkloʊks ɹævɪdʒɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ʃi hæɾ ivən dʒɹimd ə ðə sintʃæn əɡɛn. mɔɹ ðən wʌns. ðoʊz ʃi ʃʌɾ əweɪ ɪn ə dɑɹk kɔɹnɝ; ʃi wəd nɑt lɛt hɝsɛlf θɪŋk ə ðɛm. hɝ mʌðɝ ən fɑðɝ, ɛvɹi naɪt.

She had had so many dreams that she was beginning to doubt them all. Maybe it had to do with using the ter'angreal so often, or maybe with just carrying it. Maybe she was finally learning what a Dreamer did. Frantic dreams, hectic dreams. Men and women breaking out of a cage, then putting on crowns. A woman playing with puppets, and another dream where the strings on puppets led to the hands of larger puppets, and their strings led to still greater puppets, on and on until the last strings vanished into unimaginable heights. Kings dying, queens weeping, battles raging. Whitecloaks ravaging the Two Rivers. She had even dreamed of the Seanchan again. More than once. Those she shut away in a dark corner; she would not let herself think of them. Her mother and father, every night.

ʃi wɑz sɝɾən wʌt ðət mɛnt, ət list, əɹ θɔt ʃi wɑz. ɪt minz aɪm ɔf hʌntɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ən aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌt maɪ dʒɹimz min əɹ haʊ tə meɪk ðə ful tɛɹæŋɡɹil də wʌɾ ɪt ʃʊd, ən aɪm fɹaɪɾənd, ænd. . . . ən hoʊmsɪk. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt ʃi θɔt haʊ ɡʊɾ ɪt wəd bi tə hæv əɹ mʌðɝ sɛn əɹ ʌp tə bɛd noʊɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wəd bi bɛɾɝ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. oʊnli mʌðɝ kæn sɑlv maɪ pɹɑbləmz fəɹ mi ɛnimɔɹ, ən fɑðɝ kæn pɹɑməs tə tʃeɪs əweɪ mɑnstɝz ən meɪk mi bɪliv ɪt. aɪ hæv tə də ɪt maɪsɛlf naʊ.

She was certain what that meant, at least, or thought she was. It means I'm off hunting the Black Ajah, and I do not know what my dreams mean or how to make the fool ter'angreal do what it should, and I'm frightened, and. . . . And homesick. For an instant she thought how good it would be to have her mother send her up to bed knowing everything would be better in the morning. Only mother can't solve my problems for me anymore, and father can't promise to chase away monsters and make me believe it. I have to do it myself now.

haʊ fɑɹ ɪn ðə pæst ɔl ðət wɑz, naʊ. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪt bæk, nɑt ɹɪli, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn ə wɔɹm taɪm, ən ɪt sim soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ɪt wəd bi wʌndɝfəl dʒʌs tə si ðɛm əɡɛn, tə hɪɹ ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz. wən aɪ wɛɹ ðɪs ɹɪŋ ɑn ðə fɪŋɡɝ aɪ tʃuz baɪ ɹaɪt.

How far in the past all that was, now. She did not want it back, not really, but it had been a warm time, and it seemed so long ago. It would be wonderful just to see them again, to hear their voices. When I wear this ring on the finger I choose by right.

ʃi hæd faɪnəli lɛt nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn itʃ tʃɹaɪ slipɪŋ wʌn naɪt wɪð ðə stoʊn ɹɪŋ - sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ ɹɪlʌktənt ʃi hæd bɪn tə lɛɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ oʊn hænz - ən ðeɪ hæɾ əweɪkən tə spik ʌv wʌt wɑz ʃʊɹli tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, bʌt niðɝ hæd sin mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlɪmps ə ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn, nʌθɪŋ ðət wɑz ʌv ɛni jus.

She had finally let Nynaeve and Elayne each try sleeping one night with the stone ring - surprised at how reluctant she had been to let it out of her own hands - and they had awakened to speak of what was surely Tel'aran'rhiod, but neither had seen more than a glimpse of the Heart of the Stone, nothing that was of any use.

ðə θɪk kɑləm ə smoʊk naʊ leɪ əbɹɛst ə ðə blu kɹeɪn. pɝhæps faɪv əɹ sɪks maɪlz fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ, ʃi θɔt. ði ʌðɝ wɑz oʊnli ə smʌdʒ ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən. ɪt kəɾ ɔlmoʊst əv bɪn ə klaʊd, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz nɑt. smɔl θɪkəts ɡɹu taɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk ɪn səm pleɪsəz, ən bɪtwin əm ðə ɡɹæs keɪm ɹaɪt daʊn tə ðə wɔɾɝ ɪksɛpt wɛɹ ən ʌndɝkʌt bæŋk hæd fɔlən ɪn.

The thick column of smoke now lay abreast of the Blue Crane. Perhaps five or six miles from the river, she thought. The other was only a smudge on the horizon. It could almost have been a cloud, but she was sure it was not. Small thickets grew tight along the riverbank in some places, and between them the grass came right down to the water except where an undercut bank had fallen in.

ɪleɪn keɪm ɑn dɛk ən dʒɔɪn əɹ ət ðə ɹeɪl, ðə wɪnd wɪpɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk kloʊk əz wɛl. ʃi wɔɹ stɝɾi wʊl, tu. ðət hæd bɪn wʌn ɑɹɡjəmənt nɪneɪiv wʌn. ðɛɹ kloʊðz. ɛɡwin hæd meɪnteɪn ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlweɪz wɔɹ ðə bɛst, ivən wən ðeɪ tʃɹævəld - ʃi hæd bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə sɪlks ʃi wɔɹ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd - bʌt nɪneɪiv pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðəɾ ivən wɪð əz mʌtʃ ɡoʊld əz ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd lɛft ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ wɔɹdʒɹoʊb, ən ɪt wɑz ə fæt pɝs, ðeɪ stɪl hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ mʌtʃ θɪŋz wəd kɑs daʊnɹɪvɝ. ðə sɝvəns sɛd mæt hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðə sɪvəl wɔɹ ɪn kɛɹhin, ən wʌɾ ɪt hæd dʌn tə pɹaɪsəz. tə ɛɡwinz sɝpɹaɪz, ɪleɪn hæd pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðət bɹaʊn sɪstɝz wɔɹ wʊl mɔɹ ɔfən ðən sɪlk. ɪleɪn hæd bɪn soʊ iɡɝ tə bi əweɪ fɹəm ðə kɪtʃən, ɛɡwin θɔt, ʃi wʊɾə wɔɹn ɹæɡz.

Elayne came on deck and joined her at the rail, the wind whipping her dark cloak as well. She wore sturdy wool, too. That had been one argument Nynaeve won. Their clothes. Egwene had maintained that Aes Sedai always wore the best, even when they traveled - she had been thinking of the silks she wore in Tel'aran'rhiod - but Nynaeve pointed out that even with as much gold as the Amyrlin had left in the back of her wardrobe, and it was a fat purse, they still had no idea how much things would cost downriver. The servants said Mat had been right about the civil war in Cairhien, and what it had done to prices. To Egwene's surprise, Elayne had pointed out that Brown sisters wore wool more often than silk. Elayne had been so eager to be away from the kitchen, Egwene thought, she would have worn rags.

aɪ wʌndɝ haʊ mæt ɪz duɪŋ? noʊ daʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə daɪs wɪð ðə kæptən fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ ʃɪp hiz tʃɹævlɪŋ ɑn.

I wonder how Mat is doing? No doubt trying to dice with the captain for whatever ship he's traveling on.

"tɛɹəbəl," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd. "ɪɾ ɪz soʊ tɛɹəbəl."

"Terrible," Elayne murmured. "It is so terrible."

"wʌɾ ɪz?" ɛɡwin sɛɾ æbsənli. aɪ hoʊp i ɪzənt ʃoʊɪŋ ðət peɪpɝ wi ɡeɪv ɪm ɝaʊn tu fɹili.

"What is?" Egwene said absently. I hope he isn't showing that paper we gave him around too freely.

ɪleɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ə stɑɹɾəld lʊk, ən ðən ə fɹaʊn. "ðæt!" ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd təwɔɹd ðə dɪstən smoʊk. "haʊ kən jə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt?"

Elayne gave her a startled look, and then a frown. "That!" She gestured toward the distant smoke. "How can you ignore it?"

"aɪ kən ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt kəz aɪ də nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt ðə pipəl ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu, kəz aɪ kænɑt də ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ən kəz wɪv tə ɹitʃ tiɹ. kəz wʌt wɝ hʌntɪŋ ɪz ɪn tɛɹ." ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd əɾ əɹ oʊn viəməns. aɪ kæn də ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt. ən ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪz ɪn tiɹ.

"I can ignore it because I do not want to think of what the people are going through, because I cannot do anything about it, and because we have to reach Tear. Because what we're hunting is in Tear." She was surprised at her own vehemence. I can't do anything about it. And the Black Ajah is in Tear.

ðə mɔɹ ʃi θɔɾ ʌv ɪt, ðə mɔɹ sɝɾən ʃi bɪkeɪm ðət ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə faɪn ə weɪ ɪndə ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn. pɝhæps noʊ wʌn bʌt ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ə tiɹ wɝ əlaʊɾ ɪndə ɪt, bʌt ʃi wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ kənvɪns ðət ðə ki tə spɹɪŋɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑz tʃɹæp ən θwɔɹɾɪŋ əm leɪ ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn.

The more she thought of it, the more certain she became that they would have to find a way into the Heart of the Stone. Perhaps no one but the High Lords of Tear were allowed into it, but she was becoming convinced that the key to springing the Black Ajah's trap and thwarting them lay in the Heart of the Stone.

"aɪ noʊ ɔl ə ðæt, ɛɡwin, bʌɾ ɪt dʌz nɑt stɑp mi filɪŋ fəɹ ðə kɛɹhinɪn."

"I know all of that, Egwene, but it does not stop me feeling for the Cairhienin."

"aɪ hæv hɝd lɛktʃɝz əbaʊt ðə wɔɹz ændɝ fɔt wɪð kɛɹhin," ɛɡwin sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "bɛn sədaɪ sɛz jə ən kɛɹhin əv fɔt mɔɹ ɔfən ðən ɛni tu neɪʃənz ɪksɛp tiɹ ən ɪljən."

"I have heard lectures about the wars Andor fought with Cairhien," Egwene said dryly. "Bennae Sedai says you and Cairhien have fought more often than any two nations except Tear and Illian."

ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɡeɪv əɹ ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. ɪleɪn hæd nɛvɝ ɡɑɾən juz tə ɛɡwinz ɹəfjuzəl tə ədmɪt ʃi wɑz ændɔɝən hɝsɛlf. ət list, laɪnz ɑn mæps sɛd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv ændɝ, ən ɪleɪn bɪliv ðə mæps.

The other woman gave her a sidelong look. Elayne had never gotten used to Egwene's refusal to admit she was Andoran herself. At least, lines on maps said the Two Rivers was part of Andor, and Elayne believed the maps.

"wi hæv fɔt wɔɹz əɡɛns ðɛm, ɛɡwin, bʌt sɪns ðə dæmədʒ ðeɪ sʌfɝɾ ɪn ði il wɔɹ, ændɝ əz soʊld əm nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪn əz tiɹ hæz. ðə tʃɹeɪɾ əz stɑpt, naʊ. wɪð ɛvɹi kɛɹhinɪn haʊs faɪɾɪŋ ɛvɹi ʌðɝ fəɹ ðə sʌn θɹoʊn, hu wəd baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪn, əɹ si ɪt dɪstʃɹɪbjəɾəd tə ðə pipəl? ɪf ðə faɪɾɪŋ ɪz əz bæɾ əz wʌt wiv sin ɑn ðə bæŋks. . . . wɛl. jə kænɑt fiɾ ə pipəl fəɹ twɛnti jɪɹz ən fil nʌθɪŋ fəɹ əm wən ðeɪ mʌs bi stɑɹvɪŋ."

"We have fought wars against them, Egwene, but since the damage they suffered in the Aiel War, Andor has sold them nearly as much grain as Tear has. The trade has stopped, now. With every Cairhienin House fighting every other for the Sun Throne, who would buy the grain, or see it distributed to the people? If the fighting is as bad as what we've seen on the banks. . . . Well. You cannot feed a people for twenty years and feel nothing for them when they must be starving."

"eɪ ɡɹeɪ mæn," ɛɡwin sɛd, ən ɪleɪn dʒʌmpt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ət wʌns. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd hɝ.

"A Gray Man," Egwene said, and Elayne jumped, trying to look in every direction at once. The glow of saidar surrounded her.

"wɛɹ?"

"Where?"

ɛɡwin tʊk ə sloʊɝ lʊk ɝaʊn ðə dɛks, bʌt tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ. kæptən ɛlɪsɝ stɪl stʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝn, baɪ ðə ʃɝtləs mæn hoʊldɪŋ ðə lɔŋ tɪlɝ. ənʌðɝ seɪlɝ wɑz ʌp ɪn ðə vɛɹi baʊ, skænɪŋ ðə wɔɾɝz əhɛd fəɹ saɪnz ə səbmɝdʒ mʌdbæŋks, ən tu mɔɹ pæɾəd əbaʊt ðə dɛk, naʊ ən əɡɛn ədʒʌstɪŋ ə ɹoʊp tə ðə seɪlz. ðə ɹɛst ə ðə kɹu wɝ ɔl bɪloʊ. wʌn ə ðə pɛɹ stɑp tə tʃɛk ðə læʃɪŋz ɑn ðə ɹoʊboʊt taɪɾ ʌpsaɪd daʊn ɑn ðə dɛk; ʃi weɪɾəd fəɹ ɪm tə ɡoʊ ɑn bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ.

Egwene took a slower look around the decks, but to make sure no one was close enough to overhear. Captain Ellisor still stood in the stern, by the shirtless man holding the long tiller. Another sailor was up in the very bow, scanning the waters ahead for signs of submerged mudbanks, and two more padded about the deck, now and again adjusting a rope to the sails. The rest of the crew were all below. One of the pair stopped to check the lashings on the rowboat tied upside down on the deck; she waited for him to go on before speaking.

"ful!" ʃi mʌɾɝd sɔfli. "mi, ɪleɪn, nɑt ju, soʊ doʊnt ɡlaʊɝ ət mi laɪk ðæt." ʃi kəntɪnjuɾ ɪn ə wɪspɝ. "eɪ ɡɹeɪ mæn ɪz æftɝ mæt, ɪleɪn. ðət mʌs bi wʌt ðət dʒɹim mɛnt, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ sɔ ɪt. aɪm ə ful!"

"Fool!" she muttered softly. "Me, Elayne, not you, so don't glower at me like that." She continued in a whisper. "A Gray Man is after Mat, Elayne. That must be what that dream meant, but I never saw it. I am a fool!"

ðə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn ɪleɪn vænɪʃt. "du nɑt bi soʊ hɑɹɾ ɑn jɝsɛlf," ʃi wɪspɝd bæk. "pɝhæps ɪt dʌz min ðæt, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd nɑt si ɪt, ən niðɝ dɪd nɪneɪiv." ʃi pɔzd; ɹɛd-ɡoʊl kɝlz swʌŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "bʌɾ ɪt dʌzn meɪk sɛns, ɛɡwin. waɪ wəɾ ə ɡɹeɪ mæn bi æftɝ mæt? ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ ɪn maɪ lɛɾɝ tə maɪ mʌðɝ ðət kəd hɑɹm əs ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst."

The glow around Elayne vanished. "Do not be so hard on yourself," she whispered back. "Perhaps it does mean that, but I did not see it, and neither did Nynaeve." She paused; red-gold curls swung as she shook her head. "But it doesn't make sense, Egwene. Why would a Gray Man be after Mat? There is nothing in my letter to my mother that could harm us in the slightest."

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ waɪ." ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd. "ðɛɹ əz tə bi ə ɹizən. aɪm ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɪz wʌt ðət dʒɹim minz."

"I do not know why." Egwene frowned. "There has to be a reason. I am sure that is what that dream means."

"ivən ɪf jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt, ɛɡwin, ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ jə kən də əbaʊɾ ɪt."

"Even if you are right, Egwene, there is nothing you can do about it."

"aɪ noʊ ðæt," ɛɡwin sɛd bɪɾɝli. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən noʊ wɛðɝ i wɑz əhɛɾ ə ðɛm əɹ bɪhaɪnd. əhɛd, ʃi səspɛktəd; mæt wʊɾə lɛft wɪθaʊɾ ɛni dɪleɪ. "iðɝ weɪ," ʃi mʌɾɝd tə hɝsɛlf, "ɪt dʌz noʊ ɡʊd. aɪ faɪnəli noʊ wʌt wʌn ə maɪ dʒɹimz minz, ən ɪt dʌzn hɛlp ə hɛmstɪtʃ wɝθ!"

"I know that," Egwene said bitterly. She did not even know whether he was ahead of them or behind. Ahead, she suspected; Mat would have left without any delay. "Either way," she muttered to herself, "it does no good. I finally know what one of my dreams means, and it doesn't help a hemstitch worth!"

"bʌɾ ɪf jə noʊ wʌn minɪŋ," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ, "pɝhæps naʊ jəl noʊ ʌðɝz. ɪf wi sɪt daʊn ən tɔk əm oʊvɝ, pɝhæps - "

"But if you know one meaning," Elayne told her, "perhaps now you will know others. If we sit down and talk them over, perhaps - "

ðə blu kɹeɪn ɡeɪv ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ lɝtʃ, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪleɪn tə ðə dɛk ən ɛɡwin ɑn tɑp ə hɝ. wən ɛɡwin stʃɹʌɡəl tə hɝ fit, ðə ʃɔɹlaɪn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ slɪd baɪ. ðə vɛsəl hæd hɔltəd, wɪð ðə baʊ ɹeɪzd ən ðə dɛk kæntɪd tə wʌn saɪd. ðə seɪlz flæp nɔɪzəli ɪn ðə wɪnd.

The Blue Crane gave a shuddering lurch, throwing Elayne to the deck and Egwene on top of her. When Egwene struggled to her feet, the shoreline no longer slid by. The vessel had halted, with the bow raised and the deck canted to one side. The sails flapped noisily in the wind.

tʃɪn ɛlɪsɝ pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fiɾ ən ɹæn fəɹ ðə baʊ, livɪŋ ðə tɪlɝmən tə ɹaɪz ɑn ɪz oʊn. "ju blaɪnd wɝm ʌv ə fɑɹmɝ!" hi ɹɔɹd təwɔɹd ðə mæn ɪn ðə baʊ, hu wɑz klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə ɹeɪl tə kip fɹəm fɔlɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ oʊvɝ. "ju dɝt-ɡɹʌbɪŋ ɡɛɾ ʌv ə ɡoʊt! hævən jə bɪn ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ lɔŋ ɪnʌf jɛt tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz haʊ ðə wɔɾɝ ɹʌfəlz oʊvɝ ə mʌdflæt?" hi siz ðə mæn ɑn ðə ɹeɪl baɪ ðə ʃoʊldɝz ən pʊld ɪm bæk ɑntu ðə dɛk, bʌɾ oʊnli tə ʃʌv ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ soʊ hi kəd pɪɹ daʊn oʊvɝ ðə baʊ hɪmsɛlf. "ɪf juv pʊɾ ə hoʊl ɪn maɪ hʌl, əl juz jəɹ ɡʌts fəɹ kɔkɪŋ!"

Chin Ellisor pushed himself to his feet and ran for the bow, leaving the tillerman to rise on his own. "You blind worm of a farmer!" he roared toward the man in the bow, who was clinging to the rail to keep from falling the rest of the way over. "You dirt-grubbing get of a goat! Haven't you been on the river long enough yet to recognize how the water ruffles over a mudflat?" He seized the man on the rail by the shoulders and pulled him back onto the deck, but only to shove him out of the way so he could peer down over the bow himself. "If you've put a hole in my hull, I will use your guts for caulking!"

ði ʌðɝ kɹumɪn wɝ klæmbɝɪŋ tə ðɛɹ fit, naʊ, ən mɔɹ keɪm skɹæmbəlɪŋ ʌp fɹəm bɪloʊ. ðeɪ ɔl ɹæn tə klʌstɝ ɝaʊn ðə kæptən.

The other crewmen were clambering to their feet, now, and more came scrambling up from below. They all ran to cluster around the captain.

nɪneɪiv əpɪɹɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə læɾɝ ðət lɛd daʊn tə ðə pæsənʒɝ kæbənz, stɪl stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ əɹ skɝts. wɪð ə ʃɑɹp tʌɡ əɾ əɹ bɹeɪd, ʃi fɹaʊn ət ðə nɑɾ ə mɛn ɪn ðə baʊ, ðən stʃɹoʊd tə ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn. "hi ɹæn əs ɑntu sʌmθɪŋ, dɪd hi? æftɝ ɔl ɪz tɔk ə noʊɪŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ əz wɛl əz i noʊz ɪz waɪf. ðə wʊmən pɹɑbli nɛvɝ ɹəsivz əz mʌtʃ əz ə smaɪl fɹəm hɪm." ʃi dʒɝk ðə θɪk bɹeɪɾ əɡɛn ən wɛn fɔɹwɝd, pʊʃɪŋ əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə seɪlɝz tə ɹitʃ ðə kæptən. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɪntɛn ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ bɪloʊ.

Nynaeve appeared at the head of the ladder that led down to the passenger cabins, still straightening her skirts. With a sharp tug at her braid, she frowned at the knot of men in the bow, then strode to Egwene and Elayne. "He ran us onto something, did he? After all his talk of knowing the river as well as he knows his wife. The woman probably never receives as much as a smile from him." She jerked the thick braid again and went forward, pushing her way through the sailors to reach the captain. They were all intent on the water below.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɝ. hɪl əv əs ɔf fæstɝ ɪf hiz lɛf tə ɪt. nɪneɪiv wɑz pɹɑbli tɛlɪŋ ɪm haʊ tə də ðə wɝk. ɪleɪn sim tə fil ðə seɪm weɪ, fɹəm ðə ɹufəl ʃeɪk ə ðə hɛd ʃi ɡeɪv əz ʃi wɑtʃt ðə kæptən ən kɹumɪn ɔl tɝn ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən ɹɪspɛkfəli fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ʌndɝ ðə baʊ tə nɪneɪiv.

There was no point in joining her. He will have us off faster if he's left to it. Nynaeve was probably telling him how to do the work. Elayne seemed to feel the same way, from the rueful shake of the head she gave as she watched the captain and crewmen all turn their attention respectfully from whatever was under the bow to Nynaeve.

ə ɹɪpəl ʌv ædʒəteɪʃən ɹæn θɹu ðə mɛn, ən ɡɹu stʃɹɔŋɝ. fəɹ ə moʊmən ðə kæptənz hænz kəd bi sin, weɪvɪŋ ɪn pɹoʊɾɛst oʊvɝ ði ʌðɝ mɛnz hɛdz, ən ðən nɪneɪiv wɑz stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm əm - ðeɪ meɪd weɪ, boʊɪŋ naʊ - wɪð ɛlɪsɝ hɝiɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ən mɑpɪŋ ɪz ɹaʊn feɪs wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd hæŋkɝtʃɪf. hɪz æŋkʃəs vɔɪs bɪkeɪm ɑɾəbəl əz ðeɪ dʒɹu nɪɹ.

A ripple of agitation ran through the men, and grew stronger. For a moment the captain's hands could be seen, waving in protest over the other men's heads, and then Nynaeve was striding away from them - they made way, bowing now - with Ellisor hurrying beside her and mopping his round face with a large red handkerchief. His anxious voice became audible as they drew near.

". . . ə ɡʊd fɪftin maɪlz tə ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ ɑn ði ændɝ saɪd, ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ət lis faɪv əɹ sɪks maɪlz daʊnɹɪvɝ ɑn ðə kɛɹhin saɪd! ændɔɝən soʊlʒɝz hoʊld ɪt, ɪts tʃɹu, bʌt ðeɪ də nɑt hoʊl ðə maɪlz fɹəm hɪɹ tə ðɛɹ!" hi waɪpt əɾ ɪz feɪs əz ɪf i wɝ dʒɹɪpɪŋ swɛt.

". . . a good fifteen miles to the next village on the Andor side, Aes Sedai, and at least five or six miles downriver on the Cairhien side! Andoran soldiers hold it, it is true, but they do not hold the miles from here to there!" He wiped at his face as if he were dripping sweat.

"ə sʌŋkən ʃɪp," nɪneɪiv toʊl ðə ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən. "ðə wɝk ə ɹɪvɝ bɹɪɡænz, ðə kæptən θɪŋks. hi minz tə tʃɹaɪ bækɪŋ ɔf ɪt wɪð ðə swips, bʌɾ i dʌz nɑt sim tə θɪŋk ðət wɪl wɝk."

"A sunken ship," Nynaeve told the the other two women. "The work of river brigands, the captain thinks. He means to try backing off it with the sweeps, but he does not seem to think that will work."

"wi wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ fæst wən wi hɪt, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ wɑntəd tə meɪk ɡʊd spid fəɹ ju." ɛlɪsɝ ɹʌbd ivən hɑɹɾɝ əɾ ɪz feɪs. hi wɑz əfɹeɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd bleɪm hɪm, ɛɡwin ɹilaɪzd. "wi ɑɹ stʌk hɑɹd. bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk wəɹ teɪkɪŋ wɔɾɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə wɝi. ənʌðɝ ʃɪp wɪl bi əlɔŋ. tu sɛts ə swips wɪl ʃʊɹli ɡɛɾ əs fɹi. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid fəɹ jə tə bi pʊɾ əʃɔɹ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ də swɛɹ ɪt, baɪ ðə laɪt."

"We were running fast when we hit, Aes Sedai. I wanted to make good speed for you." Ellisor rubbed even harder at his face. He was afraid the Aes Sedai would blame him, Egwene realized. "We are stuck hard. But I do not think we are taking water, Aes Sedai. There is no need to worry. Another ship will be along. Two sets of sweeps will surely get us free. There is no need for you to be put ashore, Aes Sedai. I do swear it, by the Light."

"ju wɝ θɪŋkɪŋ ə livɪŋ ðə ʃɪp?" ɛɡwin æskt. "du jə θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪz waɪz?"

"You were thinking of leaving the ship?" Egwene asked. "Do you think that is wise?"

"ʌv kɔɹs, ɪts - !" nɪneɪiv stɑpt ən fɹaʊn ət hɝ. ɛɡwin ɹɪtɝn ðə fɹaʊn wɪð ə lɛvəl stɛɹ. nɪneɪiv wɛn ɑn ɪn ə kɑmɝ toʊn, ɪf stɪl ə taɪt wʌn. "ðə kæptən sɛz ɪt meɪ bi ən aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ənʌðɝ ʃɪp kʌmz əlɔŋ. wʌn wɪð ɪnʌf swips tə meɪk ə dɪfɝəns. əɹ ə deɪ. əɹ tu, meɪbi. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk wi kən əfɔɹd tə weɪst ə deɪ əɹ tu weɪɾɪŋ. wi kən bi ɪn ðɪs vɪlədʒ - wʌd jə kɔl ɪt, kæptən? dʒʊɹin? - wi kən wɔk tə dʒʊɹin ɪn tu aʊɝz əɹ lɛs. ɪf kæptən ɛlɪsɝ fɹiz ɪz vɛsəl əz kwɪkli əz i hoʊps, wi kən ɹɪbɔɹd ðɛn. hi sɛz hɪl stɑp tə si ɪf wəɹ ðɛɹ. ɪf i dʌz nɑt ɡɛt fɹi, ðoʊ, wi kən teɪk ʃɪp fɹəm dʒʊɹin. wi meɪ ivən faɪn ə vɛsəl weɪɾɪŋ. ðə kæptən sɛz tʃɹeɪɾɝz də stɑp ðɛɹ, kəz ə ði ændɔɝən soʊlʒɝz." ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs ɡɹu taɪɾɝ. "hæv aɪ ɪkspleɪn maɪ ɹizənɪŋ fʊli ɪnʌf? dʒju nid mɔɹ?"

"Of course, it's - !" Nynaeve stopped and frowned at her. Egwene returned the frown with a level stare. Nynaeve went on in a calmer tone, if still a tight one. "The captain says it may be an hour before another ship comes along. One with enough sweeps to make a difference. Or a day. Or two, maybe. I do not think we can afford to waste a day or two waiting. We can be in this village - what did you call it, Captain? Jurene? - we can walk to Jurene in two hours or less. If Captain Ellisor frees his vessel as quickly as he hopes, we can reboard then. He says he will stop to see if we are there. If he does not get free, though, we can take ship from Jurene. We may even find a vessel waiting. The captain says traders do stop there, because of the Andoran soldiers." She drew a deep breath, but her voice grew tighter. "Have I explained my reasoning fully enough? Do you need more?"

"ɪɾ ɪz klɪɹ tə mi," ɪleɪn pʊɾ ɪn kwɪkli bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin kəd spik. "æn ɪt saʊnz ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə. jə θɪŋk ɪts ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə, tu, doʊn ju, ɛɡwin?"

"It is clear to me," Elayne put in quickly before Egwene could speak. "And it sounds a good idea. You think it is a good idea, too, don't you, Egwene?"

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ nɑd. "aɪ səpoʊz ɪɾ ɪz."

Egwene gave a grudging nod. "I suppose it is."

"bʌt, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɛlɪsɝ pɹətɛstəd, "æt list ɡoʊ tə ði ændɝ bæŋk. ðə wɔɹ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. bɹɪɡænz, ən ɛvɹi sɔɹɾ ə ɹʌfaɪən, ən ðə soʊlʒɝz nɑt mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ. ðə vɛɹi ɹɛk ʌndɝ əɹ baʊ ʃoʊz ðə sɔɹɾ ə mɛn ðeɪ ɑɹ."

"But, Aes Sedai," Ellisor protested, "at least go to the Andor bank. The war, Aes Sedai. Brigands, and every sort of ruffian, and the soldiers not much better. The very wreck under our bow shows the sort of men they are."

"wi hæv nɑt sin ə lɪvɪŋ soʊl ɑn ðə kɛɹhin saɪd," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "æn ɪn ɛni keɪs, wəɹ fɑɹ fɹəm dɪfɛnsləs, kæptən. ən əl nɑt wɔk fɪftin maɪlz wən aɪ kən wɔk sɪks."

"We have not seen a living soul on the Cairhien side," Nynaeve said, "and in any case, we are far from defenseless, Captain. And I will not walk fifteen miles when I can walk six."

"ʌv kɔɹs, ɛɛs sədaɪ." ɛlɪsɝ ɹɪli wɑz swɛɾɪŋ, naʊ. "aɪ dɪd nɑt min tə sədʒɛst. . . . ʌv kɔɹs jə ɑɹ nɑt dɪfɛnsləs, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ dɪd nɑt min tə sədʒɛst ɪt." hi waɪpt ɪz feɪs fjʊɹiəsli, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl ɡlɪsənd.

"Of course, Aes Sedai." Ellisor really was sweating, now. "I did not mean to suggest. . . . Of course you are not defenseless, Aes Sedai. I did not mean to suggest it." He wiped his face furiously, but it still glistened.

nɪneɪiv oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin, ən sim tə tʃeɪnʒ wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə seɪ. "aɪ æm ɡoʊɪŋ bɪloʊ fəɹ maɪ θɪŋz," ʃi toʊl ði ɛɹ hæfweɪ bɪtwin ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn, ðən tɝn ɑn ɛlɪsɝ. "kæptən, meɪk jəɹ ɹoʊboʊt ɹɛɾi." hi baʊɾ ən skɝiɾ əweɪ ivən bɪfɔɹ ʃi tɝn fəɹ ðə hætʃ, ən wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ mɛn tə pʊt ðə boʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz bɪloʊ.

Nynaeve opened her mouth, glanced at Egwene, and seemed to change what she had intended to say. "I am going below for my things," she told the air halfway between Egwene and Elayne, then turned on Ellisor. "Captain, make your rowboat ready." He bowed and scurried away even before she turned for the hatch, and was shouting for men to put the boat over the side before she was below.

"ɪf wʌn ə jə sɛz 'ʌp,' " ɪleɪn mɝmɝd, "ði ʌðɝ sɛz 'daʊn.' ɪf jə də nɑt stɑp ɪt, wi meɪ nɑt ɹitʃ tiɹ."

"If one of you says 'up,' " Elayne murmured, "the other says 'down.' If you do not stop it, we may not reach Tear."

"wi wɪl ɹitʃ tɛɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn sunɝ wʌns nɪneɪiv ɹiəlaɪzɪz ʃiz nɑt ðə wɪzdəm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. wəɹ ɔl" - ʃi dɪd nɑt seɪ æksɛptɪd; ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni mɛn hɝiɪŋ əbaʊt - "ɑn ðə seɪm lɛvəl, naʊ." ɪleɪn saɪd.

"We will reach Tear," Egwene said. "And sooner once Nynaeve realizes she is not the Wisdom any longer. We are all" - she did not say Accepted; there were two many men hurrying about - "on the same level, now." Elayne sighed.

ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ ðə ɹoʊboʊt hæd fɛɹiɾ əm əʃɔɹ, ən ðeɪ wɝ stændɪŋ ɑn ðə bæŋk wɪð wɔkɪŋ stæfs ɪn hænd, ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz ɪn bʌndəlz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, ən hʌŋ əbaʊɾ əm ɪn paʊtʃəz ən skɹɪps. ɹoʊlɪŋ ɡɹæslæn ən skæɾɝd kɑpsɪz sɝaʊndəd ðɛm, ðoʊ ðə hɪlz wɝ fɔɹəstəɾ ə fju maɪlz ɪn fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðə swips ɑn ðə blu kɹeɪn wɝ kʌɾɪŋ ʌp fɹɔθ, bʌt feɪlɪŋ tə bʌdʒ ðə vɛsəl. ɛɡwin tɝn ən stɑɹɾəd saʊθ wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ ɡlæns. ən bɪfɔɹ nɪneɪiv kəd teɪk ðə lɛd.

In short order the rowboat had ferried them ashore, and they were standing on the bank with walking staffs in hand, their belongings in bundles on their backs, and hung about them in pouches and scripts. Rolling grassland and scattered copses surrounded them, though the hills were forested a few miles in from the river. The sweeps on the Blue Crane were cutting up froth, but failing to budge the vessel. Egwene turned and started south without another glance. And before Nynaeve could take the lead.

wən ði ʌðɝz kɑɾ ʌp tə hɝ, ɪleɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ə ɹipɹoʊvɪŋ lʊk. nɪneɪiv wɔk stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. ɪleɪn toʊl nɪneɪiv wʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd sɛɾ əbaʊt mæt ən ə ɡɹeɪ mæn, bʌt ði oʊldɝ wʊmən lɪsən ɪn saɪləns ən oʊnli sɛd, "hil əv tə lʊk æftɝ hɪmsɛlf," wɪθaʊt pɔzɪŋ ɪn əɹ stʃɹaɪd. æftɝ ə taɪm, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ɡeɪv ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ði ʌðɝ tu tɔk, ən ðeɪ ɔl wɔkt ɪn saɪləns.

When the others caught up to her, Elayne gave her a reproving look. Nynaeve walked staring straight ahead. Elayne told Nynaeve what Egwene had said about Mat and a Gray Man, but the older woman listened in silence and only said, "He'll have to look after himself," without pausing in her stride. After a time, the Daughter-Heir gave up trying to make the other two talk, and they all walked in silence.

klʌmps ə tʃɹiz kloʊs əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk sun hɪd ðə blu kɹeɪn, θɪk ɡɹoʊθs ʌv wɔɾɝoʊk ən wɪloʊ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ θɹu ðə kɑpsɪz, smɔl əz ðeɪ wɝ, fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl maɪt bi haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz ʌndɝ ðɛɹ bɹæntʃəz. ə fju loʊ bʊʃəz ɡɹu skæɾɝd bɪtwin ðə θɪkəts hɪɹ kloʊs tə ðə ɹɪvɝ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ tu spɑɹs tə haɪɾ ə tʃaɪl mʌtʃ lɛs ə bɹɪɡənd, ən ðeɪ wɝ waɪdli speɪst.

Clumps of trees close along the riverbank soon hid the Blue Crane, thick growths of wateroak and willow. They did not go through the copses, small as they were, for anything at all might be hiding in the shadows under their branches. A few low bushes grew scattered between the thickets here close to the river, but they were too sparse to hide a child much less a brigand, and they were widely spaced.

"ɪf wi də si bɹɪɡænz," ɛɡwin ənaʊnst, "aɪ æm gɑnə dɪfɛn maɪsɛlf. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ æmɪɝlɪn lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz hɪɹ."

"If we do see brigands," Egwene announced, "I am going to defend myself. There is no Amyrlin looking over our shoulders here."

nɪneɪivz maʊθ θɪnd. "ɪf nid bi," ʃi toʊl ði ɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, "wi kən fɹaɪɾən ɔf ɛni bɹɪɡænz ðə weɪ wi dɪd ðoʊz waɪtkloʊks. ɪf wi kən faɪnd noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ."

Nynaeve's mouth thinned. "If need be," she told the air in front of her, "we can frighten off any brigands the way we did those Whitecloaks. If we can find no other way."

"aɪ wɪʃ jə wəd nɑt tɔk ə bɹɪɡænz," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ wəd laɪk tə ɹitʃ ðɪs vɪlədʒ wɪθaʊt - "

"I wish you would not talk of brigands," Elayne said. "I would like to reach this village without - "

ə fɪɡjɝ ɪn bɹaʊn ən ɡɹeɪ ɹoʊz fɹəm bɪhaɪn ə bʊʃ stændɪŋ baɪ ɪtsɛlf ɔlmoʊst ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm.

A figure in brown and gray rose from behind a bush standing by itself almost in front of them.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾieɪt


CHAPTER 38

meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ


Maidens of the Spear

ɛɡwin ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə skɹim wɑz wɛl aʊɾ ə hɝ maʊθ, ən ʃi sɔ ðə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn ɪleɪn, tu. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt ʃi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɛlɪsɝ hæd hɝd ðɛɹ skɹimz ən wəd sɛn hɛlp; ðə blu kɹeɪn kəd nɑt bi mɔɹ ðən ə maɪl ʌpɹɪvɝ. ðən ʃi wɑz dɪsmɪsɪŋ ðə nid fəɹ hɛlp, ɔlɹɛɾi wivɪŋ floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ən faɪɝ ɪndə laɪtnɪŋ. ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst stɪl hɪɹ ðɛɹ jɛlɪŋ.

Egwene embraced saidar before the scream was well out of her mouth, and she saw the glow around Elayne, too. For an instant she wondered if Ellisor had heard their screams and would send help; the Blue Crane could not be more than a mile upriver. Then she was dismissing the need for help, already weaving flows of Air and Fire into lightning. She could almost still hear their yelling.

nɪneɪiv wɑz sɪmpli stændɪŋ ðəɹ wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz kɹɔs bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts ən ə fɝm ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ðət wɑz kəz ʃi wɑz nɑɾ æŋɡɹi ɪnʌf tə tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, əɹ kəz ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sin wʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz dʒʌs naʊ siɪŋ. ðə pɝsən feɪsɪŋ əm wɑz ə wʊmən noʊ oʊldɝ ðən ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf, ɪf sʌmwʌt tɔlɝ.

Nynaeve was simply standing there with her arms crossed beneath her breasts and a firm expression on her face, but Egwene was not sure whether that was because she was not angry enough to touch the True Source, or because she had already seen what Egwene was just now seeing. The person facing them was a woman no older than Egwene herself, if somewhat taller.

ʃi dɪd nɑt lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ. mɛn wɝ səmtaɪmz sɪli ɪnʌf tə θɪŋk ə wʊmən wɑz hɑɹmləs mɪɹli kəz ʃi wɑz ə wʊmən; ɛɡwin hæd noʊ sətʃ ɪluʒənz. ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ maɪnd ʃi noʊɾəd ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə ɡloʊ. ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ mʌst stɪl hɑɹbɝ fulɪʃ noʊʃənz. ʃi wɑz nɛvɝ ə sintʃæn pɹɪznɝ.

She did not let go of saidar. Men were sometimes silly enough to think a woman was harmless merely because she was a woman; Egwene had no such illusions. In a corner of her mind she noted that Elayne was no longer surrounded by the glow. The Daughter-Heir must still harbor foolish notions. She was never a Seanchan prisoner.

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt θɪŋk mɛni mɛn wəd bi stupəɾ ɪnʌf tə θɪŋk ðə wʊmən ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm wɑz nɑt deɪnʒɝəs, ivən ðoʊ hɝ hænz wɝ ɛmpti ən ʃi wɔɹ noʊ vɪzəbəl wɛpən. blu-ɡɹin aɪz ən ɹɛɾɪʃ hɛɹ kʌt ʃɔɹɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə nɛɹoʊ teɪl ðət hʌŋ tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz; sɑft, leɪs ni-buts ən kloʊs-fɪɾɪŋ koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz ɔl ɪn ðə ʃeɪdz ə ɝθ ən ɹɑk. sətʃ kʌlɝɪŋ ən kloʊðɪŋ hæd bɪn dɪskɹaɪb tə hɝ wʌns; ðɪs wʊmən wɑz il.

Egwene did not think many men would be stupid enough to think the woman in front of them was not dangerous, even though her hands were empty and she wore no visible weapon. Blue-green eyes and reddish hair cut short except for a narrow tail that hung to her shoulders; soft, laced knee-boots and close-fitting coat and breeches all in the shades of earth and rock. Such coloring and clothing had been described to her once; this woman was Aiel.

lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, ɛɡwin fɛlt ə sʌɾən ɑɾ əfɪnəɾi fəɹ ðə wʊmən. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt. ʃi lʊks laɪk ɹændz kʌzən, ðæts waɪ. jɛɾ ivən ðət filɪŋ - ɔlmoʊst ə kɪnʃɪp - kəd nɑt staɪfəl əɹ kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. wʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ɑɹ il duɪŋ hɪɹ? ðeɪ nɛvɝ liv ðə weɪst; nɑt sɪns ði il wɔɹ. ʃi hæd hɝɾ ɔl ə hɝ laɪf haʊ dɛdli il wɝ - ðiz meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ noʊ lɛs ðən ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə meɪl wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz - bʌt ʃi fɛl noʊ pɝtɪkjəlɝ fɪɹ ænd, ɪndid, səm ɪɹɪteɪʃən ət hævɪŋ bɪn əfɹeɪd. wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ fiɾɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪndə hɝ, ʃi hæd noʊ nid tə fɪɹ ɛniwʌn. ɪksɛp meɪbi ə fʊli tʃɹeɪn sɪstɝ, ʃi ədmɪɾəd. bʌt sɝɾənli nɑt wʌn wʊmən, ivən ɪf ʃiz il.

Looking at her, Egwene felt a sudden odd affinity for the woman. She could not understand it. She looks like Rand's cousin, that's why. Yet even that feeling - almost of kinship - could not stifle her curiosity. What under the Light are Aiel doing here? They never leave the Waste; not since the Aiel War. She had heard all of her life how deadly Aiel were - these Maidens of the Spear no less than the members of the male warrior societies - but she felt no particular fear and, indeed, some irritation at having been afraid. With saidar feeding the One Power into her, she had no need to fear anyone. Except maybe a fully trained sister, she admitted. But certainly not one woman, even if she is Aiel.

"maɪ neɪm ɪz eɪvinhə," ði il wʊmən sɛd, "ʌv ðə naɪn væliz sɛpt ə ðə tɑɹdæɾ il." hɝ feɪs wɑz əz flæɾ ən ɪkspɹɛʃənləs əz əɹ vɔɪs. "aɪ æm fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ, ə meɪɾən ə ðə spɪɹ." ʃi pɔzd ə moʊmənt, stʌɾiɪŋ ðɛm. "ju hæv nɑt ðə lʊk ɪn jəɹ feɪsəz, bʌt wi sɔ ðə ɹɪŋz. ɪn jəɹ lænz, juv wɪmən mʌtʃ laɪk əɹ waɪz wʌnz, ðə wɪmən kɔld ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɑɹ jə wɪmən ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, əɹ nɑt?"

"My name is Aviendha," the Aiel woman said, "of the Nine Valleys sept of the Taardad Aiel." Her face was as flat and expressionless as her voice. "I am Far Dareis Mai, a Maiden of the Spear." She paused a moment, studying them. "You have not the look in your faces, but we saw the rings. In your lands, you have women much like our Wise Ones, the women called Aes Sedai. Are you women of the White Tower, or not?"

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɛɡwin dɪd fil əniz. wi? ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn əm kɛɹfəli, bʌt sɔ noʊ wʌn bɪhaɪn ɛni bʊʃ wɪðɪn twɛnti peɪsɪz.

For a moment Egwene did feel unease. We? She looked around them carefully, but saw no one behind any bush within twenty paces.

ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz, ðeɪ hæd tə bi ɪn ðə nɛks θɪkɪt, mɔɹ ðən tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əhɛd, əɹ ɪn ðə læst wʌn, twaɪs ðət dɪstəns bɪhaɪnd. tu fɑɹ tə θɹɛɾən. ənlɛs ðeɪv baʊz. bʌt ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə bi ɡʊd wɪð ðɛm. bæk hoʊm, ɪn ðə kɑmpətɪʃənz ət bɛl taɪn ən sʌndeɪ, oʊnli ðə bɛs boʊmən ʃɑɾ əɾ ɛni dɪstəns mʌtʃ bɪɑn tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz.

If there were others, they had to be in the next thicket, more than two hundred paces ahead, or in the last one, twice that distance behind. Too far to threaten. Unless they have bows. But they would have to be good with them. Back home, in the competitions at Bel Tine and Sunday, only the best bowmen shot at any distance much beyond two hundred paces.

bʌt ʃi stɪl fɛl bɛɾɝ noʊɪŋ ʃi kəd hɝl ə laɪtnɪŋ boʊlt əɾ ɛniwʌn u tʃɹaɪd sətʃ ə ʃɑt.

But she still felt better knowing she could hurl a lightning bolt at anyone who tried such a shot.

"wi ɑɹ wɪmən ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd kɑmli. ʃi wɑz vɛɹi ɑbviəs ɪn nɑt lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn fəɹ ʌðɝ il. ivən ɪleɪn wɑz piɹɪŋ əbaʊt. "wɛðɝ jə wəd kənsɪɾɝ ɛni ʌv əs waɪz ɪz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ," nɪneɪiv wɛn ɑn. "wʌt dʒju wɑn ʌv ʌs?"

"We are women of the White Tower," Nynaeve said calmly. She was very obvious in not looking around for other Aiel. Even Elayne was peering about. "Whether you would consider any of us wise is another matter," Nynaeve went on. "What do you want of us?"

eɪvinhə smaɪld. ʃi wɑz ɹɪli kwaɪt lʌvli, ɛɡwin ɹilaɪzd; ðə ɡɹɪm ɪkspɹɛʃən hæd mæskt ɪt. "ju tɔk əz ðə waɪz wʌnz du. tə ðə pɔɪnt, ən smɔl sʌfɝɪŋ ə fulz." hɝ smaɪl feɪɾəd, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs ɹɪmeɪn kɑm. "wʌn ʌv əs laɪz ɡɹeɪvli hɝt, pɝhæps daɪɪŋ. ðə waɪz wʌnz ɔfən hil ðoʊz u wəd ʃʊɹli daɪ wɪθaʊt ðɛm, ən aɪ hæv hɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kən də mɔɹ. wɪl jə eɪd hɝ?"

Aviendha smiled. She was really quite lovely, Egwene realized; the grim expression had masked it. "You talk as the Wise Ones do. To the point, and small suffering of fools." Her smile faded, but her voice remained calm. "One of us lies gravely hurt, perhaps dying. The Wise Ones often heal those who would surely die without them, and I have heard Aes Sedai can do more. Will you aid her?"

ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊst ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn kənfjuʒən. ə fɹɛn ə hɝz ɪz daɪɪŋ? ʃi saʊnz əz ɪf ʃiz æskɪŋ ɪf wɪl lɛn əɹ ə kʌp ə bɑɹli flaʊɝ!

Egwene almost shook her head in confusion. A friend of hers is dying? She sounds as if she is asking if we'll lend her a cup of barley flour!

"aɪ wɪl hɛlp əɹ ɪf aɪ kæn," nɪneɪiv sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ kænɑt meɪk pɹɑməsəz, eɪvinhə. ʃi meɪ daɪ dɪspaɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ aɪ kən du."

"I will help her if I can," Nynaeve said slowly. "I cannot make promises, Aviendha. She may die despite anything I can do."

"dɛθ kʌmz fəɹ əs ɔl," ði il sɛd. "wi kən oʊnli tʃuz haʊ tə feɪs ɪt wən ɪt kʌmz. əl teɪk jə tə hɝ."

"Death comes for us all," the Aiel said. "We can only choose how to face it when it comes. I will take you to her."

tu wɪmən ɪn il ɡɑɹb stʊɾ ʌp noʊ mɔɹ ðən tɛn peɪsɪz əweɪ, wʌn aʊɾ ʌv ə lɪɾəl foʊld ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn ðəɾ ɛɡwin wəd nɑɾ əv səpoʊz kəd haɪɾ ə dɔɡ, ən ði ʌðɝ ɪn ɡɹæs ðət ɹitʃt oʊnli hæfweɪ tə hɝ niz. ðeɪ loʊɝd ðɛɹ blæk veɪlz əz ðeɪ stʊd - ðət ɡeɪv əɹ ənʌðɝ dʒoʊlt; ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪleɪn hæd toʊld əɹ ði il oʊnli hɪd ðɛɹ feɪsəz wən ðeɪ maɪɾ əv tə də kɪlɪŋ - ən sɛɾəld ðə klɔθ ðət hæd ɹæp ðɛɹ hɛdz əbaʊt ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. wʌn hæd ðə seɪm ɹɛɾɪʃ hɛɹ əz eɪvinhə, wɪð ɡɹeɪ aɪz, ði ʌðɝ dɑɹk blu aɪz ən hɛɹ laɪk faɪɝ. niðɝ wɑz ɛni oʊldɝ ðən ɛɡwin əɹ ɪleɪn, ən boʊθ lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə juz ðə ʃɔɹt spɪɹz ɪn ðɛɹ hænz.

Two women in Aiel garb stood up no more than ten paces away, one out of a little fold in the ground that Egwene would not have supposed could hide a dog, and the other in grass that reached only halfway to her knees. They lowered their black veils as they stood - that gave her another jolt; she was sure Elayne had told her the Aiel only hid their faces when they might have to do killing - and settled the cloth that had wrapped their heads about their shoulders. One had the same reddish hair as Aviendha, with gray eyes, the other dark blue eyes and hair like fire. Neither was any older than Egwene or Elayne, and both looked ready to use the short spears in their hands.

ðə wʊmən wɪð faɪɝi hɛɹ hændəɾ eɪvinhə wɛpənz; ə lɔŋ, hɛvi-bleɪɾɪd naɪf tə bɛlt əɾ əɹ weɪst, ən ə bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝ fəɹ ði ʌðɝ saɪd; ə dɑɹk, kɝv baʊ ðət hæd ðə dʌl ʃaɪn ə hɔɹn, ɪn ə keɪs tə fæsən ɑn əɹ bæk; ən fɔɹ ʃɔɹt spɪɹz wɪð lɔŋ pɔɪns tə ɡɹɪp ɪn əɹ lɛf hæn əlɔŋ wɪð ə smɔl, ɹaʊn haɪd bʌkəlɝ. eɪvinhə wɔɹ əm əz nætʃɹəli əz ə wʊmən ɪn ɛmənz fild wəd wɛɹ ə skɑɹf, dʒʌst əz əɹ kəmpænjənz dɪd. "kʌm," ʃi sɛd, ən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə θɪkɪt ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi pæst.

The woman with fiery hair handed Aviendha weapons; a long, heavy-bladed knife to belt at her waist, and a bristling quiver for the other side; a dark, curved bow that had the dull shine of horn, in a case to fasten on her back; and four short spears with long points to grip in her left hand along with a small, round hide buckler. Aviendha wore them as naturally as a woman in Emond's Field would wear a scarf, just as her companions did. "Come," she said, and started for the thicket they had already passed.

ɛɡwin faɪnəli ɹilist seɪaɪdɑɹ. ʃi səspɛktəɾ ɔl θɹi ʌv ði il kəd stæb əɹ wɪð ðoʊz spɪɹz bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd də ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ɪf ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd, bʌt ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ wɛɹi, ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ wʊd. ən wʌɾ ɪf nɪneɪiv kæn hil ðɛɹ fɹɛnd? aɪ wɪʃ ʃi wəɾ æsk bɪfɔɹ ʃi meɪks ðiz dɪsɪʒənz ðəɾ ɪnvɑlv ɔl ʌv ʌs!

Egwene finally released saidar. She suspected all three of the Aiel could stab her with those spears before she could do anything about it, if that was what they wanted, but though they were wary, she did not think they would. And what if Nynaeve can't Heal their friend? I wish she would ask before she makes these decisions that involve all of us!

əz ðeɪ hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə tʃɹiz, ði il skæn ðə læn ɝaʊn əm əz ɪf ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd ði ɛmpti lændskeɪp tə hoʊld ɛnəmiz əz ədɛpt ət haɪɾɪŋ əz ðɛmsɛlvz. eɪvinhə stʃɹoʊɾ əhɛd, ən nɪneɪiv kɛpt ʌp wɪð hɝ.

As they headed for the trees, the Aiel scanned the land around them as if they expected the empty landscape to hold enemies as adept at hiding as themselves. Aviendha strode ahead, and Nynaeve kept up with her.

"aɪ æm ɪleɪn ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd," ɛɡwinz fɹɛn sɛɾ əz ɪf meɪkɪŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃən, "dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tə mɔɹɡeɪs, kwin ʌv ændɝ."

"I am Elayne of House Trakand," Egwene's friend said as if making conversation, "Daughter-Heir to Morgase, Queen of Andor."

ɛɡwin stʌmbəld. laɪt, ɪz ʃi mæd? aɪ noʊ ændɝ fɔɾ əm ɪn ði il wɔɹ. ɪt maɪt bi twɛnti jɪɹz, bʌt ðeɪ seɪ il əv lɔŋ mɛmɹiz.

Egwene stumbled. Light, is she mad? I know Andor fought them in the Aiel War. It might be twenty years, but they say Aiel have long memories.

bʌt ðə fleɪm-hɛɹɾ il kloʊsəs tə hɝ oʊnli sɛd, "aɪ æm beɪn, ʌv ðə blæk ɹɑk sɛpt ə ðə ʃɝəɾ il."

But the flame-haired Aiel closest to her only said, "I am Bain, of the Black Rock sept of the Shaarad Aiel."

"aɪ æm kiæd," ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ, blɑndɝ wʊmən ɑn əɹ ʌðɝ saɪd sɛd, "ʌv ðə stoʊnz ɹɪvɝ sɛpt ə ðə ɡoʊʃin il."

"I am Chiad," the shorter, blonder woman on her other side said, "of the Stones River sept of the Goshien Aiel."

beɪn ən kiæd ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin; ðɛɹ ɪkspɹɛʃənz dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt ʃi hæd ðə filɪŋ ðeɪ θɔt ʃi wɑz ʃoʊɪŋ bæd mænɝz.

Bain and Chiad glanced at Egwene; their expressions did not change, but she had the feeling they thought she was showing bad manners.

"aɪ æm ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," ʃi toʊl ðɛm. ðeɪ sim tə ɪkspɛk mɔɹ, soʊ ʃi æɾəd, "dɔɾɝ ə mɛɹɪn ælvɪɹ, ʌv ɛmənz fild, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz." ðət sim tə sæɾəsfaɪ ðɛm, ɪn ə weɪ, bʌt ʃi wəɾ əv bɛt ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪt noʊ mɔɹ ðən ʃi dɪɾ ɔl ðiz sɛps ən klænz. ɪt mʌs min fæmliz, ɪn səm weɪ.

"I am Egwene al'Vere," she told them. They seemed to expect more, so she added, "Daughter of Marin al'Vere, of Emond's Field, in the Two Rivers." That seemed to satisfy them, in a way, but she would have bet they understood it no more than she did all these septs and clans. It must mean families, in some way.

"ju ɑɹ fɝst-sɪstɝz?" beɪn sim tə bi teɪkɪŋ ɪn ɔl θɹi ʌv ðɛm.

"You are first-sisters?" Bain seemed to be taking in all three of them.

ɛɡwin θɔt ðeɪ mʌs min sɪstɝz əz ɪt wɑz juz fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən sɛd "jɛs," dʒʌst əz ɪleɪn sɛd "noʊ."

Egwene thought they must mean sisters as it was used for Aes Sedai, and said "Yes," just as Elayne said "No."

kiæɾ ən beɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə vɛɹi kwɪk lʊk ðət sədʒɛstəd ðeɪ wɝ tɔkɪŋ tə wɪmən u maɪt nɑt bi kəmplitli hoʊl ɪn ðɛɹ maɪnz.

Chiad and Bain exchanged a very quick look that suggested they were talking to women who might not be completely whole in their minds.

"fɝst-sɪstɝ," ɪleɪn toʊld ɛɡwin əz ɪf ʃi wɝ lɛktʃɝɪŋ, "minz wɪmən u hæv ðə seɪm mʌðɝ. sɛkənd-sɪstɝ minz ðɛɹ mʌðɝz ɑɹ sɪstɝz." ʃi tɝn əɹ wɝdz tə ði il. "wi niðɝ ʌv əs noʊ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə jəɹ pipəl. aɪ æsk jə tə ɪkskjuz əɹ ɪɡnɝəns. aɪ səmtaɪmz θɪŋk ʌv ɛɡwin əz ə fɝst-sɪstɝ, bʌt wəɹ nɑt blʌd kɪn."

"First-sister," Elayne told Egwene as if she were lecturing, "means women who have the same mother. Second-sister means their mothers are sisters." She turned her words to the Aiel. "We neither of us know a great deal of your people. I ask you to excuse our ignorance. I sometimes think of Egwene as a first-sister, but we are not blood kin."

"ðɛn waɪ dʒju nɑt spik ðə wɝdz bɪfɔɹ jəɹ waɪz wʌnz?" kiæɾ æskt. "beɪn ən aɪ bɪkeɪm fɝst-sɪstɝz."

"Then why do you not speak the words before your Wise Ones?" Chiad asked. "Bain and I became first-sisters."

ɛɡwin blɪŋkt. "haʊ kən jə bɪkʌm fɝst-sɪstɝz? iðɝ juv ðə seɪm mʌðɝ, əɹ jə də nɑt. aɪ də nɑt min tə əfɛnd. moʊst ʌv wʌɾ aɪ noʊ əbaʊt ðə meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ kʌmz fɹəm ðə lɪɾəl ɪleɪn əz toʊl mi. aɪ noʊ jə faɪɾ ɪn bæɾəl ən doʊn kɛɹ fəɹ mɛn, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt." ɪleɪn nɑɾəd; ðə weɪ ʃi hæd dɪskɹaɪb ðə meɪɾənz tə ɛɡwin hæd saʊndəd mʌtʃ laɪk ə kɹɔs bɪtwin fimeɪl wɔɹɾɝz ən ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ.

Egwene blinked. "How can you become first-sisters? Either you have the same mother, or you do not. I do not mean to offend. Most of what I know about the Maidens of the Spear comes from the little Elayne has told me. I know you fight in battle and don't care for men, but no more than that." Elayne nodded; the way she had described the Maidens to Egwene had sounded much like a cross between female Warders and the Red Ajah.

ðət lʊk flæʃt bæk əkɹɔs ði ilz feɪsəz, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt sɝɾən haʊ mʌtʃ sɛns ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn hæd.

That look flashed back across the Aiel's faces, as if they were not certain how much sense Egwene and Elayne had.

"wi də nɑt kɛɹ fəɹ mɛn?" kiæd mɝmɝɾ əz ɪf pʌzəld.

"We do not care for men?" Chiad murmured as if puzzled.

beɪn nɑɾɪd əɹ bɹaʊ ɪn θɔt. "wʌt jə seɪ kʌmz nɪɹ tʃɹuθ, jɛt mɪsəz ɪt kəmplitli. wən wi wɛd ðə spɪɹ, wi plɛdʒ tə bi baʊn tə noʊ mæn əɹ tʃaɪld. səm də ɡɪv ʌp ðə spɪɹ, fəɹ ə mæn əɹ ə tʃaɪld" - hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən sɛd ʃi hɝsɛlf dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðɪs - "bʌt wʌns ɡɪvən ʌp, ðə spɪɹ kænɑt bi teɪkən bæk."

Bain knotted her brow in thought. "What you say comes near truth, yet misses it completely. When we wed the spear, we pledge to be bound to no man or child. Some do give up the spear, for a man or a child" - her expression said she herself did not understand this - "but once given up, the spear cannot be taken back."

"ɔɹ ɪf ʃiz tʃoʊzən tə ɡoʊ tə ɹɪɾiən," kiæd pʊɾ ɪn. "eɪ waɪz wʌn kænɑt bi wɛɾəd tə ðə spɪɹ."

"Or if she is chosen to go to Rhuidean," Chiad put in. "A Wise One cannot be wedded to the spear."

beɪn lʊkt əɾ əɹ əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ənaʊns ðə skaɪ wɑz blu, əɹ ðət ɹeɪn fɛl fɹəm klaʊdz. ðə ɡlæns ʃi ɡeɪv ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn sɛd pɝhæps ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ ðiz θɪŋz. "jɛs, ðəɾ ɪz tʃɹu. ðoʊ səm tʃɹaɪ tə stʃɹʌɡəl əɡɛnst ɪt."

Bain looked at her as if she had announced the sky was blue, or that rain fell from clouds. The glance she gave Egwene and Elayne said perhaps they did not know these things. "Yes, that is true. Though some try to struggle against it."

"jɛs, ðeɪ du." kiæd saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi ən beɪn wɝ ʃɛɹɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ bɪtwin ðɛm.

"Yes, they do." Chiad sounded as though she and Bain were sharing something between them.

"bʌɾ aɪ hæv ɡɔn fɑɹ fɹəm ðə tʃɹeɪl ə maɪ ɛkspləneɪʃən," beɪn wɛn ɑn. "ðə meɪɾənz də nɑt dæns ðə spɪɹz wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ ivən wən əɹ klænz du, bʌt ðə ʃɝəɾ il ən ðə ɡoʊʃin il əv hɛl blʌd fjud bɪtwin əm oʊvɝ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, soʊ kiæɾ ən aɪ fɛlt əɹ wɛɾɪŋ plɛdʒ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf. wi wɛn tə spik ðə wɝdz bɪfɔɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz ʌv əɹ klænz - ʃi ɹɪskɪŋ əɹ laɪf ɪn maɪ hoʊld, ən aɪ ɪn hɝz - tə bɑn əs əz fɝst-sɪstɝz. əz ɪz pɹɑpɝ fəɹ fɝst-sɪstɝz u ɑɹ meɪɾənz, wi ɡɑɹɾ itʃ ʌðɝz bæks, ən niðɝ wɪl lɛɾ ə mæn kʌm tə hɝ wɪθaʊt ði ʌðɝ. aɪ wəd nɑt seɪ wi də nɑt kɛɹ fəɹ mɛn." kiæd nɑɾəd, wɪð dʒʌs ðə hɪn ʌv ə smaɪl. "hæv aɪ meɪd ðə tʃɹuθ klɪɹ tə ju, ɛɡwin?"

"But I have gone far from the trail of my explanation," Bain went on. "The Maidens do not dance the spears with one another even when our clans do, but the Shaarad Aiel and the Goshien Aiel have held blood feud between them over four hundred years, so Chiad and I felt our wedding pledge was not enough. We went to speak the words before the Wise Ones of our clans - she risking her life in my hold, and I in hers - to bond us as first-sisters. As is proper for first-sisters who are Maidens, we guard each other's backs, and neither will let a man come to her without the other. I would not say we do not care for men." Chiad nodded, with just the hint of a smile. "Have I made the truth clear to you, Egwene?"

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd feɪnli. ʃi ɡlænst əɾ ɪleɪn ən sɔ ðə bɪwɪldɝmən ɪn əɹ blu aɪz ʃi nu mʌs bi ɪn əɹ oʊn. nɑt ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. ɡɹin, meɪbi. ə kɹɔs bɪtwin wɔɹɾɝz ən ɡɹin ədʒɑ, ən aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ənʌðɝ θɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðæt. "ðə tʃɹuθ ɪz kwaɪt klɪɹ tə mi, naʊ, beɪn. θæŋk ju."

"Yes," Egwene said faintly. She glanced at Elayne and saw the bewilderment in her blue eyes she knew must be in her own. Not Red Ajah. Green, maybe. A cross between Warders and Green Ajah, and I do not understand another thing out of that. "The truth is quite clear to me, now, Bain. Thank you."

"ɪf ðə tu ʌv jə fil jə ɑɹ fɝst-sɪstɝz," kiæd sɛd, "ju ʃəd ɡoʊ tə jəɹ waɪz wʌnz ən spik ðə wɝdz. bʌt jə ɑɹ waɪz wʌnz, ðoʊ jʌŋ. aɪ də nɑt noʊ haʊ ɪt wəd bi dʌn ɪn ðət keɪs."

"If the two of you feel you are first-sisters," Chiad said, "you should go to your Wise Ones and speak the words. But you are Wise Ones, though young. I do not know how it would be done in that case."

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə læf əɹ blʌʃ. ʃi kɛp hævɪŋ ən ɪmədʒ ə hɝ ən ɪleɪn ʃɛɹɪŋ ðə seɪm mæn. noʊ, ðəɾ ɪz oʊnli fəɹ fɝst-sɪstɝz u ɑɹ meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ. ɪzən ɪt? ɪleɪn dɪɾ əv spɑts ə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks, ən ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ə ɹænd. bʌt wi də nɑt ʃɛɹ hɪm, ɪleɪn. wi kən niðɝ ʌv əs əv hɪm.

Egwene did not know whether to laugh or blush. She kept having an image of her and Elayne sharing the same man. No, that is only for first-sisters who are Maidens of the Spear. Isn't it? Elayne did have spots of color in her cheeks, and Egwene was sure she was thinking of Rand. But we do not share him, Elayne. We can neither of us have him.

ɪleɪn klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. "aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ðəɹ ɪz ə nid fəɹ ðæt, kiæd. ɛɡwin ən aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɑɹɾ itʃ ʌðɝz bæks."

Elayne cleared her throat. "I do not think there is a need for that, Chiad. Egwene and I already guard each other's backs."

"haʊ kən ðət bi?" kiæɾ æsk sloʊli. "ju ɑɹ nɑt wɛɾəd tə ðə spɪɹ. ən jə ɑɹ waɪz wʌnz. hu wəd lɪft ə hæn əɡɛnst ə waɪz wʌn? ðɪs kənfjuzɪz mi. wʌt niɾ əv jə fəɹ ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ə bæks?"

"How can that be?" Chiad asked slowly. "You are not wedded to the spear. And you are Wise Ones. Who would lift a hand against a Wise One? This confuses me. What need have you for guarding of backs?"

ɛɡwin wɑz spɛɹd hævɪŋ tə kʌm ʌp wɪð ən ænsɝ baɪ ðɛɹ ɝaɪvəl ət ðə kɑps. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɔɹ il ʌndɝ ðə tʃɹiz, dip ɪndə ðə θɪkɪt, bʌt nɛks tə ðə ɹɪvɝ. dʒoʊliən, ʌv ðə sɔl flæt sɛpt ə ðə nɑkɑi il, ə blu-aɪd wʊmən wɪð ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ nɪɹli ðə kʌlɝ ʌv ɪleɪnz, wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ deɪlɪn, ʌv eɪvinhəz sɛpt ən klæn. swɛt mæɾɪd deɪlɪnz hɛɹ, meɪkɪŋ ɪɾ ə dɑɹkɝ ɹɛd, ən ʃi oʊnli oʊpən əɹ ɡɹeɪ aɪz wʌns, wən ðeɪ fɝs keɪm nɪɹ, ðən kloʊzd əm əɡɛn. hɝ koʊɾ ən ʃɝt leɪ bɪsaɪd hɝ, ən ɹɛd steɪn ðə bændədʒəz ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ mɪɾəl.

Egwene was spared having to come up with an answer by their arrival at the copse. There were two more Aiel under the trees, deep into the thicket, but next to the river. Jolien, of the Salt Flat sept of the Nakai Aiel, a blue-eyed woman with red-gold hair nearly the color of Elayne's, was watching over Dailin, of Aviendha's sept and clan. Sweat matted Dailin's hair, making it a darker red, and she only opened her gray eyes once, when they first came near, then closed them again. Her coat and shirt lay beside her, and red stained the bandages wrapped around her middle.

"ʃi tʊk ə sɔɹd," eɪvinhə sɛd. "sʌm ə ðoʊz fulz ðət ði oʊθ-bɹeɪkɪŋ tʃɹikɪlɝz kɔl soʊlʒɝz θɔt wi wɝ ənʌðɝ hændfʊl ə ðə bændəts u ənfɛs ðɪs lænd. wi hæd tə kɪl əm tə kənvɪns əm ʌðɝwaɪz, bʌt deɪlɪn. . . . kən jə hil hɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

"She took a sword," Aviendha said. "Some of those fools that the oath-breaking treekillers call soldiers thought we were another handful of the bandits who infest this land. We had to kill them to convince them otherwise, but Dailin. . . . Can you heal her, Aes Sedai?"

nɪneɪiv wɛn tə hɝ niz bɪsaɪd ði ɪnʒɝd wʊmən ən lɪftəd ðə bændədʒəz ɪnʌf tə pɪɹ ʌndɝ ðɛm. ʃi wɪnst ət wʌt ʃi sɔ. "hæv jə muvd əɹ sɪns ʃi wɑz hɝt? ðəɹ ɪz skæbɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪts bɪn bɹoʊkən."

Nynaeve went to her knees beside the injured woman and lifted the bandages enough to peer under them. She winced at what she saw. "Have you moved her since she was hurt? There is scabbing, but it has been broken."

"ʃi wɑntəd tə daɪ nɪɹ wɔɾɝ," eɪvinhə sɛd. ʃi ɡlænst wʌns ət ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðən kwɪkli əweɪ əɡɛn. ɛɡwin θɔt ʃi maɪɾ əv ʃɪvɝd, tu.

"She wanted to die near water," Aviendha said. She glanced once at the river, then quickly away again. Egwene thought she might have shivered, too.

"fulz!" nɪneɪiv bɪɡæn ɹʌmɪdʒɪŋ ɪn əɹ paʊtʃ ə ɝbz. "ju cʊɾə kɪld əɹ muvɪŋ əɹ wɪð ən ɪnʒɝi laɪk ðæt. ʃi wɑntəd tə daɪ nɪɹ wɔɾɝ!" ʃi sɛd dɪsɡʌstɪdli. "dʒʌs kəz jə kæɹi wɛpənz laɪk mɛn dʌzn min juv tə θɪŋk laɪk ðɛm." ʃi pʊld ə dip wʊɾən kʌp aʊɾ ə ðə bæɡ ən pʊʃt ɪɾ ət kiæd. "fɪl ðæt. aɪ nid wɔɾɝ tə mɪks ðiz soʊ ʃi kən dʒɹɪŋk ðɛm."

"Fools!" Nynaeve began rummaging in her pouch of herbs. "You could have killed her moving her with an injury like that. She wanted to die near water!" she said disgustedly. "Just because you carry weapons like men doesn't mean you have to think like them." She pulled a deep wooden cup out of the bag and pushed it at Chiad. "Fill that. I need water to mix these so she can drink them."

kiæɾ ən beɪn stɛp tə ðə ɹɪvɝz ɛdʒ ən ɹɪtɝn təɡɛðɝ. ðɛɹ feɪsəz nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd, bʌɾ ɛɡwin θɔt ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪkspɛktəd ðə ɹɪvɝ tə ɹitʃ ʌp ən ɡɹæb ðɛm.

Chiad and Bain stepped to the river's edge and returned together. Their faces never changed, but Egwene thought they had almost expected the river to reach up and grab them.

"ɪf wi hæd nɑt bɹɔɾ əɹ hɪɹ tə ðə . . . ɹɪvɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ," eɪvinhə sɛd, "wi wəd nɛvɝ əv faʊn ju, ən ʃi wʊɾə daɪɾ ɛniweɪ."

"If we had not brought her here to the . . . river, Aes Sedai," Aviendha said, "we would never have found you, and she would have died anyway."

nɪneɪiv snɔɹɾɪd ən bɪɡæn sɪftɪŋ paʊɾɝd ɝbz ɪndə ðə kʌp ʌv wɔɾɝ, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. "kɔɝənɹut hɛlps meɪk blʌd, ən dɔɡwɝt fəɹ nɪɾɪŋ flɛʃ, ən hilɔl, ʌv kɔɹs, ænd. . . ." hɝ mʌɾɝz tʃɹeɪld ɔf ɪndə wɪspɝz tu loʊ tə hɪɹ. eɪvinhə wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ ət hɝ.

Nynaeve snorted and began sifting powdered herbs into the cup of water, muttering to herself. "Corenroot helps make blood, and dogwort for knitting flesh, and healall, of course, and. . . ." Her mutters trailed off into whispers too low to hear. Aviendha was frowning at her.

"ðə waɪz wʌnz juz ɝbz, ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ aɪ hæd nɑt hɝd ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ juz ðɛm."

"The Wise Ones use herbs, Aes Sedai, but I had not heard that Aes Sedai used them."

"aɪ jus wʌɾ aɪ juz!" nɪneɪiv snæpt ən wɛn bæk tə sɔɹɾɪŋ θɹu hɝ paʊɾɝz ən wɪspɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf.

"I use what I use!" Nynaeve snapped and went back to sorting through her powders and whispering to herself.

"ʃi tʃɹuli dʌz saʊn laɪk ə waɪz wʌn," kiæd toʊl beɪn sɔfli, ən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɡeɪv ə taɪt nɑd.

"She truly does sound like a Wise One," Chiad told Bain softly, and the other woman gave a tight nod.

deɪlɪn wɑz ði oʊnli il wɪθaʊɾ əɹ wɛpənz ɪn hænd, ən ðeɪ ɔl lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə juz əm ɪn ə hɑɹtbit. nɪneɪiv ʃʊɹli ɪzən suðɪŋ ɛniwʌn, ɛɡwin θɔt. ɡɛɾ əm tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ. ɛniθɪŋ. noʊbɑdi filz laɪk faɪɾɪŋ ɪf ðəɹ tɔkɪŋ ə sʌmθɪŋ pisfəl.

Dailin was the only Aiel without her weapons in hand, and they all looked ready to use them in a heartbeat. Nynaeve surely isn't soothing anyone, Egwene thought. Get them talking about something. Anything. Nobody feels like fighting if they're talking of something peaceful.

"du nɑt bi əfɛndəd," ʃi sɛd kɛɹfəli, "bʌɾ aɪ noʊɾəs jə ɑɹ ɔl ənizi əbaʊt ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɪt dʌz nɑt ɡɹoʊ vaɪələn ənlɛs ðəɹ ɪz ə stɔɹm. jə kəd swɪm ɪn ɪɾ ɪf jə wɑntəd, ðoʊ ðə kɝən ɪz stʃɹɔŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə bæŋks." ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

"Do not be offended," she said carefully, "but I notice you are all uneasy about the river. It does not grow violent unless there is a storm. You could swim in it if you wanted, though the current is strong away from the banks." Elayne shook her head.

ði il lʊk blæŋk; eɪvinhə sɛd, "aɪ sɔ ə mæn - ə ʃaɪnɝən - də ðɪs swɪmɪŋ . . . wʌns."

The Aiel looked blank; Aviendha said, "I saw a man - a Shienaran - do this swimming . . . once."

"aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ noʊ ðəɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ wɔɾɝ ɪn ðə weɪst, bʌt jə sɛd jə wɝ 'stoʊnz ɹɪvɝ sɛpt,' dʒoʊliən. ʃʊɹli juv swʌm ɪn ðə stoʊnz ɹɪvɝ?" ɪleɪn lʊkt əɾ əɹ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ mæd.

"I don't understand," Egwene said. "I know there isn't much water in the Waste, but you said you were 'Stones River sept,' Jolien. Surely you have swum in the Stones River?" Elayne looked at her as if she were mad.

"swɪm," dʒoʊliən sɛɾ ɔkwɝdli. "ɪt minz . . . tə ɡɛɾ ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ? ɔl ðət wɔɾɝ? wɪð nʌθɪŋ tə hoʊld ɑn tə." ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd. "ɛɛs sədaɪ, bɪfɔɹ aɪ kɹɔs ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, aɪ hæd nɛvɝ sin floʊɪŋ wɔɾɝ aɪ kəd nɑt stɛp əkɹɔs. ðə stoʊnz ɹɪvɝ. . . . səm kleɪm ɪt hæd wɔɾɝ ɪn ɪt wʌns, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz oʊnli boʊstɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ oʊnli ðə stoʊnz. ði oʊldəst ɹɛkɝdz ə ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ðə klæn tʃif seɪ ðəɹ wɑz nɛvɝ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt stoʊnz sɪns ðə fɝs deɪ əɹ sɛp bɹoʊk ɔf fɹəm ðə haɪ pleɪn sɛpt ən kleɪm ðət lænd. swɪm!" ʃi ɡɹɪpt əɹ spɪɹz əz ɪf tə faɪt ðə vɛɹi wɝd. kiæɾ ən beɪn muvd ə peɪs fɝðɝ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk.

"Swim," Jolien said awkwardly. "It means . . . to get in the water? All that water? With nothing to hold on to." She shuddered. "Aes Sedai, before I crossed the Dragonwall, I had never seen flowing water I could not step across. The Stones River. . . . Some claim it had water in it once, but that is only boasting. There are only the stones. The oldest records of the Wise Ones and the clan chief say there was never anything but stones since the first day our sept broke off from the High Plain sept and claimed that land. Swim!" She gripped her spears as if to fight the very word. Chiad and Bain moved a pace further from the riverbank.

ɛɡwin saɪd. ən kʌlɝd wən ʃi mɛɾ ɪleɪnz aɪ. wɛl, aɪm nɑɾ ə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, tə noʊ ɔl ðiz θɪŋz. əl lɝn ðɛm, ðoʊ. əz ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn ət ði il wɪmən, ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət fɑɹ fɹəm suðɪŋ ðɛm, ʃi hæd pʊɾ əm ivən mɔɹ ɑn ɛdʒ. ɪf ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ, əl hoʊld əm wɪð ɛɹ. ʃi hæd noʊ aɪdiə wɛðɝ ʃi kəd siz fɔɹ pipəl ət wʌns, bʌt ʃi oʊpən hɝsɛlf tə seɪaɪdɑɹ, woʊv ðə floʊz ɪn ɛɹ ən hɛld əm ɹɛɾi. ðə paʊɝ pʌlsd ɪn əɹ wɪð iɡɝnəs tə bi juzd. noʊ ɡloʊ sɝaʊndəɾ ɪleɪn, ən ʃi wʌndɝd waɪ. ɪleɪn lʊkt ɹaɪɾ əɾ əɹ ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

Egwene sighed. And colored when she met Elayne's eye. Well, I am not a Daughter-Heir, to know all these things. I will learn them, though. As she looked around at the Aiel women, she realized that far from soothing them, she had put them even more on edge. If they try anything, I will hold them with Air. She had no idea whether she could seize four people at once, but she opened herself to saidar, wove the flows in Air and held them ready. The Power pulsed in her with eagerness to be used. No glow surrounded Elayne, and she wondered why. Elayne looked right at her and shook her head.

"aɪ wəd nɛvɝ hɑɹm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ," eɪvinhə sɛɾ əbɹʌpli. "aɪ wəɾ əv jə noʊ ðæt. wɛðɝ deɪlɪn laɪvz əɹ daɪz, ɪt meɪks noʊ dɪfɝəns ɪn ðæt. aɪ wəd nɛvɝ juz ðɪs" - ʃi lɪftəd wʌn ʃɔɹt spɪɹ ə tʃɹaɪfəl - "əɡɛnst ɛni wʊmən. ən jə ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ." ɛɡwin hæd ðə sʌɾən filɪŋ ðət ðə wʊmən wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə suð ðɛm.

"I would never harm an Aes Sedai," Aviendha said abruptly. "I would have you know that. Whether Dailin lives or dies, it makes no difference in that. I would never use this" - she lifted one short spear a trifle - "against any woman. And you are Aes Sedai." Egwene had the sudden feeling that the woman was trying to soothe them.

"aɪ nu ðæt," ɪleɪn sɛd, əz ɪf tɔkɪŋ tə eɪvinhə, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz toʊld ɛɡwin ðə wɝdz wɝ fəɹ hɝ. "noʊ wʌn noʊz mʌtʃ ə jəɹ pipəl, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz tɔt ðəɾ il nɛvɝ hɑɹm wɪmən ənlɛs ðeɪ ɑɹ - wʌd jə kɔl ɪt? - wɛɾəd tə ðə spɪɹ."

"I knew that," Elayne said, as if talking to Aviendha, but her eyes told Egwene the words were for her. "No one knows much of your people, but I was taught that Aiel never harm women unless they are - what did you call it? - wedded to the spear."

beɪn sim tə θɪŋk ɪleɪn wɑz feɪlɪŋ tə si tʃɹuθ klɪɹli əɡɛn. "ðæɾ ɪz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ðə weɪ ʌv ɪt, ɪleɪn. ɪf ə wʊmən nɑt wɛɾəd keɪm ət mi wɪð wɛpənz, aɪ wəd dʒɹʌb əɹ əntɪl ʃi nu bɛɾɝ ʌv ɪt. ə mæn. . . . ə mæn maɪt θɪŋk ə wʊmən ə jəɹ lænz wɑz wɛɾəd ɪf ʃi bɔɹ wɛpənz; aɪ də nɑt noʊ. mɛn kən bi stʃɹeɪnʒ."

Bain seemed to think Elayne was failing to see truth clearly again. "That is not exactly the way of it, Elayne. If a woman not wedded came at me with weapons, I would drub her until she knew better of it. A man. . . . A man might think a woman of your lands was wedded if she bore weapons; I do not know. Men can be strange."

"ʌv kɔɹs," ɪleɪn sɛd. "bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz wi də nɑɾ ətæk jə wɪð wɛpənz, jəl nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə hɑɹm ʌs." ɔl fɔɹ il lʊkt ʃɑkt, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ɛɡwin ə kwɪk səɡnɪfɪkən lʊk.

"Of course," Elayne said. "But so long as we do not attack you with weapons, you will not try to harm us." All four Aiel looked shocked, and she gave Egwene a quick significant look.

ɛɡwin hɛld ɑn tə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɛniweɪ. dʒʌs kəz ɪleɪn hæd bɪn tɔt sʌmθɪŋ dɪd nɑt min ɪt wɑz tʃɹu, ivən ɪf ði il sɛd ðə seɪm θɪŋ. ən seɪaɪdɑɹ fɛlt . . . ɡʊɾ ɪn hɝ.

Egwene held on to saidar anyway. Just because Elayne had been taught something did not mean it was true, even if the Aiel said the same thing. And saidar felt . . . good in her.

nɪneɪiv lɪftəɾ ʌp deɪlɪnz hɛɾ ən bɪɡæn pɔɹɪŋ əɹ mɪkstʃɝ ɪndə ðə wʊmənz maʊθ. "dʒɹɪŋk," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "aɪ noʊ ɪt teɪsts bæd, bʌt dʒɹɪŋk ɪɾ ɔl." deɪlɪn swɑloʊd, tʃoʊkt, ən swɑloʊɾ əɡɛn.

Nynaeve lifted up Dailin's head and began pouring her mixture into the woman's mouth. "Drink," she said firmly. "I know it tastes bad, but drink it all." Dailin swallowed, choked, and swallowed again.

"nɑɾ ivən ðɛn, ɛɛs sədaɪ," eɪvinhə toʊld ɪleɪn. ʃi kɛpt əɹ aɪz ɑn deɪlɪn ən nɪneɪiv, ðoʊ. "ɪɾ ɪz sɛd ðət wʌns, bɪfɔɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, wi sɝv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ noʊ stɔɹi sɛz haʊ. wi feɪld ɪn ðət sɝvəs. pɝhæps ðəɾ ɪz ðə sɪn ðət sɛn əs tə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd; aɪ də nɑt noʊ. noʊ wʌn noʊz wʌt ðə sɪn wɑz, ɪksɛp meɪbi ðə waɪz wʌnz, əɹ ðə klæn tʃifs, ən ðeɪ də nɑt seɪ. ɪts sɛɾ ɪf wi feɪl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɛn, ðəl dɪstʃɹɔɪ ʌs."

"Not even then, Aes Sedai," Aviendha told Elayne. She kept her eyes on Dailin and Nynaeve, though. "It is said that once, before the Breaking of the World, we served the Aes Sedai, though no story says how. We failed in that service. Perhaps that is the sin that sent us to the Three-fold Land; I do not know. No one knows what the sin was, except maybe the Wise Ones, or the clan chiefs, and they do not say. It is said if we fail the Aes Sedai again, they will destroy us."

"dʒɹɪŋk ɪɾ ɔl," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd. "sɔɹdz! sɔɹdz ən mʌsəlz ən noʊ bɹeɪnz!"

"Drink it all," Nynaeve muttered. "Swords! Swords and muscles and no brains!"

"wi ɑɹ nɑt gɑnə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ju," ɪleɪn sɛd fɝmli, ən eɪvinhə nɑɾəd.

"We are not going to destroy you," Elayne said firmly, and Aviendha nodded.

"æz jə seɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ði oʊl stɔɹiz ɑɹ ɔl klɪɹ ɑn wʌn pɔɪnt. wi mʌs nɛvɝ faɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪf jə bɹɪŋ jəɹ laɪtnɪŋz ən jəɹ bɑlfaɪɝ əɡɛns mi, əl dæns wɪð ðɛm, bʌɾ əl nɑt hɑɹm ju."

"As you say, Aes Sedai. But the old stories are all clear on one point. We must never fight Aes Sedai. If you bring your lightnings and your balefire against me, I will dance with them, but I will not harm you."

"stæbɪŋ pipəl," nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊld. ʃi loʊɝd deɪlɪnz hɛd, ən leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ðə wʊmənz bɹaʊ. deɪlɪnz aɪz hæd kloʊzd əɡɛn. "stæbɪŋ wɪmən!" eɪvinhə ʃɪftəɾ əɹ fiɾ ən fɹaʊn əɡɛn, ən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn əmʌŋ ði il.

"Stabbing people," Nynaeve growled. She lowered Dailin's head, and laid a hand on the woman's brow. Dailin's eyes had closed again. "Stabbing women!" Aviendha shifted her feet and frowned again, and she was not alone among the Aiel.

"bɑlfaɪɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "eɪvinhə, wʌɾ ɪz bɑlfaɪɝ?"

"Balefire," Egwene said. "Aviendha, what is balefire?"

ði il wʊmən tɝn əɹ fɹaʊn ɑn hɝ. "du jə nɑt noʊ, ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪn ði oʊl stɔɹiz, ɛɛs sədaɪ wildɪɾ ɪt. ðə stɔɹiz meɪk ɪɾ ə fɪɹsəm θɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ noʊ mɔɹ. ɪts sɛd wɪv fɝɡɑɾən mʌtʃ ðət wi wʌns nu."

The Aiel woman turned her frown on her. "Do you not know, Aes Sedai? In the old stories, Aes Sedai wielded it. The stories make it a fearsome thing, but I know no more. It is said we have forgotten much that we once knew."

"pɝhæps ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz fɝɡɑɾən mʌtʃ, tu," ɛɡwin sɛd. aɪ nu ʌv ɪɾ ɪn ðət . . . dʒɹim, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz. ɪt wɑz əz ɹil əz tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. aɪd ɡæmbəl wɪð mæt ɑn ðæt.

"Perhaps the White Tower has forgotten much, too," Egwene said. I knew of it in that . . . dream, or whatever it was. It was as real as Tel'aran'rhiod. I'd gamble with Mat on that.

"noʊ ɹaɪt!" nɪneɪiv snæpt. "noʊ wʌn əz ə ɹaɪt tə tɛɹ bɑɾiz soʊ! ɪts nɑt ɹaɪt!"

"No right!" Nynaeve snapped. "No one has a right to tear bodies so! It is not right!"

"ɪz ʃi æŋɡɹi?" eɪvinhə æskt ənizəli. kiæɾ ən beɪn ən dʒoʊliən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wɝid lʊks.

"Is she angry?" Aviendha asked uneasily. Chiad and Bain and Jolien exchanged worried looks.

"ɪɾ ɪz ɔl ɹaɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"It is all right," Elayne said.

"ɪɾ ɪz bɛɾɝ ðən ɔl ɹaɪt," ɛɡwin æɾəd. "ʃi ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ æŋɡɹi, ən ɪts mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən ɔl ɹaɪt."

"It is better than all right," Egwene added. "She is getting angry, and it is much better than all right."

ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd nɪneɪiv sʌɾənli - ɛɡwin lin fɔɹwɝd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si, ən soʊ dɪɾ ɪleɪn - ən deɪlɪn stɑɹɾəd ʌp wɪð ə skɹim, aɪz waɪɾ oʊpən. ɪn ən ɪnstənt, nɪneɪiv wɑz izɪŋ əɹ bæk daʊn, ən ðə ɡloʊ feɪɾəd. deɪlɪnz aɪz slɪd ʃʌt, ən ʃi leɪ ðəɹ pæntɪŋ.

The glow of saidar surrounded Nynaeve suddenly - Egwene leaned forward, trying to see, and so did Elayne - and Dailin started up with a scream, eyes wide open. In an instant, Nynaeve was easing her back down, and the glow faded. Dailin's eyes slid shut, and she lay there panting.

aɪ sɔ ɪt, ɛɡwin θɔt. aɪ . . . θɪŋk aɪ dɪd. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi hæɾ ivən bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk aʊɾ ɔl ðə mɛni floʊz, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə weɪ nɪneɪiv hæd woʊvən əm təɡɛðɝ. wʌt nɪneɪiv hæd dʌn ɪn ðoʊz fju sɛkənz hæd sim laɪk wivɪŋ fɔɹ kɑɹpəts ət wʌns waɪl blaɪndfoʊldɪd.

I saw it, Egwene thought. I . . . think I did. She was not sure she had even been able to make out all the many flows, much less the way Nynaeve had woven them together. What Nynaeve had done in those few seconds had seemed like weaving four carpets at once while blindfolded.

nɪneɪiv juz ðə blʌɾi bændədʒəz tə waɪp deɪlɪnz stʌmək, smɪɹɪŋ əweɪ bɹaɪt ɹɛd nu blʌɾ ən blæk kɹʌsts ə dʒɹaɪɾ oʊld. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ waʊnd, noʊ skɑɹ, oʊnli hɛlθi skɪn kənsɪɾɝəbli pəlɝ ðən deɪlɪnz feɪs.

Nynaeve used the bloody bandages to wipe Dailin's stomach, smearing away bright red new blood and black crusts of dried old. There was no wound, no scar, only healthy skin considerably paler than Dailin's face.

wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, nɪneɪiv tʊk ðə blʌɾi klɔθs, stʊɾ ʌp, ən θɹu ðɛm ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ. "wɑʃ ðə ɹɛst ə ðəɾ ɔf ə hɝ," ʃi sɛd, "æn pʊt səm kloʊðz bæk ɑn hɝ. ʃiz koʊld. ən bi ɹɛɾi tə fid hɝ. ʃɪl bi hʌŋɡɹi." ʃi nɛl baɪ ðə wɔɾɝ tə wɑʃ əɹ hænz.

With a grimace, Nynaeve took the bloody cloths, stood up, and threw them into the river. "Wash the rest of that off of her," she said, "and put some clothes back on her. She's cold. And be ready to feed her. She will be hungry." She knelt by the water to wash her hands.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾinaɪn


CHAPTER 39

θɹɛdz ɪn ðə pæɾɝn


Threads in the Pattern

dʒoʊliən pʊɾ ən ənstɛɾi hæn tə wɛɹ ðə waʊn hæd bɪn ɪn deɪlɪnz mɪɾəl; wən ʃi tʌtʃt smuð skɪn, ʃi ɡæspt əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt bɪlivd əɹ oʊn aɪz.

Jolien put an unsteady hand to where the wound had been in Dailin's middle; when she touched smooth skin, she gasped as if she had not believed her own eyes.

nɪneɪiv stʃɹeɪɾənd, dʒɹaɪɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ kloʊk. ɛɡwin hæd tə ədmɪt ðət ɡʊd wʊl dɪd bɛɾɝ fəɹ ə taʊəl ðən sɪlk əɹ vɛlvət. "aɪ sɛd wɑʃ əɹ ən ɡɛt səm kloʊðz ɑn hɝ," nɪneɪiv snæpt.

Nynaeve straightened, drying her hands on her cloak. Egwene had to admit that good wool did better for a towel than silk or velvet. "I said wash her and get some clothes on her," Nynaeve snapped.

"jɛs, waɪz wʌn," dʒoʊliən sɛd kwɪkli, ən ʃi, kiæd, ən beɪn ɔl lɛp tə oʊbeɪ.

"Yes, Wise One," Jolien said quickly, and she, Chiad, and Bain all leaped to obey.

ə ʃɔɹt læf bɝs fɹəm eɪvinhə, ə læf ɔlmoʊst ət ði ɛdʒ ə tɪɹz. "aɪ hæv hɝd ðəɾ ə waɪz wʌn ɪn ðə dʒæɡd spaɪɹ sɛpt ɪz sɛd tə bi eɪbəl tə də ðɪs, ən wʌn ɪn ðə fɔɹ hoʊlz sɛpt, bʌɾ aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔɾ ɪt wɑz boʊstɪŋ." ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, ɹɪɡeɪnɪŋ əɹ kəmpoʊʒɝ. "ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ oʊ jə ə dɛt. maɪ wɔɾɝ ɪz jʊɹz, ən ðə ʃeɪɾ ə maɪ sɛpθoʊld wɪl wɛlkəm ju. deɪlɪn ɪz maɪ sɛkənd-sɪstɝ." ʃi sɔ nɪneɪivz ʌnkɑmpɹihɛndɪŋ lʊk ən æɾəd, "ʃi ɪz maɪ mʌðɝz sɪstɝz dɔɾɝ. kloʊs blʌd, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ oʊ ə blʌd dɛt."

A short laugh burst from Aviendha, a laugh almost at the edge of tears. "I have heard that a Wise One in the Jagged Spire sept is said to be able to do this, and one in the Four Holes sept, but I always thought it was boasting." She drew a deep breath, regaining her composure. "Aes Sedai, I owe you a debt. My water is yours, and the shade of my septhold will welcome you. Dailin is my second-sister." She saw Nynaeve's uncomprehending look and added, "She is my mother's sister's daughter. Close blood, Aes Sedai. I owe a blood debt."

"ɪf aɪ hæv ɛni blʌd tə spɪl," nɪneɪiv sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "aɪ wɪl spɪl ɪt maɪsɛlf. ɪf jə wɪʃ tə ɹipeɪ mi, tɛl mi ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ə ʃɪp ət dʒʊɹin. ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ saʊθ ə hɪɹ?"

"If I have any blood to spill," Nynaeve said dryly, "I will spill it myself. If you wish to repay me, tell me if there is a ship at Jurene. The next village south of here?"

"ðə vɪlədʒ wɛɹ ðə soʊlʒɝz flaɪ ðə waɪt laɪən bænɝ?" eɪvinhə sɛd. "ðɛɹ wɑz ə ʃɪp ðəɹ wən aɪ skaʊɾəd jɛstɝdeɪ. ði oʊl stɔɹiz mɛnʃən ʃɪps, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ tə si wʌn."

"The village where the soldiers fly the White Lion banner?" Aviendha said. "There was a ship there when I scouted yesterday. The old stories mention ships, but it was strange to see one."

"ðə laɪt sɛn ɪts stɪl ðɛɹ." nɪneɪiv bɪɡæn pʊɾɪŋ əweɪ hɝ foʊldəd peɪpɝz ə paʊɾɝd ɝbz. "aɪ hæv dʌn wʌɾ aɪ kən fəɹ ðə ɡɝl, eɪvinhə, ən wi mʌst ɡoʊ ɑn. ɔl ðət ʃi nidz naʊ ɪz fuɾ ən ɹɛst. ən tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə lɛt pipəl stɪk sɔɹdz ɪn hɝ."

"The Light send it is still there." Nynaeve began putting away her folded papers of powdered herbs. "I have done what I can for the girl, Aviendha, and we must go on. All that she needs now is food and rest. And try not to let people stick swords in her."

"wʌt kʌmz, kʌmz, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ði il wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd.

"What comes, comes, Aes Sedai," the Aiel woman replied.

"eɪvinhə," ɛɡwin sɛd, "filɪŋ əz jə də əbaʊt ɹɪvɝz, haʊ dʒju kɹɔs ðɛm? aɪm ʃʊɹ ðəɹ ɪz ət list wʌn ɹɪvɝ nɪɹli əz bɪɡ əz ði ɛɹɪnɪn bɪtwin hɪɹ ən ðə weɪst."

"Aviendha," Egwene said, "feeling as you do about rivers, how do you cross them? I am sure there is at least one river nearly as big as the Erinin between here and the Waste."

"ði ɑlɡnjə," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ənlɛs jə wɛn ɝaʊn ɪt."

"The Alguenya," Elayne said. "Unless you went around it."

"ju hæv mɛni ɹɪvɝz, bʌt səm əv θɪŋz kɔl bɹɪdʒəz wɛɹ wi hæd nid tə kɹɔs, ən ʌðɝz wi kəd weɪd. fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, dʒoʊliən ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət wʊd floʊts." ʃi slæp ðə tʃɹʌŋk ʌv ə tɔl waɪtwʊd. "ðiz ɑɹ bɪɡ, bʌt ðeɪ floʊɾ əz wɛl əz ə bɹæntʃ. wi faʊn dɛd wʌnz ən meɪɾ aʊɝsɛlvz ə . . . ʃɪp . . . ə lɪɾəl ʃɪp, ʌv tu əɹ θɹi læʃt təɡɛðɝ tə kɹɔs ðə bɪɡ ɹɪvɝ." ʃi sɛɾ ɪt mæɾɝ-ʌv-fæktli.

"You have many rivers, but some have things called bridges where we had need to cross, and others we could wade. For the rest, Jolien remembered that wood floats." She slapped the trunk of a tall whitewood. "These are big, but they float as well as a branch. We found dead ones and made ourselves a . . . ship . . . a little ship, of two or three lashed together to cross the big river." She said it matter-of-factly.

ɛɡwin stɛɹɾ ɪn wʌndɝ. ɪf ʃi wɝ əz əfɹeɪɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ əz ði il ɑbviəsli wɝ ə ɹɪvɝz, kəd ʃi meɪk hɝsɛlf feɪs ɪt ðə weɪ ðeɪ dɪd? ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk soʊ. wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ə smɔl vɔɪs æskt. hæv jə stɑp biɪŋ əfɹeɪɾ ə ðɛm? ðəɾ ɪz dɪfɹənt, ʃi toʊld ɪt. ðɛɹz noʊ bɹeɪvɝi ɪn ðæt. aɪ iðɝ hʌn ðɛm, əɹ ɛls aɪ sɪt laɪk ə ɹæbət weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə hɔk. ʃi kwoʊɾəd ði oʊl seɪɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. "ɪɾ ɪz bɛɾɝ tə bi ðə hæmɝ ðən ðə neɪl."

Egwene stared in wonder. If she were as afraid of something as the Aiel obviously were of rivers, could she make herself face it the way they did? She did not think so. What about the Black Ajah, a small voice asked. Have you stopped being afraid of them? That is different, she told it. There's no bravery in that. I either hunt them, or else I sit like a rabbit waiting for a hawk. She quoted the old saying to herself. "It is better to be the hammer than the nail."

"wi hæd bɛs bi ɑn əɹ weɪ," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"We had best be on our way," Nynaeve said.

"ɪn ə moʊmənt," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ. "eɪvinhə, waɪ hæv jə kʌm ɔl ðɪs weɪ ən pʊɾ ʌp wɪð sətʃ hɑɹdʃɪp?"

"In a moment," Elayne told her. "Aviendha, why have you come all this way and put up with such hardship?"

eɪvinhə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd dɪsɡʌstɪdli. "wi hæv nɑt kʌm fɑɹ əɾ ɔl; wi wɝ əmʌŋ ðə læs tə sɛɾ aʊt. ðə waɪz wʌnz nɪpt ət mi laɪk waɪl dɑɡz sɝkəlɪŋ ə kæf, seɪɪŋ aɪ hæɾ ʌðɝ duɾiz." sʌɾənli ʃi ɡɹɪnd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ði ʌðɝ il. "ðiz steɪd bæk tə tɔn mi ɪn maɪ mɪzɝi, soʊ ðeɪ sɛd, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ðə waɪz wʌnz wʊɾə lemi ɡoʊ ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn ðəɹ tə kəmpænjən mi."

Aviendha shook her head disgustedly. "We have not come far at all; we were among the last to set out. The Wise Ones nipped at me like wild dogs circling a calf, saying I had other duties." Suddenly she grinned, gesturing to the other Aiel. "These stayed back to taunt me in my misery, so they said, but I do not think the Wise Ones would have let me go if they had not been there to companion me."

"wi sik ðə wʌn fɔɹtoʊld," beɪn sɛd. ʃi wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ə slipɪŋ deɪlɪn soʊ kiæd kəd slɪp ə ʃɝɾ ə bɹaʊn lɪnən ɑntu hɝ. "hi hu kʌmz wɪð ðə dɔn."

"We seek the one foretold," Bain said. She was holding a sleeping Dailin so Chiad could slip a shirt of brown linen onto her. "He Who Comes With the Dawn."

"hi wɪl liɾ əs aʊɾ ə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd," kiæɾ æɾəd. "ðə pɹɑfəsiz seɪ hi wɑz bɔɹn ə fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ."

"He will lead us out of the Three-fold Land," Chiad added. "The prophecies say he was born of Far Dareis Mai."

ɪleɪn lʊk stɑɹɾəld. "aɪ θɔt jə sɛd ðə meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ wɝ nɑɾ əlaʊd tə hæv tʃɪlʒɹən. aɪm ʃʊɹ aɪ wɑz tɔt ðæt." beɪn ən kiæɾ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ðoʊz lʊks əɡɛn, əz ɪf ɪleɪn hæd kʌm nɪɹ tʃɹuθ ən jɛt mɪst ɪt wʌns mɔɹ.

Elayne looked startled. "I thought you said the Maidens of the Spear were not allowed to have children. I am sure I was taught that." Bain and Chiad exchanged those looks again, as if Elayne had come near truth and yet missed it once more.

"ɪf ə meɪɾən bɛɹz ə tʃaɪld," eɪvinhə ɪkspleɪn kɛɹfəli, "ʃi ɡɪvz ðə tʃaɪl tə ðə waɪz wʌnz ə hɝ sɛpt, ən ðeɪ pæs ðə tʃaɪl tə ənʌðɝ wʊmən ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ ðət nʌn noʊz huz tʃaɪld ɪɾ ɪz." ʃi, tu, saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ðət stoʊn ɪz hɑɹd. "ɛvɹi wʊmən wɑns tə fɑstɝ sətʃ ə tʃaɪld ɪn ðə hoʊp ʃi meɪ ɹeɪz i hu kʌmz wɪð ðə dɔn."

"If a Maiden bears a child," Aviendha explained carefully, "she gives the child to the Wise Ones of her sept, and they pass the child to another woman in such a way that none knows whose child it is." She, too, sounded as if she were explaining that stone is hard. "Every woman wants to foster such a child in the hope she may raise He Who Comes With the Dawn."

"ɔɹ ʃi meɪ ɡɪv ʌp ðə spɪɹ ən wɛd ðə mæn," kiæd sɛd, ən beɪn æɾəd, "ðɛɹ ɑɹ səmtaɪmz ɹizənz wʌn mʌst ɡɪv ʌp ðə spɪɹ."

"Or she may give up the spear and wed the man," Chiad said, and Bain added, "There are sometimes reasons one must give up the spear."

eɪvinhə ɡeɪv əm ə lɛvəl lʊk, bʌt kəntɪnjuɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt spoʊkən. "ɪksɛp ðət naʊ ðə waɪz wʌnz seɪ hiz tə bi faʊn hɪɹ, bɪɑn ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl. 'blʌɾ ʌv əɹ blʌd mɪkst wɪð ði oʊl blʌd, ɹeɪz baɪ ən eɪntʃən blʌd nɑɾ aʊɝz.' aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt, bʌt ðə waɪz wʌnz spoʊk ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ əz tə liv noʊ daʊts." ʃi pɔzd, ɑbviəsli tʃuzɪŋ əɹ wɝdz. "ju hæv æsk mɛni kwɛstʃənz, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ wɪʃ tə æsk wʌn. jə mʌst ʌndɝstæn ðət wi lʊk fəɹ oʊmənz ən saɪnz. waɪ də θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɔk ə lænd wɛɹ ði oʊnli hænd wɪθaʊɾ ə naɪf ɪn ɪts ə hæn tu wik wɪð hʌŋɡɝ tə ɡɹæsp ðə hɪlt? wɛɹ dʒju ɡoʊ?"

Aviendha gave them a level look, but continued as if they had not spoken. "Except that now the Wise Ones say he is to be found here, beyond the Dragonwall. 'Blood of our blood mixed with the old blood, raised by an ancient blood not ours.' I do not understand it, but the Wise Ones spoke in such a way as to leave no doubts." She paused, obviously choosing her words. "You have asked many questions, Aes Sedai. I wish to ask one. You must understand that we look for omens and signs. Why do three Aes Sedai walk a land where the only hand without a knife in it is a hand too weak with hunger to grasp the hilt? Where do you go?"

"tɛɹ," nɪneɪiv sɛd bɹɪskli, "ənlɛs wi steɪ hɪɹ tɔkɪŋ əntɪl ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn kɹʌmbəlz tə dʌst." ɪleɪn bɪɡæn ədʒʌstɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾ ə hɝ bʌndəl ən ðə stʃɹæp ə hɝ skɹɪp fəɹ wɔkɪŋ, ən æftɝ ə moʊmən ɛɡwin dɪd ðə seɪm.

"Tear," Nynaeve said briskly, "unless we stay here talking until the Heart of the Stone crumbles to dust." Elayne began adjusting the cord of her bundle and the strap of her scrip for walking, and after a moment Egwene did the same.

ði il wɪmən wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, dʒoʊliən fɹoʊzən ɪn ði ækt ə kloʊzɪŋ deɪlɪnz ɡɹeɪ-bɹaʊn koʊt. "tɛɹ?" eɪvinhə sɛɾ ɪn ə kɔʃəs toʊn. "θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɔkɪŋ θɹu ə tʃɹʌbəld læn ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə tɛɹ. ðɪs ɪz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋ. waɪ dʒju ɡoʊ tə tɛɹ, ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

The Aiel women were looking at one another, Jolien frozen in the act of closing Dailin's gray-brown coat. "Tear?" Aviendha said in a cautious tone. "Three Aes Sedai walking through a troubled land on their way to Tear. This is a strange thing. Why do you go to Tear, Aes Sedai?"

ɛɡwin ɡlænst ət nɪneɪiv. laɪt, ə moʊmən əɡoʊ ðeɪ wɝ læfɪŋ, ən naʊ ðəɹ əz tɛns əz ðeɪ ɛvɝ wɝ.

Egwene glanced at Nynaeve. Light, a moment ago they were laughing, and now they're as tense as they ever were.

"wi hʌn səm ivəl wɪmən," nɪneɪiv sɛd kɛɹfəli. "dɑɹk fɹɛnz."

"We hunt some evil women," Nynaeve said carefully. "Dark friends."

"ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝz." dʒoʊliən twɪstəɾ əɹ maʊθ ɝaʊn ðə wɝɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪɾən ɪndə ə ɹɑɾən æpəl.

"Shadowrunners." Jolien twisted her mouth around the word as if she had bitten into a rotten apple.

"ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝz ɪn tɛɹ," beɪn sɛd, ən əz ɪf pɑɹɾ ə ðə seɪm sɛntəns kiæɾ æɾəd, "æn θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ sikɪŋ ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn."

"Shadowrunners in Tear," Bain said, and as if part of the same sentence Chiad added, "And three Aes Sedai seeking the Heart of the Stone."

"aɪ dɪd nɑt seɪ wi wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn," nɪneɪiv sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "aɪ mɪɹli sɛɾ aɪ dɪd nɑt wɑnə steɪ hɪɹ tɪl ɪt fɔlz tə dʌst. ɛɡwin, ɪleɪn, ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi?" ʃi stɑɹɾəd aʊɾ ə ðə θɪkɪt wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ænsɝ, wɔkɪŋ stæf θʌmpɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ən lɔŋ stʃɹaɪdz kæɹiɪŋ əɹ saʊθ.

"I did not say we were going to the Heart of the Stone," Nynaeve said sharply. "I merely said I did not want to stay here till it falls to dust. Egwene, Elayne, are you ready?" She started out of the thicket without waiting for an answer, walking staff thumping the ground and long strides carrying her south.

ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn meɪd heɪsti ɡʊdbaɪz bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ æftɝ hɝ. ðə fɔɹ il ɑn ðɛɹ fit stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ əm ɡoʊ.

Egwene and Elayne made hasty goodbyes before following after her. The four Aiel on their feet stood watching them go.

wən ðə tu ʌv əm wɝ ə lɪɾəl weɪ bɪɑn ðə tʃɹiz, ɛɡwin sɛd, "maɪ hɑɹɾ ɔlmoʊst stɑpt wən jə neɪm jɝsɛlf. wɝn jə əfɹeɪd ðeɪ maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl ju, əɹ tə teɪk jə pɹɪznɝ? ði il wɔɹ wɑz nɑt ðət lɔŋ əɡoʊ, ən wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ sɛɾ əbaʊt nɑt hɑɹmɪŋ wɪmən u doʊn kæɹi spɪɹz, ðeɪ lʊkt ɹɛɾi ɪnʌf tə juz ðoʊz spɪɹz ɑn ɛniθɪŋ, tə mi."

When the two of them were a little way beyond the trees, Egwene said, "My heart almost stopped when you named yourself. Weren't you afraid they might try to kill you, or to take you prisoner? The Aiel War was not that long ago, and whatever they said about not harming women who don't carry spears, they looked ready enough to use those spears on anything, to me."

ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɹufəli. "aɪ hæv dʒʌs lɝn haʊ mʌtʃ aɪ də nɑt noʊ əbaʊt ði il, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz tɔt ðət ðeɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ə ði il wɔɹ əz ə wɔɹ əɾ ɔl. fɹəm ðə weɪ ðeɪ bɪheɪv təwɔɹd mi, aɪ θɪŋk meɪbi ðət mʌtʃ ʌv wʌɾ aɪ lɝn ɪz tʃɹuθ. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz kəz ðeɪ θɪŋk aɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Elayne shook her head ruefully. "I have just learned how much I do not know about the Aiel, but I was taught that they do not think of the Aiel War as a war at all. From the way they behaved toward me, I think maybe that much of what I learned is truth. Or maybe it was because they think I am Aes Sedai."

"aɪ noʊ ðeɪ ɑɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ, ɪleɪn, bʌt noʊ wʌn kən kɔl θɹi jɪɹz ə bæɾəlz ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ ə wɔɹ. aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ haʊ mʌtʃ ðeɪ faɪɾ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ə wɔɹ ɪz ə wɔɹ."

"I know they are strange, Elayne, but no one can call three years of battles anything but a war. I do not care how much they fight among themselves, a war is a war."

"nɑt tə ðɛm. θaʊzənz ʌv il kɹɔs ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli ðeɪ sɔ ðɛmsɛlvz mɔɹ laɪk θif-teɪkɝz, əɹ hɛdzmɪn, kʌm æftɝ kɪŋ leɪmən ə kɛɹhin fəɹ ðə kɹaɪm ə kʌɾɪŋ daʊn ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə. tə ði il, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə wɔɹ; ɪt wɑz ən ɛksəkjuʃən."

"Not to them. Thousands of Aiel crossed the Spine of the World, but apparently they saw themselves more like thief-takers, or headsmen, come after King Laman of Cairhien for the crime of cutting down Avendoraldera. To the Aiel, it was not a war; it was an execution."

ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə wʌn ə vɛɹɪnz lɛktʃɝz, hæd bɪn ən ɔfʃuɾ ə ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf ɪtsɛlf, bɹɔt tə kɛɹhin səm faɪv hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ əz ən ənpɹɛsɪdɛntɪɾ ɔfɝ ə pis fɹəm ði il, ɡɪvən əlɔŋ wɪð ðə ɹaɪt tə kɹɔs ðə weɪst, ə ɹaɪɾ ʌðɝwaɪz ɡɪvən tə nʌn bʌt pɛdlɝz, ɡlimən, ən ðə tuætɑn. mʌtʃ ə kɛɹhinz wɛlθ hæd bɪn bɪlt ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪɾ ɪn aɪvɝi ən pɝfjumz ən spaɪsəz ænd, moʊst ʌv ɔl, sɪlk, fɹəm ðə lænz bɪɑn ðə weɪst. nɑɾ ivən vɛɹɪn hæɾ ɛni aɪdiə ʌv haʊ ði il hæd kʌm baɪ ə sæpəlɪŋ ʌv ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə - fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ði oʊl bʊks wɝ klɪɹ ðəɾ ɪt meɪd noʊ sid; fəɹ ənʌðɝ, noʊ wʌn nu wɛɹ ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf wɑz, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju stɔɹiz ðət wɝ klɪɹli ɹɔŋ, bʌt ʃʊɹli ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf kəɾ əv nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ði il - əɹ ʌv waɪ ði il hæd kɔl ðə kɛɹhinɪn ðə wɔɾɝʃɛɹɝz, əɹ ɪnsɪstəd ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnz ə mɝtʃənt wæɡənz flaɪ ə bænɝ bɛɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɛfɔɪl lif ʌv ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə.

Avendoraldera, according to one of Verin's lectures, had been an offshoot of the Tree of Life itself, brought to Cairhien some five hundred years ago as an unprecedented offer of peace from the Aiel, given along with the right to cross the Waste, a right otherwise given to none but peddlers, gleemen, and the Tuatha'an. Much of Cairhien's wealth had been built on the trade in ivory and perfumes and spices and, most of all, silk, from the lands beyond the Waste.
