Not even Verin had any idea of how the Aiel had come by a sapling of Avendesora - for one thing, the old books were clear that it made no seed; for another, no one knew where the Tree of Life was, except for a few stories that were clearly wrong, but surely the Tree of Life could have nothing to do with the Aiel - or of why the Aiel had called the Cairhienin the Watersharers, or insisted their trains of merchant wagons fly a banner bearing the trefoil leaf of Avendesora.

ɛɡwin səpoʊzd, ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli, ðət ʃi kəɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ðeɪ hæd stɑɹɾəd ə wɔɹ - ivən ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz wʌn - æftɝ kɪŋ leɪmən kʌt daʊn ðɛɹ ɡɪf tə meɪk ə θɹoʊn ənlaɪk ɛni ʌðɝ ɪn ðə wɝld. leɪmənz sɪn, ʃi hæd hɝɾ ɪt kɔld. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə vɛɹɪn, nɑɾ oʊnli hæd kɛɹhinz tʃɹeɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə weɪst ɛndəd wɪð ðə wɔɹ, bʌt ðoʊz kɛɹhinɪn u vɛntʃɝɾ ɪndə ðə weɪs naʊ vænɪʃt. vɛɹɪn kleɪm ðeɪ wɝ sɛd tə bi "soʊld əz ænəməlz" ɪn ðə lænz bɪɑn ðə weɪst, bʌt nɑɾ ivən ʃi ʌndɝstʊd haʊ ə mæn əɹ ə wʊmən kəd bi soʊld.

Egwene supposed, grudgingly, that she could understand why they had started a war - even if they did not think it was one - after King Laman cut down their gift to make a throne unlike any other in the world. Laman's Sin, she had heard it called. According to Verin, not only had Cairhien's trade across the Waste ended with the war, but those Cairhienin who ventured into the Waste now vanished. Verin claimed they were said to be "sold as animals" in the lands beyond the Waste, but not even she understood how a man or a woman could be sold.

"ɛɡwin," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ju noʊ hu hi hu kʌmz wɪð ðə dɔn mʌs bi, doʊn ju?"

"Egwene," Elayne said, "you know who He Who Comes With the Dawn must be, don't you?"

stɛɹɪŋ ət nɪneɪivz bæk stɪl wɛl əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd - dʌz ʃi min tə ɹeɪs əs tə dʒʊɹin? - ðən ɔlmoʊst stɑpt wɔkɪŋ. "ju də nɑt min - ?"

Staring at Nynaeve's back still well ahead of them, Egwene shook her head - Does she mean to race us to Jurene? - then almost stopped walking. "You do not mean - ?"

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd. "aɪ θɪŋk soʊ. aɪ də nɑt noʊ mʌtʃ ə ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, bʌɾ aɪ hæv hɝɾ ə fju laɪnz. wʌn aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪz, 'ɑn ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt ʃæl i bi bɔɹn, bɔɹn ʌv ə meɪɾən wɛɾəd tə noʊ mæn.' ɛɡwin, ɹænd dʌz lʊk laɪk ən il. wɛl, hi lʊks laɪk ðə pɪktʃɝz aɪ hæv sin ə tɪɡɹeɪn, tu, bʌt ʃi vænɪʃt bɪfɔɹ i wɑz bɔɹn, ən aɪ hɑɹdli θɪŋk ʃi cʊɾə bɪn ɪz mʌðɝ ɛniweɪ. aɪ θɪŋk ɹændz mʌðɝ wɑz ə meɪɾən ə ðə spɪɹ."

Elayne nodded. "I think so. I do not know much of the Prophecies of the Dragon, but I have heard a few lines. One I remember is, 'On the slopes of Dragonmount shall he be born, born of a maiden wedded to no man.' Egwene, Rand does look like an Aiel. Well, he looks like the pictures I have seen of Tigraine, too, but she vanished before he was born, and I hardly think she could have been his mother anyway. I think Rand's mother was a Maiden of the Spear."

ɛɡwin fɹaʊn ɪn θɔɾ əz ʃi hɝiɾ əlɔŋ, ɹʌnɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi nu ʌv ɹændz bɝθ θɹu hɝ hɛd. hi hæd bɪn ɹeɪz baɪ tæm ælθɹ æftɝ kɛɹi ælθɹ daɪd, bʌɾ ɪf wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd wɑz tʃɹu, ðeɪ kəd nɑt bi hɪz ɹil mʌðɝ ən fɑðɝ. nɪneɪiv hæd səmtaɪmz sim tə noʊ səm sikɹəɾ əbaʊt ɹændz bɝθ. bʌɾ əl bɛɾ aɪ kʊdn pɹaɪ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ wɪð ə fɔɹk!

Egwene frowned in thought as she hurried along, running everything she knew of Rand's birth through her head. He had been raised by Tam al'Thor after Kari al'Thor died, but if what Moiraine said was true, they could not be his real mother and father. Nynaeve had sometimes seemed to know some secret about Rand's birth. But I will bet I couldn't pry it out of her with a fork!

ðeɪ kɑɾ ʌp tə nɪneɪiv, ɛɡwin ɡlaʊɝɪŋ əz ʃi θɔt, nɪneɪiv stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd təwɔɹd dʒʊɹin ən ðət ʃɪp, ən ɪleɪn fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tu tʃɪlʒɹən sʌlkɪŋ oʊvɝ u ʃəɾ əv ðə lɑɹdʒɝ pis ə keɪk.

They caught up to Nynaeve, Egwene glowering as she thought, Nynaeve staring straight ahead toward Jurene and that ship, and Elayne frowning at the pair of them as if they were two children sulking over who should have the larger piece of cake.

æftɝ ə taɪm ə saɪlən stʃɹaɪdz, ɪleɪn sɛd, "ju hændəl ðət vɛɹi wɛl, nɪneɪiv. ðə hilɪŋ, ən ðə ɹɛst, tu. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ ɛvɝ daʊɾɪd jə wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. əɹ ðət wi ɔl wɝ, kəz ə ðə weɪ jə bɔɹ jɝsɛlf."

After a time of silent strides, Elayne said, "You handled that very well, Nynaeve. The Healing, and the rest, too. I do not think they ever doubted you were Aes Sedai. Or that we all were, because of the way you bore yourself."

"ju dɪd də ə ɡʊd dʒɑb," ɛɡwin sɛɾ æftɝ ə mɪnət. "ðæt wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm aɪ hæv ɛvɝ ɹɪli wɑtʃt wʌɾ ɪz dʌn dʊɹɪŋ ə hilɪŋ. ɪt meɪks meɪkɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ lʊk laɪk mɪksɪŋ oʊtkeɪk."

"You did do a good job," Egwene said after a minute. "That was the first time I have ever really watched what is done during a Healing. It makes making lightning look like mixing oatcake."

ə sɝpɹaɪz smaɪl əpɪɹɾ ɑn nɪneɪivz feɪs. "θæŋk ju," ʃi mɝmɝd, ən ɹitʃt oʊvɝ tə ɡɪv ɛɡwinz hɛɹ ə lɪɾəl tʌɡ ðə weɪ ʃi hæd wən ɛɡwin wɑz ə lɪɾəl ɡɝl.

A surprised smile appeared on Nynaeve's face. "Thank you," she murmured, and reached over to give Egwene's hair a little tug the way she had when Egwene was a little girl.

aɪm nɑɾ ə lɪɾəl ɡɝl ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ðə moʊmən pæst əz kwɪkli əz ɪt hæd kʌm, ən ðeɪ wɛn ɑn ɪn saɪləns wʌns mɔɹ. ɪleɪn saɪd laʊdli.

I am not a little girl any longer. The moment passed as quickly as it had come, and they went on in silence once more. Elayne sighed loudly.

ðeɪ kʌvɝɾ ənʌðɝ maɪl, əɹ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ, swɪfli, dɪspaɪt swɪŋɪŋ ɪn fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊn ðə θɪkəts əlɔŋ ðə bæŋk. nɪneɪiv ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn steɪɪŋ wɛl klɪɹ ə ðə tʃɹiz. ɛɡwin θɔɾ ɪt wɑz sɪli tə θɪŋk mɔɹ il wəd bi haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə kɑpsɪz, bʌt ðə swɪŋ ɪnlæn dɪd nɑɾ æd mʌtʃ dɪstəns tə wʌt ðeɪ hæd tə kʌvɝ; nʌn ə ðə ɡɹoʊθs wɝ vɛɹi bɪɡ.

They covered another mile, or a little more, swiftly, despite swinging in from the river to go around the thickets along the bank. Nynaeve insisted on staying well clear of the trees. Egwene thought it was silly to think more Aiel would be hiding in the copses, but the swing inland did not add much distance to what they had to cover; none of the growths were very big.

ɪleɪn wɑtʃt ðə tʃɹiz, ðoʊ, ən ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn u sʌɾənli skɹimd, "lʊk aʊt!"

Elayne watched the trees, though, and she was the one who suddenly screamed, "Look out!"

ɛɡwin dʒɝkt əɹ hɛɾ ɝaʊnd; mɛn wɝ stɛpɪŋ aʊt fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, slɪŋz wɝlɪŋ 'ɹaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz. ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ, ən sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹʌk əɹ hɛd, ən dɑɹknəs dʒɹæŋk ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

Egwene jerked her head around; men were stepping out from among the trees, slings whirling 'round their heads. She reached for saidar, and something struck her head, and darkness drank everything.

ɛɡwin kəd fil hɝsɛlf sweɪɪŋ, fil sʌmθɪŋ muvɪŋ ʌndɝ hɝ. hɝ hɛd sim tə bi nʌθɪŋ bʌt peɪn. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹeɪz ə hæn tə hɝ tɛmpəlz, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ dʌɡ ɪndə hɝ ɹɪsts, ən əɹ hænz dɪd nɑt muv.

Egwene could feel herself swaying, feel something moving under her. Her head seemed to be nothing but pain. She tried to raise a hand to her temples, but something dug into her wrists, and her hands did not move.

" - bɛɾɝ ðən laɪɪŋ ðəɹ ɔl deɪ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ dɑɹk," ə mænz ɹʌf vɔɪs sɛd. "hu noʊz ɪf ənʌðɝ ʃɪp wəd kʌm baɪ kloʊs ɪn? ən aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌs ðət boʊt. ɪt liks."

" - better than lying there all day waiting for dark," a man's rough voice said. "Who knows if another ship would come by close in? And I don't trust that boat. It leaks."

"ju də bɛɾɝ hoʊp æɾən dʌz bɪliv jə dɪd si ðoʊz ɹɪŋz bɪfɔɹ jə dɪd dɪsaɪd," ənʌðɝ mæn sɛd. "hi dʌz wɑn fæt kɑɹɡoʊz, nɑt wɪmən, aɪ θɪŋk." ðə fɝs mæn mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ kɔɹs əbaʊt wʌɾ æɾən kəd də wɪð ɪz liki boʊt, ən ðə kɑɹɡoʊz, tu.

"You do better hope Adden does believe you did see those rings before you did decide," another man said. "He does want fat cargoes, not women, I think." the first man muttered something coarse about what Adden could do with his leaky boat, and the cargoes, too.

hɝ aɪz oʊpənd. sɪlvɝ-flɛk spɑts dænst əkɹɔs əɹ vɪʒən; ʃi θɔt ʃi maɪt bi gɑnə θɹoʊ ʌp ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn sweɪɪŋ pæst ʌndɝ əɹ hɛd. ʃi wɑz taɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə bæk ʌv ə hɔɹs, hɝ ɹɪsts ən æŋkəlz dʒɔɪn baɪ ə ɹoʊp ɹʌnɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪts bɛli, hɝ hɛɹ hæŋɪŋ daʊn.

Her eyes opened. Silver-flecked spots danced across her vision; she thought she might be going to throw up on the ground swaying past under her head. She was tied across the back of a horse, her wrists and ankles joined by a rope running under its belly, her hair hanging down.

ɪt wɑz stɪl deɪlaɪt. ʃi kɹeɪn əɹ nɛk tə lʊk ɝaʊnd. soʊ mɛni ɹʌf-dʒɹɛs mɛn ɑn hɔɹsəz sɝaʊndəɾ əɹ ðət ʃi kəd nɑt si wɛðɝ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd, əz wɛl. səm ə ðə mɛn wɔɹ bɪts ʌv ɑɹmɝ - ə bæɾɝd hɛlmət, əɹ ə dɛntɪd bɹɛstpleɪt, əɹ ə dʒɝkɪn soʊn ɔl oʊvɝ wɪð mɛɾəl skeɪlz - bʌt moʊst wɔɹ oʊnli koʊts ðət hæd nɑt bɪn klin ɪn mʌnθs, ɪf ɛvɝ. fɹəm ðə smɛl, ðə mɛn hæd nɑt klin ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn mʌnθs, iðɝ. ðeɪ ɔl wɔɹ sɔɹdz, ət ðɛɹ weɪsts əɹ ɑn ðɛɹ bæks.

It was still daylight. She craned her neck to look around. So many rough-dressed men on horses surrounded her that she could not see whether Nynaeve and Elayne had been captured, as well. Some of the men wore bits of armor - a battered helmet, or a dented breastplate, or a jerkin sewn all over with metal scales - but most wore only coats that had not been cleaned in months, if ever. From the smell, the men had not cleaned themselves in months, either. They all wore swords, at their waists or on their backs.

ɹeɪdʒ hɪt hɝ, ən fɪɹ, bʌt moʊst ʌv ɔl waɪt-hɑɾ æŋɡɝ. aɪ woʊn bi ə pɹɪznɝ. aɪ woʊn bi baʊnd! aɪ woʊnt! ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ ən ðə peɪn nɪɹli lɪftəd ðə tɑp ə hɝ hɛd; ʃi bɛɹli staɪfəld ə moʊn.

Rage hit her, and fear, but most of all white-hot anger. I won't be a prisoner. I won't be bound! I won't! She reached for saidar and the pain nearly lifted the top of her head; she barely stifled a moan.

ðə hɔɹs pɔz fəɹ ə moʊmən ə ʃaʊts ən ðə kɹik ə ɹʌsti hɪnʒɪz, ðən wɛn əhɛɾ ə lɪɾəl fɝðɝ, ən ðə mɛn bɪɡæn tə dɪsmaʊnt. əz ðeɪ muvd əpɑɹt, ʃi kəd si sʌmθɪŋ ʌv wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ. ə lɔɡ pælɪsɑd sɝaʊndəd ðɛm, bɪlt ətɑp ə lɑɹdʒ, ɹaʊn ɝθən maʊnd, ən mɛn wɪð baʊz stʊd ɡɑɹɾ ɑn ə wʊɾən wɔk bɪl dʒʌs haɪ ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə si oʊvɝ ðə ɹʌf-hjun ɛnz ə ðə lɔɡz. wʌn loʊ, wɪndoʊləs lɔɡ haʊs sim tə bi bɪlt ɪndə ðə maʊndɪd dɝɾ ʌndɝ ðə wɔl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ stʃɹʌktʃɝ bɪɑn ə fju lin-tə ʃɛdz. əsaɪd fɹəm ðə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz ðət hæd dʒʌst ɛntɝd, ðə ɹɛst ə ði oʊpən speɪs wɑz fɪld wɪð kʊk faɪɝz, ən tɛðɝd hɔɹsəz, ən mɔɹ ənwɑʃt mɛn. ðəɹ mʌst əv bɪn ət list ə hʌnʒɹəd. keɪdʒd ɡoʊts ən pɪɡz ən tʃɪkənz fɪl ði ɛɹ wɪð skwilz ən ɡɹʌns ən klʌks ðət blɛndəd wɪð kɔɹs ʃaʊts ən læftɝ tə meɪk ə dɪn ðət pɪɹst əɹ hɛd.

The horse paused for a moment of shouts and the creak of rusty hinges, then went ahead a little further, and the men began to dismount. As they moved apart, she could see something of where they were. A log palisade surrounded them, built atop a large, round earthen mound, and men with bows stood guard on a wooden walk built just high enough for them to see over the rough-hewn ends of the logs. One low, windowless log house seemed to be built into the mounded dirt under the wall. There was no other structure beyond a few lean-to sheds. Aside from the men and horses that had just entered, the rest of the open space was filled with cook fires, and tethered horses, and more unwashed men. There must have been at least a hundred. Caged goats and pigs and chickens filled the air with squeals and grunts and clucks that blended with coarse shouts and laughter to make a din that pierced her head.

hɝ aɪz faʊnd nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn, baʊn hɛd daʊn əkɹɔs sæɾəlləs hɔɹsəz əz ʃi wɑz. niðɝ sim tə bi stɝɪŋ; ðə vɛɹi ɛn ə nɪneɪivz bɹeɪd dʒɹæɡd əkɹɔs ðə dɝɾ əz əɹ hɔɹs stɝd. ə smɔl hoʊp feɪɾəd; ðət wʌn ə ðɛm maɪt bi fɹi, tə hɛlp huɛvɝ wɑz hɛld ɪskeɪp. laɪt, aɪ kænɑt stæn tə bi ə pɹɪznɝ əɡɛn. nɑɾ əɡɛn. dʒɪnʒɝli, ʃi tʃɹaɪd ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ əɡɛn. ðə peɪn wɑz nɑt soʊ bæd ðɪs taɪm - mɪɹli əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd dʒɹɑpt ə ɹɑk ɑn əɹ hɛd - bʌɾ ɪt ʃæɾɝd ði ɛmptinəs bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ ivən θɪŋk ʌv ə ɹoʊz.

Her eyes found Nynaeve and Elayne, bound head down across saddleless horses as she was. Neither seemed to be stirring; the very end of Nynaeve's braid dragged across the dirt as her horse stirred. A small hope faded; that one of them might be free, to help whoever was held escape. Light, I cannot stand to be a prisoner again. Not again. Gingerly, she tried reaching for saidar again. The pain was not so bad this time - merely as if someone had dropped a rock on her head - but it shattered the emptiness before she could even think of a rose.

"wʌn ə ðɛmz əweɪk!" ə mænz pænɪk vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd.

"One of them's awake!" a man's panicked voice shouted.

ɛɡwin tʃɹaɪd tə hæŋ lɪmp ən lʊk ənθɹɛɾənɪŋ. haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt kəɾ aɪ lʊk θɹɛɾənɪŋ taɪɾ ʌp laɪk ə sæk ə mil! bɝn mi, aɪ hæv tə baɪ taɪm. aɪ hæv tə! "aɪ wɪl nɑt hɑɹm ju," ʃi toʊl ðə swɛɾi-feɪst fɛloʊ hu keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ təwɔɹd hɝ. əɹ ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl hɪm. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi hæɾ æktʃəli  sɛd bɪfɔɹ sʌmθɪŋ kɹæʃt ɪndə hɝ hɛɾ əɡɛn ən dɑɹknəs ɹoʊld oʊvɝ əɹ ɪn ə weɪv ə nɔziə.

Egwene tried to hang limp and look unthreatening. How in the Light could I look threatening tied up like a sack of meal! Burn me, I have to buy time. I have to! "I will not harm you," she told the sweaty-faced fellow who came running toward her. Or she tried to tell him. She was not sure how much she had actually said before something crashed into her head again and darkness rolled over her in a wave of nausea.

weɪkɪŋ wɑz iziɝ ðə nɛks taɪm. hɝ hɛd stɪl hɝt, bʌt nɑɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt hæd, ðoʊ hɝ θɔts dɪd sim tə spɪn dɪtsəli. ət lis maɪ stʌmək ɪzənt. . . . laɪt, aɪd bɛɾɝ nɑt θɪŋk ə ðæt. ðəɹ wɑz ə teɪst ə saʊɝ waɪn ən sʌmθɪŋ bɪɾɝ ɪn əɹ maʊθ. stʃɹɪps ə læmplaɪt ʃoʊd θɹu hɔɹəzɑntəl kɹæks ɪn ə kɹudli meɪd wɔl, bʌt ʃi leɪ ɪn dɑɹknəs, ɑn əɹ bæk. ɑn dɝt, ʃi θɔt. ðə dɔɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə fɪt wɛl iðɝ, bʌɾ ɪt lʊkt ɔl tu stɝɾi.

Waking was easier the next time. Her head still hurt, but not as much as it had, though her thoughts did seem to spin dizzily. At least my stomach isn't. . . . Light, I'd better not think of that. There was a taste of sour wine and something bitter in her mouth. Strips of lamplight showed through horizontal cracks in a crudely made wall, but she lay in darkness, on her back. On dirt, she thought. The door did not seem to fit well either, but it looked all too sturdy.

ʃi pʊʃt hɝsɛlf tə hɝ hænz ən niz, ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪnd ʃi wɑz nɑt taɪɾ ɪn ɛni weɪ. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðət wʌn wɔl ʌv ənpild lɔɡz, ði ʌðɝz ɔl sim tə bi ʌv ɹʌf stoʊn. ðə laɪt θɹu ðə kɹæks wɑz ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ hɝ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn laɪɪŋ spɹɔld ɑn ðə dɝt. ðəɹ wɑz blʌɾ ɑn ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz feɪs. niðɝ ə ðɛm muvd ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə ɹaɪz ən fɔl ə ðɛɹ tʃɛsts əz ðeɪ bɹiðd. ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪtwin tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə weɪk əm ɪmiɾiətli ən siɪŋ wʌt leɪ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðət wɔl. dʒʌst ə pik, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf. aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl si wʌt wɪv ɡɑɹɾɪŋ əs bɪfɔɹ aɪ weɪk ðɛm.

She pushed herself to her hands and knees, and was surprised to find she was not tied in any way. Except for that one wall of unpeeled logs, the others all seemed to be of rough stone. The light through the cracks was enough to show her Nynaeve and Elayne lying sprawled on the dirt. There was blood on the Daughter-Heir's face. Neither of them moved except for the rise and fall of their chests as they breathed. Egwene hesitated between trying to wake them immediately and seeing what lay on the other side of that wall. Just a peek, she told herself. I might as well see what we have guarding us before I wake them.

ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf ɪt wɑz nɑt kəz ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd ʃi maɪt bi əneɪbəl tə weɪkən ðɛm. əz ʃi pʊɾ əɹ aɪ tə wʌn ə ðə kɹæks nɪɹ ðə dɔɹ, ʃi θɔɾ ə ðə blʌɾ ɑn ɪleɪnz feɪs ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪɡzækli wʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɪneɪiv hæd dʌn fəɹ deɪlɪn.

She told herself it was not because she was afraid she might be unable to waken them. As she put her eye to one of the cracks near the door, she thought of the blood on Elayne's face and tried to remember exactly what it was Nynaeve had done for Dailin.

ðə nɛkst ɹum wɑz lɑɹdʒ - ɪt hæd tə bi ɔl ðə ɹɛst ə ðə lɔɡ bɪldɪŋ ʃi hæd sin - ən wɪndoʊləs, bʌt bɹaɪtli lɪt wɪð ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ læmps hæŋɪŋ fɹəm spaɪks dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ðə wɔlz ən ðə lɔɡz ðət meɪd ðə haɪ silɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ faɪɝpleɪs. ɑn ðə pæk dɝt flɔɹ fɑɹmhaʊs teɪbəlz ən tʃɛɹz mɪŋɡəld wɪð tʃɛsts kʌvɝɾ ɪn ɡɪlt-wɝk ən ɪnleɪd wɪð aɪvɝi. ə kɑɹpət woʊvən ɪn pikɑks leɪ bɪsaɪɾ ə hjudʒ kænəpid bɛd, paɪl dip wɪð fɪlθi blæŋkəts ən kʌmfɝɾɝz, wɪð ɪlæbɹətli kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd poʊsts.

The next room was large - it had to be all the rest of the log building she had seen - and windowless, but brightly lit with gold and silver lamps hanging from spikes driven into the walls and the logs that made the high ceiling. There was no fireplace. On the packed dirt floor farmhouse tables and chairs mingled with chests covered in gilt-work and inlaid with ivory. A carpet woven in peacocks lay beside a huge canopied bed, piled deep with filthy blankets and comforters, with elaborately carved and gilded posts.

ə dʌzən mɛn stʊɾ əɹ sæɾ ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, bʌɾ ɔl aɪz wɝ ɑn wʌn lɑɹdʒ, fɛɹ-hɛɹd mæn u maɪɾ əv bɪn hænsəm ɪf ɪz feɪs wɝ klinɝ. hi stʊd stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ət ðə tɑp ʌv ə teɪbəl wɪð fluɾəd lɛɡz ən ɡɪldɪd skɹɑlwɝk, wʌn hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, ə fɪŋɡɝ ə ði ʌðɝ pʊʃɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ ɪn smɔl sɝkəlz ɑn ðə teɪbəltɑp.

A dozen men stood or sat around the room, but all eyes were on one large, fair-haired man who might have been handsome if his face were cleaner. He stood staring down at the top of a table with fluted legs and gilded scrollwork, one hand on his sword hilt, a finger of the other pushing something she could not make out in small circles on the tabletop.

ði aʊɾɝ dɔɹ oʊpənd, ɹɪvilɪŋ naɪɾ aʊtsaɪd, ən ə læŋki mæn wɪð ɪz lɛft ɪɹ ɡɔn keɪm ɪn. "hi hæz noʊ kʌm, jɛt," hi sɛd ɹʌfli. hi wɑz mɪsɪŋ tu fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ɪz lɛf hænd, tu. "aɪ də noʊ laɪk dilɪŋ wɪð ðət kaɪnd."

The outer door opened, revealing night outside, and a lanky man with his left ear gone came in. "He has no come, yet," he said roughly. He was missing two fingers on his left hand, too. "I do no like dealing with that kind."

ðə bɪɡ, fɛɹ-hɛɹd mæn peɪɾ ɪm noʊ maɪnd, oʊnli kɛp muvɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi mɝmɝd, ðən læft. "ɡʊd pɹaɪsəz fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪf juv ðə bɛli tə dil wɪð ðə ɹaɪt baɪɝ. ɪf jəɹ ɹɛɾi tə ɹɪsk hævɪŋ jəɹ bɛli ɹɪpt aʊt θɹu jəɹ maʊθ ʃəd jə tʃɹaɪ sɛlɪŋ ɪm ə pɪɡ ɪn ə sæk. nɑt soʊ seɪf əz slɪɾɪŋ ðə kɹuz θɹoʊts ɑn ə tʃɹeɪɾɝz ʃɪp, ɛ, koʊk? nɑt soʊ izi, wʊdn jə seɪ?"

The big, fair-haired man paid him no mind, only kept moving whatever it was on the table. "Three Aes Sedai," he murmured, then laughed. "Good prices for Aes Sedai, if you have the belly to deal with the right buyer. If you're ready to risk having your belly ripped out through your mouth should you try selling him a pig in a sack. Not so safe as slitting the crew's throats on a trader's ship, eh, Coke? Not so easy, wouldn't you say?"

ðəɹ wɑz ə nɝvəs stɝ əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝ mɛn, ən ðə wʌn ədʒɹɛst, ə stɑki fɛloʊ wɪð ʃɪfti aɪz, lin fɔɹwɝɾ æŋkʃəsli. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, æɾən." ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðət vɔɪs; ðə mæn u hæd meɪd ðə kɔɹs sədʒɛstʃənz. "ðeɪ mʌs bi, æɾən. ðə ɹɪŋz pɹuv ɪt, aɪ tɛl ju!" æɾən pɪkt ʌp sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ðə teɪbəl, ə smɔl sɝkəl ðət ɡlɪntɪd ɡoʊld ɪn ðə læmplaɪt.

There was a nervous stir among the other men, and the one addressed, a stocky fellow with shifty eyes, leaned forward anxiously. "They are Aes Sedai, Adden." She recognized that voice; the man who had made the coarse suggestions. "They must be, Adden. The rings prove it, I tell you!" Adden picked up something from the table, a small circle that glinted gold in the lamplight.

ɛɡwin ɡæspt ən fɛlt əɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ðeɪ tʊk maɪ ɹɪŋ!

Egwene gasped and felt at her fingers. They took my ring!

"aɪ də noʊ laɪk ɪt," mʌɾɝd ðə læŋki mæn wɪð ðə mɪsɪŋ ɪɹ. "ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɛni wʌn ə ðɛm kəd kɪl əs ɔl. fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi! jə də bi ə stoʊn-kɑɹv ful, koʊk, ən aɪ ɔt tə kɑɹv jəɹ θɹoʊt. wʌɾ ɪf wʌn ə ðɛm də weɪk bɪfɔɹ i dʌz kʌm?"

"I do no like it," muttered the lanky man with the missing ear. "Aes Sedai. Any one of them could kill us all. Fortune prick me! You do be a stone-carved fool, Coke, and I ought to carve your throat. What if one of them do wake before he does come?"

"ðeɪl nɑt weɪk fəɹ aʊɝz." ðət wɑz ə fæt mæn wɪð ə hɔɹs vɔɪs ən ə ɡæp-tuθ snɪɹ. "maɪ ɡɹæni tɔt mi ʌv ðət stʌf wi fɛd ðɛm. ðəl slip tɪl sʌnɹaɪz, ən hɪl kʌm lɔŋ əfɔɹ ðɛn."

"They'll not wake for hours." That was a fat man with a hoarse voice and a gap-toothed sneer. "My granny taught me of that stuff we fed them. They'll sleep till sunrise, and he'll come long afore then."

ɛɡwin wɝkt əɹ maʊθ ɝaʊn ðə saʊɝ waɪn teɪst ən ðə bɪɾɝnəs. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, jəɹ ɡɹæni laɪd tə ju. ʃi ʃʊɾə stʃɹæŋɡəl jə ɪn jəɹ kɹeɪɾəl! bɪfɔɹ ðɪs "hi" keɪm, ðɪs mæn u θɔɾ i kəd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ - laɪk ə blʌɾi sintʃæn! - ʃi wəɾ əv nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn ɑn ðɛɹ fit. ʃi kɹɔl tə nɪneɪiv.

Egwene worked her mouth around the sour wine taste and the bitterness. Whatever it was, your granny lied to you. She should have strangled you in your cradle! Before this "he" came, this man who thought he could buy Aes Sedai - like a bloody Seanchan! - she would have Nynaeve and Elayne on their feet. She crawled to Nynaeve.

əz nɪɹ əz ʃi kəd tɛl, nɪneɪiv sim tə bi slipɪŋ, soʊ ʃi bɪɡæn wɪð ðə sɪmpəl ɪkspiɾiənt ə ʃeɪkɪŋ hɝ. tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, nɪneɪivz aɪz ʃɑɾ oʊpən.

As near as she could tell, Nynaeve seemed to be sleeping, so she began with the simple expedient of shaking her. To her surprise, Nynaeve's eyes shot open.

"wɑ - ?"

"Wha - ?"

ʃi ɡɑɾ ə hæn oʊvɝ nɪneɪivz maʊθ ɪn taɪm tə stɑp ðə wɝd. "wi ɑɹ biɪŋ hɛl pɹɪznɝ," ʃi wɪspɝd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ə dʌzən mɛn ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðət wɔl, ən mɔɹ aʊtsaɪd. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni mɔɹ. ðeɪ ɡeɪv əs sʌmθɪŋ tə meɪk əs slip, bʌɾ ɪt wɑzn vɛɹi səksɛsfəl. dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ, jɛt?"

She got a hand over Nynaeve's mouth in time to stop the word. "We are being held prisoner," she whispered. "There are a dozen men on the other side of that wall, and more outside. A great many more. They gave us something to make us sleep, but it wasn't very successful. Do you remember, yet?"

nɪneɪiv pʊld ɛɡwinz hæn əsaɪd. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz sɑft ən ɡɹɪm. ʃi ɡɹɪməst ən twɪstəɾ əɹ maʊθ, ðən sʌɾənli bɑɹkt ə nɪɹli saɪlən læf. "slipwɛl ɹut. ðə fulz ɡeɪv əs slipwɛl ɹut mɪkst ɪn waɪn. waɪn nɪɹ ɡɔn tə vɪnəɡɝ, ɪt teɪsts laɪk. kwɪk, dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ ʌv wʌɾ aɪ tɔt ju? wʌt dʌz slipwɛl ɹut du?"

Nynaeve pulled Egwene's hand aside. "I remember." Her voice was soft and grim. She grimaced and twisted her mouth, then suddenly barked a nearly silent laugh. "Sleepwell root. The fools gave us sleepwell root mixed in wine. Wine near gone to vinegar, it tastes like. Quick, do you remember anything of what I taught you? What does sleepwell root do?"

"ɪt klɪɹz hɛdeɪks soʊ jə kən slip," ɛɡwin sɛd dʒʌst əz sɔfli. ən nɪɹli əz ɡɹɪmli, əntɪl ʃi hɝd wʌt ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ. "ɪt meɪks jə ə lɪɾəl dʒɹaʊzi, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz ɔl." ðə fæt mæn hæd nɑt lɪsənd wɛl tə wʌɾ ɪz ɡɹæni toʊl hɪm. "ɔl ðeɪ dɪd wɑz hɛlp klɪɹ ðə peɪn ə biɪŋ hɪɾ ɪn ðə hɛd."

"It clears headaches so you can sleep," Egwene said just as softly. And nearly as grimly, until she heard what she was saying. "It makes you a little drowsy, but that is all." The fat man had not listened well to what his granny told him. "All they did was help clear the pain of being hit in the head."

"ɪɡzækli," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ænd wʌns wi weɪk ɪleɪn, wɪl ɡɪv əm ə θæŋkɪŋ ðeɪ woʊn fɝɡɛt." ʃi ɹoʊz, oʊnli tə kɹaʊtʃ bɪsaɪd ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən.

"Exactly," Nynaeve said. "And once we wake Elayne, we'll give them a thanking they won't forget." She rose, only to crouch beside the golden-haired woman.

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ sɔ mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm aʊtsaɪd wən ðeɪ bɹɔɾ əs ɪn," ɛɡwin wɪspɝd tə nɪneɪivz bæk. "aɪ æm ʃʊɹ jə woʊn maɪn ɪf aɪ juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən ðɪs taɪm. ən sʌmwʌn ɪz əpɛɹənli kʌmɪŋ tə baɪ ʌs. aɪ min tə də sʌmθɪŋ tə ðət fɛloʊ ðət wɪl meɪk ɪm wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt tɪl ðə deɪ hi daɪz!" nɪneɪiv wɑz stɪl kɹaʊtʃt oʊvɝ ɪleɪn, bʌt niðɝ ə ðɛm wɑz muvɪŋ. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ?"

"I think I saw more than a hundred of them outside when they brought us in," Egwene whispered to Nynaeve's back. "I am sure you won't mind if I use the Power as a weapon this time. And someone is apparently coming to buy us. I mean to do something to that fellow that will make him walk in the Light till the day he dies!" Nynaeve was still crouched over Elayne, but neither of them was moving. "What is the matter?"

"ʃi ɪz hɝt bædli, ɛɡwin. aɪ θɪŋk əɹ skʌl ɪz bɹoʊkən, ən ʃiz bɛɹli bɹiðɪŋ. ɛɡwin, ʃiz daɪɪŋ əz ʃʊɹli əz deɪlɪn wɑz."

"She is hurt badly, Egwene. I think her skull is broken, and she is barely breathing. Egwene, she is dying as surely as Dailin was."

"kæn jə də sʌmθɪŋ?" ɛɡwin tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɔl ðə floʊz nɪneɪiv hæd woʊvən tə hil ði il wʊmən, bʌt ʃi kəd ɹikɔl noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛvɹi θɝd θɹɛd. "ju hæv tə!"

"Can't you do something?" Egwene tried to remember all the flows Nynaeve had woven to Heal the Aiel woman, but she could recall no more than every third thread. "You have to!"

"ðeɪ tʊk maɪ ɝbz," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd fɪɹsli, hɝ vɔɪs tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. "aɪ kænt! nɑt wɪθaʊt ði ɝbz!" ɛɡwin wɑz ʃɑk tə ɹilaɪz nɪneɪiv wɑz ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə tɪɹz. "bɝn əm ɔl, aɪ kæn də ɪt wɪθaʊt - !" sʌɾənli ʃi sizd ɪleɪnz ʃoʊldɝz əz ɪf ʃi mɛn tə lɪf ði ʌnkɑnʃəs wʊmən ən ʃeɪk hɝ. "bɝn ju, ɡɝl," ʃi ɹæspt, "aɪ dɪd nɑt bɹɪŋ jə ɔl ðɪs weɪ tə daɪ! aɪ ʃʊɾə lɛf jə skɹʌbɪŋ pɑts! aɪ ʃʊɾə taɪd jə ʌp ɪn ə sæk fəɹ mæt tə kæɹi tə jəɹ mʌðɝ! əl nɑt lɛt jə daɪ ɑn mi! dʒju hɪɹ mi? aɪ woʊn əlaʊ ɪt!" seɪaɪdɑɹ sʌɾənli ʃoʊn ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ɪleɪnz aɪz ən maʊθ oʊpənd waɪd təɡɛðɝ.

"They took my herbs," Nynaeve muttered fiercely, her voice trembling. "I can't! Not without the herbs!" Egwene was shocked to realize Nynaeve was on the point of tears. "Burn them all, I can't do it without - !" Suddenly she seized Elayne's shoulders as if she meant to lift the unconscious woman and shake her. "Burn you, girl," she rasped, "I did not bring you all this way to die! I should have left you scrubbing pots! I should have tied you up in a sack for Mat to carry to your mother! I will not let you die on me! Do you hear me? I won't allow it!" Saidar suddenly shone around her, and Elayne's eyes and mouth opened wide together.

ɛɡwin ɡɑɾ əɹ hænz oʊvɝ ɪleɪnz maʊθ dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə mʌfəl ɛni saʊnd, ʃi θɔt, bʌɾ əz ʃi tʌtʃt hɝ, ði ɛɾiz ə nɪneɪivz hilɪŋ kɑɾ əɹ laɪk ə stʃɹɔ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə wɝl pul. koʊl fɹoʊz əɹ tə ðə boʊn, miɾɪŋ hit ðət sɪɹɾ aʊtwɝɾ əz ɪf ɪt mɛn tə kɹɪsp əɹ flɛʃ; ðə wɝl vænɪʃt ɪn ə sɛnseɪʃən ə ɹʌʃɪŋ, fɔlɪŋ, flaɪɪŋ, spɪnɪŋ.

Egwene got her hands over Elayne's mouth just in time to muffle any sound, she thought, but as she touched her, the eddies of Nynaeve's Healing caught her like a straw on the edge of a whirl pool. Cold froze her to the bone, meeting heat that seared outward as if it meant to crisp her flesh; the world vanished in a sensation of rushing, falling, flying, spinning.

wən ɪt faɪnəli ɛndəd, ʃi wɑz bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹɾ ən stɛɹɪŋ daʊn əɾ ɪleɪn, hu stɛɹd bæk oʊvɝ ðə hænz ʃi stɪl hæd pɹɛst oʊvɝ əɹ wʊmənz maʊð. ðə læst ʌv ɛɡwinz hɛdeɪk wɑz ɡɔn. ivən ðə bækwɑʃ ʌv wʌt nɪneɪiv hæd dʌn hæɾ əpɛɹənli bɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ ðæt. ðə mɝmɝ ə vɔɪsəz fɹəm ði ʌðɝ ɹum wɑz noʊ laʊɾɝ; ɪf ɪleɪn hæd meɪɾ ɛni nɔɪz - əɹ ɪf ʃi hæd - æɾən ən ði ʌðɝz hæd nɑt noʊɾəst.

When it finally ended, she was breathing hard and staring down at Elayne, who stared back over the hands she still had pressed over her woman's mouth. The last of Egwene's headache was gone. Even the backwash of what Nynaeve had done had apparently been enough for that. The murmur of voices from the other room was no louder; if Elayne had made any noise - or if she had - Adden and the others had not noticed.

nɪneɪiv wɑz ɑn əɹ hænz ən niz, hɛd daʊn ən ʃeɪkɪŋ. "laɪt!" ʃi mʌɾɝd. "duɪŋ ɪt ðət weɪ . . . wɑz laɪk pilɪŋ ɔf . . . maɪ oʊn skɪn. oʊ, laɪt!" ʃi pɪɹɾ əɾ ɪleɪn. "haʊ dʒju fil, ɡɝl?" ɛɡwin pʊld əɹ hænz əweɪ.

Nynaeve was on her hands and knees, head down and shaking. "Light!" she muttered. "Doing it that way . . . was like peeling off . . . my own skin. Oh, Light!" She peered at Elayne. "How do you feel, girl?" Egwene pulled her hands away.

"taɪɝd," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd. "æn hʌŋɡɹi. wɛɹ ɑɹ wi? ðəɹ wɝ səm mɛn wɪð slɪŋz. . . ."

"Tired," Elayne murmured. "And hungry. Where are we? There were some men with slings. . . ."

heɪstəli ɛɡwin toʊld əɹ wʌt hæd hæpənd. ɪleɪnz feɪs bɪɡæn tə dɑɹkən ə lɔŋ weɪ bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz dʌn.

Hastily Egwene told her what had happened. Elayne's face began to darken a long way before she was done.

"ænd naʊ," nɪneɪiv æɾəd ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk aɪɝn, "wi ɑɹ gɑnə ʃoʊ ðiz laʊts wʌɾ ɪt minz tə mɛɾəl wɪð ʌs." seɪaɪdɑɹ ʃoʊn ɝaʊn əɹ wʌns mɔɹ.

"And now," Nynaeve added in a voice like iron, "we are going to show these louts what it means to meddle with us." Saidar shone around her once more.

ɪleɪn wɑz ənstɛɾi ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɝ fit, bʌt ðə ɡloʊ sɝaʊndəd hɝ, əz wɛl. ɛɡwin ɹitʃt aʊt tə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ɔlmoʊst ɡlifəli.

Elayne was unsteady getting to her feet, but the glow surrounded her, as well. Egwene reached out to the True Source almost gleefully.

wən ðeɪ lʊk θɹu ðə kɹæks əɡɛn, tə si ɪɡzækli wʌt ðeɪ hæd tə dil wɪð, ðəɹ wɝ θɹi mɹdʒɹɑl ɪn ðə ɹum.

When they looked through the cracks again, to see exactly what they had to deal with, there were three Myrddraal in the room.

dɛd-blæk ɡɑɹb hæŋɪŋ ənnətʃɝəli stɪl, ðeɪ stʊd baɪ ðə teɪbəl, ən ɛvɹi mæn bʌɾ æɾən hæd muvd əz fɑɹ fɹəm əm əz i kʊd, tɪl ðeɪ ɔl hæd ðɛɹ bæks əɡɛns ðə wɔlz ən ðɛɹ aɪz ɑn ðə dɝt flɔɹ. əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl fɹəm ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, æɾən feɪs ðoʊz aɪləs stɛɹz, bʌt swɛt meɪd ɹʌnəlz ɪn ðə dɝɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs.

Dead-black garb hanging unnaturally still, they stood by the table, and every man but Adden had moved as far from them as he could, till they all had their backs against the walls and their eyes on the dirt floor. Across the table from the Myrddraal, Adden faced those eyeless stares, but sweat made runnels in the dirt on his face.

ðə feɪd pɪkt ʌp ə ɹɪŋ fɹəm ðə teɪbəl. ɛɡwin sɔ naʊ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə mʌtʃ hɛviɝ sɝkəl ʌv ɡoʊl ðən ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋz.

The Fade picked up a ring from the table. Egwene saw now that it was a much heavier circle of gold than the Great Serpent rings.

feɪs pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə kɹæk bɪtwin tu lɔɡz, nɪneɪiv ɡæsp sɔfli ən fʌmbəld ət ðə nɛk ə hɝ dʒɹɛs.

Face pressed against the crack between two logs, Nynaeve gasped softly and fumbled at the neck of her dress.

"θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ," ðə hæfmən hɪst, ɪts əmjuzmən saʊndɪŋ laɪk dɛd θɪŋz paʊɾɝɪŋ tə dʌst, "ænd wʌn kæɹid ðɪs." ðə ɹɪŋ meɪɾ ə hɛvi θʌɾ əz ðə mɹdʒɹɑl tɔst ɪt bæk ɑn ðə teɪbəl.

"Three Aes Sedai," the Halfman hissed, its amusement sounding like dead things powdering to dust, "and one carried this." The ring made a heavy thud as the Myrddraal tossed it back on the table.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə wʌnz aɪ sik," ənʌðɝ ə ðɛm ɹæspt. "ju wɪl bi wɛl ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd, hjumən."

"They are the ones I seek," another of them rasped. "You will be well rewarded, human."

"wi mʌs teɪk əm baɪ sɝpɹaɪz," nɪneɪiv sɛd sɔfli. "wʌt kaɪndə lɑk hoʊlz ðɪs dɔɹ?"

"We must take them by surprise," Nynaeve said softly. "What kind of lock holds this door?"

ɛɡwin kəd dʒʌst si ðə lɑk ɑn ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹ, ən aɪɝn θɪŋ ɑn ə tʃeɪn hɛvi ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ən ɛnɹeɪdʒ bʊl. "bi ɹɛɾi," ʃi sɛd.

Egwene could just see the lock on the outside of the door, an iron thing on a chain heavy enough to hold an enraged bull. "Be ready," she said.

ʃi θɪnd wʌn floʊ ʌv ɝθ tə faɪnɝ ðən ə hɛɹ, hoʊpɪŋ ðə hæfmən kəd nɑt sɛns soʊ smɔl ə tʃænəlɪŋ, ən woʊv ɪɾ ɪndə ði aɪɝn tʃeɪn, ɪndə ðə taɪniəs bɪts ʌv ɪt.

She thinned one flow of Earth to finer than a hair, hoping the Halfmen could not sense so small a channeling, and wove it into the iron chain, into the tiniest bits of it.

wʌn ə ðə mɹdʒɹɑl lɪftəɾ ɪts hɛd. ənʌðɝ lin əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl təwɔɹɾ æɾən. "aɪ ɪtʃ, hjumən. ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ðeɪ slip?" æɾən swɑloʊd hɑɹɾ ən nɑɾəd ɪz hɛd.

One of the Myrddraal lifted its head. Another leaned across the table toward Adden. "I itch, human. Are you sure they sleep?" Adden swallowed hard and nodded his head.

ðə θɝd mɹdʒɹɑl tɝn tə stɛɹ ət ðə dɔɹ tə ðə ɹum wɛɹ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz kɹaʊtʃt.

The third Myrddraal turned to stare at the door to the room where Egwene and the others crouched.

ðə tʃeɪn fɛl tə ðə flɔɹ, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪt snɑɹəld, ən ði aʊɾɝ dɔɹ swʌŋ oʊpən, blæk-veɪl dɛθ floʊɪŋ ɪn fɹəm ðə naɪt.

The chain fell to the floor, the Myrddraal staring at it snarled, and the outer door swung open, black-veiled death flowing in from the night.

ðə ɹum ɪɹʌptəɾ ɪn skɹimz ən ʃaʊts əz mɛn klɔd fəɹ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz tə faɪt stæbɪŋ il spɪɹz. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl dʒɹu bleɪdz blækɝ ðən ðɛɹ ɡɑɹb ən fɔt fəɹ ðɛɹ lɪvz, tu. ɛɡwin hæd wʌns sin sɪks kæts ɔl faɪɾɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ; ðɪs wɑz ðəɾ ə hʌndʒɹɛdfoʊld. ən jɛɾ ɪn sɛkənz, saɪləns ɹeɪnd. əɹ ɔlmoʊst saɪləns.

The room erupted in screams and shouts as men clawed for their swords to fight stabbing Aiel spears. The Myrddraal drew blades blacker than their garb and fought for their lives, too. Egwene had once seen six cats all fighting each other; this was that a hundredfold. And yet in seconds, silence reigned. Or almost silence.

ɛvɹi hjumən nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ə blæk veɪl leɪ dɛd wɪð ə spɪɹ θɹu hɪm; wʌn pɪn æɾən tə ðə wɔl. tu il leɪ stɪl, əz wɛl, əmɪd ðə dʒʌmbəl ʌv oʊvɝtɝn fɝnɪtʃɝ ən dɛd. ðə θɹi mɹdʒɹɑl stʊd bæk-tə-bæk ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹum, blæk sɔɹdz ɪn ðɛɹ hænz. wʌn wɑz klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz saɪɾ əz ɪf wundəd, ðoʊ hi ɡeɪv noʊ ʌðɝ saɪn ʌv ɪt. ənʌðɝ hæɾ ə lɔŋ ɡæʃ daʊn ɪts peɪl feɪs; ɪt dɪd nɑt blid. ɝaʊn əm sɝkəl ðə faɪv veɪld il stɪl əlaɪv, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ. fɹəm aʊtsaɪd keɪm skɹimz ən klæʃɪz ə mɛɾəl ðət sɛd mɔɹ il stɪl fɔɾ ɪn ðə naɪt, bʌɾ ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz ə sɑftɝ saʊnd.

Every human not wearing a black veil lay dead with a spear through him; one pinned Adden to the wall. Two Aiel lay still, as well, amid the jumble of overturned furniture and dead. The three Myrddraal stood back-to-back in the center of the room, black swords in their hands. One was clutching his side as if wounded, though he gave no other sign of it. Another had a long gash down its pale face; it did not bleed. Around them circled the five veiled Aiel still alive, crouching. From outside came screams and clashes of metal that said more Aiel still fought in the night, but in the room was a softer sound.

əz ðeɪ sɝkəld, ði il dʒɹʌm ðɛɹ spɪɹz əɡɛns ðɛɹ smɔl haɪd bʌklɝz. θɹəm-θɹəm-θɹəm-θɹəm . . . θɹəm-θɹəm-θɹʌmθɹəm . . . θɹəm-θɹəm-θɹəm-θɹəm. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl tɝnd wɪð ðɛm, ən ðɛɹ aɪləs feɪsəz simd ənsɝɾən, ənizi ðət ðə fɪɹ ðɛɹ ɡeɪz stʃɹʌk ɪndə ɛvɹi hjumən hɑɹt dɪd nɑt sim tə tʌtʃ ðiz.

As they circled, the Aiel drummed their spears against their small hide bucklers. Thrum-thrum-THRUM-thrum . . . thrum-thrum-THRUMthrum . . . thrum-thrum-THRUM-thrum. The Myrddraal turned with them, and their eyeless faces seemed uncertain, uneasy that the fear their gaze struck into every human heart did not seem to touch these.

"dæns wɪð mi, ʃæɾoʊmən," wʌn ə ði il kɔl sʌɾənli, tɔntɪŋli. hi saʊndəd laɪk ə jʌŋ mæn.

"Dance with me, Shadowman," one of the Aiel called suddenly, tauntingly. He sounded like a young man.

"dæns wɪð mi, aɪləs." ðət wɑz ə wʊmən.

"Dance with me, Eyeless." That was a woman.

"dæns wɪð mi."

"Dance with me."

"dæns wɪð mi."

"Dance with me."

"aɪ θɪŋk," nɪneɪiv sɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ, "ðæɾ ɪts taɪm." ʃi θɹu oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, ən ðə θɹi wɪmən ɹæpt ɪn ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ stɛpt aʊt.

"I think," Nynaeve said, straightening, "that it is time." She threw open the door, and the three women wrapped in the glow of saidar stepped out.

ɪt simd əz ðoʊ, fəɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, ði il hæd sis tə ɪɡzɪst, ən fəɹ ði il, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl. ði il stɛɹɾ əɾ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz əbʌv ðɛɹ veɪlz əz ɪf nɑt kwaɪt ʃʊɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ siɪŋ; ʃi hɝd wʌn ə ðə wɪmən ɡæsp laʊdli. ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz aɪləs stɛɹ wɑz dɪfɹənt. ɛɡwin kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ðə hæfmənz nɑlədʒ ə ðɛɹ oʊn dɛθs ɪn ɪt; hæfmən nu wɪmən ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs wən ðeɪ sɔ ðɛm. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd fil ə dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ əɹ dɛθ, tu, ɪf ðɛɹz kəd baɪ hɝz, ən ən ivən stʃɹɔŋɝ dɪzaɪɝ tə stʃɹɪp ðə soʊl aʊɾ ə hɝ flɛʃ ən meɪk boʊθ pleɪθɪŋz fəɹ ðə ʃædoʊ, ə dɪzaɪɝ tə. . . .

It seemed as though, for the Myrddraal, the Aiel had ceased to exist, and for the Aiel, the Myrddraal. The Aiel stared at Egwene and the others above their veils as if not quite sure what they were seeing; she heard one of the women gasp loudly. The Myrddraal's eyeless stare was different. Egwene could almost feel the Halfmen's knowledge of their own deaths in it; Halfmen knew women embracing the True Source when they saw them. She was sure she could feel a desire for her death, too, if theirs could buy hers, and an even stronger desire to strip the soul out of her flesh and make both playthings for the Shadow, a desire to. . . .

ʃi hæd dʒʌst stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum, jɛɾ ɪt simd ʃi hæd bɪn miɾɪŋ ðət stɛɹ fəɹ aʊɝz. "aɪl teɪk noʊ mɔɹ ə ðɪs," ʃi ɡɹaʊld, ən ənliʃt ə floʊ ʌv faɪɝ.

She had just stepped into the room, yet it seemed she had been meeting that stare for hours. "I'll take no more of this," she growled, and unleashed a flow of Fire.

fleɪmz bɝst aʊɾ ʌv ɔl θɹi mɹdʒɹɑl, spɹaʊɾɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, ən ðeɪ ʃɹik laɪk splɪntɝd boʊnz dʒæmɪŋ ə mit-ɡɹaɪndɝ. jɛt ʃi hæd fɝɡɑɾən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn, ðəɾ ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv wɝ wɪð hɝ. ivən əz ðə fleɪmz kənsum ðə hæfmən, ðə vɛɹi ɛɹ sim sʌɾənli tə pʊʃ əm təɡɛðɝ ɪn mɪdɛɹ, kɹʌʃɪŋ əm ɪndə ə bɔl ə faɪɝ ən blæknəs ðət ɡɹu smɔlɝ ən smɔlɝ. ðɛɹ skɹimz dʌɡ əɾ ɛɡwinz spaɪn, ən sʌmθɪŋ ʃɑɾ aʊt fɹəm nɪneɪivz hænz - ə θɪn bɑɹ ʌv waɪt laɪt ðət meɪd nundeɪ sʌn sim dɑɹk, ə bɑɹ ə faɪɝ ðət meɪd moʊltən mɛɾəl sim koʊld, kənɛktɪŋ əɹ hænz tə ðə mɹdʒɹɑl. ən ðeɪ sis tə ɪɡzɪst əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn. nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾəld dʒʌmp, ən ðə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn əɹ vænɪʃt.

Flames burst out of all three Myrddraal, sprouting in every direction, and they shrieked like splintered bones jamming a meat-grinder. Yet she had forgotten she was not alone, that Elayne and Nynaeve were with her. Even as the flames consumed the Halfmen, the very air seemed suddenly to push them together in midair, crushing them into a ball of fire and blackness that grew smaller and smaller. Their screams dug at Egwene's spine, and something shot out from Nynaeve's hands - a thin bar of white light that made noonday sun seem dark, a bar of fire that made molten metal seem cold, connecting her hands to the Myrddraal. And they ceased to exist as if they had never been. Nynaeve gave a startled jump, and the glow around her vanished.

"wʌt . . . wʌt wɑz ðæt?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"What . . . what was that?" Elayne asked.

nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd; ʃi lʊkt əz stʌn əz ɪleɪn saʊndəd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ. aɪ . . . aɪ wɑz soʊ æŋɡɹi, soʊ əfɹeɪd, ət wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd tə. . . . aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz."

Nynaeve shook her head; she looked as stunned as Elayne sounded. "I don't know. I . . . I was so angry, so afraid, at what they wanted to. . . . I do not know what it was."

bɑlfaɪɝ, ɛɡwin θɔt. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ ʃi nu, bʌt ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ʌv ɪt. ɹɪlʌktənli, ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf ɹilis seɪaɪdɑɹ; meɪɾ ɪt ɹilis hɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ wɑz hɑɹɾɝ. ən aɪ dɪd nɑt si ə θɪŋ ʌv wʌt ʃi dɪd!

Balefire, Egwene thought. She did not know how she knew, but she was certain of it. Reluctantly, she made herself release saidar; made it release her. She did not know which was harder. And I did not see a thing of what she did!

ði il ənveɪl ðɛmsɛlvz, ðɛn. ə tʃɹaɪfəl heɪstəli, ɛɡwin θɔt, əz ɪf tə tɛl əɹ ən ði ʌðɝ tu ðeɪ wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɛɾi tə faɪt. θɹi ʌv ði il wɝ meɪl, wʌn ən oʊldɝ mæn wɪð mɔɹ ðən tʌtʃəz ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn ɪz dɑɹk ɹɛd hɛɹ. ðeɪ wɝ tɔl, ðiz ilmɛn, ən jʌŋ əɹ oʊld, ðeɪ hæd ðət kɑm ʃʊɹnəs ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, ðət deɪnʒɝəs ɡɹeɪs ə moʊʃən ɛɡwin əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð wɔɹɾɝz; dɛθ ɹoʊɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ən ðeɪ nu ɪt wɑz ðəɹ ən wɝ nɑɾ əfɹeɪd. wʌn ə ðə wɪmən wɑz eɪvinhə. ðə skɹimz ən ʃaʊts aʊtsaɪd wɝ daɪɪŋ əweɪ.

The Aiel unveiled themselves, then. A trifle hastily, Egwene thought, as if to tell her and the other two they were no longer ready to fight. Three of the Aiel were male, one an older man with more than touches of gray in his dark red hair. They were tall, these Aielmen, and young or old, they had that calm sureness in their eyes, that dangerous grace of motion Egwene associated with Warders; death rode on their shoulders, and they knew it was there and were not afraid. One of the women was Aviendha. The screams and shouts outside were dying away.

nɪneɪiv stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə fɔlən il.

Nynaeve started toward the fallen Aiel.

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ nid, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ði oʊldɝ mæn sɛd. "ðeɪ tʊk ʃæɾoʊmən stil."

"There is no need, Aes Sedai," the older man said. "They took Shadowman steel."

nɪneɪiv stɪl bɛn tə tʃɛk itʃ, pʊlɪŋ ðɛɹ veɪlz əweɪ soʊ ʃi kəd pil bæk aɪlɪdz ən fil θɹoʊts fəɹ ə pʌls. wən ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm ðə sɛkənd, hɝ feɪs wɑz waɪt. ɪt wɑz deɪlɪn. "bɝn ju! bɝn ju!" ɪt wɑz nɑt klɪɹ wɛðɝ ʃi mɛn deɪlɪn, əɹ ðə mæn wɪð ɡɹeɪ ɪn ɪz hɛɹ, əɹ eɪvinhə, əɹ ɔl il. "aɪ dɪd nɑt hil əɹ soʊ ʃi kəd daɪ laɪk ðɪs!"

Nynaeve still bent to check each, pulling their veils away so she could peel back eyelids and feel throats for a pulse. When she straightened from the second, her face was white. It was Dailin. "Burn you! Burn you!" It was not clear whether she meant Dailin, or the man with gray in his hair, or Aviendha, or all Aiel. "I did not Heal her so she could die like this!"

"dɛθ kʌmz tə əs ɔl," eɪvinhə bɪɡæn, bʌt wən nɪneɪiv ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn hɝ, ʃi fɛl saɪlənt. ði il ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz, əz ɪf nɑt sɝɾən wɛðɝ nɪneɪiv maɪt də tə ðɛm wʌt hæd bɪn dʌn tə ðə mɹdʒɹɑl. ɪt wɑz nɑt fɪɹ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, oʊnli əwɛɹnəs.

"Death comes to us all," Aviendha began, but when Nynaeve rounded on her, she fell silent. The Aiel exchanged glances, as if not certain whether Nynaeve might do to them what had been done to the Myrddraal. It was not fear in their eyes, only awareness.

"ʃæɾoʊmən stil kɪlz," eɪvinhə sɛd, "ɪt dʌz nɑt waʊnd." ði oʊldɝ mæn lʊkt ət hɝ, ə slaɪt sɝpɹaɪz ɪn ɪz aɪz - ɛɡwin dɪsaɪɾɪd ðæt, laɪk læn, fəɹ ðɪs mæn ðət flɪkɝ ə ði aɪlɪdz wɑz ði ɪkwɪvələn ʌv ənʌðɝ mænz oʊpən əstɑnɪʃmənt - ən eɪvinhə sɛd, "ðeɪ noʊ lɪɾəl ə səm θɪŋz, ɹəɑɹk."

"Shadowman steel kills," Aviendha said, "it does not wound." The older man looked at her, a slight surprise in his eyes - Egwene decided that, like Lan, for this man that flicker of the eyelids was the equivalent of another man's open astonishment - and Aviendha said, "They know little of some things, Rhuarc."

"aɪ æm sɑɹi," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə klɪɹ vɔɪs, "ðæt wi ɪntɝʌptɪd jəɹ . . . dæns. pɝhæps wi ʃəd nɑɾ əv ɪntɝfɪɹd."

"I am sorry," Elayne said in a clear voice, "that we interrupted your . . . dance. Perhaps we should not have interfered."

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv əɹ ə stɑɹɾəld lʊk, ðən sɔ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. pʊɾ əm əɾ iz, ən ɡɪv nɪneɪiv ə tʃæns tə kul daʊn. "ju wɝ hænlɪŋ θɪŋz kwaɪt wɛl," ʃi sɛd. "pɝhæps wi əfɛndəd baɪ pʊɾɪŋ əɹ noʊzɪz ɪn."

Egwene gave her a startled look, then saw what she was doing. Put them at ease, and give Nynaeve a chance to cool down. "You were handling things quite well," she said. "Perhaps we offended by putting our noses in."

ðə ɡɹeɪɪŋ mæn - ɹəɑɹk - ɡeɪv ə dip tʃʌkəl. "ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ fəɹ wʌn æm ɡlæɾ ʌv . . . wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz jə dɪd." fəɹ ə moʊmən i lʊk nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ʃʊɹ ə ðæt, bʌɾ ɪn ðə nɛkst i hæɾ ɪz ɡʊd tɛmpɝ bæk. hi hæɾ ə ɡʊd smaɪl, ən ə stʃɹɔŋ, skwɛɹ feɪs; hi wɑz hænsəm, ɪf ə lɪɾəl oʊld. "wi cʊɾə kɪl ðɛm, bʌt θɹi ʃæɾoʊmən. . . . ðeɪ wʊɾə kɪl tu əɹ θɹi ʌv ʌs, sɝɾənli, pɝhæps ɔl, ən aɪ kænɑt seɪ wi wʊɾə fɪnɪʃt əm ɔl. fəɹ ðə jʌŋ, dɛθ ɪz ən ɛnəmi ðeɪ wɪʃ tə tʃɹaɪ ðɛɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ əɡɛnst. fəɹ ðoʊz ʌv əs ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ, ʃiz ən oʊl fɹɛnd, ən oʊld lʌvɝ, bʌt wʌn wəɹ nɑɾ iɡɝ tə miɾ əɡɛn sun."

The graying man - Rhuarc - gave a deep chuckle. "Aes Sedai, I for one am glad of . . . whatever it was you did." For a moment he looked not entirely sure of that, but in the next he had his good temper back. He had a good smile, and a strong, square face; he was handsome, if a little old. "We could have killed them, but three Shadowmen. . . . They would have killed two or three of us, certainly, perhaps all, and I cannot say we would have finished them all. For the young, death is an enemy they wish to try their strength against. For those of us a little older, she is an old friend, an old lover, but one we are not eager to meet again soon."

nɪneɪiv sim tə ɹɪlæks wɪð ɪz spitʃ, əz ɪf miɾɪŋ ən il u dɪd nɑt sim æŋkʃəs tə daɪ hæd litʃt ðə tɛnʃən aʊɾ ə hɝ. "aɪ ʃəd θæŋk ju," ʃi sɛd, "æn aɪ du. əl ədmɪɾ aɪm sɝpɹaɪz tə si ju, ðoʊ. eɪvinhə, dɪd jə ɪkspɛk tə faɪn əs hɪɹ? haʊ?"

Nynaeve seemed to relax with his speech, as if meeting an Aiel who did not seem anxious to die had leached the tension out of her. "I should thank you," she said, "and I do. I will admit I am surprised to see you, though. Aviendha, did you expect to find us here? How?"

"aɪ fɑloʊd ju." ði il wʊmən simd ʌnɪmbɛɹəst. "tə si wʌt jə wəd du. aɪ sɔ ðə mɛn teɪk ju, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz tu fɑɹ bæk tə hɛlp. aɪ wɑz ʃʊɹ jə mʌst si mi ɪf aɪ keɪm tu kloʊs, soʊ aɪ steɪɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz bɪhaɪnd. baɪ ðə taɪm aɪ sɔ jə kəd nɑt hɛlp jʊɹsɛlvz, ɪt wɑz tu leɪt tə tʃɹaɪ əloʊn."

"I followed you." The Aiel woman seemed unembarrassed. "To see what you would do. I saw the men take you, but I was too far back to help. I was sure you must see me if I came too close, so I stayed a hundred paces behind. By the time I saw you could not help yourselves, it was too late to try alone."

"aɪ æm ʃʊɹ jə dɪd wʌt jə kʊd," ɛɡwin sɛd feɪnli. ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz bɪhaɪn ʌs? laɪt, ðə bɹɪɡænz nɛvɝ sɔ ɛniθɪŋ.

"I am sure you did what you could," Egwene said faintly. She was just a hundred paces behind us? Light, the brigands never saw anything.

eɪvinhə tʊk əɹ wɝdz əz ɝdʒɪŋ tə tɛl mɔɹ. "aɪ nu wɛɹ kɔɹæm mʌs bi, ən i nu wɛɹ dl ən lʌeɪn wɝ, ən ðeɪ nu. . . ." ʃi pɔzd, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ði oʊldɝ mæn. "aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk tə faɪn ɛni klæn tʃif, mʌtʃ lɛs maɪ oʊn, əmʌŋ ðoʊz u keɪm. hu lidz ðə tɑɹdæɾ il, ɹəɑɹk, wɪð jə hɪɹ?"

Aviendha took her words as urging to tell more. "I knew where Coram must be, and he knew where Dhael and Luaine were, and they knew. . . ." She paused, frowning at the older man. "I did not expect to find any clan chief, much less my own, among those who came. Who leads the Taardad Aiel, Rhuarc, with you here?"

ɹəɑɹk ʃɹʌɡd əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə noʊ əkaʊnt. "ðə sɛp tʃifs wɪl teɪk ðɛɹ tɝnz, ən tʃɹaɪ tə dɪsaɪɾ ɪf ðeɪ tʃɹuli wɪʃ tə ɡoʊ tə ɹɪɾiən wən aɪ daɪ. aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv kʌm, ɪksɛp ðəɾ æmɪz ən bɛɹ ən məleɪn ən sinə stɔk mi laɪk ɹɪdʒɛkæts æftɝ ə waɪld ɡoʊt. ðə dʒɹimz sɛɾ aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ. ðeɪ æskt ɪf aɪ tʃɹuli wɑntəd tə daɪ oʊld ən fæɾ ɪn ə bɛd."

Rhuarc shrugged as if it were of no account. "The sept chiefs will take their turns, and try to decide if they truly wish to go to Rhuidean when I die. I would not have come, except that Amys and Bair and Melaine and Seana stalked me like ridgecats after a wild goat. The dreams said I must go. They asked if I truly wanted to die old and fat in a bed."

eɪvinhə læft əz ɪf əɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dʒoʊk. "aɪ hæv hɝɾ ɪt sɛd ðəɾ ə mæn kɑt bɪtwin ɪz waɪf ən ə waɪz wʌn ɔfən wɪʃɪz fəɹ ə dʌzən oʊld ɛnəmiz tə faɪɾ ɪnstɛd. ə mæn kɑt bɪtwin ə waɪf ən θɹi waɪz wʌnz, ən ðə waɪf ə waɪz wʌn hɝsɛlf, mʌs kənsɪɾɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sleɪ saɪtblɪndɝ."

Aviendha laughed as if at a great joke. "I have heard it said that a man caught between his wife and a Wise One often wishes for a dozen old enemies to fight instead. A man caught between a wife and three Wise Ones, and the wife a Wise One herself, must consider trying to slay Sightblinder."

"ðə θɔt keɪm tə mi." hi fɹaʊn daʊn ət sʌmθɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ; θɹi ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋz, ɛɡwin sɔ, ən ə mʌtʃ hɛviɝ ɡoʊldən ɹɪŋ meɪd fəɹ ə mænz lɑɹdʒ fɪŋɡɝ. "ɪt stɪl dʌz. ɔl θɪŋz mʌs tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ aɪ wəd nɑt bi ə pɑɹɾ ə ðət tʃeɪnʒ ɪf aɪ kəd sɛt maɪsɛlf əsaɪd fɹəm ɪt. θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ, tʃɹævlɪŋ tə tɛɹ." ði ʌðɝ il ɡlænst ət wʌn ənʌðɝ əz ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑn ɛɡwin ən əɹ kəmpænjənz tə noʊɾəs.

"The thought came to me." He frowned down at something on the floor; three Great Serpent rings, Egwene saw, and a much heavier golden ring made for a man's large finger. "It still does. All things must change, but I would not be a part of that change if I could set myself aside from it. Three Aes Sedai, traveling to Tear." The other Aiel glanced at one another as if they did not want Egwene and her companions to notice.

"ju spoʊk ə dʒɹimz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "du jəɹ waɪz wʌnz noʊ wʌt ðɛɹ dʒɹimz min?"

"You spoke of dreams," Egwene said. "Do your Wise Ones know what their dreams mean?"

"sʌm du. ɪf jə wəd noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt, jə mʌst spik tə ðɛm. pɝhæps ðəl tɛl ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ də nɑt tɛl mɛn, ɪksɛpt wʌt ðə dʒɹimz seɪ wi mʌs du." hi saʊndəd taɪɝd, sʌɾənli. "æn ðəɾ ɪz juʒəwəli wʌt wi wəɾ əvɔɪd, ɪf wi kʊd."

"Some do. If you would know more than that, you must speak to them. Perhaps they will tell an Aes Sedai. They do not tell men, except what the dreams say we must do." He sounded tired, suddenly. "And that is usually what we would avoid, if we could."

hi stup tə pɪk ʌp ðə mænz ɹɪŋ. ɑn ɪt, ə kɹeɪn flu əbʌv ə læns ən kɹaʊn; ɛɡwin nu ɪt naʊ. ʃi hæd sin ɪɾ ɔfən bɪfɔɹ, dæŋɡəlɪŋ əbaʊt nɪneɪivz nɛk ɑn ə lɛðɝ kɔɹd. nɪneɪiv stɛpt ɑn ði ʌðɝ ɹɪŋz tə snætʃ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz hænd; hɝ feɪs wɑz flʌʃt, wɪð æŋɡɝ ən tu mɛni ʌðɝ ɪmoʊʃənz fəɹ ɛɡwin tə ɹid. ɹəɑɹk meɪd noʊ muv tə teɪk ɪt bæk, bʌt wɛn ɑn ɪn ðə seɪm wɪɹi toʊn.

He stooped to pick up the man's ring. On it, a crane flew above a lance and crown; Egwene knew it now. She had seen it often before, dangling about Nynaeve's neck on a leather cord. Nynaeve stepped on the other rings to snatch it out of his hand; her face was flushed, with anger and too many other emotions for Egwene to read. Rhuarc made no move to take it back, but went on in the same weary tone.

"ænd wʌn ə ðɛm kæɹiz ə ɹɪŋ aɪ hæv hɝɾ ʌv əz ə bɔɪ. ðə ɹɪŋ ə mɔlkɪɹi kɪŋz. ðeɪ ɹoʊd wɪð ðə ʃaɪnɝənz əɡɛns ði il ɪn maɪ fɑðɝz taɪm. ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊɾ ɪn ðə dæns ə ðə spɪɹz. bʌt mɔlkiɝ fɛl tə ðə blaɪt. ɪts sɛɾ oʊnli ə tʃaɪl kɪŋ sɝvaɪvd, ən i kɔɹts ðə dɛθ ðət tʊk ɪz læn əz ʌðɝ mɛn kɔɹt bjuɾəfəl wɪmən. tʃɹuli, ðɪs ɪz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʌv ɔl ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ saɪts aɪ θɔɾ aɪ maɪt si wən məleɪn hɛɹid mi aʊɾ ə maɪ oʊn hoʊld ən oʊvɝ ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, nʌn əz bɪn soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ əz ðɪs. ðə pæθ jə sɛt mi ɪz wʌn aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt maɪ fit wəd fɑloʊ."

"And one of them carries a ring I have heard of as a boy. The ring of Malkieri kings. They rode with the Shienarans against the Aiel in my father's time. They were good in the dance of the spears. But Malkier fell to the Blight. It is said only a child king survived, and he courts the death that took his land as other men court beautiful women. Truly, this is a strange thing, Aes Sedai. Of all the strange sights I thought I might see when Melaine harried me out of my own hold and over the Dragonwall, none has been so strange as this. The path you set me is one I never thought my feet would follow."

"aɪ sɛt noʊ pæðz fəɹ ju," nɪneɪiv sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ɔl aɪ wɑn ɪz tə kəntɪnju maɪ dʒɝni. ðiz mɛn hæd hɔɹsəz. wɪl teɪk θɹi ʌv əm ən bi ɑn əɹ weɪ."

"I set no paths for you," Nynaeve said sharply. "All I want is to continue my journey. These men had horses. We will take three of them and be on our way."

"ɪn ðə naɪt, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ɹəɑɹk sɛd. "ɪz jəɹ dʒɝni soʊ ɝdʒən ðət jə wəd tʃɹævəl ðiz deɪnʒɝəs lænz ɪn ðə dɑɹk?"

"In the night, Aes Sedai?" Rhuarc said. "Is your journey so urgent that you would travel these dangerous lands in the dark?"

nɪneɪiv stʃɹʌɡəl vɪzəbli bɪfɔɹ seɪɪŋ, "noʊ." ɪn ə fɝmɝ toʊn ʃi æɾəd, "bʌɾ aɪ min tə liv wɪð ðə sʌnɹaɪz."

Nynaeve struggled visibly before saying, "No." In a firmer tone she added, "But I mean to leave with the sunrise."

ði il kæɹid ðə dɛɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə pælɪsɑd, bʌt niðɝ ɛɡwin nɔɹ əɹ kəmpænjənz wɑntəd tə juz ðə fɪlθi bɛɾ æɾən hæd slɛpt ɪn. ðeɪ pɪkt ʌp ðɛɹ ɹɪŋz ən slɛpt ʌndɝ ðə skaɪ ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks ən ðə blæŋkəts ði il ɡeɪv ðɛm.

The Aiel carried the dead outside the palisade, but neither Egwene nor her companions wanted to use the filthy bed Adden had slept in. They picked up their rings and slept under the sky in their cloaks and the blankets the Aiel gave them.

wən dɔn pɝl ðə skaɪ tə ði ist, ði il pɹədust ə bɹɛkfəst ə tʌf, dʒɹaɪd mit - ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊvɝ ðəɾ əntɪl eɪvinhə toʊld əɹ ɪt wɑz ɡoʊt - flætbɹɛd ðət wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz dɪfəkəl tə tʃu əz ðə stʃɹɪŋi mit, ən ə blu-veɪnd waɪt tʃiz ðət hæɾ ə tɑɹt teɪst ən wɑz hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪleɪn mɝmɝ ðət ði il mʌs pɹæktəs baɪ tʃuɪŋ ɹɑks. bʌt ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ eɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv təɡɛðɝ. ði il tɝn ðə hɔɹsəz lus - ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɹaɪɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ hæd tə, eɪvinhə ɪkspleɪnd, saʊndɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi hɝsɛlf wəɾ əz sun ɹʌn ɑn blɪstɝd fit - æftɝ tʃuzɪŋ aʊt ðə θɹi bɛs fəɹ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl tɔl ən nɪɹli əz bɪɡ əz wɔɹhɔɹsɪz, wɪð pɹaʊd nɛks ən fɪɹs aɪz. ə blæk stæljən fəɹ nɪneɪiv, ə ɹoʊn mɛɹ fəɹ ɪleɪn, ən ə ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ fəɹ ɛɡwin.

When dawn pearled the sky to the east, the Aiel produced a breakfast of tough, dried meat - Egwene hesitated over that until Aviendha told her it was goat - flatbread that was almost as difficult to chew as the stringy meat, and a blue-veined white cheese that had a tart taste and was hard enough to make Elayne murmur that the Aiel must practice by chewing rocks. But the Daughter-Heir ate as much as Egwene and Nynaeve together. The Aiel turned the horses loose - they did not ride unless they had to, Aviendha explained, sounding as if she herself would as soon run on blistered feet - after choosing out the three best for Egwene and the others. They were all tall and nearly as big as warhorses, with proud necks and fierce eyes. A black stallion for Nynaeve, a roan mare for Elayne, and a gray mare for Egwene.

ʃi tʃoʊz tə kɔl ðə ɡɹeɪ mɪst, ɪn ðə hoʊp ðəɾ ə dʒɛntəl neɪm maɪt suð hɝ, ən ɪndid, mɪs dɪd sim tə stɛp laɪtli əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd saʊθ, dʒʌst əz ðə sʌn lɪftəɾ ə ɹɛd ɹɪm əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən.

She chose to call the gray Mist, in the hope that a gentle name might soothe her, and indeed, Mist did seem to step lightly as they rode south, just as the sun lifted a red rim above the horizon.

ði il əkʌmpəniɾ əm əfʊt, ɔl ðoʊz u hæd sɝvaɪv ðə faɪt. θɹi mɔɹ hæd daɪɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðə tu ðə mɹdʒɹɑl kɪld. ðeɪ wɝ naɪntin, ɔltəɡɛðɝ, naʊ. ðeɪ loʊpt əlɔŋ izəli əlɔŋsaɪd ðə hɔɹsəz. ət fɝst, ɛɡwin tʃɹaɪd hoʊldɪŋ mɪs tə ə sloʊ wɔk, bʌt ði il θɔt ðɪs vɛɹi fʌni.

The Aiel accompanied them afoot, all those who had survived the fight. Three more had died aside from the two the Myrddraal killed. They were nineteen, altogether, now. They loped along easily alongside the horses. At first, Egwene tried holding Mist to a slow walk, but the Aiel thought this very funny.

"aɪ wɪl ɹeɪs jə tɛn maɪlz," eɪvinhə sɛd, "ænd wi ʃæl si hu wɪnz, jəɹ hɔɹs əɹ aɪ."

"I will race you ten miles," Aviendha said, "and we shall see who wins, your horse or I."

"aɪ wɪl ɹeɪs jə twɛnti!" ɹəɑɹk kɔld, læfɪŋ.

"I will race you twenty!" Rhuarc called, laughing.

ɛɡwin θɔt ðeɪ maɪɾ æktʃəli  bi sɪɹiəs, ən wən ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz lɛt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɔk əɾ ə kwɪkɝ peɪs, ði il sɝɾənli ʃoʊd noʊ saɪn ə fɔlɪŋ bæk.

Egwene thought they might actually be serious, and when she and the others let their horses walk at a quicker pace, the Aiel certainly showed no sign of falling back.

wən ðə θætʃt ɹuftɑps ə dʒʊɹin keɪm ɪn saɪt, ɹəɑɹk sɛd, "fɛɹ jə wɛl, ɛɛs sədaɪ. meɪ jə ɔlweɪz faɪnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd. pɝhæps wɪl miɾ əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃeɪnʒ kʌmz." hi saʊndəd ɡɹɪm. əz ði il kɝvd əweɪ tə ðə saʊθ, eɪvinhə ən kiæɾ ən beɪn itʃ ɹeɪzd ə hæn ɪn fɛɹwɛl. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə bi sloʊɪŋ daʊn naʊ ðət ðeɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹæn wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz; ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ðeɪ ɹæn ə lɪɾəl fæstɝ. ɛɡwin hæɾ ə səspɪʃən ðeɪ mɛn tə meɪnteɪn ðət peɪs əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt wɛɹɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ.

When the thatched rooftops of Jurene came in sight, Rhuarc said, "Fare you well, Aes Sedai. May you always find water and shade. Perhaps we will meet again before the change comes." He sounded grim. As the Aiel curved away to the south, Aviendha and Chiad and Bain each raised a hand in farewell. They did not seem to be slowing down now that they no longer ran with the horses; if anything, they ran a little faster. Egwene had a suspicion they meant to maintain that pace until they reached wherever it was they were going.

"wʌt dɪɾ i min baɪ ðæt?" ʃi æskt. " 'pɝhæps wɪl miɾ əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃeɪnʒ'?" ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

"What did he mean by that?" she asked. " 'Perhaps we will meet again before the change'?" Elayne shook her head.

"ɪt dʌz nɑt mæɾɝ wʌɾ i mɛnt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ æm dʒʌst əz ɡlæd ðeɪ keɪm læs naɪt, bʌɾ aɪm ɡlæd tə hæv əm ɡɔn, tu. aɪ hoʊp ðəɹ ɪz ə ʃɪp hɪɹ."

"It does not matter what he meant," Nynaeve said. "I am just as glad they came last night, but I am glad to have them gone, too. I hope there is a ship here."

dʒʊɹin ɪtsɛlf wɑz ə smɔl pleɪs, ɔl wʊɾən haʊsəz ən nʌn mɔɹ ðən ə sɪŋɡəl stɔɹi, bʌt ðə waɪt laɪən bænɝ ʌv ændɝ flu oʊvɝ ɪɾ ɑn ə tɔl stæf, ən fɪfti ʌv ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz hɛld ɪt, ɪn ɹɛd koʊts wɪð lɔŋ waɪt kɑlɝz bɪniθ ʃaɪnɪŋ bɹɛstpleɪts. ðeɪ hæd bɪn pleɪs ðɛɹ, ðɛɹ kæptən sɛd, tə meɪk ə seɪf heɪvən fəɹ ɹɛfjudʒiz u wɪʃt tə fli tə ændɝ, bʌt fjuɝ sətʃ keɪm ɛvɹi deɪ. moʊst wɛn tə vɪlədʒəz fɝðɝ daʊnɹɪvɝ, naʊ, nɪɹɝ ɑɹɪŋɡəl. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ðə θɹi wɪmən hæd kʌm wən ðeɪ dɪd, əz i ɪkspɛktəd tə ɹəsiv ɔɹɾɝz ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ɪz kʌmpəni tə ændɝ ɛni deɪ. ðə fju ɪnhæbəɾənts ə dʒʊɹin wəd laɪkli ɡoʊ wɪð ðɛm, livɪŋ wʌt ɹɪmeɪn fəɹ bɹɪɡænz ən ðə kɛɹhinɪn soʊlʒɝz ʌv wɔɹɪŋ haʊsəz.

Jurene itself was a small place, all wooden houses and none more than a single story, but the White Lion banner of Andor flew over it on a tall staff, and fifty of the Queen's Guards held it, in red coats with long white collars beneath shining breastplates. They had been placed there, their captain said, to make a safe haven for refugees who wished to flee to Andor, but fewer such came every day. Most went to villages further downriver, now, nearer Aringill. It was a good thing the three women had come when they did, as he expected to receive orders returning his company to Andor any day. The few inhabitants of Jurene would likely go with them, leaving what remained for brigands and the Cairhienin soldiers of warring Houses.

ɪleɪn kɛpt əɹ feɪs hɪɾən ɪn ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ stɝɾi wʊl kloʊk, bʌt nʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz sim tə əsoʊsieɪt ðə ɡɝl wɪð ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ wɪð ðɛɹ dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. səm æskt əɹ tə steɪ; ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ɪleɪn wɑz plizd əɹ ʃɑkt. ʃi hɝsɛlf toʊl ðə mɛn u æskt əɹ ðət ʃi hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ ðɛm. ɪt wɑz naɪs, ɪn ən ɑd weɪ, tə bi æskt; ʃi sɝɾənli hæd noʊ wɪʃ tə kɪs ɛni ʌv ðiz fɛloʊz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz plɛzən tə bi ɹimaɪndəd ðət səm mɛn, ət list, θɔt ʃi wɑz əz pɹɪɾi əz ɪleɪn. nɪneɪiv slæpt wʌn mænz feɪs. ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɛɡwin læf, ən ɪleɪn smaɪld oʊpənli; ɛɡwin θɔt nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn pɪntʃt, ən dɪspaɪt ðə ɡlɛɹ ɑn əɹ feɪs, ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ɪntaɪɝli dɪsplizd, iðɝ.

Elayne kept her face hidden in the hood of her sturdy wool cloak, but none of the soldiers seemed to associate the girl with red-gold hair with their Daughter-Heir. Some asked her to stay; Egwene was not sure whether Elayne was pleased or shocked. She herself told the men who asked her that she had no time for them. It was nice, in an odd way, to be asked; she certainly had no wish to kiss any of these fellows, but it was pleasant to be reminded that some men, at least, thought she was as pretty as Elayne. Nynaeve slapped one man's face. That almost made Egwene laugh, and Elayne smiled openly; Egwene thought Nynaeve had been pinched, and despite the glare on her face, she did not look entirely displeased, either.

ðeɪ wɝ nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹɪŋz. ɪt hæd nɑt teɪkən mʌtʃ ɛfɝɾ ɑn nɪneɪivz pɑɹt tə kənvɪns əm ðət wʌn pleɪs ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi teɪkən fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz tɛɹ, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ðə blæk ədʒɑ wɑz ðɛɹ. ɛɡwin hæd hɝz ɪn əɹ paʊtʃ wɪð ðə stoʊn tɛɹæŋɡɹil; ʃi tʌtʃt ɪɾ ɔfən tə ɹimaɪn hɝsɛlf ðeɪ wɝ stɪl ðɛɹ. nɪneɪiv wɔɹ hɝz ɑn ðə kɔɹd ðət hɛld lænz hɛvi ɹɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ bɹɛsts.

They were not wearing their rings. It had not taken much effort on Nynaeve's part to convince them that one place they did not want to be taken for Aes Sedai was Tear, especially if the Black Ajah was there. Egwene had hers in her pouch with the stone ter'angreal; she touched it often to remind herself they were still there. Nynaeve wore hers on the cord that held Lan's heavy ring between her breasts.

ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃɪp ɪn dʒʊɹin, taɪd tə ðə sɪŋɡəl stoʊn dɑk stɪkɪŋ ɪndə ði ɛɹɪnɪn. nɑt ðə ʃɪp eɪvinhə hæd sin, ɪt simd, bʌt stɪl ə ʃɪp. ɛɡwin wɑz dɪsmeɪd wən ʃi sɔ ɪt. twaɪs əz waɪɾ əz ðə blu kɹeɪn, ðə dɑɹɾɝ bɪlaɪɾ ɪts neɪm wɪð ə blʌf baʊ əz ɹaʊn əz ɪts kæptən.

There was a ship in Jurene, tied to the single stone dock sticking into the Erinin. Not the ship Aviendha had seen, it seemed, but still a ship. Egwene was dismayed when she saw it. Twice as wide as the Blue Crane, the Darter belied its name with a bluff bow as round as its captain.

ðət wɝði fɛloʊ blɪŋkt ət nɪneɪiv ən skɹætʃt ɪz ɪɹ wən ʃi æskt ɪf ɪz vɛsəl wɑz fæst. "fæst? aɪm fʊl ə fænsi wʊd fɹəm ʃaɪnɝ ən ɹʌɡz fɹəm kændɝ. wʌt nid tə bi fæst wɪð ə kɑɹɡoʊ laɪk ðæt? pɹaɪsəz oʊnli ɡoʊ ʌp. jɛs, aɪ səpoʊz ðəɹ ɑɹ fæstɝ ʃɪps bɪhaɪn mi, bʌt ðəl nɑt pʊɾ ɪn hɪɹ. aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv stɑp maɪsɛlf ɪf aɪ hædn faʊnd wɝmz ɪn ðə mit. ful noʊʃən ðət ðeɪɾ əv mit tə sɛl ɪn kɛɹhin. ðə blu kɹeɪn? aɪ, aɪ sɔ ɛlɪsɝ hʌŋ ʌp ɑn sʌmθɪŋ ʌpɹɪvɝ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. hɪl nɑt ɡɛɾ ɔf sun, aɪm θɪŋkɪŋ. ðæts wʌɾ ə fæst ʃɪp bɹɪŋz ju."

That worthy fellow blinked at Nynaeve and scratched his ear when she asked if his vessel was fast. "Fast? I am full of fancy wood from Shienar and rugs from Kandor. What need to be fast with a cargo like that? Prices only go up. Yes, I suppose there are faster ships behind me, but they'll not put in here. I would not have stopped myself if I hadn't found worms in the meat. Fool notion that they'd have meat to sell in Cairhien. The Blue Crane? Aye, I saw Ellisor hung up on something upriver this morning. He'll not get off soon, I'm thinking. That's what a fast ship brings you."

nɪnɑv peɪd ðɛɹ fɛɹz - ən twaɪs əz mʌtʃ əɡɛn fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz - wɪð sətʃ ə lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs ðət niðɝ ɛɡwin nɔɹ ɪleɪn spoʊk tə hɝ əntɪl lɔŋ æftɝ ðə dɑɹɾɝ hæd wɑloʊɾ əweɪ fɹəm dʒʊɹin.

Nynave paid their fares - and twice as much again for the horses - with such a look on her face that neither Egwene nor Elayne spoke to her until long after the Darter had wallowed away from Jurene.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾi


CHAPTER 40

eɪ hɪɹoʊ ɪn ðə naɪt


A Hero in the Night

linɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹeɪl, mæt wɑtʃt ðə wɔl taʊn ʌv ɑɹɪŋɡəl kʌm kloʊsɝ əz ðə swips wɝk ðə ɡɹeɪ ɡʌl ɪn təwɔɹd ðə lɔŋ, tɑɹd-tɪmbɝ dɑks. pɹətɛktəd baɪ haɪ stoʊn wɪŋ-wɔlz ðət θɹʌst aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðoʊz dɑks swɔɹmd wɪð pipəl, ən mɔɹ wɝ livɪŋ ðə ʃɪps ə vɛɹiəs saɪzəz ðət leɪ taɪɾ ɔl əlɔŋ ðɛm. səm ə ðə pipəl pʊʃt bæɹoʊz, əɹ pʊl slɛdʒɪz əɹ tɔl-wil kɑɹts, ɔl paɪl haɪ wɪð fɝnɪtʃɝ ən tʃɛsts læʃt ɪn pleɪs, bʌt moʊs kæɹid bʌndəlz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, ɪf ðæt. nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn bʌsəld. mɛni mɛn ən wɪmən hʌɾəld təɡɛðɝ ənsɝteɪnli, ən tʃɪlʒɹən klʌŋ kɹaɪɪŋ tə ðɛɹ lɛɡz. soʊlʒɝz ɪn ɹɛd koʊts ən ʃaɪni bɹɛstpleɪts kɛp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk əm muv ɔf ðə dɑks ɪndə ðə taʊn, bʌt moʊst sim tu fɹaɪɾənd tə muv.

Leaning on the rail, Mat watched the walled town of Aringill come closer as the sweeps worked the Gray Gull in toward the long, tarred-timber docks. Protected by high stone wing-walls that thrust out into the river, those docks swarmed with people, and more were leaving the ships of various sizes that lay tied all along them. Some of the people pushed barrows, or pulled sledges or tall-wheeled carts, all piled high with furniture and chests lashed in place, but most carried bundles on their backs, if that. Not everyone bustled. Many men and women huddled together uncertainly, and children clung crying to their legs. Soldiers in red coats and shiny breastplates kept trying to make them move off the docks into the town, but most seemed too frightened to move.

mæt tɝn ən ʃeɪɾɪd ɪz aɪz tə pɪɹ ət ðə ɹɪvɝ ðeɪ wɝ livɪŋ. ði ɛɹɪnɪn wɑz bɪziɝ hɪɹ ðən i hæd sin ɪt saʊθ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɪð nɪɹli ə dʌzən vɛsəlz ʌndɝ weɪ ɪn saɪt, ɹeɪnʒɪŋ fɹəm ə lɔŋ, ʃɑɹp-pɹaʊd splɪntɝ dɑɹɾɪŋ ʌpɹɪvɝ əɡɛns ðə kɝənt, pʊʃt baɪ tu tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ seɪlz, tə ə waɪd, blʌf-baʊd ʃɪp wɪð skwɛɹ seɪlz, stɪl wɑloʊɪŋ əlɔŋ wɛl tə ðə nɔɹθ.

Mat turned and shaded his eyes to peer at the river they were leaving. The Erinin was busier here than he had seen it south of Tar Valon, with nearly a dozen vessels under way in sight, ranging from a long, sharp-prowed splinter darting upriver against the current, pushed by two triangular sails, to a wide, bluff-bowed ship with square sails, still wallowing along well to the north.

nɪɹli hæf ðə ʃɪps i kəd si hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə ɹɪvɝ tʃɹeɪd, ðoʊ. tu bɹɔd-bim kɹæft wɪð ɛmpti dɛks wɝ lʌmbɝɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, təwɔɹɾ ə smɔlɝ taʊn ɑn ðə fɑɹ bæŋk, waɪl θɹi ʌðɝz leɪbɝd bæk təwɔɹɾ ɑɹɪŋɡəl, ðɛɹ dɛks pækt wɪð pipəl laɪk bæɹəlz ə fɪʃ. ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn, stɪl ɪts oʊn haɪɾ əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən, ʃæɾoʊd ə bænɝ flaɪɪŋ oʊvɝ ðəɾ ʌðɝ taʊn. ðət ʃɔɹ wɑz kɛɹhin, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt nid tə si ðə bænɝ tə noʊ ɪt wɑz ðə waɪt laɪən ʌv ændɝ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn tɔk ɪnʌf ɪn ðə fju ændɔɝən vɪlədʒəz wɛɹ ðə ɡɹeɪ ɡʌl hæd stɑp bɹifli.

Nearly half the ships he could see had nothing to do with the river trade, though. Two broad-beamed craft with empty decks were lumbering across the river, toward a smaller town on the far bank, while three others labored back toward Aringill, their decks packed with people like barrels of fish. The setting sun, still its own height above the horizon, shadowed a banner flying over that other town. That shore was Cairhien, but he did not need to see the banner to know it was the White Lion of Andor. There had been talk enough in the few Andoran villages where the Gray Gull had stopped briefly.

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. pɑlətɪks dɪd nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəs hɪm. əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ doʊn tʃɹaɪ tɛlɪŋ mi əɡɛn ɪm ən ændɔɝmən dʒʌs kəz ə səm mæp. bɝn mi, ðeɪ maɪɾ ivən tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk mi faɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ blʌɾi ɑɹmi, ɪf ðɪs kɛɹhin bɪznəs spɹɛdz. fɑloʊɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. laɪt! wɪð ə ʃɪvɝ, hi tɝn bæk tə ɑɹɪŋɡəl. bɛɹfʊt mɛn ɑn ðə ɡɹeɪ ɡʌl wɝ ɹɛɾiɪŋ ɹoʊps tə tɔs tə ʌðɝz ɑn ðə dɑks.

He shook his head. Politics did not interest him. As long as they don't try telling me again I'm an Andorman just because of some map. Burn me, they might even try to make me fight in their bloody army, if this Cairhien business spreads. Following orders. Light! With a shiver, he turned back to Aringill. Barefoot men on the Gray Gull were readying ropes to toss to others on the docks.

kæptən mɑliə wɑz aɪɪŋ ɪm fɹəm bæk baɪ ðə tɪlɝ. ðə fɛloʊ hæd nɛvɝ ɡɪvən ʌp ɪz ɛfɝts tə ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪt hɪmsɛlf wɪð ðɛm, hɪz ətɛmps tə lɝn wʌt ðɛɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt mɪʃən wɑz. mæt hæd faɪnəli ʃoʊn ɪm ðə sild lɛɾɝ ən toʊld ɪm ðəɾ i wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ɪt fɹəm ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tə ðə kwin. ə pɝsənəl mɛsədʒ fɹəm ə dɔɾɝ tə hɝ mʌðɝ; noʊ mɔɹ. mɑliə hæɾ oʊnli sim tə hɪɹ ðə wɝdz "kwin mɔɹɡeɪs."

Captain Mallia was eyeing him from back by the tiller. The fellow had never given up his efforts to ingratiate himself with them, his attempts to learn what their important mission was. Mat had finally shown him the sealed letter and told him that he was carrying it from the Daughter-Heir to the Queen. A personal message from a daughter to her mother; no more. Mallia had only seemed to hear the words "Queen Morgase."

mæt ɡɹɪn tə hɪmsɛlf. ə dip koʊt pɑkət hɛl tu pɝsɪz fæɾɝ ðən wən i hæd bɔɹɾəd ðə vɛsəl; hi hæɾ ɪnʌf lus kɔɪn tə mɔɹ ðən fɪl ənʌðɝ tu. hɪz lʌk hæd nɑt bɪn kwaɪt soʊ ɡʊɾ əz ɑn ðət fɝst, stʃɹeɪnʒ naɪt wən ðə daɪs ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls hæd sim tə ɡoʊ kɹeɪzi, bʌt stɪl ɪt wɑz ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf. æftɝ ðə θɝd naɪt, mɑliə hæd ɡɪvən ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃoʊ hɪz fɹɛnlinɪs baɪ ɡæmbəlɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪz mʌni tʃɛst wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi laɪɾɝ baɪ ðɛn. ɪt wəd bi laɪɾɝ stɪl æftɝ ɑɹɪŋɡəl. mɑliə hæd nid tə ɹistɑk ɪz fud - mæt ɡlænst ət ðə pipəl mɪlɪŋ ɑn ðə dɑks - ɪf i kʊd, hɪɹ, əɾ ɛni pɹaɪs.

Mat grinned to himself. A deep coat pocket held two purses fatter than when he had boarded the vessel; he had enough loose coin to more than fill another two. His luck had not been quite so good as on that first, strange night when the dice and everything else had seemed to go crazy, but still it was good enough. After the third night, Mallia had given up trying to show his friendliness by gambling, but his money chest was already lighter by then. It would be lighter still after Aringill. Mallia had need to restock his food - Mat glanced at the people milling on the docks - if he could, here, at any price.

ðə ɡɹɪn feɪɾəd əz ɪz θɔts wɛn bæk tə ðə lɛɾɝ. ə lɪɾəl wɝk wɪð ə hɑt naɪf bleɪd, ən ðə ɡoʊldən lɪli sil hæd bɪn lɪftəd. hi hæd faʊnd nʌθɪŋ: ɪleɪn wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ hɑɹɾ ən meɪkɪŋ pɹɑɡɹɛs ən iɡɝ tə lɝn. ʃi wɑz ə duɾifəl dɔɾɝ, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæd pʌnɪʃt əɹ fəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ ən toʊld əɹ nɛvɝ tə spik ʌv ɪɾ əɡɛn, soʊ hɝ mʌðɝ wəɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ mɔɹ. ʃi sɛd ʃi hæd bɪn ɹeɪz tə ði æksɛptɪd, ən wɑz ðət nɑt wʌndɝfəl, soʊ sun, ən ʃi wɑz biɪŋ tʃɹʌstɪd wɪð ɡɹeɪɾɝ duɾiz naʊ, ən wəɾ əv tə liv tɑɹ vəlɑn fəɹ dʒʌst ə ʃɔɹt taɪm ɑn ðə sɝvəs ə ði æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf. hɝ mʌðɝ wɑz nɑt tə wɝi.

The grin faded as his thoughts went back to the letter. A little work with a hot knife blade, and the golden lily seal had been lifted. He had found nothing: Elayne was studying hard and making progress and eager to learn. She was a dutiful daughter, and the Amyrlin Seat had punished her for running away and told her never to speak of it again, so her mother would understand why she could not say more. She said she had been raised to the Accepted, and was that not wonderful, so soon, and she was being trusted with greater duties now, and would have to leave Tar Valon for just a short time on the service of the Amyrlin herself. Her mother was not to worry.

ɪt wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl fəɹ əɹ tə tɛl mɔɹɡeɪs nɑt tə wɝi. ɪt wɑz ɪm ʃi hæd lændəɾ ɪn ðə sup kɛɾəl. ðɪs sɪli lɛɾɝ hæd tə bi ðə ɹizən ðoʊz mɛn hæd kʌm æftɝ hɪm, bʌɾ ivən tɑm hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk nʌθɪŋ ʌv ɪt, ðoʊ hi mʌɾɝd əbaʊt "sɪfɝz" ən "koʊdz" ən "ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz."

It was all very well for her to tell Morgase not to worry. It was him she had landed in the soup kettle. This silly letter had to be the reason those men had come after him, but even Thom had been able to make nothing of it, though he muttered about "ciphers" and "codes" and "the Game of Houses."

mæt hæd ðə lɛɾɝ seɪf ɪn ðə laɪnɪŋ ə hɪz koʊt, naʊ, ɪts sil ɹipleɪst, ən i wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə bɛt noʊ wʌn wəɾ ɛvɝ noʊ. ɪf sʌmwʌn wɑntəɾ ɪt bædli ɪnʌf tə kɪl ɪm fəɹ ɪt, ðeɪ maɪt tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn. aɪ toʊl jə aɪd dɪlɪvɝ ɪt, nɪneɪiv, ən aɪ blʌɾi wɪl, noʊ mæɾɝ u tʃɹaɪz tə stɑp mi. ivən soʊ, hi wəɾ əv wɝdz tə seɪ ðə nɛks taɪm i sɔ ðoʊz θɹi ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ wɪmən - ɪf aɪ ɛvɝ du. laɪt, aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ ə ðət - wɝdz i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ wəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ hɪɹɪŋ.

Mat had the letter safe in the lining of his coat, now, its seal replaced, and he was willing to bet no one would ever know. If someone wanted it badly enough to kill him for it, they might try again. I told you I'd deliver it, Nynaeve, and I bloody will, no matter who tries to stop me. Even so, he would have words to say the next time he saw those three irritating women - If I ever do. Light, I never thought of that - words he did not think they would enjoy hearing.

əz ðə kɹumɪn hɝl ðɛɹ laɪnz ɑntu ðə dɑk, tɑm keɪm ɑn dɛk, hɪz ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz ɑn ɪz bæk ən ɪz bʌndəl ɪn wʌn hænd. ivən wɪð ə lɪmp i stʃɹʌɾɪd tə ðə ɹeɪl, ɡɪvɪŋ ðə teɪl ə hɪz kloʊk lɪɾəl flɝɪʃəz tə meɪk ðə kʌlɝd pætʃəz flʌɾɝ, ən bloʊɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz lɔŋ, waɪt mʌstæʃɪz ɪmpɔɹɾəntli.

As the crewmen hurled their lines onto the dock, Thom came on deck, his instrument cases on his back and his bundle in one hand. Even with a limp he strutted to the rail, giving the tail of his cloak little flourishes to make the colored patches flutter, and blowing out his long, white mustaches importantly.

"noʊbɑdi ɪz wɑtʃɪŋ, tɑm," mæt sɛd. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ wəɾ ivən si ə ɡlimən ənlɛs i hæd fuɾ ɪn ɪz hænz."

"Nobody is watching, Thom," Mat said. "I don't think they would even see a gleeman unless he had food in his hands."

tɑm stɛɹɾ ət ðə dɑks. "laɪt! aɪ hæd hɝɾ ɪt wɑz bæd, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk ðɪs! pʊɹ fulz. hæf ə ðɛm lʊk əz ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ stɑɹvɪŋ. ɪt meɪ kɑst əs wʌn ə jəɹ pɝsɪz fəɹ ə ɹum tənaɪt. ən ði ʌðɝ fəɹ ə mil, ɪf jə ɪntɛn tə kip ɑn ðə weɪ juv bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ. nɪɹli meɪd mi ɪl tə wɑtʃ ju. jə tʃɹaɪ iɾɪŋ ðət weɪ wɛɹ ðoʊz pipəl daʊn ðəɹ kən si ju, ən jə meɪ hæv jəɹ bɹeɪnz bæɾɝd aʊt."

Thom stared at the docks. "Light! I had heard it was bad, but I did not expect this! Poor fools. Half of them look as if they are starving. It may cost us one of your purses for a room tonight. And the other for a meal, if you intend to keep on the way you've been going. Nearly made me ill to watch you. You try eating that way where those people down there can see you, and you may have your brains battered out."

mæt oʊnli smaɪld ət hɪm.

Mat only smiled at him.

mɑliə keɪm stʌmpɪŋ daʊn ðə dɛk, tʌɡɪŋ ðə pɔɪn ə hɪz bɪɹd, əz ðə ɡɹeɪ ɡʌl wɑz wɔɹpt ɪndə hɝ bɝθ. kɹumɪn ɹæn tə sɛɾ ə ɡæŋplæŋk, ən seɪnɝ stʊd ɡɑɹɾ ɑn ɪt, hɛvi ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst, ɪn keɪs ðə θɹɔŋ ɑn ðə dɑks tʃɹaɪd tə bɔɹd. nʌn ə ðɛm dɪd.

Mallia came stumping down the deck, tugging the point of his beard, as the Gray Gull was warped into her berth. Crewmen ran to set a gangplank, and Sanor stood guard on it, heavy arms folded across his chest, in case the throng on the docks tried to board. None of them did.

"soʊ jəl bi livɪŋ mi hɪɹ," mɑliə toʊl mæt. ðə kæptənz smaɪl wɑz nɑɾ əz ɹɛɾi əz ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ aɪ kən də tə hɛlp fɝðɝ? bɝn maɪ soʊl, aɪ nɛvɝ sɔ sətʃ ə ɹæbəl! ðoʊz soʊlʒɝz ɔt tə klɪɹ ðə dɑks - wɪð ðə sɔɹd, ɪf nid bi! - soʊ disən tʃɹeɪɾɝz kən də bɪznəs. pɝhæps seɪnɝ kən meɪk ə pæθ θɹu ðɪs skʌm tə jəɹ ɪn fəɹ ju."

"So you will be leaving me here," Mallia told Mat. The captain's smile was not as ready as it might have been. "Are you certain there is nothing I can do to help further? Burn my soul, I never saw such a rabble! Those soldiers ought to clear the docks - with the sword, if need be! - so decent traders can do business. Perhaps Sanor can make a path through this scum to your inn for you."

soʊ jəl noʊ wɛɹ wəɹ steɪɪŋ? nɑt blʌɾi laɪkli. "aɪ hæd θɔɾ ʌv iɾɪŋ bɪfɔɹ aɪ wɛn əʃɔɹ, ən meɪbi ə ɡeɪm ə daɪs tə pæs ðə taɪm." mɑliəz feɪs wɛnt waɪt. "bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk aɪ wəd laɪk ə stɛɾi flɔɹ ʌndɝ mi fəɹ maɪ nɛks mil. soʊ wɪl liv jə naʊ, kæptən. ɪts bɪn ən ɛndʒɔɪəbəl vɔɪədʒ."

So you'll know where we are staying? Not bloody likely. "I had thought of eating before I went ashore, and maybe a game of dice to pass the time." Mallia's face went white. "But I think I would like a steady floor under me for my next meal. So we will leave you now, Captain. It has been an enjoyable voyage."

waɪl ɹɪlif stɪl bæɾəld kɑnstɝneɪʃən ɑn ðə kæptənz feɪs, mæt pɪkt ʌp ɪz θɪŋz fɹəm ðə dɛk ænd, juzɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf əz ə wɔkɪŋ stɪk, meɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə ðə ɡæŋplæŋk wɪð tɑm. mɑliə fɑloʊɾ əz fɑɹ əz ðə hɛɾ ə ðə plæŋk, mɝmɝɪŋ ɹɪɡɹɛts ət ðɛɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ ðət dʒʌmp fɹəm ɹil tə ɪnsɪnsɪɹ ən bæk əɡɛn. mæt wɑz sɝɾən ðə mæn heɪɾəd luzɪŋ ə tʃæns tə ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪt hɪmsɛlf wɪð ɪz haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən baɪ lɝnɪŋ dɪteɪlz ʌv ə pæk bɪtwin ændɝ ən tɑɹ vəlɑn.

While relief still battled consternation on the captain's face, Mat picked up his things from the deck and, using the quarterstaff as a walking stick, made his way to the gangplank with Thom. Mallia followed as far as the head of the plank, murmuring regrets at their departure that jumped from real to insincere and back again. Mat was certain the man hated losing a chance to ingratiate himself with his High Lord Samon by learning details of a pact between Andor and Tar Valon.

əz mæt ən ðə ɡlimən pʊʃt θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz, tɑm mʌɾɝd, "aɪ noʊ ðə mæn ɪz fɑɹ fɹəm laɪkəbəl, bʌt waɪ juv tə kip tɔntɪŋ hɪm? wɑzn ɪɾ ɪnʌf ðət jə eɪɾ ɛvɹi skɹæp ʌv wʌɾ i θɔt wəd fiɾ ɪm ɔl ðə weɪ tə tɛɹ?"

As Mat and the gleeman pushed through the crowds, Thom muttered, "I know the man is far from likable, but why do you have to keep taunting him? Wasn't it enough that you ate every scrap of what he thought would feed him all the way to Tear?"

"aɪ hæv nɑt bɪn iɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɔl fəɹ nɪɹli tu deɪz." ðə hʌŋɡɝ hæd sɪmpli bɪn ɡɔn wʌn mɔɹnɪŋ, tə hɪz ɡɹeɪt ɹɪlif. ɪt hæd bɪn əz ɪf tɑɹ vəlɑn hæd lust ɪts læs hoʊld ɑn hɪm. "aɪv bɪn θɹoʊɪŋ moʊst ʌv ɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd, ən ə hɑɹd dʒɑb ɪt wɑz meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ noʊbɑdi sɔ." əmʌŋ ðiz dʒɹɔn feɪsəz, mɛni ʌv əm tʃɪlʒɹənz, ɪt dɪd nɑt sim soʊ fʌni ɛnimɔɹ. "mɑliə dɪzɝv tɔntɪŋ. wʌɾ əbaʊt ðət ʃɪp, jɛstɝdeɪ? ðə wʌn ðət wɑz stʌk ɑn ə mʌdbæŋk əɹ sʌmθɪŋ. hi cʊɾə stɑp tə hɛlp, bʌɾ i wəd nɑt ɡoʊ nɪɹ ɪt haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ðeɪ ʃaʊɾəd." ðəɹ wɑz ə wʊmən wɪð lɔŋ, dɑɹk hɛɹ əhɛɾ u maɪɾ əv bɪn pɹɪɾi ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt lʊk soʊ boʊn wɪɹi, piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə feɪs ʌv ɛvɹi mæn u pæst əɹ əz ɪf lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn; ə bɔɪ lɪɾəl tɔlɝ ðən əɹ weɪst ən tu ɡɝlz ʃɔɹɾɝ klʌŋ tə hɝ, ɔl kɹaɪɪŋ. "ɔl ðət tɔk əbaʊt ɹɪvɝ bɹɪɡænz ən tʃɹæps. ɪt dɪdn lʊk laɪk ɛni tʃɹæp tə mi."

"I have not been eating it all for nearly two days." The hunger had simply been gone one morning, to his great relief. It had been as if Tar Valon had loosed its last hold on him. "I've been throwing most of it over the side, and a hard job it was making sure nobody saw." Among these drawn faces, many of them children's, it did not seem so funny anymore. "Mallia deserved taunting. What about that ship, yesterday? The one that was stuck on a mudbank or something. He could have stopped to help, but he would not go near it however much they shouted." There was a woman with long, dark hair ahead who might have been pretty if she had not looked so bone weary, peering into the face of every man who passed her as if looking for someone; a boy little taller than her waist and two girls shorter clung to her, all crying. "All that talk about river brigands and traps. It didn't look like any trap to me."

tɑm dɑdʒd ɝaʊn ə haɪ-wil kɑɹt - ə keɪdʒ hoʊldɪŋ tu skwilɪŋ pɪɡz wɑz læʃt ətɑp ðə kænvəs-kʌvɝd maʊnd - ən nɪɹli tʃɹɪpt oʊvɝ ə slɛdʒ biɪŋ pʊld, baɪ ə mæn ən ə wʊmən. "æn jə ɡoʊ aʊɾ ə jəɹ weɪ tə hɛlp pipəl, də ju? stʃɹeɪnʒ haʊ ðəɾ əz ɪskeɪp maɪ aɪ."

Thom dodged around a high-wheeled cart - a cage holding two squealing pigs was lashed atop the canvas-covered mound - and nearly tripped over a sledge being pulled, by a man and a woman. "And you go out of your way to help people, do you? Strange how that has escaped my eye."

"aɪl hɛlp ɛniwʌn u kən peɪ," mæt sɛd fɝmli. "oʊnli fulz ɪn stɔɹiz də sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ nʌθɪŋ."

"I'll help anyone who can pay," Mat said firmly. "Only fools in stories do something for nothing."

ðə tu ɡɝlz sɑbd ɪndə ðɛɹ mʌðɝz skɝts waɪl ðə bɔɪ fɔɾ ɪz tɛɹz. ðə wʊmənz dip-sɛɾ aɪz ɹɛstəɾ ɑn mæt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, stʌɾiɪŋ ɪz feɪs, bɪfɔɹ dʒɹɪftɪŋ ɑn; ðeɪ lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd wip, tu. ɑn ɪmpəls i dʌɡ ə fɪsfəl ə lus kɔɪnz aʊɾ ə hɪz pɑkət wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ tə si wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ən pɹɛst əm ɪndə hɝ hænd. ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ə sɝpɹaɪz, stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ ɪn əɹ hænd wɪð ɪnkɑmpɹihɛnʃən ðət kwɪkli tɝn tə ə smaɪl, ən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, tɪɹz ʌv ɡɹæɾətud fɪlɪŋ əɹ aɪz.

The two girls sobbed into their mother's skirts while the boy fought his tears. The woman's deep-set eyes rested on Mat for a moment, studying his face, before drifting on; they looked as if she wished she could weep, too. On impulse he dug a fistful of loose coins out of his pocket without looking to see what they were and pressed them into her hand. She gave a start of surprise, stared at the gold and silver in her hand with incomprehension that quickly turned to a smile, and opened her mouth, tears of gratitude filling her eyes.

"baɪ ðɛm sʌmθɪŋ tə it," hi sɛd kwɪkli, ən hɝiɾ ɑn bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd spik. hi noʊɾəst tɑm lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡɔkɪŋ æt? kɔɪn kʌmz izəli əz lɔŋ əz aɪ kən faɪn sʌmbɑɾi hu laɪks tə daɪs." tɑm nɑɾəd sloʊli, bʌt mæt wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i hæd ɡɑɾən ɪz pɔɪn əkɹɔs. blʌɾi tʃɪlʒɹənz kɹaɪɪŋ wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn maɪ nɝvz, ðæts ɔl. ful ɡlimən wɪl pɹɑbli ɪkspɛk mi tə ɡɪv ɡoʊld əweɪ tə ɛvɹi weɪf ðət kʌmz əlɔŋ, naʊ. ful! fəɹ ən ənkʌmftəɹbəl moʊmənt, hi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən wɛðɝ ðə læs hæd bɪn mɛn fəɹ tɑm əɹ hɪmsɛlf.

"Buy them something to eat," he said quickly, and hurried on before she could speak. He noticed Thom looking at him. "What are you gawking at? Coin comes easily as long as I can find somebody who likes to dice." Thom nodded slowly, but Mat was not sure he had gotten his point across. Bloody children's crying was getting on my nerves, that's all. Fool gleeman will probably expect me to give gold away to every waif that comes along, now. Fool! For an uncomfortable moment, he was not certain whether the last had been meant for Thom or himself.

teɪkɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn hænd, hi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛni feɪs lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹɪli si ɪɾ əntɪl i faʊn ðə wʌn i wɑntəd, ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə dɑk. ðə hɛlmɔɪtləs soʊlʒɝ ɪn ɹɛd koʊɾ ən bɹɛstpleɪt, ɝdʒɪŋ pipəl ɪndə ðə taʊn, hæd ðə ɡɹɪzəld lʊk ʌv ə skwɑdmən, ən ɪkspɪɹiəns liɾɝ ə tɛn əɹ soʊ. skwɪntɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn, hi ɹimaɪndəd mæt ʌv ənoʊ, ðoʊ hi hæd boʊθ ɪz aɪz. hi lʊkt ɔlmoʊst əz taɪɝɾ əz ðə pipəl i wɑz tʃɪviɪŋ. "muv əlɔŋ," hi wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɪn ə hɔɹs vɔɪs. "ju kæn blʌɾi steɪ hɪɹ. muv əlɔŋ. ɪndə ðə taʊn wɪð ju."

Taking himself in hand, he avoided looking at any face long enough to really see it until he found the one he wanted, at the foot of the dock.
