The helmetless soldier in red coat and breastplate, urging people into the town, had the grizzled look of a squadman, an experienced leader of ten or so. Squinting into the setting sun, he reminded Mat of Uno, though he had both his eyes. He looked almost as tired as the people he was chivying. "Move along," he was shouting in a hoarse voice. "You can't bloody stay here. Move along. Into the town with you."

mæt steɪʃən hɪmsɛlf skwɛɹli ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝ ən pʊɾ ɑn ə smaɪl. "jɔɹ pɑɹɾən, kæptən, bʌt kən jə tɛl mi wɛɹ aɪ maɪt faɪn ə disən ɪn? ən ə steɪbəl wɪð ɡʊd hɔɹsəz tə sɛl. wɪv ə lɔŋ weɪ tə ɡoʊ, kʌm mɔɹnɪŋ."

Mat stationed himself squarely in front of the soldier and put on a smile. "Your pardon, Captain, but can you tell me where I might find a decent inn? And a stable with good horses to sell. We have a long way to go, come morning."

ðə soʊlʒɝ aɪɾ ɪm ʌp ən daʊn, ɪɡzæmən tɑm ən ɪz ɡlimənz kloʊk, ðən ʃɪftəd bæk tə mæt. "kæptən, ɪz ɪt? wɛl, bɔɪ, jəl əv ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn lʌk ɪf jə faɪn ə steɪbəl tə slip ɪn. moʊst ə ðɪs lɑɾ ɑɹ slipɪŋ ʌndɝ hɛdʒɪz. ən ɪf jə faɪn ə hɔɹs ðət hæzən bɪn slɔɾɝd fəɹ kʊkɪŋ, jəl laɪkli hæv tə faɪt ðə mæn u oʊnz ɪt tə meɪk ɪm sɛl."

The soldier eyed him up and down, examined Thom and his gleeman's cloak, then shifted back to Mat. "Captain, is it? Well, boy, you'll have the Dark One's own luck if you find a stable to sleep in. Most of this lot are sleeping under hedges. And if you find a horse that hasn't been slaughtered for cooking, you'll likely have to fight the man who owns it to make him sell."

"iɾɪŋ hɔɹs!" tɑm mʌɾɝd dɪsɡʌstɪdli. "hæz ɪt ɹɪli bɪkʌm ðət bæɾ ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ? ɪzən ðə kwin sɛndɪŋ fud?"

"Eating horse!" Thom muttered disgustedly. "Has it really become that bad on this side of the river? Isn't the Queen sending food?"

"ɪɾ ɪz bæd, ɡlimən." ðə soʊlʒɝ lʊkt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə spɪt. "ðeɪɹ kɹɔsɪŋ oʊvɝ fæstɝ ðən ðə mɪlz kən ɡɹaɪn flaʊɝ, əɹ wæɡənz kæɹi fudstʌfs fɹəm ðə fɑɹmz. wɛl, ɪɾəl nɑt læs mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ. ði ɔɹɾɝ əz kʌm daʊn. təmɑɹoʊ, wi stɑp lɛɾɪŋ ɛniwʌn əkɹɔs, ən ɪf ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ, wi sɛn əm bæk." hi skaʊld ət ðə pipəl mɪlɪŋ ɑn ðə dɑk əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɔl ðɛɹ fɔlt, ðən bɹɔt ðə seɪm hɑɹd lʊk tə bɛɹ ɑn mæt. "ju ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ ʌp speɪs, tʃɹævəlɝ. muv əlɔŋ." hɪz vɔɪs ɹoʊz tə ə ʃaʊɾ əɡɛn, dɝɛktəɾ əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɪðɪn hɪɹɪŋ. "muv əlɔŋ! jə kænɑt blʌɾi steɪ hɪɹ! muv əlɔŋ!"

"It is bad, gleeman." The soldier looked as if he wanted to spit. "They're crossing over faster than the mills can grind flour, or wagons carry foodstuffs from the farms. Well, it will not last much longer. The order has come down. Tomorrow, we stop letting anyone across, and if they try, we send them back." He scowled at the people milling on the dock as if it were all their fault, then brought the same hard look to bear on Mat. "You are taking up space, traveler. Move along." His voice rose to a shout again, directed at everyone within hearing. "Move along! You cannot bloody stay here! Move along!"

mæt ən tɑm dʒɔɪn ðə θɪn stʃɹim ə pipəl, kɑɹts, ən slɛdʒɪz floʊɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪts ɪn ðə taʊn wɔl, ən ɪndə ɑɹɪŋɡəl.

Mat and Thom joined the thin stream of people, carts, and sledges flowing toward the gates in the town wall, and into Aringill.

ðə meɪn stʃɹits wɝ peɪvd wɪð flæt ɡɹeɪ stoʊnz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ kɹaʊɾəd wɪð soʊ mɛni pipəl ðəɾ ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə si ðə stoʊnz ʌndɝ jəɹ oʊn buts. moʊst əpɪɹd tə bi muvɪŋ eɪmləsli, wɪð noʊwɛɹ tə ɡoʊ, ən ðoʊz u hæd ɡɪvən ʌp skwɑɾɪd dɪdʒɛktɪdli əlɔŋ ðə saɪdz ə ðə stʃɹit, ðə lʌki wʌnz wɪð bʌndəl bɪlɔŋɪŋz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm əɹ səm tʃɛɹɪʃt pəzɛʃən klʌtʃt ɪn ðɛɹ ɑɹmz. mæt sɔ θɹi mɛn hoʊldɪŋ klɑks, ən ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ wɪð sɪlvɝ ɡoʊbləts əɹ plæɾɝz. ðə wɪmən hɛl tʃɪlʒɹən tə ðɛɹ bɹɛsts, meɪnli. ə bæbəl fɪl ði ɛɹ, ə loʊ, wɝdləs hʌm ʌv wɝi. hi pʊʃt θɹu ðə kɹaʊd wɪð ə fɹaʊn ɑn ɪz feɪs, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə saɪn ðət wəd mɑɹk ən ɪn. ðə bɪldɪŋz wɝ ɛvɹi sɔɹt, wʊɾ ən bɹɪk ən stoʊn ɔl tʃik baɪ dʒaʊl, wɪð ɹufs ə taɪl, əɹ sleɪt, əɹ θætʃ.

The main streets were paved with flat gray stones, but they were crowded with so many people that it was difficult to see the stones under your own boots. Most appeared to be moving aimlessly, with nowhere to go, and those who had given up squatted dejectedly along the sides of the street, the lucky ones with bundled belongings in front of them or some cherished possession clutched in their arms. Mat saw three men holding clocks, and a dozen or more with silver goblets or platters. The women held children to their breasts, mainly. A babble filled the air, a low, wordless hum of worry. He pushed through the crowd with a frown on his face, searching for the sign that would mark an inn. The buildings were every sort, wood and brick and stone all cheek by jowl, with roofs of tile, or slate, or thatch.

"ɪt dʌz nɑt saʊn laɪk mɔɹɡeɪs," tɑm sɛɾ æftɝ ə taɪm, hæf tə hɪmsɛlf. hɪz bʊʃi aɪbɹaʊz wɝ pʊl daʊn laɪk ə waɪɾ æɹoʊ pɔɪntɪŋ tə hɪz noʊz.

"It does not sound like Morgase," Thom said after a time, half to himself. His bushy eyebrows were pulled down like a white arrow pointing to his nose.

"wʌt dʌz nɑt saʊn laɪk hɝ?" mæt æskt æbsənli.

"What does not sound like her?" Mat asked absently.

"stɑpɪŋ ðə kɹɔsɪŋz. sɛndɪŋ pipəl bæk. ʃi ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə tɛmpɝ laɪk laɪtnɪŋ, bʌt ʃi ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə sɑf hɑɹt, tu, fəɹ ɛniwʌn pʊɹ əɹ hʌŋɡɹi." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"Stopping the crossings. Sending people back. She always had a temper like lightning, but she always had a soft heart, too, for anyone poor or hungry." He shook his head.

mæt sɔ ə saɪn, ðən - ðə ɹɪvɝmən, ɪt sɛd, ən ʃoʊɾ ə bɛɹfʊt, ʃɝtləs fɛloʊ duɪŋ ə dʒɪɡ - ən tɝn ðət weɪ, fɔɹsɪŋ ən æŋɡəl əkɹɔs ðə floʊ wɪð ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf. "wɛl, ɪt hæd tə bi hɝ. hu ɛls kəɾ ɪt bi? fɝɡɛt mɔɹɡeɪs, tɑm. wiv ə lɔŋ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn, jɛt. fɝs lɛɾ əs si haʊ mʌtʃ ɡoʊld ɪt teɪks tə baɪ ə bɛd fəɹ ðə naɪt."

Mat saw a sign, then - The Riverman, it said, and showed a barefoot, shirtless fellow doing a jig - and turned that way, forcing an angle across the flow with the quarterstaff. "Well, it had to be her. Who else could it be? Forget Morgase, Thom. We've a long way to Caemlyn, yet. First let us see how much gold it takes to buy a bed for the night."

ðə kɑmən ɹum ə ðə ɹɪvɝmən lʊkt əz kɹaʊɾəd əz ðə stʃɹiɾ aʊtsaɪd, ən wən ði ɪnkipɝ hɝd wʌt mæt wɑntəd, hi læf tɪl ɪz tʃɪnz ʃʊk. "aɪ æm slipɪŋ fɔɹ tə ə bɛd, naʊ. ɪf maɪ oʊn mʌðɝ keɪm tə mi, aɪ kəd nɑt ɡɪv əɹ ə blæŋkət baɪ ðə faɪɝ."

The common room of The Riverman looked as crowded as the street outside, and when the innkeeper heard what Mat wanted, he laughed till his chins shook. "I am sleeping four to a bed, now. If my own mother came to me, I could not give her a blanket by the fire."

"æz jə mʌst əv noʊɾəst," tɑm sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs teɪkɪŋ ɑn ðəɾ ɛkoʊɪŋ kwɑləɾi, "aɪ æm ə ɡlimən. ʃʊɹli jə kən faɪn ət lis pæləts ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ mi ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ jəɹ peɪtʃɹənz wɪð stɔɹiz ən dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, iɾɪŋ ə faɪɝ, ən slaɪɾ ə hænd." ði ɪnkipɝ læft ɪn ɪz feɪs.

"As you must have noticed," Thom said, his voice taking on that echoing quality, "I am a gleeman. Surely you can find at least pallets in a corner in return for me entertaining your patrons with stories and juggling, eating of fire, and sleight of hand." The innkeeper laughed in his face.

əz mæt pʊld ɪm bæk ɪndə ðə stʃɹit, tɑm ɡɹaʊld ɪn ɪz nɔɹməl vɔɪs, "ju nɛvɝ ɡeɪv mi ə tʃæns tə æsk æftɝ ɪz steɪbəl. ʃʊɹli aɪ cʊɾə ɡɑɾən əs ə pleɪs ɪn ðə heɪlɔft, ət list."

As Mat pulled him back into the street, Thom growled in his normal voice, "You never gave me a chance to ask after his stable. Surely I could have gotten us a place in the hayloft, at least."

"aɪ hæv slɛpt ɪn ɪnʌf steɪbəlz ən bɑɹnz sɪns livɪŋ ɛmənz fild," mæt toʊl hɪm, "æn ʌndɝ ɪnʌf bʊʃəz, tu. aɪ wɑn ə bɛd."

"I have slept in enough stables and barns since leaving Emond's Field," Mat told him, "and under enough bushes, too. I want a bed."

bʌɾ ət ðə nɛks fɔɹ ɪnz i faʊnd, ði ɪnkipɝ ɡeɪv ɪm ðə seɪm ænsɝ əz ðə fɝst; ðə læs tu ɔlmoʊs θɹu hɪm aʊt bɑɾəli wən i ɔfɝd tə daɪs fəɹ ə bɛd. ən wən ði oʊnɝ ə ðə fɪfθ toʊld ɪm i kəd nɑt ɡɪv ə pælət tə ðə kwin hɝsɛlf - ðɪs əɾ ə pleɪs kɔl ðə ɡʊd kwin - hi saɪɾ ən æskt, "wʌɾ əbaʊt jəɹ steɪbəl, ðɛn? ʃʊɹli wi kən bɛd daʊn ɪn ðə heɪlɔft fəɹ ə pɹaɪs."

But at the next four inns he found, the innkeeper gave him the same answer as the first; the last two almost threw him out bodily when he offered to dice for a bed. And when the owner of the fifth told him he could not give a pallet to the Queen herself - this at a place called The Good Queen - he sighed and asked, "What about your stable, then? Surely we can bed down in the hayloft for a price."

"maɪ steɪbəl ɪz fəɹ hɔɹsəz," ðə ɹaʊnd-feɪs mæn sɛd, "nɑt ðət mɛni ɑɹ lɛft ɪn ðə sɪɾi." hi hæd bɪn pɑlɪʃɪŋ ə sɪlvɝ kʌp; naʊ hi oʊpənd wʌn dɔɹ ʌv ə ʃæloʊ kʌbɝd stændɪŋ ɑn tɑp ʌv ə dip, dʒɹɔɝd tʃɛst ən pleɪst ɪɾ ɪnsaɪd wɪð ʌðɝz; nʌn ə ðɛm mætʃt. ə tuld-lɛðɝ daɪs kʌp sæɾ ətɑp ðə tʃɛst, dʒʌs bɪɑn ði ɑɹk ə ðə kʌbɝdz dɔɹz. "aɪ də nɑt pʊt pipəl ɪn ðəɹ tə fɹaɪɾən ðə hɔɹsəz, ən pɝhæps meɪk ɔf wɪð ðɛm. ðoʊz u peɪ mi fəɹ stɑbəlɪŋ ðɛɹ ænəməlz wɑn əm wɛl tɛndəd, ən aɪv tu ʌv maɪ oʊn ɪn ðɛɹ, bɪsaɪdz. ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ bɛdz ɪn maɪ steɪbəl fəɹ ju."

"My stable is for horses," the round-faced man said, "not that many are left in the city." He had been polishing a silver cup; now he opened one door of a shallow cupboard standing on top of a deep, drawered chest and placed it inside with others; none of them matched. A tooled-leather dice cup sat atop the chest, just beyond the arc of the cupboard's doors. "I do not put people in there to frighten the horses, and perhaps make off with them. Those who pay me for stabling their animals want them well tended, and I've two of my own in there, besides. There are no beds in my stable for you."

mæt aɪd ðə daɪs kʌp θɔtfəli. hi pʊld ə ɡoʊld ændɔɝən kɹaʊn aʊɾ ə hɪz pɑkəɾ ən sɛɾ ɪɾ ətɑp ðə tʃɛst. ðə nɛks kɔɪn wɑz ə sɪlvɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn mɑɹk, ðən ə ɡoʊld wʌn, ən ə ɡoʊl tɛɹən kɹaʊn. ði ɪnkipɝ lʊkt ət ðə kɔɪnz ən lɪkt ɪz plʌmp lɪps. mæt æɾəd tu sɪlvɝ ɪliɑnɝ mɑɹks ən ənʌðɝ ɡoʊld ændɔɝən kɹaʊn, ən lʊkt ət ðə ɹaʊnd-feɪs mæn. ði ɪnkipɝ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. mæt ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə kɔɪnz. ði ɪnkipɝz hæn ɹitʃt əm fɝst.

Mat eyed the dice cup thoughtfully. He pulled a gold Andoran crown out of his pocket and set it atop the chest. The next coin was a silver Tar Valon mark, then a gold one, and a gold Tairen crown. The innkeeper looked at the coins and licked his plump lips. Mat added two silver Illianer marks and another gold Andoran crown, and looked at the round-faced man. The innkeeper hesitated. Mat reached for the coins. The innkeeper's hand reached them first.

"pɝhæps dʒʌs ðə tu ʌv jə wəd nɑt dɪstɝb ðə hɔɹsəz tu ɡɹeɪtli."

"Perhaps just the two of you would not disturb the horses too greatly."

mæt smaɪld ət hɪm. "spikɪŋ ə hɔɹsəz, wʌt pɹaɪs fəɹ ðoʊz tu ʌv jʊɹz? wɪð sæɾəlz ən bɹaɪɾəlz, ʌv kɔɹs."

Mat smiled at him. "Speaking of horses, what price for those two of yours? With saddles and bridles, of course."

"aɪ wɪl nɑt sɛl maɪ hɔɹsəz," ðə mæn sɛd, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə kɔɪnz tə hɪz tʃɛst.

"I will not sell my horses," the man said, clutching the coins to his chest.

mæt pɪkt ʌp ðə daɪs kʌp ən ɹæɾəld ɪt. "twaɪs əz mʌtʃ əɡɛn əɡɛns ðə hɔɹsəz, sæɾəlz, ən bɹaɪɾəlz." hi ʃʊk ɪz koʊt pɑkət tə meɪk ðə lus kɔɪnz ɹæɾəl, tu, tə ʃoʊ hi hæd mɔɹ tə kʌvɝ ðə weɪdʒɝ. "maɪ wʌn tɔs əɡɛns ðə bɛst ə jəɹ tu." hi ɔlmoʊs læft əz ɡɹid lɪt ði ɪnkipɝz ɪntaɪɝ feɪs.

Mat picked up the dice cup and rattled it. "Twice as much again against the horses, saddles, and bridles." He shook his coat pocket to make the loose coins rattle, too, to show he had more to cover the wager. "My one toss against the best of your two." He almost laughed as greed lit the innkeeper's entire face.

wən mæt wɔkt ɪndə ðə steɪbəl, ðə fɝs θɪŋ i dɪd wɑz tʃɛk əlɔŋ ðə hæf-dʌzən stɔlz wɪð hɔɹsəz ɪn əm fəɹ ə pɛɹ ə bɹaʊn ɡɛldɪŋz. ðeɪ wɝ nɑndɪskɹɪpt ænəməlz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ hɪz. ðeɪ niɾəd kʌɝiɪŋ bædli, bʌɾ ʌðɝwaɪz ðeɪ simd ɪn ɡʊd kəndɪʃən, ɪspɛʃli kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðəɾ ɔl ðə steɪbəlmən bʌt wʌn hæd ɹʌn ɔf. ði ɪnkipɝ hæd bɪn ɪkstʃɹimli dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋ ə ðɛɹ kəmpleɪns ðət ðeɪ kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lɪv ɑn wʌɾ i peɪd ðɛm, ən i sim tə θɪŋk ɪɾ ə kɹaɪm ðət ðə wʌn mæn u ɹɪmeɪn hæɾ æktʃəli  hæd ði ɑdæsəɾi tə seɪ hi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ hoʊm tə bɛd dʒʌs kəz i wɑz taɪɝd fɹəm duɪŋ θɹi mɛnz wɝk.

When Mat walked into the stable, the first thing he did was check along the half-dozen stalls with horses in them for a pair of brown geldings. They were nondescript animals, but they were his. They needed currying badly, but otherwise they seemed in good condition, especially considering that all the stablemen but one had run off. The innkeeper had been extremely disparaging of their complaints that they could no longer live on what he paid them, and he seemed to think it a crime that the one man who remained had actually had the audacity to say he was going home to bed just because he was tired from doing three men's work.

"faɪv sɪksɪz," tɑm mʌɾɝd bɪhaɪn hɪm. ðə lʊks i kæst ɝaʊn ðə steɪbəl dɪd nɑt sim əz ɛnθɹɔld əz ðeɪ maɪt, siɪŋ ðəɾ i hæd sədʒɛstəɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. dʌs moʊts ʃoʊn ɪn ðə læs laɪɾ ə ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn kʌmɪŋ θɹu ðə bɪɡ dɔɹz, ən ðə ɹoʊps juz tə hɔɪs heɪ beɪlz hʌŋ laɪk vaɪnz fɹəm pʊliz ɪn ðə ɹuf bimz. ðə heɪlɔft wɑz dɪm ɪn ðə ɡlum əbʌv. "wɛn i θɹu fɔɹ sɪksɪz ən ə faɪv ɑn ɪz sɛkən tɔs, hi θɔt jud lɔs fəɹ ʃʊɹ, ən soʊ dɪɾ aɪ. juv nɑt bɪn wɪnɪŋ ɛvɹi tɔs ə leɪt."

"Five sixes," Thom muttered behind him. The looks he cast around the stable did not seem as enthralled as they might, seeing that he had suggested it in the first place. Dust motes shone in the last light of the setting sun coming through the big doors, and the ropes used to hoist hay bales hung like vines from pulleys in the roof beams. The hayloft was dim in the gloom above. "When he threw four sixes and a five on his second toss, he thought you'd lost for sure, and so did I. You have not been winning every toss of late."

"aɪ wɪn ɪnʌf." mæt wɑz dʒʌst əz ɹɪliv nɑt tə bi wɪnɪŋ ɛvɹi θɹoʊ. lʌk wɑz wʌn θɪŋ, bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðət naɪt stɪl sɛnt ʃɪvɝz daʊn ɪz bæk. stɪl, fəɹ wʌn moʊmən əz i ʃʊk ðət daɪs kʌp, hi hæɾ ɔl bʌt noʊn wʌt ðə pɪps wəd bi. əz i tɔs ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf ʌp ɪndə ðə lɔft, θʌndɝ kɹæʃt ɪn ðə skaɪ. hi skɹæmbəld ʌp ðə læɾɝ, kɔlɪŋ bæk tə tɑm. "ðɪs wɑz ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə. aɪd θɪŋk jə wəd bi hæpi tə bi ɪn aʊɾ ə ðə ɹeɪn tənaɪt."

"I win enough." Mat was just as relieved not to be winning every throw. Luck was one thing, but remembering that night still sent shivers down his back. Still, for one moment as he shook that dice cup, he had all but known what the pips would be. As he tossed the quarterstaff up into the loft, thunder crashed in the sky. He scrambled up the ladder, calling back to Thom. "This was a good idea. I'd think you would be happy to be in out of the rain tonight."

moʊst ə ðə heɪ wɑz ɪn beɪlz stækt əɡɛns ði aʊɾɝ wɔlz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf lus fəɹ ɪm tə meɪk ə bɛd wɪð ɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ɪt. tɑm əpɪɹɾ ət ðə tɑp ə ðə læɾɝ əz i wɑz pʊlɪŋ tu loʊvz ə bɹɛɾ ən ə wɛdʒ ʌv ɡɹin-veɪn tʃiz fɹəm ɪz lɛðɝ skɹɪp. ði ɪnkipɝ - hɪz neɪm wɑz dʒɛɹəl flɔɹi - hæd pɑɹɾəd wɪð ðə fud fəɹ mɪɹli ɪnʌf kɔɪn tə hæv bɑt wʌn ə ðoʊz hɔɹsəz ɪn mɔɹ pisfəl deɪz. ðeɪ eɪt waɪl ɹeɪn bɪɡæn dʒɹʌmɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹuf, wɑʃɪŋ ðə fud daʊn wɪð wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðɛɹ wɔɾɝbətəlz - flɔɹi hæd hæd noʊ waɪn əɾ ɛni pɹaɪs - ən wən ðeɪ wɝ dʌn, tɑm dʌɡ aʊɾ ɪz tɪndɝbɑks ən θʌmd ɪz lɔŋ-stɛm paɪp fʊl ə təbæk ən sɛɾəld bæk fəɹ ə smoʊk.

Most of the hay was in bales stacked against the outer walls, but there was more than enough loose for him to make a bed with his cloak over it. Thom appeared at the top of the ladder as he was pulling two loaves of bread and a wedge of green-veined cheese from his leather scrip. The innkeeper - his name was Jeral Florry - had parted with the food for merely enough coin to have bought one of those horses in more peaceful days. They ate while rain began drumming on the roof, washing the food down with water from their waterbottles - Florry had had no wine at any price - and when they were done, Thom dug out his tinderbox and thumbed his long-stemmed pipe full of tabac and settled back for a smoke.

mæt wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz bæk, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ʃæɾoʊd ɹuf ən wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðə ɹeɪn wəd bɹeɪk bɪfɔɹ mɔɹnɪŋ - hi wɑntəd ðət lɛɾɝ aʊɾ ə hɪz hænz əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl - wən i hɝɾ ən æksəl kɹik ɪndə ðə steɪbəl. ɹoʊlɪŋ tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə lɔft, hi pɪɹd daʊn. ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf dʌsk lɛft fəɹ ɪm tə si.

Mat was lying on his back, staring at the shadowed roof and wondering if the rain would break before morning - he wanted that letter out of his hands as quickly as possible - when he heard an axle creak into the stable. Rolling to the edge of the loft, he peered down. There was enough dusk left for him to see.

ə slɛndɝ wʊmən wɑz stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ fɹəm ðə ʃæfs ə ðə haɪ-wil kɑɹt ʃi hæd dʒʌs dʒɹæɡd ɪn aʊɾ ə ðə ɹeɪn, pʊlɪŋ ɔf əɹ kloʊk ən mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf əz ʃi ʃʊk ðə wɛt fɹəm ɪt. hɝ hɛɹ wɑz pleɪɾəd ɪn ə mʌltətuɾ ə smɔl bɹeɪdz, ən əɹ sɪlk dʒɹɛs - hi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ə peɪl ɡɹin - wɑz ɪlæbɹətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd əkɹɔs əɹ bɹɛsts. ðə dʒɹɛs hæd bɪn faɪn, wʌns, bʌt naʊ ɪt wɑz tæɾɝd ən steɪnd. ʃi nʌkəld əɹ bæk, stɪl tɔkɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs, ən hɝid tə ðə steɪbəl dɔɹz tə pɪɹ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹeɪn. dʒʌst əz hɝidli, ʃi dʌkt aʊt tə pʊl ðə bɪɡ dɔɹz ʃʌt, ɛnkloʊzɪŋ ðə steɪbəl ɪn dɑɹknəs. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹʌslɪŋ bɪloʊ, ə klɪŋk ən ə slɑʃ, ən sʌɾənli ə smɔl flɛɹ ə laɪt blumd ɪndə ə læntɝn ɪn əɹ hænz. ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊnd, faʊn ə hʊk ɑn ə stɔl poʊst, hʌŋ ðə læntɝn, ən wɛn tə dɪɡ ʌndɝ ðə ɹoʊp kænvəs kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ kɑɹt.

A slender woman was straightening from the shafts of the high-wheeled cart she had just dragged in out of the rain, pulling off her cloak and muttering to herself as she shook the wet from it. Her hair was plaited in a multitude of small braids, and her silk dress - he thought it was a pale green - was elaborately embroidered across her breasts. The dress had been fine, once, but now it was tattered and stained. She knuckled her back, still talking to herself in a low voice, and hurried to the stable doors to peer out into the rain. Just as hurriedly, she ducked out to pull the big doors shut, enclosing the stable in darkness. There was a rustling below, a clink and a slosh, and suddenly a small flare of light bloomed into a lantern in her hands. She looked around, found a hook on a stall post, hung the lantern, and went to dig under the roped canvas covering her cart.

"ʃi dɪd ðət kwɪkli," tɑm sɛd sɔfli ɝaʊn ɪz paɪp. "ʃi cʊɾə sɛt faɪɝ tə ðə steɪbəl stʃɹaɪkɪŋ flɪn ən stil ɪn ðə dɑɹk laɪk ðæt."

"She did that quickly," Thom said softly around his pipe. "She could have set fire to the stable striking flint and steel in the dark like that."

ðə wʊmən keɪm aʊt wɪð ði ɛn ʌv ə loʊf ə bɹɛd, wɪtʃ ʃi nɔɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ hɑɹɾ ən əɹ hʌŋɡɝ dɪd nɑt kɛɹ.

The woman came out with the end of a loaf of bread, which she gnawed as if it were hard and her hunger did not care.

"ɪz ðəɹ ɛni ʌv ðət tʃiz lɛft?" mæt wɪspɝd. tɑm ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"Is there any of that cheese left?" Mat whispered. Thom shook his head.

ðə wʊmən bɪɡæn snɪfɪŋ ət ði ɛɹ, ən mæt ɹilaɪzd ʃi pɹɑbli smɛl tɑmz təbæk smoʊk. hi wɑz əbaʊt tə stæn ən ənaʊns ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns wən wʌn ə ðə steɪbəl dɔɹz oʊpən əɡɛn.

The woman began sniffing at the air, and Mat realized she probably smelled Thom's tabac smoke. He was about to stand and announce their presence when one of the stable doors opened again.

ðə wʊmən kɹaʊtʃt, ɹɛɾi tə ɹʌn, əz fɔɹ mɛn wɔkt ɪn aʊɾ ə ðə ɹeɪn, dɔfɪŋ ðɛɹ wɛt kloʊks tə ɹɪvil peɪl koʊts wɪð waɪd slivz ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst, ən bæɡi bɹitʃɪz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd daʊn ðə lɛɡz. ðɛɹ kloʊðz maɪt bi fænsi, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɔl bɪɡ mɛn, ən ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ ɡɹɪm.

The woman crouched, ready to run, as four men walked in out of the rain, doffing their wet cloaks to reveal pale coats with wide sleeves and embroidery across the chest, and baggy breeches embroidered down the legs. Their clothes might be fancy, but they were all big men, and their faces were grim.

"soʊ, ɑlʌdʒɹə," ə mæn ɪn ə jɛloʊ koʊt sɛd, "ju dɪd nɑt ɹʌn soʊ fæst əz jə θɔt tə, ɛ?" hi hæɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ æksɛnt, tə mæts ɪɹ.

"So, Aludra," a man in a yellow coat said, "you did not run so fast as you thought to, eh?" He had a strange accent, to Mat's ear.

"tɑmuz," ðə wʊmən sɛɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə kɝs. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑɾ ɪnʌf ðət jə kɑz mi tə bi kæst aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɪld wɪð jəɹ blʌndɝɪŋ, jə ɡɹeɪɾ ɑks-bɹeɪn ju, bʌt naʊ jə tʃeɪs æftɝ mi əz wɛl." ʃi hæd ðə seɪm ɑd weɪ ʌv spikɪŋ əz ðə mæn. "du jə θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪm ɡlæd tə si ju?"

"Tammuz," the woman said as if it were a curse. "It is not enough that you cause me to be cast out of the Guild with your blundering, you great ox-brain you, but now you chase after me as well." She had the same odd way of speaking as the man. "Do you think that I am glad to see you?"

ðə wʌn kɔl tɑmuz læft. "ju ɑɹ ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ ful, ɑlʌdʒɹə, wɪtʃ aɪ ɔlweɪz nu. hæd jə mɪɹli ɡɔn əweɪ, jə cʊɾə lɪvd ə lɔŋ laɪf ɪn səm kwaɪət pleɪs. bʌt jə kəd nɑt fɝɡɛt ðə sikɹəts ɪn jəɹ hɛd, ɛ? dɪd jə bɪliv wi wəd nɑt hɪɹ ðət jə tʃɹaɪ tə ɝn jəɹ weɪ meɪkɪŋ wʌɾ ɪts ðə ɹaɪɾ ə ðə ɡɪld əloʊn tə meɪk?" sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɑz ə naɪf ɪn ɪz hænd. "ɪt wɪl bi ə ɡɹeɪt plɛʒɝ tə kʌt jəɹ θɹoʊt, ɑlʌdʒɹə."

The one called Tammuz laughed. "You are a very large fool, Aludra, which I always knew. Had you merely gone away, you could have lived a long life in some quiet place. But you could not forget the secrets in your head, eh? Did you believe we would not hear that you try to earn your way making what it is the right of the Guild alone to make?" Suddenly there was a knife in his hand. "It will be a great pleasure to cut your throat, Aludra."

mæt wɑz nɑɾ ivən əwɛɹ ðəɾ i hæd stʊɾ ʌp əntɪl wʌn ə ðə dʌbəld ɹoʊps dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ðə silɪŋ wɑz ɪn ɪz hænz ən i hæd lɔntʃt hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə lɔft. bɝn mi fəɹ ə blʌɾi ful!

Mat was not even aware that he had stood up until one of the doubled ropes dangling from the ceiling was in his hands and he had launched himself out of the loft. Burn me for a bloody fool!

hi oʊnli hæd taɪm fəɹ ðət wʌn fɹæntɪk θɔt, ən ðən i wɑz plaʊɪŋ θɹu ðə kloʊk mɛn, sɛndɪŋ əm tɑpəlɪŋ laɪk pɪnz ɪn ə ɡeɪm ə boʊlz. ðə ɹoʊps slɪp θɹu hɪz hænz, ən i fɛl, tʌmbəlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹɔ-kʌvɝd flɔɹ hɪmsɛlf, kɔɪnz spɪlɪŋ fɹəm ɪz pɑkəts, tə ɛn ʌp əɡɛnst ə stɔl. wən i skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit, ðə fɔɹ mɛn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹaɪzɪŋ, tu. ən ðeɪ ɔl hæd naɪvz ɪn ðɛɹ hænz, naʊ. laɪt-blaɪn ful! bɝn mi! bɝn mi!

He only had time for that one frantic thought, and then he was plowing through the cloaked men, sending them toppling like pins in a game of bowls. The ropes slipped through his hands, and he fell, tumbling across the straw-covered floor himself, coins spilling from his pockets, to end up against a stall. When he scrambled to his feet, the four men were already rising, too. And they all had knives in their hands, now. Light-blind fool! Burn me! Burn me!

"mæt!"

"Mat!"

hi lʊkt ʌp, ən tɑm tɔst ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf daʊn tə hɪm. hi snæɡd ɪɾ aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə nɑk ðə bleɪɾ aʊɾ ə tɑmuzəz fɪst ən θʌmp ɪm ə ʃɑɹp kɹæk ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hɛd. ðə mæn kɹʌmpəld, bʌt ði ʌðɝ θɹi wɝ ɹaɪt bɪhaɪnd, ən fəɹ ə hɛktɪk moʊmən mæt hæɾ ɔl i kəd də wɪð ə wɝlɪŋ stæf tə kip naɪf bleɪdz əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, ɹæpɪŋ niz ən æŋkəlz ən ɹɪbz əntɪl i kəd læn ə ɡʊd bloʊ ɑn ə hɛd. wən ðə læs mæn fɛl, hi stɛɹɾ əɾ əm ə moʊmənt, ðən ɹeɪzd ɪz ɡlɛɹ tə ðə wʊmən. "dɪd juv tə tʃuz ðɪs steɪbəl tə bi mɝɾɝd ɪn?"

He looked up, and Thom tossed his quarterstaff down to him. He snagged it out of the air just in time to knock the blade out of Tammuz's fist and thump him a sharp crack on the side of the head. The man crumpled, but the other three were right behind, and for a hectic moment Mat had all he could do with a whirling staff to keep knife blades away from him, rapping knees and ankles and ribs until he could land a good blow on a head. When the last man fell, he stared at them a moment, then raised his glare to the woman. "Did you have to choose this stable to be murdered in?"

ʃi slɪpt ə slɪm-bleɪɾɪd dæɡɝ bæk ɪndə ə ʃiθ əɾ əɹ bɛlt. "aɪ wʊɾə hɛlp ju, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹd ðət jə maɪt mɪsteɪk mi fəɹ wʌn ə ðiz ɡɹeɪt bʌfunz ɪf aɪ keɪm nɪɹ wɪð stil ɪn maɪ hænd. ən aɪ tʃoʊz ðɪs steɪbəl kəz ðə ɹeɪn ɪz wɛɾ ən soʊ æm aɪ, ən noʊ wʌn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðɪs pleɪs."

She slipped a slim-bladed dagger back into a sheath at her belt. "I would have helped you, but I feared that you might mistake me for one of these great buffoons if I came near with steel in my hand. And I chose this stable because the rain is wet and so am I, and no one was watching this place."

ʃi wɑz oʊldɝ ðən i hæd θɔt, ət lis tɛn əɹ fɪftin jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hi, bʌt pɹɪɾi stɪl, wɪð lɑɹdʒ, dɑɹk aɪz ən ə smɔl, fʊl maʊθ ðət simd ɑn ðə pɔɪn ʌv ə paʊt. əɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɛɾi fəɹ ə kɪs. hi ɡeɪv ə smɔl læf ən lin ɑn ɪz stæf. "wɛl, wʌɾ ɪz dʌn ɪz dʌn. aɪ səpoʊz jə wɝ nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɹɪŋ əs tʃɹʌbəl."

She was older than he had thought, at least ten or fifteen years older than he, but pretty still, with large, dark eyes and a small, full mouth that seemed on the point of a pout. Or getting ready for a kiss. He gave a small laugh and leaned on his staff. "Well, what is done is done. I suppose you were not trying to bring us trouble."

tɑm wɑz klaɪmɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə lɔft, ɔkwɝdli kəz ə hɪz lɛɡ, ən ɑlʌdʒɹə lʊk fɹəm ɪm tə mæt. ðə ɡlimən hæd pʊɾ ɪz kloʊk bæk ɑn; hi sɛldəm lɛɾ ɛniwʌn si hɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɪt, ɪspɛʃli fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. "ðɪs ɪz laɪk ə stɔɹi," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ æm ɹɛskjud baɪ ə ɡlimən ən ə jʌŋ hɪɹoʊ" - ʃi fɹaʊn ət ðə mɛn spɹɔld ɑn ðə steɪbəl flɔɹ - "fɹʌm ðiz huz mʌðɝz wɝ pɪɡz!"

Thom was climbing down from the loft, awkwardly because of his leg, and Aludra looked from him to Mat. The gleeman had put his cloak back on; he seldom let anyone see him without it, especially for the first time. "This is like a story," she said. "I am rescued by a gleeman and a young hero" - she frowned at the men sprawled on the stable floor - "from these whose mothers were pigs!"

"waɪ dɪd ðeɪ wɑnə kɪl ju?" mæt æskt. "hi sɛd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt sikɹəts."

"Why did they want to kill you?" Mat asked. "He said something about secrets."

"ðə sikɹəts," tɑm sɛɾ ɪn vɛɹi nɪɹli hɪz pɝfɔɹmɪŋ vɔɪs, "ʌv meɪkɪŋ faɪɹwɝks, ənlɛs aɪ mɪs maɪ ɡɛs. jə ɑɹ ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ, ɑɹ jə nɑt?" hi meɪɾ ə kɔɹtli baʊ wɪð ən ɪlæbɹət swɝl ə hɪz kloʊk. "aɪ æm tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn, ə ɡlimən, əz juv sin." ɔlmoʊst əz ən æftɝθɑt, hi æɾəd, "æn ðɪs ɪz mæt, ə jʌŋ mæn wɪð ə næk fəɹ faɪndɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl."

"The secrets," Thom said in very nearly his performing voice, "of making fireworks, unless I miss my guess. You are an Illuminator, are you not?" He made a courtly bow with an elaborate swirl of his cloak. "I am Thom Merrilin, a gleeman, as you have seen." Almost as an afterthought, he added, "And this is Mat, a young man with a knack for finding trouble."

"aɪ wɑz ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd stɪfli, "bʌt ðɪs ɡɹeɪt pɪɡ tɑmuz, hi ɹuən ə pɝfɔɹməns fəɹ ðə kɪŋ ə kɛɹhin, ən nɪɹli hi dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə tʃæptɝ haʊs, tu. bʌt mi, aɪ wɑz mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə tʃæptɝ haʊs, soʊ ɪt wɑz mi ðət ðə ɡɪl hɛld ɹispɑnsəbəl." hɝ vɔɪs bɪkeɪm dɪfɛnsɪv. "aɪ də nɑt tɛl ðə sikɹəts ə ðə ɡɪld, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðət tɑmuz sɛz, bʌɾ əl nɑt lɛt maɪsɛlf stɑɹv waɪl aɪ kən meɪk faɪɹwɝks. aɪm noʊ mɔɹ ɪn ðə ɡɪld, soʊ ðə lɔz ə ðə ɡɪld, ðeɪ də nɑɾ əplaɪ tə mi naʊ."

"I was an Illuminator," Aludra said stiffly, "but this great pig Tammuz, he ruined a performance for the King of Cairhien, and nearly he destroyed the chapter house, too. But me, I was Mistress of the Chapter House, so it was me that the Guild held responsible." Her voice became defensive. "I do not tell the secrets of the Guild, no matter what that Tammuz says, but I will not let myself starve while I can make fireworks. I am no more in the Guild, so the laws of the Guild, they do not apply to me now."

"ɡɔlʒɹiən," tɑm sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz wʊɾən əz ʃi hæd. "wɛl, hiz ə dɛd kɪŋ naʊ, ən hɪl si noʊ mɔɹ faɪɹwɝks."

"Galldrian," Thom said, sounding almost as wooden as she had. "Well, he is a dead king now, and he'll see no more fireworks."

"ðə ɡɪld," ʃi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ taɪɝd, "ðeɪ ɔl bʌt bleɪm mi fəɹ ðɪs wɔɹ ɪn kɛɹhin, əz ɪf ðət wʌn naɪɾ ə dɪzæstɝ, ɪt meɪd ɡɔlʒɹiən daɪ." tɑm ɡɹɪməst. "ɪt simz aɪ kən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ," ʃi wɛn ɑn. "tɑmuz ən ðiz ʌðɝ ɑksən, ðəl weɪk sun. pɝhæps ðɪs taɪm ðəl tɛl ðə soʊlʒɝz ðəɾ aɪ stoʊl wʌɾ aɪ hæv meɪd." ʃi aɪd tɑm ən ðən mæt, fɹaʊnɪŋ ɪn θɔt, ən sim tə ɹitʃ ə dɪsɪʒən. "aɪ mʌst ɹɪwɔɹd ju, bʌɾ aɪ hæv noʊ mʌni. haʊɛvɝ, aɪ hæv sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz pɝhæps əz ɡʊɾ əz ɡoʊld. meɪbi bɛɾɝ. wi ʃæl si wʌt jə θɪŋk."

"The Guild," she said, sounding tired, "they all but blame me for this war in Cairhien, as if that one night of disaster, it made Galldrian die." Thom grimaced. "It seems I can no longer remain here," she went on. "Tammuz and these other oxen, they will wake soon. Perhaps this time they will tell the soldiers that I stole what I have made." She eyed Thom and then Mat, frowning in thought, and seemed to reach a decision. "I must reward you, but I have no money. However, I have something that is perhaps as good as gold. Maybe better. We shall see what you think."

mæt ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð tɑm əz ʃi wɛn tə ɹuɾ ʌndɝ ðə kænvəs kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ kɑɹt. əl hɛlp ɛniwʌn u kən peɪ. hi θɔɾ ə spɛkjələɾɪv laɪt hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn tɑmz blu aɪz.

Mat exchanged glances with Thom as she went to root under the canvas covering her cart. I'll help anyone who can pay. He thought a speculative light had appeared in Thom's blue eyes.

ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛpɝeɪɾəd wʌn bʌndəl fɹəm ə nʌmbɝ laɪk ɪt, ə ʃɔɹt ɹoʊl ə hɛvi, ɔɪl klɔθ ɔlmoʊst əz fæɾ əz əɹ ɑɹmz wəd ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd. sɛɾɪŋ ɪt daʊn ɑn ðə stʃɹɔ, ʃi əndɪd ðə baɪndɪŋ kɔɹdz ən ənɹoʊl ðə klɔθ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ. fɔɹ ɹoʊz ə pɑkəts ɹæn əlɔŋ ðə lɛŋθ ʌv ɪt, ðə pɑkəts ɪn itʃ ɹoʊ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðoʊz ɪn ðə wʌn bɪfɔɹ. itʃ pɑkət hɛld ə wæks-koʊɾəd sɪləndɝ ə peɪpɝ dʒʌs lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪts ɛnd, tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ə dɑɹk kɔɹd, tə stɪk aʊt.

Aludra separated one bundle from a number like it, a short roll of heavy, oiled cloth almost as fat as her arms would go around. Setting it down on the straw, she undid the binding cords and unrolled the cloth across the floor. Four rows of pockets ran along the length of it, the pockets in each row larger than those in the one before. Each pocket held a wax-coated cylinder of paper just large enough for its end, trailing a dark cord, to stick out.

"faɪɹwɝks," tɑm sɛd. "aɪ nu ɪt. ɑlʌdʒɹə, jə mʌs nɑt də ðɪs. jə kən sɛl ðoʊz fəɹ ɪnʌf tə lɪv tɛn deɪz əɹ mɔɹ əɾ ə ɡʊɾ ɪn, ən it wɛl ɛvɹi deɪ. wɛl, ɛniwɛɹ bʌt hɪɹ ɪn ɑɹɪŋɡəl."

"Fireworks," Thom said. "I knew it. Aludra, you must not do this. You can sell those for enough to live ten days or more at a good inn, and eat well every day. Well, anywhere but here in Aringill."

nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə lɔŋ stʃɹɪp ʌv ɔɪl klɔθ, ʃi snɪft ət hɪm. "bi kwaɪət, jə oʊld wʌn ju." ʃi meɪɾ ɪt saʊnd nɑɾ əŋkinli. "aɪ æm nɑɾ əlaʊd tə ʃoʊ ɡɹæɾətud? jə θɪŋk aɪ wəd ɡɪv jə ðɪs ɪf aɪ hæd noʊ mɔɹ fəɹ sɛlɪŋ? ətɛn mi kloʊsli."

Kneeling beside the long strip of oiled cloth, she sniffed at him. "Be quiet, you old one you." She made it sound not unkindly. "I am not allowed to show gratitude? You think I would give you this if I had no more for selling? Attend me closely."

mæt skwɑɾɪd bɪsaɪd hɝ, fæsəneɪɾəd. hi hæd sin faɪɹwɝks twaɪs ɪn ɪz laɪf. pɛdlɝz hæd bɹɔɾ əm tə ɛmənz fild, ət ɡɹeɪɾ ɪkspɛns tə ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl. wən i wɑz tɛn, hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kʌt wʌn oʊpən tə si wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪd, ən hæd kɑzd ən ʌpɹɔɹ. bɹæn ælvɪɹ, ðə meɪɝ, hæd kʌf hɪm; dɔɹæl bæɹən, hu hæd bɪn ðə wɪzdəm ðɛn, hæd swɪtʃt hɪm; ən ɪz fɑðɝ hæd stʃɹæpt ɪm wən i ɡɑt hoʊm. noʊbɑdi ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ wəd tɔk tə hɪm fəɹ ə mʌnθ, ɪksɛp fəɹ ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn, ən ðeɪ moʊsli toʊld ɪm wʌɾ ə ful i hæd bɪn. hi ɹitʃt aʊt tə tʌtʃ wʌn ə ðə sɪləndɝz. ɑlʌdʒɹə slæpt ɪz hæn əweɪ.

Mat squatted beside her, fascinated. He had seen fireworks twice in his life. Peddlers had brought them to Emond's Field, at great expense to the Village Council. When he was ten, he had tried to cut one open to see what was inside, and had caused an uproar. Bran al'Vere, the Mayor, had cuffed him; Doral Barran, who had been the Wisdom then, had switched him; and his father had strapped him when he got home. Nobody in the village would talk to him for a month, except for Rand and Perrin, and they mostly told him what a fool he had been. He reached out to touch one of the cylinders. Aludra slapped his hand away.

"ətɛn mi fɝst, aɪ seɪ! ðiz smɔləst, ðəl meɪk ə laʊd bæŋ, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ." ðeɪ wɝ ðə saɪz ə hɪz lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝ. "ðiz nɛkst, ðeɪ meɪk ə bæŋ ən ə bɹaɪt laɪt. ðə nɛkst, ðeɪ meɪk ðə bæŋ, ən ðə laɪt, ən mɛni spɑɹkəlz. ðə læst" - ðiz wɝ fæɾɝ ðən ɪz θʌm - "meɪk ɔl ə ðoʊz θɪŋz, bʌt ðə spɑɹkəlz, ðeɪ ɑɹ mɛni kʌlɝz. ɔlmoʊs laɪk ə naɪt-flaʊɝ, bʌt nɑɾ ʌp ɪn ðə skaɪ."

"Attend me first, I say! These smallest, they will make a loud bang, but no more." They were the size of his little finger. "These next, they make a bang and a bright light. The next, they make the bang, and the light, and many sparkles. The last" - these were fatter than his thumb - "make all of those things, but the sparkles, they are many colors. Almost like a night-flower, but not up in the sky."

naɪtfloʊɝ? mæt θɔt.

Nightflower? Mat thought.

"ju mʌs bi ɪspɛʃli kɛɹfəl ə ðiz. jə si, ðə fjuz, ɪts vɛɹi lɔŋ." ʃi sɔ hɪz blæŋk lʊk, ən wæɡəld wʌn ə ðə lɔŋ, dɑɹk kɔɹdz ət hɪm. "ðɪs, ðɪs!"

"You must be especially careful of these. You see, the fuse, it is very long." She saw his blank look, and waggled one of the long, dark cords at him. "This, this!"

"wɛɹ jə pʊt ðə faɪɝ," hi mʌɾɝd. "aɪ noʊ ðæt." tɑm meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən stʃɹoʊkt ɪz mʌstæʃɪz wɪð ə nʌkəl əz ɪf kʌvɝɪŋ ə smaɪl.

"Where you put the fire," he muttered. "I know that." Thom made a sound in his throat and stroked his mustaches with a knuckle as if covering a smile.

ɑlʌdʒɹə ɡɹʌntɪd. "wɛɹ jə pʊt ðə faɪɝ. jɛs. də nɑt steɪ kloʊs tə ɛni ʌv ðɛm, bʌt ðiz lɑɹdʒəst, jə ɹʌn əweɪ fɹəm wən jə laɪt ðə fjuz. jə kɑmpɹihɛn mi?" ʃi bɹɪskli ɹoʊld ʌp ðə lɔŋ klɔθ. "ju meɪ sɛl ðiz ɪf jə wɪʃ, əɹ juz ðɛm. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, jə mʌs nɛvɝ pʊt ðɪs kloʊs tə faɪɝ. faɪɝ wɪl meɪk əm ɔl ɪksploʊd. soʊ mɛni əz ðɪs ət wʌns, ɪt kəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ə haʊs, meɪbi." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊvɝ ɹɛɾiɪŋ ðə kɔɹdz, ðən æɾəd, "æn ðəɹ ɪz wʌn læs θɪŋ, wɪtʃ jə meɪ hæv hɝd. də nɑt kʌɾ oʊpən ɛni ʌv ðiz, əz səm ɡɹeɪt fulz də tə si wʌɾ ɪz ɪnsaɪd. səmtaɪmz wən wʌɾ ɪz ɪnsaɪd tʌtʃəz ɛɹ, ɪɾəl ɪksploʊd wɪθaʊt ðə niɾ ə faɪɝ. jə kən luz fɪŋɡɝz, əɹ ivən ə hænd."

Aludra grunted. "Where you put the fire. Yes. Do not stay close to any of them, but these largest, you run away from when you light the fuse. You comprehend me?" She briskly rolled up the long cloth. "You may sell these if you wish, or use them. Remember, you must never put this close to fire. Fire will make them all explode. So many as this at once, it could destroy a house, maybe." She hesitated over retying the cords, then added, "And there is one last thing, which you may have heard. Do not cut open any of these, as some great fools do to see what is inside. Sometimes when what is inside touches air, it will explode without the need of fire. You can lose fingers, or even a hand."

"aɪv hɝd ðæt," mæt sɛd dʒɹaɪli.

"I've heard that," Mat said dryly.

ʃi fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ i mɛn tə də ɪɾ ɛniweɪ, ðən faɪnəli pʊʃt ðə ɹoʊl bʌndəl təwɔɹd hɪm. "hɪɹ. aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ naʊ, bɪfɔɹ ðiz sʌnz ʌv ɡoʊts əweɪkən." ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə stɪl oʊpən dɔɹ, ən ðə ɹeɪn fɔlɪŋ ɪn ðə naɪt bɪɑnd, ʃi saɪd. "pɝhæps əl faɪn sʌmwɛɹ ɛls dʒɹaɪ. aɪ θɪŋk əl ɡoʊ təwɔɹd luɡɹd, təmɑɹoʊ. ðiz pɪɡz, ðəl ɪkspɛk mi tə ɡoʊ tə keɪɛmlɪn, jɛs?"

She frowned at him as if wondering whether he meant to do it anyway, then finally pushed the rolled bundle toward him. "Here. I must go now, before these sons of goats awaken." Glancing at the still open door, and the rain falling in the night beyond, she sighed. "Perhaps I will find somewhere else dry. I think I will go toward Lugard, tomorrow. These pigs, they will expect me to go to Caemlyn, yes?"

ɪt wɑz ivən fɝðɝ tə luɡɹd ðən tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən mæt sʌɾənli ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət hɑɹɾ ɛn ə bɹɛd. ən ʃi hæd sɛd ʃi hæd noʊ mʌni. ðə faɪɹwɝks wəd baɪ noʊ milz əntɪl ʃi faʊn sʌmwʌn u kəɾ əfɔɹd ðɛm. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ivən lʊkt ət ðə ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ ðət hæd spɪl fɹəm ɪz pɑkəts wən i fɛl; ɪt ɡlɪɾɝd ən spɑɹkəld əmʌŋ ðə stʃɹɔ ɪn ðə læntɝn laɪt. ɑ, laɪt, aɪ kænɑt lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ hʌŋɡɹi, aɪ səpoʊz. hi skupt ʌp əz mʌtʃ əz i kəd ɹitʃ kwɪkli.

It was even further to Lugard than to Caemlyn, and Mat suddenly remembered that hard end of bread. And she had said she had no money. The fireworks would buy no meals until she found someone who could afford them. She had never even looked at the gold and silver that had spilled from his pockets when he fell; it glittered and sparkled among the straw in the lantern light. Ah, Light, I cannot let her go hungry, I suppose. He scooped up as much as he could reach quickly.

"ʌ . . . ɑlʌdʒɹə? aɪ hæv plɛnti, jə kən si. aɪ θɔt pɝhæps. . . ." hi hɛld aʊt ðə kɔɪnz təwɔɹd hɝ. "aɪ kən ɔlweɪz wɪn mɔɹ."

"Uh . . . Aludra? I have plenty, you can see. I thought perhaps. . . ." He held out the coins toward her. "I can always win more."

ʃi pɔzd wɪð əɹ kloʊk hæf ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ðən smaɪld ət tɑm əz ʃi swɛpt ɪt ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ɑn. "hi ɪz jʌŋ jɛt, ɛ?"

She paused with her cloak half around her shoulders, then smiled at Thom as she swept it the rest of the way on. "He is young yet, eh?"

"hi ɪz jʌŋ," tɑm əɡɹid. "ænd nɑt hæf soʊ bæɾ əz i wəd laɪk tə θɪŋk hɪmsɛlf. səmtaɪmz hiz nɑt."

"He is young," Thom agreed. "And not half so bad as he would like to think himself. Sometimes he is not."

mæt ɡlaʊɝɾ ət boʊθ ə ðɛm ən loʊɝɾ ɪz hænd.

Mat glowered at both of them and lowered his hand.

lɪftɪŋ ðə ʃæfs ə hɝ kɑɹt, ɑlʌdʒɹə ɡɑɾ ɪt tɝn ɝaʊn ən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ, ɡɪvɪŋ tɑmuz ə kɪk ɪn ðə ɹɪbz əz ʃi pæst. hi ɡɹoʊnd ɡɹɑdʒəli.

Lifting the shafts of her cart, Aludra got it turned around and started for the door, giving Tammuz a kick in the ribs as she passed. He groaned groggily.

"aɪ wəd laɪk tə noʊ sʌmθɪŋ, ɑlʌdʒɹə," tɑm sɛd. "haʊ dɪd jə laɪt ðət læntɝn soʊ kwɪkli ɪn ðə dɑɹk?"

"I would like to know something, Aludra," Thom said. "How did you light that lantern so quickly in the dark?"

stɑpɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə dɔɹ, ʃi smaɪld oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət hɪm. "ju wɪʃ mi tə tɛl jə ɔl ə maɪ sikɹəts? aɪm ɡɹeɪtfəl, bʌɾ aɪm nɑɾ ɪn lʌv. ðət sikɹət, nɑɾ ivən ðə ɡɪl noʊz, fəɹ ɪts maɪ dɪskʌvɝi əloʊn. əl tɛl jə ðɪs mʌtʃ. wən aɪ noʊ haʊ tə meɪk ɪt wɝk pɹɑpɝli, ən wɝk oʊnli wən aɪ wɑn ɪt tə, stɪks wɪl meɪk maɪ fɔɹtʃən fəɹ mi." θɹoʊɪŋ əɹ weɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃæfs, ʃi pʊl ðə kɑɹɾ ɪndə ðə ɹeɪn, ən ðə naɪt swɑloʊd hɝ.

Stopping short of the door, she smiled over her shoulder at him. "You wish me to tell you all of my secrets? I am grateful, but I am not in love. That secret, not even the Guild knows, for it is my discovery alone. I will tell you this much. When I know how to make it work properly, and work only when I want it to, sticks will make my fortune for me." Throwing her weight against the shafts, she pulled the cart into the rain, and the night swallowed her.

"stɪks?" mæt sɛd. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ʃi maɪt nɑt bi ə lɪɾəl stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪn ðə hɛd.

"Sticks?" Mat said. He wondered if she might not be a little strange in the head.

tɑmuz ɡɹoʊn əɡɛn.

Tammuz groaned again.

"bɛst wi də ðə seɪm əz ʃi, bɔɪ," tɑm sɛd. "ɛls ɪts ə tʃɔɪs bɪtwin slɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ θɹoʊts ən meɪbi spɛndɪŋ ðə nɛks fju deɪz ɪkspleɪnɪŋ aʊɝsɛlvz tə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz. ðiz lʊk ðə sɔɹt hud sɛɾ əm ɑn əs aʊɾ ə spaɪt. ən ðeɪv ɪnʌf tə bi spaɪtfəl fɔɹ, aɪ səpoʊz." wʌn ə tɑmuzəz kəmpænjənz twɪtʃt əz ɪf kʌmɪŋ tə, ən mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl.

"Best we do the same as she, boy," Thom said. "Else it's a choice between slitting four throats and maybe spending the next few days explaining ourselves to the Queen's Guards. These look the sort who'd set them on us out of spite. And they have enough to be spiteful for, I suppose." One of Tammuz's companions twitched as if coming to, and muttered something incomprehensible.

baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ hæd ɡæðɝɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ən sæɾəld ðə hɔɹsəz, tɑmuz wɑz ʌp ɑn ɪz hænz ən niz wɪð ɪz hɛd hæŋɪŋ, ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ stɝɪŋ ən ɡɹoʊnɪŋ, tu.

By the time they had gathered everything and saddled the horses, Tammuz was up on his hands and knees with his head hanging, and the others were stirring and groaning, too.

swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl, mæt stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɹeɪn aʊtsaɪd ði oʊpən dɔɹ, fɔlɪŋ hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ. "ə blʌɾi hɪɹoʊ," hi sɛd. "tɑm, ɪf aɪ ɛvɝ lʊk laɪk æktɪŋ ðə hɪɹoʊ əɡɛn, jə kɪk mi."

Swinging into his saddle, Mat stared at the rain outside the open door, falling harder than ever. "A bloody hero," he said. "Thom, if I ever look like acting the hero again, you kick me."

"ænd wʌt wəd juv dʌn dɪfɹənli?"

"And what would you have done differently?"

mæt skaʊld ət hɪm, ðən pʊld ʌp ɪz hʊɾ ən spɹɛd ðə teɪl ə hɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ðə fæt ɹoʊl taɪd bɪhaɪn ðə haɪ kæntəl ə hɪz sæɾəl. ivən wɪð ɔɪl klɔθ, ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ pɹətɛkʃən fɹəm ðə ɹeɪn kəd nɑt hɝt. "dʒʌs kɪk mi!" hi buɾɪd ɪz hɔɹs ɪn ðə ɹɪbz ən ɡæləpt ɪndə ðə ɹeɪni naɪt.

Mat scowled at him, then pulled up his hood and spread the tail of his cloak over the fat roll tied behind the high cantle of his saddle. Even with oiled cloth, a little more protection from the rain could not hurt. "Just kick me!" He booted his horse in the ribs and galloped into the rainy night.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾiwʌn


CHAPTER 41

eɪ hʌntɝz oʊθ


A Hunter's Oath

əz ðə snoʊ ɡus muv təwɔɹd ðə lɔŋ stoʊn dɑks ʌv ɪljən, seɪlz fɝld ən pɹəpɛl baɪ ɪts swips, pɛɹɪn stʊd nɪɹ ðə stɝn wɑtʃɪŋ ɡɹeɪt nʌmbɝz ə lɔŋ-lɛɡəd bɝdz weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə tɔl mɑɹʃ ɡɹæs ðəɾ ɔl bʌɾ ɪnsɝkəl ðə ɡɹeɪt hɑɹbɝ. hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə smɔl waɪt kɹeɪnz, ən kəd ɡɛs ət ðɛɹ mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ blu bɹʌðɝz, bʌt mɛni ʌv ðə kɹɛstəd bɝdz - ɹɛd-fɛðɝɾ əɹ ɹoʊzi, səm wɪð flæt bɪlz bɹɔɾɝ ðən ə dʌks - hi dɪd nɑt noʊ əɾ ɔl. ə dʌzən sɔɹts ʌv ɡʌlz swupt ən sɔɹɾ əbʌv ðə hɑɹbɝ ɪtsɛlf, ən ə blæk bɝd wɪð ə lɔŋ, ʃɑɹp bik skɪm dʒʌst əbʌv ðə wɔɾɝ, ɪts ʌndɝbik kʌɾɪŋ ə fɝoʊ. ʃɪps θɹi ən fɔɹ taɪmz əz lɔŋ əz ðə snoʊ ɡus leɪ æŋkɝɾ əkɹɔs ði ɪkspæns ə ðə hɑɹbɝ, weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝnz ət ðə dɑks, əɹ fəɹ ðə taɪdz tə ʃɪf soʊ ðeɪ kəd seɪl bɪɑn ðə lɔŋ bɹeɪkwɔɾɝ. smɔl fɪʃɪŋ boʊts wɝkt kloʊs tə ðə mɑɹʃ, ən ɪn ðə kɹiks waɪndɪŋ θɹu ɪt, tu əɹ θɹi mɛn ɪn itʃ dʒɹæɡɪŋ nɛts ɑn lɔŋ poʊlz swʌŋ aʊt fɹəm iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə boʊt.

As the Snow Goose moved toward the long stone docks of Illian, sails furled and propelled by its sweeps, Perrin stood near the stern watching great numbers of long-legged birds wading in the tall marsh grass that all but encircled the great harbor. He recognized the small white cranes, and could guess at their much larger blue brothers, but many of the crested birds - red-feathered or rosy, some with flat bills broader than a duck's - he did not know at all. A dozen sorts of gulls swooped and soared above the harbor itself, and a black bird with a long, sharp beak skimmed just above the water, its underbeak cutting a furrow. Ships three and four times as long as the Snow Goose lay anchored across the expanse of the harbor, waiting their turns at the docks, or for the tides to shift so they could sail beyond the long breakwater. Small fishing boats worked close to the marsh, and in the creeks winding through it, two or three men in each dragging nets on long poles swung out from either side of the boat.

ðə wɪn kæɹiɾ ə ʃɑɹp sɛn ə sɔlt, ən dɪd lɪɾəl tə bɹeɪk ðə hit. ðə sʌn stʊd wɛl oʊvɝ hæfweɪ daʊn tə ðə hɝaɪzən, bʌɾ ɪt sim laɪk nun. ði ɛɹ fɛl dæmp; ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ hi kəd θɪŋk ʌv ɪt. dæmp. hɪz noʊz kɑt ðə smɛl ə fɹɛʃ fɪʃ fɹəm ðə boʊts, ʌv oʊl fɪʃ ən mʌd fɹəm ðə mɑɹʃ, ən ðə saʊɝ stɪŋk ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ tænɪŋ jɑɹd ðət leɪ ɑn ə tʃɹiləs aɪlən ɪn ðə mɑɹʃ ɡɹæs.

The wind carried a sharp scent of salt, and did little to break the heat. The sun stood well over halfway down to the horizon, but it seemed like noon. The air felt damp; it was the only way he could think of it. Damp. His nose caught the smell of fresh fish from the boats, of old fish and mud from the marsh, and the sour stink of a large tanning yard that lay on a treeless island in the marsh grass.

kæptən ədʒɹə mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ sɔfli bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðə tɪlɝ kɹikt, ən ðə snoʊ ɡus tʃeɪnʒd ɪts kɔɹs ə tʃɹaɪfəl. bɛɹfʊt mɛn ət ðə swips muvd əz ɪf nɑt wɑntɪŋ tə meɪk ə saʊnd. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt ɡlæns əɾ əm bɪɑn ə flɪkɝ ə hɪz aɪ.

Captain Adarra muttered something softly behind him, the tiller creaked, and the Snow Goose changed its course a trifle. Barefoot men at the sweeps moved as if not wanting to make a sound. Perrin did not glance at them beyond a flicker of his eye.

hi pɪɹɾ ət ðə tænɝi, ɪnstɛd, wɑtʃɪŋ mɛn skɹeɪp haɪdz stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn ɹoʊz ʌv wʊɾən fɹeɪmz, ən ʌðɝ mɛn lɪf haɪdz aʊɾ ə hjudʒ, sʌŋkən væts wɪð lɔŋ stɪks. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ stæk ðə haɪdz ɑn bæɹoʊz, wilɪŋ əm ɪndə ðə lɔŋ, loʊ bɪldɪŋ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə jɑɹd; səmtaɪmz ðə haɪdz wɛn bæk ɪndə ðə væts, wɪð ən ədɪʃən ə lɪkwədz pɔɹd fɹəm lɑɹdʒ stoʊn kɹɑks. ðeɪ pɹɑbli meɪd mɔɹ lɛðɝ ɪn ə deɪ ðən wɑz meɪɾ ɪn ɛmənz fild ɪn mʌnθs, ən i kəd si ənʌðɝ tænɝi ɑn ənʌðɝ aɪlən bɪɑn ðə fɝst.

He peered at the tannery, instead, watching men scrape hides stretched on rows of wooden frames, and other men lift hides out of huge, sunken vats with long sticks. Sometimes they stacked the hides on barrows, wheeling them into the long, low building at the edge of the yard; sometimes the hides went back into the vats, with an addition of liquids poured from large stone crocks. They probably made more leather in a day than was made in Emond's Field in months, and he could see another tannery on another island beyond the first.

ɪt wɑz nɑt ðəɾ i hæɾ ɛni ɹil ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ʃɪps əɹ fɪʃɪŋ boʊts əɹ tænɪŋ jɑɹdz, əɹ ivən vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɪn ðə bɝdz - ðoʊ hi dɪd wʌndɝ wʌt ðoʊz peɪl ɹɛd wʌnz kəd bi fɪʃɪŋ fəɹ wɪð ðɛɹ flæt bɪlz, ən səm ə ðɛm lʊkt ɡʊd tə iɾ ənlɛs i wɑtʃt hɪmsɛlf - bʌɾ ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən wɑtʃɪŋ ðə sin bɪhaɪn ɪm ɑn ðə dɛk ə ðə snoʊ ɡus. ði æks əɾ ɪz bɛlt wɑz noʊ dɪfɛns əɡɛns ðæt. ə stoʊn wɔl wʊdn bi dɪfɛns ɪnʌf, hi θɔt.

It was not that he had any real interest in ships or fishing boats or tanning yards, or even very much in the birds - though he did wonder what those pale red ones could be fishing for with their flat bills, and some of them looked good to eat unless he watched himself - but anything at all was better than watching the scene behind him on the deck of the Snow Goose. The axe at his belt was no defense against that. A stone wall wouldn't be defense enough, he thought.

mɔɪɹeɪn hæd bɪn niðɝ pliz nɔɹ dɪspliz tə dɪskʌvɝ ðət zɑɹin - əl nɑt kɔl əɹ feɪl, wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑns tə neɪm hɝsɛlf! ʃiz noʊ fælkən! - nu ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪn pɝhæps ə lɪɾəl əpsɛt wɪð ɪm fəɹ nɑt tɛlɪŋ hɝ. ə lɪɾəl ʌpsɛt. ʃi kɔl mi ə ful, bʌt ðət wɑz ɔl. ðɛn. mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑt sim tə kɛɹ wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ əbaʊt zɑɹin biɪŋ ə hʌntɝ ə ðə hɔɹn. bʌt wʌns ʃi lɝn ðə ɡɝl θɔt ðeɪ wəd lɛɾ əɹ tə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, wʌns ʃi lɝn i hæd noʊn ðæt, tu, ən nɑt toʊld əɹ - zɑɹin hæd bɪn mɔɹ ðən fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ əbaʊt boʊθ sʌbʒɪkts wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn, tə hɪz maɪnd - ðən əɹ koʊl dɑɹk stɛɹ hæd teɪkən ɑn ə kwɑləɾi ðət meɪɾ ɪm fil əz ɪf i hæd bɪn pækt ɪn ə bæɹəl ə snoʊ ɪn ðə dɛɾ ʌv wɪntɝ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd nʌθɪŋ, bʌt ʃi stɛɹd tu ɔfən ən tu hɑɹd fəɹ ɛni kʌmfɝt.

Moiraine had been neither pleased nor displeased to discover that Zarine - I'll not call her Faile, whatever she wants to name herself! She is no falcon! - knew she was Aes Sedai, though she had been perhaps a little upset with him for not telling her. A little upset. She called me a fool, but that was all. Then. Moiraine did not seem to care one way or another about Zarine being a Hunter of the Horn. But once she learned the girl thought they would lead her to the Horn of Valere, once she learned he had known that, too, and not told her - Zarine had been more than forthcoming about both subjects with Moiraine, to his mind - then her cold dark stare had taken on a quality that made him feel as if he had been packed in a barrel of snow in the dead of winter. The Aes Sedai said nothing, but she stared too often and too hard for any comfort.

hi lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən kwɪkli ɹɪtɝn tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə ʃɔɹlaɪn. zɑɹin wɑz sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə dɛk nɪɹ ðə hɔɹsəz tɛðɝd bɪtwin ðə mæsts, hɝ bʌndəl ən dɑɹk kloʊk bɪsaɪd hɝ, hɝ nɛɹoʊ, dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts nitli ɝeɪd, pɹitɛndɪŋ tə stʌɾi ðə ɹuftɑps ən taʊɝz ə ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ sɪɾi. mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ɪljən, tu, fɹəm dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə ðə mɛn wɝkɪŋ ðə swips, bʌt naʊ ən ðən ʃi ʃɑɾ ə hɑɹd lʊk ət ðə ɡɝl fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə dip hʊɾ ə hɝ faɪn ɡɹeɪ wʊl kloʊk. haʊ kən ʃi stænd wɛɹɪŋ ðæt? hɪz oʊn koʊt wɑz ənbʌɾənd ən ɪz ʃɝɾ ənleɪst ət ðə nɛk.

He looked over his shoulder and quickly returned to studying the shoreline. Zarine was sitting cross-legged on the deck near the horses tethered between the masts, her bundle and dark cloak beside her, her narrow, divided skirts neatly arrayed, pretending to study the rooftops and towers of the oncoming city. Moiraine was studying Illian, too, from just ahead of the men working the sweeps, but now and then she shot a hard look at the girl from under the deep hood of her fine gray wool cloak. How can she stand wearing that? His own coat was unbuttoned and his shirt unlaced at the neck.

zɑɹin mɛɾ itʃ ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊk wɪð ə smaɪl, bʌɾ ɛvɹi taɪm mɔɪɹeɪn tɝn əweɪ, ʃi swɑloʊɾ ən waɪpt əɹ fɔɹhɛd.

Zarine met each Aes Sedai look with a smile, but every time Moiraine turned away, she swallowed and wiped her forehead.

pɛɹɪn ɹæðɝ ədmaɪɝɾ əɹ fəɹ mænɪdʒɪŋ ðət smaɪl wən mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd dil mɔɹ ðən i kəd du. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃɹuli luz əɹ tɛmpɝ, bʌɾ i hɪmsɛlf wɑz ət ðə pɔɪn ʌv wɪʃɪŋ ʃi wəd ʃaʊt, əɹ ɹeɪdʒ, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt stɛɹ ət hɪm. laɪt, meɪbi nɑɾ ɛniθɪŋ! meɪbi ðə stɛɹ wɑz bɛɹəbəl.

Perrin rather admired her for managing that smile when Moiraine was watching. It was a good deal more than he could do. He had never seen the Aes Sedai truly lose her temper, but he himself was at the point of wishing she would shout, or rage, or anything but stare at him. Light, maybe not anything! Maybe the stare was bearable.

læn sæt fɝðɝ təwɔɹd ðə baʊ ðən mɔɪɹeɪn - hɪz kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk wɑz stɪl ɪn ðə sæɾəlbæɡz əɾ ɪz fit - aʊtwɝdli əbzɔɹbd ɪn ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd bleɪd, bʌt meɪkɪŋ lɪɾəl ɛfɝt tə haɪɾ ɪz əmjuzmənt. səmtaɪmz ɪz lɪps əpɪɹd tə kwɝk vɛɹi kloʊs tə ə smaɪl. pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt sɝɾən; ət taɪmz i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə ʃædoʊ. ʃædoʊz kəd meɪk ə hæmɝ sim tə smaɪl. itʃ wʊmən ɑbviəsli θɔt ʃi wɑz ði əbdʒɛkt ə ðəɾ əmjuzmənt, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə maɪn ðə taɪt-lɪp fɹaʊnz i ɹəsiv fɹəm boʊθ ə ðɛm.

Lan sat further toward the bow than Moiraine - his color-shifting cloak was still in the saddlebags at his feet - outwardly absorbed in examining his sword blade, but making little effort to hide his amusement. Sometimes his lips appeared to quirk very close to a smile. Perrin was not certain; at times he thought it was only a shadow. Shadows could make a hammer seem to smile. Each woman obviously thought she was the object of that amusement, but the Warder did not appear to mind the tight-lipped frowns he received from both of them.

ə fju deɪz ɝliɝ pɛɹɪn hæd hɝd mɔɪɹeɪn æsk læn, ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk aɪs, wɛðɝ i sɔ sʌmθɪŋ tə læf æt. "aɪ wəd nɛvɝ læf ət ju, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ," hi hæd ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, "bʌɾ ɪf jə tʃɹuli ɪntɛn tə sɛn mi tə maɪɹɛl, aɪ mʌs bɪkʌm juz tə smaɪlɪŋ. aɪ hɪɹ ðət maɪɹɛl tɛlz əɹ wɔɹɾɝz dʒoʊks. ɡeɪɾɪn mʌst smaɪl ət ðɛɹ bɑn hoʊldɝz kwɪps; juv ɔfən ɡɪvən mi kwɪps tə læf æt, hæv jə nɑt? pɝhæps jə wəd ɹæðɝ aɪ steɪ wɪð jə æftɝ ɔl." ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ə lʊk ðət wʊɾə neɪld ɛni ʌðɝ mæn tə ðə mæst, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ nɛvɝ blɪŋkt. læn meɪd koʊl stil sim laɪk tɪn.

A few days earlier Perrin had heard Moiraine ask Lan, in a voice like ice, whether he saw something to laugh at. "I would never laugh at you, Moiraine Sedai," he had replied calmly, "but if you truly intend to send me to Myrelle, I must become used to smiling. I hear that Myrelle tells her Warders jokes. Gaidin must smile at their bond holder's quips; you have often given me quips to laugh at, have you not? Perhaps you would rather I stay with you after all." She had given him a look that would have nailed any other man to the mast, but the Warder never blinked. Lan made cold steel seem like tin.

ðə kɹu hæd teɪkən tə pæɾɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ wɝk ɪn ʌɾɝ saɪləns wən mɔɪɹeɪn ən zɑɹin wɝ ɑn dɛk təɡɛðɝ. kæptən ədʒɹə hɛld ɪz hɛd tɪltəd, ən lʊkt əz ɪf i wɝ lɪsnɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə hɪɹ. hi pæst ɪz ɔɹɾɝz ɪn wɪspɝz, ɪnstɛɾ ə ðə ʃaʊts i hæd juzd ət fɝst. ɛvɹiwʌn nu mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, naʊ, ən ɛvɹiwʌn nu ʃi wɑz dɪsplizd. pɛɹɪn hæd lɛt hɪmsɛlf ɡɛɾ ɪndə wʌn ʃaʊɾɪŋ mætʃ wɪð zɑɹin, ən i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɪtʃ ə ðɛm hæd sɛd ðə wɝdz "ɛɛs sədaɪ," bʌt ðə hoʊl kɹu nu. blʌɾi wʊmən! hi wɑz ənsɝɾən wɛðɝ i mɛn mɔɪɹeɪn əɹ zɑɹin. ɪf ʃiz ðə fælkən, wʌɾ ɪz ðə hɔk səpoʊz tə bi? æm aɪ gɑnə bi stʌk wɪð tu wɪmən laɪk hɝ? laɪt! noʊ! ʃiz nɑɾ ə fælkən, ən ðəɾ ɪz ən ɛn tə ɪt! ði oʊnli ɡʊd θɪŋ i kəd faɪn ɪn ɔl ðɪs wɑz ðət wɪð ən æŋɡɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ tə wɝi əbaʊt, nʌn ə ðə kɹu lʊk twaɪs əɾ ɪz aɪz.

The crew had taken to padding about their work in utter silence when Moiraine and Zarine were on deck together. Captain Adarra held his head tilted, and looked as if he were listening for something he did not want to hear. He passed his orders in whispers, instead of the shouts he had used at first. Everyone knew Moiraine was Aes Sedai, now, and everyone knew she was displeased. Perrin had let himself get into one shouting match with Zarine, and he was not sure which of them had said the words "Aes Sedai," but the whole crew knew. Bloody woman! He was uncertain whether he meant Moiraine or Zarine. If she is the falcon, what is the hawk supposed to be? Am I going to be stuck with two women like her? Light! No! She is not a falcon, and that is an end to it! The only good thing he could find in all this was that with an angry Aes Sedai to worry about, none of the crew looked twice at his eyes.

lɔɪəl wɑz noʊwɛɹ ɪn saɪt, ət ðə moʊmənt. ði oʊɡiɝ steɪɾ ɪn ɪz staɪflɪŋ kæbən wɛnɛvɝ mɔɪɹeɪn ən zɑɹin wɝ tɑpsaɪd təɡɛðɝ - wɝkɪŋ ɑn ɪz noʊts, hi sɛd. hi oʊnli keɪm ɑn dɛk ət naɪt, tə smoʊk ɪz paɪp. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt si haʊ hi kəd teɪk ðə hit; ivən mɔɪɹeɪn ən zɑɹin wɝ bɛɾɝ ðən biɪŋ bɛlaʊdɛks.

Loial was nowhere in sight, at the moment. The Ogier stayed in his stifling cabin whenever Moiraine and Zarine were topside together - working on his notes, he said. He only came on deck at night, to smoke his pipe. Perrin did not see how he could take the heat; even Moiraine and Zarine were better than being belowdecks.

hi saɪɾ ən kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn ɪljən. ðə sɪɾi ðə ʃɪp wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ wɑz lɑɹdʒ - əz bɪɡ əz kɛɹhin əɹ keɪɛmlɪn, ði oʊnli tu ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin - ən ɪt ɹɪɹɾ aʊɾ ʌv ə hjudʒ mɑɹʃ ðət stʃɹɛtʃt fəɹ maɪlz laɪk ə pleɪn ʌv weɪvɪŋ ɡɹæs. ɪljən hæd noʊ wɔlz əɾ ɔl, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə bi ɔl taʊɝz ən pæləsəz. ðə bɪldɪŋz wɝ ɔl peɪl stoʊn, ɪksɛp fəɹ səm ðəɾ əpɪɹd kʌvɝd wɪð waɪt plæstɝ, bʌt ðə stoʊn wɑz waɪɾ ən ɡɹeɪ ən ɹɛɾɪʃ ən ivən feɪnt ʃeɪdz ʌv ɡɹin. ɹuftɑps ə taɪl spɑɹkəld ʌndɝ ðə sʌn wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd dɪfɹən hjuz. ðə lɔŋ dɑks hɛl mɛni ʃɪps, moʊs dwɔɹfɪŋ ðə snoʊ ɡus, ən bʌsəld wɪð ðə loʊɾɪŋ ən ənloʊɾɪŋ ə kɑɹɡoʊ. ðəɹ wɝ ʃɪpjɑɹdz ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə sɪɾi, wɛɹ ɡɹeɪt ʃɪps stʊɾ ɪn ɛvɹi steɪdʒ fɹəm skɛləɾənz ə θɪk wʊɾən ɹɪbz tə nɪɹli ɹɛɾi tə slaɪɾ ɪndə ðə hɑɹbɝ.

He sighed and kept his eyes on Illian. The city the ship was approaching was large - as big as Cairhien or Caemlyn, the only two great cities he had ever seen - and it reared out of a huge marsh that stretched for miles like a plain of waving grass. Illian had no walls at all, but it seemed to be all towers and palaces. The buildings were all pale stone, except for some that appeared covered with white plaster, but the stone was white and gray and reddish and even faint shades of green. Rooftops of tile sparkled under the sun with a hundred different hues. The long docks held many ships, most dwarfing the Snow Goose, and bustled with the loading and unloading of cargo. There were shipyards at the far end of the city, where great ships stood in every stage from skeletons of thick wooden ribs to nearly ready to slide into the harbor.

pɝhæps ɪljən wɑz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə kip wʊlvz ət beɪ. ðeɪ ʃʊɹli wəd nɑt hʌn ɪn ðoʊz mɑɹʃəz. ðə snoʊ ɡus hæɾ aʊtʃɹʌn ðə wʊlvz ðət hæd fɑloʊɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə maʊntənz. hi ɹitʃt aʊt fəɹ əm dʒɪnʒɝli, naʊ, ən fɛlt - nʌθɪŋ. ə kjʊɹiəsli ɛmpti filɪŋ, ɡɪvən ðəɾ ɪt wɑz wʌɾ i wɑntəd. hɪz dʒɹimz hæd bɪn ɪz oʊn - fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt - sɪns ðət fɝs naɪt. mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ æskt əbaʊɾ əm ɪn ə koʊl vɔɪs, ən i hæd toʊl ðə tʃɹuθ. twaɪs i hæd faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðəɾ ɑd sɔɹɾ ʌv wʊlf dʒɹim, ən boʊθ taɪmz hɑpɝ hæɾ əpɪɹd, tʃeɪsɪŋ ɪm əweɪ, tɛlɪŋ ɪm i wɑz tu jʌŋ jɛt, tu nu. wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn meɪɾ ə ðæt, hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə; ʃi toʊld ɪm nʌθɪŋ, ɪksɛp tə seɪ hi hæd bɛs bi wɛɹi.

Perhaps Illian was large enough to keep wolves at bay. They surely would not hunt in those marshes. The Snow Goose had outrun the wolves that had followed him from the mountains. He reached out for them gingerly, now, and felt - nothing. A curiously empty feeling, given that it was what he wanted. His dreams had been his own - for the most part - since that first night. Moiraine had asked about them in a cold voice, and he had told the truth. Twice he had found himself in that odd sort of wolf dream, and both times Hopper had appeared, chasing him away, telling him he was too young yet, too new. What Moiraine made of that, he had no idea; she told him nothing, except to say he had best be wary.

"ðæts əz wɛl baɪ mi," hi ɡɹaʊld. hi wɑz ɔlmoʊs bɪkʌmɪŋ juz tə hɑpɝ biɪŋ dɛd bʌt nɑt dɛd, ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹimz, ət list. bɪhaɪn hɪm, hi hɝd kæptən ədʒɹə skʌf ɪz buts ɑn ðə dɛk ən mʌɾɝ sʌmθɪŋ, stɑɹɾəld ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wəd spik əlaʊd.

"That's as well by me," he growled. He was almost becoming used to Hopper being dead but not dead, in the wolf dreams, at least. Behind him, he heard Captain Adarra scuff his boots on the deck and mutter something, startled that anyone would speak aloud.

laɪnz wɝ hɝld əʃɔɹ fɹəm ðə ʃɪp. waɪl ðeɪ wɝ stɪl biɪŋ meɪd fæs tə stoʊn poʊsts əlɔŋ ðə dɑks, ðə slaɪtli bɪl kæptən lɛpt ɪndə moʊʃən, wɪspɝɪŋ fɪɹsli tə hɪz kɹu. hi hæd bumz ɹɪɡd tə lɪf ðə hɔɹsəz ɑntu ðə wɔɹf ɔlmoʊst əz kwɪkli əz ðə ɡæŋplæŋk wɑz leɪɾ ɪn pleɪs. lænz blæk wɔɹ hɔɹs kɪkt ən nɪɹli bɹoʊk ðə bum hɔɪstɪŋ hɪm. lɔɪəlz hjudʒ, hɛɹi-fɛtlɑk maʊnt niɾəd tu.

Lines were hurled ashore from the ship. While they were still being made fast to stone posts along the docks, the slightly built captain leaped into motion, whispering fiercely to his crew. He had booms rigged to lift the horses onto the wharf almost as quickly as the gangplank was laid in place. Lan's black war horse kicked and nearly broke the boom hoisting him. Loial's huge, hairy-fetlocked mount needed two.

"æn ɑnɝ," ədʒɹə wɪspɝd tə mɔɪɹeɪn wɪð ə baʊ əz ʃi stɛpt ɑntu ðə waɪd plæŋk liɾɪŋ tə ðə dɑk. "æn ɑnɝ tə hæv sɝv ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ." ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ əʃɔɹ wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, hɝ feɪs hɪɾən ɪn əɹ dip hʊd.

"An honor," Adarra whispered to Moiraine with a bow as she stepped onto the wide plank leading to the dock. "An honor to have served you, Aes Sedai." She strode ashore without looking at him, her face hidden in her deep hood.

lɔɪəl dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ əntɪl ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɑz ɑn ðə dɑk, ən ðə hɔɹsəz, tu. ði oʊɡiɝ keɪm θʌmpɪŋ ʌp ðə ɡæŋplæŋk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɑn ɪz lɔŋ koʊt waɪl kæɹiɪŋ ɪz bɪɡ sæɾəlbæɡz ən stʃɹaɪp blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl, ən ɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ wʌn ɑɹm. "aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ wi hæɾ ɝaɪvd," hi ɹʌmbəl bɹɛθləsli. "aɪ wɑz ɹiɹiɾɪŋ maɪ. . . ." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf wɪð ə ɡlæns ət mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi əpɪɹd tə bi əbzɔɹbd ɪn wɑtʃɪŋ læn sæɾəl ɑldib, bʌt ði oʊɡiɝz ɪɹz flɪkɝd laɪk ə nɝvəs kæts.

Loial did not appear until everyone else was on the dock, and the horses, too. The Ogier came thumping up the gangplank trying to don his long coat while carrying his big saddlebags and striped blanketroll, and his cloak over one arm. "I did not know we had arrived," he rumbled breathlessly. "I was rereading my. . . ." He trailed off with a glance at Moiraine. She appeared to be absorbed in watching Lan saddle Aldieb, but the Ogier's ears flickered like a nervous cat's.

hɪz noʊts, pɛɹɪn θɔt. wʌn ə ðiz deɪz aɪ hæv tə si wʌt hiz seɪɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɔl ðɪs. sʌmθɪŋ tɪkəl ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk, ən i dʒʌmpt ə fʊt bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪzd i wɑz smɛlɪŋ ə klin, ɝbəl sɛn θɹu ðə spaɪsəz ən tɑɹ ən stɪŋks ə ðə dɑks.

His notes, Perrin thought. One of these days I have to see what he is saying about all this. Something tickled the back of his neck, and he jumped a foot before he realized he was smelling a clean, herbal scent through the spices and tar and stinks of the docks.

zɑɹin wɪɡɡəld əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, smaɪlɪŋ ət ðɛm. "ɪf aɪ kən də ðət wɪð dʒʌst ə bɹʌʃ ə maɪ fɪŋɡɝz, fɑɹmbɔɪ, aɪ wʌndɝ haʊ haɪ jə wəd dʒʌmp ɪf aɪ - ?"

Zarine wiggled her fingers, smiling at them. "If I can do that with just a brush of my fingers, farmboy, I wonder how high you would jump if I - ?"

hi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ə lɪɾəl taɪɝɾ ə kənsɪɾɝɪŋ lʊks fɹəm ðoʊz dɑɹk, tɪltəɾ aɪz. ʃi meɪ bi pɹɪɾi, bʌt ʃi lʊks ət mi ðə weɪ aɪd lʊk əɾ ə tul aɪd nɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʌzəl aʊt haʊ ɪt wɑz meɪd, ən wʌɾ ɪts səpoʊz tə bi juz fɔɹ.

He was growing a little tired of considering looks from those dark, tilted eyes. She may be pretty, but she looks at me the way I'd look at a tool I'd never seen before, trying to puzzle out how it was made, and what it is supposed to be used for.

"zɑɹin." mɔɪɹeɪnz vɔɪs wɑz kul bʌɾ ənɹʌfəld.

"Zarine." Moiraine's voice was cool but unruffled.

"aɪ æm kɔl feɪl," zɑɹin sɛd fɝmli, ən fəɹ ə moʊmənt, wɪð əɹ boʊl noʊz, ʃi dɪd lʊk laɪk ə fælkən.

"I am called Faile," Zarine said firmly, and for a moment, with her bold nose, she did look like a falcon.

"zɑɹin," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd fɝmli, "ɪɾ ɪz taɪm fəɹ əɹ weɪz tə pɑɹt. jəl faɪn bɛɾɝ hʌntɪŋ ɛlswɛɹ, ən seɪfɝ."

"Zarine," Moiraine said firmly, "it is time for our ways to part. You will find better Hunting elsewhere, and safer."

"aɪ θɪŋk nɑt," zɑɹin sɛd dʒʌst əz fɝmli. "eɪ hʌntɝ mʌs fɑloʊ ðə tʃɹeɪl ʃi siz, ən noʊ hʌntɝ wəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ðə tʃɹeɪl jə fɔɹ liv. ən aɪm feɪl." ʃi spɔɪld ɪɾ ə bɪt baɪ swɑloʊɪŋ, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt blɪŋk əz ʃi mɛt mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪz.

"I think not," Zarine said just as firmly. "A Hunter must follow the trail she sees, and no Hunter would ignore the trail you four leave. And I am Faile." She spoiled it a bit by swallowing, but she did not blink as she met Moiraine's eyes.

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən?" mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɔfli. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jəl nɑt tʃeɪnʒ jəɹ maɪnd . . . fælkən?"

"Are you certain?" Moiraine said softly. "Are you sure you will not change your mind . . . Falcon?"

"aɪ wɪl nɑt. ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ jə əɹ jəɹ stoʊn-feɪst wɔɹɾɝ kən də tə stɑp mi." zɑɹin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən æɾəd sloʊli, əz ɪf ʃi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bi ɪntaɪɝli tʃɹuθfəl, "æt list, ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ ðət jəl də ðət kən stɑp mi. aɪ noʊ ə lɪɾəl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ; aɪ noʊ, fəɹ ɔl ðə stɔɹiz, ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ θɪŋz jəl nɑt du. ən aɪ də nɑt bɪliv stoʊn-feɪs wəd də wʌɾ i mʌs tə meɪk mi ɡɪv oʊvɝ."

"I will not. There is nothing you or your stone-faced Warder can do to stop me." Zarine hesitated, then added slowly, as if she had decided to be entirely truthful, "At least, there is nothing that you will do that can stop me. I know a little of Aes Sedai; I know, for all the stories, that there are things you will not do. And I do not believe stone-face would do what he must to make me give over."

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf ə ðət tə ɹɪsk ɪt?" læn spoʊk kwaɪətli, ən ɪz feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt zɑɹin swɑloʊɾ əɡɛn.

"Are you sure enough of that to risk it?" Lan spoke quietly, and his face did not change, but Zarine swallowed again.

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə θɹɛɾən hɝ, læn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə ɹilaɪz i wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wɔɹɾɝ.

"There is no need to threaten her, Lan," Perrin said. He was surprised to realize he was glaring at the Warder.

mɔɪɹeɪnz ɡlæns saɪlənst ɪm ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ boʊθ. "ju bɪliv jə noʊ wʌɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl nɑt du, də ju?" ʃi sɛd mɔɹ sɔfli ðən bɪfɔɹ. hɝ smaɪl wɑz nɑt plɛzənt. "ɪf jə wɪʃ tə ɡoʊ wɪð ʌs, ðɪs ɪz wʌt jə mʌs du." lænz aɪlɪdz flɪkɝɾ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz; ðə tu wɪmən stɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ laɪk fælkən ən maʊs, bʌt zɑɹin wɑz nɑt ðə fælkən, naʊ. "ju wɪl swɛɹ baɪ jəɹ hʌntɝz oʊθ tə də əz aɪ seɪ, tə hid mi, ən nɑt tə liv ʌs. wʌns jə noʊ mɔɹ ðən jə ʃəɾ ʌv wʌt wi du, əl nɑɾ əlaʊ jə tə fɔl ɪndə ðə ɹɔŋ hænz. noʊ ðət fəɹ tʃɹuθ, ɡɝl. jəl swɛɹ tə ækt əz wʌn ʌv ʌs, ən də nʌθɪŋ ðət wɪl ɛndeɪnʒɝ əɹ pɝpəs. jəl æsk noʊ kwɛstʃənz ʌv wɛɹ wi ɡoʊ əɹ waɪ: jəl bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð wʌɾ aɪ tʃuz tə tɛl ju. ɔl ə ðɪs jəl swɛɹ, əɹ jəl ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ ɪn ɪljən. ən jəl nɑt liv ðɪs mɑɹʃ əntɪl aɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ɹilis ju, ɪf ɪt teɪks ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ laɪf. ðəɾ aɪ swɛɹ."

Moiraine's glance silenced him and the Warder both. "You believe you know what an Aes Sedai will not do, do you?" she said more softly than before. Her smile was not pleasant. "If you wish to go with us, this is what you must do." Lan's eyelids flickered in surprise; the two women stared at each other like falcon and mouse, but Zarine was not the falcon, now. "You will swear by your Hunter's oath to do as I say, to heed me, and not to leave us. Once you know more than you should of what we do, I will not allow you to fall into the wrong hands. Know that for truth, girl. You will swear to act as one of us, and do nothing that will endanger our purpose. You will ask no questions of where we go or why: you will be satisfied with what I choose to tell you. All of this you will swear, or you will remain here in Illian. And you will not leave this marsh until I return to release you, if it takes the rest of your life. That I swear."

zɑɹin tɝn əɹ hɛɾ ənizəli, wɑtʃɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn aʊɾ ʌv wʌn aɪ. "aɪ meɪ əkʌmpəni jə ɪf aɪ swɛɹ?" ði ɛɛs sədaɪ nɑɾəd. "aɪ wɪl bi wʌn ə ju, ðə seɪm əz lɔɪəl əɹ stoʊn-feɪs. bʌɾ aɪ kən æsk noʊ kwɛstʃənz. ɑɹ ðeɪ əlaʊd tə æsk kwɛstʃənz?" mɔɪɹeɪnz feɪs lɔst ə lɪɾəl ʌv ɪts peɪʃəns. zɑɹin stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾɝ ən hɛld əɹ hɛd haɪ. "vɛɹi wɛl, ðɛn. aɪ swɛɹ, baɪ ði oʊθ aɪ tʊk əz ə hʌntɝ. ɪf aɪ bɹeɪk wʌn, əl əv bɹoʊkən boʊθ. aɪ swɛɹ ɪt!"

Zarine turned her head uneasily, watching Moiraine out of one eye. "I may accompany you if I swear?" The Aes Sedai nodded. "I will be one of you, the same as Loial or stone-face. But I can ask no questions. Are they allowed to ask questions?" Moiraine's face lost a little of its patience. Zarine stood up straighter and held her head high. "Very well, then. I swear, by the oath I took as a Hunter. If I break one, I will have broken both. I swear it!"

"dʌn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə jʌŋɡɝ wʊmənz fɔɹhɛd; zɑɹin ʃɪvɝd. "sɪns jə bɹɔɾ əɹ tə ʌs, pɛɹɪn, ʃiz jəɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi."

"Done," Moiraine said, touching the younger woman's forehead; Zarine shivered. "Since you brought her to us, Perrin, she is your responsibility."

"maɪn!" hi jɛlpt.

"Mine!" he yelped.

"aɪ æm noʊ wʌnz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi bʌt maɪ oʊn!" zɑɹin nɪɹli ʃaʊɾəd.

"I am no one's responsibility but my own!" Zarine nearly shouted.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn sɝinəli ɑn əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ oʊpən ðɛɹ maʊðz. "ɪt simz juv faʊn mɪnz fælkən, tɑvɝən. aɪ hæv tʃɹaɪd tə dɪskɝɪdʒ hɝ, bʌɾ ɪɾ əpɪɹz ʃɪl pɝtʃ ɑn jəɹ ʃoʊldɝ wʌtɛvɝ aɪ du. ðə pæɾɝn wivz ə fjutʃɝ fəɹ ju, ɪt simz. jɛt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɪs. ɪf aɪ mʌst, əl snɪp jəɹ θɹɛd fɹəm ðə pæɾɝn. ən ɪf ðə ɡɝl ɛndeɪnʒɝz wʌt mʌs bi, jəl ʃɛɹ əɹ feɪt."

The Aes Sedai went serenely on as if they had never opened their mouths. "It seems you have found Min's falcon, ta'veren. I have tried to discourage her, but it appears she will perch on your shoulder whatever I do. The Pattern weaves a future for you, it seems. Yet remember this. If I must, I will snip your thread from the Pattern. And if the girl endangers what must be, you will share her fate."

"aɪ dɪd nɑɾ æsk fəɹ əɹ tə kʌm əlɔŋ!" pɛɹɪn pɹətɛstəd. mɔɪɹeɪn kɑmli maʊntəɾ ɑldib, ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ kloʊk oʊvɝ ðə waɪt mɛɹz sæɾəl. "aɪ dɪd nɑɾ æsk fəɹ hɝ!" lɔɪəl ʃɹʌɡd əɾ ɪm ən saɪlənli maʊð sʌmθɪŋ. noʊ daʊɾ ə seɪɪŋ əbaʊt ðə deɪnʒɝz ʌv æŋɡɝɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"I did not ask for her to come along!" Perrin protested. Moiraine calmly mounted Aldieb, adjusting her cloak over the white mare's saddle. "I did not ask for her!" Loial shrugged at him and silently mouthed something. No doubt a saying about the dangers of angering Aes Sedai.

"ju ɑɹ tɑvɝən?" zɑɹin sɛd dɪsbɪlivɪŋli. hɝ ɡeɪz ɹæn oʊvɝ ɪz stɝɾi kʌntʃɹi kloʊðz ən sɛɾəld ɑn ɪz jɛloʊ aɪz. "wɛl, pɝhæps. wʌtɛvɝ jə ɑɹ, ʃi θɹɛɾənz jə əz izəli əz ʃi dʌz mi. hu ɪz mɪn? wʌt dʌz ʃi min, əl pɝtʃ ɑn jəɹ ʃoʊldɝ?" hɝ feɪs taɪɾənd. "ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ meɪkɪŋ mi jəɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi, əl kɑɹv jəɹ ɪɹz. dʒju hɪɹ mi?"

"You are ta'veren?" Zarine said disbelievingly. Her gaze ran over his sturdy country clothes and settled on his yellow eyes. "Well, perhaps. Whatever you are, she threatens you as easily as she does me. Who is Min? What does she mean, I will perch on your shoulder?" Her face tightened. "If you try making me your responsibility, I will carve your ears. Do you hear me?"

ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, hi slɪpt ɪz ənstʃɹʌŋ baʊ ʌndɝ ðə sæɾəl ɡɝθs əlɔŋ stɛpɝz flæŋk, ən klaɪmd ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. ɹɛstɪv æftɝ deɪz ɑn ðə ʃɪp, ðə dʌn lɪvd ʌp tə hɪz neɪm əntɪl pɛɹɪn kɑmd ɪm wɪð ə fɝm hæn ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz ən pæts tə hɪz nɛk.

Grimacing, he slipped his unstrung bow under the saddle girths along Stepper's flank, and climbed into the saddle. Restive after days on the ship, the dun lived up to his name until Perrin calmed him with a firm hand on the reins and pats to his neck.

"nʌn ə ðət dɪzɝvz ən ænsɝ," hi ɡɹaʊld. mɪn blʌɾi toʊl hɝ! bɝn ju, mɪn! bɝn ju, tu, mɔɪɹeɪn! ən zɑɹin! hi kəd nɛvɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɹænd əɹ mæt biɪŋ bʊlid baɪ wɪmən ɑn ɛvɹi saɪd. əɹ hɪmsɛlf, bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ ɛmənz fild. nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn ði oʊnli wʌn. ən mɪstʃɹəs luhən, ʌv kɔɹs; ʃi ɹæn ɪm ən mæstɝ luhən boʊθ, ɛvɹiwɛɹ bʌɾ ɪn ðə smɪθi. ən ɛɡwin hæd hæɾ ə weɪ əbaʊt hɝ, ðoʊ moʊsli wɪð ɹænd. mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ, ɛɡwinz mʌðɝ, ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə smaɪl, bʌt θɪŋz sim tə ɛn ʌp biɪŋ dʌn əz ʃi wɑntəd, tu. ən ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl hæd lʊkt oʊvɝ ɛvɹibɑɾiz ʃoʊldɝ.

"None of that deserves an answer," he growled. Min bloody told her! Burn you, Min! Burn you, too, Moiraine! And Zarine! He could never remember Rand or Mat being bullied by women on every side. Or himself, before leaving Emond's Field. Nynaeve had been the only one. And Mistress Luhhan, of course; she ran him and Master Luhhan both, everywhere but in the smithy. And Egwene had had a way about her, though mostly with Rand. Mistress al'Vere, Egwene's mother, always had a smile, but things seemed to end up being done as she wanted, too. And the Women's Circle had looked over everybody's shoulder.

ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, hi ɹitʃt daʊn ən tʊk zɑɹin baɪ ən ɑɹm; ʃi ɡeɪv ə skwɔk ən nɪɹli dʒɹɑpt əɹ bʌndəl əz i hɔɪstəɾ əɹ ʌp bɪhaɪn ɪz sæɾəl. ðoʊz dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ə hɝz meɪɾ ɪɾ izi fəɹ əɹ tə stʃɹæɾəl stɛpɝ. "mɔɪɹeɪn wɪl əv tə baɪ jə ə hɔɹs," hi mʌɾɝd. "ju kænɑt wɔk ðə hoʊl weɪ."

Grumbling to himself, he reached down and took Zarine by an arm; she gave a squawk and nearly dropped her bundle as he hoisted her up behind his saddle. Those divided skirts of hers made it easy for her to straddle Stepper. "Moiraine will have to buy you a horse," he muttered. "You cannot walk the whole way."

"ju ɑɹ stʃɹɔŋ, blæksmɪθ," zɑɹin sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm, "bʌɾ aɪm nɑɾ ə pis ʌv aɪɝn." ʃi ʃɪftəɾ ɝaʊnd, stʌfɪŋ əɹ bʌndəl ən əɹ kloʊk bɪtwin ðɛm. "aɪ kən baɪ maɪ oʊn hɔɹs, ɪf aɪ nid wʌn. ðə hoʊl weɪ wɛɹ?"

"You are strong, blacksmith," Zarine said, rubbing her arm, "but I am not a piece of iron." She shifted around, stuffing her bundle and her cloak between them. "I can buy my own horse, if I need one. The whole way where?"

læn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɔf ðə dɑk ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn ən lɔɪəl bɪhaɪn hɪm. ði oʊɡiɝ lʊk bæk ət pɛɹɪn.

Lan was already riding off the dock into the city, with Moiraine and Loial behind him. The Ogier looked back at Perrin.

"noʊ kwɛstʃənz, ɹɪmɛmbɝ? ən maɪ neɪm ɪz pɛɹɪn, zɑɹin. nɑt 'bɪɡ mæn,' əɹ 'blæksmɪθ,' əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. pɛɹɪn. pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə."

"No questions, remember? And my name is Perrin, Zarine. Not 'big man,' or 'blacksmith,' or anything else. Perrin. Perrin Aybara."

"æn maɪn ɪz feɪl, ʃæɡi-hɛɹ."

"And mine is Faile, shaggy-hair."

wɪð sʌmθɪŋ kloʊs tə ə snɑɹl, hi buɾɪd stɛpɝ æftɝ ði ʌðɝz. zɑɹin hæd tə θɹoʊ hɝ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ɪz weɪs tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ tɔst oʊvɝ ðə dʌnz kɹʌpɝ. hi θɔt ʃi wɑz læfɪŋ.

With something close to a snarl, he booted Stepper after the others. Zarine had to throw her arms around his waist to keep from being tossed over the dun's crupper. He thought she was laughing.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾitu


CHAPTER 42

izɪŋ ðə bædʒɝ


Easing the Badger

ðə hʌbəb ə ðə sɪɾi kwɪkli səbmɝdʒ zɑɹinz læftɝ - ɪf ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɪt wɑz - bɪniθ ɔl ðə klæmɝ ðət pɛɹɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn ən kɛɹhin. ðə saʊnz wɝ dɪfɹən hɪɹ, sloʊɝ, ən pɪtʃt dɪfɹənli, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ðə seɪm, tu. buts ən wilz ən hʊvz ɑn ɹʌf, ənivən peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, kɑɹɾ ən wæɡən æksəlz skwilɪŋ, mjuzɪk ən sɔŋ ən læftɝ dʒɹɪftɪŋ fɹəm ɪnz ən tævɝnz. vɔɪsəz. ə hʌm ə vɔɪsəz laɪk pʊɾɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɪndə ə dʒaɪən bihaɪv. ə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi, lɪvɪŋ.

The hubbub of the city quickly submerged Zarine's laughter - if that was what it was - beneath all the clamor that Perrin remembered from Caemlyn and Cairhien. The sounds were different here, slower, and pitched differently, but they were the same, too. Boots and wheels and hooves on rough, uneven paving stones, cart and wagon axles squealing, music and song and laughter drifting from inns and taverns. Voices. A hum of voices like putting his head into a giant beehive. A great city, living.

fɹəm daʊn ə saɪd stʃɹiɾ i hɝd ðə klæŋ ə hæmɝ ɑn ænvəl, ən ʃɪftəɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ʌnkɑnʃəsli. hi mɪs ðə hæmɝ ən tɑŋz ɪn ɪz hænz, ðə waɪt-hɑt mɛɾəl ɡɪvɪŋ ɔf spɑɹks əz ɪz bloʊz ʃeɪpt ɪt. ðə smɪθi saʊnz feɪɾəd bɪhaɪnd, bɛɹiɾ ʌndɝ ðə ɹʌmbəl ə kɑɹts ən wæɡənz, ən ðə bæbəl ə ʃɑpkipɝz ən pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹits. ʌndɝ ɔl ðə smɛlz ə pipəl ən hɔɹsəz, kʊkɪŋ ən beɪkɪŋ, ən ə hʌnʒɹəd sɛns i hæd faʊn pəkjuljɝ tə sɪɾiz leɪ ðə smɛl ə mɑɹʃ ən sɔlt wɔɾɝ.

From down a side street he heard the clang of hammer on anvil, and shifted his shoulders unconsciously. He missed the hammer and tongs in his hands, the white-hot metal giving off sparks as his blows shaped it. The smithy sounds faded behind, buried under the rumble of carts and wagons, and the babble of shopkeepers and people in the streets. Under all the smells of people and horses, cooking and baking, and a hundred scents he had found peculiar to cities lay the smell of marsh and salt water.

hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz ðə fɝs taɪm ðeɪ keɪm tə ə bɹɪdʒ ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi - ə loʊ ɑɹtʃ ə stoʊn oʊvɝ ə wɔɾɝweɪ noʊ mɔɹ ðən θɝɾi peɪsɪz əkɹɔs - bʌt baɪ ðə θɝd sətʃ bɹɪdʒ, hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪljən wɑz kɹɪskɹɔs baɪ əz mɛni kənælz əz stʃɹits, wɪð mɛn poʊlɪŋ leɪɾən bɑɹdʒəz əz ɔfən əz plaɪɪŋ wɪps tə muv hɛvi wæɡənz. sɪdæn tʃɛɹz woʊv θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz ɪn ðə stʃɹits, ən əkeɪʒənəli ðə lækɝd koʊtʃ ə səm wɛlθi mɝtʃən əɹ ə noʊbəl, wɪð kɹɛst əɹ haʊs saɪn peɪntəd lɑɹdʒ ɑn ðə dɔɹz. mɛni ʌv ðə mɛn wɔɹ pəkjuljɝ bɪɹdz ðət lɛf ðɛɹ ʌpɝ lɪp bɛɹ, waɪl ðə wɪmən sim tə feɪvɝ hæts wɪð waɪd bɹɪmz ən ətætʃt skɑɹvz ðət ðeɪ waʊn ɝaʊn ðɛɹ nɛks.

He was surprised the first time they came to a bridge inside the city - a low arch of stone over a waterway no more than thirty paces across - but by the third such bridge, he realized that Illian was crisscrossed by as many canals as streets, with men poling laden barges as often as plying whips to move heavy wagons. Sedan chairs wove through the crowds in the streets, and occasionally the lacquered coach of some wealthy merchant or a noble, with crest or House sign painted large on the doors. Many of the men wore peculiar beards that left their upper lip bare, while the women seemed to favor hats with wide brims and attached scarves that they wound around their necks.

wʌns ðeɪ kɹɔst ə ɡɹeɪt skwɛɹ, mɛni haɪdz ɪn ɪkstɛnt, sɝaʊndəd baɪ hjudʒ kɑləmz ʌv waɪt mɑɹbəl ət lis fɪftin spænz tɔl ən tu spænz θɪk, səpɔɹɾɪŋ nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ə ɹiθ ə kɑɹvd ɑləv bɹæntʃəz ət ðə tɑp ʌv itʃ. ə hjudʒ, waɪt pæləs stʊɾ əɾ iðɝ ɛn ə ðə skwɛɹ, itʃ ɔl kɑləmd wɔks ən ɛɹi bælkəniz, slɛndɝ taʊɝz ən pɝpəl ɹufs. itʃ ɹəflɛktəd ði ʌðɝ ɪɡzækli, ət fɝst ɡlæns, bʌt ðən pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪz ðət wʌn wɑz dʒʌst ə fɹækʃən smɔlɝ ɪn itʃ dɪmɛnʃən, ɪts taʊɝz pɝhæps lɛs ðən ə peɪs ʃɔɹɾɝ.

Once they crossed a great square, many hides in extent, surrounded by huge columns of white marble at least fifteen spans tall and two spans thick, supporting nothing but a wreath of carved olive branches at the top of each. A huge, white palace stood at either end of the square, each all columned walks and airy balconies, slender towers and purple roofs. Each reflected the other exactly, at first glance, but then Perrin realized that one was just a fraction smaller in each dimension, its towers perhaps less than a pace shorter.

"ðə kɪŋz pæləs," zɑɹin sɛɾ əɡɛnst ɪz bæk, "æn ðə ɡɹeɪt hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəl. ɪts sɛd ðə fɝs kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən sɛd ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn kəɾ əv ɛni pæləs ðeɪ wɪʃt, dʒʌst əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə bɪld wʌn lɑɹdʒɝ ðən hɪz. soʊ ðə kaʊnsəl kɑpid ðə kɪŋz pæləs ɪɡzækli, bʌt tu fit smɔlɝ ɪn ɛvɹi mɛʒɝmənt. ðəɾ əz bɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ɪljən ɛvɝ sɪns. ðə kɪŋ ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn duəl wɪð itʃ ʌðɝ, ən ði əsɛmblədʒ stʃɹʌɡəlz wɪð boʊθ, ən soʊ waɪl ðeɪ kæɹi ɑn ðɛɹ bæɾəlz, ðə pipəl laɪv mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ wɪʃ, wɪð nʌn tə lʊk oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz tu mʌtʃ. ɪts nɑɾ ə bæd weɪ tə lɪv, ɪf jə mʌs bi taɪd tə wʌn sɪɾi. jə wəɾ ɔlsoʊ laɪk tə noʊ, aɪ θɪŋk, blæksmɪθ, ðət ðɪs ɪz ðə skwɛɹ ə tæməz, wɛɹ aɪ tʊk ðə hʌntɝz oʊθ. aɪ θɪŋk əl ɛn ʌp titʃɪŋ jə soʊ mʌtʃ, noʊ wʌn wɪl noʊɾəs ðə heɪ ɪn jəɹ hɛɹ."

"The King's Palace," Zarine said against his back, "and the Great Hall of the Council. It is said the first King of Illian said the Council of Nine could have any palace they wished, just as long as they did not try to build one larger than his. So the Council copied the King's palace exactly, but two feet smaller in every measurement. That has been the way of Illian ever since. The King and the Council of Nine duel with each other, and the Assemblage struggles with both, and so while they carry on their battles, the people live much as they wish, with none to look over their shoulders too much. It is not a bad way to live, if you must be tied to one city. You would also like to know, I think, blacksmith, that this is the Square of Tammaz, where I took the Hunter's Oath. I think I will end up teaching you so much, no one will notice the hay in your hair."

pɛɹɪn hɛld ɪz tʌŋ wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ɹizɑlvɪŋ nɑt tə stɛɹ soʊ oʊpənli əɡɛn.

Perrin held his tongue with an effort, resolving not to stare so openly again.

noʊ wʌn sim tə teɪk lɔɪəl əz ɛniθɪŋ mʌtʃ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi. ə fju pipəl lʊkt əɾ ɪm twaɪs, ən səm smɔl tʃɪlʒɹən skæmpɝɾ əlɔŋ ɪn ðɛɹ weɪk fəɹ ə taɪm, bʌɾ ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðəɾ oʊɡiɝ wɝ nɑɾ ənnoʊn ɪn ɪljən. nʌn ə ðə foʊk sim tə noʊɾəs ðə hiɾ əɹ ðə dæmp, iðɝ.

No one seemed to take Loial as anything much out of the ordinary. A few people looked at him twice, and some small children scampered along in their wake for a time, but it appeared that Ogier were not unknown in Illian. None of the folk seemed to notice the heat or the damp, either.

fəɹ wʌns, lɔɪəl dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ plizd wɪð ðə pipəlz æksɛptəns. hɪz lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹup daʊn ɑn ɪz tʃiks, ən ɪz ɪɹz hæd wɪltɪd, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðət wɑz nɑt dʒʌs ði ɛɹ. hɪz oʊn ʃɝt klʌŋ tə hɪm wɪð ə mɪkstʃɝ ə swɛɾ ən ðə dæmp ɛɹ.

For once, Loial did not appear pleased with the people's acceptance. His long eyebrows drooped down on his cheeks, and his ears had wilted, though Perrin was not sure that was not just the air. His own shirt clung to him with a mixture of sweat and the damp air.

"ɑɹ jə əfɹeɪd jəl faɪn ʌðɝ oʊɡiɝ hɪɹ, lɔɪəl?" hi æskt. hi fɛl zɑɹin stɝ əɡɛnst ɪz bæk ən kɝst ɪz tʌŋ. hi mɛn tə lɛt ðə wʊmən noʊ ivən lɛs ðən mɔɪɹeɪn əpɛɹənli mɛn tə tɛl hɝ. ðət weɪ, pɝhæps, ʃi wəd ɡɹoʊ bɔɹɾ ɪnʌf tə liv. ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn wɪl lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ, naʊ. bɝn mi, aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛni blʌɾi fælkən pɝtʃt ɑn maɪ ʃoʊldɝ, ivən ɪf ʃiz pɹɪɾi.

"Are you afraid you'll find other Ogier here, Loial?" he asked. He felt Zarine stir against his back and cursed his tongue. He meant to let the woman know even less than Moiraine apparently meant to tell her. That way, perhaps, she would grow bored enough to leave. If Moiraine will let her go, now. Burn me, I don't want any bloody falcon perched on my shoulder, even if she is pretty.

lɔɪəl nɑɾəd. "aʊɝ stoʊnmeɪsɑnz səmtaɪmz kʌm hɪɹ." hi spoʊk ɪn ə wɪspɝ nɑɾ oʊnli fəɹ ən oʊɡiɝ, bʌt fəɹ ɛniwʌn. ivən pɛɹɪn kəd bɛɹli hɪɹ. "fɹʌm stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ, aɪ min. ɪt wɑz meɪsənz fɹəm əɹ stɛɾɪŋ u bɪl pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪljən - ðə pæləs ə ði əsɛmblədʒ, ðə ɡɹeɪt hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəl, səm ə ði ʌðɝz - ən ðeɪ ɔlweɪz sɛn tə əs wən ɹɪpɛɹz nid tə bi dʌn. pɛɹɪn, ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ oʊɡiɝ hɪɹ, ðəl meɪk mi ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə stɛɾɪŋ. aɪ ʃʊɾə θɔɾ ʌv ɪt bɪfɔɹ naʊ. ðɪs pleɪs meɪks mi ənizi, pɛɹɪn." hɪz ɪɹz ʃɪftəd nɝvəsli.

Loial nodded. "Our stonemasons sometimes come here." He spoke in a whisper not only for an Ogier, but for anyone. Even Perrin could barely hear. "From Stedding Shangtai, I mean. It was masons from our stedding who built part of Illian - the Palace of the Assemblage, the Great Hall of the Council, some of the others - and they always send to us when repairs need to be done.
