Perrin, if there are Ogier here, they will make me go back to the stedding. I should have thought of it before now. This place makes me uneasy, Perrin." His ears shifted nervously.

pɛɹɪn muv stɛpɝ kloʊsɝ ən ɹitʃt ʌp tə pæt lɔɪəlz ʃoʊldɝ. ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ ɹitʃ, əbʌv ɪz hɛd. kɑnʃəs ə zɑɹin əɾ ɪz bæk, hi tʃoʊz ɪz wɝdz kɛɹfəli. "lɔɪəl, aɪ də nɑt bɪliv mɔɪɹeɪn wəd lɛɾ əm teɪk ju. juv bɪn wɪð əs ə lɔŋ taɪm, ən ʃi simz tə wɑn jə wɪð ʌs. ʃɪl nɑt lɛɾ əm teɪk ju, lɔɪəl." waɪ nɑt? hi wʌndɝd sʌɾənli. ʃi kips mi kəz ʃi θɪŋks aɪ meɪ bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə ɹænd, ən meɪbi kəz ʃi dʌznt wɑn mi tɛlɪŋ wʌɾ aɪ noʊ tə ɛniwʌn. meɪbi ðæts waɪ ʃi wɑns ɪm tə steɪ.

Perrin moved Stepper closer and reached up to pat Loial's shoulder. It was a long reach, above his head. Conscious of Zarine at his back, he chose his words carefully. "Loial, I do not believe Moiraine would let them take you. You have been with us a long time, and she seems to want you with us. She will not let them take you, Loial." Why not? he wondered suddenly. She keeps me because she thinks I may be important to Rand, and maybe because she doesn't want me telling what I know to anyone. Maybe that's why she wants him to stay.

"ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi wəd nɑt," lɔɪəl sɛɾ ɪn ə slaɪtli stʃɹɔŋɝ vɔɪs, ən ɪz ɪɹz pɝkt ʌp. "aɪ æm vɛɹi jusfəl, æftɝ ɔl. ʃi meɪ nid tə tʃɹævəl ðə weɪz əɡɛn, ən ʃi kəd nɑt wɪθaʊt mi." zɑɹin ʃɪftəɾ əɡɛns pɛɹɪnz bæk, ən i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ lɔɪəlz aɪ. bʌt lɔɪəl wɑz nɑt lʊkɪŋ. hi sim tə hæv dʒʌs hɝd wʌɾ i hæd sɛd, ən ðə tʌfs ɑn ɪz ɪɹz hæd fɔlən ə lɪɾəl. "aɪ də hoʊp ɪts nɑt ðæt, pɛɹɪn." ði oʊɡiɝ lʊkt ət ðə sɪɾi ɝaʊn ðɛm, ən ɪz ɪɹz wɛn ɔl ðə weɪ bæk daʊn. "aɪ də nɑt laɪk ðɪs pleɪs, pɛɹɪn."

"Of course, she would not," Loial said in a slightly stronger voice, and his ears perked up. "I am very useful, after all. She may need to travel the Ways again, and she could not without me." Zarine shifted against Perrin's back, and he shook his head, trying to catch Loial's eye. But Loial was not looking. He seemed to have just heard what he had said, and the tufts on his ears had fallen a little. "I do hope it's not that, Perrin." The Ogier looked at the city around them, and his ears went all the way back down. "I do not like this place, Perrin."

mɔɪɹeɪn ɹoʊd kloʊsɝ tə læn ən spoʊk sɔfli, bʌt pɛɹɪn mænədʒ tə kætʃ əɹ wɝdz. "sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɹɔŋ ɪn ðɪs sɪɾi." ðə wɔɹɾɝ nɑɾəd.

Moiraine rode closer to Lan and spoke softly, but Perrin managed to catch her words. "Something is wrong in this city." The Warder nodded.

pɛɹɪn fɛlt ən ɪtʃ bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd saʊndəd ɡɹɪm. fɝs lɔɪəl, ən naʊ hɝ. wʌt doʊn aɪ si? ðə sʌn ʃoʊn daʊn ɑn ðə spɑɹklɪŋ ɹuf taɪlz, meɪd ɹɪflɛkʃənz fɹəm peɪl stoʊn wɔlz. ðoʊz bɪldɪŋz lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ maɪt bi kul, ɪnsaɪd. ðə bɪldɪŋz wɝ klin ən bɹaɪt, ən soʊ wɝ ðə pipəl. ðə pipəl.

Perrin felt an itch between his shoulders. The Aes Sedai had sounded grim. First Loial, and now her. What don't I see? The sun shone down on the sparkling roof tiles, made reflections from pale stone walls. Those buildings looked as if they might be cool, inside. The buildings were clean and bright, and so were the people. The people.

ət fɝst i sɔ nʌθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi. mɛn ən wɪmən muvɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs, pɝpəsfəl, bʌt sloʊɝ ðən i wɑz juz tə fɝðɝ nɔɹθ. hi θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi ðə hit, ən ðə bɹaɪt sʌn. ðən i spɑɾəd ə beɪkɝz læd tʃɹɑɾɪŋ daʊn ðə stʃɹit wɪð ə bɪɡ tʃɹeɪ ʌv fɹɛʃ loʊvz bælənst ɑn ɪz hɛd; ðə jʌŋ fɛloʊ wɔɹ ə ɡɹɪmɑs ɑn ɪz feɪs ðət wɑz nɪɹli ə snɑɹl. ə wʊmən ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə wivɝz ʃɑp lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi maɪt baɪt ðə mæn hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ðə bɹaɪt-kʌlɝd boʊls fəɹ əɹ ɪnspɛkʃən. ə dʒʌɡəlɝ ɑn ə kɔɹnɝ ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ ən stɛɹɾ ət ðə foʊk u tɔs kɔɪnz ɪndə ðə kæp laɪɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm əz ɪf i heɪɾəd ðɛm. nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn lʊk soʊ, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə hɪm ðəɾ ət list wʌn feɪs ɪn faɪv wɔɹ æŋɡɝ ən heɪtʃɹəd. ən i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝ ivən əwɛɹ ʌv ɪt.

At first he saw nothing out of the ordinary. Men and women moving about their business, purposeful, but slower than he was used to further north. He thought it might be the heat, and the bright sun. Then he spotted a baker's lad trotting down the street with a big tray of fresh loaves balanced on his head; the young fellow wore a grimace on his face that was nearly a snarl. A woman in front of a weaver's shop looked as if she might bite the man holding up the bright-colored bolts for her inspection. A juggler on a corner ground his teeth and stared at the folk who tossed coins into the cap lying in front of him as if he hated them. Not everyone looked so, but it seemed to him that at least one face in five wore anger and hatred. And he did not think they were even aware of it.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ?" zɑɹin æskt. "ju ɑɹ tɛnsɪŋ. ɪts laɪk hoʊldɪŋ ɑn tə ə ɹɑk."

"What is the matter?" Zarine asked. "You are tensing. It is like holding on to a rock."

"sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɹɔŋ," hi toʊl hɝ. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌt, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɹɔŋ." lɔɪəl nɑɾəd sædli, ən mɝmɝɾ əbaʊt haʊ ðeɪ wəd meɪk ɪm ɡoʊ bæk.

"Something is wrong," he told her. "I do not know what, but something is wrong." Loial nodded sadly, and murmured about how they would make him go back.

ðə bɪldɪŋz ɝaʊn əm bɪɡæn tə tʃeɪnʒ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd, kɹɔsɪŋ mɔɹ bɹɪdʒəz əz ðeɪ kɹɔst ɪljən tə ɪts ʌðɝ saɪd. ðə peɪl stoʊn wɑz əz ɔfən ənʒɹəst əz pɑlɪʃt, naʊ. ðə taʊɝz ən pæləsəz vænɪʃt, tə bi ɹipleɪs baɪ ɪnz ən wɛɹhaʊzɪz. mɛni ʌv ðə mɛn ɪn ðə stʃɹits, ən səm ə ðə wɪmən, hæɾ ən ɑdli ɹoʊlɪŋ ɡeɪt; ðeɪ ɔl hæd ðə bɛɹ fiɾ i əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð seɪlɝz. ðə smɛlz ə pɪtʃ ən hɛmp wɝ stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən ðə sɛn ʌv wʊd, boʊθ fɹɛʃli kʌɾ ən kjʊɹd, wɪð saʊɝ mʌɾ oʊvɝlaɪɪŋ boʊθ. ðə kənælz' oʊɾɝz tʃeɪnʒd, tu, meɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊz ɹɪŋkəl. tʃeɪmbɝ pɑts, hi θɔt. tʃeɪmbɝ pɑts ən oʊl pɹaɪviz. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm fil kwizi.

The buildings around them began to change as they rode, crossing more bridges as they crossed Illian to its other side. The pale stone was as often undressed as polished, now. The towers and palaces vanished, to be replaced by inns and warehouses. Many of the men in the streets, and some of the women, had an oddly rolling gait; they all had the bare feet he associated with sailors. The smells of pitch and hemp were strong in the air, and the scent of wood, both freshly cut and cured, with sour mud overlying both. The canals' odors changed, too, making his nose wrinkle. Chamber pots, he thought. Chamber pots and old privies. It made him feel queasy.

"ðə bɹɪdʒ ə flaʊɝz," læn ənaʊnst əz ðeɪ kɹɔs jɛɾ ənʌðɝ loʊ bɹɪdʒ. hi ɪnheɪl dipli. "ænd naʊ wəɹ ɪn ðə pɝfjum kɔɹɾɝ. ði ɪliɑnɝz ɑɹ ə poʊɛɾɪk pipəl."

"The Bridge of Flowers," Lan announced as they crossed yet another low bridge. He inhaled deeply. "And now we are in the Perfumed Quarter. The Illianers are a poetic people."

zɑɹin staɪfəld ə læf əɡɛns pɛɹɪnz bæk.

Zarine stifled a laugh against Perrin's back.

əz ɪf i wɝ sʌɾənli ɪmpeɪʃənt wɪð ðə sloʊ peɪs ʌv ɪljən, ðə wɔɹɾɝ lɛɾ əm kwɪkli θɹu ðə stʃɹits tə ən ɪn, tu stɔɹiz ə ɹʌf, ɡɹin-veɪn stoʊn tɑpt wɪð peɪl ɡɹin taɪlz. ivnɪŋ wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɑn, ðə laɪt ɡɹoʊɪŋ sɑftɝ əz ðə sʌn sɛɾəld. ɪt ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl ɹɪlif fɹəm ðə hit, bʌt nɑt mʌtʃ. bɔɪz siɾəd ɑn maʊntɪŋ blɑks ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɪn hɑpt ʌp tə teɪk ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. wʌn blæk-hɛɹd læɾ əbaʊt tɛn æsk lɔɪəl ɪf i wɝ ən oʊɡiɝ, ən wən lɔɪəl sɛɾ i wɑz, ðə bɔɪ sɛd, "aɪ dɪd θɪŋk jə dɪd bi," wɪð ə sɛlf-sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd. hi lɛd lɔɪəlz bɪɡ hɔɹs əweɪ, tɔsɪŋ ðə kɑpɝ lɔɪəl hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ɪndə ði ɛɹ ən kætʃɪŋ ɪt.

As if he were suddenly impatient with the slow pace of Illian, the Warder led them quickly through the streets to an inn, two stories of rough, green-veined stone topped with pale green tiles. Evening was coming on, the light growing softer as the sun settled. It gave a little relief from the heat, but not much. Boys seated on mounting blocks in front of the inn hopped up to take their horses. One black-haired lad about ten asked Loial if he were an Ogier, and when Loial said he was, the boy said, "I did think you did be," with a self-satisfied nod. He led Loial's big horse away, tossing the copper Loial had given him into the air and catching it.

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊn ʌp ət ði ɪn saɪn fəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ ði ʌðɝz ɪn. ə waɪt-stʃɹaɪp bædʒɝ dænst ɑn ɪts haɪn lɛɡz wɪð ə mæn kæɹiɪŋ wʌt sim tə bi ə sɪlvɝ ʃʌvəl. izɪŋ ðə bædʒɝ, ɪt ɹɛd. ɪt mʌs bi səm stɔɹi aɪ nɛvɝ hɝd.

Perrin frowned up at the inn sign for a moment before following the others in. A white-striped badger danced on its hind legs with a man carrying what seemed to be a silver shovel. Easing the Badger, it read. It must be some story I never heard.

ðə kɑmən ɹum hæd sɔdʌst ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ən təbæk smoʊk fɪl ði ɛɹ. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ smɛld ʌv waɪn, ən fɪʃ kʊkɪŋ ɪn ðə kɪtʃən, ən ə hɛvi, flaʊɝd pɝfjum. ði ɪkspoʊz bimz ə ðə haɪ silɪŋ wɝ ɹʌf-hjun ən eɪdʒ-dɑɹk. ðɪs ɝli ɪn ði ivnɪŋ, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə kɔɹɾɝ ə ðə stulz ən bɛntʃɪz wɝ fɪld, baɪ mɛn ɪn wɝkmɪnz pleɪn koʊts ən vɛsts, səm wɪð ðə bɛɹ fiɾ ə seɪlɝz. ɔl ə ðɛm sæt klʌstɝɾ əz kloʊs əz ðeɪ kəd mænədʒ ɝaʊnd wʌn teɪbəl wɛɹ ə pɹɪɾi, dɑɹk-aɪd ɡɝl, ðə wɛɹɝ ə ðə pɝfjum, sæŋ tə ðə stʃɹʌmɪŋ ʌv ə twɛlv-stʃɹɪŋ bɪɾɝn ən dænst ɑn ðə teɪbəltɑp wɪð swɝlz ə hɝ skɝt. hɝ lus, waɪt blaʊs hæɾ ən ɪkstʃɹimli loʊ nɛk. pɛɹɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə tun - "ðə dænsɪŋ læs" - bʌt ðə wɝdz ðə ɡɝl sæŋ wɝ dɪfɹən fɹəm wʌɾ i nu.

The common room had sawdust on the floor, and tabac smoke filled the air. It also smelled of wine, and fish cooking in the kitchen, and a heavy, flowered perfume. The exposed beams of the high ceiling were rough-hewn and age-dark. This early in the evening, no more than a quarter of the stools and benches were filled, by men in workmen's plain coats and vests, some with the bare feet of sailors. All of them sat clustered as close as they could manage around one table where a pretty, dark-eyed girl, the wearer of the perfume, sang to the strumming of a twelve-string bittern and danced on the tabletop with swirls of her skirt. Her loose, white blouse had an extremely low neck. Perrin recognized the tune - "The Dancing Lass" - but the words the girl sang were different from what he knew.

"eɪ luɡɹd ɡɝl, ʃi keɪm tə taʊn, tə si wʌt ʃi kəd si.

"A Lugard girl, she came to town, to see what she could see.

wɪð ə wɪŋk ə hɝ aɪ, ən ə smaɪl ɑn əɹ lɪp, ʃi snæɡd ə bɔɪ əɹ θɹi, əɹ θɹi.

With a wink of her eye, and a smile on her lip, she snagged a boy or three, or three.

wɪð ən æŋkəl slɪm, ən skɪn soʊ peɪl, ʃi kɑt ði oʊnɝ ʌv ə ʃɪp, ə ʃɪp.

With an ankle slim, and skin so pale, she caught the owner of a ship, a ship.

wɪð ə sɑf lɪɾəl saɪ, ən ə ɡeɪ lɪɾəl læf, ʃi meɪɾ əɹ weɪ soʊ fɹi. soʊ fɹi."

With a soft little sigh, and a gay little laugh, she made her way so free. So free."

ʃi lɔntʃt ɪndə ənʌðɝ vɝs, ən wən pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪzd wʌt ʃi wɑz sɪŋɪŋ, hɪz feɪs ɡɹu hɑt. hi hæd θɔt nʌθɪŋ kəd ʃɑk ɪm æftɝ siɪŋ tɪŋkɝ ɡɝlz dæns, bʌt ðət hæɾ oʊnli hɪntəɾ ət θɪŋz. ðɪs ɡɝl wɑz sɪŋɪŋ əm ɹaɪɾ aʊt.

She launched into another verse, and when Perrin realized what she was singing, his face grew hot. He had thought nothing could shock him after seeing Tinker girls dance, but that had only hinted at things. This girl was singing them right out.

zɑɹin wɑz nɑɾɪŋ ɪn taɪm tə ðə mjuzɪk ən ɡɹɪnɪŋ. hɝ ɡɹɪn waɪɾənd wən ʃi lʊkt ət hɪm. "waɪ, fɑɹmbɔɪ, aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk aɪ ɛvɝ nu ə mæn jəɹ eɪdʒ u kəd stɪl blʌʃ."

Zarine was nodding in time to the music and grinning. Her grin widened when she looked at him. "Why, farmboy, I do not think I ever knew a man your age who could still blush."

hi ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ ən bɛɹli stɑp hɪmsɛlf fɹəm seɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ i nu wəd bi stupəd. ðɪs blʌɾi wʊmən əz mi dʒʌmpɪŋ bɪfɔɹ aɪ kən θɪŋk. laɪt, əl weɪdʒɝ ʃi θɪŋks aɪ nɛvɝ ivən kɪst ə ɡɝl! hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lɪsən tə ɛni mɔɹ ʌv wʌt ðə ɡɝl wɑz sɪŋɪŋ. ɪf i kəd nɑt ɡɛt ðə ɹɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz feɪs, zɑɹin wɑz ʃʊɹ tə meɪk mɔɹ ʌv ɪt.

He glared at her and barely stopped himself from saying something he knew would be stupid. This bloody woman has me jumping before I can think. Light, I'll wager she thinks I never even kissed a girl! He tried not to listen to any more of what the girl was singing. If he could not get the red out of his face, Zarine was sure to make more of it.

ə flæʃ ə stɑɹɾəlmənt hæd pæst əkɹɔs ðə feɪs ə ðə pɹəpɹaɪətʃɹəs wən ðeɪ ɛntɝd. ə lɑɹdʒ, ɹaʊnd wʊmən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ə θɪk ɹoʊl ət ðə bæk ə hɝ nɛk ən ə smɛl ə stʃɹɔŋ soʊp əbaʊt hɝ, ʃi səpɹɛst əɹ sɝpɹaɪz kwɪkli, ðoʊ, ən hɝid tə mɔɪɹeɪn.

A flash of startlement had passed across the face of the proprietress when they entered. A large, round woman with her hair in a thick roll at the back of her neck and a smell of strong soap about her, she suppressed her surprise quickly, though, and hurried to Moiraine.

"mɪstʃɹəs mɑɹi," ʃi sɛd, "aɪ dɪd nɛvɝ θɪŋk tə si jə hɪɹ tədeɪ." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, aɪɪŋ pɛɹɪn ən zɑɹin, ɡlænst wʌns ət lɔɪəl, bʌt nɑɾ ɪn ðə sɝtʃɪŋ weɪ ʃi lʊkt ət ðɛm. hɝ aɪz æktʃəli  bɹaɪɾənd ət ðə saɪɾ ə ði oʊɡiɝ, bʌɾ əɹ ɹil ətɛnʃən wɑz ɔl ɑn "mɪstʃɹəs mɑɹi." ʃi loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs, "hæv maɪ pɪdʒənz noʊ ɝaɪv seɪfli?" læn, ʃi sim tə æksɛpt əz ə pɑɹɾ ə mɔɪɹeɪn.

"Mistress Mari," she said, "I did never think to see you here today." She hesitated, eyeing Perrin and Zarine, glanced once at Loial, but not in the searching way she looked at them. Her eyes actually brightened at the sight of the Ogier, but her real attention was all on "Mistress Mari." She lowered her voice, "Have my pigeons no arrived safely?" Lan, she seemed to accept as a part of Moiraine.

"aɪ æm ʃʊɹ ðeɪ hæv, niɾə," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "aɪ hæv bɪn əweɪ, bʌɾ aɪm ʃʊɹ ɑdini hæz noʊɾəd daʊn ɛvɹiθɪŋ jə ɹipɔɹɾəd." ʃi aɪd ðə ɡɝl sɪŋɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɪð noʊ aʊtwɝd dɪsəpɹuvəl, nɔɹ ɛni ʌðɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən. "ðə bædʒɝ wɑz kənsɪɾɝəbli kwaɪəɾɝ wən læst aɪ wɑz hɪɹ."

"I am sure they have, Nieda," Moiraine said. "I have been away, but I am sure Adine has noted down everything you reported." She eyed the girl singing on the table with no outward disapproval, nor any other expression. "The Badger was considerably quieter when last I was here."

"aɪ, mɪstʃɹəs mɑɹi, ɪt dɪd bi ðæt. bʌt ðə laʊts əv noʊ ɡɑɾən oʊvɝ ðə wɪntɝ jɛt, ɪt dʌz sim. aɪ hæv noʊ hæɾ ə faɪɾ ɪn ðə bædʒɝ ɪn tɛn jɪɹz, tɪl ðə teɪl ə ðɪs wɪntɝ ɡɔn." ʃi nɑɾəd təwɔɹd ðə wʌn mæn nɑt sɪɾɪŋ nɪɹ ðə sɪŋɝ, ə fɛloʊ ivən bɪɡɝ ðən pɛɹɪn, stændɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl wɪð ɪz θɪk ɑɹmz foʊldəd, tæpɪŋ ɪz fʊt tə ðə mjuzɪk. "ivən bili dɪɾ əv ə hɑɹd taɪm kipɪŋ əm daʊn, soʊ aɪ dɪd haɪɝ ðə ɡɝl tə teɪk ðɛɹ maɪnz fɹəm æŋɡɝ. fɹəm səm pleɪs ɪn ɔltɑɹə, ʃi dʌz kʌm." ʃi tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛd, lɪsnɪŋ fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "ə fɛɹ vɔɪs, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd sɪŋ ɪt bɛɾɝ - aɪ, ən dæns bɛɾɝ, tu - wən aɪ dɪd bi hɝ eɪdʒ."

"Aye, Mistress Mari, it did be that. But the louts have no gotten over the winter yet, it does seem. I have no had a fight in the Badger in ten years, till the tail of this winter gone." She nodded toward the one man not sitting near the singer, a fellow even bigger than Perrin, standing against the wall with his thick arms folded, tapping his foot to the music. "Even Bili did have a hard time keeping them down, so I did hire the girl to take their minds from anger. From some place in Altara, she does come." She tilted her head, listening for a moment. "A fair voice, but I did sing it better - aye, and dance better, too - when I did be her age."

pɛɹɪn ɡeɪpt ət ðə θɔɾ ə ðɪs hjudʒ wʊmən keɪpɝɪŋ ɑn ə teɪbəl, sɪŋɪŋ ðət sɔŋ - ə bɪɾ ʌv ɪt keɪm θɹu; "aɪl wɛɹ noʊ ʃɪft əɾ ɔl. əɾ ɔl" - əntɪl zɑɹin fɪstɪɾ ɪm hɑɹɾ ɪn ðə ʃɔɹt ɹɪbz. hi ɡɹʌntɪd.

Perrin gaped at the thought of this huge woman capering on a table, singing that song - a bit of it came through; "I'll wear no shift at all. At all" - until Zarine fisted him hard in the short ribs. He grunted.

niɾə lʊkt ɪz weɪ. "aɪl mɪks jə səm hʌni ən sʌlfɝ, læd, fəɹ ðət θɹoʊt. jəl noʊ wɑnə teɪk ə tʃɪl bɪfɔɹ ðə wɛðɝ wɔɹmz, noʊ wɪð ə pɹɪɾi ɡɝl laɪk ðət wʌn ɑn jəɹ ɑɹm."

Nieda looked his way. "I'll mix you some honey and sulphur, lad, for that throat. You'll no want to take a chill before the weather warms, no with a pretty girl like that one on your arm."

mɔɪɹeɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ə lʊk ðət sɛɾ i wɑz ɪntɝfɪɹɪŋ wɪð hɝ. "stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət jə ʃəd sʌfɝ faɪts," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ wɛl ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ jəɹ nɛfju stɑps sʌtʃ. hæz sʌmθɪŋ əkɝd tə meɪk pipəl mɔɹ ɪɹəɾəbəl?"

Moiraine gave him a look that said he was interfering with her. "Strange that you should suffer fights," she said. "I well remember how your nephew stops such. Has something occurred to make people more irritable?"

niɾə mjuz fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "pɝhæps. ɪt də bi hɑɹd tə seɪ. ðə jʌŋ lɔɹɾəlɪŋz də ɔlweɪz kʌm daʊn tə ðə dɑks fəɹ ðə wɛnkɪŋ ən kəɹaʊzəŋ ðeɪ kən noʊ ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð wɛɹ ði ɛɹ dʌz smɛl fɹɛʃɝ. pɝhæps ðeɪ də kʌm mɔɹ ɔfən, naʊ, sɪns ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə wɪntɝ. pɝhæps. ən ʌðɝz də snæp əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ mɔɹ, tu. ɪt dɪd bi ə hɑɹd wɪntɝ. ðət dʌz meɪk mɛn æŋɡɹiɝ, ən wɪmən əz wɛl. ɔl ðət ɹeɪn, ən koʊld. waɪ, aɪ dɪd weɪk tu mɔɹnɪŋz tə faɪn aɪs ɪn maɪ wɑʃbeɪsən. noʊ soʊ hɑɹɾ əz ðə læst wɪntɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðət dɪd bi ə wɪntɝ fəɹ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz. ɔlmoʊst ɪnʌf tə meɪk mi bɪliv ðoʊz tʃɹævəlɝz' teɪlz ə fɹoʊzən wɔɾɝ fɔlɪŋ fɹəm ðə skaɪ." ʃi ɡɪɡəl tə ʃoʊ haʊ lɪɾəl ʃi bɪliv ðæt. ɪt wɑz ən ɑd saʊn fɹəm sətʃ ə lɑɹdʒ wʊmən.

Nieda mused for a moment. "Perhaps. It do be hard to say. The young lordlings do always come down to the docks for the wenching and carousing they can no get away with where the air does smell fresher. Perhaps they do come more often, now, since the hard of the winter. Perhaps. And others do snap at each other more, too. It did be a hard winter. That does make men angrier, and women as well. All that rain, and cold. Why, I did wake two mornings to find ice in my washbasin. No so hard as the last winter, of course, but that did be a winter for a thousand years. Almost enough to make me believe those travelers' tales of frozen water falling from the sky." She giggled to show how little she believed that. It was an odd sound from such a large woman.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ʃi dʌzn bɪliv ɪn snoʊ? bʌɾ ɪf ʃi θɔt ðɪs wɛðɝ wɑz kul, hi kəd bɪliv ɪɾ ə hɝ.

Perrin shook his head. She doesn't believe in snow? But if she thought this weather was cool, he could believe it of her.

mɔɪɹeɪn bɛn əɹ hɛɾ ɪn θɔt, hɝ hʊd ʃæɾoʊɪŋ əɹ feɪs.

Moiraine bent her head in thought, her hood shadowing her face.

ðə ɡɝl ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə nu vɝs, ən pɛɹɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf lɪsnɪŋ ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. hi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛni wʊmən duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ɹimoʊtli laɪk wʌt ðə ɡɝl wɑz sɪŋɪŋ əbaʊt, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd saʊn ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. hi noʊɾəst zɑɹin wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm lɪsən, ən tʃɹaɪd tə pɹitɛn i hæd nɑt bɪn.

The girl on the table was beginning a new verse, and Perrin found himself listening in spite of himself. He had never heard of any woman doing anything remotely like what the girl was singing about, but it did sound interesting. He noticed Zarine watching him listen, and tried to pretend he had not been.

"wʌɾ əz əkɝɾ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi ɪn ɪljən ə leɪt?" mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd faɪnəli.

"What has occurred out of the ordinary in Illian of late?" Moiraine said finally.

"aɪ də səpoʊz jə kəd kɔl lɔɹd bɹɛnz əsɛnʃən tə ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn ənjuʒəwəl," niɾə sɛd. "fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, aɪ kən noʊ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛvɝ hɪɹɪŋ ɪz neɪm bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪntɝ, bʌɾ i dɪd kʌm tə ðə sɪɾi - fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ nɪɹ ðə mʊɹændiən bɔɹɾɝ, ɪt bi ɹumɝd - ən dɪd bi ɹeɪzd ɪnsaɪɾ ə wik. ɪt də bi sɛɾ i bi ə ɡʊd mæn, ən stʃɹɔŋɡəst ə ðə naɪn - ðeɪ ɔl də fɑloʊ hɪz lɛd, ɪt bi sɛd, ðoʊ hi bi nuəst ən ənnoʊn - bʌt səmtaɪmz aɪ də hæv stʃɹeɪnʒ dʒɹimz ə hɪm."

"I do suppose you could call Lord Brend's ascension to the Council of Nine unusual," Nieda said. "Fortune prick me, I can no remember ever hearing his name before the winter, but he did come to the city - from somewhere near the Murandian border, it be rumored - and did be raised inside a week. It do be said he be a good man, and strongest of the Nine - they all do follow his lead, it be said, though he be newest and unknown - but sometimes I do have strange dreams of him."

mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ - tə tɛl niɾə ʃi hæd mɛn ɪn ðə læs fju naɪts, pɛɹɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ - bʌt ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən ɪnstɛd sɛd, "wʌt sɔɹɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ dʒɹimz, niɾə?"

Moiraine had opened her mouth - to tell Nieda she had meant in the last few nights, Perrin was sure - but she hesitated, and instead said, "What sort of strange dreams, Nieda?"

"oʊ, fulɪʃnəs, mɪstʃɹəs mɑɹi. dʒʌs fulɪʃnəs. jə də tʃɹuli wɪʃ tə hɪɹ ɪt? dʒɹimz ə lɔɹd bɹɛn ɪn stʃɹeɪnʒ pleɪsəz, ən wɔkɪŋ bɹɪdʒəz hæŋɪŋ ɪn ɛɹ. ɔl fɑɡd, ðiz dʒɹimz də bi, bʌt nɪɹ ɛvɹi naɪt ðeɪ də kʌm. dɪd jə ɛvɝ hɪɹ ə sʌtʃ? fulɪʃnəs, fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi! jɛt, ɪt də bi ɑd. bili dʌz seɪ hi dʌz dʒɹim ðə seɪm dʒɹimz. aɪ də θɪŋk i dʌz hɪɹ maɪ dʒɹimz ən kɑpi ðɛm. bili də bi nʌn tu bɹaɪt, səmtaɪmz, aɪ də θɪŋk."

"Oh, foolishness, Mistress Mari. Just foolishness. You do truly wish to hear it? Dreams of Lord Brend in strange places, and walking bridges hanging in air. All fogged, these dreams do be, but near every night they do come. Did you ever hear of such? Foolishness, Fortune prick me! Yet, it do be odd. Bili does say he does dream the same dreams. I do think he does hear my dreams and copy them. Bili do be none too bright, sometimes, I do think."

"ju meɪ də hɪm ən ɪndʒʌstɪs," mɔɪɹeɪn bɹiðd.

"You may do him an injustice," Moiraine breathed.

pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ dɑɹk hʊd. ʃi hæd saʊndəd ʃeɪkən, ivən mɔɹ ʃeɪkən ðən wən ʃi θɔɾ ə nu fɔls dʒɹæɡən hæd ɹɪzən ɪn ɡildən. hi kəd nɑt smɛl fɪɹ, bʌt. . . . mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz fɹaɪɾənd. ɪt wɑz ə fɑɹ mɔɹ tɛɹəfaɪɪŋ θɔt ðən mɔɪɹeɪn æŋɡɹi. hi kəɾ ɪmædʒən əɹ æŋɡɹi; hi kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə kənsiv ə hɝ əfɹeɪd.

Perrin stared at her dark hood. She had sounded shaken, even more shaken than when she thought a new false Dragon had risen in Ghealdan. He could not smell fear, but. . . . Moiraine was frightened. It was a far more terrifying thought than Moiraine angry. He could imagine her angry; he could not begin to conceive of her afraid.

"haʊ aɪ də mɔndɝ ɑn," niɾə sɛd, pæɾɪŋ ðə ɹoʊl hɛɹ ət ðə bæk ə hɝ nɛk. "æz ɪf maɪ fulɪʃ dʒɹimz də bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt." ʃi ɡɪɡəld əɡɛn. ə kwɪk ɡɪɡəl; ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ əz fulɪʃ əz bɪlivɪŋ ɪn snoʊ. "ju də saʊn taɪɝd, mɪstʃɹəs mɑɹi. əl ʃoʊ jə tə jəɹ ɹumz. ən ðən ə ɡʊd mil ə fɹɛʃ-kɑt ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp."

"How I do maunder on," Nieda said, patting the rolled hair at the back of her neck. "As if my foolish dreams do be important." She giggled again. A quick giggle; this was not as foolish as believing in snow. "You do sound tired, Mistress Mari. I will show you to your rooms. And then a good meal of fresh-caught red-stripe."

ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp? ə fɪʃ, hi θɔɾ ɪt mʌs bi; hi kəd smɛl fɪʃ kʊkɪŋ.

Red-stripe? A fish, he thought it must be; he could smell fish cooking.

"ɹumz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "jɛs. wɪl teɪk ɹumz. ðə mil kən weɪt. ʃɪps. niɾə, wʌt ʃɪps seɪl fəɹ tɛɹ? ɝli ɑn ðə mɑɹoʊ. aɪ hæv ðət wɪtʃ aɪ mʌs də tənaɪt." læn ɡlænst ət hɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"Rooms," Moiraine said. "Yes. We will take rooms. The meal can wait. Ships. Nieda, what ships sail for Tear? Early on the morrow. I have that which I must do tonight." Lan glanced at her, frowning.

"fɔɹ tɛɹ, mɪstʃɹəs mɑɹi?" niɾə læft. "waɪ, nʌn fəɹ tɛɹ. ðə naɪn dɪd fɝbɪɾ ɛni ʃɪp tə seɪl fəɹ tɛɹ ə mʌnθ ɡɔn naʊ, nɔɹ ɛni fɹəm tiɹ tə kɔl hɪɹ, ðoʊ aɪ də θɪŋk ðə si foʊk peɪ ɪt noʊ maɪnd. bʌt ðəɹ də bi noʊ si foʊk ʃɪp ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ. ɪt də bi ɑd, ðæt. ði ɔɹɾɝ ə ðə naɪn, aɪ də min, ən ðə kɪŋ saɪlən ɑn ɪt, wən i dʌz ɔlweɪz ɹeɪz ɪz vɔɪs ɪf ðeɪ bʌt teɪk ə stɛp wɪθaʊɾ ɪz lɛd. əɹ pɝhæps ɪt bi noʊ ðæt, ɪɡzækli. ɔl tɔk də bi ʌv wɔɹ wɪð tiɹ, bʌt ðə boʊtmən ən wæɡənɪɹz u də kæɹi səplaɪz tə ði ɑɹmi də seɪ ðə soʊlʒɝz də ɔl lʊk nɔɹθ, tə mʊɹændi."

"For Tear, Mistress Mari?" Nieda laughed. "Why, none for Tear. The Nine did forbid any ship to sail for Tear a month gone now, nor any from Tear to call here, though I do think the Sea Folk pay it no mind. But there do be no Sea Folk ship in the harbor. It do be odd, that. The order of the Nine, I do mean, and the King silent on it, when he does always raise his voice if they but take a step without his lead. Or perhaps it be no that, exactly. All talk do be of war with Tear, but the boatmen and wagoneers who do carry supplies to the army do say the soldiers do all look north, to Murandy."

"ðə pæðz ə ðə ʃædoʊ ɑɹ tæŋɡəld," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. "wi wɪl də wʌt wi mʌst. ðə ɹumz, niɾə. ən ðən wɪl it ðət mil."

"The paths of the Shadow are tangled," Moiraine said in a tight voice. "We will do what we must. The rooms, Nieda. And then we will eat that meal."

pɛɹɪnz ɹum wɑz mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl ðən i ɪkspɛktəd, ɡɪvən ðə lʊk ə ðə ɹɛst ə ðə bædʒɝ. ðə bɛd wɑz waɪd, ðə mætʃɹəs sɑft. ðə dɔɹ wɑz meɪɾ ə tɪltəd slæts, ən wən i oʊpən ðə wɪndoʊz, ə bɹiz kɹɔs ðə ɹum kæɹiɪŋ ðə smɛlz ə ðə hɑɹbɝ. ən sʌmθɪŋ ə ðə kənælz, tu, bʌɾ ət list ɪt wɑz kulɪŋ. hi hʌŋ ɪz kloʊk ɑn ə pɛɡ əlɔŋ wɪð ɪz kwɪvɝ ən æks, ən pɹɑpt ɪz baʊ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls i lɛft ɪn ðə sæɾəlbæɡz ən blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl. ðə naɪt maɪt nɑt bi ɹɛsfəl.

Perrin's room was more comfortable than he expected, given the look of the rest of the Badger. The bed was wide, the mattress soft. The door was made of tilted slats, and when he opened the windows, a breeze crossed the room carrying the smells of the harbor. And something of the canals, too, but at least it was cooling. He hung his cloak on a peg along with his quiver and axe, and propped his bow in the corner. Everything else he left in the saddlebags and blanketroll. The night might not be restful.

ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn hæd saʊndəɾ əfɹeɪd bɪfɔɹ, ɪt hæd bɪn nʌθɪŋ tə wən ʃi sɛd ðət sʌmθɪŋ mʌs bi dʌn tənaɪt. fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðɛn, fɪɹ sɛn hæd stim fɹəm əɹ əz fɹəm ə wʊmən ənaʊnsɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz gɑnə stɪk əɹ hæn ɪn ə hɔɹnəts' nɛst ən kɹʌʃ əm wɪð əɹ bɛɹ fɪŋɡɝz. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪɾ ɪz ʃi ʌp tə? ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz fɹaɪɾənd, aɪ ʃəd bi tɛɹəfaɪd.

If Moiraine had sounded afraid before, it had been nothing to when she said that something must be done tonight. For an instant then, fear scent had steamed from her as from a woman announcing that she was going to stick her hand in a hornets' nest and crush them with her bare fingers. What in the Light is she up to? If Moiraine is frightened, I should be terrified.

hi wɑz nɑt, hi ɹilaɪzd. nɑt tɛɹəfaɪd, əɹ ivən fɹaɪɾənd. hi fɛlt . . . ɪksaɪɾəd. ɹɛɾi fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə hæpən, ɔlmoʊst iɡɝ. dɪtɝmənd. hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə filɪŋz. ðeɪ wɝ wʌt wʊlvz fɛl dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ fɔt. bɝn mi, aɪd ɹæðɝ bi əfɹeɪd!

He was not, he realized. Not terrified, or even frightened. He felt . . . excited. Ready for something to happen, almost eager. Determined. He recognized the feelings. They were what wolves felt just before they fought. Burn me, I'd rather be afraid!

hi wɑz fɝs bæk daʊn tə ðə kɑmən ɪksɛp fəɹ lɔɪəl. niɾə hæɾ ɝeɪnʒd ə lɑɹdʒ teɪbəl fəɹ ðɛm, wɪð læɾɝ-bæk tʃɛɹz ɪnstɛɾ ə bɛntʃɪz. ʃi hæɾ ivən faʊn ə tʃɛɹ bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ lɔɪəl. ðə ɡɝl əkɹɔs ðə ɹum wɑz sɪŋɪŋ ə sɔŋ əbaʊɾ ə ɹɪtʃ mɝtʃən hu, hævɪŋ dʒʌs lɔst ɪz tim ə hɔɹsəz ɪn ən ɪmpɹɑbəbəl weɪ, hæd fəɹ səm ɹizən dɪsaɪɾɪd tə pʊl ɪz kæɹɪdʒ hɪmsɛlf. ðə mɛn lɪsnɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ ɹɔɹd wɪð læftɝ. ðə wɪndoʊz ʃoʊd dɑɹknəs kʌmɪŋ ɑn mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd; ði ɛɹ smɛld əz ɪf ɪt maɪt bi meɪkɪŋ ʌp tə ɹeɪn.

He was first back down to the common except for Loial. Nieda had arranged a large table for them, with ladder-back chairs instead of benches. She had even found a chair big enough for Loial. The girl across the room was singing a song about a rich merchant who, having just lost his team of horses in an improbable way, had for some reason decided to pull his carriage himself. The men listening around her roared with laughter. The windows showed darkness coming on more quickly than he had expected; the air smelled as if it might be making up to rain.

"ðɪs ɪn əz ən oʊɡiɝ ɹum," lɔɪəl sɛɾ əz pɛɹɪn sæt daʊn. "əpɛɹənli, ɛvɹi ɪn ɪn ɪljən əz wʌn, ɪn hoʊps ʌv ɡeɪnɪŋ oʊɡiɝ kʌstəm wən ðə stoʊnmeɪsɑnz kʌm. niɾə kleɪmz ɪts lʌki, hævɪŋ ən oʊɡiɝ ʌndɝ ðə ɹuf. aɪ kænɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ ɡɛt mɛni. ðə meɪsənz ɔlweɪz steɪ təɡɛðɝ wən ðeɪ ɡoʊ aʊtsaɪd tə wɝk. hjumənz ɑɹ soʊ heɪsti, ən ði ɛldɝz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz əfɹeɪd tɛmpɝz wɪl flɛɹ ən sʌmwʌn wɪl pʊɾ ə lɔŋ hændəl ɑn ɪz æks." hi aɪd ðə mɛn ɝaʊn ðə sɪŋɝ əz ɪf i səspɛktəɾ əm ʌv ɪt. hɪz ɪɹz wɝ dʒɹupɪŋ əɡɛn.

"This inn has an Ogier room," Loial said as Perrin sat down. "Apparently, every inn in Illian has one, in hopes of gaining Ogier custom when the stonemasons come. Nieda claims it is lucky, having an Ogier under the roof. I cannot think they get many. The masons always stay together when they go Outside to work. Humans are so hasty, and the Elders are always afraid tempers will flare and someone will put a long handle on his axe." He eyed the men around the singer as if he suspected them of it. His ears were drooping again.

ðə ɹɪtʃ mɝtʃənt wɑz ɪn ðə pɹɑsɛs ə luzɪŋ ɪz kæɹɪdʒ, tə mɔɹ læftɝ. "dɪd jə faɪn aʊt wɛðɝ ɛni oʊɡiɝ fɹəm stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ ɑɹ ɪn ɪljən?"

The rich merchant was in the process of losing his carriage, to more laughter. "Did you find out whether any Ogier from Stedding Shangtai are in Illian?"

"ðɛɹ wɝ, bʌt niɾə sɛd ðeɪ lɛf dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɪntɝ. ʃi sɛd ðeɪ hæd nɑt fɪnɪʃt ðɛɹ wɝk. aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt. ðə meɪsənz wəd nɑɾ əv lɛft wɝk əndʌn ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ nɑt peɪd, ən niɾə sɛɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt ðæt. wʌn mɔɹnɪŋ, ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌst ɡɔn, ðoʊ sʌmwʌn sɔ ðɛm wɔkɪŋ daʊn ðə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ kɑzweɪ ɪn ðə naɪt. pɛɹɪn, aɪ də nɑt laɪk ðɪs sɪɾi. aɪ də nɑt noʊ waɪ, bʌɾ ɪt meɪks mi . . . ənizi."

"There were, but Nieda said they left during the winter. She said they had not finished their work. I do not understand it. The masons would not have left work undone unless they were not paid, and Nieda said it was not that. One morning, they were just gone, though someone saw them walking down the Maredo Causeway in the night. Perrin, I do not like this city. I do not know why, but it makes me . . . uneasy."

"oʊɡiɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "ɑɹ sɛnsəɾɪv tə səm θɪŋz." ʃi stɪl hæɾ əɹ feɪs hɪɾən, bʌt niɾə hæɾ əpɛɹənli sɛn sʌmwʌn tə baɪ hɝ ə laɪt kloʊk ə dɑɹk blu lɪnən. ðə fɪɹ smɛl wɑz ɡɔn fɹəm hɝ, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs saʊndəɾ ʌndɝ taɪt kəntʃɹoʊl. læn hɛld əɹ tʃɛɹ fəɹ hɝ; hɪz aɪz lʊkt wɝid.

"Ogier," Moiraine said, "are sensitive to some things." She still had her face hidden, but Nieda had apparently sent someone to buy her a light cloak of dark blue linen. The fear smell was gone from her, but her voice sounded under tight control. Lan held her chair for her; his eyes looked worried.

zɑɹin wɑz ðə læs daʊn, ɹʌnɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz θɹu dʒʌst-wɑʃt hɛɹ. ði ɝbəl sɛnt wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ ɝaʊn əɹ ðən bɪfɔɹ. ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə plæɾɝ niɾə pleɪst ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. "aɪ heɪt fɪʃ."

Zarine was the last down, running her fingers through just-washed hair. The herbal scent was stronger around her than before. She stared at the platter Nieda placed on the table and muttered under her breath. "I hate fish."

ðə staʊt wʊmən hæd bɹɔɾ ɔl ðə fuɾ ɑn ə smɔl kɑɹt wɪð ʃɛlvz; ɪt wɑz dʌsti ɪn pleɪsəz, əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn heɪstəli bɹɔɾ aʊt fɹəm ðə stɔɹɹum ɪn mɔɪɹeɪnz ɑnɝ. ðə dɪʃəz wɝ si foʊk pɔɹsələn, tu, ɪf tʃɪpt.

The stout woman had brought all the food on a small cart with shelves; it was dusty in places, as if it had been hastily brought out from the storeroom in Moiraine's honor. The dishes were Sea Folk porcelain, too, if chipped.

"it," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət zɑɹin. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ ɛni mil kən bi jəɹ læst. jə tʃoʊz tə tʃɹævəl wɪð ʌs, soʊ tənaɪt jəl it fɪʃ. təmɑɹoʊ, jə meɪ daɪ."

"Eat," Moiraine said, looking straight at Zarine. "Remember that any meal can be your last. You chose to travel with us, so tonight you will eat fish. Tomorrow, you may die."

pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə nɪɹli ɹaʊnd waɪt fɪʃ wɪð ɹɛd stʃɹaɪps, bʌt ðeɪ smɛld ɡʊd. hi lɪftəd tu ɑntu hɪz pleɪt wɪð ðə sɝvɪŋ fɔɹk, ən ɡɹɪn ət zɑɹin ɝaʊn ə maʊθfʊl. ðeɪ teɪstəd ɡʊd, tu, laɪtli spaɪst. it jəɹ næsti fɪʃ, fælkən, hi θɔt. hi ɔlsoʊ θɔt ðət zɑɹin lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi maɪt baɪt hɪm.

Perrin did not recognize the nearly round white fish with red stripes, but they smelled good. He lifted two onto his plate with the serving fork, and grinned at Zarine around a mouthful. They tasted good, too, lightly spiced. Eat your nasty fish, falcon, he thought. He also thought that Zarine looked as if she might bite him.

"du jə wɪʃ mi tə stɑp ðə ɡɝl sɪŋɪŋ, mɪstʃɹəs mɑɹi?" niɾə æskt. ʃi wɑz sɛɾɪŋ boʊlz ə piz ən səm sɔɹɾ ə stɪf jɛloʊ mʌʃ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "soʊ jə kən iɾ ɪn kwaɪət?"

"Do you wish me to stop the girl singing, Mistress Mari?" Nieda asked. She was setting bowls of peas and some sort of stiff yellow mush on the table. "So you can eat in quiet?"

stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ pleɪt, mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑt sim tə hɪɹ.

Staring at her plate, Moiraine did not seem to hear.

læn lɪsən ə moʊmənt - ðə mɝtʃən hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi lɔst, ɪn səksɛʃən, hɪz kæɹɪdʒ, hɪz kloʊk, hɪz buts, hɪz ɡoʊld, ən ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz kloʊðz, ən wɑz naʊ ɹədus tə ɹɛslɪŋ ə pɪɡ fəɹ ɪts dɪnɝ - ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ʃi wɪl nɑt bɑðɝ ʌs." hi lʊkt kloʊs tə smaɪlɪŋ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bɪfɔɹ i ɡlænst ət mɔɪɹeɪn. ðən ðə wɝi ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz aɪz.

Lan listened a moment - the merchant had already lost, in succession, his carriage, his cloak, his boots, his gold, and the rest of his clothes, and was now reduced to wrestling a pig for its dinner - and shook his head. "She will not bother us." He looked close to smiling for a moment, before he glanced at Moiraine. Then the worry returned to his eyes.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɹɔŋ?" zɑɹin sɛd. ʃi wɑz ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə fɪʃ. "aɪ noʊ sʌmθɪŋ ɪz. aɪ hæv nɑt si ðət mʌtʃ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ju, stoʊn-feɪs, sɪns aɪ mɛt ju."

"What is wrong?" Zarine said. She was ignoring the fish. "I know something is. I have not see that much expression on you, stone-face, since I met you."

"noʊ kwɛstʃənz!" mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ju wɪl noʊ wʌɾ aɪ tɛl jə ən noʊ mɔɹ!"

"No questions!" Moiraine said sharply. "You will know what I tell you and no more!"

"wʌt wɪl jə tɛl mi?" zɑɹin dɪmændəd.

"What will you tell me?" Zarine demanded.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ smaɪld. "it jəɹ fɪʃ."

The Aes Sedai smiled. "Eat your fish."

ðə mil wɛn ɑn ɪn nɪɹ saɪləns æftɝ ðæt, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə sɔŋz dʒɹɪftɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn əbaʊɾ ə ɹɪtʃ mæn huz waɪf ən dɔɾɝz meɪɾ ə ful ə hɪm taɪm ən əɡɛn wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ dɪfleɪɾɪŋ ɪz sɛlf-ɪmpɔɹɾəns, ənʌðɝ ðət kənsɝn ə jʌŋ wʊmən u dɪsaɪɾɪd tə teɪk ə wɔk wɪθaʊɾ ɛni kloʊðz, ən wʌn ðət toʊld ʌv ə blæksmɪθ u mænədʒ tə ʃu hɪmsɛlf ɪnstɛɾ ə ðə hɔɹs. zɑɹin nɪɹli tʃoʊk læfɪŋ ət ðət wʌn, fɝɡɑt hɝsɛlf ɪnʌf tə teɪk ə baɪɾ ə fɪʃ, ən sʌɾənli ɡɹɪməst əz ɪf ʃi hæd pʊt mʌɾ ɪn əɹ maʊθ.

The meal went on in near silence after that, except for the songs drifting across the room. There was one about a rich man whose wife and daughters made a fool of him time and again without ever deflating his self-importance, another that concerned a young woman who decided to take a walk without any clothes, and one that told of a blacksmith who managed to shoe himself instead of the horse. Zarine nearly choked laughing at that one, forgot herself enough to take a bite of fish, and suddenly grimaced as if she had put mud in her mouth.

aɪ woʊn læf ət hɝ, pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪmsɛlf. haʊɛvɝ fulɪʃ ʃi lʊks, əl ʃoʊ hɝ wʌt mænɝz ɑɹ. "ðeɪ teɪst ɡʊd, doʊn ðeɪ," hi sɛd. zɑɹin ɡeɪv ɪm ə bɪɾɝ lʊk, ən mɔɪɹeɪn ə fɹaʊn fəɹ ɪntɝʌptɪŋ əɹ θɔts, ən ðət wɑz ɔl ðə tɔk ðəɹ wɑz.

I won't laugh at her, Perrin told himself. However foolish she looks, I'll show her what manners are. "They taste good, don't they," he said. Zarine gave him a bitter look, and Moiraine a frown for interrupting her thoughts, and that was all the talk there was.

niɾə wɑz klɪɹɪŋ əweɪ ðə dɪʃəz ən sɛɾɪŋ ən ɝeɪ ʌv tʃizɪz ɑn ðə teɪbəl wən ə stɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ vaɪl lɪftəd ðə hækəlz ɑn ðə bæk ə pɛɹɪnz nɛk. ɪt wɑz ə smɛl ə sʌmθɪŋ ðət ʃəd nɑt bi, ən i hæd smɛld ɪt twaɪs bɪfɔɹ. hi pɪɹɾ əbaʊt ðə kɑmən ɹum ənizəli.

Nieda was clearing away the dishes and setting an array of cheeses on the table when a stink of something vile lifted the hackles on the back of Perrin's neck. It was a smell of something that should not be, and he had smelled it twice before. He peered about the common room uneasily.

ðə ɡɝl stɪl sæŋ tə ðə nɑɾ ə lɪsənɝz, səm mɛn wɝ stʃɹoʊlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ fɹəm ðə dɔɹ, ən bili stɪl lin ɑn ðə wɔl tæpɪŋ ɪz fʊt tə ðə saʊnz ə ðə bɪɾɝn. niɾə pæɾəd əɹ ɹoʊl hɛɹ, ɡeɪv ðə ɹum ə kwɪk ɡlæns, ən tɝn tə pʊʃ ðə kɑɹɾ əweɪ.

The girl still sang to the knot of listeners, some men were strolling across the floor from the door, and Bili still leaned on the wall tapping his foot to the sounds of the bittern. Nieda patted her rolled hair, gave the room a quick glance, and turned to push the cart away.

hi lʊkt əɾ ɪz kəmpænjənz. lɔɪəl, ʌnsɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, hæd pʊld ə bʊk fɹəm ɪz koʊt pɑkəɾ ən sim tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən wɛɹ i wɑz. zɑɹin, æbsənli ɹoʊlɪŋ ə pis ʌv waɪt tʃiz ɪndə ə bɔl, wɑz aɪɪŋ fɝs pɛɹɪn, ðən mɔɪɹeɪn, ðən ɪm əɡɛn, waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛnd ʃi wɑz nɑt. ɪt wɑz læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn i wɑz ɹɪli ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn, ðoʊ. ðeɪ kəd sɛns ə mɹdʒɹɑl, əɹ ə tʃɹɑlɑk, əɹ ɛni ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, bɪfɔɹ ɪt keɪm kloʊsɝ ðən ə fju hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz stɛɹɪŋ dɪstənli ət ðə teɪbəl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz kʌɾɪŋ ə tʃʌŋk ə jɛloʊ tʃiz ən wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ. jɛt ðə smɛl ə ɹɔŋɡnəs wɑz ðɛɹ, əz ət dʒɹə ən ði ɛdʒ ə ɹɛmən, ən ðɪs taɪm ɪt wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ əweɪ. ɪt sim tə bi kʌmɪŋ fɹəm sʌmθɪŋ wɪðɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum.

He looked at his companions. Loial, unsurprisingly, had pulled a book from his coat pocket and seemed to have forgotten where he was. Zarine, absently rolling a piece of white cheese into a ball, was eyeing first Perrin, then Moiraine, then him again, while trying to pretend she was not. It was Lan and Moiraine he was really interested in, though. They could sense a Myrddraal, or a Trolloc, or any Shadowspawn, before it came closer than a few hundred paces, but the Aes Sedai was staring distantly at the table in front of her, and the Warder was cutting a chunk of yellow cheese and watching her. Yet the smell of wrongness was there, as at Jarra and the edge of Remen, and this time it was not going away. It seemed to be coming from something within the common room.

hi stʌɾid ðə ɹum əɡɛn. bili əɡɛns ðə wɔl, səm mɛn kɹɔsɪŋ ðə flɔɹ, ðə ɡɝl sɪŋɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ɔl ðə læfɪŋ mɛn sɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ. mɛn kɹɔsɪŋ ðə flɔɹ? hi fɹaʊn ət ðɛm. sɪks mɛn wɪð ɔɹɾənɛɹi feɪsəz, wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd wɛɹ i wɑz sɪɾɪŋ. vɛɹi ɔɹɾənɛɹi feɪsəz. hi wɑz dʒʌst stɑɹɾɪŋ tə ɹiaɪnspɛk ðə mɛn lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə ɡɝl wən sʌɾənli ɪt keɪm tə hɪm ðət ðə stɪŋk ə ɹɔŋɡnəs wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ fɹəm ðə sɪks. əbɹʌpli ðeɪ hæd dæɡɝz ɪn ðɛɹ hænz, əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd ɹilaɪzd i hæd sin ðɛm.

He studied the room again. Bili against the wall, some men crossing the floor, the girl singing on the table, all the laughing men sitting around her. Men crossing the floor? He frowned at them. Six men with ordinary faces, walking toward where he was sitting. Very ordinary faces. He was just starting to reinspect the men listening to the girl when suddenly it came to him that the stink of wrongness was rolling from the six. Abruptly they had daggers in their hands, as if they had realized he had seen them.

"ðeɪ hæv naɪvz!" hi ɹɔɹd, ən θɹu ðə tʃiz plæɾɝ ət ðɛm.

"They have knives!" he roared, and threw the cheese platter at them.

ðə kɑmən ɪɹʌptəɾ ɪndə kənfjuʒən, mɛn ʃaʊɾɪŋ, ðə sɪŋɝ skɹimɪŋ, niɾə ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ bili, ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæpənɪŋ ət wʌns. læn lɛp tə hɪz fit, ən ə bɔl ə faɪɝ dɑɹɾɪd fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪnz hænd, ən lɔɪəl snætʃt ʌp ɪz tʃɛɹ laɪk ə klʌb, ən zɑɹin dæns tə wʌn saɪd, kɝsɪŋ. ʃi hæɾ ə naɪf ɪn əɹ hænd, tu, bʌt pɛɹɪn wɑz tu bɪzi tə noʊɾəs mʌtʃ ʌv wʌɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls dɪd. ðoʊz mɛn sim tə bi lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət hɪm, ən ɪz æks wɑz hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ə pɛɡ ʌp ɪn ɪz ɹum.

The common erupted into confusion, men shouting, the singer screaming, Nieda shouting for Bili, everything happening at once. Lan leaped to his feet, and a ball of fire darted from Moiraine's hand, and Loial snatched up his chair like a club, and Zarine danced to one side, cursing. She had a knife in her hand, too, but Perrin was too busy to notice much of what anyone else did. Those men seemed to be looking straight at him, and his axe was hanging from a peg up in his room.

sizɪŋ ə tʃɛɹ, hi ɹɪpt ɔf ə θɪk tʃɛɹ lɛɡ ðət ɹæn ʌp tə meɪk wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə læɾɝ-bæk, hɝl ðə ɹɛst ə ðə tʃɛɹ ət ðə mɛn, ən sɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪm wɪð ɪz lɔŋ blʌdʒən. ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹitʃ ɪm wɪð ðɛɹ neɪkəd stil, əz ɪf læn ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ oʊnli ɑbstəkəlz ɪn ðɛɹ weɪ. ɪt wɑz ə taɪt tæŋɡəl wɛɹ ɔl i kəd mænədʒ wɑz tə nɑk bleɪdz əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, ən ɪz waɪldɝ swɪŋz θɹɛɾənd læn ən lɔɪəl ən zɑɹin əz mʌtʃ əz ɛni ʌv ɪz sɪks ətækɝz. fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ hi sɔ mɔɪɹeɪn stændɪŋ tə wʌn saɪd, fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs; ðeɪ wɝ ɔl soʊ mɪks təɡɛðɝ ðət ʃi kəd də nʌθɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɛndeɪnʒɝɪŋ fɹɛn əz wɛl əz foʊ. nʌn ə ðə naɪf wildɝz əz mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ət hɝ; ʃi wɑz nɑt bɪtwin əm ən pɛɹɪn.

Seizing a chair, he ripped off a thick chair leg that ran up to make one side of the ladder-back, hurled the rest of the chair at the men, and set about him with his long bludgeon. They were trying to reach him with their naked steel, as if Lan and the others were only obstacles in their way. It was a tight tangle where all he could manage was to knock blades away from him, and his wilder swings threatened Lan and Loial and Zarine as much as any of his six attackers. From the corner of his eye he saw Moiraine standing to one side, frustration on her face; they were all so mixed together that she could do nothing without endangering friend as well as foe. None of the knife wielders as much as glanced at her; she was not between them and Perrin.

pæntɪŋ, hi mænədʒ tə kɹæk wʌn ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi-lʊkɪŋ mɛn əkɹɔs ðə hɛd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ i hɝd boʊn splɪntɝ, ən əbɹʌpli ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ ɔl daʊn. ɪɾ ɔl sim tə hɪm tə hæv ɡɔn ɑn fəɹ ə kɔɹɾɝ ʌv ə aʊɝ əɹ mɔɹ, bʌɾ i sɔ ðət bili wɑz dʒʌs hɔltɪŋ, hɪz lɑɹdʒ hænz wɝkɪŋ əz i stɛɹɾ ət ðə sɪks mɛn spɹɔl dɛɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. bili hæd nɑɾ ivən hæd taɪm tə ɹitʃ ðə faɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪt wɑz dʌn.

Panting, he managed to crack one of the ordinary-looking men across the head so hard that he heard bone splinter, and abruptly realized they were all down. It all seemed to him to have gone on for a quarter of a hour or more, but he saw that Bili was just halting, his large hands working as he stared at the six men sprawled dead on the floor. Bili had not even had time to reach the fight before it was done.

læn wɔɹ ə feɪs ivən ɡɹɪmɝ ðən juʒəwəl; hi bɪɡæn sɝtʃɪŋ ðə bɑɾiz, θɝoʊli, bʌt wɪð ə kwɪknəs ðət spoʊk ə dɪsteɪst. lɔɪəl stɪl hæɾ ɪz tʃɛɹ ɹeɪz tə swɪŋ; hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən sɛɾ ɪt daʊn wɪð ən ɪmbɛɹəst ɡɹɪn. mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn, ən soʊ wɑz zɑɹin əz ʃi ɹitʃɹivd əɹ naɪf fɹəm ðə tʃɛst ʌv wʌn ə ðə dɛd mɛn. ðət stɛntʃ ə ɹɔŋɡnəs wɑz ɡɔn, əz ɪf ɪt hæd daɪd wɪð ðɛm.

Lan wore a face even grimmer than usual; he began searching the bodies, thoroughly, but with a quickness that spoke of distaste. Loial still had his chair raised to swing; he gave a start and set it down with an embarrassed grin. Moiraine was staring at Perrin, and so was Zarine as she retrieved her knife from the chest of one of the dead men. That stench of wrongness was gone, as if it had died with them.

"ɡɹeɪ mɛn," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd sɔfli, "æn æftɝ ju."

"Gray Men," the Aes Sedai said softly, "and after you."

"ɡɹeɪ mɛn?" niɾə læft, boʊθ laʊɾ ən nɝvəsli. "waɪ, mɪstʃɹəs mɑɹi, nɛks jəl seɪ jə də bɪliv ɪn bɑɡəlz ən bʌɡbɛɹz ən fɛtʃɪz, ən oʊld ɡɹɪm ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə blæk dɑɡz ɪn ðə waɪl hʌnt." səm ə ðə mɛn u hæd bɪn lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə sɔŋz læft, tu, ðoʊ ðeɪ lʊkt əz ənizəli ət mɔɪɹeɪn əz ət ðə dɛd mɛn. ðə sɪŋɝ stɛɹɾ ət mɔɪɹeɪn, əz wɛl, hɝ aɪz waɪd. pɛɹɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət wʌn bɔl ə faɪɝ, bɪfɔɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɡɹu tu dʒʌmbəld. wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪ mɛn hæɾ ə sʌmwʌt tʃɑɹd lʊk əbaʊt hɪm, ən ɡeɪv ɔf ə sɪkli swit bɝn smɛl.

"Gray Men?" Nieda laughed, both loud and nervously. "Why, Mistress Mari, next you'll say you do believe in boggles and bugbears and Fetches, and Old Grim riding with the black dogs in the Wild Hunt." Some of the men who had been listening to the songs laughed, too, though they looked as uneasily at Moiraine as at the dead men. The singer stared at Moiraine, as well, her eyes wide. Perrin remembered that one ball of fire, before everything grew too jumbled. One of the Gray Men had a somewhat charred look about him, and gave off a sickly sweet burned smell.

The dark-eyed girl climbed back on her table and started singing again, in an unsteady voice. Mistress Luhhan herself would not have disapproved. Light, I'm getting as bad as Mat.

læn aɪɾ əɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz ɪf i hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd nɑt tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ. "wʌtɛvɝ wi faɪnd, ɡɝl. əl noʊ ɪt wən aɪ si ɪt."

pɛɹɪn θɔɾ əbaʊt ɡoʊɪŋ əpstɛɹz fəɹ ɪz æks, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ meɪd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ, ən i wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd. hi hɑɹdli nidz ɪt, pɛɹɪn θɔt ɡɹʌmpəli. hiz ɔlmoʊst əz deɪnʒɝəs wɪθaʊɾ ɪɾ əz wɪð. hi hɛld ɑn tə ðə tʃɛɹ lɛɡ əz i fɑloʊd. ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪlif tə si ðət zɑɹin stɪl hæɾ əɹ naɪf ɪn əɹ hænd.

Thick black clouds were roiling overhead. The street was as dark as late twilight, and empty of people who had apparently not waited to be caught in the rain. "meɪbi hi mɪst siɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd, ðoʊ hi faʊn ɪt hɑɹd tə bɪliv, ən tɝn təwɔɹd ði æli. aɪm səpoʊz tə bi lʊkɪŋ, soʊ əl lʊk. meɪbi hi dɪd mɪs sʌmθɪŋ.

"Maybe he missed seeing something," Perrin muttered, though he found it hard to believe, and turned toward the alley. I am supposed to be looking, so I'll look. Maybe he did miss something.

læn hæd stɑpt ə lɪɾəl weɪ daʊn ðə stʃɹit, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz fit. ðə wɔɹɾɝ stɑɹɾəd bæk təwɔɹd ði ɪn, wɔkɪŋ kwɪkli, bʌt piɹɪŋ ət ðə stʃɹiɾ əhɛɾ ə hɪm əz ɪf fɑloʊɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz lɛd stʃɹeɪt tə wʌn ə ðə maʊntɪŋ blɑks, ɔlmoʊs bɪsaɪd ði ɪn dɔɹ. hi stɑp ðɛɹ, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə tɑp ə ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn blɑk.

Lan had stopped a little way down the street, staring at the paving stones in front of his feet. The Warder started back toward the inn, walking quickly, but peering at the street ahead of him as if following something. Whatever it was led straight to one of the mounting blocks, almost beside the inn door. He stopped there, staring at the top of the gray stone block.

pɛɹɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd tə əbændən ɡoʊɪŋ daʊn ði æli - ɪt stæŋk əz mʌtʃ əz ðə kənælz ɪn ðɪs pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪljən, fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ - ən wɔkt oʊvɝ tə læn, ɪnstɛd. hi sɔ wʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. pɹɛst ɪndə ðə tɑp ə ðə stoʊn maʊntɪŋ blɑk wɝ tu pɹɪns, əz ɪf ə hjudʒ haʊn hæd ɹɛstəɾ ɪts fɹpɔz ðɛɹ. ðə smɛl ðət wɑz ɔlmoʊs bɝn sʌlfɝ wɑz stʃɹɔŋɡəs hɪɹ. dɑɡz doʊn meɪk fʊtpɹɪns ɪn stoʊn. laɪt, ðeɪ doʊnt! hi kəd meɪk aʊt ðə tʃɹeɪl læn hæd fɑloʊd, tu. ðə haʊn hæd tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp ðə stʃɹiɾ əz fɑɹ əz ðə maʊntɪŋ blɑk, ðən tɝn ən ɡɔn bæk ðə weɪ ɪt hæd kʌm. livɪŋ tʃɹæks ɪn ðə stoʊn əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn ə plaʊd fild. ðeɪ dʒʌs doʊnt!

Perrin decided to abandon going down the alley - it stank as much as the canals in this part of Illian, for one thing - and walked over to Lan, instead. He saw what the Warder was staring at right away. Pressed into the top of the stone mounting block were two prints, as if a huge hound had rested its forepaws there. The smell that was almost burned sulphur was strongest here. Dogs don't make footprints in stone. Light, they don't! He could make out the trail Lan had followed, too. The hound had trotted up the street as far as the mounting block, then turned and gone back the way it had come. Leaving tracks in the stone as if they had been a plowed field. They just don't!

"dɑɹkhaʊnd," læn sɛd, ən zɑɹin ɡæspt. lɔɪəl moʊn sɔfli. fəɹ ən oʊɡiɝ. "eɪ dɑɹkhaʊn livz noʊ mɑɹk ɑn dɝt, blæksmɪθ, nɑɾ ivən ɑn mʌd, bʌt stoʊn ɪz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. ðəɹ hæzən bɪn ə dɑɹkhaʊn sin saʊθ ə ðə maʊntənz ə dum sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. ðɪs wʌn wɑz hʌntɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, aɪd seɪ. ən naʊ ðəɾ ɪts faʊn ɪt, ɪts ɡɔn tə tɛl ɪts mæstɝ."

"Darkhound," Lan said, and Zarine gasped. Loial moaned softly. For an Ogier. "A Darkhound leaves no mark on dirt, blacksmith, not even on mud, but stone is another matter. There hasn't been a Darkhound seen south of the Mountains of Dhoom since the Trolloc Wars. This one was hunting for something, I'd say. And now that it has found it, it has gone to tell its master."

mi? pɛɹɪn θɔt. ɡɹeɪ mɛn ən dɑɹkhaʊnz hʌntɪŋ mi? ðɪs ɪz kɹeɪzi!

Me? Perrin thought. Gray Men and Darkhounds hunting me? This is crazy!

"ɑɹ jə tɛlɪŋ mi niɾə wɑz ɹaɪt?" zɑɹin dɪmændəɾ ɪn ə ʃeɪki vɔɪs. "oʊld ɡɹɪm ɪz ɹɪli ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə waɪl hʌnt? laɪt! aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔɾ ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə stɔɹi."

"Are you telling me Nieda was right?" Zarine demanded in a shaky voice. "Old Grim is really riding with the Wild Hunt? Light! I always thought it was just a story."

"doʊn bi ə kəmplit ful, ɡɝl," læn sɛd hɑɹʃli. "ɪf ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɝ fɹi, wiɾ ɔl bi wɝs ðən dɛd baɪ naʊ." hi pɪɹɾ ɔf daʊn ðə stʃɹit, ðə weɪ ðə tʃɹæks wɛnt. "bʌt dɑɹkhaʊnz ɑɹ ɹil ɪnʌf. ɔlmoʊst əz deɪnʒɝəs əz mɹdʒɹɑl, ən hɑɹɾɝ tə kɪl."

"Don't be a complete fool, girl," Lan said harshly. "If the Dark One were free, we'd all be worse than dead by now." He peered off down the street, the way the tracks went. "But Darkhounds are real enough. Almost as dangerous as Myrddraal, and harder to kill."

"naʊ jə bɹɪŋ fɛtʃɪz ɪndə ɪt," zɑɹin mʌɾɝd. "ɡɹeɪ mɛn. fɛtʃɪz. dɑɹkhaʊnz. jə hæd bɛɾɝ lɛd mi tə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, fɑɹmbɔɪ. wʌɾ ʌðɝ sɝpɹaɪzəz juv weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi?"

"Now you bring Fetches into it," Zarine muttered. "Gray Men. Fetches. Darkhounds. You had better lead me to the Horn of Valere, farmboy. What other surprises do you have waiting for me?"

"noʊ kwɛstʃənz," læn toʊl hɝ. "ju stɪl noʊ lɪɾəl ɪnʌf ðət mɔɪɹeɪn wɪl ɹilis jə fɹəm jəɹ oʊθ, ɪf jə swɛɹ nɑt tə fɑloʊ. əl teɪk ðəɾ oʊθ maɪsɛlf, ən jə kən ɡoʊ naʊ. jə wəd bi waɪz tə ɡɪv ɪt."

"No questions," Lan told her. "You still know little enough that Moiraine will release you from your oath, if you swear not to follow. I'll take that oath myself, and you can go now. You would be wise to give it."

"ju wɪl nɑt fɹaɪɾən mi əweɪ, stoʊn-feɪs," zɑɹin sɛd. "aɪ də nɑt fɹaɪɾən izəli." bʌt ʃi saʊndəd fɹaɪɾənd. ən smɛld ɪt, tu.

"You will not frighten me away, stone-face," Zarine said. "I do not frighten easily." But she sounded frightened. And smelled it, too.

"aɪ hæv ə kwɛstʃən," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "æn aɪ wɑn ən ænsɝ. jə dɪdn sɛns ðɪs dɑɹkhaʊnd, læn, ən niðɝ dɪd mɔɪɹeɪn. waɪ nɑt?"

"I have a question," Perrin said, "and I want an answer. You didn't sense this Darkhound, Lan, and neither did Moiraine. Why not?"

ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə taɪm. "ði ænsɝ tə ðæt, blæksmɪθ," hi sɛd ɡɹɪmli ət læst, "meɪ bi mɔɹ ðən jə əɹ aɪ, iðɝ wʌn, wɑnə noʊ. aɪ hoʊp ði ænsɝ dʌz nɑt kɪl əs ɔl. jə θɹi ɡɛt wʌt slip jə kæn. aɪ daʊt wɪl steɪ ðə naɪɾ ɪn ɪljən, ən aɪ fɪɹ wɪv hɑɹd ɹaɪɾɪŋ əhɛd."

The Warder was silent for a time. "The answer to that, blacksmith," he said grimly at last, "may be more than you or I, either one, want to know. I hope the answer does not kill us all. You three get what sleep you can. I doubt we will stay the night in Illian, and I fear we have hard riding ahead."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"What are you going to do?" Perrin asked.

"aɪ æm ɡoʊɪŋ æftɝ mɔɪɹeɪn. tə tɛl əɹ əbaʊt ðə dɑɹkhaʊnd. ʃi kæn bi æŋɡɹi wɪð mi fəɹ fɑloʊɪŋ fəɹ ðæt, nɑt wən ʃi wəd nɑt noʊ ɪt wɑz ðəɹ əntɪl ɪt tʊk əɹ θɹoʊt."

"I am going after Moiraine. To tell her about the Darkhound. She can't be angry with me for following for that, not when she would not know it was there until it took her throat."

ðə fɝs bɪɡ dʒɹɑps ə ɹeɪn splɑɾɪd ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz əz ðeɪ wɛn bæk ɪnsaɪd. bili hæd ɹimuv ðə læst ə ðə dɛd ɡɹeɪ mɛn ən wɑz swipɪŋ ʌp ðə sɔdʌst wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd blɛd. ðə dɑɹk-aɪd ɡɝl wɑz sɪŋɪŋ ə sæd sɔŋ əbaʊɾ ə bɔɪ livɪŋ ɪz lʌv. mɪstʃɹəs luhən wʊɾə ɛndʒɔɪɾ ɪt ɡɹeɪtli.

The first big drops of rain splatted on the paving stones as they went back inside. Bili had removed the last of the dead Gray Men and was sweeping up the sawdust where they had bled. The dark-eyed girl was singing a sad song about a boy leaving his love. Mistress Luhhan would have enjoyed it greatly.

læn ɹæn əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, əkɹɔs ðə kɑmən ɹum ən ʌp ðə stɛɹz, ən baɪ ðə taɪm pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi stɑɹɾɪŋ bæk daʊn, bʌklɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt ɑn, kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ɑɹm əz ɪf i hɑɹdli kɛɹɾ u sɔ ɪt.

Lan ran ahead of them, across the common room and up the stairs, and by the time Perrin reached the second floor, the Warder was already starting back down, buckling his sword belt on, color-shifting cloak hanging over his arm as if he hardly cared who saw it.

"ɪf hiz wɛɹɪŋ ðəɾ ɪn ə sɪɾi. . . ." lɔɪəlz ʃæɡi hɛɹ ɔlmoʊs bɹʌʃt ðə silɪŋ əz i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ ɪf aɪ kən slip, bʌɾ əl tʃɹaɪ. dʒɹimz wɪl bi mɔɹ plɛzən ðən steɪɪŋ əweɪk."

"If he is wearing that in a city. . . ." Loial's shaggy hair almost brushed the ceiling as he shook his head. "I do not know if I can sleep, but I will try. Dreams will be more pleasant than staying awake."

nɑɾ ɔlweɪz, lɔɪəl, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ əz ði oʊɡiɝ wɛn ɑn daʊn ðə hɔl.

Not always, Loial, Perrin thought as the Ogier went on down the hall.

zɑɹin sim tə wɑnə steɪ wɪð hɪm, bʌɾ i toʊld əɹ tə ɡoʊ tə slip ən fɝmli ʃʌt ðə slæɾɪd dɔɹ ɪn əɹ feɪs. hi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz oʊn bɛd ɹɪlʌktənli əz i stʃɹɪp daʊn tə hɪz ʌndɝbɹitʃɪz.

Zarine seemed to want to stay with him, but he told her to go to sleep and firmly shut the slatted door in her face. He stared at his own bed reluctantly as he stripped down to his underbreeches.

"aɪ hæv tə faɪn aʊt," hi saɪd, ən kɹɔld ɑntu ðə bɛd. ɹeɪn dʒɹʌm daʊn aʊtsaɪd, ən θʌndɝ bumd. ðə bɹiz əkɹɔs ɪz bɛd kæɹid səm ə ðə ɹeɪnz kulnəs, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i wəd niɾ ɛni ʌv ðə blæŋkəts ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə mætʃɹəs. hɪz læs θɔt bɪfɔɹ slip kleɪmd ɪm wɑz ðəɾ i hæd fɝɡɑɾən tə laɪɾ ə kændəl əɡɛn, ðoʊ ðə ɹum wɑz dɑɹk. kɛɹləs. mʌsnt bi kɛɹləs. kɛɹləsnəs ɹuənz ðə wɝk.

"I have to find out," he sighed, and crawled onto the bed. Rain drummed down outside, and thunder boomed. The breeze across his bed carried some of the rain's coolness, but he did not think he would need any of the blankets at the foot of the mattress. His last thought before sleep claimed him was that he had forgotten to light a candle again, though the room was dark. Careless. Mustn't be careless. Carelessness ruins the work.

dʒɹimz tʌmbəl θɹu hɪz hɛd. dɑɹkhaʊnz tʃeɪsɪŋ hɪm; hi nɛvɝ sɔ ðɛm, bʌɾ i kəd hɪɹ ðɛɹ haʊlɪŋ. feɪdz, ən ɡɹeɪ mɛn. ə tɔl, slɛndɝ mæn flæʃt ɪndə ðɛm əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, ɪn ɹɪtʃli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd koʊɾ ən buts wɪð ɡoʊl fɹɪnʒ; moʊst ə ðə taɪm i hɛld wʌt sim tə bi ə sɔɹd, ʃaɪnɪŋ laɪk ðə sʌn, ən læf tʃɹaɪʌmfənli. səmtaɪmz ðə mæn sæɾ ɑn ə θɹoʊn, ən kɪŋz ən kwinz ɡɹoʊvəl bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ðiz fɛl stʃɹeɪnʒ, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ɹɪli hɪz dʒɹimz əɾ ɔl.

Dreams tumbled through his head. Darkhounds chasing him; he never saw them, but he could hear their howling. Fades, and Gray Men. A tall, slender man flashed into them again and again, in richly embroidered coat and boots with gold fringe; most of the time he held what seemed to be a sword, shining like the sun, and laughed triumphantly. Sometimes the man sat on a throne, and kings and queens groveled before him. These felt strange, as if they were not really his dreams at all.

ðən ðə dʒɹimz tʃeɪnʒd, ən i nu hi wɑz ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim i sɔt. ðɪs taɪm i hæd hoʊp fəɹ ɪt.

Then the dreams changed, and he knew he was in the wolf dream he sought. This time he had hoped for it.

hi stʊɾ ətɑp ə haɪ, flæt-tɑp stoʊn spaɪɹ, ðə wɪn ɹʌfəlɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ, bɹɪŋɪŋ ə θaʊzən dʒɹaɪ sɛns ən ə feɪn hɪn ʌv wɔɾɝ hɪɾən ɪn ðə fɑɹ dɪstəns. fəɹ ən ɪnstən i θɔɾ i hæd ðə fɔɹm ʌv ə wʊlf, ən fʌmbəld əɾ ɪz oʊn bɑɾi tə meɪk ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i sɔ wɑz ɹɪli hɪm. hi wɔɹ ɪz oʊn koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz ən buts; hi hɛld ɪz baʊ, ən ɪz kwɪvɝ hʌŋ əɾ ɪz saɪd. ði æks wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ.

He stood atop a high, flat-topped stone spire, the wind ruffling his hair, bringing a thousand dry scents and a faint hint of water hidden in the far distance. For an instant he thought he had the form of a wolf, and fumbled at his own body to make sure what he saw was really him. He wore his own coat and breeches and boots; he held his bow, and his quiver hung at his side. The axe was not there.

"hɑpɝ! hɑpɝ, wɛɹ ɑɹ ju?" ðə wʊlf dɪd nɑt kʌm.

"Hopper! Hopper, where are you?" The wolf did not come.

ɹʌɡəd maʊntənz sɝaʊndəd hɪm, ən ʌðɝ tɔl spaɪɹz sɛpɝeɪɾəd baɪ æɹəd flæts ən dʒʌmbəld ɹɪdʒəz, ən səmtaɪmz ə lɑɹdʒ plætoʊ ɹaɪzɪŋ wɪð ʃɪɹ saɪdz. θɪŋz ɡɹu, bʌt nʌθɪŋ lʌʃ. tʌf, ʃɔɹt ɡɹæs. bʊʃəz wɪɹi ən kʌvɝd wɪð θɔɹn, ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz ðəɾ ivən sim tə hæv θɔɹnz ɑn ðɛɹ fæt livz. skæɾɝd, stʌntɪd tʃɹiz, twɪstəd baɪ ðə wɪnd. jɛt wʊlvz kəd faɪn hʌntɪŋ ivən ɪn ðɪs lænd.

Rugged mountains surrounded him, and other tall spires separated by arid flats and jumbled ridges, and sometimes a large plateau rising with sheer sides. Things grew, but nothing lush. Tough, short grass. Bushes wiry and covered with thorn, and other things that even seemed to have thorns on their fat leaves. Scattered, stunted trees, twisted by the wind. Yet wolves could find hunting even in this land.

əz i pɪɹɾ ət ðɪs ɹʌf lænd, ə sɝkəl ə dɑɹknəs sʌɾənli blæŋkt aʊɾ ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə maʊntənz; hi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd wɛðɝ ðə dɑɹknəs wɑz ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs əɹ hæfweɪ tə ðə maʊntənz, bʌɾ i sim tə bi siɪŋ θɹu ɪt, ən bɪɑnd. mæt, ɹætlɪŋ ə daɪs kʌp. hɪz əpoʊnən stɛɹɾ ət mæt wɪð aɪz ə faɪɝ. mæt dɪd nɑt sim tə si ðə mæn, bʌt pɛɹɪn nu hɪm.

As he peered at this rough land, a circle of darkness suddenly blanked out a part of the mountains; he could not have said whether the darkness was right in front of his face or halfway to the mountains, but he seemed to be seeing through it, and beyond. Mat, rattling a dice cup. His opponent stared at Mat with eyes of fire. Mat did not seem to see the man, but Perrin knew him.

"mæt!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "ɪts bælzəmən! laɪt, mæt, jəɹ dɪsɪŋ wɪð bælzəmən!"

"Mat!" he shouted. "It's Ba'alzamon! Light, Mat, you're dicing with Ba'alzamon!"

mæt meɪɾ ɪz tɔs, ən əz ðə daɪs spʌn, ðə vɪʒən feɪɾəd, ən ðə dɑɹk pleɪs wɑz dʒɹaɪ maʊntənz əɡɛn.

Mat made his toss, and as the dice spun, the vision faded, and the dark place was dry mountains again.

"hɑpɝ!" pɛɹɪn tɝn sloʊli, lʊkɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. hi ivən lʊkt ʌp ɪn ðə skaɪ - hi kən flaɪ, naʊ - wɛɹ klaʊdz pɹɑməst ə ɹeɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn fɑɹ bɪloʊ ðə spaɪɹ tɑp wəd dʒɹɪŋk ʌp əz sun əz ɪt fɛl. "hɑpɝ!"

"Hopper!" Perrin turned slowly, looking in every direction. He even looked up in the sky - He can fly, now - where clouds promised a rain the ground far below the spire top would drink up as soon as it fell. "Hopper!"

ə dɑɹknəs fɔɹmd əmʌŋ ðə klaʊdz, ə hoʊl ɪndə sʌmwɛɹ ɛls. ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn stʊd lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə hjudʒ mɛɾəl keɪdʒ, wɪð ə ɹeɪz dɔɹ hɛld ɑn ə hɛvi spɹɪŋ. ðeɪ stɛpt ɪn ən ɹitʃt ʌp təɡɛðɝ tə lus ðə kætʃ. ðə bɑɹd dɔɹ snæp daʊn bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ə wʊmən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɔl ɪn bɹeɪdz læft ət ðɛm, ən ənʌðɝ wʊmən ɔl ɪn waɪt læft ət hɝ. ðə hoʊl ɪn ðə skaɪ kloʊzd, ən ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli klaʊdz.

A darkness formed among the clouds, a hole into somewhere else. Egwene and Nynaeve and Elayne stood looking at a huge metal cage, with a raised door held on a heavy spring. They stepped in and reached up together to loose the catch. The barred door snapped down behind them. A woman with her hair all in braids laughed at them, and another woman all in white laughed at her. The hole in the sky closed, and there were only clouds.

"hɑpɝ, wɛɹ ɑɹ ju?" hi kɔld. "aɪ nid ju! hɑpɝ!"

"Hopper, where are you?" he called. "I need you! Hopper!"

ən ðə ɡɹɪzəld wʊlf wɑz ðɛɹ, əlaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə spaɪɹ tɑp əz ɪf i hæd lɛp fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ haɪɝ.

And the grizzled wolf was there, alighting on the spire top as if he had leaped from somewhere higher.

deɪnʒɝəs. juv bɪn wɔɹnd, jʌŋ bʊl. tu jʌŋ. tu nu jɛt.

Dangerous. You have been warned, Young Bull. Too young. Too new yet.

"aɪ nid tə noʊ, hɑpɝ. jə sɛd ðəɹ wɝ θɪŋz aɪ mʌst si. aɪ nid tə si mɔɹ, noʊ mɔɹ." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, θɪŋkɪŋ ə mæt, ʌv ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn. "ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz aɪ si hɪɹ. ɑɹ ðeɪ ɹil?" hɑpɝz sɛndɪŋ sim sloʊ, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ soʊ sɪmpəl ðə wʊlf kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə nid tə ɪkspleɪn ɪt, əɹ haʊ tə. faɪnəli, ðoʊ, sʌmθɪŋ keɪm.

"I need to know, Hopper. You said there were things I must see. I need to see more, know more." He hesitated, thinking of Mat, of Egwene and Nynaeve and Elayne. "The strange things I see here. Are they real?" Hopper's sending seemed slow, as if it were so simple the wolf could not understand the need to explain it, or how to. Finally, though, something came.

wʌɾ ɪz ɹil ɪz nɑt ɹil. wʌɾ ɪz nɑt ɹil ɪz ɹil. flɛʃ ɪz ə dʒɹim, ən dʒɹimz əv flɛʃ.

What is real is not real. What is not real is real. Flesh is a dream, and dreams have flesh.

"ðæt dʌzn tɛl mi ɛniθɪŋ, hɑpɝ. aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd." ðə wʊlf lʊkt ət hɪm, əz ɪf i hæd sɛɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðət wɔɾɝ wɑz wɛt. "ju sɛɾ aɪ hæd tə si sʌmθɪŋ, ən jə ʃoʊd mi bælzəmən, ən lænfɝ."

"That doesn't tell me anything, Hopper. I do not understand." The wolf looked at him, as if he had said he did not understand that water was wet. "You said I had to see something, and you showed me Ba'alzamon, and Lanfear."

hɑɹtfæŋ. munhʌntɝ.

Heartfang. Moonhunter.

"waɪ dɪd jə ʃoʊ mi, hɑpɝ? waɪ dɪɾ aɪ hæv tə si ðɛm?"

"Why did you show me, Hopper? Why did I have to see them?"

ðə læs hʌn kʌmz. sædnəs fɪl ðə sɛndɪŋ, ən ə sɛns ʌv ɪnɛvɪɾəbɪlɪti. wʌt wɪl bi mʌs bi.

The Last Hunt comes. Sadness filled the sending, and a sense of inevitability. What will be must be.

"aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd! ðə læs hʌnt? wʌt læs hʌnt? hɑpɝ, ɡɹeɪ mɛn keɪm tə kɪl mi tənaɪt."

"I do not understand! The Last Hunt? What Last Hunt? Hopper, Gray Men came to kill me tonight."

ðə nɑtdɛd hʌn ju?

The Notdead hunt you?

"jɛs! ɡɹeɪ mɛn! æftɝ mi! ən ə dɑɹkhaʊnd wɑz ɹaɪɾ aʊtsaɪd ði ɪn! aɪ wɑnə noʊ waɪ ðəɹ æftɝ mi."

"Yes! Gray Men! After me! And a Darkhound was right outside the inn! I want to know why they're after me."

ʃæɾoʊbɹəðɝz! hɑpɝ kɹaʊtʃt, lʊkɪŋ tə iðɝ saɪɾ əz ɪf i ɔlmoʊst ɪkspɛktəɾ ən ətæk. lɔŋ sɪns wɪv sin ðə ʃæɾoʊbɹəðɝz. jə mʌst ɡoʊ, jʌŋ bʊl. ɡɹeɪt deɪnʒɝ! fli ðə ʃæɾoʊbɹəðɝz!

Shadowbrothers! Hopper crouched, looking to either side as if he almost expected an attack. Long since we have seen the Shadowbrothers. You must go, Young Bull. Great danger! Flee the Shadowbrothers!

"waɪ ɑɹ ðeɪ æftɝ mi, hɑpɝ? jə də noʊ. aɪ noʊ jə du!"

"Why are they after me, Hopper? You do know. I know you do!"

fli, jʌŋ bʊl. hɑpɝ lɛpt, fɹpɔz hɪɾɪŋ pɛɹɪnz tʃɛst, nɑkɪŋ ɪm bæk, oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ. fli ðə ʃæɾoʊbɹəðɝz.

Flee, Young Bull. Hopper leaped, forepaws hitting Perrin's chest, knocking him back, over the edge. Flee the Shadowbrothers.

ðə wɪn ɹʌʃt ɪn ɪz ɪɹz əz i fɛl. hɑpɝ ən ði ɛdʒ ə ðə spaɪɹ tɑp dwɪndəld əbʌv hɪm. "waɪ, hɑpɝ?" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "aɪ hæv tə noʊ waɪ!"

The wind rushed in his ears as he fell. Hopper and the edge of the spire top dwindled above him. "Why, Hopper?" he shouted. "I have to know why!"

ðə læs hʌn kʌmz.

The Last Hunt comes.

hi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɪt. hi nu ɪt. ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪloʊ ɹʌʃt ʌp ət hɪm, ən i tɛnst əɡɛns ðə kɹʌʃɪŋ ɪmpæk ðæt. . . .

He was going to hit. He knew it. The ground below rushed up at him, and he tensed against the crushing impact that. . . .

hi stɑɹɾəd əweɪk, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə kændəl flɪkɝɪŋ ɑn ðə smɔl teɪbəl bɪsaɪd ðə bɛd. laɪtnɪŋ flæʃɪz lɪt ðə wɪndoʊ, ən θʌndɝ ɹæɾəld ɪt. "wʌt dɪɾ i min, ðə læs hʌnt?" hi mʌmbəld. aɪ dɪd nɑt laɪɾ ɛni kændəl.

He started awake, staring at the candle flickering on the small table beside the bed. Lightning flashes lit the window, and thunder rattled it. "What did he mean, the Last Hunt?" he mumbled. I did not light any candle.

"ju tɔk tə jɝsɛlf. ən θɹæʃ ɪn jəɹ slip."

"You talk to yourself. And thrash in your sleep."

hi dʒʌmpt, ən kɝs hɪmsɛlf fəɹ nɑt hævɪŋ noʊɾəst ði ɝbəl sɛn ɪn ði ɛɹ. zɑɹin sæɾ ɑn ə stul ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə kændəllaɪt, ɛlboʊ ɑn əɹ ni, tʃɪn ɑn əɹ fɪst, wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm.

He jumped, and cursed himself for not having noticed the herbal scent in the air. Zarine sat on a stool at the edge of the candlelight, elbow on her knee, chin on her fist, watching him.

"ju ɑɹ tɑvɝən," ʃi sɛɾ əz ɪf tɪkɪŋ ɔf ə pɔɪnt. "stoʊn-feɪs θɪŋks ðoʊz ɑɾ aɪz ə jʊɹz kən si θɪŋz ɪz kænt. ɡɹeɪ mɛn wɑnə kɪl ju. jə tʃɹævəl wɪð ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ə wɔɹɾɝ, ən ən oʊɡiɝ. jə fɹi keɪdʒd il ən kɪl waɪtkloʊks. hu ɑɹ ju, fɑɹmbɔɪ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn?" hɝ vɔɪs sɛd ðət wɑz ðə moʊst ɹɪdɪkjələs θɪŋ ʃi kəd θɪŋk ʌv, bʌɾ i stɪl ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli. "huɛvɝ jə ɑɹ, bɪɡ mæn," ʃi æɾəd, "ju kəd də wɪð ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ hɛɹ ɑn jəɹ tʃɛst."

"You are ta'veren," she said as if ticking off a point. "Stone-face thinks those odd eyes of yours can see things his can't. Gray Men want to kill you. You travel with an Aes Sedai, a Warder, and an Ogier. You free caged Aiel and kill Whitecloaks. Who are you, farmboy, the Dragon Reborn?" Her voice said that was the most ridiculous thing she could think of, but he still shifted uneasily. "Whoever you are, big man," she added, "you could do with a little more hair on your chest."

hi twɪstəɾ ɝaʊnd, kɝsɪŋ, ən skɹæbəld wʌn ə ðə blæŋkəts oʊvɝ ɪm tə hɪz nɛk. laɪt, ʃi kips meɪkɪŋ mi dʒʌmp laɪk ə fɹɑɡ ɑn ə hɑt ɹɑk. zɑɹinz feɪs wɑz ət ði ɛdʒ ə ʃædoʊz. hi kəd nɑt si hɝ klɪɹli ɪksɛpt wən laɪtnɪŋ ʃoʊn θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ, ðə hɑɹʃ ɪluməneɪʃən kæstɪŋ ɪts oʊn ʃædoʊz əkɹɔs əɹ stʃɹɔŋ noʊz ən haɪ tʃikboʊnz. sʌɾənli hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd mɪn seɪɪŋ i ʃəd ɹʌn fɹəm ə bjuɾəfəl wʊmən. wʌns i hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz lænfɝ ɪn ðət wʊlf dʒɹim, hi hæd θɔt mɪn mʌs min əɹ - hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl fəɹ ə wʊmən tə bi ɛni mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl ðən lænfɝ - bʌt ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ɪn ə dʒɹim. zɑɹin wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð ðoʊz dɑɹk, tɪltəɾ aɪz, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ, weɪɪŋ.

He twisted around, cursing, and scrabbled one of the blankets over him to his neck. Light, she keeps making me jump like a frog on a hot rock. Zarine's face was at the edge of shadows. He could not see her clearly except when lightning shone through the window, the harsh illumination casting its own shadows across her strong nose and high cheekbones. Suddenly he remembered Min saying he should run from a beautiful woman. Once he had recognized Lanfear in that wolf dream, he had thought Min must mean her - he did not think it was possible for a woman to be any more beautiful than Lanfear - but she was just in a dream. Zarine was sitting there staring at him with those dark, tilted eyes, considering, weighing.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?" hi dɪmændəd. "wʌt dʒju wɑnt? hu ɑɹ ju?"

"What are you doing here?" he demanded. "What do you want? Who are you?"

ʃi θɹu bæk əɹ hɛɾ ən læft. "aɪ æm feɪl, fɑɹmbɔɪ, ə hʌntɝ ə ðə hɔɹn. hu dʒju θɪŋk aɪ æm, ðə wʊmən ə jəɹ dʒɹimz? waɪ dɪd jə dʒʌmp ðət weɪ? jə wəd θɪŋk aɪ hæd ɡus ju."

She threw back her head and laughed. "I am Faile, farmboy, a Hunter of the Horn. Who do you think I am, the woman of your dreams? Why did you jump that way? You would think I had goosed you."

bɪfɔɹ i kəd faɪnd wɝdz, ðə dɔɹ kɹæʃt bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, ən mɔɪɹeɪn stʊɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, hɝ feɪs əz peɪl ən ɡɹɪm əz dɛθ. "jɔɹ wʊlf dʒɹimz tɛl əz tʃɹuli əz ə dʒɹimɝz, pɛɹɪn. ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ lus, ən wʌn ə ðɛm ɹulz ɪn ɪljən."

Before he could find words, the door crashed back against the wall, and Moiraine stood in the doorway, her face as pale and grim as death. "Your wolf dreams tell as truly as a Dreamer's, Perrin. The Forsaken are loose, and one of them rules in Illian."


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾifɔɹ


CHAPTER 44

hʌntəd


Hunted

pɛɹɪn klaɪmd ɔf ðə bɛɾ ən stɑɹɾəd dʒɹɛsɪŋ, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ wɛðɝ zɑɹin wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ nɑt. hi nu wʌɾ i ɪntɛndəd tə du, bʌɾ i æsk mɔɪɹeɪn ɛniweɪ. "du wi liv?"

Perrin climbed off the bed and started dressing, not caring whether Zarine was watching or not. He knew what he intended to do, but he asked Moiraine anyway. "Do we leave?"

"ənlɛs jə wɑnə meɪk kloʊsɝ əkweɪntəns wɪð sɑmaɪl," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. θʌndɝ kɹæʃt oʊvɝhɛɾ əz ɪf tə pʌŋktʃueɪɾ əɹ sɛntəns, ən laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɛɹli ɡlænst ət zɑɹin.

"Unless you want to make closer acquaintance with Sammael," she said dryly. Thunder crashed overhead as if to punctuate her sentence, and lightning flashed. The Aes Sedai barely glanced at Zarine.

stʌfɪŋ ɪz ʃɝteɪl ɪndə hɪz bɹitʃɪz, hi sʌɾənli wɪʃt i hæɾ ɪz koʊɾ ən kloʊk ɑn. neɪmɪŋ wɪtʃ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɪt wɑz meɪd ðə ɹum sim koʊld. bælzəmən ɪzən bæɾ ɪnʌf; wɪv tə hæv ðə fɔɹseɪkən lus, tu. laɪt, dʌz ɪɾ ivən mæɾɝ ɪf wi faɪn ɹænd, naʊ? ɪz ɪt tu leɪt? bʌɾ i kɛp dʒɹɛsɪŋ, stæmpɪŋ ɪz fiɾ ɪndə hɪz buts. ɪt wɑz ðəɾ əɹ ɡɪv ʌp, ən tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk wɝ nɑt noʊn fəɹ ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp.

Stuffing his shirttail into his breeches, he suddenly wished he had his coat and cloak on. Naming which one of the Forsaken it was made the room seem cold. Ba'alzamon isn't bad enough; we have to have the Forsaken loose, too. Light, does it even matter if we find Rand, now? Is it too late? But he kept dressing, stamping his feet into his boots. It was that or give up, and Two Rivers folk were not known for giving up.

"sɑmaɪl?" zɑɹin sɛd feɪnli. "wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɹulz . . . ? laɪt!"

"Sammael?" Zarine said faintly. "One of the Forsaken rules . . . ? Light!"

"du jə stɪl wɪʃ tə fɑloʊ?" mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ wəd nɑt meɪk jə steɪ hɪɹ, nɑt naʊ, bʌɾ əl ɡɪv jə wʌn læs tʃæns tə swɛɹ tə ɡoʊ ənʌðɝ weɪ ðən aɪ."

"Do you still wish to follow?" Moiraine said softly. "I would not make you stay here, not now, but I will give you one last chance to swear to go another way than I."

zɑɹin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən pɛɹɪn pɔzd wɪð ɪz koʊt hæf ɑn. ʃʊɹli noʊ wʌn wəd tʃuz tə ɡoʊ wɪð pipəl u hæɾ ɪnkɝd ðə ɹæθ ʌv wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. nɑt naʊ ðət ʃi nu sʌmθɪŋ ʌv wʌt ðeɪ feɪst. nɑɾ ənlɛs ʃiz ə vɛɹi ɡʊd ɹizən. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ɛniwʌn u hɝd wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɑz lus ʃəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bi ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ə si foʊk ʃɪp ən æskɪŋ pæsədʒ tə ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ði il weɪst, nɑt sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ.

Zarine hesitated, and Perrin paused with his coat half on. Surely no one would choose to go with people who had incurred the wrath of one of the Forsaken. Not now that she knew something of what they faced. Not unless she has a very good reason. For that matter, anyone who heard one of the Forsaken was loose should already be running for a Sea Folk ship and asking passage to the other side of the Aiel Waste, not sitting there thinking.

"noʊ," zɑɹin sɛd faɪnəli, ən i bɪɡæn tə ɹɪlæks. "noʊ, əl nɑt swɛɹ tə ɡoʊ ənʌðɝ weɪ. wɛðɝ jə lɛd mi tə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ əɹ nɑt, nɑɾ ivən huɛvɝ dʌz faɪn ðə hɔɹn wɪl əv ə stɔɹi sətʃ əz ðɪs. aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs stɔɹi wɪl bi toʊl fəɹ ði eɪdʒəz, ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən əl bi pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt."

"No," Zarine said finally, and he began to relax. "No, I will not swear to go another way. Whether you lead me to the Horn of Valere or not, not even whoever does find the Horn will have a story such as this. I think this story will be told for the ages, Aes Sedai, and I will be part of it."

"noʊ!" pɛɹɪn snæpt. "ðæɾ ɪz nɑt ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf. wʌt dʒju wɑnt?"

"No!" Perrin snapped. "That is not good enough. What do you want?"

"aɪ hæv noʊ taɪm fəɹ ðɪs bɪkɝɪŋ," mɔɪɹeɪn bɹoʊk ɪn. "ɛni moʊmən lɔɹd bɹɛn meɪ lɝn ðət wʌn ə hɪz dɑɹkhaʊnz ɪz dɛd. jə kən bi ʃʊɹ hɪl noʊ ðət minz ə wɔɹɾɝ, ən hɪl kʌm lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɡeɪɾɪnz ɛɛs sədaɪ. dʒju min tə sɪt hɪɹ əntɪl i dɪskʌvɝz wɛɹ jə ɑɹ? muv, jə fulɪʃ tʃɪlʒɹən! muv!" ʃi vænɪʃt daʊn ðə hɔl bɪfɔɹ i kəɾ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ.

"I have no time for this bickering," Moiraine broke in. "Any moment Lord Brend may learn that one of his Darkhounds is dead. You can be sure he will know that means a Warder, and he will come looking for the Gaidin's Aes Sedai. Do you mean to sit here until he discovers where you are? Move, you foolish children! Move!" She vanished down the hall before he could open his mouth.

zɑɹin dɪd nɑt weɪt, iðɝ, ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɹum wɪθaʊɾ əɹ kændəl. pɛɹɪn heɪstəli ɡæðɝɾ ɪz θɪŋz ən dæʃt fəɹ ðə bæk stɛɹz stɪl bʌklɪŋ ɪz æks bɛlt ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst. hi kɑɾ ʌp tə lɔɪəl ɡoʊɪŋ daʊn, ði oʊɡiɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stʌf ə wʊd-baʊn bʊk ɪndə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən pʊɾ ɑn ɪz kloʊk ət ðə seɪm taɪm. pɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ə hænd wɪð ðə kloʊk waɪl ðeɪ boʊθ ɹæn daʊn ðə stɛɹz, ən zɑɹin kɑt ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd dæʃ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə pɔɹɪŋ ɹeɪn.

Zarine did not wait, either, running from the room without her candle. Perrin hastily gathered his things and dashed for the back stairs still buckling his axe belt around his waist. He caught up to Loial going down, the Ogier trying to stuff a wood-bound book into his saddlebags and put on his cloak at the same time. Perrin gave him a hand with the cloak while they both ran down the stairs, and Zarine caught the pair of them before they could dash out into the pouring rain.

pɛɹɪn hʌntʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝz əɡɛns ðə wɛɾ ən ɹæn fəɹ ðə steɪbəl əkɹɔs ðə stɔɹm-dɑɹkən jɑɹd wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ tə pʊl ʌp ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk. ʃiz tə hæv ə ɹizən. biɪŋ ɪn ə blʌɾi stɔɹi ɪzən ɹizən ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛni bʌɾ ə mædwʊmən! ðə ɹeɪn soʊkt ɪz ʃæɡi kɝlz, leɪɪŋ əm flæɾ ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd, bɪfɔɹ i dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ðə steɪbəl dɔɹ.

Perrin hunched his shoulders against the wet and ran for the stable across the storm-darkened yard without waiting to pull up the hood of his cloak. She has to have a reason. Being in a bloody story isn't reason enough for any but a madwoman! The rain soaked his shaggy curls, laying them flat around his head, before he darted through the stable door.

mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ɪn ən ɔɪl kloʊk stɪl biɾɪd wɪð ɹeɪn, ən niɾə hoʊldɪŋ ə læntɝn fəɹ læn tə fɪnɪʃ sæɾəlɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛkstʃɹə, ə beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ wɪð ən ivən stʃɹɔŋɝ noʊz ðən zɑɹinz.

Moiraine was there before them, in an oiled cloak still beaded with rain, and Nieda holding a lantern for Lan to finish saddling the horses. There was an extra, a bay gelding with an even stronger nose than Zarine's.

"aɪ wɪl sɛn pɪdʒənz ɛvɹi deɪ," ðə staʊt wʊmən wɑz seɪɪŋ. "noʊ wʌn wɪl səspɛk mi. fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi! ivən waɪtkloʊks də spik wɛl ə mi."

"I will send pigeons every day," the stout woman was saying. "No one will suspect me. Fortune prick me! Even Whitecloaks do speak well of me."

"lɪsən tə mi, wʊmən!" mɔɪɹeɪn snæpt. "ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ə waɪtkloʊk əɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛn aɪ spik ʌv. jəl fli ðɪs sɪɾi, ən meɪk ɛniwʌn jə kɛɹ fəɹ fli wɪð ju. fəɹ ə dʌzən jɪɹz juv oʊbeɪd mi. oʊbeɪ mi naʊ!" niɾə nɑɾəd, bʌt ɹɪlʌktənli, ən mɔɪɹeɪn ɡɹaʊld wɪð ɛksæspɝeɪʃən.

"Listen to me, woman!" Moiraine snapped. "This is not a Whitecloak or a Darkfriend I speak of. You will flee this city, and make anyone you care for flee with you. For a dozen years you have obeyed me. Obey me now!" Nieda nodded, but reluctantly, and Moiraine growled with exasperation.

"ðə beɪ ɪz jʊɹz, ɡɝl," læn sɛd tə zɑɹin. "ɡɛɾ ɑn ɪz bæk. ɪf jə də nɑt noʊ haʊ tə ɹaɪd, jə mʌs lɝn baɪ duɪŋ, əɹ teɪk maɪ ɔfɝ."

"The bay is yours, girl," Lan said to Zarine. "Get on his back. If you do not know how to ride, you must learn by doing, or take my offer."

pʊɾɪŋ wʌn hæn ɑn ðə haɪ pɑməl, ʃi vɔltəɾ izəli ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. "aɪ wɑz ɑn ə hɔɹs wʌns, stoʊn-feɪs, naʊ ðəɾ aɪ θɪŋk ʌv ɪt." ʃi twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn tə taɪ hɝ bʌndəl bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Putting one hand on the high pommel, she vaulted easily into the saddle. "I was on a horse once, stone-face, now that I think of it." She twisted around to tie her bundle behind her.

"wʌt dɪd jə min, mɔɪɹeɪn?" pɛɹɪn dɪmændəɾ əz i tɔst ɪz sæɾəlbæɡ əkɹɔs stɛpɝz bæk. "ju sɛɾ i wəd faɪn aʊt wɛɹ aɪ æm. hi noʊz. ðə ɡɹeɪ mɛn!" niɾə ɡɪɡəld, ən i wʌndɝɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi ɹɪli nu əɹ bɪlivd əmʌŋ ðə θɪŋz ʃi sɛd ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪn.

"What did you mean, Moiraine?" Perrin demanded as he tossed his saddlebag across Stepper's back. "You said he would find out where I am. He knows. The Gray Men!" Nieda giggled, and he wondered irritably how much she really knew or believed among the things she said she did not believe in.

"sɑmaɪl dɪd nɑt sɛn ðə ɡɹeɪ mɛn." mɔɪɹeɪn maʊntəɾ ɑldib wɪð ə kul, stʃɹeɪt-bæk pɹisɪʒən, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ hɝi. "ðə dɑɹkhaʊnd wɑz hɪz, haʊɛvɝ. aɪ bɪliv ɪt fɑloʊd maɪ tʃɹeɪl. hi wəd nɑɾ əv sɛn boʊθ. sʌmwʌn wɑns ju, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk sɑmaɪl ivən noʊz jə ɪɡzɪst. jɛt." pɛɹɪn stɑpt wɪð wʌn fʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəp, stɛɹɪŋ ət hɝ, bʌt ʃi simd mɔɹ kənsɝnd wɪð pæɾɪŋ əɹ mɛɹz ɑɹtʃɪŋ nɛk ðən wɪð ðə kwɛstʃənz ɑn ɪz feɪs.

"Sammael did not send the Gray Men." Moiraine mounted Aldieb with a cool, straight-backed precision, almost as if there were no hurry. "The Darkhound was his, however. I believe it followed my trail. He would not have sent both. Someone wants you, but I do not think Sammael even knows you exist. Yet." Perrin stopped with one foot in the stirrup, staring at her, but she seemed more concerned with patting her mare's arching neck than with the questions on his face.

"æz wɛl aɪ wɛn æftɝ ju," læn sɛd, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ snɪf laʊdli.

"As well I went after you," Lan said, and the Aes Sedai sniffed loudly.

"aɪ kəd wɪʃ jə wɝ ə wʊmən, ɡeɪɾɪn. aɪ wəd sɛn jə tə ðə taʊɝ əz ə nɑvəs tə lɝn tə oʊbeɪ!" hi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ən tʌtʃt ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd, ðən swʌŋ ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl, ən ʃi saɪd. "pɝhæps ɪts əz wɛl jə ɑɹ dɪsəbiɾiənt. səmtaɪmz ɪts wɛl. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ʃɛɹiəm ən sɪuən sɑntʃ təɡɛðɝ kəd titʃ jə oʊbiɾiəns."

"I could wish you were a woman, Gaidin. I would send you to the Tower as a novice to learn to obey!" He raised an eyebrow and touched the hilt of his sword, then swung into his saddle, and she sighed. "Perhaps it is as well you are disobedient. Sometimes it is well. Besides, I do not think Sheriam and Siuan Sanche together could teach you obedience."

"aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd," pɛɹɪn sɛd. aɪ sim tə bi seɪɪŋ ðəɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil, ən aɪm taɪɝɾ ʌv ɪt. aɪ wɑn səm ænsɝz aɪ kən ʌndɝstænd. hi pʊl hɪmsɛlf ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ʌp soʊ mɔɪɹeɪn wəd nɑt bi lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət hɪm; ʃi hæɾ ɪnʌf ædvæntɪdʒ wɪθaʊt ðæt. "ɪf i dɪd nɑt sɛn ðə ɡɹeɪ mɛn, hu dɪd? ɪf ə mɹdʒɹɑl, əɹ ənʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən. . . ." hi stɑp tə swɑloʊ. ənʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən! laɪt! "ɪf sʌmbɑɾi ɛls sɛn ðɛm, waɪ dɪd ðeɪ nɑt tɛl hɪm? ðəɹ ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ɑɹən ðeɪ? ən waɪ mi, mɔɪɹeɪn? waɪ mi? ɹænd ɪz ðə blʌɾi dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!"

"I do not understand," Perrin said. I seem to be saying that a great deal, and I'm tired of it. I want some answers I can understand. He pulled himself the rest of the way up so Moiraine would not be looking down at him; she had enough advantage without that. "If he did not send the Gray Men, who did? If a Myrddraal, or another Forsaken. . . ." He stopped to swallow. ANOTHER Forsaken! Light! "If somebody else sent them, why did they not tell him? They're all Darkfriends, aren't they? And why me, Moiraine? Why me? Rand is the bloody Dragon Reborn!"

hi hɝd ðə ɡæsps fɹəm zɑɹin ən niɾə, ən oʊnli ðən ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ i hæd sɛd. mɔɪɹeɪnz stɛɹ sim tə skɪn ɪm laɪk ðə ʃɑɹpəst stil. heɪsti blʌɾi tʌŋ. wən dɪɾ aɪ stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ bɪfɔɹ aɪ spik? ɪt sim tə hɪm ɪt hæd hæpənd wən i fɝs fɛl zɑɹinz aɪz wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. ʃi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm naʊ, wɪð əɹ maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən.

He heard the gasps from Zarine and Nieda, and only then realized what he had said. Moiraine's stare seemed to skin him like the sharpest steel. Hasty bloody tongue. When did I stop thinking before I speak? It seemed to him it had happened when he first felt Zarine's eyes watching him. She was watching him now, with her mouth hanging open.

"ju ɑɹ sil tə ʌs, naʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn toʊl ðə boʊld-feɪst wʊmən. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ tɝnɪŋ bæk fəɹ ju. ɛvɝ." zɑɹin lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ ən wɑz əfɹeɪd tə, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən ɛlswɛɹ. "niɾə, fli ɪljən tənaɪt. ɪn ðɪs aʊɝ! ən hoʊl jəɹ tʌŋ ivən bɛɾɝ ðən juv hɛld ɪɾ ɔl ðiz jɪɹz. ðəɹ ɑɹ ðoʊz u wəd kʌɾ ɪɾ aʊt fəɹ wʌt jə kəd seɪ, bɪfɔɹ aɪ kəɾ ivən faɪn ju." hɝ hɑɹd toʊn lɛf daʊts əz tə ɪɡzækli haʊ ʃi mɛn ðæt, ən niɾə nɑɾəd vɪɡɝəsli əz ɪf ʃi hæd hɝɾ ɪt boʊθ weɪz.

"You are sealed to us, now," Moiraine told the bold-faced woman. "There is no turning back for you. Ever." Zarine looked as if she wanted to say something and was afraid to, but the Aes Sedai had already turned her attention elsewhere. "Nieda, flee Illian tonight. In this hour! And hold your tongue even better than you have held it all these years. There are those who would cut it out for what you could say, before I could even find you." Her hard tone left doubts as to exactly how she meant that, and Nieda nodded vigorously as if she had heard it both ways.

"æz fəɹ ju, pɛɹɪn." ðə waɪt mɛɹ muv kloʊsɝ, ən i lin bæk fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪspaɪɾ ɔl i kəd du. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɛni θɹɛdz woʊvən ɪn ðə pæɾɝn, ən səm ɑɹ əz blæk əz ðə ʃædoʊ ɪtsɛlf. teɪk kɛɹ wʌn ə ðɛm dʌz nɑt stʃɹæŋɡəl ju." hɝ hilz tʌtʃt ɑldibz flæŋks, ən ðə mɛɹ dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ðə ɹeɪn, mændɑɹb fɑloʊɪŋ kloʊs bɪhaɪnd.

"As for you, Perrin." The white mare moved closer, and he leaned back from the Aes Sedai despite all he could do. "There are many threads woven in the Pattern, and some are as black as the Shadow itself. Take care one of them does not strangle you." Her heels touched Aldieb's flanks, and the mare darted into the rain, Mandarb following close behind.

bɝn ju, mɔɪɹeɪn, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ əz i ɹoʊɾ æftɝ ðɛm. səmtaɪmz aɪ də nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ saɪd jə ɑɹ ɑn. hi ɡlænst ət zɑɹin, ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn bɔɹn ɪn ə sæɾəl. ən huz saɪɾ ɑɹ jə ɑn?

Burn you, Moiraine, Perrin thought as he rode after them. Sometimes I do not know which side you are on. He glanced at Zarine, riding beside him as if she had been born in a saddle. And whose side are you on?

ɹeɪn kɛpt pipəl ɔf ðə stʃɹits ən kənælz, soʊ noʊ vɪzəbəl aɪz wɑtʃt əm ɡoʊ, bʌɾ ɪt meɪd ðə fʊɾɪŋ ənsɝɾən fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz ɑn ði ənivən peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ kɑzweɪ, ə waɪd ɹoʊɾ ə pæk dɝt stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ nɔɹθ θɹu ðə mɑɹʃ, ðə daʊnpɔɹ hæd bɪɡʌn tə slækən. θʌndɝ stɪl bumd, bʌt ðə laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt fɑɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, pɝhæps aʊt tə si.

Rain kept people off the streets and canals, so no visible eyes watched them go, but it made the footing uncertain for the horses on the uneven paving stones.
