By the time they reached the Maredo Causeway, a wide road of packed dirt stretching north through the marsh, the downpour had begun to slacken. Thunder still boomed, but the lightning flashed far behind them, perhaps out to sea.

pɛɹɪn fɛlt ə bɪɾ ə lʌk wɑz kʌmɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ. ðə ɹeɪn hæd steɪd lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə haɪd ðɛɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ, bʌt naʊ ɪt sim ðeɪ wəɾ əv ə klɪɹ naɪt fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ. hi sɛɾ əz mʌtʃ, bʌt læn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

Perrin felt a bit of luck was coming their way. The rain had stayed long enough to hide their departure, but now it seemed they would have a clear night for riding. He said as much, but Lan shook his head.

"dɑɹkhaʊnz laɪk klɪɹ, munlɪt naɪts bɛst, blæksmɪθ, ɹeɪn ðə list. ə ɡʊd θʌndɝstɔɹm kən kip əm əweɪ kəmplitli." əz ɪf ɪz wɝdz hæd bɪɾən ɪt, ðə ɹeɪn feɪɾəd tə ə feɪn dʒɹɪzəl. pɛɹɪn hɝd lɔɪəl ɡɹoʊn bɪhaɪn hɪm.

"Darkhounds like clear, moonlit nights best, blacksmith, rain the least. A good thunderstorm can keep them away completely." As if his words had bidden it, the rain faded to a faint drizzle. Perrin heard Loial groan behind him.

kɑzweɪ ən mɑɹʃ ɛndəd təɡɛðɝ, səm tu maɪlz əɹ soʊ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, bʌt ðə ɹoʊd kɛpt ɑn, sloʊli bɛɹɪŋ ə lɪɾəl istwɝd. klaʊd-dɑɹk ivnɪŋ feɪɾəd ɪndə naɪt, ən ðə mɪstɪŋ ɹeɪn kəntɪnjud. mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn kɛpt ə stɛɾi, ɡɹaʊnd-iɾɪŋ peɪs. ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz splæʃt θɹu pʌɾəlz ɑn ðə hɑɹd-pæk dɝt. ðə mun ʃoʊn θɹu ɡæps ɪn ðə klaʊdz. loʊ hɪlz bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪz ɝaʊn ðɛm, ən tʃɹiz tə əpɪɹ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ɔfən. pɛɹɪn θɔt ðəɹ mʌs bi fɔɹəst əhɛd, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ hi laɪk ði aɪdiə. wʊdz kəd haɪɾ əm fɹəm pɝsut; wʊdz kəd lɛt pɝsut kʌm kloʊs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ sɔ.

Causeway and marsh ended together, some two miles or so from the city, but the road kept on, slowly bearing a little eastward. Cloud-dark evening faded into night, and the misting rain continued. Moiraine and Lan kept a steady, ground-eating pace. The horses' hooves splashed through puddles on the hard-packed dirt. The moon shone through gaps in the clouds. Low hills began to rise around them, and trees to appear more and more often. Perrin thought there must be forest ahead, but he was not sure how he liked the idea. Woods could hide them from pursuit; woods could let pursuit come close before they saw.

ə θɪn haʊl ɹoʊz fɑɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. fəɹ ə moʊmən i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ə wʊlf; hi sɝpɹaɪz hɪmsɛlf baɪ nɪɹli ɹitʃɪŋ aʊt tə ðə wʊlf bɪfɔɹ i kəd stɑp. ðə kɹaɪ keɪm əɡɛn, ən i nu ɪt wɑz noʊ wʊlf. ʌðɝz ænsɝɾ ɪt, ɔl maɪlz bɪhaɪnd, ɪɹi weɪlz hoʊldɪŋ blʌɾ ən dɛθ, kɹaɪz ðət spoʊk ə naɪtmɛɹz. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn sloʊd, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stʌɾiɪŋ ðə hɪlz ɝaʊn əm ɪn ðə naɪt.

A thin howl rose far behind them. For a moment he thought it was a wolf; he surprised himself by nearly reaching out to the wolf before he could stop. The cry came again, and he knew it was no wolf. Others answered it, all miles behind, eerie wails holding blood and death, cries that spoke of nightmares. To his surprise, Lan and Moiraine slowed, the Aes Sedai studying the hills around them in the night.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ ə lɔŋ weɪ," hi sɛd. "ðeɪl nɑt kætʃ əs ɪf wi kip ɑn."

"They are a long way," he said. "They'll not catch us if we keep on."

"ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz?" zɑɹin mʌɾɝd. "ðoʊz ɑɹ ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz? ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ɪɾ ɪzən ðə waɪl hʌnt, ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

"The Darkhounds?" Zarine muttered. "Those are the Darkhounds? Are you sure it isn't the Wild Hunt, Aes Sedai?"

"bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪɾ ɪz."

"But it is," Moiraine replied. "It is."

"ju kən nɛvɝ aʊtʃɹʌn ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz, blæksmɪθ," læn sɛd, "nɑɾ ɑn ðə fæstəs hɔɹs. ɔlweɪz, jə mʌs feɪs əm ən dɪfit ðɛm, əɹ ðəl pʊl jə daʊn."

"You can never outrun the Darkhounds, blacksmith," Lan said, "not on the fastest horse. Always, you must face them and defeat them, or they will pull you down."

"aɪ cʊɾə steɪɾ ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ, jə noʊ," lɔɪəl sɛd. "maɪ mʌðɝ wʊɾə hæd mi mɛɹid baɪ naʊ, bʌɾ ɪt wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ə bæd laɪf. plɛnti ʌv bʊks. aɪ dɪd nɑɾ əv tə kʌm aʊtsaɪd."

"I could have stayed in the stedding, you know," Loial said. "My mother would have had me married by now, but it would not have been a bad life. Plenty of books. I did not have to come Outside."

"ðɛɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ə tɔl, tʃɹiləs maʊnd wɛl ɔf tə ðɛɹ ɹaɪt. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɹiz ðət pɛɹɪn kəd si fəɹ tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əɹ mɔɹ ɝaʊn ɪt, iðɝ, ən ðeɪ wɝ stɪl spɑɹs bɪɑn ðæt. "wi mʌst si ðɛm kʌmɪŋ tə hæv ə tʃæns."

"There," Moiraine said, pointing to a tall, treeless mound well off to their right. There were no trees that Perrin could see for two hundred paces or more around it, either, and they were still sparse beyond that. "We must see them coming to have a chance."

ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz' daɪɹ kɹaɪz ɹoʊz əɡɛn, kloʊsɝ, jɛt stɪl fɑɹ.

The Darkhounds' dire cries rose again, closer, yet still far.

læn kwɪkən mændɑɹbz peɪs ə lɪɾəl, naʊ ðət mɔɪɹeɪn hæd tʃoʊzən ðɛɹ ɡɹaʊnd. əz ðeɪ klaɪmd, ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz klæɾɝd ɑn ɹɑks hæf-bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə dɝɾ ən slɪk baɪ ðə dʒɹɪzəl. tə pɛɹɪnz aɪz, moʊst ə ðɛm hæd tu mɛni skwɛɹd kɔɹnɝz tə bi nætʃɹəl. ət ðə tɑp, ðeɪ dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ɝaʊnd wʌt sim tə bi ə loʊ, ɹaʊndəd boʊldɝ. ðə mun əpɪɹd θɹu ə ɡæp ɪn ðə klaʊdz, ən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə wɛðɝd stoʊn feɪs tu peɪsɪz lɔŋ. ə wʊmənz feɪs, hi θɔt fɹəm ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə hɛɹ. ðə ɹeɪn meɪɾ əɹ sim tə bi wipɪŋ.

Lan quickened Mandarb's pace a little, now that Moiraine had chosen their ground. As they climbed, the horses' hooves clattered on rocks half-buried in the dirt and slicked by the drizzle. To Perrin's eyes, most of them had too many squared corners to be natural. At the top, they dismounted around what seemed to be a low, rounded boulder. The moon appeared through a gap in the clouds, and he found himself looking at a weathered stone face two paces long. A woman's face, he thought from the length of the hair. The rain made her seem to be weeping.

mɔɪɹeɪn dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən stʊd lʊkɪŋ ɔf ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə haʊlz. ʃi wɑz ə ʃæɾoʊd, hʊɾɪd ʃeɪp, ɹeɪn kætʃɪŋ munlaɪɾ əz ɪt ɹoʊl daʊn əɹ ɔɪl kloʊk.

Moiraine dismounted and stood looking off in the direction of the howls. She was a shadowed, hooded shape, rain catching moonlight as it rolled down her oiled cloak.

lɔɪəl lɛɾ ɪz hɔɹs oʊvɝ tə pɪɹ ət ðə kɑɹvɪŋ, ðən bɛn kloʊsɝ ən fɛl ðə fitʃɝz. "aɪ θɪŋk ʃi wɑz ən oʊɡiɝ," hi sɛɾ ət læst. "bʌt ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ən oʊl stɛɾɪŋ; aɪ wəd fil ɪt. wi ɔl wʊd. ən wi wəd bi seɪf fɹəm ʃæɾoʊzpɔn."

Loial led his horse over to peer at the carving, then bent closer and felt the features. "I think she was an Ogier," he said at last. "But this is not an old stedding; I would feel it. We all would. And we would be safe from Shadowspawn."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tu stɛɹɪŋ æt?" zɑɹin skwɪntɪɾ ət ðə ɹɑk. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt? hɝ? hu?"

"What are you two staring at?" Zarine squinted at the rock. "What is it? Her? Who?"

"mɛni neɪʃənz əv ɹɪzən ən fɔlən sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd wɪθaʊt tɝnɪŋ, "sʌm livɪŋ noʊ mɔɹ ðən neɪmz ɑn ə jɛloʊd peɪdʒ, əɹ laɪnz ɑn ə tæɾɝd mæp. wɪl wi liv əz mʌtʃ bɪhaɪnd?" ðə blʌd-dʒɹɛntʃt haʊlz ɹoʊz əɡɛn, stɪl kloʊsɝ. pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə kælkjəleɪt ðɛɹ peɪs, ən θɔt læn hæd bɪn ɹaɪt; ðə hɔɹsəz kəd nɑɾ əv aʊtʃɹʌn ðɛm, æftɝ ɔl. ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv lɔŋ tə weɪt.

"Many nations have risen and fallen since the Breaking," Moiraine said without turning, "some leaving no more than names on a yellowed page, or lines on a tattered map. Will we leave as much behind?" The blood-drenched howls rose again, still closer. Perrin tried to calculate their pace, and thought Lan had been right; the horses could not have outrun them, after all. They would not have long to wait.

"oʊɡiɝ," læn sɛd, "ju ən ðə ɡɝl hoʊl ðə hɔɹsəz." zɑɹin pɹətɛstəd, bʌɾ i ɹoʊd stʃɹeɪɾ oʊvɝ tə hɝ. "jɔɹ naɪvz wɪl nɑt də mʌtʃ ɡʊd hɪɹ, ɡɝl." hɪz sɔɹd bleɪd ɡlimd ɪn ðə munlaɪɾ əz i dʒɹu ɪt. "ivən ðɪs ɪz ə læst ɹɪzɔɹt. ɪt saʊnz laɪk tɛn aʊt ðɛɹ, nɑt wʌn. jəɹ wɝk ɪz tə kip ðə hɔɹsəz fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ wən ðeɪ smɛl ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz. ivən mændɑɹb dʌz nɑt laɪk ðət smɛl."

"Ogier," Lan said, "you and the girl hold the horses." Zarine protested, but he rode straight over to her. "Your knives will not do much good here, girl." His sword blade gleamed in the moonlight as he drew it. "Even this is a last resort. It sounds like ten out there, not one. Your work is to keep the horses from running when they smell the Darkhounds. Even Mandarb does not like that smell."

ɪf ðə wɔɹɾɝz sɔɹd wɑz noʊ ɡʊd, ðən niðɝ wɑz ði æks. pɛɹɪn fɛl sʌmθɪŋ nɪɹ tə ɹɪlif ət ðæt, ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn; hi wəd nɑɾ əv tə juz ði æks. hi dʒɹu ðə lɛŋθ ə hɪz ənstʃɹʌŋ baʊ fɹəm ʌndɝ stɛpɝz sæɾəl ɡɝθs. "meɪbi ðɪs wɪl də səm ɡʊd."

If the Warder's sword was no good, then neither was the axe. Perrin felt something near to relief at that, even if they were Shadowspawn; he would not have to use the axe. He drew the length of his unstrung bow from under Stepper's saddle girths. "Maybe this will do some good."

"tʃɹaɪ ɪf jə wɪʃ, blæksmɪθ," læn sɛd. "ðeɪ də nɑt daɪ izəli. pɝhæps jəl kɪl wʌn."

"Try if you wish, blacksmith," Lan said. "They do not die easily. Perhaps you will kill one."

pɛɹɪn dʒɹu ə fɹɛʃ bɑstʃɹɪŋ fɹəm ɪz paʊtʃ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃild ɪt fɹəm ðə sɑft ɹeɪn. ðə biswæks koʊɾɪŋ wɑz θɪn, ən nɑt mʌtʃ pɹətɛkʃən əɡɛns pɹəlɔŋ dæmp. sɛɾɪŋ ðə baʊ slæntwaɪz bɪtwin ɪz lɛɡz, hi bɛn ɪɾ izəli, fɪksɪŋ ðə lups ə ðə bɑstʃɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə hɔɹn nɑks ət ði ɛnz ə ðə baʊ. wən i stʃɹeɪɾənd, hi kəd si ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz.

Perrin drew a fresh bowstring from his pouch, trying to shield it from the soft rain. The beeswax coating was thin, and not much protection against prolonged damp. Setting the bow slantwise between his legs, he bent it easily, fixing the loops of the bowstring into the horn nocks at the ends of the bow. When he straightened, he could see the Darkhounds.

ðeɪ ɹæn laɪk hɔɹsəz əɾ ə ɡæləp, ən əz i kɑt saɪɾ ə ðɛm, ðeɪ ɡæðɝd spid. ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli tɛn lɑɹdʒ ʃeɪps ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ðə naɪt, swipɪŋ θɹu ðə skæɾɝd tʃɹiz, jɛɾ i pʊld ə bɹɔdhɛɾ æɹoʊ fɹəm ɪz kwɪvɝ, nɑkt ɪt bʌt dɪd nɑt dʒɹɔ. hi hæd bɪn fɑɹ fɹəm ðə bɛs boʊmən ɪn ɛmənz fild, bʌɾ əmʌŋ ðə jʌŋɡɝ mɛn, oʊnli ɹænd hæd bɪn bɛɾɝ.

They ran like horses at a gallop, and as he caught sight of them, they gathered speed. They were only ten large shapes running in the night, sweeping through the scattered trees, yet he pulled a broadhead arrow from his quiver, nocked it but did not draw. He had been far from the best bowman in Emond's Field, but among the younger men, only Rand had been better.

ət θɹi hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz i wəd ʃut, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd. ful! juɾ əv ə hɑɹd taɪm hɪɾɪŋ ə tɑɹɡət stændɪŋ stɪl ət ðət dɪstəns. bʌɾ ɪf aɪ weɪt, ðə weɪ ðeɪ ɑɹ muvɪŋ. . . . stɛpɪŋ ʌp bɪsaɪd mɔɪɹeɪn, hi ɹeɪzd ɪz baʊ - aɪ dʒʌst əv tə ɪmædʒən ðət muvɪŋ ʃædoʊ ɪz ə bɪɡ dɔɡ - dʒɹu ðə ɡus-fɛðɝ flɛtʃɪŋz tə hɪz ɪɹ, ən lust. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə ʃæf mɝdʒd wɪð ðə nɪɹəst ʃædoʊ, bʌt ði oʊnli ɹɪzʌlt wɑz ə snɑɹl. ɪts nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə wɝk. ðəɹ kʌmɪŋ tu fæst! hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi dʒɹɔɪŋ ənʌðɝ æɹoʊ. waɪ ɑɹən jə duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, mɔɪɹeɪn? hi kəd si ðɛɹ aɪz, ʃaɪnɪŋ laɪk sɪlvɝ, ðɛɹ tiθ ɡlimɪŋ laɪk bɝnɪʃt stil. blæk əz ðə naɪɾ ɪtsɛlf ən əz bɪɡ əz smɔl poʊniz, ðeɪ spɛd təwɔɹd hɪm, saɪlənt naʊ, sikɪŋ ðə kɪl. ðə wɪn kæɹiɾ ə stɪŋk nɪɹ tə bɝn sʌlfɝ; ðə hɔɹsəz wɪkɝd fɪɹfəli, ivən lænz wɔɹhɔɹs. bɝn ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ, də sʌmθɪŋ! hi lust əɡɛn; ðə fɹʌntmoʊs dɑɹkhaʊn fɔltɝɾ ən keɪm ɑn. ðeɪ kən daɪ! hi ʃɑt wʌns mɔɹ, ən ðə lɛd dɑɹkhaʊn tʌmbəld, stæɡɝd tə ɪts fit, ðən fɛl, jɛɾ ivən əz ɪt dɪɾ i nu ə moʊmən ə dɪspɛɹ. wʌn daʊn, ən ði ʌðɝ naɪn hæd kʌvɝd tu θɝdz ə ðə dɪstəns ɔlɹɛɾi; ðeɪ sim tə bi ɹʌnɪŋ ivən fæstɝ, laɪk ʃædoʊz floʊɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnd. wʌn mɔɹ æɹoʊ. taɪm fəɹ wʌn mɔɹ, meɪbi, ən ðən ɪts ði æks. bɝn ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ! hi dʒɹu əɡɛn.

At three hundred paces he would shoot, he decided. Fool! You'd have a hard time hitting a target standing still at that distance. But if I wait, the way they are moving. . . . Stepping up beside Moiraine, he raised his bow - I just have to imagine that moving shadow is a big dog - drew the goose-feather fletchings to his ear, and loosed. He was sure the shaft merged with the nearest shadow, but the only result was a snarl. It is not going to work. They're coming too fast! He was already drawing another arrow. Why aren't you doing something, Moiraine? He could see their eyes, shining like silver, their teeth gleaming like burnished steel. Black as the night itself and as big as small ponies, they sped toward him, silent now, seeking the kill. The wind carried a stink near to burned sulphur; the horses whickered fearfully, even Lan's warhorse. Burn you, Aes Sedai, do something! He loosed again; the frontmost Darkhound faltered and came on. They can die! He shot once more, and the lead Darkhound tumbled, staggered to its feet, then fell, yet even as it did he knew a moment of despair. One down, and the other nine had covered two thirds of the distance already; they seemed to be running even faster, like shadows flowing across the ground. One more arrow. Time for one more, maybe, and then it's the axe. Burn you, Aes Sedai! He drew again.

"naʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ əz ɪz æɹoʊ lɛf ðə baʊ. ði ɛɹ bɪtwin əɹ hænz kɑt faɪɝ ən stʃɹik təwɔɹd ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz, vænkwɪʃɪŋ naɪt. ðə hɔɹsəz skwild ən lɛpt əɡɛns biɪŋ hɛld.

"Now," Moiraine said as his arrow left the bow. The air between her hands caught fire and streaked toward the Darkhounds, vanquishing night. The horses squealed and leaped against being held.

pɛɹɪn θɹu ən ɑɹm əkɹɔs ɪz aɪz tə ʃild əm fɹəm ə waɪt-hɑt ɡlɛɹ laɪk bɝnɪŋ, hit laɪk ə fɔɹdʒ kɹækɪŋ oʊpən; sʌɾən nun flɛɹɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ən wɑz ɡɔn. wən i ənkʌvɝɾ ɪz aɪz, spɑts flɪkɝɾ əkɹɔs ɪz vɪʒən, ən ðə feɪnt, feɪɾɪŋ ɪmədʒ ə ðət laɪn ə faɪɝ. wɛɹ ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz hæd bɪn wɑz nʌθɪŋ bʌt naɪt-kʌvɝd ɡɹaʊn ən ðə sɑft ɹeɪn; ði oʊnli ʃædoʊz ðət muvd wɝ kæs baɪ klaʊdz kɹɔsɪŋ ðə mun.

Perrin threw an arm across his eyes to shield them from a white-hot glare like burning, heat like a forge cracking open; sudden noon flared in the darkness, and was gone. When he uncovered his eyes, spots flickered across his vision, and the faint, fading image of that line of fire. Where the Darkhounds had been was nothing but night-covered ground and the soft rain; the only shadows that moved were cast by clouds crossing the moon.

aɪ θɔt ʃid θɹoʊ faɪɝ ət ðɛm, əɹ kɔl laɪtnɪŋ, bʌt ðɪs. . . . "wʌt wɑz ðæt?" hi æsk hɔɹsli.

I thought she'd throw fire at them, or call lightning, but this. . . . "What was that?" he asked hoarsely.

mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz piɹɪŋ ɔf təwɔɹɾ ɪljən əɡɛn, əz ɪf ʃi kəd si θɹu ɔl ðoʊz maɪlz ə dɑɹknəs. "pɝhæps i dɪd nɑt si," ʃi sɛd, ɔlmoʊs tə hɝsɛlf. "ɪɾ ɪz fɑɹ, ən ɪf i wɑz nɑt wɑtʃɪŋ, pɝhæps i dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs."

Moiraine was peering off toward Illian again, as if she could see through all those miles of darkness. "Perhaps he did not see," she said, almost to herself. "It is far, and if he was not watching, perhaps he did not notice."

"hu?" zɑɹin dɪmændəd. "sɑmaɪl?" hɝ vɔɪs ʃʊk ə lɪɾəl. "ju sɛɾ i wɑz ɪn ɪljən. haʊ kəɾ i si ɛniθɪŋ hɪɹ? wʌd jə du?"

"Who?" Zarine demanded. "Sammael?" Her voice shook a little. "You said he was in Illian. How could he see anything here? What did you do?"

"sʌmθɪŋ fɔɹbɪɾən," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd kuli. "fɔɹbɪɾən baɪ vaʊz ɔlmoʊst əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ðə θɹi oʊðz." ʃi tʊk ɑldibz ɹeɪnz fɹəm ðə ɡɝl, ən pæɾəd ðə mɛɹz nɛk, kɑmɪŋ hɝ. "sʌmθɪŋ nɑt juzd ɪn nɪɹli tu θaʊzən jɪɹz. sʌmθɪŋ aɪ maɪt bi stɪl dʒʌs fəɹ noʊɪŋ."

"Something forbidden," Moiraine said coolly. "Forbidden by vows almost as strong as the Three Oaths." She took Aldieb's reins from the girl, and patted the mare's neck, calming her. "Something not used in nearly two thousand years. Something I might be stilled just for knowing."

"pɝhæps . . . ?" lɔɪəlz vɔɪs wɑz ə feɪn bum. "pɝhæps wi ʃəd bi ɡoʊɪŋ? ðəɹ kəd bi mɔɹ."

"Perhaps . . . ?" Loial's voice was a faint boom. "Perhaps we should be going? There could be more."

"aɪ θɪŋk nɑt," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd, maʊntɪŋ. "hi wəd nɑt lus tu pæks ət wʌns, ivən ɪf hiz tu; ðeɪ wəd tɝn ɑn itʃ ʌðɝ ɪnstɛɾ ə ðɛɹ pɹeɪ. ən aɪ θɪŋk wəɹ nɑɾ ɪz meɪn kwɔɹi, əɹ i wʊɾə kʌm hɪmsɛlf. wi wɝ . . . ən ənɔɪəns, aɪ θɪŋk" - hɝ toʊn wɑz kɑm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd soʊ laɪtli - "æn pɝhæps ə lɪɾəl sʌmθɪŋ ɛkstʃɹə tə slɪp ɪndə hɪz ɡɑmbæɡ, ɪf wi wɝ nɑt tu mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl. stɪl, ðəɹ ɪz smɔl ɡʊɾ ɪn ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɛni nɪɹɝ ɪm ðən wi mʌst."

"I think not," the Aes Sedai said, mounting. "He would not loose two packs at once, even if he has two; they would turn on each other instead of their prey. And I think we are not his main quarry, or he would have come himself. We were . . . an annoyance, I think" - her tone was calm, but it was clear she did not like being regarded so lightly - "and perhaps a little something extra to slip into his gamebag, if we were not too much trouble. Still, there is small good in remaining any nearer him than we must."

"ɹænd?" pɛɹɪn æskt. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil zɑɹin linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə lɪsən. "ɪf wəɹ nɑt wʌɾ i hʌns, ɪz ɪt ɹænd?"

"Rand?" Perrin asked. He could almost feel Zarine leaning forward to listen. "If we are not what he hunts, is it Rand?"

"pɝhæps," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɔɹ pɝhæps mæt. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət hiz tɑvɝən ɔlsoʊ, ən i blu ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ."

"Perhaps," Moiraine said. "Or perhaps Mat. Remember that he is ta'veren also, and he blew the Horn of Valere."

zɑɹin meɪɾ ə stʃɹæŋɡəl saʊnd. "hi blu ɪt? sʌmwʌn əz faʊn ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi?"

Zarine made a strangled sound. "He blew it? Someone has found it already?"

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ, linɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ sæɾəl tə stɛɹ kloʊsli ɪndə pɛɹɪnz aɪz, dɑɹk ɡlimɪŋ ɪndə bɝnɪʃt ɡoʊld. "wʌns əɡɛn ɪvɛns aʊtpeɪs mi. aɪ də nɑt laɪk ðæt. ən niðɝ ʃəd ju. ɪf ɪvɛns aʊtʃɹʌn mi, ðeɪ meɪ wɛl tʃɹæmpəl ju, ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə wɝld wɪð ju."

The Aes Sedai ignored her, leaning out of her saddle to stare closely into Perrin's eyes, dark gleaming into burnished gold. "Once again events outpace me. I do not like that. And neither should you. If events outrun me, they may well trample you, and the rest of the world with you."

"wi hæv mɛni liɡz tə tɛɹ jɛt," læn sɛd. "ði oʊɡiɝz sədʒɛstʃən ɪz ə ɡʊd wʌn." hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ɪz sæɾəl.

"We have many leagues to Tear yet," Lan said. "The Ogier's suggestion is a good one." He was already in his saddle.

æftɝ ə moʊmən mɔɪɹeɪn stʃɹeɪɾənd ən tʌtʃt ðə mɛɹz ɹɪbz wɪð əɹ hilz. ʃi wɑz hæfweɪ daʊn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə maʊn bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɡɛɾ ɪz baʊ ənstʃɹʌŋ ən teɪk stɛpɝz ɹeɪnz fɹəm lɔɪəl. bɝn ju, mɔɪɹeɪn! əl faɪn səm ænsɝz sʌmwɛɹ!

After a moment Moiraine straightened and touched the mare's ribs with her heels. She was halfway down the side of the mound before he could get his bow unstrung and take Stepper's reins from Loial. Burn you, Moiraine! I'll find some answers somewhere!

linɪŋ bæk əɡɛnst ə fɔlən lɔɡ, mæt ɛndʒɔɪd ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə kæmpfaɪɝ - ðə ɹeɪnz hæd dʒɹɪftəd saʊθ θɹi deɪz ɝliɝ, bʌɾ i stɪl fɛl dæmp - jɛt ɹaɪɾ ət ðət moʊmənt, hi wɑz hɑɹdli əwɛɹ ə ðə dænsɪŋ fleɪmz. hi pɪɹd θɔtfəli ət ðə smɔl, wæks-kʌvɝd sɪləndɝ ɪn ɪz hænd. tɑm wɑz ɪnɡɹoʊst ɪn tunɪŋ ɪz hɑɹp, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf ə ɹeɪn ən wɛt, nɛvɝ ɡlænsɪŋ mæts weɪ. kɹɪkəts tʃɝpt ɪn ðə dɑɹk θɪkɪɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm. kɑt bɪtwin vɪlədʒəz baɪ sʌnsɛt, ðeɪ hæd tʃoʊzən ðɪs kɑps əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹoʊd. tu naɪts ðeɪ hæd tʃɹaɪd tə baɪ ə ɹum fəɹ ðə naɪt; twaɪs ə fɑɹmɝ hæd lust ɪz dɑɡz ɑn ðɛm.

Leaning back against a fallen log, Mat enjoyed the warmth of the campfire - the rains had drifted south three days earlier, but he still felt damp - yet right at that moment, he was hardly aware of the dancing flames. He peered thoughtfully at the small, wax-covered cylinder in his hand. Thom was engrossed in tuning his harp, muttering to himself of rain and wet, never glancing Mat's way. Crickets chirped in the dark thicket around them. Caught between villages by sunset, they had chosen this copse away from the road. Two nights they had tried to buy a room for the night; twice a farmer had loosed his dogs on them.

mæt ənʃiðd ɪz bɛl naɪf, ən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. lʌk. ɪɾ oʊnli ɪksploʊdz səmtaɪmz, ʃi sɛd. lʌk. əz kɛɹfəli əz i kʊd, hi slɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə tub. ɪt wɑz ə tub, ən ə peɪpɝ, əz i hæd θɔt - hi hæd faʊn bɪts ə peɪpɝ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn æftɝ faɪɹwɝks wɝ sɛɾ ɔf, bæk hoʊm - leɪɝz ə peɪpɝ, bʌɾ ɔl ðət fɪl ði ɪnsaɪd wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ðət lʊk laɪk dɝt, əɹ meɪbi taɪni ɡɹeɪ-blæk pɛbəlz ən dʌst. hi stɝɾ əm ɑn ɪz pɑm wɪð wʌn fɪŋɡɝ. haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt kəd pɛbəlz ɪksploʊd?

Mat unsheathed his belt knife, and hesitated. Luck. It only explodes sometimes, she said. Luck. As carefully as he could, he slit along the length of the tube. It was a tube, and of paper, as he had thought - he had found bits of paper on the ground after fireworks were set off, back home - layers of paper, but all that filled the inside was something that looked like dirt, or maybe tiny gray-black pebbles and dust. He stirred them on his palm with one finger. How in the Light could pebbles explode?

"ðə laɪt bɝn mi!" tɑm ɹɔɹd. hi θɹʌst ɪz hɑɹp ɪndə ɪts keɪs əz ɪf tə pɹətɛkt ɪt fɹəm wʌt wɑz ɪn mæts hænd. "ɑɹ jə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl ʌs, bɔɪ? hævən jə ɛvɝ hɝd ðoʊz θɪŋz ɪksploʊd tɛn taɪmz əz hɑɹd fəɹ ɛɹ əz fəɹ faɪɝ? faɪɹwɝks ɑɹ ðə nɛks θɪŋ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk, bɔɪ."

"The Light burn me!" Thom roared. He thrust his harp into its case as if to protect it from what was in Mat's hand. "Are you trying to kill us, boy? Haven't you ever heard those things explode ten times as hard for air as for fire? Fireworks are the next thing to Aes Sedai work, boy."

"meɪbi," mæt sɛd, "bʌɾ ɑlʌdʒɹə dɪd nɑt lʊk laɪk ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ tə mi. aɪ juz tə θɪŋk ðəɾ əbaʊt mæstɝ ælvɪɹz klɑk - ðəɾ ɪt hæd tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk - bʌt wʌns aɪ ɡɑt ðə bæk ə ðə kæbənəɾ oʊpən, aɪ sɔ ɪt wɑz fʊl ə lɪɾəl pisəz ə mɛɾəl." hi ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli ət ðə mɛmɹi. mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ hæd bɪn ðə fɝs tə ɹitʃ ɪm ðət taɪm, wɪð ðə wɪzdəm ən ɪz fɑðɝ ən ðə meɪɝ ɔl ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɝ, ən nʌn bɪlivɪŋ i dʒʌs mɛn tə lʊk. aɪ cʊɾə pʊɾ əm ɔl bæk təɡɛðɝ. "aɪ θɪŋk pɛɹɪn kəd meɪk wʌn, ɪf i sɔ ðoʊz lɪɾəl wilz ən spɹɪŋz ən aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɔl."

"Maybe," Mat said, "but Aludra did not look like any Aes Sedai to me. I used to think that about Master al'Vere's clock - that it had to be Aes Sedai work - but once I got the back of the cabinet open, I saw it was full of little pieces of metal." He shifted uncomfortably at the memory. Mistress al'Vere had been the first to reach him that time, with the Wisdom and his father and the Mayor all right behind her, and none believing he just meant to look. I could have put them all back together. "I think Perrin could make one, if he saw those little wheels and springs and I don't know what all."

"ju wəd bi sɝpɹaɪzd, bɔɪ," tɑm sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ivən ə bæd klɑkmeɪkɝ ɪz ə fɛɹli ɹɪtʃ mæn, ən ðeɪ ɝn ɪt. bʌɾ ə klɑk dʌz nɑɾ ɪksploʊɾ ɪn jəɹ feɪs!"

"You would be surprised, boy," Thom said dryly. "Even a bad clockmaker is a fairly rich man, and they earn it. But a clock does not explode in your face!"

"niðɝ dɪd ðɪs. wɛl, ɪts jusləs, naʊ." hi tɔs ðə hændfʊl ə peɪpɝ ən lɪɾəl pɛbəlz ɪndə ðə faɪɝ tə ə skɹitʃ fɹəm tɑm; ðə pɛbəlz spɑɹkt ən meɪd taɪni flæʃɪz, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə smɛl ʌv ækɹɪd smoʊk.

"Neither did this. Well, it is useless, now." He tossed the handful of paper and little pebbles into the fire to a screech from Thom; the pebbles sparked and made tiny flashes, and there was a smell of acrid smoke.

"ju ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl ʌs." tɑmz vɔɪs wɑz ənstɛɾi, ən ɪt ɹoʊz ɪn ɪntɛnsəɾi ən pɪtʃ əz i spoʊk. "ɪf aɪ dɪsaɪɾ aɪ wɑnə daɪ, əl ɡoʊ tə ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs wən wi ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn, ən əl pɪntʃ mɔɹɡeɪs!" hɪz lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz fleɪld. "du nɑt də ðəɾ əɡɛn!"

"You are trying to kill us." Thom's voice was unsteady, and it rose in intensity and pitch as he spoke. "If I decide I want to die, I will go to the Royal Palace when we reach Caemlyn, and I'll pinch Morgase!" His long mustaches flailed. "Do not do that again!"

"ɪt dɪd nɑɾ ɪksploʊd," mæt sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə faɪɝ. hi fɪʃt ɪndə ði ɔɪld-klɔθ ɹoʊl ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə lɔɡ ən pʊld aʊɾ ə faɪɝwɝk ə ðə nɛks lɑɹdʒɝ saɪz. "aɪ wʌndɝ waɪ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bæŋ."

"It did not explode," Mat said, frowning at the fire. He fished into the oiled-cloth roll on the other side of the log and pulled out a firework of the next larger size. "I wonder why there was no bang."

"aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ waɪ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bæŋ! də nɑt də ɪɾ əɡɛn!"

"I do not care why there was no bang! Do not do it again!"

mæt ɡlænst əɾ ɪm ən læft. "stɑp ʃeɪkɪŋ, tɑm. ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə bi əfɹeɪd. aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪz ɪnsaɪd ðɛm, naʊ. ət list, aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪt lʊks laɪk, bʌt. . . . doʊn seɪ ɪt. əl nɑt bi kʌɾɪŋ ɛni mɔɹ oʊpən, tɑm. ɪts mɔɹ fʌn tə sɛɾ əm ɔf, ɛniweɪ."

Mat glanced at him and laughed. "Stop shaking, Thom. There's no need to be afraid. I know what is inside them, now. At least, I know what it looks like, but. . . . Don't say it. I will not be cutting any more open, Thom. It is more fun to set them off, anyway."

"aɪ æm nɑɾ əfɹeɪd, jə mʌd-fʊɾɪd swɪnhɝd," tɑm sɛd wɪð ɪlæbɹət dɪɡnəɾi. "aɪ æm ʃeɪkɪŋ wɪð ɹeɪdʒ kəz aɪm tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ə ɡoʊt-bɹeɪn laʊɾ u maɪt kɪl ðə pɛɹ ʌv əs kəz i kænɑt θɪŋk pæst ɪz oʊn - "

"I am not afraid, you mud-footed swineherd," Thom said with elaborate dignity. "I am shaking with rage because I'm traveling with a goat-brained lout who might kill the pair of us because he cannot think past his own - "

"hoʊ, ðə faɪɝ!"

"Ho, the fire!"

mæt ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð tɑm əz hɔɹsəz' hʊvz əpɹoʊtʃt. ɪt wɑz leɪt fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɑnəs tə bi tʃɹævlɪŋ. bʌt ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz kɛp ðə ɹoʊdz seɪf ðɪs kloʊs tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən ðə fɔɹ u ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə faɪɹlaɪt sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt lʊk laɪk ɹɑbɝz. wʌn wɑz ə wʊmən. ðə mɛn ɔl wɔɹ lɔŋ kloʊks ən sim tə bi hɝ ɹɪteɪnɝz, waɪl ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi ən blu-aɪd, ɪn ɡoʊl nɛkləs ən ə ɡɹeɪ sɪlk dʒɹɛs ən ə vɛlvət kloʊk wɪð ə waɪd hʊd. ðə mɛn dɪsmaʊntɪd. wʌn hɛld əɹ ɹeɪnz ən ənʌðɝ əɹ stɝəp, ən ʃi smaɪld ət mæt, dɔfɪŋ əɹ ɡlʌvz əz ʃi keɪm nɪɹ ðə faɪɝ.

Mat exchanged glances with Thom as horses' hooves approached. It was late for anyone honest to be traveling. But the Queen's Guards kept the roads safe this close to Caemlyn, and the four who rode into the firelight certainly did not look like robbers. One was a woman. The men all wore long cloaks and seemed to be her retainers, while she was pretty and blue-eyed, in gold necklace and a gray silk dress and a velvet cloak with a wide hood. The men dismounted. One held her reins and another her stirrup, and she smiled at Mat, doffing her gloves as she came near the fire.

"aɪ fɪɹ wəɹ kɑɾ aʊt leɪt, jʌŋ mæstɝ," ʃi sɛd, "æn aɪ wəd tʃɹʌbəl jə fəɹ dɝɛkʃənz tə ən ɪn, ɪf jə noʊ wʌn."

"I fear we are caught out late, young master," she said, "and I would trouble you for directions to an inn, if you know one."

hi ɡɹɪn ən stɑɹɾəd tə ɹaɪz. hi hæd meɪɾ ɪɾ əz fɑɹ əz ə kɹaʊtʃ wən i hɝd wʌn ə ðə mɛn mʌɾɝ sʌmθɪŋ, ən ənʌðɝ pɹədust ə kɹɔsboʊ fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk, ɔlɹɛɾi dʒɹɔn, wɪð ə klɪp hoʊldɪŋ ðə boʊlt.

He grinned and started to rise. He had made it as far as a crouch when he heard one of the men mutter something, and another produced a crossbow from under his cloak, already drawn, with a clip holding the bolt.

"kɪl hɪm, ful!" ðə wʊmən ʃaʊɾəd, ən mæt tɔs ðə faɪɝwɝk ɪndə ðə fleɪmz ən θɹu hɪmsɛlf təwɔɹɾ ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf. ðəɹ wɑz ə laʊd bæŋ ən ə flæʃ ə laɪt - "ɛɛs sədaɪ!" ə mæn kɹaɪd. "faɪɹwɝks, ful!" ðə wʊmən ʃaʊɾəd - ən i ɹoʊl tə hɪz fit wɪð ðə stæf ɪn ɪz hæn tə si ðə kɹɔsboʊ boʊl stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə fɔlən lɔɡ ɔlmoʊst wɛɹ i hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ, ən ðə kɹɔsbaʊmən fɔlɪŋ wɪð ðə hɪlt ʌv wʌn ə tɑmz naɪvz ədɔɹnɪŋ ɪz tʃɛst.

"Kill him, fool!" the woman shouted, and Mat tossed the firework into the flames and threw himself toward his quarterstaff. There was a loud bang and a flash of light - "Aes Sedai!" a man cried. "Fireworks, fool!" the woman shouted - and he rolled to his feet with the staff in his hand to see the crossbow bolt sticking out of the fallen log almost where he had been sitting, and the crossbowman falling with the hilt of one of Thom's knives adorning his chest.

ɪt wɑz ɔl i hæd taɪm tə si, fəɹ ði ʌðɝ tu mɛn dɑɹɾɪd pæs ðə faɪɝ ət hɪm, dʒɹɔɪŋ sɔɹdz. wʌn ə ðɛm sʌɾənli stʌmbəl tə hɪz niz, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd tə klɔ ət ðə naɪf ɪn ɪz bæk əz i fɛl feɪsdaʊn. ðə læs mæn dɪd nɑt si hɪz kəmpænjən fɔl; hi ɑbviəsli ɪkspɛktəd tə bi wʌn ʌv ə pɛɹ, dɪvaɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ əpoʊnəns ətɛnʃən, əz i θɹʌst ɪz bleɪɾ ət mæts mɪɾəl. filɪŋ ɔlmoʊs kəntɛmptʃuəs, mæt kɹæk ðə fɛloʊz ɹɪst wɪð wʌn ɛn ə hɪz stæf, sɛndɪŋ ðə sɔɹd flaɪɪŋ, ən kɹækt ɪz fɔɹhɛd wɪð ði ʌðɝ. ðə mænz aɪz ɹoʊld ʌp ɪn ɪz hɛɾ əz i kəlæpst.

It was all he had time to see, for the other two men darted past the fire at him, drawing swords. One of them suddenly stumbled to his knees, dropping his sword to claw at the knife in his back as he fell facedown. The last man did not see his companion fall; he obviously expected to be one of a pair, dividing their opponent's attention, as he thrust his blade at Mat's middle. Feeling almost contemptuous, Mat cracked the fellow's wrist with one end of his staff, sending the sword flying, and cracked his forehead with the other. The man's eyes rolled up in his head as he collapsed.

fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, mæt sɔ ðə wʊmən wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm, ən i stʌk ə fɪŋɡɝ əɾ əɹ laɪk ə naɪf. "faɪn kloʊðz jə wɛɹ fəɹ ə θif, wʊmən! jə sɪt daʊn tɪl aɪ dɪsaɪd wʌt tə də wɪð ju, əɹ əl - "

From the corner of his eye, Mat saw the woman walking toward him, and he stuck a finger at her like a knife. "Fine clothes you wear for a thief, woman! You sit down till I decide what to do with you, or I'll - "

ʃi lʊkt əz sɝpɹaɪzd əz mæt ət ðə naɪf ðət sʌɾənli blumd ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, ə ɹɛd flaʊɝ ə spɹɛɾɪŋ blʌd. hi tʊk ə hæf stɛp əz ɪf tə kætʃ əɹ əz ʃi fɛl, noʊɪŋ ɪt wɑz noʊ ɡʊd. hɝ lɔŋ kloʊk sɛɾəld oʊvɝ hɝ, kʌvɝɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ bʌɾ əɹ feɪs, ən ðə hɪlt ə tɑmz naɪf.

She looked as surprised as Mat at the knife that suddenly bloomed in her throat, a red flower of spreading blood. He took a half step as if to catch her as she fell, knowing it was no good. Her long cloak settled over her, covering everything but her face, and the hilt of Thom's knife.

"bɝn ju," mæt mʌɾɝd. "bɝn ju, tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn! ə wʊmən! laɪt, wi cʊɾə taɪɾ əɹ ʌp, ɡɪvən əɹ tə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz təmɑɹoʊ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. laɪt, aɪ maɪɾ ivən əv lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ. ʃid ɹɑb noʊbɑdi wɪθaʊt ðiz θɹi, ən ði oʊnli wʌn ðət laɪvz wɪl bi deɪz bɪfɔɹ i kən si stʃɹeɪɾ ən mʌnθs bɪfɔɹ i kən hoʊld ə sɔɹd. bɝn ju, tɑm, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə kɪl hɝ!"

"Burn you," Mat muttered. "Burn you, Thom Merrilin! A woman! Light, we could have tied her up, given her to the Queen's Guards tomorrow in Caemlyn. Light, I might even have let her go. She'd rob nobody without these three, and the only one that lives will be days before he can see straight and months before he can hold a sword. Burn you, Thom, there was no need to kill her!"

ðə ɡlimən lɪmp tə wɛɹ ðə wʊmən leɪ, ən kɪk bæk əɹ kloʊk. ðə dæɡɝ hæd hæf fɔlən fɹəm əɹ hænd, ɪts bleɪɾ əz waɪɾ əz mæts θʌm ən tu hænz lɔŋ. "wʊd jə ɹæðɝ aɪ hæd weɪɾəd tɪl ʃi nɛstəd ðəɾ ɪn jəɹ ɹɪbz, bɔɪ?" hi ɹitʃɹivd ɪz oʊn naɪf, waɪpɪŋ ðə bleɪɾ ɑn əɹ kloʊk.

The gleeman limped to where the woman lay, and kicked back her cloak. The dagger had half fallen from her hand, its blade as wide as Mat's thumb and two hands long. "Would you rather I had waited till she nested that in your ribs, boy?" He retrieved his own knife, wiping the blade on her cloak.

mæt ɹilaɪzd i wɑz hʌmɪŋ "ʃi wɔɹ ə mæsk ðət hɪɾ əɹ feɪs," ən stɑpt ɪt. hi bɛn daʊn ən hɪd hɝz wɪð ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk. "bɛst wi muv ɑn," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "aɪ də nɑt wɑnə hæv tə ɪkspleɪn ðɪs ɪf ə pətʃɹoʊl ə ðə ɡɑɹdz hæpənz baɪ."

Mat realized he was humming "She Wore a Mask That Hid Her Face," and stopped it. He bent down and hid hers with the hood of her cloak. "Best we move on," he said quietly. "I do not want to have to explain this if a patrol of the Guards happens by."

"wɪð əɹ ɪn ðoʊz kloʊðz?" tɑm sɛd. "aɪ ʃəd seɪ nɑt! ðeɪ mʌst əv ɹɑbd ə mɝtʃəns waɪf, əɹ səm noʊbəlwʊmənz kæɹɪdʒ." hɪz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm dʒɛnlɝ. "ɪf wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ, bɔɪ, jə hæd bɛst si tə sæɾəlɪŋ jəɹ hɔɹs."

"With her in those clothes?" Thom said. "I should say not! They must have robbed a merchant's wife, or some noblewoman's carriage." His voice became gentler. "If we're going, boy, you had best see to saddling your horse."

mæt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən pʊld ɪz aɪz fɹəm ðə dɛd wʊmən. "jɛs, aɪ hæd bɛɾɝ, hædn aɪ?" hi dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ əɹ əɡɛn.

Mat gave a start and pulled his eyes from the dead woman. "Yes, I had better, hadn't I?" He did not look at her again.

hi hæd noʊ sətʃ kəmpʌŋkʃən əbaʊt ðə mɛn. əz fɑɹ əz i wɑz kənsɝnd, ə mæn u dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɹɑb ən kɪl dɪzɝvd wʌɾ i ɡɑt wən i lɔs ðə ɡeɪm. hi dɪd nɑt dwɛl ɑn ðɛm, bʌt niðɝ dɪɾ i dʒɝk ɪz aɪz əweɪ ɪf ðeɪ fɛl ɑn wʌn ə ðə ɹɑbɝz. ɪt wɑz æftɝ i hæd sæɾəld ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ ən taɪɾ ɪz θɪŋz ɑn bɪhaɪnd, waɪl i wɑz kɪkɪŋ dɝɾ ɑntu ðə faɪɝ, ðəɾ i faʊn hɪmsɛlf lʊkɪŋ ət ðə mæn u hæd ʃɑt ðə kɹɔsboʊ. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ fəmɪljɝ əbaʊt ðoʊz fitʃɝz, əbaʊt ðə weɪ ðə smʌðɝɪŋ faɪɝ meɪd ʃædoʊz əkɹɔs ðɛm. lʌk, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. ɔlweɪz ðə lʌk.

He had no such compunction about the men. As far as he was concerned, a man who decided to rob and kill deserved what he got when he lost the game. He did not dwell on them, but neither did he jerk his eyes away if they fell on one of the robbers. It was after he had saddled his gelding and tied his things on behind, while he was kicking dirt onto the fire, that he found himself looking at the man who had shot the crossbow. There was something familiar about those features, about the way the smothering fire made shadows across them. Luck, he told himself. Always the luck.

"ðə kɹɔsbaʊmən wɑz ə ɡʊd swɪmɝ, tɑm," hi sɛɾ əz i klaɪmd ɪndə ðə sæɾəl.

"The crossbowman was a good swimmer, Thom," he said as he climbed into the saddle.

"wʌt fulɝi ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ, naʊ?" ðə ɡlimən wɑz ɑn ɪz hɔɹs, tu, ən fɑɹ mɔɹ kənsɝnd wɪð haʊ hɪz ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn ɪz sæɾəl ðən i wɑz wɪð ðə dɛd. "haʊ kəd jə noʊ wɛðɝ i kəɾ ivən swɪm əɾ ɔl?"

"What foolery are you talking, now?" The gleeman was on his horse, too, and far more concerned with how his instrument cases rode behind his saddle than he was with the dead. "How could you know whether he could even swim at all?"

"hi meɪɾ ɪɾ əʃɔɹ fɹəm ə smɔl boʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ði ɛɹɪnɪn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt. aɪ ɡɛs ðət juzd ʌp ɔl ɪz lʌk." hi tʃɛk ðə læʃɪŋz ɑn ðə ɹoʊl ə faɪɹwɝks əɡɛn. ɪf ðət ful θɔt wʌn ə ðiz wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ wʌndɝ wʌt hiɾ əv θɔɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɔl wɛn ɔf.

"He made it ashore from a small boat in the middle of the Erinin in the middle of the night. I guess that used up all his luck." He checked the lashings on the roll of fireworks again. If that fool thought one of these was Aes Sedai, I wonder what he'd have thought if they all went off.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ, bɔɪ? ðə tʃænsəz ʌv ɪt biɪŋ ðə seɪm mæn. . . . waɪ, ivən jə wʊdn leɪ ə weɪdʒɝ əɡɛns ðoʊz ɑdz."

"Are you sure, boy? The chances of it being the same man. . . . Why, even you wouldn't lay a wager against those odds."

"aɪ æm ʃʊɹ, tɑm." ɪleɪn, əl ɹɪŋ jəɹ nɛk wən aɪ pʊt maɪ hænz ɑn ju. ən ɛɡwinz ən nɪneɪivz, tu. "æn aɪm ʃʊɹ aɪ ɪntɛn tə hæv ðɪs blʌɾi lɛɾɝ aʊɾ ə maɪ hænz ən aʊɝ æftɝ wi ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn."

"I am sure, Thom." Elayne, I will wring your neck when I put my hands on you. And Egwene's and Nynaeve's, too. "And I am sure I intend to have this bloody letter out of my hands an hour after we reach Caemlyn."

"aɪ tɛl ju, ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðət lɛɾɝ, bɔɪ. aɪ pleɪd deɪz deɪmɑɹ wən aɪ wɑz jʌŋɡɝ ðən ju, ən aɪ kən ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ə koʊɾ əɹ ə saɪfɝ ivən wən aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt sɛz."

"I tell you, there is nothing in that letter, boy. I played Daes Dae'mar when I was younger than you, and I can recognize a code or a cipher even when I don't know what it says."

"wɛl, aɪ nɛvɝ pleɪd jəɹ ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, tɑm, jəɹ blʌɾi ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ wən sʌmwʌn ɪz tʃeɪsɪŋ mi, ən ðeɪd nɑt bi tʃeɪsɪŋ ðɪs hɑɹɾ əɹ ðɪs fɑɹ fəɹ ðə ɡoʊld ɪn maɪ pɑkəts, nɑt fəɹ lɛs ðən ə tʃɛs fʊl ʌv ɡoʊld. ɪts tə bi ðə lɛɾɝ." bɝn mi, pɹɪɾi ɡɝlz ɔlweɪz ɡɛt mi ɪn tʃɹʌbəl. "du jə fil laɪk slipɪŋ tənaɪt, æftɝ ðɪs?"

"Well, I never played your Great Game, Thom, your bloody Game of Houses, but I know when someone is chasing me, and they'd not be chasing this hard or this far for the gold in my pockets, not for less than a chest full of gold. It has to be the letter." Burn me, pretty girls always get me in trouble. "Do you feel like sleeping tonight, after this?"

"wɪð ðə slip ʌv ən ɪnəsən beɪb, bɔɪ. bʌɾ ɪf jə wɑnə ɹaɪd, əl ɹaɪd."

"With the sleep of an innocent babe, boy. But if you want to ride, I'll ride."

ðə feɪs ʌv ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən floʊɾəd ɪndə mæts hɛd, wɪð ə dæɡɝ ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. jə hæd noʊ lʌk, pɹɪɾi wʊmən. "ðɛn lɛts ɹaɪd!" hi sɛd sævɪdʒli.

The face of a pretty woman floated into Mat's head, with a dagger in her throat. You had no luck, pretty woman. "Then let's ride!" he said savagely.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾifaɪv


CHAPTER 45

keɪɛmlɪn


Caemlyn

mæt hæd veɪɡ mɛmɹiz ə keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt wən ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ɪɾ ɪn ði ɝli aʊɝz æftɝ sʌnɹaɪz, ɪt simd əz ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ. ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn əloʊn ɑn ðə ɹoʊd sɪns fɝs laɪt, ən ʌðɝ ɹaɪɾɝz sɝaʊndəɾ əm naʊ, ən tʃɹeɪnz ə mɝtʃəns' wæɡənz ən foʊk əfʊt, ɔl stʃɹimɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi.

Mat had vague memories of Caemlyn, but when they approached it in the early hours after sunrise, it seemed as if he had never been there before. They had not been alone on the road since first light, and other riders surrounded them now, and trains of merchants' wagons and folk afoot, all streaming toward the great city.

bɪlt ɑn ɹaɪzɪŋ hɪlz, ɪt wɑz ʃʊɹli əz lɑɹdʒ əz tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən aʊtsaɪd ðə hjudʒ wɔlz - ə fɪfti-fʊt haɪɾ ə peɪl, ɡɹeɪɪʃ stoʊn stʃɹikt wɪð waɪɾ ən sɪlvɝ spɑɹklɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn, speɪst wɪð tɔl, ɹaʊn taʊɝz wɪð ðə laɪən bænɝ ʌv ændɝ weɪvɪŋ ətɑp ðɛm, waɪɾ ɑn ɹɛd - aʊtsaɪd ðoʊz wɔlz, ɪt simd əz ɪf ənʌðɝ ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi hæd bɪn pleɪst, ɹæpɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə wɔl sɪɾi, ɔl ɹɛd bɹɪk ən ɡɹeɪ stoʊn ən waɪt plæstɝd wɔlz, ɪnz pʊʃt ɪn ɑn haʊsəz ə θɹi ən fɔɹ stɔɹiz soʊ faɪn ðeɪ mʌs bɪlɔŋ tə wɛlθi mɝtʃəns, ʃɑps wɪð ɡʊdz dɪspleɪɾ ɑn teɪbəlz ʌndɝ ɔnɪŋz kɹaʊɾɪŋ əɡɛnst waɪd, wɪndoʊləs wɛɹhaʊzɪz. oʊpən mɑɹkəts ʌndɝ ɹɛɾ ən pɝpəl ɹuf taɪlz laɪn ðə ɹoʊɾ ɑn boʊθ saɪdz, mɛn ən wɪmən ɔlɹɛɾi kɹaɪɪŋ ðɛɹ wɛɹz, bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ ət ðə tɑp ə ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz, waɪl pɛn kævz ən ʃip ən ɡoʊts ən pɪɡz, keɪdʒd ɡis ən tʃɪkənz ən dʌks, æɾəd tə ðə dɪn. hi sim tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ θɪŋkɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn wɑz tu nɔɪzi wən i wɑz hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ; naʊ ɪt saʊndəd laɪk ə hɑɹtbit, pʌmpɪŋ wɛlθ.

Built on rising hills, it was surely as large as Tar Valon, and outside the huge walls - a fifty-foot height of pale, grayish stone streaked with white and silver sparkling in the sun, spaced with tall, round towers with the Lion Banner of Andor waving atop them, white on red - outside those walls, it seemed as if another great city had been placed, wrapping around the walled city, all red brick and gray stone and white plastered walls, inns pushed in on houses of three and four stories so fine they must belong to wealthy merchants, shops with goods displayed on tables under awnings crowding against wide, windowless warehouses. Open markets under red and purple roof tiles lined the road on both sides, men and women already crying their wares, bargaining at the top of their voices, while penned calves and sheep and goats and pigs, caged geese and chickens and ducks, added to the din. He seemed to remember thinking Caemlyn was too noisy when he was here before; now it sounded like a heartbeat, pumping wealth.

ðə ɹoʊd lɛd tə ɑɹtʃt ɡeɪts twɛnti fit haɪ, stændɪŋ oʊpən ʌndɝ ðə wɑtʃfəl aɪ ʌv ɹɛd-koʊɾəd kwinz ɡɑɹdz ɪn ðɛɹ ʃaɪnɪŋ bɹɛstpleɪts - ðeɪ aɪd tɑm ən ɪm noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls, nɑɾ ivən ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz sæɾəl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm; ɔl ðeɪ kɛɹd wɑz ðət pipəl kip muvɪŋ, ɪt simd - ən ðən ðeɪ wɝ wɪðɪn. slɛndɝ taʊɝz hɪɹ ɹoʊz ivən tɔlɝ ðən ðoʊz əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz, ən ɡlimɪŋ doʊmz ʃoʊn waɪɾ ən ɡoʊld əbʌv stʃɹits timɪŋ wɪð pipəl. dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts ðə ɹoʊd splɪɾ ɪndə tu pɛɹəlɛl stʃɹits, sɛpɝeɪɾəd baɪ ə waɪd stʃɹɪp ʌv ɡɹæs ən tʃɹiz. ðə hɪlz ə ðə sɪɾi ɹoʊz laɪk stɛps təwɔɹɾ ə pik, wɪtʃ wɑz sɝaʊndəd baɪ ənʌðɝ wɔl, ʃaɪnɪŋ əz waɪɾ əz tɑɹ vəlɑnz, wɪð stɪl mɔɹ doʊmz ən taʊɝz wɪðɪn. ðət wɑz ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi, mæt ɹɪkɔld, ən ətɑp ðoʊz haɪəs hɪlz stʊd ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs.

The road led to arched gates twenty feet high, standing open under the watchful eye of red-coated Queen's Guards in their shining breastplates - they eyed Thom and him no more than anyone else, not even the quarterstaff slanted across his saddle in front of him; all they cared was that people keep moving, it seemed - and then they were within. Slender towers here rose even taller than those along the walls, and gleaming domes shone white and gold above streets teeming with people. Just inside the gates the road split into two parallel streets, separated by a wide strip of grass and trees. The hills of the city rose like steps toward a peak, which was surrounded by another wall, shining as white as Tar Valon's, with still more domes and towers within. That was the Inner City, Mat recalled, and atop those highest hills stood the Royal Palace.

"noʊ pɔɪnt weɪɾɪŋ," hi toʊl tɑm. "aɪl teɪk ðə lɛɾɝ stʃɹeɪɾ ɑn." hi lʊkt ət ðə sɪdæn tʃɛɹz ən kæɹɪdʒɪz meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz, ðə ʃɑps wɪð ɔl ðɛɹ ɡʊdz dɪspleɪd. "ə mæn kəɾ ɝn səm ɡoʊld ɪn ðɪs sɪɾi, tɑm, wʌns i faʊn ə ɡeɪm ə daɪs, əɹ kɑɹdz." hi wɑz nɑt kwaɪt soʊ lʌki ət kɑɹdz əz ət daɪs, bʌt fju ɪksɛp noʊbəlz ən ðə wɛlθi pleɪd ðoʊz ɡeɪmz ɛniweɪ. naʊ ðæts u aɪ ʃəd faɪn ə ɡeɪm wɪð.

"No point waiting," he told Thom. "I'll take the letter straight on." He looked at the sedan chairs and carriages making their way through the crowds, the shops with all their goods displayed. "A man could earn some gold in this city, Thom, once he found a game of dice, or cards." He was not quite so lucky at cards as at dice, but few except nobles and the wealthy played those games anyway. Now that's who I should find a game with.

tɑm jɔn əɾ ɪm ən hɪtʃt əɾ ɪz ɡlimənz kloʊk əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə blæŋkət. "wi hæv ɹɪɾən ɔl naɪt, bɔɪ. lɛts ət lis faɪn sʌmθɪŋ tə it, fɝst. ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ əz ɡʊd milz." hi jɔn əɡɛn. "ænd ɡʊd bɛdz."

Thom yawned at him and hitched at his gleeman's cloak as if it were a blanket. "We have ridden all night, boy. Let's at least find something to eat, first. The Queen's Blessing has good meals." He yawned again. "And good beds."

"aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt," mæt sɛd sloʊli. hi dɪd, ɪn ə weɪ. ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ə fæt mæn wɪð ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ, mæstɝ ɡɪl. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd kɑɾ ʌp tə ɹænd ən ɪm ðɛɹ, wən i hæd θɔt ðeɪ wɝ faɪnəli fɹi ʌv hɝ. ʃiz ɔf pleɪɪŋ əɹ ɡeɪm wɪð ɹænd, naʊ. nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð mi. nɑɾ ɛnimɔɹ. "aɪ wɪl mit jə ðɛɹ, tɑm. aɪ sɛɾ aɪɾ əv ðɪs lɛɾɝ aʊɾ ə maɪ hænz ən aʊɝ æftɝ aɪ ɝaɪvd, ən aɪ min tə. jə ɡoʊ ɑn."

"I remember that," Mat said slowly. He did, in a way. The innkeeper was a fat man with graying hair, Master Gill. Moiraine had caught up to Rand and him there, when he had thought they were finally free of her. She's off playing her game with Rand, now. Nothing to do with me. Not anymore. "I will meet you there, Thom. I said I'd have this letter out of my hands an hour after I arrived, and I mean to. You go on."

tɑm nɑɾəd ən tɝn ɪz hɔɹs əsaɪd, kɔlɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ θɹu ə jɔn. "du nɑt bɪkʌm lɔst, bɔɪ. ɪts ə bɪɡ sɪɾi, keɪɛmlɪn."

Thom nodded and turned his horse aside, calling over his shoulder through a yawn. "Do not become lost, boy. It's a big city, Caemlyn."

ən ə ɹɪtʃ wʌn. mæt hild ɪz maʊn ɑn ʌp ðə kɹaʊɾəd stʃɹit. lɔst! aɪ kən faɪn maɪ blʌɾi weɪ. ðə sɪknəs əpɪɹd tə hæv ɪɹeɪs pɑɹts ə hɪz mɛmɹi. hi kəd lʊk əɾ ən ɪn, ɪts ʌpɝ flɔɹz stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊn ən ɪts saɪn kɹikɪŋ ɪn ðə bɹiz, ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ siɪŋ ɪt bɪfɔɹ, jɛt nɑt ɹikɔl ənʌðɝ θɪŋ i kəd si fɹəm ðət spɑt. ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ə stʃɹit maɪɾ əbɹʌpli spɑɹk ɪn ɪz mɛmɹi, waɪl ðə pɑɹts bɪfɔɹ ən æftɝ ɹɪmeɪn əz mɪstɪɹiəs əz daɪs stɪl ɪn ðə kʌp.

And a rich one. Mat heeled his mount on up the crowded street. Lost! I can find my bloody way. The sickness appeared to have erased parts of his memory. He could look at an inn, its upper floors sticking out over the ground floor all the way around and its sign creaking in the breeze, and remember seeing it before, yet not recall another thing he could see from that spot. A hundred paces of street might abruptly spark in his memory, while the parts before and after remained as mysterious as dice still in the cup.

ivən wɪð ðə hoʊlz ɪn ɪz mɛmɹi hi wɑz ʃʊɹ i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn tə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi əɹ ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs - aɪ kʊdn fɝɡɛt ðæt! - jɛɾ i dɪd nɑt nid tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə weɪ. ðə stʃɹits ə ðə nu sɪɾi - hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət neɪm sʌɾənli; ɪt wɑz ðə pɑɹɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn lɛs ðən tu θaʊzən jɪɹz oʊld - ɹæn ɛvɹi wɪtʃ weɪ, bʌt ðə meɪn bʊləvɑɹdz ɔl lɛd tə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi. ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə ɡeɪts meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə stɑp ɛniwʌn.

Even with the holes in his memory he was sure he had never been to the Inner City or the Royal Palace - I couldn't forget that! - yet he did not need to remember the way. The streets of the New City - he remembered that name suddenly; it was the part of Caemlyn less than two thousand years old - ran every which way, but the main boulevards all led to the Inner City. The Guards at the gates made no effort to stop anyone.

wɪðɪn ðoʊz waɪt wɔlz wɝ bɪldɪŋz ðət kəɾ ɔlmoʊst əv fɪɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðə kɝvɪŋ stʃɹits tɑp hɪlz tə ɹɪvil θɪn taʊɝz, ðɛɹ taɪld wɔlz spɑɹklɪŋ wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd kʌlɝz ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt, əɹ tə lʊk daʊn ɑn pɑɹks leɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn pæɾɝnz meɪd tə bi vjud fɹəm əbʌv, əɹ tə ʃoʊ swipɪŋ vɪstəz əkɹɔs ði ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi tə ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ pleɪnz ən fɔɹəsts bɪɑnd. ɪt dɪd nɑt ɹɪli mæɾɝ wɪtʃ stʃɹits i tʊk hɪɹ. ðeɪ ɔl spaɪɹəld ɪn ɑn wʌɾ i sɔt, ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ʌv ændɝ.

Within those white walls were buildings that could almost have fit in Tar Valon. The curving streets topped hills to reveal thin towers, their tiled walls sparkling with a hundred colors in the sunlight, or to look down on parks laid out in patterns made to be viewed from above, or to show sweeping vistas across the entire city to the rolling plains and forests beyond. It did not really matter which streets he took here. They all spiraled in on what he sought, the Royal Palace of Andor.

ɪn noʊ taɪm, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf kɹɔsɪŋ ðə hjudʒ oʊvəl plɑzə bɪfɔɹ ðə pæləs, ɹaɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɪts tɔl, ɡɪldɪd ɡeɪts. ðə pjʊɹ waɪt pæləs ʌv ændɝ wəd sɝɾənli nɑɾ əv bɪn aʊɾ ə pleɪs əmʌŋ tɑɹ vəlɑnz wʌndɝz, wɪð ɪts slɛndɝ taʊɝz ən ɡoʊldən doʊmz ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn, ɪts haɪ bælkəniz ən ɪntʃɹəkət stoʊnwɝk. ðə ɡoʊld lif ɑn wʌn ə ðoʊz doʊmz cʊɾə kɛpt ɪm ɪn lʌɡʒɝi fəɹ ə jɪɹ.

In no time, he found himself crossing the huge oval plaza before the Palace, riding toward its tall, gilded gates. The pure white Palace of Andor would certainly not have been out of place among Tar Valon's wonders, with its slender towers and golden domes shining in the sun, its high balconies and intricate stonework. The gold leaf on one of those domes could have kept him in luxury for a year.

ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ pipəl ɪn ðə plɑzə ðən ɛlswɛɹ, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɹɪzɝv fəɹ ɡɹeɪɾ əkeɪʒənz. ə dʌzən ə ðə ɡɑɹdz stʊd bɪfɔɹ ðə kloʊzd ɡeɪts, baʊz slæntəd, ɔl əɾ ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm æŋɡəl, əkɹɔs ðɛɹ ɡlimɪŋ bɹɛstpleɪts, feɪsəz hɪɾən baɪ ðə stil bɑɹz ə ðɛɹ bɝnɪʃt hɛlməts' feɪs-ɡɑɹdz. ə hɛvisɛɾ ɔfəsɝ, wɪð ɪz ɹɛd kloʊk θɹoʊn bæk tə ɹɪvil ə nɑɾ ʌv ɡoʊl bɹeɪɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, wɑz wɔkɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ðə laɪn, aɪɪŋ itʃ mæn əz ɪf i θɔɾ i maɪt faɪn ɹʌst əɹ dʌst.

There were fewer people in the plaza than elsewhere, as if it were reserved for great occasions. A dozen of the Guards stood before the closed gates, bows slanted, all at exactly the same angle, across their gleaming breastplates, faces hidden by the steel bars of their burnished helmets' face-guards. A heavyset officer, with his red cloak thrown back to reveal a knot of gold braid on his shoulder, was walking up and down the line, eyeing each man as if he thought he might find rust or dust.

mæt dʒɹu ɹeɪn ən pʊɾ ɑn ə smaɪl. "ɡʊd mɔɹnɪŋ tə ju, kæptən."

Mat drew rein and put on a smile. "Good morning to you, Captain."

ði ɔfəsɝ tɝnd, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm θɹu ðə bɑɹz ə hɪz feɪs-ɡɑɹd wɪð dip, biɾi aɪz, laɪk ə pʌdʒi ɹæɾ ɪn ə keɪdʒ. ðə mæn wɑz oʊldɝ ðən i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd - ʃʊɹli oʊld ɪnʌf tə hæv mɔɹ ðən wʌn nɑɾ ə ɹæŋk - ən fæt ɹæðɝ ðən stɑki. "wʌt dʒju wɑnt, fɑɹmɝ?" hi dɪmændəd ɹʌfli.

The officer turned, staring at him through the bars of his face-guard with deep, beady eyes, like a pudgy rat in a cage. The man was older than he had expected - surely old enough to have more than one knot of rank - and fat rather than stocky. "What do you want, farmer?" he demanded roughly.

mæt dʒɹu ə bɹɛθ. meɪk ɪt ɡʊd. ɪmpɹɛs ðɪs ful soʊ hi dʌzn kip mi weɪɾɪŋ ɔl deɪ. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hæv tə flæʃ ði æmɪɝlɪnz peɪpɝ ɝaʊn tə kip fɹəm kɪkɪŋ maɪ hilz. "aɪ kʌm fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn, fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bɛɹɪŋ ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm - "

Mat drew a breath. Make it good. Impress this fool so he doesn't keep me waiting all day. I don't want to have to flash the Amyrlin's paper around to keep from kicking my heels. "I come from Tar Valon, from the White Tower, bearing a letter from - "

"ju kʌm fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn, fɑɹmɝ?" ðə fæɾ ɔfəsɝz stʌmək ʃʊk əz i læft, bʌt ðən ɪz læftɝ kʌɾ ɔf əz ɪf sɛvɝd wɪð ə naɪf, ən i ɡlɛɹd. "wi wɑnt noʊ lɛɾɝz fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɹoʊɡ, ɪf juv sətʃ ə θɪŋ! əɹ ɡʊd kwin - meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin hɝ! - wɪl teɪk noʊ wɝd fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ əntɪl ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ɪz ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ. aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛni mɛsənʒɝ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ wɛɹɪŋ ə kʌntʃɹimənz koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz. ɪts pleɪn tə mi jə ɑɹ ʌp tə səm tʃɹɪk, pɝhæps θɪŋkɪŋ jəl faɪn ə fju kɔɪnz ɪf jə kʌm kleɪmɪŋ tə kæɹi lɛɾɝz, bʌt jəl bi lʌki ɪf jə doʊn ɛn ɪn ə pɹɪzən sɛl! ɪf jə də kʌm fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɡoʊ bæk ən tɛl ðə taʊɝ tə ɹɪtɝn ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ bɪfɔɹ wi kʌm ən teɪk hɝ! ɪf jəɹ ə tʃɹɪkstɝ æftɝ sɪlvɝ, ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt bɪfɔɹ aɪ hæv jə biɾən wɪðɪn ən ɪntʃ ə jəɹ laɪf! iðɝ weɪ, jə hæf-wɪt lubi, bi ɡɔn!"

"You come from Tar Valon, farmer?" The fat officer's stomach shook as he laughed, but then his laughter cut off as if severed with a knife, and he glared. "We want no letters from Tar Valon, rogue, if you have such a thing! Our good Queen - may the Light illumine her! - will take no word from the White Tower until the Daughter-Heir is returned to her. I never heard of any messenger from the Tower wearing a countryman's coat and breeches. It is plain to me you are up to some trick, perhaps thinking you'll find a few coins if you come claiming to carry letters, but you will be lucky if you don't end in a prison cell! If you do come from Tar Valon, go back and tell the Tower to return the Daughter-Heir before we come and take her! If you're a trickster after silver, get out of my sight before I have you beaten within an inch of your life! Either way, you half-wit looby, be gone!"

mæt hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɛdʒ ə wɝɾ ɪn fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðə mænz spitʃ. hi sɛd kwɪkli, "ðə lɛɾɝ ɪz fɹəm hɝ, mæn. ɪts fɹəm - "

Mat had been trying to edge a word in from the beginning of the man's speech. He said quickly, "The letter is from her, man. It is from - "

"dɪɾ aɪ nɑt tɛl jə tə bi ɡɔn, ɹʌfaɪən?" ðə fæt mæn bɛloʊd. hɪz feɪs wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ nɪɹli əz ɹɛɾ əz ɪz koʊt. "teɪk jɝsɛlf aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt, jə ɡʌɾɝ skʌm! ɪf jə ɑɹ nɑt ɡɔn baɪ ðə taɪm aɪ kaʊn tɛn, əl ɝɛs jə fəɹ lɪɾɝɪŋ ðə plɑzə wɪð jəɹ pɹɛzəns! wʌn! tu!"

"Did I not tell you to be gone, ruffian?" the fat man bellowed. His face was growing nearly as red as his coat. "Take yourself out of my sight, you gutter scum! If you are not gone by the time I count ten, I will arrest you for littering the plaza with your presence! One! Two!"

"kæn jə kaʊn soʊ haɪ, jə fæt ful?" mæt snæpt. "aɪ tɛl ju, ɪleɪn sɛnt - "

"Can you count so high, you fat fool?" Mat snapped. "I tell you, Elayne sent - "

"ɡɑɹdz!" ði ɔfəsɝz feɪs wɑz pɝpəl naʊ. "siz ðɪs mæn fəɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd!"

"Guards!" The officer's face was purple now. "Seize this man for a Darkfriend!"

mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ə moʊmənt, ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn kəd teɪk sətʃ ə tʃɑɹdʒ sɪɹiəsli, bʌt ðə ɹɛd-koʊɾəd ɡɑɹdz dæʃt təwɔɹd hɪm, ɔl dʌzən mɛn ɪn bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts, ən i wild ɪz hɔɹs ən ɡæləpt əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, fɑloʊd baɪ ðə fæt mænz ʃaʊts. ðə ɡɛldɪŋ wɑz noʊ ɹeɪsɝ, bʌɾ ɪɾ aʊtdɪstəns mɛn əfʊɾ izəli ɪnʌf. pipəl dɑdʒd aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ əlɔŋ ðə kɝvɪŋ stʃɹits, ʃeɪkɪŋ fɪsts æftɝ ɪm ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ əz mɛni kɝsɪz əz ði ɔfəsɝ hæd.

Mat hesitated a moment, sure no one could take such a charge seriously, but the red-coated Guards dashed toward him, all dozen men in breastplates and helmets, and he wheeled his horse and galloped ahead of them, followed by the fat man's shouts. The gelding was no racer, but it outdistanced men afoot easily enough. People dodged out of his way along the curving streets, shaking fists after him and shouting as many curses as the officer had.

ful, hi θɔt, minɪŋ ðə fæɾ ɔfəsɝ, ðən æɾəd ənʌðɝ fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. ɔl aɪ hæd tə də wɑz seɪ hɝ blʌɾi neɪm ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. "ɪleɪn, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, sɛnz ðɪs lɛɾɝ tə hɝ mʌðɝ, kwin mɔɹɡeɪs." laɪt, hu cʊɾə θɔt ðeɪd θɪŋk ðət weɪ əbaʊt tɑɹ vəlɑn. fɹəm wʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ə hɪz læs vɪzət, ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd bɪn kloʊs bɪhaɪn kwin mɔɹɡeɪs ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdz' əfɛkʃənz. bɝn hɝ, ɪleɪn cʊɾə toʊl mi. ɹɪlʌktənli, hi æɾəd, aɪ cʊɾə æskt kwɛstʃənz, tu.

Fool, he thought, meaning the fat officer, then added another for himself. All I had to do was say her bloody name in the beginning. "Elayne, the Daughter-Heir of Andor, sends this letter to her mother, Queen Morgase." Light, who could have thought they'd think that way about Tar Valon. From what he remembered of his last visit, Aes Sedai and the White Tower had been close behind Queen Morgase in the Guards' affections. Burn her, Elayne could have told me. Reluctantly, he added, I could have asked questions, too.

bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ði ɑɹtʃt ɡeɪts ðət lɛɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə nu sɪɾi, hi sloʊd tə ə wɔk. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðə ɡɑɹdz fɹəm ðə pæləs kəd stɪl bi tʃeɪsɪŋ hɪm, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn ətʃɹæktɪŋ ði aɪz ə ðoʊz ət ðə ɡeɪt baɪ ɡæləpɪŋ θɹu, bʌt ðeɪ lʊkt əɾ ɪm noʊ mɔɹ naʊ ðən wən i hæd fɝst ɛntɝd.

Before he reached the arched gates that let out into the New City, he slowed to a walk. He did not think the Guards from the Palace could still be chasing him, and there was no point in attracting the eyes of those at the gate by galloping through, but they looked at him no more now than when he had first entered.

əz i ɹoʊɾ ʌndɝ ðə bɹɔɾ ɑɹtʃ, hi smaɪld ən ɔlmoʊs tɝn bæk. hi hæd sʌɾənli ɹɪmɛmbɝd sʌmθɪŋ, ən hæɾ ən aɪdiə ðəɾ əpil tə hɪm ə ɡʊd dil mɔɹ ðən wɔkɪŋ θɹu ðə pæləs ɡeɪts. ivən ɪf ðət fæɾ ɔfəsɝ hæd nɑt bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ ðə ɡeɪts, hi θɔɾ i wəd laɪk ɪt bɛɾɝ.

As he rode under the broad arch, he smiled and almost turned back. He had suddenly remembered something, and had an idea that appealed to him a good deal more than walking through the Palace gates. Even if that fat officer had not been watching the gates, he thought he would like it better.

hi bɪkeɪm lɔs twaɪs waɪl sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ, bʌɾ ət læst i faʊn ðə saɪn wɪð ə mæn nilɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ə wʊmən wɪð ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ ən ə kɹaʊn ʌv ɡoʊldən ɹoʊzɪz, hɝ hæn ɑn ɪz hɛd. ɪt wɑz ə bɹɔd stoʊn bɪldɪŋ ə θɹi stɔɹiz, wɪð tɔl wɪndoʊz ivən ʌp ʌndɝ ðə ɹɛd ɹuf taɪlz. hi ɹoʊɾ ɝaʊn bæk tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd, wɛɹ ə hɔɹs-feɪs fɛloʊ, ɪn ə lɛðɝ vɛs ðət kəd hɑɹdli bi ɛni tʌfɝ ðən ɪz skɪn, tʊk ɪz hɔɹsəz ɹeɪnz. hi θɔɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə fɛloʊ. jɛs. ɹæmi.

He became lost twice while searching for The Queen's Blessing, but at last he found the sign with a man kneeling before a woman with red-gold hair and a crown of golden roses, her hand on his head. It was a broad stone building of three stories, with tall windows even up under the red roof tiles. He rode around back to the stableyard, where a horse-faced fellow, in a leather vest that could hardly be any tougher than his skin, took his horse's reins. He thought he remembered the fellow. Yes. Ramey.

"ɪɾ əz bɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm, ɹæmi." mæt tɔst ɪm ə sɪlvɝ mɑɹk. "ju ɹɪmɛmbɝ mi, doʊn ju?"

"It has been a long time, Ramey." Mat tossed him a silver mark. "You remember me, don't you?"

"kæn seɪ əz aɪ . . ." ɹæmi bɪɡæn, ðən kɑt ðə ʃaɪn ə sɪlvɝ wɛɹ i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd kɑpɝ; hi kɔft, ən ɪz ʃɔɹt nɑd tɝn ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ ðət kəmbaɪn ə nʌkəl fɔɹhɛd wɪð ə dʒɝki baʊ. "waɪ, ʌv kɔɹs aɪ du, jʌŋ mæstɝ. fɝɡɪv mi. slɪp maɪ maɪnd. maɪnd noʊ ɡʊd fəɹ pipəl. ɡʊd fəɹ hɔɹsəz. aɪ noʊ hɔɹsəz, aɪ du. ə faɪn ænəməl, jʌŋ mæstɝ. əl teɪk ɡʊd kɛɹ ə hɪm, jə kən bi ʃʊɹ." hi dɪlɪvɝɾ ɪɾ ɔl kwɪkli, wɪð noʊ ɹum fəɹ mæt tə seɪ ə wɝd, ðən hɝid ðə ɡɛldɪŋ ɪndə ðə steɪbəl bɪfɔɹ i maɪɾ əv tə kʌm ʌp wɪð mæts neɪm.

"Can't say as I . . ." Ramey began, then caught the shine of silver where he had expected copper; he coughed, and his short nod turned into something that combined a knuckled forehead with a jerky bow. "Why, of course I do, young master. Forgive me. Slipped my mind. Mind no good for people. Good for horses. I know horses, I do. A fine animal, young master. I'll take good care of him, you can be sure." He delivered it all quickly, with no room for Mat to say a word, then hurried the gelding into the stable before he might have to come up with Mat's name.

wɪð ə saʊɝ ɡɹɪmɑs, mæt pʊt ðə fæt ɹoʊl ə faɪɹwɝks ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm ən ʃoʊldɝd ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz. fɛloʊ kʊdn tɛl mi fɹəm hɔkwɪŋz toʊneɪlz. ə bʌlki, mʌskjəlɝ mæn wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ən ʌptɝn bæɹəl bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ tə ðə kɪtʃən, dʒɛnli skɹætʃɪŋ ði ɪɹ ʌv ə blæk-ænd-waɪt kæt kɹaʊtʃt ɑn ɪz ni. ðə mæn stʌɾid mæt wɪð hɛvi-lɪɾɪd aɪz, ɪspɛʃli ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ stɑpt ɪz skɹætʃɪŋ. mæt θɔɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd hɪm, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ ʌp ə neɪm. hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ əz i wɛn θɹu ðə dɔɹ, ən niðɝ dɪd ðə mæn. noʊ ɹizən ðeɪ ʃəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ mi. pɹɑbli hæv blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ kʌmɪŋ fəɹ pipəl ɛvɹi deɪ.

With a sour grimace, Mat put the fat roll of fireworks under his arm and shouldered the rest of his belongings. Fellow couldn't tell me from Hawkwing's toenails. A bulky, muscular man was sitting on an upturned barrel beside the door to the kitchen, gently scratching the ear of a black-and-white cat crouched on his knee. The man studied Mat with heavy-lidded eyes, especially the quarterstaff across his shoulder, but he never stopped his scratching. Mat thought he remembered him, but he could not bring up a name. He said nothing as he went through the door, and neither did the man. No reason they should remember me. Probably have bloody Aes Sedai coming for people every day.

ɪn ðə kɪtʃən, tu ʌndɝkʊks ən θɹi skʌljənz wɝ dɑɹɾɪŋ bɪtwin stoʊvz ən ɹoʊstɪŋ spɪts ʌndɝ ðə dɝɛkʃən ʌv ə ɹaʊnd wʊmən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ə bʌn ən ə lɔŋ wʊɾən spun ðət ʃi juz tə pɔɪn aʊt wʌt ʃi wɑntəd dʌn. mæt wɑz ʃʊɹ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə ɹaʊnd wʊmən. koʊlini, ən wʌɾ ə neɪm fəɹ ə wʊmən ðət waɪd, bʌɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi kɔld əɹ kʊk.

In the kitchen, two undercooks and three scullions were darting between stoves and roasting spits under the direction of a round woman with her hair in a bun and a long wooden spoon that she used to point out what she wanted done. Mat was sure he remembered the round woman. Coline, and what a name for a woman that wide, but everybody called her Cook.

"wɛl, kʊk," hi ənaʊnst, "aɪ æm bæk, ən nɑɾ ə jɪɹ sɪns aɪ lɛft."

"Well, Cook," he announced, "I am back, and not a year since I left."

ʃi pɪɹɾ əɾ ɪm ə moʊmənt, ðən nɑɾəd. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ju." hi bɪɡæn tə ɡɹɪn. "ju wɝ wɪð ðət jʌŋ pɹɪns, wɝn ju?" ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ðə wʌn u lʊk soʊ laɪk tɪɡɹeɪn, ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin əɹ mɛmɹi. jəɹ ɪz sɝvɪŋ mæn, ɑɹən ju? ɪz i kʌmɪŋ bæk, ðɛn, ðə jʌŋ pɹɪns?"

She peered at him a moment, then nodded. "I remember you." He began to grin. "You were with that young prince, weren't you?" she went on. "The one who looked so like Tigraine, the Light illumine her memory. You're his serving man, aren't you? Is he coming back, then, the young prince?"

"noʊ," hi sɛd kɝtli. ə pɹɪns! laɪt! "aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk hɪl bi ɛnitaɪm sun, ən aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə wəd laɪk ɪɾ ɪf i dɪd." ʃi pɹətɛstəd, seɪɪŋ wʌɾ ə faɪn, hænsəm jʌŋ mæn ðə pɹɪns wɑz - bɝn mi, ɪz ðəɹ ə wʊmən ɛniwɛɹ u dʌzn mun oʊvɝ ɹænd ən meɪk kæf-aɪz ɪf jə mɛnʃən ɪz blʌɾi neɪm? ʃid blʌɾi skɹim ɪf ʃi nu wʌt hiz duɪŋ naʊ - bʌɾ i ɹəfjuz tə lɛɾ əɹ ɡɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt. "ɪz mæstɝ ɡɪl əbaʊt? ən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn?"

"No," he said curtly. A prince! Light! "I do not think he will be anytime soon, and I don't think you would like it if he did." She protested, saying what a fine, handsome young man the prince was - Burn me, is there a woman anywhere who doesn't moon over Rand and make calf-eyes if you mention his bloody name? She'd bloody scream if she knew what he is doing now - but he refused to let her get it out. "Is Master Gill about? And Thom Merrilin?"

"ɪn ðə laɪbɹɛɹi," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə taɪt snɪf. "ju tɛl bɑzəl ɡɪl wən jə si hɪm ðəɾ aɪ sɛd ðoʊz dʒɹeɪnz nid klinɪŋ. tədeɪ, maɪnd." ʃi kɑt saɪɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ wʌn ə ði ʌndɝkʊks wɑz duɪŋ tə ə bif ɹoʊst ən wɑɾəld oʊvɝ tə hɝ. "nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ, tʃaɪld. jəl meɪk ðə mit tu swiɾ ɪf jə pʊt soʊ mʌtʃ ɹəθ ɑn ɪt." ʃi sim tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən mæt ɔlɹɛɾi.

"In the library," she said with a tight sniff. "You tell Basel Gill when you see him that I said those drains need cleaning. Today, mind." She caught sight of something one of the undercooks was doing to a beef roast and waddled over to her. "Not so much, child. You will make the meat too sweet if you put so much arrath on it." She seemed to have forgotten Mat already.

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz i wɛn ɪn sɝtʃ ə ðɪs laɪbɹɛɹi hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ. hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət koʊlini wɑz mɛɹid tə mæstɝ ɡɪl, iðɝ, bʌɾ ɪf i hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ɡʊdwaɪf sɛn ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə hɝ hʌzbənd, ðət hæd bɪn ɪt. ə pɹɪɾi sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl wɪð bɪɡ aɪz ɡɪɡəld ən dɝɛktəɾ ɪm daʊn ə hɔl bɪsaɪd ðə kɑmən ɹum.

He shook his head as he went in search of this library he could not remember. He could not remember that Coline was married to Master Gill, either, but if he had ever heard a goodwife send instructions to her husband, that had been it. A pretty serving girl with big eyes giggled and directed him down a hall beside the common room.

wən i stɛpt ɪndə ðə laɪbɹɛɹi, hi stɑpt ən stɛɹd. ðəɹ hæd tə bi mɔɹ ðən θɹi hʌnʒɹəd bʊks ɑn ðə ʃɛlvz bɪlt ɑn ðə wɔlz, ən mɔɹ laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəlz; hi hæd nɛvɝ sin soʊ mɛni bʊks ɪn wʌn pleɪs ɪn ɪz laɪf. hi noʊɾəst ə lɛðɝ-baʊn kɑpi ʌv ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ ɑn ə teɪbəl nɪɹ ðə dɔɹ. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz mɛn tə ɹid ðət - ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn tɛlɪŋ ɪm θɪŋz aʊɾ ʌv ɪt - bʌɾ i nɛvɝ dɪd sim tə ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn tə ɹiɾɪŋ ðə bʊks i mɛn tə ɹid.

When he stepped into the library, he stopped and stared. There had to be more than three hundred books on the shelves built on the walls, and more lying on the tables; he had never seen so many books in one place in his life. He noticed a leather-bound copy of The Travels of Jain Farstrider on a table near the door. He had always meant to read that - Rand and Perrin had always been telling him things out of it - but he never did seem to get around to reading the books he meant to read.

pɪŋk-feɪs bɑzəl ɡɪl ən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn wɝ siɾəd ət wʌn ə ðə teɪbəlz, feɪsɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ əkɹɔs ə stoʊnz bɔɹd, paɪps ɪn ðɛɹ tiθ tʃɹeɪlɪŋ θɪn blu stʃɹimɝz ə təbæk smoʊk. ə kæləkoʊ kæt sæɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl bɪsaɪɾ ə wʊɾən daɪs kʌp, hɝ teɪl kɝld oʊvɝ əɹ fit, wɑtʃɪŋ əm pleɪ. ðə ɡlimənz kloʊk wɑz noʊwɛɹ ɪn saɪt, soʊ mæt səpoʊzd i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɑɾən ə ɹum.

Pink-faced Basel Gill and Thom Merrilin were seated at one of the tables, facing each other across a stones board, pipes in their teeth trailing thin blue streamers of tabac smoke. A calico cat sat on the table beside a wooden dice cup, her tail curled over her feet, watching them play. The gleeman's cloak was nowhere in sight, so Mat supposed he had already gotten a room.

"jɔɹ dʌn sunɝ ðən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd, bɔɪ," tɑm sɛɾ ɝaʊn ɪz paɪpɛstəm. hi tʌɡd wʌn lɔŋ, waɪt mʌstæʃ əz i kənsɪɾɝd wɛɹ tə pleɪs ɪz nɛkst stoʊn ɑn ðə bɔɹdz kɹɔs-hætʃɪŋz. "bɑzəl, jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ mæt kɔθən."

"You're done sooner than I expected, boy," Thom said around his pipestem. He tugged one long, white mustache as he considered where to place his next stone on the board's cross-hatchings. "Basel, you remember Mat Cauthon."

"aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ," ðə fæɾ ɪnkipɝ sɛd, piɹɪŋ ət ðə bɔɹd. "sɪkli, ðə læs taɪm jə wɝ hɪɹ, aɪ ɹikɔl. aɪ hoʊp jə ɑɹ bɛɾɝ naʊ, læd."

"I remember," the fat innkeeper said, peering at the board. "Sickly, the last time you were here, I recall. I hope you are better now, lad."

"aɪ æm bɛɾɝ," mæt sɛd. "ɪz ðəɾ ɔl jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ? ðəɾ aɪ wɑz sɪk?"

"I am better," Mat said. "Is that all you remember? That I was sick?"

mæstɝ ɡɪl wɪnst ət tɑmz muv ən tʊk ɪz paɪp aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ. "kənsɪɾɝɪŋ u jə lɛft wɪð, læd, ən kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə weɪ θɪŋz ɑɹ naʊ, meɪbi ɪts bɛst aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt."

Master Gill winced at Thom's move and took his pipe out of his mouth. "Considering who you left with, lad, and considering the way things are now, maybe it's best I remember no more than that."

"ɛɛs sədaɪ nɑɾ ɪn sətʃ ɡʊɾ oʊɾɝ naʊ, ɑɹ ðeɪ?" mæt sɛɾ ɪz θɪŋz ɪn wʌn bɪɡ ɑɹmtʃɛɹ, ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf pɹɑpt əɡɛns ðə bæk, ən hɪmsɛlf ɪn ənʌðɝ wɪð wʌn lɛɡ swɪŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ði ɑɹm. "ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə pæləs sim tə θɪŋk ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd stoʊlən ɪleɪn." tɑm aɪd ðə ɹoʊl ə faɪɹwɝks ənizəli, lʊkt əɾ ɪz smoʊkɪŋ paɪp, ən mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə hɪz stʌɾi ʌv ðə bɔɹd.

"Aes Sedai not in such good odor now, are they?" Mat set his things in one big armchair, the quarterstaff propped against the back, and himself in another with one leg swinging over the arm. "The Guards at the Palace seemed to think the White Tower had stolen Elayne." Thom eyed the roll of fireworks uneasily, looked at his smoking pipe, and muttered to himself before going back to his study of the board.

"hɑɹdli ðæt," ɡɪl sɛd, "bʌt ðə hoʊl sɪɾi noʊz ʃi dɪsəpɪɹd fɹəm ðə taʊɝ. tɑm sɛz ʃiz ɹɪtɝnd, bʌt wiv hɝd nʌn ə ðət hɪɹ. pɝhæps mɔɹɡeɪs noʊz, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn daʊn tə ə steɪbəlbɔɪ ɪz stɛpɪŋ laɪtli soʊ ʃi dʌzn snæp ɔf ɪz hɛd. lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl əz kɛpt əɹ fɹəm æktʃəli  sɛndɪŋ ɛniwʌn tə ðə hɛdzmən, bʌɾ aɪd nɑt seɪ ʃi wəd nɑt də ɪt. hiz hæz sɝɾənli nɑt suðd əɹ tɛmpɝ təwɔɹd tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, aɪ hiz hæz meɪɾ ɪt wɝs."

"Hardly that," Gill said, "but the whole city knows she disappeared from the Tower. Thom says she's returned, but we've heard none of that here. Perhaps Morgase knows, but everyone down to a stableboy is stepping lightly so she doesn't snap off his head. Lord Gaebril has kept her from actually sending anyone to the headsman, but I'd not say she would not do it. And he has certainly not soothed her temper toward Tar Valon. If anything, I think he has made it worse."

"mɔɹɡeɪs əz ə nu ædvaɪzɝ," tɑm sɛɾ ɪn ə dʒɹaɪ vɔɪs. "ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn dɪd nɑt laɪk hɪm, soʊ bɹaɪn əz bɪn ɹɪtaɪɹd tə hɪz ɪsteɪt tə wɑtʃ ɪz ʃip ɡɹoʊ wʊl. bɑzəl, ɑɹ jə gɑnə pleɪs ə stoʊn əɹ nɑt?"

"Morgase has a new advisor," Thom said in a dry voice. "Gareth Bryne did not like him, so Bryne has been retired to his estate to watch his sheep grow wool. Basel, are you going to place a stone or not?"

"ɪn ə moʊmənt, tɑm. ɪn ə moʊmənt. aɪ wɑnə sɛɾ ɪt ɹaɪt." ɡɪl klæmpt ɪz tiθ ɝaʊn ɪz paɪpɛstəm ən fɹaʊn ət ðə bɔɹd, pʌfɪŋ ʌp smoʊk.

"In a moment, Thom. In a moment. I want to set it right." Gill clamped his teeth around his pipestem and frowned at the board, puffing up smoke.

"soʊ ðə kwin əz ən ædvaɪzɝ u dʌzn laɪk tɑɹ vəlɑn," mæt sɛd. "wɛl, ðəɾ ɪkspleɪnz ðə weɪ ðə ɡɑɹdz æktəd wən aɪ sɛɾ aɪ keɪm fɹəm ðɛɹ."

"So the Queen has an advisor who doesn't like Tar Valon," Mat said. "Well, that explains the way the Guards acted when I said I came from there."

"ɪf jə toʊld əm ðæt," ɡɪl sɛd, "ju maɪt bi lʌki jə ɪskeɪpt wɪθaʊɾ ɛni bɹoʊkən boʊnz. ɪf ɪt wɑz ɛni ʌv ðə nu mɛn, ət list. ɡeɪbɹəl əz ɹipleɪs hæf ðə ɡɑɹdz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn wɪð mɛn ə hɪz tʃuzɪŋ, ən ðəɾ ɪz noʊ min fit kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ ʃɔɹɾ ə taɪm hiz bɪn hɪɹ. səm seɪ mɔɹɡeɪs meɪ mɛɹi hɪm." hi stɑɹɾəd tə pʊɾ ə stoʊn ɑn ðə bɔɹd, ðən tʊk ɪt bæk wɪð ə ʃeɪk ə hɪz hɛd. "taɪmz tʃeɪnʒ. pipəl tʃeɪnʒ. tu mʌtʃ tʃeɪnʒ fəɹ mi. aɪ səpoʊz aɪm ɡɹoʊɪŋ oʊld."

"If you told them that," Gill said, "you might be lucky you escaped without any broken bones. If it was any of the new men, at least. Gaebril has replaced half the Guards in Caemlyn with men of his choosing, and that is no mean feat considering how short a time he has been here. Some say Morgase may marry him." He started to put a stone on the board, then took it back with a shake of his head. "Times change. People change. Too much change for me. I suppose I am growing old."

"ju sim tə min əs boʊθ tə ɡɹoʊ oʊl bɪfɔɹ jə pleɪs ə stoʊn," tɑm mʌɾɝd. ðə kæt stʃɹɛtʃt ən slɪŋkt əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl fəɹ ɪm tə stʃɹoʊk əɹ bæk. "tɔkɪŋ ɔl deɪ wɪl nɑt lɛt jə faɪn ə ɡʊd muv. waɪ doʊn jə dʒʌst ədmɪt dɪfit, bɑzəl?"

"You seem to mean us both to grow old before you place a stone," Thom muttered. The cat stretched and slinked across the table for him to stroke her back. "Talking all day will not let you find a good move. Why don't you just admit defeat, Basel?"

"aɪ nɛvɝ ədmɪt dɪfit," ɡɪl sɛd staʊtli. "aɪl bit jə jɛt, tɑm." hi sɛɾ ə waɪt stoʊn ɑn ði ɪntɝsɛkʃən ə tu laɪnz. "ju wɪl si." tɑm snɔɹɾɪd.

"I never admit defeat," Gill said stoutly. "I'll beat you yet, Thom." He set a white stone on the intersection of two lines. "You will see." Thom snorted.

fɹəm wʌt mæt kəd si ʌv ðə bɔɹd, hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɡɪl hæd mʌtʃ tʃæns. "aɪ wɪl dʒʌst əv tə əvɔɪd ðə ɡɑɹdz ən pʊɾ ɪleɪnz lɛɾɝ ɹaɪɾ ɪndə mɔɹɡeɪsəz hænz." ɪspɛʃli ɪf ðəɹ ɔl laɪk ðət fæt ful. laɪt, aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf hiz toʊld əm ɔl aɪm ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd?

From what Mat could see of the board, he did not think Gill had much chance. "I will just have to avoid the Guards and put Elayne's letter right into Morgase's hands." Especially if they're all like that fat fool. Light, I wonder if he's told them all I'm a Darkfriend?

"ju dɪd nɑt dɪlɪvɝ ɪt?" tɑm bɑɹkt. "aɪ θɔt jə wɝ æŋkʃəs tə bi ɹɪɾ ə ðə θɪŋ."

"You did not deliver it?" Thom barked. "I thought you were anxious to be rid of the thing."

"ju hæv ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ?" ɡɪl ɪkskleɪmd. "tɑm, waɪ dɪd jə nɑt tɛl mi?"

"You have a letter from the Daughter-Heir?" Gill exclaimed. "Thom, why did you not tell me?"

"aɪ æm sɑɹi, bɑzəl," ðə ɡlimən mʌɾɝd. hi ɡlɛɹɾ ət mæt fɹəm ʌndɝ ðoʊz bʊʃi aɪbɹaʊz ən blu aʊɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz. "ðə bɔɪ θɪŋks sʌmwʌn ɪz aʊt tə kɪl ɪm oʊvɝ ɪt, soʊ aɪ θɔɾ aɪd lɛɾ ɪm seɪ wʌɾ i wɑntəɾ ən noʊ mɔɹ. simz i dʌz nɑt kɛɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ."

"I am sorry, Basel," the gleeman muttered. He glared at Mat from under those bushy eyebrows and blew out his mustaches. "The boy thinks someone is out to kill him over it, so I thought I'd let him say what he wanted and no more. Seems he does not care any longer."

"wʌt kaɪndə lɛɾɝ?" ɡɪl æskt. "ɪz ʃi kʌmɪŋ hoʊm? ən lɔɹd ɡɔɪn? aɪ hoʊp ðeɪ ɑɹ. aɪv æktʃəli  hɝd tɔk ʌv wɔɹ wɪð tɑɹ vəlɑn, əz ɪf ɛniwʌn kəd bi ful ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ tə wɔɹ wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪf jə æsk ɪts ɪz ɔl wʌn wɪð ðoʊz mæd ɹumɝz wiv hɝɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ səpɔɹɾɪŋ ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə wɛst, ən juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən. nɑt ðəɾ aɪ kən si waɪ ðət wəd meɪk wɑnə tə ɡoʊ tə wɔɹ wɪð ðɛm; dʒʌs ði ɑpəzət."

"What kind of letter?" Gill asked. "Is she coming home? And Lord Gawyn? I hope they are. I've actually heard talk of war with Tar Valon, as if anyone could be fool enough to go to war with Aes Sedai. If you ask me, it is all one with those mad rumors we've heard about Aes Sedai supporting a false Dragon somewhere in the west, and using the Power as a weapon. Not that I can see why that would make anyone want to go to war with them; just the opposite."

"ɑɹ jə mɛɹid tə koʊlini?" mæt æskt, ən mæstɝ ɡɪl ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt.

"Are you married to Coline?" Mat asked, and Master Gill gave a start.

"ðə laɪt pɹəzɝv mi fɹəm ðæt! jə wəd θɪŋk ði ɪn wɑz hɝz naʊ. ɪf ʃi wɑz maɪ waɪf . . . ! wʌt dʌz ðəɾ əv tə də wɪð ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz lɛɾɝ?"

"The Light preserve me from that! You would think the inn was hers now. If she was my wife . . . ! What does that have to do with the Daughter-Heir's letter?"

"nʌθɪŋ," mæt sɛd, "bʌt jə wɛn ɑn soʊ lɔŋ, aɪ θɔt jə mʌst əv fɝɡɑɾən jəɹ oʊn kwɛstʃənz." ɡɪl meɪɾ ə tʃoʊkɪŋ saʊnd, ən tɑm bɑɹkt ə læf. mæt hɝiɾ ɑn bɪfɔɹ ði ɪnkipɝ kəd spik. "ðə lɛɾɝ ɪz sild; ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt tɛl mi wʌɾ ɪt sɛz." tɑm wɑz aɪɪŋ ɪm saɪdweɪz ən stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz. dʌz i θɪŋk əl ədmɪt wi oʊpən ðə θɪŋ? "bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ʃiz kʌmɪŋ hoʊm. ʃi minz tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪf jə æsk mi." hi toʊld əm əbaʊɾ ɪz ətɛmp tə dɪlɪvɝ ðə lɛɾɝ, smuðɪŋ oʊvɝ ə fju ɛdʒəz ðeɪ hæd noʊ nid tə noʊ əbaʊt.

"Nothing," Mat said, "but you went on so long, I thought you must have forgotten your own questions." Gill made a choking sound, and Thom barked a laugh. Mat hurried on before the innkeeper could speak. "The letter is sealed; Elayne did not tell me what it says." Thom was eyeing him sideways and stroking his mustaches. Does he think I'll admit we opened the thing? "But I don't think she is coming home. She means to be Aes Sedai, if you ask me." He told them about his attempt to deliver the letter, smoothing over a few edges they had no need to know about.

"ðə nu mɛn," ɡɪl sɛd. "ðæɾ ɔfəsɝ saʊnz ɪt, ət list. əl weɪdʒɝ ɑn ɪt. noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən bɹɪɡænz, moʊst ə ðɛm, ɪksɛp ðə wʌnz wɪð ə slaɪ aɪ. jə weɪɾ əntɪl ðɪs æftɝnun, læd, wən ðə ɡɑɹdz ɑn ðə ɡeɪt wɪl əv tʃeɪnʒd. seɪ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz neɪm ɹaɪɾ aʊt, ən dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ðə nu fɛloʊ ɪz wʌn ʌv ɡeɪbɹəlz mɛn, tu, dʌk jəɹ hɛɾ ə lɪɾəl. ə nʌkəl tə jəɹ fɔɹhɛd, ən jəl əv noʊ tʃɹʌbəl."

"The new men," Gill said. "That officer sounds it, at least. I'll wager on it. No better than brigands, most of them, except the ones with a sly eye. You wait until this afternoon, lad, when the Guards on the gate will have changed. Say the Daughter-Heir's name right out, and just in case the new fellow is one of Gaebril's men, too, duck your head a little. A knuckle to your forehead, and you'll have no trouble."

"bɝn mi ɪf aɪ wɪl. aɪ pʊl wʊl ən skɹætʃ ɡɹævəl fəɹ noʊbɑdi. nɑt tə mɔɹɡeɪs hɝsɛlf. ðɪs taɪm, əl nɑt ɡoʊ nɪɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz əɾ ɔl." aɪ wəd dʒʌst əz sun nɑt noʊ wʌt wɝd ðət fæt fɛloʊ hæz spɹɛd. ðeɪ stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i wɝ mæd.

"Burn me if I will. I pull wool and scratch gravel for nobody. Not to Morgase herself. This time, I'll not go near the Guards at all." I would just as soon not know what word that fat fellow has spread. They stared at him as if he were mad.

"haʊ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt," ɡɪl sɛd, "du jə min tə ɛntɝ ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs wɪθaʊt pæsɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹdz?" hɪz aɪz waɪɾənd əz ɪf i wɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. "laɪt, jə doʊn min tə. . . . læd, jud nid ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn lʌk tə ɪskeɪp wɪð jəɹ laɪf!"

"How under the Light," Gill said, "do you mean to enter the Royal Palace without passing the Guards?" His eyes widened as if he were remembering something. "Light, you don't mean to. . . . Lad, you'd need the Dark One's own luck to escape with your life!"

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn əbaʊt naʊ, bɑzəl? mæt, wʌt ful θɪŋ dʒju ɪntɛn tə tʃɹaɪ?"

"What are you going on about now, Basel? Mat, what fool thing do you intend to try?"

"aɪ æm lʌki, mæstɝ ɡɪl," mæt sɛd. "ju dʒʌst əv ə ɡʊd mil weɪɾɪŋ wən aɪ kʌm bæk." əz i stʊd, hi pɪkt ʌp ðə daɪs kʌp ən spʌn ðə daɪs aʊt bɪsaɪd ðə stoʊnz bɔɹd fəɹ lʌk. ðə kæləkoʊ kæt lɛp daʊn, hɪsɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð əɹ bæk ɑɹtʃt. ðə faɪv spɑɾəd daɪs keɪm tə ɹɛst, itʃ ʃoʊɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl pɪp. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz.

"I am lucky, Master Gill," Mat said. "You just have a good meal waiting when I come back." As he stood, he picked up the dice cup and spun the dice out beside the stones board for luck. The calico cat leaped down, hissing at him with her back arched. The five spotted dice came to rest, each showing a single pip. The Dark One's Eyes.

"ðæts ðə bɛs tɔs əɹ ðə wɝst," ɡɪl sɛd. "ɪt dɪpɛnz ɑn ðə ɡeɪm jə ɑɹ pleɪɪŋ, dʌzn ɪt. læd, aɪ θɪŋk jə min tə pleɪ ə deɪnʒɝəs ɡeɪm. waɪ doʊn jə teɪk ðət kʌp aʊɾ ɪndə ðə kɑmən ɹum ən luz ə fju kɑpɝz? jə lʊk tə mi laɪk ə fɛloʊ hu maɪt laɪk ə lɪɾəl ɡæmbəl. əl si ðə lɛɾɝ ɡɛts tə ðə pæləs seɪfli."

"That's the best toss or the worst," Gill said. "It depends on the game you are playing, doesn't it. Lad, I think you mean to play a dangerous game. Why don't you take that cup out into the common room and lose a few coppers? You look to me like a fellow who might like a little gamble. I will see the letter gets to the Palace safely."

"koʊlini wɑns jə tə klin ðə dʒɹeɪnz," mæt toʊl hɪm, ən tɝn tə tɑm waɪl ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz stɪl blɪŋkɪŋ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. "ɪt dʌzn sim tə meɪk ɛni ɑdz wɛðɝ aɪ ɡɛɾ ən æɹoʊ ɪn mi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪlɪvɝ ðət lɛɾɝ əɹ ə naɪf ɪn maɪ bæk weɪɾɪŋ. ɪts sɪks ʌp, ən ə hæf dʌzən daʊn. dʒʌs juv ðət mil weɪɾɪŋ, tɑm." hi tɔst ə ɡoʊl mɑɹk ɑn ðə teɪbəl ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɡɪl. "hæv maɪ θɪŋz pʊɾ ɪn ə ɹum, ɪnkipɝ. ɪf ɪt teɪks mɔɹ kɔɪn, jəl əv ɪt. bi kɛɹfəl ə ðə bɪɡ ɹoʊl; ɪt fɹaɪɾənz tɑm sʌmθɪŋ ɑfəl."

"Coline wants you to clean the drains," Mat told him, and turned to Thom while the innkeeper was still blinking and muttering to himself. "It doesn't seem to make any odds whether I get an arrow in me trying to deliver that letter or a knife in my back waiting. It's six up, and a half dozen down. Just you have that meal waiting, Thom." He tossed a gold mark on the table in front of Gill. "Have my things put in a room, innkeeper. If it takes more coin, you will have it. Be careful of the big roll; it frightens Thom something awful."

əz i stɔkt aʊt, hi hɝd ɡɪl seɪ tə tɑm, "aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔt ðət læd wɑz ə ɹæskəl. haʊ dʌz i kʌm baɪ ɡoʊld?"

As he stalked out, he heard Gill say to Thom, "I always thought that lad was a rascal. How does he come by gold?"

aɪ ɔlweɪz wɪn, ðæts haʊ, hi θɔt ɡɹɪmli. aɪ dʒʌst əv tə wɪn wʌns mɔɹ, ən aɪm dʌn wɪð ɪleɪn, ən ðæts ðə læst ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ fəɹ mi. dʒʌst wʌns mɔɹ.

I always win, that's how, he thought grimly. I just have to win once more, and I'm done with Elayne, and that's the last of the White Tower for me. Just once more.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɪks


CHAPTER 46

eɪ mɛsədʒ aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊ


A Message Out of the Shadow

ivən əz i ɹɪtɝn tə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi ɑn fʊt, mæt wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm sɝɾən ðət wʌɾ i ɪntɛndəd wəɾ æktʃəli  wɝk. ɪt wʊd, ɪf wʌɾ i hæd bɪn toʊld wɑz tʃɹu, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə tʃɹuθ ə ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʌv. hi əvɔɪɾəd ði oʊvəl plɑzə ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə pæləs, bʌt wɑndɝɾ ɝaʊn ðə saɪdz ə ðə hjudʒ stʃɹʌktʃɝ ən ɪts ɡɹaʊnz, əlɔŋ stʃɹits ðət kɝvd wɪð ðə kɑntʊɹz ə ðə hɪlz. ðə ɡoʊldən doʊmz ə ðə pæləs ɡlɪɾɝd, mɑkəŋli aʊɾ ə ɹitʃ. hi hæd meɪɾ ɪz weɪ ɔlmoʊst ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊnd, nɪɹli bæk tə ðə plɑzə, wən i sɔ ɪt. ə stip sloʊp θɪk wɪð loʊ flaʊɝz, ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə stʃɹit tə ə waɪt wɔl ə ɹʌf stoʊn. sɛvɹəl lifi tʃɹi lɪmz stʌk oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl, ən i kəd si ðə tɑps ʌv ʌðɝz bɪɑnd, ɪn ə ɡɑɹɾən ə ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs.

Even as he returned to the Inner City on foot, Mat was far from certain that what he intended would actually work. It would, if what he had been told was true, but it was the truth of that he was not sure of. He avoided the oval plaza in front of the Palace, but wandered around the sides of the huge structure and its grounds, along streets that curved with the contours of the hills. The golden domes of the Palace glittered, mockingly out of reach. He had made his way almost all the way around, nearly back to the plaza, when he saw it. A steep slope thick with low flowers, rising from the street to a white wall of rough stone. Several leafy tree limbs stuck over the top of the wall, and he could see the tops of others beyond, in a garden of the Royal Palace.

ə wɔl meɪd tə lʊk laɪk ə klɪf, hi θɔt, ən ə ɡɑɹɾən ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. meɪbi ɹænd wɑz tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ.

A wall made to look like a cliff, he thought, and a garden on the other side. Maybe Rand was telling the truth.

ə kæʒəwəl lʊk boʊθ weɪz ʃoʊɾ ɪm i hæd ðə kɝvɪŋ stʃɹit tə hɪmsɛlf fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. hi wəɾ əv tə hɝi; ðə kɝvz dɪd nɑɾ əlaʊ hɪm tə si vɛɹi fɑɹ; sʌmwʌn kəd kʌm əlɔŋ ɛni moʊmənt. hi skɹæmbəld ʌp ðə sloʊp ɑn ɔl fɔɹz, kɛɹləs ə haʊ hɪz buts ɹɪp hoʊlz ɪn ðə bæŋks ə ɹɛɾ ən waɪt blɑsəmz. ðə ɹʌf stoʊn ə ðə wɔl ɡeɪv plɛnti ʌv fɪŋɡɝhoʊlz, ən ɹɪdʒəz ən nɑbz pɹəvaɪɾəd toʊhoʊlz ivən fəɹ ə mæn ɪn buts.

A casual look both ways showed him he had the curving street to himself for the moment. He would have to hurry; the curves did not allow him to see very far; someone could come along any moment. He scrambled up the slope on all fours, careless of how his boots ripped holes in the banks of red and white blossoms. The rough stone of the wall gave plenty of fingerholds, and ridges and knobs provided toeholds even for a man in boots.

kɛɹləs ə ðɛm tə meɪk ɪt soʊ izi, hi θɔɾ əz i klaɪmd. fəɹ ə moʊmən ðə klaɪmɪŋ tʊk ɪm bæk hoʊm wɪð ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn, tə ə dʒɝni ðeɪ hæd meɪd bɪɑn ðə sæn hɪlz, ɪndə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. wən ðeɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ɛmənz fild, ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl kɑt ðə fjʊɹi fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn u kəd leɪ hænz ɑn əm - hɪm wɝst ʌv ɔl; ɛvɹiwʌn əsumd ɪt hæd bɪn ɪz aɪdiə - bʌt fəɹ θɹi deɪz ðeɪ hæd klaɪm ðə klɪfs, ən slɛpt ʌndɝ ðə skaɪ, ən iɾən ɛɡz fɪltʃt fɹəm ɹɛdkɹəsts' nɛsts, ən plʌmp, ɡɹeɪ-wɪŋd ɡɹaʊs fɛtʃt wɪð ən æɹoʊ, əɹ ə stoʊn fɹəm ə slɪŋ, ən ɹæbəts kɑt wɪð snɛɹz, ɔl ðə waɪl læfɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə maʊntənz' bæd lʌk ən haʊ ðeɪ maɪt faɪn ə tʃɹɛʒɝ. hi hæd bɹɔt hoʊm ən ɑd ɹɑk fɹəm ðəɾ ɛkspədɪʃən, wɪð ðə skʌl ʌv ə ɡʊd-saɪz fɪʃ sʌmhaʊ pɹɛst ɪndə ɪt, ən ə lɔŋ, waɪt teɪl fɛðɝ dʒɹɑp baɪ ə snoʊ iɡəl, ən ə pis ʌv waɪt stoʊn əz bɪɡ əz ɪz hæn ðət lʊkt ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn kɑɹvd ɪndə ə mænz ɪɹ. hi θɔɾ ɪt lʊk laɪk ən ɪɹ, ivən ɪf ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt, ən tæm ælθɹ hæd sɛɾ ɪt maɪt bi.

Careless of them to make it so easy, he thought as he climbed. For a moment the climbing took him back home with Rand and Perrin, to a journey they had made beyond the Sand Hills, into the edge of the Mountains of Mist.
