When they returned to Emond's Field, they had all caught the fury from everyone who could lay hands on them - him worst of all; everyone assumed it had been his idea - but for three days they had climbed the cliffs, and slept under the sky, and eaten eggs filched from redcrests' nests, and plump, gray-winged grouse fetched with an arrow, or a stone from a sling, and rabbits caught with snares, all the while laughing about how they were not afraid of the mountains' bad luck and how they might find a treasure. He had brought home an odd rock from that expedition, with the skull of a good-sized fish somehow pressed into it, and a long, white tail feather dropped by a snow eagle, and a piece of white stone as big as his hand that looked almost as if it had been carved into a man's ear. He thought it looked like an ear, even if Rand and Perrin did not, and Tam al'Thor had said it might be.

hɪz fɪŋɡɝz slɪpt aʊɾ ʌv ə ʃæloʊ ɡɹuv, hɪz bæləns ʃɪftəɾ ən i lɔs ðə toʊhoʊld ʌndɝ ɪz lɛft fʊt. wɪð ə ɡæsp, hi bɛɹli kɑt hoʊld ə ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl, ən pʊl hɪmsɛlf ʌp ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ. fəɹ ə moʊmən i leɪ ðɛɹ, bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd. ɪt wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ðət lɔŋ ə fɔl, bʌɾ ɪnʌf tə bɹeɪk ɪz hɛd. ful, lɛɾɪŋ maɪ maɪnd wɑndɝ laɪk ðæt. nɪɹli kɪl maɪsɛlf ɑn ðoʊz klɪfs ðət weɪ. ðət wɑz ɔl ə lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ. hɪz mʌðɝ hæd laɪkli θɹoʊn ɔl ðoʊz θɪŋz aʊɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, ɛniweɪ. wɪð wʌn læs lʊk itʃ weɪ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn hæd sin ɪm - ðə kɝvɪŋ lɛŋθ ə stʃɹit bɪloʊ wɑz stɪl ɛmpti - hi dʒɹɑpt ɪnsaɪd ðə pæləs ɡɹaʊnz.

His fingers slipped out of a shallow groove, his balance shifted and he lost the toehold under his left foot. With a gasp, he barely caught hold of the top of the wall, and pulled himself up the rest of the way. For a moment he lay there, breathing hard. It would not have been that long a fall, but enough to break his head. Fool, letting my mind wander like that. Nearly killed myself on those cliffs that way. That was all a long time ago. His mother had likely thrown all those things out already, anyway. With one last look each way to make sure no one had seen him - the curving length of street below was still empty - he dropped inside the Palace grounds.

ɪt wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɑɹɾən, wɪð flæɡstoʊnd wɔks θɹu ɪkspænsɪz ʌv ɡɹæs əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, ən ɡɹeɪpvaɪnz θɪk ɑn ɑɹbɝz oʊvɝ ðə wɔks. ən ɛvɹiwɛɹ, flaʊɝz. waɪt blɑsəmz kʌvɝɪŋ ðə pɛɹ tʃɹiz, ən waɪɾ ən pɪŋk dɑɾɪŋ ði æpəl tʃɹiz. ɹoʊzɪz ɪn ɛvɹi kʌlɝ, ən bɹaɪt ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst, ən pɝpəl ɛmənz ɡlɔɹi, ən mɛni hi kəd nɑɾ aɪdɛntəfaɪ. səm i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ kəd bi ɹil. wʌn hæɾ ɑd blɑsəmz ɪn skɑɹləɾ ən ɡoʊl ðət lʊkt ɔlmoʊs laɪk bɝdz, ən ənʌðɝ sim noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ə sʌnflaʊɝ ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪts jɛloʊ flaʊɝz wɝ tu fiɾ ən mɔɹ əkɹɔs ən stʊɾ ɑn stɔks əz tɔl əz ən oʊɡiɝ.

It was a large garden, with flagstoned walks through expanses of grass among the trees, and grapevines thick on arbors over the walks. And everywhere, flowers. White blossoms covering the pear trees, and white and pink dotting the apple trees. Roses in every color, and bright golden sunburst, and purple Emond's Glory, and many he could not identify. Some he was not sure could be real. One had odd blossoms in scarlet and gold that looked almost like birds, and another seemed no different from a sunflower except that its yellow flowers were two feet and more across and stood on stalks as tall as an Ogier.

buts kɹʌntʃt ɑn flæɡstoʊn, ən i kɹaʊtʃt loʊ bɪhaɪn ə bʊʃ əɡɛns ðə wɔl əz tu ɡɑɹdzmɪn mɑɹtʃt pæst, ðɛɹ lɔŋ, waɪt kɑlɝz hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ bɹɛstpleɪts. ðeɪ nɛvɝ ɡlænst ɪz weɪ, ən i ɡɹɪn tə hɪmsɛlf. lʌk. wɪð dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl lʌk, ðəl nɛvɝ si mi tɪl aɪ hæn ðə blʌɾi θɪŋ tə mɔɹɡeɪs.

Boots crunched on flagstone, and he crouched low behind a bush against the wall as two guardsmen marched past, their long, white collars hanging over their breastplates. They never glanced his way, and he grinned to himself. Luck. With just a little luck, they'll never see me till I hand the bloody thing to Morgase.

hi slɪp θɹu ðə ɡɑɹɾən laɪk ə ʃædoʊ, əz ɪf stɔkɪŋ ɹæbəts, fɹizɪŋ baɪ ə bʊʃ əɹ hɑɹɾ əɡɛnst ə tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk wən i hɝd buts. tu mɔɹ pɛɹz ə soʊlʒɝz stʃɹoʊd baɪ əlɔŋ ðə pæðz, ðə sɛkən kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə hæv teɪkən tu stɛps ən ɡus ðɛm. əz ðeɪ vænɪʃt əmʌŋ ðə flaʊɝz ən tʃɹiz, hi plʌkt ə dip ɹɛd stɑɹbleɪz ən stʌk ðə weɪvi-pɛɾəld flaʊɝ ɪn ɪz hɛɹ wɪð ə ɡɹɪn. ðɪs wɑz əz mʌtʃ fʌn əz stilɪŋ æpəlkeɪks ət sʌndeɪ, ən iziɝ. wɪmən ɔlweɪz kɛpt ə ʃɑɹp wɑtʃ ɑn ðɛɹ beɪkɪŋ; ðə ful soʊlʒɝz nɛvɝ tʊk ðɛɹ aɪz ɔf ðə flæɡstoʊnz.

He slipped through the garden like a shadow, as if stalking rabbits, freezing by a bush or hard against a tree trunk when he heard boots. Two more pairs of soldiers strode by along the paths, the second close enough for him to have taken two steps and goosed them. As they vanished among the flowers and trees, he plucked a deep red starblaze and stuck the wavy-petaled flower in his hair with a grin. This was as much fun as stealing applecakes at Sunday, and easier. Women always kept a sharp watch on their baking; the fool soldiers never took their eyes off the flagstones.

ɪt wɑz nɑt lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i faʊn hɪmsɛlf əɡɛns ðə waɪt wɔl ə ðə pæləs ɪtsɛlf, ən bɪɡæn slaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪt bɪhaɪn ə ɹoʊ ʌv flaʊɝɪŋ waɪt ɹoʊzɪz ɑn slæɾɪd fɹeɪmz, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ə dɔɹ. ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv waɪd, ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz dʒʌst oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ i θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi ə bɪt hɑɹɾɝ tə ɪkspleɪn biɪŋ faʊn klaɪmɪŋ ɪn θɹu ə wɪndoʊ ðən wɔkɪŋ daʊn ə hɔl. tu mɔɹ soʊlʒɝz əpɪɹd, ən i fɹoʊz; ðeɪ wəd pæs wɪðɪn θɹi peɪsɪz ə hɪm. hi kəd hɪɹ vɔɪsəz fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, tu mɛn, dʒʌs laʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə meɪk aʊt ðə wɝdz.

It was not long before he found himself against the white wall of the Palace itself, and began sliding along it behind a row of flowering white roses on slatted frames, searching for a door. There were plenty of wide, arched windows just over his head, but he thought it might be a bit harder to explain being found climbing in through a window than walking down a hall. Two more soldiers appeared, and he froze; they would pass within three paces of him. He could hear voices from the window over his head, two men, just loud enough for him to make out the words.

" - ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə tɛɹ, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ." ðə mæn saʊndəd fɹaɪɾənd ən əbsikwiəs.

" - on their way to Tear, Great Master." The man sounded frightened and obsequious.

"lɛɾ əm ɹuən ɪz plænz, ɪf ðeɪ kæn." ðɪs vɔɪs wɑz dipɝ ən stʃɹɔŋɝ, ə mæn juz tə kəmænd. "ɪt wɪl sɝv ɪm ɹaɪɾ ɪf θɹi əntʃɹeɪnd ɡɝlz kən fɔɪl hɪm. hi wɑz ɔlweɪz ə ful, ən hiz stɪl ə ful. ɪz ðəɹ ɛni wɝɾ ə ðə bɔɪ? hiz ðə wʌn u kən dɪstʃɹɔɪ əs ɔl."

"Let them ruin his plans, if they can." This voice was deeper and stronger, a man used to command. "It will serve him right if three untrained girls can foil him. He was always a fool, and he is still a fool. Is there any word of the boy? He is the one who can destroy us all."

"noʊ, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ. hiz vænɪʃt. bʌt, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ, wʌn ə ðə ɡɝlz ɪz mɔɹɡeɪsəz nɪt."

"No, Great Master. He has vanished. But, Great Master, one of the girls is Morgase's nit."

mæt hæf tɝnd, ðən kɑt hɪmsɛlf. ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ; ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə hæv sin ɪz stɑɹt θɹu ðə θɪkli woʊvən ɹoʊz stɛmz. muv, jə fulz! ɡɛt baɪ soʊ aɪ kən si hu ðɪs mæn blʌɾi ɪz! hi hæd lɔst səm ə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən.

Mat half turned, then caught himself. The soldiers were coming closer; they did not appear to have seen his start through the thickly woven rose stems. Move, you fools! Get by so I can see who this man bloody is! He had lost some of the conversation.

" - hæz bɪn fɑɹ tu ɪmpeɪʃən sɪns ɹɪɡeɪnɪŋ ɪz fɹiɾəm," ðə dip vɔɪs wɑz seɪɪŋ. "hi nɛvɝ ɹilaɪz ðə bɛs plænz teɪk taɪm tə mətʃʊɹ. hi wɑns ðə wɝld ɪn ə deɪ, ən kælændɝ bɪsaɪdz. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd teɪk hɪm! hi meɪ siz ðə ɡɝl ən tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk səm jus ə hɝ. ən ðət maɪt stʃɹeɪn maɪ oʊn plænz."

" - has been far too impatient since regaining his freedom," the deep voice was saying. "He never realized the best plans take time to mature. He wants the world in a day, and Callandor besides. The Great Lord take him! He may seize the girl and try to make some use of her. And that might strain my own plans."

"æz jə seɪ, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ. ʃæl aɪ ɔɹɾɝ əɹ bɹɔɾ aʊɾ ə tiɹ?"

"As you say, Great Master. Shall I order her brought out of Tear?"

"noʊ. ðə ful wəd teɪk ɪɾ əz ə muv əɡɛns hɪm, ɪf i nu. ən u kən seɪ wʌɾ i tʃuzəz tə wɑtʃ əsaɪd fɹəm ðə sɔɹd? si ðət ʃi daɪz kwaɪətli, koʊmɹ. lɛɾ əɹ dɛθ ətʃɹæk noʊ noʊɾəs əɾ ɔl." hɪz læftɝ wɑz ə ɹɪtʃ ɹʌmbəl. "ðoʊz ɪɡnɝən slæɾɝnz ɪn ðɛɹ taʊɝ wɪl əv ə dɪfəkəl taɪm pɹədusɪŋ əɹ æftɝ ðɪs dɪsəpɪɹəns. ðɪs meɪ ɔl bi dʒʌst əz wɛl. lɛɾ ɪt bi dʌn kwɪkli. kwɪkli, bɪfɔɹ hiz taɪm tə teɪk əɹ hɪmsɛlf."

"No. The fool would take it as a move against him, if he knew. And who can say what he chooses to watch aside from the sword? See that she dies quietly, Comar. Let her death attract no notice at all." His laughter was a rich rumble. "Those ignorant slatterns in their Tower will have a difficult time producing her after this disappearance. This may all be just as well. Let it be done quickly. Quickly, before he has time to take her himself."

ðə tu soʊlʒɝz wɝ ɔlmoʊst əbɹɛst ə hɪm; mæt tʃɹaɪd tə wɪl ðɛɹ fit tə muv fæstɝ.

The two soldiers were almost abreast of him; Mat tried to will their feet to move faster.

"ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ," ði ʌðɝ mæn sɛɾ ənsɝteɪnli, "ðæt meɪ bi dɪfəkəlt. wi noʊ ʃiz ɑn əɹ weɪ tə tɛɹ, bʌt ðə vɛsəl ʃi tʃɹævəld ɑn wɑz faʊn əɾ ɑɹɪŋɡəl, ən ɔl θɹi ʌv əm hæd lɛft ɪɾ ɝliɝ. wi də nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ ʃiz teɪkən ənʌðɝ ʃɪp, əɹ ɪz ɹaɪɾɪŋ saʊθ. ən ɪt meɪ nɑt bi izi tə faɪn əɹ wʌns ʃi ɹitʃəz tɛɹ, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ. pɝhæps ɪf jə - "

"Great Master," the other man said uncertainly, "that may be difficult. We know she is on her way to Tear, but the vessel she traveled on was found at Aringill, and all three of them had left it earlier. We do not know whether she has taken another ship, or is riding south. And it may not be easy to find her once she reaches Tear, Great Master. Perhaps if you - "

"ɑɹ ðəɹ nʌn bʌt fulz ɪn ðə wɝld, naʊ?" ðə dip vɔɪs sɛd hɑɹʃli. "du jə θɪŋk aɪ kəd muv ɪn tiɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɪm noʊɪŋ? aɪ də nɑt min tə faɪt hɪm, nɑt naʊ, nɑt jɛt. bɹɪŋ mi ðə ɡɝlz hɛd, koʊmɹ. bɹɪŋ mi ɔl θɹi hɛdz, əɹ jəl pɹeɪ fəɹ mi tə teɪk jʊɹz!"

"Are there none but fools in the world, now?" the deep voice said harshly. "Do you think I could move in Tear without him knowing? I do not mean to fight him, not now, not yet. Bring me the girl's head, Comar. Bring me all three heads, or you will pray for me to take yours!"

"jɛs, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ. ɪt ʃæl bi əz jə seɪ. jɛs. jɛs."

"Yes, Great Master. It shall be as you say. Yes. Yes."

ðə soʊlʒɝz kɹʌntʃt pæst, nɛvɝ lʊkɪŋ tə iðɝ saɪd. mæt oʊnli weɪɾəd fəɹ ðɛɹ bæks tə pæs bɪfɔɹ lipɪŋ ʌp tə kætʃ ðə bɹɔd stoʊn wɪndaʊsəl ən pʊl hɪmsɛlf haɪ ɪnʌf tə si θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ.

The soldiers crunched past, never looking to either side. Mat only waited for their backs to pass before leaping up to catch the broad stone windowsill and pull himself high enough to see through the window.

hi bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðə fɹɪn tæɹɑbən kɑɹpəɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, wɝθ ə fæt pɝs ə sɪlvɝ. wʌn ə ðə bɹɔd, kɑɹv dɔɹz wɑz swɪŋɪŋ ʃʌt. ə tɔl mæn, wɪð waɪd ʃoʊldɝz ən ə dip tʃɛst stʃɹeɪnɪŋ ðə ɡɹin sɪlk ə hɪz sɪlvɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd koʊt, wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ wɪð dɑɹk blu aɪz. hɪz blæk bɪɹd wɑz kloʊs kʌt, wɪð ə stʃɹik ʌv waɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz tʃɪn. ɔl ɪn ɔl, hi lʊkt ə hɑɹd mæn, ən wʌn juz tə ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz.

He barely noticed the fringed Tarabon carpet on the floor, worth a fat purse of silver. One of the broad, carved doors was swinging shut. A tall man, with wide shoulders and a deep chest straining the green silk of his silver-embroidered coat, was staring at the door with dark blue eyes. His black beard was close cut, with a streak of white over his chin. All in all, he looked a hard man, and one used to giving orders.

"jɛs, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ," hi sɛd sʌɾənli, ən mæt ɔlmoʊs lɔst ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə sɪl. hi hæd θɔt ðɪs mʌs bi ðə mæn wɪð ðə dip vɔɪs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə kɹɪŋɪŋ vɔɪs i hɝd. nɑt kɹɪŋɪŋ naʊ, bʌt stɪl ðə seɪm. "ɪt ʃæl bi əz jə seɪ, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ," ðə mæn sɛd bɪɾɝli. "aɪ wɪl kʌt ðə θɹi wɛntʃɪz' hɛdz ɔf maɪsɛlf. əz sun əz aɪ kən faɪn ðɛm!" hi stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðə dɔɹ, ən mæt lɛt hɪmsɛlf bæk daʊn.

"Yes, Great Master," he said suddenly, and Mat almost lost his grip on the sill. He had thought this must be the man with the deep voice, but it was the cringing voice he heard. Not cringing now, but still the same. "It shall be as you say, Great Master," the man said bitterly. "I will cut the three wenches' heads off myself. As soon as I can find them!" He strode through the door, and Mat let himself back down.

fəɹ ə moʊmən i kɹaʊtʃt ðəɹ bɪhaɪn ðə ɹoʊz fɹeɪmz. sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə pæləs wɑntəɾ ɪleɪn dɛd, ən hæd θɹoʊn ɪn ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv əz æftɝtɑts. wʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ duɪŋ, ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɛɹ? ɪt hæd tə bi ðɛm.

For a moment he crouched there behind the rose frames. Someone in the Palace wanted Elayne dead, and had thrown in Egwene and Nynaeve as afterthoughts. What under the Light are they doing, going to Tear? It had to be them.

hi pʊl ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz lɛɾɝ aʊɾ ə ðə laɪnɪŋ ə hɪz koʊɾ ən fɹaʊn əɾ ɪt. meɪbi, wɪð ðɪs ɪn ɪz hænd, mɔɹɡeɪs wəd bɪliv hɪm. hi kəd dɪskɹaɪb wʌn ə ðə mɛn. bʌt ðə taɪm fəɹ skʌlkɪŋ wɑz pæst; ðə bɪɡ fɛloʊ kəd bi ɔf tə tɛɹ bɪfɔɹ i ivən faʊn mɔɹɡeɪs, ən wʌtɛvɝ ʃi dɪd ðɛn, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡɛɹənti ɪt kəd stɑp hɪm.

He pulled the Daughter-Heir's letter out of the lining of his coat and frowned at it. Maybe, with this in his hand, Morgase would believe him. He could describe one of the men. But the time for skulking was past; the big fellow could be off to Tear before he even found Morgase, and whatever she did then, there was no guarantee it could stop him.

teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, mæt wɪɡɡəl bɪtwin tu ʌv ðə ɹoʊz fɹeɪmz ət ðə kɑst ʌv oʊnli ə fju pɹɪks ən snæɡz fɹəm ðə θɔɹnz, ən stɑɹɾəd daʊn ðə flæɡstoʊn pæθ æftɝ ðə soʊlʒɝz. hi hɛld ɪleɪnz lɛɾɝ aʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm soʊ ðə ɡoʊldən lɪli sil wɑz pleɪnli vɪzəbəl, ən wɛn oʊvɝ ɪn ɪz maɪn ɪɡzækli wʌɾ i mɛn tə seɪ. wən i hæd bɪn snikɪŋ əbaʊt, ɡɑɹdzmɪn kɛpt pɑpɪŋ ʌp laɪk mʌʃɹumz æftɝ ɹeɪn, bʌt naʊ hi wɔkt ɔlmoʊs ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə ɡɑɹɾən wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ivən wʌn. hi pæst sɛvɹəl dɔɹz. ɪt wəd nɑt bi soʊ ɡʊd tə ɛntɝ ðə pæləs wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən - ðə ɡɑɹdz maɪt də næsti θɪŋz fɝst ən lɪsən æftɝ - bʌɾ i wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu ə dɔɹ wən ɪɾ oʊpən ən ə hɛlmɔɪtləs jʌŋ ɔfəsɝ wɪð wʌn ɡoʊldən nɑɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ stʃɹoʊɾ aʊt.

Taking a deep breath, Mat wiggled between two of the rose frames at the cost of only a few pricks and snags from the thorns, and started down the flagstone path after the soldiers. He held Elayne's letter out in front of him so the golden lily seal was plainly visible, and went over in his mind exactly what he meant to say. When he had been sneaking about, guardsmen kept popping up like mushrooms after rain, but now he walked almost the length of the garden without seeing even one. He passed several doors. It would not be so good to enter the Palace without permission - the Guards might do nasty things first and listen after - but he was beginning to think about going through a door when it opened and a helmetless young officer with one golden knot on his shoulder strode out.

ðə mænz hæn ɪmiɾiətli wɛn tə hɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, ən i hæɾ ə fʊɾ ə stil bɛɹd bɪfɔɹ mæt kəd pʊʃ ðə lɛɾɝ təwɔɹd hɪm. "ɪleɪn, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, sɛnz ðɪs lɛɾɝ tə hɝ mʌðɝ, kwin mɔɹɡeɪs, kæptən." hi hɛl ðə lɛɾɝ soʊ ðə lɪli sil wɑz pɹɑmənənt.

The man's hand immediately went to his sword hilt, and he had a foot of steel bared before Mat could push the letter toward him. "Elayne, the Daughter-Heir, sends this letter to her mother, Queen Morgase, Captain." He held the letter so the lily seal was prominent.

ði ɔfəsɝz dɑɹk aɪz flɪkɝd tə iðɝ saɪd, əz ɪf sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ʌðɝ pipəl, wɪθaʊt ɹɪli ɛvɝ livɪŋ mæt. "haʊ dɪd jə kʌm ɪndə ðɪs ɡɑɹɾən?" hi dɪd nɑt dʒɹɔ hɪz sɔɹd fɝðɝ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt ʃiθ ɪt, iðɝ. "ɛlbɝ ɪz ɑn ðə meɪn ɡeɪts. hiz ə ful, bʌɾ i wəd nɛvɝ lɛɾ ɛniwʌn wɑndɝ lus ɪndə ðə pæləs."

The officer's dark eyes flickered to either side, as if searching for other people, without really ever leaving Mat. "How did you come into this garden?" He did not draw his sword further, but he did not sheath it, either. "Elber is on the main gates. He's a fool, but he would never let anyone wander loose into the Palace."

"ə fæt mæn wɪð aɪz laɪk ə ɹæt?" mæt kɝst ɪz tʌŋ, bʌt ði ɔfəsɝ ɡeɪv ə ʃɑɹp nɑd; hi ɔlmoʊst smaɪld, tu, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt sim tə lɛsən ɪz vɪdʒələns, əɹ ɪz səspɪʃən. "hi ɡɹu æŋɡɹi wən i lɝn aɪ hæd kʌm fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən i wʊdn ivən ɡɪmi ə tʃæns tə ʃoʊ ðə lɛɾɝ əɹ mɛnʃən ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz neɪm. hi sɛɾ i wəɾ ɝɛs mi ɪf aɪ dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ, soʊ aɪ klaɪm ðə wɔl. aɪ pɹɑməst aɪ wəd dɪlɪvɝ ðɪs tə kwin mɔɹɡeɪs hɝsɛlf, jə si, kæptən. aɪ pɹɑməst ɪt, ən aɪ ɔlweɪz kip maɪ pɹɑməsəz. jə si ðə sil?"

"A fat man with eyes like a rat?" Mat cursed his tongue, but the officer gave a sharp nod; he almost smiled, too, but it did not seem to lessen his vigilance, or his suspicion. "He grew angry when he learned I had come from Tar Valon, and he wouldn't even give me a chance to show the letter or mention the Daughter-Heir's name. He said he would arrest me if I did not go, so I climbed the wall. I promised I would deliver this to Queen Morgase herself, you see, Captain. I promised it, and I always keep my promises. You see the seal?"

"ðæt blʌɾi ɡɑɹɾən wɔl əɡɛn," ði ɔfəsɝ mʌɾɝd. "ɪt ʃəd bi bɪl θɹi taɪmz soʊ haɪ." hi aɪd mæt. "ɡɑɹdzmæn-lutɛnənt, nɑt kæptən. aɪm ɡɑɹdzmæn-lutɛnən tɑlænvɝ. aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz sil." hɪz sɔɹd faɪnəli slɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ bæk ɪndə ðə ʃiθ. hi stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ə hænd; nɑɾ ɪz sɔɹd hænd. "ɡɪv mi ðə lɛɾɝ, ən əl teɪk ɪt tə ðə kwin. æftɝ ðəfɝst ʃoʊ jə aʊt. səm wəd nɑt bi soʊ dʒɛntəl ət faɪndɪŋ jə wɔkɪŋ əbaʊt lus."

"That bloody garden wall again," the officer muttered. "It should be built three times so high." He eyed Mat. "Guardsman-lieutenant, not captain. I am Guardsman-lieutenant Tallanvor. I recognize the Daughter-Heir's seal." His sword finally slid all the way back into the sheath. He stretched out a hand; not his sword hand. "Give me the letter, and I will take it to the Queen. After I show you out. Some would not be so gentle at finding you walking about loose."

"aɪ pɹɑməs tə pʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn əɹ hænz maɪsɛlf," mæt sɛd. laɪt, aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt ðeɪ maɪt nɑt lemi ɡɪv ɪt tə hɝ. "aɪ dɪd pɹɑməs. tə ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ."

"I promised to put it in her hands myself," Mat said. Light, I never thought they might not let me give it to her. "I did promise. To the Daughter-Heir."

mæt hɑɹdli ɹilaɪz tɑlænvɝz hænd wɑz muvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ði ɔfəsɝz sɔɹd wɑz ɹɛstɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪz nɛk. "aɪ wɪl teɪk jə tə ðə kwin, kʌntʃɹimən," tɑlænvɝ sɛd sɔfli. "bʌt noʊ ðəɾ aɪ kən teɪk jəɹ hɛd bɪfɔɹ jə blɪŋk ɪf jə soʊ mʌtʃ əz θɪŋk ə hɑɹmɪŋ hɝ."

Mat hardly realized Tallanvor's hand was moving before the officer's sword was resting against his neck. "I will take you to the Queen, countryman," Tallanvor said softly. "But know that I can take your head before you blink if you so much as think of harming her."

mæt pʊɾ ɑn ɪz bɛst ɡɹɪn. ðət slaɪtli kɝv bleɪd fɛlt ʃɑɹp ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz nɛk. "aɪ æm ə lɔɪəl ændɔɝmən," hi sɛd, "æn ə feɪθfəl sʌbʒɪkt ə ðə kwin, ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin hɝ. waɪ, ɪf aɪ hæd bɪn hɪɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɪntɝ, aɪɾ əv fɑloʊd lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl fəɹ ʃʊɹ."

Mat put on his best grin. That slightly curved blade felt sharp on the side of his neck. "I am a loyal Andorman," he said, "and a faithful subject of the Queen, the Light illumine her. Why, if I had been here during the winter, I'd have followed Lord Gaebril for sure."

tɑlænvɝ ɡeɪv ɪm ə taɪt-maʊð stɛɹ, ðən faɪnəli tʊk ɪz sɔɹɾ əweɪ. mæt swɑloʊɾ ən stɑp hɪmsɛlf fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ ɪz θɹoʊt tə si ɪf i hæd bɪn kʌt.

Tallanvor gave him a tight-mouthed stare, then finally took his sword away. Mat swallowed and stopped himself from touching his throat to see if he had been cut.

"teɪk ðə flaʊɝ aʊɾ ə jəɹ hɛɹ," tɑlænvɝ sɛɾ əz i ʃiðd ɪz bleɪd. "du jə θɪŋk jə keɪm hɪɹ kɔɹɾɪŋ?"

"Take the flower out of your hair," Tallanvor said as he sheathed his blade. "Do you think you came here courting?"

mæt snætʃt ðə stɑɹbleɪz blɑsəm aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛɹ ən fɑloʊd ði ɔfəsɝ. blʌɾi ful, pʊɾɪŋ ə flaʊɝ ɪn maɪ hɛɹ. aɪ hæv tə stɑp pleɪɪŋ ðə ful, naʊ.

Mat snatched the starblaze blossom out of his hair and followed the officer. Bloody fool, putting a flower in my hair. I have to stop playing the fool, now.

ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ fɑloʊɪŋ, ɹɪli, fəɹ tɑlænvɝ kɛpt ən aɪ ɑn ɪm ivən waɪl i lɛd ðə weɪ. ðə ɹɪzʌlt wɑz ən ɑd sɔɹɾ ə pɹəsɛʃən, wɪð ði ɔfəsɝ tə wʌn saɪɾ ə hɪm ən əhɛd, bʌt hæf tɝn ɪn keɪs mæt tʃɹaɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ. fəɹ ɪz pɑɹt, mæt ətɛmptəd tə lʊk əz ɪnəsən əz ə beɪb splæʃɪŋ ɪn ɪz bæθwɔɾɝ.

It was not so much following, really, for Tallanvor kept an eye on him even while he led the way. The result was an odd sort of procession, with the officer to one side of him and ahead, but half turned in case Mat tried anything. For his part, Mat attempted to look as innocent as a babe splashing in his bathwater.

ðə kʌlɝfəl tæpəstʃɹiz ɑn ðə wɔlz hæɾ ɝn ðɛɹ wivɝz sɪlvɝ, ən soʊ hæd ðə ɹʌɡz ɑn ðə waɪt taɪl flɔɹz, ivən hɪɹ ɪn ðə hɔlz. ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ stʊɾ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, pleɪts ən plæɾɝz, boʊlz ən kʌps, ɑn tʃɛsts ən loʊ kæbənəts ə pɑlɪʃt wʊd, əz faɪn əz ɛniθɪŋ i hæd sin ɪn ðə taʊɝ. sɝvəns dɑɹɾɪd ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ɪn ɹɛd lɪvɝi wɪð waɪt kɑlɝz ən kʌfs ən ðə waɪt laɪən ʌv ændɝ ɑn ðɛɹ bɹɛsts. hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf mɔɹɡeɪs pleɪɾ ət daɪs. wʊl-hɛɾəd θɔt. kwinz doʊn tɔs daɪs. bʌt wən aɪ ɡɪv əɹ ðɪs lɛɾɝ ən tɛl əɹ sʌmbɑɾi ɪn əɹ pæləs minz tə kɪl ɪleɪn, əl weɪdʒɝ ʃi ɡɪvz mi ə fæt pɝs. hi ɪndʌlʒd hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə smɔl fænsi ʌv biɪŋ meɪɾ ə lɔɹd; ʃʊɹli ðə mæn u ɹɪvild ə plɑt tə mɝɾɝ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ kəɾ ɪkspɛk səm sətʃ ɹɪwɔɹd.

The colorful tapestries on the walls had earned their weavers silver, and so had the rugs on the white tile floors, even here in the halls. Gold and silver stood everywhere, plates and platters, bowls and cups, on chests and low cabinets of polished wood, as fine as anything he had seen in the Tower. Servants darted everywhere, in red livery with white collars and cuffs and the White Lion of Andor on their breasts. He found himself wondering if Morgase played at dice. Wool-headed thought. Queens don't toss dice. But when I give her this letter and tell her somebody in her Palace means to kill Elayne, I'll wager she gives me a fat purse. He indulged himself in a small fancy of being made a lord; surely the man who revealed a plot to murder the Daughter-Heir could expect some such reward.

tɑlænvɝ lɛɾ ɪm daʊn soʊ mɛni kɔɹɪɾɝz ən əkɹɔs soʊ mɛni kɔɹtʃjɑɹdz ðəɾ i wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wʌndɝ ɪf i kəd faɪn ɪz weɪ aʊɾ əɡɛn wɪθaʊt hɛlp, wən sʌɾənli wʌn ə ðə kɔɹts hæd mɔɹ ðən sɝvəns ɪn ɪt. ə kɑləmd wɔk sɝaʊndəd ðə kɔɹt, wɪð ə ɹaʊn pul ɪn ðə mɪɾəl wɪð waɪɾ ən jɛloʊ fɪʃ swɪmɪŋ bɪniθ lɪli pædz ən floʊɾɪŋ waɪt wɔɾɝ lɪliz. mɛn ɪn kʌlɝfəl koʊts ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ, wɪmən wɪð waɪd dʒɹɛsəz wɝkt ivən mɔɹ ɪlæbɹətli, stʊɾ ətɛndəns ɑn ə wʊmən wɪð ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ u sæɾ ɑn ðə ɹeɪzd ɹɪm ə ðə pul, tʃɹeɪlɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ ən stɛɹɪŋ sædli ət ðə fɪʃ ðət ɹoʊz tə hɝ fɪŋɡɝtɪps ɪn hoʊps ə fud. eɪ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɪnsɝkəl ðə θɝd fɪŋɡɝ ə hɝ lɛf hænd. ə tɔl, dɑɹk mæn stʊɾ əɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ðə ɹɛd sɪlk ə hɪz koʊɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪɾən baɪ ðə ɡoʊld livz ən skɹoʊlz wɝkt ɑn ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə wʊmən u hɛl mæts aɪ.

Tallanvor led him down so many corridors and across so many courtyards that he was beginning to wonder if he could find his way out again without help, when suddenly one of the courts had more than servants in it. A columned walk surrounded the court, with a round pool in the middle with white and yellow fish swimming beneath lily pads and floating white water lilies. Men in colorful coats embroidered in gold or silver, women with wide dresses worked even more elaborately, stood attendance on a woman with red-gold hair who sat on the raised rim of the pool, trailing her fingers in the water and staring sadly at the fish that rose to her fingertips in hopes of food. A Great Serpent ring encircled the third finger of her left hand. A tall, dark man stood at her shoulder, the red silk of his coat almost hidden by the gold leaves and scrolls worked on it, but it was the woman who held Mat's eye.

hi dɪd nɑt nid ðə ɹiθ ə faɪnli meɪd ɡoʊldən ɹoʊzɪz ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, əɹ ðə stoʊl hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ dʒɹɛs ʌv waɪt slæʃt wɪð ɹɛd, ðə ɹɛd lɛŋθ ə ðə stoʊl ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ðə laɪənz ʌv ændɝ, tə noʊ hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət mɔɹɡeɪs, baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt, kwin ʌv ændɝ, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə ɹɛlm, pɹətɛktɝ ə ðə pipəl, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd. ʃi hæɾ ɪleɪnz feɪs ən bjuɾi, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz wʌɾ ɪleɪn wəɾ əv wən ʃi hæd ɹaɪpənd. ɛvɹi ʌðɝ wʊmən ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd feɪɾəd ɪndə ðə bækɡɹaʊn baɪ hɝ vɛɹi pɹɛzəns.

He did not need the wreath of finely made golden roses in her hair, or the stole hanging over her dress of white slashed with red, the red length of the stole embroidered with the Lions of Andor, to know he was looking at Morgase, by the Grace of the Light, Queen of Andor, Defender of the Realm, Protector of the People, High Seat of House Trakand. She had Elayne's face and beauty, but it was what Elayne would have when she had ripened. Every other woman in the courtyard faded into the background by her very presence.

aɪd dæns ə dʒɪɡ wɪð hɝ, ən stil ə kɪs ɪn ðə munlaɪt, tu, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ oʊld ʃi ɪz. hi ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪɡzækli hu ʃi ɪz!

I'd dance a jig with her, and steal a kiss in the moonlight, too, no matter how old she is. He shook himself. Remember exactly who she is!

tɑlænvɝ wɛn tə wʌn ni, ə fɪs pɹɛs tə ðə waɪt stoʊn ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. "maɪ kwin, aɪ bɹɪŋ ə mɛsənʒɝ u bɛɹz ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn."

Tallanvor went to one knee, a fist pressed to the white stone of the courtyard. "My Queen, I bring a messenger who bears a letter from the Lady Elayne."

mæt aɪd ðə mænz pɑstʃɝ, ðən kəntɛntəd hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə dip baʊ. "fɹʌm ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ . . . ʌ . . . maɪ kwin." hi hɛld aʊt ðə lɛɾɝ əz i baʊd, soʊ ðə ɡoʊldən jɛloʊ wæks ə ðə sil wɑz vɪzəbəl. wʌns ʃi ɹidz ɪt, ən noʊz ɪleɪn ɪz ɔl ɹaɪt, əl tɛl hɝ. mɔɹɡeɪs tɝn əɹ dip blu aɪz ɑn hɪm. laɪt! əz sun əz ʃiz ɪn ə ɡʊd mud.

Mat eyed the man's posture, then contented himself with a deep bow. "From the Daughter-Heir . . . uh . . . my Queen." He held out the letter as he bowed, so the golden yellow wax of the seal was visible. Once she reads it, and knows Elayne is all right, I will tell her. Morgase turned her deep blue eyes on him. Light! As soon as she's in a good mood.

"ju bɹɪŋ ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm maɪ skeɪpɛɡɹɑs tʃaɪld?" hɝ vɔɪs wɑz koʊld, bʌt wɪð ən ɛdʒ ðət spoʊk ə hit ɹɛɾi tə ɹaɪz. "ðæt mʌs min ʃiz əlaɪv, ət list! wɛɹ ɪz ʃi?"

"You bring a letter from my scapegrace child?" Her voice was cold, but with an edge that spoke of heat ready to rise. "That must mean she is alive, at least! Where is she?"

"ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, maɪ kwin," hi mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ aʊt. laɪt, wʊdn aɪ laɪk tə si ə stɛɹɪŋ mætʃ bɪtwin əɹ ən ði æmɪɝlɪn. ɑn sɛkən θɔt, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd i wəd ɹæðɝ nɑt. "æt list, ʃi wɑz wən aɪ lɛft."

"In Tar Valon, my Queen," he managed to get out. Light, wouldn't I like to see a staring match between her and the Amyrlin. On second thought, he decided he would rather not. "At least, she was when I left."

mɔɹɡeɪs weɪvd ə hæn ɪmpeɪʃənli, ən tɑlænvɝ ɹoʊz tə teɪk ðə lɛɾɝ fɹəm mæt ən hæn ɪt tə hɝ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi fɹaʊn ət ðə lɪli sil, ðən bɹoʊk ɪt wɪð ə ʃɑɹp twɪst ə hɝ ɹɪsts. ʃi mɝmɝd tə hɝsɛlf əz ʃi ɹɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ əɾ ɛvɹi ʌðɝ laɪn. "ʃi kən seɪ noʊ mɔɹ, kən ʃi?" ʃi mʌɾɝd. "wi ʃæl si wɛðɝ ʃi hoʊlz tə ðæt. . . ."əbɹʌpli hɝ feɪs bɹaɪɾənd. "ɡeɪbɹəl, ʃiz bɪn ɹeɪz tə ði æksɛptɪd. lɛs ðən ə jɪɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ən ɹeɪzd ɔlɹɛɾi." ðə smaɪl wɛn əz sʌɾənli əz ɪt hæd kʌm, ən əɹ maʊθ taɪɾənd. "wɛn aɪ pʊt maɪ hænz ɑn ðə ɹɛtʃɪd tʃaɪld, ʃɪl wɪʃ ʃi wɝ stɪl ə nɑvəs."

Morgase waved a hand impatiently, and Tallanvor rose to take the letter from Mat and hand it to her. For a moment she frowned at the lily seal, then broke it with a sharp twist of her wrists. She murmured to herself as she read, shaking her head at every other line. "She can say no more, can she?" she muttered. "We shall see whether she holds to that. . . ."Abruptly her face brightened. "Gaebril, she has been raised to the Accepted. Less than a year in the Tower, and raised already." The smile went as suddenly as it had come, and her mouth tightened. "When I put my hands on the wretched child, she will wish she were still a novice."

laɪt, mæt θɔt, wɪl nʌθɪŋ pʊɾ əɹ ɪn ə ɡʊd mud? hi dɪsaɪɾɪd i wɑz dʒʌs gɑnə hæv tə seɪ ɪɾ aʊt, bʌɾ i wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk əz ɪf ʃi mɛn tə kʌt sʌmwʌnz hɛɾ ɔf. "maɪ kwin, baɪ tʃæns aɪ oʊvɝhɝd - "

Light, Mat thought, will nothing put her in a good mood? He decided he was just going to have to say it out, but he wished she did not look as if she meant to cut someone's head off. "My Queen, by chance I overheard - "

"bi saɪlənt, bɔɪ," ðə dɑɹk mæn ɪn ðə ɡoʊld-ɛnkɹʌstɪd koʊt sɛd kɑmli. hi wɑz ə hænsəm mæn, ɔlmoʊst əz ɡʊd-lʊkɪŋ əz ɡɑləɾ ən nɪɹli əz juθfəl-simɪŋ, dɪspaɪt ðə waɪt stʃɹikɪŋ ɪz tɛmpəlz, bʌt bɪlt ɑn ə bɪɡɝ skeɪl, wɪð mɔɹ ðən ɹændz haɪɾ ən vɛɹi nɪɹli pɛɹɪnz ʃoʊldɝz. "wi wɪl hɪɹ wʌt juv tə seɪ ɪn ə moʊmənt." hi ɹitʃt oʊvɝ mɔɹɡeɪsəz ʃoʊldɝ ən plʌk ðə lɛɾɝ aʊɾ ə hɝ hænd. hɝ ɡlɛɹ tɝn ɑn ɪm - mæt kəd si hɝ tɛmpɝ hiɾɪŋ - bʌt ðə dɑɹk mæn leɪɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz ɔf wʌɾ i wɑz ɹiɾɪŋ, ən mɔɹɡeɪsəz æŋɡɝ mɛltəd. "ɪt simz ʃiz lɛf ðə taʊɝ əɡɛn," hi sɛd. "ɑn ðə sɝvəs ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ðə wʊmən oʊvɝstɛps hɝsɛlf əɡɛn, mɔɹɡeɪs."

"Be silent, boy," the dark man in the gold-encrusted coat said calmly. He was a handsome man, almost as good-looking as Galad and nearly as youthful-seeming, despite the white streaking his temples, but built on a bigger scale, with more than Rand's height and very nearly Perrin's shoulders. "We will hear what you have to say in a moment." He reached over Morgase's shoulder and plucked the letter out of her hand. Her glare turned on him - Mat could see her temper heating - but the dark man laid a strong hand on her shoulder, never taking his eyes off what he was reading, and Morgase's anger melted. "It seems she has left the Tower again," he said. "On the service of the Amyrlin Seat. The woman oversteps herself again, Morgase."

mæt hæd noʊ tʃɹʌbəl hoʊldɪŋ ɪz tʌŋ. lʌk. ɪt wɑz stʌk tə ðə ɹuf ə hɪz maʊθ. səmtaɪmz aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ɪts ɡʊɾ əɹ bæd. ðə dɑɹk mæn wɑz ði oʊnɝ ə ðə dip vɔɪs, ðə "ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ" hu wɑntəɾ ɪleɪnz hɛd. ʃi kɔld ɪm ɡeɪbɹəl. hɝ ædvaɪzɝ wɑns tə mɝɾɝ ɪleɪn? laɪt! ən mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm laɪk ən ədɔɹɪŋ dɔɡ wɪð əɹ mæstɝz hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ.

Mat had no trouble holding his tongue. Luck. It was stuck to the roof of his mouth. Sometimes I don't know if it's good or bad. The dark man was the owner of the deep voice, the "Great Master" who wanted Elayne's head. She called him Gaebril. Her advisor wants to murder Elayne? Light! And Morgase was staring up at him like an adoring dog with her master's hand on her shoulder.

ɡeɪbɹəl tɝnd nɪɹli blæk aɪz ɑn mæt. ðə mæn hæɾ ə fɔɹsfəl ɡeɪz, ən ə lʊk ə noʊɪŋ. "wʌt kən jə tɛl əs ə ðɪs, bɔɪ?"

Gaebril turned nearly black eyes on Mat. The man had a forceful gaze, and a look of knowing. "What can you tell us of this, boy?"

"nʌθɪŋ . . . ʌ . . . maɪ lɔɹd." mæt klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt; ðə mænz stɛɹ wɑz wɝs ðən ði æmɪɝlɪnz. "aɪ wɛn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn tə si maɪ sɪstɝ. ʃiz ə nɑvəs. ɛls ɡɹɪnwɛl. aɪm tɑm ɡɹɪnwɛl, maɪ lɔɹd. ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn lɝn aɪ wɑz minɪŋ tə si keɪɛmlɪn ɑn maɪ weɪ bæk hoʊm - aɪm fɹəm kʌmfɹi, maɪ lɔɹd; ə lɪɾəl vɪlədʒ nɔɹθ ə bɛɹlən; aɪd nɛvɝ sin ɛni pleɪs bɪɡɝ ðən bɛɹlən bɪfɔɹ aɪ wɛn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn - ən ʃi - ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn, aɪ min - ɡeɪv mi ðət lɛɾɝ tə bɹɪŋ." hi θɔt mɔɹɡeɪs hæd ɡlænst əɾ ɪm wən i sɛɾ i keɪm fɹəm nɔɹθ ə bɛɹlən, bʌɾ i nu ðəɹ wɑz ə vɪlədʒ kɔl kʌmfɹi ðɛɹ; hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd hɪɹɪŋ ɪt mɛnʃənd.

"Nothing . . . uh . . . my Lord." Mat cleared his throat; the man's stare was worse than the Amyrlin's. "I went to Tar Valon to see my sister. She's a novice. Else Grinwell. I'm Thom Grinwell, my Lord. The Lady Elayne learned I was meaning to see Caemlyn on my way back home - I'm from Comfrey, my Lord; a little village north of Baerlon; I'd never seen any place bigger than Baerlon before I went to Tar Valon - and she - the Lady Elayne, I mean - gave me that letter to bring." He thought Morgase had glanced at him when he said he came from north of Baerlon, but he knew there was a village called Comfrey there; he remembered hearing it mentioned.

ɡeɪbɹəl nɑɾəd, bʌɾ i sɛd, "du jə noʊ wɛɹ ɪleɪn wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, bɔɪ? əɹ ɑn wʌt bɪznəs? spik ðə tʃɹuθ, ən juv nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ. laɪ, ən jəl bi pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən."

Gaebril nodded, but he said, "Do you know where Elayne was going, boy? Or on what business? Speak the truth, and you have nothing to fear. Lie, and you will be put to the question."

mæt dɪd nɑɾ əv tə pɹitɛn ə wɝid fɹaʊn. "maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ oʊnli sɔ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ðə wʌns. ʃi ɡeɪv mi ðə lɛɾɝ - ən ə ɡoʊl mɑɹk! - ən toʊl mi tə bɹɪŋ ɪt tə ðə kwin. aɪ noʊ noʊ mɔɹ ʌv wʌɾ ɪz ɪn ɪt ðən aɪv hɝd hɪɹ." ɡeɪbɹəl əpɪɹd tə kənsɪɾɝ ɪt, wɪð noʊ saɪn ɑn ðət dɑɹk feɪs ʌv wɛðɝ i bɪlivd ə wɝɾ əɹ nɑt.

Mat did not have to pretend a worried frown. "My Lord, I only saw the Daughter-Heir the once. She gave me the letter - and a gold mark! - and told me to bring it to the Queen. I know no more of what is in it than I've heard here." Gaebril appeared to consider it, with no sign on that dark face of whether he believed a word or not.

"noʊ, ɡeɪbɹəl," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd sʌɾənli. "tu mɛni hæv bɪn pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən. aɪ kən si ðə niɾ əz juv ʃoʊn ɪt tə mi, bʌt nɑt fəɹ ðɪs. nɑɾ ə bɔɪ hu oʊnli bɹɔɾ ə lɛɾɝ huz kɑntɛns i dʌz nɑt noʊ."

"No, Gaebril," Morgase said suddenly. "Too many have been put to the question. I can see the need as you have shown it to me, but not for this. Not a boy who only brought a letter whose contents he does not know."

"æz maɪ kwin kəmænz, soʊ ʃæl ɪt bi," ðə dɑɹk mæn sɛd. ðə toʊn wɑz ɹɪspɛkfəl, bʌɾ i tʌtʃt əɹ tʃik ɪn ə weɪ ðət meɪd kʌlɝ kʌm tə hɝ feɪs ən əɹ lɪps pɑɹɾ əz ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ə kɪs.

"As my Queen commands, so shall it be," the dark man said. The tone was respectful, but he touched her cheek in a way that made color come to her face and her lips part as if she expected a kiss.

mɔɹɡeɪs dʒɹu ən ənstɛɾi bɹɛθ. "tɛl mi, tɑm ɡɹɪnwɛl, dɪd maɪ dɔɾɝ lʊk wɛl wən jə sɔ hɝ?"

Morgase drew an unsteady breath. "Tell me, Thom Grinwell, did my daughter look well when you saw her?"

"jɛs, maɪ kwin. ʃi smaɪld, ən læft, ən ʃoʊɾ ə sɔsi tʌŋ - aɪ min. . . ."

"Yes, my Queen. She smiled, and laughed, and showed a saucy tongue - I mean. . . ."

mɔɹɡeɪs læf sɔfli ət ðə lʊk ɑn ɪz feɪs. "du nɑt bi əfɹeɪd, jʌŋ mæn. ɪleɪn dʌz əv ə sɔsi tʌŋ, fɑɹ tu ɔfən fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɡʊd. aɪm hæpi ʃiz wɛl." ðoʊz blu aɪz stʌɾid ɪm dipli. "ə jʌŋ mæn u hæz lɛft ɪz smɔl vɪlədʒ ɔfən faɪnz ɪt dɪfəkəl tə ɹɪtɝn tə ɪt. aɪ θɪŋk jəl tʃɹævəl fɑɹ bɪfɔɹ jə si kʌmfɹi əɡɛn. pɝhæps jəl ivən ɹɪtɝn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪf jə du, ən ɪf jə si maɪ dɔɾɝ, tɛl əɹ ðət wʌɾ ɪz sɛɾ ɪn æŋɡɝ ɪz ɔfən ɹɪpɛntɪd. əl nɑt ɹimuv əɹ fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ bɪfɔɹ taɪm. tɛl əɹ ðəɾ aɪ ɔfən θɪŋk ə maɪ oʊn taɪm ðɛɹ, ən mɪs ðə kwaɪət tɔks wɪð ʃɛɹiəm ɪn əɹ stʌɾi. tɛl əɹ ðəɾ aɪ sɛd ðæt, tɑm ɡɹɪnwɛl."

Morgase laughed softly at the look on his face. "Do not be afraid, young man. Elayne does have a saucy tongue, far too often for her own good. I am happy she is well." Those blue eyes studied him deeply. "A young man who has left his small village often finds it difficult to return to it. I think you will travel far before you see Comfrey again. Perhaps you will even return to Tar Valon. If you do, and if you see my daughter, tell her that what is said in anger is often repented. I will not remove her from the White Tower before time. Tell her that I often think of my own time there, and miss the quiet talks with Sheriam in her study. Tell her that I said that, Thom Grinwell."

mæt ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. "jɛs, maɪ kwin. bʌt . . . ʌ . . . aɪ də nɑt min tə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn əɡɛn. wʌns ɪn ɛni mænz laɪf ɪz ɪnʌf. maɪ dɑ nidz mi tə hɛlp wɝk ðə fɑɹm. maɪ sɪstɝz wɪl bi stʌk wɪð ðə mɪlkɪŋ, wɪð mi ɡɔn."

Mat shrugged uncomfortably. "Yes, my Queen. But . . . uh . . . I do not mean to go to Tar Valon again. Once in any man's life is enough. My da needs me to help work the farm. My sisters will be stuck with the milking, with me gone."

ɡeɪbɹəl læft, ə dip ɹʌmbəl ʌv əmjuzmənt. "ɑɹ jə æŋkʃəs ðən tə mɪlk kaʊz, bɔɪ? pɝhæps jə ʃəd si sʌmθɪŋ ə ðə wɝl bɪfɔɹ ɪt tʃeɪnʒəz. hɪɹ!" hi pɹədust ə pɝs ən tɔst ɪt; mæt fɛl kɔɪnz θɹu ðə wɑʃ-lɛðɝ wən i kɑɾ ɪt. "ɪf ɪleɪn kən ɡɪv jə ə ɡoʊl mɑɹk fəɹ kæɹiɪŋ əɹ lɛɾɝ, əl ɡɪv jə tɛn fəɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪt seɪfli. si ðə wɝl bɪfɔɹ jə ɡoʊ bæk tə jəɹ kaʊz."

Gaebril laughed, a deep rumble of amusement. "Are you anxious then to milk cows, boy? Perhaps you should see something of the world before it changes. Here!" He produced a purse and tossed it; Mat felt coins through the wash-leather when he caught it. "If Elayne can give you a gold mark for carrying her letter, I will give you ten for bringing it safely. See the world before you go back to your cows."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd." mæt lɪftəd ðə pɝs ən mænədʒd ə wik ɡɹɪn. "θæŋk ju, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Yes, my Lord." Mat lifted the purse and managed a weak grin. "Thank you, my Lord."

bʌt ðə dɑɹk mæn hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi weɪvd ɪm əweɪ ən tɝn tə mɔɹɡeɪs wɪð ɪz fɪsts ɑn ɪz hɪps. "aɪ θɪŋk ðə taɪm əz kʌm, mɔɹɡeɪs, tə læns ðət fɛstɝɪŋ sɔɹ ɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝ ʌv ændɝ. baɪ jəɹ mɛɹɪdʒ tə tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹd, juv ə kleɪm tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn. ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz kən meɪk ðət kleɪm əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɛni. pɝhæps aɪ kən ivən eɪd ðɛm, ɪn səm smɔl weɪ. hɪɹ mi."

But the dark man had already waved him away and turned to Morgase with his fists on his hips. "I think the time has come, Morgase, to lance that festering sore on the border of Andor. By your marriage to Taringail Damodred, you have a claim to the Sun Throne. The Queen's Guards can make that claim as strong as any. Perhaps I can even aid them, in some small way. Hear me."

tɑlænvɝ tʌtʃt mæt ɑn ði ɑɹm, ən ðeɪ bækt əweɪ, boʊɪŋ. mæt dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛniwʌn noʊɾəst. ɡeɪbɹəl wɑz stɪl spikɪŋ, ən ɛvɹi lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi sim tə hæŋ ɑn ɪz wɝdz. mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ əz ʃi lɪsənd, jɛt ʃi nɑɾəd əz mʌtʃ əz ɛni ʌðɝ.

Tallanvor touched Mat on the arm, and they backed away, bowing. Mat did not think anyone noticed. Gaebril was still speaking, and every lord and lady seemed to hang on his words. Morgase was frowning as she listened, yet she nodded as much as any other.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɛvən


CHAPTER 47

tə ɹeɪs ðə ʃædoʊ


To Race the Shadow

fɹəm ðə smɔl kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɪð ɪts pul ə fɪʃ, tɑlænvɝ lɛd mæt swɪfli tə ðə ɡɹeɪt kɔɹɾ ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə pæləs, bɪhaɪn ðə tɔl, ɡɪldɪd ɡeɪts ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn. ɪt wəd bi mɪddeɪ, sun. mæt fɛlt ən ɝdʒ tə bi ɡɔn, ə nid tə hɝi. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd kipɪŋ ɪz peɪs tə ðə jʌŋ ɔfəsɝz. sʌmwʌn maɪt wʌndɝ, ɪf i stɑɹɾəd ɹʌnɪŋ, ən meɪbi - dʒʌs meɪbi - θɪŋz hæd ɹɪli bɪn ðə weɪ ðeɪ sim bæk ðɛɹ. meɪbi ɡeɪbɹəl ɹɪli dɪd nɑt səspɛk ðəɾ i nu. meɪbi. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðoʊz nɪɹli blæk aɪz, sizɪŋ ən hoʊldɪŋ laɪk ə pɛɹ ə pɪtʃfɔɹk taɪnz θɹu hɪz hɛd. laɪt, meɪbi. hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə wɔk əz ɪf i hæɾ ɔl ðə taɪm ɪn ðə wɝld - dʒʌst ə heɪbɹeɪn kʌntʃɹi laʊt stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɹʌɡz ən ðə ɡoʊld. dʒʌst ə mʌdfʊt hud nɛvɝ θɪŋk ɛniwʌn maɪt pʊɾ ə naɪf ɪn ɪz bæk - əntɪl tɑlænvɝ lɛɾ ɪm θɹu ə sælipɔɹɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə ɡeɪts, ən fɑloʊɾ ɪm aʊt.

From the small courtyard with its pool of fish, Tallanvor led Mat swiftly to the great court at the front of the Palace, behind the tall, gilded gates gleaming in the sun. It would be midday, soon. Mat felt an urge to be gone, a need to hurry. It was hard keeping his pace to the young officer's. Someone might wonder, if he started running, and maybe - just maybe - things had really been the way they seemed back there. Maybe Gaebril really did not suspect that he knew. Maybe. He remembered those nearly black eyes, seizing and holding like a pair of pitchfork tines through his head. Light, maybe. He forced himself to walk as if he had all the time in the world - Just a haybrain country lout staring at the rugs and the gold. Just a mudfoot who'd never think anyone might put a knife in his back - until Tallanvor let him through a sallyport in one of the gates, and followed him out.

ðə fæɾ ɔfəsɝ wɪð ðə ɹæts aɪz wɑz stɪl ðəɹ wɪð ðə ɡɑɹdz, ən wən i sɔ mæt ɪz feɪs wɛn ɹɛɾ əɡɛn. bɪfɔɹ i kəɾ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ðoʊ, tɑlænvɝ spoʊk. "hi hæz dɪlɪvɝɾ ə lɛɾɝ tə ðə kwin fɹəm ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. bi ɡlæd, ɛlbɝ, ðət niðɝ mɔɹɡeɪs nɔɹ ɡeɪbɹəl noʊz jə tʃɹaɪd tə kip ɪt fɹəm ðɛm. lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl wɑz moʊst ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪnz mɪsɪv."

The fat officer with the rat's eyes was still there with the Guards, and when he saw Mat his face went red again. Before he could open his mouth, though, Tallanvor spoke. "He has delivered a letter to the Queen from the Daughter-Heir. Be glad, Elber, that neither Morgase nor Gaebril knows you tried to keep it from them. Lord Gaebril was most interested in the Lady Elayne's missive."

ɛlbɝz feɪs wɛn fɹəm ɹɛd tə əz waɪɾ əz ɪz kɑlɝ. hi ɡlɛɹd wʌns ət mæt, ən skʌɾəld bæk əlɔŋ ðə laɪn ʌv ɡɑɹdzmɪn, hɪz biɾi aɪz piɹɪŋ θɹu ðə bɑɹz ə ðɛɹ feɪs-ɡɑɹdz əz ɪf tə dətɝmən wɛðɝ ɛni ʌv əm hæd sin ɪz fɪɹ.

Elber's face went from red to as white as his collar. He glared once at Mat, and scuttled back along the line of guardsmen, his beady eyes peering through the bars of their face-guards as if to determine whether any of them had seen his fear.

"θæŋk ju," mæt toʊl tɑlænvɝ, ən mɛn ɪt. hi hæd fɝɡɑɾən ɔl əbaʊt ðə fæt mæn əntɪl i wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ɪm ɪn ðə feɪs əɡɛn. "fɛɹ jə wɛl, tɑlænvɝ."

"Thank you," Mat told Tallanvor, and meant it. He had forgotten all about the fat man until he was staring him in the face again. "Fare you well, Tallanvor."

hi stɑɹɾəd əkɹɔs ði oʊvəl plɑzə, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə wɔk tu fæst, ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd wən tɑlænvɝ wɔkt əlɔŋ. laɪt, ɪz i ɡeɪbɹəlz mæn, əɹ mɔɹɡeɪsəz? hi wɑz dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fil ən ɪtʃ bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz, əz ɪf ə naɪf maɪt bi əbaʊt tə ɡoʊ ɪn - hi dʌznt noʊ, bɝn mi! ɡeɪbɹəl dʌzn səspɛkt aɪ noʊ! - wən ðə jʌŋ ɔfəsɝ faɪnəli spoʊk.

He started across the oval plaza, trying not to walk too fast, and was surprised when Tallanvor walked along. Light, is he Gaebril's man, or Morgase's? He was just beginning to feel an itch between his shoulder blades, as if a knife might be about to go in - He doesn't know, burn me! Gaebril doesn't suspect I know! - when the young officer finally spoke.

"dɪd jə spɛn lɔŋ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn? ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ? lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə lɝn ɛniθɪŋ ʌv ɪt?"

"Did you spend long in Tar Valon? In the White Tower? Long enough to learn anything of it?"

"aɪ wɑz oʊnli ðəɹ θɹi deɪz," mæt sɛd kɔʃəsli. hi wʊɾə meɪd ðə taɪm lɛs - ɪf i cʊɾə dɪlɪvɝd ðə lɛɾɝ wɪθaʊɾ ædmɪɾɪŋ ɛvɝ biɪŋ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, hi wəɾ əv - bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðə mæn wəd bɪliv i hæd ɡɔn ɔl ðət weɪ tə si hɪz sɪstɝ ən lɛf ðə seɪm deɪ. wʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ɪz i æftɝ? "aɪ lɝnd wʌɾ aɪ sɔ ɪn ðət taɪm. nʌθɪŋ ʌv ɛni ɪmpɔɹɾəns. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɡaɪd mi ɝaʊn ən tɛl mi θɪŋz. aɪ wɑz oʊnli ðəɹ tə si ɛls."

"I was only there three days," Mat said cautiously. He would have made the time less - if he could have delivered the letter without admitting ever being in Tar Valon, he would have - but he did not think the man would believe he had gone all that way to see his sister and left the same day. What under the Light is he after? "I learned what I saw in that time. Nothing of any importance. They did not guide me around and tell me things. I was only there to see Else."

"ju mʌst əv hɝd sʌmθɪŋ, mæn. hu ɪz ʃɛɹiəm? dʌz tɔkɪŋ tə hɝ ɪn əɹ stʌɾi min ɛniθɪŋ?"

"You must have heard something, man. Who is Sheriam? Does talking to her in her study mean anything?"

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd vɪɡɝəsli tə kip ɹɪlif fɹəm ʃoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ hu ʃi ɪz," hi sɛd tʃɹuθfəli. pɝhæps i hæd hɝɾ ɛɡwin, əɹ pɝhæps nɪneɪiv, mɛnʃən ðə neɪm. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, meɪbi? "waɪ ʃəɾ ɪt min ɛniθɪŋ?"

Mat shook his head vigorously to keep relief from showing on his face. "I don't know who she is," he said truthfully. Perhaps he had heard Egwene, or perhaps Nynaeve, mention the name. An Aes Sedai, maybe? "Why should it mean anything?"

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ," tɑlænvɝ sɛd sɔfli. "ðɛɹ ɪz tu mʌtʃ aɪ də nɑt noʊ. səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ. . . ." hi ɡeɪv mæt ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. "ɑɹ jə ə lɔɪəl ændɔɝmən, tɑm ɡɹɪnwɛl?"

"I do not know," Tallanvor said softly. "There is too much I do not know. Sometimes I think she is trying to say something. . . ." He gave Mat a sharp look. "Are you a loyal Andorman, Thom Grinwell?"

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪ æm." laɪt, ɪf aɪ seɪ ðət mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɔfən, aɪ meɪ stɑɹt bɪlivɪŋ ɪt. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ju? dʒju sɝv mɔɹɡeɪs ən ɡeɪbɹəl lɔɪəli?"

"Of course I am." Light, if I say that much more often, I may start believing it. "What about you? Do you serve Morgase and Gaebril loyally?"

tɑlænvɝ ɡeɪv ɪm ə lʊk əz hɑɹɾ əz ðə daɪsəz mɝsi. "aɪ sɝv mɔɹɡeɪs, tɑm ɡɹɪnwɛl. hɝ, aɪ sɝv tə ðə dɛθ. fɛɹ jə wɛl!" hi tɝn ən stʃɹoʊd bæk təwɔɹd ðə pæləs wɪð ə hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt.

Tallanvor gave him a look as hard as the dice's mercy. "I serve Morgase, Thom Grinwell. Her, I serve to the death. Fare you well!" He turned and strode back toward the Palace with a hand gripping his sword hilt.

wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ɡoʊ, mæt mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf. "aɪ wɪl weɪdʒɝ ðɪs" - hi ɡeɪv ɡeɪbɹəlz wɑʃ-lɛðɝ pɝs ə tɔs - "ðæt ɡeɪbɹəl sɛz ðə seɪm." wʌtɛvɝ ɡeɪmz ðeɪ pleɪɾ ɪn ðə pæləs, hi wɑntəd noʊ pleɪs ɪn ɛni ʌv ðɛm. ən i mɛn tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ aʊɾ ə ðɛm, tu. ful wɪmən! naʊ aɪ hæv tə kip ðɛɹ beɪkən fɹəm bɝnɪŋ ɪnstɛɾ ə lʊkɪŋ æftɝ maɪ oʊn! hi dɪd nɑt stɑɹt tə ɹʌn əntɪl ðə stʃɹits hɪɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə pæləs.

Watching him go, Mat muttered to himself. "I will wager this" - he gave Gaebril's wash-leather purse a toss - "that Gaebril says the same." Whatever games they played in the Palace, he wanted no place in any of them. And he meant to make sure Egwene and the others were out of them, too. Fool women! Now I have to keep their bacon from burning instead of looking after my own! He did not start to run until the streets hid him from the Palace.

wən i keɪm dæʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ, nʌθɪŋ vɛɹi mʌtʃ hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ðə laɪbɹɛɹi. tɑm ən ði ɪnkipɝ stɪl sæɾ oʊvɝ ðə stoʊnz bɔɹd - ə dɪfɹənt ɡeɪm, hi sɔ fɹəm ðə pəzɪʃənz ə ðə stoʊnz, bʌt noʊ bɛɾɝ fəɹ ɡɪl - ən ðə kæləkoʊ kæt wɑz bæk ɑn ðə teɪbəl, wɑʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf. ə tʃɹeɪ hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ ənlɪt paɪps ən ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ʌv ə mil fəɹ tu sæt nɪɹ ðə kæt, ən ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz wɝ ɡɔn fɹəm ði ɑɹmtʃɛɹ. itʃ mæn hæɾ ə waɪn kʌp əɾ ɪz ɛlboʊ.

When he came dashing into The Queen's Blessing, nothing very much had changed in the library. Thom and the innkeeper still sat over the stones board - a different game, he saw from the positions of the stones, but no better for Gill - and the calico cat was back on the table, washing herself. A tray holding their unlit pipes and the remains of a meal for two sat near the cat, and his belongings were gone from the armchair. Each man had a wine cup at his elbow.

"aɪ wɪl bi livɪŋ, mæstɝ ɡɪl," hi sɛd. "ju kən kip ðə kɔɪn ən teɪk ə mil aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. əl steɪ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə it, bʌt ðən aɪm ɑn ðə ɹoʊd tə tɛɹ."

"I will be leaving, Master Gill," he said. "You can keep the coin and take a meal out of it. I'll stay long enough to eat, but then I am on the road to Tear."

"wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ hɝi, bɔɪ?" tɑm sim tə bi wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kæt mɔɹ ðən ðə bɔɹd. "wi oʊnli dʒʌst ɝaɪv hɪɹ."

"What is your hurry, boy?" Thom seemed to be watching the cat more than the board. "We only just arrived here."

"ju dɪlɪvɝd ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪnz lɛɾɝ, ðɛn?" ði ɪnkipɝ sɛɾ iɡɝli. "æn kɛp jəɹ skɪn hoʊl, ɪt simz. dɪd jə ɹɪli klaɪm oʊvɝ ðət wɔl laɪk ði ʌðɝ jʌŋ mæn? noʊ, ðət dʌz nɑt mæɾɝ. dɪd ðə lɛɾɝ suð mɔɹɡeɪs? də wi stɪl əv tə kip tɪptoʊɪŋ ɑn ɛɡz, mæn?"

"You delivered the Lady Elayne's letter, then?" the innkeeper said eagerly. "And kept your skin whole, it seems. Did you really climb over that wall like the other young man? No, that does not matter. Did the letter soothe Morgase? Do we still have to keep tiptoeing on eggs, man?"

"aɪ səpoʊz ɪt suð hɝ," mæt sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪt dɪd." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ə moʊmənt, baʊnsɪŋ ɡeɪbɹəlz pɝs ɑn ɪz hænd. ɪt meɪɾ ə klɪŋkɪŋ saʊnd. hi hæd nɑt lʊk tə si ɪf ɪt ɹɪli hɛl tɛn ɡoʊl mɑɹks; ðə weɪt wɑz əbaʊt ɹaɪt. "mæstɝ ɡɪl, wʌt kən jə tɛl mi ʌv ɡeɪbɹəl? əsaɪd fɹəm ðə fæk ðəɾ i dʌz nɑt laɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə sɛɾ i hæd nɑt bɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn lɔŋ?"

"I suppose it soothed her," Mat said. "I think it did." He hesitated a moment, bouncing Gaebril's purse on his hand. It made a clinking sound. He had not looked to see if it really held ten gold marks; the weight was about right. "Master Gill, what can you tell me of Gaebril? Aside from the fact that he does not like Aes Sedai. You said he had not been in Caemlyn long?"

"waɪ dʒju wɑnə noʊ əbaʊt hɪm?" tɑm æskt. "bɑzəl, ɑɹ jə gɑnə pleɪs ə stoʊn əɹ nɑt?" ði ɪnkipɝ saɪɾ ən stʌk ə blæk stoʊn ɑn ðə bɔɹd, ən ðə ɡlimən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"Why do you want to know about him?" Thom asked. "Basel, are you going to place a stone or not?" The innkeeper sighed and stuck a black stone on the board, and the gleeman shook his head.

"wɛl, læd," ɡɪl sɛd, "ðɛɹ ɪz nɑt mʌtʃ tə tɛl. hi keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə wɛs dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɪntɝ. sʌmwɛɹ aʊt jəɹ weɪ, aɪ θɪŋk. meɪbi ɪt wɑz ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. aɪv hɝd ðə maʊntənz mɛnʃənd."

"Well, lad," Gill said, "there is not much to tell. He came out of the west during the winter. Somewhere out your way, I think. Maybe it was the Two Rivers. I've heard the mountains mentioned."

"wi hæv noʊ lɔɹdz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," mæt sɛd. "meɪbi ðəɹ ɑɹ səm ʌp ɝaʊn bɛɹlən. aɪ də nɑt noʊ."

"We have no lords in the Two Rivers," Mat said. "Maybe there are some up around Baerlon. I do not know."

"ðæt kəd bi ɪt, læd. aɪ hæd nɛvɝ ivən hɝɾ ə hɪm bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt kip ʌp wɪð ðə kʌntʃɹi lɔɹdz. keɪm waɪl mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz stɪl ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, hi dɪd, ən hæf ðə sɪɾi wɑz əfɹeɪd ðə taʊɝ wɑz gɑnə meɪk əɹ dɪsəpɪɹ, tu. ði ʌðɝ hæf dɪd nɑt wɑn əɹ bæk. ðə ɹaɪəts stɑɹɾəd ʌp əɡɛn, ðə weɪ ðeɪ dɪd læs jɪɹ ət ðə teɪl ʌv wɪntɝ."

"That could be it, lad. I had never even heard of him before, but I do not keep up with the country lords. Came while Morgase was still in Tar Valon, he did, and half the city was afraid the Tower was going to make her disappear, too. The other half did not want her back. The riots started up again, the way they did last year at the tail of winter."

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ əbaʊt pɑlətɪks, mæstɝ ɡɪl. ɪts ɡeɪbɹəl aɪ wɑnə noʊ əbaʊt." tɑm fɹaʊn ət hɪm, ən bɪɡæn klinɪŋ ðə dɑɾəl fɹəm ɪz lɔŋ-stɛm paɪp wɪð ə stʃɹɔ.

Mat shook his head. "I do not care about politics, Master Gill. It's Gaebril I want to know about." Thom frowned at him, and began cleaning the dottle from his long-stemmed pipe with a straw.

"ɪɾ ɪz ɡeɪbɹəl aɪm tɛlɪŋ jə əbaʊt, læd," ɡɪl sɛd. "dʊɹɪŋ ðə ɹaɪəts, hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf liɾɝ ə ðə fækʃən səpɔɹɾɪŋ mɔɹɡeɪs - ɡɑt hɪmsɛlf wundəɾ ɪn ðə faɪɾɪŋ, aɪ hɪɹ - ən baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi ɹɪtɝnd, hi hæɾ ɪɾ ɔl səpɹɛst. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn dɪdn laɪk ɡeɪbɹəlz mɛθədz - hi kən bi ə vɛɹi hɑɹd mæn - bʌt mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz soʊ pliz tə faɪn ɔɹɾɝ ɹɪstɔɹd ðət ʃi neɪmd ɪm tə ðə poʊst ɪleɪɾə juz tə hoʊld."

"It is Gaebril I am telling you about, lad," Gill said. "During the riots, he made himself leader of the faction supporting Morgase - got himself wounded in the fighting, I hear - and by the time she returned, he had it all suppressed. Gareth Bryne didn't like Gaebril's methods - he can be a very hard man - but Morgase was so pleased to find order restored that she named him to the post Elaida used to hold."

ði ɪnkipɝ stɑpt. mæt weɪɾəd fəɹ ɪm tə ɡoʊ ɑn, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt. tɑm θʌmd ɪz paɪp fʊl ə təbæk ən wɔkt oʊvɝ tə laɪɾ ə spɪl əɾ ə smɔl læmp kɛp fəɹ ðə pɝpəs ɑn ðə mæntəl əbʌv ðə faɪɝpleɪs.

The innkeeper stopped. Mat waited for him to go on, but he did not. Thom thumbed his pipe full of tabac and walked over to light a spill at a small lamp kept for the purpose on the mantel above the fireplace.

"wʌɾ ɛls?" mæt æskt. "ðə mæn əz tə hæv ə ɹizən fəɹ wʌɾ i dʌz. ɪf i mɛɹiz mɔɹɡeɪs, wəɾ i bi kɪŋ wən ʃi daɪz? ɪf ɪleɪn wɝ dɛd, tu, aɪ min?"

"What else?" Mat asked. "The man has to have a reason for what he does. If he marries Morgase, would he be king when she dies? If Elayne were dead, too, I mean?"

tɑm tʃoʊk laɪɾɪŋ ɪz paɪp, ən ɡɪl læft. "ændɝ əz ə kwin, læd. ɔlweɪz ə kwin. ɪf mɔɹɡeɪs ən ɪleɪn boʊθ daɪd - ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt nɑt soʊ! - ðən mɔɹɡeɪsəz nɪɹəs fimeɪl ɹɛləɾɪv wəd teɪk ðə θɹoʊn. ət lis ðɛɹz noʊ kwɛstʃən ə hu ðəɾ ɪz ðɪs taɪm - ə kʌzən, ðə leɪɾi daɪɛlɪn - nɑt laɪk ðə səksɛʃən, æftɝ tɪɡɹeɪn vænɪʃt. ɪt tʊk tu jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ mɔɹɡeɪs sæɾ ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn, ðɛn. daɪɛlɪn kəd kip ɡeɪbɹəl əz əɹ ædvaɪzɝ, əɹ mɛɹi hɪm tə səmɛn ðə laɪn - ðoʊ ʃi wəd nɑt laɪkli də ðəɾ ənlɛs mɔɹɡeɪs hæd hæɾ ə tʃaɪl baɪ hɪm - bʌɾ i wəd bi ðə pɹɪns kɑnsɔɹɾ ivən ðɛn. noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt. θæŋk ðə laɪt, mɔɹɡeɪs ɪz ə jʌŋ wʊmən, jɛt. ən ɪleɪn ɪz hɛlθi. laɪt! ðə lɛɾɝ dɪd nɑt seɪ ʃiz ɪl, dɪɾ ɪt?"

Thom choked lighting his pipe, and Gill laughed. "Andor has a queen, lad. Always a queen. If Morgase and Elayne both died - the Light send it not so! - then Morgase's nearest female relative would take the throne. At least there's no question of who that is this time - a cousin, the Lady Dyelin - not like the Succession, after Tigraine vanished. It took two years before Morgase sat on the Lion Throne, then. Dyelin could keep Gaebril as her advisor, or marry him to cement the line - though she would not likely do that unless Morgase had had a child by him - but he would be the Prince Consort even then. No more than that. Thank the Light, Morgase is a young woman, yet. And Elayne is healthy. Light! The letter did not say she is ill, did it?"

"ʃi ɪz wɛl." fəɹ naʊ, ət list. "ɪzən ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls jə kən tɛl mi əbaʊt hɪm? jə də nɑt sim tə laɪk hɪm. waɪ?"

"She is well." For now, at least. "Isn't there anything else you can tell me about him? You do not seem to like him. Why?"

ði ɪnkipɝ fɹaʊn ɪn θɔt, ən skɹætʃt ɪz tʃɪn, ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ wəd nɑt laɪk ɪm mɛɹiɪŋ mɔɹɡeɪs, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt tʃɹuli noʊ waɪ. hiz sɛd tə bi ə faɪn mæn; ðə noʊbəlz ɔl lʊk tə hɪm. aɪ də nɑt laɪk moʊst ə ðə mɛn hiz bɹɔɾ ɪndə ðə ɡɑɹdz. tu mʌtʃ əz tʃeɪnʒd sɪns i keɪm, bʌɾ aɪ kænɑt leɪ ɪɾ ɔl əɾ ɪz dɔɹ. ðəɹ dʒʌst sim tə bi tu mɛni pipəl mʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn kɔɹnɝz sɪns i keɪm. jə wəd θɪŋk wi wɝ ɔl kɛɹhinɪn, ðə weɪ ðeɪ wɝ bɪfɔɹ ðɪs sɪvəl wɔɹ, ɔl plɑɾɪŋ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ædvæntɪdʒ. aɪ kip hævɪŋ bæd dʒɹimz sɪns ɡeɪbɹəl keɪm, ən aɪm nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn. ful θɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊt, dʒɹimz. ɪts pɹɑbli oʊnli wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪleɪn, ən wʌt mɔɹɡeɪs minz tə də kənsɝnɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən pipəl æktɪŋ laɪk kɛɹhinɪn. aɪ dʒʌs də nɑt noʊ. waɪ ɑɹ jə æskɪŋ ɔl ðiz kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl?"

The innkeeper frowned in thought, and scratched his chin, and shook his head. "I suppose I would not like him marrying Morgase, but I do not truly know why. He's said to be a fine man; the nobles all look to him. I do not like most of the men he's brought into the Guards. Too much has changed since he came, but I cannot lay it all at his door. There just seem to be too many people muttering in corners since he came. You would think we were all Cairhienin, the way they were before this civil war, all plotting and trying to find advantage. I keep having bad dreams since Gaebril came, and I am not the only one. Fool thing to worry about, dreams. It is probably only worry about Elayne, and what Morgase means to do concerning the White Tower, and people acting like Cairhienin. I just do not know. Why are you asking all these questions about Lord Gaebril?"

"bɪkɔz i wɑns tə kɪl ɪleɪn," mæt sɛd, "æn ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv wɪð hɝ." ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ jusfəl ɪn wʌt ɡɪl hæd toʊld ɪm ðəɾ i kəd si. bɝn mi, aɪ doʊn əv tə noʊ waɪ hi wɑns əm dɛd. aɪ dʒʌst əv tə stɑp ɪt. boʊθ mɛn wɝ stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əɡɛn. əz ɪf i wɝ mæd. əɡɛn.

"Because he wants to kill Elayne," Mat said, "and Egwene and Nynaeve with her." There was nothing useful in what Gill had told him that he could see. Burn me, I don't have to know why he wants them dead. I just have to stop it. Both men were staring at him again. As if he were mad. Again.

"ɑɹ jə kʌmɪŋ daʊn sɪk əɡɛn?" ɡɪl sɛd səspɪʃəsli. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ jə stɛɹɪŋ kɹɔsweɪz əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ðə læs taɪm. ɪts iðɝ ðæt, əɹ ɛls jə θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz səm sɔɹɾ ə pɹæŋk. juv ðə lʊk ʌv ə pɹæŋkstɝ tə mi. ɪf ðəɾ ɪz ɪt, ɪts ə næsti wʌn!"

"Are you coming down sick again?" Gill said suspiciously. "I remember you staring crossways at everyone the last time. It's either that, or else you think this is some sort of prank. You have the look of a prankster to me. If that is it, it's a nasty one!"

mæt ɡɹɪməst. "ɪɾ ɪz noʊ blʌɾi pɹæŋk. aɪ oʊvɝhɝɾ ɪm tɛlɪŋ səm mæn kɔl koʊmɹ tə kʌɾ ɪleɪnz hɛɾ ɔf. ən ɛɡwinz ən nɪneɪivz waɪl i wɑz əbaʊɾ ɪt. ə bɪɡ mæn, wɪð ə waɪt stʃɹaɪp ɪn ɪz bɪɹd."

Mat grimaced. "It is no bloody prank. I overheard him telling some man called Comar to cut Elayne's head off. And Egwene's and Nynaeve's while he was about it. A big man, with a white stripe in his beard."

"ðæt dʌz saʊn laɪk lɔɹd koʊmɹ," ɡɪl sɛd sloʊli. "hi wɑz ə faɪn soʊlʒɝ, bʌɾ ɪts sɛɾ i lɛf ðə ɡɑɹɾ oʊvɝ səm mæɾɝ ʌv weɪɾɪd daɪs. nɑt ðəɾ ɛniwʌn sɛz ɪt tə hɪz feɪs; koʊmɹ wɑz wʌn ə ðə bɛs bleɪdz ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdz. jə ɹɪli min ɪt, doʊn ju?"

"That does sound like Lord Comar," Gill said slowly. "He was a fine soldier, but it is said he left the Guard over some matter of weighted dice. Not that anyone says it to his face; Comar was one of the best blades in the Guards. You really mean it, don't you?"

"aɪ θɪŋk i dʌz, bɑzəl," tɑm sɛd. "aɪ vɛɹi mʌtʃ θɪŋk i dʌz."

"I think he does, Basel," Thom said. "I very much think he does."

"ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ʌs! wʌd mɔɹɡeɪs seɪ? jə dɪd tɛl hɝ, dɪdn ju? ðə laɪt bɝn ju, jə dɪd tɛl hɝ!"

"The Light shine on us! What did Morgase say? You did tell her, didn't you? The Light burn you, you did tell her!"

"ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ dɪd," mæt sɛd bɪɾɝli. "wɪð ɡeɪbɹəl stændɪŋ ɹaɪt ðɛɹ, ən əɹ ɡeɪzɪŋ əɾ ɪm laɪk ə lʌvisɪk læpdɔɡ! aɪ sɛd, 'aɪ meɪ bi ə sɪmpəl vɪlədʒ mæn u dʒʌs klaɪmd oʊvɝ jəɹ wɔl hæf ən aʊɝ pæst, bʌɾ aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi hæpən tə noʊ jəɹ tʃɹʌstɪɾ ædvaɪzɝ ðɛɹ, ðə wʌn jə sim tə bi ɪn lʌv wɪð, ɪntɛnz tə mɝɾɝ jəɹ dɔɾɝ.' laɪt, mæn, ʃiɾ əv kʌt maɪ hɛɾ ɔf!"

"Of course, I did," Mat said bitterly. "With Gaebril standing right there, and her gazing at him like a lovesick lapdog! I said, 'I may be a simple village man who just climbed over your wall half an hour past, but I already happen to know your trusted advisor there, the one you seem to be in love with, intends to murder your daughter.' Light, man, she'd have cut my head off!"

"ʃi maɪɾ əv ət ðæt." tɑm stɛɹɾ ɪndə ði ɪlæbɹət kɑɹvɪŋz ɑn ðə boʊl ə hɪz paɪp ən tʌɡd wʌn mʌstæʃ. "hɝ tɛmpɝ wɑz ɛvɝ əz sʌɾən əz laɪtnɪŋ, ən twaɪs əz deɪnʒɝəs."

"She might have at that." Thom stared into the elaborate carvings on the bowl of his pipe and tugged one mustache. "Her temper was ever as sudden as lightning, and twice as dangerous."

"ju noʊ ɪt bɛɾɝ ðən moʊst, tɑm," ɡɪl sɛɾ æbsənli. stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ, hi skɹʌbd boʊθ hænz θɹu hɪz ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ. "ðɛɹ əz tə bi sʌmθɪŋ aɪ kən du. aɪ hævən hɛld ə sɔɹd sɪns ði il wɔɹ, bʌt. . . . wɛl, ðət wəd də noʊ ɡʊd. ɡɛt maɪsɛlf kɪld ən də nʌθɪŋ baɪ ɪt. bʌɾ aɪ mʌs də sʌmθɪŋ!"

"You know it better than most, Thom," Gill said absently. Staring at nothing, he scrubbed both hands through his graying hair. "There has to be something I can do. I haven't held a sword since the Aiel War, but. . . . Well, that would do no good. Get myself killed and do nothing by it. But I must do something!"

"ɹumɝ." tɑm ɹʌb ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz noʊz; hi sim tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ ðə stoʊnz bɔɹɾ ən tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. "noʊ wʌn kən kip ɹumɝz fɹəm ɹitʃɪŋ mɔɹɡeɪsəz ɪɹz, ən ɪf ʃi hɪɹz ɪt stʃɹɔŋli ɪnʌf, ʃɪl stɑɹt tə wʌndɝ. ɹumɝ ɪz ðə vɔɪs ə ðə pipəl, ən ðə vɔɪs ə ðə pipəl ɔfən spiks tʃɹuθ. mɔɹɡeɪs noʊz ðæt. ðəɹ ɪz nɑɾ ə mæn əlaɪv aɪ wəd bæk əɡɛnst əɹ ɪn ðə ɡeɪm. lʌv əɹ noʊ lʌv, wʌns mɔɹɡeɪs stɑɹts ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ɡeɪbɹəl kloʊsli, hɪl nɑt bi eɪbəl tə haɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ɪz tʃaɪldhʊd skɑɹz fɹəm hɝ. ən ɪf ʃi lɝnz i minz hɑɹm tə ɪleɪn" - hi pleɪst ə stoʊn ɑn ðə bɔɹd; ɪt simd ən ɑd pleɪsmən ət fɝst ɡlæns, bʌt mæt sɔ ðəɾ ɪn θɹi mɔɹ muvz, ə θɝɾ ʌv ɡɪlz stoʊnz wəd bi tʃɹæpt - "lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl wɪl əv ə moʊst ɪlæbɹət fjunɝəl."

"Rumor." Thom rubbed the side of his nose; he seemed to be studying the stones board and talking to himself. "No one can keep rumors from reaching Morgase's ears, and if she hears it strongly enough, she will start to wonder. Rumor is the voice of the people, and the voice of the people often speaks truth. Morgase knows that. There is not a man alive I would back against her in the Game. Love or no love, once Morgase starts examining Gaebril closely, he'll not be able to hide as much as his childhood scars from her. And if she learns he means harm to Elayne" - he placed a stone on the board; it seemed an odd placement at first glance, but Mat saw that in three more moves, a third of Gill's stones would be trapped - "Lord Gaebril will have a most elaborate funeral."

"ju ən jəɹ ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz," ɡɪl mʌɾɝd. "stɪl, ɪt maɪt wɝk." ə sʌɾən smaɪl əpɪɹɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs. "aɪ ivən noʊ hu tə tɛl tə stɑɹɾ ɪt. ɔl aɪ nid də ɪz mɛnʃən tə ɡɪldə ðəɾ aɪ dʒɹimd ɪt, ən ɪn θɹi deɪz ʃɪl əv toʊl sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz ɪn hæf ðə nu sɪɾi ðəɾ ɪts ə fækt. ʃiz ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ɡɑsəp ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ɛvɝ meɪd."

"You and your Game of Houses," Gill muttered. "Still, it might work." A sudden smile appeared on his face. "I even know who to tell to start it. All I need do is mention to Gilda that I dreamed it, and in three days she'll have told serving girls in half the New City that it is a fact. She is the greatest gossip the Creator ever made."

"dʒʌs bi sɝɾən ɪt kænɑt bi tʃɹeɪs bæk tə ju, bɑzəl."

"Just be certain it cannot be traced back to you, Basel."

"noʊ fɪɹ ə ðæt, tɑm. waɪ ə wik əɡoʊ, ə mæn toʊl mi wʌn ə maɪ oʊn bæd dʒɹimz əz ə θɪŋ hid hɝd fɹəm sʌmbɑɾi hud hæɾ ɪt fɹəm sʌmwʌn ɛls. ɡɪldə mʌst əv ivzdʒɹɑpt ɑn mi tɛlɪŋ ɪt tə koʊlini, bʌt wən aɪ æskt, hi ɡeɪv mi ə stʃɹɪŋ ə neɪmz ðət lɛɾ ɔl ðə weɪ tə ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn ən vænɪʃt. waɪ, aɪ æktʃəli  wɛn oʊvɝ ðəɹ ən faʊn ðə læs mæn, dʒʌst aʊɾ ə kjʊɹiɑsəɾi tə si haʊ mɛni maʊðz hæd pæst ɪt, ən i kleɪmd ɪt wɑz ɪz vɛɹi oʊn dʒɹim. noʊ fɪɹ, tɑm."

"No fear of that, Thom. Why a week ago, a man told me one of my own bad dreams as a thing he'd heard from somebody who'd had it from someone else. Gilda must have eavesdropped on me telling it to Coline, but when I asked, he gave me a string of names that led all the way to the other side of Caemlyn and vanished. Why, I actually went over there and found the last man, just out of curiosity to see how many mouths had passed it, and he claimed it was his very own dream. No fear, Thom."

mæt dɪd nɑt ɹɪli kɛɹ wʌt ðeɪ dɪd wɪð ðɛɹ ɹumɝz - noʊ ɹumɝz wəd hɛlp ɛɡwin əɹ ði ʌðɝz - bʌt wʌn θɪŋ pʌzəl hɪm. "tɑm, jə sim tə bi teɪkɪŋ ðɪs ɔl vɛɹi kɑmli. aɪ θɔt mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz ðə ɡɹeɪt lʌv ə jəɹ laɪf."

Mat did not really care what they did with their rumors - no rumors would help Egwene or the others - but one thing puzzled him. "Thom, you seem to be taking this all very calmly. I thought Morgase was the great love of your life."

ðə ɡlimən stɛɹɾ ɪndə ðə boʊl ə hɪz paɪp əɡɛn. "mæt, ə vɛɹi waɪz wʊmən wʌns toʊl mi ðət taɪm wəd hil maɪ wunz, ðət taɪm smuðd ɛvɹiθɪŋ oʊvɝ. aɪ dɪdn bɪliv hɝ. oʊnli ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt."

The gleeman stared into the bowl of his pipe again. "Mat, a very wise woman once told me that time would heal my wounds, that time smoothed everything over. I didn't believe her. Only she was right."

"ju min jə də nɑt lʌv mɔɹɡeɪs ɛnimɔɹ."

"You mean you do not love Morgase anymore."

"bɔɪ, ɪts bɪn fɪftin jɪɹz sɪns aɪ lɛf keɪɛmlɪn ə hæf stɛp əhɛɾ ə ðə hɛdzmənz æks, wɪð ði ɪŋk ə mɔɹɡeɪsəz sɪɡnətʃɝ stɪl wɛɾ ɑn ðə wɔɹənt. sɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ lɪsnɪŋ tə bɑzəl næɾɝ ɑn" - ɡɪl pɹətɛstəd, ən tɑm ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs - "næɾɝ ɑn, aɪ seɪ, əbaʊt mɔɹɡeɪs ən ɡeɪbɹəl, ən haʊ ðeɪ maɪt mɛɹi, aɪ ɹilaɪz ðə pæʃən feɪɾəd ə lɔŋ taɪm ɡɔn. oʊ, aɪ səpoʊz aɪm stɪl fɑn ə hɝ, pɝhæps aɪ ivən lʌv əɹ ə lɪɾəl, bʌɾ ɪts nɑɾ ə ɡɹæn pæʃən ɛnimɔɹ."

"Boy, it has been fifteen years since I left Caemlyn a half step ahead of the headsman's axe, with the ink of Morgase's signature still wet on the warrant. Sitting here listening to Basel natter on" - Gill protested, and Thom raised his voice - "natter on, I say, about Morgase and Gaebril, and how they might marry, I realized the passion faded a long time gone. Oh, I suppose I am still fond of her, perhaps I even love her a little, but it is not a grand passion anymore."

"æn hɪɹ aɪ hæf θɔt jud ɡoʊ ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp tə ðə pæləs tə wɔɹn hɝ." hi læft, ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd wən tɑm dʒɔɪn hɪm.

"And here I half thought you'd go running up to the Palace to warn her." He laughed, and was surprised when Thom joined him.

"aɪ æm nɑt soʊ bɪɡ ə ful əz ðæt, bɔɪ. ɛni ful noʊz mɛn ən wɪmən θɪŋk dɪfɹənli ət taɪmz, bʌt ðə bɪɡəs dɪfɝəns ɪz ðɪs. mɛn fɝɡɛt, bʌt nɛvɝ fɝɡɪv; wɪmən fɝɡɪv, bʌt nɛvɝ fɝɡɛt. mɔɹɡeɪs maɪt kɪs maɪ tʃik ən ɡɪmi ə kʌp ʌv waɪn ən seɪ haʊ ʃiz mɪs mi. ən ðən ʃi maɪt dʒʌs lɛt ðə ɡɑɹdz hɔl mi ɔf tə pɹɪzən ən ðə hɛdzmən. noʊ. mɔɹɡeɪs ɪz wʌn ə ðə moʊs keɪpəbəl wɪmən aɪv ɛvɝ noʊn, ən ðəɾ ɪz seɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. aɪ kəɾ ɔlmoʊs pɪɾi ɡeɪbɹəl wʌns ʃi lɝnz wʌt hiz ʌp tə. tɛɹ, jə seɪ? ɪz ðəɹ ɛni tʃæns ə jə weɪɾɪŋ əntɪl təmɑɹoʊ tə liv? aɪ kəd juz ə naɪts slip."

"I am not so big a fool as that, boy. Any fool knows men and women think differently at times, but the biggest difference is this. Men forget, but never forgive; women forgive, but never forget. Morgase might kiss my cheek and give me a cup of wine and say how she has missed me. And then she might just let the Guards haul me off to prison and the headsman. No. Morgase is one of the most capable women I've ever known, and that is saying something. I could almost pity Gaebril once she learns what he is up to. Tear, you say? Is there any chance of you waiting until tomorrow to leave? I could use a night's sleep."

"aɪ min tə bi əz fɑɹ təwɔɹd tiɹ əz aɪ kən bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl." mæt blɪŋkt. "du jə min tə kʌm wɪð mi? aɪ θɔt jə mɛn tə steɪ hɪɹ."

"I mean to be as far toward Tear as I can before nightfall." Mat blinked. "Do you mean to come with me? I thought you meant to stay here."

"dɪd jə nɑt dʒʌs hɪɹ mi seɪ aɪ hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd nɑt tə hæv maɪ hɛd kʌɾ ɔf? tɛɹ saʊnz ə seɪfɝ pleɪs tə mi ðən keɪɛmlɪn, ən sʌɾənli ðət dʌz nɑt sim soʊ bæd. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ laɪk ðoʊz ɡɝlz." ə naɪf əpɪɹɾ ɪn ɪz hæn ən wɑz əz sʌɾənli ɡɔn əɡɛn. "aɪd nɑt laɪk ɛniθɪŋ tə hæpən tə ðɛm. bʌɾ ɪf jə min tə ɹitʃ tɛɹ kwɪkli, ɪts ɑɹɪŋɡəl jə wɑnt. ə fæs boʊt wɪl əv əs ðəɹ deɪz sunɝ ðən hɔɹsəz, ivən ɪf wi ɹoʊɾ əm tə dɛθ. ən aɪ doʊn seɪ ɪt dʒʌs kəz maɪ bɑɾəm əz ɔlɹɛɾi teɪkən ɑn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə sæɾəl."

"Did you not just hear me say I had decided not to have my head cut off? Tear sounds a safer place to me than Caemlyn, and suddenly that does not seem so bad. Besides, I like those girls." A knife appeared in his hand and was as suddenly gone again. "I'd not like anything to happen to them. But if you mean to reach Tear quickly, it's Aringill you want. A fast boat will have us there days sooner than horses, even if we rode them to death. And I don't say it just because my bottom has already taken on the shape of a saddle."

"ɑɹɪŋɡəl, ðɛn. əz lɔŋ əz ɪts fæst."

"Aringill, then. As long as it's fast."

"wɛl," ɡɪl sɛd, "aɪ səpoʊz ɪf jə ɑɹ livɪŋ, læd, aɪ hæd bɛɾɝ si əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ jə ðət mil." hi pʊʃt bæk ɪz tʃɛɹ ən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ.

"Well," Gill said, "I suppose if you are leaving, lad, I had better see about getting you that meal." He pushed back his chair and started for the door.

"hoʊl ðɪs fəɹ mi, mæstɝ ɡɪl," mæt sɛd, ən tɔst ɪm ðə wɑʃ-lɛðɝ pɝs.

"Hold this for me, Master Gill," Mat said, and tossed him the wash-leather purse.

"wʌts ðɪs, læd? kɔɪn?"

"What's this, lad? Coin?"

"steɪks. ɡeɪbɹəl dʌznt noʊ ɪt, bʌɾ i ən aɪ hæv ə weɪdʒɝ." ðə kæt dʒʌmp daʊn əz mæt pɪkt ʌp ðə wʊɾən daɪs kʌp ən spʌn ðə daɪs aʊɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. faɪv sɪksɪz. "æn aɪ ɔlweɪz wɪn."

"Stakes. Gaebril doesn't know it, but he and I have a wager." The cat jumped down as Mat picked up the wooden dice cup and spun the dice out on the table. Five sixes. "And I always win."


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾieɪt


CHAPTER 48

fɑloʊɪŋ ðə kɹæft


Following the Craft

əz ðə dɑɹɾɝ wɑloʊd təwɔɹd ðə dɑks ə tiɹ, ɑn ðə wɛs bæŋk ə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn, ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt si ɛniθɪŋ ə ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ sɪɾi. slʌmp hɛd daʊn ət ðə ɹeɪl, ʃi stɛɹd daʊn ət ðə wɔɾɝz ə ði ɛɹɪnɪn ɹoʊlɪŋ pæs ðə ʃɪps fæt hʌl, ən ðə fɹʌntmoʊst swip ɑn əɹ saɪɾ əz ɪt swʌŋ ɪndə hɝ vɪʒən ən bæk əɡɛn, kʌɾɪŋ waɪt fɝoʊz ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɪt meɪɾ əɹ kwizi, bʌt ʃi nu ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ hɛd wəɾ oʊnli meɪk ðə sɪknəs wɝs. lʊkɪŋ ət ðə ʃɔɹ wəɾ oʊnli meɪk ðə sloʊ, kɔɹkskɹu moʊʃən ə ðə dɑɹɾɝ mɔɹ əpɛɹənt.

As the Darter wallowed toward the docks of Tear, on the west bank of the River Erinin, Egwene did not see anything of the oncoming city. Slumped head down at the rail, she stared down at the waters of the Erinin rolling past the ship's fat hull, and the frontmost sweep on her side as it swung into her vision and back again, cutting white furrows in the river. It made her queasy, but she knew raising her head would only make the sickness worse. Looking at the shore would only make the slow, corkscrew motion of the Darter more apparent.

ðə vɛsəl hæd muvd ɪn ðət twɪstɪŋ ɹoʊl ɛvɝ sɪns dʒʊɹin. ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ haʊ ɪt hæd seɪl bɪfɔɹ ðɛn; ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf wɪʃɪŋ ðə dɑɹɾɝ hæd sʌŋk bɪfɔɹ ɹitʃɪŋ dʒʊɹin. ʃi wɪʃt ðeɪ hæd meɪd ðə kæptən pʊɾ ɪn əɾ ɑɹɪŋɡəl soʊ ðeɪ kəd faɪn ənʌðɝ ʃɪp. ʃi wɪʃt ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ ɡɔn nɪɹ ə ʃɪp. ʃi wɪʃt ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz, moʊst ə ðɛm dʒʌs tə teɪk əɹ maɪn ɔf wɛɹ ʃi wɑz.

The vessel had moved in that twisting roll ever since Jurene. She did not care how it had sailed before then; she found herself wishing the Darter had sunk before reaching Jurene. She wished they had made the captain put in at Aringill so they could find another ship. She wished they had never gone near a ship. She wished a great many things, most of them just to take her mind off where she was.

ðə twɪstɪŋ wɑz lɛs naʊ, ʌndɝ swips, ðən ɪt hæd bɪn ʌndɝ seɪl, bʌɾ ɪt hæd ɡɔn ɑn tu mɛni deɪz naʊ fəɹ ðə tʃeɪnʒ tə meɪk mʌtʃ dɪfɝəns tə hɝ. hɝ stʌmək sim tə bi slɑʃɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ laɪk mɪlk ɪn ə stoʊn dʒʌɡ. ʃi ɡʌlpt ən tʃɹaɪd tə fɝɡɛt ðəɾ ɪmədʒ.

The twisting was less now, under sweeps, than it had been under sail, but it had gone on too many days now for the change to make much difference to her. Her stomach seemed to be sloshing about inside her like milk in a stone jug. She gulped and tried to forget that image.

ðeɪ hæd nɑt dʌn mʌtʃ ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv plænɪŋ ɑn ðə dɑɹɾɝ, ʃi ən ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv. nɪneɪiv kəd sɛldəm ɡoʊ tɛn mɪnəts wɪθaʊt vɑməɾɪŋ, ən siɪŋ ðəɾ ɔlweɪz meɪɾ ɛɡwin luz wʌtɛvɝ fud ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə ɡɛt daʊn. ði ɪnkɹisɪŋ wɔɹmθ əz ðeɪ wɛn fɝðɝ daʊnɹɪvɝ dɪd nɑt hɛlp. nɪneɪiv wɑz bɪloʊ naʊ, noʊ daʊt wɪð ɪleɪn hoʊldɪŋ ə beɪsən fəɹ əɹ əɡɛn.

They had not done much in the way of planning on the Darter, she and Elayne and Nynaeve. Nynaeve could seldom go ten minutes without vomiting, and seeing that always made Egwene lose whatever food she had managed to get down. The increasing warmth as they went further downriver did not help. Nynaeve was below now, no doubt with Elayne holding a basin for her again.

oʊ, laɪt, noʊ! doʊn θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt! ɡɹin filz. mɛdoʊz. laɪt, mɛdoʊz də nɑt hiv laɪk ðæt. hʌmɪŋbɝdz. noʊ, nɑt hʌmɪŋbɝdz! lɑɹks. lɑɹks sɪŋɪŋ.

Oh, Light, no! Don't think about that! Green fields. Meadows. Light, meadows do not heave like that. Hummingbirds. No, not hummingbirds! Larks. Larks singing.

"mɪstʃɹəs dʒɔslɪn? mɪstʃɹəs dʒɔslɪn!"

"Mistress Joslyn? Mistress Joslyn!"

ɪt tʊk əɹ ə moʊmən tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə neɪm ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən tə ɡɪv kæptən keɪnɪn, ən ðə kæptənz vɔɪs. ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd sloʊli ən fɪkst əɹ aɪz ɑn ɪz lɔŋ feɪs.

It took her a moment to recognize the name she had chosen to give Captain Canin, and the captain's voice. She raised her head slowly and fixed her eyes on his long face.

"wi ɑɹ dɑkɪŋ, mɪstʃɹəs dʒɔslɪn. juv kɛp seɪɪŋ haʊ iɡɝ jə wɝ tə bi əʃɔɹ. wɛl, wɝ ðɛɹ." hɪz vɔɪs dɪd nɑt haɪɾ ɪz iɡɝnəs tə bi ɹɪɾ ə hɪz θɹi pæsənʒɝz, tu ʌv hum dɪd lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən sɪk ʌp, əz i kɔld ɪt, ən moʊn ɔl naɪt.

"We are docking, Mistress Joslyn. You've kept saying how eager you were to be ashore. Well, we're there." His voice did not hide his eagerness to be rid of his three passengers, two of whom did little more than sick up, as he called it, and moan all night.

bɛɹfʊt, ʃɝtləs seɪlɝz wɝ tɔsɪŋ laɪnz tə mɛn ɑn ðə stoʊn dɑk ðət θɹʌst aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ; ðə dɑkmən sim tə bi wɛɹɪŋ lɔŋ lɛðɝ vɛsts ɪn pleɪs ə ʃɝts. ðə swips hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn dʒɹɔn ɪn, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə pɛɹ fɛndɪŋ ðə ʃɪp ɔf fɹəm kʌmɪŋ əɡɛns ðə dɑk tu hɑɹd. ðə flæt stoʊnz ə ðə dɑk wɝ wɛt; ði ɛɹ hæɾ ə fil ə ɹeɪn nɑt lɔŋ ɡɔn, ən ðət wɑz ə lɪɾəl suðɪŋ. ðə twɪstɪŋ moʊʃən hæd sist səm taɪm sɪns, ʃi ɹilaɪzd, bʌɾ əɹ stʌmək ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ðə sʌn wɑz fɔlɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə wɛst. ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk ə sʌpɝ.

Barefoot, shirtless sailors were tossing lines to men on the stone dock that thrust out into the river; the dockmen seemed to be wearing long leather vests in place of shirts. The sweeps had already been drawn in, except for a pair fending the ship off from coming against the dock too hard. The flat stones of the dock were wet; the air had a feel of rain not long gone, and that was a little soothing. The twisting motion had ceased some time since, she realized, but her stomach remembered. The sun was falling toward the west. She tried not to think of supper.

"vɛɹi ɡʊd, kæptən keɪnɪn," ʃi sɛd wɪð ɔl ðə dɪɡnəɾi ʃi kəd sʌmən. hid nɑt saʊn laɪk ðəɾ ɪf aɪ wɝ wɛɹɪŋ maɪ ɹɪŋ, nɑɾ ivən ɪf aɪ wɝ sɪk ɑn ɪz buts. ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd ət ðə pɪktʃɝ ɪn əɹ maɪnd.

"Very good, Captain Canin," she said with all the dignity she could summon. He'd not sound like that if I were wearing my ring, not even if I were sick on his boots. She shuddered at the picture in her mind.

hɝ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ən ðə twɪstəd ɹɪŋ ə ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil hʌŋ ɑn ə lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ nɛk, naʊ. ðə stoʊn ɹɪŋ fɛl kul əɡɛnst əɹ skɪn - ɔlmoʊst ɪnʌf tə kaʊntɝæk ðə dæmp wɔɹmθ ə ði ɛɹ - bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðæt, ʃi hæd faʊn ðət ðə mɔɹ ʃi juz ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ðə mɔɹ ʃi wɑntəd tə tʌtʃ ɪt, wɪθaʊt paʊtʃ əɹ klɔθ bɪtwin ɪɾ ən hɝ.

Her Great Serpent ring and the twisted ring of the ter'angreal hung on a leather cord about her neck, now. The stone ring felt cool against her skin - almost enough to counteract the damp warmth of the air - but aside from that, she had found that the more she used the ter'angreal, the more she wanted to touch it, without pouch or cloth between it and her.

tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd stɪl ʃoʊɾ əɹ lɪɾəl ʌv ɪmiɾiət jus. səmtaɪmz ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɡlɪmpsɪz ə ɹænd, əɹ mæt, əɹ pɛɹɪn, ən mɔɹ ɪn əɹ oʊn dʒɹimz wɪθaʊt ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ʌv wɪtʃ ʃi kəd meɪk ɛni sɛns. ðə sintʃæn, hu ʃi ɹəfjuz tə θɪŋk əbaʊt. naɪtmɛɹz ʌv ə waɪt-kloʊk pʊɾɪŋ mæstɝ luhən ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə hjudʒ, tuθ tʃɹæp fəɹ beɪt. waɪ ʃəd pɛɹɪn əv ə fælkən ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən wʌt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əbaʊɾ ɪm tʃuzɪŋ bɪtwin ðəɾ æks i wɔɹ naʊ ən ə blæksmɪθs hæmɝ? wʌɾ ɪt min ðət mæt wɑz dɪsɪŋ wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən waɪ dɪɾ i kip ʃaʊɾɪŋ, "aɪ æm kʌmɪŋ!" ən waɪ dɪd ʃi θɪŋk ɪn ðə dʒɹim ðəɾ i wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət hɝ? ən ɹænd. hi hæd bɪn snikɪŋ θɹu ʌɾɝ dɑɹknəs təwɔɹd kælændɝ, waɪl ɔl ɝaʊn ɪm sɪks mɛn ən faɪv wɪmən wɔkt, səm hʌntɪŋ ɪm ən səm ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ hɪm, səm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡaɪɾ ɪm təwɔɹd ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ kɹɪstəl sɔɹɾ ən səm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑp ɪm fɹəm ɹitʃɪŋ ɪt, əpɪɹɪŋ nɑt tə noʊ wɛɹ i wɑz, əɹ oʊnli tə si hɪm ɪn flæʃɪz. wʌn ə ðə mɛn hæɾ aɪz ə fleɪm, ən i wɑntəd ɹænd dɛd wɪð ə dɛspɝeɪʃən ʃi kəd nɪɹli teɪst. ʃi θɔt ʃi nu hɪm. bælzəmən. bʌɾ u wɝ ði ʌðɝz? ɹænd ɪn ðət dʒɹaɪ, dʌsti tʃeɪmbɝ əɡɛn, wɪð ðoʊz smɔl kɹitʃɝz sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪndə hɪz skɪn. ɹænd kənfɹʌntɪŋ ə hɔɹɾ ə sintʃæn. ɹænd kənfɹʌntɪŋ hɝ, ən ðə wɪmən wɪð hɝ, ən wʌn ə ðɛm wɑz ə sintʃæn. ɪt wɑz ɔl tu kənfjuzɪŋ. ʃi hæd tə stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz ən pʊɾ əɹ maɪn tə wʌt wɑz ɹaɪɾ əhɛɾ ə hɝ. wʌɾ ɪz ðə blæk ədʒɑ ʌp tə? waɪ doʊn aɪ dʒɹim sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm? laɪt, waɪ kæn aɪ lɝn tə meɪk ɪt də wʌɾ aɪ wɑnt?

Tel'aran'rhiod still showed her little of immediate use. Sometimes there had been glimpses of Rand, or Mat, or Perrin, and more in her own dreams without the ter'angreal, but nothing of which she could make any sense. The Seanchan, who she refused to think about. Nightmares of a White-cloak putting Master Luhhan in the middle of a huge, toothed trap for bait. Why should Perrin have a falcon on his shoulder, and what was important about him choosing between that axe he wore now and a blacksmith's hammer? What did it mean that Mat was dicing with the Dark One, and why did he keep shouting, "I am coming!" and why did she think in the dream that he was shouting at her? And Rand. He had been sneaking through utter darkness toward Callandor, while all around him six men and five women walked, some hunting him and some ignoring him, some trying to guide him toward the shining crystal sword and some trying to stop him from reaching it, appearing not to know where he was, or only to see him in flashes. One of the men had eyes of flame, and he wanted Rand dead with a desperation she could nearly taste. She thought she knew him. Ba'alzamon. But who were the others? Rand in that dry, dusty chamber again, with those small creatures settling into his skin. Rand confronting a horde of Seanchan. Rand confronting her, and the women with her, and one of them was a Seanchan. It was all too confusing. She had to stop thinking about Rand and the others and put her mind to what was right ahead of her. What is the Black Ajah up to? Why don't I dream something about them? Light, why can't I learn to make it do what I want?

"hæv ðə hɔɹsəz pʊɾ əʃɔɹ, kæptən," ʃi toʊl keɪnɪn. "aɪ wɪl tɛl mɪstʃɹəs mɛɹiɪm ən mɪstʃɹəs kɛɹɪlə." ðət wɑz nɪneɪiv - mɛɹiɪm - ən ɪleɪn - kɛɹɪlə.

"Have the horses put ashore, Captain," she told Canin. "I will tell Mistress Maryim and Mistress Caryla." That was Nynaeve - Maryim - and Elayne - Caryla.

"aɪ hæv sɛn ə mæn tə tɛl ðɛm, mɪstʃɹəs dʒɔslɪn. ən jəɹ ænəməlz wɪl bi ɑn ðə dɑk əz sun əz maɪ mɛn kən ɹɪɡ ə bum."

"I have sent a man to tell them, Mistress Joslyn. And your animals will be on the dock as soon as my men can rig a boom."

hi saʊndəd vɛɹi pliz tə bi ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm. ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊt tɛlɪŋ ɪm nɑt tə hɝi, bʌt ɹɪdʒɛktɪɾ ɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli. ðə dɑɹɾɝz kɔɹkskɹuɪŋ maɪɾ əv stɑpt, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd dʒɹaɪ læn ʌndɝ əɹ fiɾ əɡɛn. naʊ. stɪl, ʃi stɑp tə pæt mɪsts noʊz ən lɛt ðə ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ nʌzəl əɹ pɑm, tə lɛt keɪnɪn si ʃi wɑz ɪn noʊ ɡɹeɪt ɹʌʃ.

He sounded very pleased to be rid of them. She thought about telling him not to hurry, but rejected it immediately. The Darter's corkscrewing might have stopped, but she wanted dry land under her feet again. Now. Still, she stopped to pat Mist's nose and let the gray mare nuzzle her palm, to let Canin see she was in no great rush.

nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn əpɪɹɾ ət ðə læɾɝ fɹəm ðə kæbənz, leɪɾən wɪð ðɛɹ bʌndəlz ən sæɾəlbæɡz, ən ɪleɪn ɔlmoʊst əz leɪɾən wɪð nɪneɪiv. wən nɪneɪiv sɔ ɛɡwin wɑtʃɪŋ, ʃi pʊʃt hɝsɛlf əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ən wɔkt əneɪɾɪd ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ tə wɛɹ mɛn wɝ sɛɾɪŋ ə nɛɹoʊ ɡæŋplæŋk tə ðə dɑk. tu kɹumɪn keɪm tə fæsən ə waɪd kænvəs slɪŋ ʌndɝ mɪsts bɛli, ən ɛɡwin hɝid bɪloʊ fəɹ əɹ oʊn θɪŋz. wən ʃi keɪm bæk ʌp, hɝ mɛɹ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðə dɑk ən ɪleɪnz ɹoʊn dæŋɡəld ɪn ðə kænvəs slɪŋ hæfweɪ ðɛɹ.

Nynaeve and Elayne appeared at the ladder from the cabins, laden with their bundles and saddlebags, and Elayne almost as laden with Nynaeve. When Nynaeve saw Egwene watching, she pushed herself away from the Daughter-Heir and walked unaided the rest of the way to where men were setting a narrow gangplank to the dock. Two crewmen came to fasten a wide canvas sling under Mist's belly, and Egwene hurried below for her own things. When she came back up, her mare was already on the dock and Elayne's roan dangled in the canvas sling halfway there.

fəɹ ə moʊmən æftɝ əɹ fit wɝ ɑn ðə dɑk, ɔl ʃi fɛlt wɑz ɹɪlif. ðɪs wəd nɑt pɪtʃ ən ɹoʊl. ðən ʃi bɪɡæn tə lʊk ət ðɪs sɪɾi huz ɹitʃɪŋ hæd kɑzd əm sətʃ peɪnz.

For a moment after her feet were on the dock, all she felt was relief. This would not pitch and roll. Then she began to look at this city whose reaching had caused them such pains.

stoʊn wɛɹhaʊzɪz bæk ðə lɔŋ dɑks ðɛmsɛlvz, ən ðəɹ sim tə bi ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni ʃɪps, lɑɹdʒ ən smɔl, əlɔŋsaɪd ðə dɑks əɹ æŋkɝɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ. heɪstəli ʃi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət ðə ʃɪps. tiɹ hæd bɪn bɪlt ɑn flæt lænd, wɪð bɛɹli ə bʌmp. daʊn mʌɾi dɝt stʃɹits bɪtwin ðə wɛɹhaʊzɪz, ʃi kəd si haʊzɪz ən ɪnz ən tævɝnz ʌv wʊɾ ən stoʊn. ðɛɹ ɹufs ə sleɪɾ əɹ taɪl hæɾ ɑdli ʃɑɹp kɔɹnɝz, ən səm ɹoʊz tə ə pɔɪnt. bɪɑn ðiz, ʃi kəd meɪk aʊɾ ə haɪ wɔl ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ stoʊn, ən bɪhaɪn ɪt ðə tɑps ə taʊɝz wɪð bælkəniz haɪ ɝaʊn əm ən waɪt-doʊm pæləsəz. ðə doʊmz hæɾ ə skwɛɹd ʃeɪp tə ðɛm, ən ðə taʊɝ tɑps lʊk pɔɪntəd, laɪk səm ə ðə ɹufs aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔl. ɔl ɪn ɔl, tiɹ wɑz izəli əz bɪɡ əz keɪɛmlɪn əɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ɪf nɑt soʊ bjuɾəfəl əz iðɝ, ɪt wɑz stɪl wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz. jɛt ʃi faʊn ɪt hɑɹd tə lʊk əɾ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ.

Stone warehouses backed the long docks themselves, and there seemed to be a great many ships, large and small, alongside the docks or anchored in the river. Hastily she avoided looking at the ships.
