Tear had been built on flat land, with barely a bump. Down muddy dirt streets between the warehouses, she could see houses and inns and taverns of wood and stone. Their roofs of slate or tile had oddly sharp corners, and some rose to a point. Beyond these, she could make out a high wall of dark gray stone, and behind it the tops of towers with balconies high around them and white-domed palaces. The domes had a squared shape to them, and the tower tops looked pointed, like some of the roofs outside the wall. All in all, Tear was easily as big as Caemlyn or Tar Valon, and if not so beautiful as either, it was still one of the great cities. Yet she found it hard to look at anything but the Stone of Tear.

ʃi hæd hɝɾ ʌv ɪɾ ɪn stɔɹiz, hɝd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst fɔɹtʃɹəs ɪn ðə wɝld ən ði oʊldəst, ðə fɝs bɪlt æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, jɛt nʌθɪŋ hæd pɹipɛɹɾ əɹ fəɹ ðɪs saɪt. ət fɝst ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ə hjudʒ, ɡɹeɪ stoʊn hɪl əɹ ə smɔl, bæɹən maʊntən kʌvɝɪŋ hʌnʒɹədz ə haɪdz, ɪts lɛŋθ stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ fɹəm ði ɛɹɪnɪn wɛs θɹu ðə wɔl ən ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. ivən æftɝ ʃi sɔ ðə hjudʒ bænɝ flæpɪŋ fɹəm ɪts ɡɹeɪɾəst haɪt - θɹi waɪt kɹɛsən munz slæntɪŋ əkɹɔs ə fil hæf ɹɛd, hæf ɡoʊld; ə bænɝ weɪvɪŋ ət lis θɹi hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əbʌv ðə ɹɪvɝ, jɛt lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə bi klɪɹli sin ət ðət haɪt - ivən æftɝ ʃi meɪɾ aʊt bæɾəlmənts ən taʊɝz, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə bɪliv ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ hæd bɪn bɪlt ɹæðɝ ðən kɑɹvd aʊɾ ʌv ə maʊntən ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ.

She had heard of it in stories, heard that it was the greatest fortress in the world and the oldest, the first built after the Breaking of the World, yet nothing had prepared her for this sight. At first she thought it was a huge, gray stone hill or a small, barren mountain covering hundreds of hides, its length stretching from the Erinin west through the wall and into the city. Even after she saw the huge banner flapping from its greatest height - three white crescent moons slanting across a field half red, half gold; a banner waving at least three hundred paces above the river, yet large enough to be clearly seen at that height - even after she made out battlements and towers, it was difficult to believe the Stone of Tear had been built rather than carved out of a mountain already there.

"meɪd wɪð ðə paʊɝ," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd. ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə stoʊn, tu. "floʊz ə ɝθ woʊvən tə dʒɹɔ stoʊn fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɛɹ tə bɹɪŋ ɪt fɹəm ɛvɹi kɔɹnɝ ə ðə wɝld, ən ɝθ ən faɪɝ tə meɪk ɪɾ ɔl ɪn wʌn pis, wɪθaʊt sim əɹ dʒɔɪn əɹ mɔɹɾɝ. əɾəən sədaɪ sɛz ðə taʊɝ kəd nɑt də ɪt, tədeɪ. stʃɹeɪnʒ, ɡɪvən haʊ ðə haɪ lɔɹdz fil kənsɝnɪŋ ðə paʊɝ naʊ."

"Made with the Power," Elayne murmured. She was staring at the Stone, too. "Flows of Earth woven to draw stone from the ground, Air to bring it from every corner of the world, and Earth and Fire to make it all in one piece, without seam or joint or mortar. Atuan Sedai says the Tower could not do it, today. Strange, given how the High Lords feel concerning the Power now."

"aɪ θɪŋk," nɪneɪiv sɛd sɔfli, aɪɪŋ ðə dɑkmən muvɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛm, "ðæt ɡɪvən ðət vɛɹi θɪŋ, wi ʃəd nɑt mɛnʃən sɝɾən ʌðɝ θɪŋz əlaʊd." ɪleɪn əpɪɹd tɔɹn bɪtwin ɪndɪɡneɪʃən - ʃi hæd spoʊkən vɛɹi sɔfli - ən əɡɹimənt; ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ əɡɹid wɪð nɪneɪiv tu ɔfən ən tu ɹɛɾəli tə suɾ ɛɡwin.

"I think," Nynaeve said softly, eyeing the dockmen moving around them, "that given that very thing, we should not mention certain other things aloud." Elayne appeared torn between indignation - she had spoken very softly - and agreement; the Daughter-Heir agreed with Nynaeve too often and too readily to suit Egwene.

oʊnli wən nɪneɪiv ɪz ɹaɪt, ʃi ədmɪɾəd tə hɝsɛlf ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. ə wʊmən u wɔɹ ðə ɹɪŋ, əɹ wɑz ivən əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð tɑɹ vəlɑn, wəd bi wɑtʃt hɪɹ. ðə bɛɹfʊt, lɛðɝ-vɛstəd dɑkmən wɝ nɑt peɪɪŋ ðə θɹi ʌv əm ɛni maɪn əz ðeɪ hɝiɾ əbaʊt, kæɹiɪŋ beɪlz əɹ kɹeɪts ɑn ðɛɹ bæks əz ɔfən əz ɑn bæɹoʊz. ə stʃɹɔŋ oʊɾɝ ə fɪʃ hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ; ðə nɛks θɹi dɑks hæd dʌzənz ə smɔl fɪʃɪŋ boʊts klʌstɝɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm, dʒʌs laɪk ðoʊz ɪn ðə dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪn ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi. ʃɝtləs mɛn ən bɛɹfʊt wɪmən wɝ hɔɪstɪŋ bæskəts ə fɪʃ aʊɾ ə ðə boʊts, maʊnz ə sɪlvɝ ən bɹɑnz ən ɡɹin, ən kʌlɝz ʃi hæd nɛvɝ səspɛktəd fɪʃ maɪt bi, sətʃ əz bɹaɪt ɹɛd, ən dip blu, ən bɹɪljən jɛloʊ, səm wɪð stʃɹaɪps əɹ splətʃəz ʌv waɪɾ ən ʌðɝ kʌlɝz.

Only when Nynaeve is right, she admitted to herself grudgingly. A woman who wore the ring, or was even associated with Tar Valon, would be watched here. The barefoot, leather-vested dockmen were not paying the three of them any mind as they hurried about, carrying bales or crates on their backs as often as on barrows. A strong odor of fish hung in the air; the next three docks had dozens of small fishing boats clustered around them, just like those in the drawing in the Amyrlin's study. Shirtless men and barefoot women were hoisting baskets of fish out of the boats, mounds of silver and bronze and green, and colors she had never suspected fish might be, such as bright red, and deep blue, and brilliant yellow, some with stripes or splotches of white and other colors.

ʃi loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs fəɹ ɪleɪnz ɪɹ əloʊn. "ʃi ɪz ɹaɪt, kɛɹɪlə. ɹɪmɛmbɝ waɪ jə ɑɹ kɛɹɪlə." ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnt nɪneɪiv tə hɪɹ sətʃ ædmɪʃənz. hɝ feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ wən ʃi hɝd, bʌɾ ɛɡwin kəd fil sæɾəsfækʃən ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ fɹəm əɹ laɪk hit fɹəm ə kʊk stoʊv.

She lowered her voice for Elayne's ear alone. "She is right, Caryla. Remember why you are Caryla." She did not want Nynaeve to hear such admissions. Her face did not change when she heard, but Egwene could feel satisfaction radiating from her like heat from a cook stove.

nɪneɪivz blæk stæljən wɑz dʒʌs biɪŋ loʊɝd tə ðə dɑk; seɪlɝz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi kæɹid ðɛɹ tæk ɔf ðə ʃɪp ən sɪmpli dʌmpt ɪɾ ɑn ðə wɛt stoʊnz ə ðə dɑk. nɪneɪiv ɡlænst ət ðə hɔɹsəz ən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ - ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz tə tɛl əm tə sæɾəl ðɛɹ ænəməlz - ðən kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn, taɪt-lɪpt, əz ɪf ɪt hæd kɑst əɹ ən ɛfɝt. ʃi ɡeɪv əɹ bɹeɪd wʌn hɑɹd tʌɡ. bɪfɔɹ ðə slɪŋ wɑz wɛl aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ, nɪneɪiv tɔs ðə blu-stʃɹaɪp sæɾəl blæŋkəɾ əkɹɔs ðə blæks bæk ən hɔɪstəɾ əɹ haɪ-kæntəl sæɾəl ətɑp ɪt. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən lʊk ət ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən.

Nynaeve's black stallion was just being lowered to the dock; sailors had already carried their tack off the ship and simply dumped it on the wet stones of the dock. Nynaeve glanced at the horses and opened her mouth - Egwene was sure it was to tell them to saddle their animals - then closed it again, tight-lipped, as if it had cost her an effort. She gave her braid one hard tug. Before the sling was well out of the way, Nynaeve tossed the blue-striped saddle blanket across the black's back and hoisted her high-cantled saddle atop it. She did not even look at the other two women.

ɛɡwin wɑz nɑɾ æŋkʃəs tə ɹaɪɾ ət ðət moʊmənt - ðə moʊʃən ʌv ə hɔɹs maɪt bi tu kloʊz tə ðə moʊʃən ə ðə dɑɹɾɝ fəɹ əɹ stʌmək - bʌɾ ənʌðɝ lʊk ət ðoʊz mʌɾi stʃɹits kənvɪns hɝ. hɝ ʃuz wɝ stɝɾi, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪ hævɪŋ tə klin mʌɾ ɔf ðɛm, əɹ hævɪŋ tə hoʊld əɹ skɝts ʌp əz ʃi wɔkt, iðɝ. ʃi sæɾəld mɪs kwɪkli ən klaɪmd ɑntu hɝ bæk, sɛɾəlɪŋ əɹ skɝts, bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd dɪsaɪd ðə mʌd maɪt nɑt bi soʊ bæɾ æftɝ ɔl. ə lɪɾəl niɾəlwɝk ɑn ðə dɑɹɾɝ - ɪleɪn hæd dʌn ɪɾ ɔl, ðɪs taɪm; ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ soʊɾ ə vɛɹi faɪn stɪtʃ - hæd dɪvaɪɾəd ɔl ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz naɪsli fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ əstʃɹaɪd.

Egwene was not anxious to ride at that moment - the motion of a horse might be too close to the motion of the Darter for her stomach - but another look at those muddy streets convinced her. Her shoes were sturdy, but she would not enjoy having to clean mud off them, or having to hold her skirts up as she walked, either. She saddled Mist quickly and climbed onto her back, settling her skirts, before she could decide the mud might not be so bad after all. A little needlework on the Darter - Elayne had done it all, this time; the Daughter-Heir sewed a very fine stitch - had divided all their dresses nicely for riding astride.

nɪneɪivz feɪs peɪl fəɹ ə moʊmənt wən ʃi swʌŋ ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl ən ðə stæljən dɪsaɪɾɪd tə fɹɪsk. ʃi kɛpt ə taɪt-maʊðd ɡɹɪp ɑn hɝsɛlf ən ə fɝm hæn ɑn əɹ ɹeɪnz ən sun hæɾ ɪm ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ hæd ɹɪɾən sloʊli pæs ðə wɛɹhaʊzɪz, ʃi kəd spik. "wi nid tə loʊkeɪt liɑnʒɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz wɪθaʊɾ əm lɝnɪŋ wəɹ æskɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm. ðeɪ ʃʊɹli noʊ wəɹ kʌmɪŋ - ðət sʌmwʌn ɪz, ət list - bʌɾ aɪ wəd laɪk əm nɑt tə noʊ wəɹ hɪɹ əntɪl ɪts tu leɪt fəɹ ðɛm." ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "aɪ kənfɛs aɪ hæv nɑt θɔɾ ʌv ɛni weɪ tə də ðɪs. jɛt. də iðɝ ə juv ɛni sədʒɛstʃənz?"

Nynaeve's face paled for a moment when she swung into her saddle and the stallion decided to frisk. She kept a tight-mouthed grip on herself and a firm hand on her reins and soon had him under control. By the time they had ridden slowly past the warehouses, she could speak. "We need to locate Liandrin and the others without them learning we are asking after them. They surely know we are coming - that someone is, at least - but I would like them not to know we are here until it is too late for them." She drew a deep breath. "I confess I have not thought of any way to do this. Yet. Do either of you have any suggestions?"

"ə θif-teɪkɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən. nɪneɪiv fɹaʊn ət hɝ.

"A thief-taker," Elayne said without hesitation. Nynaeve frowned at her.

"ju min laɪk hʊɹɪn?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌt hʊɹɪn wɑz ɪn ðə sɝvəs ə hɪz kɪŋ. wʊdn ɛni θif-teɪkɝ hɪɹ sɝv ðə haɪ lɔɹdz?"

"You mean like Hurin?" Egwene said. "But Hurin was in the service of his king. Wouldn't any thief-taker here serve the High Lords?"

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən ɛɡwin ɛnvid ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ əɹ stʌmək. "jɛs, ðeɪ wʊd. bʌt θif-teɪkɝz ɑɹ nɑt laɪk ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz, əɹ ðə tɛɹən dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn. ðeɪ sɝv ðə ɹulɝ, bʌt pipəl u hæv bɪn ɹɑb səmtaɪmz peɪ ðɛm tə ɹɪtʃɹiv wʌt wɑz stoʊlən. ən ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ səmtaɪmz teɪk mʌni tə faɪn pipəl. ət list, ðeɪ də ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. aɪ kænɑt θɪŋk ɪts dɪfɹən hɪɹ ɪn tiɹ."

Elayne nodded, and for a moment Egwene envied the Daughter-Heir her stomach. "Yes, they would. But thief-takers are not like the Queen's Guards, or the Tairen Defenders of the Stone. They serve the ruler, but people who have been robbed sometimes pay them to retrieve what was stolen. And they also sometimes take money to find people. At least, they do in Caemlyn. I cannot think it is different here in Tear."

"ðɛn wi teɪk ɹumz əɾ ən ɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd, "æn æsk ði ɪnkipɝ tə faɪn əs ə θif-teɪkɝ."

"Then we take rooms at an inn," Egwene said, "and ask the innkeeper to find us a thief-taker."

"nɑɾ ən ɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ əz fɝmli əz ʃi ɡaɪɾəd ðə stæljən; ʃi nɛvɝ sim tə lɛt ði ænəməl ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. æftɝ ə moʊmənt ʃi mɑɾɝeɪtɪd əɹ toʊn ə lɪɾəl. "liɑnʒɹɪn, ət list, noʊz ʌs, ən wɪv tə əsum ði ʌðɝz du, tu. ðəl ʃʊɹli bi wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɪnz fəɹ huɛvɝ fɑloʊd ðə tʃɹeɪl ðeɪ spɹɪŋkəl bɪhaɪn ðɛm. aɪ min tə spɹɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃɹæp ɪn ðɛɹ feɪsəz, bʌt nɑt wɪð əs ɪnsaɪd. wɪl nɑt steɪ əɾ ən ɪn."

"Not an inn," Nynaeve said as firmly as she guided the stallion; she never seemed to let the animal get out of her control. After a moment she moderated her tone a little. "Liandrin, at least, knows us, and we have to assume the others do, too. They will surely be watching the inns for whoever followed the trail they sprinkled behind them. I mean to spring their trap in their faces, but not with us inside. We'll not stay at an inn."

ɛɡwin ɹəfjuz tə ɡɪv əɹ ðə sæɾəsfækʃən ʌv æskɪŋ.

Egwene refused to give her the satisfaction of asking.

"wɛɹ ðɛn?" ɪleɪnz bɹaʊ fɝoʊd. "ɪf aɪ meɪd maɪsɛlf noʊn - ən kəd meɪk ɛniwʌn bɪliv ɪt, ɪn ðiz kloʊðz ən wɪð noʊ ɛskɔɹt - wi wəd bi wɛlkəm baɪ moʊst ə ðə noʊbəl haʊsəz, ən vɛɹi laɪkli ɪn ðə stoʊn ɪtsɛlf - ðəɹ ɑɹ ɡʊd ɹileɪʃənz bɪtwin keɪɛmlɪn ən tiɹ - bʌt ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ kipɪŋ ɪt kwaɪət. ði ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi wəd noʊ bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl. aɪ kænɑt θɪŋk ʌv ɛniwɛɹ ɛls ɪksɛpt ən ɪn, nɪneɪiv. ənlɛs jə min tə ɡoʊ aʊt tə ə fɑɹm ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi, bʌt wɪl nɛvɝ faɪn əm fɹəm ðə kʌntʃɹi."

"Where then?" Elayne's brow furrowed. "If I made myself known - and could make anyone believe it, in these clothes and with no escort - we would be welcomed by most of the noble Houses, and very likely in the Stone itself - there are good relations between Caemlyn and Tear - but there would be no keeping it quiet. The entire city would know before nightfall. I cannot think of anywhere else except an inn, Nynaeve. Unless you mean to go out to a farm in the country, but we will never find them from the country."

nɪneɪiv ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin. "aɪ wɪl noʊ wən aɪ si ɪt. lemi lʊk."

Nynaeve glanced at Egwene. "I will know when I see it. Let me look."

ɪleɪnz fɹaʊn swɛp fɹəm nɪneɪiv tə ɛɡwin ən bæk əɡɛn. " 'du nɑt kʌɾ ɔf jəɹ ɪɹz kəz jə də nɑt laɪk jəɹ ɪɹɪŋz,' " ʃi mʌɾɝd.

Elayne's frown swept from Nynaeve to Egwene and back again. " 'Do not cut off your ears because you do not like your earrings,' " she muttered.

ɛɡwin pʊɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən fɝmli ɑn ðə stʃɹit ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ. əl bi bɝn ɪf əl lɛɾ əɹ θɪŋk aɪm ivən wʌndɝɪŋ!

Egwene put her attention firmly on the street they were riding along. I will be burned if I'll let her think I am even wondering!

ðəɹ wɝ nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni pipəl aʊt, nɑt kəmpɛɹd tə ðə stʃɹits ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. pɝhæps ðə θɪk mʌɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹit dɪskɝədʒ ðɛm. kɑɹts ən wæɡənz lɝtʃt pæst, moʊs pʊl baɪ ɑksən wɪð waɪd hɔɹnz, ðə kɑɹɾɝ əɹ wæɡənɪɹ wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd wɪð ə lɔŋ ɡoʊɾ ə səm peɪl, ɹɪdʒd wʊd. noʊ kæɹɪdʒɪz əɹ sɪdæn tʃɛɹz juz ðiz stʃɹits. ði oʊɾɝ ə fɪʃ hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ hɪɹ, tu, ən noʊ fju ʌv ðə mɛn u hɝid pæs kæɹid hjudʒ bæskəts fʊl ə fɪʃ ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. ðə ʃɑps dɪd nɑt lʊk pɹɑspɝəs; nʌn dɪspleɪd wɛɹz aʊtsaɪd, ən ɛɡwin sɛldəm sɔ ɛniwʌn ɡoʊ ɪn. ðə ʃɑps hæd saɪnz - ðə teɪlɝz niɾəl ən boʊlt ə klɔθ, ðə kʌtlɝz naɪf ən sɪzɝz, ðə wivɝz lum, ən ðə laɪk - bʌt ðə peɪn ɑn moʊst ə ðɛm wɑz pilɪŋ. ðə fju ɪnz hæd saɪnz ɪn əz bæɾ ə steɪt, ən lʊk noʊ bɪziɝ. ðə smɔl haʊsəz kɹaʊɾəd bɪtwin ɪnz ən ʃɑps ɔfən hæd taɪlz əɹ sleɪts mɪsɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ ɹufs. ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə tiɹ, ət list, wɑz pʊɹ. ən fɹəm wʌt ʃi sɔ ɑn ðə feɪsəz, fju ʌv ðə pipəl hɪɹ kɛɹd tə tʃɹaɪ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ðeɪ wɝ muvɪŋ, wɝkɪŋ, bʌt moʊst ə ðɛm hæd ɡɪvən ʌp. fju əz mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ət θɹi wɪmən ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɛɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɔkt.

There were not a great many people out, not compared to the streets of Tar Valon. Perhaps the thick mud in the street discouraged them. Carts and wagons lurched past, most pulled by oxen with wide horns, the carter or wagoneer walking alongside with a long goad of some pale, ridged wood. No carriages or sedan chairs used these streets. The odor of fish hung in the air here, too, and no few of the men who hurried past carried huge baskets full of fish on their backs. The shops did not look prosperous; none displayed wares outside, and Egwene seldom saw anyone go in. The shops had signs - the tailor's needle and bolt of cloth, the cutler's knife and scissors, the weaver's loom, and the like - but the paint on most of them was peeling. The few inns had signs in as bad a state, and looked no busier. The small houses crowded between inns and shops often had tiles or slates missing from their roofs. This part of Tear, at least, was poor. And from what she saw on the faces, few of the people here cared to try any longer. They were moving, working, but most of them had given up. Few as much as glanced at three women riding where everyone else walked.

ðə mɛn wɔɹ bæɡi bɹitʃɪz, juʒəwəli taɪɾ ət ði æŋkəl. oʊnli ə hændfʊl wɔɹ koʊts, lɔŋ, dɑɹk ɡɑɹməns ðət fɪɾ ɑɹmz ən tʃɛs taɪtli, ðən bɪkeɪm lusɝ bɪloʊ ðə weɪst. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ mɛn ɪn loʊ ʃuz ðən ɪn buts, bʌt moʊst wɛn bɛɹfʊɾ ɪn ðə mʌd. ə ɡʊd mɛni wɔɹ noʊ koʊɾ əɹ ʃɝɾ əɾ ɔl, ən hæd ðɛɹ bɹitʃɪz hɛld ʌp baɪ ə bɹɔd sæʃ, səmtaɪmz kʌlɝɾ ən ɔfən dɝɾi. səm hæd waɪd, kɑnɪkəl stʃɹɔ hæts ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz, ən ə fju, klɔθ kæps ðət sæɡd daʊn wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə feɪs. ðə wɪmənz dʒɹɛsəz hæd haɪ nɛks, ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðɛɹ tʃɪnz, ən hɛmz ðət stɑpt ət ði æŋkəl. mɛni hæd ʃɔɹɾ eɪpɹənz ɪn peɪl kʌlɝz, səmtaɪmz tu əɹ θɹi, itʃ smɔlɝ ðən ðə wʌn bɪniθ ɪt, ən moʊst wɔɹ ðə seɪm stʃɹɔ hæts əz ðə mɛn, bʌt daɪd tə kɑmpləmən ði eɪpɹənz.

The men wore baggy breeches, usually tied at the ankle. Only a handful wore coats, long, dark garments that fit arms and chest tightly, then became looser below the waist. There were more men in low shoes than in boots, but most went barefoot in the mud. A good many wore no coat or shirt at all, and had their breeches held up by a broad sash, sometimes colored and often dirty. Some had wide, conical straw hats on their heads, and a few, cloth caps that sagged down one side of the face. The women's dresses had high necks, right up to their chins, and hems that stopped at the ankle. Many had short aprons in pale colors, sometimes two or three, each smaller than the one beneath it, and most wore the same straw hats as the men, but dyed to complement the aprons.

ɪt wɑz ɑn ə wʊmən ðət ʃi fɝst sɔ haʊ ðoʊz u wɔɹ ʃuz dɛlt wɪð ðə mʌd. ðə wʊmən hæd smɔl wʊɾən plætfɔɹmz taɪd tə ðə soʊlz ə hɝ ʃuz, lɪftɪŋ əm tu hænz aʊɾ ə ðə mʌd; ʃi wɔkt əlɔŋ əz ɪf əɹ fit wɝ plæntəd fɝmli ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɛɡwin sɔ ʌðɝz wɛɹɪŋ ðə plætfɔɹmz æftɝ ðæt, mɛn əz wɛl əz wɪmən. səm ə ðə wɪmən wɛn bɛɹfʊt, bʌt nɑɾ əz mɛni əz ðə mɛn.

It was on a woman that she first saw how those who wore shoes dealt with the mud. The woman had small wooden platforms tied to the soles of her shoes, lifting them two hands out of the mud; she walked along as if her feet were planted firmly on the ground. Egwene saw others wearing the platforms after that, men as well as women. Some of the women went barefoot, but not as many as the men.

ʃi wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ wɪtʃ ʃɑp maɪt sɛl ðoʊz plætfɔɹmz, wən nɪneɪiv sʌɾənli tɝn əɹ blæk daʊn ən æliweɪ bɪtwin ə lɔŋ, nɛɹoʊ tu-stɔɹi haʊs ən ə stoʊn-wɔl pɑɾɝz ʃɑp. ɛɡwin ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð ɪleɪn - ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʃɹʌɡd - ən ðən ðeɪ fɑloʊd. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ nɪneɪiv wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ əɹ waɪ - ən ʃi mɛn tə hæv wɝdz wɪð əɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt - bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt min tə bɪkʌm sɛpɝeɪɾəd, iðɝ.

She was wondering which shop might sell those platforms, when Nynaeve suddenly turned her black down an alleyway between a long, narrow two-story house and a stone-walled potter's shop. Egwene exchanged glances with Elayne - the Daughter-Heir shrugged - and then they followed. Egwene did not know where Nynaeve was going or why - and she meant to have words with her about it - but she did not mean to become separated, either.

ði æli sʌɾənli lɛɾ ɪndə ə smɔl jɑɹd bɪhaɪn ðə haʊs, fɛnst ɪn baɪ ðə bɪldɪŋz ɝaʊn ɪt. nɪneɪiv hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən taɪɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz tə ə fɪɡ tʃɹi, wɛɹ ðə stæljən kəd nɑt ɹitʃ ðə ɡɹin θɪŋz spɹaʊɾɪŋ ɪn ə vɛdʒtəbəl pætʃ ðət tʊk ʌp hæf ðə jɑɹd. ə laɪn ə stoʊnz hæd bɪn leɪd tə meɪk ə pæθ tə ðə bæk dɔɹ. nɪneɪiv stʃɹoʊd tə ðə dɔɹ ən nɑkt.

The alley suddenly let into a small yard behind the house, fenced in by the buildings around it. Nynaeve had already dismounted and tied her reins to a fig tree, where the stallion could not reach the green things sprouting in a vegetable patch that took up half the yard. A line of stones had been laid to make a path to the back door. Nynaeve strode to the door and knocked.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" ɛɡwin dɪmændəɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. "waɪ ɑɹ wi stɑpɪŋ hɪɹ?"

"What is it?" Egwene demanded in spite of herself. "Why are we stopping here?"

"dɪd jə nɑt si ði ɝbz ɪn ðə fɹʌnt wɪndoʊz?" nɪneɪiv nɑkt əɡɛn.

"Did you not see the herbs in the front windows?" Nynaeve knocked again.

"ɝbz?" ɪleɪn sɛd.

"Herbs?" Elayne said.

"eɪ wɪzdəm," ɛɡwin toʊld əɹ əz ʃi ɡɑt daʊn fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl ən taɪd mɪst əlɔŋsaɪd ðə blæk. ɡeɪɾɪn ɪz noʊ ɡʊd neɪm fəɹ ə hɔɹs. dʌz ʃi θɪŋk aɪ doʊnt noʊ hu ʃi minz ɪt fɔɹ? "nɪneɪiv əz faʊn hɝsɛlf ə wɪzdəm, əɹ sikɝ, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ kɔl əɹ hɪɹ."

"A Wisdom," Egwene told her as she got down from her saddle and tied Mist alongside the black. Gaidin is no good name for a horse. Does she think I don't know who she means it for? "Nynaeve has found herself a Wisdom, or Seeker, or whatever they call her here."

ə wʊmən oʊpən ðə dɔɹ dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə lʊk aʊt səspɪʃəsli. ət fɝst ɛɡwin θɔt ʃi wɑz staʊt, bʌt ðən ðə wʊmən oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ. ʃi wɑz sɝɾənli wɛl pæɾəd, bʌt ðə weɪ ʃi muv spoʊk ə mʌsəl ʌndɝniθ. ʃi lʊkt əz stʃɹɔŋ əz mɪstʃɹəs luhən, ən səm ɪn ɛmənz fil kleɪmd ælsbɛt luhən wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz stʃɹɔŋ əz əɹ hʌzbənd. ɪt wɑz nɑt tʃɹu, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt fɑɹ ɹɔŋ.

A woman opened the door just enough to look out suspiciously. At first Egwene thought she was stout, but then the woman opened the door the rest of the way. She was certainly well padded, but the way she moved spoke of muscle underneath. She looked as strong as Mistress Luhhan, and some in Emond's Field claimed Alsbet Luhhan was almost as strong as her husband. It was not true, but it was not far wrong.

"haʊ kən aɪ hɛlp ju?" ðə wʊmən sɛɾ ɪn ən æksɛn laɪk ði æmɪɝlɪnz. hɝ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ wɑz ɝeɪnʒd ɪn θɪk kɝlz ðət hʌŋ daʊn ðə saɪdz ə hɝ hɛd, ən əɹ θɹi eɪpɹənz wɝ ɪn ʃeɪdz ʌv ɡɹin, itʃ slaɪtli dɑɹkɝ ðən ðə wʌn bɪloʊ, bʌɾ ivən ðə tɑpmoʊs peɪl. "wɪtʃ wʌn ə jə nidz mi?"

"How can I help you?" the woman said in an accent like the Amyrlin's. Her gray hair was arranged in thick curls that hung down the sides of her head, and her three aprons were in shades of green, each slightly darker than the one below, but even the topmost pale. "Which one of you needs me?"

"aɪ du," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ nid sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ə kwizi stʌmək. ən pɝhæps wʌn ə maɪ kəmpænjənz dʌz, tu. ðəɾ ɪz, ɪf wiv kʌm tə ðə ɹaɪt pleɪs?"

"I do," Nynaeve said. "I need something for a queasy stomach. And perhaps one of my companions does, too. That is, if we've come to the right place?"

"jɔɹ nɑt tɛɹən," ðə wʊmən sɛd. "aɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn ðət baɪ jəɹ kloʊðz, bɪfɔɹ jə spoʊk. aɪm kɔl mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə. aɪm kɔld ə waɪz wʊmən, tu, bʌɾ aɪm oʊld ɪnʌf nɑt tə tʃɹʌs ðət tə kɑk ə sim. jə kʌm, ən əl ɡɪv jə sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ jəɹ stʌmək."

"You're not Tairen," the woman said. "I should have known that by your clothes, before you spoke. I'm called Mother Guenna. I am called a Wise Woman, too, but I'm old enough not to trust that to caulk a seam. You come, and I will give you something for your stomach."

ɪt wɑz ə nit kɪtʃən, ðoʊ nɑt lɑɹdʒ, wɪð kɑpɝ pɑts hæŋɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔl, ən dʒɹaɪɾ ɝbz ən sɔsɪdʒɪz fɹəm ðə silɪŋ. sɛvɹəl tɔl kʌbɝdz ə peɪl wʊd hæd dɔɹz kɑɹvd wɪð səm sɔɹɾ ə tɔl ɡɹæs. ðə teɪbəl hæd bɪn skɹʌbd ɔlmoʊst waɪt, ən ðə bæks ə ðə tʃɛɹz wɝ kɑɹvd wɪð flaʊɝz. ə pɑɾ ə fɪʃi-smɛlɪŋ sup wɑz sɪmɝɪŋ ətɑp ðə stoʊn stoʊv, ən ə kɛɾəl wɪð ə spaʊt, dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə stim. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ faɪɝ ɑn ðə stoʊn hɑɹθ, fəɹ wɪtʃ ɛɡwin wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɡɹeɪtfəl; ðə stoʊv æɾəd ɪnʌf tə ðə hit, ðoʊ mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə sim nɑt tə noʊɾəs ɪɾ əɾ ɔl. dɪʃəz laɪn ðə mæntəl, ən mɔɹ wɝ stæk nitli ɑn ʃɛlvz tə iðɝ saɪd. ðə flɔɹ lʊkt əz ɪf ɪt hæd dʒʌs bɪn swɛpt.

It was a neat kitchen, though not large, with copper pots hanging on the wall, and dried herbs and sausages from the ceiling. Several tall cupboards of pale wood had doors carved with some sort of tall grass. The table had been scrubbed almost white, and the backs of the chairs were carved with flowers. A pot of fishy-smelling soup was simmering atop the stone stove, and a kettle with a spout, just beginning to steam. There was no fire on the stone hearth, for which Egwene was more than grateful; the stove added enough to the heat, though Mother Guenna seemed not to notice it at all. Dishes lined the mantel, and more were stacked neatly on shelves to either side. The floor looked as if it had just been swept.

mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə kloʊz ðə dɔɹ æftɝ ðɛm, ən əz ʃi wɑz kɹɔsɪŋ ðə kɪtʃən tə hɝ kʌbɝdz, nɪneɪiv sɛd, "wɪtʃ ti wɪl jə ɡɪv mi? tʃeɪnlif? əɹ bluwɝt?"

Mother Guenna closed the door after them, and as she was crossing the kitchen to her cupboards, Nynaeve said, "Which tea will you give me? Chainleaf? Or bluewort?"

"aɪ wəɾ ɪf aɪ hæɾ ɛni ʌv iðɝ." mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə ɹuɾəd ɪn ðə ʃɛlvz ə moʊmən ən keɪm aʊt wɪð ə stoʊn dʒɑɹ. "sɪns aɪv hæd noʊ taɪm tə ɡlin ə leɪt, əl ɡɪv jə ə bɹu ʌv mɑɹʃwaɪt livz."

"I would if I had any of either." Mother Guenna rooted in the shelves a moment and came out with a stone jar. "Since I've had no time to glean of late, I will give you a brew of marshwhite leaves."

"aɪ æm nɑt fəmɪljɝ wɪð ðæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd sloʊli.

"I am not familiar with that," Nynaeve said slowly.

"ɪt wɝks əz wɛl əz tʃeɪnlif, bʌɾ ɪts ə baɪt tə ðə teɪst səm doʊn kɛɹ fɔɹ." ðə bɪɡ wʊmən spɹɪŋkəl dʒɹaɪɾ ən bɹoʊkən livz ɪndə ə blu tipɑɾ ən kæɹiɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ tə ðə faɪɝpleɪs tə æd hɑt wɔɾɝ. "du jə fɑloʊ ðə kɹæft, ðɛn? sɪt." ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə teɪbəl wɪð ə hæn hoʊldɪŋ tu blu-ɡleɪz kʌps ʃi hæd teɪkən fɹəm ðə mæntəl. "sɪt, ən wɪl tɔk. wɪtʃ wʌn ə jə hæz ði ʌðɝ stʌmək?"

"It works as well as chainleaf, but it has a bite to the taste some don't care for." The big woman sprinkled dried and broken leaves into a blue teapot and carried it over to the fireplace to add hot water. "Do you follow the craft, then? Sit." She gestured to the table with a hand holding two blue-glazed cups she had taken from the mantel. "Sit, and we'll talk. Which one of you has the other stomach?"

"aɪ æm faɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd kæʒəwəli əz ʃi tʊk ə tʃɛɹ. "ɑɹ jə kwizi, kɛɹɪlə?" ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʃʊk əɹ hɛd wɪð pɝhæps ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɛksæspɝeɪʃən.

"I am fine," Egwene said casually as she took a chair. "Are you queasy, Caryla?" The Daughter-Heir shook her head with perhaps a touch of exasperation.

"noʊ mæɾɝ." ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən pɔɹɾ aʊɾ ə kʌp ə dɑɹk lɪkwəd fəɹ nɪneɪiv, ðən sæɾ əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl fɹəm hɝ. "aɪ meɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ tu, bʌt mɑɹʃwaɪt ti kips lɔŋɡɝ ðən sɔltəd fɪʃ. ɪt wɝks bɛɾɝ ðə lɔŋɡɝ ɪt sɪts, tu, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ ɡɹoʊz mɔɹ bɪɾɝ. meɪks ə ɹeɪs bɪtwin haʊ mʌtʃ jə nid jəɹ stʌmək sɛɾəld ən wʌt jəɹ tʌŋ kən stænd. dʒɹɪŋk, ɡɝl." æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi fɪl ðə sɛkən kʌp ən tʊk ə sɪp. "ju si? ɪɾəl nɑt hɝt ju."

"No matter." The gray-haired woman poured out a cup of dark liquid for Nynaeve, then sat across the table from her. "I made enough for two, but marshwhite tea keeps longer than salted fish. It works better the longer it sits, too, but it also grows more bitter. Makes a race between how much you need your stomach settled and what your tongue can stand. Drink, girl." After a moment, she filled the second cup and took a sip. "You see? It will not hurt you."

nɪneɪiv ɹeɪzd əɹ oʊn kʌp, meɪkɪŋ ə smɔl saʊn ə dɪsplɛʒɝ ət ðə fɝs teɪst. wən ʃi loʊɝd ðə kʌp əɡɛn, ðoʊ, hɝ feɪs wɑz smuð. "ɪɾ ɪz dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl bɪɾɝ pɝhæps. tɛl mi, mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə, wɪl wɪv tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðɪs ɹeɪn ən mʌd mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ?"

Nynaeve raised her own cup, making a small sound of displeasure at the first taste. When she lowered the cup again, though, her face was smooth. "It is just a little bitter perhaps. Tell me, Mother Guenna, will we have to put up with this rain and mud much longer?"

ði oʊldɝ wʊmən fɹaʊnd, pɑɹsəlɪŋ dɪsplɛʒɝ əmʌŋ ðə θɹi ʌv əm bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɛɾəld ɑn nɪneɪiv. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ə si foʊk wɪndfɪndɝ, ɡɝl," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ɪf aɪ kəd tɛl ðə wɛðɝ, aɪd sunɝ stɪk lɪv sɪlvɝpaɪk daʊn maɪ dʒɹɛs ðən ədmɪɾ ɪt. ðə dɪfɛndɝz teɪk ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ fəɹ nɛks tə ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk. naʊ, dʒju fɑloʊ ðə kɹæft əɹ nɑt? jə lʊk əz ɪf juv bɪn tʃɹævlɪŋ. wʌɾ ɪz ɡʊd fəɹ fətiɡ?" ʃi bɑɹk sʌɾənli.

The older woman frowned, parceling displeasure among the three of them before she settled on Nynaeve. "I am not a Sea Folk Windfinder, girl," she said quietly. "If I could tell the weather, I'd sooner stick live silverpike down my dress than admit it. The Defenders take that sort of thing for next to Aes Sedai work. Now, do you follow the craft or not? You look as if you have been traveling. What is good for fatigue?" she barked suddenly.

"flætwɝt ti," nɪneɪiv sɛd kɑmli, "ɔɹ ændɪleɪ ɹut. sɪns jə æsk kwɛstʃənz, wʌt wəd jə də tə iz bɝθɪŋ?"

"Flatwort tea," Nynaeve said calmly, "or andilay root. Since you ask questions, what would you do to ease birthing?"

mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə snɔɹɾɪd. "əplaɪ wɔɹm taʊəlz, tʃaɪld, ən pɝhæps ɡɪv əɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪɾəfɛnəl ɪf ɪt wɑz ən ɪspɛʃli hɑɹd bɝθ. ə wʊmən nidz noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt, ən ə suðɪŋ hænd. kæn jə θɪŋk ʌv ə kwɛstʃən ɛni kʌntʃɹi fɑɹmwaɪf kəd nɑɾ ænsɝ? wʌt dʒju ɡɪv fəɹ peɪnz ɪn ðə hɑɹt? ðə kɪlɪŋ kaɪnd."

Mother Guenna snorted. "Apply warm towels, child, and perhaps give her a little whitefennel if it was an especially hard birth. A woman needs no more than that, and a soothing hand. Can't you think of a question any country farmwife could not answer? What do you give for pains in the heart? The killing kind."

"paʊɾɝd ɡindɪn blɑsəm ɑn ðə tʌŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd kɹɪspli. "ɪf ə wʊmən əz baɪɾɪŋ peɪnz ɪn əɹ bɛli ən spɪts ʌp blʌd, wʌt dʒju du?"

"Powdered gheandin blossom on the tongue," Nynaeve said crisply. "If a woman has biting pains in her belly and spits up blood, what do you do?"

ðeɪ sɛɾəld daʊn əz ɪf tɛstɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ, tɔsɪŋ kwɛstʃənz ən ænsɝz bæk ən fɔɹθ fæstɝ ən fæstɝ. səmtaɪmz ðə kwɛstʃənɪŋ læɡd ə moʊmənt wən wʌn spoʊk ʌv ə plæn ði ʌðɝ nu oʊnli baɪ ənʌðɝ neɪm, bʌt ðeɪ pɪkt ʌp spiɾ əɡɛn, ɑɹɡjuɪŋ ðə mɛɹəts ə tɪŋktʃɝz əɡɛns tiz, sɑvz əɡɛns poʊltəsəz, ən wən wʌn wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ənʌðɝ. sloʊli, ɔl ðə kwɪk kwɛstʃənz bɪɡæn ʃɪftɪŋ təwɔɹd ði ɝbz ən ɹuts wʌn nu ðət ði ʌðɝ dɪd nɑt, dɪɡɪŋ fəɹ nɑlədʒ. ɛɡwin bɪɡæn tə ɡɹoʊ ɪɹəɾəbəl lɪsnɪŋ.

They settled down as if testing each other, tossing questions and answers back and forth faster and faster. Sometimes the questioning lagged a moment when one spoke of a plant the other knew only by another name, but they picked up speed again, arguing the merits of tinctures against teas, salves against poultices, and when one was better than another. Slowly, all the quick questions began shifting toward the herbs and roots one knew that the other did not, digging for knowledge. Egwene began to grow irritable listening.

"æftɝ jə ɡɪv ɪm ðə boʊnknɪt," mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə wɑz seɪɪŋ, "ju ɹæp ðə bɹoʊkən lɪm ɪn taʊəlɪŋ soʊkt ɪn wɔɾɝ wɛɹ juv bɔɪl blu ɡoʊtfloʊɝz - oʊnli ðə blu, maɪnd!" - nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli - "æn əz hɑɾ əz i kən stæn ɪt. wʌn pɑɹt blu ɡoʊtfloʊɝz tə tɛn ʌv wɔɾɝ, noʊ wikɝ. ɹipleɪs ðə taʊəlz əz sun əz ðeɪ stɑp stimɪŋ, ən kip ɪɾ ʌp ɔl deɪ. ðə boʊn wɪl nɪt twaɪs əz fæst əz wɪð boʊnknɪɾ əloʊn, ən twaɪs əz stʃɹɔŋ."

"After you give him the boneknit," Mother Guenna was saying, "you wrap the broken limb in toweling soaked in water where you've boiled blue goatflowers - only the blue, mind!" - Nynaeve nodded impatiently - "and as hot as he can stand it. One part blue goatflowers to ten of water, no weaker. Replace the towels as soon as they stop steaming, and keep it up all day. The bone will knit twice as fast as with boneknit alone, and twice as strong."

"aɪ wɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ju mɛnʃən juzɪŋ ʃipstɔŋ ɹut fəɹ aɪ peɪn. aɪv nɛvɝ hɝd - "

"I will remember that," Nynaeve said. "You mentioned using sheepstongue root for eye pain. I've never heard - "

ɛɡwin kəd stæn ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. "mɛɹiɪm," ʃi bɹoʊk ɪn, "du jə ɹɪli bɪliv jəl ɛvɝ nid tə noʊ ðiz θɪŋz əɡɛn? jə ɑɹ nɑɾ ə wɪzdəm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, əɹ əv jə fɝɡɑɾən?"

Egwene could stand it no longer. "Maryim," she broke in, "do you really believe you'll ever need to know these things again? You are not a Wisdom any longer, or have you forgotten?"

"aɪ hæv nɑt fɝɡɑɾən ɛniθɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ə taɪm wən jə wɝ əz iɡɝ tə lɝn nu θɪŋz əz aɪ æm."

"I have not forgotten anything," Nynaeve said sharply. "I remember a time when you were as eager to learn new things as I am."

"mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə," ɪleɪn sɛd blænli, "wʌt dʒju də fəɹ tu wɪmən u kænɑt stɑp ɑɹɡjuɪŋ?"

"Mother Guenna," Elayne said blandly, "what do you do for two women who cannot stop arguing?"

ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən pɝst əɹ lɪps ən fɹaʊn ət ðə teɪbəl. "juʒəwəli, mɛn əɹ wɪmən, aɪ tɛl əm tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm itʃ ʌðɝ. ðəɾ ɪz ðə bɛs θɪŋ, ən ði iziəst."

The gray-haired woman pursed her lips and frowned at the table. "Usually, men or women, I tell them to stay away from each other. That is the best thing, and the easiest."

"juʒəwəli?" ɪleɪn sɛd. "wʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ə ɹizən ðeɪ kænɑt steɪ əpɑɹt. seɪ ðeɪ ɑɹ sɪstɝz."

"Usually?" Elayne said. "What if there is a reason they cannot stay apart. Say they are sisters."

"aɪ də hæv ə weɪ tə meɪk ən ɑɹɡɝ stɑp," ðə bɪɡ wʊmən sɛd sloʊli. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ aɪ ɝdʒ ɛniwʌn tə tʃɹaɪ, bʌt səm də kʌm tə mi." ɛɡwin θɔt ðəɹ wɑz ə səspɪʃən ʌv ə smaɪl ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ maʊθ. "aɪ tʃɑɹdʒ ə sɪlvɝ mɑɹk itʃ fəɹ wɪmən. tu fəɹ mɛn, kəz mɛn meɪk mɔɹ fʌs. ðəɹ ɑɹ səm wɪl baɪ ɛniθɪŋ, ɪf ɪt kɑsts ɪnʌf."

"I do have a way to make an arguer stop," the big woman said slowly. "It is not something I urge anyone to try, but some do come to me." Egwene thought there was a suspicion of a smile at the corners of her mouth. "I charge a silver mark each for women. Two for men, because men make more fuss. There are some will buy anything, if it costs enough."

"bʌt wʌɾ ɪz ðə kjʊɹ?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"But what is the cure?" Elayne asked.

"aɪ tɛl əm ðeɪv tə bɹɪŋ ði ʌðɝ wʌn hɪɹ wɪð ðɛm, ðə wʌn ðeɪ ɑɹɡju wɪð. boʊθ ɪkspɛk mi tə kwaɪət ði ʌðɝz tʌŋ." dɪspaɪt hɝsɛlf, ɛɡwin wɑz lɪsnɪŋ. ʃi noʊɾəst nɪneɪiv sim tə bi peɪɪŋ ʃɑɹp ətɛnʃən, əz wɛl. "wɛn ðeɪv peɪd mi," mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə kəntɪnjud, flɛksɪŋ wʌn hɛfti ɑɹm, "aɪ teɪk əm aʊt bæk ən stɪk ðɛɹ hɛdz ɪn maɪ ɹeɪn bæɹəl tɪl ðeɪ əɡɹi tə stɑp ðɛɹ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ."

"I tell them they have to bring the other one here with them, the one they argue with. Both expect me to quiet the other's tongue." Despite herself, Egwene was listening. She noticed Nynaeve seemed to be paying sharp attention, as well. "When they have paid me," Mother Guenna continued, flexing one hefty arm, "I take them out back and stick their heads in my rain barrel till they agree to stop their arguing."

ɪleɪn bɝst aʊt læfɪŋ.

Elayne burst out laughing.

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ meɪ hæv dʌn sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi laɪk ðət maɪsɛlf," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs ðət wɑz mʌtʃ tu laɪt. ɛɡwin hoʊpt əɹ oʊn ɪkspɹɛʃən lʊk nʌθɪŋ laɪk nɪneɪivz.

"I think I may have done something very like that myself," Nynaeve said in a voice that was much too light. Egwene hoped her own expression looked nothing like Nynaeve's.

"aɪd nɑt bi sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf jə hæv." mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə wɑz ɡɹɪnɪŋ oʊpənli naʊ. "aɪ tɛl əm ðə nɛks taɪm aɪ hɪɹ ðeɪv bɪn ɑɹɡjuɪŋ, əl də ɪt fəɹ fɹi, bʌɾ əl juz ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɪts ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl haʊ ɔfən ðə kjʊɹ wɝks, fəɹ mɛn ɪspɛʃli. ən ɪts ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl wʌɾ ɪts dʌn fəɹ maɪ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən. fəɹ səm ɹizən, nʌn ə ðə pipəl aɪ kjʊɹ ðɪs weɪ ɛvɝ tɛlz ɛniwʌn ɛls ðə dɪteɪlz, soʊ sʌmwʌn æsks fəɹ ðə kjʊɹ ɛvɹi fju mʌnθs. ɪf juv bɪn ful ɪnʌf tə it mədfɪʃ, jə də nɑt ɡoʊ ɝaʊn tɛlɪŋ pipəl. aɪ tʃɹʌs nʌn ə juv ɛni wɪʃ tə spɛn ə sɪlvɝ mɑɹk."

"I'd not be surprised if you have." Mother Guenna was grinning openly now. "I tell them the next time I hear they've been arguing, I will do it for free, but I'll use the river. It is remarkable how often the cure works, for men especially. And it is remarkable what it has done for my reputation. For some reason, none of the people I cure this way ever tells anyone else the details, so someone asks for the cure every few months. If you've been fool enough to eat mudfish, you do not go around telling people. I trust none of you have any wish to spend a silver mark."

"aɪ θɪŋk nɑt," ɛɡwin sɛd, ən ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪleɪn wən ʃi wɛn ɔf ɪn pilz ə læftɝ əɡɛn.

"I think not," Egwene said, and glared at Elayne when she went off in peals of laughter again.

"ɡʊd," ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən sɛd. "ðoʊz aɪ kjʊɹ ʌv ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əv ə tɛndənsi tə əvɔɪd mi laɪk stɪŋwid kɑɾ ɪn ðɛɹ nɛts, ənlɛs ðeɪ æktʃəli  teɪk sɪk, aɪm æm ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ jəɹ kʌmpəni. moʊst ə ðoʊz u kʌm ət pɹɛzənt wɑn sʌmθɪŋ tə teɪk əweɪ bæd dʒɹimz, ən ðeɪ ɡɹoʊ saʊɝ wən aɪ hæv nʌθɪŋ tə ɡɪv ðɛm." fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi slɪpt ɪndə ə fɹaʊn, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ tɛmpəlz. "ɪɾ ɪz ɡʊd tə si θɹi feɪsəz ðət də nɑt lʊk əz ɪf ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ lɛf bʌt tə dʒʌmp oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ən dʒɹaʊn. ɪf jə ɑɹ steɪɪŋ lɔŋ ɪn tɛɹ, jə mʌs kʌm si mi əɡɛn. ðə ɡɝl kɔl jə aɪm æm eɪlhuɪn. ðə nɛks taɪm, wɪl tɔk oʊvɝ səm ɡʊd si foʊk ti ɪnstɛɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ ðət kɝɾəlz jəɹ tʌŋ. laɪt, bʌɾ aɪ heɪt ðə teɪst ə mɑɹʃwaɪt; mədfɪʃ wəd teɪst swiɾɝ. ɪn fækt, juv hæv taɪm tə steɪ naʊ, əl bɹu ə pɑɾ ə tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ blæk. nɑt lɔŋ tɪl sʌpɝ, iðɝ. ɪts dʒʌs bɹɛɾ ən sup ən tʃiz, bʌt jə ɑɹ wɛlkəm."

"Good," the gray-haired woman said. "Those I cure of arguing have a tendency to avoid me like stingweed caught in their nets, unless they actually take sick, and I am enjoying your company. Most of those who come at present want something to take away bad dreams, and they grow sour when I have nothing to give them." For a moment she slipped into a frown, rubbing her temples. "It is good to see three faces that do not look as if there is nothing left but to jump over the side and drown. If you are staying long in Tear, you must come see me again. The girl called you Maryim? I am Ailhuin. The next time, we'll talk over some good Sea Folk tea instead of something that curdles your tongue. Light, but I hate the taste of marshwhite; mudfish would taste sweeter. In fact, if you have time to stay now, I'll brew a pot of Tremalking black. Not long till supper, either. It's just bread and soup and cheese, but you are welcome."

"ðæt wəd bi vɛɹi naɪs, eɪlhuɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "æktʃəli . . . . eɪlhuɪn, juv hæv ə spɛɹ bɛdʒɹum, aɪd laɪk tə haɪɝ ɪt fəɹ ðə θɹi ʌv ʌs."

"That would be very nice, Ailhuin," Nynaeve said. "Actually. . . . Ailhuin, if you have a spare bedroom, I'd like to hire it for the three of us."

ðə bɪɡ wʊmən lʊkt əɾ itʃ ə ðɛm wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ. ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɝ fit, ʃi tʌk ðə pɑɾ ə mɑɹʃwaɪt ti əweɪ ɪn ði ɝb kʌbɝd, ðən fɛtʃt ə ɹɛd tipɑɾ ən ə paʊtʃ fɹəm ənʌðɝ. oʊnli wən ʃi hæd bɹuɾ ə pɑɾ ə tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ blæk, pʊt fɔɹ klin kʌps ən ə boʊl ə hʌnikoʊm ɑn ðə teɪbəl əlɔŋ wɪð pjuɾɝ spunz, ən ɹikleɪmd əɹ tʃɛɹ dɪd ʃi spik.

The big woman looked at each of them without saying anything. Getting to her feet, she tucked the pot of marshwhite tea away in the herb cupboard, then fetched a red teapot and a pouch from another. Only when she had brewed a pot of Tremalking black, put four clean cups and a bowl of honeycomb on the table along with pewter spoons, and reclaimed her chair did she speak.

"aɪv θɹi ɛmpti bɛdʒɹumz əpstɛɹz, naʊ maɪ dɔɾɝz ɑɹ ɔl mɛɹid. maɪ hʌzbənd, ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn hɪm, wɑz lɔst ɪn ə stɔɹm ɪn ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən nɪɹ twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ. ðəɹ nid bi noʊ tɔk ə haɪɹɪŋ, ɪf aɪ dɪsaɪd tə lɛt juv ðə ɹumz. ɪf, mɛɹiɪm." stɝɪŋ hʌni ɪndə hɝ ti, ʃi stʌɾid əm əɡɛn.

"I've three empty bedrooms upstairs, now my daughters are all married. My husband, the Light shine on him, was lost in a storm in the Fingers of the Dragon near twenty years ago. There need be no talk of hiring, if I decide to let you have the rooms. If, Maryim." Stirring honey into her tea, she studied them again.

"wʌt wɪl meɪk jə dɪsaɪd?" nɪneɪiv æskt kwaɪətli.

"What will make you decide?" Nynaeve asked quietly.

eɪlhuɪn kəntɪnjud tə stɝ, əz ɪf ʃi hæd fɝɡɑɾən tə dʒɹɪŋk. "θɹi jʌŋ wɪmən, ɹaɪɾɪŋ faɪn hɔɹsəz. aɪ doʊnt noʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt hɔɹsəz, bʌt ðoʊz lʊk əz faɪn əz wʌt ðə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz ɹaɪd, tə mi. ju, mɛɹiɪm, noʊ ɪnʌf ə ðə kɹæf ðət jə ɔt tə hæv hʌŋ ɝbz ɪn jəɹ wɪndoʊ ɔlɹɛɾi, əɹ ʃəd bi tʃuzɪŋ wɛɹ tə də ɪt. aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə wʊmən pɹæktəsɪŋ ðə kɹæf tu fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi wɑz bɔɹn, bʌt baɪ jəɹ tʌŋ, jə ɑɹ ə lɔŋ weɪ." ʃi ɡlænst əɾ ɪleɪn. "nɑt mɛni pleɪsəz wɪð hɛɹ ðət kʌlɝ. ændɝ, aɪd seɪ, baɪ jəɹ spitʃ. ful mɛn ɑɹ ɔlweɪz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt faɪndɪŋ ə jɛloʊ-hɛɹɾ ændɝ ɡɝl. wʌɾ aɪ wɑnə noʊ ɪz waɪ? ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm sʌmθɪŋ? əɹ ɹʌnɪŋ æftɝ sʌmθɪŋ? oʊnli, jə doʊn lʊk laɪk θivz tə mi, ən aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə θɹi wɪmən tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ ə mæn təɡɛðɝ. soʊ tɛl mi waɪ, ən ɪf aɪ laɪk ɪt, ðə ɹumz ɑɹ jʊɹz. ɪf jə wɑnə peɪ sʌmθɪŋ, jə baɪ ə bɪɾ ə mit naʊ ən ðɛn. miɾ ɪz dɪɹ sɪns ðə tʃɹeɪɾ ʌp tə kɛɹhin fɛl əweɪ. bʌt fɝs ðə waɪ, mɛɹiɪm."

Ailhuin continued to stir, as if she had forgotten to drink. "Three young women, riding fine horses. I don't know much about horses, but those look as fine as what the lords and ladies ride, to me. You, Maryim, know enough of the craft that you ought to have hung herbs in your window already, or should be choosing where to do it. I've never heard of a woman practicing the craft too far from where she was born, but by your tongue, you are a long way." She glanced at Elayne. "Not many places with hair that color. Andor, I'd say, by your speech. Fool men are always talking about finding a yellow-haired Andor girl. What I want to know is why? Running away from something? Or running after something? Only, you don't look like thieves to me, and I never heard of three women chasing after a man together. So tell me why, and if I like it, the rooms are yours. If you want to pay something, you buy a bit of meat now and then. Meat is dear since the trade up to Cairhien fell away. But first the why, Maryim."

"wi ɑɹ tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ sʌmθɪŋ, eɪlhuɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ɔɹ ɹæðɝ, æftɝ səm pipəl." ɛɡwin skul hɝsɛlf tə stɪlnəs ən hoʊpt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ əz wɛl əz ɪleɪn, hu wɑz sɪpɪŋ əɹ ti əz ɪf ʃi wɝ lɪsnɪŋ tə tɔk əbaʊt dʒɹɛsəz. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt bɪliv eɪlhuɪn ɡeɪnəz dɑɹk aɪz mɪst ə ɡɹeɪt dil. "ðeɪ stoʊl səm θɪŋz, eɪlhuɪn," nɪneɪiv wɛn ɑn. "fɹʌm maɪ mʌðɝ. ən ðeɪ dɪd mɝɾɝ. wəɹ hɪɹ tə si dʒʌstəs dʌn."

"We are chasing after something, Ailhuin," Nynaeve said. "Or rather, after some people." Egwene schooled herself to stillness and hoped she was doing as well as Elayne, who was sipping her tea as if she were listening to talk about dresses. Egwene did not believe Ailhuin Guenna's dark eyes missed a great deal. "They stole some things, Ailhuin," Nynaeve went on. "From my mother. And they did murder. We are here to see justice done."

"bɝn maɪ soʊl," ðə lɑɹdʒ wʊmən sɛd, "hæv jə noʊ mɛnfoʊk? mɛn ɑɹ nɑt ɡʊd fəɹ mʌtʃ bɪɑn hɛvi hɔlɪŋ ən ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪ, moʊst ə ðə taɪm - ən kɪsɪŋ ən sətʃ - bʌɾ ɪf ðɛɹz ə bæɾəl tə bi fɔɾ əɹ ə θif tə kætʃ, aɪ seɪ lɛɾ əm də ɪt. ændɝ ɪz əz sɪvəlaɪzd əz tɛɹ. jə ɑɹ nɑɾ il."

"Burn my soul," the large woman said, "have you no menfolk? Men are not good for much beyond heavy hauling and getting in the way, most of the time - and kissing and such - but if there's a battle to be fought or a thief to catch, I say let them do it. Andor is as civilized as Tear. You are not Aiel."

"ðɛɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ɛls bʌɾ ʌs," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðoʊz u maɪɾ əv kʌm ɪn əɹ pleɪs wɝ kɪld."

"There was no one else but us," Nynaeve said. "Those who might have come in our place were killed."

ðə θɹi mɝɾɝd ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɛɡwin θɔt. ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn blæk ədʒɑ. bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn kɪld, ði æmɪɝlɪn wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə tʃɹʌs ðɛm. ʃiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip tə ðə blʌɾi θɹi oʊðz, bʌt ʃiz skɝɾɪŋ ɪt kloʊs.

The three murdered Aes Sedai, Egwene thought. They could not have been Black Ajah. But if they had not been killed, the Amyrlin would not have been able to trust them. She's trying to keep to the bloody Three Oaths, but she is skirting it close.

"ɑ," eɪlhuɪn sɛd sædli. "ðeɪ kɪl jəɹ mɛn? bɹʌðɝz, əɹ hʌzbənz, əɹ fɑðɝz?" spɑts ə kʌlɝ blumd ɪn nɪneɪivz tʃiks, ən ði oʊldɝ wʊmən mɪstʊk ði ɪmoʊʃən. "noʊ, doʊn tɛl mi, ɡɝl. əl nɑt pʊl ʌp oʊld ɡɹif. lɛɾ ɪt laɪ ɑn ðə bɑɾəm tɪl ɪt mɛls əweɪ. ðɛɹ, ðɛɹ, jə kɑm jɝsɛlf." ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt fəɹ ɛɡwin nɑt tə ɡɹaʊl wɪð dɪsɡʌst.

"Aaah," Ailhuin said sadly. "They killed your men? Brothers, or husbands, or fathers?" Spots of color bloomed in Nynaeve's cheeks, and the older woman mistook the emotion. "No, don't tell me, girl. I'll not pull up old grief. Let it lie on the bottom till it melts away. There, there, you calm yourself." It was an effort for Egwene not to growl with disgust.

"aɪ mʌs tɛl jə ðɪs," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə stɪf vɔɪs. ðə ɹɛd stɪl kʌlɝɾ əɹ feɪs. "ðiz mɝɾɝɝz ən θivz ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðeɪ ɑɹ wɪmən, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ əz deɪnʒɝəs əz ɛni sɔɝdzmən, eɪlhuɪn. ɪf jə wʌndɝd waɪ wi dɪd nɑt sik ən ɪn, ðəɾ ɪz waɪ. ðeɪ meɪ noʊ wi fɑloʊ, ən ðeɪ meɪ bi wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ ʌs."

"I must tell you this," Nynaeve said in a stiff voice. The red still colored her face. "These murderers and thieves are Darkfriends. They are women, but they are as dangerous as any swordsman, Ailhuin. If you wondered why we did not seek an inn, that is why. They may know we follow, and they may be watching for us."

eɪlhuɪn weɪvd ɪɾ ɔl əweɪ wɪð ə snɪf. "ʌv ðə fɔɹ moʊs deɪnʒɝəs foʊk aɪ noʊ, tu ɑɹ wɪmən u nɛvɝ kæɹi əz mʌtʃ əz ə naɪf, ən oʊnli wʌn ə ðə mɛn ɪz ə sɔɝdzmən. əz fəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. . . . mɛɹiɪm, wən jə ɑɹ əz oʊld əz aɪ, jəl lɝn ðət fɔls dʒɹæɡənz ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs, laɪənfɪʃ ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs, ʃɑɹks ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs, ən sʌɾən stɔɹmz aʊɾ ə ðə saʊθ; bʌt dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɑɹ fulz. fɪlθi fulz, bʌt fulz. ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz lɑkt ʌp wɛɹ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ pʊt hɪm, ən noʊ fɛtʃɪz əɹ fæŋfɪʃ tə skɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən wɪl ɡɛɾ ɪm aʊt. fulz doʊn fɹaɪɾən mi ənlɛs ðəɹ wɝkɪŋ ðə boʊɾ aɪm ɹaɪɾɪŋ. aɪ səpoʊz jə doʊn əv ɛni pɹuf jə kəd teɪk tə ðə dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn? ɪt wəd bi dʒʌs jəɹ wɝɾ əɡɛns ðɛɹz?"

Ailhuin waved it all away with a sniff. "Of the four most dangerous folk I know, two are women who never carry as much as a knife, and only one of the men is a swordsman. As for Darkfriends. . . . Maryim, when you are as old as I, you'll learn that false Dragons are dangerous, lionfish are dangerous, sharks are dangerous, and sudden storms out of the south; but Darkfriends are fools. Filthy fools, but fools. The Dark One is locked up where the Creator put him, and no Fetches or fangfish to scare children will get him out. Fools don't frighten me unless they're working the boat I'm riding. I suppose you don't have any proof you could take to the Defenders of the Stone? It would be just your word against theirs?"

wʌɾ ɪz ə "fɛtʃ"? ɛɡwin wʌndɝd. əɹ ə "fæŋfɪʃ," fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

What is a "Fetch"? Egwene wondered. Or a "fangfish," for that matter.

"wi wɪl əv pɹuf wən wi faɪn ðɛm," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðeɪ wɪl əv ðə θɪŋz ðeɪ stoʊl, ən wi kən dɪskɹaɪb ðɛm. ðeɪ ɑɹ oʊl θɪŋz, ən ə lɪɾəl vælju tə ɛniwʌn bʌɾ ʌs, ən əɹ fɹɛnz."

"We will have proof when we find them," Nynaeve said. "They will have the things they stole, and we can describe them. They are old things, and of little value to anyone but us, and our friends."

"ju wəd bi sɝpɹaɪzd wʌɾ oʊl θɪŋz kən bi wɝθ," eɪlhuɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "oʊld luiz mjulən pʊld ʌp θɹi hɑɹtstoʊn boʊlz ən ə kʌp ɪn ɪz nɛts læs jɪɹ, daʊn ɪn ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. naʊ, ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə fɪʃɪŋ smæk, hi oʊnz ə ʃɪp tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪvɝ. oʊl ful dɪd nɑɾ ivən noʊ wʌɾ i hæd tɪl aɪ toʊl hɪm. vɛɹi laɪkli ðɛɹz mɔɹ ɹaɪt wɛɹ ðoʊz keɪm fɹʌm, bʌt luiz kʊdn ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ði ɪɡzæk spɑt. aɪ də nɑt noʊ haʊ hi ɛvɝ mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ə fɪʃ ɪndə hɪz nɛt. hæf ðə fɪʃɪŋ boʊts ɪn tiɹ wɝ daʊn ðəɹ fəɹ mʌnθs æftɝwɝdz, dʒɹæɡɪŋ fəɹ kwəndɪlɝ, nɑt ɡɹʌns əɹ flætfɪʃ, ən səm hæd lɔɹdz seɪɪŋ wɛɹ tə pʊl ðə nɛts. ðæts wʌɾ oʊl θɪŋz kən bi wɝθ, ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ oʊld ɪnʌf. naʊ, aɪv dɪsaɪɾɪd jə də niɾ ə mæn ɪn ðɪs, ən aɪ noʊ dʒʌs ðə wʌn."

"You would be surprised what old things can be worth," Ailhuin said dryly. "Old Leuese Mulan pulled up three heartstone bowls and a cup in his nets last year, down in the Fingers of the Dragon. Now, instead of a fishing smack, he owns a ship trading up the river. Old fool did not even know what he had till I told him. Very likely there's more right where those came from, but Leuese couldn't even remember the exact spot. I do not know how he ever managed to get a fish into his net. Half the fishing boats in Tear were down there for months afterwards, dragging for cuendillar, not grunts or flatfish, and some had lords saying where to pull the nets. That's what old things can be worth, if they are old enough. Now, I've decided you do need a man in this, and I know just the one."

"hu?" nɪneɪiv sɛd kwɪkli. "ɪf jə min ə lɔɹd, wʌn ə ðə haɪ lɔɹdz, ɹɪmɛmbɝ wɪv noʊ pɹuf tə ɔfɝ tɪl wi faɪn ðɛm."

"Who?" Nynaeve said quickly. "If you mean a lord, one of the High Lords, remember we have no proof to offer till we find them."

eɪlhuɪn læft əntɪl ʃi wizd. "ɡɝl, noʊbɑdi fɹəm ðə mɔl noʊz ə haɪ lɔɹd, əɹ ɛni kaɪndə lɔɹd. mədfɪʃ doʊn skul wɪð sɪlvɝsaɪdz. əl bɹɪŋ jə ðə deɪnʒɝəs mæn aɪ noʊ hu ɪzən ə sɔɝdzmən, ən ðə mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ə ðə tu, ət ðæt. dʒulɪn sændɑɹ ɪz ə θif-kætʃɝ. ðə bɛst ə ðɛm. aɪ də nɑt noʊ haʊ ɪts ɪn ændɝ, bʌt hɪɹ ə θif-kætʃɝ wɪl wɝk fəɹ jə əɹ mi əz sun əz fəɹ ə lɔɹɾ əɹ ə mɝtʃənt, ən tʃɑɹdʒ lɛs ət ðæt. dʒulɪn kən faɪn ðiz wɪmən fəɹ jə ɪf ðeɪ kən bi faʊnd, ən bɹɪŋ jəɹ θɪŋz bæk wɪθaʊt jə hævɪŋ tə ɡoʊ nɪɹ ðiz dɑɹkfɹɛnz."

Ailhuin laughed until she wheezed. "Girl, nobody from the Maule knows a High Lord, or any kind of lord. Mudfish don't school with silversides. I will bring you the dangerous man I know who isn't a swordsman, and the more dangerous of the two, at that. Juilin Sandar is a thief-catcher. The best of them. I do not know how it is in Andor, but here a thief-catcher will work for you or me as soon as for a lord or a merchant, and charge less at that. Juilin can find these women for you if they can be found, and bring your things back without you having to go near these Darkfriends."

nɪneɪiv əɡɹiɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ stɪl nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ʃʊɹ, ən eɪlhuɪn taɪd ðoʊz plætfɔɹmz tə hɝ ʃuz - klɑɡz, ʃi kɔld əm - ən hɝiɾ aʊt. ɛɡwin wɑtʃt əɹ ɡoʊ, θɹu wʌn ə ðə kɪtʃən wɪndoʊz, pæs ðə hɔɹsəz ən ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ʌp ði æli.

Nynaeve agreed as if she were still not entirely sure, and Ailhuin tied those platforms to her shoes - clogs, she called them - and hurried out. Egwene watched her go, through one of the kitchen windows, past the horses and around the corner up the alley.

"ju ɑɹ lɝnɪŋ haʊ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, mɛɹiɪm," ʃi sɛɾ əz ʃi tɝn fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ. "ju mənɪpjəleɪt pipəl əz wɛl əz mɔɪɹeɪn." nɪneɪivz feɪs wɛnt waɪt.

"You are learning how to be Aes Sedai, Maryim," she said as she turned from the window. "You manipulate people as well as Moiraine." Nynaeve's face went white.

ɪleɪn stɔkt əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ ən slæpt ɛɡwinz feɪs. ɛɡwin wɑz soʊ ʃɑkt ʃi kəɾ oʊnli stɛɹ. "ju ɡoʊ tu fɑɹ," ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "tu fɑɹ. wi mʌs lɪv təɡɛðɝ, əɹ wɪl ʃʊɹli daɪ təɡɛðɝ! dɪd jə ɡɪv eɪlhuɪn jəɹ tʃɹu neɪm? nɪneɪiv toʊld əɹ wʌt wi kʊd, ðət wi sik dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən ðət wɑz ɹɪsk ɪnʌf, lɪŋkɪŋ əs wɪð dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ʃi toʊld əɹ ðeɪ wɝ deɪnʒɝəs, mɝɾɝɝz. wəd juv hæɾ əɹ seɪ ðeɪ ɑɹ blæk ədʒɑ? ɪn tiɹ? wəd jə ɹɪsk ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn wɛðɝ eɪlhuɪn wəd kip ðət tə hɝsɛlf?"

Elayne stalked across the floor and slapped Egwene's face. Egwene was so shocked she could only stare. "You go too far," the golden-haired woman said sharply. "Too far. We must live together, or we will surely die together! Did you give Ailhuin your true name? Nynaeve told her what we could, that we seek Darkfriends, and that was risk enough, linking us with Darkfriends. She told her they were dangerous, murderers. Would you have had her say they are Black Ajah? In Tear? Would you risk everything on whether Ailhuin would keep that to herself?"

ɛɡwin ɹʌbd əɹ tʃik dʒɪnʒɝli. ɪleɪn hæɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ ɑɹm. "aɪ də nɑɾ əv tə laɪk duɪŋ ɪt."

Egwene rubbed her cheek gingerly. Elayne had a strong arm. "I do not have to like doing it."

"aɪ noʊ," ɪleɪn saɪd. "niðɝ də aɪ. bʌt wi də hæv tə."

"I know," Elayne sighed. "Neither do I. But we do have to."

ɛɡwin tɝn bæk tə piɹɪŋ θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ ət ðə hɔɹsəz. aɪ noʊ wi du. bʌɾ aɪ də nɑɾ əv tə laɪk ɪt.

Egwene turned back to peering through the window at the horses. I know we do. But I do not have to like it.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾinaɪn


CHAPTER 49

eɪ stɔɹm ɪn tiɹ


A Storm in Tear

ɛɡwin faɪnəli ɹɪtɝn tə ðə teɪbəl ən əɹ ti. ʃi θɔt pɝhæps ɪleɪn wɑz ɹaɪt, ðət ʃi hæd ɡɔn tu fɑɹ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə əpɑlədʒaɪz, ən ðeɪ sæɾ ɪn saɪləns.

Egwene finally returned to the table and her tea. She thought perhaps Elayne was right, that she had gone too far, but she could not bring herself to apologize, and they sat in silence.

wən eɪlhuɪn ɹɪtɝnd, ʃi hæɾ ə mæn wɪð hɝ, ə lin fɛloʊ ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz u lʊkt əz ɪf i hæd bɪn kɑɹv fɹəm eɪdʒd wʊd. dʒulɪn sændɑɹ tʊk ɔf ɪz klɑɡz baɪ ðə dɔɹ ən hʌŋ ɪz flæt, kɑnɪkəl stʃɹɔ hæɾ ɑn ə pɛɡ. ə sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ, mʌtʃ laɪk hʊɹɪnz bʌt wɪð ʃɔɹt slɑts tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə lɔŋ wʌn, hʌŋ fɹəm ə bɛlt oʊvɝ ɪz bɹaʊn koʊt, ən i kæɹiɾ ə stæf ɪɡzækli əz tɔl əz i wɑz, bʌt nɑt mʌtʃ θɪkɝ ðən ɪz θʌm ən meɪɾ ə ðət peɪl wʊd, laɪk ɹɪdʒ dʒɔɪns, ðət ði ɑks-dʒɹaɪvɝz juz fəɹ ðɛɹ ɡoʊdz. hɪz ʃɔɹt-kʌt blæk hɛɹ leɪ flæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd, ən ɪz kwɪk, dɑɹk aɪz sim tə noʊɾ ən ɹəkɔɹɾ ɛvɹi dɪteɪl ə ðə ɹum. ən ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ɪt. ɛɡwin wəɾ əv bɛɾ i ɪɡzæmənd nɪneɪiv twaɪs, ən tə hɝ, ət list, nɪneɪivz læk ə ɹiækʃən wɑz bleɪɾənt; ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ʃi nu ɪt, tu.

When Ailhuin returned, she had a man with her, a lean fellow in his middle years who looked as if he had been carved from aged wood. Juilin Sandar took off his clogs by the door and hung his flat, conical straw hat on a peg. A sword-breaker, much like Hurin's but with short slots to either side of the long one, hung from a belt over his brown coat, and he carried a staff exactly as tall as he was, but not much thicker than his thumb and made of that pale wood, like ridged joints, that the ox-drivers used for their goads. His short-cut black hair lay flat on his head, and his quick, dark eyes seemed to note and record every detail of the room. And of everyone in it. Egwene would have bet he examined Nynaeve twice, and to her, at least, Nynaeve's lack of reaction was blatant; it was obvious she knew it, too.

eɪlhuɪn moʊʃən ɪm tə ə pleɪs ət ðə teɪbəl, wɛɹ i tɝn bæk ðə kʌfs ə hɪz koʊt slivz, baʊd tə itʃ ə ðɛm ɪn tɝn, ən sæt wɪð ɪz stæf pɹɑpt əɡɛnst ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, nɑt spikɪŋ əntɪl ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən hæd meɪɾ ə fɹɛʃ pɑɾ ə ti ən ɛvɹiwʌn hæd sɪp fɹəm ðɛɹ kʌps.

Ailhuin motioned him to a place at the table, where he turned back the cuffs of his coat sleeves, bowed to each of them in turn, and sat with his staff propped against his shoulder, not speaking until the gray-haired woman had made a fresh pot of tea and everyone had sipped from their cups.

"mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə hæz toʊl mi ʌv jəɹ pɹɑbləm," hi sɛd kwaɪətli əz i sɛɾ ɪz kʌp daʊn. "aɪ wɪl hɛlp jə ɪf aɪ kæn, bʌt ðə haɪ lɔɹdz meɪ hæv ðɛɹ oʊn bɪznəs tə pʊt mi tə, sun."

"Mother Guenna has told me of your problem," he said quietly as he set his cup down. "I will help you if I can, but the High Lords may have their own business to put me to, soon."

ðə bɪɡ wʊmən snɔɹɾɪd. "dʒulɪn, wən dɪd jə bɪɡɪn hæɡəlɪŋ laɪk ə ʃɑpkipɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃɑɹdʒ sɪlk pɹaɪsəz fəɹ lɪnən? də nɑt kleɪm jə noʊ wən ðə haɪ lɔɹdz wɪl sʌmən jə bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ du."

The big woman snorted. "Juilin, when did you begin haggling like a shopkeeper trying to charge silk prices for linen? Do not claim you know when the High Lords will summon you before they do."

"aɪ woʊn kleɪm ɪt," sændɑɹ toʊld əɹ wɪð ə smaɪl, "bʌɾ aɪ noʊ wən aɪv sin mɛn ɑn ðə ɹuftɑps ɪn ðə naɪt. dʒʌst aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə maɪ aɪ - ðeɪ kən haɪd laɪk paɪpfɪʃ ɪn ɹidz - bʌɾ aɪ hæv sin ðə muvmənt. noʊ wʌn əz ɹipɔɹɾəd ə θɛf jɛt, bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ θivz wɝkɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz, ən jə kən baɪ jəɹ sʌpɝ wɪð ðæt. mɑɹk mi. bɪfɔɹ ənʌðɝ wik, əl bi sʌmən tə ðə stoʊn kəz ə bæn ə θivz ɪz bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪndə mɝtʃəns' haʊsəz, əɹ ivən lɔɹdz' mænɝz. ðə dɪfɛndɝz meɪ ɡɑɹd ðə stʃɹits, bʌt wən θivz nid tʃɹækɪŋ ðeɪ sɛn fəɹ ə θif-kætʃɝ, ən mi bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌðɝ. aɪm nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒɹaɪv ʌp maɪ pɹaɪs, bʌt wʌtɛvɝ aɪ də fəɹ ðiz pɹɪɾi wɪmən, aɪ mʌs də sun."

"I won't claim it," Sandar told her with a smile, "but I know when I've seen men on the rooftops in the night. Just out of the corner of my eye - they can hide like pipefish in reeds - but I have seen the movement. No one has reported a theft yet, but there are thieves working inside the walls, and you can buy your supper with that. Mark me. Before another week, I'll be summoned to the Stone because a band of thieves is breaking into merchants' houses, or even lords' manors. The Defenders may guard the streets, but when thieves need tracking they send for a thief-catcher, and me before any other. I am not trying to drive up my price, but whatever I do for these pretty women, I must do soon."

"aɪ bɪliv i spiks ðə tʃɹuθ," eɪlhuɪn sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. "hil tɛl jə ðə mun ɪz ɡɹin ən wɔɾɝ waɪɾ ɪf i θɪŋks ɪɾəl bɹɪŋ ɪm ə kɪs, bʌɾ i laɪz lɛs ðən moʊs mɛn əbaʊɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz. hi meɪ bi ðə moʊst ɑnəs mæn ɛvɝ bɔɹn ɪn ðə mɔl." ɪleɪn pʊɾ ə hæn oʊvɝ əɹ maʊθ, ən ɛɡwin stʃɹʌɡəl nɑt tə læf. nɪneɪiv sæɾ ənmuvd ən ɑbviəsli ɪmpeɪʃənt.

"I believe he speaks the truth," Ailhuin said reluctantly. "He'll tell you the moon is green and water white if he thinks it will bring him a kiss, but he lies less than most men about other things. He may be the most honest man ever born in the Maule." Elayne put a hand over her mouth, and Egwene struggled not to laugh. Nynaeve sat unmoved and obviously impatient.

sændɑɹ ɡɹɪməst ət ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən, ðən əpɛɹənli dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ wʌt ʃi hæd sɛd. hi smaɪld ət nɪneɪiv. "aɪ wɪl ədmɪt ðəɾ aɪm kjʊɹiəs əbaʊt ðiz θivz. aɪv noʊn wɪmən θivz, ən bænz ə θivz, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə bæn ʌv wɪmən θivz bɪfɔɹ. ən aɪ oʊ mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə feɪvɝz." hɪz aɪz sim tə ɹəkɔɹd nɪneɪiv ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn.

Sandar grimaced at the gray-haired woman, then apparently decided to ignore what she had said. He smiled at Nynaeve. "I will admit that I'm curious about these thieves. I've known women thieves, and bands of thieves, but I never heard of a band of women thieves before. And I owe Mother Guenna favors." His eyes seemed to record Nynaeve all over again.

"wʌt dʒju tʃɑɹdʒ?" ʃi æskt ʃɑɹpli.

"What do you charge?" she asked sharply.

"tə ɹɪkʌvɝ stoʊlən ɡʊdz," hi sɛd bɹɪskli, "aɪ æsk ðə tɛnθ pɑɹɾ ə ðə vælju ʌv wʌɾ aɪ ɹɪkʌvɝ. fəɹ faɪndɪŋ sʌmwʌn, aɪ æsk ə sɪlvɝ mɑɹk fəɹ itʃ pɝsən. mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə sɛz ðə θɪŋz stoʊlən əv lɪɾəl vælju ɪksɛp tə ju, mɪstʃɹəs, soʊ aɪ sədʒɛs jə teɪk ðət tʃɔɪs." hi smaɪld əɡɛn; hi hæd vɛɹi waɪt tiθ. "aɪ wəd nɑt teɪk mʌni fɹəm jə əɾ ɔl, ɪksɛp ðət ðə bɹʌðɝhʊd wəd fɹaʊn ɑn ɪt, bʌɾ əl teɪk əz lɪɾəl əz aɪ kæn. ə kɑpɝ əɹ tu, noʊ mɔɹ."

"To recover stolen goods," he said briskly, "I ask the tenth part of the value of what I recover. For finding someone, I ask a silver mark for each person. Mother Guenna says the things stolen have little value except to you, mistress, so I suggest you take that choice." He smiled again; he had very white teeth. "I would not take money from you at all, except that the brotherhood would frown on it, but I will take as little as I can. A copper or two, no more."

"aɪ noʊ ə θif-teɪkɝ," ɪleɪn toʊl hɪm. "fɹʌm ʃaɪnɝ. ə vɛɹi ɹɪspɛkfəl mæn. hi kæɹiz ə sɔɹɾ əz wɛl əz ə sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ. waɪ dʒju nɑt?"

"I know a thief-taker," Elayne told him. "From Shienar. A very respectful man. He carries a sword as well as a sword-breaker. Why do you not?"

sændɑɹ lʊk stɑɹɾəld fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən ðən əpsɛt wɪð hɪmsɛlf fəɹ biɪŋ stɑɹɾəld. hi hæd nɑt kɑɾ əɹ hɪnt, əɹ ɛls hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt. "ju ɑɹ nɑt tɛɹən. aɪ hæv hɝɾ ə ʃaɪnɝ, mɪstʃɹəs, teɪlz ə tʃɹɑləks, ən ɛvɹi mæn ə wɔɹiɝ." hɪz smaɪl sɛd ðiz wɝ teɪlz fəɹ tʃɪlʒɹən.

Sandar looked startled for a moment, and then upset with himself for being startled. He had not caught her hint, or else had decided to ignore it. "You are not Tairen. I have heard of Shienar, mistress, tales of Trollocs, and every man a warrior." His smile said these were tales for children.

"tʃɹu stɔɹiz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɔɹ tʃɹu ɪnʌf. aɪ hæv bɪn tə ʃaɪnɝ."

"True stories," Egwene said. "Or true enough. I have been to Shienar."

hi blɪŋkt ət hɝ, ən wɛn ɑn. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ə lɔɹd, nɔɹ ə wɛlθi mɝtʃənt, nɔɹ ivən ə soʊlʒɝ. ðə dɪfɛndɝz də nɑt tʃɹʌbəl fɔɹənɝz mʌtʃ fəɹ kæɹiɪŋ sɔɹdz - ənlɛs ðeɪ min tə steɪ lɔŋ, ʌv kɔɹs - bʌɾ aɪ wəd bi θɹʌst ɪndə ə sɛl ʌndɝ ðə stoʊn. ðəɹ ɑɹ lɔz, mɪstʃɹəs." hɪz hæn ɹʌbd əlɔŋ ɪz stæf, əz ɪf ʌnkɑnʃəsli. "aɪ də əz wɛl əz meɪ bi, wɪθaʊɾ ə sɔɹd." hi foʊkəst ɪz smaɪl ɑn nɪneɪiv wʌns mɔɹ. "naʊ, ɪf jəl dɪskɹaɪb ðiz θɪŋz - "

He blinked at her, and went on. "I am not a lord, nor a wealthy merchant, nor even a soldier. The Defenders do not trouble foreigners much for carrying swords - unless they mean to stay long, of course - but I would be thrust into a cell under the Stone. There are laws, mistress." His hand rubbed along his staff, as if unconsciously. "I do as well as may be, without a sword." He focused his smile on Nynaeve once more. "Now, if you will describe these things - "

hi stɑpt əz ʃi sɛɾ əɹ pɝs ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə teɪbəl ən kaʊntəɾ aʊt θɝtin sɪlvɝ mɑɹks. ɛɡwin θɔt ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən ðə laɪɾəst kɔɪnz; moʊst wɝ tɛɹən, oʊnli wʌn ændɔɝən. ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd ɡɪvən əm ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɡoʊld, bʌɾ ivən ðət wəd nɑt læs fɝɛvɝ.

He stopped as she set her purse on the edge of the table and counted out thirteen silver marks. Egwene thought she had chosen the lightest coins; most were Tairen, only one Andoran. The Amyrlin had given them a great deal of gold, but even that would not last forever.

nɪneɪiv lʊkt ɪndə ðə pɝs θɔtfəli bɪfɔɹ taɪɾənɪŋ ðə stʃɹɪŋz ən pʊɾɪŋ ɪt bæk ɪndə hɝ paʊtʃ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ θɝtin wɪmən fəɹ jə tə faɪnd, mæstɝ sændɑɹ, wɪð əz mʌtʃ sɪlvɝ əɡɛn wən jə du. faɪn ðɛm, ən wɪl ɹɪkʌvɝ əɹ pɹɑpɝɾi aʊɝsɛlvz."

Nynaeve looked into the purse thoughtfully before tightening the strings and putting it back into her pouch. "There are thirteen women for you to find, Master Sandar, with as much silver again when you do. Find them, and we will recover our property ourselves."

"aɪ wɪl də ðət maɪsɛlf fəɹ lɛs ðən ðɪs," hi pɹətɛstəd. "æn ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ ɛkstʃɹə ɹɪwɔɹdz. aɪ tʃɑɹdʒ wʌɾ aɪ tʃɑɹdʒ. hæv noʊ fɪɹ əl teɪk ə bɹaɪb."

"I will do that myself for less than this," he protested. "And there's no need for extra rewards. I charge what I charge. Have no fear I'll take a bribe."

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ fɪɹ ə ðæt," eɪlhuɪn əɡɹid. "aɪ sɛd hiz ɑnəst. dʒʌs də nɑt bɪliv ɪm ɪf i sɛz i lʌvz ju." sændɑɹ ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɝ.

"There is no fear of that," Ailhuin agreed. "I said he is honest. Just do not believe him if he says he loves you." Sandar glared at her.

"aɪ peɪ ðə kɔɪn, mæstɝ sændɑɹ," nɪneɪiv sɛd fɝmli, "soʊ aɪ tʃuz wʌɾ aɪm baɪɪŋ. wɪl jə faɪn ðiz wɪmən, ən noʊ mɔɹ?" ʃi weɪɾəd fəɹ ɪm tə nɑd, ɹɪlʌktənli, bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "ðeɪ meɪ bi təɡɛðɝ, əɹ nɑt. ðə fɝst ɪz ə tæɹɑbənɝ. ʃiz ə lɪɾəl tɔlɝ ðən aɪ, wɪð dɑɹk aɪz ən peɪl, hʌni-kʌlɝd hɛɹ ðət ʃi wɛɹz ɪn mɛni smɔl bɹeɪdz æftɝ ðə tæɹɑbən fæʃən. səm mɛn maɪt θɪŋk əɹ pɹɪɾi, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt kənsɪɾɝ ɪɾ ə kɑmpləmənt. ʃiz ə min, sʌlki maʊð. ðə sɛkən ɪz kændɔɹi. ʃiz lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ wɪð ə waɪt stʃɹik əbʌv əɹ lɛft ɪɹ, ænd. . . ."

"I pay the coin, Master Sandar," Nynaeve said firmly, "so I choose what I am buying. Will you find these women, and no more?" She waited for him to nod, reluctantly, before going on. "They may be together, or not. The first is a Taraboner. She is a little taller than I, with dark eyes and pale, honey-colored hair that she wears in many small braids after the Tarabon fashion. Some men might think her pretty, but she would not consider it a compliment. She has a mean, sulky mouth. The second is Kandori. She has long black hair with a white streak above her left ear, and. . . ."

ʃi ɡeɪv noʊ neɪmz, ən sændɑɹ æsk fəɹ nʌn. neɪmz wɝ soʊ izəli tʃeɪnʒd. hɪz smaɪl wɑz ɡɔn naʊ ðət ðə bɪznəs wɑz ət hænd. θɝtin wɪmən ʃi dɪskɹaɪbd əz i lɪsən ɪntɛnli, ən wən ʃi wɑz dʌn, ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ i cʊɾə ɹəsaɪɾəd əm bæk wɝd fəɹ wɝd.

She gave no names, and Sandar asked for none. Names were so easily changed. His smile was gone now that the business was at hand. Thirteen women she described as he listened intently, and when she was done, Egwene was sure he could have recited them back word for word.

"mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə meɪ hæv toʊl jə ðɪs," nɪneɪiv fɪnɪʃt, "bʌɾ əl ɹɪpiɾ ɪt. ðiz wɪmən ɑɹ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən jə kən bɪliv. oʊvɝ ə dʌzən əv daɪɾ ət ðɛɹ hænz ɔlɹɛɾi, ðəɾ aɪ noʊ ʌv, ən aɪ wəd nɑt bi sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf ðət wɑz oʊnli ə dʒɹɑp ə ðə blʌɾ ɑn ðɛɹ hænz." sændɑɹ ən eɪlhuɪn boʊθ blɪŋkt ət ðæt. "ɪf ðeɪ dɪskʌvɝ jə ɑɹ æskɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm, jəl daɪ. ɪf ðeɪ teɪk ju, ðəl meɪk jə tɛl wɛɹ wi ɑɹ, ən mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə wɪl pɹɑbli daɪ wɪð ʌs." ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən lʊk dɪsbɪlivɪŋ. "bɪliv ɪt!" nɪneɪivz stɛɹ dɪmændəɾ əɡɹimənt. "bɪliv ɪt, əɹ əl teɪk bæk ðə sɪlvɝ ən faɪn ənʌðɝ wɪð mɔɹ bɹeɪnz!"

"Mother Guenna may have told you this," Nynaeve finished, "but I will repeat it. These women are more dangerous than you can believe. Over a dozen have died at their hands already, that I know of, and I would not be surprised if that was only a drop of the blood on their hands." Sandar and Ailhuin both blinked at that. "If they discover you are asking after them, you will die. If they take you, they will make you tell where we are, and Mother Guenna will probably die with us." The gray-haired woman looked disbelieving. "Believe it!" Nynaeve's stare demanded agreement. "Believe it, or I'll take back the silver and find another with more brains!"

"wɛn aɪ wɑz jʌŋ," sændɑɹ sɛd, vɔɪs sɪɹiəs, "ə kʌtpɝs pʊɾ əɹ naɪf ɪn maɪ ɹɪbz kəz aɪ θɔɾ ə pɹɪɾi jʌŋ ɡɝl wʊdn bi əz kwɪk tə stæb əz ə mæn. aɪ də nɑt meɪk ðət mɪsteɪk ɛnimɔɹ. əl bɪheɪv əz ɪf ðiz wɪmən ɑɹ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən blæk ədʒɑ." ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊs tʃoʊkt, ən i ɡeɪv əɹ ə ɹufəl ɡɹɪn əz i skup ðə kɔɪnz ɪndə hɪz oʊn pɝs ən stʌk ɪt bɪhaɪn ɪz sæʃ. "aɪ dɪd nɑt min tə fɹaɪɾən ju, mɪstʃɹəs. ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn tɛɹ. ɪt meɪ teɪk ə fju deɪz, ənlɛs ðeɪ ɑɹ təɡɛðɝ. θɝtin wɪmən təɡɛðɝ wɪl bi izi tə faɪnd; əpɑɹt, ðəl bi hɑɹɾɝ. bʌɾ iðɝ weɪ, əl faɪn ðɛm. ən əl nɑt fɹaɪɾən əm əweɪ bɪfɔɹ jə lɝn wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ."

"When I was young," Sandar said, voice serious, "a cutpurse put her knife in my ribs because I thought a pretty young girl wouldn't be as quick to stab as a man. I do not make that mistake anymore. I will behave as if these women are all Aes Sedai, and Black Ajah." Egwene almost choked, and he gave her a rueful grin as he scooped the coins into his own purse and stuck it behind his sash. "I did not mean to frighten you, mistress. There are no Aes Sedai in Tear. It may take a few days, unless they are together. Thirteen women together will be easy to find; apart, they will be harder. But either way, I will find them. And I will not frighten them away before you learn where they are."

wən i hæd dɑn ɪz stʃɹɔ hæɾ ən klɑɡz ən dɪpɑɹɾəd baɪ ðə bæk dɔɹ, ɪleɪn sɛd, "aɪ hoʊp hiz nɑɾ oʊvɝkɑnfɪɾənt. eɪlhuɪn, aɪ hɝd wʌɾ i sɛd bʌt. . . . hi dʌz ʌndɝstæn ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs, dʌz i nɑt?"

When he had donned his straw hat and clogs and departed by the back door, Elayne said, "I hope he is not overconfident. Ailhuin, I heard what he said but. . . . He does understand that they are dangerous, does he not?"

"hi hæz nɛvɝ bɪn ə ful ɪksɛp fəɹ ə pɛɹ ʌv aɪz əɹ ə pɹɪɾi æŋkəl," ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən sɛd, "æn ðəɾ ɪz ə feɪlɪŋ ʌv ɛvɹi mæn. hiz ðə bɛs θif-kætʃɝ ɪn tiɹ. hæv noʊ wɝi. hɪl faɪn ðiz dɑɹkfɹɛnz ə jʊɹz."

"He has never been a fool except for a pair of eyes or a pretty ankle," the gray-haired woman said, "and that is a failing of every man. He is the best thief-catcher in Tear. Have no worry. He will find these Darkfriends of yours."

"ɪt wɪl ɹeɪn əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ mɔɹnɪŋ." nɪneɪiv ʃɪvɝd, dɪspaɪt ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə ɹum. "aɪ fil ə stɔɹm ɡæðɝɪŋ." eɪlhuɪn oʊnli ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən sɛɾ əbaʊt fɪlɪŋ boʊlz wɪð fɪʃ sup fəɹ sʌpɝ.

"It will rain again before morning." Nynaeve shivered, despite the warmth of the room. "I feel a storm gathering." Ailhuin only shook her head and set about filling bowls with fish soup for supper.

æftɝ ðeɪ eɪɾ ən klin ʌp, nɪneɪiv ən eɪlhuɪn sæɾ ət ðə teɪbəl tɔkɪŋ ə ɝbz ən kjʊɹz. ɪleɪn wɝkt ɑn ə smɔl pætʃ ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ ə hɝ kloʊk, taɪni blu ən waɪt flaʊɝz, ðən ɹɛɾ ɪn ə kɑpi ʌv ði ɛseɪz ʌv wɪlɪm ə meɪnɪtʃɪz ðəɾ eɪlhuɪn hæɾ ɑn əɹ smɔl ʃɛlf ə bʊks. ɛɡwin tʃɹaɪd ɹɛɾɪŋ, bʌt niðɝ ði ɛseɪz, nɔɹ ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ, nɔɹ ðə hjumɝəs teɪlz ʌv əliɹiə ɛlfɪn kəd hoʊld əɹ ɪntʃɹəs fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə fju peɪdʒəz. ʃi fɪŋɡɝd ðə stoʊn tɛɹæŋɡɹil θɹu ðə bʊzəm ə hɝ dʒɹɛs. wɛɹ ɑɹ ðeɪ? wʌt də ðeɪ wɑn ɪn ðə hɑɹt? nʌn bʌt ðə dʒɹæɡən - nʌn bʌt ɹænd - kən tʌtʃ kælændɝ, soʊ wʌt də ðeɪ wɑnt? wʌt? wʌt?

After they ate and cleaned up, Nynaeve and Ailhuin sat at the table talking of herbs and cures. Elayne worked on a small patch of embroidery she had begun on the shoulder of her cloak, tiny blue and white flowers, then read in a copy of The Essays of Willim of Maneches that Ailhuin had on her small shelf of books. Egwene tried reading, but neither the essays, nor The Travels of Jain Farstrider, nor the humorous tales of Aleria Elffin could hold her interest for more than a few pages. She fingered the stone ter'angreal through the bosom of her dress. Where are they? What do they want in the Heart? None but the Dragon - none but Rand - can touch Callandor, so what do they want? What? What?

əz naɪt dipənd, eɪlhuɪn ʃoʊɾ əm itʃ tə ə bɛdʒɹum ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, bʌɾ æftɝ ʃi hæd ɡɔn tə hɝ oʊn, ðeɪ ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ɛɡwinz baɪ ðə laɪɾ ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl læmp. ɛɡwin hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ənʒɹəst tə hɝ ʃɪft; ðə kɔɹd hʌŋ 'ɹaʊn əɹ nɛk wɪð ðə tu ɹɪŋz. ðə stʃɹaɪp stoʊn fɛl fɑɹ hɛviɝ ðən ðə ɡoʊld. ðɪs wɑz wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn ɛvɹi naɪt sɪns livɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɪð ðə soʊl ɪksɛpʃən ə ðət naɪt wɪð ði il.

As night deepened, Ailhuin showed them each to a bedroom on the second floor, but after she had gone to her own, they gathered in Egwene's by the light of a single lamp. Egwene had already undressed to her shift; the cord hung 'round her neck with the two rings. The striped stone felt far heavier than the gold. This was what they had done every night since leaving Tar Valon, with the sole exception of that night with the Aiel.

"weɪk mi æftɝ ən aʊɝ," ʃi toʊl ðɛm.

"Wake me after an hour," she told them.

ɪleɪn fɹaʊnd. "soʊ ʃɔɹt, ðɪs taɪm?"

Elayne frowned. "So short, this time?"

"du jə fil ənizi?" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "pɝhæps jə ɑɹ juzɪŋ ɪt tu ɔfən."

"Do you feel uneasy?" Nynaeve said. "Perhaps you are using it too often."

"wi wəd stɪl bi ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn skɹʌbɪŋ pɑts ən hoʊpɪŋ tə faɪn ə blæk sɪstɝ bɪfɔɹ ə ɡɹeɪ mæn faʊn əs ɪf aɪ hæd nɑt," ɛɡwin sɛd ʃɑɹpli. laɪt, ɪleɪnz ɹaɪt. aɪm snæpɪŋ laɪk ə sʌlki tʃaɪld. ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "pɝhæps aɪm ənizi. meɪbi ɪts kəz wəɹ soʊ kloʊz tə ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn, naʊ. soʊ kloʊs tə kælændɝ. soʊ kloʊs tə ðə tʃɹæp, wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz."

"We would still be in Tar Valon scrubbing pots and hoping to find a Black sister before a Gray Man found us if I had not," Egwene said sharply. Light, Elayne's right. I am snapping like a sulky child. She took a deep breath. "Perhaps I am uneasy. Maybe it is because we are so close to the Heart of the Stone, now. So close to Callandor. So close to the trap, whatever it is."

"bi kɛɹfəl," ɪleɪn sɛd, ən nɪneɪiv sɛd, mɔɹ kwaɪətli, "bi vɛɹi kɛɹfəl, ɛɡwin. pliz." ʃi wɑz tʌɡɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪɾ ɪn ʃɔɹt dʒɝks.

"Be careful," Elayne said, and Nynaeve said, more quietly, "Be very careful, Egwene. Please." She was tugging her braid in short jerks.

əz ɛɡwin leɪ daʊn ɑn ðə loʊ-poʊstɪd bɛd, wɪð əm ɑn stulz tə iðɝ saɪd, θʌndɝ ɹoʊld əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ. slip keɪm sloʊli.

As Egwene lay down on the low-posted bed, with them on stools to either side, thunder rolled across the sky. Sleep came slowly.

ɪt wɑz ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ hɪlz əɡɛn, əz ɔlweɪz ət fɝst, flaʊɝz ən bʌɾɝflaɪz ʌndɝ spɹɪŋ sʌnʃaɪn, sɑf bɹizɪz ən bɝdz sɪŋɪŋ. ʃi wɔɹ ɡɹin sɪlk, ðɪs taɪm, wɪð ɡoʊldən bɝdz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd oʊvɝ əɹ bɹɛsts, ən ɡɹin vɛlvət slɪpɝz. ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil sim laɪɾ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹɪft ʌp aʊɾ ə hɝ dʒɹɛs ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə weɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ hoʊldɪŋ ɪt daʊn.

It was the rolling hills again, as always at first, flowers and butterflies under spring sunshine, soft breezes and birds singing. She wore green silk, this time, with golden birds embroidered over her breasts, and green velvet slippers. The ter'angreal seemed light enough to drift up out of her dress except for the weight of the Great Serpent ring holding it down.

baɪ sɪmpəl tʃɹaɪəl ən ɛɹɝ ʃi hæd lɝn ə lɪɾəl ə ðə ɹulz ə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd - ivən ðɪs wɝld ə dʒɹimz, ðɪs ənsin wɝld, hæɾ ɪts ɹulz, ɪf ɑd wʌnz; ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ə tɛnθ ə ðɛm - ən wʌn weɪ tə meɪk hɝsɛlf ɡoʊ wɛɹ ʃi wɑntəd. kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz, ʃi ɛmptiɾ əɹ maɪn əz ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz izi, kəz ðə ɹoʊzbʌd kɛp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹm, ən ʃi kɛp sɛnsɪŋ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, kɛpt eɪkɪŋ tə ɛmbɹeɪs ɪt, bʌt ʃi hæd tə fɪl ði ɛmptinəs wɪð sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. ʃi pɪktʃɝd ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn, əz ʃi hæd sin ɪɾ ɪn ðiz dʒɹimz, fɔɹmd ɪɾ ɪn ɛvɹi dɪteɪl, pɝfəkt wɪðɪn ðə vɔɪd. ðə hjudʒ, pɑlɪʃt ɹɛdstoʊn kɑləmz. ði eɪdʒ-wɔɹn stoʊnz ə ðə flɔɹ. ðə doʊm, fɑɹ oʊvɝhɛd. ðə kɹɪstəl sɔɹd, əntʌtʃəbəl, sloʊli ɹivɑlvɪŋ hɪlt-daʊn ɪn mɪdɛɹ. wən ɪt wɑz soʊ ɹil ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd ɹitʃ aʊɾ ən tʌtʃ ɪt, ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz, ən ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ, ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn. əɹ ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn əz ɪɾ ɪɡzɪstəɾ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd.

By simple trial and error she had learned a little of the rules of Tel'aran'rhiod - even this World of Dreams, this Unseen World, had its rules, if odd ones; she was sure she did not know a tenth of them - and one way to make herself go where she wanted. Closing her eyes, she emptied her mind as she would have to embrace saidar. It was not as easy, because the rosebud kept trying to form, and she kept sensing the True Source, kept aching to embrace it, but she had to fill the emptiness with something else. She pictured the Heart of the Stone, as she had seen it in these dreams, formed it in every detail, perfect within the void. The huge, polished redstone columns. The age-worn stones of the floor. The dome, far overhead. The crystal sword, untouchable, slowly revolving hilt-down in midair. When it was so real she was sure she could reach out and touch it, she opened her eyes, and she was there, in the Heart of the Stone. Or the Heart of the Stone as it existed in Tel'aran'rhiod.

ðə kɑləmz wɝ ðɛɹ, ən kælændɝ. ən ɝaʊn ðə spɑɹklɪŋ sɔɹd, ɔlmoʊst əz dɪm ən ɪnsəbstæntʃəl əz ʃædoʊz, θɝtin wɪmən sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəd, stɛɹɪŋ ət kælændɝ əz ɪt ɹivɑlvd. hʌni-hɛɹd liɑnʒɹɪn tɝn əɹ hɛd, lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əɾ ɛɡwin wɪð ðoʊz bɪɡ, dɑɹk aɪz, ən əɹ ɹoʊzbʌd maʊθ smaɪld.

The columns were there, and Callandor. And around the sparkling sword, almost as dim and insubstantial as shadows, thirteen women sat cross-legged, staring at Callandor as it revolved. Honey-haired Liandrin turned her head, looking straight at Egwene with those big, dark eyes, and her rosebud mouth smiled.

ɡæspɪŋ, ɛɡwin sæɾ ʌp ɪn bɛd soʊ fæst ʃi ɔlmoʊs fɛl ɔf ðə saɪd.

Gasping, Egwene sat up in bed so fast she almost fell off the side.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ?" ɪleɪn dɪmændəd. "wʌt hæpənd? jə lʊk fɹaɪɾənd."

"What is the matter?" Elayne demanded. "What happened? You look frightened."

"ju oʊnli dʒʌs kloʊz jəɹ aɪz," nɪneɪiv sɛd sɔfli. "ðɪs ɪz ðə fɝs taɪm sɪns ðə vɛɹi bɪɡɪnɪŋ ðət juv kʌm bæk wɪθaʊɾ əs weɪkɪŋ ju. sʌmθɪŋ dɪd hæpən, dɪdn ɪt?" ʃi tʌɡd əɹ bɹeɪd ʃɑɹpli. "ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?"

"You only just closed your eyes," Nynaeve said softly. "This is the first time since the very beginning that you've come back without us waking you. Something did happen, didn't it?" She tugged her braid sharply. "Are you all right?"

haʊ dɪɾ aɪ ɡɛt bæk? ɛɡwin wʌndɝd. laɪt, aɪ də nɑɾ ivən noʊ wʌɾ aɪ dɪd. ʃi nu ʃi wɑz oʊnli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊɾ ɔf wʌt ʃi hæd tə seɪ. ənfæsənɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, ʃi hɛl ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ən ðə lɑɹdʒɝ, twɪstəd tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɑn əɹ pɑm. "ðeɪ ɑɹ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ʌs," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə seɪ hu. "æn aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ noʊ wəɹ ɪn tiɹ."

How did I get back? Egwene wondered. Light, I do not even know what I did. She knew she was only trying to put off what she had to say. Unfastening the cord around her neck, she held the Great Serpent ring and the larger, twisted ter'angreal on her palm. "They are waiting for us," she said finally. There was no need to say who. "And I think they know we are in Tear."

aʊtsaɪd, ðə stɔɹm bɹoʊk oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi.

Outside, the storm broke over the city.

ɹeɪn dʒɹʌmɪŋ ɑn ðə dɛk oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, mæt stɛɹɾ ət ðə stoʊnz bɔɹɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl bɪtwin ɪm ən tɑm, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt ɹɪli kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə ɡeɪm, ivən wɪð ən ændɔɝən sɪlvɝ mɑɹk ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði aʊtkʌm. θʌndɝ kɹæʃt, ən laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt ɪn ðə smɔl wɪndoʊz. fɔɹ læmps lɪt ðə kæptənz kæbən ə ðə swɪft. blʌɾi ʃɪp meɪ bi əz slik əz ðə bɝd, bʌɾ ɪts stɪl teɪkɪŋ tu blʌɾi lɔŋ. ðə vɛsəl ɡeɪv ə smɔl dʒoʊlt, ðən ənʌðɝ; ðə moʊʃən sim tə tʃeɪnʒ. hi hæd bɛɾɝ nɑt ɹʌn əs ɪndə ðə blʌɾi mʌd! ɪf hiz nɑt meɪkɪŋ ðə bɛs taɪm i kən ɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɪs bʌɾɝtʌb, əl stʌf ðət ɡoʊl daʊn ɪz θɹoʊt! jɔnɪŋ - hi hæd nɑt slɛpt wɛl sɪns livɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn; hi kəd nɑt stɑp wɝiɪŋ ɪnʌf tə slip wɛl - jɔnɪŋ, hi sɛɾ ə waɪt stoʊn ɑn ði ɪntɝsɛkʃən ə tu laɪnz; ɪn θɹi muvz, hi wəd kæptʃɝ nɪɹli ə fɪfθ ə tɑmz blæk stoʊnz.

Rain drumming on the deck over his head, Mat stared at the stones board on the table between him and Thom, but he could not really concentrate on the game, even with an Andoran silver mark riding on the outcome. Thunder crashed, and lightning flashed in the small windows. Four lamps lit the captain's cabin of the Swift. Bloody ship may be as sleek as the bird, but it's still taking too bloody long. The vessel gave a small jolt, then another; the motion seemed to change. He had better not run us into the bloody mud! If he is not making the best time he can wring out of this buttertub, I will stuff that gold down his throat! Yawning - he had not slept well since leaving Caemlyn; he could not stop worrying enough to sleep well - yawning, he set a white stone on the intersection of two lines; in three moves, he would capture nearly a fifth of Thom's black stones.

"ju kəd bi ə ɡʊd pleɪɝ, bɔɪ," ðə ɡlimən sɛɾ ɝaʊn ɪz paɪp, pleɪsɪŋ ɪz nɛkst stoʊn, "ɪf jə pʊt jəɹ maɪn tə ɪt." hɪz təbæk smɛld laɪk livz ən nʌts.

"You could be a good player, boy," the gleeman said around his pipe, placing his next stone, "if you put your mind to it." His tabac smelled like leaves and nuts.

mæt ɹitʃt fəɹ ənʌðɝ stoʊn fɹəm ðə paɪl əɾ ɪz ɛlboʊ, ðən blɪŋkt ən lɛɾ ɪt laɪ. ɪn ðə seɪm θɹi muvz, tɑmz stoʊnz wəd sɝaʊn oʊvɝ ə θɝɾ ə hɪz. hi hæd nɑt sin ɪt kʌmɪŋ, ən i kəd si noʊ ɪskeɪp. "du jə ɛvɝ luz ə ɡeɪm? hæv jə ɛvɝ lɔst ə ɡeɪm?"

Mat reached for another stone from the pile at his elbow, then blinked and let it lie. In the same three moves, Thom's stones would surround over a third of his. He had not seen it coming, and he could see no escape. "Do you ever lose a game? Have you ever lost a game?"

tɑm ɹimuvd ɪz paɪp ən nʌkəld ɪz mʌstæʃɪz. "nɑɾ ɪn ə lɔŋ waɪl. mɔɹɡeɪs juz tə bit mi əbaʊt hæf ðə taɪm. ɪts sɛd ɡʊd kəmændɝz ə soʊlʒɝz ən ɡʊd pleɪɝz ə ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm ɑɹ ɡʊɾ ət stoʊnz, əz wɛl. ʃiz ðə wʌn, ən aɪv noʊ daʊt ʃi kəd kəmæn ə bæɾəl, tu."

Thom removed his pipe and knuckled his mustaches. "Not in a long while. Morgase used to beat me about half the time. It is said good commanders of soldiers and good players of the Great Game are good at stones, as well. She is the one, and I've no doubt she could command a battle, too."

"wʊdn jə ɹæðɝ daɪs səm mɔɹ? stoʊnz teɪk tu mʌtʃ taɪm."

"Wouldn't you rather dice some more? Stones take too much time."

"aɪ laɪk ə tʃæns tə wɪn mɔɹ ðən wʌn tɔs ɪn naɪn əɹ tɛn," ðə waɪt-hɛɹd mæn sɛd dʒɹaɪli.

"I like a chance to win more than one toss in nine or ten," the white-haired man said dryly.

mæt baʊndəd tə hɪz fiɾ əz ðə dɔɹ bæŋd oʊpən tə ədmɪt kæptən dɝn. ðə skwɛɹ-feɪs mæn wɪpt ɪz kloʊk fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðə ɹeɪn ɔf ən mʌɾɝɪŋ kɝsɪz tə hɪmsɛlf. "ðə laɪt sɪɹ maɪ boʊnz, aɪ də nɑt noʊ waɪ aɪ ɛvɝ lɛt jə haɪɝ swɪft. ju, dɪmændɪŋ mɔɹ fleɪmɪŋ spiɾ ɪn ðə blækəs naɪɾ əɹ ðə hɛviəst ɹeɪn. mɔɹ spid. ɔlweɪz mɔɹ blʌɾi spid! cʊɾə ɹʌn ɑn ə blʌɾi mʌdflæɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz oʊvɝ baɪ naʊ!"

Mat bounded to his feet as the door banged open to admit Captain Derne. The square-faced man whipped his cloak from his shoulders, shaking the rain off and muttering curses to himself. "The Light sear my bones, I do not know why I ever let you hire Swift. You, demanding more flaming speed in the blackest night or the heaviest rain. More speed. Always more bloody speed! Could have run on a bloody mudflat a hundred times over by now!"

"ju wɑntəd ðə ɡoʊld," mæt sɛd hɑɹʃli. "ju sɛd ðɪs hip ʌv oʊl bɔɹdz wɑz fæst, dɝn. wən də wi ɹitʃ tiɹ?"

"You wanted the gold," Mat said harshly. "You said this heap of old boards was fast, Derne. When do we reach Tear?"

ðə kæptən smaɪld ə taɪt smaɪl. "wi ɑɹ taɪɪŋ ɔf tə ðə dɑk, naʊ. ən bɝn mi fəɹ ə blʌɾi fɑɹmɝ ɪf aɪ kæɹi ɛniθɪŋ ðət kən fleɪmɪŋ tɔk ɛvɝ əɡɛn! naʊ, wɛɹ ɪz ðə ɹɛst ə maɪ ɡoʊld?"

The captain smiled a tight smile. "We are tying off to the dock, now. And burn me for a bloody farmer if I carry anything that can flaming talk ever again! Now, where is the rest of my gold?"

mæt hɝid tə wʌn ə ðə smɔl wɪndoʊz ən pɪɹɾ aʊt. ɪn ðə hɑɹʃ ɡlɛɹ ə laɪtnɪŋ flæʃɪz i kəd si ə wɛt stoʊn dɑk, ɪf nɑt mʌtʃ ɛls. hi fɪʃt ðə sɛkən pɝs ʌv ɡoʊl fɹəm ɪz pɑkəɾ ən tɔst ɪt tə dɝn. huɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə ɹɪvɝmən u dɪdn daɪs! "əbaʊt taɪm," hi ɡɹaʊld. laɪt sɛn aɪm nɑt tu leɪt.

Mat hurried to one of the small windows and peered out. In the harsh glare of lightning flashes he could see a wet stone dock, if not much else. He fished the second purse of gold from his pocket and tossed it to Derne. Whoever heard of a riverman who didn't dice! "About time," he growled. Light send I'm not too late.

hi hæd stʌft ɔl ə hɪz spɛɹ kloʊðz ən ɪz blæŋkəts ɪndə ðə lɛðɝ skɹɪp, ən i hʌŋ ðəɾ ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə hɪm ən ðə ɹoʊl ə faɪɹwɝks ɑn ði ʌðɝ, fɹəm ðə kɔɹɾ i taɪd tə ɪt. hɪz kloʊk kʌvɝɾ ɪɾ ɔl, bʌt ɡæpt ə lɪɾəl ɪn ðə fɹʌnt. bɛɾɝ i ɡɑt wɛt ðən ðə faɪɹwɝks. hi kəd dʒɹaɪ aʊɾ ən bi əz ɡʊɾ əz nu; ə tɛst wɪð ə bʌkət hæd ʃoʊn faɪɹwɝks kəd nɑt. aɪ ɡɛs ɹændz dɑ wɑz ɹaɪt. mæt hæɾ ɔlweɪz θɔt ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl wəd nɑt sɛɾ əm ɔf ɪn ðə ɹeɪn kəz ðeɪ meɪɾ ə bɛɾɝ ʃoʊ ɑn klɪɹ naɪts.

He had stuffed all of his spare clothes and his blankets into the leather scrip, and he hung that on one side of him and the roll of fireworks on the other, from the cord he tied to it.
