His cloak covered it all, but gapped a little in the front. Better he got wet than the fireworks. He could dry out and be as good as new; a test with a bucket had shown fireworks could not. I guess Rand's da was right. Mat had always thought the Village Council would not set them off in the rain because they made a better show on clear nights.

"ɑɹən jə əbaʊt ɹɛɾi tə sɛl ðoʊz θɪŋz?" tɑm wɑz sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪz ɡlimənz kloʊk ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ɪt kʌvɝɾ ɪz lɛðɝ-keɪs hɑɹp ən flut, bʌɾ ɪz bʌndəl ə kloʊðz ən blæŋkəts i slʌŋ ɑn ɪz bæk aʊtsaɪd ðə pætʃ-kʌvɝd kloʊk.

"Aren't you about ready to sell those things?" Thom was settling his gleeman's cloak on his shoulders. It covered his leather-cased harp and flute, but his bundle of clothes and blankets he slung on his back outside the patch-covered cloak.

"nɑɾ əntɪl aɪ fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ ðeɪ wɝk, tɑm. bɪsaɪdz, θɪŋk wʌt fʌn ɪɾəl bi wən aɪ sɛɾ əm ɔl ɔf."

"Not until I figure out how they work, Thom. Besides, think what fun it will be when I set them all off."

ðə ɡlimən ʃʌɾɝəd. "æz lɔŋ əz jə doʊn də ɪɾ ɔl ət wʌns, bɔɪ. əz lɔŋ əz jə doʊn θɹoʊ ðɛm ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs ət sʌpɝ. aɪd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæs ju, ðə weɪ juv bɪn bɪheɪvɪŋ wɪð ðɛm. jəɹ lʌki ðə kæptən hɪɹ dɪd nɑt θɹoʊ əs ɔf ðə ʃɪp tu deɪz əɡoʊ."

The gleeman shuddered. "As long as you don't do it all at once, boy. As long as you don't throw them in the fireplace at supper. I'd not put it past you, the way you've been behaving with them. You're lucky the captain here did not throw us off the ship two days ago."

"hi wʊdnt." mæt læft. "nɑt waɪl ðət pɝs wɑz ɪn ði ɔfɪŋ. ɛ, dɝn?"

"He wouldn't." Mat laughed. "Not while that purse was in the offing. Eh, Derne?"

dɝn wɑz tɔsɪŋ ðə pɝs ʌv ɡoʊld ɪn ɪz hænd. "aɪ hæv nɑɾ æsk bɪfɔɹ ðɪs, bʌt juv ɡɪvən mi ðə ɡoʊld, naʊ, ən jəl nɑt teɪk ɪt bæk. wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs ɔl əbaʊt? ɔl ðɪs fleɪmɪŋ spid."

Derne was tossing the purse of gold in his hand. "I have not asked before this, but you've given me the gold, now, and you'll not take it back. What is this all about? All this flaming speed."

"ə weɪdʒɝ, dɝn." jɔnɪŋ, mæt pɪkt ʌp ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf, ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ. "ə weɪdʒɝ."

"A wager, Derne." Yawning, Mat picked up his quarterstaff, ready to go. "A wager."

"ə weɪdʒɝ!" dɝn stɛɹɾ ət ðə hɛvi pɝs. ði ʌðɝ dʒʌs laɪk ɪt wɑz lɑkt ɪn ɪz mʌni tʃɛst. "ðɛɹ mʌs bi ə fleɪmɪŋ kɪŋdəm ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪt!"

"A wager!" Derne stared at the heavy purse. The other just like it was locked in his money chest. "There must be a flaming kingdom riding on it!"

"mɔɹ ðən ðæt," mæt sɛd.

"More than that," Mat said.

ɹeɪn bʌkəɾɪd daʊn ɑn ðə dɛk soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ i kəd nɑt si ðə ɡæŋplæŋk ɪksɛpt wən laɪtnɪŋ kɹækəld əbʌv ðə sɪɾi; ðə ɹɔɹ ə ðə daʊnpɔɹ bɛɹli lɛɾ ɪm hɪɹ hɪmsɛlf θɪŋk. hi kəd si laɪts ɪn wɪndoʊz ʌp ə stʃɹit, ðoʊ. ðəɹ wəd bi ɪnz, ʌp ðɛɹ. ðə kæptən hæd nɑt kʌm ɑn dɛk tə si ðɛm əʃɔɹ, ən nʌn ə ðə kɹu hæd steɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn, iðɝ. mæt ən tɑm meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə stoʊn dɑk əloʊn.

Rain bucketed down on the deck so hard that he could not see the gangplank except when lightning crackled above the city; the roar of the downpour barely let him hear himself think. He could see lights in windows up a street, though. There would be inns, up there. The captain had not come on deck to see them ashore, and none of the crew had stayed out in the rain, either. Mat and Thom made their way to the stone dock alone.

mæt kɝst wən ɪz buts sæŋk ɪndə ðə mʌɾ ə ðə stʃɹit, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt, soʊ hi kɛpt ɑn, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ əz fæst əz i kəd wɪð ɪz buts ən ðə bʌɾ ə hɪz stæf stɪkɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹi stɛp. ði ɛɹ smɛld ə fɪʃ, ɹæŋk ivən wɪð ðə ɹeɪn. "wil faɪn ən ɪn," hi sɛd, laʊdli, soʊ hi kəd bi hɝd, "æn ðən əl ɡoʊ aʊt lʊkɪŋ."

Mat cursed when his boots sank into the mud of the street, but there was nothing for it, so he kept on, striding along as fast as he could with his boots and the butt of his staff sticking at every step. The air smelled of fish, rank even with the rain. "We'll find an inn," he said, loudly, so he could be heard, "and then I will go out looking."

"ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ?" tɑm ʃaʊɾəd bæk. ɹeɪn wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn ɪz feɪs, bʌɾ i wɑz mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn kipɪŋ ɪz ɪnstʃɹəməns kʌvɝd ðən ɪz feɪs.

"In this weather?" Thom shouted back. Rain was rolling down his face, but he was more interested in keeping his instruments covered than his face.

"koʊmɹ cʊɾə lɛf keɪɛmlɪn bɪfɔɹ ʌs. ɪf i hæɾ ə ɡʊd hɔɹs ɪnstɛɾ ə ðə kɹoʊbeɪts wi wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ, hi cʊɾə sɛɾ aʊt daʊnɹɪvɝ fɹəm ɑɹɪŋɡəl meɪbi ə fʊl deɪ əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs, ən aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ mʌtʃ ə ðət wi kɑɾ ʌp wɪð ðəɾ ɪɾiət dɝn."

"Comar could have left Caemlyn before us. If he had a good horse instead of the crowbaits we were riding, he could have set out downriver from Aringill maybe a full day ahead of us, and I don't know how much of that we caught up with that idiot Derne."

"ɪt wɑz ə kwɪk pæsədʒ," tɑm əlaʊd. "swɪf dɪzɝvz ɪts neɪm."

"It was a quick passage," Thom allowed. "Swift deserves its name."

"bi ðəɾ əz ɪt meɪ, tɑm, ɹeɪn əɹ noʊ ɹeɪn, aɪ hæv tə faɪn ɪm bɪfɔɹ i faɪnz ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv, ən ɪleɪn."

"Be that as it may, Thom, rain or no rain, I have to find him before he finds Egwene and Nynaeve, and Elayne."

"ə fju mɔɹ aʊɝz woʊn meɪk mʌtʃ dɪfɝəns, bɔɪ. ðəɹ ɑɹ hʌnʒɹədz ʌv ɪnz ɪn ə sɪɾi ðə saɪz ə tɛɹ. ðəɹ meɪ bi hʌnʒɹədz mɔɹ aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz, səm ə ðɛm lɪɾəl pleɪsəz wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə dʌzən ɹumz tə lɛt, soʊ taɪni jə kəd wɔk ɹaɪt baɪ ðɛm ən nɛvɝ noʊ ðeɪ wɝ ðɛɹ." ðə ɡlimən hɪtʃt ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk ʌp mɔɹ, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. "ɪt wɪl teɪk wiks tə sɝtʃ əm ɔl. bʌɾ ɪɾəl teɪk koʊmɹ ðə seɪm wiks. wi kən spɛn ðə naɪɾ ɪn aʊɾ ə ðə ɹeɪn. jə kən weɪdʒɝ wʌtɛvɝ kɔɪn juv lɛf ðət koʊmɹ woʊn bi aʊɾ ɪn ɪt."

"A few more hours won't make much difference, boy. There are hundreds of inns in a city the size of Tear. There may be hundreds more outside the walls, some of them little places with no more than a dozen rooms to let, so tiny you could walk right by them and never know they were there." The gleeman hitched the hood of his cloak up more, muttering to himself. "It will take weeks to search them all. But it will take Comar the same weeks. We can spend the night in out of the rain. You can wager whatever coin you have left that Comar won't be out in it."

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ə taɪni ɪn wɪð ə dʌzən ɹumz. bɪfɔɹ i lɛft ɛmənz fild, ðə bɪɡəs bɪldɪŋ i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin wɑz ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn. hi daʊɾɪd ɪf bɹæn ælvɪɹ hæɾ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ə dʌzən ɹumz tə lɛt. ɛɡwin hæd lɪvd wɪð əɹ pɛɹəns ən əɹ sɪstɝz ɪn ðə ɹumz ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə sɛkən flɔɹ. bɝn mi, səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəd nɛvɝ ɛni ʌv əs əv lɛft ɛmənz fild. bʌt ɹænd ʃʊɹli hæd hæd tə, ən ɛɡwin wəd pɹɑbli hæv daɪɾ ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɔn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. naʊ ʃi maɪt daɪ kəz ʃi dɪd ɡoʊ. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i kəd sɛɾəl fəɹ ðə fɑɹm əɡɛn; ðə kaʊz ən ðə ʃip sɝɾənli wəd nɑt pleɪ daɪs. bʌt pɛɹɪn stɪl hæɾ ə tʃæns tə ɡoʊ hoʊm. ɡoʊ hoʊm, pɛɹɪn, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf θɪŋkɪŋ. ɡoʊ hoʊm waɪl jə stɪl kæn. hi ɡeɪv hɪmsɛlf ə ʃeɪk. ful! waɪ wəɾ i wɑn tə? hi θɔɾ ə bɛd, bʌt pʊʃt ɪɾ əweɪ. nɑt jɛt.

Mat shook his head. A tiny inn with a dozen rooms. Before he left Emond's Field, the biggest building he had ever seen was the Winespring Inn. He doubted if Bran al'Vere had any more than a dozen rooms to let. Egwene had lived with her parents and her sisters in the rooms at the front of the second floor. Burn me, sometimes I think we should never any of us have left Emond's Field. But Rand surely had had to, and Egwene would probably have died if she had not gone to Tar Valon. Now she might die because she did go. He did not think he could settle for the farm again; the cows and the sheep certainly would not play dice. But Perrin still had a chance to go home. Go home, Perrin, he found himself thinking. Go home while you still can. He gave himself a shake. Fool! Why would he want to? He thought of bed, but pushed it away. Not yet.

laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹikt əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ, θɹi dʒæɡd boʊls təɡɛðɝ, kæstɪŋ ə stɑɹk laɪɾ oʊvɝ ə nɛɹoʊ haʊs ðət sim tə hæv bʌntʃəz ə ɝbz hæŋɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz, ən ə ʃɑp, ʃʌɾ ʌp taɪt, bʌɾ ə pɑɾɝz fɹəm ðə saɪn wɪð ɪts boʊlz ən pleɪts. jɔnɪŋ, hi hʌntʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝz əɡɛns ðə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɹeɪn ən tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl ɪz buts aʊɾ ə ðə klɪŋɪŋ mʌd mɔɹ kwɪkli.

Lightning streaked across the sky, three jagged bolts together, casting a stark light over a narrow house that seemed to have bunches of herbs hanging in the windows, and a shop, shut up tight, but a potter's from the sign with its bowls and plates. Yawning, he hunched his shoulders against the driving rain and tried to pull his boots out of the clinging mud more quickly.

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, tɑm," hi ʃaʊɾəd. "ɔl ðɪs mʌd, ən ðət stɪŋk ə fɪʃ. kən jə si nɪneɪiv əɹ ɛɡwin - əɹ ɪleɪn! - tʃuzɪŋ tə steɪ hɪɹ? wɪmən laɪk θɪŋz niɾ ən taɪɾi, tɑm, ən smɛlɪŋ ɡʊd."

"I think I can forget about this part of the city, Thom," he shouted. "All this mud, and that stink of fish. Can you see Nynaeve or Egwene - or Elayne! - choosing to stay here? Women like things neat and tidy, Thom, and smelling good."

"meɪ bi, bɔɪ," tɑm mʌɾɝd, ðən kɔft. "ju wəd bi sɝpɹaɪzd wʌt wɪmən wɪl pʊɾ ʌp wɪð. bʌɾ ɪt meɪ bi."

"May be, boy," Thom muttered, then coughed. "You would be surprised what women will put up with. But it may be."

hoʊldɪŋ ɪz kloʊk tə kip ðə ɹoʊl ə faɪɹwɝks kʌvɝd, mæt lɛŋθən ɪz stʃɹaɪd. "kʌm ɑn, tɑm. aɪ wɑnə faɪn koʊmɹ əɹ ðə ɡɝlz tənaɪt, wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ."

Holding his cloak to keep the roll of fireworks covered, Mat lengthened his stride. "Come on, Thom. I want to find Comar or the girls tonight, one or the other."

tɑm lɪmpt æftɝ hɪm, kɑfɪŋ naʊ ən əɡɛn.

Thom limped after him, coughing now and again.

ðeɪ stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðə waɪd ɡeɪts ɪn ðə sɪɾi - ənɡɑɹɾɪd, ɪn ðə ɹeɪn - ən mæt wɑz ɹɪliv tə fil peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ʌndɝ ɪz fiɾ əɡɛn. ən nɑt mɔɹ ðən fɪfti peɪsɪz ʌp ðə stʃɹit wɑz ən ɪn, ðə wɪndoʊz ə ðə kɑmən ɹum spɪlɪŋ laɪɾ ɑntu ðə stʃɹit, mjuzɪk dʒɹɪftɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt. ivən tɑm kʌvɝd ðət læs fɪfti peɪsɪz θɹu ðə ɹeɪn kwɪkli, lɪmp əɹ noʊ lɪmp.

They strode through the wide gates in the city - unguarded, in the rain - and Mat was relieved to feel paving stones under his feet again. And not more than fifty paces up the street was an inn, the windows of the common room spilling light onto the street, music drifting out into the night. Even Thom covered that last fifty paces through the rain quickly, limp or no limp.

ðə waɪt kɹɛsən hæɾ ə lændlɔɹd huz ɡɝθ meɪɾ ɪz lɔŋ blu koʊt fɪt snʌɡli bɪloʊ ðə weɪst əz wɛl əz əbʌv, ənlaɪk ðoʊz ə moʊst ə ðə mɛn ɪn ðə loʊ-bæk tʃɛɹz ət ðə teɪbəlz. mæt θɔt ðə lændlɔɹdz bæɡi bɹitʃɪz, taɪɾ ət ði æŋkəl əbʌv loʊ ʃuz, hæd tə bi bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ tu ɔɹɾənɛɹi mɛn tə fɪɾ ɪnsaɪd, wʌn ɪn itʃ lɛɡ. ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən wɔɹ dɑɹk, haɪ-nɛk dʒɹɛsəz ən ʃɔɹt waɪɾ eɪpɹənz. ðəɹ wɑz ə fɛloʊ pleɪɪŋ ə hæmɝd dʌlsɪmɝ bɪtwin ðə tu stoʊn faɪɝpleɪsəz. tɑm aɪd ðə fɛloʊ kɹɪɾɪkəli ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ðə ɹoʊtʌn ɪnkipɝ, keɪvən loʊpɝ baɪ neɪm, wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɡlæd tə ɡɪv əm ɹumz. hi fɹaʊn ət ðɛɹ mʌɾi buts, bʌt sɪlvɝ fɹəm mæts pɑkət - ðə ɡoʊld wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ loʊ - ən tɑmz pætʃ-kʌvɝd kloʊk smuðd ɪz fæt fɔɹhɛd. wən tɑm sɛɾ i wəd pɝfɔɹm fəɹ ə smɔl fi səm naɪts, loʊpɝz tʃɪnz wæɡəld wɪð plɛʒɝ. ʌv ə bɪɡ mæn wɪð ə waɪt stʃɹik ɪn ɪz bɪɹd, hi nu nʌθɪŋ, nɔɹ ə θɹi wɪmən miɾɪŋ ðə dɪskɹɪpʃənz mæt ɡeɪv. mæt lɛft ɛvɹiθɪŋ bʌɾ ɪz kloʊk ən ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf ɪn ɪz ɹum, bɛɹli lʊkɪŋ tə si ðəɾ ɪt hæɾ ə bɛd - slip wɑz ɛntaɪsɪŋ, bʌɾ i ɹəfjuz tə lɛt hɪmsɛlf θɪŋk ʌv ɪt - ðən wʊlf daʊn ə spaɪsi fɪʃ stu ən ɹʌʃt bæk aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹeɪn. hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz ðət tɑm keɪm wɪð hɪm.

The White Crescent had a landlord whose girth made his long blue coat fit snugly below the waist as well as above, unlike those of most of the men in the low-backed chairs at the tables. Mat thought the landlord's baggy breeches, tied at the ankle above low shoes, had to be big enough for two ordinary men to fit inside, one in each leg. The serving women wore dark, high-necked dresses and short white aprons. There was a fellow playing a hammered dulcimer between the two stone fireplaces. Thom eyed the fellow critically and shook his head. The rotund innkeeper, Cavan Lopar by name, was more than glad to give them rooms. He frowned at their muddy boots, but silver from Mat's pocket - the gold was running low - and Thom's patch-covered cloak smoothed his fat forehead. When Thom said he would perform for a small fee some nights, Lopar's chins waggled with pleasure. Of a big man with a white streak in his beard, he knew nothing, nor of three women meeting the descriptions Mat gave. Mat left everything but his cloak and his quarterstaff in his room, barely looking to see that it had a bed - sleep was enticing, but he refused to let himself think of it - then wolfed down a spicy fish stew and rushed back out into the rain. He was surprised that Thom came with him.

"aɪ θɔt jə wɑntəd tə bi ɪn wɛɹ ɪts dʒɹaɪ, tɑm."

"I thought you wanted to be in where it's dry, Thom."

ðə ɡlimən pæɾəd ðə flut keɪs i stɪl hæɾ ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk. ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz θɪŋz wɝ ʌp ɪn ɪz ɹum. "pipəl tɔk tə ə ɡlimən, bɔɪ. aɪ meɪ lɝn sʌmθɪŋ jə wəd nɑt. aɪd nɑt laɪk tə si ðoʊz ɡɝlz hɑɹmd ɛni mɔɹ ðən ju."

The gleeman patted the flute case he still had under his cloak. The rest of his things were up in his room. "People talk to a gleeman, boy. I may learn something you would not. I'd not like to see those girls harmed any more than you."

ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ ɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz daʊn ðə ɹeɪn-fɪl stʃɹiɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ən ənʌðɝ tu hʌnʒɹəd bɪɑn ðæt, ən ðən mɔɹ. mæt tʊk əm əz i keɪm tə ðɛm, dʌkɪŋ ɪn lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ tɑm tə flɝɪʃ ɪz kloʊk ən tɛl ə stɔɹi, ðən lɛt sʌmwʌn baɪ hɪm ə kʌp ʌv waɪn æftɝwɝdz waɪl mæt æskt ɝaʊn æftɝ ə tɔl mæn wɪð ə waɪt stʃɹik ɪn ɪz kloʊs-kʌt blæk bɪɹɾ ən θɹi wɪmən. hi wʌn ə fju kɔɪnz ət daɪs, bʌɾ i lɝnd nʌθɪŋ, ən niðɝ dɪd tɑm. hi wɑz dʒʌst ɡlæd ðə ɡlimən sim tə bi teɪkɪŋ oʊnli ə fju sɪps ʌv waɪn əɾ itʃ ɪn; tɑm hæd bɪn kloʊz tə əbstimiəs ɑn ðə boʊt, bʌt mæt hæd nɑt bɪn sɝɾən i wəd nɑt daɪv bæk ɪndə ðə waɪn wʌns ðeɪ ɹitʃt tiɹ. baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ hæd vɪzəɾəd tu dʌzən kɑmən ɹumz, mæt fɛlt əz ɪf ɪz aɪlɪdz hæd weɪts. ðə ɹeɪn hæd lɛsən ə bɪt, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl fɛl stɛɾəli ɪn bɪɡ dʒɹɑps, ən əz ðə ɹeɪn fɛl ɔf ðə wɪn hæd fɹɛʃənd. ðə skaɪ hæd ðə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ lʊk ə kʌmɪŋ dɔn.

There was another inn a hundred paces down the rain-filled street on the other side, and another two hundred beyond that, and then more. Mat took them as he came to them, ducking in long enough for Thom to flourish his cloak and tell a story, then let someone buy him a cup of wine afterwards while Mat asked around after a tall man with a white streak in his close-cut black beard and three women. He won a few coins at dice, but he learned nothing, and neither did Thom. He was just glad the gleeman seemed to be taking only a few sips of wine at each inn; Thom had been close to abstemious on the boat, but Mat had not been certain he would not dive back into the wine once they reached Tear. By the time they had visited two dozen common rooms, Mat felt as if his eyelids had weights. The rain had lessened a bit, but it still fell steadily in big drops, and as the rain fell off the wind had freshened. The sky had the dark gray look of coming dawn.

"bɔɪ," tɑm mʌɾɝd, "ɪf wi doʊnt ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə waɪt kɹɛsənt, aɪm gɑnə ɡoʊ tə slip hɪɹ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn." hi stɑp tə kɑf. "du jə ɹilaɪz juv mɑɹtʃt ɹaɪt pæs θɹi ɪnz? laɪt, aɪm soʊ taɪɝɾ aɪ kæn θɪŋk. juv ə skim ʌv wɛɹ tə ɡoʊ ðət juv nɑt toʊl mi?"

"Boy," Thom muttered, "if we don't go back to The White Crescent, I am going to go to sleep here in the rain." He stopped to cough. "Do you realize you've marched right past three inns? Light, I am so tired I can't think. Do you have a scheme of where to go that you have not told me?"

mæt stɛɹd blɝəli ʌp ðə stʃɹiɾ əɾ ə tɔl mæn ɪn ə kloʊk hɝiɪŋ ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ. laɪt, aɪm taɪɝd. ɹænd ɪz faɪv hʌnʒɹəd liɡz fɹəm hɪɹ, pleɪɪŋ ət biɪŋ ðə blʌɾi dʒɹæɡən. "wʌt? θɹi ɪnz?" ðeɪ wɝ stændɪŋ ɔlmoʊst ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ənʌðɝ, ðə ɡoʊldən kʌp əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə saɪn kɹikɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. ɪt lʊk nʌθɪŋ laɪk ə daɪs kʌp, bʌɾ i dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɡɪv ɪɾ ə tʃɹaɪ ɛniweɪ. "wʌn mɔɹ, tɑm. ɪf wi doʊn faɪn əm hɪɹ, wɪl ɡoʊ bæk ən ɡoʊ tə bɛd." bɛd saʊndəd bɛɾɝ ðən ə daɪs ɡeɪm wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd ɡoʊl mɑɹks ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə tɔs, bʌɾ i meɪd hɪmsɛlf ɡoʊ ɪn.

Mat stared blearily up the street at a tall man in a cloak hurrying around a corner. Light, I am tired. Rand is five hundred leagues from here, playing at being the bloody Dragon. "What? Three inns?" They were standing almost in front of another, The Golden Cup according to the sign creaking in the wind. It looked nothing like a dice cup, but he decided to give it a try anyway. "One more, Thom. If we don't find them here, we'll go back and go to bed." Bed sounded better than a dice game with a hundred gold marks riding on the toss, but he made himself go in.

tu stɛps ɪndə ðə kɑmən ɹum mæt sɔ hɪm. ðə bɪɡ mæn wɔɹ ə ɡɹin koʊt wɪð blu stʃɹaɪps daʊn pʌfi slivz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz koʊmɹ, kloʊs-kʌt blæk bɪɹd wɪð ə waɪt stʃɹik oʊvɝ ɪz tʃɪn ən ɔl. hi sæɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə stʃɹeɪnʒli loʊ-bæk tʃɛɹz, əɾ ə teɪbəl ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, ɹætlɪŋ ə lɛðɝ daɪs kʌp ən smaɪlɪŋ ət ðə mæn əkɹɔs fɹəm hɪm. ðət fɛloʊ wɔɹ ə lɔŋ koʊɾ ən bæɡi bɹitʃɪz, ən i wɑz nɑt smaɪlɪŋ. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə kɔɪnz ɑn ðə teɪbəl əz ɪf wɪʃɪŋ i hæɾ əm bæk ɪn ɪz pɝs. ənʌðɝ daɪs kʌp sæɾ ət koʊmɹz ɛlboʊ.

Two steps into the common room Mat saw him. The big man wore a green coat with blue stripes down puffy sleeves, but it was Comar, close-cut black beard with a white streak over his chin and all. He sat in one of the strangely low-backed chairs, at a table on the far side of the room, rattling a leather dice cup and smiling at the man across from him. That fellow wore a long coat and baggy breeches, and he was not smiling. He stared at the coins on the table as if wishing he had them back in his purse. Another dice cup sat at Comar's elbow.

koʊmɹ ʌpɛndəd ðə lɛðɝ kʌp ɪn ɪz hænd, ən bɪɡæn læfɪŋ ɔlmoʊs bɪfɔɹ ðə daɪs stɑp spɪnɪŋ. "hu ɪz nɛkst?" hi kɔld laʊdli, pʊlɪŋ ðə weɪdʒɝ tə hɪz saɪɾ ə ðə teɪbəl. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl paɪl ə sɪlvɝ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. hi skup ðə daɪs ɪndə ðə kʌp ən ɹæɾəld ðɛm. "ʃʊɹli sʌmwʌn ɛls wɑns tə tʃɹaɪ hɪz lʌk?" ɪt sim ðət noʊ wʌn dɪd, bʌɾ i kɛpt ɹætlɪŋ ðə kʌp ən læfɪŋ.

Comar upended the leather cup in his hand, and began laughing almost before the dice stopped spinning. "Who is next?" he called loudly, pulling the wager to his side of the table. There was already a considerable pile of silver in front of him. He scooped the dice into the cup and rattled them. "Surely someone else wants to try his luck?" It seemed that no one did, but he kept rattling the cup and laughing.

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz izi tə pɪk aʊt, ðoʊ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə wɛɹ eɪpɹənz ɪn tɛɹ. hɪz koʊt wɑz ðə seɪm ʃeɪɾ ə dip blu əz ðəɾ ʌv ɛvɹi ʌðɝ ɪnkipɝ mæt hæd spoʊkən tə. ə plʌmp mæn, ðoʊ lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən hæf ðə saɪz ə loʊpɝ ən wɪð hæf ðət fɛloʊz nʌmbɝ ə tʃɪnz, hi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ əɾ ə teɪbəl baɪ hɪmsɛlf, pɑlɪʃɪŋ ə pjuɾɝ mʌɡ fjʊɹiəsli ən ɡlɛɹɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum təwɔɹd koʊmɹ, ðoʊ nɑt wən koʊmɹ wɑz lʊkɪŋ. səm ə ði ʌðɝ mɛn ɡeɪv ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn saɪɾɛlɔŋ fɹaʊnz, tu. bʌt nɑt wən i wɑz lʊkɪŋ.

The innkeeper was easy to pick out, though they did not seem to wear aprons in Tear. His coat was the same shade of deep blue as that of every other innkeeper Mat had spoken to. A plump man, though little more than half the size of Lopar and with half that fellow's number of chins, he was sitting at a table by himself, polishing a pewter mug furiously and glaring across the room toward Comar, though not when Comar was looking. Some of the other men gave the bearded man sidelong frowns, too. But not when he was looking.

mæt səpɹɛst ɪz fɝst ɝdʒ, wɪtʃ wɑz tə ɹʌʃ oʊvɝ tə koʊmɹ, dʒɹʌb ɪm oʊvɝ ðə hɛd wɪð ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf, ən dɪmæn tə noʊ wɛɹ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ hɪɹ. koʊmɹ wɑz ðə fɝs mæn i hæd sin wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹd, bʌt ðə weɪ ðə mɛn lʊkt əɾ ɪm wɑz mɔɹ ðən fɪɹ ʌv ə sɔɝdzmən. ivən ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən u bɹɔt koʊmɹ ə fɹɛʃ kʌp ʌv waɪn - ən wɑz pɪntʃt fəɹ əɹ tʃɹʌbəl - hæɾ ə nɝvəs læf fəɹ hɪm.

Mat suppressed his first urge, which was to rush over to Comar, drub him over the head with his quarterstaff, and demand to know where Egwene and the others were. Something was wrong here. Comar was the first man he had seen wearing a sword, but the way the men looked at him was more than fear of a swordsman. Even the serving woman who brought Comar a fresh cup of wine - and was pinched for her trouble - had a nervous laugh for him.

lʊk əɾ ɪt fɹəm ɛvɹi saɪd, mæt θɔt wɛɹəli. hæf ðə tʃɹʌbəl aɪ ɡɛɾ ɪndə ɪz fɹəm nɑt duɪŋ ðæt. aɪ hæv tə θɪŋk. taɪɹədnəs sim tə hæv stʌft ɪz hɛd wɪð wʊl. hi moʊʃən tə tɑm, ən ðeɪ stʃɹoʊld oʊvɝ tə ði ɪnkipɝ, hu aɪɾ əm səspɪʃəsli wən ðeɪ sæt daʊn. "hu ɪz ðə mæn wɪð ðə stʃɹaɪp ɪn ɪz bɪɹd?" mæt æskt.

Look at it from every side, Mat thought wearily. Half the trouble I get into is from not doing that. I have to think. Tiredness seemed to have stuffed his head with wool. He motioned to Thom, and they strolled over to the innkeeper, who eyed them suspiciously when they sat down. "Who is the man with the stripe in his beard?" Mat asked.

"nɑt fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, ɑɹ ju?" ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd. "hi ɪz ə fɔɹənɝ, tu. aɪv nɛvɝ sin ɪm bɪfɔɹ tənaɪt, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ wʌɾ i ɪz. səm aʊtləndɝ u hæz kʌm hɪɹ ən meɪɾ ɪz fɔɹtʃən ɪn tʃɹeɪd. ə mɝtʃən ɹɪtʃ ɪnʌf tə wɛɹ ə sɔɹd. ðəɾ ɪz noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ɪm tə tʃɹiɾ əs laɪk ðɪs."

"Not from the city, are you?" the innkeeper said. "He is a foreigner, too. I've never seen him before tonight, but I know what he is. Some outlander who has come here and made his fortune in trade. A merchant rich enough to wear a sword. That is no reason for him to treat us like this."

"ɪf juv nɛvɝ sin ɪm bɪfɔɹ," mæt sɛd, "haʊ dʒju noʊ hiz ə mɝtʃənt?"

"If you have never seen him before," Mat said, "how do you know he is a merchant?"

ði ɪnkipɝ lʊkt əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i wɝ stupəd. "hɪz koʊt, mæn, ən ɪz sɔɹd. hi kænɑt bi ə lɔɹɾ əɹ ə soʊlʒɝ ɪf hiz fɹəm ɔf, soʊ hiz tə bi ə ɹɪtʃ mɝtʃənt." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd fəɹ ðə stupɪɾɪti ʌv fɔɹənɝz. "ðeɪ kʌm tə əɹ pleɪsəz, tə lʊk daʊn ðɛɹ noʊzɪz əɾ ʌs, ən fɑndəl ðə ɡɝlz ʌndɝ əɹ vɛɹi aɪz, bʌt hiz noʊ kɔl tə də ðɪs. ɪf aɪ ɡoʊ tə ðə mɔl, aɪ doʊnt ɡæmbəl fəɹ səm fɪʃɝmænz kɔɪnz. ɪf aɪ ɡoʊ tə ðə tɑvɑɹ, aɪ də nɑt daɪs wɪð ðə fɑɹmɝz kʌm tə sɛl ðɛɹ kɹɑps." hɪz pɑlɪʃɪŋ ɡeɪn ɪn fɝɑsəɾi. "sʌtʃ lʌk, ðə mæn hæz. ɪt mʌs bi haʊ hi meɪɾ ɪz fɔɹtʃən."

The innkeeper looked at him as if he were stupid. "His coat, man, and his sword. He cannot be a lord or a soldier if he's from off, so he has to be a rich merchant." He shook his head for the stupidity of foreigners. "They come to our places, to look down their noses at us, and fondle the girls under our very eyes, but he has no call to do this. If I go to the Maule, I don't gamble for some fisherman's coins. If I go to the Tavar, I do not dice with the farmers come to sell their crops." His polishing gained in ferocity. "Such luck, the man has. It must be how he made his fortune."

"hi wɪnz, dʌz hi?" jɔnɪŋ, mæt wʌndɝd haʊ hi wəd də dɪsɪŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ mæn u hæd lʌk.

"He wins, does he?" Yawning, Mat wondered how he would do dicing with another man who had luck.

"səmtaɪmz i luzəz," ði ɪnkipɝ mʌɾɝd, "wɛn ðə steɪk ɪz ə fju sɪlvɝ pɛniz. səmtaɪmz. bʌt lɛɾ ɪt ɹitʃ ə sɪlvɝ mɑɹk. . . . noʊ lɛs ðən ə dʌzən taɪmz tənaɪt, aɪ hæv sin ɪm wɪn ət kɹaʊnz wɪð θɹi kɹaʊnz ən tu ɹoʊzɪz. ən hæf əɡɛn əz ɔfən, ət tɑp, ɪts bɪn θɹi sɪksɪz ən tu faɪvz. hi tɔsɪz nʌθɪŋ bʌt sɪksɪz ət θɹiz, ən θɹi sɪksɪz ən ə faɪv ɛvɹi θɹoʊ ət kʌmpəs. ɪf hiz sətʃ lʌk, aɪ seɪ ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn hɪm, ən wɛl tə hɪm, bʌt lɛɾ ɪm juz ɪt wɪð ʌðɝ mɝtʃəns, əz ɪz pɹɑpɝ. haʊ kən ə mæn əv sətʃ lʌk?"

"Sometimes he loses," the innkeeper muttered, "when the stake is a few silver pennies. Sometimes. But let it reach a silver mark. . . . No less than a dozen times tonight, I have seen him win at Crowns with three crowns and two roses. And half again as often, at Top, it has been three sixes and two fives. He tosses nothing but sixes at Threes, and three sixes and a five every throw at Compass. If he has such luck, I say the Light shine on him, and well to him, but let him use it with other merchants, as is proper. How can a man have such luck?"

"weɪɾɪd daɪs," tɑm sɛd, ðən kɔft. "wɛn i wɑns tə bi ʃʊɹ ʌv wɪnɪŋ, hi juzɪz daɪs ðəɾ ɔlweɪz ʃoʊ ðə seɪm feɪs. hiz smɑɹɾ ɪnʌf nɑt tə hæv meɪɾ ɪt ðə haɪəs tɔs - foʊk bɪkʌm səspɪʃəs ɪf jə ɔlweɪz θɹoʊ ðə kɪŋ" - hi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət mæt - "dʒʌst wʌn ðæts ɔl bʌɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl tə bit, bʌɾ i kænɑt tʃeɪnʒ ðət ðeɪ ɔlweɪz ʃoʊ ðə seɪm feɪs."

"Weighted dice," Thom said, then coughed. "When he wants to be sure of winning, he uses dice that always show the same face. He is smart enough not to have made it the highest toss - folk become suspicious if you always throw the king" - he raised an eyebrow at Mat - "just one that's all but impossible to beat, but he cannot change that they always show the same face."

"aɪ hæv hɝɾ ə sʌtʃ," ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd sloʊli. "ɪliɑnɝz juz ðɛm, aɪ hɪɹ." ðən i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "bʌt boʊθ mɛn juz ðə seɪm kʌp ən daɪs. ɪt kænɑt bi."

"I have heard of such," the innkeeper said slowly. "Illianers use them, I hear." Then he shook his head. "But both men use the same cup and dice. It cannot be."

"bɹɪŋ mi tu daɪs kʌps," tɑm sɛd, "æn tu sɛts ə daɪs. kɹaʊnz əɹ spɑts, ɪt meɪks noʊ dɪfɝəns, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə seɪm."

"Bring me two dice cups," Thom said, "and two sets of dice. Crowns or spots, it makes no difference, so long as they are the same."

ði ɪnkipɝ fɹaʊn ət hɪm, bʌt lɛft - pɹuɾəntli teɪkɪŋ ðə pjuɾɝ kʌp wɪð ɪm - ən keɪm bæk wɪð tu lɛðɝ kʌps. tɑm ɹoʊl ðə faɪv boʊn kjubz fɹəm wʌn ɑntu ðə teɪbəl ɪn fɹʌn ə mæt. wɛðɝ wɪð spɑts əɹ sɪmbəlz, ɛvɹi sɛɾ ə daɪs mæt hæɾ ɛvɝ sin hæd bɪn iðɝ boʊn əɹ wʊd. ðiz hæd spɑts. hi pɪkt əm ʌp, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət tɑm. "æm aɪ səpoʊz tə si sʌmθɪŋ?"

The innkeeper frowned at him, but left - prudently taking the pewter cup with him - and came back with two leather cups. Thom rolled the five bone cubes from one onto the table in front of Mat. Whether with spots or symbols, every set of dice Mat had ever seen had been either bone or wood. These had spots. He picked them up, frowning at Thom. "Am I supposed to see something?"

tɑm dʌmp ðə daɪs fɹəm ði ʌðɝ kʌp ɪndə hɪz hænd, ðɛn, ɔlmoʊs tu kwɪkli tə fɑloʊ, dʒɹɑpt əm bæk ɪn ən twɪstəd ðə kʌp oʊvɝ tə ɹɛst ʌpsaɪd daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl bɪfɔɹ ðə daɪs kəd fɔl aʊt. hi kɛpt ɪz hæn ɑn tɑp ə ðə kʌp. "pʊɾ ə mɑɹk ɑn itʃ ə ðɛm, bɔɪ. sʌmθɪŋ smɔl, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ jəl noʊ fəɹ jəɹ mɑɹk."

Thom dumped the dice from the other cup into his hand, then, almost too quickly to follow, dropped them back in and twisted the cup over to rest upside down on the table before the dice could fall out. He kept his hand on top of the cup. "Put a mark on each of them, boy. Something small, but something you'll know for your mark."

mæt faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ pʌzəld ɡlænsɪz wɪð ði ɪnkipɝ. ðən ðeɪ boʊθ lʊkt ət ðə kʌp ʌpsaɪd daʊn ʌndɝ tɑmz hænd. hi nu tɑm wɑz ʌp tə sʌmθɪŋ tʃɹɪki - ɡlimən wɝ ɔlweɪz duɪŋ θɪŋz ðət wɝ ɪmpɑsəbəl, laɪk iɾɪŋ faɪɝ ən pʊlɪŋ sɪlk aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ - bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt si haʊ tɑm kəd də ɛniθɪŋ wɪð ɪm wɑtʃɪŋ kloʊs. hi ənʃiðd ɪz bɛl naɪf ən meɪɾ ə smɔl skɹætʃ ɑn itʃ daɪ, ɹaɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə sɝkəl ə sɪks spɑts.

Mat found himself exchanging puzzled glances with the innkeeper. Then they both looked at the cup upside down under Thom's hand. He knew Thom was up to something tricky - gleemen were always doing things that were impossible, like eating fire and pulling silk out of the air - but he did not see how Thom could do anything with him watching close. He unsheathed his belt knife and made a small scratch on each die, right across the circle of six spots.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ əm bæk ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "ʃoʊ mi jəɹ tʃɹɪk."

"All right," he said, setting them back on the table. "Show me your trick."

tɑm ɹitʃt oʊvɝ ən pɪkt ʌp ðə daɪs, ðən sɛɾ əm daʊn əɡɛn ə fʊɾ əweɪ. "lʊk fəɹ jəɹ mɑɹks, bɔɪ."

Thom reached over and picked up the dice, then set them down again a foot away. "Look for your marks, boy."

mæt fɹaʊnd. tɑmz hænd wɑz stɪl ɑn ði ʌpɛndəd lɛðɝ kʌp; ðə ɡlimən hæd nɑt muvd ɪɾ əɹ teɪkən mæts daɪs ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ ɪt. hi pɪkt ʌp ðə daɪs . . . ən blɪŋkt. ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə skɹætʃ ɑn ðɛm. ði ɪn-kipɝ ɡæspt.

Mat frowned. Thom's hand was still on the upended leather cup; the gleeman had not moved it or taken Mat's dice anywhere near it. He picked up the dice . . . and blinked. There was not a scratch on them. The inn-keeper gasped.

tɑm tɝn ɪz fɹi hæn oʊvɝ, ɹɪvilɪŋ faɪv daɪs. "jɔɹ mɑɹks ɑɹ ɑn ðiz. ðəɾ ɪz wʌt koʊmɹ ɪz duɪŋ. ɪts ə tʃaɪlz tʃɹɪk, sɪmpəl, ðoʊ aɪd nɛvɝ əv θɔɾ i hæd ðə fɪŋɡɝz fəɹ ɪt."

Thom turned his free hand over, revealing five dice. "Your marks are on these. That is what Comar is doing. It is a child's trick, simple, though I'd never have thought he had the fingers for it."

"aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk aɪ wɑnə pleɪ daɪs wɪð jə æftɝ ɔl," mæt sɛd sloʊli. ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə daɪs, bʌt nɑɾ əz ɪf i sɔ ɛni səluʃən. "kɔl ðə wɑtʃ, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ jə kɔl ɪt hɪɹ," mæt toʊl hɪm. "hæv ɪm ɝɛstəd." hɪl kɪl noʊbɑdi ɪn ə pɹɪzən sɛl. jɛt wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi dɛd? hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lɪsən, bʌt ðə θɔt pɝsɪstəd. ðən əl si hɪm dɛd, ən ɡeɪbɹəl, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt teɪks! bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹənt, bɝn mi! ðeɪ kæn bi!

"I do not think I want to play dice with you after all," Mat said slowly. The innkeeper was staring at the dice, but not as if he saw any solution. "Call the Watch, or whatever you call it here," Mat told him. "Have him arrested." He'll kill nobody in a prison cell. Yet what if they are already dead? He tried not to listen, but the thought persisted. Then I'll see him dead, and Gaebril, whatever it takes! But they aren't, burn me! They can't be!

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "mi? mi, dɪnaʊns ə mɝtʃən tə ðə dɪfɛndɝz? ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ ivən lʊk əɾ ɪz daɪs. hi kəd seɪ wʌn wɝd, ən aɪ wəd bi ɪn tʃeɪnz wɝkɪŋ ðə tʃænɛldʒɹɛdʒɪz ɪn ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. hi kəd kʌt mi daʊn wɛɹ aɪ stʊd, ən ðə dɪfɛndɝz wəd seɪ aɪ hæɾ ɝn ɪt. pɝhæps hɪl ɡoʊ əweɪ æftɝ ə waɪl."

The innkeeper was shaking his head. "Me? Me, denounce a merchant to the Defenders? They would not even look at his dice. He could say one word, and I would be in chains working the channeldredges in the Fingers of the Dragon. He could cut me down where I stood, and the Defenders would say I had earned it. Perhaps he will go away after a while."

mæt ɡeɪv ɪm ə ɹaɪ ɡɹɪmɑs. "ɪf aɪ ɪkspoʊz hɪm, wɪl ðət bi ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf? wɪl jə kɔl ðə wɑtʃ, əɹ ðə dɪfɛndɝz əɹ huɛvɝ, ðɛn?"

Mat gave him a wry grimace. "If I expose him, will that be good enough? Will you call the Watch, or the Defenders or whoever, then?"

"ju də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. jə ɑɹ ə fɔɹənɝ. ivən ɪf hiz fɹəm ɔf, hiz ə wɛlθi mæn, ɪmpɔɹɾənt."

"You do not understand. You are a foreigner. Even if he is from off, he is a wealthy man, important."

"weɪt hɪɹ," mæt toʊl tɑm. "aɪ də nɑt min tə lɛɾ ɪm ɹitʃ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt teɪks." hi jɔn əz i skɹeɪp bæk ɪz tʃɛɹ.

"Wait here," Mat told Thom. "I do not mean to let him reach Egwene and the others, whatever it takes." He yawned as he scraped back his chair.

"weɪt, bɔɪ," tɑm kɔld æftɝ hɪm, sɑf jɛɾ ɝdʒənt. ðə ɡlimən pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf ʌp aʊɾ ə hɪz tʃɛɹ. "bɝn ju, jə doʊnt noʊ wʌt jəɹ pʊɾɪŋ jəɹ fʊɾ ɪntu!"

"Wait, boy," Thom called after him, soft yet urgent. The gleeman pushed himself up out of his chair. "Burn you, you don't know what you're putting your foot into!"

mæt weɪv fəɹ ɪm tə steɪ ðəɹ ən wɔkt oʊvɝ tə koʊmɹ. noʊ wʌn ɛls hæd teɪkən ʌp ðə bɪɹɾəd mænz tʃælənʒ, ən i aɪd mæt wɪð ɪntʃɹəst əz mæt lin ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf əɡɛns ðə teɪbəl ən sæt daʊn.

Mat waved for him to stay there and walked over to Comar. No one else had taken up the bearded man's challenge, and he eyed Mat with interest as Mat leaned his quarterstaff against the table and sat down.

koʊmɹ stʌɾid mæts koʊɾ ən ɡɹɪnd næstəli. "ju wɑnə weɪdʒɝ kɑpɝz, fɑɹmɝ? aɪ də nɑt weɪs maɪ taɪm wɪð - " hi kʌɾ ɔf əz mæt sɛɾ ən ændɔɝən ɡoʊl kɹaʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən jɔn ət hɪm, meɪkɪŋ noʊ ɛfɝt tə kʌvɝ ɪz maʊθ. "ju seɪ lɪɾəl, fɑɹmɝ, ðoʊ jəɹ mænɝz kəd juz ɪmpɹuvɪŋ, bʌt ɡoʊld əz ə vɔɪs ʌv ɪts oʊn ən noʊ niɾ ə mænɝz." hi ʃʊk ðə lɛðɝ kʌp ɪn ɪz hæn ən spɪl ðə daɪs aʊt. hi wɑz tʃʌklɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ keɪm tə ɹɛst, ʃoʊɪŋ θɹi kɹaʊnz ən tu ɹoʊzɪz. "jul nɑt bit ðæt, fɑɹmɝ. pɝhæps juv mɔɹ ɡoʊl hɪɾən ɪn ðoʊz ɹæɡz ðət jə wɑnə luz? wʌd jə du? ɹɑb jəɹ mæstɝ?"

Comar studied Mat's coat and grinned nastily. "You want to wager coppers, farmer? I do not waste my time with - " He cut off as Mat set an Andoran gold crown on the table and yawned at him, making no effort to cover his mouth. "You say little, farmer, though your manners could use improving, but gold has a voice of its own and no need of manners." He shook the leather cup in his hand and spilled the dice out. He was chuckling before they came to rest, showing three crowns and two roses. "You'll not beat that, farmer. Perhaps you have more gold hidden in those rags that you want to lose? What did you do? Rob your master?"

hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə daɪs, bʌt mæt skupt əm ʌp əhɛɾ ə hɪm. koʊmɹ ɡlɛɹd, bʌt lɛɾ ɪm əv ðə kʌp. ɪf boʊθ tɔsɪz wɝ ðə seɪm, ðeɪ wəd θɹoʊ əɡɛn əntɪl wʌn mæn wʌn. mæt smaɪld əz i ɹæɾəld ðə daɪs. hi dɪd nɑt min tə ɡɪv koʊmɹ ə tʃæns tə tʃeɪnʒ ðɛm. ɪf ðeɪ θɹu ðə seɪm tɔs θɹi əɹ fɔɹ taɪmz ɪn ə ɹoʊ - ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm, ɛvɹi taɪm - ivən ðiz dɪfɛndɝz wəd lɪsən. ðə hoʊl kɑmən ɹum wəd si; ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə bæk ɪz wɝd.

He reached for the dice, but Mat scooped them up ahead of him. Comar glared, but let him have the cup. If both tosses were the same, they would throw again until one man won. Mat smiled as he rattled the dice. He did not mean to give Comar a chance to change them. If they threw the same toss three or four times in a row - exactly the same, every time - even these Defenders would listen. The whole common room would see; they would have to back his word.

hi spɪl ðə daɪs ɑntu ðə teɪbəltɑp. ðeɪ baʊnst ɑdli. hi fɛlt - sʌmθɪŋ - ʃɪftɪŋ. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ɪz lʌk hæd ɡɔn waɪld. ðə ɹum sim tə bi ɹaɪðɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm, tʌɡɪŋ ət ðə daɪs wɪð θɹɛdz. fəɹ səm ɹizən i wɑntəd tə lʊk ət ðə dɔɹ, bʌɾ i kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn ðə daɪs. ðeɪ keɪm tə ɹɛst. faɪv kɹaʊnz. koʊmɹz aɪz lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə pɑp aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd.

He spilled the dice onto the tabletop. They bounced oddly. He felt - something - shifting. It was as if his luck had gone wild. The room seemed to be writhing around him, tugging at the dice with threads. For some reason he wanted to look at the door, but he kept his eyes on the dice. They came to rest. Five crowns. Comar's eyes looked ready to pop out of his head.

"ju luz," mæt sɛd sɔfli. ɪf ɪz lʌk wɑz ɪn tə ðɪs ɪkstɛnt, pɝhæps ɪt wɑz taɪm tə pʊʃ ɪt. ə vɔɪs ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd toʊld ɪm tə θɪŋk, bʌɾ i wɑz tu taɪɝd tə lɪsən. "aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ lʌk ɪz əbaʊt juzd ʌp, koʊmɹ. ɪf juv hɑɹm ðoʊz ɡɝlz, ɪts ɔl ɡɔn."

"You lose," Mat said softly. If his luck was in to this extent, perhaps it was time to push it. A voice in the back of his head told him to think, but he was too tired to listen. "I think your luck is about used up, Comar. If you've harmed those girls, it's all gone."

"aɪ hæv nɑɾ ivən faʊnd . . ." koʊmɹ bɪɡæn, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə daɪs, ðən dʒɝkt ɪz hɛɾ ʌp. hɪz feɪs hæd ɡɔn waɪt. "haʊ dʒju noʊ maɪ neɪm?"

"I have not even found . . ." Comar began, still staring at the dice, then jerked his head up. His face had gone white. "How do you know my name?"

hi hæd nɑt faʊn ðɛm, jɛt. lʌk, swit lʌk, steɪ wɪð mi. "ɡoʊ bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn, koʊmɹ. tɛl ɡeɪbɹəl jə kəd nɑt faɪn ðɛm. tɛl ɪm ðeɪ ɑɹ dɛd. tɛl ɪm ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt liv tɛɹ tənaɪt. ɪf aɪ si jə əɡɛn, əl kɪl ju."

He had not found them, yet. Luck, sweet luck, stay with me. "Go back to Caemlyn, Comar. Tell Gaebril you could not find them. Tell him they are dead. Tell him anything, but leave Tear tonight. If I see you again, I'll kill you."

"hu ɑɹ ju?" ðə bɪɡ mæn sɛɾ ənstɛɾəli. "hu - ?" ðə nɛkst ɪnstən ɪz sɔɹd wɑz aʊɾ ən i wɑz ɑn ɪz fit.

"Who are you?" the big man said unsteadily. "Who - ?" The next instant his sword was out and he was on his feet.

mæt ʃʌv ðə teɪbəl ət hɪm, oʊvɝtɝnɪŋ ɪt, ən ɡɹæb fəɹ ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf. hi hæd fɝɡɑɾən haʊ bɪɡ koʊmɹ wɑz. ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn pʊʃt ðə teɪbəl ɹaɪt bæk ət hɪm. mæt fɛl oʊvɝ wɪð ɪz tʃɛɹ, hoʊldɪŋ ə bɛɹ ɡɹæsp ɑn ɪz stæf, əz koʊmɹ hiv ðə teɪbəl aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ən stæbd ət hɪm. mæt θɹu hɪz fiɾ əɡɛns ðə mænz mɪɾəl tə stɑp ɪz ɹʌʃ, swʌŋ ðə stæf ɔkwɝdli, dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə dɪflɛk ðə sɔɹd. bʌt ðə bloʊ nɑk ðə stæf fɹəm ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, ən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɡɹɪpɪŋ koʊmɹz ɹɪst, ɪnstɛd, wɪð ðə mænz bleɪɾ ə hæn fɹəm ɪz feɪs. wɪð ə ɡɹʌn i ɹoʊl bækwɝdz, hivɪŋ əz hɑɹɾ əz i kəd wɪð ɪz lɛɡz. koʊmɹz aɪz waɪɾənd əz i seɪld oʊvɝ mæt tə kɹæʃ ɑntu ə teɪbəl, feɪs ʌp. mæt skɹæmbəl fəɹ ɪz stæf, bʌt wən i hæɾ ɪt, koʊmɹ hæd nɑt muvd.

Mat shoved the table at him, overturning it, and grabbed for his quarterstaff. He had forgotten how big Comar was. The bearded man pushed the table right back at him. Mat fell over with his chair, holding a bare grasp on his staff, as Comar heaved the table out of the way and stabbed at him. Mat threw his feet against the man's middle to stop his rush, swung the staff awkwardly, just enough to deflect the sword. But the blow knocked the staff from his fingers, and he found himself gripping Comar's wrist, instead, with the man's blade a hand from his face. With a grunt he rolled backwards, heaving as hard as he could with his legs. Comar's eyes widened as he sailed over Mat to crash onto a table, face up. Mat scrambled for his staff, but when he had it, Comar had not moved.

ðə bɪɡ mæn leɪ wɪð ɪz hɪps ən lɛɡz spɹɔld əkɹɔs ðə tɑp ə ðə teɪbəl, ðə ɹɛst ə hɪm hæŋɪŋ daʊn wɪð ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðə mɛn u hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ət ðə teɪbəl wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ fiɾ ə seɪf dɪstəns əweɪ, ɹɪŋɪŋ ðɛɹ hænz ən aɪɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ nɝvəsli. ə loʊ, wɝid bʌz fɪl ðə kɑmən ɹum, nɑt ðə nɔɪz mæt ɪkspɛktəd.

The big man lay with his hips and legs sprawled across the top of the table, the rest of him hanging down with his head on the floor. The men who had been sitting at the table were on their feet a safe distance away, wringing their hands and eyeing each other nervously. A low, worried buzz filled the common room, not the noise Mat expected.

koʊmɹz sɔɹd leɪ wɪðɪn izi ɹitʃ ə hɪz hænd. bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt muv. hi stɛɹɾ ət mæt, ðoʊ, əz mæt kɪk ðə sɔɹɾ əweɪ ən wɛn tə wʌn ni bɪsaɪd hɪm. laɪt! aɪ θɪŋk ɪz bæk ɪz bɹoʊkən! "aɪ toʊl jə jə ʃəɾ əv ɡɔn, koʊmɹ. jəɹ lʌk ɪz ɔl juzd ʌp."

Comar's sword lay within easy reach of his hand. But he did not move. He stared at Mat, though, as Mat kicked the sword away and went to one knee beside him. Light! I think his back is broken! "I told you you should have gone, Comar. Your luck is all used up."

"ful," ðə bɪɡ mæn bɹiðd. "du jə . . . θɪŋk aɪ . . . wɑz ði oʊnli . . . wʌn hʌntɪŋ ðɛm? ðeɪ woʊnt . . . lɪv tɪl. . . ." hɪz aɪz stɛɹɾ ət mæt, ən ɪz maʊθ wɑz oʊpən, bʌɾ i sɛd noʊ mɔɹ. nɔɹ ɛvɝ wəɾ əɡɛn.

"Fool," the big man breathed. "Do you . . . think I . . . was the only . . . one hunting them? They won't . . . live till. . . ." His eyes stared at Mat, and his mouth was open, but he said no more. Nor ever would again.

mæt mɛt ðə ɡleɪzɪŋ stɛɹ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɪl mɔɹ wɝdz aʊɾ ə ðə dɛd mæn. hu ɛls, bɝn ju? hu? wɛɹ ɑɹ ðeɪ? maɪ lʌk. bɝn mi, wʌt hæpən tə maɪ lʌk? hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə ði ɪnkipɝ pʊlɪŋ fɹæntəkəli əɾ ɪz ɑɹm.

Mat met the glazing stare, trying to will more words out of the dead man. Who else, burn you? Who? Where are they? My luck. Burn me, what happened to my luck? He became aware of the innkeeper pulling frantically at his arm.

"ju mʌst ɡoʊ. jə mʌst. bɪfɔɹ ðə dɪfɛndɝz kʌm. əl ʃoʊ ðɛm ðə daɪs. əl tɛl əm ɪt wɑz ən aʊtləndɝ, bʌɾ ə tɔl mæn. wɪð ɹɛd-kʌlɝd hɛɹ, ən ɡɹeɪ aɪz. noʊ wʌn wɪl sʌfɝ. ə mæn aɪ dʒɹimd ə læs naɪt. noʊ wʌn ɹil. noʊ wʌn wɪl kɑntʃɹədɪk mi. hi tʊk kɔɪn fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn wɪð ɪz daɪs. bʌt jə mʌst ɡoʊ. jə mʌst!" ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz stuɾiəsli lʊkɪŋ ənʌðɝ weɪ.

"You must go. You must. Before the Defenders come. I will show them the dice. I will tell them it was an outlander, but a tall man. With red-colored hair, and gray eyes. No one will suffer. A man I dreamed of last night. No one real. No one will contradict me. He took coin from everyone with his dice. But you must go. You must!" Everyone else in the room was studiously looking another way.

mæt lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi hɔld əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɛd mæn ən pʊʃt aʊtsaɪd. tɑm wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn. hi siz mæts ɑɹm ən lɪmp daʊn ðə stʃɹit hɝidli, pʊlɪŋ mæt stʌmbəlɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. mæts hʊd hʌŋ daʊn ɪz bæk; ðə ɹeɪn soʊkt ɪz hɛɹ ən pɔɹd daʊn ɪz feɪs, daʊn ɪz nɛk, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs. ðə ɡlimən kɛp lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, sɝtʃɪŋ ðə stʃɹit bɪɑn mæt.

Mat let himself be hauled away from the dead man and pushed outside. Thom was already waiting in the rain. He seized Mat's arm and limped down the street hurriedly, pulling Mat stumbling behind him. Mat's hood hung down his back; the rain soaked his hair and poured down his face, down his neck, but he did not notice. The gleeman kept looking over his shoulder, searching the street beyond Mat.

"ɑɹ jə əslip, bɔɪ? jə dɪd nɑt lʊk əslip bæk ðɛɹ. kʌm ɑn, bɔɪ. ðə dɪfɛndɝz wɪl ɝɛst ɛni aʊtləndɝ wɪðɪn tu stʃɹits, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt dɪskɹɪpʃən ðəɾ ɪnkipɝ ɡɪvz."

"Are you asleep, boy? You did not look asleep back there. Come on, boy. The Defenders will arrest any outlander within two streets, no matter what description that innkeeper gives."

"ɪts ðə lʌk," mæt mʌmbəld. "aɪv fɪɡjɝɾ ɪɾ aʊt. ðə daɪs. maɪ lʌk wɝks bɛst wən θɪŋz ɑɹ . . . ɹændəm. laɪk daɪs. nɑt mʌtʃ ɡʊd fəɹ kɑɹdz. noʊ ɡʊɾ ət stoʊnz. tu mʌtʃ pæɾɝn. ɪts tə bi ɹændəm. ivən faɪndɪŋ koʊmɹ. aɪd stɑp vɪzəɾɪŋ ɛvɹi ɪn. aɪ wɔkt ɪndə ðət wʌn baɪ tʃæns. tɑm, ɪf aɪm gɑnə faɪn ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz ɪn taɪm, aɪ hæv tə lʊk wɪθaʊɾ ɛni pæɾɝn."

"It's the luck," Mat mumbled. "I've figured it out. The dice. My luck works best when things are . . . random. Like dice. Not much good for cards. No good at stones. Too much pattern. It has to be random. Even finding Comar. I'd stopped visiting every inn. I walked into that one by chance. Thom, if I am going to find Egwene and the others in time, I have to look without any pattern."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt? ðə mæn ɪz dɛd. ɪf i ɔlɹɛɾi kɪl ðɛm. . . . wɛl, juv əvɛnʒd ðɛm. ɪf i hæzənt, jə seɪv ðɛm. naʊ wɪl jə blʌɾi wɔk fæstɝ? ðə dɪfɛndɝz woʊn bi lɔŋ kʌmɪŋ, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt soʊ dʒɛntəl əz ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz."

"What are you talking about? The man is dead. If he already killed them. . . . Well, you've avenged them. If he hasn't, you saved them. Now will you bloody walk faster? The Defenders won't be long coming, and they are not so gentle as the Queen's Guards."

mæt ʃʊk ɪz ɑɹm fɹi ən pɪkt ʌp ɪz peɪs ənstɛɾəli, dʒɹæɡɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf. "hi lɛɾ ɪt slɪp ðəɾ i hædn loʊkeɪɾəd ðɛm, jɛt. bʌɾ i sɛɾ i wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn. tɑm, aɪ bɪliv hɪm. aɪ wɑz lʊkɪŋ ɪm ɪn ði aɪ, ən i wɑz tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ. aɪ stɪl əv tə faɪn ðɛm, tɑm. ən naʊ aɪ doʊn ivən noʊ hu ɪz æftɝ ðɛm. aɪ hæv tə faɪn ðɛm."

Mat shook his arm free and picked up his pace unsteadily, dragging the quarterstaff. "He let it slip that he hadn't located them, yet. But he said he was not the only one. Thom, I believe him. I was looking him in the eye, and he was telling the truth. I still have to find them, Thom. And now I don't even know who is after them. I have to find them."

staɪflɪŋ ə hjudʒ jɔn wɪð ɪz fɪst, tɑm pʊl mæts hʊɾ ʌp əɡɛns ðə ɹeɪn. "nɑt tənaɪt, bɔɪ. aɪ nid slip, ən soʊ də ju."

Stifling a huge yawn with his fist, Thom pulled Mat's hood up against the rain. "Not tonight, boy. I need sleep, and so do you."

wɛt. maɪ hɛɹz dʒɹɪpɪŋ ɪn maɪ feɪs. hɪz hɛd sim fʌzi. wɪð ə nid fəɹ slip, hi ɹilaɪzd æftɝ ə moʊmənt. ən i ɹilaɪz haʊ taɪɝɾ i wɑz, ɪf i hæd tə θɪŋk dʒʌs tə noʊ ɪt. "ɔl ɹaɪt, tɑm. bʌɾ aɪm gɑnə lʊk əɡɛn əz sun əz ɪts laɪt." tɑm nɑɾəd ən kɔft, ən ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ bæk tə ðə waɪt kɹɛsən θɹu ðə ɹeɪn.

Wet. My hair's dripping in my face. His head seemed fuzzy. With a need for sleep, he realized after a moment. And he realized how tired he was, if he had to think just to know it. "All right, Thom. But I am going to look again as soon as it's light." Thom nodded and coughed, and they made their way back to The White Crescent through the rain.

dɔn wɑz nɑt lɔŋ ɪn kʌmɪŋ, bʌt mæt ɹstɪd hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə bɛd, ən i ən tɑm sɛɾ ɔf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɝtʃ ɛvɹi ɪn ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz ə tɛɹ. mæt lɛt hɪmsɛlf wɑndɝ wɛɹɛvɝ ðə muɾ ən ðə nɛks tɝnɪŋ tʊk hɪm, nɑt lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɪnz əɾ ɔl, ən tɔsɪŋ ə kɔɪn tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə ɡoʊ ɪn. fəɹ θɹi deɪz ən naɪts i dɪd ðɪs, ən fəɹ θɹi deɪz ən naɪts ɪt ɹeɪnd wɪθaʊt stɑpɪŋ, səmtaɪmz θʌndɝɪŋ, səmtaɪmz kwaɪət, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz pɔɹɪŋ daʊn.

Dawn was not long in coming, but Mat rousted himself out of bed, and he and Thom set off trying to search every inn inside the walls of Tear. Mat let himself wander wherever the mood and the next turning took him, not looking for inns at all, and tossing a coin to decide whether to go in. For three days and nights he did this, and for three days and nights it rained without stopping, sometimes thundering, sometimes quiet, but always pouring down.

tɑmz kɑf ɡɹu wɝs, soʊ hi hæd tə stɑp pleɪɪŋ ðə fluɾ ən tɛlɪŋ stɔɹiz, ən i wəd nɑt kæɹi hɪz hɑɹp aʊɾ ɪn ðət wɛðɝ; hi ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ɡoʊɪŋ əlɔŋ, haʊɛvɝ, ən mɛn stɪl tɔk tə ə ɡlimən. mæts lʌk wɪð ðə daɪs simd ivən bɛɾɝ sɪns i hæd bɪɡʌn ðɪs ɹændəm wɑndɝ, ðoʊ hi nɛvɝ steɪɾ ɪn wʌn ɪn əɹ tævɝn lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə wɪn mɔɹ ðən ə fju kɔɪnz. niðɝ ə ðɛm hɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl. ɹumɝz ʌv wɔɹ wɪð ɪljən. ɹumɝz ʌv ɪnveɪɾɪŋ min. ɹumɝz ʌv ɪnveɪʒən fɹəm ændɝ, ʌv ðə si foʊk ʃʌɾɪŋ ɔf tʃɹeɪd, ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɛd. ɹumɝz ðə dʒɹæɡən wɑz kʌmɪŋ. ðə mɛn mæt ɡæmbəld wɪð wɝ əz ɡlumi əbaʊt wʌn ɹumɝ əz ðə nɛkst; ðeɪ sim tə hɪm tə hʌn fəɹ ðə dɑɹkəst ɹumɝz ðeɪ kəd faɪn ən hæf bɪliv əm ɔl. bʌɾ i hɝd nɑɾ ə wɪspɝ ðət maɪt lɛɾ ɪm tə ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz. nɑt wʌn ɪnkipɝ hæd sin wɪmən mætʃɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪskɹɪpʃənz.

Thom's cough grew worse, so he had to stop playing the flute and telling stories, and he would not carry his harp out in that weather; he insisted on going along, however, and men still talked to a gleeman. Mat's luck with the dice seemed even better since he had begun this random wander, though he never stayed in one inn or tavern long enough to win more than a few coins. Neither of them heard anything useful. Rumors of war with Illian. Rumors of invading Mayene. Rumors of invasion from Andor, of the Sea Folk shutting off trade, of Artur Hawkwing's armies returning from the dead. Rumors the Dragon was coming. The men Mat gambled with were as gloomy about one rumor as the next; they seemed to him to hunt for the darkest rumors they could find and half believe them all. But he heard not a whisper that might lead him to Egwene and the others. Not one innkeeper had seen women matching their descriptions.

hi bɪɡæn tə hæv bæd dʒɹimz, noʊ daʊt fɹəm ɔl ɪz wɝiɪŋ. ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn, ən səm fɛloʊ wɪð kloʊs-kɹɑpt waɪt hɛɹ, wɛɹɪŋ ə koʊt wɪð pʌfi, stʃɹaɪp slivz laɪk koʊmɹz, læfɪŋ ən wivɪŋ ə nɛɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm. oʊnli səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz mɔɪɹeɪn i wɑz wivɪŋ ðə nɛt fɔɹ, ən səmtaɪmz i hɛld ə kɹɪstəl sɔɹɾ ɪnstɛd, ə sɔɹd ðət bleɪz laɪk ðə sʌn əz sun əz i tʌtʃt ɪt. səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz ɹænd u hɛl ðə sɔɹd. fəɹ səm ɹizən, hi dʒɹimd ə ɹænd ə ɡʊd dil.

He began to have bad dreams, no doubt from all his worrying. Egwene and Nynaeve and Elayne, and some fellow with close-cropped white hair, wearing a coat with puffy, striped sleeves like Comar's, laughing and weaving a net around them. Only sometimes it was Moiraine he was weaving the net for, and sometimes he held a crystal sword instead, a sword that blazed like the sun as soon as he touched it. Sometimes it was Rand who held the sword. For some reason, he dreamed of Rand a good deal.

mæt wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ɔl kəz i wɑz nɑt ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪnʌf slip, nɑɾ iɾɪŋ ɪksɛpt wən i hæpən tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ, bʌɾ i wəd nɑt stɑp. hi hæɾ ə weɪdʒɝ tə wɪn, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf, ən i mɛn tə wɪn ðɪs wʌn ɪf ɪt kɪl hɪm.

Mat was sure it was all because he was not getting enough sleep, not eating except when he happened to remember, but he would not stop. He had a wager to win, he told himself, and he meant to win this one if it killed him.


tʃæptɝ fɪfti


CHAPTER 50

ðə hæmɝ


The Hammer

ði æftɝnun sʌn wɑz hɑɾ əz ðə fɛɹi dɑkt ɪn tɛɹ; pʌɾəlz stʊɾ ɑn ðə stimɪŋ stoʊnz ə ðə dɑk, ən ði ɛɹ simd ɔlmoʊst əz dæmp tə pɛɹɪn əz ɪljənz hæd. ði ɛɹ smɛld ə pɪtʃ ən wʊɾ ən ɹoʊp - hi kəd si ʃɪpjɑɹdz fɝðɝ saʊθ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ - ʌv spaɪsəz ən aɪɝn ən bɑɹli, ʌv pɝfjumz ən waɪnz ən ə hʌnʒɹəd dɪfɹən ɝoʊməz i kəd nɑt sɪŋɡəl aʊt fɹəm ðə mɛlæŋ, moʊs kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə wɛɹhaʊzɪz bɪhaɪn ðə dɑks. wən ðə wɪn swɝl moʊməntɛɹəli aʊɾ ə ðə nɔɹθ, hi kɑt ðə sɛns ə fɪʃ, tu, bʌt ðoʊz feɪɾəd əz ðə wɪn swʌŋ bæk. noʊ smɛlz ʌv ɛniθɪŋ tə hʌnt. hɪz maɪn ɹitʃt aʊt tə fil fəɹ wʊlvz bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ ən snæpt ɪz ɡɑɹdz ʃʌt. hi hæd dʌn ðət tu ɔfən ə leɪt. ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ wʊlvz, ʌv kɔɹs. nɑɾ ɪn ə sɪɾi laɪk ðɪs. hi wɪʃt ɪt dɪd nɑt fil soʊ - əloʊn.

The afternoon sun was hot as the ferry docked in Tear; puddles stood on the steaming stones of the dock, and the air seemed almost as damp to Perrin as Illian's had. The air smelled of pitch and wood and rope - he could see shipyards further south along the river - of spices and iron and barley, of perfumes and wines and a hundred different aromas he could not single out from the melange, most coming from the warehouses behind the docks. When the wind swirled momentarily out of the north, he caught the scents of fish, too, but those faded as the wind swung back. No smells of anything to hunt. His mind reached out to feel for wolves before he realized what he was doing and snapped his guards shut. He had done that too often of late. There had been no wolves, of course. Not in a city like this. He wished it did not feel so - alone.

əz sun əz ðə ɹæmp ət ði ɛn ə ðə bɑɹdʒ wɑz loʊɝd, hi lɛd stɛpɝ ʌp tə ðə dɑk æftɝ mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn. ðə hjudʒ ʃeɪp ə ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ leɪ ɔf tə ðɛɹ lɛft, ʃæɾoʊd soʊ ðəɾ ɪt lʊk laɪk ə maʊntən dɪspaɪt ðə ɡɹeɪt bænɝ əɾ ɪts haɪəs pɔɪnt. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə lʊk ət ðə stoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl tə lʊk ət ðə sɪɾi wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ɪt. ɪz i hɪɹ jɛt? laɪt, ɪf hiz ɔlɹɛɾi tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðæt, hi kəd bi dɛɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ən ðən ɪt wəɾ ɔl bi fəɹ nʌθɪŋ.

As soon as the ramp at the end of the barge was lowered, he led Stepper up to the dock after Moiraine and Lan. The huge shape of the Stone of Tear lay off to their left, shadowed so that it looked like a mountain despite the great banner at its highest point. He did not want to look at the Stone, but it seemed impossible to look at the city without seeing it. Is he here yet? Light, if he has already tried to get into that, he could be dead already. And then it would all be for nothing.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ wi mɛn tə faɪn hɪɹ?" zɑɹin æsk bɪhaɪn hɪm. ʃi hæd nɑt stɑpt æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz; ʃi dʒʌs dɪd nɑɾ æsk əm ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝ. "ɪljən ʃoʊɾ əs ɡɹeɪ mɛn ən ðə waɪl hʌnt. wʌt dʌz tɛɹ hoʊl ðət - ðət sʌmwʌn wɑns tə kip jə fɹəm soʊ bædli?"

"What are we meant to find here?" Zarine asked behind him. She had not stopped asking questions; she just did not ask them of the Aes Sedai or the Warder. "Illian showed us Gray Men and the Wild Hunt. What does Tear hold that - that someone wants to keep you from so badly?"

pɛɹɪn ɡlænst ɝaʊnd; nʌn ə ðə dɑkmən ʃʌɾəlɪŋ kɑɹɡoʊ əbaʊt sim tə hæv hɝd. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ i wʊɾə smɛl fɪɹ ɪf ðeɪ hæd. hi bɪt bæk ðə ʃɑɹp ɹɪmɑɹk ðət hʌŋ ɑn ði ɛn ə hɪz tʌŋ. ʃi hæɾ ə kwɪkɝ tʌŋ, ən ə ʃɑɹpɝ.

Perrin glanced around; none of the dockmen shuttling cargo about seemed to have heard. He was sure he would have smelled fear if they had. He bit back the sharp remark that hung on the end of his tongue. She had a quicker tongue, and a sharper.

"aɪ wɪʃ jə dɪd nɑt saʊn soʊ iɡɝ," lɔɪəl ɹʌmbəld. "ju sim tə θɪŋk ɪɾəl ɔl bi əz izi əz ɪljən, feɪl."

"I wish you did not sound so eager," Loial rumbled. "You seem to think it will all be as easy as Illian, Faile."

"izi?" zɑɹin mʌɾɝd. "izi! lɔɪəl, wi wɝ nɪɹli kɪl twaɪs ɪn wʌn naɪt. ɪljən wɑz ɪnʌf fəɹ ə hʌntɝz sɔŋ ɪn ɪtsɛlf. wʌt meɪks jə kɔl ɪɾ izi?"

"Easy?" Zarine muttered. "Easy! Loial, we were nearly killed twice in one night. Illian was enough for a Hunter's song in itself. What makes you call it easy?"

pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪməst. hi wɪʃt lɔɪəl hæd nɑt dɪsaɪɾɪd tə kɔl zɑɹin baɪ ðət neɪm ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən; ɪt wɑz ə kɑnstən ɹimaɪndɝ ðət mɔɪɹeɪn θɔt ʃi wɑz mɪnz fælkən. ən ɪt dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə stɑp pɛɹɪn wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ʃi wɑz ðə bjuɾəfəl wʊmən mɪn hæd wɔɹn ɪm əɡɛnst, tu. ət list aɪv nɑt ɹʌn ʌp əɡɛns ðə hɔk. əɹ ə tuætɑn wɪð ə sɔɹd! naʊ ðət wəd ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɪst ʌv ɔl, əɹ aɪm ə wʊl mɝtʃənt!

Perrin grimaced. He wished Loial had not decided to call Zarine by that name she had chosen; it was a constant reminder that Moiraine thought she was Min's falcon. And it did nothing to stop Perrin wondering if she was the beautiful woman Min had warned him against, too. At least I've not run up against the hawk. Or a Tuatha'an with a sword! Now that would the strangest of all, or I am a wool merchant!

"stɑp æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz, zɑɹin," hi sɛɾ əz i swʌŋ ʌp ɪndə stɛpɝz sæɾəl. "ju wɪl faɪn aʊt waɪ wəɹ hɪɹ wən mɔɪɹeɪn dɪsaɪdz tə tɛl ju." hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk ət ðə stoʊn.

"Stop asking questions, Zarine," he said as he swung up into Stepper's saddle. "You will find out why we are here when Moiraine decides to tell you." He tried not to look at the Stone.

ʃi tɝn ðoʊz dɑɹk, tɪltəɾ aɪz ɑn hɪm. "aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk jə noʊ waɪ, blæksmɪθ. aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪz waɪ jəl nɑt tɛl mi, kəz jə kænɑt. ədmɪɾ ɪt, fɑɹmbɔɪ."

She turned those dark, tilted eyes on him. "I do not think you know why, blacksmith. I think that is why you will not tell me, because you cannot. Admit it, farmboy."

wɪð ə smɔl saɪ, hi ɹoʊɾ ɔf ðə dɑks æftɝ mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn. zɑɹin dɪd nɑt dɪɡ ət lɔɪəl ɪn ðət kʌɾɪŋ weɪ wən ði oʊɡiɝ ɹəfjuz tə ænsɝ əɹ kwɛstʃənz. hi θɔt ʃi mʌs bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɹaʊbiɾ ɪm ɪndə juzɪŋ ðət neɪm. hi wəd nɑt.

With a small sigh, he rode off the docks after Moiraine and Lan. Zarine did not dig at Loial in that cutting way when the Ogier refused to answer her questions. He thought she must be trying to browbeat him into using that name. He would not.

mɔɪɹeɪn hæd taɪd ði ɔɪl kloʊk bɪhaɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ətɑp ði ɪnɑkjuəs-lʊkɪŋ bʌndəl ðət hɛl ðə dʒɹæɡən bænɝ, ən dɪspaɪt ðə hit hæd dɑn ðə blu lɪnən kloʊk fɹəm ɪljən. ɪts dip, waɪd hʊd hɪɾ əɹ feɪs. hɝ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ wɑz ɑn ə kɔɹɾ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. tɛɹ, ʃi hæd sɛd, dɪd nɑt fɝbɪd ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, oʊnli tʃænəlɪŋ, bʌt ðə dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn kɛpt ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn ɛni wʊmən u wɔɹ ðə ɹɪŋ. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi wɑtʃt ɑn ðɪs vɪzət tə tɛɹ.

Moiraine had tied the oiled cloak behind her saddle, atop the innocuous-looking bundle that held the Dragon banner, and despite the heat had donned the blue linen cloak from Illian. Its deep, wide hood hid her face. Her Great Serpent ring was on a cord around her neck. Tear, she had said, did not forbid the presence of Aes Sedai, only channeling, but the Defenders of the Stone kept a close eye on any woman who wore the ring. She did not want to be watched on this visit to Tear.

læn hæd stʌft ɪz kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk ɪndə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz tu deɪz ɝliɝ, wən ɪt hæd bɪkʌm əpɛɹən ðət huɛvɝ hæd sɛn ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz - sɑmaɪl, pɛɹɪn θɔt wɪð ə ʃɪvɝ, ən tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk ə ðə neɪm əɾ ɔl - huɛvɝ hæd sɛn əm hæd nɑt sɛn ɛni mɔɹ pɝsut. ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd meɪd noʊ kənsɛʃənz tə ðə hiɾ ʌv ɪljən, ən i meɪd nʌn tə ðə lɛsɝ hiɾ ə tɛɹ. hɪz ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin koʊt wɑz bʌɾənd ʌp ɔl ðə weɪ.

Lan had stuffed his color-shifting cloak into his saddlebags two days earlier, when it had become apparent that whoever had sent the Darkhounds - Sammael, Perrin thought with a shiver, and tried not to think of the name at all - whoever had sent them had not sent any more pursuit. The Warder had made no concessions to the heat of Illian, and he made none to the lesser heat of Tear. His gray-green coat was buttoned up all the way.

pɛɹɪn wɔɹ ɪz koʊt hæf əndʌn, ən ðə nɛk ə hɪz ʃɝɾ əntaɪd. tiɹ maɪt bi ə lɪɾəl kulɝ ðən ɪljən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl əz hɑɾ əz sʌmɝ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən əz ɔlweɪz æftɝ ɹeɪn, ðə dæmpnəs ə ði ɛɹ meɪd ðə hit sim wɝs. hɪz æks bɛl hʌŋ lupt ɝaʊn ðə tɔl pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl. ɪt wɑz hændi ðɛɹ, ɪf i niɾəd ɪt, ən i fɛl bɛɾɝ nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ɪt.

Perrin wore his coat half undone, and the neck of his shirt untied. Tear might be a little cooler than Illian, but it was still as hot as summer in the Two Rivers, and as always after rain, the dampness of the air made the heat seem worse. His axe belt hung looped around the tall pommel of his saddle. It was handy there, if he needed it, and he felt better not wearing it.

hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət ðə mʌɾ ɪn ðə fɝst stʃɹits ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ əlɔŋ. oʊnli vɪlədʒəz ən smɔlɝ taʊnz hæd dɝt stʃɹits, ðəɾ i hæd sin, ən tiɹ wɑz wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz. bʌt ðə pipəl dɪd nɑt sim tə maɪnd, mɛni ɡoʊɪŋ bɛɹfʊt. ə wʊmən wɔkɪŋ ɑn lɪɾəl wʊɾən plætfɔɹmz kɑɾ ɪz ətɛnʃən fəɹ ə taɪm, ən i wʌndɝd waɪ ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɔl wɛɹ ðɛm. ðoʊz bæɡi bɹitʃɪz ɑn ðə mɛn lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ maɪt bi kulɝ ðən ðə snʌɡ wʌnz i wɔɹ, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ i wəd fil ə ful ɪf i tʃɹaɪd ðɛm. hi meɪɾ ə pɪktʃɝ ɪn ɪz hɛɾ ə hɪmsɛlf wɛɹɪŋ ðoʊz bɹitʃɪz ən wʌn ə ðoʊz ɹaʊn stʃɹɔ hæts, ən tʃʌkəld əɾ ɪt.

He was surprised at the mud in the first streets they rode along. Only villages and smaller towns had dirt streets, that he had seen, and Tear was one of the great cities. But the people did not seem to mind, many going barefoot. A woman walking on little wooden platforms caught his attention for a time, and he wondered why they did not all wear them. Those baggy breeches on the men looked as if they might be cooler than the snug ones he wore, but he was sure he would feel a fool if he tried them. He made a picture in his head of himself wearing those breeches and one of those round straw hats, and chuckled at it.

"wʌt dʒju faɪn fʌni, pɛɹɪn?" lɔɪəl æskt. hɪz ɪɹz wɝ dʒɹupɪŋ tɪl ðɛɹ tʌfs wɝ hɪɾən ɪn ɪz hɛɹ, ən i lʊkt ət ðə pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹit wɝidli. "ðiz foʊk lʊk . . . dɪfiɾəd, pɛɹɪn. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt lʊk ðɪs weɪ wən aɪ wɑz hɪɹ læst. ivən pipəl u lɛt ðɛɹ ɡɹoʊv bi kʌt daʊn də nɑt dɪzɝv tə lʊk laɪk ðɪs."

"What do you find funny, Perrin?" Loial asked. His ears were drooping till their tufts were hidden in his hair, and he looked at the people in the street worriedly. "These folk look . . . defeated, Perrin. They did not look this way when I was here last. Even people who let their grove be cut down do not deserve to look like this."

əz pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn tə stʌɾi feɪsəz ɪnstɛɾ ə dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ət wʌns, hi sɔ ðət lɔɪəl wɑz ɹaɪt. sʌmθɪŋ hæd ɡɔn aʊɾ ə tu mɛni ʌv ðoʊz feɪsəz. hoʊp, meɪbi. kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. ðeɪ bɛɹli ɡlænst ət ðə pɑɹɾi ɹaɪɾɪŋ baɪ, ɪksɛp tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ðə hɔɹsəz. ði oʊɡiɝ, maʊntəɾ ɑn ən ænəməl əz bɪɡ əz ə dʒɹæf hɔɹs, maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn læn, əɹ pɛɹɪn.

As Perrin began to study faces instead of just looking at everything at once, he saw that Loial was right. Something had gone out of too many of those faces. Hope, maybe. Curiosity. They barely glanced at the party riding by, except to get out of the way of the horses. The Ogier, mounted on an animal as big as a draft horse, might as well have been Lan, or Perrin.

ðə stʃɹits tʃeɪnʒd, ɡeɪnɪŋ waɪd stoʊn peɪvɪŋ, æftɝ ðeɪ pæst ɪnsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts ə ðə haɪ, ɡɹeɪ sɪɾi wɔl, pæs ðə hɑɹd, dɑɹk aɪz ə soʊlʒɝz ɪn bɹɛstpleɪts oʊvɝ ɹɛd koʊts wɪð waɪd slivz ɛndɪŋ ɪn nɛɹoʊ waɪt kʌfs, ən ɹɪmd, ɹaʊn hɛlməts wɪð ə ɹɪdʒ oʊvɝ ðə tɑp. ɪnstɛɾ ə ðə bæɡi bɹitʃɪz ʌðɝ mɛn wɔɹ, ðɛɹz wɝ taɪt, ən tʌkt ɪndə ni-haɪ buts. ðə soʊlʒɝz fɹaʊn ət lænz sɔɹɾ ən fɪŋɡɝd ðɛɹ oʊn, stɛɹd ʃɑɹpli ət pɛɹɪnz æks ən ɪz baʊ, bʌɾ ɪn ə weɪ, dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ fɹaʊnz ən ʃɑɹp lʊks, ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ biɾən ɪn ðɛɹ feɪsəz, tu, əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ wɝ ɹɪli wɝθ ði ɛfɝɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ.

The streets changed, gaining wide stone paving, after they passed inside the gates of the high, gray city wall, past the hard, dark eyes of soldiers in breastplates over red coats with wide sleeves ending in narrow white cuffs, and rimmed, round helmets with a ridge over the top. Instead of the baggy breeches other men wore, theirs were tight, and tucked into knee-high boots. The soldiers frowned at Lan's sword and fingered their own, stared sharply at Perrin's axe and his bow, but in a way, despite their frowns and sharp looks, there was something beaten in their faces, too, as if nothing were really worth the effort any longer.

ðə bɪldɪŋz wɝ lɑɹdʒɝ ən tɔlɝ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz, ðoʊ moʊst wɝ meɪd noʊ dɪfɹənli fɹəm ðoʊz aʊtsaɪd. ðə ɹufs lʊkt ə bɪɾ ɑd tə pɛɹɪn, ɪspɛʃli ðoʊz ðət keɪm tə pɔɪns, bʌɾ i hæd sin soʊ mɛni dɪfɹən kaɪnz ə ɹuf sɪns livɪŋ hoʊm ðəɾ i oʊnli wʌndɝd wʌt kaɪndə neɪlz ðeɪ juzd wɪð ðɛɹ taɪlz. ɪn səm pleɪsəz, ðə pipəl dɪd nɑt juz neɪlz ɑn ðɛɹ ɹuf taɪlz əɾ ɔl.

The buildings were larger and taller inside the walls, though most were made no differently from those outside. The roofs looked a bit odd to Perrin, especially those that came to points, but he had seen so many different kinds of roof since leaving home that he only wondered what kind of nails they used with their tiles. In some places, the people did not use nails on their roof tiles at all.

pæləsəz ən ɡɹeɪt bɪldɪŋz stʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə smɔlɝ ən mɔɹ ɔɹɾənɛɹi, simɪŋli pleɪs hæfəzɝdli; ə stʃɹʌktʃɝ ə taʊɝz ən skwɛɹɪʃ, waɪt doʊmz, sɝaʊndəɾ ɑn ɔl saɪdz baɪ waɪd stʃɹits, maɪɾ əv ʃɑps ən ɪnz ən haʊsəz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪdz ə ðoʊz stʃɹits. ə hjudʒ hɔl fɹʌntɪd baɪ skwɛɹd kɑləmz ə mɑɹbəl fɔɹ peɪsɪz ɑn ə saɪd, wɪð fɪfti stɛps tə klaɪm tə ɹitʃ bɹɑnz dɔɹz faɪv spænz haɪ, hæɾ ə beɪkɝi wʌn saɪɾ ən ə teɪlɝ ɑn ði ʌðɝ.

Palaces and great buildings stood among the smaller and more ordinary, seemingly placed haphazardly; a structure of towers and squarish, white domes, surrounded on all sides by wide streets, might have shops and inns and houses on the other sides of those streets. A huge hall fronted by squared columns of marble four paces on a side, with fifty steps to climb to reach bronze doors five spans high, had a bakery one side and a tailor on the other.

mɔɹ mɛn wɔɹ koʊts ən bɹitʃɪz laɪk ðə soʊlʒɝz' hɪɹ, ðoʊ ɪn bɹaɪɾɝ kʌlɝz ən wɪθaʊɾ ɑɹmɝ, ən səm ivən wɔɹ sɔɹdz. nʌn ə ðɛm wɛn bɛɹfʊt, nɑɾ ivən ðoʊz ɪn bæɡi bɹitʃɪz. ðə wɪmənz dʒɹɛsəz wɝ ɔfən lɔŋɡɝ, ðɛɹ nɛklinz loʊɝ tə bɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən ivən bʊzəm, ðə klɔθ əz laɪkli tə bi sɪlk əz wʊl. ðə si foʊk tʃɹeɪɾɪd ə ɡʊd dil ə sɪlk θɹu tiɹ. əz mɛni sɪdæn tʃɛɹz ən kæɹɪdʒɪz dʒɹɔn baɪ timz ə hɔɹsəz muv θɹu ðə stʃɹits əz ɑks-kɑɹts ən wæɡənz. jɛt tu mɛni ʌv ðə feɪsəz hæd ðət seɪm lʊk ə hævɪŋ ɡɪvən ʌp.

More men wore coats and breeches like the soldiers' here, though in brighter colors and without armor, and some even wore swords. None of them went barefoot, not even those in baggy breeches. The women's dresses were often longer, their necklines lower to bare shoulders and even bosom, the cloth as likely to be silk as wool. The Sea Folk traded a good deal of silk through Tear. As many sedan chairs and carriages drawn by teams of horses moved through the streets as ox-carts and wagons. Yet too many of the faces had that same look of having given up.

ði ɪn læn tʃoʊz, ðə stɑɹ, hæɾ ə wivɝz ʃɑp ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən ə smɪθi ɑn ði ʌðɝ, wɪð nɛɹoʊ æliweɪz bɪtwin. ðə smɪθi wɑz ʌv ənʒɹəst ɡɹeɪ stoʊn, ðə wivɝz ən ði ɪn ʌv wʊd, ðoʊ ðə stɑɹ stʊd fɔɹ stɔɹiz tɔl ən hæd smɔl wɪndoʊz ɪn ɪts ɹuf əz wɛl. ðə ɹæɾəl ə lumz wɑz hɑɹd-pɹɛs tə kəmpit wɪð ðə klæŋ ə ðə smɪθs hæmɝ. ðeɪ hændəd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz oʊvɝ tə steɪbəlmən, tə bi teɪkən ɝaʊn bæk, ən wɛn ɪnsaɪd ði ɪn. ðəɹ wɝ fɪʃ smɛlz fɹəm ðə kɪtʃən, beɪkɪŋ ən pɝhæps stuɪŋ, ən ðə sɛn ə ɹoʊs mʌɾən. ðə mɛn ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum ɔl wɔɹ ðə taɪt koʊts ən lus bɹitʃɪz; pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɹɪtʃɝ mɛn - sʌmhaʊ hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə mɛn ɪn kʌlɝfəl koʊts wɪð pʌfi slivz ən ðə bɛɹ-ʃoʊldɝd wɪmən ɪn bɹaɪt sɪlk wɝ ɔl ɹɪtʃ, əɹ noʊbəlz - ðoʊz foʊk wəd nɑt pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðə nɔɪz. pɝhæps ðət wɑz waɪ læn hæd tʃoʊzən ɪt.

The inn Lan chose, the Star, had a weaver's shop on one side and a smithy on the other, with narrow alleyways between. The smithy was of undressed gray stone, the weaver's and the inn of wood, though the Star stood four stories tall and had small windows in its roof as well. The rattle of looms was hard-pressed to compete with the clang of the smith's hammer. They handed their horses over to stablemen, to be taken around back, and went inside the inn. There were fish smells from the kitchen, baking and perhaps stewing, and the scent of roast mutton. The men in the common room all wore the tight coats and loose breeches; Perrin did not think richer men - somehow he was sure the men in colorful coats with puffy sleeves and the bare-shouldered women in bright silk were all rich, or nobles - those folk would not put up with the noise. Perhaps that was why Lan had chosen it.

"haʊ ɑɹ wi səpoʊz tə slip wɪð ðɪs ɹækəɾɪŋ?" zɑɹin mʌɾɝd.

"How are we supposed to sleep with this racketing?" Zarine muttered.

"noʊ kwɛstʃənz?" hi sɛd wɪð ə smaɪl. fəɹ ə moʊmən i θɔt ʃi wɑz gɑnə stɪk aʊɾ əɹ tʌŋ ət hɪm.

"No questions?" he said with a smile. For a moment he thought she was going to stick out her tongue at him.

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ə ɹaʊnd-feɪst, bɔldɪŋ mæn ɪn ə lɔŋ, dip blu koʊɾ ən ðoʊz lus bɹitʃɪz, hu baʊɾ oʊvɝ hænz klæspt əkɹɔs ɪz staʊt bɛli. hɪz feɪs hæd ðət lʊk, ə wɪɹi ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən. "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju, mɪstʃɹəsəz, ən wɛlkəm," hi saɪd. "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju, mæstɝz, ən wɛlkəm." hi ɡeɪv ə smɔl stɑɹɾ ət pɛɹɪnz jɛloʊ aɪz, ðən pæst wɛɹəli ɑn tə lɔɪəl. "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju, fɹɛn oʊɡiɝ, ən wɛlkəm. ɪts ə jɪɹ əɹ mɔɹ sɪns aɪ hæv sin wʌn ə jəɹ kaɪn ɪn tɛɹ. səm wɝk əɹ ʌðɝ ət ðə stoʊn. ðeɪ steɪɾ ɪn ðə stoʊn, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ aɪ sɔ ðɛm ɪn ðə stʃɹit wʌn deɪ." hi fɪnɪʃt wɪð ənʌðɝ saɪ, simɪŋli əneɪbəl tə sʌmən ɛni kjʊɹiɑsəɾi əz tə waɪ ənʌðɝ oʊɡiɝ hæd kʌm tə tɛɹ, əɹ waɪ ɛni ʌv əm hæd kʌm, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

The innkeeper was a round-faced, balding man in a long, deep blue coat and those loose breeches, who bowed over hands clasped across his stout belly. His face had that look, a weary resignation. "The Light shine on you, mistresses, and welcome," he sighed. "The Light shine on you, masters, and welcome." He gave a small start at Perrin's yellow eyes, then passed wearily on to Loial. "The Light shine on you, friend Ogier, and welcome. It is a year or more since I have seen one of your kind in Tear. Some work or other at the Stone. They stayed in the Stone, of course, but I saw them in the street one day." He finished with another sigh, seemingly unable to summon any curiosity as to why another Ogier had come to Tear, or why any of them had come, for that matter.

ðə bɔldɪŋ mæn, huz neɪm wɑz dʒʊɹə hɛɹət, ʃoʊɾ əm tə ðɛɹ ɹumz hɪmsɛlf. əpɛɹənli mɔɪɹeɪnz sɪlk dʒɹɛs ən ðə weɪ ʃi kɛpt əɹ feɪs hɪɾən, teɪkən wɪð lænz hɑɹd feɪs ən sɔɹd, meɪɾ əm ə leɪɾi ən əɹ ɡɑɹɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz, ən soʊ wɝði ʌv ɪz pɝsənəl ətɛnʃən. pɛɹɪn i ɑbviəsli tʊk əz səm kaɪndə ɹɪteɪnɝ, ən zɑɹin i wɑz pleɪnli ənʃʊɹ ʌv - tə hɝ vɪzəbəl dɪsɡʌst - ən lɔɪəl wɑz, æftɝ ɔl, ən oʊɡiɝ. hi kɔl mɛn tə pʊʃ bɛdz təɡɛðɝ fəɹ lɔɪəl, ən ɔfɝd mɔɪɹeɪn ə pɹaɪvət ɹum fəɹ əɹ milz ɪf ʃi wɪʃt. ʃi æksɛptɪd ɡɹeɪʃəsli.

The balding man, whose name was Jurah Haret, showed them to their rooms himself. Apparently Moiraine's silk dress and the way she kept her face hidden, taken with Lan's hard face and sword, made them a lady and her guard in his eyes, and so worthy of his personal attention. Perrin he obviously took as some kind of retainer, and Zarine he was plainly unsure of - to her visible disgust - and Loial was, after all, an Ogier. He called men to push beds together for Loial, and offered Moiraine a private room for her meals if she wished. She accepted graciously.

ðeɪ kɛp təɡɛðɝ θɹu ɪɾ ɔl, meɪkɪŋ ə smɔl pɹəsɛʃən θɹu ði ʌpɝ hɔlz əntɪl hɛɹət baʊɾ ən saɪɾ ɪz weɪ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns, livɪŋ əm ɔl wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪɡʌn, aʊtsaɪd mɔɪɹeɪnz ɹum. ðə wɔlz wɝ waɪt plæstɝ, ən lɔɪəlz hɛd bɹʌʃt ðə hɔl silɪŋ.

They kept together through it all, making a small procession through the upper halls until Haret bowed and sighed his way out of their presence, leaving them all where they had begun, outside Moiraine's room. The walls were white plaster, and Loial's head brushed the hall ceiling.

"oʊɾiəs fɛloʊ," zɑɹin mʌɾɝd, bɹʌʃɪŋ fjʊɹiəsli ət ðə dʌst ɑn əɹ nɛɹoʊ skɝts wɪð boʊθ hænz. "aɪ bɪliv i tʊk mi fəɹ jəɹ hændmeɪd, ɛɛs sədaɪ. əl nɑt stæn fəɹ ðæt!"

"Odious fellow," Zarine muttered, brushing furiously at the dust on her narrow skirts with both hands. "I believe he took me for your handmaid, Aes Sedai. I will not stand for that!"

"wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋ," læn sɛd sɔfli. "ɪf jə jus ðət neɪm wɛɹ foʊk kən hɪɹ, jəl ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt, ɡɝl." ʃi lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɑɹɡju, bʌɾ ɪz aɪsi blu aɪz stɪld əɹ tʌŋ ðɪs taɪm, ɪf ɪt dɪd nɑt kul əɹ ɡlɛɹ.

"Watch your tongue," Lan said softly. "If you use that name where folk can hear, you will regret it, girl." She looked as if she were going to argue, but his icy blue eyes stilled her tongue this time, if it did not cool her glare.

mɔɪɹeɪn ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. stɛɹɪŋ ɔf ət nʌθɪŋ, ʃi wɝkt əɹ kloʊk ɪn əɹ hænz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf waɪpɪŋ ðɛm. ʌnəwɛɹ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, ɪn pɛɹɪnz əpɪnjən.

Moiraine ignored them. Staring off at nothing, she worked her cloak in her hands almost as if wiping them. Unaware what she was doing, in Perrin's opinion.

"haʊ də wi ɡoʊ əbaʊt faɪndɪŋ ɹænd?" hi æskt, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə hɪɹ hɪm. "mɔɪɹeɪn?"

"How do we go about finding Rand?" he asked, but she did not appear to hear him. "Moiraine?"

"ɹɪmeɪn kloʊs tə ði ɪn," ʃi sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "tiɹ kən bi ə deɪnʒɝəs sɪɾi fəɹ ðoʊz u də nɑt noʊ ɪts weɪz. ðə pæɾɝn kən bi tɔɹn, hɪɹ." ðət læst wɑz sɑft, əz ɪf tə hɝsɛlf. ɪn ə stʃɹɔŋɝ vɔɪs ʃi sɛd, "læn, lɛɾ əs si wʌt wi kən dɪskʌvɝ wɪθaʊɾ ətʃɹæktɪŋ ətɛnʃən. ðə ɹɛst ə ju, steɪ kloʊs tə ði ɪn!"

"Remain close to the inn," she said after a moment. "Tear can be a dangerous city for those who do not know its ways. The Pattern can be torn, here." That last was soft, as if to herself. In a stronger voice she said, "Lan, let us see what we can discover without attracting attention. The rest of you, stay close to the inn!"

" 'steɪ kloʊs tə ði ɪn,' " zɑɹin mɪmɪkt əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ dɪsəpɪɹd daʊn ðə stɛɹz. bʌt ʃi sɛɾ ɪt kwaɪətli ɪnʌf ðət ðeɪ wəd nɑt hɪɹ. "ðɪs ɹænd. hiz ðə wʌn jə kɔl ðə. . . ." ɪf ʃi lʊk laɪk ə fælkən ɹaɪt ðɛn, ɪt wɑz ə vɛɹi ənizi fælkən. "ænd wəɹ ɪn tiɹ, wɛɹ ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn hoʊlz. . . . ən ðə pɹɑfəsiz seɪ. . . . ðə laɪt bɝn mi, tɑvɝən, ɪz ðɪs ə stɔɹi aɪ wɑnə bi ɪn?"

" 'Stay close to the inn,' " Zarine mimicked as the Aes Sedai and the Warder disappeared down the stairs. But she said it quietly enough that they would not hear. "This Rand. He is the one you called the. . . ." If she looked like a falcon right then, it was a very uneasy falcon. "And we are in Tear, where the Heart of the Stone holds. . . . And the Prophecies say. . . . The Light burn me, ta'veren, is this a story I want to be in?"

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə stɔɹi, zɑɹin." fəɹ ə moʊmən pɛɹɪn fɛlt ɔlmoʊst əz hoʊpləs əz ði ɪnkipɝ hæd saʊndəd. "ðə wil wivz əs ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn. jə tʃoʊz tə tæŋɡəl jəɹ θɹɛd wɪð aʊɝz; ɪts tu leɪt tə əntæŋɡəl ɪt, naʊ."

"It is not a story, Zarine." For a moment Perrin felt almost as hopeless as the innkeeper had sounded. "The Wheel weaves us into the Pattern. You chose to tangle your thread with ours; it's too late to untangle it, now."

"laɪt!" ʃi ɡɹaʊld. "naʊ jə saʊn laɪk hɝ!"

"Light!" she growled. "Now you sound like her!"

hi lɛft əɹ ðəɹ wɪð lɔɪəl ən wɛn tə pʊɾ ɪz θɪŋz ɪn ɪz ɹum - ɪt hæɾ ə loʊ bɛd, kʌmftəɹbəl bʌt smɔl, əz sɪɾi pipəl sim tə θɪŋk bɪfɪɾɪd ə sɝvənt, ə wɑʃstænd, ə stul, ən ə fju pɛɡz ɑn ðə kɹæk plæstɝ wɔl - ən wən i keɪm aʊt, ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ ɡɔn. ðə ɹɪŋ ə hæmɝ ɑn ænvəl kɔl tə hɪm.

He left her there with Loial and went to put his things in his room - it had a low bed, comfortable but small, as city people seemed to think befitted a servant, a washstand, a stool, and a few pegs on the cracked plaster wall - and when he came out, they were both gone. The ring of hammer on anvil called to him.

soʊ mʌtʃ ɪn tɛɹ lʊkt ɑd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪlif tə wɔk ɪndə ðə smɪθi. ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ wɑz ɔl wʌn lɑɹdʒ ɹum wɪð noʊ bæk wɔl ɪksɛp fəɹ tu lɔŋ dɔɹz ðət stʊɾ oʊpən ɑn ə jɑɹd fəɹ ʃuɪŋ hɔɹsəz ən ɑksən, kəmplit wɪð ən ɑks slɪŋ. hæmɝz stʊɾ ɪn ðɛɹ stænz, tɑŋz ə vɛɹiəs kaɪnz ən saɪzəz hʌŋ ɑn ði ɪkspoʊz dʒɔɪsts ə ðə wɔlz, bʌtʃɹəsəz ən huf naɪvz ən ʌðɝ fɛɹiɝz tulz leɪ nitli ɝeɪnʒd ɑn wʊɾən bɛntʃɪz wɪð tʃɪzəlz ən bik aɪɝnz ən swædʒəz ən ɔl ði ɪmpləməns ə ðə blæksmɪθs kɹæft. bɪnz hɛld lɛŋθs ʌv aɪɝn ən stil ɪn vɛɹiəs θɪknəsəz. faɪv ɡɹaɪndɪŋ wilz ə dɪfɹən ɹʌnəs stʊɾ əbaʊt ðə hɑɹd dɝt flɔɹ, sɪks ænvəlz, ən θɹi stoʊn-saɪɾəd fɔɹdʒɪz wɪð ðɛɹ bɛloʊz, ðoʊ oʊnli wʌn hɛld ɡloʊɪŋ koʊlz. kwɛntʃɪŋ bæɹəlz stʊd ɹɛɾi tə hænd.

So much in Tear looked odd that it was a relief to walk into the smithy. The ground floor was all one large room with no back wall except for two long doors that stood open on a yard for shoeing horses and oxen, complete with an ox sling. Hammers stood in their stands, tongs of various kinds and sizes hung on the exposed joists of the walls, buttresses and hoof knives and other farrier's tools lay neatly arranged on wooden benches with chisels and beak irons and swages and all the implements of the blacksmith's craft. Bins held lengths of iron and steel in various thicknesses. Five grinding wheels of different roughness stood about the hard dirt floor, six anvils, and three stone-sided forges with their bellows, though only one held glowing coals. Quenching barrels stood ready to hand.

ðə smɪθ wɑz plaɪɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ ɑn jɛloʊ-hɑɾ aɪɝn ɡɹɪpt ɪn hɛvi tɑŋz. hi wɔɹ bæɡi bɹitʃɪz ən hæd peɪl blu aɪz, bʌt ðə lɔŋ lɛðɝ vɛst oʊvɝ ɪz bɛɹ tʃɛst ən eɪpɹən wɝ nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðoʊz pɛɹɪn ən mæstɝ luhən hæd wɔɹn bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild, ən ɪz θɪk ɑɹmz ən ʃoʊldɝz spoʊk ə jɪɹz wɝkɪŋ mɛɾəl. hɪz dɑɹk hɛɹ hæɾ ɔlmoʊs ðə seɪm əmaʊn ʌv ɡɹeɪ ðət pɛɹɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪn mæstɝ luhənz. mɔɹ vɛsts ən eɪpɹənz hʌŋ ɑn ðə wɔl, əz ɪf ðə mæn hæɾ əpɹɛntəsɪz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɪn ɛvəɾəns naʊ. ðə fɔɹdʒ-faɪɝ smɛld laɪk hoʊm. ðə hɑɾ aɪɝn smɛld laɪk hoʊm.

The smith was plying his hammer on yellow-hot iron gripped in heavy tongs. He wore baggy breeches and had pale blue eyes, but the long leather vest over his bare chest and apron were not much different from those Perrin and Master Luhhan had worn back in Emond's Field, and his thick arms and shoulders spoke of years working metal. His dark hair had almost the same amount of gray that Perrin remembered in Master Luhhan's. More vests and aprons hung on the wall, as if the man had apprentices, but they were not in evidence now. The forge-fire smelled like home. The hot iron smelled like home.

ðə smɪθ tɝn tə θɹʌs ðə pis i wɑz wɝkɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə koʊlz, ən pɛɹɪn stɛpt oʊvɝ tə wɝk ðə bɛloʊz fəɹ hɪm. ðə mæn ɡlænst ət hɪm, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. pɛɹɪn pʊl ðə bɛloʊz hændəl ʌp ən daʊn wɪð sloʊ, stɛɾi, ivən stʃɹoʊks, kipɪŋ ðə koʊlz ət ðə ɹaɪt hit. ðə smɪθ wɛn bæk tə wɝkɪŋ ðə hɑɾ aɪɝn, ɑn ðə ɹaʊndəd hɔɹn ə ði ænvəl, ðɪs taɪm. pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i maɪt bi meɪkɪŋ ə bæɹəl skɹeɪp. ðə hæmɝ ɹæŋ wɪð ʃɑɹp, kwɪk bloʊz.

The smith turned to thrust the piece he was working back into the coals, and Perrin stepped over to work the bellows for him. The man glanced at him, but said nothing. Perrin pulled the bellows handle up and down with slow, steady, even strokes, keeping the coals at the right heat. The smith went back to working the hot iron, on the rounded horn of the anvil, this time. Perrin thought he might be making a barrel scrape. The hammer rang with sharp, quick blows.

ðə mæn spoʊk wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ɪz wɝk. "əpɹɛntəs?" wɑz ɔl i sɛd.

The man spoke without looking up from his work. "Apprentice?" was all he said.

"jɛs," pɛɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd dʒʌst əz sɪmpli.

"Yes," Perrin replied just as simply.

ðə smɪθ wɝkt ɑn fəɹ ə taɪm. ɪt wɑz ə bæɹəl skɹeɪp, fəɹ klinɪŋ ði ɪnsaɪdz ʌv wʊɾən bæɹəlz. naʊ ən əɡɛn i aɪd pɛɹɪn kənsɪɾɝɪŋli. sɛɾɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ daʊn, dʒʌs fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðə smɪθ pɪkt ʌp ə ʃɔɹt lɛŋθ ə θɪk, skwɛɹ stɑk ən pʊʃt ɪɾ ɪndə pɛɹɪnz hænd, ðən pɪkt ʌp ɪz hæmɝ əɡɛn ən ɹɪzumd wɝk. "si wʌt jə kən də wɪð ðæt," hi sɛd.

The smith worked on for a time. It was a barrel scrape, for cleaning the insides of wooden barrels. Now and again he eyed Perrin consideringly. Setting his hammer down, just for a moment, the smith picked up a short length of thick, square stock and pushed it into Perrin's hand, then picked up his hammer again and resumed work. "See what you can do with that," he said.

wɪθaʊɾ ivən θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, pɛɹɪn stɛpt oʊvɝ tə ən ænvəl ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə fɔɹdʒ ən tæp ðə stɑk əɡɛnst ɪts ɛdʒ. ɪt meɪɾ ə naɪs ɹɪŋ. ðə stil hæd nɑt bɪn lɛf lɔŋ ɪnʌf ɪn ðə sloʊfɝnəs tə pɪk ʌp ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə kɑɹbən fɹəm ðə koʊl. hi pʊʃt ɪɾ ɪndə ðə hɑt koʊlz fəɹ ɔlmoʊst ɪts ɪntaɪɝ lɛŋθ, teɪstəd ðə tu wɔɾɝ bæɹəlz tə si wɪtʃ hæd bɪn sɔltəd - ðə θɝd wɑz ɑləv ɔɪl - ðən tʊk ɔf ɪz koʊɾ ən ʃɝɾ ən tʃoʊz ə lɛðɝ vɛs ðət wəd fɪɾ ɪz tʃɛst. moʊst ə ðiz tɛɹən fɛloʊz wɝ nɑɾ əz lɑɹdʒ əz hi, bʌɾ i faʊnd wʌn ðət wəd du. faɪndɪŋ ən eɪpɹən wɑz iziɝ.

Without even thinking about it, Perrin stepped over to an anvil on the other side of the forge and tapped the stock against its edge. It made a nice ring. The steel had not been left long enough in the slowfurnace to pick up a great deal of carbon from the coal. He pushed it into the hot coals for almost its entire length, tasted the two water barrels to see which had been salted - the third was olive oil - then took off his coat and shirt and chose a leather vest that would fit his chest. Most of these Tairen fellows were not as large as he, but he found one that would do. Finding an apron was easier.

wən i tɝn ɝaʊnd, hi sɔ ðə smɪθ, stɪl wɪð ɪz hɛd daʊn oʊvɝ ɪz wɝk, nɑɾɪŋ ən smaɪlɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. bʌt dʒʌs kəz i nu hɪz weɪ ɝaʊn ə smɪθi dɪd nɑt min i hæɾ ɛni skɪl ət smɪθɪŋ. ðət wɑz jɛt tə bi ʃoʊn.

When he turned around, he saw the smith, still with his head down over his work, nodding and smiling to himself. But just because he knew his way around a smithy did not mean he had any skill at smithing. That was yet to be shown.

wən i keɪm bæk tə ði ænvəl wɪð tu hæmɝz, ə sɛɾ ə lɔŋ-hændəl flæt-tɑŋz, ən ə ʃɑɹp-tɑp hɑɹɾi, ðə stil bɑɹ hæd hiɾəd tə ə dɑɹk ɹɛɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə smɔl bɪɾ ʌv wʌɾ i hæd lɛft aʊɾ ə ðə koʊlz. hi wɝk ðə bɛloʊz, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kʌlɝ ə ðə mɛɾəl laɪɾən, əntɪl ɪt ɹitʃt ə jɛloʊ dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ʌv waɪt. ðən i pʊld ɪɾ aʊt wɪð ðə tɑŋz, leɪɾ ɪɾ ɑn ði ænvəl, ən pɪkt ʌp ðə hɛviɝ ə ðə tu hæmɝz. əbaʊt tɛn paʊnz, hi ɛstəmeɪɾəd, ən wɪð ə lɔŋɡɝ hændəl ðən moʊs pipəl, hu dɪd nɑt noʊ mɛɾəl wɝkɪŋ, θɔt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. hi hɛld ɪt nɪɹ ði ɛnd; hɑt mɛɾəl ɡeɪv ɔf spɑɹks, səmtaɪmz, ən i hæd sin ðə skɑɹz ɑn ðə hænz ə ðə smɪθ fɹəm ʌp ət ɹaʊndɪl, ə kɛɹləs fɛloʊ.

When he came back to the anvil with two hammers, a set of long-handled flat-tongs, and a sharp-topped hardy, the steel bar had heated to a dark red except for a small bit of what he had left out of the coals. He worked the bellows, watching the color of the metal lighten, until it reached a yellow just short of white. Then he pulled it out with the tongs, laid it on the anvil, and picked up the heavier of the two hammers. About ten pounds, he estimated, and with a longer handle than most people, who did not know metal working, thought was necessary. He held it near the end; hot metal gave off sparks, sometimes, and he had seen the scars on the hands of the smith from up at Roundhill, a careless fellow.

hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə meɪk ɛniθɪŋ ɪlæbɹəɾ əɹ fænsi. sɪmpəl θɪŋz sim bɛst ət ðə moʊmənt. hi bɪɡæn baɪ ɹaʊndɪŋ ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə bɑɹ, ðən hæmɝd ðə mɪɾəl aʊɾ ɪndə ə bɹɔd bleɪd, ɔlmoʊst əz θɪk əz ði ɝɪdʒənəl ət ðə bʌt, bʌɾ ə ɡʊd hæn ən ə hæf lɔŋ. fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm i ɹɪtɝn ðə mɛɾəl tə ðə koʊlz, tə kip ɪɾ ət ðə peɪl jɛloʊ, ən æftɝ ə taɪm i ʃɪftəd tə ðə laɪɾɝ hæmɝ, hæf ðə weɪɾ ə ðə fɝst. ðə pis bɪɑn ðə bleɪd, hi θɪn daʊn, ðən bɛn ɪɾ oʊvɝ ði ænvəl hɔɹn ɪn ə kɝv daʊn bɪsaɪd ðə bleɪd. ə wʊɾən hændəl kəd bi fɪkst ɑntu ðæt, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. sɛɾɪŋ ðə ʃɑɹp-tʃɪzəl hɑɹɾi ɪn ði ænvəlz hɑɹɾi-hoʊl, hi leɪd ðə ɡloʊɪŋ mɛɾəl ətɑp ɪt. wʌn ʃɑɹp bloʊ ʌv ðə hæmɝ kʌɾ ɔf ðə tul i hæd meɪd. əɹ ɔlmoʊs meɪd. ɪt wəd bi ə tʃæmfɝ naɪf, fəɹ smuðɪŋ ən lɛvəlɪŋ ðə tɑps ə bæɹəl steɪvz æftɝ ðeɪ wɝ hɑp təɡɛðɝ, əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz. wən i wɑz dʌn. ði ʌðɝ mænz bæɹəl skɹeɪp hæd meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ʌv ɪt.

He did not want to make anything elaborate or fancy. Simple things seemed best at the moment. He began by rounding the edges of the bar, then hammered the middle out into a broad blade, almost as thick as the original at the butt, but a good hand and a half long. From time to time he returned the metal to the coals, to keep it at the pale yellow, and after a time he shifted to the lighter hammer, half the weight of the first. The piece beyond the blade, he thinned down, then bent it over the anvil horn in a curve down beside the blade. A wooden handle could be fixed onto that, eventually. Setting the sharp-chisel hardy in the anvil's hardy-hole, he laid the glowing metal atop it. One sharp blow of the hammer cut off the tool he had made. Or almost made. It would be a chamfer knife, for smoothing and leveling the tops of barrel staves after they were hopped together, among other things. When he was done. The other man's barrel scrape had made him think of it.
