ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən stɛɹd wɛɹəli ət ðə stoʊv wɛɹ əɹ spaʊɾəd kɛɾəl wɑz stimɪŋ. hɝ maʊθ wɝkt, bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

The gray-haired woman stared wearily at the stove where her spouted kettle was steaming. Her mouth worked, but she said nothing.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ ðeɪ?" mæt dɪmændəd. "ɪɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt! ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn deɪnʒɝ ɪf aɪ doʊn faɪn ðɛm."

"Where are they?" Mat demanded. "It is important! They are in danger if I don't find them."

"ju də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "ju ɑɹ ən aʊtləndɝ. ðə haɪ lɔɹdz. . . ."

"You do not understand," she said softly. "You are an outlander. The High Lords. . . ."

"aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ əbaʊɾ ɛni - " mæt blɪŋkt, ən lʊkt ət tɑm. ðə ɡlimən sim tə bi fɹaʊnɪŋ, bʌɾ i wɑz kɑfɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd, mæt kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ. "wʌt də ðə haɪ lɔɹdz əv tə də wɪð maɪ fɹɛnz?"

"I do not care about any - " Mat blinked, and looked at Thom. The gleeman seemed to be frowning, but he was coughing so hard, Mat could not be sure. "What do the High Lords have to do with my friends?"

"ju dʒʌs də nɑt - "

"You just do not - "

"doʊn tɛl mi aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd! əl peɪ fəɹ ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən!"

"Don't tell me I do not understand! I will pay for the information!"

mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm. "aɪ də nɑt teɪk mʌni fəɹ . . . !" ʃi ɡɹɪməs fɪɹsli. "ju æsk mi tə tɛl jə θɪŋz aɪ hæv bɪn toʊl nɑt tə spik ʌv. dʒju noʊ wʌt wɪl hæpən tə mi ɪf aɪ də ən jə bɹið maɪ neɪm? əl luz maɪ tʌŋ, tə bɪɡɪn. ðən əl luz ʌðɝ pɑɹts bɪfɔɹ ðə haɪ lɔɹdz əv wʌɾ ɪz lɛft ə mi hʌŋ ʌp tə skɹim ɪts læst aʊɝz əz ə ɹimaɪndɝ tə ʌðɝz tə oʊbeɪ. ən ɪɾəl də ðoʊz jʌŋ wɪmən noʊ ɡʊd, nɑt maɪ tɛlɪŋ əɹ maɪ daɪɪŋ!"

Mother Guenna glared at him. "I do not take money for . . . !" She grimaced fiercely. "You ask me to tell you things I have been told not to speak of. Do you know what will happen to me if I do and you breathe my name? I will lose my tongue, to begin. Then I will lose other parts before the High Lords have what is left of me hung up to scream its last hours as a reminder to others to obey. And it will do those young women no good, not my telling or my dying!"

"aɪ pɹɑməs əl nɛvɝ mɛnʃən jəɹ neɪm tə ɛniwʌn. aɪ swɛɹ ɪt." ən əl kip ðəɾ oʊθ, oʊld wʊmən, ɪf jə oʊnli tɛl mi wɛɹ ðeɪ blʌɾi ɑɹ! "pliz? ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn deɪnʒɝ."

"I promise I will never mention your name to anyone. I swear it." And I'll keep that oath, old woman, if you only tell me where they bloody are! "Please? They are in danger."

ʃi stʌɾid ɪm fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm; bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz dʌn i hæd ðə filɪŋ ʃi nu ɛvɹi dɪteɪl ə hɪm. "ɑn ðəɾ oʊθ, əl tɛl ju. aɪ . . . laɪk ðɛm. bʌt jə kən də nʌθɪŋ. jə ɑɹ tu leɪt, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. tu leɪt baɪ nɪɹli θɹi aʊɝz. ðeɪv bɪn teɪkən tə ðə stoʊn. ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɑmən sɛn fəɹ ðɛm." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn wɝid pʌzəlmənt. "hi sɛnt . . . wɪmən u . . . kəd tʃænəl. aɪ hoʊl nʌθɪŋ əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪsɛlf, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz əɡɛns ðə lɔ. ðə lɔ ðə haɪ lɔɹdz meɪd. ɪf ðeɪ bɹeɪk ɛvɹi ʌðɝ lɔ, ðeɪ wəd nɑt bɹeɪk ðət wʌn. waɪ wəɾ ə haɪ lɔɹd sɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ɪz ɛɹənz? waɪ wəɾ i wɑn ðoʊz ɡɝlz əɾ ɔl?"

She studied him for a long time; before she was done he had the feeling she knew every detail of him. "On that oath, I will tell you. I . . . liked them. But you can do nothing. You are too late, Matrim Cauthon. Too late by nearly three hours. They have been taken to the Stone. The High Lord Samon sent for them." She shook her head in worried puzzlement. "He sent . . . women who . . . could channel. I hold nothing against Aes Sedai myself, but that is against the law. The law the High Lords made. If they break every other law, they would not break that one. Why would a High Lord send Aes Sedai on his errands? Why would he want those girls at all?"

mæt ɔlmoʊs bɝst aʊt læfɪŋ. "ɛɛs sədaɪ? mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə, jə hæd maɪ hɑɹɾ ɪn maɪ θɹoʊt, ən meɪbi maɪ lɪvɝ, tu. ɪf ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm fəɹ ðɛm, ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊt. ɔl θɹi ʌv əm ɑɹ gɑnə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ ðɛmsɛlvz. nɑt ðəɾ aɪ laɪk ɪt mʌtʃ, bʌt ðæts wʌt ðeɪ - " hɪz ɡɹɪn feɪɾəd ət ðə hɛvi weɪ ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

Mat almost burst out laughing. "Aes Sedai? Mother Guenna, you had my heart in my throat, and maybe my liver, too. If Aes Sedai came for them, there is nothing to worry about. All three of them are going to be Aes Sedai themselves. Not that I like it much, but that's what they - " His grin faded at the heavy way she shook her head.

"bɔɪ, ðoʊz ɡɝlz fɔt laɪk laɪənfɪʃ ɪn ə nɛt. wɛðɝ ðeɪ min tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ nɑt, ðoʊz u tʊk əm tʃɹiɾəd əm laɪk bɪlʒ pʌmpɪŋz. fɹɛnz də nɑt ɡɪv bɹuzəz laɪk ðæt."

"Boy, those girls fought like lionfish in a net. Whether they mean to be Aes Sedai or not, those who took them treated them like bilge pumpings. Friends do not give bruises like that."

hi fɛlt ɪz feɪs twɪstɪŋ. ɛɛs sədaɪ hɝt ðɛm? wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt? ðə blʌɾi stoʊn. ɪt meɪks ðə pæləs ɪn keɪɛmlɪn lʊk laɪk wɔkɪŋ ɪndə ə bɑɹnjɑɹd! bɝn mi! aɪ stʊd ɹaɪɾ aʊt ðəɹ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn ən stɛɹɾ ət ðɪs haʊs! bɝn mi fəɹ ə blʌɾi laɪt-blaɪndɪd ful!

He felt his face twisting. Aes Sedai hurt them? What in the Light? The bloody Stone. It makes the Palace in Caemlyn look like walking into a barnyard! Burn me! I stood right out there in the rain and stared at this house! Burn me for a bloody Light-blinded fool!

"ɪf jə bɹeɪk jəɹ hænd," mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə sɛd, "aɪ wɪl splɪn ən poʊltɪs ɪt, bʌɾ ɪf jə dæmədʒ maɪ wɔl, əl stʃɹɪp jəɹ haɪd laɪk ə ɹɛdfɪʃ!"

"If you break your hand," Mother Guenna said, "I will splint and poultice it, but if you damage my wall, I will strip your hide like a redfish!"

hi blɪŋkt, ðən lʊkt əɾ ɪz fɪst, ət skɹeɪp nʌkəlz. hi dɪd nɑɾ ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ pʌntʃɪŋ ðə wɔl.

He blinked, then looked at his fist, at scraped knuckles. He did not even remember punching the wall.

ðə bɹɔd wʊmən tʊk ɪz hæn ɪn ə stʃɹɔŋ ɡɹɪp, bʌt ðə fɪŋɡɝz ʃi juz tə pɹoʊb wɝ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli dʒɛntəl. "nʌθɪŋ bɹoʊkən," ʃi ɡɹʌntɪɾ æftɝ ə waɪl. hɝ aɪz wɝ dʒʌst əz dʒɛntəl əz ʃi stʌɾid ɪz feɪs. "ɪt simz jə kɛɹ fəɹ ðɛm. wʌn ə ðɛm, ət list, aɪ səpoʊz ɪɾ ɪz. aɪm sɑɹi, mæt kɔθən."

The broad woman took his hand in a strong grip, but the fingers she used to probe were surprisingly gentle. "Nothing broken," she grunted after a while. Her eyes were just as gentle as she studied his face. "It seems you care for them. One of them, at least, I suppose it is. I am sorry, Mat Cauthon."

"doʊn bi," hi toʊl hɝ. "æt list aɪ noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ, naʊ. ɔl aɪ hæv tə də ɪz ɡɛɾ əm aʊt." hi fɪʃt aʊɾ ɪz læs tu ændɔɝən ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz ən pɹɛst əm ɪndə hɝ hænd. "fɔɹ tɑmz mɛɾəsənz, ən fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ mi noʊ əbaʊt ðə ɡɝlz." ɑn ɪmpəls, hi ɡeɪv əɹ ə kwɪk kɪs ɑn ðə tʃik ən ə ɡɹɪn. "æn ðæts fəɹ mi."

"Don't be," he told her. "At least I know where they are, now. All I have to do is get them out." He fished out his last two Andoran gold crowns and pressed them into her hand. "For Thom's medicines, and for letting me know about the girls." On impulse, he gave her a quick kiss on the cheek and a grin. "And that's for me."

stɑɹɾəld, ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ tʃik, nɑt simɪŋ tə noʊ wɛðɝ tə lʊk ət ðə kɔɪnz əɹ ət hɪm. "ɡɛɾ əm aʊt, jə seɪ. dʒʌs laɪk ðæt. aʊɾ ə ðə stoʊn." əbɹʌpli ʃi stæbd ɪm ɪn ðə ɹɪbz wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ əz hɑɹɾ əz ə tʃɹi stʌb. "ju ɹimaɪn mi ʌv maɪ hʌzbənd, mæt kɔθən. hi wɑz ə hɛdstʃɹɔŋ ful u wəd seɪl ɪndə ðə tiθ ʌv ə ɡeɪl ən læf, tu. aɪ kəɾ ɔlmoʊs θɪŋk jəl mænədʒ ɪt." sʌɾənli ʃi sɔ hɪz mʌɾi buts, əpɛɹənli fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. "ɪt tʊk mi sɪks mʌnθs tə titʃ ɪm nɑt tə tʃɹæk mʌɾ ɪndə maɪ haʊs. ɪf jə də ɡɛt ðoʊz ɡɝlz aʊt, wɪtʃɛvɝ ə ðɛm juv jəɹ aɪ ɑn wɪl əv ə hɑɹd taɪm tʃɹeɪnɪŋ jə tə meɪk jə fɪt tə bi lɛɾ ɪnsaɪd."

Startled, she touched her cheek, not seeming to know whether to look at the coins or at him. "Get them out, you say. Just like that. Out of the Stone." Abruptly she stabbed him in the ribs with a finger as hard as a tree stub. "You remind me of my husband, Mat Cauthon. He was a headstrong fool who would sail into the teeth of a gale and laugh, too. I could almost think you'll manage it." Suddenly she saw his muddy boots, apparently for the first time. "It took me six months to teach him not to track mud into my house. If you do get those girls out, whichever of them you have your eye on will have a hard time training you to make you fit to be let inside."

"ju ɑɹ ði oʊnli wʊmən u kəd də ðæt," hi sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹɪn ðət bɹɔɾənd əɾ əɹ ɡlɛɹ. ɡɛɾ əm aʊt. ðæts ɔl aɪ hæv tə du. bɹɪŋ əm ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə stoʊn ə blʌɾi tɛɹ. tɑm kɔft əɡɛn. hi ɪzənt ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə stoʊn laɪk ðæt. oʊnli, haʊ də aɪ stɑp hɪm? "mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə, kən aɪ liv maɪ fɹɛn hɪɹ? aɪ θɪŋk hiz tu sɪk tə ɡoʊ bæk tə ði ɪn."

"You are the only woman who could do that," he said with a grin that broadened at her glare. Get them out. That's all I have to do. Bring them right out of the Stone of bloody Tear. Thom coughed again. He isn't going into the Stone like that. Only, how do I stop him? "Mother Guenna, can I leave my friend here? I think he is too sick to go back to the inn."

"wʌt?" tɑm bɑɹkt. hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɛɹ, kɑfɪŋ soʊ hi kəd hɑɹdli spik. "aɪ æm noʊ . . . sətʃ θɪŋ, bɔɪ! jə θɪŋk . . . wɔkɪŋ ɪndə ðə stoʊn . . . wɪl bi laɪk . . . wɔkɪŋ ɪndə jəɹ mʌðɝz kɪtʃən? jə θɪŋk jə . . . wəd meɪk ɪt . . . əz fɑɹ əz ðə ɡeɪts . . . wɪθaʊt mi?" hi hʌŋ ɑn ðə bæk ə ðə tʃɛɹ, hɪz wizɪŋ ən hækɪŋ kipɪŋ ɪm fɹəm ɹaɪzɪŋ mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ tə hɪz fit.

"What?" Thom barked. He tried to push himself out of the chair, coughing so he could hardly speak. "I am no . . . such thing, boy! You think . . . walking into the Stone . . . will be like . . . walking into your mother's kitchen? You think you . . . would make it . . . as far as the gates . . . without me?" He hung on the back of the chair, his wheezing and hacking keeping him from rising more than halfway to his feet.

mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən pʊʃt ɪm bæk daʊn əz izəli əz ə tʃaɪld. ðə ɡlimən ɡeɪv əɹ ə stɑɹɾəld lʊk. "aɪ wɪl teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪm, mæt kɔθən," ʃi sɛd.

Mother Guenna put a hand on his shoulder and pushed him back down as easily as a child. The gleeman gave her a startled look. "I will take care of him, Mat Cauthon," she said.

"noʊ!" tɑm ʃaʊɾəd. "ju kænɑt . . . də ðɪs tə mi! jə kænt . . . liv mi . . . wɪð ðɪs oʊld. . . ." oʊnli hɝ hæn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ kɛpt ɪm fɹəm dʌbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ.

"No!" Thom shouted. "You cannot . . . do this to me! You can't . . . leave me . . . with this old. . . ." Only her hand on his shoulder kept him from doubling over.

mæt ɡɹɪn ət ðə waɪt-hɛɹd mæn. "aɪ hæv ɛndʒɔɪd noʊɪŋ ju, tɑm."

Mat grinned at the white-haired man. "I have enjoyed knowing you, Thom."

əz i hɝiɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stʃɹit, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ hi hæd sɛd ðæt. hi ɪzən gɑnə blʌɾi daɪ. ðət wʊmən wɪl kip ɪm əlaɪv ɪf ʃiz tə dʒɹæɡ hɪm kɪkɪŋ ən skɹimɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz ɡɹeɪv baɪ hɪz mʌstæʃɪz. jɛs, bʌɾ u ɪz gɑnə kip mi əlaɪv?

As he hurried out into the street, he found himself wondering why he had said that. He isn't going to bloody die. That woman will keep him alive if she has to drag him kicking and screaming out of his grave by his mustaches. Yes, but who is going to keep me alive?

əhɛɾ ə hɪm, ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ lumd oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi, ɪmpɹɛɡnəbəl, ə fɔɹtʃɹəs bɪsidʒd ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz, ə stoʊn ɑn wɪtʃ ə hʌnʒɹəd ɑɹmiz hæd bɹoʊkən ðɛɹ tiθ. ən i hæd tə ɡɛɾ ɪnsaɪd, sʌmhaʊ.

Ahead of him, the Stone of Tear loomed over the city, impregnable, a fortress besieged a hundred times, a stone on which a hundred armies had broken their teeth. And he had to get inside, somehow.

ən bɹɪŋ aʊt θɹi wɪmən. sʌmhaʊ. wɪð ə læf ðət meɪɾ ivən ðə sʌlən foʊk ɪn ðə stʃɹit lʊk ət hɪm, hi hɛɾəd bæk fəɹ ðə waɪt kɹɛsənt, ənkɛɹɪŋ ə mʌɾ əɹ ðə dæmp hit. hi kəd fil ðə daɪs tʌmbəlɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd.

And bring out three women. Somehow. With a laugh that made even the sullen folk in the street look at him, he headed back for The White Crescent, uncaring of mud or the damp heat. He could feel the dice tumbling inside his head.


tʃæptɝ fɪftiθɹi


CHAPTER 53

eɪ floʊ ʌv ðə spɪɹət


A Flow of the Spirit

pɛɹɪn ʃɹʌɡd ɪndə hɪz koʊɾ əz i wɔk bæk təwɔɹd ðə stɑɹ θɹu ði ivnɪŋ ʃædoʊz. ə ɡʊd taɪɹədnəs soʊk θɹu hɪz ɑɹmz ən ʃoʊldɝz; əlɔŋ wɪð mɔɹ kɑmən wɝk, mæstɝ ɑjɑlə hæd hæɾ ɪm meɪk ə lɑɹdʒ pis ʌv ɔɹnəmɛntəl wɝk, ɔl ɪlæbɹət kɝvz ən skɹoʊlz, tə ɡoʊ ɑn səm kʌntʃɹi lɔɹdz nu ɡeɪt. hi hæɾ ɛndʒɔɪd meɪkɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ soʊ pɹɪɾi.

Perrin shrugged into his coat as he walked back toward the Star through the evening shadows. A good tiredness soaked through his arms and shoulders; along with more common work, Master Ajala had had him make a large piece of ornamental work, all elaborate curves and scrolls, to go on some country lord's new gate. He had enjoyed making something so pretty.

"aɪ θɔɾ ɪz aɪz wəd kʌm aʊɾ ə hɪz feɪs, blæksmɪθ, wən jə sɛd jə wəd nɑt meɪk ðət θɪŋ ɪf ɪt wɑz fəɹ ə haɪ lɔɹd."

"I thought his eyes would come out of his face, blacksmith, when you said you would not make that thing if it was for a High Lord."

hi ɡlænst saɪdweɪz ət zɑɹin, wɔkɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm, ðə ʃædoʊz mæskɪŋ əɹ feɪs. ivən fəɹ ɪz aɪz, ðə ʃædoʊz wɝ ðɛɹ, dʒʌs feɪntɝ ðən ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn fəɹ ənʌðɝz. ðeɪ ɛmfəsaɪzd əɹ haɪ tʃikboʊnz, sɔfən ðə stʃɹɔŋ kɝv ə hɝ noʊz. hi dʒʌs kəd nɑt meɪk ʌp ɪz maɪn əbaʊt hɝ. ivən ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn stɪl ɪnsɪstəd ðeɪ steɪ kloʊs tə ði ɪn, hi wɪʃt ʃi kəd faɪn sʌmθɪŋ ɛls tə də bɪsaɪdz wɑtʃ ɪm wɝk. fəɹ səm ɹizən, hi hæd faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɑkwɝd wɛnɛvɝ i θɔɾ ə hɝ tɪltəɾ aɪz ɑn hɪm. mɔɹ ðən wʌns i hæd fʌmbəld wɪð ɪz hæmɝ tɪl mæstɝ ɑjɑlə fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm wʌndɝɪŋli. ɡɝlz hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk ɪm fil ɑkwɝɾ ɪspɛʃli wən ðeɪ smaɪld ət hɪm, bʌt zɑɹin dɪd nɑɾ əv tə smaɪl. oʊnli lʊk. hi wʌndɝɾ əɡɛn ɪf ʃi wɑz ðə bjuɾəfəl wʊmən mɪn hæd wɔɹn ɪm əɡɛnst. bɛɾɝ ɪf ʃiz ðə fælkən. ðət θɔt sɝpɹaɪzd ɪm soʊ mʌtʃ ðəɾ i stʌmbəld.

He glanced sideways at Zarine, walking beside him, the shadows masking her face. Even for his eyes, the shadows were there, just fainter than they would have been for another's. They emphasized her high cheekbones, softened the strong curve of her nose. He just could not make up his mind about her. Even if Moiraine and Lan still insisted they stay close to the inn, he wished she could find something else to do besides watch him work. For some reason, he had found himself growing awkward whenever he thought of her tilted eyes on him. More than once he had fumbled with his hammer till Master Ajala frowned at him wonderingly. Girls had always been able to make him feel awkward especially when they smiled at him, but Zarine did not have to smile. Only look. He wondered again if she was the beautiful woman Min had warned him against. Better if she is the falcon. That thought surprised him so much that he stumbled.

"aɪ dɪd nɑt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ aɪ meɪk tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə hænz ʌv wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən." hɪz aɪz ɡloʊd ɡoʊldən əz i lʊkt ət hɝ. "ɪf ɪt wɑz fəɹ ə haɪ lɔɹd, haʊ kəɾ aɪ tɛl wɛɹ ɪt maɪɾ ɛnd?" ʃi ʃɪvɝd. "aɪ dɪd nɑt min tə fɹaɪɾən ju, faɪ - zɑɹin."

"I did not want anything I make to get into the hands of one of the Forsaken." His eyes glowed golden as he looked at her. "If it was for a High Lord, how could I tell where it might end?" She shivered. "I did not mean to frighten you, Fai - Zarine."

ʃi smaɪl bɹɔdli, noʊ daʊt θɪŋkɪŋ i kəd nɑt si hɝ. "ju wɪl fɔl jɛt, fɑɹmbɔɪ. hæv jə ɛvɝ θɔɾ ʌv wɛɹɪŋ ə bɪɹd?"

She smiled broadly, no doubt thinking he could not see her. "You will fall yet, farmboy. Have you ever thought of wearing a beard?"

ɪts bæɾ ɪnʌf ʃiz ɔlweɪz mɑkɪŋ mi, bʌt hæf ðə taɪm aɪ də nɑɾ ivən ʌndɝstæn hɝ!

It is bad enough she's always mocking me, but half the time I do not even understand her!

əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ ə ði ɪn, mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn mɛt ðɛm, kʌmɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ. mɔɪɹeɪn wɔɹ ðət lɪnən kloʊk wɪð ðə waɪd, dip hʊd ðət hɪɾ əɹ feɪs. laɪt fɹəm ðə kɑmən-ɹum wɪndoʊz meɪd jɛloʊ pulz ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. tu əɹ θɹi kæɹɪdʒɪz ɹʌmbəl pæst, ən ðəɹ wɝ pɝhæps ə dʌzən pipəl ɪn saɪt, hɝiɪŋ hoʊm fəɹ ðɛɹ sʌpɝz, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ʃædoʊz pɑpjəleɪɾəd ðə stʃɹit. ðə wivɝz ʃɑp wɑz kloʊz taɪt. ðə saɪləns wɑz dɛfənɪŋ.

As they reached the front door of the inn, Moiraine and Lan met them, coming the other way. Moiraine wore that linen cloak with the wide, deep hood that hid her face. Light from the common-room windows made yellow pools on the paving stones. Two or three carriages rumbled past, and there were perhaps a dozen people in sight, hurrying home for their suppers, but for the most part, shadows populated the street. The weaver's shop was closed tight. The silence was deafening.

"ɹæn ɪz ɪn tɛɹ." ði ɛɛs sədaɪz kul vɔɪs ɪʃud fɹəm ðə dɛpθs ə hɝ hʊɾ əz fɹəm ə kævɝn.

"Rand is in Tear." The Aes Sedai's cool voice issued from the depths of her hood as from a cavern.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "aɪ hæv nɑt hɝɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒ hæpənɪŋ. noʊ wɛɾɪŋz, əɹ wɛlz dʒɹaɪɪŋ ʌp." hi sɔ zɑɹin fɹaʊn ɪn kənfjuʒən. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd nɑt bɪn fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ wɪð hɝ, ən niðɝ hæd hi. kipɪŋ lɔɪəlz tʌŋ saɪlən hæd bɪn mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt.

"Are you sure?" Perrin asked. "I have not heard of anything strange happening. No weddings, or wells drying up." He saw Zarine frown in confusion. Moiraine had not been forthcoming with her, and neither had he. Keeping Loial's tongue silent had been more difficult.

"doʊn jə lɪsən tə ɹumɝz, blæksmɪθ?" ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd. "ðɛɹ əv bɪn mɛɹɪdʒɪz, əz mɛni ɪn ðə læs fɔɹ deɪz əz ɪn hæf ə jɪɹ bɪfɔɹ. ən əz mɛni mɝɾɝz əz ɪn ə hoʊl jɪɹ. ə tʃaɪl fɛl fɹəm ə taʊɝ bælkəni tədeɪ. ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ɑntu stoʊn peɪvɪŋ. ʃi ɡɑɾ ʌp ən ɹæn tə hɝ mʌðɝ wɪθaʊɾ ə bɹuz. ðə fɝst ə min, ə 'ɡɛst' ɪn ðə stoʊn sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪntɝ, ənaʊns tədeɪ ðət ʃɪl səbmɪt tə ðə wɪl ə ðə haɪ lɔɹdz, æftɝ seɪɪŋ jɛstɝdeɪ ʃi wəd si min ən ɔl ɪts ʃɪps bɝn bɪfɔɹ wʌn tɛɹən kʌntʃɹi lɔɹd sɛt fʊɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɹɔt ðɛmsɛlvz tə tɔɹtʃɝ hɝ, ən ðət jʌŋ wʊmən əz ə wɪl laɪk aɪɝn, soʊ jə tɛl mi ɪf jə θɪŋk ɪt maɪt bi ɹændz duɪŋ. blæksmɪθ, fɹəm tɑp tə bɑɾəm, tɛɹ bʌbəlz laɪk ə kɑlʒɹən."

"Don't you listen to rumors, blacksmith?" the Warder said. "There have been marriages, as many in the last four days as in half a year before. And as many murders as in a whole year. A child fell from a tower balcony today. A hundred paces onto stone paving. She got up and ran to her mother without a bruise. The First of Mayene, a 'guest' in the Stone since before the winter, announced today that she will submit to the will of the High Lords, after saying yesterday she would see Mayene and all its ships burn before one Tairen country lord set foot in the city. They had not brought themselves to torture her, and that young woman has a will like iron, so you tell me if you think it might be Rand's doing. Blacksmith, from top to bottom, Tear bubbles like a cauldron."

"ðiz θɪŋz wɝ nɑt niɾəd tə tɛl mi," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "pɛɹɪn, dɪd jə dʒɹim ə ɹænd læs naɪt?"

"These things were not needed to tell me," Moiraine said. "Perrin, did you dream of Rand last night?"

"jɛs," hi ədmɪɾəd. "hi wɑz ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn, hoʊldɪŋ ðət sɔɹd" - hi fɛl zɑɹin ʃɪf bɪsaɪɾ ɪm - "bʌɾ aɪ hæv bɪn wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðət soʊ mʌtʃ ɪts noʊ wʌndɝ aɪ dʒɹim ʌv ɪt. aɪ hæd nʌθɪŋ bʌt naɪtmɛɹz læs naɪt."

"Yes," he admitted. "He was in the Heart of the Stone, holding that sword" - he felt Zarine shift beside him - "but I have been worrying about that so much it is no wonder I dream of it. I had nothing but nightmares last night."

"ə tɔl mæn?" zɑɹin sɛd. "wɪð ɹɛɾɪʃ hɛɹ ən ɡɹeɪ aɪz? hoʊldɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ðət ʃaɪnz soʊ bɹaɪtli ɪt hɝts jəɹ aɪz? ɪn ə pleɪs ðəɾ ɪz ɔl ɡɹeɪt ɹɛdstoʊn kɑləmz? blæksmɪθ, tɛl mi ðət wɑz nɑt jəɹ dʒɹim."

"A tall man?" Zarine said. "With reddish hair and gray eyes? Holding something that shines so brightly it hurts your eyes? In a place that is all great redstone columns? Blacksmith, tell me that was not your dream."

"ju si," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "aɪ hæv hɝd ðɪs dʒɹim spoʊkən ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz tədeɪ. ðeɪ ɔl spik ə naɪtmɛɹz - bɛləl əpɛɹənli dʌz nɑt kɛɹ tə ʃild ɪz dʒɹimz - bʌt ðət wʌn əbʌv ɔl ɛls." ʃi læf sʌɾənli, laɪk loʊ, kul tʃaɪmz. "pipəl seɪ hiz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðeɪ seɪ hiz kʌmɪŋ. ðeɪ wɪspɝ ɪt fɪɹfəli ɪn kɔɹnɝz, bʌt ðeɪ seɪ ɪt."

"You see," Moiraine said. "I have heard this dream spoken of a hundred times today. They all speak of nightmares - Be'lal apparently does not care to shield his dreams - but that one above all else." She laughed suddenly, like low, cool chimes. "People say he is the Dragon Reborn. They say he is coming. They whisper it fearfully in corners, but they say it."

"ænd wʌɾ ə bɛləl?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"And what of Be'lal?" Perrin asked.

mɔɪɹeɪnz ɹɪplaɪ wɑz koʊld-dʒɹɔn stil. "aɪ wɪl dil wɪð ɪm tənaɪt." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ fɪɹ sɛn fɹəm hɝ.

Moiraine's reply was cold-drawn steel. "I will deal with him tonight." There was no fear scent from her.

"wi wɪl dil wɪð ɪm tənaɪt," læn toʊl hɝ.

"We will deal with him tonight," Lan told her.

"jɛs, maɪ ɡeɪɾɪn. wɪl dil wɪð hɪm."

"Yes, my Gaidin. We will deal with him."

"ænd wʌt də wi du? sɪt hɪɹ ən weɪt? aɪ hæɾ ɪnʌf weɪɾɪŋ tə læs mi ə laɪftaɪm ɪn ðə maʊntənz, mɔɪɹeɪn."

"And what do we do? Sit here and wait? I had enough waiting to last me a lifetime in the mountains, Moiraine."

"ju ən lɔɪəl - ən zɑɹin - wɪl ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn," ʃi toʊl hɪm. "əntɪl ðɪs ɪz dʌn. ɪɾəl bi ðə seɪfəs pleɪs fəɹ ju."

"You and Loial - and Zarine - will go to Tar Valon," she told him. "Until this is done. It will be the safest place for you."

"wɛɹ ɪz ði oʊɡiɝ?" læn sɛd. "aɪ wɑn ɔl θɹi ʌv jə ɑn jəɹ weɪ nɔɹθ əz sun əz pɑsəbəl."

"Where is the Ogier?" Lan said. "I want all three of you on your way north as soon as possible."

"əpstɛɹz, aɪ səpoʊz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɪn ɪz ɹum, əɹ meɪbi ðə daɪnɪŋ ɹum. ðəɹ ɑɹ laɪts ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz ʌp ðɛɹ. hiz ɔlweɪz wɝkɪŋ ɑn ðoʊz noʊts ə hɪz. aɪ səpoʊz hɪl əv plɛnti tə seɪ ɪn ɪz bʊk əbaʊɾ əs ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ." hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət ðə bɪɾɝnəs ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. laɪt, ful, dʒju wɑnə feɪs wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən? noʊ. noʊ, bʌɾ aɪm taɪɝɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ nɑt ɹʌnɪŋ, wʌns. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ faɪɾɪŋ bæk, ən ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ. ivən ɪf aɪ θɔɾ aɪ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ, ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ.

"Upstairs, I suppose," Perrin said. "In his room, or maybe the dining room. There are lights in the windows up there. He is always working on those notes of his. I suppose he will have plenty to say in his book about us running away." He was surprised at the bitterness in his voice. Light, fool, do you want to face one of the Forsaken? No. No, but I am tired of running. I remember not running, once. I remember fighting back, and it was better. Even if I thought I was going to die, it was better.

"aɪ wɪl faɪn hɪm," zɑɹin ənaʊnst. "aɪ hæv noʊ ʃeɪm ɪn ædmɪɾɪŋ əl bi ɡlæɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹʌn fɹəm ðɪs faɪt. mɛn faɪt wən ðeɪ ʃəd ɹʌn, ən fulz faɪt wən ðeɪ ʃəd ɹʌn. bʌɾ aɪ hæd noʊ nid tə seɪ ɪt twaɪs." ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, hɝ nɛɹoʊ, dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts meɪkɪŋ smɔl wɪskɪŋ nɔɪzɪz əz ðeɪ ɛntɝd ði ɪn.

"I will find him," Zarine announced. "I have no shame in admitting I will be glad enough to run from this fight. Men fight when they should run, and fools fight when they should run. But I had no need to say it twice." She strode ahead of them, her narrow, divided skirts making small whisking noises as they entered the inn.

pɛɹɪn ɡlænst ɝaʊn ðə kɑmən ɹum əz ðeɪ fɑloʊɾ əɹ təwɔɹd ðə stɛɹz ɪn ðə bæk. ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ mɛn ət ðə teɪbəlz ðən i ɪkspɛktəd. səm sæɾ əloʊn, wɪð dʌl aɪz, bʌt wɛɹ tu əɹ θɹi sæt təɡɛðɝ ðeɪ tɔkt ɪn fɹaɪɾənd wɪspɝz ɪz ɪɹz kəd bɛɹli kætʃ. ivən soʊ, hi hɝd "dʒɹæɡən" θɹi taɪmz.

Perrin glanced around the common room as they followed her toward the stairs in the back. There were fewer men at the tables than he expected. Some sat alone, with dull eyes, but where two or three sat together they talked in frightened whispers his ears could barely catch. Even so, he heard "Dragon" three times.

əz i ɹitʃt ðə tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz, hi hɝɾ ənʌðɝ sɑf saʊnd, ə θʌmp əz ə sʌmθɪŋ fɔlɪŋ ɪn ðə pɹaɪvət daɪnɪŋ ɹum. hi pɪɹd ðət weɪ əlɔŋ ðə hɔl. "zɑɹin?" ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ænsɝ. hi fɛl ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk ʃɪft, ən pæɾəd ðət weɪ. "zɑɹin?" hi pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. "feɪl!"

As he reached the top of the stairs, he heard another soft sound, a thump as of something falling in the private dining room. He peered that way along the hall. "Zarine?" There was no answer. He felt the hair on the back of his neck shift, and padded that way. "Zarine?" He pushed open the door. "Faile!"

ʃi wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ nɪɹ ðə teɪbəl. əz i stɑɹɾəd tə ɹʌʃ ɪndə ðə ɹum, mɔɪɹeɪnz kəmændɪŋ ʃaʊt hɔltəd hɪm.

She was lying on the floor near the table. As he started to rush into the room, Moiraine's commanding shout halted him.

"stɑp, jə ful! stɑp, fəɹ jəɹ laɪf!" ʃi keɪm əlɔŋ ðə hɔlweɪ sloʊli, hɛd tɝnɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ lɪsnɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, əɹ sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ. læn fɑloʊd wɪð ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd - ən ə lʊk ɪn ɪz aɪ əz ɪf i ɔlɹɛɾi nu stil wəd də noʊ ɡʊd. ʃi keɪm əbɹɛst ə ðə dɔɹ ən stɑpt. "muv bæk, pɛɹɪn. muv bæk!"

"Stop, you fool! Stop, for your life!" She came along the hallway slowly, head turning as if she were listening for something, or searching for something. Lan followed with his hand on his sword - and a look in his eye as if he already knew steel would do no good. She came abreast of the door and stopped. "Move back, Perrin. Move back!"

ɪn æɡəni hi stɛɹɾ ət zɑɹin. ət feɪl. ʃi leɪ ðəɹ əz ɪf laɪfləs. faɪnəli hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf stɛp bæk fɹəm ðə dɔɹ, livɪŋ ɪɾ oʊpən, stændɪŋ wɛɹ i kəd si hɝ. ʃi lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɝ dɛd. hi kəd nɑt si hɝ tʃɛst stɝ. hi wɑntəd tə haʊl. fɹaʊnɪŋ, hi wɝkt ɪz hænd, ðə wʌn i hæd juz tə pʊʃ ðə dɔɹ ɪndə ðə ɹum, oʊpənɪŋ ən kloʊzɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. ɪt tɪŋɡəld ʃɑɹpli, əz ɪf i hæd stʃɹʌk ɪz ɛlboʊ. "ɑɹən jə gɑnə də ɛniθɪŋ, mɔɪɹeɪn? ɪf jəl nɑt, aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɝ."

In agony he stared at Zarine. At Faile. She lay there as if lifeless. Finally he made himself step back from the door, leaving it open, standing where he could see her. She looked as if she were dead. He could not see her chest stir. He wanted to howl. Frowning, he worked his hand, the one he had used to push the door into the room, opening and closing his fingers. It tingled sharply, as if he had struck his elbow. "Aren't you going to do anything, Moiraine? If you will not, I am going to her."

"stæn stɪl əɹ jəl ɡoʊ noʊwɛɹ," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. "wʌɾ ɪz ðət baɪ hɝ ɹaɪt hænd? əz ɪf ɪt dʒɹɑp fɹəm əɹ ɡɹɪp wən ʃi fɛl. aɪ kænɑt meɪk ɪɾ aʊt."

"Stand still or you will go nowhere," she said calmly. "What is that by her right hand? As if it dropped from her grip when she fell. I cannot make it out."

hi ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɝ, ðən pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum. "ə hɛdʒhɑɡ. ɪt lʊks laɪk ə hɛdʒhɑɡ kɑɹvd aʊɾ ʌv wʊd. mɔɪɹeɪn, tɛl mi wʌɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn! wʌɾ əz hæpənd? tɛl mi!"

He glared at her, then peered into the room. "A hedgehog. It looks like a hedgehog carved out of wood. Moiraine, tell me what is going on! What has happened? Tell me!"

"ə hɛdʒhɑɡ," ʃi mɝmɝd. "ə hɛdʒhɑɡ. bi saɪlənt, pɛɹɪn. aɪ mʌs θɪŋk. aɪ fɛlt ɪt tʃɹɪɡɝ. aɪ kən sɛns ðə ɹɛzəduz ə ðə floʊz woʊvən tə sɛɾ ɪt. spɪɹət. pjʊɹ spɪɹət, ən nʌθɪŋ ɛls. ɔlmoʊs nʌθɪŋ juzɪz pjʊɹ floʊz ə spɪɹət! waɪ dʌz ðət hɛdʒhɑɡ meɪk mi θɪŋk ə spɪɹət?"

"A hedgehog," she murmured. "A hedgehog. Be silent, Perrin. I must think. I felt it trigger. I can sense the residues of the flows woven to set it. Spirit. Pure Spirit, and nothing else. Almost nothing uses pure flows of Spirit! Why does that hedgehog make me think of Spirit?"

"ju fɛlt wʌt tʃɹɪɡɝ, mɔɪɹeɪn? wʌt wɑz sɛt? ə tʃɹæp?"

"You felt what trigger, Moiraine? What was set? A trap?"

"jɛs, ə tʃɹæp," ʃi sɛd, ɪɹɪteɪʃən meɪkɪŋ taɪni kɹæks ɪn əɹ kul sɝɛnəɾi. "ə tʃɹæp mɛn fəɹ mi. aɪ wʊɾə bɪn fɝst ɪndə ðət ɹum ɪf zɑɹin hæd nɑt ɹʌʃt əhɛd. læn ən aɪ wəd ʃʊɹli hæv ɡɔn ðəɹ tə plæn ən weɪt fəɹ sʌpɝ. əl nɑt weɪɾ ɑn sʌpɝ naʊ. bi kwaɪət, ɪf jə wɪʃ mi tə hɛlp ðə ɡɝl əɾ ɔl. læn! bɹɪŋ mi ðəɾ ɪnkipɝ!" ðə wɔɹɾɝ floʊɾ əweɪ daʊn ðə stɛɹz.

"Yes, a trap," she said, irritation making tiny cracks in her cool serenity. "A trap meant for me. I would have been first into that room if Zarine had not rushed ahead. Lan and I would surely have gone there to plan and wait for supper. I will not wait on supper now. Be quiet, if you wish me to help the girl at all. Lan! Bring me that innkeeper!" The Warder flowed away down the stairs.

mɔɪɹeɪn peɪst ʌp ən daʊn ɪn ðə hɔl, səmtaɪmz stɑpɪŋ tə pɪɹ θɹu ðə dɔɹ fɹəm ðə dɛpθs ə hɝ hʊd. pɛɹɪn kəd si noʊ saɪn ðət zɑɹin lɪvd. hɝ bɹɛs dɪd nɑt stɝ. hi tʃɹaɪd lɪsnɪŋ fəɹ əɹ hɑɹtbit, bʌɾ ivən fəɹ ɪz ɪɹz ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl.

Moiraine paced up and down in the hall, sometimes stopping to peer through the door from the depths of her hood. Perrin could see no sign that Zarine lived. Her breast did not stir. He tried listening for her heartbeat, but even for his ears it was impossible.

wən læn ɹɪtɝnd, ʃʌvɪŋ ə fɹaɪɾənd dʒʊɹə hɛɹəɾ əhɛɾ ə hɪm baɪ ðə skɹʌf ə hɪz fæt nɛk, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ðə bɔldɪŋ mæn. "ju pɹɑməs tə kip ðɪs ɹum fəɹ mi, mæstɝ hɛɹət." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz əz hɑɹd, əz pɹɪsaɪs, əz ə skɪnɪŋ naɪf. "tə əlaʊ nɑɾ ivən ə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən tə ɛntɝ tə klin ənlɛs aɪ wɑz pɹɛzənt. hu dɪd jə lɛɾ ɛntɝ ɪt, mæstɝ hɛɹət? tɛl mi!"

When Lan returned, shoving a frightened Jurah Haret ahead of him by the scruff of his fat neck, the Aes Sedai rounded on the balding man. "You promised to keep this room for me, Master Haret." Her voice was as hard, as precise, as a skinning knife. "To allow not even a serving woman to enter to clean unless I was present. Who did you let enter it, Master Haret? Tell me!"

hɛɹət ʃʊk laɪk ə boʊl ə pʊɾɪŋ. "oʊ-oʊnli ðə ti-tu leɪɾiz, mɪstʃɹəs. ti-ðeɪ dʌbəlju-wɪʃt tə liv ə sɝpɹaɪz fəɹ ju. aɪ swɛɹ, mɪstʃɹəs. ti-ðeɪ ʃoʊɾ ɪt ti-tə mi. ə lɪɾəl eɪtʃ-hɛdʒhɑɡ. ti-ðeɪ sɛd jə dʌbəlju-wʊd bi sɝpɹaɪzd."

Haret shook like a bowl of pudding. "O-only the t-two Ladies, mistress. T-they w-wished to leave a surprise for you. I swear, mistress. T-they showed it t-to me. A little h-hedgehog. T-they said you w-would be surprised."

"aɪ wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd, ɪnkipɝ," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "liv mi! ən ɪf jə wɪspɝ ə wɝɾ ə ðɪs, ivən ɪn jəɹ slip, əl pʊl ðɪs ɪn daʊn ən liv oʊnli ə hoʊl ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd."

"I was surprised, innkeeper," she said softly. "Leave me! And if you whisper a word of this, even in your sleep, I will pull this inn down and leave only a hole in the ground."

"waɪ-jɛs, mɪstʃɹəs," hi wɪspɝd. "aɪ swɛɹ ɪt! aɪ də swɛɹ!

"Y-yes, mistress," he whispered. "I swear it! I do swear!

"ɡoʊ!"

"Go!"

ði ɪnkipɝ fɛl tə hɪz niz ɪn ɪz heɪs tə ɹitʃ ðə stɛɹz, ən wɛn skɹæmbəlɪŋ daʊn wɪð θʌmps ðət sədʒɛstəɾ i fɛl mɔɹ ðən wʌns əz i ɹæn.

The innkeeper fell to his knees in his haste to reach the stairs, and went scrambling down with thumps that suggested he fell more than once as he ran.

"hi noʊz aɪm hɪɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn toʊl ðə wɔɹɾɝ, "æn hiz faʊn sʌmwʌn ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ tə sɛɾ ɪz tʃɹæp, jɛt pɝhæps i θɪŋks aɪm kɑɾ ɪn ɪt. ɪt wɑz ə taɪni flæʃ ə ðə paʊɝ, bʌt pɝhæps hiz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə hæv sɛnst ɪt."

"He knows I am here," Moiraine told the Warder, "and he has found someone of the Black Ajah to set his trap, yet perhaps he thinks I am caught in it. It was a tiny flash of the Power, but perhaps he is strong enough to have sensed it."

"ðɛn hɪl nɑt səspɛkt wəɹ kʌmɪŋ," læn sɛd kwaɪətli. hi ɔlmoʊst smaɪld.

"Then he will not suspect we are coming," Lan said quietly. He almost smiled.

pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət ðɛm, hɪz tiθ bɛɹd. "wʌɾ əbaʊt hɝ?" hi dɪmændəd. "wʌt wɑz dʌn tə hɝ, mɔɪɹeɪn? ɪz ʃi əlaɪv? aɪ kænɑt si hɝ bɹið!"

Perrin stared at them, his teeth bared. "What about her?" he demanded. "What was done to her, Moiraine? Is she alive? I cannot see her breathe!"

"ʃi ɪz əlaɪv," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ kænɑt, aɪ dɛɹ nɑt, ɡoʊ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɝ tə tɛl mʌtʃ bɪɑn ðæt, bʌt ʃiz əlaɪv. ʃi . . . slips, ɪn ə weɪ. əz ə bɛɹ slips ɪn ðə wɪntɝ. hɝ hɑɹt bits soʊ sloʊli jə kəd kaʊn mɪnəts bɪtwin. hɝ bɹiðɪŋ ɪz ðə seɪm. ʃi slips." ivən fɹəm wɪðɪn ðət hʊd, hi kəd fil əɹ aɪz ɑn hɪm. "aɪ fɪɹ ʃiz nɑt ðɛɹ, pɛɹɪn. nɑɾ ɪn əɹ bɑɾi ɛni lɔŋɡɝ."

"She is alive," Moiraine said slowly. "I cannot, I dare not, go close enough to her to tell much beyond that, but she is alive. She . . . sleeps, in a way. As a bear sleeps in the winter. Her heart beats so slowly you could count minutes between. Her breathing is the same. She sleeps." Even from within that hood, he could feel her eyes on him. "I fear she is not there, Perrin. Not in her body any longer."

"wʌt dʒju min ʃiz nɑɾ ɪn əɹ bɑɾi? laɪt! jə doʊn min ðeɪ . . . tʊk əɹ soʊl. laɪk ðə ɡɹeɪ mɛn!" mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ən i dʒɹu ə ɹɪliv bɹɛθ. hɪz tʃɛs hɝɾ əz ɪf i hæd nɑt bɹið sɪns ʃi læst spoʊk. "ðɛn wɛɹ ɪz ʃi, mɔɪɹeɪn?"

"What do you mean she is not in her body? Light! You don't mean they . . . took her soul. Like the Gray Men!" Moiraine shook her head, and he drew a relieved breath. His chest hurt as if he had not breathed since she last spoke. "Then where is she, Moiraine?"

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ hæv ə səspɪʃən, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt noʊ."

"I do not know," she said. "I have a suspicion, but I do not know."

"ə səspɪʃən, ə hɪnt, ɛniθɪŋ! bɝn mi, wɛɹ?" læn ʃɪftəɾ ət ðə ɹʌnəs ɪn ɪz vɔɪs, bʌɾ i nu hi wəd tʃɹaɪ tə bɹeɪk ðə wɔɹɾɝ laɪk aɪɝn oʊvɝ ə hɑɹɾi ɪf ðə mæn tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp hɪm. "wɛɹ?"

"A suspicion, a hint, anything! Burn me, where?" Lan shifted at the roughness in his voice, but he knew he would try to break the Warder like iron over a hardy if the man tried to stop him. "Where?"

"aɪ noʊ vɛɹi lɪɾəl, pɛɹɪn." mɔɪɹeɪnz vɔɪs wɑz laɪk koʊld, ənfilɪŋ mjuzɪk. "aɪ hæv ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə lɪɾəl aɪ noʊ ʌv wʌt kənɛks ə kɑɹv hɛdʒhɑɡ wɪð spɪɹət. ðə kɑɹvɪŋ ɪz ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil læst stʌɾid baɪ kɔɹiənɪn nɪdil, ðə læs dʒɹimɝ ðə taʊɝ hæd. ðə tælən kɔl dʒɹimɪŋ ɪz ə θɪŋ ə spɪɹət, pɛɹɪn. ɪts nɑɾ ə θɪŋ aɪ hæv ɛvɝ stʌɾid; maɪ tæləns laɪ ɪn ʌðɝ weɪz. aɪ bɪliv ðət zɑɹin əz bɪn tʃɹæpt ɪnsaɪɾ ə dʒɹim, pɝhæps ivən ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ɔl ðəɾ ɪz əɹ ɪz ɪnsaɪd ðət dʒɹim. ɔl. eɪ dʒɹimɝ sɛnz oʊnli ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝsɛlf. ɪf zɑɹin dʌz nɑt ɹɪtɝn sun, hɝ bɑɾi wɪl daɪ. pɝhæps ʃɪl lɪv ɑn ɪn ðə dʒɹim. aɪ də nɑt noʊ."

"I know very little, Perrin." Moiraine's voice was like cold, unfeeling music. "I have remembered the little I know of what connects a carved hedgehog with Spirit. The carving is a ter'angreal last studied by Corianin Nedeal, the last Dreamer the Tower had. The Talent called Dreaming is a thing of Spirit, Perrin. It is not a thing I have ever studied; my Talents lie in other ways. I believe that Zarine has been trapped inside a dream, perhaps even the World of Dreams, Tel'aran'rhiod. All that is her is inside that dream. All. A Dreamer sends only a part of herself. If Zarine does not return soon, her body will die. Perhaps she will live on in the dream. I do not know."

"ðɛɹ ɪz tu mʌtʃ jə doʊnt noʊ," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd. hi pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum ən wɑntəd tə kɹaɪ. zɑɹin lʊk soʊ smɔl, laɪɪŋ ðɛɹ, soʊ hɛlpləs. feɪl. aɪ swɛɹ əl oʊnli kɔl jə feɪl, ɛvɝ əɡɛn. "waɪ doʊn jə də sʌmθɪŋ!"

"There is too much you don't know," Perrin muttered. He peered into the room and wanted to cry. Zarine looked so small, lying there, so helpless. Faile. I swear I will only call you Faile, ever again. "Why don't you do something!"

"ðə tʃɹæp əz bɪn spɹʌŋ, pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ ɪts ə tʃɹæp ðət wɪl stɪl kætʃ ɛniwʌn u stɛps ɪndə ðət ɹum. aɪ wəd nɑt ɹitʃ əɹ saɪd bɪfɔɹ ɪt tʊk mi. ən aɪ hæv wɝk aɪ mʌs də tənaɪt."

"The trap has been sprung, Perrin, but it is a trap that will still catch anyone who steps into that room. I would not reach her side before it took me. And I have work I must do tonight."

"bɝn ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ! bɝn jəɹ wɝk! ðɪs wɝld ə dʒɹimz? ɪz ɪt laɪk ðə wʊlf dʒɹimz? jə sɛd ðiz dʒɹimɝz səmtaɪmz sɔ wʊlvz."

"Burn you, Aes Sedai! Burn your work! This World of Dreams? Is it like the wolf dreams? You said these Dreamers sometimes saw wolves."

"aɪ hæv toʊl jə wʌɾ aɪ kæn," ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ɪɾ ɪz taɪm fəɹ jə tə ɡoʊ. læn ən aɪ mʌs bi ɑn əɹ weɪ tə ðə stoʊn. ðəɹ kən bi noʊ weɪɾɪŋ, naʊ."

"I have told you what I can," she said sharply. "It is time for you to go. Lan and I must be on our way to the Stone. There can be no waiting, now."

"noʊ." hi sɛɾ ɪt kwaɪətli, bʌt wən mɔɪɹeɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, hi ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs. "noʊ! əl nɑt liv hɝ!"

"No." He said it quietly, but when Moiraine opened her mouth, he raised his voice. "No! I will not leave her!"

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "vɛɹi wɛl, pɛɹɪn." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz aɪs; kɑm, smuð, koʊld. "ɹɪmeɪn ɪf jə wɪʃ. pɝhæps jəl sɝvaɪv ðɪs naɪt. læn!"

The Aes Sedai took a deep breath. "Very well, Perrin." Her voice was ice; calm, smooth, cold. "Remain if you wish. Perhaps you will survive this night. Lan!"

ʃi ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ stʃɹoʊd daʊn ðə hɔl tə ðɛɹ ɹumz. ɪn moʊməns ðeɪ ɹɪtɝnd, læn wɛɹɪŋ ɪz kʌlɝ-tʃeɪnʒɪŋ kloʊk, ən vænɪʃt daʊn ðə stɛɹz wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝd tə hɪm.

She and the Warder strode down the hall to their rooms. In moments they returned, Lan wearing his color-changing cloak, and vanished down the stairs without another word to him.

hi stɛɹd θɹu ði oʊpən dɔɹ ət feɪl. aɪ hæv tə də sʌmθɪŋ. ɪf ɪts laɪk ðə wʊlf dʒɹimz. . . .

He stared through the open door at Faile. I have to do something. If it is like the wolf dreams. . . .

"pɛɹɪn," keɪm lɔɪəlz dip ɹʌmbəl, "wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs əbaʊt feɪl?" ði oʊɡiɝ keɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔl ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz, ɪŋk ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən ə pɛn ɪn ɪz hænd. "læn toʊl mi aɪ hæd tə ɡoʊ, ən ðən i sɛd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt feɪl, ɪn ə tʃɹæp. wʌɾ i min?"

"Perrin," came Loial's deep rumble, "what is this about Faile?" The Ogier came striding down the hall in his shirtsleeves, ink on his fingers and a pen in his hand. "Lan told me I had to go, and then he said something about Faile, in a trap. What did he mean?"

dɪstʃɹæktɪdli, pɛɹɪn toʊld ɪm wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sɛd. ɪt maɪt wɝk. ɪt maɪt. ɪts tə! hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd wən lɔɪəl ɡɹaʊld.

Distractedly, Perrin told him what Moiraine had said. It might work. It might. It has to! He was surprised when Loial growled.

"noʊ! pɛɹɪn, ɪts nɑt ɹaɪt! feɪl wɑz soʊ fɹi. ɪts nɑt ɹaɪt tə tʃɹæp hɝ!"

"No! Perrin, it is not right! Faile was so free. It is not right to trap her!"

pɛɹɪn pɪɹɾ ʌp ət lɔɪəlz feɪs, ən sʌɾənli ɹɪmɛmbɝd ði oʊl stɔɹiz ðət kleɪmd oʊɡiɝ wɝ ɪmplækəbəl ɛnəmiz. lɔɪəlz ɪɹz hæd leɪd bæk əlɔŋ ðə saɪdz ə hɪz hɛd, ən ɪz bɹɔd feɪs wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz ən ænvəl.

Perrin peered up at Loial's face, and suddenly remembered the old stories that claimed Ogier were implacable enemies. Loial's ears had laid back along the sides of his head, and his broad face was as hard as an anvil.

"lɔɪəl, aɪm gɑnə tʃɹaɪ tə hɛlp feɪl. bʌɾ əl bi hɛlpləs maɪsɛlf waɪl aɪ du. wɪl jə ɡɑɹd maɪ bæk?"

"Loial, I am going to try to help Faile. But I will be helpless myself while I do. Will you guard my back?"

lɔɪəl ɹeɪz ðoʊz hjudʒ hænz ðət hɛl bʊks soʊ kɛɹfəli, ən ɪz θɪk fɪŋɡɝz kɝld əz ɪf tə kɹʌʃ stoʊn. "nʌn wɪl pæs mi waɪl aɪ laɪv, pɛɹɪn. nɑt mɹdʒɹɑl əɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf." hi sɛɾ ɪt laɪk ə sɪmpəl steɪtmən ə fækt.

Loial raised those huge hands that held books so carefully, and his thick fingers curled as if to crush stone. "None will pass me while I live, Perrin. Not Myrddraal or the Dark One himself." He said it like a simple statement of fact.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, ən lʊk θɹu ðə dɔɹ əɡɛn. ɪts tə wɝk. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ ɪf mɪn wɔɹn mi əɡɛnst əɹ əɹ nɑt! wɪð ə snɑɹl i lɛp təwɔɹd feɪl, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz hænd. hi θɔɾ i tʌtʃt əɹ æŋkəl bɪfɔɹ i wɑz ɡɔn.

Perrin nodded, and looked through the door again. It has to work. I don't care if Min warned me against her or not! With a snarl he leaped toward Faile, stretching out his hand. He thought he touched her ankle before he was gone.

wɛðɝ ðɪs dʒɹim ə ðə tʃɹæp wɑz tɛlɝɑnɹhiəɾ əɹ nɑt, pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ, bʌɾ i nu ɪt fəɹ ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. ɹoʊlɪŋ, ɡɹæsi hɪlz sɝaʊndəd hɪm, ən skæɾɝd θɪkəts. hi sɔ dɪɹ bɹaʊzɪŋ ət ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə tʃɹiz, ən ə hɝɾ ə səm sɔɹɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ ænəməl baʊndɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹæs, laɪk bɹaʊn-stʃɹaɪp dɪɹ, bʌt wɪð lɔŋ, stʃɹeɪt hɔɹnz. ðə smɛlz ɑn ðə wɪn toʊld ɪm ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊd tə it, ən ʌðɝ sɛns spoʊk ə mɔɹ ɡʊd hʌntɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn hɪm. ðɪs wɑz ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

Whether this dream of the trap was Tel'aran'rhiod or not, Perrin did not know, but he knew it for the wolf dream. Rolling, grassy hills surrounded him, and scattered thickets. He saw deer browsing at the edges of the trees, and a herd of some sort of running animal bounding across the grass, like brown-striped deer, but with long, straight horns. The smells on the wind told him they were good to eat, and other scents spoke of more good hunting all around him. This was the wolf dream.

hi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ðə blæksmɪθs lɔŋ lɛðɝ vɛst, hi ɹilaɪzd, wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz bɛɹ. ən ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd. hi tʌtʃt ði æks bɛlt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt ði æks hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɪts lup. hi ɹæn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz oʊvɝ ðə hɛɾ ə ðə hɛvi smɪθs hæmɝ. ɪt fɛlt ɹaɪt.

He was wearing the blacksmith's long leather vest, he realized, with his arms bare. And there was a weight at his side. He touched the axe belt, but it was not the axe hanging from its loop. He ran his fingers over the head of the heavy smith's hammer. It felt right.

hɑpɝ əlaɪɾɪd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm.

Hopper alighted in front of him.

əɡɛn jə kʌm, laɪk ə ful. ðə sɛndɪŋ wɑz ʌv ə kʌb stɪkɪŋ ɪts noʊz ɪndə ə hɑloʊ tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk tə læp hʌni dɪspaɪt ðə biz stɪŋɪŋ ɪts mʌzəl ən aɪz. ðə deɪnʒɝ ɪz ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ, jʌŋ bʊl. ivəl θɪŋz wɔk ðə dʒɹim. ðə bɹʌðɝz ən sɪstɝz əvɔɪd ðə maʊntənz ə stoʊn ðə tu-lɛɡz paɪl ʌp, ən ɔlmoʊs fɪɹ tə dʒɹim tə wʌn ənʌðɝ. jə mʌst ɡoʊ!

Again you come, like a fool. The sending was of a cub sticking its nose into a hollow tree trunk to lap honey despite the bees stinging its muzzle and eyes. The danger is greater than ever, Young Bull. Evil things walk the dream. The brothers and sisters avoid the mountains of stone the two-legs pile up, and almost fear to dream to one another. You must go!

"noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "feɪl ɪz hɪɹ, sʌmwɛɹ, tʃɹæpt. aɪ hæv tə faɪn hɝ, hɑpɝ. aɪ hæv tə!" hi fɛlt ə ʃɪftɪŋ ɪnsaɪd hɪm, sʌmθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. hi lʊk daʊn əɾ ɪz kɝli-hɛɹd lɛɡz, hɪz waɪd pɔz. hi wɑz ən ivən lɑɹdʒɝ wʊlf ðən hɑpɝ.

"No," Perrin said. "Faile is here, somewhere, trapped. I have to find her, Hopper. I have to!" He felt a shifting inside him, something changing. He looked down at his curly-haired legs, his wide paws. He was an even larger wolf than Hopper.

jə ɑɹ hɪɹ tu stʃɹɔŋli! ɛvɹi sɛndɪŋ kæɹid ʃɑk. jəl daɪ, jʌŋ bʊl!

You are here too strongly! Every sending carried shock. You will die, Young Bull!

ɪf aɪ də nɑt fɹi ðə fælkən, aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ, bɹʌðɝ.

If I do not free the falcon, I do not care, brother.

ðən wi hʌnt, bɹʌðɝ.

Then we hunt, brother.

noʊzɪz tə ðə wɪnd, ðə tu wʊlvz ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə pleɪn, sikɪŋ ðə fælkən.

Noses to the wind, the two wolves ran across the plain, seeking the falcon.


tʃæptɝ fɪftifɔɹ


CHAPTER 54

ɪndə ðə stoʊn


Into the Stone

ðə ɹuftɑps ə tiɹ wɝ noʊ pleɪs fəɹ ə sɛnsəbəl mæn tə bi ɪn ðə naɪt, mæt dɪsaɪɾɪd əz i pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə mun ʃædoʊz. ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən fɪfti peɪsɪz ə bɹɔd stʃɹit, əɹ pɝhæps nɛɹoʊ plɑzə, sɛpɝeɪɾəd ðə stoʊn fɹəm ɪz taɪld ɹuf, ɪtsɛlf θɹi stɔɹiz əbʌv ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. bʌt wən wɑz aɪ ɛvɝ sɛnsəbəl? ði oʊnli pipəl aɪ ɛvɝ mɛɾ u wɝ sɛnsəbəl ɔl ðə taɪm wɝ soʊ bɔɹɪŋ ðət wɑtʃɪŋ əm kəd pʊt jə tə slip. wɛðɝ ðə θɪŋ wɑz ə stʃɹiɾ əɹ ə plɑzə, hi hæd fɑloʊɾ ɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊn ðə stoʊn sɪns naɪtfɔl; ði oʊnli pleɪs ɪt dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ wɑz ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ saɪd, wɛɹ ði ɛɹɪnɪn ɹæn ɹaɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə fʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs, ən nʌθɪŋ ɪntɝʌptɪɾ ɪɾ ɪksɛp ðə sɪɾi wɔl. ðət wɔl wɑz oʊnli tu haʊsəz tə hɪz ɹaɪt. soʊ fɑɹ, ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl sim ðə bɛs pæθ tə ðə stoʊn, bʌt nɑt wʌn i wəd bi oʊvɝdʒɔɪd tə teɪk.

The rooftops of Tear were no place for a sensible man to be in the night, Mat decided as he peered into the moon shadows. A little more than fifty paces of broad street, or perhaps narrow plaza, separated the Stone from his tiled roof, itself three stories above the paving stones. But when was I ever sensible? The only people I ever met who were sensible all the time were so boring that watching them could put you to sleep. Whether the thing was a street or a plaza, he had followed it all the way around the Stone since nightfall; the only place it did not go was on the river side, where the Erinin ran right along the foot of the fortress, and nothing interrupted it except the city wall. That wall was only two houses to his right. So far, the top of the wall seemed the best path to the Stone, but not one he would be overjoyed to take.

pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf ən ə smɔl, waɪɝ-hændəl tɪn bɑks, hi muv kɛɹfəli tə ə bɹɪk tʃɪmni ə lɪɾəl nɪɹɝ ðə wɔl. ðə ɹoʊl ə faɪɹwɝks - wʌt hæd bɪn ðə ɹoʊl ə faɪɹwɝks bɪfɔɹ i wɝkt ɑn ɪt bæk ɪn ɪz ɹum - ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ɪz bæk. ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ʌv ə bʌndəl, naʊ, ɔl dʒæm təɡɛðɝ əz taɪɾ əz i kəd meɪk ɪt, bʌt stɪl tu bɪɡ fəɹ kæɹiɪŋ ɝaʊn ɹuftɑps ɪn ðə dɑɹk. ɝliɝ, ə slɪp ə hɪz fʊt kəz ə ðə θɪŋ hæd sɛn ə ɹuf taɪl skɪɾɝɪŋ oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ, ən ɹaʊz ðə mæn slipɪŋ ɪn ə ɹum bɪloʊ tə bɛloʊ "θif!" ən sɛn ɪm ɹʌnɪŋ. hi hɪtʃt ðə bʌndəl bæk ɪndə pəzɪʃən wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ən kɹaʊtʃt ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz ə ðə tʃɪmni. æftɝ ə moʊmən i sɛt ðə tɪn bɑks daʊn; ðə waɪɝ hændəl wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɡɹoʊ ənkʌmftəbli wɔɹm.

Picking up his quarterstaff and a small, wire-handled tin box, he moved carefully to a brick chimney a little nearer the wall. The roll of fireworks - what had been the roll of fireworks before he worked on it back in his room - shifted on his back. It was more of a bundle, now, all jammed together as tight as he could make it, but still too big for carrying around rooftops in the dark. Earlier, a slip of his foot because of the thing had sent a roof tile skittering over the edge, and roused the man sleeping in a room below to bellow "thief!" and send him running. He hitched the bundle back into position without thinking about it, and crouched in the shadows of the chimney. After a moment he set the tin box down; the wire handle was beginning to grow uncomfortably warm.

ɪt fɛlt ə lɪɾəl seɪfɝ, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə stoʊn fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz, bʌt nɑt mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ. ðə sɪɾi wɔl wɑz nɑt nɪɹli əz θɪk əz ðoʊz i hæd sin ɪn ʌðɝ pleɪsəz, ɪn keɪɛmlɪn əɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə peɪs waɪd, səpɔɹɾəd baɪ ɡɹeɪt stoʊn bʌtʃɹəsəz kloʊkt ɪn dɑɹknəs, naʊ. ə peɪs wɑz mɔɹ ðən səfɪʃənt wɪdθ fəɹ wɔkɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪksɛp ðət ðə fɔl tə iðɝ saɪd wɑz nɪɹli tɛn spænz. θɹu ðə dɑɹk, tə hɑɹd peɪvmənt. bʌt səm ə ðiz blʌɾi haʊsəz bæk ɹaɪɾ ʌp əɡɛnst ɪt, aɪ kən meɪk ɪt tə ðə tɑp izəli ɪnʌf, ən ɪt blʌɾi ɹʌnz stʃɹeɪt tə ðə blʌɾi stoʊn!

It felt a little safer, studying the Stone from the shadows, but not much more encouraging. The city wall was not nearly as thick as those he had seen in other places, in Caemlyn or Tar Valon, no more than a pace wide, supported by great stone buttresses cloaked in darkness, now. A pace was more than sufficient width for walking, of course, except that the fall to either side was nearly ten spans. Through the dark, to hard pavement. But some of these bloody houses back right up against it, I can make it to the top easily enough, and it bloody runs straight to the bloody Stone!

ɪt dɪd ðæt, bʌt ðət wɑz noʊ pɝtɪkjəlɝ kʌmfɝt. ðə saɪdz ə ðə stoʊn lʊk laɪk klɪfs. aɪɪŋ ðə haɪɾ əɡɛn, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf i ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə klaɪm ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ kæn. dʒʌs laɪk ðoʊz klɪfs ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz stʃɹeɪɾ ʌp bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wɑz ə bæɾəlmənt. ðəɹ mʌs bi æɹoʊslɪts loʊɝ daʊn, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk əm aʊɾ ɪn ðə naɪt. ən i kəd nɑt skwiz θɹu ən æɹoʊslɪt. ə hʌnʒɹəd blʌɾi peɪsɪz. meɪbi ə hʌnʒɹəd ən twɛnti. bɝn mi, ivən ɹænd wəd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə klaɪm ðæt. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə wʌn weɪ ɪn i hæd faʊnd. ɛvɹi ɡeɪɾ i hæd sin hæd bɪn ʃʌt taɪɾ ən lʊk stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə stɑp ə hɝɾ ə bʊlz, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə dʌzən əɹ soʊ soʊlʒɝz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ vɛɹi nɪɹli ɛvɹi læst wʌn, ɪn hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts, ən sɔɹdz ət ðɛɹ bɛls.

It did that, but that was no particular comfort. The sides of the Stone looked like cliffs. Eyeing the height again, he told himself he should be able to climb it. Of course, I can. Just like those cliffs in the Mountains of Mist. Over a hundred paces straight up before there was a battlement. There must be arrowslits lower down, but he could not make them out in the night. And he could not squeeze through an arrowslit. A hundred bloody paces. Maybe a hundred and twenty. Burn me, even Rand would not try to climb that. But it was the one way in he had found. Every gate he had seen had been shut tight and looked strong enough to stop a herd of bulls, not to mention the dozen or so soldiers guarding very nearly every last one, in helmets and breastplates, and swords at their belts.

sʌɾənli hi blɪŋkt, ən skwɪntɪɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stoʊn. ðəɹ wɑz səm ful klaɪmɪŋ ɪt, dʒʌs vɪzəbəl əz ə muvɪŋ ʃædoʊ ɪn ðə munlaɪt, ən oʊvɝ hæfweɪ ʌp ɔlɹɛɾi, wɪð ə dʒɹɑp ə sɛvənti peɪsɪz tə ðə peɪvmən ʌndɝ ɪz fit. ful, ɪz hi? wɛl, aɪm əz bɪɡ ə wʌn, kəz aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp, tu. bɝn mi, hɪl pɹɑbli ɹeɪz ən əlɑɹm ɪn ðəɹ ən ɡɛt mi kɑt. hi kəd nɑt si ðə klaɪmɝ ɛnimɔɹ. hu ɪn ðə laɪɾ ɪz hi? wʌt dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ u hi ɪz? bɝn mi, bʌt ðɪs ɪz ə blʌɾi weɪ tə wɪn ə weɪdʒɝ. aɪm gɑnə wɑn ə kɪs fɹəm ɔl ə ðɛm, ivən nɪneɪiv!

Suddenly he blinked, and squinted at the side of the Stone. There was some fool climbing it, just visible as a moving shadow in the moonlight, and over halfway up already, with a drop of seventy paces to the pavement under his feet. Fool, is he? Well, I'm as big a one, because I am going up, too. Burn me, he'll probably raise an alarm in there and get me caught. He could not see the climber anymore. Who in the Light is he? What does it matter who he is? Burn me, but this is a bloody way to win a wager. I'm going to want a kiss from all of them, even Nynaeve!

hi ʃɪftəd tə pɪɹ təwɔɹd ðə wɔl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃuz ɪz spɑt tə klaɪm, ən sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɑz stil əkɹɔs ɪz θɹoʊt. wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, hi nɑkt ɪɾ əweɪ ən swɛp ðə mænz fiɾ aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪm wɪð ɪz stæf. sʌmwʌn ɛls kɪkt ɪz oʊn fiɾ əweɪ ən i fɛl ɔlmoʊst ɑn tɑp ə ðə mæn i hæd nɑk daʊn. hi ɹoʊld ɔf ɑntu ðə ɹuf taɪlz, lusɪŋ ðə bʌndəl ə faɪɹwɝks - ɪf ðət fɔlz ɪndə ðə stʃɹit, əl bɹeɪk ðɛɹ nɛks! - stæf wɝlɪŋ; hi fɛlt ɪt stʃɹaɪk flɛʃ, ən ə sɛkən taɪm, hɝd ɡɹʌns. ðən ðəɹ wɝ tu bleɪdz əɾ ɪz θɹoʊt.

He shifted to peer toward the wall, trying to choose his spot to climb, and suddenly there was steel across his throat. Without thinking, he knocked it away and swept the man's feet out from under him with his staff. Someone else kicked his own feet away and he fell almost on top of the man he had knocked down. He rolled off onto the roof tiles, loosing the bundle of fireworks - If that falls into the street, I'll break their necks! - staff whirling; he felt it strike flesh, and a second time, heard grunts. Then there were two blades at his throat.

hi fɹoʊz, ɑɹmz aʊtfləŋ. ðə pɔɪns ə ʃɔɹt spɪɹz, dʌl soʊ ðeɪ hɑɹdli kɑt ðə feɪn laɪɾ ə ðə mun əɾ ɔl, pɹɛst ɪndə hɪz flɛʃ dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə bɹɪŋɪŋ blʌd. hɪz aɪz fɑloʊɾ əm ʌp tə ðə feɪsəz ə huɛvɝ wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt ðɛɹ hɛdz wɝ ʃɹaʊɾɪd, ðɛɹ feɪsəz veɪld ɪn blæk ɪksɛp fəɹ ðɛɹ aɪz, stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm. bɝn mi, aɪ hæv tə ɹʌn ɪndə ɹil θivz! wʌt hæpən tə maɪ lʌk?

He froze, arms outflung. The points of short spears, dull so they hardly caught the faint light of the moon at all, pressed into his flesh just short of bringing blood. His eyes followed them up to the faces of whoever was holding them, but their heads were shrouded, their faces veiled in black except for their eyes, staring at him. Burn me, I have to run into real thieves! What happened to my luck?

hi pʊɾ ɑn ə ɡɹɪn, wɪð plɛnti ʌv tiθ soʊ ðeɪ kəd si ɪɾ ɪn ðə munlaɪt. "aɪ də nɑt min tə tʃɹʌbəl jə ɪn jəɹ wɝk, soʊ ɪf jə lemi ɡoʊ maɪ weɪ, əl lɛt jə ɡoʊ jʊɹz ən seɪ nʌθɪŋ." ðə veɪl mɛn dɪd nɑt muv, ən niðɝ dɪd ðɛɹ spɪɹz. "aɪ wɑnt noʊ mɔɹ aʊtkɹaɪ ðən ju. əl nɑt bɪtʃɹeɪ ju." ðeɪ stʊd laɪk stætʃuz, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ət hɪm. bɝn mi, aɪ də nɑɾ əv taɪm fəɹ ðɪs. taɪm tə tɔs ðə daɪs. fəɹ ə tʃɪlɪŋ moʊmən i θɔt ðə wɝdz ɪn ɪz hɛd hæd bɪn stʃɹeɪnʒ. hi taɪɾənd ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf, laɪɪŋ aʊt tə wʌn saɪɾ ə hɪm - ən ɔlmoʊs kɹaɪɾ aʊt wən sʌmwʌn stɛp hɑɹɾ ɑn ɪz ɹɪst.

He put on a grin, with plenty of teeth so they could see it in the moonlight. "I do not mean to trouble you in your work, so if you let me go my way, I'll let you go yours and say nothing." The veiled men did not move, and neither did their spears. "I want no more outcry than you. I'll not betray you." They stood like statues, staring down at him. Burn me, I do not have time for this. Time to toss the dice. For a chilling moment he thought the words in his head had been strange. He tightened his grip on the quarterstaff, lying out to one side of him - and almost cried out when someone stepped hard on his wrist.

hi ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz tə si hu. bɝn mi fəɹ ə ful, aɪ fɝɡɑt ðə wʌn aɪ fɛl ɑn. bʌɾ i sɔ ənʌðɝ ʃeɪp muvɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə wʌn stændɪŋ ɑn ɪz ɹɪst, ən dɪsaɪɾɪd meɪbi ɪt wɑz əz wɛl i hæd nɑt mænədʒ tə bɹɪŋ ðə stæf ɪndə jus æftɝ ɔl.

He rolled his eyes to see who. Burn me for a fool, I forgot the one I fell on. But he saw another shape moving behind the one standing on his wrist, and decided maybe it was as well he had not managed to bring the staff into use after all.

ɪt wɑz ə sɑf but, leɪs tə ðə ni, ðət ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. ɪt tʌɡd əɾ ɪz mɛmɹi. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ə mæn mɛɾ ɪn maʊntənz. hi aɪd ðə naɪt-kloʊkt ʃeɪp ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ʌp, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk aʊt ðə kʌɾ ən kʌlɝz ə hɪz kloʊðz - ðeɪ simd ɔl ʃædoʊ, kʌlɝz ðət blɛndəd wɪð ðə dɑɹknəs tu wɛl tə si ðɛm klɪɹli - pæst ə lɔŋ-bleɪɾɪd naɪf ət ðə fɛloʊz weɪst, ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðə dɑɹk veɪl əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs. ə blæk-veɪl feɪs. blæk-veɪld.

It was a soft boot, laced to the knee, that rested on his arm. It tugged at his memory. Something about a man met in mountains. He eyed the night-cloaked shape the rest of the way up, trying to make out the cut and colors of his clothes - they seemed all shadow, colors that blended with the darkness too well to see them clearly - past a long-bladed knife at the fellow's waist, right up to the dark veil across his face. A black-veiled face. Black-veiled.

il! bɝn mi, wʌɾ ɑɹ blʌɾi il duɪŋ hɪɹ! hi hæɾ ə sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ ɪn ɪz stʌmək əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd hɪɹɪŋ ðəɾ il veɪl ðɛmsɛlvz wən ðeɪ kɪld.

Aiel! Burn me, what are bloody Aiel doing here! He had a sinking feeling in his stomach as he remembered hearing that Aiel veiled themselves when they killed.

"jɛs," sɛɾ ə mænz vɔɪs, "wi ɑɹ il." mæt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt; hi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪzd i hæd spoʊkən əlaʊd.

"Yes," said a man's voice, "we are Aiel." Mat gave a start; he had not realized he had spoken aloud.

"ju dæns wɛl fəɹ wʌn kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz," ə jʌŋ wʊmənz vɔɪs sɛd. hi θɔt ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn stændɪŋ ɑn ɪz ɹɪst. "pɝhæps ənʌðɝ deɪ əl əv taɪm tə dæns wɪð jə pɹɑpɝli."

"You dance well for one caught by surprise," a young woman's voice said. He thought she was the one standing on his wrist. "Perhaps another day I will have time to dance with you properly."

hi stɑɹɾəd tə smaɪl - ɪf ʃi wɑns tə dæns, ðeɪ kæn bi gɑnə kɪl mi, ət list! - ðən fɹaʊn ɪnstɛd. hi sim tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ il səmtaɪmz mɛn sʌmθɪŋ dɪfɹənt wən ðeɪ sɛd ðæt.

He started to smile - If she wants to dance, they can't be going to kill me, at least! - then frowned instead. He seemed to remember Aiel sometimes meant something different when they said that.

ðə spɪɹz wɝ pʊl bæk, ən hænz hɔld ɪm tə hɪz fit. hi ʃʊk əm əweɪ ən bɹʌʃt hɪmsɛlf ɔf əz ɪf i wɝ stændɪŋ ɪn ə kɑmən ɹum ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɑn ə naɪt-kloʊkt ɹuftɑp wɪð fɔɹ il. ɪɾ ɔlweɪz peɪd tə lɛt ði ʌðɝ mæn noʊ jə hæɾ ə stɛɾi nɝv. ði il hæd kwɪvɝz ət ðɛɹ weɪsts əz wɛl əz naɪvz, ən mɔɹ ə ðoʊz ʃɔɹt spɪɹz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks wɪð keɪs baʊz, ðə lɔŋ spɪɹ pɔɪns stɪkɪŋ ʌp əbʌv ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. hi hɝd hɪmsɛlf hʌmɪŋ "aɪm daʊn ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə wɛl," ən stɑpt ɪt.

The spears were pulled back, and hands hauled him to his feet. He shook them away and brushed himself off as if he were standing in a common room instead of on a night-cloaked rooftop with four Aiel. It always paid to let the other man know you had a steady nerve. The Aiel had quivers at their waists as well as knives, and more of those short spears on their backs with cased bows, the long spear points sticking up above their shoulders. He heard himself humming "I'm Down at the Bottom of the Well," and stopped it.

"wʌt dʒju də hɪɹ?" ðə mænz vɔɪs æskt. wɪð ðə veɪlz, mæt wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ʃʊɹ wɪtʃ wʌn hæd spoʊkən; ðə vɔɪs saʊndəɾ oʊldɝ, kɑnfəɾənt, juz tə kəmænd. hi θɔɾ i kəd pɪk aʊt ðə wʊmən, ət list; ʃi wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən hi, ən ðət nɑt baɪ mʌtʃ. ði ʌðɝz ɔl stʊɾ ə hɛd tɔlɝ ðən i əɹ mɔɹ. blʌɾi il, hi θɔt. "wi hæv wɑtʃt jə fəɹ səm lɪɾəl taɪm," ði oʊldɝ mæn wɛn ɑn, "wɑtʃt jə wɑtʃ ðə stoʊn. juv stʌɾid ɪt fɹəm ɛvɹi saɪd. waɪ?"

"What do you do here?" the man's voice asked. With the veils, Mat was not entirely sure which one had spoken; the voice sounded older, confident, used to command. He thought he could pick out the woman, at least; she was the only one shorter than he, and that not by much. The others all stood a head taller than he or more. Bloody Aiel, he thought. "We have watched you for some little time," the older man went on, "watched you watch the Stone. You have studied it from every side. Why?"

"aɪ kəɾ æsk ðə seɪm ʌv ɔl ə ju," ənʌðɝ vɔɪs sɛd. mæt wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn u ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əz ə mæn ɪn bæɡi bɹitʃɪz stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz. ðə fɛloʊ əpɪɹd tə bi ʃuləs, fəɹ bɛɾɝ fʊɾɪŋ ɑn ðə taɪlz. "aɪ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn θivz, nɑɾ il," ðə mæn wɛn ɑn, "bʌt də nɑt θɪŋk jəɹ nʌmbɝz fɹaɪɾən mi." ə slɪm stæf noʊ tɔlɝ ðən ɪz hɛd meɪɾ ə blɝ ən ə hʌm əz i wɝld ɪt. "maɪ neɪm ɪz dʒulɪn sændɑɹ, ən aɪm ə θif-kætʃɝ, ən aɪ wəd noʊ waɪ jə ɑɹ ɑn ðə ɹuftɑps, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə stoʊn."

"I could ask the same of all of you," another voice said. Mat was the only one who gave a start as a man in baggy breeches stepped out of the shadows. The fellow appeared to be shoeless, for better footing on the tiles. "I expected to find thieves, not Aiel," the man went on, "but do not think your numbers frighten me." A slim staff no taller than his head made a blur and a hum as he whirled it. "My name is Juilin Sandar, and I am a thief-catcher, and I would know why you are on the rooftops, staring at the Stone."

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. haʊ mɛni blʌɾi pipəl ɑɹ ɑn ðə ɹufs tənaɪt? ɔl ðət wɑz niɾəd wɑz fəɹ tɑm tə əpɪɹ ən pleɪ hɪz hɑɹp, əɹ sʌmwʌn tə kʌm lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ən ɪn. ə blʌɾi θif-teɪkɝ! hi wʌndɝd waɪ ði il wɝ dʒʌst stændɪŋ ðɛɹ.

Mat shook his head. How many bloody people are on the roofs tonight? All that was needed was for Thom to appear and play his harp, or someone to come looking for an inn. A bloody thief-taker! He wondered why the Aiel were just standing there.

"ju stɔk wɛl, fəɹ ə sɪɾi mæn," ði oʊldɝ mænz vɔɪs sɛd. "bʌt waɪ dʒju fɑloʊ ʌs? wɪv stoʊlən nʌθɪŋ. waɪ hæv jə lʊk soʊ ɔfən ət ðə stoʊn tənaɪt jɝsɛlf?"

"You stalk well, for a city man," the older man's voice said. "But why do you follow us? We have stolen nothing. Why have you looked so often at the Stone tonight yourself?"

ivən ɪn ðə munlaɪt ðɪs sændɑɹz sɝpɹaɪz wɑz ɛvəɾənt. hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, oʊpən ɪz maʊθ - ən kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn əz fɔɹ mɔɹ il ɹoʊz aʊɾ ə ðə dɪmnəs bɪhaɪn hɪm. wɪð ə saɪ, hi lin ɑn ɪz slɛndɝ stæf. "ɪt simz aɪm kɑt maɪsɛlf," hi mʌɾɝd. "ɪt simz aɪ mʌst ænsɝ jəɹ kwɛstʃənz." hi pɪɹd təwɔɹd ðə stoʊn, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ . . . dɪɾ ə θɪŋ tədeɪ ðət . . . tʃɹʌbəlz mi." hi saʊndəɾ ɔlmoʊst əz ðoʊ hi wɝ tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʌzəl ɪɾ aʊt. "pɑɹɾ ə mi sɛz ɪt wɑz ɹaɪt, wʌɾ aɪ dɪd, ðəɾ aɪ mʌst oʊbeɪ. ʃʊɹli, ɪt simd ɹaɪt wən aɪ dɪɾ ɪt. bʌɾ ə smɔl vɔɪs tɛlz mi aɪ . . . bɪtʃɹeɪd sʌmθɪŋ. aɪm sɝɾən ðɪs vɔɪs ɪz ɹɔŋ, ən ɪts vɛɹi smɔl, bʌɾ ɪɾəl nɑt stɑp." hi stɑp ðən hɪmsɛlf, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn.

Even in the moonlight this Sandar's surprise was evident. He gave a start, opened his mouth - and closed it again as four more Aiel rose out of the dimness behind him. With a sigh, he leaned on his slender staff. "It seems I am caught myself," he muttered. "It seems I must answer your questions." He peered toward the Stone, then shook his head. "I . . . did a thing today that . . . troubles me." He sounded almost as though he were talking to himself, trying to puzzle it out. "Part of me says it was right, what I did, that I must obey. Surely, it seemed right when I did it. But a small voice tells me I . . . betrayed something. I am certain this voice is wrong, and it is very small, but it will not stop." He stopped then himself, shaking his head again.

wʌn ə ði il nɑɾəd, ən spoʊk wɪð ði oʊldɝ mænz vɔɪs. "aɪ æm ɹəɑɹk, ʌv ðə naɪn væliz sɛpt ə ðə tɑɹdæɾ il, ən wʌns aɪ wɑz æɛθən dɔɹ, ə ɹɛd ʃild. səmtaɪmz ðə ɹɛd ʃilz də əz jəɹ θif-kætʃɝz du. aɪ seɪ ðɪs soʊ jəl ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪts jə du, ən ðə kaɪndə mæn jə mʌs bi. aɪ min noʊ hɑɹm tə ju, dʒulɪn sændɑɹ ə ðə θif-kætʃɝz, nɔɹ tə ðə pipəl ə jəɹ sɪɾi, bʌt jəl nɑt bi sʌfɝd tə ɹeɪz ði ɑɹmkɹi. ɪf jəl kip saɪləns, jəl lɪv; ɪf nɑt, nɑt."

One of the Aiel nodded, and spoke with the older man's voice. "I am Rhuarc, of the Nine Valleys sept of the Taardad Aiel, and once I was Aethan Dor, a Red Shield. Sometimes the Red Shields do as your thief-catchers do. I say this so you will understand that I know what it is you do, and the kind of man you must be. I mean no harm to you, Juilin Sandar of the thief-catchers, nor to the people of your city, but you will not be suffered to raise the armcry. If you will keep silence, you will live; if not, not."

"ju min noʊ hɑɹm tə ðə sɪɾi," sændɑɹ sɛd sloʊli. "waɪ ɑɹ jə hɪɹ, ðɛn?"

"You mean no harm to the city," Sandar said slowly. "Why are you here, then?"

"ðə stoʊn." ɹəɑɹks toʊn meɪɾ ɪt pleɪn ðət wɑz ɔl i mɛn tə seɪ.

"The Stone." Rhuarc's tone made it plain that was all he meant to say.

æftɝ ə moʊmən sændɑɹ nɑɾəd, ən mʌɾɝd, "aɪ kəɾ ɔlmoʊst wɪʃ jə hæd ðə paʊɝ tə hɑɹm ðə stoʊn, ɹəɑɹk. əl hoʊl maɪ tʌŋ."

After a moment Sandar nodded, and muttered, "I could almost wish you had the power to harm the Stone, Rhuarc. I will hold my tongue."

ɹəɑɹk tɝn ɪz veɪl feɪs tə mæt. "æn ju, neɪmləs jʌŋɡəlɪŋ? wɪl jə tɛl mi naʊ waɪ jə wɑtʃ ðə stoʊn soʊ kloʊsli?"

Rhuarc turned his veiled face to Mat. "And you, nameless youngling? Will you tell me now why you watch the Stone so closely?"

"aɪ dʒʌst wɑntəɾ ə wɔk ɪn ðə munlaɪt," mæt sɛd laɪtli. ðə jʌŋ wʊmən pʊɾ əɹ spɪɹpɔɪn tə hɪz θɹoʊɾ əɡɛn; hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə swɑloʊ. wɛl, meɪbi aɪ kən tɛl əm sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ɪt. hi mʌs nɑt lɛɾ əm noʊ hi wɑz ʃeɪkən; ɪf jə lɛt ði ʌðɝ fɛloʊ noʊ ðæt, jə lɔst wʌtɛvɝ ɛdʒ jə maɪt hæv. vɛɹi kɛɹfəli, wɪð tu fɪŋɡɝz, hi muvd əɹ stil əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. ɪt sim tə hɪm ðət ʃi læf sɔfli. "sʌm fɹɛnz ə maɪn ɑɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə stoʊn," hi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn kæʒəwəl. "pɹɪznɝz. aɪ min tə bɹɪŋ əm aʊt."

"I just wanted a walk in the moonlight," Mat said lightly. The young woman put her spearpoint to his throat again; he tried not to swallow. Well, maybe I can tell them something of it. He must not let them know he was shaken; if you let the other fellow know that, you lost whatever edge you might have. Very carefully, with two fingers, he moved her steel away from him. It seemed to him that she laughed softly. "Some friends of mine are inside the Stone," he said, trying to sound casual. "Prisoners. I mean to bring them out."

"əloʊn, neɪmləs wʌn?" ɹəɑɹk sɛd.

"Alone, nameless one?" Rhuarc said.

"wɛl, ðəɹ dʌzn sim tə bi ɛniwʌn ɛls," mæt sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ənlɛs jə kɛɹ tə hɛlp? jə sim ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ðə stoʊn jɝsɛlf. ɪf jə min tə ɡoʊ ɪndə ɪt, pɝhæps wi kəd ɡoʊ təɡɛðɝ. ɪts ə taɪt ɹoʊl ə ðə daɪs ɛni weɪ jə lʊk əɾ ɪt, bʌt maɪ lʌk ɹʌnz ɡʊd." soʊ fɑɹ, ɛniweɪ. aɪv ɹʌn ɪndə blæk-veɪld il ən ðeɪv nɑt kʌt maɪ θɹoʊt; lʌk kænɑt ɡɛt mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən ðæt. bɝn mi, ɪt wəd nɑt bi bæd tə hæv ə fju il əlɔŋ wɪð mi ɪn ðɛɹ. "ju kəd də wɝs ðən bɛɾɪŋ ɑn maɪ lʌk."

"Well, there doesn't seem to be anyone else," Mat said dryly. "Unless you care to help? You seem interested in the Stone yourself. If you mean to go into it, perhaps we could go together. It is a tight roll of the dice any way you look at it, but my luck runs good." So far, anyway. I've run into black-veiled Aiel and they have not cut my throat; luck cannot get much better than that. Burn me, it would not be bad to have a few Aiel along with me in there. "You could do worse than betting on my luck."

"wi ɑɹ nɑt hɪɹ fəɹ pɹɪznɝz, ɡæmblɝ," ɹəɑɹk sɛd.

"We are not here for prisoners, gambler," Rhuarc said.

"ɪɾ ɪz taɪm, ɹəɑɹk." mæt kəd nɑt tɛl fɹəm wɪtʃ ə ði il ðət keɪm, bʌt ɹəɑɹk nɑɾəd.

"It is time, Rhuarc." Mat could not tell from which of the Aiel that came, but Rhuarc nodded.

"jɛs, ɡɔl." hi lʊk fɹəm mæt tə sændɑɹ ən bæk. "du nɑt ɡɪv ði ɑɹmkɹi." hi tɝn əweɪ, ən ɪn tu stɛps i hæd blɛndəɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt.

"Yes, Gaul." He looked from Mat to Sandar and back. "Do not give the armcry." He turned away, and in two steps he had blended into the night.

mæt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. ði ʌðɝ il wɝ ɡɔn, tu, livɪŋ ɪm əloʊn wɪð ðə θif-teɪkɝ. ənlɛs ðeɪ lɛf sʌmbɑɾi tə wɑtʃ ʌs. bɝn mi, haʊ kəɾ aɪ tɛl ɪf ðeɪ dɪd? "aɪ hoʊp jə doʊn min tə tʃɹaɪ stɑpɪŋ mi, iðɝ," hi toʊl sændɑɹ əz i slʌŋ ðə bʌndəl ə faɪɹwɝks ɑn ɪz bæk əɡɛn ən pɪkt ʌp ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf. "aɪ min tə ɡoʊ ɪnsaɪd, baɪ jə əɹ θɹu ju, wʌn weɪ əɹ ði ʌðɝ." hi wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə tʃɪmni tə pɪk ʌp ðə tɪn bɑks; ðə waɪɝ hændəl wɑz mɔɹ ðən wɔɹm, naʊ.

Mat gave a start. The other Aiel were gone, too, leaving him alone with the thief-taker. Unless they left somebody to watch us. Burn me, how could I tell if they did? "I hope you don't mean to try stopping me, either," he told Sandar as he slung the bundle of fireworks on his back again and picked up his quarterstaff. "I mean to go inside, by you or through you, one way or the other." He went over to the chimney to pick up the tin box; the wire handle was more than warm, now.

"ðiz fɹɛnz ə jʊɹz," sændɑɹ sɛd. "ðeɪ ɑɹ θɹi wɪmən?"

"These friends of yours," Sandar said. "They are three women?"

mæt fɹaʊn ət hɪm, wɪʃɪŋ ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf laɪt tə ʃoʊ ðə mænz feɪs klɪɹli. ðə fɛloʊz vɔɪs saʊndəɾ ɑd. "wʌt dʒju noʊ ʌv ðɛm?"

Mat frowned at him, wishing there was enough light to show the man's face clearly. The fellow's voice sounded odd. "What do you know of them?"

"aɪ noʊ ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə stoʊn. ən aɪ noʊ ə smɔl ɡeɪt nɪɹ ðə ɹɪvɝ wɛɹ ə θif-kætʃɝ kən ɡeɪn ɛntʃɹɑns wɪð ə pɹɪznɝ, tə teɪk ɪm tə ðə sɛlz. ðə sɛlz wɛɹ ðeɪ mʌs bi. ɪf jəl tʃɹʌs mi, ɡæmblɝ, aɪ kən teɪk əs ðət fɑɹ. wʌt hæpənz æftɝ ðəɾ ɪz ʌp tə tʃæns. pɝhæps jəɹ lʌk wɪl bɹɪŋ əs aʊɾ əɡɛn əlaɪv."

"I know they are inside the Stone. And I know a small gate near the river where a thief-catcher can gain entrance with a prisoner, to take him to the cells. The cells where they must be. If you will trust me, gambler, I can take us that far. What happens after that is up to chance. Perhaps your luck will bring us out again alive."

"aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz bɪn lʌki," mæt sɛd sloʊli. də aɪ fil lʌki ɪnʌf tə tʃɹʌs hɪm? hi dɪd nɑt mʌtʃ laɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ə pɹɪznɝ; ɪt sim tu izi fəɹ pɹitɛns tə bɪkʌm ɹiæləɾi. bʌɾ ɪt sim noʊ bɪɡɝ ɹɪsk ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə klaɪm θɹi hʌnʒɹəd fiɾ əɹ mɔɹ stʃɹeɪɾ ʌp ɪn ðə dɑɹk.

"I have always been lucky," Mat said slowly. Do I feel lucky enough to trust him? He did not much like the idea of pretending to be a prisoner; it seemed too easy for pretense to become reality. But it seemed no bigger risk than trying to climb three hundred feet or more straight up in the dark.

hi ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə sɪɾi wɔl, ən stɛɹd. ʃædoʊz floʊɾ əlɔŋ ɪt; dɪm ʃeɪps tʃɹɑɾɪŋ. il, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ. ðəɹ mʌst əv bɪn oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd. ðeɪ vænɪʃt, bʌt naʊ hi kəd meɪk aʊt ʃædoʊz muvɪŋ ɑn ðə klɪf feɪs ðət wɑz ðə ʃɪɹ saɪɾ ə ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp ðət weɪ. ðət wʌn fɛloʊ ɝliɝ maɪɾ əv meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪnsaɪd wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ ən əlɑɹm - ɹəɑɹks ɑɹmkɹi - bʌɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ il wəɾ əv tə bi laɪk saʊndɪŋ bɛlz. ðeɪ maɪt meɪk ə daɪvɝʒən, ðoʊ. ɪf ðeɪ kɑzd ə kəmoʊʃən sʌmwɛɹ ʌp ðɛɹ, ɪnsaɪd ðə stoʊn, ðən huɛvɝ wɑz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɛlz maɪt nɑt peɪ əz mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən tə ə θif-teɪkɝ bɹɪŋɪŋ ə θif.

He glanced toward the city wall, and stared. Shadows flowed along it; dim shapes trotting. Aiel, he was sure. There must have been over a hundred. They vanished, but now he could make out shadows moving on the cliff face that was the sheer side of the Stone of Tear. So much for going up that way. That one fellow earlier might have made it inside without raising an alarm - Rhuarc's armcry - but a hundred or more Aiel would have to be like sounding bells. They might make a diversion, though. If they caused a commotion somewhere up there, inside the Stone, then whoever was guarding the cells might not pay as much attention to a thief-taker bringing a thief.

aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl æɾ ə lɪɾəl tə ðə kənfjuʒən. aɪ wɝk hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf ɑn ɪt. "vɛɹi wɛl, θif-teɪkɝ. dʒʌs doʊn dɪsaɪɾ aɪm ə ɹil pɹɪznɝ ət ðə læs mɪnət. wi kən stɑɹt fəɹ jəɹ ɡeɪɾ əz sun əz aɪ stɝ ði æntɪl ə bɪt." hi θɔt sændɑɹ fɹaʊnd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt min tə tɛl ðə mæn mɔɹ ðən i hæd tə.

I might as well add a little to the confusion. I worked hard enough on it. "Very well, thief-taker. Just don't decide I am a real prisoner at the last minute. We can start for your gate as soon as I stir the anthill a bit." He thought Sandar frowned, but he did not mean to tell the man more than he had to.

sændɑɹ fɑloʊɾ ɪm əkɹɔs ðə ɹuftɑps, klaɪmɪŋ tə haɪɝ lɛvəlz əz izəli əz i dɪd. ðə læst ɹuf wɑz oʊnli ə lɪɾəl loʊɝ ðən ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl ən ɹæn ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ɪt, ə mæɾɝ ə pʊlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɹæðɝ ðən klaɪmɪŋ.

Sandar followed him across the rooftops, climbing to higher levels as easily as he did. The last roof was only a little lower than the top of the wall and ran right up to it, a matter of pulling himself up rather than climbing.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?" sændɑɹ wɪspɝd.

"What are you doing?" Sandar whispered.

"weɪt hɪɹ fəɹ mi."

"Wait here for me."

wɪð ðə tɪn bɑks dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm wʌn hæn baɪ ɪts waɪɝ hændəl ən ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf hɛl hɔɹɪzɑntəli ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, mæt tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə stoʊn. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk ə haʊ fɑɹ ɪt wɑz tə ðə peɪvmən bɪloʊ. laɪt, ðə blʌɾi θɪŋ ɪz θɹi fit waɪd! aɪ kəd wɔk ɪt wɪð ə blʌɾi blaɪndfoʊld, ɪn maɪ slip! θɹi fit waɪd, ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ən bɛɾɝ ðən fɪfti fit tə ðə peɪvmənt. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt sændɑɹ nɑt biɪŋ ðəɹ wən i keɪm bæk, iðɝ. hi wɑz ɔl bʌt kəmɪɾəd tə ðɪs ful noʊʃən ə pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ə θif kɑt baɪ ðə mæn, bʌɾ ɪt simd ɔl tu pɹɑbəbəl ðəɾ i wəd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə ɹuf tə faɪn sændɑɹ ɡɔn, meɪbi bɹɪŋɪŋ mɔɹ mɛn tə meɪk ɪm ə pɹɪznɝ ɪn tʃɹuθ. doʊn θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt. dʒʌs də ðə dʒɑb ət hænd. ət list əl faɪnəli si wʌɾ ɪts laɪk.

With the tin box dangling from one hand by its wire handle and his quarterstaff held horizontally in front of him, Mat took a deep breath and started toward the Stone. He tried not to think of how far it was to the pavement below. Light, the bloody thing is three feet wide! I could walk it with a bloody blindfold, in my sleep! Three feet wide, in the dark, and better than fifty feet to the pavement. He tried not to think about Sandar not being there when he came back, either. He was all but committed to this fool notion of pretending to be a thief caught by the man, but it seemed all too probable that he would return to the roof to find Sandar gone, maybe bringing more men to make him a prisoner in truth. Don't think about it. Just do the job at hand. At least I'll finally see what it is like.

əz i hæd səspɛktəd, ðəɹ wɑz ən æɹoʊslɪɾ ɪn ðə wɔl ə ðə stoʊn ɹaɪɾ ət ði ɛn ə ðə wɔl, ə dip wɛdʒ kʌɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɑk hoʊldɪŋ ə tɔl, nɛɹoʊ oʊpənɪŋ fəɹ ən ɑɹtʃɝ tə ʃut θɹu. ɪf ðə stoʊn wɝ ətækt, ðə soʊlʒɝz ɪnsaɪd wəd wɑn səm weɪ tə stɑp ɛni tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðɪs pæθ. ðə slɪt wɑz dɑɹk, naʊ. ðəɹ dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə bi ɛniwʌn wɑtʃɪŋ. ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ i hæd tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt, tu.

As he had suspected, there was an arrowslit in the wall of the Stone right at the end of the wall, a deep wedge cut into the rock holding a tall, narrow opening for an archer to shoot through. If the Stone were attacked, the soldiers inside would want some way to stop any trying to follow this path. The slit was dark, now. There did not appear to be anyone watching. That was something he had tried not to think about, too.

kwɪkli hi sɛt daʊn ðə tɪn bɑks əɾ ɪz fit, bælənst ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf əkɹɔs ðə wɔl ɹaɪɾ əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stoʊn, ən ənsləŋ ðə bʌndəl fɹəm ɪz bæk. hɝidli hi wɛdʒd ɪɾ ɪndə ðə slɪt, fɔɹsɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn əz fɑɹ əz i kʊd; hi wɑntəɾ əz mʌtʃ ə ðə nɔɪz tə bi ɪnsaɪɾ əz i kəd mænədʒ. pʊlɪŋ əsaɪɾ ə kɔɹnɝ ə ði ɔɪl klɔθ kʌvɝ ɹɪvil nɑɾɪd fjuzəz. æftɝ ə lɪɾəl θɪŋkɪŋ, bæk ɪn ɪz ɹum, hi hæd kʌt ðə lɔŋɡɝ fjuzəz tə mætʃ ðə ʃɔɹɾɪst, juzɪŋ ðə pisəz tə hɛlp taɪ ɔl ðə fjuzəz təɡɛðɝ. ɪt sim ðeɪ ʃəɾ ɔl ɡoʊ ɔf ət wʌns, ən ə bæŋ-ænd-flæʃ laɪk ðət ʃəd bi ɪnʌf tə pʊl ɛvɹiwʌn u wɑz nɑt kəmplitli dɛf.

Quickly he set down the tin box at his feet, balanced his quarterstaff across the wall right against the side of the Stone, and unslung the bundle from his back. Hurriedly he wedged it into the slit, forcing it in as far as he could; he wanted as much of the noise to be inside as he could manage. Pulling aside a corner of the oiled cloth cover revealed knotted fuses. After a little thinking, back in his room, he had cut the longer fuses to match the shortest, using the pieces to help tie all the fuses together. It seemed they should all go off at once, and a bang-and-flash like that should be enough to pull everyone who was not completely deaf.

ðə lɪɾ ə ðə tɪn bɑks wɑz hɑɾ ɪnʌf ðəɾ i hæd tə bloʊ ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz twaɪs bɪfɔɹ i kəd pɹaɪ ɪɾ ɔf - hi wɪʃt i hæd wʌtɛvɝ ɑlʌdʒɹəz tʃɹɪk hæd bɪn, laɪɾɪŋ ðət læntɝn soʊ izəli - tə ɪkspoʊz ðə dɑɹk bɪɾ ə tʃɑɹkoʊl ɪnsaɪd, laɪɪŋ ɑn ə bɛɾ ə sænd. ðə waɪɝ hændəl keɪm ɔf tə meɪk tɑŋz, ən ə lɪɾəl bloʊɪŋ hæd ðə koʊl ɡloʊɪŋ ɹɛɾ əɡɛn. hi tʌtʃt ðə hɑt koʊl tə ðə nɑɾɪd fjuzəz, lɛt tɑŋz ən koʊl fɔl oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl əz ðə fjuzəz hɪst ɪndə fleɪm, snætʃt ʌp ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf ən dɑɹɾɪd bæk əlɔŋ ðə wɔl.

The lid of the tin box was hot enough that he had to blow on his fingers twice before he could pry it off - he wished he had whatever Aludra's trick had been, lighting that lantern so easily - to expose the dark bit of charcoal inside, lying on a bed of sand. The wire handle came off to make tongs, and a little blowing had the coal glowing red again. He touched the hot coal to the knotted fuses, let tongs and coal fall over the side of the wall as the fuses hissed into flame, snatched up his quarterstaff and darted back along the wall.

ðɪs ɪz kɹeɪzi, hi θɔɾ əz i ɹæn. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ bɪɡ ə bæŋ ɪt meɪks. aɪ kəd bɹeɪk maɪ ful nɛk duɪŋ θi - !

This is crazy, he thought as he ran. I don't care how big a bang it makes. I could break my fool neck doing thi - !

ðə ɹɔɹ bɪhaɪn ɪm wɑz laʊɾɝ ðən ɛniθɪŋ i hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝɾ ɪn ɪz laɪf; ə mɑnstʃɹəs fɪs pʌntʃt ɪm ɪn ðə bæk, nɑkɪŋ ɔl ðə wɪn aʊɾ ə hɪm ivən bɪfɔɹ i lændəd, spɹɔld ɑn ɪz bɛli ɑn ðə wɔl tɑp, bɛɹli hoʊldɪŋ ɑn tə hɪz stæf əz ɪt swʌŋ oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ. fəɹ ə moʊmən i leɪ ðɛɹ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɪz lʌŋz wɝk əɡɛn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə θɪŋk haʊ hi mʌst əv juzd ʌp ɔl ɪz lʌk ðɪs taɪm baɪ nɑt fɔlɪŋ ɔf ðə wɔl. hɪz ɪɹz ɹæŋ laɪk ɔl ðə bɛlz ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn.

The roar behind him was louder than anything he had ever heard in his life; a monstrous fist punched him in the back, knocking all the wind out of him even before he landed, sprawled on his belly on the wall top, barely holding on to his staff as it swung over the edge. For a moment he lay there, trying to make his lungs work again, trying not to think how he must have used up all his luck this time by not falling off the wall. His ears rang like all the bells in Tar Valon.

pʊʃɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp kɛɹfəli, hi lʊk bæk təwɔɹd ðə stoʊn. ə klaʊɾ ə smoʊk hʌŋ ɝaʊn ði æɹoʊslɪt. bɪhaɪn ðə smoʊk, ðə ʃæɾoʊd ʃeɪp ə ði æɹoʊslɪɾ ɪtsɛlf sim dɪfɹənt. lɑɹdʒɝ. hi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn haʊ əɹ waɪ, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd sim lɑɹdʒɝ.

Pushing himself up carefully, he looked back toward the Stone. A cloud of smoke hung around the arrowslit. Behind the smoke, the shadowed shape of the arrowslit itself seemed different. Larger. He did not understand how or why, but it did seem larger.

hi oʊnli θɔt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ət wʌn ɛn ə ðə wɔl sændɑɹ maɪt bi weɪɾɪŋ, maɪt bi ɪntɛndɪŋ tə teɪk ɪm ɪndə ðə stoʊn əz ə pɹitɛn pɹɪznɝ - əɹ maɪt bi hɝiɪŋ bæk wɪð soʊlʒɝz. ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə wɔl, ðəɹ maɪt bi ə weɪ ɪnsaɪd wɪθaʊɾ ɛni tʃæns ə sændɑɹ bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ hɪm. hi dɑɹɾɪd bæk ðə weɪ hi hæd dʒʌs kʌm, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðə dɑɹknəs əɹ ðə dʒɹɑp tə iðɝ saɪd.

He only thought for a moment. At one end of the wall Sandar might be waiting, might be intending to take him into the Stone as a pretend prisoner - or might be hurrying back with soldiers. At the other end of the wall, there might be a way inside without any chance of Sandar betraying him. He darted back the way he had just come, no longer worrying about the darkness or the drop to either side.

ði æɹoʊslɪt wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ, moʊst ə ðə θɪnɝ stoʊn ət ðə mɪɾəl sɪmpli ɡɔn, livɪŋ ə ɹʌf hoʊl əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd hæmɝɾ əɾ ɪt wɪð ə slɛdʒ fəɹ aʊɝz. ə hoʊl dʒʌs bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə mæn. haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt? ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ wʌndɝɪŋ.

The arrowslit was larger, most of the thinner stone at the middle simply gone, leaving a rough hole as if someone had hammered at it with a sledge for hours. A hole just big enough for a man. How in the Light? There was no time for wondering.

hi pʊʃt θɹu ðə dʒæɡd oʊpənɪŋ, kɑfɪŋ ət ði ækɹɪd smoʊk, dʒʌmp tə ðə flɔɹ ɪnsaɪd, ən hæd ɹʌn ə dʌzən stɛps bɪfɔɹ dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn əpɪɹd, ət lis tɛn ə ðɛm, ɔl ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɪn kənfjuʒən. moʊst wɔɹ oʊnli ðɛɹ ʃɝts, ən nʌn hæd hɛlməɾ əɹ bɹɛstpleɪt. səm kæɹid læntɝnz. səm hɛl bɛɹd sɔɹdz.

He pushed through the jagged opening, coughing at the acrid smoke, jumped to the floor inside, and had run a dozen steps before Defenders of the Stone appeared, at least ten of them, all shouting in confusion. Most wore only their shirts, and none had helmet or breastplate. Some carried lanterns. Some held bared swords.

ful! hi ʃaʊɾəd ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd. ðɪs ɪz waɪ jə sɛt ðə blʌɾi θɪŋz ɔf ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs! laɪt-blaɪndɪd ful!

Fool! he shouted inside his head. This is why you set the bloody things off in the first place! Light-blinded fool!

hi hæd noʊ taɪm tə meɪk ɪt bæk aʊɾ ɑntu ðə wɔl. kɔɹɾɝstæf spɪnɪŋ, hi θɹu hɪmsɛlf ət ðə soʊlʒɝz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæɾ ə tʃæns tə də mɔɹ ðən si hi wɑz ðɛɹ, hɝl hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ðɛm, smæʃɪŋ ət hɛdz, sɔɹdz, niz, wʌtɛvɝ i kəd ɹitʃ, noʊɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ tu mɛni fəɹ ɪm tə hændəl əloʊn, noʊɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz ful tɔs ə ðə daɪs hæd kɑst ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz wʌtɛvɝ tʃæns i maɪɾ əv hæd.

He had no time to make it back out onto the wall. Quarterstaff spinning, he threw himself at the soldiers before they had a chance to do more than see he was there, hurled himself into them, smashing at heads, swords, knees, whatever he could reach, knowing they were too many for him to handle alone, knowing that his fool toss of the dice had cost Egwene and the others whatever chance he might have had.

sʌɾənli sændɑɹ wɑz ðəɹ bɪsaɪd hɪm, ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə læntɝnz dʒɹɑp baɪ mɛn klɔɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz, hɪz slɛndɝ stæf wɝlɪŋ ivən fæstɝ ðən mæts kɔɹɾɝstæf. kɑt bɪtwin tu stæfmən, teɪkən baɪ sɝpɹaɪz, ðə soʊlʒɝz wɛn daʊn laɪk pɪnz ɪn ə ɡeɪm ə boʊlz.

Suddenly Sandar was there beside him, in the light of lanterns dropped by men clawing for their swords, his slender staff whirling even faster than Mat's quarterstaff. Caught between two staffmen, taken by surprise, the soldiers went down like pins in a game of bowls.

sændɑɹ stɛɹɾ ət ðə fɔlən mɛn, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn. aɪ hæv ətæk dɪfɛndɝz! ðəl əv maɪ hɛd fəɹ - ! wʌt wɑz ɪt ðət jə dɪd, ɡæmblɝ? ðət flæʃ ə laɪt, ən θʌndɝ, bɹeɪkɪŋ stoʊn. dɪd jə kɔl laɪtnɪŋ?" hɪz vɔɪs fɛl tə ə wɪspɝ. "hæv aɪ dʒɔɪn maɪsɛlf tə ə mæn u kən tʃænəl?"

Sandar stared at the fallen men, shaking his head. "Defenders of the Stone. I have attacked Defenders! They will have my head for - ! What was it that you did, gambler? That flash of light, and thunder, breaking stone. Did you call lightning?" His voice fell to a whisper. "Have I joined myself to a man who can channel?"

"faɪɹwɝks," mæt sɛd kɝtli. hɪz ɪɹz wɝ stɪl ɹɪŋɪŋ, bʌɾ i kəd hɪɹ mɔɹ buts kʌmɪŋ, ɹʌnɪŋ buts θəɾɪŋ ɑn stoʊn. "ðə sɛlz, mæn! ʃoʊ mi ðə weɪ tə ðə sɛlz bɪfɔɹ ɛni mɔɹ ɡɛt hɪɹ!"

"Fireworks," Mat said curtly. His ears were still ringing, but he could hear more boots coming, running boots thudding on stone. "The cells, man! Show me the way to the cells before any more get here!"

sændɑɹ ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf. "ðɪs weɪ!" hi dæʃt daʊn ə saɪd hɔl, əweɪ fɹəm ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ buts. "wi mʌs hɝi! ðəl kɪl əs ɪf ðeɪ faɪn ʌs!" sʌmwɛɹ əbʌv, ɡɔŋz bɪɡæn tə saʊn ən əlɑɹm, ən mɔɹ θʌndɝɾ ɛkoʊz θɹu ðə stoʊn.

Sandar shook himself. "This way!" He dashed down a side hall, away from the oncoming boots. "We must hurry! They will kill us if they find us!" Somewhere above, gongs began to sound an alarm, and more thundered echoes through the Stone.

aɪm kʌmɪŋ, mæt θɔɾ əz i ɹæn æftɝ ðə θif-teɪkɝ. əl ɡɛt jə aʊɾ əɹ daɪ! aɪ pɹɑməs ɪt!

I'm coming, Mat thought as he ran after the thief-taker. I'll get you out or die! I promise it!

ði əlɑɹm ɡɔŋz sɛn ɛkoʊz kɹæʃɪŋ θɹu ðə stoʊn, bʌt ɹænd peɪd noʊ mɔɹ ətɛnʃən tə ðɛm ðən i hæd tə ðə ɹɔɹ ðət hæd kʌm bɪfɔɹ, laɪk mʌfəl θʌndɝ fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ bɪloʊ. hɪz saɪɾ ætʃt; ði oʊld waʊn bɝnd, stʃɹeɪn ɔlmoʊs tə tɛɹɪŋ baɪ ðə klaɪm ʌp ðə saɪɾ ə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs. hi ɡeɪv ðə peɪn noʊ hid, iðɝ. ə kɹʊkəd smaɪl wɑz fɪkst ɑn ɪz feɪs, ə smaɪl ʌv æntɪsəpeɪʃən ən dʒɹɛɾ i kəd nɑɾ əv waɪpt əweɪ ɪf i hæd wɑntəd tə. ɪt wɑz kloʊs, naʊ. wʌɾ i hæd dʒɹimd ʌv. kælændɝ.

The alarm gongs sent echoes crashing through the Stone, but Rand paid no more attention to them than he had to the roar that had come before, like muffled thunder from somewhere below. His side ached; the old wound burned, strained almost to tearing by the climb up the side of the fortress. He gave the pain no heed, either.
