A crooked smile was fixed on his face, a smile of anticipation and dread he could not have wiped away if he had wanted to. It was close, now. What he had dreamed of. Callandor.

əl fɪnɪʃ ɪɾ ət læst. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ɪɾəl bi dʌn wɪð. ðə dʒɹimz, fɪnɪʃt. ðə beɪɾɪŋ, ən ðə tɔntɪŋ, ən ðə hʌntɪŋ. əl fɪnɪʃ ɪɾ ɔl!

I will finish it at last. One way or another, it will be done with. The dreams, finished. The baiting, and the taunting, and the hunting. I'll finish it all!

læfɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, hi hɝid θɹu ðə dɑɹk kɔɹɪɾɝz ə ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ.

Laughing to himself, he hurried through the dark corridors of the Stone of Tear.

ɛɡwin pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɝ feɪs, wɪnsɪŋ. hɝ maʊθ hæɾ ə bɪɾɝ teɪst, ən ʃi wɑz θɝsti. ɹænd? wʌt? waɪ wɑz aɪ dʒɹimɪŋ əbaʊt mæt əɡɛn, ɔl mɪkst wɪð ɹænd, ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz kʌmɪŋ? wʌt?

Egwene put a hand to her face, wincing. Her mouth had a bitter taste, and she was thirsty. Rand? What? Why was I dreaming about Mat again, all mixed with Rand, and shouting that he was coming? What?

ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz, stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn wɔlz, wʌn smoʊki ɹʌʃ tɔɹtʃ kæstɪŋ flɪkɝɪŋ ʃædoʊz, ən skɹimd əz ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪɾ ɔl. "noʊ! əl nɑt bi tʃeɪn əɡɛn! aɪ woʊn bi kɑlɝd! noʊ!"

She opened her eyes, stared at the gray stone walls, one smoky rush torch casting flickering shadows, and screamed as she remembered it all. "No! I will not be chained again! I won't be collared! No!"

nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɝ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɪn ən ɪnstənt, ðɛɹ bɹuz feɪsəz tu wɝiɾ ən fɪɹfəl fəɹ ðə suðɪŋ saʊnz ðeɪ meɪd tə bi bɪlivd. bʌt dʒʌs ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ wɝ ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf tə stɪl əɹ skɹimz. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. ə pɹɪznɝ, bʌt nɑɾ əloʊn. ən nɑt kɑlɝd.

Nynaeve and Elayne were beside her in an instant, their bruised faces too worried and fearful for the soothing sounds they made to be believed. But just the fact that they were there was enough to still her screams. She was not alone. A prisoner, but not alone. And not collared.

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə sɪɾ ʌp, ən ðeɪ hɛlp hɝ. ðeɪ hæd tə hɛlp hɝ; ʃi ætʃt ɪn ɛvɹi mʌsəl. ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛvɹi ənsin bloʊ dʊɹɪŋ ðə fɹɛnzi ðət hæɾ ɔl bʌt dʒɹɪvən əɹ mæd wən ʃi ɹilaɪzd. . . . əl nɑt θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt. aɪ hæv tə θɪŋk əbaʊt haʊ wəɹ tə ɪskeɪp. ʃi slɪd bækwɝdz əntɪl ʃi kəd lin əɡɛnst ə wɔl. hɝ peɪnz fɔt wɪð wɪɹinəs; ðət stʃɹʌɡəl wən ʃi hæd ɹəfjuz tə ɡɪv ɪn hæd teɪkən ɛvɹi læst skɹæp ə hɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən ðə bɹuzəz sim tə sæp ivən mɔɹ.

She tried to sit up, and they helped her. They had to help her; she ached in every muscle. She could remember every unseen blow during the frenzy that had all but driven her mad when she realized. . . . I will not think about that. I have to think about how we are to escape. She slid backwards until she could lean against a wall. Her pains fought with weariness; that struggle when she had refused to give in had taken every last scrap of her strength, and the bruises seemed to sap even more.

ðə sɛl wɑz æbsəlutli ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə θɹi ʌv əm ən ðə tɔɹtʃ. ðə flɔɹ wɑz bɛɹ, ən koʊld, ən hɑɹd. ðə dɔɹ ə ɹʌf plæŋks, splɪntɝɾ əz ɪf kaʊnləs fjuɾəl fɪŋɡɝz hæd klɔɾ əɾ ɪt, wɑz ði oʊnli bɹeɪk ɪn ðə wɔlz. mɛsədʒəz hæd bɪn skɹætʃt ɪn ðə stoʊn, moʊs baɪ ənstɛɾi hænz. ðə laɪɾ əv mɝsi ən lemi daɪ, wʌn ɹɛd. ʃi blæŋk ðəɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd.

The cell was absolutely empty except for the three of them and the torch. The floor was bare, and cold, and hard. The door of rough planks, splintered as if countless futile fingers had clawed at it, was the only break in the walls. Messages had been scratched in the stone, most by unsteady hands. The Light have mercy and let me die, one read. She blanked that out of her head.

"ɑɹ wi stɪl ʃildɪd?" ʃi mʌmbəld. ivən tɔkɪŋ hɝt. ivən əz ɪleɪn nɑɾəd, ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæd nɑt hæd tə æsk. ðə swoʊlən tʃik ɑn ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən, hɝ splɪt lɪp ən blæk aɪ, wɝ ænsɝ ɪnʌf, ivən ɪf əɹ oʊn peɪnz hæd nɑt bɪn. ɪf nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə ɹitʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, ðeɪ ʃʊɹli wʊɾə bɪn hild.

"Are we still shielded?" she mumbled. Even talking hurt. Even as Elayne nodded, she realized she had not had to ask. The swollen cheek on the golden-haired woman, her split lip and black eye, were answer enough, even if her own pains had not been. If Nynaeve had been able to reach the True Source, they surely would have been Healed.

"aɪ hæv tʃɹaɪd," nɪneɪiv sɛd dɪspɛɹɪŋli. "aɪ hæv tʃɹaɪd, ən tʃɹaɪd, ən tʃɹaɪd." ʃi ɡeɪv əɹ bɹeɪɾ ə ʃɑɹp tʌɡ, æŋɡɝ sipɪŋ θɹu dɪspaɪt ðə hoʊpləs fɪɹ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "wʌn ə ðɛm ɪz sɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. ɑmikoʊ, ðət mɪlk-feɪs tʃɪt, ɪf ðeɪv nɑt tʃeɪnʒd sɪns wi wɝ θɹoʊn ɪn hɪɹ. aɪ səpoʊz wʌn ɪz ɪnʌf tə meɪnteɪn ðə ʃildɪŋ wʌns ɪts bɪn woʊvən." ʃi bɑɹkt ə bɪɾɝ læf. "fɔɹ ɔl ðə peɪnz ðeɪ tʊk - ən ɡeɪv! - tə teɪk ʌs, jə wəd θɪŋk wi wɝ ə noʊ ɪmpɔɹɾəns əɾ ɔl. ɪts bɪn aʊɝz sɪns ðeɪ slæm ðət dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ʌs, ən noʊ wʌn əz kʌm tə æsk ə kwɛstʃən, əɹ lʊk, əɹ ivən bɹɪŋ ə dʒɹɑp ʌv wɔɾɝ. pɝhæps ðeɪ min tə liv əs hɪɹ əntɪl wi daɪ ʌv θɝst."

"I have tried," Nynaeve said despairingly. "I have tried, and tried, and tried." She gave her braid a sharp tug, anger seeping through despite the hopeless fear in her voice. "One of them is sitting outside. Amico, that milk-faced chit, if they have not changed since we were thrown in here. I suppose one is enough to maintain the shielding once it has been woven." She barked a bitter laugh. "For all the pains they took - and gave! - to take us, you would think we were of no importance at all. It has been hours since they slammed that door behind us, and no one has come to ask a question, or look, or even bring a drop of water. Perhaps they mean to leave us here until we die of thirst."

"beɪt." ɪleɪnz vɔɪs kweɪvɝd, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz ɑbviəsli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn ʌnəfɹeɪd. ən feɪlɪŋ mɪzɝəbli. "liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd wəɹ beɪt."

"Bait." Elayne's voice quavered, though she was obviously trying to sound unafraid. And failing miserably. "Liandrin said we are bait."

"beɪt fəɹ wʌt?" nɪneɪiv æskt ʃɑkəli. "beɪt fəɹ hu? ɪf aɪm beɪt, aɪd laɪk tə ʃʌv maɪsɛlf daʊn ðɛɹ θɹoʊts tɪl ðeɪ tʃoʊk ɑn mi!"

"Bait for what?" Nynaeve asked shakily. "Bait for who? If I am bait, I'd like to shove myself down their throats till they choke on me!"

"ɹænd." ɛɡwin stɑp tə swɑloʊ; ivən ə dʒɹɑp ʌv wɔɾɝ wəd bi wɛlkəm. "aɪ dʒɹimd əbaʊt ɹænd, ən kælændɝ. aɪ θɪŋk hiz kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ." bʌt waɪ dɪɾ aɪ dʒɹim ə mæt? ən pɛɹɪn? ɪt wɑz ə wʊlf, bʌɾ aɪm ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz hɪm. "du nɑt bi soʊ əfɹeɪd," ʃi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn kɑnfəɾənt. "wi wɪl ɪskeɪp əm sʌmhaʊ. ɪf wi kəd bɛɾɝ ðə sintʃæn, wi kən bɛs liɑnʒɹɪn."

"Rand." Egwene stopped to swallow; even a drop of water would be welcome. "I dreamed about Rand, and Callandor. I think he is coming here." But why did I dream of Mat? And Perrin? It was a wolf, but I am sure it was him. "Do not be so afraid," she said, trying to sound confident. "We will escape them somehow. If we could better the Seanchan, we can best Liandrin."

nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks oʊvɝ hɝ. nɪneɪiv sɛd, "liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd θɝtin mɹdʒɹɑl ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ, ɛɡwin."

Nynaeve and Elayne exchanged looks over her. Nynaeve said, "Liandrin said thirteen Myrddraal are coming, Egwene."

ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf stɛɹɪŋ ət ðət mɛsədʒ skɹætʃt ɑn ðə stoʊn wɔl əɡɛn: ðə laɪɾ əv mɝsi ən lemi daɪ. hɝ hænz klɛntʃt ɪndə fɪsts. hɝ dʒɔz kɹæmpt wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ ə nɑt skɹimɪŋ ðoʊz wɝdz. bɛɾɝ tə daɪ. bɛɾɝ dɛθ ðən biɪŋ tɝn tə ðə ʃædoʊ, meɪd tə sɝv ðə dɑɹk wʌn!

She found herself staring at that message scratched on the stone wall again: The Light have mercy and let me die. Her hands clenched into fists. Her jaws cramped with the effort of not screaming those words. Better to die. Better death than being turned to the Shadow, made to serve the Dark One!

ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət wʌn ə hɝ hænz hæd taɪɾənd ɝaʊn ðə paʊtʃ əɾ əɹ bɛlt. ʃi kəd fil ðə tu ɹɪŋz ɪnsaɪd, ðə smɔl sɝkəl ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ən ðə lɑɹdʒɝ, twɪstəd stoʊn ɹɪŋ.

She realized that one of her hands had tightened around the pouch at her belt. She could feel the two rings inside, the small circle of the Great Serpent and the larger, twisted stone ring.

"ðeɪ dɪd nɑt teɪk ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil," ʃi sɛd wʌndɝɪŋli. ʃi fʌmbəld ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ paʊtʃ. ɪt leɪ hɛvəli ɑn əɹ pɑm, ɔl stʃɹaɪps ən flɛks ə kʌlɝ, ə ɹɪŋ wɪð oʊnli wʌn ɛdʒ.

"They did not take the ter'angreal," she said wonderingly. She fumbled it out of her pouch. It lay heavily on her palm, all stripes and flecks of color, a ring with only one edge.

"wi wɝ nɑɾ ivən ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnʌf tə sɝtʃ," ɪleɪn saɪd. "ɛɡwin, ɑɹ jə sɝɾən ɹænd ɪz kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ? aɪ wəd mʌtʃ ɹæðɝ fɹi maɪsɛlf ðən weɪt fəɹ ðə tʃæns ə hɪm, bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛniwʌn u kən dɪfit liɑnʒɹɪn ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm, ɪt mʌs bi hɪm. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz mɛn tə wil kælændɝ. hi mʌs bi eɪbəl tə dɪfit ðɛm."

"We were not even important enough to search," Elayne sighed. "Egwene, are you certain Rand is coming here? I would much rather free myself than wait for the chance of him, but if there is anyone who can defeat Liandrin and the rest of them, it must be him. The Dragon Reborn is meant to wield Callandor. He must be able to defeat them."

"nɑɾ ɪf wi pʊl ɪm ɪndə ə keɪdʒ æftɝ ʌs," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd. "nɑɾ ɪf ðeɪv ə tʃɹæp sɛɾ i dʌz nɑt si. waɪ ɑɹ jə stɛɹɪŋ ət ðət ɹɪŋ, ɛɡwin? tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd wɪl nɑt hɛlp əs naʊ. nɑɾ ənlɛs jə kən dʒɹim ə weɪ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ."

"Not if we pull him into a cage after us," Nynaeve muttered. "Not if they have a trap set he does not see. Why are you staring at that ring, Egwene? Tel'aran'rhiod will not help us now. Not unless you can dream a way out of here."

"pɝhæps aɪ kæn," ʃi sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ kəd tʃænəl ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ðɛɹ ʃildɪŋ woʊn stɑp mi ɹitʃɪŋ ɪt. ɔl aɪ nid də ɪz slip, nɑt tʃænəl. ən aɪm ʃʊɹli wɪɹi ɪnʌf tə slip."

"Perhaps I can," she said slowly. "I could channel in Tel'aran'rhiod. Their shielding won't stop me reaching it. All I need do is sleep, not channel. And I am surely weary enough to sleep."

ɪleɪn fɹaʊnd, wɪnsɪŋ əz ɪt pʊld əɹ bɹuzəz. "aɪ wɪl teɪk ɛni tʃæns, bʌt haʊ kən jə tʃænəl ivən ɪn ə dʒɹim, kʌɾ ɔf fɹəm ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs? ən ɪf jə kæn, haʊ kən ɪt hɛlp əs hɪɹ?"

Elayne frowned, wincing as it pulled her bruises. "I will take any chance, but how can you channel even in a dream, cut off from the True Source? And if you can, how can it help us here?"

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ, ɪleɪn. dʒʌs kəz aɪm ʃildɪd hɪɹ dʌz nɑt min aɪm ʃildɪɾ ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz. ɪts ət list wɝθ ə tʃɹaɪ."

"I do not know, Elayne. Just because I am shielded here does not mean I am shielded in the World of Dreams. It is at least worth a try."

"pɝhæps," nɪneɪiv sɛd wɝidli. "aɪ wɪl teɪk ɛni tʃæns, tu, bʌt jə sɔ liɑnʒɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz ðə læs taɪm jə juz ðət ɹɪŋ. ən jə sɛd ðeɪ sɔ ju, tu. wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ ðəɹ əɡɛn?"

"Perhaps," Nynaeve said worriedly. "I will take any chance, too, but you saw Liandrin and the others the last time you used that ring. And you said they saw you, too. What if they are there again?"

"aɪ hoʊp ðeɪ ɑɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "aɪ hoʊp ðeɪ ɑɹ."

"I hope they are," Egwene said grimly. "I hope they are."

klʌtʃɪŋ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn əɹ hænd, ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz. ʃi kəd fil ɪleɪn smuðɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ, hɪɹ əɹ mɝmɝɪŋ sɔfli. nɪneɪiv bɪɡæn tə hʌm ðət wɝdləs lʌləbaɪ fɹəm əɹ tʃaɪldhʊd; fəɹ wʌns, ʃi fɛl noʊ æŋɡɝ əɾ ɪɾ əɾ ɔl. ðə sɑf saʊnz ən tʌtʃəz suð hɝ, lɛɾ əɹ sɝɛndɝ tə hɝ wɪɹinəs, lɛt slip kʌm.

Clutching the ter'angreal in her hand, she closed her eyes. She could feel Elayne smoothing her hair, hear her murmuring softly. Nynaeve began to hum that wordless lullaby from her childhood; for once, she felt no anger at it at all. The soft sounds and touches soothed her, let her surrender to her weariness, let sleep come.

ʃi wɔɹ blu sɪlk ðɪs taɪm, bʌt ʃi bɛɹli noʊɾəst mɔɹ ðən ðæt. sɑf bɹizɪz kɝɛst əɹ ənbɹwz feɪs, ən sɛn ðə bʌɾɝflaɪz swɝlɪŋ əbʌv ðə waɪldflaʊɹz. hɝ θɝst wɑz ɡɔn, hɝ eɪks. ʃi ɹitʃt aʊt tə ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ ən wɑz fɪld wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ivən ðə tʃɹaɪəmf ʃi fɛlt ət səksiɾɪŋ wɑz smɔl bɪsaɪd ðə sɝdʒɪŋ ə ðə paʊɝ θɹu hɝ.

She wore blue silk this time, but she barely noticed more than that. Soft breezes caressed her unbruised face, and sent the butterflies swirling above the wildflowers. Her thirst was gone, her aches. She reached out to embrace saidar and was filled with the One Power. Even the triumph she felt at succeeding was small beside the surging of the Power through her.

ɹɪlʌktənli ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf ɹilis ɪt, kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, ən fɪl ði ɛmptinəs wɪð ə pɝfəkt ɪmədʒ ə ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn. ðət wɑz ðə wʌn pleɪs ɪn ðə stoʊn ʃi kəd pɪktʃɝ əsaɪd fɹəm əɹ sɛl, ən haʊ tə dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃ wʌn fitʃɝləs kjubɪkəl fɹəm ənʌðɝ? wən ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz, ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ. bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn.

Reluctantly she made herself release it, closed her eyes, and filled the emptiness with a perfect image of the Heart of the Stone. That was the one place in the Stone she could picture aside from her cell, and how to distinguish one featureless cubicle from another? When she opened her eyes, she was there. But she was not alone.

ðə fɔɹm ə dʒɔɪjə bɝ stʊd bɪfɔɹ kælændɝ, hɝ ʃeɪp soʊ ɪnsəbstæntʃəl ðət ðə sɝdʒɪŋ laɪɾ ə ðə sɔɹd ʃoʊn θɹu hɝ. ðə kɹɪstəl sɔɹd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ mɪɹli ɡlɪɾɝd wɪð ɹɪfɹæktɪd laɪt. ɪn pʌlsɪz ɪt ɡloʊd, əz ɪf səm laɪɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪt wɝ biɪŋ ənkʌvɝd, ðən kʌvɝɾ ən ənkʌvɝɾ əɡɛn. ðə blæk sɪstɝ stɑɹɾəd wɪð sɝpɹaɪz ən spʌn tə feɪs ɛɡwin. "haʊ? jə ɑɹ ʃildɪd! jəɹ dʒɹimɪŋ ɪz əɾ ən ɛnd!"

The form of Joiya Byir stood before Callandor, her shape so insubstantial that the surging light of the sword shone through her. The crystal sword no longer merely glittered with refracted light. In pulses it glowed, as if some light inside it were being uncovered, then covered and uncovered again. The Black sister started with surprise and spun to face Egwene. "How? You are shielded! Your Dreaming is at an end!"

bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝst wɝdz wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə wʊmənz maʊθ, ɛɡwin ɹitʃt fəɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ əɡɛn, woʊv ðə kɑmpləkeɪɾəd floʊ ʌv spɪɹəɾ əz ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪt biɪŋ juzd əɡɛns hɝ, ən kʌt dʒɔɪjə bɝ ɔf fɹəm ðə sɔɹs. ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz aɪz waɪɾənd, ðoʊz kɹuəl aɪz soʊ ɪŋkɔŋɹuəs ɪn ðət bjuɾəfəl, kaɪnli feɪs, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi wivɪŋ ɛɹ. ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz fɔɹm maɪt sim laɪk mɪst, bʌt ðə bɑnz hɛld ɪt. ɪt sim tə ɛɡwin ðət ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɛfɝɾ ɪnvɑlvd ɪn hoʊldɪŋ boʊθ floʊz ɪn ðɛɹ wivɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz swɛɾ ɑn dʒɔɪjə bɝz fɔɹhɛɾ əz ʃi wɔkt kloʊsɝ.

Before the first words were out of the woman's mouth, Egwene reached for saidar again, wove the complicated flow of Spirit as she remembered it being used against her, and cut Joiya Byir off from the Source. The Darkfriend's eyes widened, those cruel eyes so incongruous in that beautiful, kindly face, but Egwene was already weaving Air. The other woman's form might seem like mist, but the bonds held it. It seemed to Egwene that there was no effort involved in holding both flows in their weaving. There was sweat on Joiya Byir's forehead as she walked closer.

"ju hæv ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil!" fɪɹ wɑz pleɪn ɑn ðə wʊmənz feɪs, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs fɔt tə haɪɾ ɪt. "ðæt mʌs bi ɪt. ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðəɾ ɪskeɪpt ʌs, ən wʌn ðət dʌz nɑt ɹikwaɪɝ tʃænəlɪŋ. dʒju θɪŋk ɪɾəl dʒju ɛni ɡʊd, ɡɝl? wʌtɛvɝ jə də hɪɹ, ɪt kænɑɾ əfɛkt wʌt hæpənz ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld. tɛlɝɑnɹhiəɾ ɪz ə dʒɹim! wən aɪ weɪk, əl teɪk jəɹ tɛɹæŋɡɹil fɹəm jə maɪsɛlf. bi kɛɹfəl wʌt jə du, lɛst aɪ hæv ɹizən tə bi æŋɡɹi wən aɪ kʌm tə jəɹ sɛl."

"You have a ter'angreal!" Fear was plain on the woman's face, but her voice fought to hide it. "That must be it. A ter'angreal that escaped us, and one that does not require channeling. Do you think it will do you any good, girl? Whatever you do here, it cannot affect what happens in the real world. Tel'aran'rhiod is a dream! When I wake, I will take your ter'angreal from you myself. Be careful what you do, lest I have reason to be angry when I come to your cell."

ɛɡwin smaɪld ət hɝ. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən jəl weɪk, dɑɹkfɹɛnd? ɪf jəɹ tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɹikwaɪɝz tʃænəlɪŋ, waɪ dɪd jə nɑt weɪk əz sun əz aɪ ʃildɪd ju? pɝhæps jə kænɑt weɪk soʊ lɔŋ əz jə ɑɹ ʃildɪd hɪɹ." hɝ smaɪl feɪɾəd əweɪ; ði ɛfɝɾ ə smaɪlɪŋ ət ðɪs wʊmən wɑz mɔɹ ðən ʃi kəd bɛɹ. "ə wʊmən wʌns ʃoʊd mi ə skɑɹ ʃi ɹəsivd ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, dɑɹkfɹɛnd. wʌt hæpənz hɪɹ ɪz stɪl ɹil wən jə weɪk."

Egwene smiled at her. "Are you certain you will wake, Darkfriend? If your ter'angreal requires channeling, why did you not wake as soon as I shielded you? Perhaps you cannot wake so long as you are shielded here." Her smile faded away; the effort of smiling at this woman was more than she could bear. "A woman once showed me a scar she received in Tel'aran'rhiod, Darkfriend. What happens here is still real when you wake."

ðə swɛt ɹoʊl daʊn ðə blæk sɪstɝz smuð, eɪdʒləs feɪs, naʊ. ɛɡwin wʌndɝɾ ɪf ʃi θɔt ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə daɪ. ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt ʃi wɝ kɹuəl ɪnʌf tə də ðæt. moʊst ə ði ənsin bloʊz ʃi hæd ɹəsiv hæd kʌm fɹəm ðɪs wʊmən, laɪk ə paʊndɪŋ ə fɪsts, fəɹ noʊ ɹizən mɔɹ ðən ðət ʃi hæd kɛp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɹɔl əweɪ, noʊ ɹizən mɔɹ ðən ðət ʃi hæd ɹəfjuz tə ɡɪv ʌp.

The sweat rolled down the Black sister's smooth, ageless face, now. Egwene wondered if she thought she was about to die. She almost wished she were cruel enough to do that. Most of the unseen blows she had received had come from this woman, like a pounding of fists, for no reason more than that she had kept trying to crawl away, no reason more than that she had refused to give up.

"ə wʊmən u kən ɡɪv sətʃ biɾɪŋz," ʃi sɛd, "ʃʊɾ əv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃənz tə ə maɪldɝ wʌn." ʃi woʊv ənʌðɝ floʊ ʌv ɛɹ kwɪkli; dʒɔɪjə bɝz dɑɹk aɪz bʌlʒd ɪn dɪsbɪlif əz ðə fɝs bloʊ lændəɾ əkɹɔs əɹ hɪps. ɛɡwin sɔ haʊ tə ədʒʌs ðə wivɪŋ soʊ ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə meɪnteɪn ɪt. "ju wɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɪs, ən fil ɪt, wən jə weɪkən. wən aɪ əlaʊ jə tə weɪkən. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɪs, tu. ɪf jə ɛvɝ ivən tʃɹaɪ tə bit mi əɡɛn, əl ɹɪtɝn jə hɪɹ ən liv jə fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ laɪf!" ðə blæk sɪstɝz aɪz stɛɹd heɪɾ ət hɝ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə sədʒɛstʃən ə tɪɹz ɪn ðɛm, tu.

"A woman who can give such beatings," she said, "should have no objections to a milder one." She wove another flow of Air quickly; Joiya Byir's dark eyes bulged in disbelief as the first blow landed across her hips. Egwene saw how to adjust the weaving so she did not have to maintain it. "You will remember this, and feel it, when you waken. When I allow you to waken. Remember this, too. If you ever even try to beat me again, I will return you here and leave you for the rest of your life!" The Black sister's eyes stared hate at her, but there was a suggestion of tears in them, too.

ɛɡwin fɛlt ə moʊmən ə ʃeɪm. nɑɾ ət wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ tə dʒɔɪjə - ðə wʊmən dɪzɝvd ɛvɹi bloʊ, ɪf nɑt fəɹ əɹ oʊn biɾɪŋ, ðən fəɹ ðə dɛθs ɪn ðə taʊɝ - nɑt ðæt, nɑt ɹɪli, bʌt kəz ʃi hæd spɛn taɪm ɑn əɹ oʊn ɹivɛnʒ waɪl nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə sɛl hoʊpɪŋ əɡɛns hoʊp ðət ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɹɛskju ðɛm.

Egwene felt a moment of shame. Not at what she was doing to Joiya - the woman deserved every blow, if not for her own beating, then for the deaths in the Tower - not that, not really, but because she had spent time on her own revenge while Nynaeve and Elayne were sitting in a cell hoping against hope that she might be able to rescue them.

ʃi taɪɾ ɔf ən sɛt ðə floʊz ə hɝ wivɪŋz bɪfɔɹ ʃi nu ʃi hæd dʌn ɪt, ðən pɔz tə stʌɾi wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn. θɹi sɛpɹət wivɪŋz, ən nɑɾ oʊnli hæɾ ɪt bɪn noʊ tʃɹʌbəl tə hoʊld əm ɔl ət wʌns, bʌt naʊ ʃi hæd dʌn sʌmθɪŋ soʊ ðeɪ wəd meɪnteɪn ðɛmsɛlvz. ʃi θɔt ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ, tu. ən ɪt maɪt bi jusfəl.

She tied off and set the flows of her weavings before she knew she had done it, then paused to study what she had done. Three separate weavings, and not only had it been no trouble to hold them all at once, but now she had done something so they would maintain themselves. She thought she could remember how, too. And it might be useful.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi ənɹævəld wʌn ə ðə wivɪŋz, ən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn sɑbd əz mʌtʃ fɹəm ɹɪlif əz fɹəm peɪn. "aɪ æm nɑt laɪk ju," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz ðə sɛkən taɪm aɪ hæv dʌn sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs, ən aɪ də nɑt laɪk ɪt. aɪm gɑnə hæv tə lɝn tə kʌt θɹoʊts ɪnstɛd." fɹəm ðə blæk sɪstɝz feɪs, ʃi θɔɾ ɛɡwin mɛn tə stɑɹt lɝnɪŋ wɪð hɝ.

After a moment, she unraveled one of the weavings, and the Darkfriend sobbed as much from relief as from pain. "I am not like you," Egwene said. "This is the second time I have done something like this, and I do not like it. I am going to have to learn to cut throats instead." From the Black sister's face, she thought Egwene meant to start learning with her.

meɪkɪŋ ə dɪsɡʌstəd saʊnd, ɛɡwin lɛft əɹ stændɪŋ ðɛɹ, tʃɹæpt ən ʃildɪd, ən hɝiɾ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst ə pɑlɪʃt ɹɛdstoʊn kɑləmz. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ daʊn tə ðə sɛlz sʌmwɛɹ.

Making a disgusted sound, Egwene left her standing there, trapped and shielded, and hurried into the forest of polished redstone columns. There had to be a way down to the cells somewhere.

ðə stoʊn kɔɹəɾɝ fɛl saɪlən əz ðə faɪnəl daɪɪŋ skɹim wɑz kʌɾ ɔf baɪ jʌŋ bʊlz dʒɔz kloʊzɪŋ ɑn ðə tu-lɛɡzəz θɹoʊt, kɹʌʃɪŋ ɪt. ðə blʌd wɑz bɪɾɝ ɑn ɪz tʌŋ.

The stone corridor fell silent as the final dying scream was cut off by Young Bull's jaws closing on the two-legs's throat, crushing it. The blood was bitter on his tongue.

hi nu ðɪs wɑz ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt seɪ haʊ hi nu. ðə tu-lɛɡz laɪɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm, wʌn kɪkɪŋ ɪz læst wɪð hɑpɝz tiθ bɛɹiɾ ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt, hæd smɛld ɹæŋk wɪð fɪɹ əz ðeɪ fɔt. ðeɪ hæd smɛl kənfjuzd. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ hæd noʊn wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ - ðeɪ sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt bɪlɔŋ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim - bʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn sɛt tə kip ɪm fɹəm ðət tɔl dɔɹ əhɛd, wɪð ɪts aɪɝn lɑk. tə ɡɑɹɾ ɪt, ət list. ðeɪ hæd sim stɑɹɾəld tə si wʊlvz. hi θɔt ðeɪ hæd bɪn stɑɹɾəld ət biɪŋ ðəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz.

He knew this was the Stone of Tear, though he could not say how he knew. The two-legs lying around him, one kicking his last with Hopper's teeth buried in his throat, had smelled rank with fear as they fought. They had smelled confused. He did not think they had known where they were - they certainly did not belong in the wolf dream - but they had been set to keep him from that tall door ahead, with its iron lock. To guard it, at least. They had seemed startled to see wolves. He thought they had been startled at being there themselves.

hi waɪpt ɪz maʊθ, ðən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz hænd wɪð ə moʊməntɛɹi læk ə kɑmpɹihɛnʃən. hi wɑz ə mæn əɡɛn. hi wɑz pɛɹɪn. bæk ɪn ɪz oʊn bɑɾi, ɪn ðə blæksmɪθs vɛst, wɪð ðə hɛvi hæmɝ əɾ ɪz saɪd.

He wiped his mouth, then stared at his hand with a momentary lack of comprehension. He was a man again. He was Perrin. Back in his own body, in the blacksmith's vest, with the heavy hammer at his side.

wi mʌs hɝi, jʌŋ bʊl. ðəɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ivəl nɪɹ.

We must hurry, Young Bull. There is something evil near.

pɛɹɪn pʊl ðə hæmɝ fɹəm ɪz bɛlt əz i stʃɹoʊd tə ðə dɔɹ. "feɪl mʌs bi hɪɹ." wʌn ʃɑɹp bloʊ ʃæɾɝd ðə lɑk. hi kɪkt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ.

Perrin pulled the hammer from his belt as he strode to the door. "Faile must be here." One sharp blow shattered the lock. He kicked open the door.

ðə ɹum wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ə lɔŋ stoʊn blɑk ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə flɔɹ. feɪl leɪ ɑn ðət blɑk əz ɪf slipɪŋ, hɝ blæk hɛɹ spɹɛɾ aʊt laɪk ə fæn, hɝ bɑɾi soʊ ɹæpt ɪn tʃeɪnz ðəɾ ɪt tʊk ɪm ə moʊmən tə ɹilaɪz ʃi wɑz ənkloʊðd. ɛvɹi tʃeɪn wɑz hɛl tə ðə stoʊn baɪ ə θɪk boʊlt.

The room was empty except for a long stone block in the middle of the floor. Faile lay on that block as if sleeping, her black hair spread out like a fan, her body so wrapped in chains that it took him a moment to realize she was unclothed. Every chain was held to the stone by a thick bolt.

hi wɑz hɑɹdli əwɛɹ ə kɹɔsɪŋ ðə speɪs əntɪl ɪz hæn tʌtʃt əɹ feɪs, tʃɹeɪsɪŋ əɹ tʃikboʊn wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ.

He was hardly aware of crossing the space until his hand touched her face, tracing her cheekbone with a finger.

ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz ən smaɪld ʌp ət hɪm. "aɪ kɛp dʒɹimɪŋ jə wəd kʌm, blæksmɪθ."

She opened her eyes and smiled up at him. "I kept dreaming you would come, blacksmith."

"aɪ wɪl əv jə fɹi ɪn ə moʊmənt, feɪl." hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hæmɝ, smæʃt wʌn ə ðə boʊls əz ɪf ɪt wɝ wʊd.

"I will have you free in a moment, Faile." He raised his hammer, smashed one of the bolts as if it were wood.

"aɪ wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. pɛɹɪn."

"I was sure of it. Perrin."

əz ɪz neɪm feɪɾəd fɹəm əɹ tʌŋ, ʃi feɪɾəd, tu. wɪð ə klæɾɝ, ðə tʃeɪnz dʒɹɑp tə ðə stoʊn wɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn.

As his name faded from her tongue, she faded, too. With a clatter, the chains dropped to the stone where she had been.

"noʊ!" hi kɹaɪd. "aɪ faʊn hɝ!"

"No!" he cried. "I found her!"

ðə dʒɹim ɪz nɑt laɪk ðə wɝld ə flɛʃ, jʌŋ bʊl. hɪɹ, ðə seɪm hʌn kən əv mɛni ɛndɪŋz.

The dream is not like the world of flesh, Young Bull. Here, the same hunt can have many endings.

hi dɪd nɑt tɝn tə lʊk ət hɑpɝ. hi nu hɪz tiθ wɝ bɛɹɾ ɪn ə snɑɹl. əɡɛn i ɹeɪz ðə hæmɝ, bɹɔɾ ɪt daʊn wɪð ɔl ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ əɡɛns ðə tʃeɪnz ðət hæd hɛl feɪl. ðə stoʊn blɑk kɹækt ɪn tu ʌndɝ ɪz bloʊ; ðə stoʊn ɪtsɛlf ɹæŋ laɪk ə stʌk bɛl.

He did not turn to look at Hopper. He knew his teeth were bared in a snarl. Again he raised the hammer, brought it down with all his strength against the chains that had held Faile. The stone block cracked in two under his blow; the Stone itself rang like a stuck bell.

"ðɛn əl hʌn əɡɛn," hi ɡɹaʊld.

"Then I will hunt again," he growled.

hæmɝ ɪn hænd, pɛɹɪn stʃɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum wɪð hɑpɝ bɪsaɪd hɪm. ðə stoʊn wɑz ə pleɪs ə mɛn. ən mɛn, hi nu, wɝ kɹuəlɝ hʌntɝz ðən ɛvɝ wʊlvz wɝ.

Hammer in hand, Perrin strode out of the room with Hopper beside him. The Stone was a place of men. And men, he knew, were crueler hunters than ever wolves were.

əlɑɹm ɡɔŋz sʌmwɛɹ əbʌv sɛn sɑnɝəs klæŋz daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, nɑt kwaɪt dʒɹaʊnɪŋ aʊt ðə ɹɪŋ ə mɛɾəl ɑn mɛɾəl ən ðə ʃaʊts ə faɪɾɪŋ mɛn ɹæðɝ kloʊsɝ. ði il ən ðə dɪfɛndɝz, mæt səspɛktəd. tɔl, ɡoʊldən læmp stænz, itʃ wɪð fɔɹ ɡoʊldən læmps, laɪn ðə hɔl wɛɹ mæt wɑz, ən sɪlk tæpəstʃɹiz ə bæɾəl sinz hʌŋ ɑn ðə pɑlɪʃt stoʊn wɔlz. ðəɹ wɝ ivən sɪlk kɑɹpəts ɑn ðə flɔɹ, dɑɹk ɹɛɾ ɑn dɑɹk blu, woʊvən ɪn ðə tɛɹən meɪz. fəɹ wʌns, mæt wɑz tu bɪzi tə pʊɾ ə pɹaɪs ɑn ɛniθɪŋ.

Alarm gongs somewhere above sent sonorous clangs down the corridor, not quite drowning out the ring of metal on metal and the shouts of fighting men rather closer. The Aiel and the Defenders, Mat suspected. Tall, golden lamp stands, each with four golden lamps, lined the hall where Mat was, and silk tapestries of battle scenes hung on the polished stone walls. There were even silk carpets on the floor, dark red on dark blue, woven in the Tairen maze. For once, Mat was too busy to put a price on anything.

ðɪs blʌɾi fɛloʊ ɪz ɡʊd, hi θɔɾ əz i mænədʒ tə swip ə sɔɹd θɹʌst əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, bʌt ðə bloʊ hi eɪmd ət ðə mænz hɛd wɪð ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə stæf hæd tə tɝn ɪndə ənʌðɝ blɑk ə ðət dɑɹɾɪŋ bleɪd. aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf hiz wʌn ə ðiz blʌɾi haɪ lɔɹdz? hi ɔlmoʊs mænədʒd ə sɑləd bloʊ əɾ ə ni, bʌɾ ɪz əpoʊnən spɹæŋ bæk, hɪz stʃɹeɪt bleɪd ɹeɪzd ɑn ɡɑɹd.

This bloody fellow is good, he thought as he managed to sweep a sword thrust away from him, but the blow he aimed at the man's head with the other end of the staff had to turn into another block of that darting blade. I wonder if he is one of these bloody High Lords? He almost managed a solid blow at a knee, but his opponent sprang back, his straight blade raised on guard.

ðə blu-aɪd mæn sɝɾənli wɔɹ ðə pʌfi-sliv koʊt, jɛloʊ wɪð θɹɛd-ʌv-ɡoʊl stʃɹaɪps, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl əndʌn, hɪz ʃɝɾ oʊnli hæf tʌkt ɪndə hɪz bɹitʃɪz, ən ɪz fit bɛɹ. hɪz ʃɔɹt-kɹɑpt, dɑɹk hɛɹ wɑz tɔsəld, laɪk ðəɾ ʌv ə mæn ɹaʊz heɪstəli fɹəm slip, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt faɪt laɪk ɪt. faɪv mɪnəts əɡoʊ hi hæd kʌm dɑɹɾɪŋ aʊt fɹəm wʌn ə ðə tɔl, kɑɹv dɔɹz ðət laɪn ðɪs hɔl, ə skæbɹdləs sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, ən mæt wɑz oʊnli ɡɹeɪtfəl ðə fɛloʊ hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm ən nɑt bɪhaɪnd. hi wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs mæn dʒɹɛst soʊ ðət mæt hæd feɪst ɔlɹɛɾi, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹli ðə bɛst.

The blue-eyed man certainly wore the puffy-sleeved coat, yellow with thread-of-gold stripes, but it was all undone, his shirt only half tucked into his breeches, and his feet bare. His short-cropped, dark hair was tousled, like that of a man roused hastily from sleep, but he did not fight like it. Five minutes ago he had come darting out from one of the tall, carved doors that lined this hall, a scabbardless sword in his hands, and Mat was only grateful the fellow had appeared in front of them and not behind. He was not the first man dressed so that Mat had faced already, but he was surely the best.

"kæn jə meɪk ɪt pæs mi, θif-kætʃɝ?" mæt kɔld, kɛɹfəl nɑt tə teɪk ɪz aɪz ɔf ðə mæn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm wɪð bleɪd pɔɪz tə stʃɹaɪk. sændɑɹ hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli ɑn "θif-kætʃɝ," nɑt "θif-teɪkɝ," ðoʊ mæt kəd nɑt si ɛni dɪfɝəns.

"Can you make it past me, thief-catcher?" Mat called, careful not to take his eyes off the man waiting for him with blade poised to strike. Sandar had insisted irritably on "thief-catcher," not "thief-taker," though Mat could not see any difference.

"aɪ kænɑt," sændɑɹ kɔl fɹəm bɪhaɪn hɪm. "ɪf jə muv tə lemi baɪ, jəl luz ɹum tə swɪŋ ðəɾ ɔɹ jə kɔl ə stæf, ən hɪl spɪt jə laɪk ə ɡɹʌnt."

"I cannot," Sandar called from behind him. "If you move to let me by, you will lose room to swing that oar you call a staff, and he will spit you like a grunt."

laɪk ə wʌt? "wɛl, θɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ, tɛɹən. ðɪs ɹæɡəmfɪn ɪz ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ maɪ nɝvz."

Like a what? "Well, think of something, Tairen. This ragamuffin is grating my nerves."

ðə mæn ɪn ðə ɡoʊld-stʃɹaɪp koʊt snɪɹd. "ju wɪl bi ɑnɝd tə daɪ ɑn ðə bleɪɾ ə ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn, pɛzənt, ɪf aɪ əlaʊ ɪt soʊ." ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm i hæd dn tə spik. "ɪnstɛd, aɪ θɪŋk əl əv ðə pɛɹ ə jə hʌŋ baɪ ðə hilz, ən wɑtʃ waɪl ðə skɪn ɪz stʃɹɪp fɹəm jəɹ bɑɾiz - "

The man in the gold-striped coat sneered. "You will be honored to die on the blade of the High Lord Darlin, peasant, if I allow it so." It was the first time he had deigned to speak. "Instead, I think I will have the pair of you hung by the heels, and watch while the skin is stripped from your bodies - "

"aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk aɪd laɪk ðæt," mæt sɛd.

"I do not think I'd like that," Mat said.

ðə haɪ lɔɹdz feɪs ɹɛɾənd wɪð ɪndɪɡneɪʃən ət biɪŋ ɪntɝʌptɪd, bʌt mæt ɡeɪv ɪm noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɛni aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ kɑmɛnt. kɔɹɾɝstæf wɝlɪŋ ɪn ə taɪt dʌbəl-lup wiv, soʊ kwɪk ðə stæf blɝɾ ət ði ɛnz, hi lɛp fɔɹwɝd. ɪt wɑz ɔl ə snɑɹlɪŋ dɑɹlɪn kəd də tə kip ðə stæf fɹəm hɪm. fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. mæt nu hi kəd nɑt kip ðɪs ʌp vɛɹi lɔŋ, ən ɪf i wɑz lʌki ðɛn, ɪt wəɾ ɔl ɡoʊ bæk tə tə ðə stʃɹaɪk ən kaʊntɝstʃɹaɪk. ɪf i wɑz lʌki. bʌɾ i hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə kaʊntɪŋ ɑn lʌk ðɪs taɪm. əz sun əz ðə haɪ lɔɹd hæɾ ə moʊmən tə sɛt hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə pæɾɝn ə dɪfɛns, mæt ɔltɝɾ ɪz ətæk ɪn mɪdwɝl. ði ɛn ə ðə stæf dɑɹlɪn hæd bɪn ɪkspɛktɪŋ əɾ ɪz hɛd dɪpt ɪnstɛd tə swip ɪz lɛɡz aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ hɪm. ði ʌðɝ ɛn dɪd stʃɹaɪk əɾ ɪz hɛd ðɛn, əz i fɛl, ə ʃɑɹp kɹæk ðət ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz bæk ʌp ɪn ɪz hɛd.

The High Lord's face reddened with indignation at being interrupted, but Mat gave him no time for any outraged comment. Quarterstaff whirling in a tight double-loop weave, so quick the staff blurred at the ends, he leaped forward. It was all a snarling Darlin could do to keep the staff from him. For the moment. Mat knew he could not keep this up very long, and if he was lucky then, it would all go back to to the strike and counterstrike. If he was lucky. But he had no intention of counting on luck this time. As soon as the High Lord had a moment to set himself in a pattern of defense, Mat altered his attack in midwhirl. The end of the staff Darlin had been expecting at his head dipped instead to sweep his legs out from under him. The other end did strike at his head then, as he fell, a sharp crack that rolled his eyes back up in his head.

pæntɪŋ, mæt lin ɑn ɪz stæf oʊvɝ ði ʌnkɑnʃəs haɪ lɔɹd. bɝn mi, ɪf aɪ hæv tə faɪt wʌn əɹ tu mɔɹ laɪk ðɪs, əl blʌɾi wɛl fɔl oʊvɝ fɹəm ɪɡzɔstʃən! ðə stɔɹiz də nɑt tɛl jə biɪŋ ə hɪɹoʊ ɪz sətʃ hɑɹd wɝk! nɪneɪiv ɔlweɪz dɪd faɪn ə weɪ tə meɪk mi wɝk.

Panting, Mat leaned on his staff over the unconscious High Lord. Burn me, if I have to fight one or two more like this, I'll bloody well fall over from exhaustion! The stories do not tell you being a hero is such hard work! Nynaeve always did find a way to make me work.

sændɑɹ keɪm tə stæn bɪsaɪd hɪm, fɹaʊnɪŋ daʊn ət ðə kɹʌmpəl haɪ lɔɹd. "hi dʌz nɑt lʊk soʊ maɪɾi laɪɪŋ ðɛɹ," hi sɛd wʌndɝɪŋli. "hi dʌz nɑt lʊk soʊ mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən mi."

Sandar came to stand beside him, frowning down at the crumpled High Lord. "He does not look so mighty lying there," he said wonderingly. "He does not look so much greater than me."

mæt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən pɪɹd daʊn ðə hɔl, wɛɹ ə mæn hæd dʒʌst ɡɔn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ əkɹɔs əlɔŋ ə dʒɔɪnɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ. bɝn mi, ɪf aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪt wɑz kɹeɪzi, aɪ wəd swɛɹ ðət wɑz ɹænd!

Mat gave a start and peered down the hall, where a man had just gone trotting across along a joining corridor. Burn me, if I did not know it was crazy, I would swear that was Rand!

"sændɑɹ, jə faɪn ðət - " hi bɪɡæn, swɪŋɪŋ ɪz stæf ʌp ɑntu hɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən kʌɾ ɔf wən ɪt θʌddɪɾ ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ.

"Sandar, you find that - " he began, swinging his staff up onto his shoulder, and cut off when it thudded into something.

spɪnɪŋ, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf feɪsɪŋ ənʌðɝ hæf-dʒɹɛs haɪ lɔɹd, ðɪs wʌn wɪð ɪz sɔɹɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, hɪz niz bʌklɪŋ, ən boʊθ hænz tə hɪz hɛd wɛɹ mæts stæf hæd splɪɾ ɪz skælp. heɪstəli, mæt poʊkt ɪm hɑɹɾ ɪn ðə stʌmək wɪð ðə bʌɾ ə ðə stæf tə bɹɪŋ ɪz hænz daʊn, ðən ɡeɪv ɪm ənʌðɝ θʌmp ɑn ðə hɛd tə pʊɾ ɪm daʊn ɪn ə hip ɑn tɑp ə hɪz sɔɹd.

Spinning, he found himself facing another half-dressed High Lord, this one with his sword on the floor, his knees buckling, and both hands to his head where Mat's staff had split his scalp. Hastily, Mat poked him hard in the stomach with the butt of the staff to bring his hands down, then gave him another thump on the head to put him down in a heap on top of his sword.

"lʌk, sændɑɹ," hi mʌɾɝd. "ju kænɑt bit blʌɾi lʌk. naʊ, waɪ doʊn jə faɪn ðɪs blʌɾi pɹaɪvət weɪ ðə haɪ lɔɹdz teɪk daʊn tə ðə sɛlz?" sændɑɹ hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd ðəɹ wɑz sətʃ ə stɛɹweɪ, ən juzɪŋ ɪt wəɾ əvɔɪd hævɪŋ tə ɹʌn θɹu moʊst ə ðə stoʊn. mæt dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i laɪk mɛn soʊ iɡɝ tə wɑtʃ pipəl pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən ðət ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ə kwɪk ɹut tə ðə pɹɪznɝz fɹəm ðɛɹ əpɑɹtməns.

"Luck, Sandar," he muttered. "You cannot beat bloody luck. Now, why don't you find this bloody private way the High Lords take down to the cells?" Sandar had insisted there was such a stairway, and using it would avoid having to run through most of the Stone. Mat did not think he liked men so eager to watch people put to the question that they wanted a quick route to the prisoners from their apartments.

"dʒʌs bi ɡlæd jə wɝ soʊ lʌki," sændɑɹ sɛɾ ənstɛɾəli, "ɔɹ ðɪs wʌn wʊɾə kɪld əs boʊθ bɪfɔɹ wi sɔ hɪm. aɪ noʊ ðə dɔɹ ɪz hɪɹ sʌmwɛɹ. ɑɹ jə kʌmɪŋ? əɹ dʒju min tə weɪt fəɹ ənʌðɝ haɪ lɔɹd tə əpɪɹ?"

"Just be glad you were so lucky," Sandar said unsteadily, "or this one would have killed us both before we saw him. I know the door is here somewhere. Are you coming? Or do you mean to wait for another High Lord to appear?"

"lɛɾ ɑn." mæt stɛpt oʊvɝ ði ʌnkɑnʃəs haɪ lɔɹd. "aɪ æm noʊ blʌɾi hɪɹoʊ."

"Lead on." Mat stepped over the unconscious High Lord. "I am no bloody hero."

tʃɹɑɾɪŋ, hi fɑloʊd ðə θif-kætʃɝ, hu pɪɹɾ ət ðə tɔl dɔɹz ðeɪ pæst, mʌɾɝɪŋ ðəɾ i nu ɪt wɑz hɪɹ sʌmwɛɹ.

Trotting, he followed the thief-catcher, who peered at the tall doors they passed, muttering that he knew it was here somewhere.


tʃæptɝ fɪftifaɪv


CHAPTER 55

wʌɾ ɪz ɹɪɾən ɪn pɹɑfəsi


What Is Written in Prophecy

ɹænd ɛntɝd ðə tʃeɪmbɝ sloʊli, wɔkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt pɑlɪʃt ɹɛdstoʊn kɑləmz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɹəm ɪz dʒɹimz. saɪləns fɪl ðə ʃædoʊz, jɛt sʌmθɪŋ kɔl tə hɪm. ən sʌmθɪŋ flæʃt əhɛd, ə moʊməntɛɹi laɪt θɹoʊɪŋ bæk ʃædoʊ, ə bikən. hi stɛpt aʊt bɪniθ ə ɡɹeɪt doʊm, ən sɔ wʌɾ i sɔt. kælændɝ, hæŋɪŋ hɪl daʊn ɪn mɪdɛɹ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ noʊ hæn bʌt ðəɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. əz ɪt ɹivɑlvd, ɪt bɹoʊk wʌt lɪɾəl laɪt ðəɹ wɑz ɪndə splɪntɝz, ən naʊ ən ðən ɪt flɛɹɾ əz ɪf wɪð ə laɪɾ ʌv ɪts oʊn. kɔlɪŋ hɪm. weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɪm.

Rand entered the chamber slowly, walking among the great polished redstone columns he remembered from his dreams. Silence filled the shadows, yet something called to him. And something flashed ahead, a momentary light throwing back shadow, a beacon. He stepped out beneath a great dome, and saw what he sought. Callandor, hanging hilt down in midair, waiting for no hand but that of the Dragon Reborn. As it revolved, it broke what little light there was into splinters, and now and then it flared as if with a light of its own. Calling him. Waiting for him.

ɪf aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪf aɪm nɑt dʒʌst səm hæf-mæd mæn kɝst wɪð ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl, ə pʌpət dænsɪŋ fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

If I am the Dragon Reborn. If I am not just some half-mad man cursed with the ability to channel, a puppet dancing for Moiraine and the White Tower.

"teɪk ɪt, luz θɝɪn. teɪk ɪt, kɪnsleɪɝ."

"Take it, Lews Therin. Take it, Kinslayer."

hi spʌn tə feɪs ðə vɔɪs. ðə tɔl mæn wɪð kloʊs-kɹɑpt waɪt hɛɹ u stɛp fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz wɑz fəmɪljɝ tə hɪm. ɹænd hæd noʊ aɪdiə hu hi wɑz, ðɪs fɛloʊ ɪn ə ɹɛd sɪlk koʊt wɪð blæk stʃɹaɪps daʊn ɪts pʌfi slivz ən blæk bɹitʃɪz tʌkt ɪndə ɪlæbɹətli sɪlvɝ-wɝk buts. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ ðə mæn, bʌɾ i hæd sin ɪm ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz. "ju pʊɾ əm ɪn ə keɪdʒ," hi sɛd. "ɛɡwin, ən nɪneɪiv, ən ɪleɪn. ɪn maɪ dʒɹimz. jə kɛpt pʊɾɪŋ əm ɪn ə keɪdʒ, ən hɝɾɪŋ ðɛm."

He spun to face the voice. The tall man with close-cropped white hair who stepped from the shadows among the columns was familiar to him. Rand had no idea who he was, this fellow in a red silk coat with black stripes down its puffy sleeves and black breeches tucked into elaborately silver-worked boots. He did not know the man, but he had seen him in his dreams. "You put them in a cage," he said. "Egwene, and Nynaeve, and Elayne. In my dreams. You kept putting them in a cage, and hurting them."

ðə mæn meɪɾ ə dɪsmɪsɪv dʒɛstʃɝ ə hɪz hænd. "ðeɪ ɑɹ lɛs ðən nʌθɪŋ. pɝhæps wʌn deɪ, wən ðeɪv bɪn tʃɹeɪnd, bʌt nɑt naʊ. aɪ kənfɛs sɝpɹaɪz ðət jə kɛɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk əm jusfəl. bʌt jə wɝ ɛvɝ ə ful, ɛvɝ ɹɛɾi tə fɑloʊ jəɹ hɑɹt bɪfɔɹ paʊɝ. jə keɪm tu sun, luz θɝɪn. naʊ jə mʌs də wʌt jə ɑɹ nɑt jɛt ɹɛɾi fɔɹ, əɹ ɛls daɪ. daɪ, noʊɪŋ juv lɛf ðiz wɪmən jə kɛɹ fəɹ ɪn maɪ hænz." hi sim tə bi weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, ɪkspɛktənt. "aɪ min tə juz əm mɔɹ, kɪnsleɪɝ. ðəl sɝv mi, sɝv maɪ paʊɝ. ən ðət wɪl hɝɾ əm fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪv sʌfɝd bɪfɔɹ."

The man made a dismissive gesture of his hand. "They are less than nothing. Perhaps one day, when they have been trained, but not now. I confess surprise that you cared enough to make them useful. But you were ever a fool, ever ready to follow your heart before power. You came too soon, Lews Therin. Now you must do what you are not yet ready for, or else die. Die, knowing you have left these women you care for in my hands." He seemed to be waiting for something, expectant. "I mean to use them more, Kinslayer. They will serve me, serve my power. And that will hurt them far more than anything they have suffered before."

bɪhaɪn ɹænd, kælændɝ flæʃt, θɹoʊɪŋ wʌn pʌls ʌv wɔɹmθ əɡɛnst ɪz bæk. "hu ɑɹ ju?"

Behind Rand, Callandor flashed, throwing one pulse of warmth against his back. "Who are you?"

"ju də nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ mi, də ju?" ðə waɪt-hɛɹd mæn læf sʌɾənli. "aɪ də nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ju, iðɝ, lʊkɪŋ ðɪs weɪ. ə kʌntʃɹi læd wɪð ə flut keɪs ɑn ɪz bæk. dɪɾ ɪʃəml spik ðə tʃɹuθ? hi wɑz ɛvɝ wʌn tə laɪ wən ɪt ɡeɪn ɪm ən ɪntʃ əɹ ə sɛkənd. dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ nʌθɪŋ, luz θɝɪn?"

"You do not remember me, do you?" The white-haired man laughed suddenly. "I do not remember you, either, looking this way. A country lad with a flute case on his back. Did Ishamael speak the truth? He was ever one to lie when it gained him an inch or a second. Do you remember nothing, Lews Therin?"

"ə neɪm!" ɹænd dɪmændəd. "wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ neɪm?"

"A name!" Rand demanded. "What is your name?"

"kɔl mi bɛləl." ðə fɔɹseɪkən skaʊld wən ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɹiæk tə ðə neɪm. "teɪk ɪt!" bɛləl snæpt, θɹoʊɪŋ ə hæn təwɔɹd ðə sɔɹd bɪhaɪn ɹænd. "wʌns wi ɹoʊd tə wɔɹ saɪd baɪ saɪd, ən fəɹ ðəɾ aɪ ɡɪv jə ə tʃæns. ə bɛɹ tʃæns, bʌɾ ə tʃæns tə seɪv jɝsɛlf, ə tʃæns tə seɪv ðoʊz θɹi aɪ min tə meɪk maɪ pɛts. teɪk ðə sɔɹd, kʌntʃɹimən. pɝhæps ɪɾəl bi ɪnʌf tə hɛlp jə sɝvaɪv mi."

"Call me Be'lal." The Forsaken scowled when Rand did not react to the name. "Take it!" Be'lal snapped, throwing a hand toward the sword behind Rand. "Once we rode to war side by side, and for that I give you a chance. A bare chance, but a chance to save yourself, a chance to save those three I mean to make my pets. Take the sword, countryman. Perhaps it will be enough to help you survive me."

ɹænd læft. "du jə bɪliv jə kən fɹaɪɾən mi soʊ izəli, fɔɹseɪkən? bælzəmən hɪmsɛlf əz hʌntəd mi. dʒju θɪŋk əl kaʊɝ naʊ fəɹ ju? ɡɹɑvəl bɪfɔɹ ə fɔɹseɪkən wən aɪ hæv dɪnaɪd ðə dɑɹk wʌn tə hɪz feɪs?"

Rand laughed. "Do you believe you can frighten me so easily, Forsaken? Ba'alzamon himself has hunted me. Do you think I will cower now for you? Grovel before a Forsaken when I have denied the Dark One to his face?"

"ɪz ðət wʌt jə θɪŋk?" bɛləl sɛd sɔfli. "tʃɹuli, jə noʊ nʌθɪŋ." sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɑz ə sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, ə sɔɹd wɪð ə bleɪd kɑɹv fɹəm blæk faɪɝ. "teɪk ɪt! teɪk kælændɝ! θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz, waɪl aɪ leɪ ɪmpɹɪzənd, ɪts weɪɾəd ðɛɹ. fəɹ ju. wʌn ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl sɑŋɡɹil wi ɛvɝ meɪd. teɪk ɪt, ən dɪfɛn jɝsɛlf, ɪf jə kæn!"

"Is that what you think?" Be'lal said softly. "Truly, you know nothing." Suddenly there was a sword in his hands, a sword with a blade carved from black fire. "Take it! Take Callandor! Three thousand years, while I lay imprisoned, it has waited there. For you. One of the most powerful sa'angreal we ever made. Take it, and defend yourself, if you can!"

hi muv təwɔɹd ɹænd əz ɪf tə dʒɹaɪv ɪm bæk təwɔɹd kælændɝ, bʌt ɹænd ɹeɪzd ɪz oʊn hænz - seɪɾɪn fɪl hɪm; swit ɹʌʃɪŋ floʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ; stʌmək-ɹɛntʃɪŋ vɪlnəs ə ðə teɪnt - ən i hɛld ə sɔɹd ɹɔt fɹəm ɹɛd fleɪm, ə sɔɹd wɪð ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk ɑn ɪts faɪɝi bleɪd. hi stɛpt ɪndə ðə fɔɹmz læn hæd tɔɾ ɪm tɪl i floʊd fɹəm wʌn tə ðə nɛkst əz ɪf ɪn ə dæns. pɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪlk. wɔɾɝ floʊz daʊnhɪl. wɪn ən ɹeɪn. bleɪɾ ə blæk faɪɝ mɛt bleɪɾ ə ɹɛɾ ɪn ʃaʊɝz ə spɑɹks, ɹɔɹz laɪk waɪt-hɑt mɛɾəl ʃæɾɝɪŋ.

He moved toward Rand as if to drive him back toward Callandor, but Rand raised his own hands - saidin filled him; sweet rushing flow of the Power; stomach-wrenching vileness of the taint - and he held a sword wrought from red flame, a sword with a heron-mark on its fiery blade. He stepped into the forms Lan had taught him till he flowed from one to the next as if in a dance. Parting the Silk. Water Flows Downhill. Wind and Rain. Blade of black fire met blade of red in showers of sparks, roars like white-hot metal shattering.

ɹænd keɪm bæk smuðli ɪndə ə ɡɑɹd stæns, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə lɛɾ ɪz sʌɾən ənsɝɾənti ʃoʊ. ə hɛɹən stʊɾ ɑn ðə blæk bleɪd, tu, ə bɝd soʊ dɑɹk əz tə bi nɪɹli ɪnvɪzəbəl. wʌns i hæd feɪst ə mæn wɪð ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪɾ ə stil, ən bɛɹli sɝvaɪvd. hi nu ðəɾ i hɪmsɛlf hæd noʊ ɹil ɹaɪt tə ðə bleɪdmæstɝz mɑɹk; ɪt hæd bɪn ɑn ðə sɔɹɾ ɪz fɑðɝ hæd ɡɪvən hɪm, ən wən i θɔɾ ʌv ə sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, hi θɔɾ ə ðət sɔɹd. wʌns i hæɾ ɛmbɹeɪs dɛθ, əz ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd tɔt, bʌt ðɪs taɪm, hi nu, hɪz dɛθ wəd bi faɪnəl. bɛləl wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən i wɪð ðə sɔɹd. stʃɹɔŋɝ. fæstɝ. ə tʃɹu bleɪdmæstɝ.

Rand came back smoothly into a guard stance, trying not to let his sudden uncertainty show. A heron stood on the black blade, too, a bird so dark as to be nearly invisible. Once he had faced a man with a heron-mark blade of steel, and barely survived. He knew that he himself had no real right to the blademaster's mark; it had been on the sword his father had given him, and when he thought of a sword in his hands, he thought of that sword. Once he had embraced death, as the Warder had taught, but this time, he knew, his death would be final. Be'lal was better than he with the sword. Stronger. Faster. A true blademaster.

ðə fɔɹseɪkən læft, əmjuzd, swɪŋɪŋ ɪz bleɪɾ ɪn kwɪk flɝɪʃəz tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm; ðə blæk faɪɝ ɹɔɹɾ əz ɪf swɪf pæsədʒ θɹu ði ɛɹ kwɪkən ɪt. "ju wɝ ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ sɔɝdzmən, wʌns, luz θɝɪn," hi sɛd mɑkəŋli. "du jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ wən wi tʊk ðət teɪm spɔɹt kɔl sɔɹdz ən lɝn tə kɪl wɪð ɪt, əz ði oʊl vɑljumz sɛd mɛn wʌns hæd? dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ ivən wʌn ə ðoʊz dɛspɹɪt bæɾəlz, ivən wʌn ʌv əɹ daɪɹ dɪfits? ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ nʌθɪŋ, də ju? ðɪs taɪm juv nɑt lɝn ɪnʌf. ðɪs taɪm, luz θɝɪn, əl kɪl ju." bɛləlz mɑkɝi dipənd. "pɝhæps ɪf jə teɪk kælændɝ, jə maɪɾ ɪkstɛn jəɹ laɪf ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ."

The Forsaken laughed, amused, swinging his blade in quick flourishes to either side of him; the black fire roared as if swift passage through the air quickened it. "You were a greater swordsman, once, Lews Therin," he said mockingly. "Do you remember when we took that tame sport called swords and learned to kill with it, as the old volumes said men once had? Do you remember even one of those desperate battles, even one of our dire defeats? Of course not. You remember nothing, do you? This time you have not learned enough. This time, Lews Therin, I will kill you." Be'lal's mockery deepened. "Perhaps if you take Callandor, you might extend your life a little longer. A little longer."

hi keɪm fɔɹwɝd sloʊli, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf tə ɡɪv ɹænd taɪm tə də dʒʌs ðæt, tɝn ən ɹeɪs tə kælændɝ, tə ðə sɔɹd ðət kænɑt bi tʌtʃt, tə teɪk ɪt. bʌt ðə daʊts wɝ stɪl stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ɹænd. kælændɝ kəɾ oʊnli bi tʌtʃt baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hi hæɾ əlaʊɾ əm tə pɹoʊkleɪm ɪm soʊ fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹizənz ðət sim tə liv ɪm noʊ tʃɔɪs ət ðə taɪm. bʌt wɑz i tʃɹuli ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? ɪf i ɹeɪs tə tʌtʃ kælændɝ ɪn tʃɹuθ, nɑɾ ɪn ə dʒɹim, wəɾ ɪz hæn miɾ ən ɪnvɪzəbəl wɔl waɪl bɛləl kʌɾ ɪm daʊn fɹəm bɪhaɪnd?

He came forward slowly, almost as if to give Rand time to do just that, turn and race to Callandor, to the Sword That Cannot Be Touched, to take it. But the doubts were still strong in Rand. Callandor could only be touched by the Dragon Reborn. He had allowed them to proclaim him so for a hundred reasons that seemed to leave him no choice at the time. But was he truly the Dragon Reborn? If he raced to touch Callandor in truth, not in a dream, would his hand meet an invisible wall while Be'lal cut him down from behind?

hi mɛt ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ i nu, ðə bleɪɾ ə faɪɝ ɹɔt wɪð seɪɾɪn. ən wɑz dʒɹɪvən bæk. ðə fɔlɪŋ lif mɛt wɔɾɝd sɪlk. ðə kæt dænsəz ɑn ðə wɔl mɛt ðə bɔɹ ɹʌʃəz daʊnhɪl. ðə ɹɪvɝ ʌndɝkʌts ðə bæŋk nɪɹli lɔst ɪm ɪz hɛd, ən i hæd tə θɹoʊ hɪmsɛlf ənɪləɡənli tə wʌn saɪd wɪð blæk fleɪm bɹʌʃɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ, ɹoʊlɪŋ tə hɪz fit tə kənfɹʌn ðə stoʊn fɔlz fɹəm ðə maʊntən. məθɑɾɪkəli, dɪlɪbɝətli, bɛləl dʒɹoʊv ɪm bæk ɪn ə spaɪɹəl ðət sloʊli taɪɾənd ɑn kælændɝ.

He met the Forsaken with the sword he knew, the blade of fire wrought with saidin. And was driven back. The Falling Leaf met Watered Silk. The Cat Dances on the Wall met the Boar Rushes Downhill. The River Undercuts the Bank nearly lost him his head, and he had to throw himself inelegantly to one side with black flame brushing his hair, rolling to his feet to confront the Stone Falls From the Mountain. Methodically, deliberately, Be'lal drove him back in a spiral that slowly tightened on Callandor.

ʃaʊts ɛkoʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz, skɹimz, ðə klæʃ ə stil, bʌt ɹænd bɛɹli hɝd. hi ən bɛləl wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əloʊn ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn. mɛn ɪn bɹɛstpleɪts ən ɹɪm hɛlməts fɔt wɪð sɔɹdz əɡɛnst ʃæɾoʊi, veɪld ʃeɪps ðət dɑɹɾɪd əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz wɪð ʃɔɹt spɪɹz stæbɪŋ. səm ə ðə soʊlʒɝz fɔɹmd ə ɹæŋk; æɹoʊz flæʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə dɪmnəs tʊk əm ɪn ðə θɹoʊt, ðə feɪs, ən ðeɪ daɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ laɪn. ɹænd hɑɹdli noʊɾəst ðə faɪɾɪŋ, ivən wən mɛn fɛl dɛd wɪðɪn peɪsɪz ə hɪm. hɪz oʊn faɪt wɑz tu dɛspɹɪt; ɪt tʊk ɔl ə hɪz kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən. wɛt wɔɹmθ tʃɹɪkəl daʊn ɪz saɪd. ði oʊld waʊnd wɑz bɹeɪkɪŋ oʊpən.

Shouts echoed among the columns, screams, the clash of steel, but Rand barely heard. He and Be'lal were no longer alone in the Heart of the Stone. Men in breastplates and rimmed helmets fought with swords against shadowy, veiled shapes that darted among the columns with short spears stabbing. Some of the soldiers formed a rank; arrows flashing out of the dimness took them in the throat, the face, and they died in their line. Rand hardly noticed the fighting, even when men fell dead within paces of him. His own fight was too desperate; it took all of his concentration. Wet warmth trickled down his side. The old wound was breaking open.

hi stʌmbəl sʌɾənli, nɑt siɪŋ ðə dɛd mæn əɾ ɪz fiɾ əntɪl i wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz bæk ətɑp ɪz flut keɪs ɑn ðə stoʊn flɔɹ.

He stumbled suddenly, not seeing the dead man at his feet until he was lying on his back atop his flute case on the stone floor.

bɛləl ɹeɪzd ɪz bleɪɾ ə blæk faɪɝ, snɑɹlɪŋ. "teɪk ɪt! teɪk kælændɝ ən dɪfɛn jɝsɛlf! teɪk ɪt, əɹ əl kɪl jə naʊ! ɪf jəl nɑt teɪk ɪt, əl sleɪ ju!"

Be'lal raised his blade of black fire, snarling. "Take it! Take Callandor and defend yourself! Take it, or I will kill you now! If you will not take it, I will slay you!"

"noʊ!"

"No!"

ivən bɛləl ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ət ðə kəmæn ɪn ðət wʊmənz vɔɪs. ðə fɔɹseɪkən stɛp bæk aʊɾ ə ði ɑɹk ə ɹændz sɔɹɾ ən tɝn ɪz hɛd tə fɹaʊn ət mɔɪɹeɪn əz ʃi keɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə bæɾəl, hɝ aɪz fɪkst ɑn hɪm, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə skɹimɪŋ dɛθs ɝaʊn hɝ. "aɪ θɔt jə wɝ nitli aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ, wʊmən. noʊ mæɾɝ. jə ɑɹ oʊnli ən ənɔɪəns. ə stɪŋɪŋ flaɪ. ə baɪtim. əl keɪdʒ jə wɪð ði ʌðɝz, ən titʃ jə tə sɝv ðə ʃædoʊ wɪð jəɹ pjuni paʊɝz," hi fɪnɪʃt wɪð ə kəntɛmptʃuəs læf, ən ɹeɪzd ɪz fɹi hænd.

Even Be'lal gave a start at the command in that woman's voice. The Forsaken stepped back out of the arc of Rand's sword and turned his head to frown at Moiraine as she came striding through the battle, her eyes fixed on him, ignoring the screaming deaths around her. "I thought you were neatly out of the way, woman. No matter. You are only an annoyance. A stinging fly. A biteme. I will cage you with the others, and teach you to serve the Shadow with your puny powers," he finished with a contemptuous laugh, and raised his free hand.

mɔɪɹeɪn hæd nɑt stɑpt əɹ sloʊd waɪl i spoʊk. ʃi wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən θɝɾi peɪsɪz fɹəm ɪm wən i muvd ɪz hænd, ən ʃi ɹeɪz boʊθ ə hɝz əz wɛl.

Moiraine had not stopped or slowed while he spoke. She was no more than thirty paces from him when he moved his hand, and she raised both of hers as well.

ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪnstən ə sɝpɹaɪz ɑn ðə fɔɹseɪkənz feɪs, ən i hæd taɪm tə skɹim "noʊ!" ðən ə bɑɹ ʌv waɪt faɪɝ hɑɾɝ ðən ðə sʌn ʃɑt fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪz hænz, ə ɡlɛɹɪŋ ɹɑd ðət bænɪʃt ɔl ʃædoʊz. bɪfɔɹ ɪt, bɛləl bɪkeɪm ə ʃeɪp ə ʃɪmɝɪŋ moʊts, spɛks dænsɪŋ ɪn ðə laɪt fəɹ lɛs ðən ə hɑɹtbit, flɛks kənsum bɪfɔɹ ɪz kɹaɪ feɪɾəd.

There was an instant of surprise on the Forsaken's face, and he had time to scream "No!" Then a bar of white fire hotter than the sun shot from the Aes Sedai's hands, a glaring rod that banished all shadows. Before it, Be'lal became a shape of shimmering motes, specks dancing in the light for less than a heartbeat, flecks consumed before his cry faded.

ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns ɪn ðə tʃeɪmbɝ əz ðət bɑɹ ə laɪt vænɪʃt, saɪləns ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə moʊnz ə ðə wundəd. ðə faɪɾɪŋ hæd stɑp dɛd, veɪl mɛn ən mɛn ɪn bɹɛstpleɪts əlaɪk stændɪŋ əz ɪf stʌnd.

There was silence in the chamber as that bar of light vanished, silence except for the moans of the wounded. The fighting had stopped dead, veiled men and men in breastplates alike standing as if stunned.

"hi wɑz ɹaɪt kənsɝnɪŋ wʌn θɪŋ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, əz kuli sɝin əz ɪf ʃi wɝ stændɪŋ ɪn ə mɛdoʊ. "ju mʌs teɪk kælændɝ. hi mɛn tə sleɪ jə fəɹ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪts jəɹ bɝθɹaɪt. bɛɾɝ baɪ fɑɹ ðət jə nu mɔɹ bɪfɔɹ jəɹ hæn hɛl ðət hɪlt, jɛt juv kʌm tə ðə pɔɪnt naʊ, ən ðəɹ ɪz noʊ fɝðɝ taɪm fəɹ lɝnɪŋ. teɪk ɪt, ɹænd."

"He was right concerning one thing," Moiraine said, as coolly serene as if she were standing in a meadow. "You must take Callandor. He meant to slay you for it, but it is your birthright. Better by far that you knew more before your hand held that hilt, yet you have come to the point now, and there is no further time for learning. Take it, Rand."

wɪps ə blæk laɪtnɪŋ kɝld ɝaʊn hɝ; ʃi skɹimd əz ðeɪ lɪftəd hɝ, hɝld əɹ tə slaɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə flɔɹ laɪk ə sæk əntɪl ʃi keɪm ʌp əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðə kɑləmz.

Whips of black lightning curled around her; she screamed as they lifted her, hurled her to slide along the floor like a sack until she came up against one of the columns.

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ʌp ət wɛɹ ðə laɪtnɪŋ hæd kʌm fɹʌm. ðəɹ wɑz ə dipɝ ʃædoʊ ʌp ðɛɹ, nɪɹ ðə tɑp ə ðə kɑləmz, ə blæknəs ðət meɪɾ ɔl ʌðɝ ʃædoʊz lʊk laɪk nundeɪ, ən fɹəm ɪt, tu aɪz ə faɪɝ stɛɹd bæk ət hɪm.

Rand stared up at where the lightning had come from. There was a deeper shadow up there, near the top of the columns, a blackness that made all other shadows look like noonday, and from it, two eyes of fire stared back at him.

sloʊli ðə ʃædoʊ dɪsɛndəd, ɹizɑlvɪŋ ɪndə bælzəmən, kloʊðd ɪn dɛd blæk, laɪk ə mɹdʒɹɑlz blæk. jɛɾ ivən ðət wɑz nɑt soʊ dɑɹk əz ðə ʃædoʊ ðət klʌŋ tə hɪm. hi hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, tu spænz əbʌv ðə flɔɹ, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ɹænd wɪð ə ɹeɪdʒ əz fɪɹs əz ɪz aɪz. "twaɪs ɪn ðɪs laɪf aɪ hæv ɔfɝd jə ðə tʃæns tə sɝv mi lɪvɪŋ." fleɪmz lɛpt ɪn ɪz maʊθ əz i spoʊk, ən ɛvɹi wɝd ɹɔɹd laɪk ə fɝnəs. "twaɪs juv ɹəfjuzd, ən wundəd mi. naʊ jəl sɝv ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪn dɛθ. daɪ, luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ. daɪ, ɹænd ælθɹ. ɪts taɪm fəɹ jə tə daɪ! aɪ teɪk jəɹ soʊl!"

Slowly the shadow descended, resolving into Ba'alzamon, clothed in dead black, like a Myrddraal's black. Yet even that was not so dark as the shadow that clung to him. He hung in the air, two spans above the floor, glaring at Rand with a rage as fierce as his eyes. "Twice in this life I have offered you the chance to serve me living." Flames leaped in his mouth as he spoke, and every word roared like a furnace. "Twice you have refused, and wounded me. Now you will serve the Lord of the Grave in death. Die, Lews Therin Kinslayer. Die, Rand al'Thor. It is time for you to die! I take your soul!"

əz bælzəmən pʊt fɔɹθ ɪz hænd, ɹænd pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf ʌp, θɹu hɪmsɛlf dɛspɝətli təwɔɹd kælændɝ, stɪl ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ən flæʃɪŋ ɪn mɪdɛɹ. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ i kəd ɹitʃ ɪt, əɹ tʌtʃ ɪɾ ɪf i dɪd, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ɪz oʊnli tʃæns.

As Ba'alzamon put forth his hand, Rand pushed himself up, threw himself desperately toward Callandor, still glittering and flashing in midair. He did not know whether he could reach it, or touch it if he did, but he was sure it was his only chance.

bælzəmənz bloʊ stʃɹʌk ɪm əz i lɛpt, stʃɹʌk ɪnsaɪd hɪm, ə ɹɪpɪŋ ən kɹʌmplɪŋ, tɛɹɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ lus, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm əweɪ. ɹænd skɹimd. hi fɛlt əz ɪf i wɝ kəlæpsɪŋ laɪk ən ɛmpti sæk, əz ɪf i wɝ biɪŋ tɝn ɪnsaɪɾ aʊt. ðə peɪn ɪn ɪz saɪd, ðə waʊn teɪkən ət fɑlm, wɑz ɔlmoʊst wɛlkəm, sʌmθɪŋ tə hæŋ ɑn tə, ə ɹimaɪndɝ ə laɪf. hɪz hæn kloʊz kənvʌlsɪvli. ɑn kælændɝz hɪlt.

Ba'alzamon's blow struck him as he leapt, struck inside him, a ripping and crumpling, tearing something loose, trying to pull a part of him away. Rand screamed. He felt as if he were collapsing like an empty sack, as if he were being turned inside out. The pain in his side, the wound taken at Falme, was almost welcome, something to hang on to, a reminder of life. His hand closed convulsively. On Callandor's hilt.

ðə wʌn paʊɝ sɝdʒ θɹu hɪm, ə tɔɹənt ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən i kəd bɪliv, fɹəm seɪɾɪn ɪndə ðə sɔɹd. ðə kɹɪstəl bleɪd ʃoʊn bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ivən mɔɪɹeɪnz faɪɝ hæd. ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə lʊk æt, ɪmpɑsəbəl ɛni lɔŋɡɝ tə si ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə sɔɹd, oʊnli ðət laɪt bleɪzd ɪn ɪz fɪst. hi fɔt ðə floʊ, ɹɛsəld wɪð ði ɪmplækəbəl taɪd ðət θɹɛɾənd tə kæɹi hɪm, ɔl ðət wɑz ɹɪli hɪm, ɪndə ðə sɔɹd wɪð ɪt. fəɹ ə hɑɹtbit ðət tʊk sɛntʃɝiz i hʌŋ, weɪvɝɪŋ, bælənst ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə biɪŋ skaʊɝɾ əweɪ laɪk sæn bɪfɔɹ ə flæʃ flʌd. wɪð ɪnfənət sloʊnəs ðə bæləns fɝmd. ɪt wɑz stɪl əz ðoʊ hi stʊd bɛɹfʊɾ ɑn ə ɹeɪzɝz ɛdʒ əbʌv ə bɑɾəmləs dʒɹɑp, jɛt sʌmθɪŋ toʊld ɪm ðɪs wɑz ðə bɛs ðət kəd bi ɪkspɛktəd. tə tʃænəl ðɪs mʌtʃ ə ðə paʊɝ, hi mʌs dæns ɑn ðət ʃɑɹpnəs əz i hæd dæns ðə fɔɹmz ə ðə sɔɹd.

The One Power surged through him, a torrent greater than he could believe, from saidin into the sword. The crystal blade shone brighter than even Moiraine's fire had. It was impossible to look at, impossible any longer to see that it was a sword, only that light blazed in his fist. He fought the flow, wrestled with the implacable tide that threatened to carry him, all that was really him, into the sword with it. For a heartbeat that took centuries he hung, wavering, balanced on the brink of being scoured away like sand before a flash flood. With infinite slowness the balance firmed. It was still as though he stood barefoot on a razor's edge above a bottomless drop, yet something told him this was the best that could be expected. To channel this much of the Power, he must dance on that sharpness as he had danced the forms of the sword.

hi tɝn tə feɪs bælzəmən. ðə tɛɹɪŋ wɪðɪn ɪm hæd sist əz sun əz ɪz hæn tʌtʃt kælændɝ. oʊnli ən ɪnstən hæd pæst, jɛɾ ɪt sim tə hæv læstəd fɝɛvɝ. "ju wɪl nɑt teɪk maɪ soʊl," hi ʃaʊɾəd. "ðɪs taɪm, aɪ min tə fɪnɪʃ ɪt wʌns ən fəɹ ɔl! aɪ min tə fɪnɪʃ ɪt naʊ!"

He turned to face Ba'alzamon. The tearing within him had ceased as soon as his hand touched Callandor. Only an instant had passed, yet it seemed to have lasted forever. "You will not take my soul," he shouted. "This time, I mean to finish it once and for all! I mean to finish it now!"

bælzəmən flɛd, mæn ən ʃædoʊ vænɪʃɪŋ.

Ba'alzamon fled, man and shadow vanishing.

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd stɛɹd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə sɛns ʌv - foʊldɪŋ - əz bælzəmən lɛft. ə twɪstɪŋ, əz ɪf bælzəmən hæɾ ɪn səm weɪ bɛnt wʌt wɑz. ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə mɛn stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn kɹʌmpəld ət ðə kɑləm beɪs, ɹænd ɹitʃt aʊt, θɹu kælændɝ, ən twɪstəd ɹiæləɾi tə meɪk ə dɔɹ tə sʌmwɛɹ ɛls. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ tə wɛɹ, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪt wɑz wɛɹ bælzəmən hæd ɡɔn.

For a moment Rand stared, frowning. There had been a sense of - folding - as Ba'alzamon left. A twisting, as if Ba'alzamon had in some way bent what was. Ignoring the men staring at him, ignoring Moiraine crumpled at the column base, Rand reached out, through Callandor, and twisted reality to make a door to somewhere else. He did not know to where, except that it was where Ba'alzamon had gone.

"aɪ æm ðə hʌntɝ naʊ," hi sɛd, ən stɛp θɹu.

"I am the hunter now," he said, and stepped through.

ðə stoʊn ʃʊk ʌndɝ ɛɡwinz fit. ðə stoʊn ʃʊk; ɪt ɹæŋ. ʃi kɑɾ əɹ bæləns ən stɑpt, lɪsnɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ saʊnd, noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɹɛmɝ. wʌtɛvɝ hæd hæpənd, ɪt wɑz oʊvɝ. ʃi hɝiɾ ɑn. ə dɔɹ ʌv aɪɝn bɑɹz stʊɾ ɪn əɹ weɪ, wɪð ə lɑk əz bɪɡ əz əɹ hɛd. ʃi tʃænəld ɝθ bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹitʃt ɪt, ən wən ʃi pʊʃt əɡɛns ðə bɑɹz, ðə lɑk tɔɹ ɪn hæf.

The stone shook under Egwene's feet. The Stone shook; it rang. She caught her balance and stopped, listening. There was no more sound, no other tremor. Whatever had happened, it was over. She hurried on. A door of iron bars stood in her way, with a lock as big as her head. She channeled Earth before she reached it, and when she pushed against the bars, the lock tore in half.

ʃi wɔkt kwɪkli əkɹɔs ðə tʃeɪmbɝ bɪɑn ɪt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə lʊk ət ðə θɪŋz hæŋɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔlz. wɪps ən aɪɝn pɪnsɝz wɝ ðə moʊst ɪnɑkjuəs. wɪð ə smɔl ʃʌɾɝ ʃi pʊʃt oʊpən ə smɔlɝ aɪɝn ɡeɪɾ ən ɛntɝɾ ə kɔɹəɾɝ laɪnd wɪð ɹʌf wʊɾən dɔɹz, ɹʌʃ tɔɹtʃɪz bɝnɪŋ əɾ ɪntɝvəlz ɪn aɪɝn bɹækəts; ʃi fɛlt ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ ɹɪlif ət livɪŋ ðoʊz θɪŋz bɪhaɪn əz ʃi dɪɾ ət faɪndɪŋ wʌt ʃi sɔt. bʌt wɪtʃ sɛl?

She walked quickly across the chamber beyond it, trying not to look at the things hanging on the walls. Whips and iron pincers were the most innocuous. With a small shudder she pushed open a smaller iron gate and entered a corridor lined with rough wooden doors, rush torches burning at intervals in iron brackets; she felt almost as much relief at leaving those things behind as she did at finding what she sought. But which cell?

ðə wʊɾən dɔɹz oʊpən izəli. səm wɝ ənlɑkt, ən ðə lɑks ɑn ði ʌðɝz læstəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðət lɑɹdʒɝ lɑk hæɾ ɝliɝ. bʌɾ ɛvɹi sɛl wɑz ɛmpti. ʌv kɔɹs. noʊ wʌn wəd dʒɹim ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ðɪs pleɪs. ɛni pɹɪznɝ u mænədʒ tə ɹitʃ tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd wəd dʒɹim ʌv ə plɛzɑntɝ pleɪs.

The wooden doors opened easily. Some were unlocked, and the locks on the others lasted no longer than that larger lock had earlier. But every cell was empty. Of course. No one would dream themselves in this place. Any prisoner who managed to reach Tel'aran'rhiod would dream of a pleasanter place.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ kloʊs tə dɪspɛɹ. ʃi hæd wɑntəd tə bɪliv ðət faɪndɪŋ ðə ɹaɪt sɛl wəd meɪk ə dɪfɝəns. ivən faɪndɪŋ ɪt kəd bi ɪmpɑsəbəl, ðoʊ. ðɪs fɝs kɔɹəɾɝ stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn ən ɑn, ən ʌðɝz dʒɔɪn ɪt.

For a moment she felt something close to despair. She had wanted to believe that finding the right cell would make a difference. Even finding it could be impossible, though. This first corridor stretched on and on, and others joined it.

sʌɾənli ʃi sɔ sʌmθɪŋ flɪkɝ dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə hɝ. ə ʃeɪp ivən lɛs səbstæntʃəl ðən dʒɔɪjə bɝ hæd bɪn. ɪt hæd bɪn ə wʊmən, ðoʊ. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ə ðæt. ə wʊmən siɾəd ɑn ə bɛntʃ bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə sɛl dɔɹz. ði ɪmədʒ flɪkɝɾ ɪndə biɪŋ əɡɛn, ən wɑz ɡɔn. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðət slɛndɝ nɛk ən ðə peɪl, ɪnəsənt-əpɪɹɪŋ feɪs wɪð ɪts aɪlɪdz flʌɾɝɪŋ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə slip. ɑmikoʊ nəɡɔɪən wɑz dʒɹɪftɪŋ təwɔɹd slip, dʒɹimɪŋ ə hɝ ɡɑɹd duɾiz. ən əpɛɹənli tɔɪɪŋ dʒɹaʊsəli wɪð wʌn ə ðə stoʊlən tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ɛɡwin kəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt; ɪt hæd bɪn ə ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝt tə stɑp juzɪŋ ðə wʌn vɛɹɪn hæd ɡɪvən hɝ, ivən fəɹ ə fju deɪz.

Suddenly she saw something flicker just ahead of her. A shape even less substantial than Joiya Byir had been. It had been a woman, though. She was sure of that. A woman seated on a bench beside one of the cell doors. The image flickered into being again, and was gone. There was no mistaking that slender neck and the pale, innocent-appearing face with its eyelids fluttering on the edge of sleep. Amico Nagoyin was drifting toward sleep, dreaming of her guard duties. And apparently toying drowsily with one of the stolen ter'angreal. Egwene could understand that; it had been a great effort to stop using the one Verin had given her, even for a few days.

ʃi nu ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə kʌɾ ə wʊmən ɔf fɹəm ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ivən ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌt sɛvɝɪŋ ə wiv ɔlɹɛɾi ɪstæblɪʃt hæd tə bi mʌtʃ hɑɹɾɝ ðən dæmɪŋ ðə floʊ bɪfɔɹ ɪt bɪɡæn. ʃi sɛt ðə pæɾɝnz ə ðə wivɪŋ, ɹɛɾid ðɛm, meɪkɪŋ ðə θɹɛdz ə spɪɹət mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ, ðɪs taɪm, θɪkɝ ən hɛviɝ, ə dɛnsɝ wiv wɪð ə kʌɾɪŋ ɛdʒ laɪk ə naɪf.

She knew it was possible to cut a woman off from the True Source even if she had already embraced saidar, but severing a weave already established had to be much harder than damming the flow before it began. She set the patterns of the weaving, readied them, making the threads of Spirit much stronger, this time, thicker and heavier, a denser weave with a cutting edge like a knife.

ðə weɪvɝɪŋ ʃeɪp ə ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn əpɪɹɾ əɡɛn, ən ɛɡwin stʃɹʌk aʊt wɪð ðə floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ən spɪɹət. fəɹ ən ɪnstən sʌmθɪŋ sim tə ɹɪzɪs ðə wivɪŋ ə spɪɹət, ən ʃi fɔɹst ɪt wɪð ɔl ə hɝ maɪt. ɪt slɪɾ ɪndə pleɪs.

The wavering shape of the Darkfriend appeared again, and Egwene struck out with the flows of Air and Spirit. For an instant something seemed to resist the weaving of Spirit, and she forced it with all of her might. It slid into place.

ɑmikoʊ nəɡɔɪən skɹimd. ɪt wɑz ə θɪn saʊnd, bɛɹli hɝd, əz feɪn əz ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz, ən ʃi simd ɔlmoʊs laɪk ə ʃædoʊ ʌv wʌt dʒɔɪjə bɝ hæd bɪn. jɛt ðə bɑnz woʊvən ʌv ɛɹ hɛl hɝ; ʃi dɪd nɑt vænɪʃ əɡɛn. tɛɹɝ twɪstəd ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz lʌvli feɪs; ʃi sim tə bi bæbəlɪŋ, bʌɾ əɹ ʃaʊts wɝ wɪspɝz tu sɑft fəɹ ɛɡwin tə ʌndɝstænd.

Amico Nagoyin screamed. It was a thin sound, barely heard, as faint as she herself was, and she seemed almost like a shadow of what Joiya Byir had been. Yet the bonds woven of Air held her; she did not vanish again. Terror twisted the Darkfriend's lovely face; she seemed to be babbling, but her shouts were whispers too soft for Egwene to understand.

taɪɪŋ ən sɛɾɪŋ ðə wivz ɝaʊn ðə blæk sɪstɝ, ɛɡwin tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃənz tə ðə sɛl dɔɹ. ɪmpeɪʃənli, ʃi lɛɾ ɝθ flʌɾ ɪndə ði aɪɝn lɑk. ɪt fɛl əweɪ ɪn blæk dʌst, ɪn ə mɪs ðət dɪzɑlv kəmplitli bɪfɔɹ ɪt stʃɹʌk ðə flɔɹ. ʃi swʌŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, ən wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ðə sɛl ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn bɝnɪŋ ɹʌʃ tɔɹtʃ.

Tying and setting the weaves around the Black sister, Egwene turned her attentions to the cell door. Impatiently, she let Earth flood into the iron lock. It fell away in black dust, in a mist that dissolved completely before it struck the floor. She swung open the door, and was not surprised to find the cell empty except for one burning rush torch.

bʌɾ ɑmikoʊ ɪz baʊnd, ən ðə dɔɹ ɪz oʊpən.

But Amico is bound, and the door is open.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi θɔɾ ʌv wʌt tə də nɛkst. ðən ʃi stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə dʒɹim . . .

For a moment she thought of what to do next. Then she stepped out of the dream . . .

. . . ən woʊk tə ɔl əɹ bɹuzəz ən eɪks ən θɝst, tə ðə wɔl ə ðə sɛl əɡɛnst əɹ bæk, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə taɪtli ʃʌt sɛl dɔɹ. ʌv kɔɹs. wʌt hæpənz tə lɪvɪŋ θɪŋz ðəɹ ɪz ɹil wən ðeɪ weɪk. wʌɾ aɪ dɪd tə stoʊn əɹ aɪɝn əɹ wʊɾ əz noʊ ɪfɛkt ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld.

. . . and woke to all her bruises and aches and thirst, to the wall of the cell against her back, staring at the tightly shut cell door. Of course. What happens to living things there is real when they wake. What I did to stone or iron or wood has no effect in the waking world.

nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɝ stɪl nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɝ.

Nynaeve and Elayne were still kneeling beside her.

"huɛvɝ ɪz aʊt ðɛɹ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "skɹimd ə fju moʊməns əɡoʊ, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ɛls əz hæpənd. dɪd jə faɪn ə weɪ aʊt?"

"Whoever is out there," Nynaeve said, "screamed a few moments ago, but nothing else has happened. Did you find a way out?"

"wi ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə wɔk aʊt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "hɛlp mi tə maɪ fit, ən əl ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə lɑk. ɑmikoʊ wɪl nɑt tʃɹʌbəl ʌs. ðət skɹim wɑz hɝ."

"We should be able to walk out," Egwene said. "Help me to my feet, and I will get rid of the lock. Amico will not trouble us. That scream was her."

ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ hæv bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ ɛvɝ sɪns jə lɛft. ɪts dɪfɹənt, naʊ, bʌɾ aɪm stɪl kʌɾ ɔf."

Elayne shook her head. "I have been trying to embrace saidar ever since you left. It is different, now, but I am still cut off."

ɛɡwin fɔɹm ði ɛmptinəs ɪnsaɪd hɝ, bɪkeɪm ðə ɹoʊzbʌɾ oʊpənɪŋ tə seɪaɪdɑɹ. ði ɪnvɪzəbəl wɔl wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ. ɪt ʃɪmɝd naʊ. ðəɹ wɝ moʊməns wən ʃi ɔlmoʊs θɔt ʃi kəd fil ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fɪl əɹ wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ɔlmoʊst. ðə ʃild weɪvɝɾ ɪn ən aʊɾ ʌv ɛɡzɪstəns tu fæs fəɹ əɹ tə dɪtɛkt. ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl əv stɪl bɪn sɑləd.

Egwene formed the emptiness inside her, became the rosebud opening to saidar. The invisible wall was still there. It shimmered now. There were moments when she almost thought she could feel the True Source beginning to fill her with the Power. Almost. The shield wavered in and out of existence too fast for her to detect. It might as well have still been solid.

ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən. "aɪ baʊn hɝ. aɪ ʃildɪd hɝ. ʃiz ə lɪvɪŋ θɪŋ, nɑt laɪfləs aɪɝn. ʃi mʌs bi ʃildɪd stɪl."

She stared at the other two women. "I bound her. I shielded her. She is a living thing, not lifeless iron. She must be shielded still."

"sʌmθɪŋ əz hæpən tə ðə ʃil sɛɾ ɑn ʌs," ɪleɪn sɛd, "bʌɾ ɑmikoʊ ɪz stɪl mænɪdʒɪŋ tə hoʊld ɪt."

"Something has happened to the shield set on us," Elayne said, "but Amico is still managing to hold it."

ɛɡwin lɛɾ əɹ hɛd sæɡ bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl. "aɪ wɪl əv tə tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn."

Egwene let her head sag back against the wall. "I will have to try again."

"ɑɹ jə stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf?" ɪleɪn ɡɹɪməst. "tə bi blʌnt, jə saʊn ivən wikɝ ðən jə dɪd bɪfɔɹ. ðɪs tʃɹaɪ tʊk sʌmθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ju, ɛɡwin."

"Are you strong enough?" Elayne grimaced. "To be blunt, you sound even weaker than you did before. This try took something out of you, Egwene."

"aɪ æm stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf ðɛɹ." ʃi dɪd fil mɔɹ wɪɹi, lɛs stʃɹɔŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ oʊnli tʃæns ðət ʃi kəd si. ʃi sɛɾ əz mʌtʃ, ən ðɛɹ feɪsəz sɛd ðeɪ əɡɹid wɪð hɝ, haʊɛvɝ ɹɪlʌktənli.

"I am strong enough there." She did feel more weary, less strong, but it was their only chance that she could see. She said as much, and their faces said they agreed with her, however reluctantly.

"kæn jə ɡoʊ tə slip əɡɛn soʊ sun?" nɪneɪiv æsk faɪnəli.

"Can you go to sleep again so soon?" Nynaeve asked finally.

"sɪŋ tə mi." ɛɡwin mænədʒd ə smaɪl. "laɪk wən aɪ wɑz ə lɪɾəl ɡɝl. pliz?" hoʊldɪŋ nɪneɪivz hænd wɪð wʌn ə hɝz, ðə stoʊn ɹɪŋ klæspt ɪn ði ʌðɝ, ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz ən tʃɹaɪd tə faɪn slip ɪn ðə wɝdləs hʌmɪŋ tun.

"Sing to me." Egwene managed a smile. "Like when I was a little girl. Please?" Holding Nynaeve's hand with one of hers, the stone ring clasped in the other, she closed her eyes and tried to find sleep in the wordless humming tune.

ðə waɪd dɔɹ ʌv aɪɝn bɑɹz stʊɾ oʊpən, ən ðə ɹum bɪɑn simd ɛmpti ʌv laɪf, bʌt mæt ɛntɝd kɔʃəsli. sændɑɹ wɑz stɪl aʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɪɹ boʊθ weɪz ət wʌns, sɝɾən ðəɾ ə haɪ lɔɹd, əɹ meɪbi ə hʌnʒɹəd dɪfɛndɝz əɹ soʊ, wəɾ əpɪɹ əɾ ɛni moʊmənt.

The wide door of iron bars stood open, and the room beyond seemed empty of life, but Mat entered cautiously. Sandar was still out in the hall, trying to peer both ways at once, certain that a High Lord, or maybe a hundred Defenders or so, would appear at any moment.

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɛn ɪn ðə ɹum naʊ - ən baɪ ðə lʊks ə ðə hæf-iɾən milz ɑn ə lɔŋ teɪbəl, ðeɪ hæd lɛf hɝidli; noʊ daʊt kəz ə ðə faɪɾɪŋ əbʌv - ən fɹəm ðə lʊks ə ðə θɪŋz ɑn ðə wɔlz, hi wɑz dʒʌst əz ɡlæɾ i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə miɾ ɛni ʌv ðɛm. wɪps ɪn dɪfɹən saɪzəz ən lɛŋθs, dɪfɹən θɪknəsəz, wɪð dɪfɹənt nʌmbɝz ə teɪlz. pɪnsɝz, ən tɑŋz, ən klæmps, ən aɪɝnz. θɪŋz ðət lʊk laɪk mɛɾəl buts, ən ɡɔnləts, ən hɛlməts, wɪð ɡɹeɪt skɹuz ɔl oʊvɝ əm əz ɪf tə taɪɾən əm daʊn. θɪŋz i kəd nɑɾ ivən bɪɡɪn tə ɡɛs ðə jus ʌv. ɪf i hæd mɛt ðə mɛn u juz ðiz θɪŋz, hi θɔɾ i wəd ʃʊɹli hæv tʃɛk ðət ðeɪ wɝ dɛd bɪfɔɹ i wɔkt əweɪ.

There were no men in the room now - and by the looks of the half-eaten meals on a long table, they had left hurriedly; no doubt because of the fighting above - and from the looks of the things on the walls, he was just as glad he did not have to meet any of them. Whips in different sizes and lengths, different thicknesses, with different numbers of tails. Pincers, and tongs, and clamps, and irons. Things that looked like metal boots, and gauntlets, and helmets, with great screws all over them as if to tighten them down. Things he could not even begin to guess the use of. If he had met the men who used these things, he thought he would surely have checked that they were dead before he walked away.

"sændɑɹ!" hi hɪst. "ɑɹ jə gɑnə steɪ aʊt ðəɹ ɔl blʌɾi naɪt!" hi hɝid tə ði ɪnɝ dɔɹ - bɑɹd laɪk ði aʊɾɝ, bʌt smɔlɝ - wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ænsɝ, ən wɛn θɹu.

"Sandar!" he hissed. "Are you going to stay out there all bloody night!" He hurried to the inner door - barred like the outer, but smaller - without waiting for an answer, and went through.

ðə hɔl bɪɑnd wɑz laɪn baɪ ɹʌf wʊɾən dɔɹz, ən lɪt baɪ ðə seɪm ɹʌʃ tɔɹtʃɪz əz ðə ɹum i hæd dʒʌs lɛft. noʊ mɔɹ ðən twɛnti peɪsɪz fɹəm hɪm, ə wʊmən sæɾ ɑn ə bɛntʃ bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə dɔɹz, linɪŋ bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl ɪn ə kjʊɹiəsli stɪf fæʃən. ʃi tɝn əɹ hɛd sloʊli təwɔɹɾ ɪm ət ðə saʊn ə hɪz buts ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə stoʊn. ə pɹɪɾi jʌŋ wʊmən. hi wʌndɝd waɪ ʃi dɪd nɑt muv mɔɹ ðən əɹ hɛd, ən waɪ ivən ðət muvd əz ɪf ʃi wɝ hæf-əslip.

The hall beyond was lined by rough wooden doors, and lit by the same rush torches as the room he had just left. No more than twenty paces from him, a woman sat on a bench beside one of the doors, leaning back against the wall in a curiously stiff fashion. She turned her head slowly toward him at the sound of his boots grating on the stone. A pretty young woman. He wondered why she did not move more than her head, and why even that moved as if she were half-asleep.

wɑz ʃi ə pɹɪznɝ? aʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔl? bʌt noʊbɑdi wɪð ə feɪs laɪk ðət kəd bi wʌn ə ðə pipəl u juzɪz ðə θɪŋz ɑn ðoʊz wɔlz. ʃi dɪd lʊk ɔlmoʊst əslip, wɪð əɹ aɪz oʊnli pɑɹtli oʊpən. ən ðə sʌfɝɪŋ ɑn ðət lʌvli feɪs ʃʊɹli meɪɾ əɹ wʌn ə ðə tɔɹtʃɝd, nɑɾ ə tɔɹtʃɝɝ.

Was she a prisoner? Out in the hall? But nobody with a face like that could be one of the people who uses the things on those walls. She did look almost asleep, with her eyes only partly open. And the suffering on that lovely face surely made her one of the tortured, not a torturer.

"stɑp!" sændɑɹ ʃaʊɾəd bɪhaɪn hɪm. "ʃi ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ! ʃiz wʌn ə ðoʊz u tʊk ðə wɪmən jə sik!"

"Stop!" Sandar shouted behind him. "She is Aes Sedai! She is one of those who took the women you seek!"

mæt fɹoʊz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə stɛp, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wʊmən. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd mɔɪɹeɪn hɝlɪŋ bɔlz ə faɪɝ. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf i kəd dɪflɛkt ə bɔl ə faɪɝ wɪð ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɪz lʌk ɪkstɛndəd tə aʊtʃɹʌnɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Mat froze in the middle of a step, staring at the woman. He remembered Moiraine hurling balls of fire. He wondered if he could deflect a ball of fire with his quarterstaff. He wondered if his luck extended to outrunning Aes Sedai.

"hɛlp mi," ʃi sɛd feɪnli. hɝ aɪz stɪl lʊk nɪɹli əslip, bʌt ðə pliɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs wɑz fʊli əweɪk. "hɛlp mi. pliz!"

"Help me," she said faintly. Her eyes still looked nearly asleep, but the pleading in her voice was fully awake. "Help me. Please!"

mæt blɪŋkt. ʃi stɪl hæd nɑt muvd ə mʌsəl bɪloʊ hɝ nɛk. kɔʃəsli, hi stɛp kloʊsɝ, weɪvɪŋ tə sændɑɹ tə stɑp ɪz ɡɹoʊnɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi muvd əɹ hɛd tə fɑloʊ hɪm. noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt.

Mat blinked. She still had not moved a muscle below her neck. Cautiously, he stepped closer, waving to Sandar to stop his groaning about her being Aes Sedai. She moved her head to follow him. No more than that.

ə lɑɹdʒ aɪɝn ki hʌŋ əɾ əɹ bɛlt. fəɹ ə moʊmən i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ɛɛs sədaɪ, sændɑɹ sɛd. waɪ dʌznt ʃi muv? swɑloʊɪŋ, hi iz ðə ki fɹi əz kɛɹfəli əz ɪf i wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk ə pis ə mit fɹəm ə wʊlfs dʒɔz. ʃi ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ən meɪɾ ə saʊn laɪk ə kæt ðət hæd dʒʌst sin ə hjudʒ dɔɡ kʌm snɑɹlɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum ən nu ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ aʊt.

A large iron key hung at her belt. For a moment he hesitated. Aes Sedai, Sandar said. Why doesn't she move? Swallowing, he eased the key free as carefully as if he were trying to take a piece of meat from a wolf's jaws. She rolled her eyes toward the door beside her and made a sound like a cat that had just seen a huge dog come snarling into the room and knew there was no way out.

hi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt, bʌɾ əz lɔŋ əz ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp ɪm oʊpənɪŋ ðət dɔɹ, hi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ waɪ ʃi dʒʌst sæt ðəɹ laɪk ə stʌf skɑɹɛkɹoʊ. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd wɝθ biɪŋ əfɹeɪɾ ʌv. ɪf ʃiz wʌn ə ðoʊz u tʊk ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz, ɪt stænz tə ɹizən ʃiz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðɛm. tɪɹz lik fɹəm ðə wʊmənz aɪz. oʊnli ʃi lʊks laɪk ɪts ə blʌɾi hæfmən ɪn ðɛɹ. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə faɪn aʊt. pɹɑpɪŋ ɪz stæf əɡɛns ðə wɔl, hi tɝn ðə ki ɪn ðə lɑk ən flʌŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, ɹɛɾi tə ɹʌn ɪf nid bi.

He did not understand it, but as long as she did not try to stop him opening that door, he did not care why she just sat there like a stuffed scarecrow. On the other hand, he wondered if there was something on the other side worth being afraid of. If she is one of those who took Egwene and the others, it stands to reason she's guarding them. Tears leaked from the woman's eyes. Only she looks like it's a bloody Halfman in there. But there was only one way to find out. Propping his staff against the wall, he turned the key in the lock and flung open the door, ready to run if need be.

nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɝ nilɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ wɪð ɛɡwin əpɛɹənli əslip bɪtwin ðɛm. hi ɡæspt ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɛɡwinz swoʊlən feɪs, ən tʃeɪnʒd ɪz maɪn əbaʊɾ əɹ slipɪŋ. ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən tɝn təwɔɹɾ ɪm əz i oʊpən ðə dɔɹ - ðeɪ wɝ ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾɝd əz ɛɡwin; bɝn mi! bɝn mi! - lʊkt ət hɪm, ən ɡeɪpt.

Nynaeve and Elayne were kneeling on the floor with Egwene apparently asleep between them. He gasped at the sight of Egwene's swollen face, and changed his mind about her sleeping. The other two women turned toward him as he opened the door - they were almost as battered as Egwene; Burn me! Burn me! - looked at him, and gaped.

"meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," nɪneɪiv sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ʃɑkt, "wʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?"

"Matrim Cauthon," Nynaeve said, sounding shocked, "what under the Light are you doing here?"

"aɪ keɪm tə blʌɾi ɹɛskju ju," hi sɛd. "bɝn mi ɪf aɪ ɪkspɛktəd tə bi ɡɹiɾəd əz ɪf aɪ hæd kʌm tə stil ə paɪ. jə kən tɛl mi waɪ jə lʊk əz ɪf jud bɪn faɪɾɪŋ bɛɹz leɪɾɝ, ɪf jə wɑnt. ɪf ɛɡwin kænɑt wɔk, əl kæɹi hɝ ɑn maɪ bæk. ðəɹ ɑɹ il ɔl oʊvɝ ðə stoʊn, əɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf, ən iðɝ ðeɪ ɑɹ kɪlɪŋ ðə blʌɾi dɪfɛndɝz əɹ ðə blʌɾi dɪfɛndɝz ɑɹ kɪlɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt wɪtʃɛvɝ weɪ ɪɾ ɪz, wi hæd bɛɾɝ ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ waɪl wi blʌɾi wɛl kæn. ɪf wi kæn!"

"I came to bloody rescue you," he said. "Burn me if I expected to be greeted as if I had come to steal a pie. You can tell me why you look as if you'd been fighting bears later, if you want. If Egwene cannot walk, I'll carry her on my back. There are Aiel all over the Stone, or near enough, and either they are killing the bloody Defenders or the bloody Defenders are killing them, but whichever way it is, we had better get out of here while we bloody well can. If we can!"

"maɪn jəɹ læŋɡwədʒ," nɪneɪiv toʊl hɪm, ən ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ɪm wʌn ə ðoʊz dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ stɛɹz wɪmən wɝ soʊ ɡʊɾ æt. niðɝ wʌn sim tə hæv əɹ fʊl ətɛnʃən ɪn ɪt, ðoʊ. ðeɪ bɪɡæn ʃeɪkɪŋ ɛɡwin əz ɪf ʃi wɝ nɑt kʌvɝd wɪð mɔɹ bɹuzəz ðən i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ɪn ɪz laɪf.

"Mind your language," Nynaeve told him, and Elayne gave him one of those disapproving stares women were so good at. Neither one seemed to have her full attention in it, though. They began shaking Egwene as if she were not covered with more bruises than he had ever seen in his life.

ɛɡwinz aɪlɪdz flʌɾɝd oʊpən, ən ʃi ɡɹoʊnd. "waɪ dɪd jə weɪk mi? aɪ mʌst ʌndɝstæn ɪt. ɪf aɪ lus ðə bɑnz ɑn hɝ, ʃɪl weɪk ən əl nɛvɝ kætʃ əɹ əɡɛn. bʌɾ ɪf aɪ də nɑt, ʃi kænɑt ɡoʊ ɔl ðə weɪ tə slip, ən - " hɝ aɪz fɛl ɑn ɪm ən waɪɾənd. "meɪtʃɹim kɔθən, wʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?"

Egwene's eyelids fluttered open, and she groaned. "Why did you wake me? I must understand it. If I loose the bonds on her, she will wake and I'll never catch her again. But if I do not, she cannot go all the way to sleep, and - " Her eyes fell on him and widened. "Matrim Cauthon, what under the Light are you doing here?"

"ju tɛl hɝ," hi toʊl nɪneɪiv. "aɪ æm tu bɪzi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɛskju jə tə wɑtʃ maɪ læŋɡʌ - " ðeɪ wɝ ɔl stɛɹɪŋ bɪɑn hɪm, ɡlɛɹɪŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɪʃt ðeɪ hæd naɪvz ɪn ðɛɹ hænz.

"You tell her," he told Nynaeve. "I am too busy trying to rescue you to watch my langu - " They were all staring beyond him, glaring as if they wished they had knives in their hands.

hi spʌn, bʌɾ ɔl i sɔ wɑz dʒulɪn sændɑɹ, lʊkɪŋ əz ɪf i hæd swɑloʊɾ ə ɹɑɾən plʌm hoʊl.

He spun, but all he saw was Juilin Sandar, looking as if he had swallowed a rotten plum whole.

"ðeɪ hæv kɑz," hi toʊl mæt. "aɪ. . . . aɪ bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛm. bʌɾ aɪ hæd təðæt wɑz ədʒɹɛs pæs mæt tə ðə wɪmən. "ðə wʌn wɪð mɛni hʌni-kʌlɝd bɹeɪdz spoʊk tə mi, ən aɪ. . . . aɪ hæd tə də ɪt." fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən ðə θɹi kəntɪnjud tə stɛɹ.

"They have cause," he told Mat. "I. . . . I betrayed them. But I had to."That was addressed past Mat to the women. "The one with many honey-colored braids spoke to me, and I. . . . I had to do it." For a long moment the three continued to stare.

"liɑnʒɹɪn əz vaɪl tʃɹɪks, mæstɝ sændɑɹ," nɪneɪiv sɛd faɪnəli. "pɝhæps jə ɑɹ nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli tə bleɪm. wi kən əpɔɹʃən ɡɪlt leɪɾɝ."

"Liandrin has vile tricks, Master Sandar," Nynaeve said finally. "Perhaps you are not entirely to blame. We can apportion guilt later."

"ɪf ðəɾ ɪz ɔl klɪɹɾ ʌp," mæt sɛd, "kʊd wi ɡoʊ naʊ?" ɪt wɑz əz klɪɹ əz mʌd tə hɪm, bʌɾ i wɑz mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn livɪŋ ɹaɪt ðɛn.

"If that is all cleared up," Mat said, "could we go now?" It was as clear as mud to him, but he was more interested in leaving right then.

ðə θɹi wɪmən lɪmpt æftɝ ɪm ɪndə ðə hɔl, bʌt ðeɪ stɑpt ɝaʊn ðə wʊmən ɑn ðə bɛntʃ. ʃi ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz əɾ əm ən wɪmpɝd. "pliz. əl kʌm bæk tə ðə laɪt. əl swɛɹ tə oʊbeɪ ju. wɪð ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ɪn maɪ hænz əl swɛɹ. pliz də nɑt - "

The three women limped after him into the hall, but they stopped around the woman on the bench. She rolled her eyes at them and whimpered. "Please. I will come back to the Light. I will swear to obey you. With the Oath Rod in my hands I will swear. Please do not - "

mæt dʒʌmpt əz nɪneɪiv sʌɾənli ɹɪɹd bæk ən swʌŋ ə fɪst, nɑkɪŋ ðə wʊmən kəmplitli ɔf ðə bɛntʃ. ʃi leɪ ðɛɹ, hɝ aɪz kloʊzd ɔl ðə weɪ faɪnəli, bʌɾ ivən laɪɪŋ ɑn əɹ saɪd ʃi wɑz stɪl ɪn ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm pəzɪʃən ʃi hæd bɪn ɪn ɑn ðə bɛntʃ.

Mat jumped as Nynaeve suddenly reared back and swung a fist, knocking the woman completely off the bench. She lay there, her eyes closed all the way finally, but even lying on her side she was still in exactly the same position she had been in on the bench.

"ɪɾ ɪz ɡɔn," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪksaɪɾədli.

"It is gone," Elayne said excitedly.

ɛɡwin bɛn tə ɹʌmɪdʒ ɪn ði ʌnkɑnʃəs wʊmənz paʊtʃ, tʃɹænsfɝɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ mæt kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt tə hɝ oʊn. "jɛs. ɪt filz wʌndɝfəl. sʌmθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd əbaʊɾ əɹ wən jə hɪt hɝ, nɪneɪiv. aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌt, bʌɾ aɪ fɛlt ɪt."

Egwene bent to rummage in the unconscious woman's pouch, transferring something Mat could not make out to her own. "Yes. It feels wonderful. Something changed about her when you hit her, Nynaeve. I do not know what, but I felt it."
