ɪleɪn nɑɾəd. "aɪ fɛlt ɪt, tu."

Elayne nodded. "I felt it, too."

"aɪ wəd laɪk tə tʃeɪnʒ ɛvɹi læs θɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd ɡɹɪmli. ʃi tʊk ɛɡwinz hɛɾ ɪn əɹ hænz; ɛɡwin ɹoʊz ɑntu hɝ toʊz, ɡæspɪŋ. wən nɪneɪiv tʊk əɹ hænz əweɪ tə pʊɾ əm ɑn ɪleɪn, ɛɡwinz bɹuzəz wɝ ɡɔn. ɪleɪnz vænɪʃt əz kwɪkli.

"I would like to change every last thing about her," Nynaeve said grimly. She took Egwene's head in her hands; Egwene rose onto her toes, gasping. When Nynaeve took her hands away to put them on Elayne, Egwene's bruises were gone. Elayne's vanished as quickly.

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!" mæt ɡɹaʊld. "wʌt dʒju min hɪɾɪŋ ə wʊmən u wɑz dʒʌst sɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ? aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ʃi kəɾ ivən muv!" ðeɪ ɔl θɹi tɝn tə lʊk ət hɪm, ən i meɪɾ ə stʃɹæŋɡəl saʊn əz ði ɛɹ sim tə tɝn tə θɪk dʒɛli ɝaʊn hɪm. hi lɪftəɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ, əntɪl ɪz buts dæŋɡəld ə ɡʊd peɪs əbʌv ðə flɔɹ. oʊ, bɝn mi, ðə paʊɝ! hɪɹ aɪ wɑz əfɹeɪd ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd juz ðə blʌɾi paʊɝ ɑn mi, ən naʊ ðə blʌɾi wɪmən aɪm ɹɛskjuɪŋ də ɪt! bɝn mi!

"Blood and bloody ashes!" Mat growled. "What do you mean hitting a woman who was just sitting there? I don't think she could even move!" They all three turned to look at him, and he made a strangled sound as the air seemed to turn to thick jelly around him. He lifted into the air, until his boots dangled a good pace above the floor. Oh, burn me, the Power! Here I was afraid that Aes Sedai would use the bloody Power on me, and now the bloody women I'm rescuing do it! Burn me!

"ju də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɛniθɪŋ, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs.

"You do not understand anything, Matrim Cauthon," Egwene said in a tight voice.

"əntɪl jə də ʌndɝstænd," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ən ivən taɪɾɝ, "aɪ sədʒɛs jə kip jəɹ əpɪnjənz tə jɝsɛlf."

"Until you do understand," Nynaeve said in an even tighter, "I suggest you keep your opinions to yourself."

ɪleɪn kəntɛntəd hɝsɛlf wɪð ə ɡlɛɹ ðət meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə hɪz mʌðɝ ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt tə kʌɾ ə swɪtʃ.

Elayne contented herself with a glare that made him think of his mother going out to cut a switch.

fəɹ səm ɹizən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɡɪvɪŋ əm ðə ɡɹɪn ðət hæd soʊ ɔfən sɛn ɪz mʌðɝ æftɝ ðət swɪtʃ. bɝn mi, ɪf ðeɪ kən də ðɪs, aɪ doʊn si haʊ ɛnibəɾi ɛvɝ lɑkt əm ɪn ðət sɛl ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs! "wʌɾ aɪ ʌndɝstæn ɪz ðəɾ aɪ ɡɑt jə aʊɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ jə kʊdnt ɡɛt jʊɹsɛlvz aʊɾ ʌv, ən jə ɔl əv əz mʌtʃ ɡɹæɾətud əz ə blʌɾi tɛɹən fɛɹi mæn wɪð ə tuθæk!"

For some reason he found himself giving them the grin that had so often sent his mother after that switch. Burn me, if they can do this, I don't see how anybody ever locked them in that cell in the first place! "What I understand is that I got you out of something you couldn't get yourselves out of, and you all have as much gratitude as a bloody Taren Ferry man with a toothache!"

"ju ɑɹ ɹaɪt," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ən ɪz buts sʌɾənli hɪt ðə flɔɹ soʊ hɑɹɾ ɪz tiθ dʒɑɹd. bʌɾ i kəd muv əɡɛn. "æz mʌtʃ əz ɪt peɪnz mi tə seɪ ɪt, mæt, jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt."

"You are right," Nynaeve said, and his boots suddenly hit the floor so hard his teeth jarred. But he could move again. "As much as it pains me to say it, Mat, you are right."

hi wɑz tɛmptəd tə ænsɝ sʌmθɪŋ sɑɹkæstɪk, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ɪnʌf əpɑlədʒi ɪn əɹ vɔɪs əz ɪt wɑz. "naʊ kən wi ɡoʊ? wɪð ðə faɪɾɪŋ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn, sændɑɹ θɪŋks i ən aɪ kən teɪk jə aʊt baɪ ə smɔl ɡeɪt nɪɹ ðə ɹɪvɝ."

He was tempted to answer something sarcastic, but there was barely enough apology in her voice as it was. "Now can we go? With the fighting going on, Sandar thinks he and I can take you out by a small gate near the river."

"aɪ æm nɑt livɪŋ dʒʌs jɛt, mæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ min tə faɪn liɑnʒɹɪn ən skɪn hɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ʃi mɛn ɪt lɪɾɝəli.

"I am not leaving just yet, Mat," Nynaeve said. "I mean to find Liandrin and skin her," Egwene said, sounding almost as if she meant it literally.

"ɔl aɪ wɑnə du," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ɪz paʊn dʒɔɪjə bɝ tɪl ʃi skwilz, bʌɾ əl sɛɾəl fəɹ ɛni ʌv ðɛm."

"All I want to do," Elayne said, "is pound Joiya Byir till she squeals, but I will settle for any of them."

"ɑɹ jə ɔl dɛf?" hi ɡɹaʊld. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə bæɾəl ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn aʊt ðɛɹ! aɪ keɪm hɪɹ tə ɹɛskju ju, ən aɪ min tə ɹɛskju ju." ɛɡwin pæɾəd ɪz tʃik əz ʃi wɔk baɪ hɪm, ən soʊ dɪɾ ɪleɪn. nɪneɪiv mɪɹli snɪft. hi stɛɹɾ æftɝ əm wɪð ɪz maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən. "waɪ dɪdn jə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ?" hi ɡɹaʊld ət ðə θif-kætʃɝ.

"Are you all deaf?" he growled. "There is a battle going on out there! I came here to rescue you, and I mean to rescue you." Egwene patted his cheek as she walked by him, and so did Elayne. Nynaeve merely sniffed. He stared after them with his mouth hanging open. "Why didn't you say something?" he growled at the thief-catcher.

"aɪ sɔ wʌt spikɪŋ ɝn ju," sændɑɹ sɛd sɪmpli. "aɪ æm noʊ ful."

"I saw what speaking earned you," Sandar said simply. "I am no fool."

"wɛl, aɪm nɑt steɪɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə bæɾəl!" hi ʃaʊɾəd ət ðə wɪmən. ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ θɹu ðə smɔl, bɑɹd dɔɹ. "aɪ æm livɪŋ, dʒju hɪɹ?" ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ivən lʊk bæk. pɹɑbli ɡɛt ðɛmsɛlvz kɪld aʊt ðɛɹ! sʌmbɑɾi wɪl stɪk ə sɔɹɾ ɪn əm waɪl ðəɹ lʊkɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ! wɪð ə snɑɹl, hi pʊɾ ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən stɑɹɾəd æftɝ. "ɑɹ jə gɑnə stæn ðɛɹ?" hi kɔl tə ðə θif-kætʃɝ. "aɪ dɪd nɑt kʌm ðɪs fɑɹ tə lɛɾ əm daɪ naʊ!"

"Well, I am not staying in the middle of a battle!" he shouted at the women. They were just disappearing through the small, barred door. "I am leaving, do you hear?" They did not even look back. Probably get themselves killed out there! Somebody will stick a sword in them while they're looking the other way! With a snarl, he put his quarterstaff across his shoulder and started after. "Are you going to stand there?" he called to the thief-catcher. "I did not come this far to let them die now!"

sændɑɹ kɑɾ ʌp tə hɪm ɪn ðə ɹum wɪð ðə wɪps. ðə θɹi wɪmən wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɔn, bʌt mæt hæɾ ə filɪŋ ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi tu hɑɹd tə faɪnd. dʒʌs faɪn ðə mɛn blʌɾi hæŋɪŋ ɪn mɪdɛɹ! blʌɾi wɪmən! hi kwɪkən ɪz peɪs tə ə tʃɹɑt.

Sandar caught up to him in the room with the whips. The three women were already gone, but Mat had a feeling they would not be too hard to find. Just find the men bloody hanging in midair! Bloody women! He quickened his pace to a trot.

pɛɹɪn stʃɹoʊd daʊn ðə hɔlz ə ðə stoʊn ɡɹɪmli, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ səm saɪn ə feɪl. hi hæd ɹɛskjuɾ əɹ twaɪs mɔɹ, naʊ, bɹeɪkɪŋ əɹ aʊɾ ʌv ən aɪɝn keɪdʒ wʌns, mʌtʃ laɪk ðə wʌn ðət hæd hɛl ði il ɪn ɹɛmən, ən wʌns bɹeɪkɪŋ oʊpən ə stil tʃɛst wɪð ə fælkən wɝkt ɑn ɪts saɪd. boʊθ taɪmz ʃi hæd mɛltəɾ ɪndə ɛɹ æftɝ seɪɪŋ ɪz neɪm. hɑpɝ tʃɹɑɾəd baɪ hɪz saɪd, snɪfɪŋ ði ɛɹ. əz ʃɑɹp əz pɛɹɪnz noʊz wɑz, ðə wʊlfs wɑz ʃɑɹpɝ; ɪt hæd bɪn hɑpɝ u lɛɾ əm tə ðə tʃɛst.

Perrin strode down the halls of the Stone grimly, searching for some sign of Faile. He had rescued her twice more, now, breaking her out of an iron cage once, much like the one that had held the Aiel in Remen, and once breaking open a steel chest with a falcon worked on its side. Both times she had melted into air after saying his name. Hopper trotted by his side, sniffing the air. As sharp as Perrin's nose was, the wolf's was sharper; it had been Hopper who led them to the chest.

pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ i wɑz ɛvɝ gɑnə fɹi hɝ ɪn tʃɹuθ. ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn ɛni saɪn ɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm, ɪt simd. ðə hɔlz ə ðə stoʊn wɝ ɛmpti, læmps bɝnɪŋ, tæpəstʃɹiz ən wɛpənz hæŋɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔlz, bʌt nʌθɪŋ muvd ɪksɛp hɪmsɛlf ən hɑpɝ. ɪksɛpt aɪ θɪŋk ðət wɑz ɹænd. ɪt hæɾ oʊnli bɪn ə ɡlɪmps, ə mæn ɹʌnɪŋ əz ɪf tʃeɪsɪŋ sʌmwʌn. ɪt kəd nɑt bi hɪm. ɪt kʊdnt, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ɪt wɑz.

Perrin wondered whether he was ever going to free her in truth. There had not been any sign in a long time, it seemed. The halls of the Stone were empty, lamps burning, tapestries and weapons hanging on the walls, but nothing moved except himself and Hopper. Except I think that was Rand. It had only been a glimpse, a man running as if chasing someone. It could not be him. It couldn't, but I think it was.

hɑpɝ kwɪkən ɪz stɛps sʌɾənli, hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ sɛɾ ə tɔl dɔɹz, ðiz klæɾ ɪn bɹɑnz. pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə mætʃ ðə peɪs, stʌmbəld, ən fɛl tə hɪz niz, θɹoʊɪŋ aʊɾ ə hæn tə kætʃ hɪmsɛlf ʃɔɹɾ ə dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs. wiknəs wɑʃt θɹu hɪm əz ɪf ɔl ɪz mʌsəlz hæd ɡɔn tə wɔɾɝ. ivən æftɝ ðə filɪŋ ɹəsiɾəd, ɪt tʊk səm ə hɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð ɪt. ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt tə stʃɹʌɡəl tə hɪz fit. hɑpɝ hæd tɝn tə lʊk ət hɪm.

Hopper quickened his steps suddenly, heading for another set of tall doors, these clad in bronze. Perrin tried to match the pace, stumbled, and fell to his knees, throwing out a hand to catch himself short of dropping on his face. Weakness washed through him as if all his muscles had gone to water. Even after the feeling receded, it took some of his strength with it. It was an effort to struggle to his feet. Hopper had turned to look at him.

jə ɑɹ hɪɹ tu stʃɹɔŋli, jʌŋ bʊl. ðə flɛʃ wikənz. jə də nɑt kɛɹ tə hoʊld ɑn tə ɪɾ ɪnʌf. sun flɛʃ ən dʒɹim wɪl daɪ təɡɛðɝ.

You are here too strongly, Young Bull. The flesh weakens. You do not care to hold on to it enough. Soon flesh and dream will die together.

"faɪn hɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz ɔl aɪ æsk. faɪn feɪl."

"Find her," Perrin said. "That is all I ask. Find Faile."

jɛloʊ aɪz mɛt jɛloʊ aɪz. ðə wʊlf tɝn ən tʃɹɑɾəd tə ðə dɔɹz. bɪɑn hɪɹ, jʌŋ bʊl.

Yellow eyes met yellow eyes. The wolf turned and trotted to the doors. Beyond here, Young Bull.

pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt ðə dɔɹz ən pʊʃt. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt bʌdʒ. ðəɹ sim tə bi noʊ weɪ tə oʊpən ðɛm, noʊ hændəlz, nʌθɪŋ tə ɡɹɪp. ðəɹ wɑz ə taɪni pæɾɝn wɝkt ɪndə ðə mɛɾəl, soʊ faɪn ɪz aɪz ɔlmoʊs dɪd nɑt si ɪt. fælkənz. θaʊzənz ə taɪni fælkənz.

Perrin reached the doors and pushed. They did not budge. There seemed to be no way to open them, no handles, nothing to grip. There was a tiny pattern worked into the metal, so fine his eyes almost did not see it. Falcons. Thousands of tiny falcons.

ʃiz tə bi hɪɹ. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk aɪ kən læs mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ. wɪð ə ʃaʊt, hi swʌŋ ɪz hæmɝ əɡɛns ðə bɹɑnz. ɪt ɹæŋ laɪk ə ɡɹeɪt ɡɔŋ. əɡɛn i stʃɹʌk, ən ðə pil dipənd. ə θɝd bloʊ, ən ðə bɹɑnz dɔɹz ʃæɾɝd laɪk ɡlæs.

She has to be here. I do not think I can last much longer. With a shout, he swung his hammer against the bronze. It rang like a great gong. Again he struck, and the peal deepened. A third blow, and the bronze doors shattered like glass.

wɪðɪn, ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə bɹoʊkən dɔɹz, ə sɝkəl ə laɪt sɝaʊndəɾ ə fælkən tʃeɪn tə ə pɝtʃ. dɑɹknəs fɪld ɔl ðə ɹɛst ə ðət væs tʃeɪmbɝ, dɑɹknəs ən feɪn ɹʌsəlɪŋz əz ə hʌnʒɹədz ʌv wɪŋz.

Within, a hundred paces from the broken doors, a circle of light surrounded a falcon chained to a perch. Darkness filled all the rest of that vast chamber, darkness and faint rustlings as of hundreds of wings.

hi tʊk ə stɛp ɪndə ðə ɹum, ən ə fælkən stupt aʊɾ ə ðə mɝk, təlɑnz skɔɹɪŋ ɪz feɪs əz ɪt pæst. hi θɹu ən ɑɹm əkɹɔs ɪz aɪz - təlɑnz tɔɹ əɾ ɪz fɔɹɑɹm - ən stæɡɝd təwɔɹd ðə pɝtʃ. əɡɛn ən əɡɛn ðə bɝdz keɪm, fælkənz daɪvɪŋ, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ hɪm, tɛɹɪŋ hɪm, bʌɾ i lʌmbɝɾ ɑn wɪð blʌd pɔɹɪŋ daʊn ɪz ɑɹmz ən ʃoʊldɝz, ðət wʌn ɑɹm pɹətɛktɪŋ ði aɪz i hæd fɪkst ɑn ðə fælkən ɑn ðə pɝtʃ. hi hæd lɔs ðə hæmɝ; hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ, bʌɾ i nu ðəɾ ɪf i wɛn bæk tə sɝtʃ, hi wəd daɪ bɪfɔɹ i faʊn ɪt.

He took a step into the room, and a falcon stooped out of the murk, talons scoring his face as it passed. He threw an arm across his eyes - talons tore at his forearm - and staggered toward the perch. Again and again the birds came, falcons diving, striking him, tearing him, but he lumbered on with blood pouring down his arms and shoulders, that one arm protecting the eyes he had fixed on the falcon on the perch. He had lost the hammer; he did not know where, but he knew that if he went back to search, he would die before he found it.

əz i ɹitʃt ðə pɝtʃ, ðə slaɪsɪŋ təlɑnz dʒɹoʊv ɪm tə hɪz niz. hi pɪɹɾ ʌp ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm ət ðə fælkən ɑn ðə pɝtʃ, ən ʃi stɛɹd bæk wɪð dɑɹk, ənblɪŋkɪŋ aɪz. ðə tʃeɪn ðət hɛld əɹ lɛɡ wɑz fæsən tə ðə pɝtʃ wɪð ə taɪni lɑk ʃeɪp laɪk ə hɛdʒhɑɡ. hi siz ðə tʃeɪn wɪð boʊθ hænz, kɛɹləs ə ði ʌðɝ fælkənz ðət naʊ bɪkeɪm ə wɝlwɪn ə kʌɾɪŋ təlɑnz ɝaʊn hɪm, ən wɪð ɪz læst stʃɹɛŋkθ snæpt ɪt. peɪn ən ðə fælkənz bɹɔt dɑɹknəs.

As he reached the perch, the slicing talons drove him to his knees. He peered up under his arm at the falcon on the perch, and she stared back with dark, unblinking eyes. The chain that held her leg was fastened to the perch with a tiny lock shaped like a hedgehog. He seized the chain with both hands, careless of the other falcons that now became a whirlwind of cutting talons around him, and with his last strength snapped it. Pain and the falcons brought darkness.

hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz tə stɪŋɪŋ æɡəni, əz ɪf ɪz feɪs ən ɑɹmz ən ʃoʊldɝz hæd bɪn slaɪst wɪð ə θaʊzənd naɪvz. ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. feɪl wɑz nilɪŋ oʊvɝ hɪm, ðoʊz dɑɹk, tɪltəɾ aɪz fɪld wɪð wɝi, waɪpɪŋ ɪz feɪs wɪð ə klɔθ ɔlɹɛɾi soʊkt ɪn ɪz blʌd.

He opened his eyes to stinging agony, as if his face and arms and shoulders had been sliced with a thousand knives. It did not matter. Faile was kneeling over him, those dark, tilted eyes filled with worry, wiping his face with a cloth already soaked in his blood.

"maɪ pʊɹ pɛɹɪn," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "maɪ pʊɹ blæksmɪθ. jə ɑɹ hɝt soʊ bædli."

"My poor Perrin," she said softly. "My poor blacksmith. You are hurt so badly."

wɪð ən ɛfɝt ðət kɑs mɔɹ peɪn, hi tɝn ɪz hɛd. ðɪs wɑz ðə pɹaɪvət daɪnɪŋ ɹum ɪn ðə stɑɹ, ən nɪɹ wʌn lɛɡ ʌv ðə teɪbəl leɪ ə wʊɾən kɑɹvɪŋ ʌv ə hɛdʒhɑɡ, bɹoʊkən ɪn hæf. "feɪl," hi wɪspɝd tə hɝ. "maɪ fælkən."

With an effort that cost more pain, he turned his head. This was the private dining room in the Star, and near one leg of the table lay a wooden carving of a hedgehog, broken in half. "Faile," he whispered to her. "My falcon."

ɹænd wɑz stɪl ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dɪfɹənt. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɛn faɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ, noʊ dɛd mɛn, noʊ wʌn əɾ ɔl bʌt hɪmsɛlf. əbɹʌpli ðə saʊn ʌv ə ɡɹeɪt ɡɔŋ ɹæŋ θɹu ðə stoʊn, ðən əɡɛn, ən ðə vɛɹi stoʊnz bɪniθ ɪz fit ɹɛzəneɪɾɪd. ə θɝd taɪm ðə bumɪŋ keɪm, bʌt kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli, əz ɪf ðə ɡɔŋ hæd ʃæɾɝd. ɔl wɑz stɪl.

Rand was still in the Heart of the Stone, but it was different. There were no men fighting here, no dead men, no one at all but himself. Abruptly the sound of a great gong rang through the Stone, then again, and the very stones beneath his feet resonated. A third time the booming came, but cut off abruptly, as if the gong had shattered. All was still.

wɛɹ ɪz ðɪs pleɪs? hi wʌndɝd. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, wɛɹ ɪz bælzəmən?

Where is this place? he wondered. More important, where is Ba'alzamon?

əz ɪf tə ænsɝ hɪm, ə bleɪzɪŋ ʃæf laɪk ðə wʌn mɔɪɹeɪn hæd meɪd ʃɑɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz, stʃɹeɪt təwɔɹɾ ɪz tʃɛst. hɪz ɹɪs twɪstəd ðə sɔɹɾ ɪnstɪŋktɪvli; ɪt wɑz ɪnstɪŋkt əz mʌtʃ əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ðət meɪɾ ɪm lus floʊz fɹəm seɪɾɪn ɪndə kælændɝ, ə flʌɾ ə ðə paʊɝ ðət meɪd ðə sɔɹd bleɪz bɹaɪɾɝ ivən ðən ðət bɑɹ stʃɹikɪŋ ət hɪm. hɪz ənsɝɾən bæləns bɪtwin ɛɡzɪstəns ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən weɪvɝd. ʃʊɹli ðət tɔɹənt wəd kənsum hɪm.

As if to answer him, a blazing shaft like the one Moiraine had made shot out of the shadows among the columns, straight toward his chest. His wrist twisted the sword instinctively; it was instinct as much as anything else that made him loose flows from saidin into Callandor, a flood of the Power that made the sword blaze brighter even than that bar streaking at him. His uncertain balance between existence and destruction wavered. Surely that torrent would consume him.

ðə ʃæft ə laɪt stʃɹʌk ðə bleɪɾ ə kælændɝ - ən pɑɹɾəd ɑn ɪts ɛdʒ, fɔɹkɪŋ tə stʃɹim pæst ɑn iðɝ saɪd. hi fɛlt ɪz koʊt sɪnʒ fɹəm ɪts nɪɹ pæsədʒ, smɛl ðə wʊl bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə bɝn. bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðə tu pɹɔŋz ə fɹoʊzən faɪɝ, ʌv lɪkwəd laɪt, stʃɹʌk hjudʒ ɹɛdstoʊn kɑləmz; wɛɹ ðeɪ stʃɹʌk, stoʊn sis tə ɪɡzɪst, ən ðə bɝnɪŋ bɑɹz bɔɹd θɹu tə ʌðɝ kɑləmz, sɛvɝɪŋ ðoʊz ɪnstəntæniəsli əz wɛl. ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn ɹʌmbəld əz kɑləmz fɛl ən ʃæɾɝd ɪn klaʊdz ə dʌst, spɹeɪz ə stoʊn fɹæɡməns. wʌt fɛl ɪndə ðə laɪt, haʊɛvɝ, sɪmpli - wɑz nɑt, ɛnimɔɹ.

The shaft of light struck the blade of Callandor - and parted on its edge, forking to stream past on either side. He felt his coat singe from its near passage, smelled the wool beginning to burn. Behind him, the two prongs of frozen fire, of liquid light, struck huge redstone columns; where they struck, stone ceased to exist, and the burning bars bored through to other columns, severing those instantaneously as well. The Heart of the Stone rumbled as columns fell and shattered in clouds of dust, sprays of stone fragments. What fell into the light, however, simply - was not, anymore.

ə snɑɹl ə ɹeɪdʒ keɪm fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz, ən ðə bleɪzɪŋ ʃæft ə pjʊɹ waɪt hit vænɪʃt.

A snarl of rage came from the shadows, and the blazing shaft of pure white heat vanished.

ɹænd swʌŋ kælændɝ əz ɪf i wɝ stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ðə waɪt laɪɾ əbskjʊɹɪŋ ðə bleɪɾ ɪkstɛndəd, bleɪzd əhɛd, ən ʃɪɹd θɹu ðə ɹɛdstoʊn kɑləm ðət hɪd ðə snɑɹl. ðə pɑlɪʃt stoʊn slaɪs laɪk sɪlk. ðə sɛvɝd kɑləm tʃɹɛmbəld; pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt tɔɹ lus ən dʒɹɑp fɹəm ðə silɪŋ, smæʃɪŋ ɪndə hjudʒ, dʒæɡd tʃʌŋks ɑn ðə flɔɹ. əz ðə ɹʌmbəlɪŋ feɪɾəd, hi hɝd bɪɑn ɪt ðə saʊn ə buts ɑn stoʊn. ɹʌnɪŋ.

Rand swung Callandor as if he were striking at something in front of him. The white light obscuring the blade extended, blazed ahead, and sheared through the redstone column that hid the snarl. The polished stone sliced like silk. The severed column trembled; part of it tore loose and dropped from the ceiling, smashing into huge, jagged chunks on the floor. As the rumbling faded, he heard beyond it the sound of boots on stone. Running.

kælændɝ ət ðə ɹɛɾi, ɹænd hɝiɾ æftɝ bælzəmən.

Callandor at the ready, Rand hurried after Ba'alzamon.

ðə tɔl ɑɹtʃweɪ liɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə hɑɹt kəlæpst əz i ɹitʃt ɪt, ði ɪntaɪɝ wɔl fɔlɪŋ ɪn klaʊdz ə dʌst ən ɹɑk əz ɪf tə bɛɹi hɪm, bʌɾ i θɹu ðə paʊɝ əɾ ɪt, ən ɔl bɪkeɪm dʌs floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. hi ɹæn ɑn. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i hæd dʌn, əɹ haʊ, bʌɾ i hæd noʊ taɪm tə θɪŋk ɑn ɪt. hi ɹæn æftɝ bælzəmənz ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ fʊtstɛps, ɛkoʊɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔlz ə ðə stoʊn.

The tall archway leading out of the Heart collapsed as he reached it, the entire wall falling in clouds of dust and rock as if to bury him, but he threw the Power at it, and all became dust floating in the air. He ran on. He was not sure what he had done, or how, but he had no time to think on it. He ran after Ba'alzamon's retreating footsteps, echoing down the halls of the Stone.

mɹdʒɹɑl ən tʃɹɑləks lɛpt aʊɾ ə θɪn ɛɹ, hjudʒ bɛstʃəl ʃeɪps ən aɪləs feɪsəz dɪstɔɹɾəd wɪð ə ɹeɪdʒ tə kɪl, ɪn hʌnʒɹədz, soʊ ðeɪ dʒæm ðə hɔl bɪfɔɹ ɪm ən bɪhaɪnd, saɪð laɪk sɔɹdz ən bleɪdz ə dɛdli blæk stil sikɪŋ ɪz blʌd. wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ haʊ, hi tɝn əm tə veɪpɝ ðət pɑɹɾəd bɪfɔɹ ɪm - ən vænɪʃt. ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn ɪm sʌɾənli bɪkeɪm tʃoʊkɪŋ sʊt, klɑɡɪŋ ɪz nɑstʃɹəlz, ʃʌɾɪŋ ɔf bɹɛθ, bʌɾ i meɪɾ ɪt fɹɛʃ ɛɹ əɡɛn, ə kul mɪst. fleɪmz lɛp fɹəm ðə flɔɹ bɪniθ ɪz fit, spɝɾɪd fɹəm ðə wɔlz, ðə silɪŋ, fjʊɹiəs dʒɛts ðət flæʃt tæpəstʃɹiz ən ɹʌɡz, teɪbəlz ən tʃɛsts tə wɪsps ʌv æʃ, flʌŋ ɔɹnəməns ən læmps əhɛɾ ə ðɛm əz dʒɹɑps ə moʊltən, bɝnɪŋ ɡoʊld; hi smæʃt ðə faɪɝz flæt, hɑɹɾənd əm ɪndə ə ɹɛd ɡleɪz ɑn ðə ɹɑk.

Myrddraal and Trollocs leaped out of thin air, huge bestial shapes and eyeless faces distorted with a rage to kill, in hundreds, so they jammed the hall before him and behind, scythe like swords and blades of deadly black steel seeking his blood. Without knowing how, he turned them to vapor that parted before him - and vanished. The air around him suddenly became choking soot, clogging his nostrils, shutting off breath, but he made it fresh air again, a cool mist. Flames leaped from the floor beneath his feet, spurted from the walls, the ceiling, furious jets that flashed tapestries and rugs, tables and chests to wisps of ash, flung ornaments and lamps ahead of them as drops of molten, burning gold; he smashed the fires flat, hardened them into a red glaze on the rock.

ðə stoʊnz ɝaʊn ɪm feɪɾəd ɔlmoʊs tə mɪst; ðə stoʊn feɪɾəd. ɹiæləɾi tʃɹɛmbəld; hi kəd fil ɪɾ ənɹævəlɪŋ, fil hɪmsɛlf ənɹævəlɪŋ. hi wɑz biɪŋ pʊʃt aʊɾ ə ðə hɪɹ, ɪndə səm ʌðɝ pleɪs wɛɹ nʌθɪŋ ɪɡzɪstəɾ əɾ ɔl. kælændɝ bleɪzd ɪn ɪz hænz laɪk ðə sʌn tɪl i θɔɾ ɪt wəd mɛlt. hi θɔɾ i hɪmsɛlf wəd mɛl fɹəm ðə sɝdʒ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ θɹu hɪm, ðə flʌd ðəɾ i sʌmhaʊ dɝɛktəɾ ɪndə silɪŋ ʌp ðə hoʊl ðət hæɾ oʊpən ɝaʊn hɪm, ɪndə hoʊldɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɛɡzɪstəns. ðə stoʊn bɪkeɪm sɑləɾ əɡɛn.

The stones around him faded almost to mist; the Stone faded. Reality trembled; he could feel it unraveling, feel himself unraveling. He was being pushed out of the here, into some other place where nothing existed at all. Callandor blazed in his hands like the sun till he thought it would melt. He thought he himself would melt from the surge of the One Power through him, the flood that he somehow directed into sealing up the hole that had opened around him, into holding himself on the side of existence. The Stone became solid again.

hi kəd nɑɾ ivən bɪɡɪn tə ɪmædʒən wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðəɾ i dɪd. ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɹeɪdʒd ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm tɪl i bɛɹli nu hɪmsɛlf, tɪl i bɛɹli wɑz hɪmsɛlf, tɪl wʌt wɑz hɪmsɛlf ɔlmoʊs dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst. hɪz pɹikɛɹiəs stəbɪlɪɾi tiɾɝd. tə iðɝ saɪd leɪ ði ɛnləs fɔl, əbliɾɝeɪʃən baɪ ðə paʊɝ ðət kɔɹs θɹu hɪm ɪndə ðə sɔɹd. oʊnli ɪn ðə dæns əlɔŋ ðə ɹeɪzɝz ʃɑɹp ɛdʒ wɑz ðəɹ ivən ən ənsɝɾən seɪfti. kælændɝ ʃoʊn ɪn ɪz fɪst əntɪl ɪt simd i kæɹid ðə sʌn. dɪmli wɪðɪn hɪm, flʌɾɝɪŋ laɪk ə kændəl fleɪm ɪn ə stɔɹm, wɑz ðə ʃʊɹəɾi ðət hoʊldɪŋ kælændɝ, hi kəd də ɛniθɪŋ. ɛniθɪŋ.

He could not even begin to imagine what it was that he did. The One Power raged inside him till he barely knew himself, till he barely was himself, till what was himself almost did not exist. His precarious stability teetered. To either side lay the endless fall, obliteration by the Power that coursed through him into the sword. Only in the dance along the razor's sharp edge was there even an uncertain safety. Callandor shone in his fist until it seemed he carried the sun. Dimly within him, fluttering like a candle flame in a storm, was the surety that holding Callandor, he could do anything. Anything.

θɹu ɛnləs kɔɹɪɾɝz i ɹæn, dænsɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹeɪzɝ, tʃeɪsɪŋ ðə wʌn u wəd sleɪ hɪm, ðə wʌn i mʌst sleɪ. ðəɹ kəd bi noʊ ʌðɝ ɛnd, ðɪs taɪm. ðɪs taɪm wʌn ə ðɛm mʌs daɪ! ðət bælzəmən nu ɪɾ əz wɛl wɑz klɪɹ. ɔlweɪz i flɛd, ɔlweɪz steɪɪŋ əhɛɾ ə saɪt soʊ ðəɾ oʊnli ðə saʊnz ə hɪz flaɪt dʒɹu ɹænd ɑn, bʌɾ ivən fliɪŋ i tɝn ðɪs stoʊn ə tiɹ ðət wɑz nɑt ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ əɡɛnst ɹænd, ən ɹænd fɔt bæk wɪð ɪnstɪŋkt ən ɡɛsəz ən tʃæns, fɔɾ ən ɹæn daʊn ðət naɪf ɛdʒ ɪn pɝfək bæləns wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ðə tul ən wɛpən ðət wəd kənsum ɪm ʌɾɝli ɪf i fɔltɝd.

Through endless corridors he ran, dancing along the razor, chasing the one who would slay him, the one he must slay. There could be no other end, this time. This time one of them must die! That Ba'alzamon knew it as well was clear. Always he fled, always staying ahead of sight so that only the sounds of his flight drew Rand on, but even fleeing he turned this Stone of Tear that was not the Stone of Tear against Rand, and Rand fought back with instinct and guesses and chance, fought and ran down that knife edge in perfect balance with the Power, the tool and weapon that would consume him utterly if he faltered.

wɔɾɝ fɪl ðə hɔlz fɹəm tɑp tə bɑɾəm, θɪk ən blæk əz ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə si, tʃoʊkɪŋ ɔf bɹɛθ. hi meɪɾ ɪɾ ɛɹ əɡɛn, ənnoʊɪŋli, ən ɹæn ɑn, ən sʌɾənli ði ɛɹ ɡeɪnd weɪɾ əntɪl ɪt simd ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ə hɪz skɪn səpɔɹɾəd ə maʊntən, skwizɪŋ ɪn fɹəm ɔl dɝɛkʃənz. ɪn ði ɪnstən bɪfɔɹ i wɑz kɹʌʃt tə nʌθɪŋnəs i tʃoʊz taɪdz aʊɾ ə ðə flʌɾ ə paʊɝ ɹeɪdʒɪŋ θɹu hɪm - hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ əɹ wɪtʃ əɹ waɪ; ɪt wɑz tu fæs fəɹ θɔɾ əɹ noʊɪŋ - ən ðə pɹɛʃɝ vænɪʃt. hi pɝsud bælzəmən, ən ðə vɛɹi ɛɹ wɑz əbɹʌpli sɑləd ɹɑk ɛnkəsɪŋ hɪm, ðən moʊltən stoʊn, ðən nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl tə fɪl ɪz lʌŋz. ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪniθ ɪz buts pʊld əɾ ɪm əz ɪf ɛvɹi paʊn sʌɾənli weɪɾ ə θaʊzənd, ðən ɔl weɪt vænɪʃt soʊ ðəɾ ə stɛp lɛft ɪm spɪnɪŋ ɪn mɪdɛɹ. ənsin mɔz ɡeɪp tə ɹɪp ɪz maɪn fɹəm ɪz bɑɾi, tə tɛɹ əweɪ hɪz soʊl. hi spɹæŋ itʃ tʃɹæp ən ɹæn ɑn; wʌt bælzəmən twɪstəd tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪm, hi meɪd ɹaɪt wɪθaʊt biɪŋ əwɛɹ ə haʊ. veɪɡli hi nu ðəɾ ɪn səm weɪ hi hæd bɹɔt θɪŋz bæk ɪndə nætʃɹəl bæləns, fɔɹst əm ɪndə laɪn wɪð ɪz oʊn dæns daʊn ðəɾ ɪmpɑsəbli θɪn dɪvaɪd bɪtwin ɛɡzɪstəns ən nʌθɪŋnəs, bʌt ðət nɑlədʒ wɑz dɪstənt. ɔl ɪz əwɛɹnəs leɪ ɪn ðə pɝsut, ðə hʌnt, ðə dɛθ ðət mʌst ɛn ɪt.

Water filled the halls from top to bottom, thick and black as the bottom of the sea, choking off breath. He made it air again, unknowingly, and ran on, and suddenly the air gained weight until it seemed every inch of his skin supported a mountain, squeezing in from all directions. In the instant before he was crushed to nothingness he chose tides out of the flood of Power raging through him - he did not know how or which or why; it was too fast for thought or knowing - and the pressure vanished. He pursued Ba'alzamon, and the very air was abruptly solid rock encasing him, then molten stone, then nothing at all to fill his lungs. The ground beneath his boots pulled at him as if every pound suddenly weighed a thousand, then all weight vanished so that a step left him spinning in midair. Unseen maws gaped to rip his mind from his body, to tear away his soul. He sprang each trap and ran on; what Ba'alzamon twisted to destroy him, he made right without being aware of how. Vaguely he knew that in some way he had brought things back into natural balance, forced them into line with his own dance down that impossibly thin divide between existence and nothingness, but that knowledge was distant. All his awareness lay in the pursuit, the hunt, the death that must end it.

ən ðən i wɑz ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn əɡɛn, stɔkɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹʌbəld ɡæp ðət hæd bɪn ə wɔl. səm ə ðə kɑləmz hʌŋ laɪk bɹoʊkən tiθ, naʊ. ən bælzəmən bækt əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, aɪz bɝnɪŋ, ʃædoʊ kloʊkɪŋ hɪm. blæk laɪnz laɪk stil waɪɝz sim tə ɹʌn ɔf fɹəm bælzəmən ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs maʊndɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm, vænɪʃɪŋ ɪndə ʌnɪmædʒɪnəbəl haɪts ən dɪstənsəz wɪðɪn ðət blæknəs.

And then he was in the Heart of the Stone again, stalking through the rubbled gap that had been a wall. Some of the columns hung like broken teeth, now. And Ba'alzamon backed away from him, eyes burning, shadow cloaking him. Black lines like steel wires seemed to run off from Ba'alzamon into the darkness mounding around him, vanishing into unimaginable heights and distances within that blackness.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt bi əndʌn!" bælzəmən kɹaɪd. hɪz maʊθ wɑz faɪɝ; hɪz ʃɹik ɛkoʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz. "aɪ kænɑt bi dɪfiɾəd! eɪd mi!" səm ə ðə dɑɹknəs ʃɹaʊɾɪŋ ɪm dʒɹɪftəɾ ɪndə hɪz hænz, fɔɹmd ɪndə ə bɔl soʊ blæk ɪt sim tə soʊk ʌp ivən ðə laɪɾ ə kælændɝ. sʌɾən tʃɹaɪəmf bleɪzd ɪn ðə fleɪmz ə hɪz aɪz.

"I will not be undone!" Ba'alzamon cried. His mouth was fire; his shriek echoed among the columns. "I cannot be defeated! Aid me!" Some of the darkness shrouding him drifted into his hands, formed into a ball so black it seemed to soak up even the light of Callandor. Sudden triumph blazed in the flames of his eyes.

"ju ɑɹ dɪstʃɹɔɪd!" ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd. kælændɝ spʌn ɪn ɪz hænz. ɪts laɪt ɹɔɪl ðə dɑɹknəs, sɛvɝd ðə stil-blæk laɪnz ɝaʊn bælzəmən, ən bælzəmən kənvʌlsd. əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ tu ʌv ɪm i sim tə dwɪndəl ən ɡɹoʊ lɑɹdʒɝ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. "ju ɑɹ əndʌn!" ɹænd plʌnʒd ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ bleɪɾ ɪndə bælzəmənz tʃɛst.

"You are destroyed!" Rand shouted. Callandor spun in his hands. Its light roiled the darkness, severed the steel-black lines around Ba'alzamon, and Ba'alzamon convulsed. As if there were two of him he seemed to dwindle and grow larger at the same time. "You are undone!" Rand plunged the shining blade into Ba'alzamon's chest.

bælzəmən skɹimd, ən ðə faɪɝz ə hɪz feɪs flɛɹd waɪldli. "ful!" hi haʊld. "ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk kən nɛvɝ bi dɪfiɾəd!"

Ba'alzamon screamed, and the fires of his face flared wildly. "Fool!" he howled. "The Great Lord of the Dark can never be defeated!"

ɹænd pʊl kælændɝz bleɪd fɹi əz bælzəmənz bɑɾi sæɡd ən bɪɡæn tə fɔl, ðə ʃædoʊ ɝaʊn ɪm vænɪʃɪŋ.

Rand pulled Callandor's blade free as Ba'alzamon's body sagged and began to fall, the shadow around him vanishing.

ən sʌɾənli ɹænd wɑz ɪn ənʌðɝ hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn, sɝaʊndəd baɪ kɑləmz stɪl hoʊl, ən faɪɾɪŋ mɛn skɹimɪŋ ən daɪɪŋ, veɪl mɛn ən mɛn ɪn bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts. mɔɪɹeɪn stɪl leɪ kɹʌmpəld ət ðə beɪs ʌv ə ɹɛdstoʊn kɑləm. ən ət ɹændz fit leɪ ðə bɑɾi ʌv ə mæn, spɹɔld ɑn ɪts bæk wɪð ə hoʊl bɝn θɹu ðə tʃɛst. hi maɪɾ əv bɪn ə hænsəm mæn ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz, ɪksɛp ðət wɛɹ ɪz aɪz ən maʊθ ʃʊɾə bɪn wɝ oʊnli pɪts fɹəm wɪtʃ ɹoʊz tɛnʒɹəlz ə blæk smoʊk.

And suddenly Rand was in another Heart of the Stone, surrounded by columns still whole, and fighting men screaming and dying, veiled men and men in breastplates and helmets. Moiraine still lay crumpled at the base of a redstone column. And at Rand's feet lay the body of a man, sprawled on its back with a hole burned through the chest. He might have been a handsome man in his middle years, except that where his eyes and mouth should have been were only pits from which rose tendrils of black smoke.

aɪ hæv dʌn ɪt, hi θɔt. aɪ hæv kɪl bælzəmən, kɪld ʃeɪtɑn! aɪ hæv wʌn ðə læs bæɾəl! laɪt, aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn! ðə bɹeɪkɝ ə neɪʃənz, ðə bɹeɪkɝ ə ðə wɝld. noʊ! əl ɛn ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, ɛn ðə kɪlɪŋ! əl meɪk ɪɾ ɛnd!

I have done it, he thought. I have killed Ba'alzamon, killed Shai'tan! I have won the Last Battle! Light, I AM the Dragon Reborn! The breaker of nations, the Breaker of the World. No! I will END the breaking, end the killing! I will MAKE it end!

hi ɹeɪz kælændɝ əbʌv ɪz hɛd. sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ kɹækəl fɹəm ðə bleɪd, dʒæɡd stʃɹiks ɑɹtʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹeɪt doʊm əbʌv. "stɑp!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. ðə faɪɾɪŋ sist; mɛn stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm ɪn wʌndɝ, oʊvɝ blæk veɪlz, fɹəm bɪniθ ðə ɹɪmz ə ɹaʊn hɛlməts. "aɪ æm ɹænd ælθɹ!" hi kɔld, soʊ hɪz vɔɪs ɹæŋ θɹu ðə tʃeɪmbɝ. "aɪ æm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!" kælændɝ ʃoʊn ɪn ɪz ɡɹæsp.

He raised Callandor above his head. Silver lightning crackled from the blade, jagged streaks arching toward the great dome above. "Stop!" he shouted. The fighting ceased; men stared at him in wonder, over black veils, from beneath the rims of round helmets. "I am Rand al'Thor!" he called, so his voice rang through the chamber. "I am the Dragon Reborn!" Callandor shone in his grasp.

wʌn baɪ wʌn, veɪl mɛn ən hɛlməɾɪd, ðeɪ nɛl tə hɪm, kɹaɪɪŋ, "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz ɹibɔɹn! ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz ɹibɔɹn!"

One by one, veiled men and helmeted, they knelt to him, crying, "The Dragon is Reborn! The Dragon is Reborn!"


tʃæptɝ fɪftisɪks


CHAPTER 56

pipəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən


People of the Dragon

θɹuaʊt ðə sɪɾi ʌv tɛɹ pipəl woʊk wɪð ðə dɔn, spikɪŋ ə ðə dʒɹimz ðeɪ hæd hæd, dʒɹimz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən bæɾəlɪŋ bælzəmən ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn, ən wən ðɛɹ aɪz ɹoʊz tə ðə ɡɹeɪt fɔɹtʃɹəs ə ðə stoʊn, ðeɪ bɪhɛld ə bænɝ weɪvɪŋ fɹəm ɪts ɡɹeɪɾəst haɪt. əkɹɔs ə fild ʌv waɪt floʊɾ ə sɪnwəs fɔɹm laɪk ə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən skeɪld ɪn skɑɹləɾ ən ɡoʊld, bʌt wɪð ə ɡoʊldən laɪənz meɪn ən fɔɹ lɛɡz, itʃ tɪpt wɪð faɪv ɡoʊldən klɔz. mɛn keɪm, stʌn ən fɹaɪɾənd, fɹəm ðə stoʊn tə spik ɪn hʌʃt toʊnz ʌv wʌt hæd hæpən ɪn ðə naɪt, ən mɛn ən wɪmən θɹɔŋ ðə stʃɹits, wipɪŋ əz ðeɪ ʃaʊɾəd ðə fʊlfɪlmən ə pɹɑfəsi.

Throughout the city of Tear people woke with the dawn, speaking of the dreams they had had, dreams of the Dragon battling Ba'alzamon in the Heart of the Stone, and when their eyes rose to the great fortress of the Stone, they beheld a banner waving from its greatest height. Across a field of white flowed a sinuous form like a great serpent scaled in scarlet and gold, but with a golden lion's mane and four legs, each tipped with five golden claws. Men came, stunned and frightened, from the Stone to speak in hushed tones of what had happened in the night, and men and women thronged the streets, weeping as they shouted the fulfillment of Prophecy.

"ðə dʒɹæɡən!" ðeɪ ʃaʊɾəd. "ælθɹ! ðə dʒɹæɡən! ælθɹ!"

"The Dragon!" they shouted. "Al'Thor! The Dragon! Al'Thor!"

piɹɪŋ θɹu ən æɹoʊslɪt haɪ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stoʊn, mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz i lɪsən tə ðə kɔɹəs ɹaɪzɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ɪn weɪvz. wɛl, meɪbi hi ɪz. hi wɑz stɪl hævɪŋ ə hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf taɪm kʌmɪŋ tə ɡɹɪps wɪð ɹænd ɹɪli biɪŋ ðɛɹ.

Peering through an arrowslit high on the side of the Stone, Mat shook his head as he listened to the chorus rising out of the city in waves. Well, maybe he is. He was still having a hard enough time coming to grips with Rand really being there.

ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə stoʊn sim tə əɡɹi wɪð ðə pipəl bɪloʊ, əɹ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt lɛɾɪŋ ɑn. hi hæd sin ɹænd dʒʌst wʌns sɪns ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ə hɔl wɪð kælændɝ ɪn ɪz hænd, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə dʌzən veɪld il ən tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ə klaʊɾ ə tɛɹənz, ə nɑɾ ə dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn ən moʊst ə ðə fju sɝvaɪvɪŋ haɪ lɔɹdz. ðə haɪ lɔɹdz, ət list, sim tə θɪŋk ɹænd wəd niɾ əm tə hɛlp ɪm ɹul ðə wɝld; ði il kɛpt ɛvɹiwʌn bæk wɪð ʃɑɹp lʊks, ðoʊ, ən spɪɹz ɪf nid bi. ðeɪ ʃʊɹli bɪlivd ɹænd wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən, ðoʊ ðeɪ kɔld ɪm i hu kʌmz wɪð ðə dɔn. ðəɹ wɝ nɪɹli tu hʌnʒɹəd il ɪn ðə stoʊn. ðeɪ hæd lɔst ə θɝɾ ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz ɪn ðə faɪt, bʌt ðeɪ hæd kɪld əɹ kæptʃɝd tɛn taɪmz əz mɛni dɪfɛndɝz.

Everyone in the Stone seemed to agree with the people below, or if they did not, they were not letting on. He had seen Rand just once since the night before, striding along a hall with Callandor in his hand, surrounded by a dozen veiled Aiel and trailing a cloud of Tairens, a knot of Defenders of the Stone and most of the few surviving High Lords. The High Lords, at least, seemed to think Rand would need them to help him rule the world; the Aiel kept everyone back with sharp looks, though, and spears if need be. They surely believed Rand was the Dragon, though they called him He Who Comes With the Dawn. There were nearly two hundred Aiel in the Stone. They had lost a third of their numbers in the fight, but they had killed or captured ten times as many Defenders.

əz i tɝn fɹəm ði æɹoʊslɪt, hɪz aɪz bɹʌʃt əkɹɔs ɹəɑɹk. ðəɹ wɑz ə tɔl stæn ət wʌn ɛn ə ðə ɹum, kɑɹvd ən pɑlɪʃt əpɹaɪt wilz ə səm peɪl, dɑɹk-stʃɹaɪpt wʊd wɪð ʃɛlvz slʌŋ bɪtwin əm soʊ ɔl ə ðə ʃɛlvz wəd steɪ flæɾ əz ðə wilz wɝ ɹivɑlvd. itʃ ʃɛlf hɛld ə lɑɹdʒ bʊk, baʊn ɪn ɡoʊld, kʌvɝz sɛt wɪð spɑɹklɪŋ dʒɛmz. ði il hæd wʌn ə ðə bʊks oʊpən ən wɑz ɹiɾɪŋ. səm sɔɹɾ ʌv ɛseɪz, mæt θɔt. hu wʊɾə θɔɾ ən il wəd ɹɛd bʊks? huɾ əv θɔɾ ən il kəd blʌɾi ɹɛd?

As he turned from the arrowslit, his eyes brushed across Rhuarc. There was a tall stand at one end of the room, carved and polished upright wheels of some pale, dark-striped wood with shelves slung between them so all of the shelves would stay flat as the wheels were revolved. Each shelf held a large book, bound in gold, covers set with sparkling gems. The Aiel had one of the books open and was reading. Some sort of essays, Mat thought. Who would have thought an Aiel would read books? Who'd have thought an Aiel could bloody read?

ɹəɑɹk ɡlænst ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən, ɔl koʊl blu aɪz ən lɛvəl stɛɹ. mæt lʊkt əweɪ heɪstəli, bɪfɔɹ ði il kəd ɹiɾ ɪz θɔts ɑn ɪz feɪs. ət lis hiz nɑt veɪld, θæŋk ðə laɪt! bɝn mi, ðəɾ eɪvinhə nɪɹli tʊk maɪ hɛɾ ɔf wən aɪ æskt əɹ ɪf ʃi kəd də ɛni dænsəz wɪθaʊt spɪɹz. beɪn ən kiæd pɹizɛntəɾ ənʌðɝ pɹɑbləm. ðeɪ wɝ sɝɾənli pɹɪɾi ən mɔɹ ðən fɹɛnli, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt mænədʒ tə tɔk tə wʌn wɪθaʊt ði ʌðɝ. ðə meɪl il sim tə θɪŋk ɪz ɛfɝts tə ɡɛt wʌn ə ðɛm əloʊn wɝ fʌni, ən fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, soʊ dɪd beɪn ən kiæd. wɪmən ɑɹ ɑd, bʌɾ il wɪmən meɪk ɑd sim nɔɹməl!

Rhuarc glanced in his direction, all cold blue eyes and level stare. Mat looked away hastily, before the Aiel could read his thoughts on his face. At least he is not veiled, thank the Light! Burn me, that Aviendha nearly took my head off when I asked her if she could do any dances without spears. Bain and Chiad presented another problem. They were certainly pretty and more than friendly, but he could not manage to talk to one without the other. The male Aiel seemed to think his efforts to get one of them alone were funny, and for that matter, so did Bain and Chiad. Women are odd, but Aiel women make odd seem normal!

ðə ɡɹeɪt teɪbəl ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum, ɔɹnətli kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪɾ ɑn ɛdʒəz ən θɪk lɛɡz, hæd bɪn mɛn fəɹ ɡæðɝɪŋz ə ðə haɪ lɔɹdz. mɔɪɹeɪn sæɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə θɹoʊn laɪk tʃɛɹz, wɪð ðə kɹɛsən bænɝ ə tɛɹ wɝkt ɪndə ɪts taʊɝɪŋ bæk ɪn ɡɪlt ən pɑlɪʃt kɑɹnɛliən ən pɝlʃɛl. ɛɡwin, nɪneɪiv, ən ɪleɪn sæt kloʊs baɪ hɝ.

The great table in the middle of the room, ornately carved and gilded on edges and thick legs, had been meant for gatherings of the High Lords. Moiraine sat in one of the throne like chairs, with the Crescent Banner of Tear worked into its towering back in gilt and polished carnelian and pearlshell. Egwene, Nynaeve, and Elayne sat close by her.

"aɪ stɪl kænɑt bɪliv pɛɹɪn ɪz hɪɹ ɪn tɛɹ," nɪneɪiv wɑz seɪɪŋ. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ hiz ɔl ɹaɪt?"

"I still cannot believe Perrin is here in Tear," Nynaeve was saying. "Are you sure he is all right?"

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd pɛɹɪn tə hæv bɪn ʌp ɪn ðə stoʊn læs naɪt; ðə blæksmɪθ hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn bɹeɪvɝ ðən ɛniwʌn wɪð ɡʊd sɛns.

Mat shook his head. He would have expected Perrin to have been up in the Stone last night; the blacksmith had always been braver than anyone with good sense.

"hi wɑz wɛl wən aɪ lɛf hɪm." mɔɪɹeɪnz vɔɪs wɑz sɝin. "wɛðɝ i stɪl ɪz, aɪ də nɑt noʊ. hɪz . . . kəmpænjən ɪz ɪn səm kənsɪɾɝəbəl deɪnʒɝ, ən i meɪ hæv pʊt hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ɪt, ɔlsoʊ."

"He was well when I left him." Moiraine's voice was serene. "Whether he still is, I do not know. His . . . companion is in some considerable danger, and he may have put himself into it, also."

"hɪz kəmpænjən?" ɛɡwin sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "wɑ - hu ɪz pɛɹɪnz kəmpænjən?"

"His companion?" Egwene said sharply. "Wha - Who is Perrin's companion?"

"wʌt sɔɹɾ ə deɪnʒɝ?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd.

"What sort of danger?" Nynaeve demanded.

"nʌθɪŋ ðət nid kənsɝn ju," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd kɑmli. "aɪ wɪl ɡoʊ ən si tə hɝ əz aɪ meɪ, ʃɔɹtli. aɪ hæv dɪleɪɾ oʊnli tə ʃoʊ jə ðɪs, wɪtʃ aɪ faʊn əmʌŋ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz ə ðə paʊɝ ðə haɪ lɔɹdz kəlɛktəɾ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz." ʃi tʊk sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm əɹ paʊtʃ ən leɪɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl bɪfɔɹ hɝ. ɪt wɑz ə dɪsk ðə saɪz ʌv ə mænz hænd, simɪŋli meɪɾ ə tu tɪɹdʒɹɑps fɪɾəd təɡɛðɝ, wʌn blæk əz pɪtʃ, ði ʌðɝ waɪɾ əz snoʊ.

"Nothing that need concern you," the Aes Sedai said calmly. "I will go and see to her as I may, shortly. I have delayed only to show you this, which I found among the ter'angreal and other things of the Power the High Lords collected over the years." She took something from her pouch and laid it on the table before her. It was a disc the size of a man's hand, seemingly made of two teardrops fitted together, one black as pitch, the other white as snow.

mæt sim tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ siɪŋ ʌðɝz laɪk ɪt. eɪntʃənt, laɪk ðɪs wʌn, bʌt bɹoʊkən, wɛɹ ðɪs wɑz hoʊl. θɹi ʌv ðɛm, hi hæd sin; nɑɾ ɔl təɡɛðɝ, bʌɾ ɔl ɪn pisəz. bʌt ðət kəd nɑt bi; hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət ðeɪ wɝ meɪɾ ə kwəndɪlɝ, ənbɹeɪkəbəl baɪ ɛni paʊɝ, ivən ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

Mat seemed to remember seeing others like it. Ancient, like this one, but broken, where this was whole. Three of them, he had seen; not all together, but all in pieces. But that could not be; he remembered that they were made of cuendillar, unbreakable by any power, even the One Power.

"wʌn ə ðə sɛvən silz luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ ən ðə hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz pʊɾ ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən wən ðeɪ ɹisild ɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ əz ɪf kənfɝmɪŋ əɹ oʊn mɛmɹi.

"One of the seven seals Lews Therin Kinslayer and the Hundred Companions put on the Dark One's prison when they resealed it," Elayne said, nodding as if confirming her own memory.

"mɔɹ pɹɪsaɪsli," mɔɪɹeɪn toʊl hɝ, "ə foʊkəs pɔɪn fəɹ wʌn ə ðə silz. bʌɾ ɪn ɛsəns, jə ɑɹ kɝɛkt. dʊɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝl ðeɪ wɝ skæɾɝd ən hɪɾən fəɹ seɪfti; sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ðeɪv bɪn lɔst ɪn tʃɹuθ." ʃi snɪft. "aɪ bɪɡɪn tə saʊn laɪk vɛɹɪn."

"More precisely," Moiraine told her, "a focus point for one of the seals. But in essence, you are correct. During the Breaking of the World they were scattered and hidden for safety; since the Trolloc Wars they have been lost in truth." She sniffed. "I begin to sound like Verin."

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ ʃʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn ðət hɪɹ. twaɪs bɪfɔɹ ɹænd feɪs bælzəmən, ən boʊθ taɪmz ət list wʌn ə ðə silz wɑz pɹɛzənt."

Egwene shook her head. "I suppose I should have expected to find that here. Twice before Rand faced Ba'alzamon, and both times at least one of the seals was present."

"æn ðɪs taɪm ənbɹoʊkən," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "fɔɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ðə sil ɪz ənbɹoʊkən. əz ɪf ðət mæɾɝd, naʊ."

"And this time unbroken," Nynaeve said. "For the first time, the seal is unbroken. As if that mattered, now."

"ju θɪŋk ɪt dʌz nɑt?" mɔɪɹeɪnz vɔɪs wɑz deɪnʒɝəs ɪn ɪts kwaɪət, ən ði ʌðɝ wɪmən fɹaʊn ət hɝ.

"You think it does not?" Moiraine's voice was dangerous in its quiet, and the other women frowned at her.

mæt ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz. ðeɪ kɛp tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ənɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋz. hi dɪd nɑt mʌtʃ laɪk stændɪŋ nɑt twɛnti fit fɹəm ðət dɪsk naʊ ðəɾ i nu wʌɾ ɪt wɑz, noʊ mæɾɝ ðə vælju ʌv kwəndɪlɝ, bʌt. . . . "jɔɹ pɑɹɾən?" hi sɛd.

Mat rolled his eyes. They kept talking about unimportant things. He did not much like standing not twenty feet from that disc now that he knew what it was, no matter the value of cuendillar, but. . . . "Your pardon?" he said.

ðeɪ ɔl tɝn tə stɛɹ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i wɝ ɪntɝʌptɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. bɝn mi! bɹeɪk əm aʊɾ ʌv ə pɹɪzən sɛl, seɪv ðɛɹ lɪvz hæf ə dʌzən taɪmz bɪtwin əm bɪfɔɹ ðə naɪɾ ɪz dʌn, ən ðeɪ ɡlaʊɝ əz hɑɹɾ əz ðə blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ! wɛl, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt θæŋk mi ðɛn, iðɝ, dɪd ðeɪ? juɾ əv θɔɾ aɪ wɑz stɪkɪŋ maɪ noʊz ɪn wɛɹ ɪt wɑznt wɑntəd ðɛn, tu, ɪnstɛɾ ə kipɪŋ səm blʌɾi dɪfɛndɝ fɹəm pʊɾɪŋ ə sɔɹd θɹu wʌn ə ðɛm. əlaʊd, hi sɛd maɪldli, "ju də nɑt maɪn ɪf aɪ æsk ə kwɛstʃən, də ju? juv ɔl bɪn tɔkɪŋ ðɪs ɛɛs sədaɪ . . . ʌ . . . bɪznəs, ən noʊ wʌn əz bɑðɝd tə tɛl mi ɛniθɪŋ."

They all turned to stare at him as if he were interrupting something important. Burn me! Break them out of a prison cell, save their lives half a dozen times between them before the night is done, and they glower as hard as the bloody Aes Sedai! Well, they did not thank me then, either, did they? You'd have thought I was sticking my nose in where it wasn't wanted then, too, instead of keeping some bloody Defender from putting a sword through one of them. Aloud, he said mildly, "You do not mind if I ask a question, do you? You have all been talking this Aes Sedai . . . uh . . . business, and no one has bothered to tell me anything."

"mæt?" nɪneɪiv sɛd wɔɹnɪŋli, tʌɡɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪd, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, ɪn ə kɑm oʊnli dʒʌs tʌtʃt wɪð ɪmpeɪʃəns, "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt ðət jə wɪʃ tə noʊ?"

"Mat?" Nynaeve said warningly, tugging her braid, but Moiraine said, in a calm only just touched with impatience, "What is it that you wish to know?"

"aɪ wɑnə noʊ haʊ ɔl ə ðɪs kən bi." hi mɛn tə kip ɪz toʊn sɑft, bʌt dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf i pɪkt ʌp ɪntɛnsəɾi əz i wɛn əlɔŋ. "ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ əz fɔlən! ðə pɹɑfəsiz sɛd ðət wəd nɛvɝ hæpən tɪl ðə pipəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən keɪm. dʌz ðət min wəɹ ðə blʌɾi pipəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən? ju, mi, læn, ən ə fju hʌnʒɹəd blʌɾi il?" hi hæd sin ðə wɔɹɾɝ dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt; ðəɹ hæd nɑt sim tə bi mʌtʃ ɛdʒ bɪtwin læn ən ði il əz tə hu wɑz ðə mɔɹ dɛdli. əz ɹəɑɹk stʃɹeɪɾənd tə stɛɹ ət hɪm, hi heɪstəli æɾəd, "ʌ, sɑɹi, ɹəɑɹk. slɪp ə ðə tʌŋ."

"I want to know how all of this can be." He meant to keep his tone soft, but despite himself he picked up intensity as he went along. "The Stone of Tear has fallen! The Prophecies said that would never happen till the People of the Dragon came. Does that mean we are the bloody People of the Dragon? You, me, Lan, and a few hundred bloody Aiel?" He had seen the Warder during the night; there had not seemed to be much edge between Lan and the Aiel as to who was the more deadly. As Rhuarc straightened to stare at him, he hastily added, "Uh, sorry, Rhuarc. Slip of the tongue."

"pɝhæps," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ keɪm tə stɑp bɛləl fɹəm kɪlɪŋ ɹænd. aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk tə si ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ fɔl. pɝhæps wi ɑɹ. pɹɑfəsiz ɑɹ fʊlfɪld əz ðeɪ ɑɹ mɛn tə bi, nɑɾ əz wi θɪŋk ðeɪ ʃəd bi."

"Perhaps," Moiraine said slowly. "I came to stop Be'lal from killing Rand. I did not expect to see the Stone of Tear fall. Perhaps we are. Prophecies are fulfilled as they are meant to be, not as we think they should be."

bɛləl. mæt ʃɪvɝd. hi hæd hɝd ðət neɪm læs naɪt, ən i dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪɾ ɛni mɔɹ ɪn deɪlaɪt. ɪf i hæd noʊn wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɑz lus - ən ɪnsaɪd ðə stoʊn - hi wəd nɛvɝ əv ɡɔn nɪɹ ðə pleɪs. hi ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin, ən nɪneɪiv, ən ɪleɪn. wɛl, aɪɾ əv kʌm ɪn laɪk ə blʌɾi maʊs, ɛniweɪ, nɑt θʌmpɪŋ pipəl lɛft ən ɹaɪt! sændɑɹ hæd ɡɔn skɝiɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə stoʊn ət deɪbɹeɪk; tə teɪk ðə nuz tə mʌðɝ ɡeɪnə, hi kleɪmd, bʌt mæt θɔɾ ɪt wɑz dʒʌs tə ɪskeɪp ðoʊz stɛɹz fɹəm ðə θɹi wɪmən, hu lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt jɛt kwaɪt dɪsaɪɾɪd wʌt tə də əbaʊt hɪm.

Be'lal. Mat shivered. He had heard that name last night, and he did not like it any more in daylight. If he had known one of the Forsaken was loose - and inside the Stone - he would never have gone near the place. He glanced at Egwene, and Nynaeve, and Elayne. Well, I'd have come in like a bloody mouse, anyway, not thumping people left and right! Sandar had gone scurrying out of the Stone at daybreak; to take the news to Mother Guenna, he claimed, but Mat thought it was just to escape those stares from the three women, who looked as if they had not yet quite decided what to do about him.

ɹəɑɹk klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "wɛn ə mæn wɪʃɪz tə bɪkʌm ə klæn tʃif, hi mʌst ɡoʊ tə ɹɪɾiən, ɪn ðə lænz ə ðə dʒɛn il, ðə klæn ðəɾ ɪz nɑt." hi spoʊk sloʊli ən fɹaʊn ɔfən ət ðə ɹɛd-fɹɪn sɪlk kɑɹpəɾ ʌndɝ ɪz sɑf buts, ə mæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪkspleɪn wʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɪkspleɪn əɾ ɔl. "wɪmən u wɪʃ tə bɪkʌm waɪz wʌnz ɔlsoʊ meɪk ðɪs dʒɝni, bʌt ðɛɹ mɑɹkɪŋ, ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ mɑɹkt, ɪz kɛp sikɹəɾ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. ðə mɛn u ɑɹ tʃoʊzən ət ɹɪɾiən, ðoʊz u sɝvaɪv, ɹɪtɝn mɑɹkt ɑn ðə lɛft ɑɹm. soʊ."

Rhuarc cleared his throat. "When a man wishes to become a clan chief, he must go to Rhuidean, in the lands of the Jenn Aiel, the clan that is not." He spoke slowly and frowned often at the red-fringed silk carpet under his soft boots, a man trying to explain what he did not want to explain at all. "Women who wish to become Wise Ones also make this journey, but their marking, if they are marked, is kept secret among themselves. The men who are chosen at Rhuidean, those who survive, return marked on the left arm. So."

hi pʊʃt bæk ðə slivz ə hɪz koʊɾ ən ʃɝt təɡɛðɝ tə ɹɪvil ɪz lɛft fɔɹɑɹm, ðə skɪn mʌtʃ pəlɝ ðən ðəɾ ə hɪz hænz ən feɪs. ɛtʃt ɪndə ðə skɪn əz ɪf pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt, ɹæp twaɪs ɝaʊnd, mɑɹtʃt ðə seɪm ɡoʊld-ænd-skɑɹlət fɔɹm əz ɹɪpəld ɑn ðə bænɝ əbʌv ðə stoʊn.

He pushed back the sleeves of his coat and shirt together to reveal his left forearm, the skin much paler than that of his hands and face. Etched into the skin as if part of it, wrapped twice around, marched the same gold-and-scarlet form as rippled on the banner above the Stone.

ði il lɛɾ ɪz sliv fɔl wɪð ə saɪ. "ɪɾ ɪz ə neɪm nɑt spoʊkən ɪksɛpt əmʌŋ ðə klæn tʃifs ən ðə waɪz wʌnz. wi ɑɹ. . . ." hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ əɡɛn, əneɪbəl tə seɪ ɪt hɪɹ.

The Aiel let his sleeve fall with a sigh. "It is a name not spoken except among the clan chiefs and the Wise Ones. We are. . . ." He cleared his throat again, unable to say it here.

"ði il ɑɹ ðə pipəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən." mɔɪɹeɪn spoʊk kwaɪətli, bʌt ʃi saʊndəɾ əz kloʊs tə stɑɹɾəlmənt əz mæt kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛvɝ hɪɹɪŋ hɝ. "ðæɾ aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ."

"The Aiel are the People of the Dragon." Moiraine spoke quietly, but she sounded as close to startlement as Mat could remember ever hearing her. "That I did not know."

"ðɛn ɪt ɹɪli ɪz ɔl dʌn," mæt sɛd, "dʒʌst əz ðə pɹɑfəsiz sɛd. wi kən ɔl ɡoʊ ɑn əɹ weɪ wɪð noʊ mɔɹ wɝiz." ði æmɪɝlɪn woʊnt nid mi tə bloʊ ðət blʌɾi hɔɹn naʊ!

"Then it really is all done," Mat said, "just as the Prophecies said. We can all go on our way with no more worries." The Amyrlin won't need me to blow that bloody Horn now!

"haʊ kən jə seɪ ðæt?" ɛɡwin dɪmændəd. "doʊn jə ʌndɝstæn ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ lus?"

"How can you say that?" Egwene demanded. "Don't you understand the Forsaken are loose?"

"nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə blæk ədʒɑ," nɪneɪiv æɾəd ɡɹɪmli. "wi tʊk oʊnli ɑmikoʊ ən dʒɔɪjə hɪɹ. ɪlɛvən ɪskeɪpt - ən aɪ wəd laɪk tə noʊ haʊ! - ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn noʊz haʊ mɛni ʌðɝz ðəɹ ɑɹ wi də nɑt noʊ."

"Not to mention the Black Ajah," Nynaeve added grimly. "We took only Amico and Joiya here. Eleven escaped - and I would like to know how! - and the Light alone knows how many others there are we do not know."

"jɛs," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə toʊn dʒʌst əz hɑɹd. "aɪ meɪ nɑt bi ʌp tə feɪsɪŋ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, bʌɾ aɪ min tə teɪk pisəz aʊɾ ə liɑnʒɹɪnz haɪd!"

"Yes," Elayne said in a tone just as hard. "I may not be up to facing one of the Forsaken, but I mean to take pieces out of Liandrin's hide!"

"ʌv kɔɹs," mæt sɛd smuðli. "ʌv kɔɹs." ɑɹ ðeɪ kɹeɪzi? ðeɪ wɑnə tʃeɪs æftɝ ðə blæk ədʒɑ ən ðə fɔɹseɪkən? "aɪ oʊnli mɛn ðə hɑɹɾəst pɑɹɾ ɪz dʌn. ðə stoʊn əz fɔlən tə ðə pipəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, ɹænd əz kælændɝ, ən ʃeɪtɑn ɪz dɛd." mɔɪɹeɪnz stɛɹ wɑz soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ i θɔt ðə stoʊn ʃʊk fəɹ ə moʊmənt.

"Of course," Mat said smoothly. "Of course." Are they crazy? They want to chase after the Black Ajah and the Forsaken? "I only meant the hardest part is done. The Stone has fallen to the People of the Dragon, Rand has Callandor, and Shai'tan is dead." Moiraine's stare was so hard that he thought the Stone shook for a moment.

"bi kwaɪət, jə ful!" ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk ə naɪf. "du jə wɑnə kɔl ɪz ətɛnʃən tə ju, neɪmɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn?"

"Be quiet, you fool!" the Aes Sedai said in a voice like a knife. "Do you want to call his attention to you, naming the Dark One?"

"bʌt hiz dɛd!" mæt pɹətɛstəd. "ɹæn kɪl hɪm. aɪ sɔ ðə bɑɾi!" ən ə faɪn stɪŋk ðət wɑz, tu. aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ ɛniθɪŋ kəd ɹɑt ðət fæst.

"But he's dead!" Mat protested. "Rand killed him. I saw the body!" And a fine stink that was, too. I never thought anything could rot that fast.

"ju sɔ 'ðə bɑɾi,' " mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd wɪð ə twɪs tə hɝ maʊð. "ə mænz bɑɾi. nɑt ðə dɑɹk wʌn, mæt."

"You saw 'the body,' " Moiraine said with a twist to her mouth. "A man's body. Not the Dark One, Mat."

hi lʊkt əɾ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən; ðeɪ əpɪɹɾ əz kənfjuzd əz hi. ɹəɑɹk lʊk tə bi θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ə bæɾəl i hæd θɔt wɑz wʌn ən naʊ lɝn hæd nɑɾ ivən bɪn fɔt. "ðɛn u wɑz ɪt?" mæt dɪmændəd. "mɔɪɹeɪn, maɪ mɛmɹi hæz hoʊlz bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə wæɡən ən tim, bʌɾ aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ bælzəmən biɪŋ ɪn maɪ dʒɹimz. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ! bɝn mi, aɪ də nɑt si haʊ aɪ kən ɛvɝ fɝɡɛt! ən aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd wʌt wɑz lɛft ə ðət feɪs."

He looked at Egwene and the other two women; they appeared as confused as he. Rhuarc looked to be thinking of a battle he had thought was won and now learned had not even been fought. "Then who was it?" Mat demanded. "Moiraine, my memory has holes big enough for a wagon and team, but I remember Ba'alzamon being in my dreams. I remember! Burn me, I do not see how I can ever forget! And I recognized what was left of that face."

"ju ɹɛkəɡnaɪz bælzəmən," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɔɹ ɹæðɝ, ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bælzəmən. ðə dɑɹk wʌn jɛt lɪvz, ɪmpɹɪzən ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, ən ðə ʃædoʊ jɛt laɪz əkɹɔs ðə pæɾɝn."

"You recognized Ba'alzamon," Moiraine said. "Or rather, the man who called himself Ba'alzamon. The Dark One yet lives, imprisoned at Shayol Ghul, and the Shadow yet lies across the Pattern."

"ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ən pɹətɛkt ʌs," ɪleɪn mɝmɝɾ ɪn ə feɪn vɔɪs. "aɪ θɔt. . . . aɪ θɔt ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɝ ðə wɝst wi hæd tə wɝi əbaʊt, naʊ."

"The Light illumine and protect us," Elayne murmured in a faint voice. "I thought. . . . I thought the Forsaken were the worst we had to worry about, now."

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ, mɔɪɹeɪn?" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ɹænd wɑz sɝɾən - ɪz sɝɾən - ðəɾ i kɪl ðə dɑɹk wʌn. jə sim tə bi seɪɪŋ bælzəmən wɑz nɑt ðə dɑɹk wʌn əɾ ɔl. aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd! haʊ kən jə bi soʊ ʃʊɹ? ən ɪf i wɑz nɑt ðə dɑɹk wʌn, hu wɑz hi?"

"Are you sure, Moiraine?" Nynaeve said. "Rand was certain - is certain - that he killed the Dark One. You seem to be saying Ba'alzamon was not the Dark One at all. I don't understand! How can you be so sure? And if he was not the Dark One, who was he?"

"aɪ kən bi ʃʊɹ fəɹ ðə sɪmpləst ə ɹizənz, nɪneɪiv. haʊɛvɝ fæs dəkeɪ tʊk ɪt, ðət wɑz ə mænz bɑɾi. kən jə bɪliv ðəɾ ɪf ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɝ kɪld i wəd liv ə hjumən bɑɾi? ðə mæn ɹænd kɪld wɑz ə mæn. pɝhæps i wɑz ðə fɝst ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən fɹid, əɹ pɝhæps i wɑz nɛvɝ ɪntaɪɝli baʊnd. wi meɪ nɛvɝ noʊ wɪtʃ."

"I can be sure for the simplest of reasons, Nynaeve. However fast decay took it, that was a man's body. Can you believe that if the Dark One were killed he would leave a human body? The man Rand killed was a man. Perhaps he was the first of the Forsaken freed, or perhaps he was never entirely bound. We may never know which."

"aɪ . . . meɪ noʊ hu hi wɑz." ɛɡwin pɔzd wɪð ən ənsɝɾən fɹaʊn. "æt list, aɪ meɪ hæv ə klu. vɛɹɪn ʃoʊd mi ə peɪdʒ fɹəm ən oʊl bʊk ðət mɛnʃən bælzəmən ən ɪʃəml təɡɛðɝ. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊs haɪ tʃæn ən vɛɹi nɪɹli ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl, bʌɾ aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt 'ə neɪm hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ə neɪm.' meɪbi bælzəmən wɑz ɪʃəml."

"I . . . may know who he was." Egwene paused with an uncertain frown. "At least, I may have a clue. Verin showed me a page from an old book that mentioned Ba'alzamon and Ishamael together. It was almost High Chant and very nearly incomprehensible, but I remember something about 'a name hidden behind a name.' Maybe Ba'alzamon was Ishamael."

"pɝhæps," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ɪʃəml. bʌɾ ɪf ɪt wɑz, ət lis naɪn ə ðə θɝtin stɪl lɪv. lænfɝ, ən sɑmaɪl, ən ɹævhɪn, ænd. . . . pɑ! ivən noʊɪŋ ðət səm ə ðoʊz naɪn ət list ɑɹ fɹi ɪz nɑt ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ." ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ətɑp ðə blæk-ænd-waɪt dɪsk ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "θɹi ʌv ðə silz ɑɹ bɹoʊkən. oʊnli fɔɹ stɪl hoʊld. oʊnli ðoʊz fɔɹ silz stæn bɪtwin ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ðə wɝld, ən ɪt meɪ bi ðəɾ ivən wɪð ðoʊz hoʊl i kən tʌtʃ ðə wɝld æftɝ ə fæʃən. wʌtɛvɝ bæɾəl wi wʌn hɪɹ - bæɾəl əɹ skɝmɪʃ - ɪts fɑɹ fɹəm ðə læst."

"Perhaps," Moiraine said. "Perhaps it was Ishamael. But if it was, at least nine of the thirteen still live. Lanfear, and Sammael, and Ravhin, and. . . . Paah! Even knowing that some of those nine at least are free is not the most important thing." She laid a hand atop the black-and-white disc on the table. "Three of the seals are broken. Only four still hold. Only those four seals stand between the Dark One and the world, and it may be that even with those whole he can touch the world after a fashion. Whatever battle we won here - battle or skirmish - it is far from the last."

mæt wɑtʃt ðɛɹ feɪsəz fɝm - ɛɡwinz ən nɪneɪivz ən ɪleɪnz; sloʊli, ɹɪlʌktənli, bʌt dətɝmənədli, tu - ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. blʌɾi wɪmən! ðəɹ ɔl ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð ðɪs, ɡoʊ ɑn tʃeɪsɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪt ðə fɔɹseɪkən ən ðə blʌɾi dɑɹk wʌn. wɛl, ðeɪ nidn θɪŋk aɪm gɑnə kʌm pʊl əm aʊɾ ə ðə sup pɑɾ əɡɛn. ðeɪ dʒʌs nidn θɪŋk ɪt, ðæts ɔl!

Mat watched their faces firm - Egwene's and Nynaeve's and Elayne's; slowly, reluctantly, but determinedly, too - and shook his head. Bloody women! They're all ready to go on with this, go on chasing the Black Ajah, trying to fight the Forsaken and the bloody Dark One. Well, they needn't think I am going to come pull them out of the soup pot again. They just needn't think it, that's all!

wʌn ə ðə tɔl, pɛɹd dɔɹz pʊʃt oʊpən waɪl i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ tə seɪ, ən ə tɔl jʌŋ wʊmən ə ɹiɡəl bɛɹɪŋ ɛntɝd ðə ɹum, wɛɹɪŋ ə kɔɹənɛt wɪð ə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪɾ əbʌv əɹ bɹaʊz. hɝ blæk hɛɹ swɛp tə peɪl ʃoʊldɝz, ən əɹ dʒɹɛs ə ðə faɪnəst ɹɛd sɪlk lɛf ðoʊz ʃoʊldɝz bɛɹ, əlɔŋ wɪð ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɪkspæns ʌv wʌt mæt noʊɾəd əz ən ædmɝəbəl bʊzəm. fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi stʌɾid ɹəɑɹk ɪntʃɹəstɪdli wɪð lɑɹdʒ, dɑɹk aɪz; ðən ʃi tɝn əm ɑn ðə wɪmən ət ðə teɪbəl, kuli ɪmpɪɹiəs. mæt ʃi əpɪɹd tə ɪɡnɔɹ kəmplitli.

One of the tall, paired doors pushed open while he was trying to think of something to say, and a tall young woman of regal bearing entered the room, wearing a coronet with a golden hawk in flight above her brows. Her black hair swept to pale shoulders, and her dress of the finest red silk left those shoulders bare, along with a considerable expanse of what Mat noted as an admirable bosom. For a moment she studied Rhuarc interestedly with large, dark eyes; then she turned them on the women at the table, coolly imperious. Mat she appeared to ignore completely.

"aɪ æm nɑt juz tə biɪŋ ɡɪvən mɛsədʒəz tə kæɹi," ʃi ənaʊnst, flɝɪʃɪŋ ə foʊldəd pɑɹtʃmən ɪn wʌn slɪm hænd.

"I am not used to being given messages to carry," she announced, flourishing a folded parchment in one slim hand.

"æn u ɑɹ ju, tʃaɪld?" mɔɪɹeɪn æskt.

"And who are you, child?" Moiraine asked.

ðə jʌŋ wʊmən dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp ivən mɔɹ, wɪtʃ mæt wʊɾə θɔt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. "aɪ æm bɹəleɪn, fɝst ə min." ʃi tɔs ðə pɑɹtʃmən daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl ɪn fɹʌn ə mɔɪɹeɪn wɪð ə hɔɾi dʒɛstʃɝ ən tɝn bæk tə ðə dɔɹ.

The young woman drew herself up even more, which Mat would have thought was impossible. "I am Berelain, First of Mayene." She tossed the parchment down on the table in front of Moiraine with a haughty gesture and turned back to the door.

"ə moʊmənt, tʃaɪld," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, ənfoʊldɪŋ ðə pɑɹtʃmənt. "hu ɡeɪv ðɪs tə ju? ən waɪ dɪd jə bɹɪŋ ɪt, ɪf jə ɑɹ soʊ ənjuz tə kæɹiɪŋ mɛsədʒəz?"

"A moment, child," Moiraine said, unfolding the parchment. "Who gave this to you? And why did you bring it, if you are so unused to carrying messages?"

"aɪ . . . də nɑt noʊ." bɹəleɪn stʊd feɪsɪŋ ðə dɔɹ; ʃi saʊndəd pʌzəld. "ʃi wɑz . . . ɪmpɹɛsɪv." ʃi ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk ən sim tə ɹɪkʌvɝ əɹ əpɪnjən ə hɝsɛlf. fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi stʌɾid ɹəɑɹk wɪð ə smɔl smaɪl. "ju ɑɹ ðə liɾɝ ə ðiz ilmɛn? jəɹ faɪɾɪŋ dɪstɝb maɪ slip. pɝhæps əl æsk jə tə daɪn wɪð mi. wʌn deɪ kwaɪt sun." ʃi lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət mɔɪɹeɪn. "aɪ æm toʊl ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz teɪkən ðə stoʊn. ɪnfɔɹm ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ðət ðə fɝst ə min wɪl daɪn wɪð ɪm tənaɪt." ən ʃi mɑɹtʃt aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum; mæt kəd θɪŋk ə noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ tə dɪskɹaɪb ðət steɪtli, wʌn-wʊmən pɹəsɛʃən.

"I . . . do not know." Berelain stood facing the door; she sounded puzzled. "She was . . . impressive." She gave herself a shake and seemed to recover her opinion of herself. For a moment she studied Rhuarc with a small smile. "You are the leader of these Aielmen? Your fighting disturbed my sleep. Perhaps I will ask you to dine with me. One day quite soon." She looked over her shoulder at Moiraine. "I am told the Dragon Reborn has taken the Stone. Inform the Lord Dragon that the First of Mayene will dine with him tonight." And she marched out of the room; Mat could think of no other way to describe that stately, one-woman procession.

"aɪ wəd laɪk tə hæv əɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ əz nɑvəs." ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs laɪk ɛkoʊz, ðən ʃɛɹɾ ə taɪt smaɪl.

"I would like to have her in the Tower as novice." Egwene and Elayne said it almost like echoes, then shared a tight smile.

"lɪsən tə ðɪs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. " 'luz θɝɪn wɑz maɪn, hiz maɪn, ən hɪl bi maɪn, fɝɛvɝ. aɪ ɡɪv ɪm ɪndə jəɹ tʃɑɹdʒ, tə kip fəɹ mi əntɪl aɪ kʌm.' ɪts saɪnd 'lænfɝ.' " ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tɝn ðət kul ɡeɪz ɑn mæt. "æn jə θɔɾ ɪt wɑz dʌn? jə ɑɹ tɑvɝən, mæt, ə θɹɛd mɔɹ kɹuʃəl tə ðə pæɾɝn ðən moʊst, ən ðə saʊndɝ ə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. nʌθɪŋ ɪz dʌn fəɹ ju, jɛt."

"Listen to this," Moiraine said. " 'Lews Therin was mine, he is mine, and he will be mine, forever. I give him into your charge, to keep for me until I come.' It is signed 'Lanfear.' " The Aes Sedai turned that cool gaze on Mat. "And you thought it was done? You are ta'veren, Mat, a thread more crucial to the Pattern than most, and the sounder of the Horn of Valere. Nothing is done for you, yet."

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. nɪneɪiv sædli, ɛɡwin əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪm bɪfɔɹ, ɪleɪn əz ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪndə sʌmwʌn ɛls. ɹəɑɹk hæɾ ə sɝɾən ɹɪspɛkt ɪn ɪz aɪz, ðoʊ mæt wəd dʒʌst əz sun əv dʌn wɪθaʊɾ ɪt, ɔl θɪŋz kənsɪɾɝd.

They were all looking at him. Nynaeve sadly, Egwene as though she had never seen him before, Elayne as if she expected him to change into someone else. Rhuarc had a certain respect in his eyes, though Mat would just as soon have done without it, all things considered.

"wɛl, ʌv kɔɹs," hi toʊl ðɛm. bɝn mi! "aɪ ʌndɝstænd." aɪ wʌndɝ haʊ sun tɑm wɪl bi fɪt tə tʃɹævəl? taɪm tə ɹʌn. meɪbi pɛɹɪn wɪl kʌm wɪð ʌs. "ju kən kaʊn ɑn mi."

"Well, of course," he told them. Burn me! "I understand." I wonder how soon Thom will be fit to travel? Time to run. Maybe Perrin will come with us. "You can count on me."

fɹəm aʊtsaɪd, ðə kɹaɪz stɪl ɹoʊz, ənsisɪŋ. "ðə dʒɹæɡən! ælθɹ! ðə dʒɹæɡən! ælθɹ! ðə dʒɹæɡən! ælθɹ! ðə dʒɹæɡən!"

From outside, the cries still rose, unceasing. "The Dragon! Al'Thor! The Dragon! Al'Thor! The Dragon! Al'Thor! The Dragon!"

ən ɪt wɑz ɹɪɾən ðət noʊ hæn bʌɾ ɪz ʃəd wil ðə sɔɹd hɛld ɪn ðə stoʊn, bʌɾ i dɪd dʒɹɔ ɪɾ aʊt, laɪk faɪɝ ɪn ɪz hænd, ən ɪz ɡlɔɹi dɪd bɝn ðə wɝld. ðʌs dɪɾ ɪt bɪɡɪn. ðʌs də wi sɪŋ ɪz ɹibɝθ. ðʌs də wi sɪŋ ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

And it was written that no hand but his should wield the Sword held in the Stone, but he did draw it out, like fire in his hand, and his glory did burn the world. Thus did it begin. Thus do we sing his Rebirth. Thus do we sing the beginning.

 - fɹəm duən toʊldɑɹə ti, sɔŋz ə ðə læst eɪdʒ, kwɔɹɾoʊ naɪn: ðə lɛdʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən.

 - from Do'in Toldara te, Songs of the Last Age, Quarto Nine: The Legend of the Dragon.

kəmpoʊz baɪ boʊn, sɔŋməstʃɹəs ət tæɹələn, ðə fɔɹθ eɪdʒ.

Composed by Boanne, Songmistress at Taralan, the Fourth Age.

ði ɛn ə ðə θɝd bʊk ə ðə wil ə taɪm ɡlɔsɝi eɪ noʊɾ ɑn deɪts ɪn ðɪs ɡlɔsɝi. θɹi sɪstəmz ə ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ deɪts əv bɪn ɪn dʒɛnɝəl jus sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ðə fɝst ɹəkɔɹɾəd jɪɹz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ (æb). sɪns ðə jɪɹz ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ən ɪmiɾiətli æftɝ wɝ jɪɹz ʌv ɔlmoʊs toʊɾəl keɪɑs, ən sɪns ðɪs kæləndɝ wɑz ədɑptəɾ ə ɡʊd hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz æftɝ ði ɛn ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, ɪts stɑɹɾɪŋ pɔɪnt wɑz ɑɹbɪtʃɹɛɹəli əsaɪnd. ət ði ɛn ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz mɛni ɹɛkɝdz hæd bɪn lɔst, soʊ mʌtʃ soʊ ðət ðəɹ wɑz ɑɹɡjəmən əbaʊt ði ɪɡzæk jɪɹ ʌndɝ ði oʊl sɪstəm. ə nu kæləndɝ wɑz ðɛɹfɔɹ ɪstæblɪʃt, deɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ði ɛn ə ðə wɔɹz ən sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ ðə səpoʊz fɹiɾəm ə ðə wɝl fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk θɹɛt. ðɪs sɛkən kæləndɝ ɹəkɔɹɾəd itʃ jɪɹ əz fɹi jɪɹ (fi). æftɝ ðə dɪsɹʌpʃən, dɛθ, ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən kɑz baɪ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ə θɝd kæləndɝ keɪm ɪndə biɪŋ. ðɪs kæləndɝ, ʌv ðə nu ɛɹə (nəbɹæskə), ɪz kɝənli ɪn jus.

The End of the Third Book of The Wheel of Time GLOSSARY A Note on Dates in This Glossary. Three systems of recording dates have been in general use since the Breaking of the World. The first recorded years After the Breaking (AB). Since the years of the Breaking and immediately after were years of almost total chaos, and since this calendar was adopted a good hundred years after the end of the Breaking, its starting point was arbitrarily assigned. At the end of the Trolloc Wars many records had been lost, so much so that there was argument about the exact year under the old system. A new calendar was therefore established, dating from the end of the Wars and celebrating the supposed freedom of the world from the Trolloc threat. This second calendar recorded each year as Free Year (FY). After the disruption, death, and destruction caused by the War of the Hundred Years, a third calendar came into being. This calendar, of the New Era (NE), is currently in use.

æksɛptɪd, ðə: jʌŋ wɪmən ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæv ɹitʃt ə sɝɾən lɛvəl ə paʊɝ ən pæst sɝɾən tɛsts. ɪt nɔɹməli teɪks faɪv tə tɛn jɪɹz tə bi ɹeɪz fɹəm nɑvəs tə ði æksɛptɪd. æksɛptɪɾ ɑɹ sʌmwʌt lɛs kənfaɪn baɪ ɹulz ðən nɑvəsɪz, ən ɑɹ əlaʊd tə tʃuz ðɛɹ oʊn ɛɹiəz ə stʌɾi, wɪðɪn lɪməts. ən æksɛptɪɾ əz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ, bʌɾ oʊnli ɑn ðə θɝd fɪŋɡɝ ə hɝ lɛf hænd. wən ən æksɛptɪɾ ɪz ɹeɪz tə ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi tʃuzəz əɹ ədʒɑ, ɡeɪnz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ðə ʃɔl, ən meɪ wɛɹ ðə ɹɪŋ ɑn ɛni fɪŋɡɝ əɹ nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ɪf sɝkəmstænsəz wɔɹənt.

Accepted, the: Young women in training to be Aes Sedai who have reached a certain level of power and passed certain tests. It normally takes five to ten years to be raised from novice to the Accepted. Accepted are somewhat less confined by rules than novices, and are allowed to choose their own areas of study, within limits. An Accepted has the right to wear a Great Serpent ring, but only on the third finger of her left hand. When an Accepted is raised to Aes Sedai, she chooses her Ajah, gains the right to wear the shawl, and may wear the ring on any finger or not at all if circumstances warrant.

ɛɛs sədaɪ (aɪɛz sɛ-dɪaɪ): wildɝz ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ. sɪns ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, ɔl sɝvaɪvɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ wɪmən. waɪdli dɪstʃɹʌstəɾ ən fɪɹd, ivən heɪɾəd, ðeɪ ɑɹ bleɪm baɪ mɛni fəɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ən ɑɹ θɔt tə mɛɾəl ɪn ði əfɛɹz ə neɪʃənz. ət ðə seɪm taɪm, fju ɹulɝz wɪl bi wɪθaʊɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ædvaɪzɝ, ivən ɪn lænz wɛɹ ði ɛɡzɪstəns ə sətʃ ə kənɛkʃən mʌs bi kɛp sikɹət. æftɝ səm jɪɹz ə tʃænəlɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ teɪk ɑn ən eɪdʒləs kwɑləɾi, soʊ ðəɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ɪz oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi ə ɡɹændmʌðɝ meɪ ʃoʊ noʊ saɪnz ʌv eɪdʒ ɪksɛpt pɝhæps ə fju ɡɹeɪ hɛɹz. si ɔlsoʊ ədʒɑ; æmɪɝlɪn sit; taɪm ə mædnəs.

Aes Sedai (EYEZ seh-DEYE): Wielders of the One Power. Since the Time of Madness, all surviving Aes Sedai are women. Widely distrusted and feared, even hated, they are blamed by many for the Breaking of the World, and are thought to meddle in the affairs of nations. At the same time, few rulers will be without an Aes Sedai advisor, even in lands where the existence of such a connection must be kept secret. After some years of channeling the One Power, Aes Sedai take on an ageless quality, so that an Aes Sedai who is old enough to be a grandmother may show no signs of age except perhaps a few gray hairs. See also Ajah; Amyrlin Seat; Time of Madness.

eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz: ði eɪdʒ ɛndəd baɪ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ ən ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ə taɪm wən ɛɛs sədaɪ pɝfɔɹmd wʌndɝz naʊ oʊnli dʒɹimd ʌv. si ɔlsoʊ wil ə taɪm; bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld; wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ.

Age of Legends: The Age ended by the War of the Shadow and the Breaking of the World. A time when Aes Sedai performed wonders now only dreamed of. See also Wheel of Time; Breaking of the World; War of the Shadow.

il (aɪ-il): ðə pipəl ə ði il weɪst. fɪɹs ən hɑɹɾi. ɔlsoʊ kɔld ilmɛn. ðeɪ veɪl ðɛɹ feɪsəz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kɪl, ɡɪvɪŋ ɹaɪz tə ðə seɪɪŋ "æktɪŋ laɪk ə blæk-veɪld il" tə dɪskɹaɪb sʌmwʌn u ɪz biɪŋ vaɪələnt. dɛdli wɔɹiɝz wɪð ɛni wɛpən əɹ wɪð nʌθɪŋ bʌt ðɛɹ bɛɹ hænz, ðəl nɑt tʌtʃ ə sɔɹd. ðɛɹ paɪpɝz pleɪ ðɛm ɪndə bæɾəl wɪð ðə mjuzɪk ə dænsəz, ən ilmɛn kɔl bæɾəl "ðə dæns," ən "ðə dæns ə spɪɹz." si ɔlsoʊ il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz; il weɪst.

Aiel (eye-EEL): The people of the Aiel Waste. Fierce and hardy. Also called Aielmen. They veil their faces before they kill, giving rise to the saying "acting like a black-veiled Aiel" to describe someone who is being violent. Deadly warriors with any weapon or with nothing but their bare hands, they will not touch a sword. Their pipers play them into battle with the music of dances, and Aielmen call battle "the dance," and "the dance of spears." See also Aiel warrior societies; Aiel Waste.

il wɔɹ, ðə: (naɪnsɛvənsɪkssɛvəneɪt ni) wən kɪŋ leɪmən ə kɛɹhin kʌt daʊn ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə, sɛvɹəl klænz ə ði il kɹɔs ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. ðeɪ luɾəd ən bɝn ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv kɛɹhin əz wɛl əz mɛni ʌðɝ sɪɾiz ən taʊnz, ən ðə kɑnflɪkt ɪkstɛndəɾ ɪndə ændɝ ən tɛɹ. ðə kənvɛnʃənəl vju ɪz ðət ði il wɝ faɪnəli dɪfiɾəd ət ðə bæɾəl ə ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz, bɪfɔɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn, bʌɾ ɪn fækt, leɪmən wɑz kɪld ɪn ðət bæɾəl, ən hævɪŋ dʌn wʌt ðeɪ hæd kʌm fɔɹ, ði il ɹɛkɹɔs ðə spaɪn. si ɔlsoʊ ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə; kɛɹhin.

Aiel War, the: (97678 NE) When King Laman of Cairhien cut down Avendoraldera, several clans of the Aiel crossed the Spine of the World. They looted and burned the capital city of Cairhien as well as many other cities and towns, and the conflict extended into Andor and Tear. The conventional view is that the Aiel were finally defeated at the Battle of the Shining Walls, before Tar Valon, but in fact, Laman was killed in that battle, and having done what they had come for, the Aiel recrossed the Spine. See also Avendoraldera; Cairhien.

il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz: il wɔɹiɝz ɑɹ ɔl mɛmbɝz ʌv wʌn ə ðə wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz, sətʃ əz ðə stoʊn dɑɡz (ʃeɪin tɑl), ðə ɹɛd ʃilz (æɛθən dɔɹ), əɹ ðə meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ (fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ). itʃ səsaɪəɾi hæz ɪts oʊn kʌstəmz, ən səmtaɪmz spəsɪfɪk duɾiz. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, ɹɛd ʃilz ækt əz pəlis. stoʊn dɑɡz ɔfən vaʊ nɑt tə ɹitʃɹit wʌns bæɾəl əz bɪn dʒɔɪnd, ən wɪl daɪ tə ðə læs mæn ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi tə fʊlfɪl ðɪs vaʊ. ðə klænz ə ði il - əmʌŋ əm ðə ɡoʊʃin, ɹn, ʃɝəd, ən tɑɹdæɾ il - fɹikwənli faɪɾ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌt mɛmbɝz ə ðə seɪm səsaɪəɾi wɪl nɑt faɪɾ itʃ ʌðɝ ivən ɪf ðɛɹ klænz ɑɹ duɪŋ soʊ. ɪn ðɪs weɪ, ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz laɪnz ə kɑntæk bɪtwin ðə klænz ivən wən ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn oʊpən wɔɹfɛɹ. si ɔlsoʊ il; il weɪst; fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ.

Aiel warrior societies: Aiel warriors are all members of one of the warrior societies, such as the Stone Dogs (Shae'en M'taal), the Red Shields (Aethan Dor), or the Maidens of the Spear (Far Dareis Mai). Each society has its own customs, and sometimes specific duties. For example, Red Shields act as police. Stone Dogs often vow not to retreat once battle has been joined, and will die to the last man if necessary to fulfill this vow. The clans of the Aiel - among them the Goshien, Reyn, Shaarad, and Taardad Aiel - frequently fight among themselves, but members of the same society will not fight each other even if their clans are doing so. In this way, there are always lines of contact between the clans even when they are in open warfare. See also Aiel; Aiel Waste; Far Dareis Mai.

il weɪst: ðə hɑɹʃ, ɹʌɡəd, ən ɔl-bʌt-wɔɾɝləs læn ist ə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. kɔl ðə θɹi-foʊld læn baɪ ði il. fju aʊtsaɪɾɝz ɡoʊ ðɛɹ, nɑɾ oʊnli kəz wɔɾɝ ɪz ɔlmoʊst ɪmpɑsəbəl tə faɪn fəɹ wʌn nɑt bɔɹn ðɛɹ, bʌt kəz ði il kənsɪɾɝ ðɛmsɛlvz ət wɔɹ wɪð ɔl ʌðɝ pipəlz ən də nɑt wɛlkəm stʃɹeɪnʒɝz. oʊnli pɛdlɝz, ɡlimən, ən ðə tuætɑn ɑɹ əlaʊd seɪf ɛntʃɹi, ən kɑntækt ivən wɪð əm ɪz lɪməɾəd. noʊ mæps ə ðə weɪst ɪtsɛlf ɑɹ noʊn tə ɪɡzɪst.

Aiel Waste: The harsh, rugged, and all-but-waterless land east of the Spine of the World. Called the Three-fold Land by the Aiel. Few outsiders go there, not only because water is almost impossible to find for one not born there, but because the Aiel consider themselves at war with all other peoples and do not welcome strangers. Only peddlers, gleemen, and the Tuatha'an are allowed safe entry, and contact even with them is limited. No maps of the Waste itself are known to exist.

ədʒɑ (ɑ-dʒɑ): səsaɪəɾiz əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə wɪtʃ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪksɛp ði æmɪɝlɪn sit bɪlɔŋ. ðeɪ ɑɹ dɛzɪɡneɪɾɪd baɪ kʌlɝz: blu, ɹɛd, waɪt, ɡɹin, bɹaʊn, jɛloʊ, ən ɡɹeɪ. itʃ fɑloʊz ə spəsɪfɪk fəlɑsəfi ʌv ðə jus ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən ðə pɝpəsəz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ bɛnz ɔl ɪts ɛnɝdʒiz tə faɪndɪŋ mɛn u ɑɹ ətɛmptɪŋ tə wil ðə paʊɝ, ən tə dʒɛntəlɪŋ ðɛm. ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, fɔɹseɪks ɪnvɑlvmənt wɪð ðə məndeɪn wɝld ən dɛɾɪkeɪts ɪtsɛlf tə sikɪŋ nɑlədʒ, waɪl ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ, lɑɹdʒli ɛʃuɪŋ boʊθ ðə wɝld ən ðə vælju ʌv wɝldli nɑlədʒ, dɪvoʊts ɪtsɛlf tə kwɛstʃənz ə fəlɑsəfi ən tʃɹuθ. ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ (kɔl ðə bæɾəl ədʒɑ dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz) hoʊlz ɪtsɛlf ɹɛɾi tə kaʊntɝ ɛni nu dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz wən tɑɹmən ɡdən kʌmz. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɹumɝz ʌv ə blæk ədʒɑ, dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə sɝvɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

Ajah (AH-jah): Societies among the Aes Sedai to which all Aes Sedai except the Amyrlin Seat belong. They are designated by colors: Blue, Red, White, Green, Brown, Yellow, and Gray. Each follows a specific philosophy of the use of the One Power and the purposes of the Aes Sedai. For example, the Red Ajah bends all its energies to finding men who are attempting to wield the Power, and to gentling them. The Brown Ajah, on the other hand, forsakes involvement with the mundane world and dedicates itself to seeking knowledge, while the White Ajah, largely eschewing both the world and the value of worldly knowledge, devotes itself to questions of philosophy and truth. The Green Ajah (called the Battle Ajah during the Trolloc Wars) holds itself ready to counter any new Dreadlords when Tarmon Gai'don comes. There are rumors of a Black Ajah, dedicated to serving the Dark One.

ɑlɑnə mɑsvɑni (ɑ-læn-nɑ mɔs-væn-ni): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ.

Alanna Mosvani (ah-LAN-nah mos-VANH-nie): An Aes Sedai of the Green Ajah.

ɑlmɹə, nɪneɪiv (æl-miɝ-ɑ, naɪ-niv): ə wʊmən wʌns ðə wɪzdəm ʌv ɛmənz fild, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz dɪstʃɹɪkt ʌv ændɝ (æn-dɔɹ). naʊ wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd.

al'Meara, Nynaeve (al-MEER-ah, NIGH-neev): A woman once the Wisdom of Emond's Field, in the Two Rivers district of Andor (AN-door). Now one of the Accepted.

ælθɹ, ɹænd (æl-θɔɹ, ɹænd): ə jʌŋ mæn fɹəm ɛmənz fild u ɪz tɑvɝən. wʌns ə ʃɛpɝd. naʊ pɹoʊkleɪmd əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

al'Thor, Rand (al-THOR, RAND): A young man from Emond's Field who is ta'veren. Once a shepherd. Now proclaimed as the Dragon Reborn.

ælvɪɹ, ɛɡwin (ɑl-vɪɹ, ɛ-ɡweɪn): ə jʌŋ wʊmən fɹəm ɛmənz fild. naʊ ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ.

al'Vere, Egwene (ahl-VEER, eh-GWAIN): A young woman from Emond's Field. Now in training to be Aes Sedai.

əmɑlɑsən, ɡɛɹ (ɑm-ɑ-lɑ-sɪn, ɡwɛɹ): si wɔɹ ə ðə sɛkən dʒɹæɡən.

Amalasan, Guaire (ahm-ah-LAH-sin, Gware): See War of the Second Dragon.

æmɪɝlɪn sit (ɑm-ɛɹ-lɪn sit): (wʌn) liɾɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪlɛktəd fəɹ laɪf baɪ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ðə haɪəs kaʊnsəl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɪtʃ kənsɪsts ə θɹi ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪvz (kɔl sɪɾɝz, əz ɪn "ə sɪɾɝ fəɹ ðə ɡɹin") fɹəm itʃ ə ðə sɛvən ədʒəz. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæz, θiɝɛɾɪkəli ət list, ɔlmoʊst səpɹim əθɔɹəɾi əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ɹæŋks soʊʃəli əz ði ikwəl ʌv ə kɪŋ əɹ kwin. ə slaɪtli lɛs fɔɹməl jusədʒ ɪz sɪmpli ði æmɪɝlɪn. (tu) ðə θɹoʊn ɑn wɪtʃ ðə liɾɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɪts.

Amyrlin Seat (AHM-ehr-lin SEAT): (1) Leader of the Aes Sedai. Elected for life by the Hall of the Tower, the highest council of the Aes Sedai, which consists of three representatives (called Sitters, as in "a Sitter for the Green") from each of the seven Ajahs. The Amyrlin Seat has, theoretically at least, almost supreme authority among the Aes Sedai, and ranks socially as the equal of a king or queen. A slightly less formal usage is simply the Amyrlin. (2) The throne on which the leader of the Aes Sedai sits.

æneɪjə (ɑ-naɪ-jɑ): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ.

Anaiya (ah-NYE-yah): An Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah.

æŋɡɹil (æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ðəɾ əlaʊ ɛniwʌn keɪpəbəl ə tʃænəlɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə hændəl ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðən kəd seɪfli bi tʃænəld əneɪɾɪd. ðɛɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ noʊn. fju ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɛɡzɪstəns. si ɔlsoʊ sɑŋɡɹil; tɛɹæŋɡɹil.

angreal (anh-gree-AHL): Remnants of the Age of Legends that allow anyone capable of channeling the One Power to handle a greater amount of the Power than could safely be channeled unaided. Their making is no longer known. Few remain in existence. See also sa'angreal; ter'angreal.

ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ: si hɔkwɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ.

Artur Hawkwing: See Hawkwing, Artur.

əsɛmblədʒ, ðə: ə bɑɾi ɪn ɪljən, tʃoʊzən baɪ ən fɹəm ðə mɝtʃəns ən ʃɪpoʊnɝz, ðəɾ ɪz səpoʊz tə ædvaɪz boʊθ ðə kɪŋ ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn, bʌt hɪstɔɹɪkəli hæz kəntɛndɪd wɪð əm fəɹ paʊɝ.

Assemblage, the: A body in Illian, chosen by and from the merchants and shipowners, that is supposed to advise both the King and the Council of Nine, but historically has contended with them for power.

æθɑn maɪɹ (ɑ-θɑ-æn mi-ɛɹ): si si foʊk.

Atha'an Miere (ah-thah-AHN mee-EHR): See Sea Folk.

ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə (ɑ-vɛn-dɛ-soʊ-ɹɑ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf." mɛnʃən ɪn mɛni stɔɹiz ən lɛdʒənz.

Avendesora (AH-vehn-deh-SO-rah): In the Old Tongue, "the Tree of Life." Mentioned in many stories and legends.

ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə (ɑ-vɛn-doʊ-ɹæl-dɛ-ɹɑ): ə tʃɹi ɡɹoʊn ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʌv kɛɹhin fɹəm ə sæpəlɪŋ ʌv ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə. ðɪs sæpəlɪŋ wɑz ə ɡɪft fɹəm ði il ɪn faɪvhʌnʒɹədsɪkstisɪks ni, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðət noʊ ɹɛkɝd ʃoʊz ɛni kənɛkʃən wʌtsoʊɛvɝ bɪtwin ði il ən ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə. si ɔlsoʊ il wɔɹ.

Avendoraldera (AH-ven-doh-ral-DEH-rah): A tree grown in the city of Cairhien from a sapling of Avendesora. This sapling was a gift from the Aiel in 566 NE, despite the fact that no record shows any connection whatsoever between the Aiel and Avendesora. See also Aiel War.

eɪvinhə (ɑ-vi-ɛn-dɑ): ə wʊmən ə ðə naɪn væliz sɛpt ə ðə tɑɹdæɾ il; ə fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ, ə meɪɾən ə ðə spɪɹ.

Aviendha (Ah-vee-EHN-dah): A woman of the Nine Valleys sept of the Taardad Aiel; a Far Dareis Mai, a Maiden of the Spear.

eɪbɑɹə, pɛɹɪn (eɪ-bɛɹ-ɑ, pɛɹ-ɹɪn): ə jʌŋ mæn fɹəm ɛmənz fild, fɔɹmɝli ə blæksmɪθs əpɹɛntəs.

Aybara, Perrin (ay-BAHR-ah, PEHR-rihn): A young man from Emond's Field, formerly a blacksmith's apprentice.

bælzəmən (bɑ-ɑl-zɑ-moʊn): ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk tʌŋ, "hɑɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk." bɪliv tə bi ðə tʃɹɑlɑk neɪm fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. si ɔlsoʊ dɑɹk wʌn; tʃɹɑləks.

Ba'alzamon (bah-AHL-zah-mon): In the Trolloc tongue, "Heart of the Dark." Believed to be the Trolloc name for the Dark One. See also Dark One; Trollocs.

bæʃɪɹ, zɑɹin (bɑ-ʃɪɹ, zɑ-ɹin): ə jʌŋ wʊmən fɹəm sɑldɑiə hu ɪz ə hʌntɝ ə ðə hɔɹn. ʃi wɪʃɪz tə bi kɔl feɪl (fɑ-il), wɪtʃ, ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, minz "fælkən."

Bashere, Zarine (bah-SHEER, zah-REEN): A young woman from Saldaea who is a Hunter of the Horn. She wishes to be called Faile (fah-EEL), which, in the Old Tongue, means "falcon."

bɛləl (bɛ-lɑl): wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

Be'lal (beh-LAAL): One of the Forsaken.

bɛl taɪn (bɛl taɪn): spɹɪŋ fɛstəvəl sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ ði ɛn ʌv wɪntɝ, ðə fɝst spɹaʊɾɪŋ ə kɹɑps, ən ðə bɝθ ə ðə fɝs læmz.

Bel Tine (BEHL TINE): Spring festival celebrating the end of winter, the first sprouting of crops, and the birth of the first lambs.

bɪtʃɹeɪɝ ə hoʊp: si ɪʃəml.

Betrayer of Hope: See Ishamael.

baɪtim (baɪt-mi): ə smɔl, ɔlmoʊst ɪnvɪzəbəl baɪɾɪŋ ɪnsɛkt.

biteme (BITE-me): A small, almost invisible biting insect.

bɪɾɝn (l-tɛɹn): ə mjuzɪkəl ɪnstʃɹəmən ðət meɪ hæv sɪks, naɪn, əɹ twɛlv stʃɹɪŋz, ən ɪz hɛl flæɾ ɑn ðə niz ən pleɪd baɪ plʌkɪŋ əɹ stʃɹʌmɪŋ.

bittern (BlHT-tehrn): A musical instrument that may have six, nine, or twelve strings, and is held flat on the knees and played by plucking or strumming.

blaɪt, ðə: si ɡɹeɪt blaɪt, ðə.

Blight, the: See Great Blight, the.

bɔɹɾɝlændz, ðə: ðə neɪʃənz bɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt: sɑldɑiə, ɝæfəl, kændɝ, ən ʃaɪnɝ.

Borderlands, the: The nations bordering the Great Blight: Saldaea, Arafel, Kandor, and Shienar.

bɔɹnhəld, deɪn (-hɑld, deɪ-ɪn): ən ɔfəsɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, sʌn ə lɔɹd kæptən dʒɛəfɹeɪm bɔɹnhəld, hu daɪɾ ət fɑlm, ɑn toʊmən hɛd.

Bornhald, Dain (BOHRN-hahld, DAY-ihn): An officer of the Children of the Light, son of Lord Captain Geofraim Bornhald, who died at Falme, on Toman Head.

bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ðə: dʊɹɪŋ ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd ɡɔn ɪnseɪn, ən u kəd wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə ə dɪɡɹi naʊ ənnoʊn, tʃeɪnʒd ðə feɪs ə ði ɝθ. ðeɪ kɑzd ɡɹeɪɾ ɝθkweɪks, lɛvəld oʊl maʊntən ɹeɪnʒəz ən ɹeɪz nu maʊntənz, lɪftəd dʒɹaɪ lænd wɛɹ siz hæd bɪn ən meɪd ði oʊʃən ɹʌʃ ɪn wɛɹ dʒɹaɪ læn hæd bɪn. mɛni pɑɹts ə ðə wɝld wɝ kəmplitli dɪpɑpjəleɪɾɪd, ən ðə sɝvaɪvɝz wɝ skæɾɝd laɪk dʌst ɑn ðə wɪnd. ðɪs dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ɪz ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪn stɔɹiz, lɛdʒənz, ən hɪstɝi əz ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. si ɔlsoʊ taɪm ə mædnəs; hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz, ðə.

Breaking of the World, the: During the Time of Madness, male Aes Sedai who had gone insane, and who could wield the One Power to a degree now unknown, changed the face of the earth. They caused great earthquakes, leveled old mountain ranges and raised new mountains, lifted dry land where seas had been and made the ocean rush in where dry land had been. Many parts of the world were completely depopulated, and the survivors were scattered like dust on the wind. This destruction is remembered in stories, legends, and history as the Breaking of the World. See also Time of Madness; Hundred Companions, the.

baɪɑɝ, jɹət (baɪ-ɑɹ, dʒɑ-ɹɛt): ən ɔfəsɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Byar, Jaret (BY-ahr, JAH-ret): An officer of the Children of the Light.

keɪɛmlɪn (keɪm-lɪn): ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ændɝ.

Caemlyn (KAYM-lihn): The capital city of Andor.

kɛɹhin (kaɪ-ɹi-ɛn): boʊθ ə neɪʃən əlɔŋ ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld ən ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðət neɪʃən. ðə sɪɾi wɑz bɝn ən luɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði il wɔɹ, əz wɝ mɛni ʌðɝ taʊnz ən vɪlədʒəz. ðə kɑnsəkwən əbændənmən ə fɑɹmlænd nɪɹ ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝl meɪd nɛsəsɛɹi ði ɪmpɔɹteɪʃən ʌv ɡɹeɪt kwɑntəɾiz ʌv ɡɹeɪn. ði əsæsəneɪʃən ə kɪŋ ɡɔlʒɹiən (naɪnhʌnʒɹədnaɪntieɪt ni) hæz ɹɪzʌltɪɾ ɪn ə sɪvəl wɔɹ əmʌŋ ðə noʊbəl haʊsəz fəɹ səksɛʃən tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn, ɪn ðə dɪsɹʌpʃən ʌv ɡɹeɪn ʃɪpməns, ən ɪn fæmən. ðə saɪn ə kɛɹhin ɪz ə mɛni-ɹeɪd ɡoʊldən sʌn ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ə fild ə skaɪ blu.

Cairhien (KEYE-ree-EHN): Both a nation along the Spine of the World and the capital city of that nation. The city was burned and looted during the Aiel War, as were many other towns and villages. The consequent abandonment of farmland near the Spine of the World made necessary the importation of great quantities of grain. The assassination of King Galldrian (998 NE) has resulted in a civil war among the noble Houses for succession to the Sun Throne, in the disruption of grain shipments, and in famine.
