The sign of Cairhien is a many-rayed golden sun rising from the bottom of a field of sky blue.

kælændɝ (kɑ-læn-dɔɹ): ðə sɔɹd ðəɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə sɔɹd, ðə sɔɹd ðət kænɑt bi tʌtʃt. ə kɹɪstəl sɔɹd hɛld ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ, ɪn ðə tʃeɪmbɝ kɔl ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn. noʊ hæn kən tʌtʃ ɪɾ ɪksɛp ðəɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, wʌn ə ðə meɪdʒɝ saɪnz ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz ɹibɝθ ən ði əpɹoʊtʃ ə tɑɹmən ɡdən wɪl bi ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz teɪkən kælændɝ.

Callandor (CAH-lahn-DOOR): The Sword That Is Not a Sword, the Sword That Cannot Be Touched. A crystal sword held in the Stone of Tear, in the chamber called the Heart of the Stone. No hand can touch it except that of the Dragon Reborn. According to the Prophecies of the Dragon, one of the major signs of the Dragon's Rebirth and the approach of Tarmon Gai'don will be that the Dragon Reborn has taken Callandor.

kɔθən, mæt (kɔ-θɑn, mæt): ə jʌŋ mæn fɹəm ɛmənz fild ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. fʊl neɪm: meɪtʃɹim (mæt-tʃɹɪm) kɔθən.

Cauthon, Mat (CAW-thon, MAT): A young man from Emond's Field in the Two Rivers. Full name: Matrim (MAT-trim) Cauthon.

tʃænəl: (vɝb) tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə floʊ ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ. si ɔlsoʊ wʌn paʊɝ.

channel: (verb) To control the flow of the One Power. See also One Power.

tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt: ə səsaɪəɾi hoʊldɪŋ stʃɹɪkt əsɛɾɪk bɪlifs, dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə dɪfiɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʌv ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz. faʊndəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz baɪ lɑthɛɹ mæntəlɝ (loʊ-θheɪɹ mæn-ti-lɑɹ) tə pɹɑsələtaɪz əɡɛnst ən ɪnkɹis ɪn ðə nʌmbɝz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðeɪ ɪvɑlv dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ɪndə ə kəmplitli mɪlətɛɹi ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɪdʒəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ bɪlifs, ən sɝɾən ðəɾ oʊnli ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ən ðə ɹaɪt. ðeɪ heɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðɛm, ən ɛni hu səpɔɹɾ əɹ bɪfɹɛn ðɛm, dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊn dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli əz waɪtkloʊks. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ɑn ə fild ʌv waɪt. si ɔlsoʊ kwɛstʃənɝz.

Children of the Light: A society holding strict ascetic beliefs, dedicated to the defeat of the Dark One and the destruction of all Darkfriends. Founded during the War of the Hundred Years by Lothair Mantelar (LOH-thayr MAHN-tee-LAHR) to proselytize against an increase in the numbers of Darkfriends, they evolved during the war into a completely military organization. They are extremely rigid in their beliefs, and certain that only they know the truth and the right. They hate Aes Sedai, considering them, and any who support or befriend them, Darkfriends. They are known disparagingly as Whitecloaks. Their sign is a golden sunburst on a field of white. See also Questioners.

kɹɑnəkəlz, kipɝ ə ðə: sɛkən ɪn əθɔɹəɾi tə ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi ɔlsoʊ æks əz sɛkɹətɛɹi tə ði æmɪɝlɪn. tʃoʊzən fəɹ laɪf baɪ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ən juʒəwəli ʌv ðə seɪm ədʒɑ əz ði æmɪɝlɪn. si ɔlsoʊ æmɪɝlɪn sit; ədʒɑ.

Chronicles, Keeper of the: Second in authority to the Amyrlin Seat among the Aes Sedai, she also acts as secretary to the Amyrlin. Chosen for life by the Hall of the Tower, and usually of the same Ajah as the Amyrlin. See also Amyrlin Seat; Ajah.

kaʊnsəl ə naɪn: ɪn ɪljən, ə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn lɔɹdz u ɑɹ səpoʊz tə ædvaɪz ðə kɪŋ, bʌɾ u hɪstɔɹɪkəli kəntɛnd wɪð ɪm fəɹ paʊɝ. boʊθ ðə kɪŋ ən ðə naɪn ɔfən mʌs kəntɛnd wɪð ði əsɛmblədʒ, əz wɛl.

Council of Nine: In Illian, a council of nine Lords who are supposed to advise the King, but who historically contend with him for power. Both the King and the Nine often must contend with the Assemblage, as well.

kwəndɪlɝ (kweɪn-dɛ-jɑɹ): si hɑɹtstoʊn.

cuendillar (CWAIN-deh-yar): See heartstone.

deɪz deɪmɑɹ (dɑ-ɛs deɪ-mɑɹ): ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz. neɪm ɡɪvən ðə skimɪŋ, plɑts, ən mənɪpjəleɪʃənz fəɹ ædvæntɪdʒ baɪ ðə noʊbəl haʊsəz. ɡɹeɪt vælju ɪz ɡɪvən tə sʌɾəlti, tə eɪmɪŋ ət wʌn θɪŋ waɪl simɪŋ tə eɪm əɾ ənʌðɝ, ən tə ətʃivɪŋ ɛnz wɪð ðə lis vɪzəbəl ɛfɝt.

Daes Dae'mar (DAH-ess day-MAR): The Great Game, also known as the Game of Houses. Name given the scheming, plots, and manipulations for advantage by the noble Houses. Great value is given to subtlety, to aiming at one thing while seeming to aim at another, and to achieving ends with the least visible effort.

dəmədʒɹd, lɔɹd ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd (dæm-oʊ-dʒɹɛd, ɡɑ-lɑd-ɛ-dʒɹaɪd): hæf bɹʌðɝ tə ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn. hɪz saɪn ɪz ə wɪŋ sɪlvɝ sɔɹd, pɔɪn daʊn.

Damodred, Lord Galadedrid (DAHM-oh-drehd, gah-LAHD-eh-drihd): Half brother to Elayne and Gawyn. His sign is a winged silver sword, point down.

dɑɹkfɹɛnz: ðoʊz u fɑloʊ ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən bɪliv ðəl ɡeɪn ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ ən ɹɪwɔɹdz, ən ivən ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi, wən hiz fɹid fɹəm ɪz pɹɪzən.

Darkfriends: Those who follow the Dark One and believe they will gain great power and rewards, and even immortality, when he is freed from his prison.

dɑɹkhaʊnz: si waɪl hʌnt.

Darkhounds: See Wild Hunt.

dɑɹk wʌn: moʊs kɑmən neɪm, juzd ɪn ɛvɹi lænd, fəɹ ʃeɪtɑn. ðə sɔɹs ʌv ivəl, æntɪθəsəs ə ðə kɹieɪɾɝ. ɪmpɹɪzən baɪ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ət ðə moʊmən ə kɹieɪʃən. ði ətɛmp tə fɹi hɪm fɹəm ðət pɹɪzən bɹɔɾ əbaʊt ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ðə teɪntɪŋ ə seɪɾɪn, ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ən ði ɛn ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz.

Dark One: Most common name, used in every land, for Shai'tan. The source of evil, antithesis of the Creator. Imprisoned by the Creator in Shayol Ghul at the moment of Creation. The attempt to free him from that prison brought about the War of the Shadow, the tainting of saidin, the Breaking of the World, and the end of the Age of Legends.

dɑɹk wʌn, neɪmɪŋ ðə: seɪɪŋ ðə tʃɹu neɪm ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn (ʃeɪtɑn) dʒɹɔz ɪz ətɛnʃən, ɪnɛvəɾəbli bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪl fɔɹtʃən ət bɛst, dɪzæstɝ ət wɝst. fəɹ ðət ɹizən, mɛni jufəmɪzəmz ɑɹ juzd, əmʌŋ əm ðə dɑɹk wʌn, fɑðɝ ə laɪz, saɪtblɪndɝ, lɔɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪv, ʃɛpɝɾ ə ðə naɪt, hɝstbeɪn, soʊlsbeɪn, hɑɹtfæŋ, oʊld ɡɹɪm, ɡɹæsbɝnɝ, ən lifblaɪɾɝ. dɑɹkfɹɛnz kɔl ɪm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk. sʌmwʌn u simz tə bi ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ ɪl fɔɹtʃən ɪz ɔfən sɛd tə bi "neɪmɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

Dark One, naming the: Saying the true name of the Dark One (Shai'tan) draws his attention, inevitably bringing ill fortune at best, disaster at worst. For that reason, many euphemisms are used, among them the Dark One, Father of Lies, Sightblinder, Lord of the Grave, Shepherd of the Night, Hearstbane, Soulsbane, Heartfang, Old Grim, Grassburner, and Leafblighter. Darkfriends call him the Great Lord of the Dark. Someone who seems to be inviting ill fortune is often said to be "naming the Dark One."

dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ: taɪɾəl ə ði ɛɹ tə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ. ði ɛldəs dɔɾɝ ə ðə kwin səksidz əɹ mʌðɝ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn. wɪθaʊɾ ə sɝvaɪvɪŋ dɔɾɝ, ðə θɹoʊn ɡoʊz tə ðə nɪɹəs fimeɪl blʌd ɹileɪʃən ə ðə kwin.

Daughter-Heir: Title of the heir to the throne of Andor. The eldest daughter of the Queen succeeds her mother on the throne. Without a surviving daughter, the throne goes to the nearest female blood relation of the Queen.

dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪt: si lænfɝ.

Daughter of the Night: See Lanfear.

dʒɹæɡən, fɔls: əkeɪʒənəli mɛn kleɪm tə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən səmtaɪmz wʌn ə ðiz mɛn ɡeɪnz fɑloʊɪŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹikwaɪɝ ən ɑɹmi tə pʊɾ ɪt daʊn. səm əv bɪɡʌn wɔɹz ðəɾ ɪnvɑlv mɛni neɪʃənz. oʊvɝ ðə sɛntʃɝiz moʊst ə ðiz əv bɪn mɛn əneɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, bʌɾ ə fju kəd də soʊ. ɔl, haʊɛvɝ, iðɝ dɪsəpɪɹɾ əɹ wɝ kæptʃɝɾ əɹ kɪld wɪθaʊt fʊlfɪlɪŋ ɛni ʌv ðə pɹɑfəsiz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə ɹibɝθ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. ðiz mɛn ɑɹ kɔl fɔls dʒɹæɡənz. əmʌŋ ðoʊz u kəd tʃænəl, ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl wɝ ɹɑoʊlɪn dɑɹksbeɪn (θɹiθɹifaɪvθɹisɪks æb), jʊɹiən stoʊnboʊ (sɝkə wʌnθɹizɪɹoʊzɪɹoʊwʌnθɹizɪɹoʊeɪɾ æb), dɑviən (fi θɹihʌnʒɹədfɪftiwʌn), ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsən (fi naɪnθɹinaɪnfɔɹθɹi), ən lɑɡən (naɪnhʌnʒɹədnaɪntisɛvən ni). si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Dragon, false: Occasionally men claim to be the Dragon Reborn, and sometimes one of these men gains following enough to require an army to put it down. Some have begun wars that involved many nations. Over the centuries most of these have been men unable to channel the One Power, but a few could do so. All, however, either disappeared or were captured or killed without fulfilling any of the Prophecies concerning the Rebirth of the Dragon. These men are called false Dragons. Among those who could channel, the most powerful were Raolin Darksbane (33536 AB), Yurian Stonebow (circa 13001308 AB), Davian (FY 351), Guaire Amalasan (FY 93943), and Logain (997 NE). See also Dragon Reborn.

dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə: lɪɾəl noʊn ən sɛldəm spoʊkən ʌv, ðə pɹɑfəsiz, ɡɪvən ɪn ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl, fɔɹtɛl ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪl bi fɹiɾ əɡɛn tə tʌtʃ ðə wɝld. ən ðət luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, ðə dʒɹæɡən, bɹeɪkɝ ə ðə wɝld, wɪl bi ɹibɔɹn tə faɪt tɑɹmən ɡdən, ðə læs bæɾəl əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

Dragon, Prophecies of the: Little known and seldom spoken of, the Prophecies, given in The Karaethon Cycle, foretell that the Dark One will be freed again to touch the world. And that Lews Therin Telamon, the Dragon, Breaker of the World, will be reborn to fight Tarmon Gai'don, the Last Battle against the Shadow. See also Dragon, the.

dʒɹæɡən, ðə: ðə neɪm baɪ wɪtʃ luz θɝɪn tɛləmən wɑz noʊn dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪn ðə mædnəs ðəɾ oʊvɝtʊk ɔl meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, luz θɝɪn kɪld ɛvɹi lɪvɪŋ pɝsən u kæɹiɾ ɛni ʌv ɪz blʌd, əz wɛl əz ɛvɹiwʌn i lʌvd, ðʌs ɝnɪŋ ðə neɪm kɪnsleɪɝ. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn; dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə.

Dragon, the: The name by which Lews Therin Telamon was known during the War of the Shadow. In the madness that overtook all male Aes Sedai, Lews Therin killed every living person who carried any of his blood, as well as everyone he loved, thus earning the name Kinslayer. See also Dragon Reborn; Dragon, Prophecies of the.

dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn: əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə pɹɑfəsi ən lɛdʒən ðə dʒɹæɡən wɪl bi bɔɹn əɡɛn ət mænkaɪnz ɡɹeɪɾəst aʊɝ ə nid tə seɪv ðə wɝld. ðɪs ɪz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ pipəl lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə, boʊθ kəz ðə pɹɑfəsiz seɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl bɹɪŋ ə nu bɹeɪkɪŋ tə ðə wɝld ən kəz luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ, ðə dʒɹæɡən, ɪz ə neɪm tə meɪk mɛn ʃʌɾɝ, ivən mɔɹ ðən θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz æftɝ ɪz dɛθ. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən, ðə; dʒɹæɡən, fɔls; dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə.

Dragon Reborn: According to prophecy and legend the Dragon will be born again at mankind's greatest hour of need to save the world. This is not something people look forward to, both because the Prophecies say the Dragon Reborn will bring a new Breaking to the world and because Lews Therin Kinslayer, the Dragon, is a name to make men shudder, even more than three thousand years after his death. See also Dragon, the; Dragon, false; Dragon, Prophecies of the.

dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz: mɛn ən wɪmən eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə ʃædoʊ dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, æktɪŋ əz kəmændɝz ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk fɔɹsɪz. əkeɪʒənəli kənfjuzd wɪð ðə fɔɹseɪkən baɪ ðə lɛs wɛl ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd.

Dreadlords: Men and women able to channel the One Power, who went over to the Shadow during the Trolloc Wars, acting as commanders of the Trolloc forces. Occasionally confused with the Forsaken by the less well educated.

dʒɹimɝ: si tæləns.

Dreamer: See Talents.

ɪleɪɾə (ɛ-laɪ-dɑ): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. fɔɹmɝ ædvaɪzɝ tə kwin mɔɹɡeɪs ʌv ændɝ. ʃi səmtaɪmz əz ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ.

Elaida (eh-LY-da): An Aes Sedai of the Red Ajah. Former advisor to Queen Morgase of Andor. She sometimes has the Foretelling.

ɪleɪn ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd (tʃɹɑ-kænd): kwin mɔɹɡeɪsəz dɔɾɝ, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ. naʊ ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. hɝ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən lɪli.

Elayne of House Trakand (trah-KAND): Queen Morgase's daughter, the Daughter-Heir to the throne of Andor. Now in training to be Aes Sedai. Her sign is a golden lily.

fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ (fɑɹ dɑ-ɹaɪz maɪ): lɪɾɝəli "meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ." ə wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾi ʌv ði il, wɪtʃ, ənlaɪk ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz, ədmɪts wɪmən ən oʊnli wɪmən. eɪ meɪɾən meɪ nɑt mɛɹi ən ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə səsaɪəɾi, nɔɹ meɪ ʃi faɪt waɪl kæɹiɪŋ ə tʃaɪld. ɛni tʃaɪl bɔɹn tə ə meɪɾən ɪz ɡɪvən tə ənʌðɝ wʊmən tə ɹeɪz, ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ ðət noʊ wʌn noʊz u ðə tʃaɪlz mʌðɝ wɑz. ("ju meɪ bɪlɔŋ tə noʊ mæn, nɔɹ meɪ ɛni mæn bɪlɔŋ tə ju, nɔɹ ɛni tʃaɪld. ðə spɪɹ ɪz jəɹ lʌvɝ, jəɹ tʃaɪld, ən jəɹ laɪf.") ðiz tʃɪlʒɹən ɑɹ tʃɹɛʒɝd, fəɹ ɪts pɹɑfəsaɪd ðəɾ ə tʃaɪl bɔɹn ʌv ə meɪɾən wɪl junaɪt ðə klænz ən ɹɪtɝn ði il tə ðə ɡɹeɪtnəs ðeɪ nu dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. si ɔlsoʊ il; il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz.

Far Dareis Mai (FAHR DAH-rize MY): Literally "Maidens of the Spear." A warrior society of the Aiel, which, unlike any of the others, admits women and only women. A Maiden may not marry and remain in the society, nor may she fight while carrying a child. Any child born to a Maiden is given to another woman to raise, in such a way that no one knows who the child's mother was. ("You may belong to no man, nor may any man belong to you, nor any child. The spear is your lover, your child, and your life.") These children are treasured, for it is prophesied that a child born of a Maiden will unite the clans and return the Aiel to the greatness they knew during the Age of Legends. See also Aiel; Aiel warrior societies.

fɛtʃɪz: si mɹdʒɹɑl.

Fetches: See Myrddraal.

faɪv paʊɝz, ðə: ðəɹ ɑɹ θɹɛdz tə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən ɛniwʌn u kən tʃænəl kən juʒəwəli ɡɹæsp səm θɹɛdz bɛɾɝ ðən ʌðɝz. ðiz θɹɛdz ɑɹ neɪmd əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə sɔɹts ə θɪŋz ðət kən bi dʌn juzɪŋ əm - ɝθ, ɛɹ (səmtaɪmz kɔld wɪnd), faɪɝ, wɔɾɝ, ən spɪɹət - ən ɑɹ kɔl ðə faɪv paʊɝz. ɛni wildɝ ə ðə paʊɝ wɪl əv ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ dɪɡɹi ʌv stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð wʌn, əɹ pɑsəbli tu, ʌv ðiz, ən lɛsɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ði ʌðɝz. səm fju meɪ hæv ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð θɹi, bʌt sɪns ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz noʊ wʌn əz hæd ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð ɔl faɪv. ivən ðən ðɪs wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɛɹ. ðə dɪɡɹi ʌv stʃɹɛŋkθ kən vɛɹi ɡɹeɪtli bɪtwin ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz. pɝfɔɹmɪŋ sɝɾən æks wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɹikwaɪɝz ði əbɪləɾi tə wiv floʊz ɪn wʌn əɹ mɔɹ ə ðə faɪv paʊɝz. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, stɑɹɾɪŋ əɹ kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ə faɪɝ ɹikwaɪɝz faɪɝ, ən əfɛktɪŋ ðə wɛðɝ ɹikwaɪɝz ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ, waɪl hilɪŋ ɹikwaɪɝz ɛɹ, wɔɾɝ ən spɪɹət. waɪl spɪɹət wɑz faʊn ikwəli ɪn mɛn ən ɪn wɪmən, ɡɹeɪɾ əbɪləɾi wɪð ɝθ ænslæʃɔɹ faɪɝ wɑz faʊn mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɔfən əmʌŋ mɛn; wɪð wɔɾɝ ænslæʃɔɹ ɛɹ əmʌŋ wɪmən. ðəɹ wɝ ɪksɛpʃənz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz soʊ ɔfən soʊ ðəɾ ɝθ ən faɪɝ keɪm tə bi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əz meɪl paʊɝz, ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ əz fimeɪl. dʒɛnɝəli, noʊ əbɪləɾi ɪz kənsɪɾɝd stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ, ðoʊ ðəɹ ɪz ə seɪɪŋ əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ: "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɹɑk soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðət wɔɾɝ ən wɪn kænɑt wɛɹ ɪɾ əweɪ, noʊ faɪɝ soʊ fɪɹs ðət wɔɾɝ kænɑt kwɛntʃ ɪɾ əɹ wɪn snʌf ɪɾ aʊt." ɪt ʃəd bi noʊɾəd ðəɾ ɛni ɪkwɪvələn seɪɪŋ əmʌŋ meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz lɔŋ lɔst.

Five Powers, the: There are threads to the One Power, and anyone who can channel can usually grasp some threads better than others. These threads are named according to the sorts of things that can be done using them - Earth, Air (sometimes called Wind), Fire, Water, and Spirit - and are called the Five Powers. Any wielder of the Power will have a greater degree of strength with one, or possibly two, of these, and lesser strength in the others. Some few may have great strength with three, but since the Age of Legends no one has had great strength with all five. Even then this was extremely rare. The degree of strength can vary greatly between individuals. Performing certain acts with the One Power requires the ability to weave flows in one or more of the Five Powers. For example, starting or controlling a fire requires Fire, and affecting the weather requires Air and Water, while Healing requires Air, Water and Spirit. While Spirit was found equally in men and in women, great ability with Earth and/or Fire was found much more often among men; with Water and/or Air among women. There were exceptions, but it was so often so that Earth and Fire came to be regarded as male Powers, Air and Water as female. Generally, no ability is considered stronger than any other, though there is a saying among Aes Sedai: "There is no rock so strong that water and wind cannot wear it away, no fire so fierce that water cannot quench it or wind snuff it out." It should be noted that any equivalent saying among male Aes Sedai is long lost.

fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn: sɪmbəl ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə staɪlaɪzd ɹɛpɹəzɛnteɪʃən ʌv ə fleɪm; ə waɪt tɪɹdʒɹɑp wɪð ðə pɔɪn ʌpwɝd.

Flame of Tar Valon: Symbol of Tar Valon, the Amyrlin Seat, and the Aes Sedai. A stylized representation of a flame; a white teardrop with the point upward.

fɔɹseɪkən, ðə: neɪm ɡɪvən tə θɝtin ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, wɪtʃ meɪɾ əm əmʌŋ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɛvɝ noʊn, hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ðə pɹɑməs ʌv ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə boʊθ lɛdʒən ən fɹæɡməntɛɹi ɹɛkɝdz, ðeɪ wɝ ɪmpɹɪzən əlɔŋ wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn wən ɪz pɹɪzən wɑz ɹisild. ðɛɹ neɪmz - əmʌŋ əm lænfɝ, bɛləl, sɑmaɪl, æzmɑɾiən, ɹɑvɪn, ən ɪʃəml - ɑɹ stɪl juz tə fɹaɪɾən tʃɪlʒɹən.

Forsaken, the: Name given to thirteen of the most powerful Aes Sedai of the Age of Legends, which made them among the most powerful ever known, who went over to the Dark One during the War of the Shadow in return for the promise of immortality. According to both legend and fragmentary records, they were imprisoned along with the Dark One when his prison was resealed. Their names - among them Lanfear, Be'lal, Sammael, Asmodean, Rahvin, and Ishamael - are still used to frighten children.

fɔɹtʃɹəs ə ðə laɪt: ðə ɡɹeɪt fɔɹtʃɹəs ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, loʊkeɪɾəd ɪn æmədɔɹ (ɑ-mɑ-dɔɹ), ðə kæpəɾəl ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə (ɑ-mɑ-di-tʃi-ɑ). ðəɹ ɪz ə kɪŋ ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə, bʌt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɹul ɪn ɔl bʌt neɪm. si ɔlsoʊ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Fortress of the Light: The great fortress of the Children of the Light, located in Amador (AH-mah-door), the capital of Amadicia (AH-mah-DEE-cee-ah). There is a King of Amadicia, but the Children rule in all but name. See also Children of the Light.

ɡeɪɾɪn (ɡaɪ-din): lɪɾɝəli "bɹʌðɝ tə bæɾəlz." ə taɪɾəl juz baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝz. si ɔlsoʊ wɔɹɾɝ.

Gaidin (GYE-deen): Literally "Brother to Battles." A title used by Aes Sedai for the Warders. See also Warder.

ɡɑləd (ɡɑ-lɑd): si dəmədʒɹd, lɔɹd ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd.

Galad (gah-LAHD): See Damodred, Lord Galadedrid.

ɡeɪm ə haʊzɪz, ðə: si deɪz deɪmɑɹ.

Game of Houses, the: See Daes Dae'mar.

ɡɔl (): ən il ə ði ɪmɹən sɛpt ə ðə ʃɝəd, ə ʃeɪin tɑl, ə stoʊn dɔɡ.

Gaul (GAHWL): An Aiel of the Imran sept of the Shaarad, a Shae'en M'taal, a Stone Dog.

ɡɔɪn (ɡɑ-wɪn) ʌv haʊs tʃɹəkənd (tʃɹɑ-kænd): kwin mɔɹɡeɪsəz sʌn, ən ɪleɪnz bɹʌðɝ, hu wɪl bi fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd wən ɪleɪn əsɛnz tə ðə θɹoʊn. hɪz saɪn ɪz ə waɪt bɔɹ.

Gawyn (GAH-wihn) of House Trakand (trah-KAND): Queen Morgase's son, and Elayne's brother, who will be First Prince of the Sword when Elayne ascends to the throne. His sign is a white boar.

dʒɛntəlɪŋ: ði ækt, pɝfɔɹm baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv ʃʌɾɪŋ ɔf ə meɪl u kən tʃænəl fɹəm ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðɪs ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi kəz ɛni mæn u lɝnz tə tʃænəl wɪl ɡoʊ ɪnseɪn fɹəm ðə teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn ən wɪl ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli də hɔɹəbəl θɪŋz wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn ɪz mædnəs. ə mæn u hæz bɪn dʒɛntəl kən stɪl sɛns ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, bʌɾ i kænɑt tʌtʃ ɪt. wʌtɛvɝ mædnəs əz kʌm bɪfɔɹ dʒɛntəlɪŋ ɪz ɝɛstəd baɪ ði ækt ə dʒɛntəlɪŋ, bʌt nɑt kjʊɹd baɪ ɪt, ən ɪf ɪts dʌn sun ɪnʌf dɛθ kən bi əvɝɾəd. si ɔlsoʊ wʌn paʊɝ, ðə; stɪlɪŋ.

gentling: The act, performed by Aes Sedai, of shutting off a male who can channel from the One Power. This is necessary because any man who learns to channel will go insane from the taint on saidin and will almost certainly do horrible things with the Power in his madness. A man who has been gentled can still sense the True Source, but he cannot touch it. Whatever madness has come before gentling is arrested by the act of gentling, but not cured by it, and if it is done soon enough death can be averted. See also One Power, the; stilling.

ɡlimən: ə tʃɹævlɪŋ stɔɹitɛlɝ, mjuzɪʃən, dʒʌɡəlɝ, tʌmblɝ, ən ɔl-ɝaʊn ɛntɝteɪnɝ. noʊn baɪ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪdmɑɹk kloʊks ə mɛni-kʌlɝd pætʃəz, ɡlimən pɝfɔɹm meɪnli ɪn ðə vɪlədʒəz ən smɔlɝ taʊnz.

gleeman: A traveling storyteller, musician, juggler, tumbler, and all-around entertainer. Known by their trademark cloaks of many-colored patches, gleemen perform mainly in the villages and smaller towns.

ɡɹeɪ mæn: sʌmwʌn u hæz vɑləntɛɹəli sɝɛndɝɾ ɪz əɹ əɹ soʊl ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə bɪkʌm ən əsæsən sɝvɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊ. ɡɹeɪ mɛn ɑɹ soʊ ɔɹɾənɛɹi ɪn əpɪɹəns ðət ði aɪ kən slaɪd ɹaɪt pæst wɪθaʊt noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðɛm. ðə væs mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv ɡɹeɪ mɛn ɑɹ ɪndid mɛn, bʌɾ ə smɔl nʌmbɝ ɑɹ wɪmən.

Gray Man: Someone who has voluntarily surrendered his or her soul in order to become an assassin serving the Shadow. Gray Men are so ordinary in appearance that the eye can slide right past without noticing them. The vast majority of Gray Men are indeed men, but a small number are women.

ɡɹeɪt blaɪt, ðə: ə ɹidʒən ɪn ðə fɑɹ nɔɹθ, ɪntaɪɝli kɝʌptɪd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ə hɔn ə tʃɹɑləks, mɹdʒɹɑl, ən ʌðɝ kɹitʃɝz ə ðə ʃædoʊ.

Great Blight, the: A region in the far north, entirely corrupted by the Dark One. A haunt of Trollocs, Myrddraal, and other creatures of the Shadow.

ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, ðə: si deɪz deɪmɑɹ.

Great Game, the: See Daes Dae'mar.

ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn, ðə: ə saɪkəl ə stɔɹiz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi sɝtʃ fəɹ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ɪn ðə jɪɹz bɪtwin ði ɛn ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ən ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ɪf toʊld ɪn ɪts ɪntaɪɝɾi, ðə saɪkəl wəd teɪk mɛni deɪz. si ɔlsoʊ hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ.

Great Hunt of the Horn, The: A cycle of stories concerning the legendary search for the Horn of Valere, in the years between the end of the Trolloc Wars and the beginning of the War of the Hundred Years. If told in its entirety, the cycle would take many days. See also Horn of Valere.

ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk: ðə neɪm baɪ wɪtʃ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɹəfɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kleɪmɪŋ ðət tə juz ɪz tʃɹu neɪm wəd bi blæsfəməs.

Great Lord of the Dark: The name by which Darkfriends refer to the Dark One, claiming that to use his true name would be blasphemous.

ɡɹeɪt sɝpənt: ə sɪmbəl fəɹ taɪm ən ɪtɝnəɾi, eɪntʃən bɪfɔɹ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz bɪɡæn, kənsɪstɪŋ ʌv ə sɝpən iɾɪŋ ɪts oʊn teɪl. ə ɹɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɪz əwɔɹɾəd tə wɪmən u hæv bɪn ɹeɪz tə ði æksɛptɪɾ əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Great Serpent: A symbol for time and eternity, ancient before the Age of Legends began, consisting of a serpent eating its own tail. A ring in the shape of the Great Serpent is awarded to women who have been raised to the Accepted among the Aes Sedai.

ɡɹɪm, oʊld: si dɑɹk wʌn; waɪl hʌnt.

Grim, Old: See Dark One; Wild Hunt.

hæfmən: si mɹdʒɹɑl.

Halfman: See Myrddraal.

hɔkwɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ: ə lɛdʒəndɛɹi kɪŋ (ɹul fi naɪnfɔɹθɹinaɪnfɔɹ) hu junaɪɾəd ɔl ðə lænz wɛst ə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. hi ivən sɛn ɑɹmiz əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən (fi naɪnhʌnʒɹədnaɪntitu), bʌɾ ɔl kɑntækt wɪð ðiz wɑz lɔst əɾ ɪz dɛθ, wɪtʃ sɛɾ ɔf ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. hɪz saɪn wɑz ə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪt. si ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz.

Hawkwing, Artur: A legendary king (ruled FY 94394) who united all the lands west of the Spine of the World. He even sent armies across the Aryth Ocean (FY 992), but all contact with these was lost at his death, which set off the War of the Hundred Years. His sign was a golden hawk in flight. See also War of the Hundred Years.

hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn: si kælændɝ.

Heart of the Stone: See Callandor.

hɑɹtstoʊn: ən ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl sʌbstəns kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɛni fɔɹs juzd ɪn ən ətɛmp tə bɹeɪk ɪts əbzɔɹbd, meɪkɪŋ hɑɹtstoʊn stʃɹɔŋɝ. ənʌðɝ neɪm fəɹ kwəndɪlɝ.

heartstone: An indestructible substance created during the Age of Legends. Any force used in an attempt to break it is absorbed, making heartstone stronger. Another name for cuendillar.

haɪd: ə junəɾ ʌv ɛɹiə fəɹ mɛʒɝɪŋ lænd, ikwəl tə wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz baɪ wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz.

hide: A unit of area for measuring land, equal to 100 paces by 100 paces.

haɪ lɔɹdz ə tɛɹ: æktɪŋ əz ə kaʊnsəl, ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ɑɹ ðə ɹulɝz ə ðə neɪʃən ə tɛɹ, wɪtʃ əz niðɝ kɪŋ nɔɹ kwin. ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz ɑɹ nɑt fɪkst, ən əv vɛɹiɾ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz fɹəm əz mɛni əz twɛnti tə əz fju əz sɪks. nɑt tə bi kənfjuzd wɪð ðə lɔɹdz ə ðə lænd, hu ɑɹ lɛsɝ tɛɹən lɔɹdz.

High Lords of Tear: Acting as a council, the High Lords are the rulers of the nation of Tear, which has neither king nor queen. Their numbers are not fixed, and have varied over the years from as many as twenty to as few as six. Not to be confused with the Lords of the Land, who are lesser Tairen lords.

hɑpɝ: ə wʊlf.

Hopper: A wolf.

hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ (vɑ-lɪɹ): ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi əbdʒɛkt ə ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn. ðə hɔɹn səpoʊzədli kən kɔl bæk dɛd hɪɹoʊz fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv tə faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ.

Horn of Valere (vah-LEER): The legendary object of the Great Hunt of the Horn. The Horn supposedly can call back dead heroes from the grave to fight against the Shadow.

hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz, ðə: wʌn hʌnʒɹəd meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, əmʌŋ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, hu, lɛd baɪ luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, lɔntʃt ðə faɪnəl stʃɹoʊk ðəɾ ɛndəd ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ baɪ silɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn bæk ɪndə hɪz pɹɪzən. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz kaʊntɝstʃɹoʊk teɪntɪd seɪɾɪn; ðə hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz wɛn mæɾ ən bɪɡæn ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. si ɔlsoʊ taɪm ə mædnəs; bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld; tʃɹu sɔɹs; wʌn paʊɝ.

Hundred Companions, the: One hundred male Aes Sedai, among the most powerful of the Age of Legends, who, led by Lews Therin Telamon, launched the final stroke that ended the War of the Shadow by sealing the Dark One back into his prison. The Dark One's counterstroke tainted saidin; the Hundred Companions went mad and began the Breaking of the World. See also Time of Madness; Breaking of the World; True Source; One Power.

ɪljən (ɪl-li-æn): ə ɡɹeɪt pɔɹɾ ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðə neɪʃən ə ðə seɪm neɪm.

Illian (IHL-lee-an): A great port on the Sea of Storms, capital city of the nation of the same name.

ɪluməneɪɾɝz, ɡɪld ʌv: ə səsaɪəɾi ðət hoʊlz ðə sikɹəɾ ə meɪkɪŋ faɪɹwɝks. ɪt ɡɑɹdz ðɪs sikɹət vɛɹi kloʊsli, ivən tə mɝɾɝ. ðə ɡɪld ɡeɪnz ɪts neɪm fɹəm ðə ɡɹæn dɪspleɪz, kɔld ɪluməneɪʃənz, ðəɾ ɪt pɹəvaɪdz fəɹ ɹulɝz ən səmtaɪmz fəɹ ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz. lɛsɝ faɪɹwɝks ɑɹ soʊl fəɹ jus baɪ ʌðɝz, bʌt wɪð daɪɹ wɔɹnɪŋz ə ðə dɪzæstɝ ðət kən ɹɪzʌl fɹəm ətɛmptɪŋ tə lɝn wʌɾ ɪz ɪnsaɪd ðɛm. ðə ɡɪl tʃæptɝ haʊs ɪz ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ, ðə kæpəɾəl ə tæɹɑbən. ðə ɡɪld ɪstæblɪʃt wʌn ʌðɝ tʃæptɝ haʊs ɪn kɛɹhin, bʌɾ ɪts noʊ lɔŋɡɝ æktɪv.

Illuminators, Guild of: A society that holds the secret of making fireworks. It guards this secret very closely, even to murder. The Guild gains its name from the grand displays, called Illuminations, that it provides for rulers and sometimes for great lords. Lesser fireworks are sold for use by others, but with dire warnings of the disaster that can result from attempting to learn what is inside them. The Guild chapter house is in Tanchico, the capital of Tarabon. The Guild established one other chapter house in Cairhien, but it is no longer active.

ɪʃəml (ɪ-ʃɑ-meɪ-ɛl): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "bɪtʃɹeɪɝ ə hoʊp." wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. neɪm ɡɪvən tə ðə liɾɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪn ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪts sɛd ðəɾ ivən i fɝɡɑɾ ɪz tʃɹu neɪm. si ɔlsoʊ fɔɹseɪkən.

Ishamael (ih-SHAH-may-EHL): In the Old Tongue, "Betrayer of Hope." One of the Forsaken. Name given to the leader of the Aes Sedai who went over to the Dark One in the War of the Shadow. It is said that even he forgot his true name. See also Forsaken.

kæɹæəθən saɪkəl, ðə (kɑ-ɹi-ɑ-θɑn): si dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə.

Karaethon Cycle, The (ka-REE-ah-thon): See Dragon, Prophecies of the.

leɪmən (leɪ-mæn): ə kɪŋ ə kɛɹhin, ʌv haʊs dəmədʒɹd, hu lɔst ɪz θɹoʊn ɪn ði il wɔɹ. si ɔlsoʊ il wɔɹ; ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə.

Laman (LAY-mahn): A king of Cairhien, of House Damodred, who lost his throne in the Aiel War. See also Aiel War; Avendoraldera.

læn (læn); ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən (ɑl-læn mæn-dʒɹæɡ-ɔɹ-æn): eɪ wɔɹɾɝ, bɑndəd tə mɔɪɹeɪn. ʌnkɹoʊn kɪŋ ə mɔlkiɝ, daɪ ʃæn, ən ðə læst sɝvaɪvɪŋ mɔlkɪɹi lɔɹd. si ɔlsoʊ wɔɹɾɝ; mɔɪɹeɪn; mɔlkiɝ.

Lan (LAN); al'Lan Mandragoran (AHL-LAN man-DRAG-or-an): A Warder, bonded to Moiraine. Uncrowned King of Malkier, Dai Shan, and the last surviving Malkieri lord. See also Warder; Moiraine; Malkier.

lænfɝ (læn-fɪɹ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪt." wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, pɝhæps ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl nɛks tə ɪʃəml. ənlaɪk ði ʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən, ʃi tʃoʊz ðɪs neɪm hɝsɛlf. ʃiz sɛd tə hæv bɪn ɪn lʌv wɪð luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, ən tə hæv heɪɾəd ɪz waɪf, aɪlaɪɛnə. si ɔlsoʊ fɔɹseɪkən; dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

Lanfear (LAN-fear): In the Old Tongue, "Daughter of the Night." One of the Forsaken, perhaps the most powerful next to Ishamael. Unlike the other Forsaken, she chose this name herself. She is said to have been in love with Lews Therin Telamon, and to have hated his wife, Ilyena. See also Forsaken; Dragon, the.

liɡ: si lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv.

league: See length, units of.

lin (li-æn-ɛ): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ, ən kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz. si ɔlsoʊ ədʒɑ; kɹɑnəkəlz, kipɝ ə ðə.

Leane (lee-AHN-eh): An Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah, and Keeper of the Chronicles. See also Ajah; Chronicles, Keeper of the.

lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv: tɛn ɪntʃəz ikwəlz wʌn fʊt; θɹi fiɾ ikwəlz wʌn peɪs; tu peɪsɪz ikwəlz wʌn spæn; wʌnθaʊzən spænz ikwəlz wʌn maɪl; fɔɹ maɪlz ikwəlz wʌn liɡ.

length, units of: 10 inches = 1 foot; 3 feet = 1 pace; 2 paces = 1 span; 1000 spans = 1 mile; 4 miles = 1 league.

luz θɝɪn tɛləmən; luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ: si dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

Lews Therin Telamon; Lews Therin Kinslayer: See Dragon, the.

liɑnʒɹɪn (li-æn-dʒɹɪn): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fɔɹmɝli ʌv ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, fɹəm tæɹɑbən. naʊ noʊn tə bi ʌv ðə blæk ədʒɑ.

Liandrin (lee-AHN-drihn): An Aes Sedai formerly of the Red Ajah, from Tarabon. Now known to be of the Black Ajah.

laɪt, tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə: si tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Light, Children of the: See Children of the Light.

lɔɪəl (lɔɪ-ɑl) sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən: ən oʊɡiɝ fɹəm stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ.

Loial (LOY-ahl) son of Arent son of Halan: An Ogier from Stedding Shangtai.

mɔlkiɝ (mɑl-kiɪɹ): ə neɪʃən, wʌns wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, naʊ kənsum baɪ ðə blaɪt. ðə saɪn ə mɔlkiɝ wɑz ə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn ɪn flaɪt.

Malkier (mahl-KEER): A nation, once one of the Borderlands, now consumed by the Blight. The sign of Malkier was a golden crane in flight.

meɪnɛðɝən (mæn--ɛɹ-ɛn): wʌn ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz ðət meɪd ðə sɛkən kʌvənənt. ɔlsoʊ ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðət neɪʃən. boʊθ sɪɾi ən neɪʃən wɝ ʌɾɝli dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz.

Manetheren (mahn-EHTH-ehr-ehn): One of the Ten Nations that made the Second Covenant. Also the capital city of that nation. Both city and nation were utterly destroyed in the Trolloc Wars.

mæsimə (mɑ-si-mɑ): eɪ ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝ u heɪts il.

Masema (mah-SEE-mah): A Shienaran soldier who hates Aiel.

min (meɪ-ɛn): sɪɾi-steɪt ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz ðət dɝaɪvz ɪts wɛlθ ən ɪts ɪndɪpɛndəns fɹəm nɑlədʒ ʌv wɛɹ tə faɪn ði ɔɪlfɪʃ ʃoʊlz, wɪtʃ ɹaɪvəl ɪn ɛkənɑmɪk ɪmpɔɹɾəns ði ɑləv ɡɹoʊvz ə tɛɹ, ɪljən, ən tæɹɑbən. ɔɪlfɪʃ ən ɑlɪvz pɹəvaɪd nɪɹli ɔl læmp ɔɪl. ðə kɝən ɹulɝ ə min ɪz bɹəleɪn, ðə fɝst ə min. ðə ɹulɝz ə min kleɪm tə bi dɪsɛndəns ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. ðə saɪn ə min ɪz ə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪt.

Mayene (may-EHN): City-state on the Sea of Storms that derives its wealth and its independence from knowledge of where to find the oilfish shoals, which rival in economic importance the olive groves of Tear, Illian, and Tarabon. Oilfish and olives provide nearly all lamp oil. The current ruler of Mayene is Berelain, the First of Mayene. The Rulers of Mayene claim to be descendants of Artur Hawkwing. The sign of Mayene is a golden hawk in flight.

mɛɹɪlɪn, tɑm (mɛɹ-ɹɪ-lɪn, tɑm): ə ɡlimən, ən wʌns ðə lʌvɝ ə kwin mɔɹɡeɪs.

Merrilin, Thom (MER-rih-lihn, TOM): A gleeman, and once the lover of Queen Morgase.

maɪl: si lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv.

mile: See length, units of.

mɪn (mɪn): ə jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð ði əbɪləɾi tə ɹid θɪŋz əbaʊt pipəl ɪn ði ɔʊɹəz ən ɪmədʒəz ʃi səmtaɪmz siz sɝaʊndɪŋ ðɛm.

Min (MIN): A young woman with the ability to read things about people in the auras and images she sometimes sees surrounding them.

mɔɪɹeɪn (mwɑ-ɹeɪn): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ. bɔɹn ɪn haʊs dəmədʒɹd, ðoʊ nɑɾ ɪn laɪn ə səksɛʃən tə ðə θɹoʊn, ʃi wɑz ɹeɪzd ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ɪn kɛɹhin.

Moiraine (mwah-RAIN): An Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah. Born in House Damodred, though not in line of succession to the throne, she was raised in the Royal Palace in Cairhien.

mɔɹɡeɪs (mʊɹ-ɡeɪz): baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt, kwin ʌv ændɝ, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə ɹɛlm, pɹətɛktɝ ə ðə pipəl, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd. hɝ saɪn ɪz θɹi ɡoʊldən kiz. ðə saɪn ə haʊs tʃɹəkən ɪz ə sɪlvɝ kistoʊn.

Morgase (moor-GAYZ): By the Grace of the Light, Queen of Andor, Defender of the Realm, Protector of the People, High Seat of House Trakand. Her sign is three golden keys. The sign of House Trakand is a silver keystone.

mɹdʒɹɑl (-dʒɹɑl): kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kəmændɝz ə ðə tʃɹɑləks. twɪstəɾ ɔfspɹɪŋ ə tʃɹɑləks ɪn wɪtʃ ðə hjumən stɑk juz tə kɹieɪt ðə tʃɹɑləks əz ɹisɝfəst, bʌt teɪntɪd baɪ ði ivəl ðət meɪd ðə tʃɹɑləks. ðeɪv noʊ aɪz, bʌt kən si laɪk iɡəlz ɪn laɪɾ əɹ dɑɹk. ðeɪv sɝɾən paʊɝz stɛmɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə kɑz pɛɹəlaɪzɪŋ fɪɹ wɪð ə lʊk ən ði əbɪləɾi tə vænɪʃ wɛɹɛvɝ ðəɹ ɑɹ ʃædoʊz. ðeɪv fju noʊn wiknəsəz, bʌt wʌn ə ðiz ɪz ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɪlʌktən tə kɹɔs ɹʌnɪŋ wɔɾɝ. ɪn dɪfɹən lænz ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊn baɪ mɛni neɪmz, əmʌŋ əm hæfmən, ði aɪləs, ʃæɾoʊmən, lɝk, fɛtʃ, ən feɪd.

Myrddraal (MUHRD-draal): Creatures of the Dark One, commanders of the Trollocs. Twisted offspring of Trollocs in which the human stock used to create the Trollocs has resurfaced, but tainted by the evil that made the Trollocs. They have no eyes, but can see like eagles in light or dark. They have certain powers stemming from the Dark One, including the ability to cause paralyzing fear with a look and the ability to vanish wherever there are shadows. They have few known weaknesses, but one of these is that they are reluctant to cross running water. In different lands they are known by many names, among them Halfman, the Eyeless, Shadowman, Lurk, Fetch, and Fade.

nɪdil, kɔɹiənɪn: si tæləns.

Nedeal, Corianin: See Talents.

naɪl, peɪdʒɹən (naɪ-ɔl, peɪ-dʒɹɑn): lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. si ɔlsoʊ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Niall, Pedron (NEYE-awl, PAY-drohn): Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light. See also Children of the Light.

oʊðz, θɹi: ði oʊðz teɪkən baɪ ən æksɛptɪɾ u ɪz biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. spoʊkən waɪl hoʊldɪŋ ði oʊθ ɹɑd, ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət meɪks oʊðz baɪndɪŋ. ðeɪ ɑɹ: (wʌn) tə spik noʊ wɝd ðəɾ ɪz nɑt tʃɹu. (tu) tə meɪk noʊ wɛpən wɪð wɪtʃ wʌn mæn meɪ kɪl ənʌðɝ. (θɹi) nɛvɝ tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən ɪksɛpt əɡɛnst ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, əɹ ɪn ðə læst ɪkstʃɹim ə dɪfɛns ə hɝ oʊn laɪf, əɹ ðəɾ ə hɝ wɔɹɾɝ əɹ ənʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðiz oʊðz wɝ nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ɹikwaɪɝd, bʌt vɛɹiəs ɪvɛns bɪfɔɹ ən sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ kɑzd əm tə bi nɛsəsɛɹi. ðə sɛkən oʊθ wɑz ðə fɝst ədɑptəd, ɪn ɹiækʃən tə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ. ðə fɝst oʊθ, waɪl hɛl tə ðə lɛɾɝ, ɪz ɔfən sɝkəmvɛntɪd baɪ kɛɹfəl spikɪŋ. ɪts bɪliv ðət ðə læs tu ɑɹ ɪnvaɪələbəl.

Oaths, Three: The oaths taken by an Accepted who is being raised to Aes Sedai. Spoken while holding the Oath Rod, a ter'angreal that makes oaths binding. They are: (1) To speak no word that is not true. (2) To make no weapon with which one man may kill another. (3) Never to use the One Power as a weapon except against Shadowspawn, or in the last extreme of defense of her own life, or that of her Warder or another Aes Sedai. These oaths were not always required, but various events before and since the Breaking caused them to be necessary. The second oath was the first adopted, in reaction to the War of the Power. The first oath, while held to the letter, is often circumvented by careful speaking. It is believed that the last two are inviolable.

oʊɡiɝ (oʊhaɪoʊ-dʒɛɹ): (wʌn) ə nɑn-hjumən ɹeɪs, kɛɹəktɝaɪz baɪ ɡɹeɪt haɪt (tɛn fiɾ ɪz ævɝɪdʒ fəɹ ədʌl meɪlz), bɹɔd, ɔlmoʊst snaʊt laɪk noʊzɪz, ən lɔŋ, tʌftəɾ ɪɹz. ðeɪ lɪv ɪn ɛɹiəz kɔl stɛɾɪŋ. ðɛɹ sɛpɝeɪʃən fɹəm ðiz stɛɾɪŋ æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld (ə taɪm kɔl ði ɛɡzaɪl baɪ oʊɡiɝ) ɹɪzʌltɪɾ ɪn wʌɾ ɪz kɔl ðə lɔŋɪŋ; ən oʊɡiɝ u ɪz tu lɔŋ aʊɾ ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ, sɪkənz ən daɪz. waɪdli noʊn əz wʌnʒɹəs stoʊnmeɪsɑnz u bɪl ðə ɡɹeɪt hjumən sɪɾiz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, ðeɪ kənsɪɾɝ stoʊnwɝk sɪmpli sʌmθɪŋ lɝn dʊɹɪŋ ði ɛɡzaɪl ən nɑɾ əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz tɛndɪŋ ðə tʃɹiz ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ, ɪspɛʃli ðə taʊɝɪŋ ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz. ɪksɛp fəɹ stoʊnwɝk, ðeɪ ɹɛɹli liv ðɛɹ stɛɾɪŋ ən tɪpəkli hæv lɪɾəl kɑntækt wɪð hjumənkaɪnd. nɑlədʒ ə ðɛm əmʌŋ hjumənz ɪz spɑɹs, ən mɛni bɪliv oʊɡiɝ tə bi oʊnli lɛdʒənz. ɔlðoʊ bɪliv tə bi ə pəsɪfɪk pipəl ən ɪkstʃɹimli sloʊ tə æŋɡɝ, səm oʊl stɔɹiz seɪ ðeɪ fɔɾ əlɔŋsaɪd hjumənz ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, ən kɔl əm ɪmplækəbəl ɛnəmiz. baɪ ən lɑɹdʒ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪkstʃɹimli fɑn ə nɑlədʒ, ən ðɛɹ bʊks ən stɔɹiz ɔfən kənteɪn ɪnfɝmeɪʃən lɔs tə hjumənz. ə tɪpəkəl oʊɡiɝ laɪfspæn ɪz ət lis θɹi tə fɔɹ taɪmz ðəɾ ʌv ə hjumən. (tu) ɛni ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl ə ðət nɑn-hjumən ɹeɪs. si ɔlsoʊ bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld; stɛɾɪŋ; tʃɹisɪŋʒɝ.

Ogier (OH-gehr): (1) A non-human race, characterized by great height (ten feet is average for adult males), broad, almost snout like noses, and long, tufted ears. They live in areas called stedding. Their separation from these stedding after the Breaking of the World (a time called the Exile by Ogier) resulted in what is called the Longing; an Ogier who is too long out of the stedding, sickens and dies. Widely known as wondrous stonemasons who built the great human cities after the Breaking, they consider stonework simply something learned during the Exile and not as important as tending the trees of the stedding, especially the towering Great Trees. Except for stonework, they rarely leave their stedding and typically have little contact with humankind. Knowledge of them among humans is sparse, and many believe Ogier to be only legends. Although believed to be a pacific people and extremely slow to anger, some old stories say they fought alongside humans in the Trolloc Wars, and call them implacable enemies. By and large, they are extremely fond of knowledge, and their books and stories often contain information lost to humans. A typical Ogier lifespan is at least three to four times that of a human. (2) Any individual of that non-human race. See also Breaking of the World; stedding; Treesinger.

oʊld ɡɹɪm: si dɑɹk wʌn.

Old Grim: See Dark One.

oʊl tʌŋ: ðə læŋɡwədʒ spoʊkən dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɪts dʒɛnɝəli ɪkspɛktəd ðət noʊbəlz ən ði ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd wɪl əv lɝn tə spik ðɪs, bʌt moʊs noʊ oʊnli ə fju wɝdz.

Old Tongue: The language spoken during the Age of Legends. It is generally expected that nobles and the educated will have learned to speak this, but most know only a few words.

wʌn paʊɝ, ðə: ðə paʊɝ dʒɹɔn fɹəm ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. ðə væs mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv pipəl ɑɹ kəmplitli əneɪbəl tə lɝn tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ə vɛɹi smɔl nʌmbɝ kən bi tɔt tə tʃænəl, ən ən ivən taɪniɝ nʌmbɝ əv ði əbɪləɾi ɪnbɔɹn. fəɹ ðiz fju ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə bi tɔt; ðəl tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ən tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɑnə əɹ nɑt, pɝhæps wɪθaʊɾ ivən ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ duɪŋ. ðɪs ɪnbɔɹn əbɪləɾi juʒəwəli mænəfɛsts ɪtsɛlf ɪn leɪɾ æɾəlɛsəns əɹ ɝli ədʌlthʊd. ɪf kəntʃɹoʊl ɪz nɑt tɔt, əɹ sɛlf-lɝnd (ɪkstʃɹimli dɪfəkəlt, wɪð ə səksɛs ɹeɪɾ ʌv oʊnli wʌn ɪn fɔɹ), dɛθ ɪz sɝɾən. sɪns ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, noʊ mæn əz bɪn eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɡoʊɪŋ kəmplitli, hɔɹəbli mæd, ən ðɛn, ivən ɪf hiz lɝn səm kəntʃɹoʊl, daɪɪŋ fɹəm ə weɪstɪŋ sɪknəs ðət kɑzəz ðə sʌfɝɝ tə ɹɑɾ əlaɪv, ə sɪknəs kɑzd, əz ɪz ðə mædnəs, baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn. fəɹ ə wʊmən ðə dɛθ ðət kʌmz wɪθaʊt kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə paʊɝ ɪz lɛs hɔɹəbəl, bʌɾ ɪts dɛθ dʒʌs ðə seɪm. ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝtʃ fəɹ ɡɝlz wɪð ði ɪnbɔɹn əbɪləɾi əz mʌtʃ tə seɪv ðɛɹ laɪvz əz tə ɪnkɹis ɛɛs sədaɪ nʌmbɝz, ən fəɹ mɛn wɪð ɪɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə stɑp ðə tɛɹəbəl θɪŋz ðeɪ ɪnɛvəɾəbli də wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn ðɛɹ mædnəs. si ɔlsoʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ; tʃænəl; faɪv paʊɝz; taɪm ə mædnəs; tʃɹu sɔɹs.

One Power, the: The power drawn from the True Source. The vast majority of people are completely unable to learn to channel the One Power. A very small number can be taught to channel, and an even tinier number have the ability inborn. For these few there is no need to be taught; they will touch the True Source and channel the Power whether they want to or not, perhaps without even realizing what they are doing. This inborn ability usually manifests itself in late adolescence or early adulthood. If control is not taught, or self-learned (extremely difficult, with a success rate of only one in four), death is certain. Since the Time of Madness, no man has been able to channel the Power without eventually going completely, horribly mad, and then, even if he has learned some control, dying from a wasting sickness that causes the sufferer to rot alive, a sickness caused, as is the madness, by the Dark One's taint on saidin. For a woman the death that comes without control of the Power is less horrible, but it is death just the same. Aes Sedai search for girls with the inborn ability as much to save their lives as to increase Aes Sedai numbers, and for men with it in order to stop the terrible things they inevitably do with the Power in their madness. See also Aes Sedai; channel; Five Powers; Time of Madness; True Source.

ɔɹdiθ (ɔɹ-diθ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wɝmwʊd." neɪm teɪkən baɪ ə mæn u ædvaɪzɪz ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Ordeith (OHR-deeth): In the Old Tongue, "Wormwood." Name taken by a man who advises the Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light.

pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ: ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ðə θɹɛdz ə hjumən lɪvz ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ, ɔfən kɔl sɪmpli ðə pæɾɝn, wɪtʃ fɔɹmz ðə sʌbstəns ə ɹiæləɾi fəɹ ðəɾ eɪdʒ. si ɔlsoʊ tɑvɝən.

Pattern of an Age: The Wheel of Time weaves the threads of human lives into the Pattern of an Age, often called simply the Pattern, which forms the substance of reality for that Age. See also ta'veren.

paʊɝz, ðə faɪv: si faɪv paʊɝz, ðə.

Powers, the Five: See Five Powers, the.

kwɛstʃənɝz, ðə: ən ɔɹɾɝ wɪðɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. ðɛɹ əvaʊd pɝpəsəz ɑɹ tə dɪskʌvɝ ðə tʃɹuθ ɪn dɪspjəteɪʃənz ən ənkʌvɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ɪn ðə sɝtʃ fəɹ tʃɹuθ ən ðə laɪt, ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mɛθəɾ ʌv ɪnkwaɪɹi ɪz tɔɹtʃɝ; ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mænɝ ðət ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ɔlɹɛɾi ən mʌst oʊnli meɪk ðɛɹ vɪktəm kənfɛs tə ɪt. ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɹəfɝ tə ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt, ðə hæn ðət dɪɡz aʊt tʃɹuθ, ən ət taɪmz ækt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɪntaɪɝli sɛpɹət fɹəm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd, wɪtʃ kəmænz ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɪz ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ, hu sɪts ɑn ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə blʌd-ɹɛd ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk.

Questioners, the: An order within the Children of the Light. Their avowed purposes are to discover the truth in disputations and uncover Darkfriends. In the search for truth and the Light, their normal method of inquiry is torture; their normal manner that they know the truth already and must only make their victim confess to it. The Questioners refer to themselves as the Hand of the Light, the Hand that digs out truth, and at times act as if they were entirely separate from the Children and the Council of the Anointed, which commands the Children. The head of the Questioners is the High Inquisitor, who sits on the Council of the Anointed. Their sign is a blood-red shepherd's crook.

ɹɛd ʃilz: si il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz.

Red Shields: See Aiel warrior societies.

ɹəɑɹk (ɹaʊɹk): ən il, klæn tʃif ə ðə tɑɹdæɾ il.

Rhuarc (RHOURK): An Aiel, clan chief of the Taardad Aiel.

ɹəɡoʊʃ iɡəl-aɪ: ə lɛdʒəndɛɹi hɪɹoʊ mɛnʃən ɪn ə nʌmbɝ ʌv oʊl stɔɹiz.

Rogosh Eagle-eye: A legendary hero mentioned in a number of old stories.

sɑŋɡɹil (sɑ-æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ɛni wʌn ʌv ə nʌmbɝ ʌv ɑbʒɛkts ðəɾ əlaʊ ən ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl tə tʃænəl mʌtʃ mɔɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðən wəɾ ʌðɝwaɪz bi pɑsəbəl əɹ seɪf. ə sɑŋɡɹil ɪz laɪk ʌntu, bʌt mʌtʃ mɔɹ paʊɝfəl ðæn, ən æŋɡɹil. ði əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðət kən bi wildɪd wɪð ə sɑŋɡɹil kəmpɛɹz tə ði əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðət kən bi hændəld wɪð ən æŋɡɹil əz ðə paʊɝ wildɪd wɪð ði eɪɾ ʌv ən æŋɡɹil dʌz tə ði əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðət kən bi hændəld əneɪɾɪd. ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ðɛɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ noʊn. oʊnli ə hændfʊl ɹɪmeɪn, fɑɹ fjuɝ ivən ðən æŋɡɹil.

sa'angreal (SAH-ahn-GREE-ahl): Any one of a number of objects that allow an individual to channel much more of the One Power than would otherwise be possible or safe. A sa'angreal is like unto, but much more powerful than, an angreal. The amount of the Power that can be wielded with a sa'angreal compares to the amount of the Power that can be handled with an angreal as the power wielded with the aid of an angreal does to the amount of the Power that can be handled unaided. Remnants of the Age of Legends, their making is no longer known. Only a handful remain, far fewer even than angreal.

seɪaɪdɑɹ (sɑ-ɪ-dɑɹ); seɪɾɪn (sɑ-ɪ-din): si tʃɹu sɔɹs.

saidar (sah-ih-DAHR); saidin (sah-ih-DEEN): See True Source.

si foʊk: mɔɹ pɹɑpɝli, ði æθɑn maɪɹ (ɑ-θɑ-æn mi-ɛɹ), ðə pipəl ə ðə si. ɪnhæbəɾənts ʌv aɪlənz ɪn ði ɛɹɪθ (ɑ-ɹɪθ) oʊʃən ən ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, ðeɪ spɛn lɪɾəl taɪm ɑn ðoʊz aɪlənz, lɪvɪŋ moʊst ə ðɛɹ laɪvz ɑn ðɛɹ ʃɪps. moʊst sibɔɹn tʃɹeɪɾ ɪz kæɹid baɪ ðə si foʊks ʃɪps.

Sea Folk: More properly, the Atha'an Miere (ah-thah-AHN mee-AIR), the People of the Sea. Inhabitants of islands in the Aryth (AH-rihth) Ocean and the Sea of Storms, they spend little time on those islands, living most of their lives on their ships. Most seaborne trade is carried by the Sea Folk's ships.

sintʃæn (ʃɔn-tʃæn): (wʌn) dɪsɛndəns ə ði ɑɹmiz ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ sɛn əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. (tu) ðə læn fɹəm wɪtʃ ðə sintʃæn kʌm.

Seanchan (SHAWN-CHAN): (1) Descendants of the armies Artur Hawkwing sent across the Aryth Ocean. (2) The land from which the Seanchan come.

səlin (sɛ-lin): ə neɪm juz baɪ ðə fɔɹseɪkən kɔld lænfɝ.

Selene (seh-LEEN): A name used by the Forsaken called Lanfear.

sɝvəns, hɔl ə ðə: ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ðə ɡɹeɪt miɾɪŋ hɔl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Servants, Hall of the: In the Age of Legends, the great meeting hall of the Aes Sedai.

ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ (ʃɑ-dɑɹ loʊ-ɡɑθ): ə sɪɾi əbændən ən ʃʌn sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. ɪts teɪntɪd ɡɹaʊnd, ən nɑɾ ə pɛbəl ʌv ɪts seɪf.

Shadar Logoth (SHAH-dahr LOH-goth): A city abandoned and shunned since the Trolloc Wars. It is tainted ground, and not a pebble of it is safe.

ʃeɪtɑn (ʃeɪ-ɪ-tæn): si dɑɹk wʌn.

Shai'tan (SHAY-ih-TAN): See Dark One.

ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl (ʃeɪ-əl ɡul): ə maʊntən ɪn ðə blæstəd lænz, ðə saɪɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən.

Shayol Ghul (SHAY-ol GHOOL): A mountain in the Blasted Lands, the site of the Dark One's prison.

ʃɛɹiəm (ʃɪɹ-i-ɑm): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Sheriam (SHEER-ee-ahm): An Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah. The Mistress of Novices in the White Tower.

sɪuən sɑntʃ (swɑn sæn-tʃeɪ): ðə dɔɾɝ ʌv ə tɛɹən fɪʃɝmæn, ʃi wɑz, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə tɛɹən lɔ, pʊɾ ɑn ə ʃɪp tə tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪfɔɹ ðə sɛkən sʌnsɛɾ æftɝ ɪt wɑz dɪskʌvɝd ðət ʃi hæd ðə pətɛnʃəl tə tʃænəl. fɔɹmɝli ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ. ɹeɪz tə ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪn naɪnhʌnʒɹədeɪtieɪt ni.

Siuan Sanche (SWAHN SAHN-chay): The daughter of a Tairen fisherman, she was, according to Tairen law, put on a ship to Tar Valon before the second sunset after it was discovered that she had the potential to channel. Formerly of the Blue Ajah. Raised to the Amyrlin Seat in 988 NE.

soʊlləs: si ɡɹeɪ mæn.

Soulless: See Gray Man.

spæn: si lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv.

span: See length, units of.

spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, ðə: ə taʊɝɪŋ maʊntən ɹeɪnʒ, wɪð oʊnli ə fju pæsəz, wɪtʃ sɛpɝeɪts ði il weɪs fɹəm ðə lænz tə ðə wɛst.

Spine of the World, the: A towering mountain range, with only a few passes, which separates the Aiel Waste from the lands to the west.

stɛɾɪŋ (stɛd-dɪŋ): ən oʊɡiɝ (oʊhaɪoʊ-ɡɪɹ) hoʊmlænd. mɛni stɛɾɪŋ əv bɪn əbændən sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ðeɪ ɑɹ ʃildɪɾ ɪn səm weɪ, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ʌndɝstʊd, soʊ ðət wɪðɪn əm noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ kən tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, nɔɹ ivən sɛns ðət ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ɪɡzɪsts. ətɛmps tə wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ fɹəm aʊtsaɪɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ əv noʊ ɪfɛkt ɪnsaɪɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ baʊndɝi. noʊ tʃɹɑlɑk wɪl ɛntɝ ə stɛɾɪŋ ənlɛs dʒɹɪvən, ən ivən ə mɹdʒɹɑl wɪl də soʊ oʊnli ət ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst niɾ ən ðən wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ɹɪlʌktəns ən dɪsteɪst. ivən dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ɪf tʃɹuli dɛɾəkeɪtəd, fil ənkʌmftəɹbəl wɪðɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ.

stedding (STEHD-ding): An Ogier (OH-geer) homeland. Many stedding have been abandoned since the Breaking of the World. They are shielded in some way, no longer understood, so that within them no Aes Sedai can channel the One Power, nor even sense that the True Source exists. Attempts to wield the One Power from outside a stedding have no effect inside a stedding boundary. No Trolloc will enter a stedding unless driven, and even a Myrddraal will do so only at the greatest need and then with the greatest reluctance and distaste. Even Darkfriends, if truly dedicated, feel uncomfortable within a stedding.

stɪlɪŋ: ði ækt, pɝfɔɹm baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv ʃʌɾɪŋ ɔf ə wʊmən u kən tʃænəl fɹəm ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ə wʊmən u hæz bɪn stɪl kən sɛns ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, bʌt ʃi kænɑt tʌtʃ ɪt. soʊ sɛldəm əz ɪt bɪn dʌn ðət nɑvəsɪz ɑɹ ɹikwaɪɝd tə lɝn ðə neɪmz ən kɹaɪmz ʌv ɔl wɪmən u hæv sʌfɝɾ ɪt.

stilling: The act, performed by Aes Sedai, of shutting off a woman who can channel from the One Power. A woman who has been stilled can sense the True Source, but she cannot touch it. So seldom has it been done that novices are required to learn the names and crimes of all women who have suffered it.

stoʊn dɑɡz: si il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz.

Stone Dogs: See Aiel warrior societies.

stoʊn ə tɛɹ: ə ɡɹeɪt fɔɹtʃɹəs ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʌv tɛɹ, sɛd tə hæv bɪn meɪd sun æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ən tə hæv bɪn meɪd juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɪts bɪn bɪsidʒd əɹ ətækt kaʊnləs taɪmz, bʌt nɛvɝ səksɛsfəli. ðə stoʊn ɪz mɛnʃən twaɪs ɪn ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. wʌns ðeɪ seɪ ðə stoʊn wɪl nɛvɝ fɔl əntɪl ðə pipəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən kʌm. ɪn ənʌðɝ pleɪs, ðeɪ seɪ ðə stoʊn wɪl nɛvɝ fɔl əntɪl ðə dʒɹæɡənz hænd wilz ðə sɔɹd ðət kænɑt bi tʌtʃt, kælændɝ. səm bɪliv ðət ðiz pɹɑfəsiz əkaʊn fəɹ ði æntɪpəθi ʌv ðə haɪ lɔɹdz tə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən fəɹ ðə tɛɹən lɔ ðət fɝbɪdz tʃænəlɪŋ. dɪspaɪt ðɪs æntɪpəθi, ðə stoʊn kənteɪnz ə kəlɛkʃən ʌv æŋɡɹil ən tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɹaɪvəlɪŋ ðəɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ə kəlɛkʃən wɪtʃ wɑz ɡæðɝd, səm seɪ, ɪn ən ətɛmp tə dɪmɪnɪʃ ðə ɡlɛɹ ə pəzɛsɪŋ kælændɝ.

Stone of Tear: A great fortress in the city of Tear, said to have been made soon after the Breaking of the World, and to have been made using the One Power. It has been besieged or attacked countless times, but never successfully. The Stone is mentioned twice in the Prophecies of the Dragon. Once they say the Stone will never fall until the People of the Dragon come. In another place, they say the Stone will never fall until the Dragon's hand wields the Sword That Cannot Be Touched, Callandor. Some believe that these Prophecies account for the antipathy of the High Lords to the One Power, and for the Tairen law that forbids channeling. Despite this antipathy, the Stone contains a collection of an'greal and ter'angreal rivaling that of the White Tower, a collection which was gathered, some say, in an attempt to diminish the glare of possessing Callandor.

sʌndeɪ: ə fistdeɪ ən fɛstəvəl ɪn mɪdsʌmɝ, waɪdli sɛləbɹeɪɾəd ɪn mɛni pɑɹts ə ðə wɝld.

Sunday: A feastday and festival in midsummer, widely celebrated in many parts of the world.

sʌŋ wʊd: si tʃɹisɪŋʒɝ.

sung wood: See Treesinger.

tæləns: əbɪləɾiz ɪn ðə jus ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn spəsɪfɪk ɛɹiəz. ðə bɛs noʊn ə ðiz, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪz hilɪŋ. sʌm, sətʃ əz tʃɹævlɪŋ, ði əbɪləɾi tə ʃɪft wʌnsɛlf fɹəm wʌn pleɪs tə ənʌðɝ wɪθaʊt kɹɔsɪŋ ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ speɪs, hæv bɪn lɔst. ʌðɝz sətʃ əz fɔɹtɛlɪŋ (ði əbɪləɾi tə fɔɹtɛl fjutʃɝ ɪvɛns, bʌɾ ɪn ə dʒɛnɝəl weɪ) ɑɹ naʊ faʊn oʊnli ɹɛɹli ɪf əɾ ɔl. ənʌðɝ tælən lɔŋ θɔt lɔst ɪz dʒɹimɪŋ, wɪtʃ ɪnvɑlvz, əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz, ɪntɝpɹɛɾɪŋ ðə dʒɹimɝz dʒɹimz tə fɔɹtɛl fjutʃɝ ɪvɛns ɪn mɔɹ spəsɪfɪk fæʃən ðən fɔɹtɛlɪŋ dʌz. səm dʒɹimɝz hæd ði əbɪləɾi tə ɛntɝ tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, ən (ɪɾ ɪz sɛd) ivən ʌðɝ pipəlz dʒɹimz. ðə læs noʊn dʒɹimɝ wɑz kɔɹiənɪn nɪdil, hu daɪɾ ɪn faɪvhʌnʒɹədtwɛntisɪks ni.

Talents: Abilities in the use of the One Power in specific areas. The best known of these, of course, is Healing. Some, such as Traveling, the ability to shift oneself from one place to another without crossing the intervening space, have been lost. Others such as Foretelling (the ability to foretell future events, but in a general way) are now found only rarely if at all. Another Talent long thought lost is Dreaming, which involves, among other things, interpreting the Dreamer's dreams to foretell future events in more specific fashion than Foretelling does. Some Dreamers had the ability to enter Tel'aran'rhiod, the World of Dreams, and (it is said) even other people's dreams. The last known Dreamer was Corianin Nedeal, who died in 526 NE.

tæmɹəleɪlən (tɑ-mɑɹ-ɑl-aɪ-lɛn): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wɛb ə dɛstəni." ə ɡɹeɪt tʃeɪnʒ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ, sɛntɝɾ ɝaʊnd wʌn əɹ mɔɹ pipəl u ɑɹ tɑvɝən. si ɔlsoʊ pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ; tɑvɝən.

ta'maral'ailen (tah-MAHR-ahl-EYE-lehn): In the Old Tongue, "Web of Destiny." A great change in the Pattern of an Age, centered around one or more people who are ta'veren. See also Pattern of an Age; ta'veren.

tænɹəl, ɑɹɾɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ (tæn-ɹi-ɑl, ɑɹ-tʃɹ peɪ-ɛn-dʒɹæɡ): si hɔkwɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ.

Tanreall, Artur Paendrag (tahn-REE-ahl, AHR-tuhr PAY-ehn-DRAG): See Hawkwing, Artur.

tɑɹmən ɡdən (tɑɹ-mɑn ɡeɪ-dɑn): ðə læs bæɾəl. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə; hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ.

Tarmon Gai'don (TAHR-mohn GAY-dohn): The Last Battle. See also Dragon, Prophecies of the; Horn of Valere.

tɑvɝən (tɑ-vɪɹ-ɛn): ə pɝsən ɝaʊn hum ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ɔl sɝaʊndɪŋ laɪf-θɹɛdz, pɝhæps ɔl laɪf-θɹɛdz, tə fɔɹm ə wɛb ə dɛstəni. si ɔlsoʊ pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ.

ta'veren (tah-VEER-ehn): A person around whom the Wheel of Time weaves all surrounding life-threads, perhaps ALL life-threads, to form a Web of Destiny. See also Pattern of an Age.

tɛɹ (tɪɹ): ə neɪʃən ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz. ɔlsoʊ ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðət neɪʃən, ə ɡɹeɪt sipɔɹt. ðə bænɝ ə tiɹ ɪz θɹi waɪt kɹɛsən munz slæntɪŋ əkɹɔs ə fil hæf ɹɛd, hæf ɡoʊld. si ɔlsoʊ stoʊn ə tiɹ.

Tear (TEER): A nation on the Sea of Storms. Also the capital city of that nation, a great seaport. The banner of Tear is three white crescent moons slanting across a field half red, half gold. See also Stone of Tear.

tɛləmən, luz θɝɪn (tɛl-ɑ-moʊn, luz θɛ-ɹɪn): si dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

Telamon, Lews Therin (TEHL-ah-mon, LOOZ THEH-rihn): See Dragon, the.

tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd (tɛl-aɪ-ɹæn-ɹi-ɑd): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ði ənsin wɝld," əɹ "ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz." ə wɝld ɡlɪmpst ɪn dʒɹimz wɪtʃ wɑz bɪliv baɪ ði eɪntʃəns tə pɝmieɪɾ ən sɝaʊn ɔl ʌðɝ pɑsəbəl wɝlz. ənlaɪk ʌðɝ dʒɹimz, wʌt hæpənz tə lɪvɪŋ θɪŋz ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz ɪz ɹil; ə waʊn teɪkən ðəɹ wɪl stɪl bi ðəɹ ɑn əweɪkənɪŋ, ən wʌn u daɪz ðəɹ dʌz nɑt weɪk əɾ ɔl.

Tel'aran'rhiod (tel-AYE-rahn-rhee-ODD): In the Old Tongue, "the Unseen World," or "the World of Dreams." A world glimpsed in dreams which was believed by the ancients to permeate and surround all other possible worlds. Unlike other dreams, what happens to living things in the World of Dreams is real; a wound taken there will still be there on awakening, and one who dies there does not wake at all.

tɛɹæŋɡɹil (tɪɹ-æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ɛni wʌn ʌv ə nʌmbɝ ə ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ðət juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ənlaɪk æŋɡɹil ən sɑŋɡɹil, itʃ tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz meɪd tə də ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ θɪŋ. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, wʌn meɪks oʊðz teɪkən wɪð ɪt baɪndɪŋ. səm tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɑɹ juz baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ði ɝɪdʒənəl pɝpəsəz ə mɛni ʌðɝz ɑɹ lɑɹdʒli ənnoʊn. səm wɪl kɪl əɹ dɪstʃɹɔɪ ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl ʌv ɛni wʊmən u juzɪz ðɛm. si ɔlsoʊ æŋɡɹil; sɑŋɡɹil.

ter'angreal (TEER-ahn-GREE-ahl): Any one of a number of remnants of the Age of Legends that use the One Power. Unlike angreal and sa'angreal, each ter'angreal was made to do a particular thing. For example, one makes oaths taken with it binding. Some ter'angreal are used by Aes Sedai, but the original purposes of many others are largely unknown. Some will kill or destroy the ability to channel of any woman who uses them. See also angreal; sa'angreal.

tɪɡɹeɪn (ti-ɡɹeɪn): əz dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, ʃi mɛɹid tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹɾ ən bɔɹ ɪz sʌn ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd. hɝ dɪsəpɪɹəns ɪn naɪnhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntitu ni, ʃɔɹtli æftɝ əɹ bɹʌðɝ luk vænɪʃt ɪn ðə blaɪt, lɛd tə ðə stʃɹʌɡəl ɪn ændɝ kɔl ðə səksɛʃən, ən kɑz ði ɪvɛns ɪn kɛɹhin ðəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli bɹɔɾ ɑn ði il wɔɹ. hɝ saɪn wɑz ə wʊmənz hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ə θɔɹni ɹoʊz stɛm wɪð ə waɪt blɑsəm.

Tigraine (tee-GRAIN): As Daughter-Heir of Andor, she married Taringail Damodred and bore his son Galadedrid. Her disappearance in 972 NE, shortly after her brother Luc vanished in the Blight, led to the struggle in Andor called the Succession, and caused the events in Cairhien that eventually brought on the Aiel War. Her sign was a woman's hand gripping a thorny rose stem with a white blossom.

taɪm ə mædnəs: ðə jɪɹz æftɝ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz kaʊntɝstʃɹoʊk teɪntɪd ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, wən meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn mæɾ ən bɹoʊk ðə wɝld. ði ɪɡzæk dʊɹeɪʃən ə ðɪs pɪɹiəɾ ɪz ənnoʊn, bʌɾ ɪts bɪliv tə hæv læstəd nɪɹli wʌn hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ɪɾ ɛndəd kəmplitli oʊnli wɪð ðə dɛθ ə ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ. si ɔlsoʊ hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz; tʃɹu sɔɹs; wʌn paʊɝ.

Time of Madness: The years after the Dark One's counterstroke tainted the male half of the True Source, when male Aes Sedai went mad and Broke the world. The exact duration of this period is unknown, but it is believed to have lasted nearly one hundred years. It ended completely only with the death of the last male Aes Sedai. See also Hundred Companions; True Source; One Power.

tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl: si tuætɑn.

Traveling People: See Tuatha'an.

tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ, ðə: ə vɛɹi wɛl-noʊn bʊk ə tʃɹævəl stɔɹiz ən ɑbzɝveɪʃənz baɪ ə noʊɾəd mɔlkɪɹi ɹaɪɾɝ ən tʃɹævəlɝ. ðə bʊk wɑz fɝs pɹɪntəɾ ɪn naɪnhʌnʒɹədsɪkstieɪt ni ən əz bɪn ɹipɹɪntɪd kəntɪnjuəsli ɛvɝ sɪns. dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ dɪsəpɪɹd ʃɔɹtli æftɝ ði il wɔɹ ən ɪz dʒɛnɝəli bɪliv tə bi dɛd.

Travels of Jain Farstrider, The: A very well-known book of travel stories and observations by a noted Malkieri writer and traveler. The book was first printed in 968 NE and has been reprinted continuously ever since. Jain Farstrider disappeared shortly after the Aiel War and is generally believed to be dead.

tʃɹikɪlɝz: ən il neɪm fəɹ ðə kɛɹhinɪn, ɔlweɪz sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz ə hɔɹɝ ən dɪsɡʌst.

Treekillers: An Aiel name for the Cairhienin, always said in tones of horror and disgust.

tʃɹisɪŋʒɝ: ən oʊɡiɝ u hæz ði əbɪləɾi tə sɪŋ tə tʃɹiz (kɔld "tʃɹisɔŋ"), iðɝ hilɪŋ ðɛm, əɹ hɛlpɪŋ əm tə ɡɹoʊ ən flaʊɝ, əɹ meɪkɪŋ θɪŋz fɹəm ðə wʊd wɪθaʊt dæmɪdʒɪŋ ðə tʃɹi. ɑbʒɛkts meɪɾ ɪn ðɪs mænɝ ɑɹ kɔld "sʌŋ wʊd" ən ɑɹ haɪli pɹaɪzd. fju oʊɡiɝ ɹɪmeɪn u ɑɹ tʃɹisɪŋɝz; ði əbɪləɾi simz tə bi daɪɪŋ aʊt.

Treesinger: An Ogier who has the ability to sing to trees (called "treesong"), either healing them, or helping them to grow and flower, or making things from the wood without damaging the tree. Objects made in this manner are called "sung wood" and are highly prized. Few Ogier remain who are Treesingers; the ability seems to be dying out.

tʃɹɑləks (tʃɹæl-loʊks): kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. hjudʒ ə stætʃɝ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ə twɪstəd blɛn ʌv ænəməl ən hjumən stɑk. ðeɪ ɑɹ dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə tʃɹaɪb laɪk bænz, əmʌŋ əm ðə dɑvɑl, ðə koʊbəl, ən ðə deɪmən. vɪʃəs baɪ neɪtʃɝ, ðeɪ kɪl fəɹ ðə pjʊɹ plɛʒɝ ə kɪlɪŋ. dəsitfəl ɪn ði ɪkstʃɹim, ðeɪ kænɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪɾ ənlɛs koʊɝs baɪ fɪɹ.

Trollocs (TRAHL-lohks): Creatures of the Dark One, created during the War of the Shadow. Huge of stature, they are a twisted blend of animal and human stock. They are divided into tribe like bands, among them the Dha'vol, the Ko'bal, and the Dhai'mon. Vicious by nature, they kill for the pure pleasure of killing. Deceitful in the extreme, they cannot be trusted unless coerced by fear.

tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz: ə sɪɹiz ʌv wɔɹz, bɪɡɪnɪŋ əbaʊt wʌnθaʊzən æb ən læstɪŋ mɔɹ ðən θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, dʊɹɪŋ wɪtʃ tʃɹɑlɑk ɑɹmiz ɹævɪdʒ ðə wɝld. ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ dʒɹɪvən bæk ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt, bʌt səm neɪʃənz sis tə ɪɡzɪst, ən ʌðɝz ðət sɝvaɪvd wɝ ɔlmoʊs dɪpɑpjəleɪɾɪd. ɔl ɹɛkɝdz ə ðə taɪm ɑɹ fɹæɡməntɛɹi.

Trolloc Wars: A series of wars, beginning about 1000 AB and lasting more than three hundred years, during which Trolloc armies ravaged the world. Eventually the Trollocs were driven back into the Great Blight, but some nations ceased to exist, and others that survived were almost depopulated. All records of the time are fragmentary.

tʃɹu sɔɹs: ðə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ fɔɹs ə ðə junəvɝs, wɪtʃ tɝnz ðə wil ə taɪm. ɪts dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə ə meɪl hæf (seɪɾɪn) ən ə fimeɪl hæf (seɪaɪdɑɹ), wɪtʃ wɝk ət ðə seɪm taɪm wɪð ən əɡɛnst itʃ ʌðɝ. oʊnli ə mæn kən dʒɹɔ ɑn seɪɾɪn, oʊnli ə wʊmən ɑn seɪaɪdɑɹ. sɪns ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, seɪɾɪn əz bɪn teɪntɪd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ. si ɔlsoʊ wʌn paʊɝ.

True Source: The driving force of the universe, which turns the Wheel of Time. It is divided into a male half (saidin) and a female half (saidar), which work at the same time with and against each other. Only a man can draw on saidin, only a woman on saidar. Since the beginning of the Time of Madness, saidin has been tainted by the Dark One's touch. See also One Power.

tuætɑn (tu-ɑ-θɑ-æn): ə wɑndɝɪŋ foʊk, ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz ðə tɪŋkɝz ən əz ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl, hu lɪv ɪn bɹaɪtli peɪntəd wæɡənz ən fɑloʊ ə toʊɾəli pæsɪfɪs fəlɑsəfi kɔl ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif. θɪŋz mɛndɪd baɪ tɪŋkɝz ɑɹ ɔfən bɛɾɝ ðən nu. ðeɪ ɑɹ əmʌŋ ðə fju hu kən kɹɔs ði il weɪst ʌnməlɛstɪd, fəɹ ði il stʃɹɪkli əvɔɪɾ ɔl kɑntækt wɪð ðɛm.

Tuatha'an (too-AH-thah-AHN): A wandering folk, also known as the Tinkers and as the Traveling People, who live in brightly painted wagons and follow a totally pacifist philosophy called the Way of the Leaf. Things mended by Tinkers are often better than new. They are among the few who can cross the Aiel Waste unmolested, for the Aiel strictly avoid all contact with them.

vɛɹɪn mæθwɪn (vɛɹ-ɪn mɑ-θwɪn): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ.

Verin Mathwin (VEHR-ihn MAH-thwihn): An Aes Sedai of the Brown Ajah.

wɔɹɾɝ: ə wɔɹiɝ bɑndəd tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə bɑndɪŋ ɪz ə θɪŋ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən baɪ ɪɾ i ɡeɪnz sətʃ ɡɪfs əz kwɪk hilɪŋ, ði əbɪləɾi tə ɡoʊ lɔŋ pɪɹiədz wɪθaʊt fud, wɔɾɝ, əɹ ɹɛst, ən ði əbɪləɾi tə sɛns ðə teɪn ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn əɾ ə dɪstəns. soʊ lɔŋ əz ə wɔɹɾɝ lɪvz, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hum hiz bɑndəd noʊz hiz əlaɪv haʊɛvɝ fɑɹ əweɪ hi ɪz, ən wən i daɪz ʃɪl noʊ ðə moʊmən ən mænɝ ə hɪz dɛθ. waɪl moʊst ədʒəz bɪliv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ hæv wʌn wɔɹɾɝ bɑndəd tə hɝ əɾ ə taɪm, ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ɹəfjuz tə bɑn ɛni wɔɹɾɝz əɾ ɔl, waɪl ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ bɪliv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ bɑn əz mɛni wɔɹɾɝz əz ʃi wɪʃɪz. ɛθɪkəli ðə wɔɹɾɝ mʌst æksid tə ðə bɑndɪŋ vɑləntɛɹəli, bʌɾ ɪts bɪn noʊn tə bi dʌn əɡɛns ðə wɔɹɾɝz wɪl. wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪn fɹəm ðə bɑndɪŋ ɪz ə kloʊsli hɛl sikɹət. si ɔlsoʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Warder: A warrior bonded to an Aes Sedai. The bonding is a thing of the One Power, and by it he gains such gifts as quick healing, the ability to go long periods without food, water, or rest, and the ability to sense the taint of the Dark One at a distance. So long as a Warder lives, the Aes Sedai to whom he is bonded knows he is alive however far away he is, and when he dies she will know the moment and manner of his death. While most Ajahs believe an Aes Sedai may have one Warder bonded to her at a time, the Red Ajah refuse to bond any Warders at all, while the Green Ajah believe an Aes Sedai may bond as many Warders as she wishes. Ethically the Warder must accede to the bonding voluntarily, but it has been known to be done against the Warder's will. What the Aes Sedai gain from the bonding is a closely held secret. See also Aes Sedai.

wɔɹ ə paʊɝ: si wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ.

War of Power: See War of the Shadow.

wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz: ə sɪɹiz ʌv oʊvɝlæpɪŋ wɔɹz əmʌŋ kɑnstənli ʃɪftɪŋ əlaɪənsəz, pɹɪsɪpɪteɪɾɪd baɪ ðə dɛθ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ən ðə ɹɪzʌltɪŋ stʃɹʌɡəl fəɹ ɪz ɛmpaɪɝ. ɪt læstəd fɹəm fi naɪnhʌnʒɹədnaɪntifɔɹ tə fi wʌnθaʊzəndwʌnhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntin. ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz dɪpɑpjəleɪɾɪd lɑɹdʒ pɑɹts ə ðə lænz bɪtwin ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən ən ði il weɪst, fɹəm ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz tə ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt. soʊ ɡɹeɪt wɑz ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ðəɾ oʊnli fɹæɡməntɛɹi ɹɛkɝdz ə ðə taɪm ɹɪmeɪn. ði ɛmpaɪɝ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wɑz pʊld əpɑɹɾ ɪn ðə wɔɹz, ən ðə neɪʃənz ə ðə pɹɛzən deɪ wɝ fɔɹmd. si ɔlsoʊ hɔkwɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ.

War of the Hundred Years: A series of overlapping wars among constantly shifting alliances, precipitated by the death of Artur Hawkwing and the resulting struggle for his empire. It lasted from FY 994 to FY 1117. The War of the Hundred Years depopulated large parts of the lands between the Aryth Ocean and the Aiel Waste, from the Sea of Storms to the Great Blight. So great was the destruction that only fragmentary records of the time remain. The empire of Artur Hawkwing was pulled apart in the wars, and the nations of the present day were formed. See also Hawkwing, Artur.

wɔɹ ə ðə sɛkən dʒɹæɡən: ðə wɔɹ fɔt (fi naɪnθɹinaɪnfɔɹθɹi) əɡɛns ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsən. dʊɹɪŋ ðɪs wɔɹ ə jʌŋ kɪŋ neɪmd ɑɹɾɝ tænɹəl pɛndʒɹæɡ, leɪɾɝ noʊn əz ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, ɹoʊz tə oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ pɹɑmənəns.

War of the Second Dragon: The war fought (FY 93943) against the false Dragon Guaire Amalasan. During this war a young king named Artur Tanreall Paendrag, later known as Artur Hawkwing, rose to overwhelming prominence.

wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ: ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ, ðɪs wɔɹ ɛndəd ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɪt bɪɡæn ʃɔɹtli æftɝ ði ətɛmp tə fɹi ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən sun ɪnvɑlv ðə hoʊl wɝld. ɪn ə wɝld wɛɹ wɔɹ hæd bɪn fɝɡɑɾən, ivən ðə mɛmɹi ʌv ɪt, ɛvɹi fæsəɾ ʌv wɔɹ wɑz ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd, ɔfən twɪstəd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ ɑn ðə wɝld, ən ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɑz juzd əz ə wɛpən. ðə wɔɹ wɑz ɛndəd baɪ ðə ɹisilɪŋ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪndə hɪz pɹɪzən. si ɔlsoʊ hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz, ðə; dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

War of the Shadow: Also known as the War of Power, this war ended the Age of Legends. It began shortly after the attempt to free the Dark One, and soon involved the whole world. In a world where war had been forgotten, even the memory of it, every facet of war was rediscovered, often twisted by the Dark One's touch on the world, and the One Power was used as a weapon. The war was ended by the resealing of the Dark One into his prison. See also Hundred Companions, the; Dragon, the.

weɪt, junəts ʌv: tɛn aʊnsəz ikwəlz fɔɹɾiwʌn paʊnd; tɛn paʊnz ikwəlz wʌn stoʊn; tɛn stoʊn ikwəlz wʌn hʌnʒɹədweɪt; tɛn hʌnʒɹədweɪt ikwəlz wʌn tʌn.

weight, units of: 10 ounces = 41 pound; 10 pounds = 1 stone; 10 stone = 1 hundredweight; 10 hundredweight = 1 ton.

wil ə taɪm, ðə: taɪm ɪz ə wil wɪð sɛvən spoʊks, itʃ spoʊk ən eɪdʒ. əz ðə wil tɝnz, ði eɪdʒəz kʌm ən ɡoʊ, itʃ livɪŋ mɛmɹiz ðət feɪd tə lɛdʒənd, ðən tə mɪθ, ən ɑɹ fɝɡɑɾən baɪ ðə taɪm ðəɾ eɪdʒ kʌmz əɡɛn. ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ ɪz slaɪtli dɪfɹən itʃ taɪm ən eɪdʒ kʌmz, ən itʃ taɪm ɪts sʌbʒɪkt tə ɡɹeɪɾɝ tʃeɪnʒ.

Wheel of Time, the: Time is a wheel with seven spokes, each spoke an Age. As the Wheel turns, the Ages come and go, each leaving memories that fade to legend, then to myth, and are forgotten by the time that Age comes again. The Pattern of an Age is slightly different each time an Age comes, and each time it is subject to greater change.

waɪtkloʊks: si tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Whitecloaks: See Children of the Light.

waɪldɝ: ə wʊmən u hæz lɝn tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɑn əɹ oʊn, sɝvaɪvɪŋ ðə kɹaɪsəs əz oʊnli wʌn ɪn fɔɹ dʌz. sətʃ wɪmən juʒəwəli bɪl bæɹiɝz əɡɛns noʊɪŋ wʌɾ ɪts ðeɪ ɑɹ duɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪf ðiz kən bi bɹoʊkən daʊn, waɪldɝz ɑɹ əmʌŋ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə tʃænlɝz. ðə tɝm ɪz ɔfən juzd ɪn dɝɑɡətɔɹi fæʃən.

wilder: A woman who has learned to channel the One Power on her own, surviving the crisis as only one in four does. Such women usually build barriers against knowing what it is they are doing, but if these can be broken down, wilders are among the most powerful of channelers. The term is often used in derogatory fashion.

waɪl hʌnt: ɪts bɪliv baɪ mɛni ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn (ɔfən kɔld ɡɹɪm, əɹ oʊld ɡɹɪm, ɪn tɛɹ, ɪljən, mʊɹændi, ɔltɑɹə, ən ɡildən) ɹaɪdz aʊɾ ɪn ðə naɪt wɪð ðə "blæk dɑɡz," əɹ ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz, hʌntɪŋ soʊlz. ðɪs ɪz ðə waɪl hʌnt. ɹeɪn kən kip ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt, bʌt wʌns ðeɪ ɑɹ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪl, ðeɪ mʌs bi kənfɹʌntəɾ ən dɪfiɾəd əɹ ðə vɪktəmz dɛθ ɪz ɪnɛvəɾəbəl. ɪts bɪliv ðət mɪɹli siɪŋ ðə waɪl hʌn pæs minz ɪmənən dɛθ, iðɝ fəɹ ðə vjuɝ əɹ fəɹ sʌmwʌn dɪɹ tə ðə vjuɝ.

Wild Hunt: It is believed by many that the Dark One (often called Grim, or Old Grim, in Tear, Illian, Murandy, Altara, and Ghealdan) rides out in the night with the "black dogs," or the Darkhounds, hunting souls. This is the Wild Hunt. Rain can keep the Darkhounds out of the night, but once they are on the trail, they must be confronted and defeated or the victim's death is inevitable. It is believed that merely seeing the Wild Hunt pass means imminent death, either for the viewer or for someone dear to the viewer.

wɪzdəm: ɪn vɪlədʒəz, ə wʊmən tʃoʊzən baɪ ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl fəɹ əɹ nɑlədʒ ə sətʃ θɪŋz əz hilɪŋ, ən fɔɹtɛlɪŋ ðə wɛðɝ, əz wɛl əz fəɹ kɑmən ɡʊd sɛns. ə pəzɪʃən ʌv ɡɹeɪt ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi ən əθɔɹəɾi, boʊθ æktʃəwəl ən ɪmplaɪd. ʃiz dʒɛnɝəli kənsɪɾɝd ði ikwəl ə ðə meɪɝ, ən ɪn səm vɪlədʒəz ɪz supɪɹiɝ. ənlaɪk ðə meɪɝ, ʃiz tʃoʊzən fəɹ laɪf, ən ɪts vɛɹi ɹɛɹ fəɹ ə wɪzdəm tə bi ɹimuv fɹəm ɔfəs bɪfɔɹ əɹ dɛθ. ɔlmoʊs tʃɹədɪʃənəli ɪn kɑnflɪkt wɪð ðə meɪɝ. dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ðə lænd, ʃi meɪ ɪnstɛɾ əv ənʌðɝ taɪɾəl, sətʃ əz ɡaɪd, hilɝ, waɪz wʊmən, sikɝ, əɹ waɪz wʌn.

Wisdom: In villages, a woman chosen by the Women's Circle for her knowledge of such things as healing, and foretelling the weather, as well as for common good sense. A position of great responsibility and authority, both actual and implied. She is generally considered the equal of the Mayor, and in some villages his superior. Unlike the Mayor, she is chosen for life, and it is very rare for a Wisdom to be removed from office before her death. Almost traditionally in conflict with the Mayor. Depending on the land, she may instead have another title, such as Guide, Healer, Wise Woman, Seeker, or Wise One.

əbaʊt ði ɔθɝ ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən wɑz bɔɹn ɪn naɪntinfɔɹɾieɪt ɪn tʃɑɹlstən, saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə. hi tɔt hɪmsɛlf tə ɹid wən i wɑz fɔɹ wɪð ði ɪnsɪdɛntəl eɪɾ ʌv ə twɛlv-jɪɹz-oʊldɝ bɹʌðɝ, ən wɑz tæklɪŋ mɑɹk tweɪn ən dʒulz vɝn baɪ faɪv. hi wɑz ə ɡɹædʒəwəɾ ə ðə sɪɾədɛl, ðə mɪlətɛɹi kɑlɪdʒ ə saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə, wɪð ə dɪɡɹi ɪn fɪzɪks. hi sɝv tu tʊɹz ɪn viɛtnɑm wɪð ðə juɛs. ɑɹmi; əmʌŋ ɪz dɛkɝeɪʃənz ɑɹ ðə dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt flaɪɪŋ kɹɔs wɪð bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ðə bɹɑnz stɑɹ wɪð "vi" ən bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ən tu viɛtnɑmis ɡæləntʃɹi kɹɔsɪz wɪð pɑm. ə hɪstɝi bʌf, hi ɔlsoʊ ɹoʊt dæns ən θiəɾɝ kɹɪɾɪsɪzəm. hi ɛndʒɔɪd ði aʊtdɔɹ spɔɹts ə hʌntɪŋ, fɪʃɪŋ, ən seɪlɪŋ, ən ði ɪndɔɹ spɔɹts ə poʊkɝ, tʃɛs, pul, ən paɪp kəlɛktɪŋ. hi bɪɡæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn naɪntinsɛvəntisɛvən ən kəntɪnjuɾ əntɪl ɪz dɛθ ɑn sɛptɛmbɝ sɪkstinθ, tuθaʊzənsɛvən.

About the Author Robert Jordan was born in 1948 in Charleston, South Carolina. He taught himself to read when he was four with the incidental aid of a twelve-years-older brother, and was tackling Mark Twain and Jules Verne by five. He was a graduate of The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina, with a degree in physics. He served two tours in Vietnam with the U.S. Army; among his decorations are the Distinguished Flying Cross with bronze oak leaf cluster, the Bronze Star with "V" and bronze oak leaf cluster, and two Vietnamese Gallantry Crosses with Palm. A history buff, he also wrote dance and theater criticism. He enjoyed the outdoor sports of hunting, fishing, and sailing, and the indoor sports of poker, chess, pool, and pipe collecting. He began writing in 1977 and continued until his death on September 16, 2007.
